https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/06/world.main_headline: C.I.A. SAID TO OVERSPEND ITS BUDGET ON NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/06/world.print_headline: C.I.A. SAID TO OVERSPEND ITS BUDGET ON NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/06/world.body_text: **********The House Intelligence Committee will meet Wednesday to discuss evidence obtained by its staff indicating that the Central Intelligence Agency has spent more than the $24 million allocated for covert activities in Nicaragua in the current fiscal year, two committee members said today. **********The committee then plans to invite William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, to discuss whether the agency has surpassed Congressional limits for the financing, the committee members said. **********''The story is that they have overdrawn,'' a highly placed committee member said. ''They've been transferring accounts in order to be sure that the insurgents could continue on for the rest of the fiscal year.'' **********Another committee member said, ''From all the evidence we have, they've overdrawn.'' He noted the agency's involvement in the mining of Nicaraguan harbors and added, ''Funds for the mother ship alone would have done it.''  Extent of Overspending **********The extent to which the agency had overdrawn its Nicaragua account could not be learned. But one member said the amount was ''significant.'' **********The two committee members said the Senate Intelligence Committee also was looking into reports that the C.I.A. had exceeded Congressional funding limitations in Nicaragua, but this could not be confirmed by members or aides of the Senate committee. **********Such charges open a new issue in the already troubled relations Congres has with the agency, which has been criticized by both the House and the Senate intelligence committees for failing to keep Congress ''fully and currently informed'' of its activities, as required by law. **********The charges come at a time of heightened tensions between the Administration and Congress concerning new funds for covert activities in Nicaragua. The Senate approved $21 million in emergency supplemental money, but the House rejected the aid.   Emergency Aid Bill **********The money is contained in a $1.4 billion emergency aid bill, which also includes $62 million for El Salvador. The Administration has placed this bill on hold, while it seeks to persuade House Democratic leaders to change their minds on the Nicaraguan aid. **********Representative Edward P. Boland, Democrat of Massachussetts, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, has expressed a willingness to compromise by providing $4 million to $6 million to ''wind down'' the United States covert involvement in Nicaragua. The Administration has thus far refused to accept any such compromise, however. **********On May 24, the House voted, 241 to 177, to reject the Administration's request for the $21 million to continue aiding the Nicaraguan guerrillas until Oct. 1, the beginning of the new fiscal year. That vote was the House's third party-line vote against United States involvement in the Nicaraguan fighting since last July and demonstrated that the House Democratic leaders were determined to end the covert aid. After that vote, the Administration sought to find ways to continue aiding the guerillas while lobbying Congress for more money in fiscal 1985. **********Anti-Sandinista guerrilla leaders in Honduras said last week that the Reagan Administration had assured continued support for their efforts to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government. The leaders of the Nicaraguan Democratic Front, which operates primarily in northern Nicaragua and has bases in Honduras, refused to be specific about who gave the assurances. **********The rebel leaders said President Reagan's public statements had convinced them he was not backing away from his commitment to their cause, and they added that private statements from people in Washington had reinforced Mr. Reagan's comments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/11/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Aviation Administration, for the second time, denied permission for Eastern Airlines to take over from the bankrupt Air Florida 16 takeoff and landing slots at Washington and New York airports. **********Air Florida last month filed for creditor protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, and has grounded all flights and laid off its employees. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/10/world.main_headline: SHULTZ RULES OUT A TESTING FREEZE ON SPACE WEAPONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/10/world.print_headline: SHULTZ RULES OUT A TESTING FREEZE ON SPACE WEAPONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/10/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States was ready to discuss a joint moratorium on tests of new space weapons with the Soviet Union, but he ruled out a Soviet proposal for a freeze of such tests in advance of actual negotiations. **********Previously, the Reagan Administration said it was willing to engage in talks with the Russians on curbing the militarization of outer space so long as there were no conditions. The United States had not specifically addressed itself publicly to the moratorium question. **********Mr. Shultz's remarks were apparently meant to convey an American readiness to discuss everything at the table, including a moratorium on future testing, but not to accept any Russian condition - in this case, a ban on tests while negotiations were taking place. The United States is expected to test an antisatellite weapon this fall. **********Soviet Made Offer in June **********In the Administration view, such a moratorium would be unverifiable, and would only play into Soviet hands by delaying an American program without any guarantee of results. **********Other State Department officials said the Russians have been told through diplomatic channels of the American willingness to talk about a freeze on testing of antisatellite weapons at an early stage in negotiations. The Administration, however, is firmly opposed, they said, to the moratorium proposed by Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader. **********The Soviet Union proposed in June that the two sides hold talks in Vienna on Sept. 18 on ways of banning the militarization of outer space, and suggested a joint moratorium on space tests as a good-will gesture in advance of talks. The United States agreed to such talks, but, as Mr. Shultz repeated today, said they should also include ways of renewing the negotiations on medium-range and strategic arms. **********Moscow Questions U.S. Sincerity **********The American response led Moscow to say that the United States was not serious. After several public and private exchanges, both sides have seemed to accept the likelihood that there will be no negotiations in Vienna, at least before the November elections. But both sides have continued to say they favored talks and that the lack of progress in relations was due to the other. **********Appearing on the NBC News television program ''Meet the Press,'' Mr. Shultz said there was no question that ties were ''cool,'' but he added, ''I don't think that the situation is dangerous, in a literal, military sense.'' **********''The President and all of us working with him have addressed ourselves to this relationship very hard for a very long time and continue to do so to be sure that we do everything possible to see that the relationship is a constructive one,'' he said. **********Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic candidate for the Presidency, said last week that, if elected, one of his first actions as President would be to call for a meeting with the Soviet leader to take place in six months and that he would announce a ''limited moratorium'' on development of new American weapons during that six-month period as an incentive for talks. **********Mr. Shultz, when asked about Mr. Mondale's plan, said: ''I don't think it's a good idea to suddenly turn back our own capability to be prepared and to deter. To stop your own capacity to be prepared and to deter aggression is just as reprehensible as not being prepared to engage in negotiations for peace.''  Meeting With Gromyko **********The Secretary said this did not mean he did not favor meetings with the Soviet leaders. He pointed out that he had one scheduled for Sept. 26 in New York with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, who will be in New York for the regular fall session of the United Nations General Assembly. **********''The point is not to have meetings but to achieve something,'' he said, asserting that Mr. Reagan had achieved ''a great deal'' by building up American military strength, and having ''stopped'' the Soviet Union from moving into other countries. **********President Reagan, in an interview published in The Sunday Times of London, said his chief goal, if elected for a second term, would be ''the development of a better working relationship with the Soviet Union - one marked by greater cooperation and understanding and leading to stable, secure and peaceful relations.'' **********But a commentator for Tass, the Soviet press agency, said the President was trying ''to delude the world public.'' Anatoly Krasikov said relations between the two countries ''have dropped to the lowest point in their history.''  Question of Treaty Violation **********On the question of the space weapons negotiations, Mr. Shultz said the United States was ready to go to Vienna. He added, ''We think that one of the most threatening uses of outer space in a military way is the use of it for ballistic missiles to go through outer space and to hit other countries.'' **********''So we think it's important to discuss defensive and offensive systems that go through outer space and we said so,'' he said. ''But we're prepared to meet with the Soviet Union, in Vienna or elsewhere, with or without a prearranged agenda, and discuss the problems of outer space, including questions about a moratorium on testing, but not to do it before we have the meetings.'' **********At another point, he was asked if he agreed with a statement by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, made in an interview on an NBC News documentary on space weapons, charging that the Soviet Union had violated the terms of the 1972 Soviet-American treaty limiting antiballistic missiles. The ABM treaty, as it is known, and since modified, allows each side up to 100 such missiles in one area. The Soviet Union has its site around Moscow; the United States has not deployed a system. **********''Yes, I do,'' he said. But then he seemed to modify his answer by saying, ''They are in the process of constructing a radar that we believe is a violation, if it is put into being, of the ABM treaty.'' **********''It is still under construction, and it has a long ways to go as far as we can see,'' he said. He said the United States had raised its concerns at the special channel provided for by the treaty.   Shultz Clarifies Statement **********Later, after the television show, Mr. Shultz said he had not meant to go further in his reply than the Administration had gone last January when it first publicized its findings. **********At that time, a senior State Department official said the Soviet construction of a so-called large phased array radar near Krasnoyarsk in the central Soviet Union ''is almost certainly a violation of a legal obligation the Soviet Union has assumed.'' **********The treaty bars construction of radars and other equipment that could enhance a country's defense against incoming missiles, except at its borders to serve as an early warning system.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/01/world.main_headline: LOWER OIL REVENUE A FACTOR IN NIGERIA COUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/01/world.print_headline: LOWER OIL REVENUE A FACTOR IN NIGERIA COUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/01/world.body_text: **********Lower oil revenues have compounded Nigeria's difficulties in keeping up with payments on $14 billion of foreign debts and may have been a contributing factor in the seizure of power by the military, financial specialists said today. **********For the last six months, the Nigerians have been negotiating with the International Monetary Fund for a $2 billion line of credit to stabilize their shaky financial position. **********Although negotiations were in an advanced stage, no agreement was reached. Monetary officials said one problem was Nigeria's unwillingness to devalue its currency. **********The monetary fund, which is a 146- nation lending agency with headquarters in Washington, declined to comment on the situation. But officials familiar with its operations said it would wait until the new Government decides whether it wants to resume negotiations.    Funds Plays Pivotal Role **********The fund, which has played a pivotal role in the world debt crisis, lends to a host of poor countries, but only on condition that they take action to strengthen their economic performance. **********These include such measures as devaluation, the scaling back of imports, the phasing out of consumer subsidies for food, transportation and the like, the curbing of money supply growth and the freezing of wages. **********President Shehu Shagari of Nigeria, who won a second four-year term after elections last August, had only a fragile political consensus, according to specialists here. They said his political base had been maintained by handing out economic largesse to various tribes. **********Widespread reports of election irregularities in August may also have undermined his position. **********If a country accepts the prescriptions of the International Monetary Fund, the institution also helps to reschedule debts among commercial creditors. It has done this already for Brazil and Mexico. **********The fund requires that banks not only accept a new schedule of payments, but also put up new loans and reduce their interest rates. **********Nigeria's debt of $14 billion is mainly to British and American banks. Because of its formerly substantial oil revenues, Nigeria was considered eligible for commercial bank credits.    Close Links With Britain **********It maintains commercial and financial links with Britain as a former colony. Its ties to the Americans are reinforced by its position as the second largest foreign supplier of oil to the United States, after Saudi Arabia. **********Banking specialists here said it was unclear what would happen now with efforts to reschedule. Much will depend on the position taken by the new Government. **********If it decided to break off financial relations and default on loans, British and American banks would have to write off the debt and see their earnings decline. **********This comes at a time when bank earnings are already under some pressure because of financial difficulties in other foreign countries as well as bankruptcies in the United States. **********On the other hand, a default would hurt Nigeria by destroying its credit rating and ruling out new credits for financing food and other imports. **********Oil is the source of more than 90 percent of Nigeria's foreign exchange. According to American analysts, oil revenues this year will be $10 billion, less than half of the $22.4 billion earned in 1980, when Nigeria produced an average of 2 million barrels a day. **********Oil production, now down to a little over 1 million barrels, has been hit both by the slack demand for oil and weakening price levels. **********The global recession has been an important background factor, reducing demand not only for oil, but for Nigeria's other exports, such as cocoa, palm products, rubber, timber and tin. **********Other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have also been forced to cut exports. Saudi Arabia, the biggest OPEC producer, now exports 3 million barrels daily, compared with more than 8 million at the peak of demand. **********The loss of oil revenue has affected Nigeria more than some of the other producers because of its large population, some 85 million people, compared with, say, 5 million in Saudi Arabia. **********Analysts said that $8 billion of foreign exchange reserves had been virtually wiped out before the Shagari Government went to the International Monetary Fund and its commercial creditors for help. **********Negotiations have been under way with a consortium of 26 banks to refinance about $1.5 billion of short- term debt falling due in 1983. In addition, Nigeria opened talks with suppliers of $4 billion to $5 billion of short-term trade credits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/26/world.body_text: **********Thousands of people demonstrated around France today in favor of a secular, state-run school system and against what many denounced as inadequate Government efforts to bring private schools under state control. **********In large cities and small towns around the country there were 90 marches. **********Organizers said the demonstration in Paris drew more than half a million people; Agence France-Presse estimated the crowd at more than 150,000. people. The other marches around France drew 250,000, according to initial estimates by the news agency. **********The Socialist Government has proposed a bill to put some restrictions on private schools but to continue state aid. **********The bill would maintain state aid to the private schools, but would put their budgets under the control of the regional bodies. **********Roman Catholic leaders and other advocates of private schools say the measure would give the Government too much influence on education. But many of the marchers today said the Government had given up too much ground to the church. **********Although many demonstrators expressed their dissatisfaction with the Government bill on private schools, the Socialist Party itself supported the march.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/24/world.body_text: **********President Francois Mitterrand traveled today to Volgograd, where he saluted the memory not only of the victorious Soviet Army but also of the Germans and their Rumanian, Hungarian and Italian allies who fell there in the 1942-43 Battle of Stalingrad. **********That battle marked the end of the road for German invaders on the Russian front and the start of their long retreat to Berlin. **********After laying a wreath at an eternal flame, Mr. Mitterrand said, ''Today's reconciliation supersedes the rifts of yesterday.'' **********He said it was a ''useless quarrel'' to try to determine whether the Eastern front of the Russians or the Western front of the British, French, Americans and others had decided the final victory over Hitler's forces. **********Mr. Mitterrand ended a three-day visit to the Soviet Union by his trip to the Stalingrad battlefield. The name of the city was changed to Volgograd in 1961 during the de-Stalinization campaign. **********The French leader was accompanied to the battlefield by reporters who had flown with him from Paris.   Careful Not to Offend **********Mr. Mitterrand appeared to take care not to say anything that might offend the Russians with his call for reconciliation. But his insistence that both fronts were important to the World War II victory ran counter to the mood in Moscow. Here, the stress is on the Soviet role as the country prepares for 40th anniversary next May of the victory over Nazi Germany. **********The crushing of Hitler's forces in what is known here as the Great Patriotic War is a source of national pride. The memory of the war is kept alive in art, literature, films and politics as well as in ceremonies that reach their high point each year at May 9 victory celebrations. **********But these remembrances also carry with them persisting bitterness against the German invaders and pride in the belief it was the Russians who held the final line against Hitler, and who suffered the most with an estimated total of 20 million dead. **********Mr. Mitterrand praised the bravery of Russian soldiers who, he said, ''decided the fate of the world'' in Stalingrad - fighting ''street by street, house by house, floor by floor.'' But he also noted that the largest toll of casualties in that battle was borne by the Germans, giving a figure of 150,000 dead.   Victims of a Suicidal System' **********''Let us not forget those soldiers who were then on the opposite side,'' he said, ''but with whom, as survivors, we have become reconciled - Germans, Rumanians, Italians, Hungarians - all those who suffered and fell on this soil far from their homes, absurd victims of a suicidal system.'' **********Mr. Mitterrand awarded Volgograd the Legion of Honor, pinning the medal to a scarlet flag held by Mayor Vladimir I. Atopov. **********He then visited a huge monument complex on Mamayev Hill, overlooking the Volga River. The hill was the site of the fiercest fighting in the Battle of Stalingrad, which went on from September 1942 until February 1943, when the German Sixth Army survivors, surrounded, starving and without ammunition or fuel, finally surrendered. **********The French leader took leave in Moscow from Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. **********Mr. Mitterrand spoke plainly in Moscow on sensitive subjects, including the plight of Andrei D. Sakharov, the exiled dissident; Afghanistan and Poland. However, the atmosphere of the visit remained cordial and both sides said they believed it had been useful. **********Mitterrand Is Praised **********PARIS, June 23 - The stepdaughter of Andrei D. Sakharov today praised President Francois Mitterrand for speaking up in Moscow this week on behalf of the exiled dissident physicist. But she said she still did not know whether Dr. Sakharov was alive. **********The stepdaughter, Tatyana Yankelevich, told a radio interviewer that although she had urged that President Mitterrand not make his trip to the Soviet Union, she now felt that there were positive results from the three- day visit, which ended today. **********Mrs. Yankelevich, the daughter of Miss Bonner, expressed concern about the fate of the couple because, she said, the Soviet authorities have not provided evidence they are indeed well.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/02/world.main_headline: NATO ISSUE: WHEN TO LET ITS SHIPS FIRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/02/world.print_headline: NATO ISSUE: WHEN TO LET ITS SHIPS FIRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/02/world.body_text: **********Military   Analysis **********The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's naval leaders are debating whether to change an element of the rules of engagement to permit NATO ships to open fire first if threatened, alliance officials say.  At present the alliance's ships are restricted to returning enemy fire, in keeping with NATO's defensive strategy. **********Alliance officials in the United States and at headquarters in Brussels emphasize that the present rules of engagement invite attack in an era of long-range, highly accurate missiles. One official said a naval commander is not now permitted to deploy his ships in combat formation until after he has been fired upon and is not allowed to order a pre-emptive strike. **********The alliance is divided over the question. Adm. William Stavely of Britain, the commander in chief for the English Channel, and Adm. Wesley McDonald, NATO's Supreme Atlantic Commander, are said to be pushing for a change in the engagement rules. Admiral McDonald said he did not wish to comment on the dispute. **********British and American officials are said to believe that the present rules make alliance fleets easy targets for a pre-emptive strike by Soviet missiles and bombers, which can attack from ''over the horizon'' ranges. **********West German, Canadian, Danish and Dutch naval leaders are said to oppose any change. Their argument is that firing the first shot would be a serious departure from alliance principles.   A Growing Uneasiness **********Behind the debate lies a growing uneasiness about the security of the North Atlantic sea lanes in any conflict with the Warsaw Pact. The Soviet Union's naval building program, intelligence officials say, suggests that sizable Soviet squadrons would be at sea at the outbreak of war and that they would not hesitate to fire on allied naval ships and merchantmen. **********Another suggestion being discussed in NATO is the creation in a crisis of ''Maritime Exclusion Zones'' comparable to the zone established by Britain in its campaign against Argentina in 1982. Once the zones were created and potential enemies notified, NATO ships would be free to fire on any hostile ship entering such a zone. **********A spokesman for the alliance's Military Committee said the American and British admirals had submitted the proposal for revising the rules of engagement. The next step, he said, would be staff consultations. Any revision adopted by the committee would require the approval of all NATO governments.   Might Take Months or Years **********Diplomats familiar with the problem say they are not optimistic. They suggest that in the present political environment in Western Europe, governments would be reluctant to approve any changes that might appear to indicate NATO aggressiveness. Unless the environment changes, they said, it might take months or years for some governments to act upon the proposal. **********These governments, the officials said, would probably cite the NATO policy announced at the alliance's 1982 meeting in Bonn that says, ''None of our weapons will ever be used except in response to attack.'' **********But the present debate, naval sources said, is not over giving a naval commander the right to instigate a war. Rather, he said, it is about precautionary measures, including ''first fire,'' that would enable a squadron commander to save his ships. Many naval officers, including some from countries opposed to any change in the rules, feel that under the present restrictions a NATO force could be destroyed ''before the commander knew hostilities had begun.'' **********Such an attack would be helped for Warsaw Pact navies by the constant shadowing of NATO naval forces by Soviet intelligence-gathering ships. These ships keep watch on all major NATO naval deployments and are on station off bases in Europe and North America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/26/busin.body_text: **********The Palm Beach County Solid Waste Authority was about to plunge into the bond market with a $320 million financing for a trash incinerator when the deal fell apart. **********Fuji Bank's decision on Dec. 7 not to back the bonds with its letter of credit could hardly have come at a worse time, according to Timothy F. Hunt, the authority's executive director. ''We are under a lot of pressure to sell these bonds before the end of the year, when new Federal laws come into effect,'' he said. **********Normally, a bank's backing out or a similar reversal would set back a bond sale by several weeks. But, feeling the pressure of the year-end deadline, the authority was back in the market in 10 days, after obtaining insurance for the issue from the Ambac Indemnity Corporation. **********The Florida county's experience was one of the more harrowing ones as dozens of offerings pushed into the tax-exempt market in recent weeks. They are all trying to get on the market before the Deficit Reduction Act, passed last July, imposes limits on the amount of tax-exempt bonds that state and local governments can issue to help finance projects of corporations or quasi-governmental agencies. **********The most important new restriction is on the amount of industrial development bonds that each state may issue. Another key provision would sharply reduce the profits municipal issuers could earn from investing the proceeds of bond sales in higher- yielding securities. **********The Treasury contends that tax-exempt industrial development bonds deprive the Federal Government of billions of dollars in revenue and unfairly subsidize some borrowers. **********Industrial development bonds are typically sold by a local government on behalf of a private company that will use the proceeds to build a new factory or warehouse. But the definition used by the Treasury includes financings for solid waste resource recovery plants, pollution control facilities and airports. **********The limitations are causing concern for those involved in financing local projects. Jim Caffrey, a spokesman for the Bergen County Utilities Authority in New Jersey, said, ''Under the Federal rule limiting each state's industrial development bond financings to $150 per person, we felt there wasn't any opportunity for us to get financing.'' **********Such worries have also fueled a surge in offerings. The volume of new tax-exempt bonds has been more than $11 billion in each of the last three months, up from a monthly average of about $6.2 billion in the first nine month of 1984. Bonds to finance resource recovery plants were in heaviest supply, with an estimated $2.5 billion of new issues sold in the last two months, or five times the amount sold in the previous five years. **********The flurry of activity has brought not only higher interest rates for some kinds of bonds, but also long hours for lawyers and financial advisers, delayed ratings on new issues, confusion among sales people and investors, and even a few typographical errors in normally letter-perfect bond- sale documents. **********'Pretty Hectic' **********''For a while things were pretty hectic,'' said John T. Feeny, president of Moore & Schley Municipals Inc. ''We got through the supply by putting extraordinarily attractive yields on bonds and selling them to institutions who just ate it up.'' **********In order for the market to digest the recent spate of new issues quickly, many of the offerings provide adjustable interest rates and allow investors to redeem the bonds instantly or with one week's notice. **********Those features helped open a new market for tax-exempts by attracting safety-conscious corporate treasurers with excess cash to invest. Even so, the glut was enough to cause interest rates to rise to about 6 3/4 percent from 5 3/4 percent in mid-November for bonds whose rate is adjusted weekly. **********Because of the Dec. 31 deadline for delivery of bonds, which marks the legal completion of a sale, securities firms are breaking the old rule of thumb that calls for bonds to be sold about two weeks before delivery. And the mechanics of putting out the documents for all these issues has become more complicated. **********''With modern technology and plants across the country, there is no real backlog in the printing of documents,'' said Roy A. Cardia, chief operating officer at the Sorg Printing Company, New York. ''But every surge in this business brings late- night sessions where the lawyers are writing and proofreading at the plant.'' **********Temporary Certificates **********While Mr. Cardia can print official statements quickly, there is a backlog for ornately engraved bonds. To complete new financings before the end of the year, securities dealers are using temporary bond certificates that will be replaced early next year. **********''We knew the supply was coming, but it has still been quite a crunch,'' said Freda S. Ackerman, head of the municipal bond rating department at Moody's Investors Service. ''Everyone may want to do their deal before the end of the year, but the issuers do not always have complete financial information, and that is usually the direct cause of a rating coming in late.'' **********For waste resource recovery plants, the rush to market was even more acute because they will need huge amounts of money; a new plant can cost upwards of $400 million to build. In the future, in order to get tax-exempt financing for such plants, local governments may have to own the facilities outright rather than build them for a private company to own and operate. **********Because construction on new resource recovery plants is not expected to begin for about two years, the recent bonds required special features to attract investors who are normally wary of projects using unfamiliar technology at a site still to be selected. Details vary from issue to issue, but generally the bonds are secured by an escrow account of Treasury securities until construction begins, when the bonds will be backed by the plant revenues. **********'Belts and Suspenders' **********Many issues also carry other guarantees for the preconstruction period. ''The market has seen an incredible variety of bonds supported by a lot of belts and suspenders,'' said J. Douglas Casey, national sales manager in the tax-exempt department at Kidder, Peabody & Company. **********A recent study by the National Governors Association concluded that the new limitations will force 14 states to curtail their offerings in 1985 to below their volume in 1983. **********Most states are setting up procedures that will allocate the allowed amount of financing among local governments and agencies. ''I expect there will be quite a bit of competition to get approval, and a lot of politics,'' said Morgan J. Murray, an executive vice president at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. **********Mr. Caffrey of the Bergen County Utilities Authority noted that the state Economic Development Authority could by itself use all of the $1.12 billion in financing that New Jersey will be allowed in 1985. He also said he found it ironic that some Federal agencies encourage development of waste recovery plants while the Treasury imposes regulations that make financing the facilities more difficult. **********The tax-exempt market also faces potential threats from the Treasury's tax revision proposals. For example, a little-noticed provision in the second volume of proposals disallows a tax exemption for bonds in which more than 1 percent of the proceeds are used by private business; that rule would have eliminated more than 60 percent of all tax-exempt bonds sold in 1983. **********''The Treasury Department has a long history of trying to curb the use of the tax-exempt market, and there is serious concern about the extent to which Congress will impose restrictions beyond those already in place'' said John Schopfer, vice president at Kidder, Peabody.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/04/busin.body_text: **********A senior State Department official said today that the Reagan Administration favored selling Alaskan oil to Japan as a way to offset the growing trade deficit between Japan and the United States. **********Allen Wallis, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, told a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee that ''to allow export of Alaskan crude would provide great economic benefit for the United States and help reduce the deficit with Japan.'' **********Sale of Alaskan oil in overseas markets has been banned, in part, because Congress felt the United States should not be exporting crude while buying oil abroad. **********The Administration has been pressing Tokyo to remove barriers to American goods and has made some progress, although Mr. Wallis and other officials agreed in testimony that there was still much to be done. **********Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce, said the deficit with Japan remained on the upswing, growing from $19 billion in 1983 to about $30 billion this year and a projected $36 billion in 1985.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/15/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new American-made automobiles rose 32.6 percent in the first 10 days of February from the corresponding period last year, the manufacturers reported today. **********The six major companies, General Motors, Ford, Chrysler, American Motors, Volkswagen and American Honda, sold 181,694 cars in the Feb. 1-10 period, or 20,188 daily, the best daily selling rate for the early February period since 1979. The companies sold 137,078 cars in Feb. 1-10, 1983. There were nine selling days in both periods. **********The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate was set at 7.8 million units, down from 8.9 million in late January but up sharply from 6.2 million last year. **********''It's difficult to make sense of the annually adjusted numbers, the way they have jumped around in recent periods,'' said Joseph Phillippi, an auto analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. ''Some of the strength late in January had to be from delayed deliveries.'' **********There is a long wait for some large cars that are selling well right now, he added, ''but these are still very good sales in very rotten weather and at a time of the year when sales are traditionally slow.'' **********Mr. Phillippi said there was one group of customers that had not yet returned to dealers' showrooms: ''The guy at the bottom end of the market is still not in on the recovery. The average factory worker, not at the car companies, is still not financially healthy enough or convinced in his own mind that he can afford a new car. He's worried about what interest rates might do yet this year.'' **********This absence of buying at the lower end of the market is causing imbalances in inventory at the manufacturers, with small, less expensive cars piling up, while wealthier customers wait for full size and luxury cars. **********Sales-Incentive Programs **********Arthur G. Davis, an analyst with Prescott, Ball & Turben, said he expected the increasing supply of small cars would lead to sales-incentive programs, probably financing below market rates or packages of options, in March or April. **********Analysts also noted that a wide range of incentive programs at the factory-to-dealer level were helping increase sales at all the major companies. **********In the Feb. 1-10 period, the Ford Motor Company led the auto makers in improved sales with a 65.5 percent jump from last year, to 51,166 units delivered. **********The General Motors Corporation reported sales of 99,353, up 18.9 percent. **********Both companies recently reported record earnings for 1983 and both are optimistic about sales for the near future. **********''We are in a strong winter market and the spring uptick is ahead,'' said Philip E. Benton, vice president of sales operations for Ford. ''The economic factors that pulled sales up in the past two months will keep the market moving.'' **********Robert D. Lund, vice president in charge of sales and marketing at G.M., said, ''Business in 1984 continues to be considerably stronger than we anticipated, and we look for sustained growth as we aproach the spring market.'' **********Chrysler Up 35.2% **********The Chrysler Corporation reported a 35.2 percent rise in sales, to 22,772 units. The American Motors Corporation estimated that it sold 4,600 cars in the period, up 9.5 percent from estimated sales of 4,200 last year. **********Only Volkswagen of America reported a decline - of 15 percent, to 1,329 cars delivered. Honda of America Manufacturing Inc., which began building cars in Ohio last spring, sold 2,747 units in the period. **********In the Jan. 1-Feb. 10 period, G.M. sales totaled 444,032, up 31.4 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. Ford sales of 190,388 were up 55.2 percent. Chrysler reported selling 92,163 new cars, a 44.1 percent increase, and A.M.C. said it sold approximately 18,871 units, up 3.9 percent. **********VW sales of 8,548 were up 19.9 and Honda sales totaled 11,121.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/22/busin.main_headline: BANK CHIEF NAMED AT FLORIDA NATIONAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; BANK CHIEF NAMED AT FLORIDA NATIONAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/22/busin.body_text: **********E. Bruce Bower, president and chief operating officer of the Florida National Bank and its holding company, Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., will become chairman and chief executive officer of the bank, it was announced yesterday. **********The appointment will be effective Jan. 1, following the retirement of George C. Whitner, 61 years old. **********Florida National said that Mr. Bower, who is 43, would be succeeded at the bank by Charles R. Hoskins, also 43. Mr. Bower will remain president of the parent company. **********Florida National, based in Jacksonville, is the fourth-largest bank holding company in Florida. On June 30, its assets totaled $4.7 billion. **********Mr. Bower joined Florida National in May 1982 when the bank acquired the Alliance Corporation from the Charter Corporation. At the time, Mr. Bower was president of the Jacksonville National Bank, a subsidiary of Alliance. Mr. Bower joined Jacksonville National in February 1972 and became its president a year later. **********Before joining Jacksonville National, Mr. Bower worked for the Citizens and Southern National Bank in Atlanta. **********Mr. Bower, a graduate of Johns Hopkins University, is married and has two children. **********Florida National's acquisition of Alliance was regarded as a way of repelling takeover attempts by the Southeast Banking Corporation and its Venezuelan ally, C.A. Cavendes Sociedad Financiera, which had been buying Florida National shares. **********As an additional antitakeover response, Florida National also entered into an agreement with the Chemical New York Corporation for Chemical to acquire Florida National whenever Federal law begins to allow interstate banking. **********In a telephone interview yesterday, John D. Uible, chairman and chief executive officer of the holding company, said the original agreement with Chemical had been amended. **********''When legislation permits, the acquisition now calls for 1.5 times book value, or $40 per share, whichever is greater,'' he said. **********Mr. Bower said: ''The agreement has sufficient flexibility to allow us to participate in a regional interstate banking scheme if we choose to do so. At the moment, however, we don't have any particular interest in acquiring anything outside the state of Florida.'' **********Speaking of Mr. Bower, Mr. Uible, who was the major controlling shareholder in Alliance, said: ''I have worked with him for 10 years, and I have a lot of confidence in him. He is an excellent manager.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/01/world.main_headline: ARMS UNIT CRITICAL OF LEFT AND RIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/01/world.print_headline: ARMS UNIT CRITICAL OF LEFT AND RIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/01/world.body_text: **********President Reagan's Commission on Strategic Forces has issued a report that is critical of the arms control approaches of both the Reagan Administration and its detractors. **********The report says both expect too much too soon from arms control talks with the Soviet Union. It urges a modest, step-by-step approach in arms negotiations. **********Several commission members and people close to the commission said the commission'sintention in the report was to create more support for arms control in the center of the political spectrum and to free the arms control process from what they saw as the unrealistic demands of the left and right, particularly with the political pressures of a Presidential election year. **********The report questioned the Administration's heavy emphasis on seeking sharp reductions in nuclear arms and the idea of a nuclear freeze advanced by many Democrats. It concluded that increased strategic stability, ''if it can be achieved at all, will come only after extended and sustained effort over many years.''  General Principles Stressed **********The Commission did not make a particular new arms-control proposal but stressed general principles: step- by-step approaches that take both sides' interests into account, agreement on a way to measure and reduce the destructive potential of dissimiliar kinds of forces and less concern about seeking large arms reductions and more concern about limiting first- strike weapons. **********The report was made public by the White House on March 23. It was accompanied by a brief statement that Mr. Reagan would review and comment on it later. **********Administration officials acknowledge that Mr. Reagan is not in a good position to disregard the commission's recommendations because commission members played a central role in gaining Congressional support for the MX missile program last year and their help is needed again. **********The commission, headed by Lieut. Gen. Brent Scowcroft, retired, was formed in January 1983. A report was made public in April with full Administration support and news conferences, and Mr. Reagan publicly embraced its recommendations. **********That report insisted on a package of force modernization and arms control: Congressional support for deployment of the new MX missile; a new, mobile and small Midgetman missile, and Administration commitment to serious efforts in the Geneva arms control talks. The final report reaffirmed these positions but advanced a number of new points that have not been well received in the most conservative quarters of the Administration.   Warning on Missile Defense **********In particular, the commission warned the President to proceed with ''extreme caution'' in doing anything that might jeopardize the existing Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972. This was intended by the commission and was taken by Administration officials to raise basic questions about Mr. Reagan's so-called ''Star Wars'' speech, in which he called for a program to develop new technology to protect the United States from incoming missiles. **********The report also warned against using current purported violations of arms limitation treaties by Moscow as an excuse to jettison arms control. The commission recommended maintaining ''a system of communication for review and correction of such incidents.'' **********Touching on the complexities of this matter, the commissioners noted: ''There may not always be available, however, effective responses proportionate to the violations themselves.'' According to several commission members, they were trying to say that no violations should be simply ignored or excused but that as a practical matter only continued serious violations should bring serious responses.   Answering Left and Right **********The report, according to some commission members, was addressed specifically to what they saw as a powerful group in the Administration opposed to arms control. To those who argue that the Soviet Union is trying to use arms control to lull the American people into a false sense of security and slow American military programs, the report retorted that the ''very fact of arms control negotiations also has utility,'' that ''arms control should be pursued because the peoples of the world expect it of their leaders'' and that ''careful definition and pursuit of realistic arms control measures'' should prevent Soviet manipulation. **********The commission's most critical comments, however, were reserved for liberal arms control advocates who, in the commission's judgment, make the mistake of believing that arms control can end the threat of nuclear war, reduce casualties and damage ''by itself'' should war occur, or open the door to ''deep or early cuts in defense budgets.'' **********In particular, the report condemned the nuclear freeze idea, which, it said, would be complicated to negotiate, would prevent force improvements that could increase nuclear stability and would do ''nothing to increase stability.'' A freeze, it stated, would also ''lock the United States into a permanent disadvantge in high-yield highly accurate missile warheads.'' In other words, the commission still favors the deployment of the MX. **********Commission members include former Defense Secretary Harold Brown, former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Thomas C. Reed, former special assistant to Mr. Reagan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/16/world.main_headline: BLUNT TALK MARKS REAGAN'S WELCOME FOR MEXICO'S CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/16/world.print_headline: BLUNT TALK MARKS REAGAN'S WELCOME FOR MEXICO'S CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/16/world.body_text: **********FRANCIS X. CLINES **********WASHINGTON, May 15 - President Reagan and President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico used a White House welcoming ceremony today to voice their disagreement over Central America. **********The Mexican President cautioned that the ''risk of a generalized war, the scope and duration of which no one can foresee,'' was growing in Central America. **********President Reagan, showing no less candor, told Mr. de la Madrid that ''responsible governments of this hemisphere cannot afford to close their eyes to what is happening or be lulled by unrealistic optimism'' in Central America. **********The flags of both nations snapped in a strong breeze outside the White House as the two leaders shook hands, surveyed the attendant array of diplomats and then punctuated what is normally a ceremony of gentle greeting with a blunt exchange of their differences. **********Reagan Picks Up on Theme **********Mr. Reagan was surprised at a welcoming ceremony in Mexico last August by President de la Madrid's caution about a show of force risking ''conflagration'' in the hemisphere, and he picked up on this theme as he greeted the Mexican President this morning on the South Lawn. **********''The conflagration in Central America appears too close to ignore,'' Mr. Reagan said. ''Like a fire in one's neighborhood, this threat should be of concern to every nation in the hemisphere.'' **********Mr. de la Madrid, in turn, after thanking Mr. Reagan for the ''cordial welcome,'' called on nations to reject ''interventionist solutions of any kind'' and to ''apply the principles and rules of international law established by the countries of the American continent.'' **********Disagreements Are Highlighted **********Their comments, although devoid of direct criticism, emphasized the two leaders' disagreement over Central America. The two Presidents then moved into a 45- minute private discussion that aides said afterward was largely taken up by the same question. A breakfast meeting was later scheduled for Thursday. On Wednesday, Mr. de la Madrid is to address a joint meeting of Congress.  Meanwhile, the White House announced today that President Reagan would meet Monday with Jose Napoleon Duarte, the President-elect of El Salvador. Mr. Duarte is also scheduled to meet with other Administration officials during the visit, which a White House statement described as having been arranged ''in order to carry forward U.S.-Salvadoran cooperation on bilateral and regional matters.'' **********The Reagan Administration has said it feels Mexico is underestimating the threat of what Mr. Reagan today termed a Soviet-backed ''totalitarian coalition'' undermining the hemisphere. **********Mexican officials, however, have questioned President Reagan's understanding of the historic forces of change in Latin America. Mexico has been friendly toward Cuba and Nicaragua and shown support for Salvadoran opposition groups. **********'Warmth and Good Will' **********On a personal level, the Mexican President praised the ''friendly and honorable dealings'' with Mr. Reagan and the support he extended to help Mexico deal with its debt problems. Mr. Reagan expressed ''warmth and good will'' in his welcome and praised ''the trust between us.'' **********''We do not agree on everything concerning this situation,'' Mr. Reagan said of Latin America, contending that the differences were not over ''goals or principles,'' but only over ''the means by which to achieve our goals.'' **********In denouncing ''aggressor regimes,'' he quoted Mr. de la Madrid's own book on constitutional law, saying, ''Liberty and equality are values incompatible with despotism.'' **********Mr. Reagan focused on what he called ''totalitarians'' who, he said, ''have been pouring gasoline onto the fire by pumping massive supplies of weapons into Central America and encouraging tyranny and aggression.'' He said this flow had been accompanied by ''thousands of Cuban and Soviet bloc military personnel'' in the region. **********Focuses on Need for Aid **********Mr. de la Madrid, although cautioning about the risk of widening war, focused on the need for social and economic development. ''Latin America is suffering the most severe economic crisis of modern times,'' he said. **********''Peace has been disrupted in Central America,'' Mr. de la Madrid said, ''and the risk of a generalized war, the scope and duration of which no one can foresee, is growing.  ''Every country on the continent,'' he said, ''must do its utmost to restore peace and avoid war by respecting and upholding the sovereignty of its people to decide their own destiny and by rejecting interventionist solutions of any kind.'' **********He added, ''Let us apply the principles and rules of international law established by the countries of the American continent: self-determination, nonintervention, equality of states before the law, peaceful solution of conflicts and international cooperation for development.'' **********Few Details on Private Talks **********Administration officials had few concrete details on the two leaders' private discussion. The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said he did not know whether they discussed such factors as the Administration's decision to suspend United States acceptance of World Court jurisdiction on Central American matters, the United States covert aid in the mining of Nicaraguan harbors and the Administration's warning that Cuba is planning a major offensive in the fall to try to topple the Salvadoran Government. **********Mr. Speakes said President Reagan expressed appreciation to Mr. de la Madrid for encouraging the Contadora group's peace efforts in the hemisphere. He said Mr. Reagan added that if the Contadora principles could be embodied in what Mr. Speakes termed a ''verifiable and enforceable'' agreement, then that would ''satisfy'' Nicaragua's neighbors and have the support of the United States. The Contadora group, comprising Mexico, Panama, Venezuela and Colombia, has been trying to negotiate a settlement of disputes in Central America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/27/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Accounts At Y. & R., Ayer Shift
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/27/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Accounts At Y. & R., Ayer Shift
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/27/busin.body_text: **********A S last week came to a close, N. W. Ayer and Young & Rubicam were party to a pair of account moves involving two of Ayer's oldest clients - Dart & Kraft Inc.'s Dairy Products Group and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********Ayer had been agency for both Sealtest and Breyers ice creams, Kraft products that compete with one another in a number of markets east of the Mississippi. **********But Breyers will become the first Kraft assignment at Y.&R., the largest American agency. **********Ayer, which was told that the move was the result of the competitive situation existing between the brands and the changing nature of ice cream marketing, will continue to be agency for Breyers yogurt as well as for Sealtest ice cream. The Ayer relationship with the company dates to 1929, when it was the National Dairy Corporation. Dart & Kraft spent $199.2 million for advertising in 1982, making it the nation's 31st-largest national advertiser. **********A number of A.T.&T. assignments were shuffled between the two agencies; most of them are still in the developmental stage and hush-hush. But the incoming assignments at Ayer involve credit cards for individuals and the development of the concept of giving telephone call credits as gifts. The only assignment that can be fully disclosed, though, is A.T.&.T. Communications, known as International Long Lines before the Bell System breakup, which goes to Y.&R., according to Philip Shyposh, advertising manager. The assignment is to encourage overseas telephone calls. **********Y.&R.'s Chicago office had something to celebrate as well. In competition with Doyle Dane Bernbach, New York, it won the International Harvester Company's corporate advertising account, formerly handled by Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago. The billings reportedly will be about $5 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/09/busin.main_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Managerial Shifts At Reader's Digest
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Managerial Shifts At Reader's Digest
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/09/busin.body_text: **********A raft of top managerial changes were announced yesterday by the board of directors of the Reader's Digest Association Inc. **********The announcement came on the same day that Lila Acheson Wallace, who along with her late husband, DeWitt Wallace, founded the Reader's Digest, died in Mount Kisco, N.Y., at the age of 94. **********The company said the managerial shifts had been planned long ago. **********In a release, the board said that, effective immediately, George V. Grune, 54, previously publisher of Reader's Digest, had been appointed chairman of the board and chief executive officer. **********He succeeds John A. O'Hara, 56, president and chief executive officer, who announced yesterday that he intends to retire in June. A company spokesman said that Mr. O'Hara's future plans were unknown. **********The post of chairman of the board has been unfilled since the retirement in 1978 of Kent Rhodes. **********In addition to Mr. Grune's appointment, the board announced that Richard F. McLoughlin, 55, would fill the newly created slot of vice chairman, and William J. Cross, 56, would become president and chief operating officer.  All three executives have been with the company for more than 20 years. **********Together with Kenneth O. Gilmore, 53, editor in chief, the three men will make up the executive committee of the Reader's Digest Association Inc. Mr. Gilmore became editor in chief last March, when Edward T. Thompson resigned, citing editorial differences with members of the Wallace Trust, which owns Reader's Digest. **********A graduate of Duke University, Mr. Grune joined the publishing company in 1960 as a member of its adversiting sales unit. After holding various marketing and advertising positions within the company, in 1977 Mr. Grune was elected a member of the board of directors. From June 1982 until July 1983, Mr. Grune served as chief executive officer of the Source Telecomputing Corporation, a company acquired by Reader's Digest in 1980. He became publisher of Reader's Digest on Jan. 1, 1984. **********Before his appointment as vice chairman, Mr. McLoughlin was director of new business and planning. He joined Reader's Digest in 1956, and in 1977 was elected to the board of directors. Mr. Grune said Mr. McLoughlin would also become publisher of Reader's Digest. **********Mr. Cross joined Reader's Digest as its chief accountant in 1961, following seven years at Time Inc. and three years with W. R. Grace & Company. He was named treasurer in 1973. In a statement, Mr. Grune said that Mr. Cross would have responsibility for the company's international business operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/14/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said tonight that the Soviet Union refused to renew relations with Israel because of its hatred of the Jewish people. **********Addressing a rally in support of Soviet Jews, Mr. Shamir said: ''There has never been a sensible explanation by Moscow of why it refuses to renew its ties with Israel. It can only be because of the Soviet Union's irrational hatred of the Jewish people.'' **********After the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, the Soviet Union severed its relations with Israel. **********Mr. Shamir appealed to the Soviet authorities to allow Jews who wish to do so to emigrate. **********The Soviet Union generally restricts emigration for all of its citizens. However, Jews have been permitted to leave in substantial numbers over the last 14 years, until a recent sharp decline in emigration. **********The Israel Public Council for Soviet Jewry said that last year 1,315 Jews were permitted to leave the Soviet Union, the smallest number since 1970. In 1979, a record 51,320 Jews left, but in 1982 only 2,672 were allowed out. **********Israeli officials appealed this week to Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, to allow Jews to leave the Soviet Union for Israel. **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said the hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews who had applied to come to Israel ''walk as shadows, with neither work nor livelihood, without reason to live, cut off and miserable.'' **********At a special Parliament session on the issue today, Speaker Menahem Savidor said the Soviet Union was ''trying to burn the souls of Soviet Jews through discrimination and vicious anti-Semitism.'' **********About 160,000 Jews have moved to Israel from the Soviet Union since 1970. **********The Council for Soviet Jewry says that in 1982 an estimated 10,000 Soviet Jews were refused exit visas. **********It says about 400,000 others requested an affidavit or invitation from Israel, the first step in a complicated emigration process, and those Jews endangered their careers and family future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/12/busin.main_headline: Market Place; The Challenge For Hewlett
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/12/busin.print_headline: Market Place; The Challenge For Hewlett
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/12/busin.body_text: **********W ITH a whirlwind of new products and price reductions buffeting the computer industry, competition has intensified, and even the industry leaders have had to adjust to the challenge. **********Consider the Hewlett-Packard Company, the nation's second-largest producer of minicomputers, after the Digital Equipment Corporation, and a growing factor in the personal computer field. **********Many analysts believe that Hewlett, long considered the country's most tightly run high-technology company, with half of its profits coming from other electronic equipment business, may benefit more than any other computer concern from the current improved economic environment. Others, however, see the marketing costs needed to keep up with competition cutting into profit growth of the company, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif. **********''During the next eight quarters there should not be the surprises - both negative and positive - that they experienced in the last five quarters,'' said Adam F. Cuhney, electronics analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc. **********After a disappointing 9 percent profit gain in the first fiscal quarter of 1984, Hewlett's per-share earnings in the second fiscal quarter, ended April 30, climbed 28 percent, to 55 cents a share. **********Analysts attribute this volatile earnings pattern, evident for the last two years, to the protracted recession, which significantly restricted management's ability to plan growth, manage assets and introduce key new products. They say that situation has ended and a period of improved production scheduling, easier inventory controls and rising backlogs is beginning. **********''Because of being totally dedicated to self-financing growth, Hewlett tends to have trouble adjusting to recovery business conditions,'' Mr. Cuhney said. ''They keep inventories tight and have a tremendous amount of production scheduling, and outlays for research and marketing.'' **********He said that in the last five quarters the company's gross profit margins had not varied by more than two-tenths to fourth-tenths of a percentage point, despite the fact that sales growth has varied from increases of 6 percent to 33 percent. ''Over the next two years,'' Mr. Cuhney went on, ''the company will better match dollar volume output to overhead expenditures.'' **********Some feel that Hewlett, which is shifting increasingly toward computers, has an identity crisis. ''For Hewlett to keep up with I.B.M. they're going to have to spend more money,'' said John Geraghty, electronics analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds. He noted that the company had recently increased its television advertising substantially. **********''People previously thought of Hewlett as an instrument-based company selling to a select clientele,'' Mr. Geraghty said. ''Now we are thinking in terms of a large-scale manufacturing company selling standard products such as personal computers through standard retail outlets where they are not well known. ''This will cost them even more to make their presence felt.'' **********He said that Hewlett, always a big spender on marketing, would have to spend even more now to meet the new competition. The company's marketing budget, he said, averaged 15 1/2 percent of the sales dollar between 1972 and 1982, but it rose to 16.4 percent in 1983 and has been running above 18 percent through the first two fiscal quarters of 1984. **********''Over the longer term, because they are becoming involved in more direct product competition with I.B.M., the premium that they previously enjoyed will probably be reduced,'' Mr. Geraghty said. He feels that Hewlett stock is a good investment for the short term because it is near its 52- week low of $31.25 a share. It closed yesterday at $35.375, off 62 1/2 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********There are other bullish factors that analysts point to at Hewlett. Its soon-to-be-introduced top- of-the-line computer series code-named Spectrum is expected to have a major impact on dollar volume. Prices of the models will range from $30,000 to $500,000. The company's previous top-priced model cost $250,000. **********A second plus, analysts say, is the market courted by Hewlett. According to a recently released Dun & Bradstreet survey, the fastest growth for capital spending by far will be among small and medium-sized companies - those with fewer than 500 employees. Hewlett's base for the 3,000 minicomputer series - a key product - fits this market perfectly, they say. **********The survey shows that companies with 100 to 1,000 employees have a growth rate of 20 percent, while those with 5,000 or more have a growth of only 7 percent. **********A third positive factor, analysts say, is Hewlett's portable computer, which will sell for about $2,995 and will compete against comparable models from Sharp and Compaq. The overall market for the portable computer is projected at 200,000 units in 1984, 300,000 to 350,000 in 1985 and more than 500,000 in 1986. **********''We believe that the company can achieve a portable-computer market share of 25 percent or more over the next 12 months,'' said Mr. Cuhney of Salomon Brothers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/20/busin.body_text: **********Jonathan Logan Inc., one of the apparel industry's largest producers, has scheduled a special board meeting today to consider a leveraged buyout of the company at $32 a share, according to Wall Street sources. Reports indicate that Richard Schwartz, chairman, will be a principal in the transaction, but he could not be reached for comment yesterday. **********Ira Cagan, Logan's treasurer, said that a board meeting would be held today but would not comment on reports of the buyout offer.  Heavy trading in Logan's stock yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was attributed to the reported buyout proposal. The stock was the biggest percentage gainer, jumping $2.375, to $27.875, on a volume of 191,100 shares.  Analysts said the company might be attempting to find a means of fighting off United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., which recently acquired a 9.8 percent stake in Logan. **********Last month, when United Merchants announced its investment, it said that it might seek control of Logan. A United Merchants spokesman said yesterday that the company had neither increased its position in the Logan stock nor made an offer to Logan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/27/world.body_text: **********President Hernan Siles Zuazo began a hunger strike today to protest a congressional censure of his decision to negotiate with drug traffickers. **********The traffickers are believed to be responsible for a $2 billion-a-year cocaine industry. **********''In an act of supreme protest, I have decided to declare a hunger strike to restore a climate of peace and reflection by all Bolivians,'' Mr. Siles Zuazo said in nationwide broadcast Thursday night. **********The 71-year-old President said his fast was designed to protest the congressional censure Wednesday of his decision to negotiate with cocaine smugglers in an attempt to end the country's drug trade.   Meeting With Drug Smuggler **********Conservative members of Congress voted 70 to 61 to condemn the President for allowing the former director of the Government's committee against drug trafficking to meet directly with the country's most important drug smuggler, Roberto Suarez, in June 1983. **********A Government official, Rafael Otazo, said that at the meeting Mr. Suarez offered $2 billion toward the country's foreign debt if the authorities would allow him to operate freely. The Government did not respond to the offer. **********Opposition legislators brought up the meeting last year for censure as part of an effort to oust Mr. Siles Zuazo. **********Drug trafficking is believed to be Bolivia's main export earner. This country sells about $2 billion a year in cocaine, much of it smuggled to the United States.   Default on Foreign Debt **********Bolivia, the second poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, defaulted on its $4.6 billion foreign debt in March. **********A cardiologist who examined him said Mr. Siles Zuazo, who was kidnapped for 10 hours last June in an unsuccessful coup attempt, was in good health but said his age could cause problems during the fast. It was not known how long he intended to fast. **********''I'm perfectly well,'' Mr. Siles Zuazo said today, about 12 hours into the strike. The President said he would continue working as usual. **********It was the second time the Bolivian politician has gone on a hunger strike during his presidency. The first was in 1956, in the first year of his initial presidential term, when he sought backing from the country for a drastic economic stabilization plan. That four-day fast was successful.
