https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/23/busin.main_headline: DeSoto Chief Welcomes A Looser Link to Sears
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; DeSoto Chief Welcomes A Looser Link to Sears
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/23/busin.body_text: **********When Richard R. Missar, the chairman of DeSoto Inc., announced this week that his company was buying back 867,609 shares of its stock from Sears, Roebuck & Company, it was a further assertion of DeSoto's independence from the giant retailer. **********He said the buyback was undertaken at ''our initiative,'' but was in line with the expressed desire of Sears to reduce its ownership in key manufacturing sources. This week's action reduced Sears's stake in DeSoto to 18 percent, from 31 percent. **********DeSoto, a paint and specialty chemicals manufacturer based in Des Plaines, Ill., was formed in 1910 as wholly-owned subsidiary of Sears. For the 12 months ended Sept. 30, DeSoto reported sales of $385 million. Of that total, purchases by Sears totaled $254 million. DeSoto still supplies roughly 95 percent of Sears's paint, according to Mr. Missar. **********He said the stock purchase, which was financed by a $31.7 million non- negotiable subordinated note, will not be burdensome for DeSoto. ''When we withdrew from furniture manufacturing in 1982 it freed up a tremendous amount of cash,'' the 55-year-old executive said. ''We have a very strong balance sheet.'' DeSoto has acquired four paint and specialty chemical companies this year. **********Mr. Missar said DeSoto's ''strategic thrust'' is to expand its private label marketing of coatings, detergents and chemicals. Other retailers that market DeSoto products under their own names include the Zayre Corporation and Home Depot Inc., he added. **********DeSoto has also targeted its industrial coatings segment for growth, according to Mr. Missar. The company's paint is used by major airframe manufacturers on their jet fleets and DeSoto is a leader as well in producing coatings that are used to make sensitive optical fiber cables more durable, he said. **********A chemist by training, Mr. Missar began his career with DeSoto in 1950. He later spent 10 years in sales and marketing and headed the company's paint manufacturing operations before moving on to various other executive positions. He was named chairman and chief executive officer in 1979. **********A native of Chicago, his studies at the Illinois Institute of Technology were interrupted by service in the Marine Corps from 1952 to 1954. Mr. Missar later graduated from Harvard University's Advanced Management Program in 1974. He is married and has three daughters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/19/busin.main_headline: TAXES ADD NEW TRAUMA TO DIVORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/19/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; TAXES ADD NEW TRAUMA TO DIVORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/19/busin.body_text: **********The new tax law has radically changed the tax **********treatment of divorce. In addition to the usual **********heartache of a marital breakup, the unwary may now find that the Government will take a much larger share of alimony payments than they originally anticipated, and may even be able to assess tax retroactively, years after a split-up. **********The Tax Reform Act of 1984 makes changes in three key areas: alimony, property transfers and dependency exemptions. The law will finally remove a major obstacle to property settlements that often meant husbands were saddled with a large capital gains tax on property that they transferred to their ex-wives as part of the settlement. And it will simplify the wrangling over which parent gets the dependency exemption for any children. **********But it may have some unintended negative consequences regarding alimony payments. ''It will change the whole economics of divorce,'' said Steven D. Kittrell, a partner in O'Connell & Kittrell, a Washington law firm specializing in divorce tax. ''There's just not going to be as much money to go around, because Uncle Sam will be taking more out of every payment.'' **********The basic rule, that alimony payments can be claimed as a tax deduction by the person making the payments (usually the husband) but must be reported as taxable income by the person receiving the payments (usually the wife), remains the same. But almost everything else has changed. **********Under the old rules, payments not designated as child support were considered alimony. But now, any portion of payments linked to a child is disqualified as alimony. For example, if an agreement specifies that alimony payments will drop by $100 a month once a child reaches age 18, $100 a month of the payments will now be considered child support (which is nondeductible by the husband and nontaxable to the wife) instead of alimony. The result is that husbands will be much less inclined to give generous child support payments and place more of the burden on the wife. ''People who are now on the margins may not be able to come up with the money,'' Mr. Kittrell said. **********Moreover, to qualify for the deduction, alimony payments in excess of $10,000 a year must last for at least six years, and they cannot vary by more than $10,000. If they fluctuate by more than that, they are subject to ''recapture'' - a new divorce tax concept introduced by the act. Recapture means that the Internal Revenue Service can go back and tax the early payments that qualify as alimony. The aim of these changes was to prevent large up-front payments that are really property settlements from being disguised and deducted as alimony. **********For example, if a husband makes payments of $25,000 in the first year and $12,000 in the second, then $3,000 (the difference of $13,000 minus $10,000) will be ''recaptured.'' The impact will be to treat excess payments in the first year as income to the husband and as a deduction for the wife. **********Mr. Kittrell, chairman of an American Bar Association committee that studied the problem, said that most matrimonial attorneys he has spoken with oppose the wide sweep of the new law. ''They are angered that Congress has intruded so much on what had been a state jurisdiction.'' **********Sandra K. Lewis, an editor specializing in divorce taxation with Prentice-Hall Inc., a publisher of tax material, said some people may wish to establish alimony trusts as a way to sidestep the onerous new alimony provisions. ''Trusts get you out from the recapture rules, and also allow for payments over shorter periods than six years,'' she said. **********The new law will also give the I.R.S. the wherewithal to track down women who have been receiving alimony payments, but have not been reporting the income on their tax returns. Now, men paying alimony must also furnish the Social Security numbers of their ex-wives. **********THE good news, however, in the 1984 tax law is **********that for the first time, spouses receiving alimony payments can treat them as compensation for purposes of an Individual Retirement Account. The maximum contribution is 100 percent of compensation or $2,000, whichever is less. Under the old law, alimony could be applied toward an I.R.A. only in very limited situations, and the maximum contribution was $1,125. **********The new law will also scuttle old treatment of property transfers connected with divorce. Under prior law, a husband who transferred appreciated property, such as the family home, to his wife as part of the divorce settlement was liable for capital gains tax on the increase in the property's value; the transaction was treated as a sale, even though the husband received no cash. Under the new law, property transfers from one spouse to another are considered nontaxable transactions. But the spouse receiving the property (usually the wife) now assumes the original tax cost of the property, and if she turns around and sells it the next day at a profit, then she must pay tax on the capital gain. **********''The planning for divorce transfers is now similar to the planning for gifts,'' said Sidney Kess, director of tax planning and policy with the accounting firm of Main Hurdman. ''In general, the strategy for the party who is making the transfer is to give property with a low basis and high value to the other spouse.'' **********The new property settlement rules went into effect on July 18, and the new alimony rules go into effect on Jan. 1, 1985. But people who are divorced or who reach property or alimony settlements in 1984 have the option of using the old or the new rules, whichever are more beneficial, providing both spouses agree. However, the new requirement for Social Security numbers applies regardless of whether the recipient is receiving alimony under the old or new rules. **********The new law also simplifies the rules about dependency exemptions. Starting Jan. 1, 1985, the parent who has custody of the child will get the $1,000 exemption, regardless of how much or how little that parent contributes financially to the child's support. The only time the custodial parent will not get the exemption is if he or she signs a written declaration waiving that right. **********The decision about who gets the dependency exemption ''can be changed on a year-to-year basis, depending on who needs the exemption most that year,'' said Paul W. Eldridge, a tax supervisor with the accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney.  Furthermore, he said, both parents can now claim a medical deduction for any medical expenditures they make on the child's behalf, as long as each parent's payments exceed the floor of 5 percent of their adjusted gross income. Previously, only the parent with the dependency exemption was able to claim a medical deduction for the child.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company today announced a record profit of $781 million, or $4.29 a share, in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a loss of $236 million a year earlier. The previous record earnings were $595 million in the first quarter of 1979. **********Sales for the quarter were up 34.8 percent, to $12.4 billion, from $9.2 billion in the same period in 1982. **********For the full year, aided by tax credits from past losses, Ford posted earnings of $1.87 billion, or $10.29 a share, in contrast to a loss of $657.8 million in 1982. The annual profit was also a record for the No. 2 auto maker, exceeding the $1.67 billion earned in 1977. **********Several Reasons Are Cited **********Philip Caldwell, chairman, said the surge in profitability ''was made possible by a combination of higher industry sales, a strong reception of our new cars and trucks and the cumulative effect of several years of productivity improvement and restructuring actions.'' **********Industry analysts have noted, however, that restraints on the import of Japanese cars have shifted some demand to domestic cars and permitted substantial effective price increases by permitting the ending of rebates and other sales incentives. **********The Ford report follows record earnings of $3.73 billion in 1983 posted by the General Motors Corporation and helps confirm projections that 1983 was a banner year for the domestic auto industry. When the Chrysler Corporation reports, as expected, next week, the Big Three should show combined profits in excess of $6 billion. **********According to the company's financial statements, Ford only paid $270.2 million in taxes for 1983, all of it on income earned overseas. Its earnings in the United States were not subject to income taxes because of losses sustained in previous years. If normal taxes had been paid, Donald Healy, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert, estimated, the 1983 profit would have totalled only about $1.22 billion. **********''Nevertheless, it's quite a turnaround, particularly in North America,'' Mr. Healy observed. ''Their operating margins are strong and they've picked up some market share.'' **********Ford's losses from 1980 through 1982 totaled $2.2 billion, primarily on operations in the United States, Canada and Mexico. **********Year's Sales Rise by 19.8% **********Sales for the year were up 19.8 percent, to $44.4 billion, from $37.1 billion in 1982. Unit sales during 1983 reached 5,002,000 cars, trucks and tractors, a 15 percent increase. The greater increase in dollar sales over unit sales reflects the higher effective prices of the company's products and increased consumer interest in larger, more expensive cars. **********In 1983, Ford's net income in the United States totaled $1.52 billion, compared with a loss of $1.1 million in 1982. The company said lower marketing costs were a factor in the recovery, along with increased sales volumes, greater market share and ''a more profitable sales mix.'' **********Outside the United States, the company reported a profit of $351 million, a decline of $109 million, which Ford attributed to the adverse efects of foreign exchange translations in Europe and Latin America and the costs of closing some overseas plants. **********As with G.M., the sizable 1983 earnings will mean good news to Ford employees, who will receive $69 million in profit sharing, or about $440 each. It will also be worthwhile for the 6,200 executives on the bonus roll, who will share a pool of $83 million. Like his counterpart at G.M., Roger B. Smith, it is expected within the industry that Mr. Caldwell's total compensation for the year will exceed $1 million. **********Mr. Caldwell noted that the profit sharing only applied to the 66 percent of the company's operations that are in the United States, while the bonuses will be paid to Ford executives worldwide. **********Stephen P. Yokich, the head of the United Automobile Workers union's Ford department, said in a statement that the company's earnings should strengthen its ''ability to continue moderation in the prices of Ford products for the benefit of consumers, while equitably sharing its economic progress with workers.'' **********But he said he was ''concered that there is a wide gulf between the amount earned by workers and the amounts paid to company executives.'' He said this disparity would be an issue in the contract talks that are scheduled to begin this summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/30/busin.print_headline: TECHNOLOGY; PROGRESS MADE ON HAY FEVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/30/busin.body_text: **********THE Labor Day holiday may mean rest to **********many, but for 18 million Americans this **********weekend also means something much less pleasant - the traditional high point of the hay fever season. **********Recent advances in medical technology, however, have produced more effective, more rapid, less costly treatments for hay fever. Some have recently been introduced; others are just coming to market. Indeed, research now being done may make hay fever a malady of the past. Among the companies involved are Merrell Dow, Fisons, Key Pharmaceuticals, and Johnson & Johnson. **********''The basic information on allergies has just burgeoned,'' said Dr. Jordan N. Fink, president of the American Academy of Allergy and Immunology. Many drug companies are developing products for the large international market. **********The benefits span nearly every business: Figures from various Federal agencies indicate that five million workdays a year - worth more than $300 million - are lost by hay fever sufferers in the United States alone, not counting the lower productivity caused by working in discomfort. **********''Hay fever'' is a misnomer. It does not come from hay and causes no fever. The name was coined 150 years ago in Britain, when people associated the runny nose and congestion - symptoms of fever - with the fall hay harvest. Instead, hay fever stems from a complex chemical reaction of the immune system of some people to proteins in pollen released from trees, grasses, weeds and fungi and breathed in from spring to fall. The condition is called ''allergic rhinitis,'' meaning an inflammation of the nose from an allergy.  In most people, pollen proteins are destroyed by the body's defense mechanisms. But hay fever sufferers have an inherited tendency not to destroy the pollen proteins but instead to produce another protein, called immunoglobin E, or IGE, in response. Both the hay fever proteins and the IGE attach themselves to certain body cells called ''mast cells.'' These cells then emit the chemicals that cause runny nose and other allergic irritation. The best-known chemical is histamine, but there are perhaps 10 others. **********Ragweed, which releases pollen in August and September, is the most common cause of American hay fever. It is most severe when heavy spring and summer rains spur ragweed growth and then dry, windy weather spreads the pollen. This year is a little worse than average in the New York area, said Dr. William I. Weiss, chief allergist at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., and developer of a regional pollen tracking system. **********The first defense against hay fever, medical experts say, is avoidance: staying in an air-conditioned room on bad days or far from sources. Mostly, avoidance is expensive and inconvenient. ''I finally found a case of a woman who goes to Europe every ragweed season,'' said Dr. Dorothy Sgon, allergy and clinical immunology chief at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. There is virtually no ragweed in Europe, although other plants cause hay fever. **********The next defenses are antihistamines - which block the irritation caused by histamines - or decongestants, which reduce inflammation, itching and runny nose. But antihistamines traditionally cause drowsiness as well, and decongestants are progressively less effective after a few days. **********An alternative, oral steroids, also eases hay fever symptoms, but can produce side effects such as higher blood pressure, more facial hair and thinning of bones. None of these drugs stops production of the irritating chemicals. **********Immunization is considered the most effective because it attacks the causes of hay fever. It works somewhat like a vaccine: Pollen proteins are injected and the body gradually becomes immune. Less IGE, histamine and other irritants are produced. **********The problem is that the injected pollen proteins can cause a major allergic reaction, so the process must start with very low doses and gradually be increased. Many dozens of shots are often required over several years: It is costly and can be painful. **********Against this backdrop, research has mushroomed. ''Every company that puts out an antihistamine is involved in new research,'' said Dr. Lynn Britton of Schering-Plough in Kenilworth, N.J. One new product Schering sells is Vancenase, a steroid sprayed into the nose. It acts locally, not systemically, reducing hay fever symptoms without the side effects. Syntex Laboratories of Palo Alto, Calif., has developed a similar product called Nasilide. **********The first antihistamines that do not cause drowsiness have recently been developed. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Cincinnati began selling Seldane in Europe in late 1981 and in Canada in May 1983; the company hopes to begin American sales early next year. Janssen Pharmaceutica, a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary, introduced Hismanal in Britain last year and is testing to obtain Federal approval for American sales. **********The Fisons Corporation of Bedford, Mass., last year introduced chromolyn sodium, which inhibits production of histamine and related chemicals that cause hay fever. It is sold as Nasalcrom, a nasal spray. **********Research sponsored by Key Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Miami has resulted in a new type of immunization that reduces the number of injections to 12 to 15 by linking hay fever proteins together in polymers. The system, developed by Dr. Roy Patterson, allergy chief at the Northwestern University Medical School, awaits Federal approval. **********Dr. Robert E. Reisman of the State University of New York at Buffalo is testing the same basic substance as a nasal spray. At the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, Dr. Lawrence M. Lichtenstein and associates are studying other bodily substances that cause hay fever, hoping to more clearly describe the basic process so the malady can be completely neutralized. **********One thing is clear, medical experts say. As Dr. Fink put it: ''Today we can do a lot about hay fever; next year we'll do even more.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/27/world.main_headline: BASQUE VOTERS FAIL TO GIVE CLEAR MAJORITY TO MODERATES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/27/world.print_headline: BASQUE VOTERS FAIL TO GIVE CLEAR MAJORITY TO MODERATES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/27/world.body_text: **********After a violent campaign in the Basque country, the moderate Basque Nationalist Party retained its hold on the regional Parliament today. But it did not gain the clear majority that would allow it to rule unchallenged. **********The Socialist Party, which controls the central Government in Madrid, did better than expected, consolidating its position as the second party in the Basque country, the three northern provinces. **********The nationalist party, the Herri Batasuna coalition, lost ground. The coalition, which is regarded as the political arm of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. and which campaigned under the slogan ''Punish with your vote,'' came in third. **********These elections, the second regional voting in the Basque area since the area won home rule in 1979, were to expand the regional Parliament from 60 members to 75 with a change in boundaries. The Socialists' gains will affect the Basque Nationalist Party's ability to pursue its goal of securing more powers for the autonomous region.   Relations With Madrid **********It will also change the equation in the often troubled relations between the Basque Government and the central Government. Carlos Garaikoetxea, the 45-year-old Basque Nationalist Party leader who will undoubtedly continue as the region's President, may have to seek more compromise than he would like with the regional Socialists, who are tied directly to Madrid. **********In the outgoing regional Parliament, which was seated four years ago, the Basque Nationalist Party had 25 of the 60 seats but governed with an effective majority because Herri Batasuna, which regards the Parliament as a tame organization under Madrid's domination, refused to take its 11 seats. **********Herri Batasuna has said it will continue the boycott, but even so the Socialists gained enough seats - making deeper inroads than any national party ever in the fiercely nationalistic region - to hold the Basque Nationalists' margin down. **********With over 97 per cent of the vote counted, the Basque Nationalist Party had won 32 seats, the Socialists 19, Herri Batasuna 11, the right-wing Popular Coalition 7, and the leftist, pacifist Euskadiko Ezqurra 6.   Socialists Gain 10 Seats **********In the outgoing Parliament, the Socialists had nine seats. Their rise was seen in part as a reaction to the continuing terrorist violence. Their slogan was simple: ''For peace.'' **********Despite bad weather, with rain over much of the area and snow in the mountains, the turnout among the 1.5 million eligible voters was high, over 68 percent. Security was tight during the balloting, with some 5,000 police stationed near voting areas, but no major incidents were reported. **********Terrorist violence overshadowed the two-week election campaign, which opened and closed with the funerals of victims. **********On the weekend of Feb. 12, police battled Basque separatists who were protesting the killing of suspected E.T.A. members just across the French border by a shadowy right-wing death squad, that calls itself G.A.L., or Anti- terrorist Liberation Groups, and professes to oppose terrorism by Basque separatists.   Riots Follow Killing **********On Saturday, which was supposed to be a ''day of reflection,'' police and demonstrators clashed once again in the streets of San Sebastian, the resort capital of Guipuzcoa province. Youths there overturned and set fire to buses in anger over the most recent G.A.L. assassination, only the day before. **********In a call to the Spanish news agency EFE, G.A.L. claimed to have assassinated Eugenio Gutierrez Salazar, a 30- year-old Basque exile nicknamed ''The Tiger,'' who was thought to be a member of E.T.A. Gunmen shot him Friday from a passing car in the French village of Idaux Mendy. The slaying was the fifth claimed by G.A.L., which has vowed to avenge E.T.A. killings one for one, since the group emerged in December. **********Major parties suspended campaigning in shock and anger over the assassination Thursday of Enrique Casas Vila, a prominent Socialist and senator who was heading the ticket in Guipuzcoa. His death, which was thought to have triggered the G.A.L. reprisal, brought a 24-hour protest strike and highlighted the issue of violence as never before, since he was the first member of Parliament to fall under an assassin's bullet since democracy was restored eight years ago. **********Mr. Casas's funeral, attended by the Socialist Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, turned into an emotional and gloomy demonstration against terrorism, with thousands lining the narrow streets chanting ''E.T.A. assassins'' as the cortege passed.   Anarchist Splinter Group **********The most active, hard-line group of ETA, the ''military'' faction, denied having anything to do with the Casas killing. An anarchist splinter group called the Autonomous Anticapitalist Commandos, whose relationship to the militant wing is not altogether clear, claimed responsibility. **********The effects of the continuing violence, which was perhaps not more widespread than usual but may have been more horrifying because it occurred during an exercise of democracy, were evident in final statements from the parties and in remarks by candidates as they voted. **********''The cycle of death and violence is leading us to a dead end and supports the enemies of liberty who want to push this country into the brink of disaster,'' the Basque Nationalist Party said in a statement. **********Jose Maria Benegas, the Socialist contender for presidency of the regional Government, said, ''All I feel is that at the end of the campaign we've had a climate of terrible violence.''  Socialists' Strength **********The Socialists had been looking to a large turnout to help them consolidate and expand the gains they won in the general elections of October 1982, which swept them into control of the central Government in Madrid. In that year, in the Basque region, they for the first time surpassed Herri Batasuna to become the No. 2 party, behind the Basque Nationalist Party. Nearly half the region's three million people are non-Basques. **********The campaign was marked by bitter exchanges between the Basque Nationalists and the Socialists, which even descended to the level of personal insults. Mr. Garaikoetxea centered his re-election bid on the theme that the region must be given more powers under autonomy statutes negotiated in 1979, arguing that only this could make for an effective, local administration that would undermine support for E.T.A. **********He attacked the Socialists, both in Madrid and locally, for ''foot dragging'' in the complicated devolution of powers over everything from taxation to education and police. **********The Socialists, who have turned toward more effective police measures and cooperation with France to defeat E.T.A., have on occasion hinted that the Basque Nationalist Party is using E.T.A. as a tool to secure more autonomy. Mr. Benegas has argued that a Socialist government in the Basque region would have more success in drawing powers from a Socialist government in Madrid. **********The autonomy debate overshadowed the issue of unemployment in the heavily industrialized area centered in Bilbao, which is running 2.5 percent higher than the national average of 17 percent. The central Government's plans for ''industrial conversion,'' to share down industries to make them competitive with those in Common Market countries, has a deep bite on the Basque steel industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/17/world.body_text: **********Janos Kadar, the Hungarian leader, said today that there was no leadership crisis in Moscow and that the Soviet Union was under ''collective, collegial'' control. **********His remarks came at joint news conference here with President Francois Mitterrand. Mr. Kadar's visit to France is the first by a Soviet-bloc leader since Mr. Mitterrand took office in 1981, and it coincides with a visit to West Germany by Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania. **********Mr. Kadar was asked by a reporter to explain who was effectively running the Soviet Union and the nature of the role of Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, who is thought to be ill and playing a diminished role. **********The Hungarian leader said it was wrong to talk about a crisis in Soviet leadership, which has been a subject of speculation and analysis in the West. **********''It is a stable leadership'' he said, ''and the continuity of its leadership is the mark of its stability.''  Kadar Assesses Soviet Leaders **********The Soviet leaders, he said, referring to those since Nikita S. Khrushchev, have been men of differing temperaments and diverging characters, while remaining profoundly Soviet. Although he mentioned Mr. Chernenko, Mr. Kadar did not define his role. Rather, he said, there is a ''collective, collegial leadership.'' **********Mr. Kadar's two days of meetings with Mr. Mitterrand were low-key. French officials, in contrast to the West German Government's attitude toward Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conversations with Mr. Ceausescu, made no effort to present the visit by Mr. Kadar as a major event. The reason is that a wide consensus, including both the right-wing opposition and Mr. Mitterrand's Socialist Party, appears to share the assessment that, for all its difficulties, the East-West relationship is not in a critical phase. **********As if to emphasize the French perception, the room in Elysee Palace where the news conference was held was only half-full. The French press has given little attention to Mr. Kadar's visit.   Kadar Calls Visit Meaningful **********The Hungarian leader described his meetings with Mr. Mitterrand as meaningful within the context of East- West relations. In reply to a question about the significance of his visit to France, after the cancellation of planned trips to West Germany by Erich Honecker of East Germany and by Todor Zhivkov of Bulgaria, Mr. Kadar replied: **********''Without trying to exaggerate, I think the talks here have a certain importance.'' **********He said he felt he and Mr. Mitterrand had found some areas of common language that could serve as an example to others.  The two men stressed the importance of resuming arms talks and reducing what Mr. Mitterrand referred to as ''overarmament.'' He said, ''We know that the negotiations must start again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/14/busin.body_text: **********The nation's six major automobile manufacturers today reported a 31.8 percent gain in car sales in the first 10 days of the year, from the corresponding period a year earlier. There were seven selling days in each period. **********Total sales were 149,127 cars, for a daily selling rate of 21,304, the highest for the period since 1973, when the rate was 23,390 a day. **********For domestically produced cars, sales were at an annual rate of 8.2 million units, up from 6.1 million a year earlier. The figures are adjusted for seasonal variation. **********'Nice Way to Start' **********''It's a nice way to start the year,'' said Joseph Phillippi, an auto analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. ''With all the bad weather, all the economic worries, and with low inventories and shortages in some car lines, it's a very good way to start.'' **********David Healy of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. called it ''a good, strong performance.'' He said: ''There are no major distortions in these numbers. They are just continuing the strength of the last couple of periods.'' The annual selling rates in the mid- and late-December periods were 8 million and 8.1 million, respectively. **********Mr. Phillippi said the latest data were encouraging, but he cautioned that ''a few periods don't make a trend.'' He added: ''You must remember that there were a lot of delayed deliveries at the end of the year that fell into this period. But that's fine, and at least we're getting caught up.'' **********Mr. Phillippi said he did not foresee any changes in production schedules in light of today's strong report. Just after the Christmas and New Year holidays, the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company slightly trimmed their first-quarter production schedules, mostly because of sluggish sales of small cars. **********Many analysts say the annual sales rate throughout the first quarter will be between 7 million and 8 million, and they predict car sales for the year of between 10 million and 10.5 million units, including sales of about 2.4 million imports. Imports are being restrained by voluntary export curbs adopted by Japan in response to pressure from Washington. **********25.6% Jump at G.M. **********In the Jan. 1-10 period, General Motors sold 91,488 new cars, an increase of 25.6 percent. Robert D. Lund, vice president in charge of sales and marketing staff, said: ''G.M.'s model-year car sales continue to run 20 percent ahead of last year's pace. There is every reason to expect this sales improvement to continue in coming months.'' **********Ford's sales soared 43.9 percent, to 32,673. The Chrysler Corporation sold 16,935 vehicles, up 32.4 percent, and the American Motors Corporation sold an estimated 3,925, up 3.3 percent. **********Volkswagen of America reported an increase of 27.2 percent, to 1,239. The American Honda Motor Company, which began making cars in Ohio in the spring of 1983, said it sold 2,876 domestically produced cars.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/22/busin.main_headline: MANILA'S NUCLEAR PLANS SPUR IRE AND REFLECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/22/busin.print_headline: MANILA'S NUCLEAR PLANS SPUR IRE AND REFLECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Of the many ambitious development projects started by President Ferdinand E. Marcos, the biggest construction venture of them all has been a $2 billion nuclear power plant here on Bataan Peninsula, overlooking the South China Sea. **********With completion near, the plant has become a hotly contested issue, uniting opponents of the Government with opponents of nuclear power. **********Moreover, it has become the focal point for a rethinking of the development strategy pursued during Mr. Marcos's 19-year rule. Much of the strategy emphasized large industrial projects that were costly, employed few and relied on sophisticated technology. **********The Government itself, faced with a faltering economy and an inability to keep up on foreign debts, is joining in the re-examination. It is shifting from industrial projects toward export-earning agricultural development, which provides more jobs and consumes less capital. **********And the international lending organizations and overseas banks are also back-to-the-farm enthusiasts. **********A Westinghouse Plant **********Still, the policy change does not alter the fact that the Philippines has huge amounts of money sunk into some big industrial projects, especially the nuclear plant, which was supplied by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. **********The price tag on the Bataan plant is more than three times the $650 million standby credit that the Government says it will obtain from the International Monetary Fund. Looked at another way, the cost amounts to nearly 10 percent of the nation's foreign debt of $25.6 billion. **********Geronimo Z. Velasco, the Minister of Energy, says he has no doubts about the safety of the Bataan plant. ''But for a developing country like the Philippines, I question the wisdom of building a costly nuclear plant,'' said Mr. Velasco, who is also chairman of the National Power Corporation. **********The Philippines is among the poorest of the 22 countries that have chosen nuclear power. Those poorer, such as India, tend to be nations that are believed to have experience with nuclear technology through weapons development. **********Handling an Emergency **********The three East Asian countries that have taken the nuclear path - Japan, Taiwan and South Korea - are far more advanced than the Philippines. Much of the argument against operating the plant, despite all the money spent, is that the Philippines does not have the skill to handle an emergency, should one arise. **********Among those opposed to the plant are some who would oppose anything the Government does, and others convinced that nuclear technology is dangerous under any circumstances. But many others simply question whether a country where the telephones and lights often do not work, where the water service is intermittently shut off, is an appropriate place for a nuclear plant. **********''This Government cannot provide its people with the most basic services reliably,'' says Salvador H. Laurel, president of the United Nationalist Independent Democratic Organization, which includes the main opposition parties. ''So we can't risk letting it try to run something so delicate as a nuclear plant.'' **********For their part, Westinghouse officials in the Philippines say that the plant is safe and that the Filipino operators are proficient. As of late August, the National Power Corporation said it had 35 engineers who had passed a course in the United States similar to that administered by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Only 24 certified operators are required to run the plant. **********''We think the Filipino operators here definitely have the capability to run this plant safely,'' said M. W. Walcher, vice president for the Westinghouse International Projects Company. **********Last May, the plant was tested by bringing it up to normal operating temperature and pressure, but using electrical energy instead of nuclear power. It was done efficiently, with no significant problems, according to Mr. Walcher, who said it compared favorably with similar tests in other countries. **********A Product of the Oil Embargo **********The decision to buy a nuclear plant was made in 1974, after the Arab oil embargo and at a time when the Philippines got 96 percent of its energy from imported oil. But since the ground breaking in 1976, the plant has been plagued by cost overruns, delays caused by safety questions and charges of improper payments. **********Meanwhile, largely because of its successful geothermal program, the nation's dependence on imported oil has fallen to 57 percent this year. ''If we knew in 1974 what we know now, we never would have gone ahead with the nuclear plant,'' Mr. Velasco says. **********The plant is intended to supply 15 percent of the power on the nation's most populous island, Luzon. That is the equivalent of six million barrels of oil worth roughly $180 million a year. **********But if the plant never opens, the Philippines would still bear a net cost of $155 million a year, considering interest expenses and other factors. **********Last month, groups against the Bataan plant filed suit with the Supreme Court, calling for public hearings on its safety and cost before the National Power Corporation is licensed to operate it. **********And recently President Marcos directed the Philippine Atomic Energy Commission to investigate the safety of the plant once again.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/23/busin.body_text: **********THERE may have been joy on Wall Street last **********week over the continued fall in interest rates **********and the rally in the bond market, but that euphoria could be short-lived. The consensus among many professional bond managers is that interest rates will move upward in early 1985 and the bond market will sag. As a result, some managers have shortened the average maturity of their holdings, while others plan to do so in coming weeks and some have sold off holdings and have moved into short-term instruments like Treasury bills and commercial paper. **********These investors are troubled by the recent indications that the economy is stronger than previously thought. They think that the strong economy, coupled with continued credit demands, will heat up inflation and cause interest rates to rise. ''We think the bond rally is about over with,'' said William H. Gross, managing director of the Pacific Investment Management Company in Newport Beach, Calif. ''There is no more juice that the Fed can safely allow to flow into the marketplace.'' **********Of course, it should be noted that many bond managers were asleep at the switch when the bond market burst open last summer. Consequently, they have been as unable to beat their market proxy - the Shearson Lehman Brothers Index - just as their colleagues who specialize in buying stocks have been unable to beat the Standard & Poor's 500 Stock Index. **********According to S.E.I. Funds Evaluation Services, a Chicago firm that measures 5,300 stock and bond portfolios, only 26 percent of the nation's bond managers beat the Shearson Lehman Index for the first nine months of this year. The median bond fund was up 6.1 percent compared with the 7 percent rise of the Shearson Index for the first three quarters. In a typical comment about this year's bond rally, George Collins, president of T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, which had only 70 percent of its accounts in cash instruments before the rally, said: ''We were non-believers of this whole market.'' **********Nevertheless, many of these professionals are now cautious about the market. One bond firm which has attracted almost $8 billion in institutional funds in recent years is Pacific Investment. According to Mr. Gross, his firm has some $2.5 billion set aside in cash instruments. And in the next few weeks, the firm's managers will be shortening the average maturity of the issues in the client portfolios from 10 years to seven or eight years, he added. (Since when interest rates climb the value of bonds fall, traders, in anticipation of higher rates, tend to sell off their longer holdings, thereby reducing the average maturity.) **********Likewise at the Marine Midland Bank, Wayne Wong, senior vice president and head of the bank's $2 billion fixed-income trust department, reported that he had lowered the average maturity of his holdings from 15 1/2 years to 10 1/2 years. ''We feel rates have pretty much hit bottom,'' he said. About 28 percent of Mr. Wong's portfolios are now parked in cash. And if the market continues to rally, Mr. Wong plans to sell some of his intermediate bonds and go into two- or three-year issues rather than 7- to 10-year bonds. **********At T. Rowe Price, which manages more than $9 billion in fixed income accounts, Mr. Collins said that the average maturity in client portfolios is now 13 years. To lower that to 10 years, he said that the firm's managers will sell some of their 25-year bonds and buy 3- and 4-year issues. ''If you get a discount rate cut, the market could perform well for a week or two,'' he said. But after that, the reporting of strong economic numbers and the pressure to reduce the budget could ''weaken the market,'' he added. **********Of course, there are those who disagree and have put almost all of their clients' assets in long-term issues, primarily Treasury Bonds. One who has been extremely successful this year is S.T.W. Fixed Income Management in Santa Barbara. Its institutional accounts are up 15 percent through November. According to Billy H. Williams, a principal of the firm, almost all of his clients' portfolios are invested in long-term Treasuries issues. ''It looks to me like interest rates are pretty high at 11 1/2 percent,'' he said, explaining his investment posture. ''Inflation is a lot lower than 11 1/2 percent so they seem like a good thing to invest in.'' **********Mr. Williams said that in making investment decisions he does not forecast interest rates or try to determine the direction of the bond market. He said that he simply tries to find the cheapest bonds available and sell them when they no longer seem cheap. Like others, he doubts that anyone could forecast rates. If people actually had that predictive ability they could invest their own assets, Mr. Williams noted, and their ''wealth would be so great that I'd doubt that they'd be managing other people's portfolios. They could have purchased several small countries and be kings instead of money managers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/24/world.body_text: **********A judge today ordered a week-long recess in the trial of nine churchmen, including three priests, accused of ambushing and killing a mayor and four aides in 1982. **********The nine assert that the military trumped up the charges because they had been organizing farm workers to resist abuses by soldiers and rich sugar planters. **********Prosecutors asked that today's session be canceled because they had other cases that needed attention. **********More than 200 people, including representatives of the Australian and Irish Governments, Catholic bishops and two dozen reporters and cameramen, jammed into the courtroom. **********The Rev. Brian Gore of Perth, Australia, the Rev. Vicente Dangan, a Filipino, had been jailed for one month and the six Filipino lay workers for more than eight months. The trial is expected to last several months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/06/busin.body_text: **********Two entertainment companies reported quarterly earnings yesterday. MCA Inc., said its profit in the third quarter fell 23.2 percent as revenues edged up 1.5 percent. **********The MGM/UA Home Entertainment Company said earnings rose 15.9 percent in its fourth fiscal quarter on a 9.8 percent increase in revenues. **********MCA Inc. **********MCA, citing disappointing results of theatrical film releases, said that net income in the latest quarter fell to $35.4 million, or 72 cents a share, from $46.1 million, or 95 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. MCA, which owns Universal Studios, said revenues increased to $412.7 million from $406.8 million. **********MCA's book publishing division reported record third-quarter operating income, while its retail mail-order division reported an operating loss. MCA had lower investment income because of tax reasons and a lower average amount of funds invested.  The company's music publishing and recordings division reported record third-quarter earnings. **********MGM/UA **********MGM/UA Home Entertainment said that net income in the latest fiscal quarter ended Aug. 31 rose to $13.1 million, or 44 cents a share, from $11.3 million, or 38 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues jumped to $51.4 million from $46.8 million. **********For the full fiscal year ended Aug. 31, MGM/UA said that net income rose 18.6 percent, to $46.6 million, or $1.58 a share, from $39.3 million, or $1.40 a share, in the fiscal year 1983. Revenues increased 22.7 percent, to $197.2 million, from $160.7 million. **********MGM/UA, based in New York, is one of the world's largest distributors of filmed entertainment for pay television and home video and is 85 percent owned by the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, based in Culver City, Calif. The company handles worldwide marketing of the film libraries of the MGM and United Artists studios.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/10/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; An Unresolved Issue: Taxation
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/10/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; An Unresolved Issue: Taxation
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/10/busin.body_text: **********WHAT will be done about taxes after the election? The 1984 political campaign appears to be driving the candidates further and further apart on how to deal with the looming budget deficits, which the Democratic challenger, Walter F. Mondale, has sought to make the key economic issue of the election. **********During Sunday night's televised debate, Mr. Mondale said that a re-elected Mr. Reagan would have to propose a tax increase. Mr. Reagan, in response, declared that he would not raise taxes. **********Asked by a reporter whether he intended to stand by that statement or qualify it as in the past by saying he would raise taxes only as a ''last resort,'' Mr. Reagan indicated the latter and then defined what he meant by ''last resort.'' **********He said it would require two conditions: (1) if further spending cuts meant the Government would no longer be performing some vital services; (2) if economic growth was providing the ultimate in revenues and still did not catch up with slower-rising spending. But Mr. Reagan said he did not foresee those things happening and therefore was confident he would not seek a tax increase. **********While the Presidential candidates are being driven apart by the combat of the campaign - ''politics ain't beanbag,'' as an old dictum has it, and a Presidential debate is not an economics seminar - a less-noticed consensus seems to be forming among other Republican and Democratic leaders on what to do about the tax system. **********Two potential Presidential contenders for 1988, Representative Jack Kemp, the upstate New York Republican, and Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat, have both introduced bills that would broaden the tax base and reduce tax rates as the key to providing the nation with a tax system that would be more likely to sustain economic growth and to be simpler and fairer. **********The bills differ in their details, but both amount to modified flat-tax proposals. Mr. Kemp is proposing a flat tax of 25 percent, after creating a floor for lower-income taxpayers. Similarly, Mr. Bradley would bring down tax rates to a three-step structure rising from 16 percent at the bottom to 30 percent at the top. **********In their discussion about taxes in The New York Times of Oct. 2 last year, Mr. Kemp, co-author of the Kemp-Kasten ''FAST'' tax bill - FAST being an acronym for fair and simple tax - warmly embraced the Bradley-Gephardt ''Fair Tax,'' saying that the two bills ought to be merged. **********Senator Bradley was more cautious about accepting the Kemp-Kasten bill, presumably because it has less progressivity than his own. Neverthless, a marriage between some version of the two bills is not unthinkable. **********Some Democrats believe that Mr. Mondale made a mistake in calling for measures to impose surcharges, especially on upper-income taxpayers and corporations, but reaching down to families of four with incomes of $25,000 or more. They would have preferred to see him go for the Bradley-Gephardt bill. **********President Reagan has also spoken up for greater simplicity in the tax code, but he has yet to give clear support to the Kemp-Kasten bill. His Treasury Secretary, Donald T. Regan, indicated at a breakfast meeting with reporters last week that, in the report he is preparing for the President, which is to be delivered after the election, he is likely to urge tax reform along flat-tax lines. **********Both President Reagan and Mr. Mondale have understandable reasons to hold back from being specific during the political campaign about how they would go about closing loopholes and eliminating tax shelters, deductions and exemptions. Virtually all of these base-broadening moves are likely to provoke stiff resistance in Congress and political opposition from assorted blocs of voters. **********To get any sort of modified flat tax through after the election, whoever is President would be likely to try to make it revenue-neutral, rather than a big revenue-raiser. Nevertheless, there is a lot of revenue ultimately to be raised from base broadening. The Congressional Budget Office has identified 25 such changes that would raise $90.4 billion annually in tax revenues by the fiscal year 1989. **********Should discussion of these matters be conducted during this electoral campaign, laying the foundation for changes to come? Or is this a fit subject, as the economist Alan Greenspan has suggested, only for a smoke-filled room - after the election? As the debate between the candidates heats up, this key issue may yet emerge into the open.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/04/busin.body_text: **********BUENOS AIRES BERNARDO GRINSPUN, Economics Minister of Argentina's two-month old democratic Government, describes one of his critics as a ''worker for dictators'' and calls another ''a crystal ball gazer.'' A third, he says, ''doesn't know what he's talking about.'' **********Mr. Grinspun is what Argentines call a person with no hair on his tongue - he speaks his mind in no uncertain terms. That outspokenness is only one of several traits that set the 58-year-old economist apart from many of his more decorous predecessors. He is also only the third Jew ever to hold a ministerial post in this officially Catholic state, a man of humble origins in a position often held by patricians and an unreconstructed politician doing what in the last decade has been mostly a technocrat's job. **********Whether Mr. Grinspun's unusual background and opinionated manner will have any impact on the Argentine economy remains to be seen. But clearly some break with the past is required: Mr. Grinspun and the fledgling Administration of President Raul Alfonsin, whose election last October followed eight years of military rule, are facing the worst economic crisis in Argentine history.  ''All the economic variables are out of control,'' Mr. Grinspun groaned in a recent interview. ''It's a very tough challenge, but what we want now is to slowly put them back together again, into an understandable scheme, without any traumatic moves that could disturb the social peace and democracy Argentines have just won.'' **********The challenge is formidable. Last year, Argentina's annual inflation rate soared to 434 percent - making it the world's most inflationary nation. Although the economy did grow a bit last year, after a two-year recession, real wages remain far behind what they were a decade ago and a third of the nation's industrial capacity is idle. Meanwhile, in a bountiful breadbasket that is one of the world's leading exporters of beef and grain, childhood malnutrition has grown alarmingly and soup kitchens are thriving. **********These problems are compounded by Argentina's $43 billion foreign debt - the world's third largest, after Brazil and Mexico. The sum is so strapping that the new Government has declared a moratorium until July on the interest payments. The Government has also put off until late summer all refinancing negotiations with international banks. **********Once they do resume, the negotiations are expected to be the toughest yet faced by the bankers, who will be owed $6 billion in accrued interest payments alone by the end of the year. ''Paying is a matter of honor,'' Mr. Grinspun said, although he acknowledged that the resumption of interest payments - nothing has been paid since last October - is not his first priority. And he offered no definitive repayment schedule. When Aldo Ferrer, president of the powerful, state-owned Bank of the Province of Buenos Aires, for example, suggested that Mr. Grinspun limit the country's debt payments to 15 percent of its exports, Mr. Grinspun rejected the idea. ''Why should I pay 15 percent when I may have a trade surplus of 20 percent?'' he asked. ''I want to use everything I can to pay off this debt.'' **********Bolstered by grain exports, Argentina's trade surplus is expected to reach $3.5 billion this year. **********Mr. Grinspun said that reviving the Argentine economy is of more immediate importance than debt repayment. He said he would attempt to stimulate the Argentina economy by simultaneously increasing real wages and slashing hyperinflation. He would do this partly by continuing a price freeze now in effect and partly by reducing the Government's budget deficit. The latter would be achieved through a cutback in spending and a surcharge on consumer goods that would raise new tax revenue. Once prosperity returned, Mr. Grinspun said, enough wealth would be generated to pay the foreign debt. His critics contend that these goals, while laudable, aren't practical. **********MR. Grinspun's self-assurance in tackling Argentina's huge economic problems stems in part from his close relationship with the President. He is a longtime political confidant, friend and economic adviser of Mr. Alfonsin. Before the President and his wife recently moved to the Presidential residence, the two families were regular visitors in each other's homes. **********It is a relationship that dates back three decades, when Mr. Grinspun and Mr. Alfonsin were doctoral students, Mr. Alfonsin in law and Mr. Grinspun in economics, at the University of Buenos Aires. There, they found their respective upbringings and politics a common ground for friendship. Mr. Alfonsin, the son of a country store owner, and Mr. Grinspun, the son a clothing retailer, both worked their way through school and were activists in the Radical Party, now in power under Mr. Alfonsin's leadership. **********Even as a teen-ager, before entering the university, Mr. Grinspun was drawn to the Radical Party, whose slightly left-of-center politics are similar to those of Europe's Social Democrats. He rose to be a student leader and since then he has held a number of party posts, mostly as an economic adviser. In addition to Mr. Grinspun's ministerial position today, he is also secretary general of the party's national committee, a position that gives him clout within the party. **********It was in his early days as a soap box speaker that Mr. Grinspun developed his aggressiveness and his political savvy, said Juan Manuel Casella, a Radical legislator and a friend of the economist since boyhood. ''He is different from the other intellectuals in the Cabinet,'' Mr. Casella said. ''He speaks forcefully, even inside the party, but it's because he is so passionate.'' **********Mr. Grinspun's strong opinions have gotten him into trouble more than once. During last year's campaign, for example, when Mr. Grinspun did not like some of the news stories probing his planned policies, he lashed out at reporters during a news conference, labeling their work ''irresponsible.'' It provoked a backlash in the Argentine press at a politically sensitive time for Mr. Alfonsin. **********Eva Grinspun, his wife of nearly 30 years, is said by family friends to be a calming influence on her husband. ''When she is present,'' Mr. Casella said, ''Bernardo lowers the voltage.'' The Grinspuns have three sons. The eldest works in the Argentine Embassy in Washington and the younger two are university students in Buenos Aires. The Grinspuns are no strangers to the United States. When he worked as a financial adviser to a number of Argentine banks and companies, Mr. Grinspun traveled so often to Washington that he finally bought an apartment there. He has also worked over the years as an economic consultant to the United Nations and the Organization of American States. **********As a Radical Party leader, Mr. Grinspun helped to draw to Mr. Alfonsin the vote of Argentina's Jewish community of 350,000 people, the world's fifth largest. Mr. Grinspun's appointment as Economics Minister, although not viewed as a concession to the Jewish community, is a sign of the growing achievement of Jews in Argentine society. Mr. Grinspun, however, does not think of his rise as a historical benchmark. ''I don't react in this job like a Jew,'' he said. ''I react like an Argentine who wants liberty.'' **********Argentine journalists and political analysts, however, are frustratedwith Mr. Grinspun's refusal to outline his views on economics. When asked his economic persuasion, Mr. Grinspun simply replies ''Radical.'' The party, however, is not known for a definitive economic or political platform, but rather an eclectic mixture of economic measures deemed practical. **********BUT over the years, Mr. Grinspun has proved himself to be an essentially Keynesian economist with a strong social consciousness. He calls himself ''an interventionist, not a statist,'' and points to the policies by the United States and Europe after World War II as precedents he is following to spur consumer spending and the country's economic growth. **********Mr. Grinspun's announced economic plan sets three simultaneous goals: combating inflation, reviving the economy and increasing real income. To combat inflation, he plans to cut the fiscal deficit from 14 percent of the gross national product to 4 percent by the end of the year. He also plans to curb interest rates, stimulate industry and restrain defense spending. These measures, he said, should trigger strong growth in the private sector. Then the Government hopes to sell off some of its state industries. **********In spite of his goal to pare down the public sector, Mr. Grinspun's first acts in office have seemed contradictory. To relieve the financial pressures on working-class Argentines, Mr. Grinspun began a national feeding plan for children, increased construction of public housing and ordered wage increases slightly higher than the inflation rate. The costs of these social programs, say his critics, will offset some of the gains made by cuts in defense spending. Mr. Grinspun's response to charges of inconsistency: ''We're not here to apply an economic theory. This is not an academy; this is a Government.'' **********Argentina's multiple Goverments over the last decade, however, with their stop-and-go policies, have played havoc with the nation's economy. Since the late 1970's, industrial output has crumbled and the deficit has ballooned, due partly to the free trade policies imposed by former Economics Minister Jose Martinez de Hoz. After the military took power in 1976, Mr. Martinez de Hoz introduced an open market by lowering tariffs, a move that unleashed a flood of low- cost imports and drove into bankruptcy a number of Argentine businesses whose products had been protected by the tariffs. He also put into effect restrictive money supply measures to drive up the value of the peso. These policies - carried out by Mr. Martinez de Hoz and the three other Economics Ministers that served under the military Government - failed to promote the economic prosperity that were their goal. Instead, the result was spiraling inflation and economic chaos. The financial strain of last year's war in the Falkland Islands added to the Government's economic problems. **********And then there is the foreign debt. In addition to the $43 billion it owes around the world, Argentina is about $1 billion behind in repaying its short- term trade credits to banks. The country was also unable to pay the $350 million it owed last month on a short-term loan granted by banks last year. The twist is that Argentina can't pay those loans, said Mr. Grinspun, without the disbursals it is due on new loans. The banks are currently withholding payments from a $1 billion bailout loan they approved last August. The International Monetary Fund as well is withholding disbursals from a $900 million loan it approved last year because Argentina is unable to keep pace with its interest payments. **********The Government's failure, so far, to introduce major domestic initiatives - aside from price controls and some tariff barriers that have reduced imports - has raised not only the most stinging criticism, but also new doubts that Argentina's economic platform will be supported by the international financial community. Bankers, businessmen and opposition economists say that Mr. Grinspun's plan is no plan at all, and that it fails to detail how the Government will achieve those goals. The policies, they contend, are a mere continuation of those of the past military Government. ''The targets are a repetition of the inherited disorder, coupled with campaign promises,'' said Alvaro Alsogaray, a member of Congress who served as an Economics Minister in the military Government that was in power in the early 1960's. **********Mr. Grinspun strongly refutes his critics, accusing them of ''bad faith'' for not giving the new Government more time to collect itself. When he came into office he discovered, for example, that there were no accurate data on the size of the debt or who held it, or on the size of the fiscal deficit. He said that the Government will lay out more specific plans in its annual budget presentation to Congress this month. **********But Mr. Grinspun is not the first Argentine Economics Minister to start up with a roar. The position is not known for its longevity. In fact, there has been an average of one Economics Minister a year for the last 44 years. **********Mr. Grinspun, however, quickly dismisses the common prediction here that he will last only six months, and exchanges verbal volleys with his critics with good humor and a sense of enjoyment. After so many years of military rule, ''they are now allowed their freedom of expression,'' he said, ''and I am, too.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/26/world.main_headline: 2 GERMANYS AT ODDS OVER LEADER'S VISIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/26/world.print_headline: 2 GERMANYS AT ODDS OVER LEADER'S VISIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/26/world.body_text: **********East Germany today accused ''certain forces'' in Bonn of trying to sabotage a visit to West Germany next month by Erich Honecker, the East German Communist Party leader. **********In a commentary, the East German party daily Neues Deutschland attacked Alfred Dregger, the parliamentary floor leader of the West German Christian Democratic Party, who two days ago declared that ''our future does not depend on whether Mr. Honecker pays us the honor of a visit.'' **********The editorial assailed Mr. Dregger, who voices right-wing concerns of his party, and the anti-Communist Springer newspaper chain, saying they ''do not want the possible visit'' to take place. It described Mr. Dregger's remarks as ''scandalous and provocative sallies.'' **********''The campaign of such forces,'' said Neues Deutschland, ''does no small damage.'' It said that in light of the purported campaign, it should be clear that Mr. Honecker ''is not pushing to visit'' West Germany. **********The Neues Deutschland commentary was the first to hint that the visit, which would be the first by an East German party leader to West Germany, might not take place. But officials here noted that the editorial avoided criticism of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who returns from vacation Monday.  Although the visit has not been formally announced, Bonn officials have been fleshing out the details of a busy, five-day swing that would start on Sept. 26. The Neues Deutschland article maintained that ''no date, catalogue of discussion topics or program have yet been agreed upon.'' **********Criticism in Soviet Press **********Since the beginning of this month, the Soviet press has sharply criticized the warming ties between the two Germanys, charging the Kohl Government with trying to undermine East Germany's stability. The press blasts are widely seen as an expression of unease over the implications of the Honecker visit, although Western diplomats express uncertainty over whether Moscow will try to veto the trip. **********As East Germany's links with West Germany have tightened, Mr. Honecker has emerged as an ally of Janos Kadar of Hungary and Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania in defending broadened ties with the West to spur both economic growth and East-West detente. This line of argument has tended to undercut Soviet efforts to convey a chill in East-West relations in the wake of the deployment of American medium-range missiles in Western Europe. **********This week Mr. Honecker was conspicuous as the sole Eastern European party chief to attend the 40th-anniversary celebrations in Bucharest of Rumania's ''antifascist liberation.'' Rumania recently underscored its maverick standing in the Warsaw Pact by spurning the Soviet-led boycott of the Los Angeles Olympics. **********Two days ago Mr. Honecker and Mr. Ceausescu issued a communique that urged ''a turning to a politics of reason'' between East and West. **********With Mr. Kohl on holiday, other Bonn politicians tried to limit the possible fallout from Mr. Dregger's remarks. J"urgen Sudhoff, a Government spokesman, said Friday that Mr. Honecker was welcome in West Germany. **********Campaigning for local elections in Essen, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher today urged politicians to be circumspect in their remarks about East Germany and ''not gamble away'' the chances for better relations between the two states. **********If trim is needed take graf beginning ''Two days ago....''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/14/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 3 Killed in Spain; Basques Are Suspected
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/14/world.body_text: **********Two masked gunmen shot to death a retired army officer outside a fruit market today, and two national policemen died when the gunmen's booby-trapped car exploded, the authorities said. **********The retired commander, Jesus Alcocer, 65 years old, was shot twice in the head as he entered the market on the outskirts of Pamplona to buy produce for his three supermarkets, the police said. **********His attackers, who authorities said were believed to be members of the Basque separatist group E.T.A., escaped in a green Renault, the police said. Three national police officers, alerted by a bulletin on their car radio, spotted the getaway car parked outside a high school. When officers Tomas Palacin Pellejero, 42, and Juan Vicedo Calero, 26, tried to open the trunk, it exploded, police sources said, killing them.
