https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/18/busin.body_text: **********It started with a simple clerical mistake at Mosher, Pooley, Sullivan & Henderson, one of the most successful firms in Silicon Valley's fast-growing legal community. **********A busy lawyer, making a routine court filing for the National Semiconductor Corporation, neglected to ask the judge to seal a 12-page document. The slip-up was by no means trivial. The document described some of National's most precious trade secrets, the coin-of-the-realm in the cutthroat competition of the Valley. **********To the horror of James H. Pooley, one of the firm's senior partners, seven of those trade secrets showed up two weeks ago in Microelectronic News, an industry newsletter whose subscribers include every important competitor of National. ''I can only say it was a shock,'' said Mr. Pooley, whose firm has been paid millions by such companies as Tymeshare, Itek and Verbatim to protect their trade secrets. **********The Mania for Secrecy **********If Mr. Pooley was shocked, the Valley at first was highly amused. But the National episode has quickly taken on a broader importance here. It has drawn attention, industry executives and lawyers say, to the corporate mania for secrecy in Silicon Valley that has spawned scores of trade secrets cases. Moreover, National's rushed efforts to prevent others from publishing its secrets have raised serious First Amendment questions. **********The National case is not Mr. Pooley's first brush with trade secrets problems. The 36-year-old author of a standard text on trade secrets already stands accused by the International Business Machines Corporation of disclosing some of the secrets about the computer giant's disk drive technology to a competitor, the Control Data Corporation. A trial in that case, in which Mr. Pooley maintains that I.B.M. was largely at fault, is expected to begin in a few months. **********The National Semiconductor episode, coming on the heels of the I.B.M. suit, is bound to hurt the Pooley firm, another lawyer predicted. ''The Valley will forgive this kind of thing once, but not twice,'' he said.  Unusual Court Order **********In the hours after Microelectronic News printed excerpts from National's court filing, National obtained an unusual court order issued by Judge Marilyn Zecher restraining other publications from printing company trade secrets they may have found in the public record, and forcing them to return their copies of the court documents. ''At that point, there was just panic to get the information back,'' said Linda Baker, a spokesman for National. **********''I was amazed,'' said Jerome M. Ceppos, managing editor of The San Jose Mercury-News, which was served with the court order. ''Prior restraints are presumed to be unconstitutional, except maybe when the utmost national security is at stake.'' Trade secrets, he said, ''are a little different.'' **********The story of how National managed to hand away its trade secrets goes back to 1981, when a group of engineers defected to start up Linear Technology Inc. The new company laid plans to compete with National in the market for specialized microchips commonly used in stereo equipment, automobile engines, and other non-computer applications. **********National sued, charging that the engineers had walked off with proprietary knowledge about chip manufacturing processes. The lawsuit was hardly an unusual event here, where companies sometimes hold a goodbye dinner for a departing employee one night, and serve him with court papers the next day. This suit was quickly settled, with Linear agreeing to let an independent inspector review its manufacturing processes to determine if any National trade secrets were in use. New Suit Filed **********When the inspection was carried out last December, the inspector found 7 reported infringements, out of a list of about 40 trade secrets. National sued again, and in support of a motion in court one of its lawyers - Mr. Pooley declined to identify which one - filed the unsealed inventory of secrets. **********Then three weeks ago, Don C. Hoefler, the publisher of Microelectronic News, received an anonymous telephone call at his home in Carmel, Calif. The caller told him that the trade secrets were available for the price of a photocopy at the Santa Clara County Courthouse in San Jose. **********''It was sitting right there,'' Mr. Hoefler recalled recently, ''and I got it legally.'' Mr. Hoefler printed the paragraph-long descriptions of the 7 trade secrets at issue in the lawsuit, but not the other 30 or so in the court record. **********Mr. Pooley insists he smells a rat, and it is Linear. ''Nothing would have happened if Linear had not gotten Hoefler to send a copy out to his subscribers,'' said the lawyer, who calls Microelectronic News a ''gossip sheet.''  Linear Issues Denial **********Linear's lawyer, Michael A. Ladra, suggests that an embarrassed Mr. Pooley is passing the blame. ''The bottom line is that no one at Linear called Mr. Hoefler,'' Mr. Ladra said Tuesday. **********The issue of motive is critical to Mr. Pooley. In California, and in most states, a trade secret is destroyed if it is generally published. That could threaten National's case against Linear and, experts say, make it impossible for National to use the secrets in any further suits. **********But Mr. Pooley argues that the secrets were never really put in the public domain because Microelectronic News has only a few thousand subscribers. In any case, he maintains, they should not have been published in the first place because all but the top page of the document was stamped ''Company Private,'' and ''Do Not Reproduce.'' Thus, Mr. Pooley suggests, the publication was malicious. **********He blamed Mr. Hoefler, whom he likened to ''a teen-ager who steals a car and joyrides, and says it is O.K. because the keys were left inside.'' National, he said, is contemplating suing Mr. Hoefler for disclosing its trade secrets. First Amendment Issue **********Such a suit, if filed, would likely bring to the fore a First Amendment question that has pervaded the National case: Whether a publication can be barred from publishing legally obtained trade secrets. **********''The First Amendment issue is the most interestisng part of the case to me,'' said Robert A. Spanner, another lawyer in Silicon Valley specializing in trade secrets. ''It is compelling because the value of the trade secrets has widely baeen thought to be destroyed once the secret is published.'' But he quickly added that in some cases secrecy no longer seems required to maintain the validity of a trade secret. **********Others, however, note that anything in the public record is fair game for publication regardless of whether the company maintains that it could be harmed. **********National has demanded that Mr. Hoefler not only return his photocopy of the trade secrets, which he did, but also that he turn over to the company his subscriber list. ''They wanted to serve every subscriber with the court order to return their copies,'' Mr. Hoefler said. **********But Mr. Hoefler refused the demand for the subscriber list, and late last week, in a meeting at National's headquarters, a compromise was reached. He agreed to include a copy of the court order with each copy of his next issue. **********The Mercury-News also returned its copy of the court documents, but only after National went back to court, of its own accord, to get The Mercury-News exempted from the prior restraint order.  'Very Technical Stuff' **********''I'm not quite sure why they backed down,'' said Mr. Ceppos of The Mercury-News, adding, ''We never actually printed the descriptions of the trade secrets anyway, because they were very technical stuff.'' By the time the newspaper returned the court document, he said, ''we had gotten what we wanted from them,'' which was just a brief discription of how the secrets fell into public hands. **********Mr. Pooley, conceding he is angered and embarrassed by the disclosure of the trade secrets, said office procedures were being tightened. But lawyers here say the damage is done. They expect I.B.M. to seize on the National incident in its case against Mr. Pooley. Mr. Pooley insisted that ''the two cases are entirely different.'' **********The I.B.M. suit, which the Valley is following closely, arose from Mr. Pooley's defense of two ex-I.B.M. employees who left to start a firm that is now called Trimedia. A settlement was eventually reached, but Mr. Pooley remained in possesion of some I.B.M. trade secrets disclosed during the negotiations. **********I.B.M. charges that Mr. Pooley, while helping Trimedia attract investors, allowed a Control Data executive to see a confidential document. Mr. Pooley admitted that, but said I.B.M. did not properly warn his firm that the document was confidential. **********If the two cases are focusing attention on Mr. Pooley, he said, ''I would like to think it would not hurt business,'' National does not plan to change lawyers, he added, as he left for his honeymoon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/26/world.body_text: **********The White House called a news conference today for a commercial announcement - the resumption of Cunard vacation cruises with stops at Grenada. **********Reporters from news agencies and television networks were summoned to the office of a deputy press secretary, Peter Roussel, for an announcement, which appeared to promote the service by the Cunard Steam-Ship Company to the Caribbean island invaded by Americans last October. **********The announcement was made by James Coyne, head of the President's Office of Private Sector Initiative. He was accompanied by Ralph Bahna, president of Cunard, and Dennis Noel, the Grenadian charge d'affaires. **********Asked why the White House was announcing a commercial venture, Mr. Coyne said: ''We have worked to develop this opportunity. It's part of what we consider private sector development.'' **********Mr. Coyne's office has recruited private companies to invest in Grenada to restore the economy - much of it based on tourism - that was wrecked by the short-lived October revolution and the subsequent invasion. **********Cunard, a British-owned company, has stopped at Grenada since 1948 and resumes its calls there next Tuesday after a three-month hiatus. **********Americans Finance Paper **********LYFORD CAY, the Bahamas, Jan. 25 (AP) - The board of the American Newspaper Publishers Association has approved a $30,000 grant to help revive a weekly Grenada newspaper. **********The money will go to the World Press Freedom Committee to buy a reconditioned printing press for The Voice, which was shut down by Prime Minister Maurice Bishop in 1981. **********The Voice resumed publication soon after Americans invaded Grenada on Oct. 25 and freed the newspaper's editor, who was jailed in 1981. Lacking a press, the newspaper is being printed at The Trinidad Express.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/23/world.main_headline: 2D ARAB DEMONSTRATOR IN 2 DAYS IS SHOT DEAD BY ISRAELI ARMY FIRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/23/world.print_headline: 2D ARAB DEMONSTRATOR IN 2 DAYS IS SHOT DEAD BY ISRAELI ARMY FIRE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/23/world.body_text: **********In the second such incident in as many days, Israeli soldiers shot and killed a young Palestinian demonstrator today in the occupied West Bank. **********Israeli authorities asserted that the soldiers opened fire after the youth and other demonstrators had ignored warnings to stop throwing stones at Israeli vehicles in the town of Ramallah. **********On Wednesday, one student was killed and six others were wounded when Israeli troops opened fire to disperse a large crowd of Bir Zeit University students who were pelting Israeli soldiers with rocks and shouting slogans in support of the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat. **********Agitation Increases **********With the Palestine National Council meeting beginning in Amman today, the West Bank has started to boil over with political agitation - partly from Palestinians who want to demonstrate solidarity with their compatriots in Amman and partly because of infighting between pro- and anti-Arafat factions. **********According to several shopkeepers interviewed in Ramallah, the incident today began in the morning with a demonstration by a group of women outside a mosque. The women were mourning the death of the Bir Zeit student, Sharif Khalil Taibe. They wore black and carried black flags. The shopkeepers, who witnessed the event, said the women were dispersed by Israeli troops using tear gas. **********A short time later, about 50 youths gathered in Ramallah's central Al- Manara Circle and apparently started throwing stones at Israeli vehicles. **********Differing Accounts **********What happened next is not clear. Each side has tried to portray the actions of the other in the most negative light. **********The Israeli Army statement said Israeli soldiers called on the rioters to disperse and, at the same time, called on four of the leaders to halt in their tracks. It was not clear how the Israeli soldiers were able to determine in the confusion who was inciting the demonstrators and who was simply demonstrating. **********Local shopkeepers, who would not give their names for fear of making themselves vulnerable to reprisal, said that after the youths threw some stones, they all started to scatter and were shot at by Israeli troops while running away. This could not be independently confirmed. **********The official statement of the Israeli Army spokesman said: ''During disturbances of the peace in Ramallah today, which included stone throwing at Israeli forces, Israeli forces called on the rioters to disperse. They also called on four of them, who were inciting the demonstrators, to stop. The latter continued to throw stones and flee the area. They were called upon again by the Israeli soldiers to stop and when they failed to respond warning shots were fired into the air.'' **********''Even after the warning shots the inciters did not stop and continued to throw stones,'' the statement added. ''An Israeli force fired at them, and two of the rioters were wounded from the shots. They were transferred to hospital, where one of them died.'' **********According to Dr. Issa Salti, the director of Ramallah Hospital, the slain youth, Bakr Abdullah, was hit by a bullet in the chest and died on the operating table. Mr. Abdullah, who was 20 years old, was a student at the Ramallah Industrial Secondary School. The wounded youth, Jihad Selim, was hit by a bullet in the thigh, and his life was not considered in danger.   Other Disturbances Reported **********Many shopkeepers in Ramallah closed their stores after the incident but Israeli troops forced them to re- open, several merchants said. **********Meanwhile, smaller rock-throwing incidents were reported in the Jelaila refugee camp near Gaza and in Nablus, but these demonstrators were dispersed without any shooting. The universities of Bir Zeit and Bethlehem closed for the day in mourning for the student who was killed on Wednesday. **********Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin announced late Wednesday night that he had decided not to order Bir Zeit closed in punishment for the incident that day. The Israeli commander in the West Bank, Maj. Gen. Amnon Lipkin, had recommended to the Defense Minister that Mr. Rabin close the school. The previous Likud Government frequently shut down schools after such demonstrations. **********An aide to Mr. Rabin said the Defense Minister felt that quiet and normality on the West Bank would best be served by allowing the students to resume their studies.   Disagreement Over Tactics **********Mr. Rabin's move was criticized by a right-wing member of Parliament, Yuval Neeman, who was quoted by Israeli radio as saying that the ''Arab unversities of Nablus, Bir Zeit and Bethlehem have become focal points for Arab terrorist organizations and should be closed until they are able to teach academic subjects instead of anti-Jewish terrorism.'' **********The student association of Bar-Ilan University in Tel Aviv also issued a statement today calling for Bir Zeit to be closed down, saying that the university was a ''hornets' nest'' and that solidarity with it was tantamount to ''solidarity with the P.L.O.'' **********The Bar-Ilan statement was in reference to a statement issued Wednesday night, after the Bir Zeit shooting, by the Israeli Committee for Solidarity with Bir Zeit, an ad hoc group made up largely of Arab and Jewish academicians. The group had said that ''an army that shoots on unarmed students is an army that has lost the battle.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/11/world.body_text: **********The long-overdue report by the panel investigating the assassination of the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., has been delayed by disputes among the panel members over the findings, according to board officials. **********''You have five intelligent, independent-minded people on the board, so there are bound to be differences of opinion,'' Andres Narvasa, the panel's general counsel, said. **********According to published reports quoting board officials, members have agreed that the military conspired to kill Mr. Aquino, but that has not been confirmed by the board members themselves. The main reason for the delay, board officials say, is disagreement among the members about how high to go in identifying officers responsible for Mr. Aquino's death. **********The citizens' board originally said it hoped to have the report ready by Aug. 21, the first anniversary of Mr. Aquino's death. Since then, several deadlines have been announced and have slipped by. **********Now board officials are saying the report will be made public very soon, within a matter of days. That is what they have been saying for weeks.   The Implications for Marcos **********How high in the military hierarchy the panel's accusations extend is crucial for the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos because the more senior the officer, say the board officials, Filipino politicians and foreign diplomats, the more difficult it will be for the President to put distance between himself and the findings. **********Particular attention has been paid to Gen. Fabian C. Ver, Chief of Staff of the armed forces and a close associate of Mr. Marcos. **********Board officials said that in essence, board members must decide whether the general was ultimately responsible for security as Mr. Aquino arrived at the Manila airport after three years of self-exile in the United States. General Ver has supported the military version of events, which is that Mr. Aquino was killed by a lone Communist gunman. **********A finding of a military conspiracy of some type would be a serious blow to the morale of the armed forces. The military, which is estimated to have 170,000 troops, three times the number before martial law was declared in 1972, is one of the most powerful institutions in the Philippines and it has been one of Mr. Marcos's most loyal supporters.   Importance of Reactions **********The investigating panel could accuse the military of conspiring to kill Mr. Aquino without identifying the person who shot him. Mr. Aquino was killed while being accompanied by armed escorts after he stepped off a plane that brought him home from the United States. No credible civilian witness to the crime came forward to testify during the investigation. **********Yet more significant than the details of the report will be the Government and public reactions to it. ''This operates on two levels - one is the strictly legal and the other and far more important is the political side,'' said J. V. Cruz, the Philippine Ambassador to London and a former Cabinet member who has recently spent most of his time in Manila. **********The report is expected to set off more anti-Government demonstrations, but beyond that its political effects on the Marcos Government are uncertain. **********''No matter what the board decides, Marcos loses,'' Rafael Recto, an opposition Member of Parliament, says. **********But a foreign diplomat had another view, saying, ''If Marcos reacts firmly, it may let him take the strategic high ground, appearing to be a statesman who wants to see justice done.'' **********One response, according to a senior Government official, will be to offer the post of special prosecutor to Mr. Narvasa, the respected general counsel on the citizens' panel. **********''It's the best for us,'' the official said. ''Then there can be no accusations of a whitewash or lack of enthusiasm in pursuing the prosecution of those charged.''  Marcos Plans a Response **********The civilian panel is heading by Corazon Juliano Agrava, a retired Court of Appeals justice. Other members are Ernesto Herrera, a labor leader; Dante Santos, a businessman; Amado Dizon, an educator, and Luciano Salazar, a corporate lawyer. **********The President is also preparing to issue a statement as soon as he is handed the report, a top Government official said. **********The President's response will be made, he added, assuming that the report is in line with published reports on its contents that are being received by Mr. Marcos, namely, that the board will charge that a military conspiracy was responsible for Mr. Aquino's death. **********The investigating board has said the President would have no advance knowledge of the findings. **********But an official close to Mr. Marcos said: ''It's ridiculous to think that he does not know. Given all the interpersonal connnections here, all the friends and relatives, all the favors owed and offered, he would have to know.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/29/busin.main_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; M.T.A. Revenue Issue To Yield Up to 10.839%
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/29/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; M.T.A. Revenue Issue To Yield Up to 10.839%
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/29/busin.body_text: **********The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which operates New York City's subway and bus system, is selling $135 million of revenue bonds backed by passenger fares plus subsidies from the state and city governments and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. The sale is part of the authority's five-year, $6.3 billion capital improvement program to improve mass transit service. **********Underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company tentatively offered the bonds yesterday with yields ranging from 7 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 10.50 percent in 1999 and 10.839 percent in 2004. The largest part of the financing consists of nearly $90 million of 10 7/8 percent bonds due in 2014, tentatively priced at 99 1/4 to yield 10.957 percent. **********Although the transit system is plagued with run-down facilities and has long depended on state, city and Federal subsidies, the bonds offer enough assurances of repayment to be assigned investment grade ratings of Baa by Moody's Investors Service and BBBx by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********Bondholders have first claim on fare box revenues, which are kept segregated from other funds. Fare box revenues totaled about $1.3 billion last year, or half of the authority's operating revenues. The authority estimates that the maximum annual payment of interest and principal on its bonds will be $200 million. Also the Legislature has promised that the authority may not declare bankruptcy. **********Beyond their first lien on fare box revenues and the support of operating subsidies from the state, the city and the Triborough agency, analysts said bondholders' fundamental protection comes from the indispensable nature of the subway and bus system. **********''Bondholder protection rests in the system's importance to the city, the responsibilities assumed to be met by other governmental participants'' and the authority's promises to improve management of the transit system, analysts at Moody's said in the latest issue of Bond Survey. **********The strong promise to bondholders of fare box revenues and debt service reserves ''are intended to compensate for the political and economic vulnerabilities inherent in intergovernmental supports,'' the bond rating service said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/30/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********I thoroughly enjoyed the article on Senator Bob Packwood (''A Blunt New Tax Chief Takes Over in the Senate,'' Dec. 2). His blunt style is refreshing and one that is needed if we are to successfuly reduce the deficit. **********However, I must take strong exception to the expressed view that Mr. Packwood is a ''member of a vanishing breed of Republicans.'' During the recent Presidential and Congressional campaign, the ''clear'' choice between the Republicans and Democrats troubled me greatly. **********Where was I, a fiscal conservative and liberal humanitarian, to find common ground? I found many others, Republicans and Democrats, sharing my confusion. Perhaps the Republican Party has gone too far right, and, rather than a vanishing breed, Mr. Packwood may be pointing the way for a new majority in 1988. BARRY P. KORN White Plains, N.Y., Dec. 3

Fernandez, a highly respected private banker, to be the new head of the Philippine central bank, the Government's television station announced. **********Sources in the presidential press office said Mr. Fernandez, 60 years old, had accepted the appointment but would not be sworn in for a few more days to give him time to wind up business with his bank. **********Mr. Fernandez is chairman and president of the Far East Bank and Trust Company, one of the country's leading commercial banks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/24/busin.body_text: **********The JWT Group released its 1984 second-quarter earnings yesterday and its revenues were up to $128.1 million, from $117.6 in the comparable period in 1983. **********Net income rose by 3.3 percent, to $6.2 million, or $1.01 a share, from $6 million, or $1.08 a share. The 1983 per share figure was greater because there were fewer shares outstanding. For the first half the agency holding company had revenues of $248.8 million, up from the $220.5 million last year, while net income rose to $9.9 million, or $1.63 a share, from $7.1 million, or $1.29 a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/11/busin.main_headline: LESLIE FAY'S PARTNERS NEGOTIATING A BUYOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/11/busin.print_headline: LESLIE FAY'S PARTNERS NEGOTIATING A BUYOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/11/busin.body_text: **********The partners in the Leslie Fay Company, who bought the apparel manufacturer less than two years ago for $54 million, are negotiating a new leveraged buyout of the company for $169 million. **********Under the plan, LMX will sell its 75 percent holding in Leslie Fay, which it acquired when the original investors bought the company in April 1982 and took it private. **********''We are under negotiations to do it,'' said John J. Pomerantz, president of Leslie Fay and one of the original investors. The company makes dresses and women's sportswear in the medium price range, **********The principal partner, a toy manufacturer then known as Louis Marx & Company, emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings in 1982 with a substantial tax loss carry-forward. Louis Marx, since renamed LMX, has used up the loss carry-forward by offsetting it against pretax income from Leslie Fay, said Herman Gordon, attorney for Leslie Fay. **********The plan requires the approval of LMX shareholders. **********Partner in Buyout **********LMX is being bought out by its current partner, the management group directed by Mr. Pomerantz; Walter I. Leiter, executive vice president, and Alan Golub, senior vice president. The group, which currently owns 25 percent of the company's equity, will continue to manage Leslie Fay under a 15-year agreement, but their direct equity positions will be reduced. **********The management group's new partners include Odyssey Partners, a private investment firm, and a private investor, Ira Hechler, Mr. Pomerantz said. **********Manufacturers Hanover Trust, which financed the original 1982 buyout, is expected to supply most of the funds for the new leveraged buyout, he said. In a leveraged buyout, the assets of the business purchased are used as collateral in borrowing the necessary capital. **********Leslie Fay said last September that it was discussing with brokers the possibility of going public. But since then the market for apparel issues has softened, Mr. Pomerantz said. **********Thus, the company has been negotiating the deal for several months as an alternative to going public. **********''They would have difficulty selling to the public and would have to go for a lower price,'' said Edward Johnson, director of the Johnson Redbook Service, a division of Prescott, Ball & Turben, which follows the apparel and textile industries. **********Leslie Fay's financial position has strengthened. In the nine months ended Oct. 1, the company earned $30.5 million before taxes on sales of $288 million. In the eight months ended Dec. 31, 1982, profits were $14.8 million on sales of $214 millions. **********Sales in 1983 were estimated at nearly $400 million and should increase in 1984, Mr. Johnson said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/22/busin.body_text: **********R. Foster Winans, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal, has subpoenaed his calendar and office diary, as part of his defense against criminal charges that he engaged in insider trading, lawyers for Mr. Winans and The Journal said yesterday. The Journal is resisting the subpoena on the ground of a First Amendment privilege to protect its confidential sources. **********Newspapers have often claimed such privilege, but this appears to be the first case in which a newspaper is claiming the right against the reporter who talked to those sources.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/18/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Trade Commission is seeking to block two proposed mergers in the carbon black industry on the ground that they would hinder competition. **********The commission said it had asked a Federal District Court in Cleveland to block the mergers while it prepares legal challenges to them under Federal antitrust laws. The F.T.C. is opposing the proposed takeover by Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. of the Ashland Chemical Company's carbon black division and the proposal by Consolidated Mining and Industries to take over the Continental Carbon Company. Carbon black is used primarily in the rubber industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/24/busin.main_headline: THE SECRETIVE LIFE OF AN ARB
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/24/busin.print_headline: TOP ARBITRAGER: IVAN F. BOESKY; THE SECRETIVE LIFE OF AN ARB
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/24/busin.body_text: **********THERE he was, sitting on a park **********bench, out of a job and staring **********into space. Even then, he was impeccably dressed, vest and all, killing time in Central Park, wondering when his chance would come. **********That was just 14 years ago. **********Nobody had ever heard of Ivan F. Boesky, except maybe around Detroit, where in the old days the family name stood above the best delicatessen in town. **********Today, he is known as one of best- informed men on Wall Street, widely feared, grudgingly respected and at the age of 47 probably worth $250 million or more. **********The    ''more''    is what seems to propel Mr. Boesky, the world's most successful arbitrager, and member of a secret clique of audacious professional traders who bet hundreds of millions of dollars on the outcome of corporate takeovers. **********The past few years of rampant merger activity have been big ones for the arbs. But just how big is anybody's guess because their businesses are private. Mr. Boesky, for example, was one of the biggest buyers of Gulf stock before the oil company was bought by California Standard, and was just as big a buyer of Getty stock before it was bought by Texaco. He is reputed to have made between $50 million and $100 million on each of them. **********In essence, what arbitragers do is to buy a company's stock when it becomes a takeover target, betting that they will make a profit if the deal goes through. The art is to measure the risk they face if the deal fails and catches them with stock that nobody wants - either because the target resists, the courts or the Government step in or the deal disintegrates. How much they can find out about a situation often spells the difference between success and failure. **********Some professionals treat arbitrage as their only business, although Mr. Boesky is now moving into other areas such as buying companies. Investment banking firms, such as Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers, treat arbitrage as one of many businesses. **********What separates Mr. Boesky from the rest is not easy to define. The heart of all arbitrage dealings is information, but Mr. Boesky's appetite for minutiae is legendary, and he is willing to pay for every scrap of information, no matter how seemingly inconsequential. **********''He's the best in the business,'' a close Wall Street friend maintained. ''He's made more money than any of us and that makes him the best.'' **********Mr. Boesky's philosophy seems clear enough. It is spelled out on a plaque in his private office. The inscription, by A. Bartlett Giamatti, president of Yale University, reads in part: ''Winning is not everything but it is something powerful, indeed beautiful, in itself, something as necessary to the strong spirit as striving is necessary to the healthy character.'' **********But Mr. Boesky's winning streak was a long time in coming. **********WHEN he was just a few years out of college, his old roommate, Marvin H. Davidson, now an executive with Bear, Stearns & Company, had been telling him about his work in arbitrage. It sounded exciting. **********Determined to try his hand, he came to New York in 1966. Before long he had landed a job at L. F. Rothschild & Company, where he became a stock analyst. Set on getting into arbitrage, he soon joined the First Manhattan Company, where he worked alongside Harry L. Schick, the premier arbitrager, and discovered his calling. But by 1970, First Manhattan decided to de-emphasize arbitrage, so Mr. Boesky left, working for a time in a variety of Wall Street jobs. **********But even when he was spending his time in Central Park, he was convinced that arbitrage was his way to the top. By 1972, his chance came. Edwards & Hanly asked him to create an arbitrage department, and it soon became the company's biggest profit center. Within three years he was in business for himself. **********Even for Mr. Boesky, the perils of being an ''arb'' can make life harrowing. In the first few weeks on his own, he almost lost half his capital. **********And there was the time in 1982, when Gulf backed out of its agreement to buy Cities Service. Mr. Boesky and other arbs had loaded up on Cities Service stock in hopes of reselling it to Gulf later at a huge profit. But when Gulf withdrew, Cities Service shares plunged and Mr. Boesky was left with a bundle of stock. Occidental subsequently agreed to step in but would not pay nearly as much as Gulf. It was enough, however, to cushion Mr. Boesky and others.  These days, Mr. Boesky wins more than he loses. A former associate recalled the other day that a few years ago, after Mr. Boesky had made a killing in the market, he said, ''Ivan, you've already made more money than you can ever spend. What are you    really    after?'' **********''I want to be    rich   ,'' he quoted Mr. Boesky as replying. ''I want to be worth. . . .'' Mr. Boesky mentioned a big number, but the former associate wouldn't repeat it. But he added, ''He's a driven man.'' **********Another close observer thought that money alone was no longer Mr. Boesky's goal, that what he really wanted was ''to establish a name, be a modern Rothschild.'' **********The reference to one of the world's great banking families pleased Mr. Boesky immensely. ''Of course,'' he said softly, ''one has an ambition to succeed.'' The French and English Rothschilds, he said, are his ''very good friends.'' Jacob Rothschild is an investor in his British company and Baron Elie de Rothschild once gave him a bottle of wine for his cellar. **********BUT there is another side to Ivan Boesky, a side that perhaps explains why dozens of millionaire Wall Street executives absolutely refuse to talk about him. Those who do, discuss him from a distance, often with sketchy details and usually only after assurance that they will not be identified. **********''If anecdotes are supposed to be funny, there aren't any about Ivan,'' said Alan C. Greenberg, head of Bear Stearns. ''He's too serious.'' **********Aware that his movements are watched - by other arbitragers who want to buy when he buys and sell when he sells - Mr. Boesky may ask one broker to tell a second broker to buy for him through yet a third. **********But the sheer size and audacity of Mr. Boesky's dealings, unlike anything ever seen on Wall Street, make him stand out almost as if he had a sign pinned on his back. **********''Ivan's buying,'' the word goes out. **********His hunger for every share of stock that money can buy came in for good- natured ribbing the other day at a private dinner in New York's Regency Hotel, given by the arbitrage community in honor of T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who precipitated the takeover of Gulf. **********An arbitrager who attended the dinner said the host got a laugh when he gave Mr. Boesky, as a joke, an award for buying and selling more Gulf stock than was available. **********He is reputed to be the only Wall Street arbitrager to use a press agent to attract wealthy investors. But he is reluctant to reveal even the most mundane facts. **********He rushed through an interview the other day, glancing several times at his Patek Philippe pocket watch, with individual dials for London, Los Angeles and New York. **********But he once spent an hour posing for Arnold Newman, the photographer who is known for ''environmental portraits'' that identify the subject with his craft. Unlike Stravinsky, who posed with his piano, and Henry Ford, who had the Dearborn auto plants as a backdrop, Mr. Boesky refused to pose in his office with its 300-button phone console and its long, 200-year- old brass telescope. So Mr. Newman photographed him in an anteroom, but without the identifying accouterments the portrait might have been of almost anybody. **********''He can be the most charming guy in the world,'' one Wall Streeter said of him, ''but he's a Jekyll and Hyde, and can be very demanding.'' **********A former partner shot back, ''He makes no demands of his employees that he wouldn't make on himself.'' **********Pointing to Mr. Boesky's predilection for sleeping three hours a night, another former partner said: ''Ivan's no genius. He's bright but he makes up for a lot by working long hours. And then he gets tired and under pressure and is accused of erratic behavior.'' **********IF Mr. Boesky is guarded about his **********business dealings, he is even more **********grudging with the details of his private life. **********He lives on a 188-acre estate in upstate New York, purchased six years ago from John Revson of the Revlon cosmetics family. **********Visitors to the red-brick Georgian home remember maids, cooks, security guards, gardeners, ''beautiful lawns and flowers everywhere you look,'' paintings, statuary, horses, sauna, squash court, tennis court, swimming pool, and a cobblestone courtyard that can accommodate 30 cars. **********Mr. Revson said that the house, one of four on the estate, has five bedrooms, two full bathrooms and two and a half powder rooms - just for the servants. The family has another seven bedrooms, each with bath. **********Then there are the collections - the classic cars, including two antique Rolls-Royces; the fine wines; paintings (including a Renoir nude); sculpture (including a life-size bronze by Maillol), and rare books, Hebraica and Judaica. **********Mr. Boesky finds most of this too private to discuss. He will not speak of his wife and family for publication, although almost everyone on Wall Street knows or has been told by Mr. Boesky that one of his companies, Seemala, is named for his wife, Seema, two others for his children and yet another for his home. Another investment company in Bermuda has been dubbed Farnsworth & Hastings, which sounds something like an aristocratic British company. Actually, he said, it's a street corner in Detroit where his family's deli used to be. **********A few glimpses into the Boesky life style are revealed: He has three phones in the chauffeur-driven car in which he commutes to work. A little white Wheaten terrier named Bibi drives with him daily (some arbs have heard it barking in the background during phone conversations), and another Wheaten named Max stays home. **********It's a far cry from the life of his childhood. His father, William, an immigrant from Czarist Russia, went to work at 12 as a milkman's helper, switching later to restaurants. Young Ivan went into business at 13, selling ice cream from a panel truck. He left ice cream when someone discovered that he was too young to drive. At 15, to stay in shape, he unloaded box cars, soon turning to accounting because he ''knew a lot about numbers.'' A tall, lean and dignified-looking man who is never without a vest, he still stays in shape by playing squash. **********In the early 1960's, he met his wife, the daughter of a major stockholder in the Beverly Hills Hotel Corporation, while he was a student at the University of Michigan and she was at Michigan State. They were married in 1962. **********Two years later he was graduated from the Detroit College of Law and subsequently became law clerk to the chief judge of the United States District Court in Detroit, Theodore Levin, a relative of his wife. Between college and law school he joined the United States Information Agency and taught English literature and language to Iranians in Teheran. **********By 1975, after stints at other Wall Street firms, he had opened Ivan F. Boesky & Company with $700,000 in capital, some of it thought to have come from his wife's family. Three years ago, he reorganized as the Ivan F. Boesky Corporation. Its assets stand at more than $500 million. **********His investors include banks, insurance companies and a number of individual and corporate investors. Among them are Eli Broad, the West Coast real estate executive; Martin Peretz, editor of The New Republic, and the Reliance Insurance Company, owned by Saul Steinberg, the New York financier. **********AS might be expected of a man of **********his means, he is generous.  His donations to Harvard University's School of Public Health amount to more than $100,000, including $35,000 last year to support a fellowship for science writers. He was subsequently named visiting committee member at the School of Public Health, a post that gave him full privileges at New York's Harvard Club. It has become his favorite meeting spot, although he has never attended the university. **********He has also given at least $100,000 to the American Ballet Theatre, and $2 million to the Jewish Theological Seminary for the Ivan F. Boesky Library. In recognition of donations over the years of more than $1 million, he has been named New York City chairman of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies 1985 drive. **********His bonuses are generous, too. Some of his staff - researchers and traders - collected close to $1 million apiece last March. It was a good year. **********ARBITRAGEMINUS THE ROMANCE **********Walking arm-in-arm with her husband down the Champs Elysees in Paris, one evening several years ago, Seema Boesky waxed romantic, as a friend tells the story. **********''Ivan,'' she sighed, ''it's a beautiful evening. Just look at the moon. Isn't it gorgeous?'' **********''What good is the moon,'' he replied, ''if you can't buy it or sell it?'' **********As the man reputed to be the richest and most powerful arbitrager of modern times, Mr. Boesky has turned buying and selling into a science. **********In the pre-Boesky days, arbitrage was a sideline of the big, old-line investment houses. They enjoyed substantial ''spreads'' between the price they paid and the price they collected for a stock. As a result, profits were substantial, even though the money committed was far less than it is today. **********''Ivan broke new ground,'' one Boesky watcher said. ''He took arbitrage out of the closet. He took it public, hired a press agent and invited investors to join him,'' thus committing far more money to the game than ever before. **********Above all, he told anybody who cared to listen, arbitrage is a business unto itself - one with high returns. Instead of a sideline, he made it his only activity, although he has since expanded into buying companies. **********His outlay in Esmark, for example, after the company became a takeover target last month, hit $120 million, more than the entire stock portfolio of most other arbitragers. **********His activities, some say, have cut everybody's profit margins by reducing spreads. But his organization has also produced a number of talented arbitrage graduates. Among them are Salim B. Lewis, head of S. B. Lewis & Company; George A. Kellner and Philip F. DiLeo, heads of Kellner, DiLeo & Company, and Barry S. Lafer, a managing partner of Lafer Amster & Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/28/busin.body_text: **********According to plan, the directors of Philip Morris Inc. yesterday named Hamish Maxwell to succeed George Weissman as chairman and chief executive. **********The only departure from the succession procedure was that Mr. Maxwell, 57, was to have taken office Aug. 1 after Mr. Weissman turns 65. Instead, he will take over on July 1. Mr. Weissman will be 65 on July 12. **********''The transition has been going so well,'' Mr. Weissman said in a statement, ''that the board and I agreed there was no need to continue it for another month as originally planned.'' **********Later, in a phone conversation, Mr. Weissman said that he planned to use the time to do some salmon fishing and ''go through decompression'' as he makes the transition to retirement. **********''I'd just like to take it easy for a while,'' he said. **********Mr. Weissman said that he would still be chairman of the board's executive committee and active in business and cultural affairs. **********Mr. Hamish was named president and chief operating officer of Philip Morris last November when the succession plan was announced. He now gives up those posts to John A. Murphy, 54, who has been widely credited for the sales growth of Miller Beer under Philip Morris ownership. **********Mr. Hamish previously was chief executive of Philip Morris International, having been named to that job in 1978. He is a native of Liverpool, England, and a graduate of Cambridge University. He began his career with Philip Morris as a salesman in Richmond in 1954. **********Mr. Hamish said yesterday that he planned no essential changes in Philip Morris. The company's products include Marlboro, the world's top-selling cigarette; Miller Beer and 7-Up. In addition, Philip Morris Industrialmakes packaging materials, and Mission Viejo Realty is a development company in the American West. **********The board also elected Hugh Cullman a vice chairman; Geoffrey C. Bible a vice president; Ehud Houminer vice president for planning; George R. Lewis vice president and treasurer; William K. Howell president and chief executive of Miller Brewing; James A. Remington, president of Philip Morris Tobacco Technology Group; Frank E. Resnik, president and chief executive, Philip Morris U.S.A., and Mark A. Serrano, executive vice president for operations, Philip Morris U.S.A.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/07/world.main_headline: Poland Detains 15 In Raid on Printing Plant
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/07/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Poland Detains 15 In Raid on Printing Plant
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/07/world.body_text: **********The Polish police have detained 15 people in a raid on an underground printing center and seven others who put up anti- Communist placards in public places, the official press said today. **********The reports were issued only 11 days before Poles are to vote in local elections. The clandestine wing of the outlawed Solidarity labor union has urged Poles to boycott the elections. **********The Communist Party newspaper Trybuna Ludu said officers in Warsaw detained 15 people who helped produce and distribute illegal literature. **********In Tomaszow southwest of Warsaw, seven young people were detained for putting up antistate placards in public places, the Polish press agency said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/04/world.body_text: **********Two conservative Republican Senators warned today that they might vote against the deployment of 100 MX land-based missiles if President Reagan did not stop abiding by provisions of the 1979 strategic arms limitation agreement with the Soviet Union. **********Senators Steven D. Symms of Idaho and John P. East of North Carolina gave the warning in a letter to Mr. Reagan, which they made public. Congressional conservatives have been pressing the Administration to renounce arms-control agreements with the Soviet Union on the ground that Moscow has been charged with violating them. **********New Talks Set for January **********The issue is sensitive for the Administration because Mr. Reagan, who has accused the Russians of cheating, is seeking new arms- control accords with the Soviet Union. Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko are to open arms-control talks early next month in Geneva. **********The Administration was supposed to have supplied Congress with a new report two days ago on purported Soviet violations of arms-control accords, but decided last week to delay it until February - after the Shultz-Gromyko meeting - on the ground that the work was not completed. **********A major complaint of Mr. Symms and Mr. East in their letter to Mr. Reagan was that the United States is living up to the terms of the 1979 strategic arms agreement even though the accord was never ratified by the Senate. Mr. Reagan has said the agreement is not a good one. **********In the letter, they specifically criticized the Administration for what they said was a plan, drawn up under the terms of the 1979 pact, to dismantle 100 submarine-launched missiles that could survive a Soviet attack more easily than the MX land-based missile could. They contended that the Administration was planning to dismantle the missiles at the same time that it was seeking Congressional support for key votes in March authorizing the start of deployment of 100 MX missiles.  The senators said the United States was, in effect, ''appeasing'' the Russians by living up to the terms of the 1979 agreement while Moscow was violating it. **********Because of the Administration's decision in 1981 not to undercut the 1979 agreement if the Soviet Union did the same, the Administration is obliged not to exceed a limit of 1,200 multiple-warhead land-based and submarine- launched missiles. Of that total, there was a sublimit of 820 land-based missiles with multiple warheads. **********When a seventh Trident submarine, the Alaska, starts its sea trials sometime in the second half of next year, the Administration will have to dismantle older missiles to stay within the 1,200 limit. Currently, the United States total of multiple-warhead missiles is just under 1,200. **********Earlier in the year, some liberal senators expressed concern that the Administration might not take steps to keep within the 1,200 limit. **********Senators Symms and East, in their letter, said they had been told ''that your Administration is planning to begin dismantling in June 1985 six perfectly serviceable and highly survivable Poseidon submarines'' with 96 ballistic missiles and a total of 960 warheads. This, they said, was to allow the newer Trident submarines to begin their sea trials.   'Unilateral Disarmament' **********''We do not believe,'' the letter said, ''that it is rational on either military or cost-effectiveness grounds to deploy 100 relatively nonsurvivable MX ICBM's, when at the same time you are planning to dismantle 96 highly survivable Poseidon SLBM's, in order to comply with an unratified, unequal treaty which you have confirmed that the Soviets are violating.'' **********ICBM stands for intercontinental ballistic missile, and SLBM for submarine-launched ballistic missile. **********The letter said that deploying the MX missiles while scrapping the Poseidon missiles ''is ridiculous.'' **********They said this would amount to ''unilatral disarmament'' by the United States ''in the face of Soviet violations'' and ''can only be described as U.S. appeasement of the Soviets.'' **********The Senators said that ''our support for the MX, when it is voted upon in mid-March 1985 may be contingent'' on the Administration's reporting more fully on Soviet violations and on formally withdrawing the 1979 strategic arms accord from the Senate. **********Neither the White House, the State Department, the Pentagon nor the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency had an immediate comment on the contents of the letter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/17/busin.main_headline: Washington Watch; Freddie Mac Plan Opposed
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/17/busin.print_headline: Washington Watch; Freddie Mac Plan Opposed
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/17/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON EDWIN J. GRAY'S plan to shift ownership of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, the quasi-public Government agency, to the nation's savings and loan industry, has hit heavy opposition from an unexpected Administration source: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. **********In an effort to strengthen the financial underpinnings of the thrift industry, Mr. Gray announced a plan Dec. 7 that calls for the distribution of 15 million preferred shares in the Mortgage Corporation to more than 3,000 thrift institutions. The stock would have a book value of at least $600 million. **********Mr. Gray serves as chairman of both the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac. He is also widely viewed as one of the few Federal financial regulatory heads with White House clout. Thus, Treasury and Bank Board officials have gone to unusual lengths to insure that the disagreement over the stock transfer not become a public squabble, which could prove embarrassing for both sides. **********Mr. Gray's plan, which he calls a ''paper transfer,'' would mean that the savings institutions would be able to show additional capital and net worth on their balance sheets, although no cash would be transferred. The stock of Freddie Mac is now owned by the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks, which contributed $100 million in capital to the corporation after it was chartered by Congress in 1970. **********In announcing the deal, Mr. Gray stressed that it would not alter the fundamental character of Freddie Mac. ''It is simply a paper transfer that will not change the directions, operations or statutory purposes of the corporation.'' **********But that's the rub, at least from Treasury's perspective. ''It seems to be in direct opposition to the Administration's ultimate goal of 'privatization,' '' said a senior Treasury official. **********''The Administration has consistently defined privitization as private ownership without ties to the Government,'' this official said. **********''At first blush,'' he added, ''it looks like a distribution of the ownership without changing any of the ties.'' **********Adds another Administration official, who said the Office of Management and Budget is also looking into the stock transfer: ''There's a feeling here, that, as a matter of course, we at least ought to have been informed. There are some people who are not too happy'' with Mr. Gray and the plan. **********A third Government official noted that the preferred stock is not scheduled to be issued to individual thrift institutions until Jan. 3, 1985. The implication is that there is still plenty of time to modify or perhaps block the deal. **********According to a Freddie Mac official, Treasury Secretary Regan and Mr. Gray are expected to meet today to discuss the transfer of ownership. **********Asked about the meeting, Julie Gould, an aide to Mr. Gray, answered with a terse: ''No comment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/25/world.main_headline: TEXT OF STATEMENT ISSUED BY CATHOLIC THEOLOGIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/25/world.print_headline: TEXT OF STATEMENT ISSUED BY CATHOLIC THEOLOGIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/25/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of a statement issued for publication today by Concilium, an unofficial group of Roman Catholic theologians: **********Liberation theology is in the public eye. It has been the subject of comment by high ecclesiastical authorities, of articles in various newspapers and reviews, and of questions put to several individual theologians. We consider it our duty to take a position on this problem. **********1.*Birth of basic Christian communities and of the theology of liberation: **********Since Vatican II, we have witnessed a real renewal in the life of the churches in poor countries. This has shown itself in the flourishing of numerous basic ecclesial communities and of groups of biblical reflection, in a new vitality of faith among the people, and in the involvement of Christians (laity, priests and bishops) in the struggle for the defense of the right of the poorest to life. **********In this way, the church has begun to enter the world of the poor and to share their destiny, while at the same time the people have assumed new responsibilities within its communion. From the moment that the People of God committed itself to this road, there began a critical reflection whose purpose has been to address the problem of the oppressed in the light of the faith and to promote their full liberation. **********Simultaneously, in other contexts but as part of the same vital movement, there has been a process of liberation and reflection among women, finding themselves marginal to the life of society and of the church, and among races and cultures conscious of their position as minorities in church and society. **********2.*Current tensions: **********These developments, and the hopes and claims which they embody, have provoked contrary reactions, incomprehension and even hostility on the part of those who hold political and economic power. We have seen men and women disappear, forced into exile, tortured and assassinated. These things are absolutely unacceptable. Within the church, while some holding positions of authority have sometimes supported and accepted these movements of liberation, we have also seen people defamed, forbidden to teach theology, rendered suspect of infidelity to the Christian message, and accused of substituting ideologies for the gospel, under the influence of Marxism. Against such procedures we register a strong and vigorous protest. **********There are tensions necessary to the life of the church, but today these are exacerbated by integrist and neoconservative groups. Resisting all social change and holding that religion has nothing to do with politics, they fight against movements of liberation and make choices that constitute an offense against the poor and oppressed. **********All of these factors have created a climate which is unfavorable to the search for new ways of being church and of proclaiming the gospel. **********3.*The position of the theologians of Concilium: **********Wishing to remain always faithful to the orientations and inspirations of Vatican II, in line with a preferential option for the poor, and in keeping with its own distinctive theological identity, Concilium expresses its solidarity with these new movements, with the local churches affected by them, and with the theologians of liberation, both within the Catholic Church and in other Christian churches. The theologians of Concilium wish to express our solidarity not only with their theological thought but also with the concrete positions that they take. **********In doing this, we are pursuing an orientation taken within recent years, as evidenced by the creation of new sections (Third World Theology, Feminist Theology) and by the line taken in several recent numbers of the review. A future number of Concilium will be devoted to the ecclesial context within which these tensions have to be situated. **********Certainly, it is not our pretension to possess the fullness of truth, and we are conscious of being but one voice among several, a voice, however, that is fully ecclesial. In fact, it is a sign of the fecundity of the gospel today that it is lived in different contexts and in different ways. Theology is but an expression of, and a reflection upon, this situation, a situation that is cause for joy and not for alarm. This is the dimension of pluralism inherent to catholicity. To fulfill its role, theology needs that freedom of research and expression which we claimed for it in our declaration of 1971. **********4.*Conclusion: **********As these movements are a sign of hope for the whole church, any premature intervention from higher authorities risks stifling the Spirit, which animates and guides local churches. We express our strong solidarity with these movements of liberation and with their theology. We protest against the suspicions and unjust criticisms registered against them.  We firmly believe that the future of the church, the coming of the kingdom, and the judgment of God on the world are tied up with these movements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/30/busin.body_text: **********Canadian coal production rose 24.3 percent in April to 4.6 million tons from 3.7 million tons a year earlier, Statistics Canada said today. For January through April, production totaled 19.9 million tons, up 27.2 percent from 14.5 million tons a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/21/world.main_headline: ISRAELIS SEAL ROAD TO SOUTH LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/21/world.print_headline: ISRAELIS SEAL ROAD TO SOUTH LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/21/world.body_text: **********Israel, citing security concerns, today sealed off to traffic the only road linking southern Lebanon with the rest of the country. The road will stay closed until Wednesday. **********Israeli officials said the closing of the crossing, at Bater in the Shuf Mountains, was carried out to allow troops to set up strict new security measures against the increasing attacks on their occupation forces in the south. **********Since the Beirut Government ordered the Israeli liaison office here closed last month, the Israelis occupying southern Lebanon have stepped up their pressure on the local people by restricting travel permits, among other measures. **********At the same time, Israeli soldiers and the South Lebanese Army they set up have come under steadily growing attacks from the largely Shiite Moslem population.   Backups of Days Are Common **********The Bater crossing has become a particular sore point in the south, with hundreds of people and scores of trucks often backing up for days to clear the Israeli checkpoint. The delays have badly damaged the agricultural economy of the south and made commerce and normal life difficult. **********Signs posted at the crossing say that under new regulations only pedestrians will be allowed into the south. Buses or taxis will pick up the travelers past the Israeli checkpoint. **********All trucks carrying cargo will have to be unloaded and the goods carried across and loaded on trucks on the other side. **********The closing of the crossing and the new regulations, Israeli officials said, were designed to set up new security arrangements and to prevent arms smuggling. **********Prime Minister Rashid Karami, describing the Israeli policies in the south as ''inhumane,'' said the Government would consider filing a complaint to the United Nations.   Meetings With Syrian **********In another development, a high-ranking Syrian official met for five hours in Beirut today with President Amin Gemayel and Mr. Karami to press for progress on the Government's attempt to expand its peace plan outside the capital to the nearby mountains. **********The visit of Brig. Gen. Mohammed al-Kholy, security adviser to President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, came after a night of heavy fighting between the Lebanese Army and Druse militiamen around Suk al Gharb, during which several shells landed on the grounds of the presidential palace. **********The Government's wobbly efforts to extend its peace plan into the Druse- held mountains south and east of Beirut ran into snags over the weekend as heavy fighting broke out between the army and militiamen of the Progressive Socialist Party of Tourism Minister Walid Jumblat. **********The Government wants to move army units into the area and open up the main highway to Damascus, but Mr. Jumblat and his Druse supporters are resisting the deployment of the army, contending it is linked to the Christian militia of the rival Phalangist Party.   Problems Remain, General Said **********General Kholy's visit today was seen as part of a Syrian effort to continue brokering peace efforts here. There were reports that a meeting between President Gemayel and President Assad might be in the offing. **********In remarks to reporters after the meeting in the Gemayel summer home in the mountain resort of Bikfeiya, the general said problems remained. **********Prime Minister Karami met tonight with Mr. Jumblat and Nabih Berri, the Shiite Moslem leader and Minister for the South and Reconstruction. The two regard themselves as ''opposition members'' of the Government. **********Mr. Jumblat has said that because he is going on a visit to Rumania he will not attend a Cabinet meeting scheduled for Wednesday, which will presumably discuss the mountain security plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/19/busin.body_text: **********The Pennzoil Company, gambling that Texaco Inc. will face Government opposition or long legal delays in its $10 billion deal to buy the Getty Oil Company, said yesterday that it was prepared to increase its own offer for Getty stock to $125 a share - the same price offered by Texaco. **********But Pennzoil said that, while it was seeking antitrust approval to buy up to half of Getty's shares, it was prepared at the moment to buy only 30 percent. **********Pennzoil said its proposal carries several conditions. For example, the proposal would not go ahead unless the Delaware Chancery Court upheld an earlier agreement that Pennzoil thought it had with the Sarah C. Getty Trust and the J. Paul Getty Museum to buy control of Getty, or unless Texaco withdrew its bid. **********Texaco said in a statement that the Pennzoil bid was ''an apparent attempt to create confusion.'' **********It added that, as it understood Pennzoil's conditions, Pennzoil would not make the $125-a-share offer to public stockholders unless it reached a new agreement with Gordon P. Getty, sole trustee of the Sarah Getty Trust. Analysts expressed doubt yesterday that Mr. Getty would agree to Pennzoil's terms. **********Professionals Back Away **********Wall Street professionals, initially heartened by the Pennzoil offer, bid up the market price of Getty stock to nearly $120 yesterday. But they backed away as soon as details of Pennzoil's conditions became clear. By the end of the day, Getty stood at $117.875, up 87 1/2 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Pennzoil stock fell 50 cents, to $35. **********The battle for Getty Oil began last month when Pennzoil offered to buy 20 percent of the shares for $100 each. Within days, it reached a deal to join with Mr. Getty to buy all the stock. **********Getty Oil also agreed to give Pennzoil an option to buy 8 million new shares for $110 each, thus enabling Pennzoil to show a profit if - as later happened - it was outbid. Getty now maintains that the option, worth $120 million, is not binding since it was only an agreement in principle. **********Subsequently, Texaco announced firm contracts to buy both the Sarah Getty stock and the museum's stock at $125 a share. Other shareholders would get the same price. **********Pennzoil immediately sued all parties in Delaware Chancery Court to enforce its deal, particularly the stock option. It then sued Texaco and Getty in Tulsa, Okla., on antitrust grounds. **********Yesterday there was conjecture on Wall Street that there could yet be a settlement between Texaco and Pennzoil if the dispute dragged on. Analysts pointed out that the museum has the right to back out if Texaco cannot make payment in 120 days. Any such settlement, analysts said, would probably involve giving some of Getty's oil reserves to Pennzoil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/22/world.main_headline: Reuters Reporter Freed In Lebanon Unharmed
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/22/world.print_headline: Reuters Reporter Freed In Lebanon Unharmed
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/22/world.body_text: **********A correspondent for Reuters who disappeared in Lebanon 23 days ago was released unharmed today by his abductors. **********The correspondent, Jonathon Wright, a 30-year-old Briton, said he was not able to identify his captors. **********He later left Beirut for London, accompanied by the chief representative of Reuters in Lebanon, David Betts. Mr. Betts said Mr. Wright's release came after the intervention of friends and officials. **********Mr. Wright, who was in good health, appeared at the Reuters office in Beirut today. He said he had not been mistreated by the gunmen who seized him after he left Beirut on Aug. 29 on a reporting trip to eastern Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; 2d Executive Leaving Flying Tiger Position
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/08/busin.body_text: **********John Flynn resigned as president of Tiger International Inc.'s air cargo operations, the company said yesterday. He was the second person to leave the post since June. **********At that time, Thomas F. Grojean, who had been expected to become chairman and chief executive of the diversified transportation company, resigned as president of the cargo operations, the Flying Tiger Lines. **********Wayne M. Hoffman, 61, chairman and chief executive of the parent, will now take on Mr. Flynn's duties as well as his own, the company said in a news release from its Los Angeles headquarters. **********Mr. Flynn, 43, resigned, effective March 1, for personal reasons, the company said. He was not available in calls to the company yesterday. **********He had been executive vice president of Flying Tiger under Mr. Grojean and was promoted when Mr. Grojean resigned during a management reorganization. **********Flying Tiger has been working its way out of a financial tailspin, selling off parts of the company and restructuring its debt. Last month it announced plans to sell its leasing operations, and it signed a bank accord to reschedule some debt and establish more credit. **********In last year's final quarter, Tiger International reported a profit from continuing operations of $4.7 million, compared with a loss in the same period a year earlier.
