https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/29/world.print_headline: ISRAELI VOTE SET FOR JULY 23; SHAMIR-PERES CONTEST SEEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/29/world.body_text: **********After a week of negotiation and compromise, the governing Likud bloc and the opposition Labor Party agreed today on July 23 as the date for new parliamentary elections. **********Politicians on both sides said the early date made leadership struggles in either party unlikely, meaning that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, as head of the Herut Party - the dominant faction in the Likud bloc - would probably be defending his position against Shimon Peres, the leader of the Labor Party. **********But the situation remained volatile, and upheavals were still regarded as possible. The key question in Labor was whether former President Yitzhak Navon would challenge Mr. Peres for the party leadership. The two men met over a private lunch today; Mr. Navon, who cut short a trip to the United States and Canada to return to Israel on Tuesday, told Mr. Peres that he would announce his intentions on Friday. **********Outcome Is Far From Certain **********Mr. Peres has not proven to be much of a vote-getter, losing twice, in 1977 and 1981, to Menachem Begin. But Mr. Shamir, who assumed the party leadership when Mr. Begin resigned last September, is seen as a bland figure compared with the fiery Mr. Begin and has not been tested at the polls. Consequently, many in Herut doubt Mr. Shamir's ability to conduct an exciting, attractive campaign and thus the outcome of the July election is viewed as being far from certain. **********The latest public opinion polls show Labor defeating Likud, but polls did before the 1981 elections as well. **********Mr. Peres's unpopularity with the electorate has created a significant mood in Labor for a change to Mr. Navon, a moderate who is thought capable of appealing to a broad range of Israei voters. But Mr. Peres has shown no signs of willingness to relinquish his leadership, and any challenge to him could be expected to unleash supporters of former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, whose rivalry with Mr. Peres has had a nasty edge for years. Many Laborites fear that a struggle would be so divisive that the party would not have time to heal the wounds before election day.   'Waiting for His Answer' **********Mr. Peres, in an interview on the Israeli Army radio, was asked about a possible challenge from Mr. Navon. ''I hope there won't be,'' he replied. ''Yitzhak Navon told me he would give me an answer on Friday. We had a very open, friendly conversation in a good spirit.'' **********Prominent Labor figures predicted that a place in the party short of the top spot would be found for Mr. Navon. This was the gist of an analysis by Moshe Shahal, Labor's whip in Parliament. The July 23 date, he said, was not far enough away for a full leadership struggle and not near enough to preclude some shifts. Some speculated that Mr. Navon would be offered a place as second or third on the Labor list and possibly a high Cabinet post, such as Deputy Prime Minister, should Labor be able to form a government. **********In Herut, both former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon and Deputy Prime Minister David Levy were being mentioned as potential contenders for the leadership. But whether either would make an effort to unseat Prime Minister Shamir remained uncertain. **********Mr. Sharon, glum and uncharacteristically taciturn in the dining room in Parliament, confirmed past declarations of intent to make a challenge, but only with a nod and affirmative mumble, not with the ringing statements that have been his trademark. **********Another Herut member speculated that Mr. Sharon would be satisfied this time around with the promise of a key Cabinet position such as Defense Minister, from which he was forced to resign after a state commission found him and other officials ''indirectly responsible'' for the massacre of Palestinian civilians in Beirut by Lebanese Christian Phalangists. **********One of Mr. Levy's associates, Moshe Katzav, said the Deputy Prime Minister had not decided about a challenge. Mr. Katzav said there would not be time for Herut to recover from an intraparty fight before elections. **********Another former Defense Minister, Ezer Weizman, previously a member of the Herut Party, has announced his intention to run a slate of candidates in the election. Most of those who have joined with him are former high-ranking officers of the Israeli Army. **********The move toward early elections began last week when the Tami Party, which holds three seats, defected from the governing coalition on the question. Two other legislators also dropped away, and the Parliament gave preliminary approval to three bills setting dates in May or June.   Threats and Counterthreats Current law requires elections no later than November 1985. Mr. Shamir sought a date of November 1984, hoping to allow time for an economic recovery. His coalition threatened to hold up the bill in committee, thereby making it impossible for Parliament to take final action before it recessed this week until May. **********In turn, Labor threatened to move every 24 hours to muster the required 30 members needed to call a special session. Days of bargaining ensued, with Mr. Shamir compromising to September and Mr. Peres giving in to June. As of this morning, the difference between the two parties' positions was early July and late July. **********''Labor wanted a much earlier date,'' Mr. Peres said in the radio interview. ''In essence, we wanted the end of June, both to shorten the period of election campaigns, and to cut expenses, and to release the state from an unclear situation.'' **********Another factor was the large number of affluent Israelis, including probably a disproportionately high number of Labor voters, who travel abroad in the summer. There are no absentee ballots in Israeli elections. **********Parliament is scheduled to reconvene in special session early next week to enact the required legislation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/20/busin.main_headline: HAVE YOU EVER TRIED TO GIVE YOUR KIDS SOME MONEY SENSE?
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/20/busin.print_headline: AT THE BEGINNING; HAVE YOU EVER TRIED TO GIVE YOUR KIDS SOME MONEY SENSE?
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/20/busin.body_text: **********I'VE given a good deal of thought to the issue of children and money. I'm not speaking of those depressing figures one encounters that say what it costs to **********raise a child these days - figures that (if I'm to take them seriously) leave my husband and me, with three kids, about a million dollars short. **********What I'm speaking of is the way a parent goes about teaching children the value of a dollar, and about money in general. You shouldn't love it, can't hate it, have to respect it, mustn't worship it. This money-explaining business makes communicating the facts about sex, religion, or the electoral college system, seem elementary. **********A child's earliest relationship with money is oral. Around 12 months (but of course mine were precocious) they start putting coins into their mouths. Now my older son - he's two - likes to put pennies in his big sister's bank, counting as he goes. (One, four, seven, two, nine.) He has been known to tap me on the head at three in the morning with the sweetly voiced request, ''Penny please, mom.''(And in his rowdier moments, to tear through the house, yelling, at top volume, ''Five dollars! Five dollars! Five dollars!'') Clearly, it doesn't take long for a child to grasp the idea that these are powerful words. **********But where Charlie remains happy with any coin (and Willy, at six weeks, oblivious to all), their six-year-old sister has learned about the deceptive value of a dime over a nickel. Her greatest reverence she reserves for paper currency. And when, once, she observed me bent over a stack of bills, in tears, she hustled off to her room and came back a few minutes later to shower me with hand-colored tens, twenties and fifties, all bearing presidential-looking profiles. If money can't buy happiness, she's learned, it can cheer a person up, at least . **********My husband and I - a painter and a writer - collect our dollars pretty haphazardly. Every now and then they rain down on us and we may buy three lobsters or a car. And then comes a drought and, the next thing you know, I'm setting up a tableful of our possessions at the town flea market. We work very hard at being parents our children can rely upon. But as for owning a piece of the rock - the best we can offer are shifting sands. **********Of course, our own hard times bear no resemblance to genuine poverty. For us there is generally an end in sight, the promise of a check in the mail, no fear of being cold or hungry. We don't let our children entertain the notion that doing without this month's Sesame Street magazine has anything to do with hardship. Still, it certainly hasn't hurt them to get the sense, during our leaner times, that my husband's wallet is not bottomless. **********Partly because of the intermittent instability of our situation, our daughter is close to obsessed with the theme of rich people and poor ones. Like parents everywhere, we hold forth when Audrey's making faces over her asparagus and requesting that the crusts be cut off her toast on the hungry children who would give anything for those crusts. Audrey's comprehension seems to come and go. I have found her feeding steak to our dog. But I have also heard her, as she stood throwing away school worksheets at the edge of the town dump, musing on how lucky it is that she did them in pencil, because some poor little girl who can't afford to go to school could now pick them out, erase the answers and do the work all over again. **********I may have gone overboard invoking the picture of good little poor girls and the spoiled ones who waste asparagus. When Audrey plays with her Barbie dolls, the rich girl, in the evening gown and fur stole, is usually mean and speaks in a vain, cruel voice, while the poor one is sweet and humble. And having grasped the meaning of wealth, she is wasting no time in passing on the news to her brother Charlie. At the school she periodically runs, whose classes he has little choice but to attend, a recent lesson was titled ''How to Draw a Rich Girl.'' (With lots of frills on her skirt and a broad smile, that's how.) **********What else are my children learning about money? The concept of inflation seemed to come naturally: At a recent art show held in her bedroom, Audrey's pictures started out with price tags of 1 and 2 cents, but when they started selling like hotcakes (with her father, brothers and me as customers), she began crossing out prices, upping them to 10 cents, even 30, as fast as we could hand over our coins. (When we ran out of money, she promptly opened her bank and distributed its contents so we could keep on buying.) **********I try all the time, but pretty lamely, to make sense of the world for our children. I explain the nightly news to Audrey as best I can, during the commercials, reducing to a six-year-old's terms the idea of money for defense versus a nuclear freeze. But I know that, however much information my husband and I give our kids, the world of finance and economics (ours, theirs, Reagan's) must seem more than a little surreal. What we have are a two-year- old son who, at the mention of Jesse Jackson, starts dancing wildly around the room and singing ''Beat it'' or ''Thriller,'' and a daughter who believed, after my wallet was stolen in New York last fall, that now we'd be poor. **********And here am I, trying to untangle things for them, while our checking account stands mysteriously overdrawn again. After a four-year correspondence, we have just come to terms with the I.R.S. over the disappearance, from its computer, of several years' worth of our joint tax returns. All this time, it turns out, I had been writing down in the appropriate box a composite of my Social Security and telephone numbers. **********Joyce Maynard is working on a book called ''Domestic Affairs.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/world.main_headline: 400 FOES OF HANOI SAID TO FACE TRIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/world.print_headline: 400 FOES OF HANOI SAID TO FACE TRIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/world.body_text: **********Vietnam appears to be starting a public campaign against dissidents at home while it steps up military activities against the Chinese on its northern border and rebel forces in Cambodia. **********According to diplomatic reports from Hanoi this week, the Vietnamese are preparing to put on trial in Ho Chi Minh City, the former Saigon, a group of at least 100 people accused of plotting to overthrow the Hanoi Government.  Some Western reporters are being given permission to go to Vietnam for the trial, according to Vienamese diplomats here. **********Reports from Hanoi this week quoting foreign diplomats there, said that the dissidents were being described as rebels trained and armed in China and Thailand. The Thais have denied any involvement in or knowledge of such activities. **********The Vietnamese Government radio has at the same time been reporting new fighting near the border with China.   Border Is Strengthened **********On Wednesday the Vietnamese press agency said the country's six northern provinces were being strengthened against ''an eventual large-scale invasion'' from China. It said 100 Chinese troops were killed in 40 clashes along the border in the last week in November. **********The reports of clashes with Chinese troops come at a time when Vietnamese forces are stepping up military pressure on Cambodian guerrilla forces seeking to overthrow the Vietnamese-installed Government in Phnom Penh from bases along the Thai border inside Cambodia. **********Since mid-November, Vietnamese troops have been shelling and occasionally overrunning camps belonging to the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, a non-Communist faction within the loose coalition of groups that is fighting against the Cambodian Government of Heng Samrin. **********Hanoi is thought to have between 160,000 and 180,000 troops in Cambodia, which it invaded in late 1978 to overthrow the Khmer Rouge Government under Pol Pot.   Anti-Government Forces **********Arrayed against the Vietnamese are a surviving Khmer Rouge army of about 30,000, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front force of about 15,000 and a smaller army of 7,000 who are followers of Prince Norodom Sihanouk. **********In the recent attacks on border camps the Vietnamese have concentrated on the Khmer People's National Liberation Front and have not mounted attacks on the Khmer Rouge camps. **********Some Thai and foreign specialists who have followed the patterns of fighting in Cambodia since Vietnam installed the present Government in early 1979, suggest that Hanoi has the capacity to destroy the Khmer Rouge camps, but does not do so because the presence of the Pol Pot forces provide an excuse for prolonged Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia. **********Further, experts say, as long as the Khmer Rouge remain the strongest element in the three-part opposition coalition called Democratic Kampuchea, Cambodian and foreign opinion would not be in favor of returning the coalition to power. The Khmer Rouge, who were originally backed by the Vietnamese, are thought to have killed more than a million Cambodians during their years in power in Phnom Penh from 1975 through 1978. **********Recruits to the Khmer People's National Liberation Front are reported to be increasing. That organizaton, and the Sihanouk faction, would be more popular within and outside Cambodia than the Khmer Rouge as an alternative government to Heng Samrin, diplomats and Cambodian refugees say, and this may be causing concern in Hanoi. Cambodian refugees are now telling reporters that Vietnamese troops are making it more difficult for would-be defectors and refugees to reach the front's camps. **********Interviews with Vietnamese refugees along the border area over the last few months lend some credence to Hanoi's charges that there may be at least a small armed uprising within Vietnam itself. Former inmates of Vienamese prison camps say that they believe increasing numbers of dissidents are being arrested, some on charges of possessing illegal weapons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/27/world.body_text: **********President Reagan's chief of staff, James A. Baker, jokingly called Massachusetts a Communist country, and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis is angry. **********Reporters accompanying the Presidential entourage in Guam Wednesday asked Mr. Baker if the trip to China was his first visit to a Communist country. Mr. Baker visited China in 1980. **********''No,'' Mr. Baker said. ''I've been to Massachusetts.'' **********Governor Dukakis called the remark an ''an outrageous failure at humor which is a grievous insult to the citizens of a commonwealth who were the first to lay down their lives against tyranny in the defense of freedom.'' **********State Representative Andrew Natsios, chairman of the Massachusetts Republican Party, found humor in the quip. **********''Given the voting habits of some parts of this state, I can understand his statement,'' Mr. Natsios said. ''The People's Republic of China is more conservative than parts of Cambridge.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/29/busin.body_text: **********BOSTON **********It was 7 A.M., and Richard F. Greene of **********Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & **********Smith Inc. navigated his 1983 black Cadillac to a roadside motel where the Business Roundtable of Boston was holding a breakfast meeting. Its members were not exactly the heavyweights of Massachusetts business, but Mr. Greene accepted an invitation to speak anyway. **********The gamble paid off. Not only was Mr. Greene able to distribute his name and phone number to more than 30 potential investors, but he found one man in particular who was interested in talking further. **********''The other fellows will be getting in at 9 A.M., and I already have a customer,'' Mr. Greene said, looking pleased, as he returned to his neat 33d-floor office in Boston's financial district. Sure enough, a week later, Mr. Greene reports, the man bought $250,000 in municipal bonds. **********Such hustling for new customers is typical of the way Mr. Greene does business, and associates say it is key to his long-running success at Merrill. Last year, the 50- year-old broker brought in commissions totaling $4.2 million - he gets about 40 percent - and ranked second among Merrill's 9,000 retail brokers. His business is off 20 percent this year, but in third place, he still ranks high. **********''While some perceive him as sort of insensitive and hard-nosed, in fact, he has pretty much done away with the concept of horsing around at work,'' said Samuel E. Bane, a broker who worked at Merrill before moving to Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. ''Month in and month out, he constantly prospects no matter how successful he gets.'' **********Added Jeffrey K. Wilgus, a former Merrill broker now with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.: ''Every day, for years, he's had a face-to-face meeting in the morning on the way in. That's more than the average guy would ever do.'' **********Nonetheless, Mr. Greene's oratory is not what wins new customers. His pitch to the Roundtable was short and somewhat flat. But, he says, his success comes from listening, not talking. **********''People like you when you listen to them,'' he explained. Listening also lets him glean valuable bits of information - like the fact the Roundtable member might have money to invest. **********A cigar smoker with a Boston accent and distinctly Irish face, Mr. Greene grew up in Brookline, Mass., the son of a teacher and a blue-collar worker with the telephone company. A graduate of Boston University with a degree in business and accounting, he was flying for the Air Force when he opened his first account with Merrill Lynch in 1956. He bought 100 shares of American Motors at 7 5/8 each. ''I sold at 9, and watched it go to 120,'' he recalled. ''I said, 'This is a good game, but maybe I don't know how to do it right.' '' **********BEFORE seeking the answer, Mr. Greene worked as a cost accounting trainee with United States Steel in Trenton. ''I had been there four months,'' he related. ''I said, 'Is this all there is?' '' **********So, he answered a Merrill advertisement, had four interviews and was hired as a broker. Within four years, he was the top producer in Manhattan, staying there until 1972, when he transferred to the Boston area with his wife and four children. With the fourth child now on his way to college, Mr. Greene and his wife live in a downtown Boston apartment during the week. On weekends, they go to their Cape Cod house, which he said has ''all the capitalistic tools,'' including a Jeep and power boat. A small airplane is the next purchase, he said. **********Mr. Greene's days at work move rapidly. He sits in a large corner office with four assistants whose Merrill Lynch salaries he supplements with bonuses. The assistants deal with routine transactions, place calls and keep the paperwork straight. Mr. Greene, meanwhile, constantly makes and receives client calls, snapping his fingers at one of the assistants to signal his readiness for the next call. The client roster is a hefty 500 names long, and he talks to all of them at least every two months, although only 150 accounts are active. They include individuals, pension funds, profit-sharing plans, charities and a well-known rock band, whose name Mr. Greene did not want published. Individual accounts range from $10,000 to $20 million, and his accounts total about $300 million. **********Although he makes strong recommendations, Mr. Greene said he does not accept money to manage at his own discretion. ''It's good discipline on my part if I have to explain why I'm doing what I'm doing,'' he said. ''You can't get referrals'' with discretionary money, he added, because ''people don't know why they bought what they bought and can't tell the next guy at the country club.'' **********Also contrary to custom for some big brokers, Mr. Greene does not insist on a minimum account. ''I don't think you can forget the big clients you have, how much money they started with,'' he said. ''Many times large accounts will deal with you because you handled their secretary's money, and treated her right.'' **********Mr. Greene is known for taking large positions in relatively few stocks. ''Ten securities is diversified,'' he said. But, he said, his stocks are generally in conservative companies that are No. 1 in their business, have a strong balance sheet and are involved in a ''long-term concept.'' **********HIS favorites now include American Telephone and Telegraph, which he says will ''get its game together,'' and which has ''   the    franchise in the U.S. for long distance.'' He also likes International Business Machines and some savings and loan associations, because their prices have been so depressed. But his biggest bet now is on falling interest rates. He is buying long-term Government and A.T.& T. subsidiary bonds now selling at large discounts from par, which would skyrocket in price if rates fell. **********''I buy good quality things,'' he said. ''Before I buy anything, I say, 'If I'm wrong, how bad is it going to hurt?' If you invest that way, you'll make money, because you won't have any big hits on the downside.'' He insists on taking a long- term approach - one reason, he said, why he can take ''a lot of vacation,'' including a trip to England next month. He is fond of saying, ''Time must go on in order to make money,'' adding, ''I don't buy things that have to work out in 15 seconds.'' **********If prices do sometimes turn against Mr. Greene's clients - and it happens, of course - he does his best to keep them encouraged. He spent a recent morning calling clients for whom he bought El Torito Restaurants. Since its purchase, the stock fell to about $10, from $13. But the earnings reported that morning were strong. **********''Everyone needs some good news,'' he told a client cheerfully before reciting the earnings. ''The reasons we bought it are falling in line,'' he continued. He acknowledged that the earnings report did not do much for the stock price that morning, but added, ''If the earnings weren't good, we could be watching it at 5.'' **********Later, he said, ''My biggest problem is making sure I keep myself up so I can keep my clients' morale up.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/09/world.body_text: **********Suriname's Cabinet, apparently seeking restoration of $90 million in annual development money from the Netherlands, approved a proposal Friday to create a national assembly. **********The proposal would have to be sanctioned by the military regime headed by Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse and officials said approval would also be sought from unions and businessmen. **********The proposal accepted by the Cabinet would create a 31-member assembly to draw up a new constitution within 27 months. The assembly also would have the power to legislate and authorize government spending. **********Under the proposal, 14 seats would go to the military, 11 to organized labor and 6 to the private sector. **********A Government official said a decision to form the assembly must be reached by Dec. 31, when the mandate expires for the Cabinet headed by Prime Minister Wim Udenhout.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/20/busin.body_text: **********The Beatrice Foods Company in Chicago, which in November announced the seven ad agencies that would benefit from the consolidation of its ad assignments from more than 100 agencies, made the agency-of- record assignments for the seven yesterday. **********Agencies of record get a small percentage of the 15 percent media commission for placing advertising for it. **********By bunching such assignments, advertisers hope to get additional clout with the media. Beatrice expects to spend $120 million on advertising this year. **********For network television, the Leo Burnett Company will be in charge of buying for prime time, late night and children's programming; J. Walter Thompson for daytime, and McCann- Erickson for news. **********Mandabach & Simms is agency of record for the trade press; Marsteller for consumer magazines, Bozell & Jacobs for newspapers, and D'Arcy- MacManus & Masius for out-of-home media, which means billboards, transit advertising and the like. **********McCann has been assigned cost forcasting, which was described as ''long-range media trend tracking and forcasting for brand and business planning.'' **********Each agency will buy local spot TV and radio and network radio for the brands they are regularly assigned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/01/busin.body_text: **********Adjustable rates, which became commonplace in home mortgages as interest rates soared, are fast becoming fixtures in auto loans, the backbone of the consumer loan industry. **********Jerry Alderman Ford in Indianapolis, for example, was one of the first to offer the new loans, starting two years ago. ''I can count on one hand the number of times our customers have gone the fixed-rate route,'' Steven Edging, vice president and general manager, said. ''Variable- rate loans are here to stay.'' **********John R. Gilker, Ford's manager of marketing and credit, said Ford's move was ''an experiment to test the market reaction; this is an idea that's taking hold in certain parts of the country, and we want to be competitive with the marketplace.'' **********In a fixed-rate loan, borrowers know how much they will repay at what interest rate. But in an adjustable- or variable-rate loan, whether for a house or car, the interest rate, and thus the final cost, may change. **********At stake for lenders and borrowers are billions of dollars in interest costs. Auto loans made up $142.4 billion of the $396 billion in consumer installment loans made last year, according to the Federal Reserve, which said that, as of July of this year, the average amount of a new- car loan was just under $9,400 and its term was just over 48 months. **********The variable-rate loan was popularized in mortgage lending at a time when high interest rates were scaring off potential home buyers. By offering a loan rate that could be adjusted, lenders were hoping to entice borrowers with the prospect that they would not be locked into the high rates. At the same time, the lenders were protecting themselves: Since the banks have to pay changing market rates on deposits, they believed borrowers should pay changing market rates. **********In auto loans, supporters say, the practice marks a fundamental change, one that makes the risks of borrowers and lenders more equal. **********But some consumer advocates and economists argue that the arrangement shifts the interest-rate burden onto the borrower. ''Interest fees are already supposed to pay for the risk of the loan; that's what they've always done,'' said Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the New York State Consumer Protection Board. ''Variable-rate loans may put consumers in the position of paying for that risk twice.'' **********In variable-rate loans, the lender is in effect gambling that rates will go up, while the borrower is gambling they will rise. And lately the borrowers have been winning, as a drop in rates overall has begun to filter into the consumer marketplace. **********Enthusiastic Response **********Precise statistics on the prevalence of variable-rate loans are not available. But officials of the American Bankers Association and the National Auto Dealers Association say the practice, which began about three years ago, has met an enthusiastic response among lenders and consumers. Where available, consumers appear to be choosing the variable-rate loan in far greater numbers than the traditional fixed-rate car loan. **********According to data gathered by the bankers association, 20 percent of the 14,000 banks in the United States - and 34 percent of banks with more than $500 million in assets - now offer variable-rate loans. **********Lenders, including the Chase Manhattan Bank and Marine Midland Bank in New York and Connecticut Bank and Trust, are among those that offer the loans, or plan to do so soon. **********Further, a statute permitting variable-rate financing for all consumer loans is being considered by the New Jersey Legislature. **********The variable-rate concept received a strong endorsement when the Ford Motor Credit Company, a subsidiary of the auto maker and the second- largest finance company in the world, recently began offering variable-rate auto loans at 500 Ford dealerships in Indiana, Kentucky and Texas. **********Still, many lenders remain unconvinced of the depth of the variable- rate program's attractiveness to consumers. And neither the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the world's largest finance company, nor the Chrysler Finance Corporation has plans to offer variable-rate loans, according to company spokesmen. **********In addition, Citibank, Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust, three of the biggest banks in New York, said they had no plans for variable-rate consumer loans, either. **********One reason variable-rate loans are proving attractive is that their initial interest fee is usually set at one to two percentage points below that for a fixed-rate loan. **********For example, the Merchants National Bank and Trust of Indianapolis offers those loans with an intial interest rate of 13 1/4 percent. By contrast, the interest rate on the bank's fixed- rate auto loan is 14 3/4 percent. James D. Madigan, Merchant's executive vice president, described that bank's experience with the loans as ''excellent,'' saying that variable-rate loans now make up 65 percent of its car- loan portfolio. **********The response has been similarly positive at California's Crocker National Bank, which began offering variable- rates in March. Robert L. Lowe, vice president for business planning and development, said 75 percent of new- car loan customers since then have chosen the new loans, accounting for about $100 million in loans. **********Loan Rate Pegged to Other Rates **********The interest on a variable-rate loan is not permanently set, as in a fixed- rate loan. Rather, it is pegged to a particular floating index, such as the rate for six-month Treasury bills, or some other easily-verifiable financial instrument. The rate is reviewed on a fixed schedule, such as every six months or once a year. **********For example, Marine Midland Bank of New York offers variable- rate car loans at 13.95 percent for customers and 14.95 percent for non-customers. The rate is pegged to the sixth-month Treasury bill. Thus, a borrower's interest payments would be higher if that index rises, or lower if the index falls. **********The difference between a fixed-rate car loan and a variable one can be seen as follows: **********- The borrower of an $12,000 auto loan, with a fixed rate of interest at 15 percent over 48 months, would repay the $12,000, plus interest of $7,200, for a total of $19,200. **********- The borrower of $12,000 at variable rates, in which the rate remained at the initial 13 percent, would pay $6,240 in interest; a total of $18,240. But should the rate decline, to, say, 12.5 percent the second year, 12 percent the third and 11.5 percent in the final year, the borrower would pay about $5,880 in interest - or a total of $17,880. **********- Conversely, if rates rose one-half of one percentage point a year over the course of the loan, the borrower would pay $6,600 in interest costs, for a total of $18,600. **********All examples assume the same number of payments and no amortization of principal. **********For competitive purposes, banks and other lenders often structure their variable-rate programs to appeal to consumers. At Marine Midland, for example, interest fees on the variable-rate loan cannot be increased more than two percentage points from one adjustment period to the next, nor more than six percentage points over the life of the loan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/06/busin.main_headline: CORPORATE PHONE LISTS TO BE AUCTIONED BY MAIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/06/busin.print_headline: CORPORATE PHONE LISTS TO BE AUCTIONED BY MAIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/06/busin.body_text: **********How valuable are the telephone directories of some of the nation's top banks, investment and accounting firms, insurance companies and corporations - especially those that include not only direct office numbers for managers, but also home addresses and phone numbers and, in at least one instance, such data for summer homes? **********Steven Olsen is counting on their being worth a great deal. **********Mr. Olsen said his firm, Corporate Information Services, plans to sell copies of directories for such companies as the General Motors Corporation; the RCA Corporation; Chase Manhattan Bank; Goldman, Sachs & Company; Arthur Andersen & Company, and Booz, Allen & Hamilton, the management consulting firm. **********Semiannual Auctions Planned **********Prospective buyers are told to write to a box number and ask for a catalog detailing what Mr. Olsen said would be a package of directories for 250 companies from around the world. They must then submit bids through the mail for the package. **********Bidders topping a minimum set by Mr. Olsen's company would receive the package, and, he said, ''we're not talking small money.'' **********He added that although a date for the mail-order auction had not yet been set, it would be ''the first of regular semiannual auctions.'' **********''This is a valuable source of information to stockbrokers, executive recruiters, insurance and real estate brokers and those engaged in direct- mail marketing or telemarketing,'' Mr. Olsen said. ''We're talking about the most powerful companies and some of the highest-salaried people in the world,'' he added. **********Copies Displayed **********Mr. Olsen, who said he got his idea while working as an editor for a computer publication, showed off copies of in-house directories for Chase Manhattan and Goldman, Sachs during an interview. **********His plans drew a cool response from both companies. **********Philip Adams, a spokesman for Goldman, Sachs, said that the firm had no specific knowledge of it, but it knew the directories were circulated. **********Chase Manhattan, in a statement released through its public relations office, said only that the bank would prefer that its directories not be available outside the company. **********Many other companies declined comment on the attempted sale of their directory information. The reaction among those that did ranged from outrage to hearty amusement. **********Robert Stovall of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said caustically: ''It's an invitation to subject our employees to unwanted solicitations. We don't think it's very sporting. The book wasn't prepared for some parasite to grab it and sell it.'' **********'That's America for You' **********However, Alan Greenberg, chief executive at the investment firm of Bear, Stearns & Company, laughed and said, ''I don't know and couldn't care less if they have it. Wish them luck. That's America for you.'' **********Those interviewed said that it was common for a company's directory to circulate informally outside of the company. Indeed, company officers often give the directories to clients and friends in other companies. But a systematic attempt to sell directories, as Mr. Olsen is doing, apparently is unique. **********During an interview last week, Mr. Olsen said he was 24 years old, but he generally declined to disclose details of his background, or that of his partner, Sheldon Copeland. He said that Mr. Copeland had extensive experience as a management consultant with leading industrial companies. **********Mr. Olsen also declined to discuss in detail how he obtained the directories, other than to say that stock brokers had been one key source. **********Traded 'Like Baseball Cards' **********''They have top people as clients who give them the directories, as a source of new clients, and they pass them on to other people for other directories.'' he remarked. ''They trade them like baseball cards.'' **********''We only have copies of the directories,'' Mr. Olsen stressed, not the directories themselves. ''So we're not in receipt of stolen properties, and I acquired them all legally.'' **********But Mr. Olsen, who wants to sell other people's addresses and telephone numbers, declined for ''reasons of security'' to disclose the address or telephone number of his company. There was no listing for Corporate Information Services in telephone information for New York City, and the address to which inquiries about the auction are to be sent is a mailbox in a private postal drop company on lower Fifth Avenue. Mr. Olsen was reached through an answering service, whose number is not as closely guarded. **********Mr. Olsen said that such secrecy was necessary ''as protection against attempts to steal or destroy this valuable database.'' He said he was followed for a time and ''had to take evasive action'' last year after a newspaper published an article about the company. **********No Copyrighted Directories **********Mr. Olsen also said that he had no copies of company directories that are copyrighted. **********Victor A. Kovner, a lawyer who is a copyright expert, said that if a company has copyrighted its directory and given notice in it, the book cannot be reproduced without permission. **********For example, The New York Times Company copyrighted the 1984 edition of its internal directory to prevent unauthorized reproduction. Notice of the copyright is given on the bottom of every page of the directory. **********Mr. Kovner said that if a company has not copyrighted its directory, then in most cases it could not prevent copies from being disseminated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/18/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; LOEWS PURSUING MULTISCREEN CONCEPT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/18/busin.body_text: **********A construction crew is burrowing deep into the ground at the northeast corner of Broadway and 84th Street as part of the initial stages of construction for a six-auditorium cinema complex being built by the Loews theater chain. **********The 22,000-square-foot theater, to be known as Loews 84th Street, is expected to be completed in time for Christmas releases and is rising on property adjacent to Loews Quad, the four-screen movie house the company owns and operates on Broadway at 83d Street. The new theater is being built on a site that includes a hotel, which the Loews Corporation owned for several years, and a former parking lot that the company acquired once the multiscreen movie house was planned. **********Loews 84th Street is the company's first ''sixplex'' in Manhattan and the second multiscreen theater to be constructed by Loews Theaters Inc., a division of the Loews Corporation. Loews 34th Street Showplace, a 1,600- seat triplex between First Avenue and Second Avenue, opened in 1981. **********Until then the company's four other multiscreen facilities in Manhattan resulted from renovations of existing auditoriums into two- or three-screen houses. The cutting up of large auditoriums, including many of the movie palaces built in the 1920's and 1930's, was the theater owners' way of competing with television. **********''When TV became big, we found ourselves operating these huge theaters with 3,000 or more seats for an audience of 300 or 400 patrons,'' said Bernard Meyerson, president of Loews Theaters and executive vice president of the Loews Corporation. ''It just was not economical.'' **********In 1968 Loews converted the 57- year-old Loews State on Broadway at 45th Street to a twin-screen theater at a cost of about $40 a square foot. **********''Today the same renovation costs $100 per square foot for the average theater,'' Mr. Meyerson said. ''But it is worth it because the multiplex allows us to show a variety of movies for what is the same basic cost of operating one large house. The concept not only was a lifesaver for the movie- theater and movie-making industries but also saved many historical structures.'' **********Construction costs for the average multiscreen theater, Mr. Meyerson said, start at $3 million, and his company is spending $5 million to build Loews 84th Street. The new West Side theater will have between 2,600 and 2,700 seats. Two auditoriums will hold approximately 600 seats each, and the four smaller screening rooms will each have between 350 and 425 seats. **********Held & Rubin, the Long Island architectural firm responsible for several Loews multiplexes throughout the country, has designed a building that will seem from the outside to have just one story, but its interior will have three levels. Patrons will enter the lobby on Broadway and find three theaters on a level below the street and three auditoriums on a balcony level. The main waiting area and refreshment stand will occupy space on the same level as the street. **********Mr. Meyerson, who has been in the industry for some 45 years, says the new theater, in its way, will be as luxurious as yesterday's movie palaces. He is not just alluding to the chandelier and handpainted murals that will adorn the Loews 84th Street. **********''Luxury in Manhattan is space,'' Mr. Meyerson said, discussing the project from his Loews Corporation offices at 666 Fifth Avenue. ''Patrons will not have to stand in line outside. For the waiting areas, we have allocated four square feet for every theater seat.'' **********Despite the emergence of cable television, Mr. Meyerson said, movie theaters are stronger now than they have been in years. **********''A couple of years ago I did not think we would be constructing theaters in Manhattan,'' he said. ''And the West Side has become a new hub for the city.'' **********Loews Theaters, meanwhile, is negotiating for a site at Avenue of the Americas and Sixth Street, where it hopes to rebuild the Loews Sheridan, the movie theater that was closed in 1970 after the property was sold to St. Vincent's Hospital. **********Mr. Meyerson is not alone in his confident assessment of the current strength of movie theater properties. Peter Elson, executive vice president of Guild Enterprises, which owns and operates eight screens in five Manhattan theaters, said scouting for potential sites had become a continuing practice for his company. **********''A good many movies that are being made today - like the 'Star Wars' series - have to be seen in theaters where there are large screens and special sound systems,'' Mr. Elson said. **********''At one time it seemed that cable would be a serious threat, but we are finding that people still want the magic of seeing a film in a movie theater.'' **********While staying alert to potential development sites, Mr. Elson said, Guild Enterprises will convert its 450- seat theater in Rockefeller Center, at 33 West 50th Street, into a twin some time before the end of the year. **********The conversion will result in one 275-seat auditorium and a theater with 375 seats. The project is expected to cost between $400,000 and $500,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/busin.main_headline: A FED GOVERNOR PONDERS THE PAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/busin.print_headline: A FED GOVERNOR PONDERS THE PAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON T **********HE Board of Governors of the **********Federal Reserve is losing one of **********its more frequent dissenters - Nancy Hays Teeters. The 53-year-old economist, who has spent more than 25 years in Washington working for such agencies as the Office of Management and Budget and the Council of Economic Advisers, was the first women to serve as a Fed governor. **********Mrs. Teeters was appointed by President Jimmy Carter in 1978, when she was chief economist for the House Budget Committee, and was seen as one of the more liberal members of the Fed. In her more than five years on the board, she often disagreed with monetary policy decisions, particularly when she thought the Fed was pushing interest rates too high. **********However, despite her dissents, she generally went along with the central bank's tight monetary policy of the early 1980's, having decided that the less stringent Fed policies of the 1970's had not been successful in curbing inflation. **********Her term as a governor ended last month, and Mrs. Teeters plans to leave as soon as her replacement is appointed by President Reagan and confirmed by the Senate. In an interview last week, she reflected on her years at the Fed. Excerpts follow.   Q. How would you describe yourself as a Federal Reserve Board governor? **********A. I was probably more concerned than the other governors about the impact of very high interest rates in 1980 and 1981, and the possibility of causing a great deal of damage to both the domestic economy and then later on to the international economy. If you look at my voting record, it was usually when the rates started getting very high that I would dissent on policy decisions. I don't really have any basic disagreement with the thrust of the policy. It's just that I think we could have accomplished the same thing without the rates going over 15 or 16 percent. **********It may have taken a little bit longer, but I think that you would have gotten essentially the same result without the extraordinary high rates.  Q. Do you think, though, that the Fed's anti-inflation policy has worked? **********A. Yes. And I think it was almost inevitable, given the very sharp price increases that had occurred both in the mid-70's and again in the late 70's, that a major adjustment was necessary in order to force inflation out of not only the United States economy but the world economy as well.  Q. Do you think it's better that it happened even if the adjustment was severe? **********A. It's better that it happened. You always have a hope that you'll be able to break the back of an inflation without causing a recession. As you look back, it's very depressing to conclude that we've never been able to do it since World War II. Moreover, we really had to stop the inflationary spiral in the decade of the 70's or we would have had more severe consequences later on. I think it was the right policy. My reservations were always on the degree.  Q. Do you think that the projected budget deficits threaten to undo the Fed's accomplishments on inflation? **********A. They certainly are a major threat. The structural deficit (the deficit that remains after the economy has achieved full growth at low inflation rates) is going up. And we're going to end up with structural deficits that we haven't seen since World War II.  Q. What does that mean? **********A. It means a lot of pressure on the credit markets, which at present I don't think has shown up. Well, it has shown up because I think the whole level of interest rates is higher than it ever was in a recovery. But it hasn't reached any sort of unmanageable proportion because the rising corporate profits have provided a very substantial cash flow for the corporations to meet their investment requirements. One of the sources of financing that I certainly didn't anticipate being available to us is this very large flow of international capital to the United States. And for the richest nation in the world to be a major importer of capital does not strike me as acceptable.  Q. Is there reason to believe, as some people suggest, that the dollar will turn around soon and that this capital flow may disappear? **********A. We've been expecting the value of the dollar to drop for 18 months. The deepening current account deficit would indicate that there should be some downward pressure on the dollar, and there should have been some downward pressure on the dollar for quite some time now, except it hasn't developed.  Q. Do you believe that the economy can grow at the 4.5 percent rate that the Fed, the Administration and most private forecasters expect this year with a $180 billion deficit projected for 1984 and again for 1985? **********A. I think our current interest rates are high and we're getting a substantial recovery even with fairly high levels of interest rates.  Q. Does that mean that deficits are not that bad? **********A. No, I think it's a matter of the deficits catching up with us at some point. Very high deficits, which were heavily cyclical up until, say, this year, were not a major problem because you didn't have very much private demand for credit. But when you get a rapidly recovering economy on a growing deficit base, you're going to have more demand for credit than is domestically available. And as the foreign capital backs out, then the pressure on the domestic markets - by that I mean including the interest rates - is going to be even stronger. **********I'm much more concerned about 1985. I sat down to do my economic forecast and was surprised that, independently, I had the same view as the Fed staff of what a drag our net exports are going to be. Net exports are a vulnerable sector in the economy, and greatly depressed exports is something we have never had any experience with. It's quite possible that we'll have some sort of very unpleasant surprise.  Q. So is the President's three-year $100 billion reduction enough for this year? And what happens by waiting for further major cuts in the deficit until 1985, after the election? **********A. My opinion is we should be doing more sooner. We should never have gotten into a position of a high and rising structural deficit and so the quicker we correct them the better off we will be.  Q. Can you put a finger on what that translates into? **********A. Getting the deficit down to $50 billion by 1989 would fit my rule of thumb.  Q. Given the projected deficits, what do you think the economy looks like after 1984? **********A. I would guess that what you're going to have is a continued sluggish housing market, and a continued slowdown in the rate of business fixed investment.  Q. Another recession? **********A. You might have another recession, or you just may get down to very low rates of growth. Now, theoretically, you face the idea that you could come down to low but sustainable rates of growth in the future. Historically, it's never happened that way. It either goes up or it goes down.  Q. Is it important to have a woman on the Fed? **********A. I think it's been important to have a woman on the board but not particularly for feminist reasons. I think it's important as a breakthrough of equality of access to jobs. We don't get a lot of feminist issues around here really. But the fact that women are as qualified as men to serve in appointed jobs, it seems to me, is important.  Q. Do you think your successor should be a woman? **********A. My successor should be a person who's very well qualified for the job. I hope that turns out to be a woman.  Q. It seems that the Fed is beginning to pay more attention to the specific growth in the money supply. Is this good? **********A. I'm speaking again for myself. I think the behavior of the economy is more important than any measurement or particular component of it. Basically, what monetary and fiscal policy are aimed at is maintaining an acceptable real rate of growth which absorbs our labor force and produces a rising standard of living for our people with as low an inflation rate as we can get. **********The monetary aggregates always have to be an intermediate target because we can't give instructions to the trading desk at the New York Fed to achieve a certain gross national product in the second quarter of 1984. So you have to express those instructions in a number of ways, and in the past, we've used different ways of doing it. In the 1960's we focused on crude reserves, in the 1970's we focused on Federal funds. From 1979 to 1982, we focused on the aggregates. All of them are imperfect. If I had my druthers, I would have some sort of amalgam of all of these because I think they are all important. And to judge whether you have the right policy or not you have to see what the effect of it is. **********I think fluctuating interest rates that are associated with strict monetarism did cause a lot of damage. And I would be reluctant to go back to them. I would be equally reluctant to go back to pinpointing the Federal funds rate. **********So, I guess the one thing that I have learned is that there are no simple rules for running monetary policy, much as the outside world would like to think. There have been so many times the board has done this or that and something completely different happened. **********When you don't have rules, then you have to rely on the judgment of the people who make the policy. That doesn't bother me as long as policy makers have to explain their decisions to Congressional inquiries. But I have not yet spotted a rule that is a replacement for judgment.  Q. It appears that Fed policy since December has been aimed at holding the line and that the main worry of the Federal Open Market Committee is that the economy might begin to grow too fast. How do you feel about that? **********A. We had two back-to-back quarters of very rapid growth. If that had continued, then I would have begun to worry. But I fully expected that the rate of growth would drop off to something that was much more sustainable, like 4 percent. **********Now I think what's going to be difficult to interpret over the course of 1984 is whether this is happening. Very rarely do you get a very nice even 4 percent rate of growth. **********When you look back to the 1975 experience, at the time in the recovery of 1975 and into 1976, the current numbers in the G.N.P. see-sawed by quarters. You'd have a good quarter, then you'd have a bad quarter. But nonetheless, it seems to me that we're more likely to have a continuation of economic data that is hard to interpret.  Q. So where is the Fed now? **********A. Every individual member has a different position, and my position right now is to wait and see what happens. What I would like to see is for the rate of real growth to come down to something in the 3.5 to 4.5 percent range.  Q. How crucial was Paul Volcker to the policy of the last four and a half years? **********A. Paul has provided a lot of leadership, but it really is a collegial group. First of all, the level of staff analysis is excellent. And we're all basically working off of a common base of information. **********At an Open Market Committee meeting, the members of the committee, including the nonvoting presidents, give their views as to what they think ought to be done. With a few exceptions, the chairman usually speaks last. And one of his functions is to develop the consensus - take into account all of the advice and information, and then to develop a consensus as to what the policy should be for the next period of time. He's very good at that.  Q. What are you going to do now? **********A. Look for a job.  Q. What do you want to do? **********A. Well, I don't honestly know. There are a number of possibilities. I'm an economist by training and I do enjoy it, so I suppose it'll be in the general area of economics.  Q. More government? **********A. I doubt it. **********VOLCKER'SVAGUE PROMISES **********WASHINGTON **********Some of the people who monitor the actions of the Federal Reserve most closely suspect that its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, would acquiesce under White House pressure to aid President Reagan's re-election. Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin and ranking minority member of the Senate Banking Committee, tried to examine the question with Mr. Volcker last week during testimony. The following is a transcript of their discussion. Proxmire: Chairman Volcker, some have argued that the Federal Reserve has historically tried to help the incumbent in the White House in a Presidential election year by easing monetary policy. There was one conspicuous exception to that. **********In October of 1979, the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board (adopted) a policy of slowing down the greatest increase in the supply of money, and I don't think Paul Volcker could argue that Paul Volcker did anything helpful to Jimmy Carter in 1980. **********Do you have any understanding with the Administration explicit or tacit that will involve accommodative policies in 1984? **********Volcker: No sir. **********P: Do you agree to report to this committee and to the House Banking Committee any instances of the Administration bringing pressure on the Federal Reserve to relax its policy?  V: I don't know what context you're thinking of exactly. We have close contact with Administration officials and we discuss fiscal policy and in many cases we discuss monetary policy. I don't interpret that as pressure. I don't assume you would interpret those continuing discussions as pressure. **********P: What I'm talking about (is what they) are saying to you privately or in public statements . . .   V: For political purposes? **********P: For political purposes. It's 1984.   V: I understand. I will not make a commitment that everytime I have a conversation with somebody in the Administration that I make a report on what the nature of those conversatioins were because we have a continuing discussions on various aspects of . . . **********P: I mean pressure when you see it.   V: That's why I make a distinction between a kind of continuing discussion which I think is normal and something one would interpret as part of the election campaign. I think sometimes I can tell the difference. (Laughter) **********P: Well how about letting us in on it. Will you do that?   V: If I can see the distinction. (Laughter)

But the car maker rehabilitated itself and sales are now booming again. The Conservative Government intends to return British Leyland to private ownership in a series of steps and Jaguar was chosen as the first division to be sold off because of its recent success.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/world.main_headline: ISSUE AS DANES VOTE: A MAJORITY AT LAST?
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/world.print_headline: ISSUE AS DANES VOTE: A MAJORITY AT LAST?
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/world.body_text: **********It is widely believed here that Denmark's Prime Minister, Poul Schluter, will be returned to office as a result of the national election on Tuesday. Officials here say the real question is whether he can turn his personal popularity into a working majority in Parliament. **********It is a tantalizing question in a country grown weary of minority governments and seven elections in the last 13 years. **********The 54-year-old Prime Minister has been selling the country on a stringent cost-cutting program that he says is the only way Denmark can ultimately protect its high standard of living and one of the most generous welfare systems in Western Europe. **********He said that in his 16 months in office, Denmark's annual balance of payments deficit had been halved to about a billion dollars, inflation had been reduced to 6 percent from about 10 percent and Government spending cuts had helped turn around the flagging economy. **********Thirteen parties will be on the ballot, and surveys indicate that Mr. Schluter's four-party coalition may win 80 of the 179 seats in Parliament, a 15- seat improvement over its current 65. Even with a 15-seat improvement the Government would still be 10 seats short of a majority. If the Radical Liberal Party, which is moderate despite its name, adds one seat to its current 9, Mr. Schluter may try to form the country's first majority coalition in more than a decade.   Blocking an Opposition Majority **********However, the secret of governing in Demark, one of Europe's more stable societies, is not the creation of a working majority, it is making sure no majority is working in opposition. **********Therefore, in the view of people in Government, the Prime Minister may be content to proceed without formally bringing the Radical Liberals into the coalition. The party has already assured him that it will support his Government on the vital issue of austerity in public spending. **********Mr. Schluter called the election after his budget package for 1984 was defeated in Parliament last month. It called for deep cuts in the social welfare system. **********Mr. Schluter did not resign, a tactic that will keep him in power even if his Conservative People's Party runs second to the Social Democrats on Tuesday. **********If he falls short of his goal of stitching together 90 votes, his Government could run into more stormy times on the budget, although it is doubtful that the Social Democrats would invite public anger by forcing another election through a no-confidence vote or another determined stand against cuts in spending. **********According to a poll published today, Mr. Schluter's party is expected to take 46 seats in the new Parliament. It now has 26. The Social Democrats, with 59 seats, are expected to lose several.   Fears Within the Coaliton **********Another projected big loser is the right-wing Progress Party, the antitax party that splintered traditional Danish politics in 1973 when it entered Parliament with 28 seats. Now the party has 16 seats, its leader, Mogens Glistrup, is serving a three-year prison sentence for tax fraud, and recent polls predict it will lose 9 seats in the election. **********In the coalition, the Liberals, the Central Democrats and the anti-abortion Christian People's Party are worried that the Prime Minister's soaring popularity will draw votes away from their candidates and that their influence in the coalition will be reduced if candidates from Mr. Schluter's Conservative People's Party ride his coattails into office. **********One possible victim, officials say, could be Henning Christophersen, a Liberal who as Minister of Finance is the second most powerful figure in the Government. Paradoxically, Mr. Christophersen is regarded as the architect of the Government's fiscal strategy, and his political home is in the North Zealand area above Copenhagen where these policies are broadly welcomed by suburban commuters in the vaguely defined middle class. They, like dairy farmers and businessmen and white-collar workers who support the center-right parties, say that the country can no longer afford programs that were introduced during long years of prosperity when the country had full employment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.main_headline: NICARAGUA LINKS COPTER VICTIMS TO THE C.I.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.print_headline: NICARAGUA LINKS COPTER VICTIMS TO THE C.I.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.body_text: **********The Nicaraguan Defense Minister today dismissed reports that at least two of three men killed in a helicopter over northern Nicaragua Saturday were independent mercenaries. **********''Nobody is going to believe that story,'' said the minister, Humberto Ortega Saavedra, at a news conference this afternoon. ''If they are mercenaries, they are C.I.A. mercenaries.'' **********There was no positive identification of the men, who were killed when their Hughes 500 helicopter was shot down by Sandinista ground fire during a raid on a Nicaraguan military school. Mr. Ortega asserted that at least one of the men was American. **********Photographs of the man were published in newspapers here today. The face was bloodied and partly mutilated. **********On Sunday, the Central Intelligence Agency told Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan that two American mercenaries were involved in the operation that resulted in the helicopter crash. Today, Reagan Administration officials asserted that two men killed in the helicopter were American mercenaries apparently recruited by rebel sympathizers in the United States to help compensate for the withdrawal of official American support. **********Mr. Ortega said the air attack, on the town of Santa Clara, less than five miles from the Honduran border, was carried out ''with the direct involvement of elements trained by the C.I.A.'' He said the raid was part of a plan that could lead to direct American military intervention later this year or in the first months of 1985. **********''These actions can generate situations that cannot be discussed easily, but they could be very tense and difficult,'' Mr. Ortega said. ''We expect that in September and October the situation will be more tense than it has been up to now.'' **********Mr. Ortega said that three Honduran military bases at which Americans are regularly stationed, those at Jamastran, Palmerola and Aguacate, have been used as support bases for anti-Sandinista insurgents. He said that planes flying from the bases ''carry out constant aerial reconnaissance over Nicaragua to collect information that is used by the C.I.A. to plan attacks like the one at Santa Clara.'' **********At today's news conference, reporters were shown several items said to have been removed from both the helicopter and the rebel transport plane that crashed inside Nicaragua a week ago. They include burned pages from a flight manual as well as charred pieces of machinery. **********Mr. Ortega also displayed a large and detailed map of the border area that he said was used by the helicopter pilot for navigation. He said markings on the map indicated that the craft had taken off from the base at Jamastran. **********According to reports published in the pro-Sandinista press today, the four civilian victims of the air attack on Santa Clara were a 40-year-old man and three young girls who were picking fruit when the rockets began to hit. Three small planes were said to have flown with the helicopter that was shot down. They were apparently able to return safely to their base. **********Mr. Ortega said all three men aboard the plane had died either at the moment of impact or before. He said that Sandinista troops in the north are under orders to capture insurgents alive if possible and that if anyone had emerged alive from the crash, an effort would have been made to apprehend him. **********The official Sandinista newspaper, Barricada, asked in the caption accompanying the picture of the dead man thought to be an American, ''In which American state was this mercenary assassin of children and peasants born?'' **********Reporters were permitted to view the man's body at the city morgue today. It did not appear to be that of a typical Nicaraguan or Central American. **********The victim had been stocky, tall and fair-skinned. What appeared to be a bullet hole was visible in the right temple. The body was clothed in olive- green pants and a camouflage shirt. **********Mr. Ortega said the Foreign Ministry would ask the American Embassy here to assist in efforts to identify the man. A spokesman for the embassy, John Roney, said the embassy had not received any instructions from Washington about the matter and had no information about the identity of the victims.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/19/busin.body_text: **********Construction of new homes rose to a 1.9 million-unit annual rate in June, from 1.8 million in May, bolstered by a surge in apartment and condominium building. At the same time, starts of single- family homes fell to their lowest point since December. Economists noted that high mortgage rates are driving prospective home buyers to the rental market. (Page D1.) **********President Reagan signed the Deficit Reduction Act, raising taxes $50 billion and cutting spending $13 billion through 1987. (D13.) **********Markets **********Round-the-clock trading is being considered by the New York and American Stock Exchanges as a service to international traders. The first step may be to extend the trading day by one or two hours. Before any decision is made, brokerages, money managers and others will be consulted, the exchanges said. (D1.) **********Stock prices ended a three-session rally as interest rate fears prevailed. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 11.26 points, to 1,111.64. Volume fell to 76.6 million shares. (D11.) Bond prices surged in late trading, with the 30-year Government bond up almost a half a point. (D18.) **********The dollar rose to a record high against the French franc and gained against other major currencies. Gold fell in Europe, but later recovered in New York, rising $3 an ounce, to $349. (D15.) Livestock prices fell in futures trading. Among the regional companies, Bell Atlantic earned $246.7 million, U S West $203.4 million and Southwestern Bell $212.1 million. First Interstate earnings rose 11.2 percent, and Republic New York gained 14.6 percent. Bank officials were said to fear a renewed run on the bank if, as analysts expect, the report shows a large loss. (D19.) **********Irwin L. Jacobs and four partners control 5.8 percent of Walt Disney stock. The Minneapolis financier confirmed reports that most of the transactions were done through Jefferies & Company, but he said he does not plan to seek control of Disney. (D4.) **********A $12 million suit accuses two defendants in The Wall Street Journal trading case of using an actor's inheritance fund for their insider trading. (D11.) **********Warner Communications eliminated its 25-cent dividend for the current quarter. (D4.) **********International **********Britain will sell its Sealink ferry system to Sea Containers Ltd., a Bermuda-based company headed by the American entrepreneur James B. Sherwood, for $86.9 million. (D15.) **********Today's Columns **********For years auto makers have wanted to build cars that ride on a ''magic cloud.'' The microchip has made it possible. Ford has two models with an air suspension system. Technology. (D2.) **********Upjohn's stock continues to act sick, falling another 3 1/2 points yesterday.
