https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/03/world.main_headline: U.S. TELLS WHY IT BARRED SOVIET OLYMPIC OFFICIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/03/world.print_headline: U.S. TELLS WHY IT BARRED SOVIET OLYMPIC OFFICIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/03/world.body_text: **********The State Department said today that it had refused to grant a visa to a Soviet Olympic official for reasons of ''internal security.'' **********The Soviet official, Oleg N. Yermishkin, had applied for a visa to serve as an ''Olympics attache'' in Los Angeles for six months before and during the Summer Games there. **********A senior State Department official said privately that Mr. Yermishkin, who had been a young second secretary assigned to the press section of the Soviet Embassy in the mid-1970's, was a known agent of the K.G.B., the Soviet security and intelligence service. **********John Hughes, the department spokesman, said that when Soviet officials informally submitted Mr. Yermishkin's name in December for the Los Angeles assignment, the American Embassy in Moscow told them that he would be turned down because of his background and that another name should be submitted. But Mr. Hughes said the Russians had refused to withdraw Mr. Yermishkin's name. It was submitted formally on Feb. 10, he said, and rejected on Tuesday.   He Would Have Immunity **********Mr. Hughes said Mr. Yermishkin had been in the United States in November as a part of a delegation that went to Los Angeles for talks about arrangements for the Olympics. He said factors taken into account in denying the visa were the length of his planned stay and the fact that he would have full diplomatic immunity. **********He said the United States would live up to its commitment to permit visas for all Soviet team members for Los Angeles, and to permit an attache to accompany them, provided ''his activities will be solely related to the Olympics.'' **********In Los Angeles on Thursday, Peter V. Ueberroth, the president of the Olympic Organizing Committee for the city, said, ''We are deeply troubled by the timing of this denial, which appears to be inefficient and unfair.'' **********Mr. Ueberroth said he was not quarreling with the decision to deny the visa, but rather objected to the apparent delay in doing so. He said Mr. Yermishkin was supposed to arrive in Los Angeles today. **********But Mr. Hughes blamed the Soviet Union for the timing, repeating that Moscow knew in December that Mr. Yermishkin would not be permitted to stay in Los Angeles. **********Under the complicated system by which the Soviet Union and the United States bar parts of their country to each other's diplomats, sections of Los Angeles are normally off limits to Soviet officials. Los Angeles International Airport, for instance, is in the prohibited zone. But for the Olympics, the State Department agreed to lift the ban and to permit Aeroflot planes, now barred from this country, to fly chartered flights to bring athletes, officials and fans from the Soviet Union.   Many Questions From Press **********At today's news conference at the State Department, Mr. Hughes was asked many questions about the visa refusal. He was asked, for instance, what assurances the United States would have that a substitute for Mr. Yermishkin might not be a K.G.B. agent, unknown to the American authorities. He was asked why the United States was worried about Mr. Yermishkin, if it was already known that he was an agent. He was also asked how the United States knew that Mr. Yermishkin would be involved in activities not connected with the Olympics. **********To all these kinds of questions, he had no comment. **********The visa denial, he said, ''was a matter of internal security, the nature and details of which I am not at liberty to discuss.'' He added, ''Host governments reserve the right to protect their own security and other interests.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/01/world.body_text: **********A South African naval officer was sentenced to life imprisonment today and his Swiss-born wife given a 10-year prison term after they were convicted of spying for the Soviet Union. **********The high treason convictions of the 47-year-old officer, Commodore Dieter Gerhardt, who said he was a double agent for the West, and his 41-year-old wife, Ruth, had carried a maximum possible punishment of death by hanging. **********The sentences were handed down by a Cape Province Supreme Court Judge, G. G. A. Munnik. **********The Gerhardts' lawyers indicated they would file appeals in the next few days against the convictions and sentences. The couple had pleaded innocent to the charges, and Commodore Gerhardt contended he was a double agent working for a friendly country that he did not name. **********They were found guilty on Thursday, and lawyers gave pre-sentence arguments Friday. The 45 days of court proceedings were held behind closed doors, with the Government citing security reasons for the secrecy.   Statement to Reporters **********Judge Munnik summarized his findings in a public statement to reporters after his judgment in the case. **********A career navy man, Commodore Gerhardt admitted during the trial that he worked for Soviet intelligence for more than two decades, but said he was a double agent working for Western intelligence and was feeding ''disinformation'' to the Russians. **********CAPETOWN can bite

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/08/busin.main_headline: ECHOES OF A GRAIOUS ERA ON LONG ISLAND'S GOLD COAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/08/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; ECHOES OF A GRAIOUS ERA ON LONG ISLAND'S GOLD COAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/08/busin.body_text: **********One result of New York's leadership as the nation's financial and mercantile capital during the Industrial Revolution was to endow the metropolitan area with great estates that expressed the material and social aspirations of the wealthy. **********No place had a greater concentration of these estates, with their mansions, villas and ch^ateaux, than Long Island's Gold Coast, the area of the North Shore that stretches in an irregular triangle from Manhasset to Old Westbury to Huntington. Before the Great Depression, there were more than 500 of these estates on the North Shore, according to ''The Mansions of Long Island's Gold Coast,'' a book by Monica Randall. **********As these estates, or parts of them, have been broken up and sold off, builders have been getting government permission to create new developments that are necessarily denser but in some sense true to the old uses of the land. **********Gerald and Elliot Monter, a father- and-son development team on Long Island, are builders who seem to have found a successful formula for doing that. **********In the late 1970's they purchased the former Orin Lehman estate in Jericho and built the Hamlet, an 86- acre development of 320 condominiums that were priced initially from $130,000 to above $200,000. **********Now the Monters are clearing a 76- acre tract off Shelter Rock Road in North Hills that once belonged to the Grace family for a new development of 128 single-family homes. It will be called the Hamlet Estates. **********One question is why the Monters chose to repeat the Hamlet name. (They are also building a 162-unit town house condominium development in Jericho called the Hamlet East. Units there will cost from $215,000.) **********In a recent interview, Elliott Monter explained, ''The Hamlet drew such a tremendous response, we wanted to capitalize on the name association.'' He added that he and his father also wanted to capitalize on ''the concept behind the Hamlet, which people have seen, understand and are attracted to.'' **********Part of that concept was housing designed not in the conservative colonial style common to Long Island but in a contemporary style of cathedral ceilings, open staircases and upstairs halls that overlook lower rooms. **********Despite their contemporary style, the units at the Hamlet are clustered in a way that gives privacy to the owners of each unit, but the profile of each cluster echoes the shapes of the great estate houses. **********Mr. Monter said the concern's approach to building on former estates also involves adapting principles of estate planning to tract development. **********The buildings are designed to fit onto the site, with as much of the original landscape as possible retained to preserve the characteristically rolling terrain of the North Shore. **********Mr. Monter said these were the Hamlet's general guidelines, which is what he and his father intend for the Hamlet Estates, too. The houses will range in size from 3,300 to 4,700 square feet and will be set on a minimum of two-fifths of an acre. **********They have been designed in contemporary style by Robert Swedroe of Miami. There are six basic types, and buyers may choose among several exterior colors and materials - cedar shingles or brick or stone veneer. **********The interiors will feature at least two cathedral ceilings, master bathrooms done in marble and large expanses of glass. The development will have two tennis courts, a swimming pool and a gatehouse at its own entrance on Shelter Rock Road. **********With their large dimensions and Gold Coast location, the houses are expensive, costing from $440,000 to $620,000. **********Although construction of the first phase of 47 houses will not begin until next fall, however, all 47 have already been contracted for. Mr. Monter called this response ''more than we expected.'' **********Ron Bloomfield, the development's sales director, said many of the purchasers are North Shore residents who are ''trading up'' - selling an old home to buy a bigger one.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/31/busin.body_text: **********A Video Review **********As a testimonial to increased penetration of videotape and disk machines into the homes of America, Publications International in February will begin publication of a monthly magazine called Video Movies that will review all of the motion pictures released in that form. **********The cover price will be $2.95. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/28/busin.body_text: **********Alcon Laboratories of Fort Worth, an eye-care company owned by Nestle S.A., said yesterday that it had terminated its $513 million offer to buy Coopervision Inc., an eye-care company based in Menlo Park, Calif. **********Alcon backed out after the Federal Trade Commission said it would seek a preliminary injunction to block the deal on antitrust grounds. **********Alcon said it felt the deal was ''not anticompetitive'' and that it ''would prevail if the matter were to be fully litigated.'' But it said the uncertainty and delay in litigating the case had made it terminate the deal. **********Last April, Alcon offered shareholders $25 a share for Coopervision's slightly more than 20 million shares. Any shares tendered will be returned, Alcon said. **********Earlier yesterday, the F.T.C. said it had authorized its staff to seek a preliminary injunction in United States District Court in Washington before Tuesday, the deadline for it to act. **********Divestiture Option **********James McCarty, an assistant to Timothy Muris, director of the agency's Bureau of Competition, said, however, that the deal could proceed if Coopervision divested itself of about a fourth of its operations, accounting for an estimated $50 million in sales. **********Alcon's termination of the deal came after the markets closed. But in heavy trading in response to news of the commission's opposition, Coopervision shares slid $1, to $18.375, on the New York Stock Exchange; on Thursday they fell $1.625, to $19.375. Altogether, more than a million shares changed hands in the last two days. **********In a sign that traders had been nervous for most of the week over the outcome of close Government scrutiny, Coopervision stock began falling on Monday, fell further on Tuesday, bounced back on Wednesday and then began sliding again as reports of the negotiations rocked one way and then the other. **********Both companies have been meeting with Federal regulators over the last week. **********Options for Coopervision **********Robert V. Mahoney, vice president and treasurer of Coopervision, said the company now felt ''free to review all the options available to us, including to continue operating the business as an independent company.'' He said its directors had called a meeting next Tuesday to consider their next move. He declined to comment on whether Coopervision had been negotiating with other suitors before Alcon. **********The commission said it had based its charges on the ''significant anticompetitive effects'' that would take place in markets for a number of eye medications, including those used in eye surgery and to treat glaucoma. **********It also said it challenged the merger's effect on markets for soft contact lens products, including disinfectants, cleaners and lubricants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/24/busin.body_text: **********The Pulaski County Circuit Court in Little Rock, Ark., approved a plan under which investors in Baldwin-United annuities would receive their money back over a maximum period of three and a half years and most likely at a below-market interest rate. **********The Baldwin-United Corporation, now seeking to reorganize under the Federal Bankruptcy Act, had sold 163,000 annuities for a total of $3.7 billion through six insurance subsidiaries. **********These subsidiaries, based in Arkansas and Indiana, have been under the control of insurance regulators in those two states since last summer. **********Final Indiana approval for the so-called rehabilitation plan is expected now that Arkansas has worked out last- minute amendments, according to Linda Garner, the Arkansas state insurance commissioner. **********The plan approved yesterday was basically as proposed, although a sixth basic option was added. Investors could choose to withdraw 30 percent of their money immediately, 30 percent after two years and the remaining 40 percent after the rehabilitation plan ends in three and a half years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Warner Communications Inc., the financially troubled entertainment and communications company, yesterday reported that its second quarter loss had widened to $437.5 million from $283.4 million in the period last year. Revenues rose 28.3 percent, to $475.5 million, from $370.5 million. **********The company's announcement of a substantial loss, which was expected, came as Warner began another round of dismissals of hundreds of employees at its New York headquarters. **********A Warner spokesman, who said that long-range plans called for reducing the staff of 500 to 250 by the end of the year, said employees began receiving layoff notices yesterday but declined to give the number dismissed. Last October, there were 800 people working at the New York headquarters. **********Dividend Cut **********Two weeks ago, the company said it would drop the 25-cent dividend on its common stock for the current quarter. Officials estimated that the measure would save $16.5 million. **********Robert B. Ladd, an analyst in Chicago for Duff & Phelps, a brokerage firm, said Warner ''appears to be moving to get things under control, but they still have a huge debt load and huge overhead expenses at corporate headquarters. They have a long way to go to get to solid footing.'' **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Warner's stock closed at $19.125, down 87 1/2 cents. **********In a statement from New York, Steven J. Ross, Warner's chairman and chief executive officer, said that the loss was largely attributable to the Atari division's $78.4 million operating loss, and the $332 million loss Warner took on the sale of Atari last month. **********Mr. Ross added that the layoffs and plans to sell other divisions, including the Franklin Mint direct response marketing company, should help produce a profit from continuing operations in the second half. **********He also cited the strong performances of Warner's film entertainment group and its recorded music group. Its movie hits include ''Gremlins,'' which thus far has grossed more than $100 million, ''Police Academy,'' ''Sudden Impact,'' and ''Greystoke.'' **********The record division's profit rose to $13.4 million, from $5.1 million, as the album ''Purple Rain,'' by the rock star, Prince, sold nearly 2 million copies in its first two weeks of release and became the best-selling album in the country. **********Earnings Tables, 35

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/05/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; U.S. BOND PRICES CLIMB AGAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/05/busin.body_text: **********Treasury note and bond prices rose sharply for the third consecutive day yesterday even though government securities dealers said demand came mostly from speculators and other securities firms, not investors. **********By late in the day, prices were up more than a point for most Treausry issues due in seven years or more, with some issues rising by 1 7/8 points, for a cumulative gain of about 5 1/8 points from the lowest levels of last week. **********''At these levels, investor demand dried up,'' one government securities dealer said. Another agreed that investor demand was far less than on last Thursday, when prices began rising sharply, and added that ''a lot of other dealers seem to have decided that the Fed is not going to tighten and they want to own some securities.'' **********At the same time as price gains of up to 1 7/8 points reduced yields as much as a quarter of a percentage point for Treasury issues due in seven years or more, interest rates on short- term securities were mixed. **********6-Month Bill at 10.57% **********In the Treasury bill market, the rate for the outstanding three-month issue rose slightly as investors shifted funds from low-risk, short-term instruments into longer-term issues where prices were rising. At the regular weekly auction of new Treasury bills, the three-month issue sold at an average rate of 9.90 percent, up from 9.83 percent last week, and the six- month issue sold at 10.57 percent, down from 10.62 percent. **********While investor demand for interest- bearing Treasury notes and bonds was modest, investment bankers appear to have spotted demand for non- interest bearing, or zero coupon, Treasury issues. **********Several market participants said yesterday that Salomon Brothers was in the midst of arranging a large issue of Certificates of Accrual on Treasury Securities, or Cats, which is its name for zero-coupon Treasury issues. An official at Merrill Lynch, who asked not be be identified, acknowledged that they were preparing a large issue of Treasury Investment Growth Receipts, or Tigrs, to be created from $750 million face amount of 13 1/4 percent bonds due in 2014. **********To satisfy demand for zero-coupon issues, securities firms must purchase Treasury bonds. Those purchases, or the realization that the purchases have been made, helped raise the 13 1/4 percent Treasury bonds due in 2014 to an offered price of 99 7/8, to yield 13.27 percent, up from 98 to yield 13.53 percent late Friday. Last Wednesday,the bellwether Treasury bond traded as low as 94 22/32 to yield 14 percent. **********Interest Payments 'Stripped' **********Zero-coupon Treasury issues are created by 'stripping'' the semiannual interest payments from the principal, or face amount, of a Treasury issue. Each of the semiannual interest payments can be sold as a zero-coupon security, as can the principal. Although the price of zero-coupon issues is more volatile than regular, interest bearing issues, the non-interest-bearing securities have been very popular with investors in the last two years. **********Contributors to an individual retirement account can use zero-coupon issues to ''lock in'' a high interest rate. Since there are no interest payments to be reinvested - perhaps at lower interest rates than those now prevailing - the yield of a zero-coupon issue is guaranteed by the United States Government if it is held to maturity. **********Elsewhere in the note and bond market, prices rose by a point or more for most Treasury isseus due in seven years or longer. The 13 7/8 percent notes due in 1989, which sold last Wednesday at an average price of a about 99 5/8 to yield 13.93 percent, were offered at 102 1/8 to yield 13.26 percent. **********Despite an increase in the rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market to 11 percent from 10.53 percent Friday, the belief was widespread that the Federal Reserve would not tighten monetary policy or encourage higher interest rates until it had more information about economic activity for May and June. The Fed temporarily supplied reserves to the banking system yesterday with one-day purchases of securities. **********Later this week, some analysts said, the Fed may make permanent purchases of Treasury notes and bonds to supply reserves that are drained from the banking system as currency in circulation rises during the summer holiday season. Another technical factor encouraging higher prices is the light schedule of Treasury financing, with no note or bond auctions until June 20. **********Many analysts continue to describe the three-day rally as a short-lived phenomenon in the midst of a longer- term trend toward higher interest rates. ''Long term, we are still looking for higher interest rates,'' reflecting strong credit demands and a Fed move to tighten monetary policy in 1985, said Bernard Markstein, a financial economist at Chase Econometrics. **********Following are results of yesterday's auctions of new three- and six- month Treasury issues:  (000 omitted in dollar figures)  3-Mo. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/30/world.print_headline: GENERAL IS SLAIN IN MADRID; BASQUE TERRORISTS SUSPECTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/30/world.body_text: **********Two gunmen thought to be Basque terrorists shot and killed a high-ranking military officer on his way home from church here this afternoon. **********The killing, which was quickly and soundly condemned by Government leaders and by the ruling Socialists and other political parties, thrust terrorism to the forefront of national concern once again. **********It was widely regarded here as an attempt by the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. to demonstrate that, despite a series of setbacks in recent weeks, it is still able to mount attacks intended to unbalance the Government. The group has carried out scores of similar murders in its campaign for independence for Spain's four northern provinces. **********Slain in Front of Home **********The victim, Lieut. Gen. Guillermo Quintana Lacaci, who was 67 years old and semiretired, was gunned down on the sidewalk in front of his home on Romero Robledo Street in a fashionable residential district of the capital shortly before 1 P.M. **********His wife, Elena Ramos, 50, was slightly wounded in the attack, receiving a bullet wound in the leg. A retired colonel, Francisco Gil Pachon, 64, was grazed by two shots. **********General Quintana, a veteran of the Franco forces in the 1936-39 civil war and of the Blue Division that fought alongside Nazi German forces against the Soviet Union in World War II, was a conservative military man but also a defender of the post-Franco Constitution. From 1979 until 1982 he held a key position as commander of the Madrid military region. He was instrumental in persuading officers in the strategically situated command to obey King Juan Carlos and refrain from joining an attempted coup in February 1981. **********General Quintana was the sixth army general assassinated since 1978 and the first since the Socialists took office in December 1982.   Getaway Car Is Found **********The assailants fled in a white Renault driven by an accomplice and then transferred to another car. The Renault, bearing Madrid license plates, was found by the police in a nearby street. **********Although no group had taken responsibility for the assassination by tonight, the police and officials said the attack had the markings of an E.T.A. operation. **********In particular, police sources said that 13 bullet shells recovered in front of the general's house, a building for military officers, were of a type customarily used by E.T.A. assassins. General Quintana was shot three times in the head and died instantly. **********Among the blows that have set back the Basque terrorist organization recently was a decision by the French Government to remove E.T.A. activists from southern France. According to the Spanish Government, E.T.A. leaders and militants have used bases in southern France for years to plan and execute assassinations, kidnappings and extortion across the border.   French Police in Crackdown **********In mid-January, several weeks after the problem was discussed at a meeting between Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez and President Francois Mitterrand, the French police began rounding up E.T.A. activists. So far at least seven have been moved to northern France and six have been expelled from France to Guadeloupe in the Caribbean and then to Panama. **********After the French crackdown, Spanish authorities began an antiterrorist sweep of their own in the northern region. Five days ago, 14 people, including a policeman from the town of Tolosa, were arrested on charges of having links with E.T.A., whose initials in the Basque language stand for Basque Homeland and Freedom, **********At the same time, Basque refugees in southern France and suspected E.T.A. members in Spain were frightened by the actions of a shadowy organization called G.A.L. The group has vowed to retaliate in kind for every E.T.A. killing and is believed responsible for the disappearance of several E.T.A. members, **********The Socialist Government's tough stand on Basque terrorism is codified in new legislation that will permit detention without trial for up to two and a half years, increase penalties for acts of terrorism and expand police powers in searching homes, making arrests without warrants and tapping telephones. **********But it is accompanied by the stepped- up application of a year-and-a-half-old program that allows E.T.A. members abroad who renounce violence to return to Spain and pay token fines if they are not wanted for acts that shed blood. A group of four such people returned only last week.   Dramatic Exploit Expected **********It is widely believed here that the pressures closing in on E.T.A. from all sides have serverely, though perhaps not indefinitely, hampered its operations. Many expected it to engage in some dramatic exploit to show that it is still a force to contend with. Ten days ago, the police tightened security in Madrid after reports that an E.T.A. hit squad was in the capital. **********It is questionable whether the killing of General Quintana will be seen as dramatic enough. Although a high- ranking officer, he passed into semiretirement in April 1982. He was an easy target since he was not accompanied by bodyguards and often followed the same routine, attending mass at the Sacred Heart Church near his home at the same time every Sunday. **********By contrast, the previous army general killed by E.T.A., Gen. Victor Lago Roman, gunned down inside a car on Nov. 4, 1982, was still in a command position, heading the elite Brunete First Armored Division outside of Madrid. **********After the slaying today, the police mounted roadblocks around Madrid and tightened security at Barajas airport. King Juan Carlos cut short a visit to Barcelona and Queen Sofia visited the general's widow in Generalisimo Hospital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/world.main_headline: FOR TINY LAND'S RULER, HOME IS 1,788 ROOMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/world.print_headline: FOR TINY LAND'S RULER, HOME IS 1,788 ROOMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/world.body_text: **********Sultan Muda Hassanal Bolkiah of Brunei rules one of the smallest independent countries, but his new 1,788-room palace on a partly manmade 100-foot hill overlooking this capital is believed to be the largest royal residence in the world. **********An informant here with intimate knowledge of the project put the cost at about $300 million, twice as much as it cost to build Madison Square Garden when that structure was completed in 1968. Other palaces may be taller or more ornate than the Brunei building, which reflects chaste Islamic taste in architecture, but none eclipses the 37-year-old Sultan's new home for sheer size. **********The four interconnected three-story buildings, topped by two globular domes encased in shining gold leaf, occupy about 50 acres and are the centerpiece of a landscaped garden that covers 300 acres, more than one- third the size of New York's Central Park. **********This magnificence will be the seat of power, with four thrones in case a foreign king and queen come calling, in a land of only 2,226 square miles, about the size of Delaware. The 500- year-old sultanate was carved out of virgin rain forest on the northern coast of the huge island of Borneo, the rest of which is divided between Malaysia and Indonesia. **********The two larger countries showed interest in absorbing tiny Brunei and its great oil wealth in the late 1950's and early 1960's. But Sultan Omar Ali Saifuddin, father of the present ruler, declined an invitation to join a Malaysian federation. At his request, Britain sent Gurkha troops here under a defense treaty with London to put down an an abortive rebellion backed by Indonesia. **********Brunei is now on friendly terms with its larger neighbors, officials say. **********On Feb. 23 the new palace will be the scene of a delayed celebration of Brunei's assumption of full sovereignty on New Year's Day, when the young Sultan formally broke his state's last political links with Britain. It is expected that Britain's Prince Charles will attend the event, along with the Kings of Nepal and Tonga and diplomats and other notables from around the world. **********The polo-playing Sultan, who has supreme authority under the state's Constitution, controls revenues from oil and gas amounting to $4 billion a year, and accumulated investments abroad of about $14 billion, equivalent to about two-thirds of the foreign reserves of the United States. With such resources at his command, a $300-million palace puts no strain on the state budget.   Palace Has 1,800 Rooms **********The imminent opening of the Sultan's new palace seems to call for some revisions in the Guinness Book of Records, which lists the Vatican as the ''largest residential palace.'' The papal residence has 1,400 rooms, compared with nearly 1,800 in the Sultan's new home.  The Vatican is compressed into 13 acres, 3 acres smaller than the area of the Brunei palace's marbled floors alone, which would cover all of New York's Washington Square Park. **********For a major function like next month's independence festivity, the Sultan's palace can put 8,100 people under roofs, while more thousands will be able to view the proceedings going on inside on closed-circuit television screens mounted on numerous pillars. The public banquet hall can hold 4,000 people, 2,000 more can be accommodated in the throne room, 1,000 in the main reception hall, 500 in a ceremonial dining room, 300 in the royal banquet room and an equal number in still another reception space. **********A walking tour around the palace the other day with Alexander P. Castro of the Ayala Corporation, the Philippine contractor for the project, afforded stunning glimpses of the blended traditional and modern designs achieved by the Filipino architect Leandro Locsin. **********Moorish arches, among other features, reflect the state's Islamic character. Peaked roofs simulate the longhouses in which indigenous tribal people live, while long, smooth planes in white concrete recall Mr. Locsin's modern designs for the new Philippine Cultural Center. **********The smaller of the two golden domes caps the Sultan's private miniature mosque for worship. On the roof close by is a heliport where the ruler can land one of the craft that he likes to pilot himself. There is an underground parking area for 800 automobiles, including 100 spaces reserved for the Sultan, a motor buff, who owns about 40 sports cars.   Personal Recreation Center **********At the northern end of the quadrangular group of interconnected buildings is the Sultan's personal recreation center with a swimming pool, courts for tennis, squash and badminton and a practice field for polo. **********The whole estate is enclosed by a high fence of discreetly ornamental ironwork like the one that surrounds Buckingham Palace in London. That residence of Britain's royal family has 614 rooms, nearly 300 fewer than the 900 alloted as private quarters for the Sultan and his extended family of about 20 people, including his three brothers, their families, and the Sultan's father, who abdicated in 1967 in order to give his son training. **********The connection between the Sultan and the Ayala Corporation, one of the biggest companies in the Philippines, is the result of a long and warm friendship between the company's head, Enrique Zobel, and the Sultan, who met on the polo field when the industrialist brought a Philippine team here to play a Brunei team led by the Sultan. **********The ruler first mentioned his plan for a new palace to Mr. Zobel on Sept. 19, 1980, Mr. Castro recalled, and the contract was approved on three months later.   30 Subcontractors Hired **********Mr. Zobel went right to work, eventually hiring 30 subcontractors and 20 consultants for various phases of a job that soon had 5,000 workers on the site. ''We stopped counting the different nationalities involved when we passed 15,'' Mr. Castro said. **********A Japanese group did the landscaping. Dale Keller, an American formerly based in Tokyo and now working out of Greece, was the interior designer. The crystal chandeliers were ordered from Vienna and the carpets and fine hardwoods from the Philippines, which also supplied the bulk of the labor force.  A crew of 14 artisans from Yugoslavia is still laying down the last of the marble tiles made in Italy. The furniture was purchased in New York and Chicago. The Bechtel Corporation of the United States was engaged to construct the 3.5 miles of paved road on the palace estate. **********Brunei is thoroughly up to date in high technology, Mr. Castro said. Computerized electronic surveillance gear will function throughout the complex, ready to trigger instant countermeasures for any mechanical flaw that may develop in the elaborate mechanization, such as the air-conditioning system that will keep the huge palace cool in the worst of the subequatorial heat. **********As for the abundance of rooms, Mr. Castro said, ''this palace has been built for future generations of grandchildren.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/30/busin.body_text: **********UNC Resources Inc. said an out-of-court settlement appeared to be near in its litigation involving contracts with the General Atomic Company. **********A trial, which began last week in a New Mexico state court, has been suspended pending completion of the settlement, UNC said. The company requested a halt in trading of its stock on the New York Stock Exchange until terms of the proposed settlement could be released. Before the halt, UNC's stock climbed $1, to $7.125, making it the biggest percentage gainer for the day. UNC said earlier this month that a judge had ruled in its favor and that a jury would decide damages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/22/busin.body_text: **********In an effort to avoid years of complex litigation, Minet Holdings P.L.C. and the New York-based Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. today proposed a $52 million settlement of claims growing out of a scandal that shook the Lloyd's of London insurance market two years ago. **********The scandal involved premiums paid to PCW Underwriting, a Minet agency that has since been renamed Richard Beckett Underwriting Agencies Ltd., and WMD Underwriting Agencies Ltd., an associate firm. **********The premiums were for insurance guaranteed by the assets of more than 1,000 investors in two Lloyd's syndicates. **********The agencies were said to have funneled the premiums through an Alexander Howden Group subsidiary into shell companies set up for the offshore use of Minet executives, disguising the transactions as the laying off of risk through normal reinsurance deals. **********As a result, the Lloyd's investors became liable for huge sums of money pending the resolution of the claims and counterclaims. The settlement proposal would reduce the maximum loss for individual investors to just over $4,000.  The diversion of funds came to light after Alexander purchased Howden in 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/07/busin.print_headline: Rates on Loans Up in Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/07/busin.body_text: **********Major British commercial banks raised their base lending rates today to 10 percent, from 9 1/4 percent, despite a warning by the Bank of England that an increase in interest rates was not needed. **********The British pound has been under increasing pressure since the Bank of England, the British equivalent of the Federal Reserve System, advised banks last week to hold the line on interest rates. **********On Thursday, sterling touched a new all-time low of $1.3180, although it edged up to $1.3210 today. **********The rise in interest rates represents a setback for the Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, which contends that higher rates hamper economic recovery. **********The equivalent rate in the United States is 13 percent. The interest spread between the two countries is typical, because American banks are required to tie up a percentage of their assets as non-interest- bearing reserves with the Federal Reserve.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Although buoyed by the best Christmas season in years, retailers at a national convention in New York were warned yesterday that their high expectations for 1984 could be adversely affected by unusual volatility in the economy. **********The year will be less predictable on a quarter-by-quarter basis, and inflation will probably rise at a somewhat faster rate than in 1983, Leif H. Olsen, chairman of the economic committee of Citibank, said yesterday. **********Speaking to 1,000 retail executives at the annual convention of the National Retail Merchants Association, Mr. Olsen declared: ''Total personal consumption expenditures for 1983 increased by 5.5 percent in real terms and more than 10 percent in money terms. That ranks with one of the best of the first-year recoveries. However in 1984, we expect spending to rise about 3 percent, somewhat less than the average performance in the second year of economic recovery.'' **********He told the retailers at the convention's opening session at the New York Hilton Hotel, ''This is consistent with the expected slowdown in the economy as a result of monetary policy and the fact that capital investment, which has already picked up sharply, will play a bigger role'' in the overall rise in the gross national product this year. **********But two other speakers at the same session differed with the Citibank economist. **********Sales of general merchandise should rise 9 percent this year, compared with gains of 8.4 percent last year and 1.3 percent in 1982, Thomas E. Swanstrom, chief economist for Sears, Roebuck & Company, predicted. **********Walter F. Loeb, vice president of Morgan Stanley & Company, said: ''I believe retail sales will be strong throughout 1984 and earnings will again be better than the historical pattern. I project sales to increase 14 percent in 1984 and earnings to increase 17 percent to 19 percent over 1983.'' **********The Sears economist based his prediction on higher discretionary income, which he expects to be up 9.7 percent in 1984 after a 7.6 percent rise in 1983. **********Retailers interviewed after the session said they were somewhat confused by the varying predictions, but most tended to agree with the higher estimates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/01/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Indian Protesters Accuse C.I.A. in Sikh Unrest
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/01/world.body_text: **********About 100 demonstrators marched on the United State Embassy today to criticize what they said was involvement by the United States Central Intelligence Agency with Sikh extremists. **********The police erected a rope fence in front of the embassy gate as speakers said the United States Government was trying to destabilize India and encourage Sikh separatism. **********Indian press reports have alleged that the C.I.A. supervised training camps in Pakistan, but the embassy in India and the State Department have issued strong denials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/01/busin.body_text: **********Asarco Inc., which earlier this week reported a third-quarter loss of $10.1 million, said it would omit the dividend on its common stock in the fourth quarter. The producer of silver, copper, lead, zinc and other nonferrous metals had been paying a quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share since the second quarter of 1982. **********Ralph L. Hennebach, chairman and chief executive, attributed the decision to the low price of silver and a drop in the price of copper after the Government decided not to provide the industry protection from imports. The third-quarter loss was in contrast to a profit of $2.9 million a year earlier. Sales fell 25.7 percent in the latest quarter, to $287.2 million, from $386.8 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/06/busin.body_text: **********WEDNESDAY, JUNE 6, 1984 **********Companies **********A $2.1 billion offer for Continental Group was made informally by Sir James Goldsmith, the chairman of Cavenham and Generale Occidentale. Continental, formerly Continental Can, termed the offer ''unsolicited,'' indicating that it would not be receptive. Executives close to the situation stressed that the approach was intended to be friendly. (Page D1.) Continental has just come through a campaign of redeploying assets. (D1.) **********Merrill Lynch's chief executive, Roger E. Birk, stepped down at 53, in a surprise move. He will be replaced by William A. Schreyer, president. Mr. Birk's resignation comes at a time of plunging earnings for the parent of the world's largest securities firm, but the executive and several directors said he was not forced out. (D1.) Mr. Schreyer is a popular figure who faces a a tough job: cutting costs and reshaping Merrill into a leaner competitor. (D1.) **********Penn Central and Mesa agreed to swap $1.1 billion worth of notes and securities, ending an arrangement whereby Penn Central backed Mesa's failed attempt to take over Gulf. (D5.) **********Smith International's tender offer for Gearhart was blocked when a Federal judge issued a preliminary injunction. (D5.) **********A bill to let an out-of-state bank buy Continental Illinois was tentatively endorsed by an Illinois Senate committee. The endorsement came after the head of First Chicago, the rival bank that is Continental's main suitor, testified against the change. (D6.) **********International **********Negotiations on a long-term solution to Mexico's debt will begin soon, bankers announced, and similar talks on Brazil are expected. Substantially lower interest rates are likely to result from the new approach, which marks an attempt to defuse the crisis atmosphere surrounding the Latin American loans. (D1.)  The Economy **********Sales of new cars jumped 19.1 percent in late May from the 1983 period, with the daily selling rate by the nation's major auto makers the best for the period since 1978. Imports were strong, too. (D1.) **********The power of the Interstate Commerce Commission to enforce antitrust laws was strengthened by the Supreme Court, which ruled that the I.C.C. could penalize trucking companies by rescinding freight tariffs and ordering refunds. (D6.) **********The Postal Service will get out of computer mail, selling its E-COM operation to a private contractor if possible. (D15.) **********Major tax increases seem assured as House-Senate conferees begin meeting today to resolve differences in two bills. The biggest disputes are expected to involve business taxes. Its strength undercut gold, which was bid late in the day in New York at $394.50, down 75 cents. (D22.) Live hog futures prices advanced, while cattle and frozen pork bellies were mostly lower. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/11/world.body_text: **********25 on French Plane Hurt By Chad Airport Bomb **********PARIS, March 10 (UPI) - Two bombs exploded aboard a French passenger jet today during a stopover at the Ndjamena airport in Chad, wounding 25 people, officials here said. **********Diplomats in Paris said the DC-8 of the airline Union des Transports Aeriens had been destroyed by the second bomb, which exploded 20 minutes after the first and after the 100 people aboard were evacuated. **********There were no immediate claims of responsibility. French forces support the Chad Government against Libyan- backed rebels, and Chad's Ambassador to France, Allam Mi Ahmad, accused Libya of carrying out the bombings. **********The first bomb exploded as the DC-8 was parked at the airport with its engines off during a stopover on a flight from Brazzaville, Congo, to Paris. **********Of the wounded, 12 were passengers, all French, and 13 were airline or airport personnel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/25/world.main_headline: APPLE OF TOWN'S EYE:NEWTON, NOT MRS. THATCHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/25/world.print_headline: APPLE OF TOWN'S EYE:NEWTON, NOT MRS. THATCHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/25/world.body_text: **********Margaret Thatcher is the second most famous person to have grown up in this quiet market town in Lincolnshire, but you could drive into town, do some shopping, have a bite of lunch and leave without ever knowing she came from here. **********The roadside signs outside Grantham tell you it is ''twinned'' with Sankt Augustin, a town near Bonn in West Germany, but they make no mention of the fact that Britain's, indeed Europe's, first Prime Minister who is a woman was born above her father's grocery store on North Parade, at the edge of the downtown area, on Oct. 13, 1925. Nor are many of the people here likely to mention the fact unless they are asked. **********''The average person in Grantham is proud of her as a Grantham success story,'' said John Hare, the chief reporter on The Grantham Journal, a weekly. ''But she left town at 17 to go to Oxford, glad to get away, as I hear it, and she hasn't been back much. I don't think many people around Grantham know her.'' **********At W. G. Harrison Ltd., a big stationery shop on High Street, they sell a booklet called ''The Glory of Grantham,'' but it is not about Hilda Margaret Roberts Thatcher, local girl made good; it is about St. Wulfram's Church, whose handsome 14th-century crocketed spire can claim, at 272 feet, to be the sixth loftiest steeple in the realm. Harrison's stocks no books about the Prime Minister, and a clerk there commented, ''We'd be more inclined to think better of her if she put in an appearance once in a while.''  Visited Once Since 1979 **********Mrs. Thatcher has been here only once since taking office in 1979 and only twice since taking over as leader of the Conservative Party in 1975. She has never made a campaign speech in Grantham; her constituency is Finchley, in the northern suburbs of London. **********But the Prime Minister talks constantly of Grantham, its country common sense, and the values she learned here. On her last visit, in February 1982, she stopped at the grammar school where she prepared for Oxford, the Kesteven and Grantham Girls' School, and told the students that she had learned there a sense of discipline and duty - ''a marvelous foundation.'' **********A country, she often says, can no more live beyond its means than could her family in the days when she sliced bacon and weighed beans in the shop. With evident pride, she once told a national television audience that her father, Alfred Roberts, earned only 12 shillings a week when he came to Grantham, of which he spent 10 shillings on food and housing, putting aside a shilling as ''spending money'' and saving a shilling. He was finally able to buy the shop where he worked, and he later served as Mayor. **********It is the Roberts shop that provides the only visible memento of Mrs. Thatcher's life here. Derelict for years - ''The most famous eyesore in town,'' The Journal called it - the shop was sold three years ago to Rodney Cloke, a businessman from southern England, who turned it into a restaurant called The Premier. The shop's windows and the reception area have been restored to their appearance during the Prime Minister's girlhood, with cans and packages from that era carrying the prices that were charged in those days.   'They're Typically English' **********Victoria Buckley, the manager, says the restaurant's first year ''has been very good, considering the recession,'' and she says customers come from all parts of England and from abroad to eat where the Prime Minister was born. But the town, she said, ''doesn't seem to take much notice - they're typically English, reluctant ever to blow their own trumpet.'' **********Grantham's only visible tribute to its famous daughter is a tiny slate plaque, high up on the outside wall of the shop, invisible to all but the most observant passer-by. Another is in the Guildhall. **********The man the locals brag about is Sir Isaac Newton, the mathematician and philosopher, who was born at Woolsthorpe Manor, seven miles south of town, where he is said to have deduced the law of gravity from watching an apple fall from a tree. He went to the King's School in Grantham, leaving behind his name carved on a windowsill. **********A statue of Newton, holding a mathematical diagram in his left hand, stands in front of the Guidhall, and Grantham boasts a Newton pub, road and school, plus a spanking-new, $15 million Sir Isaac Newton Shopping Center.   The Gold Yawn Award **********Not a great deal happens here these days. As a matter of fact, when a BBC radio disk jockey conducted a contest to find the most boring town in the country, it was Grantham that was given the ''Golden Yawn Award.'' **********Such tourists as come to Grantham come mostly because of the Newton connection. Last summer, said Doreen Cubitt of the local tourist office, only about 15 of the 350 inquiries she averaged each week came from people asking about the Prime Minister. The mimeographed sheet she hands out for those wanting to make a tour describes St. Wulfram's and Grantham House, where Margaret Tudor stayed on her trip to Scotland to marry James IV, and the George Hotel, which is mentioned in ''Nicholas Nickleby,'' and even the working beehive outside the Beehive Inn. **********It says nary a word about the Prime Ministerial birthplace. **********Nor has Mrs. Thatcher's success meant new jobs for Grantham. Unlike some American Presidents and members of Congress, British Prime Ministers do not favor their birthplaces with military installations or other big government centers. **********But Grantham remains loyally Tory, saving the Prime Minister the embarrassment of having her hometown voting for the opposition. The local Member of Parliament is Douglas Hogg, scion of an old Conservative family whose father, Viscount Hailsham, is in his second term as Lord Chancellor. **********The town also has several pubs whose names include the Tory color, blue - The Blue Pig, The Blue Bell, and so on. But that reflects the local politics of the 17th century, not the 20th. The pubs ''turned blue'' to match the allegiance of a powerful local squire, the Earl of Dysart.
