https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/03/busin.main_headline: Talking Businesswith Norris of Control Data ; Cooperation In Industry
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/03/busin.print_headline: Talking Businesswith Norris of Control Data ; Cooperation In Industry
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/03/busin.body_text: **********William C. Norris is best known for having built the Control Data Corporation into a computer giant. Today the company's outspoken 72-year-old chairman is concentrating on long-term policy. **********One of his principal concerns is to assure that American industry remains competitive in the global marketplace. He is preaching cooperation - between companies, states and countries - as the solution. His Minneapolis-based company has helped set up a research program with the State of Minnesota and the University of Minnesota and has also helped establish a joint research venture between several computer companies. **********Q. What about the challenge from Japan? **********A. The Japanese are taking advantage of us. They're living off our technology. That has to be addressed but in a totally constructive way that's good for them as well as for us. It's not in their best interest to continue relying upon our technology. The situation can be improved by furthering access to technology on an equitable basis. Their access here is far better than our access over there. **********Q. What do you urge to ease that situation? **********A. First, the states should cooperate among themselves by setting up research institutes in different fields - advanced materials, acid rain, toxic materials. There's a host of technologies that are very high-risk, very long-term and will not be addressed by the private sector unless there's a partnership with government. Many states are setting up innovation centers or research institutes, but it would be much better to pool their resources. **********Q. Do you think a regional approach would **********be better than a Federal one? **********A. Yes, because the Feds can't get their act together. You can't get a consensus from Congress on damn near anything or in the executive branch of the Government. There are just too many diverse interests. This country was blessed - I guess it's turning out to be a curse - with economic activity so high that everybody could go off in his own direction and we still prospered. But we didn't have to reckon then with foreign competition. As you know, 70 percent of our domestic market is exposed to imports, and we can't afford everybody going in his own direction any longer. **********Q. What other cooperative measures are you **********calling for? **********A. Another thrust is to get cooperation from other countries. We're thinking in terms initially of two countries: Japan and Britain. The idea is for Japan also to participate in those research centers and for the United States and the regions to participate in centers in Japan. The reason for picking Japan is the serious inequities regarding access to technology. The reason for picking Britain is that it is the second most productive country in technology research. They're very inventive, but they don't carry it on through the innovation process. It would be in their best interest to have a close working relationship with the United States. **********Q. Why would Japan give up information it **********might want to keep for itself? **********A. Another part of our concept is that there should be a balance in the technology exchange. We're planning to set up a technology bank, which will keep track of technology flows. If a company feels it has to sell some technology to improve its cash flow and it gets an offer from the Japanese for a couple of hundred thousand dollars, it would sell the technology to the technology bank. Then the bank will make sure that we get an appropriate exchange of technology from the Japanese. **********Q. What about the Administration's efforts **********for licensing computer exports to Europe? **********A. Even if you can't sell technology, it will seep out from under you, for one thing. A more appropriate approach is to set it up on the basis of, for instance, when the Soviet Union gets some technology from us, we get something back from them. And boy, they've got plenty of it. It's not in a commercialized form - it's research results. And that's really the most important thing of all. **********Q. Wouldn't that hurt us militarily? **********A. If we get technology from the Soviet Union that's equivalent to what we give them and it's not any of this exotic military stuff, I think that's a fine deal for the United States, and I think it would not change the military picture. After all, the Russians don't seem to lack much when it comes to military capability, in spite of all the controls we've had. **********Q. Control Data is pushing public-private **********ventures in Minnesota. Is that creating jobs? **********A. It's starting to. The discouraging aspect is that you don't create jobs overnight, and most politicians have a pretty short time span in office. They want results now, so it's hard to get support for long-term projects like job creation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/12/busin.body_text: **********''Here's how I read,'' Stewart Wiggins said. He picked up a small lens that was wired to a device that resembled a tape recorder. It was called an Optacon. He deftly ran the lens over a computer printout while he stuck his left index finger into the tape recorder-like device. As the lens swept over sentences, the device vibrated. Mr. Wiggins has been trained to translate the vibrations into words. **********Mr. Wiggins, 49 years old, works as a computer programmer here in Wilmington for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. Late in 1972, a benign tumor was removed from his optic nerve. Ever since, he has been blind. **********W. J. Schaffers, Mr. Wiggins's boss, estimated that Du Pont had spent about $19,000 on adjustments for his handicap. He considered it a trivial expense. ''His attitude is remarkable,'' Mr. Schaffers said. ''Just close your eyes and see how you feel. With the sun outside and everything, and the man has no sight. He's a tremendous influence on all of us with his attitude.'' **********Discrimination against the handicapped has been one of the simmering civil rights issues of the 1970's and 1980's. Du Pont has attracted attention for its willingness to treat the disabled like anyone else and to make the physical and mental adjustments necessary for the handicapped to work for the company. **********''There are a number of major corporations - not too big a number - that are willing to stand up and be counted in their employment of the handicapped, and Du Pont is one of them,'' said Bernard Posner, executive director of the President's Committee on Employment of the Handicapped. ''It's among the Alps in this area.'' **********A Terminal That 'Talks' **********In addition to his Optacon ''reader,'' Mr. Wiggins proudly shows off his new ''talker,'' an electronic machine called the Vert 6000. Plugged into any computer terminal, it could make the terminal ''talk.'' Mr. Wiggins typed some sentences onto the screen. Out of a small speaker, through the wonders of voice synthesis, words emerged. The pronunciation was not the best, but Mr. Wiggins seemed able to figure it out. **********He uses earphones so co-workers won't be disturbed. ''I don't always like the earphones,'' he said. ''They get a little warm on your head when you have them on all the time. My co- worker here gets used to the noise - my Vert talking and my Optacon buzzing.'' **********And other co-workers include James Prettyman, a blind spin pump mechanic for Du Pont in Seaford, Del. By touch, he services dozens of pumps a day. There are Bill and Barbara Monaghan, both mentally retarded. They met at a school for the handicapped, fell in love and married. Now they work as messengers at Du Pont's headquarters. **********Du Pont's sensitivity to the handicapped dates to the company's early years. Its business then was gunpowder, made in mills that perched along the banks of the Brandywine River in Wilmington. In the middle 1850's, an explosion at one of the black powder mills killed a number of employees and maimed others. **********Du Pont points to that episode as the trigger for the first pension plan of an industrial company. It provided compensation for the families of those killed and found jobs for the disabled. Ever since, Du Pont has been attuned to safety and continuation of employment. **********Periodically, Du Pont produces a statistical portrait of how the handicapped perform. It is an unusual study, important because there is so much mythology about how well the handicapped hold down jobs. **********The most recent report, in 1981, showed that Du Pont employed 2,745 handicapped workers, about 2.4 percent of its work force. Its handicapped employment grew by 89 percent from the 1973 level, while overall employment climbed 13 percent. **********In job performance, supervisors rated 92 percent of handicapped workers as average or above, compared with 91 percent for nonimpaired employees. Some 85 percent were average or above in attendance, compared with 91 percent for the able-bodied. In safety, 96 percent of the handicapped were average or above, while 92 percent of the others were in that category. **********''The bottom line is we've got a job to be done,'' said Mark Suwyn, Du Pont's vice president for employee relations. ''And we need to find people who are 150 percent enthusiastic and have the ability to do the job. And we find that there are a lot of handicapped people who can do that.'' As for failures, he said the only case that came to mind was an epileptic who was unable, mentally or physically, to handle his work. **********Brian Hennessey, a draftsman in Du Pont's engineering department, is 27 and has been deaf since birth. He wanted to explain what the attitude of his co-workers has been like. His hands worked nimbly. He wore an easy smile. His thoughts were conveyed by an interpreter. **********''I'm really like a normal person,'' Mr. Hennessey said. ''Just if they have a meeting they have to prepare notes for me. And if there's a really important meeting that requires dialogue, then they hire an interpreter.'' **********''Here I am,'' Elrey McCann said. He was wheeling down the hallway in what appeared to be a hopped-up scooter. Mr. McCann is 41, a research chemist. He suffers from multiple sclerosis. **********He puttered into his office and sat down in an amply-cushioned chair. ''I'll take the best seat,'' he said. He talked about life at Du Pont since his affliction began to hamper his mobility five years ago: **********''I have difficulty walking. That's how it started. They began by giving me my own private parking place. Then they put up railings outside on the sidewalks to make it easier for me. Then it got worse. In 1982, they got me this motorized wheelchair to allow me to get around the building better.'' **********''Du Pont then built a special ramp that allows me to drive up the parking lot,'' he continued. ''There was this grassy hill. This thing doesn't go up grassy hills very well. So they built me this concrete freeway. Then there's another handrail that they built for me out front. Special grab bars were built in the washroom. The other thing is, everyone I work with doesn't hesitate to help me. Everyone I work for treats me like everyone else. I'm not some poor soul.'' **********He chuckled, then added, ''I met a fellow in the hospital several years ago whose employer said that if you can walk up this flight of stairs and get to your office and then walk down at the end of the day, you can have your job. Otherwise, forget it. He had to forget it. Here, you don't have to forget it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; ALEXANDER & BALDWIN NAMES NEW PRESIDENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.body_text: **********Michael S. Wasacz was named president and chief operating officer of Alexander & Baldwin Inc., a Honolulu-based transportation, sugar and real estate company. **********Mr. Wasacz, 48 years old, had been senior executive vice president. **********He replaces R.J. Pfeiffer as president, although the 64-year-old Mr. Pfeiffer continues as chairman and chief executive officer. **********Mr. Pfeiffer said yesterday that the promotion was part of the company's plan for an orderly transition after his retirement, tentatively scheduled for April 1986. In his new position, Mr. Wasacz is to assume responsibility for all the operating organizations of Alexander & Baldwin and its subsidiaries. **********In a related advancement, John C. Couch, 45, the executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Matson Navigation Company, an Alexander subsidiary, was made executive vice president of Alexander and president and chief operating officer of Matson. **********Alexander & Baldwin has been touched by acrimony. Last month Harry Weinberg, the company's largest shareholder, said he would wage a proxy battle to oust the directors of the company. Mr. Weinberg, who owns about a quarter of the company's outstanding shares, has been at odds with Alexander & Baldwin's management for more than four years. **********Mr. Weinberg, who is 75, has said he wants the board to take several actions, including selling Alexander & Baldwin so that the stockholders can receive the value of the company's real estate holdings. Mr. Pfeiffer said the company would oppose Mr. Weinberg's efforts. **********Mr. Wasacz joined the Matson subsidiary in 1959 and became a vice president in 1976, a senior vice president in 1978 and president and chief operating officer in 1981. That year he also became executive vice president of the parent company, and last January he rose to senior executive vice president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/25/world.main_headline: U.S. MOVES TO END NAMIBIA DEADLOCK
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/25/world.print_headline: U.S. MOVES TO END NAMIBIA DEADLOCK
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/25/world.body_text: **********The United States has decided to mount an intensive diplomatic effort in the next several weeks to bring about a formula for ending South African control of South-West Africa along with a parallel withdrawal of Cuban soldiers from Angola, State Department officials said today. **********One official said ''a window of opportunity'' was now opening that could provide the impetus for a solution to the persistent southern African problem. **********The key to the new effort was South Africa's agreeing to withdraw all its troops from Angola starting next Tuesday for at least a month, provided that Angolan forces or guerrillas seeking control of South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, do not try to take military advantage of the situation. **********U.S. Official to Visit Area **********Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, will leave on Wednesday and fly to South Africa to confer with officials there, before going on to Tanzania, Zambia and Mozambique, and possibly other African nations, officials said. **********Meanwhile, Mr. Crocker's senior deputy, Frank G. Wisner, has just met with Angolan officials in Cape Verde, after they in turn had conferred with South African diplomats. Mr. Wisner is now in Lisbon, but will fly to Luanda, the Angolan capital, if the Angolan leaders decide to continue the diplomatic effort that is under way, State Department officials said. **********''We want to explore with the Angolans the potential for moving forward on the whole issue of regional security in southern Africa,'' one department official said. ''That is a code word for implementation of Security Council Resolution 435 on Namibia, circumstances in which there will be parallel movement on the Cuban troop issue.'' **********There are some 25,000 Cuban combat troops, as well as about 2,000 Soviet and 5,000 East German advisers in Angola. They are helping the Government there protect itself from attacks from the opposition group known as the Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, led by Jonas Savimbi, as well as from South African military incursions into southern Angola. The South Africans recently carried out a major military action in Angola aimed at the Namibian rebels who are based there, the South- West Africa People's Organization. **********The Reagan Administration has given the Namibia issue a relatively high priority, and in 1981 then Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was optimistic that a solution could be worked out soon. But the United States, working with its allies, was unable to persuade Angola to agree to a parallel withdrawal of Cuban troops. **********The Angolans have been insisting that the South Africans pull all their troops out of Angola and accept the provisions of Security Council Resolution 435, which calls for the entry of United Nations troops into Namibia, the withdrawal of South African troops and elections for a constituent assembly. Only then, the Angolans have said, would they ask the Cubans to leave.   'There Is Cautious Optimism' **********But State Department officials said the Angolans and their backers have to understand that there will not be a solution unless the South African concerns about the Cubans are taken care of. **********''We are underscoring the point,'' one official said, ''that there is no change in the American position on the importance of parallel movement. It is our clear understanding that the South Africans will not bend on that.'' **********''I would say that there is cautious optimism,'' one official said, in speaking about the new effort. **********This is because, in part, the Angolan Government has suffered from military defeats at the hands of the Unita forces and from the South African incursions. Another factor, officials said, is that the United States has offered to establish diplomatic relations with Angola once the Cubans are gone. This would carry with it an implicit promise of American economic aid.   Rains Slow Military Activity **********The rainy season in Angola will last through March, making military activity difficult. This is seen by officials here as giving the diplomats at least that much time to work with before the strife is likely to break out again. **********After his talks in Africa Mr. Crocker will fly to Europe to meet with the four Western ''contact'' countries, Britain, Canada, France and West Germany, that together with the United States have acted as a kind of intermediary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/10/busin.body_text: **********The executives sent here six weeks ago by Citicorp to merge the $4 billion First Federal Savings and Loan Association into the bank holding company have barely unpacked, but already there are signs of the changes they promise to bring to banking here. **********In a series of moves aimed at building the ailing thrift unit into a major banking force in Chicago, Citicorp officials have cut its mortgage lending rates, raised deposit rates and aggressively promoted a wide range of new and traditional services. At the same time, a well-coordinated advertising and public relations blitz has kept Citicorp's name before the public as First Federal's new owners. **********The moves appear to be paying off. Citicorp officials say that First Federal's mortgage loan applications are up sharply and that new deposits are on the rise. And competing bankers concede that Citicorp has quickly won high visibility in the Chicago market. **********''They've come in as strong competitors,'' said William Kundert, vice president-personal banking at the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company. ''They've had a heavy focus on advertising and community involvement.'' **********'Expandable' C.D.'s **********Citicorp's most dramatic move yet, however, came with its heavily promoted introduction two weeks ago of a new ''six-month expandable certificate of deposit.'' **********The certificates, which have set Chicago banking circles abuzz, permit depositors, after an initial investment of $1,000, to increase their investment by $100 increments until maturity. The interest rate at sign-on is guaranteed for any subsequent deposits. **********''They're taking a big chance on this product,'' said Edmond Shanahan, president of Bell Federal Savings and Loan. ''I'm surprised they didn't put some limits on it. They could lose a bundle if rates go down.'' **********Taking risks on consumer banking has become characteristic of Citicorp since the late 1970's, however, when it made a strategic decision to rapidly expand its consumer deposits. In the last few years, that strategy has made it a leader in the movement to win approval for interstate banking. **********Monitoring State Banking Laws **********Citicorp has a staff of hundreds that monitors state banking laws and lobbies legislatures for changes in favor of interstate banking. Since last year, Citicorp has acquired three big thrift units from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board: Fidelity Savings of Oakland, Calif., Biscayne Federal of Miami and First Federal. **********When it became known for certain that Citicorp would be coming to Chicago, bankers here studied its operating habits in California, where Fidelity Federal became profitable within a year of being acquired. **********The locals apparently did not learn the extent of Citicorp's eagerness to get into the Chicago market. Other local bidders for First Federal, including Sears, Roebuck & Company and many of the city's larger banks, were caught flat-footed by Citicorp's willingness to spend. **********Purchase Price Criticized **********Area bankers said later that the $120 million Citicorp paid for First Federal was far too much for an institution with a negative net worth of $470 million. **********''We paid what we think the future of First Federal is worth,'' said Barry Burkeholder, who was sent from Citicorp's mortgage lending subsidiary in St. Louis to become chairman of First Federal. **********''It fits in with our long-term strategy of serving consumers,'' he continued. ''Consumer financial services is a rapidly evolving market. There are a lot of big names that have decided that this is where it's at in the 1980's and 1990's, and this is just part and parcel of that.'' **********Citicorp's revenues from consumer banking activities rose by 26 percent last year, to $2.4 billion, while income from consumer banking soared to $202 million, about one-fifth of total profits, from $66 million. The holding company aim is to generate one-third of its profits from consumer activity. **********Challenged By Attorney General **********Citicorp's arrival here has not been an unalloyed success. Neil Hartigan, the Illinois Attorney General, is challenging First Federal's takeover in Federal court in an effort to get the F.H.L.B.B. to disclose more details about the bids that it rejected. In the meantime, a cloud of uncertainty hangs over the merger. **********Another incident illustrates how an out-of-town outfit can make embarrassing mistakes when dealing on unfamiliar territory. **********Two weeks ago, Citicorp Information Services published a rosy outlook for the Chicago area's economy and its commercial real estate markets. The study, which generated good television coverage and a banner headline on page one of The Chicago Tribune, was almost immediately refuted by local real estate experts. The analysts contended that Citicorp's assumptions on commercial office space contained gross errors. **********Chagrined, the bank admitted its errors to the press - but stoutly defended its conclusions. **********Reversing Prior Image **********While looking for a grand strategy, the thrift unit is concentrating on getting bigger. And growing, in this case, means offering higher rates on deposits and lower rates on loans. **********''Any consumer who shopped the market place would not have come to First Federal,'' Mr. Burkeholder conceded in a recent interview. **********But mortgage rates have now been cut. Interest rates on 30-year adjustable mortgages have fallen to 9.875 percent from 10.9 percent; there is a 2 percent cap on monthly increases, where there was none before, and a new 15-year fixed mortgage has been introduced, at 13.25 percent. **********First Federal, with 61 branches, already enjoys a considerable advantgage over its commercial bank competitiors, most of which are limited by state law to three deposit-taking locations. Still, the thrift unit's new managers are trying to become part of an automated teller network that has outlets in 270 Jewel food stores. **********First Federal says it will now sell more of its mortgage loans in the secondary market, a practice virtually ignored by previous management. It intends to actively seek loan business from small entrepreneurs and professionals. And consumer services in areas only recently authorized for thrift units - auto loans, Visa cards and checking accounts - will receive special emphasis. **********But Citicorp is also courting a reputation for civic-mindedness here, as it did in the San Francisco area, as one way to earn acceptance in this market. It promises a ''dramatic'' announcement concerning Dearborn Park, a downtown residential redevelopment that is its initial civic project. **********In the Bay area, Citicorp executives contributed their expertise to such nonprofit groups as the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the United Way, and to neighborhood housing rehabilitation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/24/busin.body_text: **********Contary to widespread belief, the dramatic sales of dollars by the West German central bank last Friday was not part of a grand European plan to drive down the price of the United States currency, according to German bankers attending the annual meetings here of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. **********The move, in which the Deutsch Bundesbank sold about $450 million of dollars, was designed to stabilize the foreign exchange markets and to earn a profit by selling dollars when the price was particularly high, the bankers said. **********''The Bundesbank regarded the hectic upward movement of the dollar as disorderly,'' said Walter Seipp, chairman of the Commerzbank, one of West Germany's three largest commercial banks. Mr. Seipp made his remarks after having left a briefing with German Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg and Karl Otto P"ohl, president of the Bundesbank. **********And Otmar Emminger, former president of the Bundesbank, said that despite the strength of the dollar, interest rates have been declining in Germany.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/19/busin.body_text: **********-service brokerage houses may soon regret letting go large numbers of commodity account executives in belt- tightening moves brought on by shrinking business and the increasing competition from discount brokers. The reason: Many of the fired brokers have become ''introducing brokers,'' and they are generating even more business for the discounters. **********Introducing brokers, or I.B.'s, as they are known in the trade, are not a new phenomenon. What is new and promises to radically change the futures and options brokerage business is the large numbers of experienced account executives who are becoming I.B.'s. **********Herbert Young, president of Lind-Waldock & Company, the largest futures discount broker, explained: ''The growing number of I.B.'s are one of the major reasons discounters have been getting larger shares of the futures business. These are people with the kind of experience you can't go out and buy. And they don't clear their clients' business through firms like ours just because they are mad at their former employers.'' **********Lind-Waldock, for example, has attracted hundreds of former account executives, many of whom work out of their homes, by offering them legal help in registering as I.B.'s. Depending on the I.B.'s past record, the company will advance the $25,000 guarantee fee, and, if the I.B. generates enough business, the discounters will provide equipment that allows the I.B. to transmit orders from a home or office directly to the exchange trading floor through the discount house's own computer systems. **********Another reason why the discounters cultivate the I.B.'s is that they, not the brokerage house that clears the trade, are responsible to the client. **********''For the I.B. to make a living, he has to offer competitive commissions,'' Mr. Young continued. ''With the rates charged by discounters, the I.B. can offer competitive rates, tack on something for himself and still give his client a lower commission than that offered by the full-service houses. Right now, we have 771 I.B.'s. A year from now, we think there will be more than 5,000, and they will all be clearing through discount houses.'' **********Until the Futures Trading Act of 1982 became law, the typical I.B. was a small-town agent who would execute his client's commodity futures business through the nearest branch of a major brokerage house. As an agent, they were not liable for any mistakes in execution of orders, only the clearing brokerage house was. The 1982 law shifted that liability to the agent or I.B. **********To become an I.B. now requires passing stringent competency examinations and registration with both the Federal Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the National Futures Association, an industry self-policing group created in 1982 with the blessing of Congress. **********Last week, Susan Philips, chairman of the regulatory agency, said in a telephone interview: **********''The N.F.A. has done such a great job in helping us process I.B.'s and A.P.'s, or persons associated with the I.B.'s, that we plan to turn over the whole responsibility to it by Dec. 3. We will then be able to use our resources to crack down on shady operators as well as perform the other oversight duties mandated by Congress.'' **********Robert K. Wilmouth, N.F.A.'s president and former chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest futures exchange, said the agency had given his group the responsibility for policing and registering ''about 90,000 futures account executives, commodity pool operators, commodity trading advisers, futures commission merchants and others involved in the industry.'' **********''Our two-year-old association has done a fine job policing our industry, thanks to the help of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other law enforcement groups,'' Mr. Wilmouth noted, ''to the point that I doubt any of the many our group has barred or expelled can ever deal in futures again.'' **********Thomas A. Russo, partner in the Wall Street law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft and one of the writers of the first regulations of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission a decade ago, observed; **********''For better or worse, the N.F.A. is now the most powerful regulator in the commodity industry, and I must say that thus far it has been a force for good. But the N.F.A. has also greatly speeded up and facilitated the process of becoming an I.B. How they are going to police the tens of thousands of potential I.B.'s is something else.'' **********How does an industry get to regulate itself? Faced with growing demands for stricter Government regulation of the futures business, the industry persuaded Congress in 1982 to give it the opportunity to police itself at its own expense, and Congress agreed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/05/world.main_headline: WITH A 'SIR' AT STAKE, FLORIDAN WINS THE DAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/05/world.print_headline: WITH A 'SIR' AT STAKE, FLORIDAN WINS THE DAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/05/world.body_text: **********To hundreds who have not actually met him, he is the frail, white-haired steward who on a Saturday or Sunday once showed them to a seat in Canterbury Cathedral. He has been a banker and a British Army officer. In childhood, his mother introduced him as ''the little baronet.'' **********This week, 91 years into his life, he finally had to concede that he would never be a baronet, only William Henry George Dunbar of Kilconzie. **********The venerable title of Dunbar of Mochrum rests securely in the hands of Colonel Dunbar's American cousin, the 13th baronet, Sir Jean Ivor Dunbar, according to a ruling last week by Lord Lyon, King of Arms, who decides on matters of nobility in Scotland. **********''Oh I'm a bona fide baron all right,'' said Sir Jean, a 66-year-old retired jockey. ''That bum tried to challenge my title.'' The baronet, who says he once rode for Al Capone, spoke to an interviewer last week at his apartment in Pembroke Pines, Fla., where he moved to be close to Calder Race Course. **********''The judgment is bitter, I assure you,'' said Colonel Dunbar, whose pursuit of the baronetcy has cost him three years and $14,000 in court costs and attorneys' fees. ''But as a soldier, I say good luck and good fortune - let him proceed.'' **********Succession Is Challenged **********Colonel Dunbar's half-brother, Richard, had held the title, but died within days of inheriting it. It then passed, not to the colonel, but to Sir Jean's father and then to Sir Jean. The colonel, who was disqualified because he was illegitimate at birth, subsequently challenged the succession under a 1968 law that says an ille gitimate child whose parents eventually marry can inherit a title under certain circumstances. **********Harold Brooks-Baker, publishing director of Burke's Peerage, praised the decision, saying: ''If it had gone the other way, it would have opened a Pandora's box for the genealogical world because it would mean that any illegitimate member of a noble family could instigate a claim, spurious or otherwise, for a title,'' . **********The tale of the two cousins is worthy of Dickens. **********Sir Jean, according to Mr. Brooks- Baker, was born in the United States and had to fend for himself after the death of his mother, who was Belgian and considered by her husband's family to be socially inferior. His father went home to Scotland, married well and had two more sons. The son he left behind became a jockey when he was a teen-ager. **********When it became clear that the jockey would become the next baronet, Mr. Brooks-Baker said, the family sold off the family silver and a huge family estate, complete with the family ghost, an ancestor named Jacobina Copland, whom the 10th baronet said he once saw and whose footsteps he reported often hearing.   Lineage Is Verified **********Hugh Peskett, the senior genealogist at Burke's Peerage, found Sir Jean's birth certificate and his parents' marriage certificate, which gave him both the family title and the family trust fund. **********Colonel Dunbar and Sir Jean are first cousins once removed. The colonel's father and Sir Jean's grandfather were brothers. **********Colonel Dunbar, unlike his cousin, was brought up in a comfortable home and educated at the best schools. He was 12 when his mother learned, to her shock, that his father had another family, which he had abandoned, that the first wife was still living and that her son was therefore illegitimate. **********Although his parents legitimized him by marrying again when he was 19, his claim to the title was ruined. Instead of spending his twilight years as a baronet, he has spent them as a pensioner. **********''Everyone knows that William the Conqueror was a bastard and that of the 25 nonroyal dukes in England today, five are descended from Charles II's bastards,'' said Mr. Brooks-Baker. ''Most English monarchs and every single English noble family has a large number of illegitimate members. Burke's Peerage is not against illegitimacy. The point is that when there is a legitimate heir, he must take precedence over an illegitimate one, because his rights are somewhat greater.''  'I'm Strictly United States' **********From the sitting room of Greenways, where his rose garden lies a few hundred yards from the shore in Herne Bay, Kent, Colonel Dunbar conceded that he didn't know his cousin very well, although he remembers his cousin's father, Sir Adrian. **********''I went up to his place in Scotland,'' he said. ''He wasn't quite the person to hold a baronetcy. He didn't know the behavior patterns. So of course he didn't have many friends.'' **********The colonel, who has written three books about the Dunbars, explained that the family traces its line to the younger son of Crinan the Thane, who died in 1045. Crinan's older son, Duncan, was murdered by Macbeth. **********''I'm strictly United States,'' said Sir Jean in his Florida apartment as he talked happily of his career as a jockey - he won 601 races in 22 years. ''I was born here, and I intend to die here.'' **********After his career as a jockey, he worked as a cloth cutter in the New York garment district for $200 a week. **********''I'm one of the best cutters in the country and I'm one of the best riders,'' he said. He added that his life had been threatened when he rode horses owned by Al Capone in the mid-1930's in Chicago. **********Although he is happy that people now know his title is authentic, ''I don't want to be called sir. **********''Just call me plain Jean,'' he said. **********Lucy Breznikar, a former neighbor, was one of several who said she hadn't believed he was a baronet. ''He told me that,'' she said. ''I thought maybe he was dreaming, just like I do sometimes.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/busin.body_text: **********TUESDAY, JULY 10, 1984 **********Companies **********Eastern Airlines touched off a fare war by announcing a major cut in its New York-Florida price. The carrier lowered round-trip fares between New York-area airports and five Florida cities to $198. Delta and Pan Am, Eastern's largest competitors in that market, said they would match the cuts. (Page D1.) A Miami bankrutpcy court ruled that Air Florida could use up to $4 million of its cash to continue operations in hopes of resuming its flights. (D4.) **********St. Regis said Rupert Murdoch was secretly negotiating with a group of banks, including the Midland Bank of London, to raise $750 million for a possible takeover of the big forest products company. The charge was included in a suit filed by St. Regis to block any takeover effort. Mr. Murdoch, the Australian publisher, has said publicly that he has no current designs on St. Regis. (D1.) **********CBS will stop making videodisks.  Its announcement cited diminishing consumer demand and growing orders for conventional records and cassettes. The move will cause a $15.7 milion second- quarter write-down for CBS. (D2.) **********Caterpillar Tractor reported a second-quarter profit of $24 million. It was the company's first profit in eight quarters. (D11.) **********Apple Computer plans to double the manufacturing capacity for its Macintosh computer by year-end.  (D4.) **********Guardian Industries' president, William Davidson, plans to offer $24 a share for the stock of the glass and film company he does not already own. (D4.) **********The president of 20th Century-Fox's production unit, Joe Wizan, resigned and will be replaced by Lawrence Gordon, a producer, the company announced. (C13.) **********Employees of the Long Island Lighting Company set a strike for today. Lilco said the chief area of disagreement was the need for austerity measures.  (B1.) **********The Economy **********State utility regulators are slowing the pace of Federal telephone deregulation. Consequently, the expected doubling or tripling of local telephone rates predicted in the wake of the A.T.&T. breakup will probably occur much more slowly. (D1.) **********A.T.&T. reported that its backlog of unfilled orders for business phone installations rose 16 percent in June, to 41,700. This seemed to confirm reports that telephone service quality has declined. (D6.) **********Markets **********The credit markets had their best day of the year, as bond prices rose as much as 2 points, or $20 for every $1,000 in face value. Analysts cited greater foreign demand and low levels of inflation and money growth as reasons for the rally. (D1.) Stock prices followed the lead of the bond market. The Dow rose 11.48, to 1.134.05, after being down 5 1/2 points at noon. Volume expanded slightly to 74.8 million shares. (D8.) **********Gold recovered from four days of declining prices, rising $2.50 an ounce in New York to close at $347.50. The dollar continued to set record levels against the British pound, and near record levels against the French franc.  (D17.) **********Heating oil and gasoline futures prices fell sharply on the eve of an OPEC meeting, amid skepticism that the organization would be able to keep output in line with its daily quotas. (D17.) **********International **********An OPEC advisory panel is urging the oil cartel to hold oil production to official ceilings as a way to keep prices from falling. Ministers of the 13 member nations gather today in Vienna. (D23.) **********Today's Columns **********More companies are terminating their pension plans to gain access to the excess cash in them. And it has generated a lot of controversy. Employees think the extra funds belong to them, while the companies claim the money. The Government has come down on the side of the corporations, but has set certain safeguards for employees. Business and the Law. (D2.) **********Despite heavy trading in MCA stock, nobody has acknowledged accumulating it. A takeover attempt is possible, analysts note, but the entertainment company has taken steps to assure that any unfriendly bid would stir up a tough fight. Market Place. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/03/world.main_headline: Iranian Claims Right To Strike at U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/03/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Iranian Claims Right To Strike at U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/03/world.body_text: **********Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, the President of Iran, marked the fifth anniversary of the student seizure of the United States Embassy two days early today by saying that Iran would not hesitate to strike against United States interests anywhere. **********''As long as the U.S. conspires against this nation and against the Islamic republic, we consider it is our right to retaliate and to hit against U.S. interests anywhere in the world,'' he declared. **********Devoting much of his sermon at a weekly prayer rally to the takeover by Islamic militants on Nov. 4, 1979, Hojatolislam Khamenei said the United States would have to change its policies before relations could be restored. **********The former embassy is now a headquarters for Revolutionary Guards, and the Swiss Embassy looks after American interests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/17/world.main_headline: REAGAN USED U.S.I.A.'S GLOBAL TV NETWORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/17/world.print_headline: REAGAN USED U.S.I.A.'S GLOBAL TV NETWORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/17/world.body_text: **********President Reagan's speech on United States- Soviet relations today was beamed by satellite to American embassies abroad, the latest example of the United States Information Agency reaching journalists in foreign countries with the Administration's message as it is being delivered. **********Mr. Reagan's speech went to what the U.S.I.A. calls Euronet, a satellite system that provides a direct relay to embassies in Western European capitals. The Euronet system, part of a global communications effort called Worldnet, now reaches London, Bonn, Rome, The Hague, Paris, Geneva, Stockholm and Brussels. **********According to Al Snyder, the information agency's director of television and film, the operation will be expanded next month to include the embassies in Vienna, Madrid, Copenhagen and Oslo. **********Each embassy receiving the relay can invite local reporters to attend the telecast and, in some cases such as two last week, they are allowed to question the speaker directly.    Shultz Used the New System **********On Thursday, Secretary of State George P. Shultz used the system to discuss his forthcoming meeting in Stockholm with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union. The day before, the agency used the system to televise a news conference held by Henry A. Kissinger on the report of his Central American commission. **********U.S.I.A. also used a new Latin American component of the system to relay the Kissinger news conference. The Latin American network now reaches the embassies in Buenos Aires; Rio de Janeiro; Caracas, Venezuela, and San Jose, Costa Rica. **********For Mr. Kissinger's news conference, there was simultaneous interpretation into Spanish and, for the transmission to Brazil, into Portuguese. Questions from Latin American journalists were translated into English so that Mr. Kissinger could respond to them. The Spanish interpreters worked in Washington; the Portuguese interpreter worked at the embassy in Rio. **********According to Mr. Snyder, the telecasts to most of the embassies in Western Europe are in English. An exception is Rome, where the embassy handles interpretation into Italian. **********The transmission of Mr. Reagan's speech did not include a question-and- answer session. Idea of Present Director **********The relay system was the idea of the agency's present director, Charles Z. Wick, Mr. Snyder said. The European part went into operation on Nov. 3, with the transmission of a speech by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United Nations delegate. **********The agency decides which events are to be transmitted to embassies, Mr. Snyder said. The transmissions are made available to television stations abroad directly from the satellite, he said, and the television stations may also send crews to embassies, particularly when their reporters are questioning an American official. **********Events beamed to Euronet are generally scheduled for the morning in the United States so that they can reach Europe in the afternoon in time for the evening news or for the morning editions of newspapers. Mr. Reagan's speech, at 10 A.M. Washington time, was at 4 P.M. in Western Europe. **********The world communications network has an annual budget of $1.7 million and makes use of existing transmission systems. In addition to the European and Latin American components, it has a Middle Eastern arm that now reaches the embassies in Amman, Jordan, and Tel Aviv. Next month it is to be expanded to cover Cairo; Kuwait; Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates. **********Two other components that are still in the planning stage will cover the western Pacific and the Indian subcontinent. The Pacific network, to start up in April, will reach Tokyo; Canberra, Australia; Manila; Peking; Bangkok, Thailand; Singapore, and Jakarta, Indonesia. The other, to begin in July, will tie in the embassies in New Delhi; Islamabad, Pakistan; Dhaka, Bangladesh, and Colombo, Sri Lanka.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/13/busin.main_headline: CRITICISM REPORTED ON BID FOR REGISTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/13/busin.print_headline: CRITICISM REPORTED ON BID FOR REGISTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/13/busin.body_text: **********The chairman of the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company, David Kruidenier, has reportedly criticized the $112 million buyout offer the company received last week from Dow Jones & Company and an investor group that includes two top Register executives, saying that he regretted it had been made. **********However, sources close to the company, in which the descendants of Gardner Cowles have a substantial holding, said yesterday that the offer had produced ''intensive interest'' and that pressure for a sale appeared to be building. The Register and Tribune's holdings include The Des Moines Register, Iowa's leading daily newspaper. **********Pressure may also be building for the sale of Cowles Media Inc., the other part of the Cowles communications empire. Kingsley H. Murphy Jr., whose family holds a 17 percent block of Cowles Media stock, said yesterday that his family wanted to sell its stake. **********A decision by the Murphy family to dispose of its stock in Cowles Media could also affect the Register and Tribune, the sources said, because the Register owns 14.3 percent of Cowles. If a purchaser of the Murphy stake also bought the Register company, the buyer would have substantial influence over Cowles Media, the sources added. **********Mr. Murphy, who is a Cowles Media director, said in a letter to the board that his family felt the company is not being managed well and its holdings were undervalued. **********In the letter, Mr. Murphy said that the family had retained Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment house, and the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom as advisers. He said that Morgan Stanley's preliminary assessment of the company had put its value at more than $350 million. That figure is significantly higher than the current value of its stock, which is trading in the mid-30's. **********Calls to the headquarters of Cowles Media, whose holdings include The Minneapolis Star and Tribune newspaper, were not returned. **********Mr. Kruidenier, chairman of the Register company, declined yesterday to comment on the buyout offer or his reported reaction to it. **********According to news reports, in speaking to a group of employees on Sunday, he said: ''I very much regret this offer was made. And I particularly regret the manner in which it was made,'' adding that it was ''developed privately without my knowledge.'' **********The investor group allied with Dow Jones in the offer for the Register company includes Michael G. Gartner, the Register and Tribune Company's president and chief operating officer, and Gary G. Gerlach, publisher of The Des Moines Register. **********Last Friday, Mr. Kruidenier placed Mr. Gartner and Mr. Gerlach on paid leaves of absence pending the outcome of the offer. **********'Cordial' Action **********On Sunday, Mr. Gartner, who is also a director of the company, issued a statement saying that Mr. Kruidenier's action was a ''cordial'' one intended to remove any conflict-of-interest questions from consideration of the offer. **********Mr. Gartner also said Sunday of himself and Mr. Gerlach: ''We share the goals and principles that we learned from David. If the manner of our approach was wrong, we apologize publicly for that.'' **********Despite the words of conciliation, however, a source familiar with the Register company characterized the participation of the two executives in the buyout offer as ''a palace coup'' motivated in part by their loss of confidence in Mr. Kruidenier and their concern that the company was vulnerable to a takeover. **********The company has tentatively scheduled a board meeting for Dec. 10 to make a decision about the offer. The bid by the investor group and Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, would give stockholders $100 a share in cash. **********Mr. Gartner said last week that Register stock, which is traded infrequently over the counter, normally sells for about $33 a share. Yesterday, the stock was reported to be trading at about $95 a share. **********Shawn Kirkstein, a Cowles family member who has been advocating the sale of the Register company for three years, said yesterday that it was ''imperative'' for Mr. Kruidenier and the board to ''take control of the bidding process and sell the company to a buyer of our choosing and in a manner that redounds to the credit of the Register and Tribune tradition and Dave Kruidenier himself.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/08/world.main_headline: AND SEA ROLE; REBEL UNITS TAKE LAST OF MOSLEM SECTOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/08/world.print_headline: REAGAN ORDERS MARINES MOVED TO SHIPS OFF BEIRUT BUT WIDENS AIR; AND SEA ROLE; REBEL UNITS TAKE LAST OF MOSLEM SECTOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/08/world.body_text: **********Reagan statement, page A9. **********WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 - President Reagan announced tonight that he had ordered the 1,400 marines in the Beirut area to begin ''shortly'' a phased redeployment to Navy ships offshore. **********The President also said there would be increased American military activity in the area. He said American naval and air forces off the coast would now attack any units behind Syrian lines that were firing into the Beirut area. That would break with the practice of firing only when Americans were threatened. **********The decision to move the marines and to intensify naval and air action was taken after an intensive review of the worsening political and military situation in Beirut in recent days. **********On Capitol Hill, lawmakers from both parties praised Mr. Reagan's move, but many said the decision was an acknowledgment that his policy in Lebanon had failed. (Page A11.) **********White House and Pentagon officials said after the President's announcement that it might take as long as a month for the marines to turn over the task of guarding the Beirut airport to the Lebanese Army before moving to ships offshore. (Page A8.) **********Some Personnel to Remain **********Mr. Reagan said some American military personnel would remain in Lebanon to continue training and supplying Lebanese armed forces and to protect the remaining personnel. **********The shift in the location of the marines and the new battle orders were announced in a printed statement handed to reporters after Mr. Reagan arrived at the Point Mugu Naval Air Station near Santa Barbara, Calif., where he has gone on vacation for the rest of this week. **********Mr. Reagan said Britain, France and Italy, who with the United States form the multinational force in the Beirut area, had been ''consulted.'' But it appeared that the allies could not have had more than a few hours' warning. **********Italy Urges 4-Nation Meeting **********The Italian Foreign Minister, Giulio Andreotti, in an urgent message to Secretary of State George P. Shultz today, asked for a meeting of foreign ministers of the multinational-force countries to discuss the future of the force. Mr. Reagan's statement seemed to assume that the allies would keep their forces in the Beirut area while the Americans were moved to ships, but it was unclear what the others would do. **********In London, senior officials said Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was on the verge of ordering Britain's 115-member military contingent out of Beirut. The British attitude became known a few hours before Mr. Reagan's announcement. (Page A11.) **********Mr. Reagan also said President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon had ''requested'' the steps that he announced. It was not immediately clear when that request was made. **********Moslems Hold West Beirut **********The steps were taken after Moslem militias took control of West Beirut from the Lebanese Army and President Gemayel's Cabinet resigned. Mr. Reagan, however, did not describe the moves as a retreat but as ''decisive new steps'' aimed at demonstrating American resolve to continue to back the Gemayel Government. **********Mr. Reagan said in the statement that even before the latest outbreak of violence in Beirut, ''we had been considering ways of reconcentrating our forces and the nature of our support in order to take the initiative away from the terrorists.'' **********The decision to redeploy the marines away from the Beirut airport, where they had been since September 1982, came as a surprise. The Administration had been vigorously resisting calls by House Democrats for the marines to be removed from Lebanon. Spokesmen for the Administration had said that pulling the marines out of Lebanon now would be tantamount to giving in to terrorists, and they had vowed that the Administration would not ''cut and run,'' in the words of Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the No. 3 man in the State Department. **********The move to the ships, however, was a proposal favored by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, who had publicly called for it last October after 241 American servicemen were killed in a suicide truck bombing at the Marine headquarters at the airport. **********According to White House aides the President tentatively agreed to these steps on Sunday, but gave his final assent only today.  Senior Administration officials and diplomatic sources in Washington said earlier that the rapid political and military deterioration had been caused by the refusal of some 30 to 40 percent of the Lebanese Army to fight in recent days and the continued refusal by Syria to cooperate in a political solution.   Declines Television Appearance **********In the past, Mr. Reagan has personally addressed the nation on important Middle East developments. He did so when the marines were sent to Beirut and he did so after the killing of the servicemen in Beirut. But tonight he chose not to speak in front of television cameras in announcing a decision that may be interpreted as a retreat in Lebanon, although he went out of his way to describe it as a strengthening of resolve. **********Mr. Reagan said the moves were consistent with the agreement reached with Congress last fall to keep the marines in Lebanon for no more than 18 months. That accord said the size and mission of the Marine force could not be changed without Congressional approval. It seemed as if the increased military role to be played by American naval and air forces might reflect a change in that understanding. **********Congressional leaders were kept informed as today's events unrolled. Senate Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, said he had talked to Vice President Bush ''off and on all day.'' **********''The first conversation with him was early this morning, and in the course of the day he's kept me apprised of the situation,'' he said on Cable News Network. **********Mr. Baker said that late in the morning Deputy Secretary of State Kenneth W. Dam briefed him and Senator Robert C. Byrd, the Democratic leader, and that in the afternoon ''I received a call from the Vice President indicating that the President would make a statement about 5:55 or 6 o'clock.'' **********The decision, he said, ''was clearly being considered'' at the time of the briefing by Mr. Dam. **********The decision to use naval and air power against any forces attacking Beirut will be welcomed by Mr. Gemayel, whose own forces have been set back badly by the refusal of Moslem soldiers and officers to fight in West Beirut.   'We Will Stand Firm' **********Mr. Reagan said, ''I have authorized U.S. naval forces, under the existing mandate of the multinational force, to provide naval gunfire and air support against any units firing into greater Beirut from parts of Lebanon controlled by Syria as well as against any units directly attacking American or M.N.F. personnel or facilities.'' **********''Those who conduct these attacks will no longer have sanctuary from which to bombard Beirut at will,'' he said. ''We will stand firm to deter those who seek to influence Lebanon's future by intimidation.'' **********Mr. Reagan also said that when Lebanon had a ''broadly based representative government,'' the United States would ''vigorously accelerate'' the training and supply of the Lebanese armed forces. He said there would be particular emphasis on antiterrorism. **********In describing the redeployment of the marines, Mr. Reagan said, ''I have asked Secretary of Defense Weinberger to present to me a plan for redeployment of the Marines from Beirut airport to their ships off shore.'' **********A senior White House official said the first stage of withdrawal, of about 500 of the marines, should be concluded within a month. **********The official said American armed forces would remain in small numbers to protect the embassy personnel and those training the Lebanese.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING ; Fortune Confirmation Of Y. & R. Resignation
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/busin.body_text: **********Fortune magazine confirmed yesterday that Young & Rubicam, its ad agency since 1967, had resigned the account rather that participate in an agency review. **********Annual billings, according to Fortune, are generally between $2 million and $3 million. David Nimz, promotion director, said about six agencies had been selected to compete and a decision on the victor should be made before the end of February. **********Y. & R. has long been associated with Time Inc. and is currently the agency also for both Time and Discover magazines, does some work for People magazine and serves Time's Book of the Month Club through Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, its direct marketing subsidiary.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/18/busin.body_text: **********Wholesale prices in Japan rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May from April but fell one-tenth of 1 percent from May 1983, the Bank of Japan said Friday. Analysts at the Japanese central bank said the rise was partly fueled by a weakened yen, which caused import prices to increase. But they said the yen was stronger in May than it was a year earlier, leading to the year-to- year drop in wholesale prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/19/busin.main_headline: A.H. Belo President Adds Chairman's Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A.H. Belo President Adds Chairman's Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/19/busin.body_text: **********James M. Moroney Jr., 62, the president and chief executive of the A. H. Belo Corporation, was elected to the additional post of chairman. A. H. Belo owns The Dallas Morning News and seven community newspapers in the Dallas-Forth Worth area and five television stations and four radio stations. The company sold its cable system last week. **********His promotion is part of the continuing pattern of family management at A. H. Belo. The company was purchased from the Belo family in 1926 by G. B. Dealey, Mr. Moroney's grandfather. The Dealey family still owns about 35 percent of the company's shares. **********Mr. Moroney succeeds Joe M. Dealey, 64, as chairman. Mr. Dealey, a grandson of G. B. Dealey and Mr. Moroney's first cousin, will serve as a consultant until the end of the year. He will continue as a member of the board. **********In three years, when Mr. Moroney is required to retire by company rules, it is expected that he will be succeeded by Robert W. Decherd, 33, the great-grandson of G. B. Dealey, the founder of The Dallas Morning News. **********In preparation for the retirement of his generation from management, Mr. Moroney said that during the last two years he and Joe Dealey had separated the operations of the company from those of the newspaper. **********''We didn't feel that we could successfully move the company forward and also be operating the newspaper,'' Mr. Moroney said. ''We felt that operating the newspaper was a full- time job.'' **********Before becoming president and chief executive of the corporation, Mr. Moroney, a graduate of the University of Texas at Austin, was president of the newspaper. Since assuming his job as head of the corporation, Mr. Moroney has been responsible for supervising the company's broadcasting operations. **********In June 1983, A. H. Belo purchased the Corinthian Broadcasting Group's six television stations from the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation for $606 million. ''We never really realized that we were going to get such handsome properties as Corinthian,'' he said. ''They really moved us forward.'' **********''Our strategy is to become a major media company headquartered in Dallas,'' he said.  Pamela G. Hollie

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/23/world.main_headline: Hanoi Said to Pledge Aid On Missing Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/23/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Hanoi Said to Pledge Aid On Missing Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/23/world.body_text: **********Vietnam has given a ''clear commitment'' to move more rapidly in determining the status of the nearly 2,500 Americans still listed as missing in the Vietnam war, a member of a United States delegation to Hanoi said today. **********The Vietnamese Government no longer links the missing Americans with other issues between the two countries, said Ann Mills Griffiths, executive director of the National League of Missing In Action-Prisoners of War Families. **********Mrs. Griffiths spoke at a news conference here after traveling to Hanoi with four American officials. The delegation was led by Richard L. Armitage, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/08/busin.body_text: **********Fearful that last week's sharp rise in stock prices may not endure, large numbers of investors either stayed on the sidelines or cashed in their stock for profit yesterday. The result was that share prices moved up and down like a yo-yo, and trading volume slowed markedly from its recent furious pace. **********For the second consecutive day, the Dow Jones industrial average finished virtually unchanged. After dropping sharply in the morning, the index of 30 blue-chip stocks battled back, to close at 1,204.62, up 1.66 points. On Monday, the index rose 0.88 point. **********But in the New York Stock Exchange over all, 894 stocks lost value compared with 723 that rose. Volume on the Big Board, which reached a record 236.6 million shares last Friday and continued at a torrid pace of 203.1 million on Monday, slackened to 128 million shares yesterday. **********Taking a Breather **********The seesawing of prices and the sizable drop in trading volume prompted many analysts to conclude that last week's rally, while not necessarily ended, has taken a breather. **********Equity investors were also concerned about the future direction of interest rates, as they were in the credit markets. There, strong investor demand for the Treasury's auctions of three-year notes led to lower yields and higher prices, and some dealers said investors were optimistic about that market's outlook. (Page D13.) **********''People are still buying stocks, but much slower than last week,'' said Stanley B. Shopkorn, the head of equity trading at Salomon Brothers Inc. **********Jack A. Conlon, an executive vice president at E. F. Hutton & Company, said, ''You have many individual accounts taking profits, and you have institutional investors taking a step back to decide what their strategy will be next.'' **********Decline in Participation **********Indeed, many large brokerage firms and banks that act as stockbrokers reported yesterday a sharp decline in market participation by institutions, which in the previous five sessions had propelled the Dow Jones average up 93 points. **********According to Mr. Conlon, the money managers who direct institutional funds remain concerned that high inflation may resume and that interest rates may rise again - despite the recent drop in rates paid on long-term corporation bonds. **********Higher interest rates hurt stocks because they lift the return on bonds, which compete with stocks for investors' money. **********Fund managers also remain concerned about the outcome of the Presidential election, Mr. Conlon said. Only when institutional investors' fears are allayed, he said, will the rally resume. **********'Extraordinarily Confusing' **********''This has been one of the most extraordinarily confusing times economically for investors in recent history,'' Mr. Conlon said. ''Investors are trying to sort out answers to a whole host of questions.'' **********Investors appeared to be far from a consensus yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 13 points in the morning, was ahead 9 points in the afternoon and then steadily lost ground to eke out its small gain for the day. **********Other indicators also reflected a wait-and-see attitude among investors. The exchange's composite index, for example, ended the day down 0.02 at 93.43, while Standard & Poor's 500- stock index closed at 162.71, up 0.11. **********Biggest Winners **********Among the biggest winners on the Big Board was the Digital Equipment Corporation, which rose 3, to close at 96 1/4. The big maker of electronic equipment reported a large increase in fourth-quarter earnings. **********The Carnation Company, whose price has been rising amid takeover rumors, finished the day at 66 1/8, up 4 1/8. A company spokesman, however, said there were no developments yesterday that would explain the stock's movement. **********The biggest percentage winner on the Big Board was the Orange Company Inc., a maker of citrus products, which rose 2 1/8, to 12 3/8. **********Auto Makers Advance **********Among the most actively traded issues, the Big Three auto makers continued to perform impressively. Ford closed at 45 5/8, up 1 1/8; General Motors ended at 75 5/8, up 1 1/8; and Chrysler finished at 30 3/8, up 5/8. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index fell 0.47, to 204.55. Hasbro Industries rose 4 3/8, to 58. The company had no comment, but analysts said traders who had borrowed shares of the stock to sell them were now buying up the issue to return those borrowed. **********In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index was off 0.18, to 249.09.
