https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/11/busin.body_text: **********The United States and the world's other leading democracies are likely to call for a new international monetary conference similar to the one that led to the Bretton Woods agreement 40 years ago, a senior Reagan Administration official said today. **********''We are building toward a monetary conference in the mid-eighties,'' probably in 1986, the official said. **********Such a conference would consider abandoning the present system, which lets nations' currencies and exchange rates fend for themselves in the world markets, and subject them instead to international control. **********The official, a leader of the American delegation to the seven-nation summit conference that closed here yesterday, insisted on not being named. **********He discussed monetary reform during a review of the summit conference over breakfast with reporters at his suite in a London hotel. **********The official's comment goes far beyond statements in the summit communique on monetary issues. According to other summit participants, there was little discussion of such issues here. Because of the dollar's strength and volatility, currency questions have occupied the major industrial countries for more than two years. **********Scheduling a major monetary-reform conference, which French President Francois Mitterrand has sought for years, has been impossible without American participation because of the power of the American economy and the key role of the dollar. **********The American official's comment, however, does not mean that the Reagan Administration supports a radical change in currency-management policies. But it does signal a softening of the Administration's view that currencies and exchange rates are better managed by the marketplace than by laws and institutions. **********On related summit issues, the official said an agreement expressed in the communique to ''continue to act together'' to assure adequate oil supplies reflected an informal, but unstated, agreement to stay out of the spot oil market. Doing so, he said, would avert the hoarding and panic buying that worsened the shortages during the oil crises of the 1970's and forced prices above those set by the Middle Eastern oil-producing countries. **********The official also belittled some of the statements in the communique issued by the seven nations at the close of their conference, especially those statements endorsing easier payment terms for developing-country debtors. **********The summit countries agreed to encourage commercial banks and their own financing agencies to extend the payment terms on loans to countries that have succeeded in strengthening their own economies. Such multiyear reschedulings of debts, many of which are one- and two-year loans, would reduce the annual payment burdens. **********Providing such terms, however, would require substantial changes in the regulations governing American commercial banks. These banks, unlike those in Europe, are held to tight schedules of quarterly reporting, and losses on nonperforming loans must be disclosed sooner than is required in other countries. **********The other summit countries, the official said, argued that the regulations, and not the the performance of the borrowers, create false payment crises. **********''We said we'd point this problem out to our regulators,'' the Washington official said. Nevertheless, he defended the regulations. The quarterly reporting requirements, he said, have helped prevent failures like the one that the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company faced last month. **********Other people in the Administration seem less skeptical of the multiyear rescheduling proposal. George P. Shultz, Secretary of State, an economist and a former Treasury Secretary, said at a news briefing Saturday night, ''I think it's fundamentally a proper idea.'' **********Critical of Debt Conversion **********The official who met with reporters this morning raised questions about another summit statement, one that supported conversion of some short- term loans to the developing world into longer-term debt for investors to add to their portfolios. **********''Who's going to buy that lousy debt?'' he asked. He said the United States had opposed the proposal but was been voted down, 6 to 1. **********Some economists say that many of the problems related to third-world debt - currency exchange rates, interest rates and trade - could be prevented by a reform of the monetary system similar in dimension to the one that was agreed upon at Bretton Woods, N.H., in 1944 but different in detail. **********At the summit conference just ended here, the leaders of the seven participating countries - the United States, Britain, West Germany, France, Italy, Japan and Canada - urged their finance ministers to press ahead with studies into monetary reform. **********At last year's conference in Williamsburg, Va., the Reagan Administration opposed even undertaking the studies but went along to appease President Mitterrand, who insists that the volatility of the dollar is linked to the debt crisis. At a meeting of finance ministers last month, the Administration succeeded in delaying completiton of such studies, initially expected at the London conference, until next May. **********Accord at Bretton Woods **********But the problems are such now that the Administration has begun to look in the same direction as France and the developing countries for solutions. **********The Bretton Woods agreement established order in world trade and the values of major currencies by linking them to the dollar and the value of the dollar to the value of gold, which was fixed at $32 an ounce. **********By the 1960's the system was proving too rigid for countries to handle. As inflation spread and imbalances in countries' trade developed, governments would announce huge devaluations of their currencies. Finally, in August 1971, President Nixon ended the dollar's convertibility into gold, which removed a standard and left currencies free to find their own levels in the marketplace. **********Since then, the United States and Japan have allowed their currencies to float, while most of the leading European nations have adopted a system that allows exchange rates to float but only within narrow limits. **********But the free-floating dollar plays havoc with the world monetary system. Because each of the currencies are linked, the dollar tends to push them all up or down when it rises or falls in relation to just one. **********What worries other countries more than the strength of the dollar is its volatility and the certainty, in many economists' view, that it must fall back into line with other currencies. The turmoil that accompanies a sharply falling or rising currency troubles a nation as much as an overvalued but stable currency. **********So a conference on monetary reform, in these countries' view, could eliminate the linking and could stablize the currency markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/06/world.main_headline: UNESCO REPORTED TO MOVE AWAY FROM ISSUE OF LICENSING REPORTERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/06/world.print_headline: UNESCO REPORTED TO MOVE AWAY FROM ISSUE OF LICENSING REPORTERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/06/world.body_text: **********A longtime critic of the communications policies of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization said yesterday that the agency's Director General had sent him a statement of Unesco policy that represents a ''significant shift'' away from involvement with the issue of licensing journalists. **********The letter comes only weeks before President Reagan is scheduled to review his decision to withdraw the United States from Unesco as of Jan. 1, 1985. When he announced the decision last December, Mr. Reagan said it was subject to change if Unesco made changes this year in areas such as management and its policies on the free flow of information. **********The policy statement was contained in a letter dated Oct. 20 from Amadou- Mahtar M'Bow, Director General of Unesco, to Leonard R. Sussman, executive director of Freedom House, which has monitored Unesco policies on the press. **********In the letter, Mr. M'Bow described guidelines for a policy that, according to Mr. Sussman, would seem to rule out Unesco sponsorship or financing for meetings on the working conditions or safety of journalists - subjects considered by many Western press organizations to include the licensing issue - unless asked to do so by ''all parties concerned,'' including the Western press.   Defusing Criticism **********Mr. Sussman, who has been a critic of Unesco's communications policies for many years, said he viewed Mr. M'Bow's letter as ''categorically'' leaving such issues to professional organizations of journalists, thus defusing part of the criticism that has been leveled at Unesco. **********Mr. M'Bow's statement was a response to a letter from Mr. Sussman about Unesco's possible involvement as a sponsor or source of financing for a journalists' conference scheduled to be held in Mexico City in March. The planned meeting has been denounced by several Western news organizations, including the American Newspaper Publishers Association, as a likely forum for promoting the licensing of journalists. **********But some other journalists and Government officials expressed reservations about the precise meaning of the guidelines in Mr. M'Bow's letter. **********''It's possibly encouraging, but falls short of setting every fear to rest,'' said Dana Bullen, executive director of the World Press Freedom Committee, which has also monitored the Unesco debate on the press. Mr. Bullen noted that the letter did not explicitly state that Unesco would not take part in any way - as an observer, perhaps - or provide any financing for the Mexico City meeting.   Broad Concept **********Many Western news organizations view licensing as a means of exerting government control on journalists and the flow of information under the guise of improving safety conditions for journalists. The issue has come to be associated with a ''new world information order,'' a broad concept that includes increasing technical and professional assistance to developing nations. **********According to Doudou Diene, a Unesco spokesman in New York, the statement by Mr. M'Bow was an ''important clarification'' of Unesco policy, but was not a change in policy. Mr. Diene added that it was hoped by Mr. M'Bow that the ''clarification'' would ''have an impact on the press perception of what Unesco is.'' **********The proposed meeting in Mexico City has become an important test of Unesco's attitude regarding communications issues, according to Gregory J. Newell, an Assistant Secretary of State whose area of responsibility includes the Unesco withdrawal. **********The meeting is being sponsored by five organizations: the Prague-based International Organization of Journalists; the Latin American Federation of Journalists, which is described by Mr. Bullen as the sister organization to the Prague-based group; the Brussels- based International Federation of Journalists; the International Catholic Journalists Union, and the Union of African Journalists.   Meeting in Geneva **********A group including the sponsoring organizations met in June in Geneva to discuss the feasibility of a conference on ''working conditions,'' and, according to Mr. Diene, Unesco representatives were there only as observers. Unesco did provide $10,000 to finance the meeting, according to Mr. Diene, but not directly. Each year, Unesco gives $10,000 to the Consultative Committee of Unions of Journalists, Mr. Diene said, and it was the committee's decision to use the money for the Geneva meeting. **********At a later meeting in Prague in late September, no Unesco representatives took part, and Unesco provided no financing for the meeting, according to Mr. Diene. **********But the official minutes of that meeting indicate that the participants were anticipating significant financing for the proposed conference from Unesco. The minutes refer to contributions from Unesco of $20,000 for working papers, $20,000 for travel of participants and up to $10,000 for a meeting of working journalists to take place at the same time as the conference.   Statement Last Month **********Challenged on the apparent contradiction, Mr. M'Bow issued a statement in early October that ''Unesco's program does not include the organization of such a conference and its budget does not provide for any financial support for it.'' **********In his letter to Mr. Sussman, Mr. M'Bow expanded on the earlier statement, declaring that ''all parties concerned with the working conditions of journalists should participate in any undertaking in this field'' and mentions ''publishers, broadcasters and news agency'' representatives. This marks the first time such guidelines have been so explicit, Mr. Sussman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/busin.main_headline: ALLOWING BOND OWNERS TO REMAIN ANONYMOUS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/busin.print_headline: ISSUE AND DEBATE; ALLOWING BOND OWNERS TO REMAIN ANONYMOUS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/busin.body_text: **********The Treasury Department, exploring new ways to reduce the cost of financing the nation's huge debt, is considering reviving bearer bonds to elicit greater demand from foreign investors who have a penchant for anonymity. **********Such a change would come a year after Congress, seeking to curb tax evasion, outlawed the issuance of bearer bonds in the United States by requiring that all securities be registered in the owner's name. **********With bearer bonds, no record of ownership is listed on the certificate or maintained by the issuer. Holders of the bonds are presumed to be the owners. On presenting the certificates to an issuer or paying agent, the holders are entitled to receive interest and principal payments without identification. The Treasury has not issued bonds in bearer form since the 1960's, a spokesman said. **********New Tax Bill **********But the $50 billion tax bill aproved last month by Congress and awaiting President Reagan's signature gives the Government and corporations new authority to issue bonds in bearer form - provided they are sold only to foreign investors with safeguards to prevent them from falling into the hands of American tax evaders. **********Investment bankers believe that selling bearer bonds overseas could save the Treasury money in financing the Federal deficit because many foreign investors are willing to accept a lower interest rate if they are able to buy securities without revealing their identity. **********But concerns have been expressed about whether it is appropriate for the Government to depart from its longstanding practice of requiring its bonds to be registered with the owner's name at a time when the Administration and Congress have escalated efforts to curb American tax evasion and solicited the cooperation of other nations. **********The BackgroundThe Treasury, whose borrowing needs have been swollen by giant budget deficits, has been taking a close look at overseas markets, where bonds can often be sold at lower rates than in America. Despite their worldwide reputation as the safest and most liquid securities, United States Government bonds have not sold as well abroad as their reputation would suggest. **********The reasons, according to investment bankers and Treasury officials, is that American bonds now carry a 30 percent withholding tax on interest paid to foreign investors and require buyers to reveal their identity. Bonds sold by many other governments and corporations carry no tax and can be bought in anonymity. **********While Government bond sales may have been inhibited by the tax and registration requirements, American corporations were able to take advantage of the lower financing rate available overseas by issuing bonds through offshore tax havens, where the tax was effectively eliminated and bonds could be sold in bearer form.   Changes for Foreign Investors **********The new tax bill, however, would eliminate the 30 percent withholding tax on new bond issues sold to foreign investors and allow the bonds to be issued in bearer form. The Treasury was assigned the responsibility of drafting regulations to govern the sale of bearer securities with safeguards to prevent their sale or resale to Americans. But the Treasury was also given the authority to bar the issuance of bearer bonds. **********According to a senior Treasury official, the agency has to decide whether to permit issuers to sell bearer bonds, how the issues could be sold, and whether the Treasury itself should issue bearer bonds. **********The discussions center on the financial prospect of being able to borrow overseas at lower rates, versus the concerns that bearer bonds will provide a new means for Americans to evade taxes and for foreign investors to launder money overseas and evade their own country's taxes. **********For Bearer BondsBy most accounts, the Government would reap savings on its borrowing costs by selling tax-exempt bonds overseas. By doing so, this should help ease pressures on interest rates in the United States, where the Government's huge borrowing needs have helped keep interest rates high. **********But most investment bankers believe that for the Government to successfully market its bonds overseas and reap the greatest savings, the bonds must be tailored to the market. Even with the 30 percent wihholding tax eliminated, investment bankers familiar with the market say that many investors will be deterred from buying American bonds if they are required to reveal their identities.  ''We don't make markets, we just respond to them,'' asserted Stuart McFarland, chief financial officer of the Federal National Mortgage Association, a quasi-Federal agency that is eager to sell some of its $40 billion a year in debt obligations overseas. ''The only way you can sell debt in Europe is in bearer form.'' **********H.J. Runnion Jr., the chairman of a Government securities dealers advisory group to the Treasury, said that issuing bearer bonds would open new markets. ''There are certain investors that insist on anonymity and just won't buy registered securities,'' said Mr. Runnion, who is also chief financial officer of the Wachovia Bank and Trust Company of Winston-Salem, N.C. ''But just how big a group that is, I couldn't tell you.'' **********Proponents contend that restrictions can be placed on the method of sale and payment of interest on the bearer bonds to limit the number of bearer bonds outstanding and make it difficult for them to fall into the hands of Americans seeking to evade taxes. **********Further, even Treasury officials have noted that there are already so many other opportunities for Americans intent on evading taxes to do so, that the withholding-tax repeal and the issuance of bearer bonds is unlikely to increase evasion. **********Against Bearer BondsMany in Congress worry that if few limits are placed on the issuance of bearer securities, tax evasion will increase sharply. They contend that Americans would have the opportunity to buy the bonds through secret bank accounts abroad or by otherwise posing as a foreigner. Since the tax would no longer be withheld for foreign investors, an American buyer posing as a foreigner could evade taxes by not reporting the interest income, and the Internal Revenue Service would have no records to trace. **********Further, there is concern that bearer securities would increase tax evasion in other countries, since there would be no record of the foreign investor's income for other governments to trace. This, critics contend, could thwart American efforts to win the cooperation of foreign governments in helping curb tax evasion by American citizens. **********''It would be undermining the enormous progress we've made in the last four or five years on tax compliance,'' said Peter Barash, staff director of the House subcommittee of Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs. ''The United States would join several other countries as among the worst tax havens in the world.'' **********While many foreign governments also issue bearer bonds to be sold outside their borders, Mr. Barash questions whether the United States should contribute to the international flow of illegal money that can readily be laundered through bearer securities. ''Even if other countries issue bearer bonds, it wouldn't necessarily make it right for the United States to do it,'' said Mr. Barash. **********Importance Questioned **********From a financial point of view, there is uncertainty about how important the bearer form really is to foreign investors, and thus how much more savings could be reaped. **********''It's perceived to be a big, big, big deal,'' said Nicholas Rey, managing director of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. But, he said, big overseas institutional investors are generally not concerned about registration requirements. And, he said, many foreign investors have lived with registration requirements in their own countries for years and may not find the bearer form important. **********Further, by selling a separate bearer class of bonds strictly from overseas points, there is the concern that the market for Government bonds would be less liquid since there would, in effect, be two segmented trading markets - one overseas and one in the United States. **********OutlookTreasury officials say they expect to announce a decision later this month or in early August. One Treasury official indicated that bearer securities probably would be permitted. But he said the questions about how they could be sold and whether the Government itself would sell bearer bonds are still unresolved. **********Doug Barnard Jr., Democrat of Georgia and chairman of the House Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs subcommittee, said his committee would hold hearings if the Treasury regulations do not contain adequate safeguards to prevent the tax-free debt obligations from being sold to United States taxpayers ''masquerading as foreigners.'' **********In a letter sent last week to the I.R.S. Commissioner, Roscoe L. Egger Jr., Mr. Barnard expressed concern over reports that the Treasury may be willing to ''sacrifice hard- won tax-compliance gains'' achieved by Congress and the Administration in recent years ''to faciliate the marketability to foreign persons of U.S. Treasury and corporate debt obligations.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/13/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union said today that the successful testing by the United States of a ballistic missile interceptor was a step toward ''the militarization of outer space.'' **********The official press agency Tass said the interceptor system is intended as ''one of the elements of a multitier defense system which would guarantee a high effectiveness of antiballistic missile defense'' and would include space- based systems. **********''The United States has made yet another step along the lines of the militarization of outer space,'' the agency said. **********Tass was referring to the successful test of an experimental United States Army system that uses an interceptor to ram a ballistic missile head-on and destroy it before it can reach its target.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/31/world.body_text: **********Two Government ministers said today that the Dominican Republic would have faced full- scale civil strife last week if it had agreed to demands from the International Monetary Fund to raise the price of gasoline and other oil products as a condition for new loans. **********Foreign Minister Jose Augusto Vega and Economic Planning Minister L. Orlando Haza recalled that civil strife resulted in late April when the Government bowed to another set of demands by the fund - to raise food prices sharply. About 60 people were killed and hundreds were left injured. **********The two ministers were interviewed at Santo Domingo Airport on their way to El Salvador for the inauguration ceremonies for that country's President-elect, Jose Napoleon Duarte, who is to be sworn in on Friday. **********Mr. Vega said he expected to meet Secretary of State George P. Shultz at the ceremonies. He said he would tell Mr. Shultz, ''Our problem is a common problem for the democracies in the region.''  Shultz's Intercession Sought **********The Minister said he would ask the Secretary of State to use his influence with the I.M.F.'s managing director, Jacques de Larosi ere, to apply conditions less rigidly. **********On Friday President Salvador Jorge Blanco suspended negotiations with the fund after its delegation in Santo Domingo insisted on termination of Government subsidies on oil products as a condition for a second installment of a $430 million, three-year loan. **********Ending the subsidies would have tripled the price of gasoline from the present levels of slightly more than 70 cents a gallon. **********''The whole country asked the Government not to do it,'' Mr. Haza said. ''Labor groups. Almost all the political groups. The church. The Chamber of Deputies passed a resolution not to increase the prices.''  Graffiti on Walls **********The anger is seen in some of the graffiti on walls in poverty-stricken neighborhoods around Santo Domingo. The slogans can be summed up as ''I.M.F. get out of the country.'' **********(A spokesman for President Jorge Blanco announced that the Government had ordered a 25 percent cutback in Government fuel use and imposed other austerity measures, The Associated Press reported. It said the new directives also called for a suspension of most official travel abroad, the banning of weekend and off-duty use of official vehicles and an order that public buildings be left dark at night and street lights turned off in the early dawn. **********(The President was also reported to have ordered the administrator of the Government-owned Dominican Electricity Corporation to study the establishment of a nationwide energy conservation plan and to have named a special committee to prepare a cost-reducing plan for the public sector, The Associated Press said.).  Mr. Haza, the Economic Planning Minister, said that the quest for better terms from the I.M.F. did not mean ''that we are unwilling to put our house in order. It means that we want to keep our house and not let it go up in flames.'' **********The Economic Planning Minister added that ''I think we faced full-scale civil strife'' if the Government had met the I.M.F. demands and not listened to the internal protests. **********However, he acknowledged that the suspension of negotiations with the I.M.F. has cut off practically all new loans to the country.   Commercial Loans Triggered **********When the I.M.F. approves credit for a country, commercial bank loans for much larger amounts than the amount borrowed from the I.M.F. are usually triggered. **********In this case, Mr. Haza said, the only fresh money coming into the country now will be from a $50 million loan from the Inter-American Development Bank to help finance industrial imports and raw materials. **********Because of low prices for the sugar, cocoa, coffee, and tobacco that it sells abroad, the Dominican Republic is running a heavy deficit in trade accounts. **********The country owes about $2 billion to foreign creditors. **********''We feel that the only way we can pay is if we produce - not if we get into a deep depression,'' said Mr. Haza. **********''The I.M.F. has its rules,'' he continued. ''The I.M.F. mission could not accept anything that went beyond the rules. We feel the rules have to be changed at the top.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/28/busin.body_text: **********BEhind the tumultuous debate on acid rain lies a key public policy question: Should the nation incur the enormous economic and social costs of another major reduction in sulfur dioxide emissions to deal in an uncertain way with a problem that is neither widespread nor health threatening and that does not appear to be getting worse? **********The acid rain debate started with the hypothesis that sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-fired electric utility plants in the Middle West mix in the atmosphere to produce highly acidic rainfall in the Northeast and Canada, ultimately rendering some lakes incapable of supporting fish life. Later, it was argued that acidity was more widespread and potential problems were cited in the South, in high Rocky Mountain lakes and in the Los Angeles basin. More recently, acid rain has been blamed for dying forests in parts of this country and West Germany. Whatever the environmental problem, the prescribed cure never varies:legislation to place strict new controls on coal-fired plants. **********During the past four years, intensive research on acid rain has been conducted by the National Academy of Sciences, the Environmental Protection Agency, universities and hundreds of individual scientists. The findings have been far from conclusive. Sulfur dioxide emissions in the Middle West have not been proven to contribute significantly to lake and stream acidity. Nitrogen oxides and ozone - the primary emissions from automobiles - and not sulfur dioxide, have been identified as the most likely suspects in the few observed instances of forest decline. No evidence supports the hypothesis that acid precipitation is endangering either crops or human health. Local sources of pollution, rather than distant emissions, are the more likely culprit in damage to certain kinds of materials. **********Despite the lack of even a credible scientific basis for legislation, Congress is still being asked to decide whether to impose costly new controls to further ratchet down emissions or to continue our current course under the Clean Air Act. The most often ignored or least appreciated aspect of the acid rain debate is that the United States has implemented the world's most effective air quality management program. **********As a result of the Clean Air Act, **********nearly every county in the country currently meets the standards set to protect people's health. Total sulfur dioxide emissions fell 26 percent between 1973 - the peak year - and 1983. Electric power plant emissions alone were down 17 percent although coal use grew by 53 percent. The cost of this effort have been equally impressive. According to the E.P.A., the capital, operating and maintenance costs to comply with existing Federal air pollution control standards on electric utilities totaled $20.9 billion between 1970 and 1978, about $2.9 billion a year. For the next three years, 1979-81, we spent another $21 billion, about $7 billion a year. Over the following eight years, 1982- 90, another $88.3 billion, or about $11 billion a year in 1981 dollars, will have been spent. **********THE call for acid rain control legislation, requiring additional sulfur dioxide reductions of 10 to 12 million tons a year in 31 eastern states, must be considered against this backdrop of solid progress. Proponents would impose additional costs totaling hundreds of billions of dollars in hopes of attaining by 1995 what the current Clean Air Act will achieve by 2010. Furthermore, the effectiveness of the proposed legislation is uncertain. Researchers at M.I.T. have estimated it would produce a barely measurable change in the acidity of the problem areas. **********Nevertheless, there are those in the Congress ready to impose such controls. The so-called Waxman/Sikorski bill, calling for a 10 million-ton reduction in sulfur dioxide by 1995 from 1980 levels will cost $7.9 billion a year. And this is on top of what we will be paying under current law. Furthermore, the costs are unequally distributed throughout various states. **********Efforts to spread the costs through a fund derived from a national tax on electricity generation have not proved popular. In the states that would receive the most money from such a fund, compliance costs would be reduced 25 percent, but they still would pay higher costs than other states. Finally, other areas of the country that consider themselves removed from the controversy, such as the West, are reluctant to participate in the scheme. **********It is precisely this sort of haggling that has stymied acid rain control legislation. **********Much more cost-effective and proven methods are available to remedy the observed effects of acidity in the environment. For instance, the total cost of liming the fishless acidic lakes in the Adirondacks - to neutralize the acid - is approximately $1 million. The liming would have to be repeated every few years to maintain acceptable balance, but the results would be certain and the cost far less than that of acid rain control legislation. **********When Congress returns, newer members will realize that the call for acid rain controls is little more than a facade for imposing drastically tightened emission limits. They will also realize that the costs are great and certain, while the benefits are small, uncertain and attainable through cheaper means.  Veterans of past Clean Air Act debates will recognize the issue as another effort to shunt the nation onto the road of severely constrained economic growth, a road whose byways would be littered with the debris of shattered hopes and stillborn jobs. **********Carl E. Bagge is president of the National Coal Association in Washington.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/28/busin.main_headline: Market Place; The Capital Spending Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/28/busin.print_headline: Market Place; The Capital Spending Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/28/busin.body_text: **********WHILE many sectors of the stock market face an uncertain future, a developing boom in capital spending means that selected suppliers of new plant and equipment stand to enjoy increased sales and profits. ''This is the time, fundamentally, to focus on capital spending,'' the First Boston Corporation said recently. **********Commenting on this growth in business investment, the Merrill Lynch Market Letter said: ''Inflation-adjusted spending in the final quarter of 1983 jumped almost 13 percent from the year- earlier period and a gain of 16 percent appears likely to occur in the first quarter of this year.'' **********For all of 1984, economists at Merrill Lynch forecast a 12 percent increase in capital spending, which would mark the sharpest recovery since 1966, when expenditures rose 13 percent. **********This spending boom is being fed by prospects for improved earnings and increased cash flow in a variety of companies. Meanwhile, the nation's plant utilization rate has climbed to around 80 percent - a level that encourages outlays for new factories and equipment. **********In the current economic cycle, the main spending thrust has centered on technology stocks, according to John R. Groome, senior vice president of the United States Trust Company. ''International Business Machines is king of the hill in this regard,'' he said, ''but other beneficiaries range from Perkin-Elmer, Teradyne Inc. and Cipher Data Products to National Data and Hewlett-Packard.'' First Boston said its primary recommendation in capital spending, ''assuming a stable market,'' would be Caterpillar Tractor. Caterpillar lost money in 1982 and 1983, following a string of highly profitable years. It is described by Standard & Poor's as the largest manufacturer of earthmoving machinery and equipment, as well as a major producer of diesel and natural gas engines and turbines. **********''Within the current cycle, Caterpillar is projected to earn $3 a share in 1984, all in the second half,'' according to First Boston. ''For 1985, the current earnings estimate of between $6 and $7 a share could prove low by $1 to $2 a share if the economic recovery continues. As Caterpillar traditionally sells on future earnings expectations, especially coming out of a recession, now is the time to buy the stock.'' **********When First Boston recommended Caterpillar in mid-March, the stock was selling at 49. Yesterday, on the New York Stock Exchange, it eased 1/8, to 50. On Monday, the stock traded as high as 50 3/4, equaling its highest price over the last 52 weeks. **********Both Caterpillar and Joy Manufacturing appear on the recommended list at Oppenheimer & Company. Within the capital goods industry, Oppenheimer accords an even higher rating to Cummins Engine and Kennametal Inc., which are carried on the firm's emphasis list, as well as its recommended list. **********Insights, a market advisory letter written by Justin Mamis, has recommended both Caterpillar and the Harnischfeger Corporation, chiefly because of prospective expenditures in road construction. Harnischfeger has lost money in its last two fiscal years. Mr. Mamis also favors certain cement stocks. **********The recovery in capital spending was initially centered in the military sector along with high technology. Meanwhile, Merrill Lynch points out that the pattern of increased business investment has broadened to include virtually every area except petroleum, aviation, and marine and railroad equipment. **********''We look for sales of producers' durable equipment to be especially strong in 1984, rising nearly 16 percent,'' the firm said. ''We think the accelerating pace of capital spending will insure several good years of profits growth for producers of capital goods. **********''Rising order rates and expanding backlogs suggest that these companies will be well situated to ride out any temporary slowdown in economic growth that may develop toward the end of 1985.'' **********Accordingly, the firm's market letter has selected four issues it regards as ''particularly attractive.'' One recommendation is Clark Equipment, a leading manufacturer of materials-handling equipment - primarily forklift trucks - as well as construction equipment, axles and transmissions. **********Another recommendation is the Dover Corporation, which makes machinery and equipment used in the building, petroleum and other industries. Rounding out the four stocks are Parker Hannifin, whose hydraulic and fluid power components are used in a variety of industrial products, and Rexnord Inc., a broadly diversified manufacturer of industrial machinery, components and fasteners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/29/world.main_headline: NICARAGUAN INSURGENT GROUP STAGES RALLY IN NEW ORLEANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/29/world.print_headline: NICARAGUAN INSURGENT GROUP STAGES RALLY IN NEW ORLEANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/29/world.body_text: **********Nicaraguan insurgent leaders, seeking support for their United States-backed military effort against the Government in Managua, held a rally today in the central business district here. **********It was part of a weekend conference described as ''the first national meeting'' of the Honduran-based Nicaraguan Democratic Force. The meeting began Friday night at the new Sheraton Hotel in downtown New Orleans. **********The Democratic Force is the largest of three insurgent groups. The others are the Democratic Revolutionary Alliance, based in Costa Rica, and Misura, an organization of Miskito, Sumo and Rama Indians. **********More than 100 Nicaraguan activists from across the United States gathered at the conference to hear progress reports on their military struggle, to discuss ways to generate political support, and to talk to reporters about their need for help in Congress.   Support for Reagan **********The rally and parade of several hundred people, whose theme was support for President Reagan's policies in Central America, began on Canal Street beside a monument to Simon Bolivar, who led South America's struggle for independence from Spain. **********Before noon, while the anti-Sandinistas were ending a committee meeting, a counterdemonstration began. The counterdemonstrators, carrying signs reading ''Contras are C.I.A. puppets'' and chanting ''U.S. out, U.S. out now,'' consolidated their forces for television cameras and then moved across the street. **********Neither group attracted much more than a glance from the passing crowds of Saturday shoppers. **********The counterdemonstrators moved on, and several hundred Central Americans and others, some carrying Reagan-Bush signs, marched in the blazing sun to the Spanish Plaza. **********In the address that opened the conference last night, the leader of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, Adolfo Calero Portocarrero, said: ''The purpose of this first meeting is for all of us to come together and exchange ideas with the objective of informing the people in this country and to have them also project this information to the people in their own states.''  The Rebels' Purpose **********Mr. Calero was speaking to an audience including local residents and Nicaraguans who had traveled here from New York, New Jersey, California, Texas, Florida and Washington. He said the purpose of the rebels' fight is ''not to win a military victory'' but ''to force the Sandinista Government to fulfill the commitment made to democracy or to resign or step aside and give back the people their sovereignty.'' **********He said the insurgents had ''started out gradually and were able to grow inside the country.'' **********''From a very few we have grown to 8,000 combatants inside Nicaragua and 2,000 volunteers who are now in the process of being armed and trained,'' he said. ''Pretty soon our army will be made up of 10,000 soldiers and more coming.'' **********He spoke of recent military victories, ''75 confrontations during March'' and ''a proportionate share in April,'' and added, ''We have inflicted a heavy number of casualties to the Sandinista Army and the army has been showing signs of being tired.'' **********He said the Sandinista Army had shown ''a lack of discipline and lack of morale, while on the other hand, our soldiers are in the best shape they've ever been.'' **********In response to a New Orleans reporter's question about the organization's mining of Nicaraguan waters, Mr. Calero shook his head and answered, ''Really, mining was a minuscule part of this war.'' **********He said: ''Our mines haven't killed one single person, but they have curtailed the flow of Soviet arms into Nicaragua. I would say that the mining of Nicaraguan ports saved lives becaase it prevented the flow of Soviet arms. **********''The uproar that has been raised'' over the mining, he said, ''we consider was more a political confrontation than a moral uproar.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/08/world.print_headline: 8 Injured as Striking Miners Clash With Police in London
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/08/world.body_text: **********Surging crowds of striking miners and their supporters battled the police outside the House of Commons today. The police said 8 people were injured and 120 were arrested. **********Later, in a victory for the National Union of Mineworkers, leaders of Britain's two million transport and steel workers called on union drivers to halt fuel deliveries to power stations and steel works. **********Truck drivers have ignored previous such urgings, and it was not immediately clear how effective the newest call for support would be. **********Thousands of protesters snarled traffic in central London during a march to Parliament, which was debating the 13- week strike triggered by the coal board's plan to close 20 unprofitable mines at a cost of 20,000 jobs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/26/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; PRIVATE ANNUITIES FOR DO-IT-YOURSELFERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/26/busin.body_text: **********MENTION the word ''annuity'' and most people yawn and think of insurance companies, the usual source of such payments. Yet annuity agreements can also be drawn up among private parties and can be a potent tool for reducing income and estate taxes. They are, in essence, quid pro quo arrangements that allow elderly individuals to shift the ownership and management of substantial assets to younger relatives while keeping the family wealth within the family. **********''A private annuity is kind of a super gimmick, but it isn't for just anyone,'' said Julian S. Bush, partner in charge of the estate planning department at the New York City law firm of Shea & Gould. While such arrangements are not common, they can be very useful for people with sizable assets whose heirs are likely to face a large estate tax bill. A private annuity is ''simply a sale of property in exchange for an annuity,'' said Mr. Bush, but because of many uncertainties about the economics of the transaction it is also ''a piece of very aggressive tax planning.'' **********While the mechanics of a private annuity are complex, the basic idea is simple. A person called the annuitant, often an elderly person such as a parent, transfers ownership of appreciated property such as stock, real estate or an interest in a closely held business to a person called the obligor, typically a younger relative such as a child. In return, the child promises to make periodic payments to the parent for the rest of the parent's life. ''Generally, it's a one-shot transaction between private parties who normally don't write annuities,'' according to Prentice-Hall, a publisher of tax materials for professionals. **********As long as the parent completely divests himself or herself of all interest in the transferred property, the property is not included in the parent's estate. If, for example, a mother transfers stock worth $200,000 to her only son in return for a lifetime annuity, $200,000 would be removed from her gross estate, even if the stock had cost her only $50,000. In effect, the arrangement ''freezes'' the value of the transferred property, so that all future appreciation of the property is removed from the parent's estate as well. **********Moreover, the mother can transfer the large block of stock to her son without incurring a gift tax as long as the present value of the annuity - that is, the value in today's dollars of the mother's right to receive the payments in the future - equals the value of the transferred property. Outright gifts, by contrast, escape gift tax only if their value is $10,000 or less. **********The value of the annuity is determined by actuarial tables drawn up by the Internal Revenue Service and depends upon the annuitant's age; the older the annuitant, the larger the payments that must be made. **********A private annuity can be particularly helpful in cases where the parent does not expect to live as long as the average life expectancy built into the I.R.S. tables. Prentice-Hall gives the example of Susan, a 50-year-old widow who is very ill and does not expect to live as long as the tables predict. So she transfers $200,000 of property to her only child, Rosella, in return for a yearly annuity of $15,900. (New actuarial tables proposed by the I.R.S., however, would require a larger annuity payment.) Susan then dies a year later. **********Since Susan dies only a year after making the transfer, Rosella's payments end much earlier than projected in the actuarial tables. ''In effect, Rosella received $200,000 of property in exchange for a single payment of $15,900,'' commented Prentice-Hall. **********However, it warned that a parent who is very ill should not wait too long before setting up a private annuity. If death is ''clearly imminent'' - say, likely to occur in less than a year - the I.R.S. may not permit the use of its estate and gift tables to value the annuity and may instead treat part of the transaction as a taxable gift. **********Another advantage of a private annuity is that the annual payments received by the parent may well lower his or her income tax bill. The reason is that part of the payment is considered a tax-free return of capital, representing the parent's original cost of the transferred property prorated over the parent's life expectancy. **********The rest of the payment is taxable as capital gains on the appreciated property, ordinary income, or both, depending on individual circumstances. But the parent does not have to pay the entire capital gains tax up front when the property is transferred in a private annuity arrangement; instead, the capital gains are spread out over the parent's life expectancy. **********''The annuitant, in effect, has the benefit of an interest-free Government loan repayable, in periods of inflation, with 'cheaper' dollars,'' said Commerce Clearing House Inc., a tax publisher. Had the annuitant wanted to purchase a commercial annuity from an insurance company instead, it added, he or she would have had to sell the property first, pay capital gains tax on it, and then use whatever proceeds remained to buy the annuity. **********BUT there are several drawbacks to private annuities. For one thing, the parent unconditionally transfers property to the child in return for an unsecured promise that the child will in turn pay the parent a set amount for the rest of his or her life. Thus, the parent's income depends upon the child's trustworthiness and financial security. If the child encounters financial difficulties, the parent may not receive the payments as promised. **********''The private annuity can be useful in selective situations, but a lot depends upon the feelings that the older generation has about the younger generation's ability to make the payments,'' observed Philip T. Temple, a partner in the New York law firm of Prerau & Teitell. **********Moreover, even though annuity payments have an interest element in them, the child making payments to a parent is not permitted to claim an interest deduction for the payments because they are not considered a tax-deductible debt. The net effect is that the child makes the payments with after-tax dollars. **********In addition, if the parent lives longer than his projected life expectancy, the child may wind up paying more for the property - by making annuity payments for a longer period than expected - than he would have, had he bought the property outright. **********For this reason, said Prentice-Hall, the prime candidates for private annuities are individuals with shorter-than-average life expectancies. It noted that the children of such individuals get a ''bargain purchase'' in that their annuity payments are likely to end sooner than the actuarial tables project.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/16/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Needham Is Watching Hamburger Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/16/busin.body_text: **********For Needham, Harper & Steers, with its main bastions in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, the place to watch these days is Washington. The reason is hamburger consumption, especially those at McDonald's. **********In a surprise move a while back, the fast-food giant invited Needham, which had lost the huge McDonald's national account to the Leo Burnett Company, to do advertising for the chain's operation in the Washington- Baltimore area. Whatever Needham did, it must have been spectacular because travelers to that area have praised the results. **********The next caper will be a commercial featuring members of both the Orioles baseball team and the Redskins football team. To make sure the word gets around, local franchisers and journalists will be invited to the filming. Free burgers? Of course.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/24/busin.body_text: **********School districts stung by the recent collapse of two Wall Street securities firms will be given legislative authority to borrow against anticipated property taxes and state aid payments, the Senate and Assembly sponsors of the measure said today. **********The bill is intended to provide cash for payrolls and other expenses of 27 school districts across the state that invested more than $26 million in Lion Capital Group and RTD Securities. Both are small government securities firms that declared bankruptcy this month, freezing the assets that the districts had invested in the firms. **********Arthur J. Kremer, chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee and the principal Democratic sponsor of the legislation, characterized the bill as "a stopgap measure" to ease the "serious cash flow problems" of the affected districts. Repurchase Agreements Involved **********Collectively, the districts invested $21.7 million in repurchase agreements with Lion Capital Group and $4.4 million with RTD Securities. In these repurchase agreements, school districts purchased securities held at a bank selected by the securities firm. The securities were then to be repurchased by the firm at a later specified d date for a higher price, representing interest for the district. **********While school districts already have authority to borrow against state aid payments due within 30 days, the State Education Commissioner, Gordon M. Ambach, said at a special hearing of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee today that some of the districts needed to issue longer-term revenue anticipation notes to meet payrolls over the next several months. **********Bankruptcy proceedings to settle claims against the investment firms "won't be over until the fall," Mr. Ambach said in an interview. **********School district officials said they might have to lay off teachers and other employees if state asistance was not forthcoming. **********Howard Koenig, Superintendent of East Meadown Union Free School District on Long Island, said his district had filed suit against the state, specifically blaming the State Education Department for endorsing National Money Market Services of Irvine, Calif., the broker that steered idle cash held by school districts to Lion Capital, RTD and other small securities firms.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/20/busin.main_headline: Market Place; A Rough Time At Thrift Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/20/busin.print_headline: Market Place; A Rough Time At Thrift Units
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/20/busin.body_text: **********THAT Wall Street adage, ''Let your profits **********ride,'' was apt advice for people who bought **********the stock of the fast-growing Financial Corporation of America in 1980 when it sold for as little as $1.50 a share. Adjusted for splits, the stock soared to a record high of $32.75 in July of last year, just as a speculative market boom reached its peak. **********But the other half of that adage, ''Cut your losses,'' somehow seems harder for many investors to follow. Last week, for some hapless shareowners, stock market losses continued to mount in the holding company of the nation's largest thrift institution. Financial Corporation shares finished Friday at $4.75, their price cut virtually in half from the previous week's close of $9.37 1/2 on the New York Stock Exchange. Early this year the stock traded as high as $24.37 1/2. **********Forced by the Securities and Exchange Commission to revise its accounting methods concerning $2 billion of mortgage-backed securities, the Financial Corporation announced on Wednesday an unanticipated loss of $107.5 million for the quarter ended June 30. This loss is believed to be the largest reported for a single quarter by any American thrift institution. **********Although industry observers consider the Financial Corporation's situation to be unique among thrift units, one analyst said, ''It served to tarnish the group just as the problems at Continental Illinois tarnished all commercial banks.'' **********This was a reference to the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, which once ranked as the nation's seventh-largest bank. Last month the Government put into place a $4.5 billion rescue package for the Continental Illinois Corporation, the holding company for the Chicago bank. **********Suffering mainly from an increase in short-term interest rates, stock prices of thrift institutions have been declining for about a year. Reflecting the developments at the Financial Corporation, the savings and loan group monitored by the Standard & Poor's Corporation fell 12.9 percent in the week ended last Wednesday, in contrast to the six-tenths of 1 percent gain for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. So far this year, the thrift group has dropped 42 percent in value while the S.&P. 500 has edged downward by 1.3 percent. **********On Friday security analysts were divided in their assessment of the thrift sector. ''I've had a sell recommendation on these stocks since March of this year,'' said Jerome I. Baron of the First Boston Corporation. ''I expect interest rates to continue to rise. As a result, I believe the cyclical earnings peak for the thrifts will be the second or third quarter of 1984.'' **********In San Francisco, Allan G. Bortel of Shearson Lehman/American Express took the view that values have been created for certain thrift institutions that are restructuring their balance sheets. His four recommendations are H. F. Ahmanson, Golden West Financial, First Federal Savings and Loan of Arizona and Home Federal Savings and Loan in San Diego. **********The setback in the Financial Corporation's stock, together with the resurfacing concern about the health of financial institutions in general, helped to subdue investor enthusiasm for equities last week. The stock market's recent stampede pulled back, as the Dow Jones industrial average retreated 6.11 points, to 1,211.90. Over the three previous weeks, the indicator had amassed a gain of 116 points, responding primarily to improving prices and declining yields in the bond market. **********Volume on the Big Board contracted to 416.5 million shares last week from the previous week's record of 754.6 million shares. **********Home Depot's Plunge **********On Friday institutional investors served notice once again that they have little tolerance for earnings disappointments. After Home Depot Inc. estimated flat earnings for its quarter ended July 31, money managers rushed for the exits, sending the stock tumbling $6.12 1/2 a share, to $16.12 1/2, on a turnover exceeding 2.5 million shares. **********The Atlanta-based company, which operates a chain of warehouse-type stores selling building materials and home improvement products in the Sun Belt, said that adverse weather conditions last month affected passenger traffic and store sales. **********Pension funds and other institutions own about 43 percent of Home Depot's 24.8 million common shares. A steady increase in institutional ownership previously was reflected in the price of the stock. It went from $1.50 a share in 1981 to a high of $31.75 by mid-1983, adjusted for splits. At one point last year, the stock sold at 77 times earnings. **********But no matter how stock prices fare, market optimists can always find reasons to remain bullish. Last week, in a memo meant for internal use, one professional adviser made this observation: ''For the last two months, brokerage houses have drastically reduced their personnel. This has always been a positive stock market indicator.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/18/busin.body_text: **********Merrill Lynch & Company has begun a grass- roots lobbying effort to overturn a regulation proposed by Federal banking regulators that would limit the availability of insurance on deposits placed by brokers. **********At issue is a regulation, proposed in separate but coordinated actions last month by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, that would sharply curtail the protection those agencies provide for brokered deposits - money raised from financial middlemen rather than from individual investors. **********If the regulations become final, they would deny insurance on deposits in excess of $100,000 placed by any broker at any one insured bank or savings association. **********'Sledgehammer Rule' **********On Feb. 10, Merrill Lynch mailed letters to more than 500,000 of its customers who have purchased certificate of deposits, and urged them to write their Senators and Representatives and, in the words of the letters, ''make them aware that you are against the sledgehammer rule.'' **********The big securities firm has also been trying to recruit other brokerages that have retail customers across the country to join the campaign. At the same time, a number of smaller money brokers are gearing up to wage a lobbying campaign against the proposed regulations. **********Last year, a similar lobbying effort led by commercial banks forced Congress to repeal withholding taxes on dividend and interest payments. **********Although the target of the curb appears to be the small but growing corps of money brokers, the action would make it all but impossible for stockbrokers to offer their customers federally insured certificates of deposits. Offering such certificates would be unwieldy, and perhaps unprofitable, because they would have to be scattered among a large number of banks to absorb all of the funds seeking such investments - possibly more banks than would be interested in the business. **********Stake for F.D.I.C.'s Chairman **********It also appears that the future of William M. Isaac as chairman of the F.D.I.C. may be intertwined with the outcome of the regulatory issue. Mr. Isaac's term expires March 15, and neither the White House nor Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan favors reappointing him to another six-year term, according to an Administration aide who asked not to be named. Secretary Regan, in a rare public difference between financial agencies, opposes the proposed restriction on brokered deposits. Before becoming Secretary of the Treasury, Mr. Regan headed Merrill Lynch. **********The President would like to replace Mr. Isaac with Richard Heldridge, a former California banker who is a director of the United States Export- Import Bank, the aide said. Mr. Heldridge has been interviewed by Secretary Regan and deputy secretary R. T. McNamar.  However, Mr. Isaac, a 40-year-old lawyer and former banker, would like to serve as a lame duck for another year or so, his friends say, in hopes that Congress will enact his proposal to let the F.D.I.C. charge higher deposit insurance premiums to banks that make high-risk loans. **********By law, Mr. Isaac can stay on as long as the Senate has not confirmed a successor. With the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, threatening to bottle up a Heldridge nomination, Mr. Isaac appears to have a chance to stay on, especially if he modifies the brokered deposit rule to the satisfaction of the Treasury. **********Three Other Possibilities **********Others mentioned within the Administration as possible successors to Mr. Isaac are two former Republican Representatives, John H. Rousselot of California and James K. Coyne of Pennsylvania, and Doyle L. Arnold, a senior deputy comptroller of the currency. **********As for the proposed regulation, a Merrill Lynch executive, Edwin H. Hall, director of financial products marketing, said ''we feel strongly about this issue.'' He added that Merrill Lynch has been meeting weekly with representatives from Shearson/ American Express, Dean Witter Reynolds, and Prudential-Bache. **********''We have urged them to make similar appeals to their customers. This is definitely a consumer issue,'' Mr. Hall said. **********Congress is mindful of the analogy to the withholding campaign in 1983. But House Banking Committee aides cautioned that there are significant differences between the withholding and money broker issues. ''The money brokers are not lobbying against legislation, they're lobbying regs,'' said one aide. **********Among smaller brokers, Thomas M. Coan, president of the Federal Insured Savings Network of Washington, said his company plans to make a mass mailing soon to all its customers about the proposed rule. **********''We're financial intermediaries brought on by deregulation, and we hold a valid place in the economy,'' he said, adding: ''This is simply a form of re-regulation.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/16/world.main_headline: Syrian Forces Ordered To Help Find Reporter
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/16/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Syrian Forces Ordered To Help Find Reporter
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/16/world.body_text: **********President Hafez al-Assad has ordered Syrian security forces to help find a Reuters correspondent who disappeared in Lebanon 17 days ago, a Government spokesman said today. **********The President has ''issued instructions to the competent Syrian security authorities to exert all possible efforts to help find his abductors, free him and return him to his family,'' a spokesman for Mr. Assad said. **********The correspondent, Jonathan Wright, a 30-year-old Briton, disappeared Aug. 29 after he left the Reuters office in Beirut to visit the scene of an Israeli air raid against Palestinian positions in a Syrian-controlled region of eastern Lebanon. News organizations in Europe have received anonymous telephone calls saying Mr. Wright was being held by a revolutionary group. **********Lebanese authorities and militias and Palestinian groups are also helping in the search for Mr. Wright.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/16/busin.main_headline: Producer Price Index Unchanged Last Month
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/16/busin.print_headline: Producer Price Index Unchanged Last Month
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/16/busin.body_text: **********Overall producer prices were unchanged in May for a second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today, and food prices fell at the steepest rate in nearly two years. **********The overall prices actually declined very slightly, but the change was too small to show up in the rounded-off official figures released in the department's Producer Price Index for finished goods. **********Donald Ratajczak, director of Georgia State University's economic forecasting project, said that ''the economy is moving forward but not overheating.'' **********Annual Rate of 3.5 Percent **********So far this year, the price report said, producer prices are rising at an annual rate of 3.5 percent, a bit lower than economists' predictions for the year. Last year's increase, the smallest in 20 years, was only six-tenths of 1 percent. **********The April and May back-to-back reports of unchanged overall prices provided the lowest two-month figures since prices declined one-tenth of 1 percent in March 1983 and then were unchanged the following month. **********Analysts expect higher numbers later this summer, perhaps in the range of one-half percent a month as food prices begin rising again. However, no one is expecting a major inflation surge. **********Indicator on Consumer Costs **********The Producer Price Index measures changes in prices paid to producers for food, energy products and other items. The prices American consumers actually pay - usually to retailers - are measured by the Consumer Price Index. The producer price measure often gives a good indication of the direction in which consumer prices will move. **********In detailing the producer price situation, the Labor Department said that food prices declined 1.2 percent, the sharpest drop since the 1.4 percent fall of July 1982, during the recession. **********The new decline, following a decrease of six-tenths of 1 percent in April, included drops of 14.7 percent for vegetables, 14.3 percent for eggs, 7.8 percent for beef and veal, 4.9 percent for poultry and 2 percent for pork. Fruit prices rose 10.6 percent, dairy prices edged up two-tenths of 1 percent, and fish costs rose three- tenths of 1 percent. **********5.2 Percent Rise for Fuel Oil **********Energy prices, which actually cover April rather than May costs because of reporting lags, rose strongly to balance the food decline. The 1.5 percent energy rise, following an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, included rises of 5.2 percent for fuel oil, 2 percent for gasoline and seven-tenths of 1 percent for natural gas. **********New-car costs fell seven-tenths of 1 percent after declining three-tenths of 1 percent in April. Prices of light trucks held steady. **********Prices of capital equipment rose two-tenths of 1 percent after increasing three-tenths of 1 percent in each of the previous two months. **********In May, the Producer Price Index stood at 291.5, meaning that goods costing $10 in 1967 would have cost $29.15 last month. **********All of the figures were adjusted to discount for normal seasonal variations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.main_headline: Judge Bars Loan Plan Of Storage Technology
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.print_headline: Judge Bars Loan Plan Of Storage Technology
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.body_text: **********A Federal bankruptcy judge today rejected a $140 million loan deal aimed at keeping the Storage Technology Corporation in business, but left the door open for lawyers to return with a similar plan. **********Lawyers for the Louisville-based computer components organization seemed stunned by the decision, which United States Bankruptcy Judge Jay Gueck outlined in a 40- minute opinion from the bench. **********William Mansfield, chief executive officer of Storage, said: ''We will review the judge's opinion to see what he said. We're looking strictly at the judge's opinion.'' **********He refused to comment on steps the company might take, including layoffs or other cost-cutting measures, in the wake of the judge's decision. **********Storage, already involved in reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code, had asked Judge Gueck to approve the loan from a subsidiary, the Storage Technology Finance Corporation. As part of the deal, creditors of the finance company would have been granted favored status in repayment. **********Confusion Over Ruling **********More than three dozen lawyers representing Storage Technology and various creditors have attended three days of hearings on the loan plan, and several indicated they were confused about the reasons for the ruling. **********One Denver bankruptcy lawyer who observed the hearings said Judge Gueck had turned down the plan as offered by Storage because he felt it ''was too favorable'' to the creditors of Storage Technology Finance. **********Lawyers for Storage had warned the rejection of the plan would leave the company without enough money to pay its bills and force it to close, likely by Christmas. **********Chief Officer Testimony **********In testimony this week, Mr. Mansfield said the loan would have given Storage money enough to operate ''well into or through the first quarter.'' **********Without the loan, he said, about 12,300 employees, including 6,300 in Colorado, would be without jobs by ''the third or fourth week in December.'' **********Storage, plagued by increased competition and high supply costs, has already laid off about 2,500 workers in Colorado. **********Eight creditors, saying Storage owes them a total of $86.8 million, have objected to the stipulated agreement in testimony before Judge Gueck. **********Storage has lost about $120 million since the summer of 1983. **********When it filed for reorganization under Chapter 11, Storage reported about $1.2 billion in assets and about $700 million in debts. **********Mr. Mansfield said Storage had been unable to arrange a loan from any other source since going into Chapter 11 proceedings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/08/busin.body_text: **********The Tandy Corporation, seeking to bolster its shrinking presence in the personal computer market, today will introduce an inexpensive computer compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's PC. **********The Tandy 1000 will be priced at $1,200 for a model including a single floppy disk drive and 128,000 bytes of internal memory. The price also includes Deskmate, a program that combines six applications including word-processing, filing, calendar and a spreadsheet. **********Tandy, which owns the Radio Shack chain of electronics stores, said the computer will be available immediately. The introduction is thus likely to put increased Christmas selling season competition on Apple, whose Apple II line dominates the market in the $1,000 to $1,500 price range for computers that straddle both home and office use. **********I.B.M. is also in that market with the PCjr, which it is aggressively promoting. John Roach, Tandy chairman and chief executive, said he expects the Tandy machine to do better than the PCjr, which has so far not sold well. ''It's first a good office machine and then also a home machine, as opposed to PCjr, which is primarily a home machine,'' he said. **********The new machine is further evidence of Tandy's move into the I.B.M. camp. Last month it introduced the 1200 HD, a computer with a hard disk compatible with I.B.M.'s PC-XT. **********Tandy, once a leader in the personal computer business, has slipped behind I.B.M. and Apple, and its earnings have been hurt. In the quarter ended Sept. 30, the company reported a 37 percent decline in net income, to $37.4 million. **********Part of the problem is that by using its own operating system, Tandy isolated itself from the mainstream of the market, which was adopting the I.B.M. standard. In addition, thousands of independent computer stores have sprung up in the last few years, so nullifying the distribution advantage that Tandy once had with its Radio Shack stores. **********Michele Preston, an analyst with L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, said the Tandy 1000, by offering ''PC capability at junior prices'' could be a strong seller for Tandy. She said the company was ''taking steps to fix'' the problems it had had in the personal computer market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/17/busin.body_text: **********Grand Metropolitan Appoints U.S. Head **********When the American Express Company bought Investors Diversified Services last January, it tapped Harvey Golub, a 45-year-old management consultant with McKinsey & Company, as president and chief executive officer of the big Minneapolis- based financial services company. **********The appointment was logical enough since Mr. Golub had helped American Express as part of the McKinsey team that studied the company before American Express bought it. **********In the aftermath, however, Walter D. Scott, 52, who had run the company as president and chief executive of I.D.S. for the previous four years, became chairman. It was no secret, however, that Mr. Scott, a former Wall Street investment banker who had also run the Lehman Brothers Chicago office, liked the idea of being boss. **********Yesterday, he got the chance again. **********Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the big British food, beverage and hotel company, announced in London that it had appointed him to its board as a managing director in charge of its activities in the United States. He was also named chairman of Grandmet USA Inc., the United States arm of Grand Metropolitan, in Montvale, N.J. The American company, a major Pepsi-Cola bottler, runs the Children's World day-care centers and makes Alpo pet food. It also owns the Liggett & Myers Tobacco Company, a leading producer of unbranded cigarettes along with Chesterfield, L.& M., Lark and Eve brands. **********''There was a new guy at the top,'' Mr. Scott remarked yesterday about his switch from I.D.S., ''and when an opportunity came along with a much larger company to run its United States operation, I took it.'' **********It was not the first time that opportunity called. Before joining I.D.S. four years ago, Mr. Scott had been executive vice president for administration and chief financial officer of the Pillsbury Company, also in Minneapolis. **********''Pillsbury is a great company,'' he said, ''but there were plenty of opportunities elsewere and I left to be chief executive officer of another major company, I.D.S.'' **********Asked what his new post at Grand Metropolitan would entail, he replied, ''They want to expand in a dramatic way and have a much greater presence in consumer products and services.'' And when asked if the company might buy something, he said, ''Yes, pieces, or it could be something big.'' As much as $1 billion? ''Yes,'' he replied. **********Mr. Scott has considerable experience along those lines. He helped Pillsbury buy the Green Giant Company, Steak & Ale and Totino's Pizza Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/02/busin.body_text: **********Spending for new construction rose 1.2 percent in March from February, with a small gain in private building offsetting a decline in Government projects, the Commerce Department reported today. The gain put the spending at $295.6 billion on a seasonally adjusted annual rate. **********The modest improvement compared with a strong 5.9 percent gain in February and a 3.9 percent rise in January, but building activity was still running 22 percent above the level of a year ago, when the construction industry was pulling out of the 1981-82 recession. **********Some analysts said they had expected the smaller increase because March weather was unusually severe. The Government had earlier reported that construction starts for single-family homes and apartments had fallen 26.6 percent in March, the sharpest decline on record. **********Today's report, which measures the amount of money spent on construction during the month, put residential building at an annual rate of $131.9 billion, up 2.8 percent from February. A 1.2 percent increase in spending on construction of single- family homes offset a 2.5 percent decline in construction work on apartment units, the report said. **********Among other private construction, commercial buildings posted an increase of 11.7 percent, while spending on office buildings fell 4 percent and industrial plant construction by 1.4 percent. **********Over all, private construction rose 1.8 percent, to an annual rate of $243.5 billion, following a 6.3 percent increase in February. **********Government building dropped 1.5 percent in March, to an annual rate of $52 billion, following a 4.1 percent increase in February. A rise of 3 percent in Federal construction in March was offset by a 3 percent decline in state and local government activity. **********Michael Sumichrast, chief economist of the National Association of Home Builders, said he expected construction spending to rise 7 percent for the rest of the year. For 1983, spending totaled $265 billion, up 14 percent from the depressed 1982 level.
