https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/24/world.main_headline: PRESIDENT AFFIRMS HIS POLICY TO KEEP MARINES IN BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/24/world.print_headline: PRESIDENT AFFIRMS HIS POLICY TO KEEP MARINES IN BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/24/world.body_text: **********Reagan's letter on Lebanon, page A6. **********WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 - President Reagan, in a policy statement on Lebanon, said today that the United States could not withdraw the marines suddenly without raising questions about its commitment to ''moderation and negotiation in the Middle East.'' **********In a reply to two Democratic members of the House of Representatives who had raised questions about American policy, Mr. Reagan also said the Soviet Union, Syria and Iran were complicating efforts to bring about Lebanese national unity. **********He said the marines and the other members of the four-nation force in Beirut were contributing to President Amin Gemayel's ''ability to have a national reconciliation process on a basis that is more Lebanese than Syrian.'' **********U.S. Irritated With Syria **********Mr. Reagan's letter reflected irritation with Syria, which earlier this month seemed to be acting in a more conciliatory manner, only to take a harder line. On Sunday, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said the Syrian Foreign Minister, Abdel Halim Khaddam, had told American officials that the United States ''is short of breath'' and will leave Lebanon before Syria has to withdraw. **********The Reagan letter, dated last Thursday, was described by the White House as a definitive statement on Lebanon. It was made public by the two House members, Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana and Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, as Congress returned from its recess, with Lebanon likely to be a major topic. **********Donald Rumsfeld, the special envoy, returned from his Middle East mission to brief members of Congress and the Administration on his failure to persuade Syria to cooperate in a Lebanese security arrangement. **********Iran Put on Outlaw List **********In another development, the State Department said that Iran, because of its purported role in the bombing of Marine headquarters in Beirut and of the United States Embassy in Kuwait, had been placed on a list of nations that have ''repeatedly provided support for acts of international terrorism.'' **********Nations on the list, which is maintained in compliance with an act of Congress and includes Syria, Southern Yemen, Libya and Cuba, are barred from importing some American equipment. **********The inclusion of Iran was described by officials as symbolic of the United States' anti-Iranian policy. Washington has favored Iraq in the war against Iran, even though no arms are being sold to either side. In 1982 the United States removed Iraq from the terrorist list when relations improved. **********On Sunday, Secretary Shultz said the United States was prepared to make pre-emptive strikes if there were signs that Iranian planes might attack American ships. There have been reports of pilots being trained in Iran for suicide missions. **********Meanwhile, a joint American-Israeli committee began putting into effect an agreement on enhanced military and political cooperation announced in November. The committee will work out arrangements for joint maneuvers, the storage of American equipment in Israel and other planning. **********The letter of Representatives Hamilton and Aspin to Mr. Reagan on Dec. 13 said that, although they had supported the Congressional decision to allow the marines to remain in Lebanon for 18 months, they said the commitment ''should not be open-ended.'' **********The letter said Mr. Reagan had ''overstated our stake'' in Lebanon by blaming the Russians for the problems in the area, and had failed to push for a political settlement. **********Mr. Reagan, in his reply, said Lebanon was ''a flash point of confrontation between Israel and Syria - and potentially the United States and the Soviet Union - and has been for several years now.'' **********The marines are in Lebanon, he said, ''to support our goal of diplomatic solutions which are agreeable to the parties concerned.'' **********''Our forces should not and will not be there permanently, but we cannot simply withdraw unilaterally without raising questions about the U.S. commitment to moderation and negotiation in the Middle East,'' Mr. Reagan said. **********The 18-month period for the marines allows the Gemayel Government ''a breathing spell'' to extend its authority, Mr. Reagan said. **********''There is no question about the complicating role of the Soviet Union, Syria and Iran,'' he said. ''The Lebanese could already have had a new national reconciliation government on Syria's terms, but the presence of the multinational force allows Mr. Gemayel to produce a truly Lebanese government.'' **********Iran Warns Against 'Adventures' **********TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 23 (Reuters) - Iranian leaders today warned the United States against any ''adventures'' after Secretary of State Shultz said there might be pre-emptive strikes to prevent suicide attacks on United States forces. **********President Ali Khamenei said Iran would reply to any ''adventures,'' and the Speaker of Parliament, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, said United States interests would be endangered.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/28/world.main_headline: JUDGES GIVER FREER REIN IN CASE IN ARGENTINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/28/world.print_headline: JUDGES GIVER FREER REIN IN CASE IN ARGENTINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/28/world.body_text: **********Nine members of former Argentine juntas accused of murder and torture will be tried under unusual legal procedures that will open the proceedings to the public and allow judges freer rein in ruling on evidence, the chief judge in the case says. **********The judge, Jorge Torlasco, said in an interview here that the civilian court would use the military code of justice. **********Under the civilian code, he said, the proceedings would have been recorded and sessions would have been closed to the public. Moreover, the prosecutors would have had to present specific evidence to prove their case. **********But under the military code, Judge Torlasco said, the six judges who will try the case can determine for themselves what evidence is necessary to reach a verdict and will not have to use a specified list of evidence. **********The public trial, which will begin within a month, is expected to attract considerable attention from international legal and human rights groups. **********President Raul Alfonsin has charged the nine officers, including three former Presidents, with ordering the murder and torture of thousands of Argentines during the antisubversive campaign in the 1970's. A presidential commission concluded last month that some 9,000 Argentines disappeared during the so-called ''dirty war.''  Likely Defense **********The defendants have indicated in earlier judicial proceedings that they are likely to base their defense on the argument that they were carrying out orders by the Government of Isabel Martinez de Peron to ''neutralize and annihilate'' the country's ''subversive elements.'' The armed forces overthrew Mrs. Peron in March 1976. **********The judge said a decision had not yet been made on where the public hearing would be held or on how many spectators would be permitted to attend. He said the court would not allow the trial to become a ''show.'' **********The civilian court can use the military code to try the officers because of a special law approved by Congress this year. Few officials had expected the law to be used, since the military was responsible for trying the cases and the civilian courts were only supposed to review the decisions made by the military tribunals. But after the military court said in late September that it could not meet an Oct. 11 deadline, the appellate court decided against granting an extension and instead assumed jurisdiction of the cases. **********The first stage of the trial will take five days, Judge Torlasco said. During this stage, which is closed to the public, the defending and prosecuting attorneys will outline the evidence and say what witnesses they would like to present during the public proceedings. **********The court could question the defendants privately, as it did recently with former President Roberto E. Viola.   President Appointed Judges **********The six judges, who were appointed by Mr. Alfonsin and approved by the Senate, will decide what evidence to permit the two parties to present. The court can, for example, limit the number of witnesses called by either side. **********At the end of this five-day period, the court will begin the public session, which could take several months, according to Judge Torlasco. **********Most of the defendants have named lawyers. But former President Rafael Videla has told the court that he will not take part in the proceedings and will not appoint a lawyer. It is unclear if the court will appoint a lawyer to represent him. **********The members of the first junta were General Videla, Adm. Emilio Massera and Brig. Orlando Agosti. **********The second junta consisted of General Viola, Adm. Armando Lambruschini and Brig. Omar Graffigna. **********The third junta was led by Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri and included Adm. Jorge Isaac Anaya and Brig. Basilio Lami Dozo. **********Three of the nine junta members - General Viola, General Videla and Admiral Massera - have been jailed while awaiting the trial.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/28/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S ADDRESS IN GREAT HALL OF THE PEOPLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/28/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S ADDRESS IN GREAT HALL OF THE PEOPLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/28/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from President Reagan's address today in the Great Hall of the People: **********Twelve years ago, former President Nixon arrived in Beijing, stepped down from Air Force One, and shook hands with former Premier Zhou Enlai. Premier Zhou would later tell him, ''Your handshake came over the vastest ocean in the world - 25 years of no communication.'' **********With one handshake, America and China each turned a new page in their histories. I believe history beckons again. We have begun to write a new chapter for peace and progress in our histories, with America and China going forward hand in hand. **********We must always be realistic about our relationship, frankly acknowledging the fundamental differences in ideology and institutions between our two societies. Yes, let us acknowledge those differences. Let us never minimize them, but let us not be dominated by them. I have not come to China to hold forth on what divides us, but to build on what binds us. I have not come to dwell on a closed- door past, but to urge that Americans and Chinese look to the future, because, together, we can and will make tomorrow a better day. **********I believe if we were to ask citizens all over this world what they desire most for their children, and for their children's children, their answer, in English, Chinese or any language would likely be the same: We want peace. We want freedom. We want a better life. **********America and China are both great nations, and we have a special responsibility to preserve world peace. To help fulfill that responsibility, the United States is rebuilding its defenses, which had been neglected for more than a decade.   'We Threaten No Nation' **********But we threaten no nation. America's troops are not massed on China's borders and we occupy no lands. The only foreign land we occupy, anywhere in the world, is beneath grave sites where Americans shed their blood for peace and freedom. Nor do we commit wanton acts, such as shooting 269 innocent people out of the sky for the so-called cause of sacred airspace. America and China both condemn military expansionism - the brutal occupation of Afghanistan, the crushing of Cambodia - and we share a stake in preserving peace on the Korean peninsula. **********How did America, which began as an improverished country and a melting pot, attracting immigrants from every corner of the globe, pull together and become the leading economic nation in the world? **********Well, we are people who have always believed the heritage of our past is the seed that brings forth the harvest of our future. And from our roots, we have drawn tremendous power from two great forces, faith and freedom. America was founded by people who sought freedom to worship God and to trust Him to guide them in their daily lives with wisdom, strength, goodness, and compassion. **********These great principles have nourished the soul of America. And they have been enriched by values such as the dignity of work, the friendship of neighbors and the warmth of family. Like China, our people see the future in the eyes of our children. And, like China, we revere our elders.   Trusting the People **********Trust the people. These three words are not only the heart and soul of American history, but the most powerful force for human progress in the world today. **********Today, China's economy crackles with the dynamics of change: expansion of individual incentives for farms in your new responsibility system; new bonuses for workers and more disciplined management in terms of profits and losses; improved methods of market distribution; opening your economy to the world through China's membership in the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, and through your invitation to trade and invest, and your commitment to attract capital and scientific knowledge to create a high technology base for the future. **********We Americans have always considered ourselves pioneers, so we appreciate such vitality and optimism. Today I bring you a message from my countrymen: As China moves forward on this new path, America welcomes the opportunity to walk by your side.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/09/busin.main_headline: A MIXED BAG OF OPTION TYPES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/09/busin.print_headline: A MIXED BAG OF OPTION TYPES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/09/busin.body_text: **********While most employees prefer I.S.O.'s, three related methods of delivering long-term compensation complement I.S.O.'s or provide comparable benefits. Non-qualified stock options, stock appreciation rights (S.A.R.'s) and ''phantom stock'' promise some of the profits of I.S.O.'s with far fewer restrictions. **********How do corporations pick and choose in this alphabet soup of possibilities? ''Most companies use a combination of I.S.O.'s and non-qualifieds,'' said Mr. Tilghman. The trend is to use I.S.O.'s where possible, he noted, substituting non- qualifieds when managers are stuck with underwater options that would be unprofitable to exercise. **********But the employee will pay more tax for the extra flexibility. With non- qualified options, the holder pays ordinary income tax, not capital gains tax, on the increase between the grant price and the market price when he exercises the option. If the executive in the earlier example had chosen non-qualifieds over I.S.O.'s, for instance, his tax bill would rise to $10,500 from $6,000, reflecting the extra tax bite on the $15 gain between the grant price and the market price, assuming he is in the 50 percent income tax bracket. **********Companies fare better with non- qualified options than with I.S.O.'s, however, since they take deductions equal to the executive's taxable gain. Assume that an executive who is granted a non-qualified option at $40 exercises that option when the stock price hits $55. The corporation takes a $15 deduction, realizing $6.90 in savings, assuming a 46 percent tax rate. The company can take no deduction with an I.S.O. **********Stock appreciation rights (S.A.R.'s) and ''phantom stock'' are incentive plans that also give better tax breaks to the company than to the employee.  But they offer a big plus for executives who can reap profits without putting up their own cash. **********An S.A.R. entitles the recipient to an amount equal to the difference between the grant price and the market price on the day that he exercises his right. Suppose an executive is granted 1,000 S.A.R.'s when the stock is selling at $40, for example; if the stock rises to $45 and he decides to cash in, the executive pockets a $5,000 profit without buying a single share. **********''Phantom stock'' is not stock at all, but an unfunded, unsecured corporate promise to pay an executive deferred compensation measured by the market share price. In effect, the company sets up an account with a specified number of hypothetical shares, paying over the appreciated value of those shares at a future date, as with an S.A.R. With phantom shares, however, the recipient is entitled to the value of the accrued dividends, as well. **********Unlike I.S.O.'s, both phantom stock and S.A.R.'s generate charges that reduce the company's earnings. And since their value rises with the market price of the shares, the company cannot control the cost either when the liability is carried on the balance sheet or when these rights are cashed in. Accordingly, S.A.R.'s and phantom stock are usually awarded only to key managers. **********Executives reaping the rewards of S.A.R.'s or phantom stock pay ordinary income tax on their gains, not the lower capital gains tax. However, since they never invested any money of their own, all the profits are, in effect, a risk-free windfall.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/25/world.main_headline: PENTAGON TIGHTENS CONTROL ON AIDES' CENTRAL AMERICA STATEMENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/25/world.print_headline: PENTAGON TIGHTENS CONTROL ON AIDES' CENTRAL AMERICA STATEMENTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/25/world.body_text: **********A senior Defense Department official has directed Pentagon officials to clear in advance with his office any communication with Congress about American military activities in Central America. **********Pentagon officials said the order reflected concern in the Reagan Administration about increasingly assertive efforts by Congress, particularly Democratic lawmakers, to examine whether the Pentagon has established a permanent military presence in Honduras without Congressional authorization. **********Administration officials, including Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, have denied that the United States intends to establish a long-term military presence in Honduras. **********The order, issued Feb. 17 by Fred C. Ikle, Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, said that advance coordination of contacts with Congress was necessary to insure that information provided by the Defense Department ''is accurate and consistent with DOD policy.'' A copy of the order was provided by an opponent of Administration policy in Central America.   10 Officials Got Memo **********The memo from Mr. Ikle was sent to 10 of the Defense Department's highest-ranking officials, including the Secretaries of the Army, the Navy and the Air Force, the Assistant Secretary for Legislative Affairs, the Assistant Secretary for Public Affairs, the Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency and the assistant to the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. **********Four Republican Senators, Ted Stevens of Alaska, the majority whip, Mack Mattingly of Georgia, Pete Wilson of California and Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, left today for a weekend visit to Honduras to inspect American military activities. Mr. Stevens is scheduled to report on the trip in a news conference in Washington on Monday. **********Congressional critics of Administration policy in Central America have suggested that the Pentagon used recently completed military exercises in Honduras to construct a variety of permanent military installations, including airfields and storage facilities, that were not explicitly approved by Congress. **********Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee and Representative Bill Alexander, Democrat of Arkansas, have pressed the Defense Department to provide a breakdown of expenditures in Honduras.   Complaint by Alexander **********Mr. Alexander complained in a speech to the House on Thursday that the Defense Department and the Central Intelligence Agency had not fully cooperated with a General Accounting Office study of American military and intelligence activities in Central America. The accounting office, the Congressional auditing agency, is conducting the review at Mr. Alexander's request. **********The focus of Congressional concern is whether funds designated for military operations and maintenance have been used for construction projects.  Mr. Alexander, who is a member of the House appropriations subcommittee on military construction, said in an interview this week that the use of operations and maintenance funds for the construction of airfields and other facilities would violate the intent of Congress and might be illegal. **********A recent report by the staff of the subcommittee concluded that construction activities in Honduras were consistent with planning for a long- range American military role. The staff reported that a number of the projects had not been approved by the subcommittee.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/24/busin.body_text: **********A consortium of 37 Western banks, led by the Deutsche Bank, the largest West German commercial bank, has assembled a loan package for East Germany totaling $400 million, the Deutsche Bank said today. **********Bank officials in Frankfurt, the West German financial center, expressed puzzlement at the timing and size of the loans, which the banks assembled in the Luxembourg market for Eurodollar credits, and which are unattached to specific trade deals. **********Speculation in Frankfurt focused on the possibility that East Germany, whose credit standing with Western commercial banks is among the most favorable of Soviet bloc countries, is amassing credit for the purchase of Western technology that might benefit the entire East bloc. **********Another possibility mentioned today is that the loans are intended to enable East Germany to restructure the bulk of its hard currency debt in the West, to reduce the percentage of costly short-term loans in favor of softer long-term credit. **********It is the third major loan East Germany has received in the last 15 months, despite a continued slowdown in commercial bank lending to most Soviet bloc countries. **********In that period, West German banks, encouraged by German Government credit guarantees, twice assembled loans each worth the equivalent of $328 million. **********Deutsche Bank said the loan agreement will be signed by representatives of the banks at Deutsche Bank's Luxembourg affiliate on Dec. 21. The loans are for a six-year period, and bear an interest rate of one percentage point above the London interbank offered rate, or Libor. **********Deutsche Bank said German banks would account for roughly one-fourth of the total loan sum. No United States banks are included in the loan consortium, it said, which includes banks from England, France, the Netherlands, Denmark, Austria, Finland, Canada, Japan and Australia. **********The bank said loans totaling only $150 million were originally planned, but the amount was increased to $400 million in response to lively interest from numerous Western banks. **********Frankfurt's bank officials said it was not unusual for United States banks to abstain from such a loan package, since they tend to avoid loans pegged exclusively to Libor. **********But they were at a loss to explain the timing and size of the large loans East Germany has received in recent months. According to statistics of the Basel-based Bank for International Settlements, East German debts to Western commercial banks totaled $8.4 billion at midyear, up from $8.1 billion at the end of 1983.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/25/busin.print_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE; DEFICIT OUTLOOK: DIVERSE VIEWS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/25/busin.body_text: **********-risk course with his budget, saying in effect, ''Damn the deficits - full speed ahead.'' Even on the Administration's own optimistic assumptions of strong, steady growth for the next five years, the budget the President will present to Congress next week will show deficits of $180 billion in the fiscal year 1985, $177 billion in 1986, $187 billion in 1987, $151 billion in 1988 and $122 billion in 1989. **********But those projections are contradicted by the steeply rising deficits foreseen by the Congressional Budget Office. Now headed by Rudolph Penner, a conservative who was formerly chief fiscal economist at the American Enterprise Institute, the budget office estimates that the deficit will climb to about $325 billion in 1989. It will release its new analysis of the budget about a week after the President sends his budget to Congress. **********The budget office's deficit projections are bigger than the President's primarily because it expects higher interest payments on the public debt and higher inflation in the cost of virtually all Government programs. And the budget office expects less real growth and more inflation than the Administration does. **********Curiously enough, Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, agrees with Congress. He has now disowned the Administration's economic projections as inconsistent with the deficits envisioned in the President's budget. When he signed on to the economic assumptions for the budget in December 1983, Mr. Feldstein assumed lower budget deficits, but the President rejected his case for higher taxes and bigger budget cuts. **********The White House, however, is holding to the original economic assumptions. These call for the 91-day Treasury bill rate, currently a little below 9 percent, to fall to 5 percent by 1989. Mr. Feldstein thinks that is too low. **********The Administration says inflation will come down to 3.5 percent by 1989, but Mr. Feldstein now believes that is too optimistic. **********And the Administration projects real economic growth at 4.5 percent in the calendar year 1989 and 4 percent a year from 1985 through 1989, but the Administration's chief economic adviser - and the Congressional economists - believes that is too high. **********An inside joke in earlier administrations about the budget process used to go: ''The Treasury controls taxes, the Office of Management and Budget controls expenditures and the Council of Economic Advisers controls the deficits.'' But now Mr. Feldstein has walked away from the economic assumptions and hence the deficits. **********Similarly, David Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, seems to have abandoned hope of controlling expenditures. In an interview with Fortune magazine, Mr. Stockman said the Reagan Administration had already cut so much out of Federal spending that further cuts were almost a political impossibility. ''There are a lot of dreamers,'' Mr. Stockman said, ''including in the Administration,'' who think the White House can get Congress to slash the costs of entitlement programs, such as Medicare, Medicaid and Federal and military pension programs, as the Presidential commission headed by J. Peter Grace recommends. **********Like Mr. Stockman, old Congressional hands think the White House and Mr. Grace are dreaming if they think huge cuts in those benefit programs are politically feasible. **********During this election year, Mr. Reagan has forcibly rejected tax increases. But Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said yesterday that after the election the Administration would consider simplification of the tax system and ''temporary'' adoption of a consumption tax - presumably some sort of sales tax. This may give the President an opportunity in his State of the Union address tonight to parry Democratic charges that he is being irresponsible about budget deficits. **********Is Mr. Reagan suddenly shifting his ground on a tax increase or is this a new political ploy? If, as many economists and businessmen expect, the economic expansion starts to weaken in 1985, a big tax increase would aggravate the downturn. **********And a temporary consumption tax would do nothing to alter the big deficits projected for the out- years unless the tax increase was not so temporary. The ''temporary'' in Secretary Regan's statement would appear to be a way of getting around President Reagan's opposition to tax increases. **********The President has also made it abundantly clear that he will fight against any military budget cuts, or rather any Congressional slowing of the rate of increase in military spending. He wants a 14 percent increase in the military budget for next year and a lot more thereafter, but Congress may resist that, sensing the electorate's concern. Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of the House has said the big national concern now is to get the Marines out of Beirut, not the deficits. **********The President appears to agree. He may try to put the deficit monkey on the Democrats' back by campaigning for a constitutional amendment to balance the budget and a line-item veto on Congressional appropriations. **********The President thinks the economists, including those in his Administration, have been wrong so often that he has no need to pay them any mind now. But the economic consequences of the long stream of budget deficits are starting to alarm the securities markets. The President may be ready to go for broke, but Wall Street isn't.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.main_headline: MAVERICK BRITON CUTTING A SWATH IN U.S. DEALINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.print_headline: MAVERICK BRITON CUTTING A SWATH IN U.S. DEALINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.body_text: **********Just what is Sir James Goldsmith, the secretive British millionaire, up to now? **********A few months ago, the 51-year-old maverick tried and failed to buy Continental Group Inc., the old Continental Can Company, for $2.5 billion. Before that, he had sought to buy into the St. Regis Corporation in a big way, but St. Regis proved coldly unreceptive. **********In neither instance was Sir James entirely disappointed. In the St. Regis episode, the group he headed accepted a $50 million profit for its 9 percent of the company's shares. His stake in Continental yielded an estimated $35 million profit when he bowed out after losing to Peter Kiewit Sons Inc. and David H. Murdock, the West Coast millionaire. **********Now Sir James has apparently set his sights on two other corporate giants: the Colgate-Palmolive Company, the big household products producer, and - most recently - the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, a forest products company with vast timberlands. His adviser in these deals is Rothschild Inc. of New York. **********Not Showing His Hand **********Typically, Sir James is not showing too much of his hand. His interest in Colgate became known to that company (but not the public) when Sir James sought Federal antitrust clearance to buy more than 15 percent of Colgate. Neither Colgate nor Sir James chose to say anything publicly for weeks, but when Sir James sought similar clearance for Crown Zellerbach, that company immediately announced the move and declared it would fight. **********Sir James has not disclosed his holdings in either company, which implies that he does not yet own 5 percent. If he did, he would be required to disclose that fact within 10 days. **********People who know Sir James say that if he landed Colgate, he might sell off operations outside its mainstream, such as the manufacture of shoes, clothing and crystal. And the key to his interest in Crown Zellerbach appears to be forest land, a subject he knows well. **********Four years ago, after a hotly contested battle, he seized control of the Diamond International Corporation, a big paper and forest products company. He broke it up and sold off the pieces - for a profit of more than $500 million - but kept one piece: more than a million acres of American forest lands. Crown Zellerbach, however, owns almost twice as much as Sir James does. **********Sir James has proved, on several occasions, to be a scrapper, with bulldog determination. **********''You only have to take his batting record,'' one friend, Sir Gordon White, head of Hanson Industries in New York, a British-owned conglomerate, remarked. ''He is is not only incredibly successful, but very willing to fight for what he believes in.'' **********But some of his friends say Sir James may have mellowed. The financier was said to have felt offended several months ago when Wall Street traders pegged him as a ''greenmailer'' for selling stock back to St. Regis. The implication was that he had sought only a quick profit and had never intended to take over St. Regis. **********''St. Regis,'' Sir James remarked, ''was a failure, not a success.'' He proposed merging his forest lands into St. Regis, raising his stake to 25 percent, joining the board and settling down to become a model citizen. St. Regis refused, so he got out. **********Sir James has one of the more unusual resumes in world financial circles. More than 30 years ago, as a moneyless 20-year-old socialite, he made headlines around the world when he defied Antenor Patino, the Bolivian tin king, and eloped to Scotland in a borrowed Rolls-Royce with the Bolivian's 18-year-old daughter, Isabel. She was to die tragically within months, following the birth of their daughter, also named Isabel. **********Sued Gossip Sheet **********Seven years ago, he sued Private Eye, a British gossip sheet, winning an apology and substantial damages after he was accused erroneously of being a business associate of Roberto Calvi, the controversial Italian banker. Mr. Calvi, sometimes called ''God's banker'' because of his association with the Vatican, was found hanged under Blackfriar's Bridge in London two years ago in a mystery yet to be solved. **********Sir James is reputed to be worth as much as $900 million, but there is no way of knowing because of his penchant for secrecy. **********His two main companies apparently, are Cia. Financiera Lido of Panama, of which he owns 40 percent, and the Brunneria Foundation of Liechtenstein, which owns the rest of Lido. These, in turn, own other companies in Hong Kong, France, Britain, the Bahamas and the United States. **********Most of them do little more than own other companies. But it seems clear that Sir James, whose operations are now concentrated in this country, controls the Grand Union Company, owns considerable acreage left over from the dismemberment of Diamond International, commands oil reserves in Guatemala, plus a smattering of publishing companies in France and gambling interests in Britain. **********'A First-Class Person' **********Laurence A. Tisch, head of the Loews Corporation and a director of the Grand Union Company when Sir James bought the food chain years ago, remarked: ''We found him to be a first-class person to do business with, honorable and decisive. I have great admiration for his ability.'' **********He controls, for example, 40 percent of the Aspinall casinos in Britain, owned by his friend, John Aspinall. He also owns L'Express, the largest news magazine in France, the newly started Paris Express, a city magazine somewhat in concept like New York, and Lire, the largest literary magazine in France. **********Except for Continental, his biggest project to date has been converting Grand Union to one of the most exciting food stores in the country. A hundred of them now stock not only staples, but also such gourmet fare as duckling glazed with honey or soy sauce, and live trout swimming in a tank. **********One of two sons of a British father and a French mother, James Michael Goldsmith was born in Paris in 1933. The Goldschmidts, as they were known earlier in Frankfurt, had been wealthy German Jewish bankers as far back as 1790. But because of Prussian anti-Semitism in the 1860's, the family gave up banking, moved to England and changed its name. **********His father, Frank, had been a major in the British Army and a Member of Parliament. Later he became a hotel operator, and while not wealthy, sent his sons to fine schools: James to Eton and Edward to Magdalen College at Oxford, where he himself had studied. **********Joins British Army **********At 17, James dropped out of Eton and took a cook's job at the famous Palace Hotel. At 18, he joined the British Army, entering as a private and emerging two years later as a lieutenant. **********At 20, with $200, he bought the French rights to a British rheumatism cream and started a company. Three years later he sold the company for $500,000, using the money to begin a dietary foods concern. The young Goldsmith was already building a reputation for creating new ventures on the profits of earlier ones. **********Widely known as Jimmy, despite his knighthood, Sir James stands 6 feet 4 inches tall, weighs more than 200 pounds and is baldish. **********His friends describe him as charming, outgoing and easy to know but also somewhat rumpled, with his shirt often half out and his tie askew. **********He is the father of six children, Isabel, 30, being the oldest, and Benjamin, 4, being the youngest. His second marriage, to Ginette Lery, was dissolved, and he is now married to Lady Annabel Vane Tempest Stewart. Once exceptionally open about keeping a mistress, he rarely talks of such matters today and friends say he has become ''very private'' about his personal life. **********Clio Goldsmith, the actress who played the sex-kittenish title role in the film ''The Gift,'' is the 26-year-old daughter of his brother, Edward, now a leading British environmentalist and scholar. **********Voracious Reader **********Sir James regards publishing as his main hobby, plays tennis badly and reads voraciously. **********While he does not own a yacht, he has a house in Paris and another in London, and one of his companies maintains a house for him in the fashionable East 80's in Manhattan. He brings his butler with him when in town and rents a car to get around. In London, he is chauffered in a company Ford; in Paris it is a Peugeot. **********Sir James is nothing if not optimistic. Consider his investment in Grand Union. ''We've taken big risks in Grand Union,'' he remarked in a phone interview from London earlier this year. ''It's not yet proven, but I believe it's going to be our biggest success.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/15/world.main_headline: FIRE PUT OUT ON GULF TANKER, BUT SHIP REMAINS IN DANGER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/15/world.print_headline: FIRE PUT OUT ON GULF TANKER, BUT SHIP REMAINS IN DANGER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/15/world.body_text: **********A fire aboard a gas tanker damaged by missiles in the Persian Gulf was put out today, but the Greek-owned vessel remained in danger, shipping officials here said. **********The vessel, the Gas Fountain, was attacked Friday by unidentified warplanes after taking on a load of propane and butane from the Saudi Arabian port of Ras Tanura. **********The shipping officials said Philippine and Dutch firefighting experts had put out the flames. ''Three tugboats spent the night combating the fire, which is now totally under control,'' a salvage company executive in Bahrain said. **********But the executive said that ''fire might break out again.'' **********The tugs, two belonging to the British Gray McKenzie Company and one belonging to the Singapore-based Selco Company, put out the fire ''simply by cooling it down with an enormous spray of water,'' he said. There had been fears of that the volatile cargo would explode.   Iran Is Suspected **********Owners of the Panamanian-registered Gas Fountain and shipping sources in the region said they suspected Iran was responsible for the attack. Neither Iran or Iraq, which have been at war for four years, claimed responsibility. The Teheran radio blamed Iraq for the incident. **********Iraq has claimed responsibility for several attacks in a 50-mile exclusion zone that it declared around the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island in February. However, sources in the region said the attack Friday occurred in the center of the gulf, too far away from Kharg Island to be Iraq's work. **********Iraq declared the exclusion zone in an effort to cut Iran's oil exports, but Iran has warned that it will retaliate for every Iraqi attack on Kharg Island shipping. **********Last Monday Iraq attacked the 254,000-ton Liberian-registered World Knight. Nine crew members were killed and six were injured.   Crew Members Unhurt **********The Gas Fountain's 33 crew members abandoned the ship after the attack Friday, and there were no injuries. **********The vessel sustained ''considerable damage,'' a gulf shipping executive said, ''but probably half its cargo is still intact.'' **********British experts were to arrive from London today to ''deal with the situation and make sure the fire will not break out anew,'' another executive said. **********''Gas is still leaking out,'' he said. ''But there's no danger of air pollution.'' **********Another salvage company expert said the Gas Fountain was a total loss, having been turned into a ''skeleton of charred steel.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/01/world.body_text: **********After less than a week in the United States, Jennifer Henricus, a young journalist from Sri Lanka, says she is surprised, even a bit disappointed, to learn that the press in the United States is not as she had imagined. **********''We have this idea that you can publish anything and everything you like, but it isn't like that,'' said the 24-year- old reporter, who is taking part in one of two new programs intended to expose third world journalists to journalism as practiced in this country. ''For instance, I didn't know that American newspapers endorsed candidates for the Presidency. We'd got the idea they were strictly nonpartisan.'' **********Miss Henricus and nine other journalists from developing countries are the first group to be designated Alfred Friendly Press Fellows. They have begun a six-month stay in the United States, with five months devoted to gaining practical experience in the newsroom of one of the participating news organizations. **********The program, intended to be an annual one, is administered by the Institute of International Education and principally financed by about $180,000 from the Alfred Friendly Foundation, a family trust created by the former managing editor of The Washington Post, for whom it is named. Mr. Friendly died last year.   Third World Internship Program **********In September the American Society of Newspaper Editors will begin its Third World Internship Program, which will provide a dozen experienced journalists from developing countries with a six-week stay in the United States, including four weeks as part of a newspaper staff. **********''We are hoping to create new understanding in other countries of our concept of a free press,'' said Richard D. Smyser, president of the society and editor of The Oak Ridger in Oak Ridge, Tenn. **********Both programs, according to the sponsoring organizations, are designed as a partial answer to the need expressed by the third-world press in recent years for professional and technical aid while at the same time introducing the participants to this country's free press tradition and techniques. **********''The two programs are extremely important because of the demand for an improved flow of information between the developed and undeveloped countries,'' said Leonard R. Sussman, executive director of Freedom House, an organization based in New York that monitors press freedom in the third world. ''They are a direct way of rather quickly adding to improvement in the quality of journalism. They also allow us to get the flavor of third world interests and concerns.''  'Broaden Their Perspective' **********But because of the short time involved and the difference in laws governing the press in various countries, the usefulness of the programs has yet to be proved. **********''Whether these internship programs will provide the participating journalists with the skills they need to work as professional journalists in their own countries is open to question,'' said Narinder K. Aggarwala, an Indian journalist working for the United Nations Development Program who has spoken often in recent years on third world information needs. ''But the participants are bound to broaden their perspective by being exposed to the functioning of a free press, warts and all, in the United States.'' **********Among the Alfred Friendly Fellows, the first group to arrive, the initial reaction has been shock at the complexity of this country's laws and standards constraining the absolutely free press they had expected, according to David Nalle, executive director of the Alfred Friendly Press Fellowships. The group is in Washington immersed in a two-week orientation led by Elie Abel, chairman of the department of communication at Stanford University. **********''They are amazed to learn how complicated it is, with the First Amendment, libel law and all,'' Mr. Nalle said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/21/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will reduce its 12 regional offices to six in the next several years, officials announced today. **********They said the consolidation would increase efficiency in the agency that insures bank accounts. Offices to be closed are in Boston, Memphis, Minneapolis, Omaha, Philadelphia and Columbus, Ohio, agency officials said. They said the remaining regional offices, in Kansas City, Mo., Atlanta, Chicago, Dallas, New York and San Francisco, would be strengthened.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/04/busin.main_headline: ALUMINUM PRICES FIRM IN A GROWING MARKET
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/04/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; ALUMINUM PRICES FIRM IN A GROWING MARKET
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/04/busin.body_text: **********Prices of aluminum futures firmed yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, although trading has been light since the March contract expired last week. At yesterday's close, the spot April aluminum contract was quoted at a nominal 67.60 cents a pound, up 0.15 cent for the day. **********Metal brokers said they expect trading in the new aluminum futures market, which opened last Dec. 8, to remain sluggish until more traders become convinced that the long slide in cash prices is nearing an end. **********But what interests metal traders more is that this young market has quietly attracted a surprising number of commercial users of aluminum. This became evident with the expiration of the March contract on March 27, when about 1,000 contracts of 40,000 pounds each, one-fourth of the open interest, were exchanged for metal rather than offset by trades, as is usually the case in futures markets. **********Comment by a Specialist **********David L. Moison, specialist in base metals at Merrill Lynch Futures, observed, ''While the older London Metal Exchange aluminum market was much more liquid, we see a steady and healthy rise in the number of hedgers and speculators using the Comex futures, albeit in small quantities.'' **********The latest tally of aluminum stocks registered at the Comex was 42,000 tons, compared with 199,450 on the London Metal Exchange, long the dominant market for aluminum futures. **********The exchange stocks reflect the continuing global reduction in primary ingot aluminum since the peak of 2,169,000 metric tons last August, when prices began to slide from 76.41 cents a pound. The global stocks then fell to 1,955.000 tons in November before rising to just over 2 million tons on Jan. 31, the latest reporting date. **********''By June 30 the stocks should be down another 150,000 to 200,000 tons,'' Mr. Moison said, ''because the use of aluminum rises and falls with the temperature.'' **********Aside from the increased use of aluminum in food and beverage containers and for construction, the industry is also expected to benefit from the general improvement in the American and overseas economies. ''It is significant that the L.M.E. aluminum stocks have been slowly but steadily falling since since last August,'' Mr. Moison said. **********Si Wakesberg, vice president-commodities at the National Association of Recycling Industries, said: ''Aluminum's basic problem was that producers were overly optimistic about the strength of the recovery. Last year they produced too much too quickly, and their primary stocks began to rise with the seasonal downturn in demand that often occurs after Labor Day. With primary supplies falling and the fact that aluminum scrap supplies have grown tighter in recent weeks, we think primary and recycled aluminum prices may turn upward, at least until the fall.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/17/busin.body_text: **********A settlement has been reached by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation with one of six former officers and directors of the Penn Square Bank who were blamed for the bank's failure in 1982. **********Terms of the accord call for Carl W. Swan, an Oklahoma City oilman, to consent to a $20 million judgment against him, which would be satisfied by payments totaling $2 million. **********A Tulsa attorney representing the F.D.I.C., Charles Baker, said the $2 million payment is based on information that Mr. Swan's liability-to-asset ratio is 10 to 1. Mr. Baker said he was not party to the negotiations and did not know how the $20 million figure was determined. **********Mr. Swan became a director of Penn Square in 1976, and his businesses had borrowed $342 million through the bank by July 5, 1982, when the bank was closed by Federal regulators, F.D.I.C. figures show. **********The settlement with Mr. Swan relates only to damage claims against him in the lawsuit and does not affect his contractual debts, Mr. Baker said. The $2 million will be paid into the receivership estate and will be used to pay holders of receiver's certificates and others with proved claims.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/world.body_text: **********At least 16 people were killed by an explosion at a natural-gas pipeline in Pakistan's Punjab Province today. The police said the blast in Rahim Yar Khan district was caused by pressure in the pipeline. Eleven people were injured.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/27/busin.main_headline: BANK EXPANSION LIMITS ARE PLANNED BY F.D.I.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/27/busin.print_headline: BANK EXPANSION LIMITS ARE PLANNED BY F.D.I.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/27/busin.body_text: **********Acknowledging that issues of states' rights were involved, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it was moving to restrict banks from going into new lines of business under authority recently granted by some states. **********The proposed regulations, which would apply not only to federally chartered, or national, banks but to state-chartered banks also, would restrict the ability of banks to engage in real estate; insurance brokerage and underwriting, and travel services. **********A number of states, including New York, have recently authorized state- chartered banks to enter these lines of businesses. In June, for example, the New York State Assembly approved a bill that would allow state- chartered savings banks to invest in and control real estate development. **********Move Follows One on Securities **********Today's action was the second time this month that the F.D.I.C. has moved to set new rules in an area that has been generally regarded as the exclusive jurisdiction of the states. **********On Nov. 19, over the strenuous objections of the securities industry, the F.D.I.C. adopted a regulation that would allow subsidiaries of about 9,300 state-chartered banks to underwrite corporate securities. **********As he did today, William M. Isaac, the chairman of the F.D.I.C., insisted then that in adopting the securities underwriting rule, the agency was not breaking down barriers in banking; it was only seeking to clarify existing rules. However, a number of Congressional critics as well as banking and securities industry officials say that the agency, in the guise of clarification, is pushing further banking deregulation. **********The Reagan Administration favors expanding bank powers. But bills passed this year by the Senate and House moved in opposite directions, leaving the issue unresolved until Congress reconvenes in January. **********Establishment of Subsidiary **********A 60-day comment period follows today's F.D.I.C. proposal; it is not clear what the next step will be, however. In the past, the agency has taken as much as two years before voting on whether it should adopt a regulation. If finally adopted, however, the rule would require banks to place those activities in a ''bona fide'' subsidiary that would operate separately from the parent bank. **********Mr. Isaac insisted today that the rule was ''neutral; it does not authorize or restrict; it does not add new powers, it does not subtract.'' **********But state banking officials strongly disagreed. Lawrence E. Kreider, executive vice president of the Conference of State Bank Supervisors, said the F.D.I.C.'s action amounted to a Federal intrusion into an area traditionally managed by the states. **********''What they would do here is really destroy or seriously dilute the state's flexibility to experiment,'' Mr. Kreider said. ''Clearly, it's a reregulatory, not a deregulatory, move.'' **********Saul Klaman, president of the National Council of Savings Institutions, also criticized the new regulation for being ''unusually restrictive.'' **********''It has an adverse impact on institutions that have been doing this for a long time.'' Mr. Klaman said. He complained that forcing institutions to operate new services in the subsidiary form would likely be ''difficult, awkward and more expensive.'' **********In announcing the proposed rule today, the F.D.I.C. said it strongly supports expansion of bank powers that would allow banks to seek new sources of income. However, the agency said it cannot ignore that such expansion may increase the risk to the deposit insurance system. **********According to the Conference of State Bank Supervisors, 13 states now allow state-chartered institutions to offer some form of real estate underwriting, 8 allow securities underwriting, 3 permit full-service brokerage activities, 12 permit management consulting and 15 permit banks to offer travel services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/18/busin.main_headline: LOANS TO ARGENTINA CUT CITICORP PROFIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/18/busin.print_headline: LOANS TO ARGENTINA CUT CITICORP PROFIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/18/busin.body_text: **********Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were reduced by $11 million because of loans to Argentina. Citicorp is Argentina's second-largest American bank creditor. **********In the last full quarter under the leadership of Walter B. Wriston, chairman, the company's earnings fell 1.9 percent, to $206 million, from $210 million. On a per share basis, Citicorp earned $1.49, down from $1.59 a share last year. Mr. Wriston retires from Citicorp on Sept. 1. He will be succeeded by John S. Reed, a vice chairman. **********Also reporting yesterday, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation said earnings rose 4.3 percent in the second quarter despite a $1.7 million after-tax reduction in profits from loans to Argentina. Also, Mellon Bank said earnings fell 19.8 percent in the period, but attributed the decline mainly to domestic lending and higher operating expenses. Wells Fargo & Company said that, excluding a one-time gain a year earlier, profits were up 16.9 percent for the period. **********Analysts said that despite the decline at Citicorp, Mr. Wriston would be leaving the bank in solid financial shape. **********Earnings for all three of the company's major divisions - consumer banking, corporate and government lending, and investment banking - fell slightly in the second quarter. Analysts were surprised, however, at the strength of the bank's corporate and government lending operation, which managed to post profits of $159 million, down 10.2 percent from last year's $177 million, but high in light of domestic and foreign loan problems and a decline in foreign exchange trading profits. **********Robert Albertson, banking analyst for Smith Barney, said without volatility and aberrations in bond and foreign exchange trading and unusual adjustments to loan loss reserves, the company probably would have earned about $1.75 a share for the quarter. **********''I'd call that a record,'' Mr. Albertson said. **********A senior Citicorp executive who asked not to be named said of Mr. Wriston's final quarter: ''We made $429 million in the last six months in a tough environment. I would say he was pretty pleased.'' **********Still, return on total assets, an important measure of the bank's performance, slipped in the quarter to 0.58 percent, from 0.67 percent in the comparable quarter last year. **********In June, the Federal Reserve Board told banks to adopt tougher accounting rules concerning loans to Argentina, but said they did not have to go into effect until the third quarter. The rules limit the amount of interest income banks can report as earned. **********Many banks have chosen to make the adjustment in the second quarter, however, to build credibility with investors and customers, analysts say. Other banks, including Citicorp, have been using the more conservative reporting method all along. **********Mellon Bank, which made the adjustment during the period, said the effect was ''insignificant'' because the bank placed most of its $124 million in loans to Argentina in the nonaccruing catagory in the first quarter. Wells Fargo and Bankers Trust, which both also have relatively few loans to Argentina, also adopted the new rules in the second quarter. Wells Fargo also said the impact was ''not significant.'' **********Citicorp **********Citicorp said net income in its consumer banking division fell 7 percent, to $52 million, from $56 million in the comparable quartera year earlier. At the same time, profits from investment banking operations, which include such activities as bond trading, fell 9 percent, to $31 million, from $34 million. **********The company said second-quarter results were also reduced by $3 million because of acquisitions and absorption of losses from its newly purchased savings and loan associations in Florida and Illinois. **********Citicorp increased its provision for loan losses to $139 million, compared with $99 million at the end of the second quarter in 1983. Problem loans rose to $2.4 billion, from $2.3 billion. **********Bankers Trust **********Bankers Trust, the nation's 10th-largest banking company, said profits rose to $72 million, from $69 million. On a per share basis, profits rose to $2.25, from $2.29 a share. The company had 1.7 million more shares outstanding in the second quarter than in the perioda year earlier. Profits for the period include a $2 million after-tax gain from the sale of upstate branches, while the period a year earlier includes a $7.2 million gain from the sale of upstate branches and from a debt-for-equity swap. **********Bankers Trust increased its provision for loan losses to $40 million, compared with $10 million a year earlier. Problem loans rose to $604 million, from $463 million a year ago. **********Mellon **********Pittsburgh-based Mellon Bank, the nation's 12th-largest banking concern, said profits fell to $39.4 million, from $49.1 million a year earlier. Per share earnings fell to $1.40, from $1.90. **********The provision for loan losses rose to $30.4 million, from $9.7 million a year earlier. Nonperforming loans fell to $506.5 million, from $584.9 million. **********Wells Fargo **********Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, said it earned $40.9 million in the second quarter, up slightly from $40.6 million. On a per share basis, earnings were $1.63, against $1.56 a share. The company repurchased 1.5 million of its outstanding shares during the quarter. **********Last year's results include a nonrecurring gain of $5.6 million after-tax, or 24 cents a share, from the sale of the company's San Francisco office building.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Belgian wholesale prices rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month from December, putting prices 10.9 percent above the January l983 level, the Economics Ministry said today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/11/busin.body_text: **********WARREN PFAFF, who founded Warren Pfaff Inc. 14 years ago, has brought in a president. And if John N. Carpender were a bit taller and less stocky, Mr. Pfaff might be accused of cloning. **********Not that they are perfect lookalikes. It is really just the skin tone and the way they have their white hair cut, quite short and parted on the left. **********But the similarities do not end there. There is a shared love of advertising and of money. And both are 1951 graduates of lesser-known Ivy League schools. For the chairman it was Dartmouth and his new associate, Brown. And both are former Navy officers. **********The big difference is that Mr. Pfaff is dedicated to the creation of advertising and Mr. Carpender to account management. **********The new president is in the Pfaff penthouse offices at 185 Madison Avenue mainly because after years of contentment at the $10 million to $12 million billings level, Warren Pfaff, the one-time J. Walter Thompson copywriting executive, decided about six months ago that he wanted to double the agency's billings. **********Why?  ''More excitement. More fun. And more money,'' he said quickly and surely. **********The agency has eight clients, eight employees and farms out all of its media buying, research work and public relations needs. Generally new business has come to it. There has been little organized new business activity. **********Enter Mr. Carpender, who sees new accounts coming in in three ways: from pitching a list of some 110 or so companies in various fields that he and the boss put together; by referrals from giant agencies that really do not want to be tied to smaller accounts, and the friends Mr. Carpender collected during his years in the package goods field. **********He plans to use the old let-me-work- on-your-worst-brand tactic. Or is it, give your dog a new home? He does have the contacts. **********Before joining Caravatt Communications two years ago, he had been senior vice president of marketing services at the W. E. Long Company, a cooperative association of baking companies; was director of marketing at Abbott Laboratories, maker of such things as Selsun Blue and Murine, and worked for Revlon and Chesebrough-Pond's. Also nestled among his work experiences is a 10- year tour with the Carl Ally agency, where Paul Caravatt was his boss for the first time. **********Mr. Pfaff had talked to some 27 candidates for the job, described in trade press classified ads as a ''top account-management position.'' It was done at lunch or cocktails, generally at the Park Ten Restaurant down the block on 34th Street. **********He had four sessions, each more than three hours long, with Mr. Carpender before he popped the question. The prospect never saw the ads, but he did pick a message off the grapevine, which, like the classified, said nothing about a president's title. **********As a matter of fact, the founder did not have it firmly in mind until he met the man from Caravatt. **********''The president thing was vaguely in back of my mind,'' Mr. Pfaff confided, ''but I really didn't think I'd find a guy that would fill the bill. **********''When we reached an agreement about his joining, he said, 'What will I be called?' **********''What would you like to be called?' I asked, and he said, 'Director of account services,' and I said, 'What else?' and he said, 'Vice president? Senior vice president?' **********''I said, 'I have something else in mind. President.' '' **********All accomplished with a certain amount of flair. Mr. Pfaff has a certain amount of that, certainly. While he was in his late teens in Great Neck, L.I., he had a flair for sports, particularly baseball, and in fact played the infield for the Olean Oilers, a St. Louis Browns farm team in upstate New York. **********Out of college he had other interests and went to Paris to study painting, only to come back to the States and decide on an acting career, but only if he could support himself and a wife. He could not, so the stage's loss was advertising's gain and he started as an art director with the old Bryan Houston agency. **********Five months later he got calls on the same day from J.W.T. and N.W. Ayer, both of whom had interviewed him earlier. He picked Thompson and stayed for 12 years, mostly as a copywriter, deciding on the business without loving it and then falling in love with it, just like in the stories of arranged marriages. And that late- blooming love affair has not ended.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/21/busin.body_text: **********Geer, DuBois, the advertising home of Peak Freans cookies, has gotten considerably more to nibble on: the Casa Lupita chain of Mexican family restaurants started by Ponderosa Inc. of Dayton, Ohio. **********The agency only knows that the ad spending will be in the ''low seven figures,'' and that is keeping it happy at the moment. **********Casa Lupita, whose advertising assignment was formerly at Avrell, Free & Ginsberg, was started in 1982 and has 15 widely separated units, all company owned. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/10/busin.body_text: **********The New York Insurance Superintendent's office said it is investigating whether brokers illegally sold annuities that were issued by a subsidiary of the Charter Company. **********The investigation involves single-premium deferred annuities issued by the Charter Security Life Insurance Company. That Charter unit is based in New Jersey and is not licensed to issue policies in New York. **********Charter acknowledged that it knew of the investigation but said that the company had not done anything wrong and was not aware of any charges that had been filed. The New York Insurance Superintendent did not identify which brokerage firms were being investigated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/11/busin.body_text: **********PROPOSAL writers at about 500 graduate schools of business will be scrambling in the next few months to formulate plans for submission to the International Business Machines Corporation. **********The big computer maker wants to make sizable grants to graduate business schools interested in strengthening training programs and doing research in the field of management information systems. M.I.S., as it is known, has become one of the hottest subspecialties in management. **********''Our aim is to encourage business schools to develop more graduates who understand the role information systems will play in coming years,'' John R. Opel, I.B.M.'s chairman, said last week. Information systems, he said, are ''strategic tools'' for management. **********The graduates of the M.I.S. programs will be called on to perform a wide variety of managerial tasks. They will need to understand the use of telecommunications equipment, mainframe computers and terminals, cable systems, interoffice systems, outside information services, and all kinds of security problems. **********Cash grants totaling $12 million will be given over five years to a dozen graduate schools selected through the proposal system. Initial planning grants ranging from $5,000 to $12,000 will be given to 30 graduate business schools submitting the best preliminary proposals. **********Each of the dozen ultimate winners will also receive up to $1 million in data processing equipment as well as programming, or software, for use with it. **********The grants will provide not only good publicity for I.B.M. but also an entry, if it does not have one already, into the educational institutions. **********In focusing on management information systems, I.B.M. has indeed selected a fast-growing management area. **********''M.I.S. jobs are weighing down the want ad sections of newspapers,'' Dr. Michael E. Lawson of Boston University said the other day. He is director of the university's Master of Science program in management information systems. **********Last fall, to meet the need for more trained people in the field, Dr. Lawson enrolled 41 full-time students, all of whom had undergraduate degrees in business, in his program. About 25 percent had an accounting background, he said. **********Besides a year's course work, the students also started internships in January with Boston-area companies. As interns, they must spend at least one day a week working on projects at the Shawmut Bank of Boston, Honeywell Inc., the Kendall Company, the Computervision Corporation, the Foxboro Company, Massachusetts General Hospital and the State of Massachusetts. The first class will be graduated in August.  At Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Dr. William A. Wallace, chairman of statistical management and information sciences, welcomed the I.B.M. program. **********''This project is very exciting to us,'' he said. ''Even in losing, you have gone through an excellent process yourself. You have thought through the problem.'' In recent years, Rensselaer, which has many graduates working for I.B.M., has won major awards from the company. **********Dr. Wallace said some of the other colleges with programs like R.P.I.'s in the management information systems field were Dartmouth, the University of Minnesota, New York University and the University of California at Los Angeles. **********On college campuses, proposal writing for money grants from alumni, foundations and corporations has become a major undertaking, offering quite a few employment opportunities in development offices, whose personnel work with professors in writing proposals. **********Typically, a proposal for a grant could be 50 to 100 pages long, or even more. Faculty, deans, the development office, and, in the case of Boston University, the grants and contracts department, will work on the proposal. **********The I.B.M. announcement follows several other educational grants. Last year, the company announced a $50 million program to help 22 graduate schools of engineering improve education in the manufacturing area. This is in line with efforts all over the country to increase productivity and enable American products to be more competitive. The effort involves CAD/CAM - ''computer-assisted design'' and ''computer-assisted manufacturing.'' **********I.B.M. also started a $3 million- a-year program to help universities retain outstanding faculty in critical shortage areas like computer science, materials science and electrical engineering.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/20/world.main_headline: SENATE DEFEATS A PROPOSAL TO BAN SEA-BASED NUCLEAR CRUISE MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/20/world.print_headline: SENATE DEFEATS A PROPOSAL TO BAN SEA-BASED NUCLEAR CRUISE MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/20/world.body_text: **********The Senate, moving toward approval of its $230 billion military authorization bill, rejected an attempt today to impose a moratorium on deployment of nuclear- armed cruise missiles at sea. **********Still ahead, as the Senate moved through dozens of amendments, was a measure from Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, that would prod more military contributions from the Western European members of the North Atlantic Treaty organization. **********Senator Nunn said Administration officials, including President Reagan, as well as foreign officials had kept in touch with him on his amendment. **********On Monday, Senator Nunn said in a speech that the Atlantic alliance was not prepared to stop a conventional attack by the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact forces with conventional weapons. **********''Even if the Soviets limit their attack to conventional means,'' he said, ''NATO will be forced to escalate the conflict into a nuclear exchange.'' **********Today, he said allied officials were concerned about the timing of provisions in the amendment, such as the withdrawal of some American troops, if the Western Europeans did not meet military spending goals. **********A Senate source said the Republican leadership was trying to modify the amendment to make it more acceptable to the Administration. The source said the Republican leaders believed the chances for passage were good. **********The proposal for a moratorium on sea-based cruise missiles was offered by Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, who noted that the deployment was scheduled to begin this month. At a cost of $3 million apiece, he said, the missiles have ''macabre appeal'' as a bargain. But he said they endangered prospects for verifiable arms control. **********Senator David Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota and a co-sponsor of the amendment, said that ''unlike MX, the issue is timing, not technology.'' He was referring to the prospect of renewed negotiations with the Soviet Union after the Presidential election. **********He added, ''It would be tragic if we limited the chance for a post-November agreement with hasty action in June.'' **********Speaking on behalf of the Administration, which opposed the amendment, Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, called it a ''unilateral moratorium.'' **********Mr. Mathias and Mr. Durenberger dropped the tougher language in their amendment and accepted a compromise measure offered by Mr. Cohen that expressed a nonbinding sense of Congress that the President should seek negotiations on the nuclear cruise missiles with Moscow and advise the Kremlin of the necessity of ''intrusive on-site inspection procedures.'' The Senate agreed to this compromise on the amendment by a vote of 97 to 0.   House Acted Last Month **********Last month, the House of Representatives passed an amendment to its version of the military bill that would ban the deployment of new sea-launched nuclear cruise missiles unless the President certified that the Soviet Union had deployed similar weapons. **********A spokesman for Mr. Durenberger said that Senate proponents of a moratorium realized that they could not obtain a restriction similar to the House's. By accepting the Cohen substitute, they were assured that the Senate would at least hold some position on cruise missiles from which to negotiate later in committee conference. **********Both the Senate and the House measures were aimed at nuclear-armed models of the Navy's Tomahawk missile. The Administration requested $593 million in the fiscal year 1985 for building nuclear and conventional types, calling them the ''cornerstone of our effort to increase and diversify the striking power of our fleet.'' **********Need for Missiles Challenged **********The missiles are designed to be fired from surface ships or submarines. The nuclear version reportedly can carry a warhead with the explosive power of 200,000 tons of TNT to within 300 feet of a target 1,500 miles away. About $225 million of the total Administration request is for nuclear Tomahawks. **********Mr. Mathias also challenged the need for the missiles on the Senate floor last year, urging as he did today that they be included in strategic arms reduction talks with Moscow. A motion to kill his amendment was approved last year by a close vote that showed bipartisan support for a restriction on the Tomahawk. **********In their authorization reports, the Armed Services Committees of the Senate and the House both approved the full Administration request. The Senate committee noted that its ''serious concern'' about the Tomahawk program before 1983, when more than 50 percent of all Tomahawk tests were failures, had been largely addressed by the Navy.  On another arms-control issue, the Senate, by a vote of 82 to 17, passed an amendment offered by two Democrats, Dale Bumpers of Arkansas and Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, that would reinforce the current American policy of not undercutting provisions of the second strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union. **********''This expresses for the first time the will of more than two-thirds of the Senate that SALT II should not be undercut,'' Mr. Leahy said, referring to the fact that a two-thirds majority is required for Senate approval of treaties. **********Although the Senate has never approved the treaty, which was signed by President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev in 1979, the United States has repeatedly said it will do nothing to upset its main provisions as long as the Soviet Union does the same.
