It was the first Iranian military plane known to have landed here in four years of war between the two countries. **********The American-made Phantom jet arrived a day after the Minister of ture and Information, Latif Nsayyef Jassem, announced that Iraq was ''ready to receive any Iranian plane.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/03/busin.body_text: **********If history is a guide, the months following Tuesday's Presidential election will be anything but a celebration for the stock market. In fact, post- election blues have soured investors on stocks every four years since the election of Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964. **********But this year could be different. ''The fear of the market going into the tank after the election is overdone,'' said Charles H. Brunie, chairman of the Oppenheimer Capital Corporation, which manages $3.5 billion in equities. **********He pointed out that the causes of the market downturns in the first six months of the year following the last five elections were higher interest rates and a slowing of the economy caused by Federal Reserve Board's tightening of the money supply. This time around, private credit demand and the economy have already cooled off on their own. **********''If anything, the Fed may try to get things moving again by loosening up on the money supply,'' Mr. Brunie said. For the last six months, the money supply has grown at an average 2 percent annual rate, in contrast to an average of more than 7 percent for the similar periods prior to the last five Presidential elections. **********Growing Spirit of Optimism **********Indeed, despite the indecisive tone to the market of late, there is a growing spirit of optimism that stocks are poised for a longer rally than the market has seen in the choppy trading of the last year and a half. Such a burst of activity would take the Dow Jones industrial average beyond the 1,287 record level of last November. The Dow closed yesterday at 1,216.65, gaining 11.70 points for the week. **********The kickoff, however, for the market's next big move up may still be a few weeks, if not a few months, away, market strategists and money managers say. They are not looking for the market to start flying in the next few days if President Reagan wins the election, for instance. **********A big Reagan victory is already expected by the market, said Suresh Bhirud, market strategist for the First Boston Corporation. About the only way the market will get a shot in the arm from a Republican victory is if a Reagan landslide is large enough to turn control of the House of Representatives over to the Republicans, he said. **********But sooner rather than later, ''There is another big surge coming in the market when investors reflect on the Reagan victory and the fact that the economy is O.K.,'' said Barton Biggs, chief investment strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, reflecting Wall Street's assumption of a Reagan victory. He expects the Dow to be in a range of 1,400 to 1,500 by next spring. **********Mr. Bhirud added that ''the psychology of the market will shift when it realizes that the economic recovery is sustainable in 1985.'' The market could get ''an extra kicker,'' he said, from a further decline in oil prices and a stronger export climate because of a topping out of the dollar's strength. **********Lower Interest Rates Help **********''Things are beginning to fall in place,'' said Thomas Williams, senior vice president of Kemper Financial Services. Most important, he said, the decline in interest rates in the last month makes stocks more attractive investments compared with short- or long-term fixed income securities. And it could spur more consumer and business spending, thus pumping new life into the flagging economy, analysts say. **********Further, Mr. Williams sees the possibility after the election of a cut by the Fed in the discount rate for the funds it lends to member banks. And he expects further downward pressure on rates coming from pension funds, which will move to lock up current rates on long-term bonds before they fall further. **********How long will a market rally last? Richard Hoffman, a market strategist who advises institutions out of his own firm, R. J. Hoffman & Company, believes the gains will ''be short but sweet.'' By next April or May, he expects investors to turn bearish because the economy will have become overheated and little will have been done to curb the Federal deficit. **********To be sure, there is still a tug-of- war between investors who fear the slowdown in the growth of the economy will lead to a recession and those who believe the more modest growth rate can be sustained well into 1985. It is what has kept the market in a state of fits and starts for the last few months. **********18% in Cash Investments **********Andrew Furtak, portfolio manager in charge of the $1.4 billion IDS Stock Fund, for instance, is ''staying loose,'' as he puts it, by setting aside a relatively high 18 percent of his portfolio for short-term cash investments. **********''There are just too many crosscurrents,'' he said. ''The market is so volatile. It can go 50 to 70 points either way.'' He believes it will take further cuts in interest rates, so that money market funds, for instance, will be less appealing, before the retail investor returns to the stock market. **********Institutional investors are already fairly heavily invested, said Dudley Eppel, managing director in charge of trading for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''If the market gets going, it will have to do so on its own,'' he said. **********More trouble lies ahead before that happens, according to Steven Kroll, chief investment officer of Hutton Asset Management, which manages $1.2 billion of mutual funds. ''After the election, people are going to realize that corporate earnings estimates will continue to come down,'' he said. The market, he added, has not ''discounted the earnings shortfall'' that will result from a slight decrease in sales coupled with corporations' inability to raise prices in a non-inflationary environment. **********Nonetheless, the good news about interest rates outweighs that risk, says Robert Hill, executive vice president of Favia, Hill Inc., the money management subsidiary of the Chemical Bank. In the last few weeks, his firm has moved $200 million out of cash investments into stocks. ''Consumer confidence is high and capital spending will accelerate with the decline in interest rates,'' he said. ''We view the current malaise in the market as a lag in appreciation of a decline in interest rates.'' **********'The Stage Is Set' **********''The stage is set for an enormous rally,'' said Robert Chamine, head trader at Wertheim & Company. ''I think the market is going sky-high.'' With lower interest rates and the expectation for continued low inflation, ''there's isn't a negative on the horizon,'' he said. Institutional investors, he added ''want to buy stocks; they just need a catalyst.'' **********The stocks that institutions are buying these days reflect the current lower interest rate, low inflation environment. Many money managers, for instance, have moved more aggressively into the so-called interest- sensitive stocks, such as banks and savings and loan associations that stand to benefit from lower costs of funds. They also like utilities because their high dividends compare more favorably with fixed-income investments now. **********Mr. Hill of Favia, Hill has been a recent buyer of Northern States Power as an interest rate play, and he also favors a number of consumer product companies, such as Pillsbury and Squibb. They should perform well, he said, because they are enjoying ''high unit growth'' and do not need large increases in the price of their products to show good earnigns gains. **********A ''major theme'' of recent new investments for Mr. Furtak's IDS Stock Fund has been stocks that will benefit from a topping out of the strength in the dollar due to less demand by foreigners for dollar-denominated fixed income securities. Multinational stocks, such as the drug companies and General Electric, have caught his eye, Mr. Furtak said, because of the likelihood of stronger United States exports and a more favorable atmosphere for foreign earnings translations. **********If the market does take off, a far broader list of stocks than the current favorites will start hopping, of course. These could well include the much beaten down technology stocks, which Mr. Williams says ''nobody loves, nobody even likes right now.'' He believes they may well be among the strongest performers next year because of their current depressed levels and because even in a modest growth economy they will turn in above-average earnings gains. **********Like Mr. Hoffman, Mr. Biggs of Morgan Stanley expects that by early spring the surging market will be at a crossroads. But ''whether the runup will be the last leg of the bull market or just a beginning,'' he said, ''depends on declining oil prices and if Reagan takes a big whack at the deficit.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/11/busin.main_headline: COMPANY NEWS Retailers Seek Growth Ideas
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/11/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS Retailers Seek Growth Ideas
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/11/busin.body_text: **********With the year's sales outlook already robust, retailers at a national convention in New York yesterday pushed for new ideas that could provide still more strength. **********In session after session at the annual convention of the National Retail Merchants' Association, new tools for merchandising, credit, competition and marketing were suggested. **********''Marketing has finally come to retailing,'' said Samuel J. Cohen, a management consultant. **********'A Golden Era' **********''Retailing will be coming into a golden era, when the biggest buying segment, the 25- to 45-year olds, becomes the principal population segment,'' said Austin Kiplinger, editor in chief of the Kiplinger Washington Letter, speaking to a luncheon of the association's independent store unit at the New York Hilton Hotel. **********America's retailers should emulate the airlines and promote customer loyalty with ''frequent shopper'' programs similar to ''frequent flier'' plans, said Alfred Eisenpreis, vice president for retail marketing of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. **********''A frequent shopper's cumulative purchases could be tracked through the year with bonuses on reaching different purchase levels,'' he said, adding that incentives could be built in to stimulate shopping on slow days or for slow-moving merchandise. **********Time to 'Rehumanize' **********Criticizing cuts in salespeople, Mr. Eisenpreis said it was time to ''rehumanize the retail selling floor,'' adding: ''First we got rid of the phrase, 'May I help you?' Then we got rid of anyone who could help. The decline in manufacturing jobs has created a new labor pool. If we reposition store work as a rewarding career, practice outreach, provide effective training and discipline, we can create a new sales floor environment.'' **********What should long-established stores do when the bottom falls out of their area's economy? David A. Horr, president of Marting's Department Store in Portsmouth, Ohio, told a session that when the local steel mill closed permanently three years ago, idling 5 percent of the labor force, his century-old store decided to chart a new plan for the future. The result was short-term and long-term strategies developed from a professionally conducted attitude survey. **********'Get on With It' **********But the biggest hurdle, he said, was to finally stop planning ''and get on with it, probably the most difficult phase of all.'' He added: ''Plans should be reassessed from time to time. They need to be kept realistic and must involve as many employees as possible. Our lesson learned from hard times is - plan, plan, plan - it will give you control of the business.'' **********In another session, Stanley Marcus, chairman emeritus of Neiman-Marcus, Dallas, said retailing was insufficiently creative, often leaving it to the smaller operators. ''I suspect that most retailers are so busy buying goods, taking care of markdowns and so on that they have too little time to give thought to creativity,'' he said. ''It seems to me that the most creative people are shunning retailing and going into scientific and technological fields where creativity is encouraged, rather than sat upon.'' **********More Creativity Urged **********Mr. Marcus said retailers should study new methods of ''editing and putting together merchandise and how they display them in their stores.'' He added: ''Since merchandise creativity is hampered by the reluctance of manufacturers to do special things for an individual store, it might be well to increase purchases in foreign markets more able to accept innovative ideas.'' **********His suggestion, coincidentally or not, was endorsed by a unanimous vote taken by the association's executive board. That group yesterday approved a program to fight the Administration's tightened regulations of textile and apparel imports, which the retail group said cost its member concerns $600 million in lost business last year. The program calls for a campaign of political and legislative action, legal effort, international lobbying, public relations and research to fight the effort to stem curbs on buying abroad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/world.main_headline: SOVIET EXPECTED TO FREE 5 ALASKANS SOON
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/world.print_headline: SOVIET EXPECTED TO FREE 5 ALASKANS SOON
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/world.body_text: **********The captain of an Alaskan coastal fuel-supply ship that was seized last week by the Russians said today that he and his four-man crew had been told by United States diplomats that they would be released soon, ''maybe in a day, maybe two.'' **********In a telephone interview, Capt. Tabb Thoms said he understood that he and his crew would be put back aboard their vessel, the supply ship Frieda K, and ''escorted to the Soviet maritime boundary.'' **********But he said the Russians still had not told the sailors directly that they would be freed from their place of detention, which is in Urelik, just south of Provideniya, in northeastern Siberia. **********''They tell us very little and they won't tell us when we can go home,'' the captain said. **********(In Washington, the State Department said it had protested to the Soviet Union against its handling of the case and expected the seamen to be released within 48 hours.)   Hesitant to Sign Papers **********Captain Thoms said Soviet officials had been asking the Americans to sign papers acknowledging that they were in Soviet waters. **********''They want us to sign many papers,'' he said. ''We did not intentionally violate any laws, but we do not understand Soviet law and we do not want to sign the wrong kind of papers.'' **********Speaking over a poor telephone connection with the remote Siberian outpost on the Bering Sea, the captain confirmed with a ''roger'' that the crew was fine and being fed well. **********He said that he had not been permitted to get in touch by telephone with the United States Embassy in Moscow, but that an embassy officer had managed to telephone him. **********''He told us we will be released as soon as possible,'' Captain Thoms said. ''Maybe in a day, maybe two.'' **********An embassy spokesman said Foreign Ministry officials had said that the sailors would be released. But he did not say when they would be sent home to Alaska.    On Way to Delivery Fuel **********According to the Coast Guard in Juneau, the Frieda K was seized while on route south to Nome after having delivered fuel near Point Lay in northwest Alaska. **********Captain Thoms said his ship was seized Wednesday in what he thought were American waters, and the Russians then towed the ship to Urelik. **********''We were on our way to an island,'' he said when asked to describe how the 120-foot supply ship was seized. **********''We neared a gray ship to obtain local knowledge of any danger,'' he said. ''We were boarded by many soldiers carrying guns and were later towed by another battleship. Hours later they came and towed us to where we are.'' **********''They say we violated the Soviet boundary,'' he added.   U.S. Files Official Protest **********WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) - The State Department said today that it lodged an official protest on Monday over the Soviet Union's handling of the incident. **********John Hughes, the State Department spokesman, said the Russians had agreed to turn the Americans over to a Coast Guard cutter in international waters off Urelik. He said the transfer would probably occur within the next 24 to 48 hours. **********He said it would take the Coast Guard ship at least 24 hours to reach the rendezvous spot. **********With regard to the reported Soviet attempt to have the Americans sign a statement about being in Soviet waters, Mr. Hughes said he did not know whether they had actually signed. **********He also said, even if they had been in Soviet waters, ''clearly their voyage was an innocent one.'' **********He said the protest note had complained that United States officials were not given proper access to the seamen and that the seamen were asked to sign a statement declaring they had intentionally sailed into Soviet waters. **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz also raised the matter with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin on Monday, Mr. Hughes said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/24/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today visited the Golden Temple in Amritsar, the Sikh shrine that was the scene of fighting 16 days ago. She was reported to have heard demands from the head priest that the army be withdrawn and pilgrims be allowed to return. **********Amritsar itself, which had been the center of a Sikh movement aimed at greater autonomy for Punjab state, was described as returning to normal. **********The army continued its operation to round up Sikh militants. Seventeen were arrested Friday and today, and one person wanted in at least six murder cases was said to have been killed by the police in Jullundur district. **********Residents of Amritsar arriving here, along with Indian reporters, said the climate of fear that had gripped the city for months had eased. **********Nearly 600 people, according to official reports, and perhaps more than 1,000, according to other estimates, were killed during the army's invasion of the Golden Temple compound, which militants had turned into a fortress. Among the dead was a Sikh leader, Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale.   Half-Hour Visit to Temple **********Mrs. Gandhi, accompanied by Government radio and television reporters, spent half an hour in the temple. She touched her shrouded head to the floor of the gold-sheathed inner sanctum, tendered an offering of rupees and, while musicians chanted prayers, she took a mouthful of the mush that is used in what corresponds to communion for Sikhs. **********The scene was televised, apparently as part of an effort to mollify Sikhs angry over the invasion of the temple. **********During the visit, Mrs. Gandhi was told that some Sikh scriptures had been damaged during the battle. Giani Sahib Singh, the head priest, demanded that the army be pulled out and that worshippers be allowed to use the temple during fixed hours. **********The Punjab Government said it would soon begin taking busloads of pilgrims to the temple to quell misgivings about its condition. **********The head priest also urged Mrs. Gandhi to bring about an early release of innocent people arrested during the temple raid and in army sweeps through the Punjabi countryside. Some official sources say that perhaps 200 of the nearly 1,600 people arrested in the temple raid are innocent pilgrims and that more than 100 are temple employees. More than 4,000 have been reported arrested in all, and many of them are expected to be released after screening.   Lower Estimate Being Offered **********Some Government officials have now returned to an estimate, made before the army moved into Punjab on June 2, that no more than 400 to 500 militants were operating from the temple. The identity of the others is unclear, though they are presumed to include criminals, fugitives, and fringe members of the Bhindranwale group. **********As normal traffic in and out of Punjab picked up, a longtime Sikh resident of Amritsar arrived here Friday and reported that ''in general, there is a very, very big sense of relief in Amritsar.'' **********Just before the army action, he said, Sikh militants capitalizing on the situation had created a climate of fear throughout the city and its surrounding villages. **********The resident said Sikhs and Hindus alike felt the relief, although a residual fear remained that militants might still seek revenge on people who were not with them. **********At the same time, the Amritsar resident said, ''people are afraid that when the army leaves, there will be further looting and killing.''  Soldiers Are Called Courteous **********The resident also said that, according to preliminary reports, army troops in both the city and the countryside were behaving with restraint and courtesy. Although the soldiers searched houses at will, first reports said, there was said to be little or no brutality. **********Some people were reported killed in curfew violations, however. **********A team of reporters from the Press Trust of India, a news agency, also reported from Amritsar that there were visible signs of relief among citizens and that, while there was uneasy silence, there seemed to be no tension. **********Business and social activity was said to be reviving rapidly, in contrast to the weeks before the army crackdown, when militants struck at will, business in some places came to a halt, and people began to stay indoors. **********Foreigners, including reporters, are not allowed into Punjab, which for all the reported signs of normalcy still remains essentially under martial law.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/17/busin.main_headline: INSURANCE SALES BEGIN AT 2 CITIBANK BRANCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/17/busin.print_headline: INSURANCE SALES BEGIN AT 2 CITIBANK BRANCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/17/busin.body_text: **********Citibank, which has said that it wants to add insurance to its array of financial products, began offering life insurance policies yesterday through an insurance company at two of its New York City branches. **********Under the arrangement, term, universal and whole-life policies will be sold at Citibank by salaried employees of the American International Life Assurance Company of New York. The company, a member of the American International Group, which took in more than $1 billion in life insurance premiums last year, has leased space in Citibank branches. **********Leasing Terms **********A spokesman for Citibank, Susan Weeks, said that the bank would receive a flat rate or a percentage of sales, whichever is higher, for the use of its space. She declined to say what the rate or the percentage would be, adding that the bank had made no sales projections. ''We were primarily interested in giving customers a chance to buy insurance in a one- stop environment,'' she said. **********The first two branches to offer the service are at 42d Street and Madison Avenue, and at 86th Street and Broadway. Citibank said that six more branches in the New York area would add insurance centers by the end of this year, and that the program would be expanded to more branches in 1985. It also said that in the next year, the centers would introduce policies for cars, homeowners and renters.  Citibank has long expressed an interest in developing an insurance business. Last year it was one of several major banks that applied to buy state-chartered institutions in South Dakota, which permits such banks to sell insurance. However, at the request of the Federal Reserve Board, which said that banking's entry into insurance should be addressed at a national level, the banks withdrew their applications. **********Separately, Citibank makes life and health insurance available to its Mastercard and Visa cardholders under another arrangement with insurance companies. The bank, a unit of Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, is the nation's largest issuer of bank credit cards. **********With the new insurance plan, Citibank joins a growing number of banks providing branch space for financial services they are not permitted to sell directly. **********Earlier this year, both Bank of America, the nation's second-largest banking company, and First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles announced plans to lease space to insurance companies. Bank of America, which is based in San Francisco, said yesterday that it would introduce the program in two areas this fall. **********Arthur Soter, a securities analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company, said that the banks would benefit by gaining additional revenues from subletting their excess space. **********In addition, ''there's lots of uncertainty in Washington over the swiftness of product deregulation,'' he said, citing as a reason the troubles at the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company. Pending further deregulation, Mr. Soter said that making space available for an insurance office is ''a way to get customers even more reliant on a bank for all their financial services.'' He added, ''It's another little step in the evolution toward a more rational banking system.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/10/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Foreign Stocks Lure Big Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/10/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Foreign Stocks Lure Big Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/10/busin.body_text: **********SINCE stock prices in many foreign countries have outperformed United States equities for 18 months or longer, corporate pension and profit-sharing funds are increasingly turning to investment possibilities overseas. And money managers, in turn, busily court these American institutional investors. **********It is a business dominated by big players: major New York City banks, investment counseling firms, merchant banks in Britain and specialized boutiques on the Continent. Pension fund money that has traveled abroad runs into billions of dollars. Most of that money, of course, has been invested overseas for some years. **********A relative newcomer to this league, and admittedly a small player, is Wardley Marine International Investment Management. Based in London, Wardley Marine is a part of the huge Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation and was formed by Wardley Investment Services Ltd. and Marine Midland Banks. Its specific aim is to tap the pension fund pool for equity investing outside the United States. **********Stephen M. Swift, managing director of Wardley Marine in London, talked about investments abroad during a visit this week to New York. **********''We expect Japan to continue as the largest segment of an overseas fund since it offers liquidity and, next to the United States, is the largest of all stock markets,'' he said. ''Currently, 45 percent of our portfolio is in Japanese stocks. **********''Last year, our investments were oriented mainly towards those Japanese companies, often of a technological nature, ranking as major exporters. Typical examples would be Fanuc Ltd., a manufacturer of numerical controls, and Matsushita Electric Industries, a leading maker of consumer electronic products.'' **********At present, however, Wardley Marine's holdings in Japan are more closely related to that country's domestic economy. **********''We are buying basically two types of stocks,'' Mr. Swift said. ''One consists of insurance companies, such as Sumitomo Marine and Fire, and Tokio Marine and Fire. The other includes cyclical and basic chemical issues, such as Sumitomo Chemical and Mitsubishi Petrochemical.'' **********European countries represented in the portfolio are typical: Britain, West Germany and the Netherlands. Holdings in Germany include Siemens, which makes electrical and electronic products, while Royal Dutch Petroleum is a leading investment in the Netherlands. As for Britain, the favorites range from British Petroleum to the General Electric Company P.L.C. (which has no connection with the United States company). **********Mr. Swift's experience as an international money manager includes stints in Hong Kong and Singapore. He was asked to name several stocks that appear to be attractive investments, anywhere in the world, over the next year or so. **********''In Japan, I would suggest Mitsui Chemical as a basic industry company and also Nippon Oil in energy,'' he replied. ''In Europe, there's a little Belgian stock trading at a ludicrously low price- earnings multiple. This is Bekaert, a producer of specialty steel for radial tires.'' **********There is no way for American investors, big or small, to buy into Wardley Marine itself. However, shares of Hongkong and Shanghai Banking are traded on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market here in the form of American depository receipts. **********In its research coverage of foreign stocks, Merrill Lynch carries an ''O.K. to buy'' opinion on shares of the bank. On the basis of investor suitability, the stock is rated ''speculative,'' the brokerage firm noted, ''because of the political uncertainty in Hong Kong.'' This is an allusion to the future of the British colony, one of the most aggressive and successful trading centers in the world, after 1997, when Britain's lease from China on 90 percent of the territory expires. **********Elsewhere, the Securities Industry Association has reported that no fewer than 12 foreign stock exchanges chalked up bigger gains last year in dollar terms than the United States equity market. **********''The boom of stock markets worldwide sent U.S. investors on an unparalleled buying spree,'' the brokerage firm trade group said. ''Net purchases of foreign securities reached a record $3.8 billion,'' compared with the previous high of $2.1 billion in 1980. **********American investors of all types were net buyers of $1.1 billion of British stocks last year. Japan ranked as the next favorite overseas market, with net purchases totaling $950 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/20/busin.print_headline: YOUR MONEY; I.R.A. ACCOUNT AND INSURANCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Your MoneyLeonard Sloane I.R.A. Account And Insurance **********WHEN a bank offers an Individual Retirement Account, as thousands around the country do, any edge over its competitors' products could lure many additional customers. And one such marketing tool that hundreds of banks and savings institutions are offering these days is free life and/or disability insurance under a concept generically known as I.R.A. completion insurance. **********The name is actually a misnomer, because the insurance does not necessarily guarantee the completion of an I.R.A. program. What these programs do, though, is give one or both types of insurance - frequently of an amount only up to the annual allowable investment of $2,000, or $2,250 for a couple with a nonworking spouse - at no charge to the investor. **********Typically, the insurance will pay to the I.R.A. holder or beneficiary the amount that would have been accumulated if deposits had continued on the same basis. The customer thereby gets something for nothing, while the institution gets an add-on that helps it compete, not only against other banks but against individual retirement annuities sold by insurance companies as well. **********''If I saw an I.R.A. plan at a bank that gives you this thing, I'd say sure, take it, it doesn't hurt,'' said W. Wesley Howard, editor of the IRA Reporter, a Cleveland-based newsletter that follows this field. ''It really is group term life insurance.'' **********''The pitch is that, instead of shopping rates only, the consumer is also shopping benefits,'' said Kelly Green, first vice president of Financial Institution Services Inc., a Nashville service company that has set up an insurance program for 100 banks and other institutions. ''We can show that a bank may not have the highest rate in town, but consumers say that it has the best benefits.'' **********In addition to these programs, there are others through which financial institutions sell insurance to holders of their I.R.A.'s. But although the price of such insurance may be lower than the individual would pay elsewhere, this type of I.R.A. completion insurance has not been as popular among consumers as the kind provided free. **********Most of the free programs, moreover, are created by insurance companies, insurance brokers or service organizations that originate the plans and sell them to participating banks and thrift institutions. If the cost of the insurance is paid by the institution, however, it is limited by Internal Revenue Service regulations covering the value of giveaways in connection with retirement accounts. **********These rules - which apply to other items that may be offered in connection with I.R.A.'s, such as cameras or toasters - set dollar limits to the value of such premiums. The maximum value permitted is $10 for deposits up to $5,000 and $20 for deposits over $5,000. **********The impetus for the I.R.A. completion insurance programs came in 1982, when I.R.A.'s were opened to all working people with earned income of at least $2,000 a year. Since then they have grown, faster in some areas than others, as more and more banks recognize the need to retain I.R.A. customers who might otherwise move accounts elsewhere in search of higher rates or other considerations. **********For example, the Citizens Community and Savings Bank in Flint, Mich., offers free $25,000 common-carrier coverage and accidental death protection equal to the account balance, with a maximum of $25,000. This insurance is available to I.R.A. customers with a minimum balance of $500. **********''It helps us to differentiate our product offerings from other institutions,'' said Alex Bese, assistant cashier. ''We're the only institution in our local market area that has something like this.'' **********Another version of I.R.A. completion insurance is offered by the Franklin Savings Association of Ottawa, Kan., in such a way that it is not covered by the Federal premium limitations. I.R.A. customers who are under age 59 1/2 can purchase a combination disability and life insurance policy for the amount of their deposit up to $2,000 or $2,250 at an annual cost of $30. But when they pay for the insurance, their accounts are credited with bonus interest of the same $30. **********''Roughly 50 percent of the eligible customers have taken advantage of it,'' said Edward Barnes, vice president for marketing. ''Some people say, 'It sounds too good to be true, what's the gimmick?' '' **********Some of the completion insurance programs have as features other advantages besides the insurance, also presented free to the customer as an extra incentive to obtain and retain accounts. These benefits include a discount telephone shopping service, a discount on hotel rooms, emergency cash services and financial newsletters. **********Among the reasons cited for the development of I.R.A. completion insurance is that there are enough financial institutions that would rather compete in the marketplace by offering that feature than by changing their interest rates to match the highest ones advertised locally. **********For the public, whenever this insurance is tied to a rate that is close to the best in the area, it is well worth considering when selecting a location for I.R.A. funds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/03/busin.body_text: **********The word conjures up images of a rugged, agile Tibetan guide leading adventuresome British climbers up the face of Mount Everest. In the world of modern economics, however, the term has taken on a more genteel meaning. **********Today's sherpas are the seven key government aides who lead their nation's chief executives in their ascent to the world's economic summit. There, the leaders of the world's seven largest non-Communist industrial nations, primed for both the obvious and the arcane questions of economic policy, work to narrow the gap on global disagreements. The sherpas and their backup teams try to assure that their nations' leaders are not embarrassed by surprises at the highly publicized meetings - and to see that issues most important to their chief executives are given sufficient airing. **********This year, the 10th economic summit conference will be held in London, starting next Thursday and ending Saturday night with a state banquet at Buckingham Palace. In addition to President Reagan, the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan and West Germany will attend. (The European Economic Community also sends a sherpa and its president.) For Mr. Reagan, it will be summit No. 4. And for his lead sherpa, W. Allen Wallis, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, it will be summit No. 2. **********According to the 71-year-old Mr. Wallis, work on the 1984 meeting began on the last day of the 1983 summit meeting in Williamsburg, Va., when the seven sherpas began planning for London. The stately, self-confident economist, who believes in free market capitalism with a fervor rivaling the President's, does not expect substantive disagreements this year - primarily because the world economic recovery is proceeding apace and Europe is a chief beneficiary. Even high United States interest rates and big budget deficits should not cause much friction, according to Mr. Wallis. **********But despite the hundreds of hours of meetings and careful Presidential briefings, there are some aspects of summitry that Mr. Wallis and his counterparts cannot control. The informal agenda instituted last year at Williamsburg by President Reagan will be continued this year. Half of the meeting time in London will involve only the seven leaders - no finance ministers, no foreign ministers, no sherpas attending. It will perhaps be in those times that the bluntest expressions of concern over United States eco nomic policy will be voiced and where the sherpa's preparations could be most severely tested. **********What follows are answers to questions asked Mr. Wallis during a recent visit to New York.  Q. What does the Administration  hope to accomplish in London? **********A. It will have two broad goals. One will be to emphasize that the recovery is here and that the problem now is to strengthen the recovery, make sure that it lasts, make sure that it is non- inflationary and make sure that it spreads to the rest of the world as rapidly as possible. **********The other big goal will be to strengthen the world trading system and finance system by keeping markets open and opening some that never have been open, such as in the developing countries and in Japan.  Q. What objections will the other  countries raise to American eco nomic policy? **********A. I don't think there will be really basic disagreements on major issues. I think there will be differences about how to achieve various goals. For example, the United States is convinced that it is important to get a firm decision as soon as possible from the GATT (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade) on launching the work for a new round of multilateral trade negotiations. Q. Which would do what? **********A. Well, it would have to deal with a lot of issues that the preceding rounds have not dealt with. The other ones were confined largely to tariffs on manufactured products. Now, we need to consider such physical restraints as quotas, which have come to replace tariffs in recent years. We need to limit them in some way. We also need to open up more markets for agricultural products and services. **********The modern economies are becoming more and more service-oriented and there is no provision in the GATT for maintaining open markets for services - things like banking, insurance, management consulting, engineering services and so on. **********And then they need to deal with Government subsidies, such as the European subsidies for agricultural exports, which have become more important in international trade than tariffs used to be. **********It is going to take a lot of work even to start a round. That is, you cannot start a round like that until you get pretty good agreement on what the problems are and what the range of possible solutions is that people might agree to.  Q. How far away from a new round  of international trade talks do you  think you are? **********A. We would hope that the GATT would decide by the end of '85 to launch the work for a new round. But even if they do it, I doubt that they can start the negotiations before '87.  Q. So what can the summit hope to  accomplish? **********A. We would like to get the heads of state to urge the GATT to make a decision by the end of '85 on going ahead with a new multilateral trade negotiations.  Q. Do you think you will have a  problem getting them to agree to  that? **********A. Well, some countries want to and some don't. Q. Who would be against it? **********A. That is fairly public information. In the European Economic Community, France and Italy are resistant. The Japanese first floated the idea. We welcomed it. The Germans do. The British do.  Q. Why would the French oppose a  new GATT round? **********A. Well, France has always been quite a protectionist country, although they deny it. And I think they have the feeling that they have lagged in modern high-technology products, behind the Japanese and the United States - and I guess they have. So they probably feel they would be at a competitive disadvantage if we started major talks on breaking down trade restraints. **********The French have not said, ''No, we'll never do that.'' If they had, we would not be considering it seriously. They'll consider it. But they'll have some arguments against it, which will show just how slow you have to go in starting a new trade round.  Q. Are you expecting strong objec tions from the other countries as to  the size of the United States Federal  budget deficit? **********A. Not a lot, because that is the pot calling the kettle black. The other countries are going to be sensitive to the fact that their deficits as percentages of their gross national products are on the whole as large as ours. I think they will be a bit concerned. They will be saying that the deficit has pushed interest rates and the dollar up. As you know, Marty Feldstein thinks that is a factor. But I don't think deficits cause rates to rise and other economists around in Washington don't seem to share that view either.  Q. You're talking about the Admin istration's economists, aren't you? **********A. Yes, but it does not matter. High interest rates are without a doubt a problem because they increase the problem of debt service for the less- developed countries. But they are not caused by the deficit. I think a large factor in the rise of interest rates is the boom in economic activity - the demand for resources to invest is pushing rates up. **********At the same time, however, the boom in economic activity is expanding the market for exports of the industrial nations and the less-developed countries, and that is very much to their advantage. We have made some preliminary calculations that show in the case of one L.D.C. that a 1 percent increase in its exports sparked by economic expansion will probably more than offset the effects of a 1 percent rise in interest rates.   Q. But does that justify high inter est rates? **********A. Of course they would be better off if they could have the increase in exports and a decrease in interest rates. All I am saying is that before you say the increase in interest rates is going to throw them into a tailspin, you want to look at what is associated with it. The rise in interest rates is a consequence of the big increase in economic activity, which in turn increases their export markets, which in turn makes it easier for them to service their debt problem.  Q. What will Mr. Reagan say if the  other nations want to talk seriously  about lowering interest rates? Will he  say there is nothing the United States  can do but just let the market oper ate? **********A. I don't know what he will say. I would say for myself that I would like to know what the other countries have in mind. If they think having the Fed increase the quantity of money would lower interest rates, I think they have got it backwards. Nowadays, the interest rate market is supersensitive to the prospects for inflaton. Even though inflation is under control, the markets just don't believe it is going to stay under control. **********So the markets are going to be very sensitive to anything that suggests there is going to be an increase in inflation. Once they see the money supply growing fast, they immediately get jumpy and that tends to raise interest rates.  Q. Will the United States be pressed  to intervene more frequently on cur rency markets? **********A. No. The most the other countries do now is say that in disorderly markets we should maybe intervene to smooth them out. And once in awhile we do that in a small way. But nobody knows whether when something starts in the currency markets it is a temporary turbulence or a permanent change setting in. And the market knows that better than the Government will ever know it - and the market knows it faster.  Q. In light of the collapse of the Con tinental Illinois Bank, do you think  the other leaders will voice concern  about the international banking sys tem? **********A. Oh, I don't think that will come into the discussion at all. The bank's problems did not arise out of international debt. Q. But could not the lack of confi dence that plagued Continental arise  from a similar confidence problem in  banks holding large amounts of third  world debt? **********A. If someone thinks that, then the lesson is that the Continental problem did not disrupt the domestic financial system. The lesson would be that we seem to have devices that can move in and take up a problem like that. **********I am not saying that nobody is apprehensive about the banking system. There are major problems in some of these debtor countries. But it looks as if the system is working. We think that if people stick to the policies, it will work out. But any idea that people are relaxed or complacent or saying that problem is solved is completely wrong.  Q. What is the role of a sherpa in an  economic summit? **********A. It is really to prepare for the summit. When the President goes, he would like to know which subjects are going to be discussed. And beyond that, he would like to have some input beforehand into deciding what subjects are going to be discussed. And also, he would like to know what are the attitudes of the other countries. Some of the same questions you are asking me. He wants to know that before he gets there, so that he is prepared to carry on an intelligent discussion, and not say, ''Gee, I never heard that before. I'll have to go off and think about it.'' **********So basically the work of the sherpas is to find out. You meet with your head of Government and tell him what the others have said, and he reacts to that and at the next sherpas' meeting you react to what is going on according to the reaction you got at home. **********So it is basically an elaborate effort to make sure that the time at the summit is most efficiently used, and to know where the areas of disagreement will be.  Q. Is there no pre-agreed  communique this year? **********A. No. There was no pre-agreed communique at Williamsburg and there will not be one this year either.  Q. Why did the President dispense  with that last year? **********A. Usually, as I understand it, the seven countries began to meet about four months before the summit and they wrote the final communique. The President told me that when he went to his first summit in Ottawa, he was flabbergasted. The first thing they did was pull out the communique and start to go through it word by word. Is this the right word? Is this the idea? And is that the right punctuation? The communique just dominated the whole meeting, so they did not get this free-for-all, give-and-take that they wanted. Q. How closely do you work with the  President? **********A. The closer you get to the summit the more time you spend with him. Last year we did have a couple weeks when we were meeting several times during the week. Q. And who participates in those  meetings?  A. Well, the other members of the sherpa team - Beryl Sprinkel (Under Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Affairs), and Douglas McMinn, who is a senior staff member and trade specialist at the National Security Council. Then there is a White House summit team of which the co-heads are Michael Deaver, the Deputy Chief of Staff, and Robert McFarlane, head of the N.S.C. Q. George Shultz? Donald Regan? **********A. Almost always Shultz and Regan, because the Secretary of State and Treasury Secretary always go to the summit. But sometimes other Cabinet members on issues that may come up there. Just basically whoever has something to contribute that will help enlighten the President on all the issues he may run into. There are a hundred things that could be sprung on him there.  Q. Do you think the other countries  could rightly accuse the Reagan Ad ministration of stepping up protec tionism over the last year? **********A. Not really. Again, it would be the pot calling the kettle black. We are about the least protectionist country that there is, unless you think of Hong Kong. In the last year, they have all taken additional protectionist measures, especially the Common Market. They will not bring that up just because they will be too vulnerable themselves. **********Q. It seems that this is not going to  be an eventful summit. **********A. In a way, summits should never be big treaty-signing dramas. It is not what they do there that counts, it is what you do after the summit that means something. Moreover, there is a sense in which they do not ever talk about the really important economic issues. Should you really have free trade? Should countries be buying and selling internationally, and so on? Because what they discuss are points of friction that arise when you do have a lot of trade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/01/busin.body_text: **********The Boston Stock Exchange said today that it had agreed to link its trading floor electronically with the Montreal Exchange. **********The agreement is intended to make the two small exchanges more competitive with their larger rivals, said Charles Mohr, chairman and chief executive of the Boston Stock Exchange. If the venture succeeds, Boston exchange officials will take steps to link with European cities, Mr. Mohr said. **********He added that the Montreal link would be the first between an American and a foreign stock exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/29/busin.body_text: **********The LTV Steel Company said it plans a joint venture with Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd. of Japan to build a $130 million galvanizing line at LTV's Cleveland works. **********An LTV spokesman, Mark Thomasch, declined to give more details, saying that the information will be provided when the announcement is officially made. **********The plant would use a sophisticated technique known as electrogalvanizing to simultaneously apply smooth, uniform coats of zinc to both sides of the sheet metal. The galvanized steel resists corrosion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/08/busin.body_text: **********Fortunately for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, the opening of the economic summit conference today coincided with the House of Commons' first debate on Britain's coal strike, now three months old. **********While Mrs. Thatcher and Britain's news media were preparing for the pageantry of summit delegations arriving at the Orangery beside Kensington Palace, 10,000 coal miners were marching angrily along Fleet Street toward the House of Commons to focus attention on their grievances. **********The traffic-snarling march followed embarrassing disclosures about the Government's handling of the dispute. Memos leaked this week suggested that Mrs. Thatcher and the Government were far more involved than previously acknowledged in the handling of the strike by the state-owned National Coal Board. **********The memos showed the Government to have ordered British Rail to increase its pay offer to railway workers to keep them from joining the miners in a strike that could have paralyzed the nation. This contradicted Mrs. Thatcher's repeated assertions that negotiations by state-owned enterprises were left to professional managers.   10 Downing Street Spruced Up **********During the Commons debate this evening, Mrs. Thatcher played host for the heads of state at 10 Downing Street - dressed up this week with the addition of several new paintings and a Henry Moore statue - instead of facing tough questioning from political opponents. **********In addition to taking the spotlight away from the miners, politicians suspect that the summit meeting may pay political dividends for Britain's Conservatives by allowing Mrs. Thatcher to play the role of a world leader and eminent European in the days before next week's European Parliament elections. **********Although the European campaign has left most British voters bored, the results will be closely analyzed for signs that the Labor Party has rebounded under the leadership of Neil Kinnock from last June's crushing election defeat, which left Mrs. Thatcher's Conservatives with a 144-seat overall majority, the largest since Clement R. Attlee's 147-seat margin in 1946. Recent polls show Labor trailing the Conservatives by only one or two percentage points. The European election is also viewed as a crucial test of the Social Democratic Party/Liberal Party Alliance. **********'She Certainly Is Fortunate' **********''It's frustrating,'' said Simon Hughes, a Liberal Party Member of Parliament, in reference to the coverage Mrs. Thatcher's week is garnering. ''She certainly is fortunate.'' **********The summit conference does hold risks for Mrs. Thatcher, too. She will be anxious to observe the unspoken rule of summit meetings - never embarrass a candidate - but she can ill afford any appearance of subservience to President Reagan. **********President Reagan's decision to invade Grenada, a Commonwealth member, despite British opposition, dented Mrs. Thatcher's reputation here. **********Mrs. Thatcher's critics are also attacking her efforts to play down the importance of any action at the summit talks. **********''It would be better if the summit had been held at Madame Tussaud's,'' said Denis Healey, the Labor Party's spokesman on foreign affairs, referring to London's famous wax figure museum. ''It is clear that the heads of government there will be waxworks. They will not make an attempt to act on any problem.'' **********A number of groups are hoping to turn the deliberately deflated expectations for policy actions at the talks into a political liability for Mrs. Thatcher. They are staging competing events to draw attention to their own policies.   Other 'Summit' Conferences **********A group of Labor Party members will be meeting with Socialists from other countries and with economists who argue for coordinated increases in government spending and transfers of wealth as the best policy for summit nations at one ''countersummit.'' **********Separately, a ''green'' philosophy is being presented to 120 participants at the ''Other Summit,'' where Britain's Ecology Party and other groups are arguing that the leaders at the summit meeting and the Socialists have mistakenly focused solely on growth as a solution to economic problems. **********In addition, the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament is planning large demonstrations here Saturday to protest cruise missiles. **********Mrs. Thatcher has planned her summit talks so that the visitors are unlikely to encounter such events. The summit meetings and meals will be held in a handful of tradition-rich sites well screened from the public by a huge police operation. **********''The key words from the Prime Minister's point of view are 'informal' and 'workmanlike,' '' said Ian Kydd, a press spokesman. ''There's to be a minimum of ceremony.'' **********The summit conference is budgeted for just over $5 million, less than the cost of the three previous gatherings. **********Aides said that few details seemed too small to interest Mrs. Thatcher. Shortly before flying to France for the D-Day ceremonies, she was seen touring Lancaster House, where the meetings will take place, in a final inspection of everything from seating arrangements to floral displays.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/31/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Chrysler Financial Plans More Notes
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/31/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Financial Corporation said yesterday that it intends to continuously offer up to $500 million of medium-term notes, both directly and through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Salomon Brothers as agents. The notes will have maturities ranging from nine months to seven years from the date of issue. **********The continuous offering of these medium-term notes is in addition to the Chrysler Corporation subsidiary's continuous offering of up to $300 million of variable-rate notes due in 1992, an offering that began in late June. The company has sold $210 million of the variable-rate notes so far. Their interest rate, changing quarterly, is one-fourth percentage point above the offered rate for three- month interbank deposits in London. **********In a separate development, Duff & Phelps, a rating agency, assigned a rating of D&P 10 to Chrysler Financial's medium-term notes. The rating corresponds to the low triple-B category and is slightly higher than the rating assigned by Moody's or Standard & Poor's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/world.main_headline: HOST OF PROBLEMS FACE NEW LEADER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/world.print_headline: HOST OF PROBLEMS FACE NEW LEADER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/world.body_text: **********Whoever takes the place of Yuri V. Andropov as leader of the Soviet Union will face a host of problems that he might be called upon to address immediately. **********Around the Soviet Union's far-flung borders, the policies of the last two decades have saddled the Kremlin with costly and unproductive dependencies, with a vexing war in Afghanistan, frustrated ambitions in the Middle East and, most seriously, with a stalemate in disarmament talks and the worst relations with the United States in at least two decades. **********This weekend, in well-appointed parlors and suites around Moscow, powerful men are probably gathered in clusters, their thoughts and schemes focused on the vacancy in one of the world's most powerful offices. **********The complex maneuvering may never come to light, since all that the world is likely to see sometime soon is a ''unanimous'' decision by the Central Committee of the Communist Party on a successor to Yuri V. Andropov. **********And sometime next week, one of the late leader's comrades from the Politburo will have to stand alone on the figurative ramparts of the Kremlin and survey what he had fought so arduously to take charge of. **********Vice President Bush, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Chancellor Helmut Kohl have all announced plans to come to Moscow for Mr. Andropov's funeral, and all will be looking for signals from the new chief on the future of East-West relations. **********On the domestic front, the new leader will inherit a system choked by inefficiency, lack of motivation and corruption, despite the campaigns his predecessor launched against these evils. **********With a military machine crying for resources to meet what it sees as the threat of American rearmament under President Reagan, the new chief will be pressured to accelerate the economic experiments and tinkering that Mr. Andropov set in motion before illness sent him to the sidelines. **********The new man will take charge of an agricultural system unable to supply the nation's needs, a high-technology industry decades behind that of the West and falling ever farther behind, and a sluggish, bloated bureaucracy. **********These challenges are essentially the same ones Mr. Andropov faced in his 15-month tenure. But in contrast to the current contenders for the job, the late chief came to office armed with the prestige and power of a man who had spent 15 years at the head of the K.G.B. security police, and who had the backing of the military and majority support in the Politburo.   A Few Advantages **********The advantages a new leader will face are those offered by a totalitarian system. Once in office, he is unlikely to face serious challenges to his job, and in the highly centralized system political powers will naturally gravitate toward him, especially as the old power brokers like Dmitri F. Ustinov, Nikolai A. Tikhonov or Andrei A. Gromyko pass away. **********For all the occasional talk in the West of a crisis in Soviet morale because of the lack of consumer goods or food, the reality is that Russians seem capable of tightening their belts to a degree few in the West could tolerate, and there have been no tangible signs - beyond widespread grumbling - of serious dissatisfaction. **********The dissident movement, once reasonably organized and widely publicized, has been effectively decimated. The most immediate challenge to any new leader will be to find ways out of the freeze in East-West relations and the deadlock in arms talks. **********In the bitter dispute over the new American missiles in Europe, the Kremlin had staked its strategy on dissuading the Europeans from accepting the rockets. The policy failed last November, and the Russians walked out of the talks on medium-range missiles and refused to set a date for resumption of the talks on strategic arms.   Another Daunting Problem **********Since then, the Soviet position has been that negotiations can resume only if the Americans return to the situation that existed before the beginning of the deployment of medium-range missiles. Washington is hardly likely to do this, especially if President Reagan is re-elected. And the harsh words slung between Washington and Moscow in the past months will make reconciliation difficult even for a new leader. **********Most diplomats here believe that the Soviet military, in the person of Marshal Ustinov, and the Foreign Ministry, in the person of Mr. Gromyko, are unlikely to let a new chief make overtures to Washington after the slights they feel they have suffered in the negotiations and at Mr. Reagan's hands. Most diplomats, however, believe the prospects of huge new investments in a continued arms race must persuade the Russians to find a way back to the negotiating table, if necessary with Mr. Reagan. **********A more promising arena for Soviet foreign policy is the Middle East. Against a background of recent military successes by leftist Moslem militias in Beirut, the United States has decided to move its marines out of the city to ships offshore. Those militias' successes have given new leverage to their Syrian backers.  After years of supplying Syria with costly weapons, the Kremlin can hope at last to get some returns in the the Middle East. **********On other fronts, Mr. Reagan's demonstrated willingness to use force has made Soviet foraging for gains in Central and Latin America far more risky. In Africa and Asia, those allies gained at such expense in the 1970's - Angola, Mozambique, Ethiopia, Vietnam, Cambodia - remain in serious economic trouble. **********With Poland now seeming to be effectively back in harness, Moscow seems to have bought temporary peace in Eastern Europe. But pressures for greater economic independence, and dissatisfaction with East-West tension, demand permanent vigilance in Moscow.  In Afghanistan, a police operation to salvage a Communist regime has developed into a nagging, drawn-out tangle with armed mountain men. **********More generally, Soviet leaders face the fact that infatuation with Soviet- style ideology waned long ago outside the country's borders. In international forums, where for a while Moscow could count on automatic support from third-world allies, the Soviet Union has found itself under attack on issues such as Afghanistan or the downing of the South Korean jetliner. **********No prospective party secretary will be able to sharply reverse foreign policies in force today, especially with the extensive authority Mr. Gromyko has forged over all foreign affairs. But it is on the domestic front that the next leader will ultimately be judged. **********In the 15 months Mr. Andropov was in office, labor productivity nudged upward and agriculture production registered a slight improvement. Mr. Andropov also experimented in less centralized management techniques, began a shakeup of party cadres, ordered a crackdown on inefficiency in the workplace and took stern measures against corruption. **********It was an impressive effort by Soviet standards, but Western diplomats believe that even were they followed through with vigor, the measures would have fallen short of solving Russia's economic woes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/06/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with yields for most long-term bonds rising modestly while rates for three- and six-month Treasury bills fell by an eighth of a percentage point or more. **********Analysts said the rise in yields of some recent Treasury bonds, which accompanied price declines of about half a point, reflected a decline in speculative buying by securities firms and other traders that had helped buoy prices by more than five points over the previous three trading sessions. **********Investor demand for notes and bonds was modest, but was great enough to lift note and bond prices above their lowest levels of the day. The Treasury's 13 7/8 percent notes due in 1989 attracted some buyers at a price of 101 7/8 and ended the day with an offered price of 102 1/4, up 2/32 to yield 13.22 percent. The 13 1/4 percent bonds traded around 98 22/32 early in the day, but rebounded to an offered price of 99 3/8, down half a point, to yield 13.33 percent. **********Federal Funds Rate Falls **********The impetus for lower rates on Treasury bills due in six months or less was a decline in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, a closely watched benchmark for short-term securities.  Reports of a growing conflict in the Persian Gulf led to increased buying of safe, liquid Treasury bills by some cautious investors. **********After averaging 10.99 percent Monday, the overnight funds rate fell to an estimated average of 10.67 percent yesterday. In a sympathetic reaction, the rate for three-month Treasury bills fell to 9.76 percent, from 9.90 percent at Monday's auction, while the six-month bill fell to 10.45 percent, from 10.57 percent. **********In advance of tomorrow's auction of new one-year Treasury bills, the outstanding one-year issue was bid at a rate of 10.69 percent. **********Bond yields remain well below the peaks set in the middle of last week when the bellwether 30-year issue traded briefly at 14 percent and the five-year issue was auctioned at an average of 13.93 percent. but analysts are still debating whether the change in prices and yields is the result of speculative trading or a fundamental shift in investor perceptions. **********''The market improvement is not due to drastically altered perceptions of the economic or inflation outlook,'' said analysts at Money Market Services, an economic news analysis firm based in Belmont, Calif. **********Turning Point Seen **********Other analysts said the economy was nearing a turning point, where weakness could become clear enough that the Federal Reserve might adopt an easier monetary policy. **********''Perhaps the market should focus on how soon it is before the Fed moves toward an easing of credit'' said Ralph Peters, chairman of the Discount Corporation, a government securities dealer. **********''If there is any justification in terms of a slowdown in economic activity'' he said the Fed could encourage some drop in short-term rates. ''Given the seriousness of the international debt problems, it is clear that it would be in the best interest of the world if our interest rates were lower,'' he added. **********Although economic data showed slower economic growth in May, inflation is still expected to rise later this year. The leading index of inflation compiled by the Center for International Business Cycle Research at the Columbia Business School, for example, rose during May, and continues to rise more sharply than the average of the past six economic expansions. **********According to Geoffrey H. Moore, director of the center, ''By the end of the year or early next year consumer price rises will be getting into double- digit territory.'' **********In government agency financing, the Federal National Mortgage Association said its $1 billion issue of 13.05 percent debentures due in 1986 are offered at a price of 100 through various securities dealers. **********Prices for long-term bonds of the Southern California Public Power Authority were reduced slightly by underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds. The 11 1/2 percent bonds due in 2017 are offered at 99 to yield about 11.61 percent, down from a price of 100 tentatively set on Monday. The bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's and Ax by Standard & Poor's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/28/world.main_headline: TOUGHER POLICY AGAINST TERROR IS SEEN GAINING
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/28/world.print_headline: TOUGHER POLICY AGAINST TERROR IS SEEN GAINING
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/28/world.body_text: **********White House and State Department officials said today that, despite continuing disputes, the United States was moving closer to the tough policy on terrorists advocated by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. **********They said this could include the swift use of military force, even if it resulted in civilian deaths. **********But the officials acknowledged that there was no certainty so far that the United States in specific incidents would be ready to take the pre-emptive or retaliatory strikes called for by Mr. Shultz in a speech on terrorism in New York on Thursday. **********There was embarrassment within the Government to the publicity given, with less than two weeks to go in the campaign, to the seeming contradictions among senior officials over how to deal with terrorism. **********Mondale Critical of the Confusion **********In San Francisco, the Democratic nominee, Walter F. Mondale, was critical of the apparent confusion. **********''The worst thing you can do is say in the abstract what you will do except that you are going to be tough,'' he said. ''What they have done in the last day is to encourage terrorists to believe we don't know what we are doing.'' **********A State Department official, in commenting on the apparent conflict, said: **********''On the one hand, the contradictions are real, because we have not ironed out every detail. On the other hand, they are not, because we are going to move against the terrorists. There will be a war on terrorists. You just watch and see.'' **********The White House and State Department officials said that part of the confusion stemmed from the fact that President Reagan and Vice President Bush were on the campaign trail and it was difficult to coordinate with the State Department. Part of the problem was that Mr. Bush had not seen Mr. Shultz's speech ahead of time. **********''At the end of the day,'' a State Department official said, ''there was no distance between George Shultz and Ronald Reagan on terrorism.'' **********Mr. Shultz's aides said he felt that the United States, despite its frequent warnings, had not been willing to take decisive actions that would deter or punish terrorists. **********He has argued, officials said, that the United States should be willing, as Israel is, to respond, as he said on Thursday, ''on a moment's notice,'' and to strike even though ''we may never have the kind of evidence that can stand up in an American court of law.'' **********''We cannot allow ourselves to become the Hamlet of nations, worrying endlessly over whether and how to respond,'' Mr. Shultz said. **********Aides said he was particularly critical of the caution shown by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and by the covert side of the Central Intelligence Agency in stressing the dangers of retaliation to American foreign and domestic policy.  Mr. Shultz's differences with Mr. Weinberger go back to the dispute over the marines in Lebanon, with Mr. Shultz opposing a withdrawal and Mr. Weinberger arguing they should not be there. Pentagon Aide Concedes Caution **********An official close to Mr. Weinberger said today: **********''It is true that the Pentagon is more aware of the downside of military operations and therefore is cautious about undertaking operations where the results are as unpredictable as in pre-emptive strikes against terrorists.'' **********Another official said Friday, ''One has to proceed with caution and with a lot of thought about unintended consequences from the use of force.'' **********According to White House and State Department officials, Mr. Shultz is supported by Robert C. McFarlane, the White House national security adviser, who, like Mr. Shultz, is a former Marine Corps officer. The officials also said Mr. Reagan, depite some comments to the contrary, basically agreed with the Shultz call for a firmer approach. **********''Look, George Shultz is a cautious man,'' an aide said today. ''Can you imagine him making that speech on Thursday if he did not believe that he also spoke for the President?''   McFarlane Supported Shultz **********Mr. McFarlane read the speech before it was given and supported it, a White House official said. The speech was also circulated to the Pentagon, but elicited no official comment. **********Mr. Shultz said in his speech that the public should understand beforehand that there was ''potential for loss of life of some of our fighting men and the loss of life of some innocent people'' when force was used against terrorists. **********Mr. Reagan, in his most recent remarks on terrorism, on Sunday in the debate with Mr. Mondale, was more cautious. **********''We want to retaliate,'' he said, ''but only if we can put our finger on the people responsible and not endanger the lives of innocent civilians.'' **********Vice President Bush while campaigning in Ohio on Friday, was asked about taking the risk to hurt civilians. **********''I don't agree with that,'' Mr. Bush said. ''I think you have got to pinpoint the source of that attack. We are not going to go out and bomb innocent civilians or something of that nature. I don't think we ever get to the point where you kill 100 innocent women and children just to kill one terrorist. I don't think we have reached that point.'' Reagan Tried to Resolve Conflict **********Mr. Reagan, when asked about the apparent conflict, tried to resolve it by saying of Mr. Shultz's speech, ''I don't think it was a statement of policy.'' **********''He was saying all these things must be considered,'' he said. ''I think what Secretary Shultz was saying was that you couldn't rule out the possibility of innocent people being killed. He was not saying that we would do that.'' **********Mr. Reagan created the impression that he was not supporting the speech. This led Larry Speakes, his spokesman, to say, ''Shultz's speech was Administration policy from top to bottom.'' **********Today officials close to Mr. Bush were saying that he was caught off guard since he had not been sent a copy of the speech. They said Mr. Bush was trying to reflect Mr. Reagan's comment in Sunday's debate that the lives of civilians should not be risked. Comment Offered by Mondale **********Some State Department officials also said that Mr. Bush's position, in general, was closer to Mr. Weinberger's. **********Today Mr. Mondale told reporters in San Francisco; **********''This past day we have the U.S. Government all over the map - the Secretary saying we will attack terrorists even if innocents are killed; then the Vice Presideny saying, 'Oh, no, only if they can be attacked without touching innocents;' then the President backing up and taking a different position, underscoring the fact that there is no one in charge.'' **********''All that theoretical talk yesterday, and the inconsistency,'' Mr. Mondale said, ''only emboldens terrorists to think this Government does not know **********what it is doing.''  Bush Hails Shultz's Leadership **********Today, Mr. Bush, speaking to the Zionist Organization of America in Washington, hailed Secretary Shultz for his ''able leadership'' in efforts to fight international terrorism. But the Vice President made no mention of the retaliation issue. **********''Under the able leadership of Secretary Shultz, the State Department is focusing as never before on international terrorism and what can be done about it,'' Mr. Bush said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/09/busin.main_headline: Chairman's Title Added By G.R.I.'s President
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  Chairman's Title Added By G.R.I.'s President
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/09/busin.body_text: **********David R. Rubin, president of the Chicago-based G.R.I. Corporation, has been appointed to the additional post of chairman, succeeding Maurice H. Bronner, who has resigned for reasons of health. **********Mr. Bronner, who is 69 years old, will remain a director. G.R.I., formerly known as Geriatrics Research Inc., for the past two decades has been a mail-order marketer through four ''continuity'' mail-order clubs it operates and the circulation of various catalogues. **********The ''continuity'' clubs, which charge customers a one-time fee of $1 to join, sell a ''continuous flow'' of various products to mostly women of moderate income in the 16-to-40 age group. ''The aim is that by coming up with a steady flow of attractive products,'' Mr. Rubin said, ''we attempt to keep our customers with us.'' **********G.R.I.'s units are the World of Beauty, which sells name-brand cosmetics; S.A.V.E., an acronym for Shoppers' Association of Value and Economy, which sells household and grocery products; Homeward House, which distributes Oneida flatware, and American Heritage, which sells etched glassware. **********Mr. Rubin, who is 50, brings a financial and management background to his new job. A former executive vice president of the Midwest Stock Exchange, he received a B.S. in economics from Harvard in 1955 and an M.B.A. from the University of Michigan in 1959. **********He hopes his background will enable him to keep the company's older businesses vital while developing new programs, he said. **********''Most of my time at G.R.I. will be devoted to counseling my people, listening to the problems they encounter and making sure they use the management and information disciplines that an increasingly complex business needs,'' he said.
