''We said we have had a long and positive history of supporting both the public and private sectors in Colombia, but talks are still continuing regarding financing needs,'' said a spokesman, who asked not to be identified. Yesterday, Colombia's Finance Minister, Edgardo Gutierrez, who said on Friday that Colombia had been offered a $700 million loan by Chase, said in London that Chase has only ''indicated'' to Colombia that it may attempt to arrange such a loan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/18/busin.main_headline: INDIVIDUALS ARE BUYING BONDS IN RECORD NUMBERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/18/busin.print_headline: INDIVIDUALS ARE BUYING BONDS IN RECORD NUMBERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/18/busin.body_text: **********WITH bond yields remaining high, individual investors are diving into the bond markets in record numbers. Indeed, while high interest rates have been a bane to home buyers and other borrowers, as well as to economists concerned about the strong dollar, they have been a boon to individual investors. In the past few years, small investors, who normally have bypassed the bond markets, have decided the yields are too good to pass up. **********Nowhere is this more evident than in tax-exempt municipal bonds. Once the domain of institutional investors, such as banks and insurance companies, that market is now inundated with small investors, who buy about three-fourths of all new tax-exempt bonds. The appeal of tax-exempt bonds, which are issued by states, local governments and local government authorities, is that the interest paid on them is free from Federal income tax. **********''Why invest in a money market fund earning 11 percent, when you have to give back half of it in taxes?'' asked Howard Brody, a New York City insurance broker. ''I'm better off buying New York Power Authority paying 10 percent.'' **********''It's not the amount of your income that counts,'' added Robert Lamb, a New York University professor and specialist in the tax-exempt bond market. ''It's the income you get to keep after you have paid all the taxes on that income.'' **********Next to tax-exempts, small investors prefer United States Treasury securities, which have a special position in the bond market, because it is assumed that the United States would never default on an interest or principal payment. State and local governments also have a good safety record, and defaults have been rare since the Depression. **********Under the current progressive income tax, most individuals or families earning more than $30,000 a year find that the interest earned on tax-exempt bonds compares favorably with the after-tax interest paid on Treasury securities. **********Small investors are not the only ones who are impressed with the bond markets. Pension fund trustees at such major companies as Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation earlier this year bought a combination of securities that locked in high yields, enabling them to reduce the size of future pension plan contributions. **********Of course, bonds, despite their reputation for safety, are not riskless. Fluctuating interest rates in recent years have played havoc with bond prices. While investors cannot avoid the risk that interest rates might rise higher than when the bonds were bought, they can hedge against it by buying shorter-term securities. As a rule of thumb, the shorter the maturity of a debt security, the less volatile will be the price fluctuations in the secondary market. **********Many investors, however, being content simply to get the income from their bond holdings, ignore fluctuating interest rates and the consequent change in the value of the bonds. This buy-and-hold strategy works well when interest rates are stable or falling. But when interest rates are rising, many financial advisers recommend some turnover in an individual's bond portfolio. By selling bonds at a loss, the investor reduces his total income, which cuts the size of his tax bill, and, in effect, lets Uncle Sam absorb part of the loss. When money from the sale of the old bonds is reinvested in new bonds, the investor can adjust the risk of the new portfolio according to maturity and quality, and the higher interest rates available on new issues can recoup the loss from the sale of the old bonds within a few years. **********To reduce the investor's risk, traditional bond offerings are now supplemented by special features - ''bells and whistles'' in the jargon of those in the securities business. The emergence of special features, such as put options (a device allowing the investor to redeem the bond at 100 percent of face value at specified dates) and floating interest, is a sign that a deep-seated fear still persists among investors that today's seemingly high bond yields might not protect against another round of high inflation. Rising inflation during the 1960's and 1970's turned the low interest rate bonds of that era into a bad investment, and investors are ever conscious that today's double-digit yields might not look so good if inflation reappears. **********And, investors seem to be stubbornly clinging to the belief that the economy's rapid growth eventually will mean renewed inflation. ''Deep down inside, many investors are not willing to put their money on continued growth'' of the economy, said Thomas Johnson, president of the Chemical Bank. As a result, many individual investors prefer shorter-term bonds, even though they must accept a lower yield. In recent months, the investor in one-year tax-exempt bonds has accepted a yield that was three percentage points less than was available on 20- and 30-year issues. **********Bonds of states, cities and counties are often the safest, lowest yielding of tax-exempt issues because they have the backing of a government. ''There is nothing to match the appeal of tax-exempt bonds for individuals,'' said Richard Franke, president of John Nuveen & Company, the leading sponsor of unit investment trusts - pools of bonds that are sold to the public through a number of securities firms. **********A wide variety of revenue bonds also have a good safety record, but are vulnerable to the risk that hospitals, electric power systems, or toll-roads may not generate as much revenue as expected and could default. The Washington Public Power Supply System, for example, has missed two interest payments on $2.25 billion of bonds it issued to build two nuclear power plants, which have since been abandoned. Bondholders are now embroiled in lawsuits to recover their money . **********The widely publicized default has been a boost to a handful of companies that insure the interest and principal payments of tax-exempt bonds. Of the $85 billion of new bonds sold in 1983, about 14 percent were insured, up from 2 percent five years ago. Insured bonds sell with lower yields than most other issues in the market, except for the highest quality issues. Still, insured yields of 10 percent are widely available. The most active and best known insurers are the Municipal Bond Insurance Association, the Ambac Indemnity Corporation and the Financial Guaranty Insurance Corporation. **********One new bond in seven is insured.  Yields, though lower, can exceed 10 percent and such issues are widely available.  While all tax-exempt bonds are exempt from Federal income tax, some local issues are also exempt from state and city income taxes. California bonds are exempt from the California income tax, for example, but are taxable to residents of New York. **********Because of the difficulty in selecting tax-exempt bonds - there are more than 40,000 issuers - many investors prefer to buy an interest in a pool of bonds and reap the benefits of a professionally selected, diverse group of securities, bought at wholesale prices available only to large buyers. Of course, the investor pays a fee for the professional help and service, but the cost of a fully disclosed fee ought to be weighed against the higher prices small investors must pay when buying odd lots of bonds, or amounts of less than $50,000. **********Unit investment trusts are the most common way of investing in a pool of tax- exempt bonds. An interest can be bought for as little as $1,000, which entitles the investor to his proportional share of interest paid on an underlying pool of bonds. The investor also shares proportionally in increases and decreases in the value of the bonds should the bonds be sold by the trust (which is not common but is allowable under certain conditions) or should the investor sell his units before maturity. Once a trust is created, the trust sponsor does not adjust the portfolio, except occasionally to sell bonds that are considered a bad risk. **********Funds and trusts prove popular.  Acquiring shares in a mutual fund invested in tax-exempt bonds is another way of buying into a professionally managed fund with a small initial investment. Rather than paying a sales commission (about four percent is not uncommon for long-term unit investment trusts), the investor in a mutual fund pays an annual management fee of about seven-tenths of a percent. In return for the management fee, the fund manager is supposed to be active in trading the portfolio of bonds, so that the fund minimizes losses when interest rates rise and maximizes gains when rates fall.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/25/busin.body_text: **********The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) believes ''it will be difficult for the last half of 1984 to match the first half unless petroleum products and metal prices improve more quickly than we expect,'' it said in its second-quarter report to shareholders. In the first half, profits rose 11.4 percent, to $839 million, from $753 million in the period a year earlier. Sohio, 53 percent of which is owned by the British Petroleum Company, said petroleum product inventories, especially gasoline, are high.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/17/busin.main_headline: Top Management Shifts At Madison Resources
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Top Management Shifts At Madison Resources
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/17/busin.body_text: **********Top management changes at Madison Resources Inc. were announced yesterday in what were described as the final steps in the transition of the company from a mutual fund to an oil and gas investment concern. **********Stanley R. Rawn Jr., the chairman and chief executive of Madison Oil and Gas, a subsidiary, was named president. **********He succeeds William B. Breed Jr., president and chief operating officer of Madison Resources since 1982, who was named to the newly created posts of vice chairman and chief financial officer. **********Mr. Rawn, who is 56, will also remain chairman and chief executive of Danville Resources Inc., a private New York investment company that owns a controlling 53 percent interest in Madison Resources. **********''I think that the intent in naming me president was to have somebody with oil and gas experience as the operating head of Madison Resources,'' Mr. Rawn said in an interview. ''This is a reflection of the ongoing change of Madison from what had been a mutual fund 18 months ago to an oil and gas company.'' **********After graduating in 1953 with a master's degree in chemical engineering from the California Institute of Technology - where he now serves as a board member - Mr. Rawn worked as a research engineer for Chevron before venturing out in 1958 with a partner to form a number of private oil companies. **********Madison Resources, formerly known as the Madison Fund Inc., is a natural resources holding company based in New York with assets of about $500 million. The company, headed by George D. Gould, is involved primarily in oil and gas exploration, development and production operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/06/world.main_headline: Gun in Athens Shooting Killed 2 Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Gun in Athens Shooting Killed 2 Americans
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/06/world.body_text: **********The Greek police said today that the gun that wounded a United States Army master sergeant this week was the same weapon used to assassinate two American officials serving in Greece. **********The chief of the Athens suburban police, Gregory Kartsonakis, said bullets fired at Master Sgt. Robert Judd Jr. on Tuesday came from the .45-caliber pistol that killed the Central Intelligence Agency station chief, Richard Welch, in 1975 and Capt. George Tsantes of the Navy last November. **********Master Sergeant Judd, 36 years old, was transporting official documents and mail when two gunmen on motorcycles fired through the rear window of his car, wounding him in the shoulder and wrist. He was recovering today at the United States Air Force base here.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/17/busin.body_text: **********R EVENUES of the nine public ad agencies have experienced decent growth over the last five years, but not so profits, according to a study by Veronis, Suhler & Associates, an investment banking firm that started in consulting for the magazine industry. According to the study, the agencies' collective earnings dropped 34.1 percent in the period although revenues were up 16 percent. **********The Mickelberry Corporation, the holding company that made the switch from meatpacking to advertising via acquisitions, was singled out in the study for its exceptionally strong performance. In 1982, the last annual statement available to the investment bankers, Mickelberry reported a 121 percent gain in revenues, to $74.7 million, while net income almost doubled, to $2.8 million, or 77 cents a share. **********(Mickelberry's 1983 results, released yesterday, were hardly as exciting. While revenues were up 22.1 percent, to $91.2 million, net income declined 7.1 percent, to $2.6 million, or 66 cents a share.) **********John Suhler, president of the investment banking firm, noted that Mickelberry's revenues in the five- year period grew at a 76 percent compound annual rate, by far the best of the agencies surveyed. Doyle Dane Bernbach was second, with a 19 percent rate, followed by Grey Advertising, with 17 percent. **********In the category of pretax operating income, the study noted, Mickelberry similarly ''stood head and shoulders above the rest'' with a 57 percent rate of increase. Second and third places were occupied by Foote, Cone & Belding, with 9 percent, and Ogilvy & Mather, with 8 percent. **********The study of public agency performance is part of a review of the whole communications business, which includes all of the publicly held media companies as well as companies in business information services. **********Complete reports will be sent to about 400 chief executive officers of communications companies, according to Mr. Suhler. The complete study is available to others for a price.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/15/busin.body_text: **********LAS VEGAS The festivities at this year's International Winter Consumer Electronics Show here generally took the form of staid luncheons, not the flashy, all-night fetes of years past. Parties, when they were held, usually ended by 10 P.M., sometimes to save money. In fact, the four-day show held here last week was dominated by an atmosphere of caution and unease. The great fear was that the spiral of overproduction and price cutting that cost hundreds of millions of dollars for video game and home computer makers like Atari, Mattel and Texas Instruments last year could spread to other areas of the industry before the new year is out. **********In fact, the one-time high-fliers were among the most cautious exhibitors. Their executives announced almost no new products, and used phrases like ''a time of retrenchment'' and ''finding new markets'' - terms that were anathema just 12 months ago. Atari, the proud star of conventions past, did not even have a ''hospitality suite'' where potential customers could examine its newest products over hors d'oeuvres and cocktails. ''Companies that lose $500 million shouldn't have suites,'' James J. Morgan, Atari's new president, observed. **********But outside of the video game and computer arenas, the picture was much brighter. Consumer demand for video products - from video cassette recorders to small video cameras and more sophisticated television sets - reached record heights in 1983, with factory sales topping the previous year's by 26 percent. And industry experts at the conference said they expect that the American appetite for electronic gadgetry will continue to grow this year - albeit more slowly than in 1983 - leading to retail sales of $30 billion for 1984. **********There was abundant evidence that the industry, while still volatile, is maturing. Few products were truly innovative; most were simply improvements on items clearly in demand. Televisions became a bit clearer, radios a bit smaller, telephones a bit more sophisticated and computer-like. Manufacturers seemed to realize that high-tech products can become obsolete almost overnight.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The Midlands Energy Company's stock plunged after Freeport- McMoran Inc. said that about 8 million Midlands common shares - or nearly double the amount Freeport- McMoran was obligated to buy - had been tendered in response to an offer to acquire the company. **********Under an agreement announced Sept. 13, Freeport was to buy 4.5 million of the tendered shares at $30 each as part of a two-step transaction. **********Under the second part, the 4.2 million common shares remaining would each be converted into $27.50 principal amount of a new 10 1/2 percent convertible subordinated sinking fund debenture due 2014 of Freeport- McMoran. **********On the New York Stock Exchange today, Midlands dropped $3.50, to $22.625, making it the biggest percentage loser. Freeport-McMoran slipped 25 cents, to $16.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/29/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; John Wiley Selling Professional Computing
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/29/busin.body_text: **********John Wiley & Sons, publisher of technical books and journals, has suspended publication of its first consumer magazine in its 177-year history, and is in the midst of negotiations to sell it. **********It is Professional Computing, for owners of Hewlett-Packard personal computers, which made its debut in April with a six-a-year frequency. **********It started as subscription only and then added newsstand sales. Although 30 of its 100 pages have been advertising, sales were weaker than expected in the first half.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/02/world.main_headline: Ha'penny Is Done For After Seven Centuries
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/02/world.print_headline: Ha'penny Is Done For After Seven Centuries
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/02/world.body_text: **********For nearly seven centuries the halfpenny was one of the most useful coins of the realm, but it has been shrunk by decimalization, devalued by inflation and rendered nearly useless. Next month the Royal Mint will stop making it. **********The copper coin, with a diameter of five-eighths of an inch, now costs more to mint than its face value, which is about seven-tenths of one United States cent. Production will halt on March 29, after 704 years. **********Nigel Lawson, the Chancellor of the Exchequor, sent a statement to the House of Commons today announcing the plans to cease minting the coin. He said it would remain legal tender after that, but would probably be withdrawn by the end of the year. There are 2.5 billion in circulation. **********Introduced by King Edward I in 1280, the halfpenny was made of silver for 400 years. When Britain decimalized its currency in 1971, the halfpenny was reduced in size but more than doubled in value. Before decimalization, when there were 12 pence in a shilling and 20 shillings in a pound, there were 480 halfpennies in a pound; afterward there were 200.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The Air Force awarded a $1.58 billion contract for 428 engines for the new B-1B bomber fleet to the General Electric Company. **********The Reagan Administration plans to build 100 of the advanced bombers, with the first scheduled to become combat-ready next year. The expected award was made to G.E.'s aircraft engine business group, which is based in Cincinnati. The announcement did not say where the engines would be built.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/busin.body_text: **********The Coca-Cola Company said today that strong sales of soft drinks everywhere but in Latin America helped push its profit to $124.6 million, or 91 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1983, up 2.7 percent, from $121.3 million, or 89 cents a share, a year earlier. **********Revenues rose 6.3 percent, to $1.7 billion, from $1.6 billion. **********For the full year, Coca-Cola, the world's No. 1 soft drink maker, said a strong performance by its Columbia Pictures subsidiary helped increase profits by 9.1 percent, to $558.8 million, from $512.2 million in 1982. Profits per share was up 3.8 percent, to $4.10, from $3.95, **********Revenues rose 13.3 percent, to $6.8 billion, from $6 billion in 1982. **********In its first full year as part of Coca- Cola, Columbia Pictures earned $91 million, which Roberto C. Goizueta, chairman and chief executive, said was more than expected. **********The company's soft drink sales in the United States rose 6 percent in the fourth quarter and 7 percent for the full year, largely as a result of the success of Diet Coke, which has become the nation's fourth-largest-selling soft drink and the leading low- calorie soft drink, Coca-Cola said. **********Operating income of Coke's combined United States operations - soft drinks, food and entertainment - was up 24 percent last year over 1982 levels, with United States operations accounting for 60 percent of total net revenue and 47 percent of business sector operating income, the company said. **********But falling sales in Latin America hurt overseas results. Blaming ''severely depressed economic conditions,'' as well as sharply lower exchange rates, the company said soft drink sales in Latin America declined 8 percent for the full year and 12 percent in the fourth quarter. **********Coca-Cola said it earned $4 million in the fourth quarter of 1983 from the sale of its wine-making unit, in addition to operating income of $120 million. **********Earnings tables, D13.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/14/busin.body_text: **********Jack Tramiel, the hard-driving executive who brought Commodore International to the top of the home computer market, resigned suddenly today as president and chief executive and as a director. **********In a statement, Commodore quoted Mr. Tramiel as saying, ''Personal reasons prevent my continuing on a full-time basis with Commodore.'' Mr. Tramiel was reported to be traveling and unavailable for comment. **********Report of Dispute With Chairman **********One source said the resignation resulted from a long-running dispute between Mr. Tramiel and Irving Gould, the chairman. ''There was a problem between Irv and Jack,'' the source said. ''It was a problem over a long period of time and it finally came to a head.'' **********The dispute may have involved Mr. Tramiel's management style. Insiders say Mr. Tramiel ran the company like a one-man show, making it difficult for the company to recruit and retain executives. **********The unexpected resignation came as Commodore was achieving its best performance ever: The company emerged from the price wars in the home computer sector last year as the clear leader in market share and profits as its competitors were hit by huge losses. **********Commodore's revenues for 1983 surpassed $1 billion and its net income will exceed $100 million, the company estimates. For the quarter that ended Dec. 31, Commodore estimates revenues at $425 million, more than twice the $176 million of a year earlier. **********Mr. Tramiel, who has survived everything from concentration camps to near-bankruptcy to a legal scandal, is thus leaving at the time of what should be his greatest triumph. **********Steven A. Greenberg, a spokesman for Commodore, said Mr. Tramiel was not forced to resign. ''This is definitely Jack's decision based upon clear reasoning,'' he said. **********Commodore said Mr. Tramiel would remain a consultant to the company. **********It also said the board had has chosen a replacement for Mr. Tramiel, to be announced in a few days. Mr. Greenberg said the replacement was formerly president of a manufacturing company with more than $1 billion in annual revenues that is not in the computer business. **********It is unclear what effect Mr. Tramiel's resignation will have on Commodore, but it is bound to be dramatic. Mr. Tramiel founded Commodore in 1955 and has built the company as the lowest-cost producer of home computers - and one that can change directions in an instant. **********Commodore officials certainly gave little hint that trouble was brewing at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas earlier this week, where a beaming Mr. Tramiel and other executives introduced a new line of home computers. Sig Hartmann, head of Commodore's software division, said Commodore executives had a surprise dinner for Mr. Tramiel at which Mr. Gould made a speech. Mr. Tramiel was presented with a silver platter with his colleagues' names inscribed. **********Mr. Tramiel, who is 55 years old, was born in Poland and came to the United States in 1945 after his release from a concentration camp. In the 1950's, he started a typewriter manufacturing business in Canada. **********In the mid-1960's, a scandal arose involving the Atlantic Acceptance Corporation, a Canadian finance company with close ties to Mr. Tramiel and Commodore. He was not indicted, however, and kept his business going with money from Mr. Gould, a Canadian financier who has been chairman ever since. **********In the mid-1970's, Commodore was almost driven out of business when Texas Instruments, a supplier of computer chips to calculator makers like Commodore, went into the calculator business and slashed prices. **********Mr. Tramiel vowed that Commodore would make its own chips to cut costs. That vertical integration and attention to cost-cutting helped Commodore survive the price wars which, ironically, forced Texas Instruments out of the home computer business. **********Under Mr. Tramiel, Commodore introduced products if there was a market for them, even if the new product cut sales of an existing product. The Commodore 64, introduced about a year ago, was not compatible with the previous home computer, the VIC-20, and hurt sales of the VIC-20. But Mr. Tramiel maintained he would rather compete with himself than with others.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/30/busin.body_text: **********The United States foreign trade deficit widened to a record $10.1 billion in February, the Commerce Department reported today, providing fresh evidence that 1984 may be the worst trading year ever. **********The February deficit exceeded the old record of $9.5 billion, set in January, and would give the country a deficit of more than $120 billion if it held for the rest of the year. **********David Lund, chief trade analyst for the Commerce Department, said that while he was surprised at the size of the February deficit, he saw nothing that would cause him to change his already gloomy prediction of a $110 billion deficit in 1984. The country's trade deficit last year was a record $69.4 billion. **********The poor February showing came despite a 1.8 percent decline in imports, to $27.3 billion, from their January level. But exports were down an even sharper 6 percent in February, to $17.2 billion. **********Most economists attribute the country's trade problems to two factors: The high value of the dollar makes United States exports relatively expensive and imports relatively cheap. And the American economy is growing much faster than others, so that the demand for imports among Americans has been outstripping demand elsewhere for American goods. **********Imports of petroleum products declined 1.2 percent in February, but the amount of petroleum imported rose to 5.5 million barrels a day, up from 5.3 million barrels in January and 3.7 million barrels in February 1983. **********There was also a slight decline in imports of non-petroleum products, reflecting small decreases in imports of new automobiles, commercial aircraft, electrical machinery, office machines and telecommunications equipment. However, the declines were partially offset by sizable increases in imports of clothing, diamonds and aluminum.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/19/world.main_headline: TOKYO'S VENERABLE GINZA: IS IT TIME FOR A FACELIFT?
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/19/world.print_headline: TOKYO'S VENERABLE GINZA: IS IT TIME FOR A FACELIFT?
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/19/world.body_text: **********The lights of the Ginza glitter, as ever, and the black limousines line the narrow side streets, waiting for the well-heeled and well- oiled to find their way back from another sake-hazed evening. By day, the shoppers hold sway, streaming in and out of the department stores and jewelry shops in a finely groomed parade. **********But beneath its shiny surface, the Ginza has reason to worry about holding on to its reputation as Japan's leading - not to mention best-known - entertainment and shopping district. Other centers of this sprawling city glow brighter, move faster and echo with younger voices. By comparison, the venerable Ginza is like a cashmere coat with frayed sleeves, attractive but perhaps best not examined too closely. **********Now the Japanese Government thinks it may be time for a facelift. **********It is talking about a development program for the district, an ambitious project involving underground shopping arcades, new condominiums, a monorail service and improvements in what city planners like to call the infrastructure. The hope is to attract a younger crowd, to shift slightly from the Ginza's image as a showcase of middle-aged self-indulgence. Any development cost will be high, perhaps $1.7 billion, and no one is sure who will pay. If it fails, it will not be the first project of this sort proposed for the Ginza and then discarded.   Maintaining the Vitality **********But the discussions seem to be more serious this time, and with an official study of the possibilities scheduled to be completed in a few weeks, the store owners and restaurateurs of the Ginza are waiting eagerly. **********''It's something we'd like to have, but I don't think this is a must for maintaining the Ginza's vitality,'' said Yuji Ishimaru, secretary general of the Ginza Street Association, a business group. Others involved in business disagree; they think the district needs to change if it hopes to keep its competitive edge. **********None of this is to suggest that the Ginza is ready for a going-out-of-business sale. The area still encompasses 180 acres of some of the more remarkable stretches of urban real estate in the world - a place of style and contrasts, where one can plunk down $200,000 on a pearl necklace at Mikimoto and eat a passable stand-up meal at a noodle stall for about a dollar. **********The name means Silver Seat, a reference to the silver market that was centered there in feudal days. As recently as 30 years ago, willow trees lined the streets and murky canals veined the back paths.   A Monument of Commerce **********Now there is mainly concrete and granite, a monument of commerce dominated by offices, specialty shops and opulent department stores. Women still come in kimonos, and families like to stroll on weekends, when the main avenue is closed to traffic. **********But the Ginza is really the night. There is a word, mizushobai, that means water business. The word, however, suggests more life than its literal definition, speaking of a swifter pulse than the mere statistic that along the Ginza one can find 3,000 bars and restaurants. Many are no bigger than respectable closets, tucked enticingly into narrow alleyways or piggybacked inside drab buildings that no one would glance at twice during the day but that gleam bewitchingly at night. **********Women venture there, but it is essentially a world for men, expense-account executives who go out with associates or business contacts and forget the day or strike a deal. For a price that is merely outrageous, one can buy a drink with a whisper of alcohol and be indulged by hostesses whose craft is illusion - of hanging on every word, of enjoying the oldest joke, of admiring the foreign visitor for the skill in Japanese he has just demonstrated by ordering a ''biru.'' **********Increasingly, younger people seem less amused by such pastimes. They go out at night, too, but they take their entertainment in other quarters, possibly the frenetic Shinjuku section or stylized Roppongi or pell-mell Shibuya. Dining in a top-flight restaurant no longer means an obligatory trip to the Ginza. Much of the excitement has moved elsewhere.   Appeal to the Older **********It takes only a brisk walk around town to see that the Ginza appeals to older people. According to Mr. Ishimaru, surveys confirm that the average age of customers in Shinjuku is 18 to 25 while half the people who go to the Ginza are 25 to 45 years old. Much of the considerable amount of money spent by affluent youngsters is going to the old district's rivals. **********What bothers some merchants more than their lack of appeal to youth is the influx of fast-food chains in recent years. In spots the main boulevard, Ginza-dori, looks like a trendy stretch of New York's Columbus Avenue that has been pockmarked by touches of West 34th Street. Some stores hang out merchandise on the street, and traditionalists close their eyes when walking past Shakey's and Pizza Hut. **********A popular McDonald's on the street level of the Mitsukoshi department store has especially irritated some neighborhood store owners. There is no place to sit at the hamburger stand, so customers munch their Big Macs in the street. Older Ginza establishments are not thrilled by the sight, and they want McDonald's out. Mr. Ishimaru, for his part, said that although '' 'evict' is too strong a word,'' his association had ''advised Mitsukoshi to improve the present eating situation of McDonald's customers.'' **********To create an atmosphere that might appeal to a younger crowd, Ginza merchants are looking to underground arcades. There is not much affordable space on the street, where land goes for as much as $10,000 a square foot. In the plan under study, the subway lines that crisscross below ground would be lowered even farther, creating new space to be occupied by shops.   Sassiness vs. Mass Appeal **********Some store owners think this is a mistake. Let Roppongi lure the kids, they say. They are not troubled by the thought of letting the Ginza hold onto its faintly musty air and its discreet sassiness. **********Many visitors seem to agree. In a college survey of them taken last summer, 40 percent said they wanted the Ginza to remain a ''high class'' area, while only 10 percent preferred that it appeal to ''the masses.'' **********There are even those who would yank out blocks of concrete and plant willow trees again.  ''Widen the sidewalks,'' said the writer of a recent letter to The Mainichi Daily News. ''Close some streets to traffic and lay down pedestrian thoroughfares - complete with landscaping, stone lanterns and a footbridge or two. **********''Tone down the flash and neon.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/28/world.body_text: **********Afghanistan's Government-run radio has reported that reconstruction has begun in the Panjshir Valley, a traditional guerrilla stronghold that the Government says it now controls. **********The Kabul radio, monitored in Islamabad Saturday night, said the valley was peaceful, but the report was not confirmed by Afghan exiles or Western diplomats in Pakistan. **********Diplomats said Soviet forces, which launched an offensive in the area April 21, seemed to be in control of the floor of the 70-mile-long valley but it was not clear whether fighting had ended in the many side valleys. Guerrilla sources in Peshawar said clashes were continuing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/busin.body_text: **********A group of telephone equipment suppliers formally asked the Federal Communications Commission late today to set aside an order that allows the Bell System companies to refer customers who need a telephone to their own subsidiaries. **********The group, known as the North American Telecommunications Association, asked the commission to stay the effectiveness of its order pending full reconsideration. **********The filing had been expected, since the members of the association voted five weeks ago to challenge the agency's decision. **********The commission order that prompted the petition was adopted Nov. 23 and became effective Jan. 1. It specifies that the Bell companies, which became independent of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on Jan. 1, cannot enter the telephone equipment business without establishing a separate subsidiary or division to do so. **********Some Flexibility Granted **********The commission had already imposed a similar requirement on A.T.& T. It said the same requirement was justified for the Bell companies to prevent them from subsidizing their equipment activities with local service revenues. **********While requiring a separate subsidiary, the commission decided to provide the Bell companies with some flexibility by authorizing what is known as ''dial-tone referral.'' **********In other words, a person calling the local Bell company to arrange for service could be transferred to the phone company's equipment subsidiary, as long as the customer service representative advised the caller he could deal with other equipment companies as well. **********The association, which represents more than 550 independent manufacturers, suppliers and distributors of telephone equipment, charged today that such referrals ''pose a serious threat to the viability of independent equipment vendors'' because the Bell companies can easily abuse their position as the providers of basic phone service.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/05/busin.main_headline: PATENTS ; Security Setup Detects Intruder, Fire or Smoke
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/05/busin.print_headline: PATENTS ; Security Setup Detects Intruder, Fire or Smoke
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/05/busin.body_text: **********Ronald E. Pyle of Austin, Tex., has patented a home security system intended to offer protection against intrusion, fire and smoke. **********Patent 4,446,454, granted Mr. Pyle this week, specifies intrusion detectors at doors and windows. When an entry is opened, an alarm is sounded and electronic signals are sent to a central monitoring unit. The unit may set off external and internal alarms, turn on lights and send a telephone call for help. Fire and smoke detection can be included. The system is adaptable to the shape and size of a dwelling.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/18/busin.body_text: **********Walt Disney Productions, in an apparent move to avoid being taken over, said today that it had agreed to acquire the Arvida Corporation, a prospering community and resort developer, for $200 million in newly issued stock. **********Disney has been the subject of takeover rumors for weeks. Saul Steinberg, chairman of the Reliance Group, owns 12.1 percent of Disney's common shares and has said he intends to acquire up to 25 percent of the company. **********Ron Miller, Disney's president and chief executive, said at a news conference today that the Arvida acquisition had not been taken to thwart Mr. Steinberg. However, the Bass brothers of Texas control 70 percent of Arvida's stock, which is privately held, and could receive a stake of as much as 6.9 percent in Disney through the Arvida sale. **********''This brings a major new player to the party,'' said Ronald Rotter, an analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards, a regional brokerage in Los Angeles. ''I have to believe there is more to this than meets the eye.'' **********Charles E. Cobb Jr., chairman of Arvida, will be given a seat on Disney's board. Also, there are no restrictions preventing the Bass brothers from acquiring more shares, according to Raymond L. Watson, Disney's chairman. **********Arvida, with headquarters in Boca Raton, Fla., had revenues of about $320 million and a net income of more than $30 million in 1983, according to Mr. Watson. Those figures are approximately double the results of 1979, he added. **********Started by Arthur Vining Davis, the founder of the Aluminum Company of America, Arvida owns 20,000 acres of land in Florida, Georgia and California. The company specializes in community and resort development. **********Disney owns 27,000 acres in central Florida, the site of its Walt Disney World vacation resort. Mr. Watson said that about 15,000 of the remaining acreage is suitable for development and indicated that part of Disney's plan to remain independent is to swiftly develop the land. **********Mr. Watson, a former president of the Irvine Company, developer of the nation's largest planned industrial and residential community, in Orange County, Calif., has been a Disney director for 10 years. He was elected chairman a year ago. **********The Arvida acquisition will not dilute Disney's earnings, Mr. Miller said, but it will add $190 million to existing long-term debt of $350 million. **********Disney's profits have been under pressure for several quarters, and the company has ''almost no'' cash, Mr. Bagnall said. **********Mr. Miller said the recent profit declines related to the start-up of the Disney Channel and a drop in attendance at Walt Disney World. **********Net income in the quarter fell 26 percent, to $22.3 million, or 64 cents a share, compared with $30.0 million, or 8 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 10 percent to $346.1 million. **********The agreement calls for Disney to issue the number of shares needed to equal a market value of $200 million. That is to be determined by the stock price over 20 days prior to the completion of the definitive agreement with Arvida. **********Disney's shares closed at $63.50, unchanged, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, but had been down to $61.50 before trading was halted about 45 minutes prior to close of trading. The minimum stock price for calculating the number of shares to be issued is $52.63 a share, and the maximum is $75.47 a share. **********If today's close at $63.50 were the average, Disney would issue 3.15 million new shares, increasing its total outstanding shares to 37.75 million. **********Assuming that figure, Mr. Steinberg's stake in Disney, at 4.2 million shares on May 1, would fall to 11.1 percent, from 12.1 percent. He would continue as Disney's largest shareholder. The Bass Brothers holding would be 2.2 million shares, or 5.9 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/19/busin.main_headline: Rise in Use Of Capacity Cut to 0.2%
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/19/busin.print_headline: Rise in Use Of Capacity Cut to 0.2%
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/19/busin.body_text: **********In an apparent new sign of slowing economic expansion, the Federal Reserve Board reported today that the nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 81.7 percent of capacity in May, up two-tenths of a percentage point from April's revised figure. **********The rise was just one-third the April gain of six-tenths of a point, and economists suggested that smaller monthly increases could be welcome in staving off any new inflation surge. **********The current level compares with factory use of only 69.6 percent near the end of the 1981-82 recession. The high marks of recoveries following recessions in the 1970's were 88.4 percent in 1973 and 87.3 percent in the 1978-80 period, the report said. **********Rule of Thumb Cited **********Robert Ortner, chief economist for the Commerce Department, cited a rule of thumb, that once factory use gets to about 84 percent, inflation also tends to begin picking up, at least partly because of production bottlenecks and other difficulties in meeting consumer demand for certain items. **********However, he said, a recent Commerce Department survey found business executives planning big increases in spending on new plants and equipment. **********Rob Wescott, an economist with Wharton Econometrics in Philadelphia, said Wharton did not expect factory use to get above about 84.5 percent, leveling off at that point in mid- or late 1985. Soon after that point, he added, the current economic expansion could well yield to a new recession, mostly because of the damaging effects of high interest rates. **********Rein on Inflation Seen **********In the meantime, Mr. Wescott said, the new report and others along the same lines in recent weeks ''suggest we're entering a period of gradually moderating growth, with healthy gains in production and gross national product through 1984 and into '85.'' He added that he saw no likelihood of greatly higher inflation. **********In its report, the Federal Reserve said that the operating rate in manufacturing edged up one-tenth of a point, to 81.9 percent of capacity, in May, the highest since March 1980. The manufacturing total included a decline for auto makers, to 77.9 percent of capacity from 79.2 percent. **********In mining, utilization rose 1.3 percentage points, to 75.4 percent, reaching its January level again after declining for three months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/29/world.main_headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MRS. THATCHER SHUNS A SIEGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/29/world.print_headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MRS. THATCHER SHUNS A SIEGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/29/world.body_text: **********One of the oddest features of the siege at the Libyan Embassy in St. James's Square, which ended on Friday with the departure of 30 Libyan diplomats and others, was the distance Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher put between herself and the crisis. **********No major political or diplomatic event that has occurred in London since Mrs. Thatcher took office five years ago has had so little overt involvement from the Prime Minister - a surprising circumstance, as one Western diplomat commented, for someone ''usually so fond of standing up to people who she thinks are trying to push Britain around.'' **********For the first 72 hours after the fatal shooting of Constable Yvonne Fletcher, the Prime Minister was in Lisbon on an official visit, an important trip but not one whose cancellation would have caused vast problems. When she returned, she went to Chequers, her country estate, for the weekend. And when the decision to sever diplomatic relations with Tripoli was announced last Sunday, it was explained to the press not by Mrs. Thatcher but by Richard Luce, a junior minister at the Foreign Office. **********As negotiations dragged on last week, and even after the Libyans filed stony-faced out of the embassy, it was not Mrs. Thatcher who commented in the House of Commons and on television but Leon Brittan, the Home Secretary. When first the families of diplomats in Tripoli, then the diplomats themselves, returned safely to London, and when Miss Fletcher's funeral was held in Salisbury, Mrs. Thatcher was absent.   Saw Ice Skaters **********Her principal public engagement on Friday, the climactic day, was a farewell performance by Britain's world champion ice skaters, Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean. **********The official explanation was that the Prime Minister had complete confidence in Mr. Brittan's judgment. But among many British politicians the conclusion was that Mrs. Thatcher could see from the start that the episode was likely to end in public frustration and anger and that she wanted as little blame as possible. **********''She hates this kind of fudge and compromise,'' a Conservative Member of Parliament said. ''She has no time for diplomatic niceties. She didn't want to look the way Jimmy Carter did over the hostages in Iran, so she wanted to stay out of it and get it over with quickly.'' **********If she was indeed engaged in trying to limit the political damage, she seems to have succeeded. Newspapers across the spectrum reacted unhappily to the episode this morning with The Daily Express calling it a ''humiliation for Britain'' and The Guardian descibing it as ''a bleak little tragedy.'' But there was no criticism - indeed, almost no mention at all - of the Prime Minister. **********Even though from the start it looked unlikely that anyone could ever be brought to trial for killing Miss Fletcher, Scotland Yard went to extraordinary lengths to find out who did it and to build as much of a case as was possible under the circumstances. **********Lest someone escape, even the sewers were sealed off. Long-range cameras, some of them with infrared film, were set up, along with television surveillance equipment. Bugging devices were attached to the walls of adjacent buildings and super- sensitive microphones were aimed at the besieged ''People's Bureau,'' as the Libyans call their embassy. Radio circuits linking the embassy with the Triploi were monitored, as were telephone lines. **********From all of these sources, plus interviews with people known to have close links to the Libyan Embassy, a ''fairly complete picture'' of activities in the building after the shooting was built up, a senior police official said. More information may have been gleaned from questioning the 30 occupants of the embassy at the Civil Service College in Sunningdale, Berkshire, Friday afternoon before they left for home. **********Even after the evacuation, Scotland Yard was looking for clues. Policemen crawled through the square on all fours on Friday afternoon and again this morning, looking for spent bullets or other forensic evidence, and the police broadcast an appeal for a man in his 40's known from television film to have walked through the square at the time of the shooting with a tightly furled umbrella clutched in his right hand. **********Without citing sources, some British newspapers suggested today that the police now know who fired the murder weapon. The Daily Mail said his identity was finally nailed down at Sunningdale and described him as a dark-haired man in his early 30's. The Daily Telegraph said there were still two names on the list of Libyans who are suspects. **********If anyone gave the British a lift during an unpleasant 11 days, it was Julia Miles, the 39-year-old wife of the British Ambassador in Tripoli. While her husband, Oliver, carried on negotiations with the Libyans and prepared to close down the embassy, Mrs. Miles gave a series of telephone interviews to newspapers and broadcasters here. **********A steady, matter-of-fact woman, given to saying things like ''we're rather up a gum tree,'' Mrs. Miles was generally photographed wearing a T-shirt and a denim skirt as she busied herself packing and looking after four children. **********She joked about the size of the dining table in the ambassadorial residence - ''a friend gave me a back- scratcher to push the salt pot across the table to my husband'' - and calmly described the difficulties the British were facing each day. **********''Julia Miles, coping,'' said Sir Robin Day admiringly at the end of one of his lunchtime talks with her on BBC radio last week. **********When she and other dependents were finally permitted to board a plane for the trip back to Britain on Thursday night, Mrs. Miles led the group in singing ''Rule Britannia.'' **********The building that was besieged by the police is one of the finest 18th century houses in London, formerly known as Wentworth House, with elaborately paneled reception rooms and ornate chandeliers. It was bought by the Libyans for more than $4 million in 1978 from the family of the Earls of Strafford. **********St. James's Square, at whose northeast corner the house stands, was laid out in the 17th century and is filled with historic buildings. At No. 31, George III was born, the Dukes of Norfolk lived for more than 200 years and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower presided over Allied headquarters in 1944. No. 4 was for three decades the home of Nancy Astor, then from 1943 to 1945 the headquarters of Charles de Gaulle and the Free French. No. 10, which now houses the Royal Institute of International Affairs, was the residence of no fewer than three Prime Ministers - William Pitt, Lord Derby and William Gladstone. **********Jermyn Street, where the police vans waited for the departing Libyans, is one of the most fashionable in London, leading past such shops as Fortnum and Mason; Turnbull and Asser, the haberdashers; Paxton and Whitfield, the cheese merchants, and Floris, the perfumier. Benjamin Franklin once lived there. **********''It's been a dreadful time,'' said Paul Bentley, owner of Astley's Pipe Shop. ''Some days we haven't been able to open at all.'' **********''We'll never recover our losses,'' said another businessman, George Racz. ''What are we supposed to do - send a bill to Qaddafi?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/31/busin.body_text: **********The Louisville Cement Company said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the Coplay Cement Company for $72 a share, or $112.5 million. **********As part of the transaction, Coplay, which is based in Nazareth, Pa., has signed binding purchase agreements with certain Louisville Cement shareholders who own 57 percent of the 1.56 million shares outstanding, the companies said. **********On the American Stock Exchange today, Louisville Cement rose $4.125, to $68.125. **********Both companies said the acquisition must be approved by stockholders and cleared on antitrust grounds, with the purchase expected to be completed by early 1985. **********Louisville Cement has been among the most profitable companies in its industry. **********''I hate to see a Louisville-based company sold,'' said Gene P. Gardner, the company's president. ''But I think the value that was offered is a value that the board could not reasonably turn down.'' **********The cash offer is 1.6 times the value of Louisville Cement, he said. **********Mr. Gardner will continue as Louisville Cement's president and chief executive officer, and he said the acquisition is not expected to affect the company's employees, organization or operation. **********Louisville Cement has 495 employees and two plants in Indiana. About 50 people work in the company's corporate offices. **********Coplay is a subsidiary of the French company, Societe des Ciments Fran,cais, with headquarters in Paris. **********Louisville Cement, for the nine months ended Sept. 30, reported a profit of $4.3 million, or $2.77 a share, more than twice the $1.9 million, or $1.20 a share, for the comparable period a year earlier. Sales rose to $54.9 million, from $46.2 million.
