https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/16/world.main_headline: SANDINISTA SAYS SOME INSURGENTS REMAIN IN COUNTRY AFTER ATTACKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/16/world.print_headline: SANDINISTA SAYS SOME INSURGENTS REMAIN IN COUNTRY AFTER ATTACKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/16/world.body_text: **********The anti-Sandinista military offensive begun in March in northern and central Nicaragua appears to have ended with rebel forces having established some bases inside the country, according to a Nicaraguan military commander. **********The Nicaraguan authorities also say they believe a force of 6,500 insurgents is regrouping and will begin a new and more destructive offensive in coming weeks. **********''We know that it is coming and that we are going to have major confrontations,'' said Cmdr. Manuel Salvatierra, who oversees Sandinista operations in the area. ''We realize that this war is going to continue for a long time.'' **********Commander Salvatierra told reporters here Thursday that insurgent forces had been ''partly successful'' in setting up bases of operation deep inside Nicaragua. He said his troops had killed 913 rebel soldiers in 156 battles since the offensive began in March, but he declined to disclose the number of Sandinista casualties. **********Estimates 3,000 in Country **********The commander said he believed that 3,000 insurgents remained inside Nicaragua and that 3,500 more would soon begin infiltrating in from Honduras. He said new rebel troops were being trained at bases in Honduras to take part in a coming offensive. **********He did not reveal the source of his information, but both sides in the Nicaraguan conflict are believed to be infiltrated by enemy agents. **********''They are trying to influence the peasants and create a social base for themselves,'' Commander Salvatierra said. Because rebels are operating in isolated areas ''where we have no mass organizations,'' he said, they have managed to win some popular support. **********To confront these problems, deal with the expected offensive and resolve a host of difficulties that face this vital coffee-growing region, the Sandinista Government has sent one of its top leaders, Jaime Wheelock, the Minister of Agrarian Reform, to Matagalpa. Officials said he was now working here almost full time and had left his ministry in the hands of subordinates. **********In towns and villages in the north, residents said they had heard no reports of major fighting since the beginning of June. Many said earlier attacks had led them to believe some of their neighbors might be secretly collaborating with insurgents. **********Houses in some remote areas are papered with handbills urging rebels to desert and surrender.   Supply Routes Cited **********According to Sandinista officers and independent military analysts here and in Managua, the recent offensive was aimed at opening supply routes that would permit insurgent units to remain inside Nicaragua for extended periods. Commander Salvatierra said as many as 1,100 rebels appeared to be based in the eastern part of Matagalpa Province. **********In recent attacks on the northern towns of Ocotal, Waslala and San Rafael del Norte, rebels apparently operating in conjunction with local residents inflicted millions of dollars in damage on Government offices, food warehouses and vehicles. A spokesman for the Ministry of Construction estimated that the attack on Ocotal inflicted more than $1 million damage to installations controlled by his ministry. **********In several towns, according to local officials and residents, rebel attackers have gone directly to the homes of Sandinista organizers, accused them of repressive abuses and killed them. The most recent victim was said to have been the head of the Sandinista youth organization in Ocotal, which was hit by a rebel squad two weeks ago. **********Much of northern Nicaragua is virtually unpopulated and covered wih rugged mountains, which at this time of year are shrouded in thick fog. The Sandinistas themselves started their guerrilla war here, as did the man after whom their movement is named, Augusto Cesar Sandino, who fought Government troops and United States marines in the 1920's and 30's.   Ortegas Visit Area **********The Sandinista junta coordinator, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, and his brother, Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra, have visited this area in the last few days. They assured soldiers and civilians that the Government considered defense its top priority. **********The official Sandinista newspaper Barricada reported today that a high- level official delegation would make ''a working visit'' to the Soviet Union later this month. It will be headed by Daniel Ortega and will include Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto Brockman and Comdr. Henry Ruiz, who speaks Russian and attended Patrice Lumumba University in Moscow. **********Commander Salvatierra said Sandinista forces were using new Soviet-made heavy artillery pieces that have a range of over 10 miles and can simultaneously fire 40 projectiles, each containing 1,500 pounds of explosives. ''In a short time we can saturate an area,'' he said. **********Sandinista officers and rebel leaders have said the rebel force is growing in size. Officials have attributed this to forced recruitment of peasants in northern Nicaragua, but the insurgents say their new soldiers are mostly young people alienated by the regime.   'Massive Mobilization' Cited **********Defense Minister Ortega said Nicaragua was involved in ''massive and prominent mobilization'' for the war effort. He also said Sandinistas should work ''to neutralize rightists in our cities and towns, who are conspiring by launching campaigns of confusion.'' His statement coincided with what appears to be a new crackdown on suspected collaborators. **********At least four people were arrested by the security police in Matagalpa this week, according to human rights activists and religious workers. Their whereabouts is unknown and no charges are known to have been lodged against them, but associates said they assumed the four were suspected of anti-Sandinista activity. **********Today's issue of the pro-Sandinista newspaper Nuevo Diario reported one of the arrests and said the woman taken into custody, Edith Guerrero de Arias, had been proven to have ''ties to counterrevolutionary activities'' that endanger the security of the country. **********In the provincial capital of Chinandega, 50 miles west of here, the police this week reported finding crates of C-4 plastic explosives and several light antitank weapons in a home. The occupant was said to have been arrested.   U.S. Support Denounced **********The United States has provided anti- Sandinista forces with military advice and millions of dollars in war supplies. Commander Salvatierra characterized the rebels as ''a mercenary army which exists because the Reagan Administration maintains it.'' He said the United States was supporting rebels in the hope their successes would force the Sandinistas to the bargaining table, but he declared, ''We will never give in to pressure.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/world.main_headline: DISPUTE OVER MARINE WOUNDED IN HONDURAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/world.print_headline: DISPUTE OVER MARINE WOUNDED IN HONDURAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/world.body_text: **********The Defense Department told Congress earlier this year that a United States marine was shot by accident in Honduras last November even though a Marine Corps investigation concluded that the victim was hit by hostile fire, according to Pentagon documents. **********In a report submitted to Congress in April, the Defense Department said the marine, who was shot while guarding a radar installation on Tiger Island in the Gulf of Fonseca, ''was wounded accidentally by either his own weapon, or that of a fellow sentry.'' **********The incident at Tiger Island, off the coast of Honduras not far from Nicaragua and El Salvador, took place on the night of Nov. 3, 1983, the first day a Marine unit was used for sentry duty on the island. **********On Nov. 9, six days after the incident, a Marine Corps investigation concluded that ''the fired weapon was not friendly fire.'' **********The victim, Lance Cpl. Thomas P. Petrucci, was shot in the right thigh. He has recovered. **********Fred C. Ikle, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, said today that the discrepancy was ''not unusual'' and was the result of ''differing interpretations as those in a traffic accident on a rainy night when a police officer may make one judgment and an insurance investigator may come up with a different one.'' **********Mr. Ikle added: ''Why isn't there equally minute attention given to an American soldier who gets shot accidentally in the foot in Germany or Korea? There is no sense of proportion when it comes to Central America.'' **********Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, who is a critic of the Administration's policies in Central American and who provided copies of the documents, said, ''The conflicting reports fuel suspicion that the Administration is being less than forthright in its description of the danger and exposure to hostilities that American troops face in Central America.'' **********The Marines, who were pulled out of Tiger island in May, have told Defense Department officials that they consider the island a potential combat area and would prefer not to return until they are given approval to fortify its defenses. **********Department lawyers have resisted the Marines' preference for increased protective measures, the officials said, because introducing United States troops into foreign territory when they are ''equipped for combat'' requires special notification of Congress. **********Corporal Petrucci, according to a sworn statement he made, reported hearing movement about 9 P.M. in the grass outside the Marine perimeter near the top of a volcanic mountain on the island. After calling ''halt'' in Spanish, Corporal Petrucci said, a single shot was fired from the grassy area. **********When a fellow marine returned fire, Corporal Petrucci said, a second ''blast in front of me between two and three meters away'' hit him in the leg. **********Corporal Petrucci, reached by telephone at his parents home in Boswell, Ga., said today that he could not comment on the shooting. **********The other sentry, Pvt. Alfredo R. Townsend, corroborated Corporal Petrucci's account of the incident in a sworn statement. **********The officer in charge of the Marine detachment, Capt. D. M. Compton, said in a report dated Nov. 9: ''The question arose as to the source of the firing possibly being friendly. However, after extensive questioning of nearly everyone at the radar site and the time of the shooting incident, I find it highly unlikely that any organic site personnel initiated any firing.'' **********Captain Compton added, ''Questioning each individual and/or his superior as to his exact whereabouts at the time of the first shots fired placed no one anywhere near where the muzzle flashes purportedly were located.'' **********Captain Compton found that in the confusion and dark, numerous shots were fired by the marines. In the ''Opinion'' section of his report, Captain Compton concluded, ''The fired weapon which wounded'' Lance Corporal Petrucci ''was not friendly fire.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/busin.main_headline: REVCO D.S. EXECUTIVE ADDS PURCHASING DUTIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; REVCO D.S. EXECUTIVE ADDS PURCHASING DUTIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/busin.body_text: **********Revco D.S. Inc., the drug store chain, yesterday said it had named Daniel Horwitz, a vice president of merchandising, to the new position of vice president of merchandising and purchasing. **********Sidney Dworkin, the company's chairman, said that Mr. Horwitz's appointment was made to consolidate ''two vital company functions in one office.'' Mr. Horwitz, 42, will supervise the purchase of all nonpharmaceutical products. **********Mr. Horwitz thus will take over the purchasing functions from Elliot Dworkin, one of Mr. Dworkin's two sons who are part of Revco's management. **********Elliot Dworkin will continue as a senior vice president of marketing, a company spokesman said. **********Last week the Twinsburg, Ohio- based company formed a special committee formed of directors and its auditors, Peat Marwick, to investigate allegations about the company's purchasing operations. **********The allegations were made by officers of the Odd-Lot Trading Company, which Revco acquired in May for $113 million. The 58-store Odd-Lot chain sells non-clothing consumer goods, consisting of manufacturers' overruns, close-outs and discontinued items. **********A company spokesman said that the Cleveland-born Mr. Horwitz began working for the company at 18, as a stockboy in Revco's first drugstore. At 22 he was named corporate director of merchandising. He was named an assistant vice president in 1972 and vice president the following year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/28/world.main_headline: OFFICIALS SAY U.S. PLANS TO DOUBLE SUPPLY OF ARMS TO AFGHAN REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/28/world.print_headline: OFFICIALS SAY U.S. PLANS TO DOUBLE SUPPLY OF ARMS TO AFGHAN REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/28/world.body_text: **********United States officials say $280 million has been earmarked in covert military aid for the Afghan insurgents this fiscal year, more than doubling the aid in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30. **********This will bring total American aid to $625 million since Soviet troops intervened in Afghanistan in December 1979. This does not include additional aid of $100 million provided last year by Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries, China and Israel, according to official estimates. **********Although all those interviewed agreed that the aid was substantial, there was disagreement over how much arms aid was actually reaching the rebels, whether the weapons were adequate and, above all, whether the guerrillas were winning or losing. **********Dispute Over U.S. Purpose **********Beyond this, there remains a dispute over the American purpose. The Administration talks about making the Soviet Union ''pay a price'' for its intervention. To Congressional officials, the Administration's approach condemns the rebels to defeat. **********By all accounts, Congress has been responsible for most of the increases in covert aid, sometimes encountering Administration resistance. **********Officials of the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency say that the fighting is not going well for Soviet and Afghan Government troops, and that the rebels are well supplied. **********Other intelligence sources and several outside experts assert that the Russians are making gradual progress, that 15 to 40 percent of the arms aid is being skimmed off by the Pakistanis and by Afghan exiles and that, of the arms that do get through, many are old or ineffective. **********The sources described the system for supplying arms to the rebels. According to these accounts, American dollars are used to purchase mainly Soviet-made arms from countries such as China, Egypt and Israel. The price is said to be exorbitant. **********The arms are then delivered to Pakistani ports. At that point, by agreement between the C.I.A. and Pakistan, the supplies pass to Pakistani control for delivery to the political leaders of the Afghan insurgency in Peshawar, Pakistan, and elsewhere. They, in turn, are supposed to pass them to the guerrillas.  ''Accounting procedures are next to nil,'' said an American intelligence official. **********According to Administration officials, Pakistan is given full control on the ground that it is running the risk of incurring Soviet displeasure and possible military retaliation. **********The sources said that Pakistan skimmed off some arms and played favorites among the Afghan exiles, but that most of the skimming was done by the exiles themselves. **********As a result, a Senate Foreign Relations Committee staff report said in April, ''signs of Western aid are indeed scarce.'' **********Report by Senate CommitteeA more detailed report was given at the end of September to the Senate Intelligence Committee by Alexander Alexiev of the Rand Corporation working under a Pentagon contract. To him, the problem was the quality, more than the quantity, of the arms being delivered to the Afghan rebels, who he called the Mujahedeen. **********''The most glaring deficiency,'' he testified, ''continues to be the lack of any effective means to combat Soviet jets and helicopters. **********''The Soviets are able to operate with virtual impunity in the air, which, given the fact that perhaps 80 percent of all Soviet combat and logistics operations depend on air, virtually precludes any significant and lasting Mujahedeen military gains.'' **********By all accounts, the Afghan rebels operate with Soviet-built ground-to-air missiles known as SAM-7's rather than more effective American, British or French shoulder-fired weapons. **********Administration officials say that the United States could not plausibly deny involvement if it were to provide its own arms. As for the use of British and French arms, the officials add, Pakistan has not given approval. **********Shortages ReportedMr. Alexiev and others also reported shortages in ammunition for mortars and heavy machine guns and in mines, communications equipment, binoculars, maps, warm clothing and sleeping bags. **********Andrew L. Eiva, head of the Federation for American Afghan Action, the lobby for the Afghan rebels, said: **********''To the guerrilla in the field, clutching a World War I rifle that has just run out of bullets, the rosy claims of our executive branch have no meaning.'' **********Administration officials said the shortages were being corrected as supplies approved last year were only now reaching the rebels. **********To critics such as Mr. Eiva, these arguments are ''just an excuse.'' **********Administration officials said the quality of arms was upgraded more than a year ago to its present level, and that the Afghan insurgents could not manage more advanced arms. **********The $280 million approved by Congress for this year will not begin reaching the rebels for about a year. For the first time, it will include cash for food purchases on Afghan markets. **********''As a result of the Soviet strategy of forcing people off their land,'' an intelligence official said, ''classical guerrilla warfare strategy is being reversed. Instead of the people feeding the guerrillas, the guerrillas have to feed the people and themselves.'' **********Mr. Alexiev and others said Soviet troops had been effective in military operations against noncombatants and had been ''largely successful'' in their strategy of controlling the urban areas and major transport routes. **********Their goal, Mr. Alexiev said, is not to achieve a purely military solution through a defeat of the guerrillas, but to cut them off from their base of support among the people. **********Officials of the C.I.A. and the State Department deny that Soviet and Afghan Government forces are secure in their control of cities and roads.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/25/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; London Talks: Getting Ready
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/25/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; London Talks: Getting Ready
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/25/busin.body_text: **********THE next economic summit conference among **********the leaders of the major industrial democracies will take place in London June 7-9, with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher as host. **********The London conference is intended, as a principal purpose, to follow through on the program of trade liberalization mapped out last May at the summit conference in Williamsburg, Va. Despite its high rhetoric, however, Williamsburg was followed by a wave of protectionism. **********Ambassador Robert Morris, deputy to the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, is representing the United States in preparations for the London conference. In an interview yesterday, he conceded, ''For a variety of reasons, some of us - and not just the United States - took protectionist actions after Williamsburg.'' **********But he insisted, ''If we are not simon pure, we remain fairly credible.'' **********He said this country's main protectionist moves were to impose quotas on foreign steel and to tighten the administration of import barriers against textiles, while the Europeans refused to ''unbind'' agricultural restrictions, especially on corn gluten. Yet, he said, the Reagan Administration held out against many other demands for protection, and ''we do not have to hang our heads in shame.'' **********At the London conference, the participants - the leaders of the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Italy, Canada and the European Economic Community - will try to finish Phase One by completing the lowering of trade barriers agreed to at the Tokyo Round, which began back in 1973. It has become urgent to open Western markets to the debt- burdened third world. Mr. Morris said the Reagan Administration would press a resistant Congress to give preferences to goods exported by developing countries. **********In Phase Two of the trade talks the United States will call for a new ''safeguards'' code in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, with more realistic and fairer antidumping and retaliation procedures. **********In Phase Three the nations will take up the proposal of Japan's Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, for a new round of multilateral trade negotiations, now that the Tokyo Round is nearing completion. It is likely, Mr. Morris said, that the London conference will support a new round and that it will get under way in the autumn. But it probably will not be completed until the late 1980's or early 1990's. **********In London the national leaders will also tackle the international debt problem, the world monetary system and the functioning of the world economy. ''Some people were optimistic at Williamsburg about recovery,'' Mr. Morris said. ''But now there is no disputing it.'' The United States will continue to urge that world recovery can best be achieved if nations pursue stable, noninflationary policies. As usual, though, the United States is likely to be censured for its huge budget deficits and high interest rates, which have slowed world growth and aggravated the debt-repayment problems of developing countries. **********Mr. Morris regards it as a ''healthy sign'' that the European governments are coming to recognize that their economies have lacked dynamism because of ''a lack of flexibility in labor and capital markets and too much government interference.'' **********If the Americans have their way, the London conference will not address the issue of creating a new mechanism for refunding the debts of third-world countries. The United States will stick to its ''immediate strategy,'' Mr. Morris said, of dealing with debt crises on a ''case-by-case basis.'' He said, ''Mexico is not Argentina, and Brazil is not the Philippines.'' The international debt problem, he predicted, ''will be with us for a long, long time'' and can be solved only by enabling debtor countries to expand their exports and foreign-exchange earnings. That would necessitate, he added, ''a more open world economic regime and a reduction of export subsidies skewed against the developing countries.'' **********There is a planned and unplanned aspect to every summit conference. **********In his new book, ''The Age of Interdependence,'' Michael Stewart of University College, London, writes: ''The June 1982 Versailles summit is remembered as having aggravated a long and acrimonious row between the United States and the European countries over economic relations with the Soviet bloc. **********''The Williamsburg summit of May 1983 was chiefly used by President Reagan to secure the support of his major allies for his controversial arms deployment proposals; little progress was made in convincing him of the need for a reduction in the structural American budget deficit in order to reduce world interest rates.'' **********The London conference may have a hidden agenda that will not emerge until the national leaders actually get together behind closed doors. **********But at this point it looks as though the London meeting may, with the recovery spreading to other countries, be a key exercise in promoting a more open and integrated world economy. It has become increasingly clear that national leaders must take account of developments in the world economy. Integrated financial markets, capital movements, labor markets, technological diffusion, electronic communications and data processing - all have shrunk the world and bound economies together. **********Economic summitry has become a national and international necessity, not just a media event.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/09/busin.body_text: **********Regan as Scrooge **********Regardless of whether the tax reforms proposed by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan make him the Scrooge of Christmases to come, many economists and merchants say he deserves the moniker this year. They believe that many middle-income consumers, faced with the prospect of higher taxes and lower deductions, are likely to cut their spending - an unpleasant prospect for retailers hoping for a holiday buying binge.  ''The tax reform proposals couldn't have been delivered at a worse time, two weeks before the holiday shopping season starts,'' said Edward E.  Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''Even before the tax proposals were announced, consumers were saving more and spending less.'' Now, he said, that trend is likely to be accelerated as uncertainty abounds. **********For example, he said, third-quarter savings were 6.5 percent of disposable personal income, the highest percentage since the depths of the 1982 recession. This would mean that consumers are buying less and reducing consumer installment credit levels, which are regarded as important barometers of a healthy economy. ''We may well see consumer installment credit for October up only $3.5 billion, when the figures are released next Friday, compared with the rises of $4.3 billion in September and $6 billion in August,'' he said. This, he added, could further depress interest rates and inflation levels - and the spirits of retailers. **********Spending Freeze Fears **********The Treasury Department's tax proposals are also being blamed for the recent decline in stock prices. ''The only impact the tax package has had has been fear among investors that debate of the proposals may freeze corporate spending plans,'' said Steven G. Einhorn, vice chairman of the investment policy committee of Goldman, Sachs & Company. **********When the market began its downward trend last January, he noted, it was correctly signaling that the recovery was going to run out of steam sometime during the summer, which is what happened. **********What about now? ''We have,'' he said, ''a stand-off between investors who fear that any strong signs of renewed economic growth will send interest rates climbing and those who fear that continued economic anemia will reduce corporate earnings further. Until one side becomes convinced otherwise, the markets will continue to churn in a choppy narrow range.'' **********More Days, More Discounts **********The long weekend that many consumers will enjoy before celebrating Christmas on Tuesday this year may encourage retailers to slash prices for another 48 hours, according to Bruce R. Grier, retailing analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''This season,'' he said, ''is turning out to be a cliffhanger, with consumers waiting for more price cutting and retailers, many of whom have already slashed prices of the heavy inventories by 20 to 30 percent, wondering how much more they should cut.'' **********November's retail sales figures, due out Thursday, may not offer hints of what could follow. Since the summer, retail sales have been erratic: nearly flat in October, up 1.2 percent in September and off eight-tenths of 1 percent in August. ''Nobody is going to guess about November sales. Even if they were up, they weren't very profitable,'' Mr. Grier said. ''The only items that are moving are toys, mostly traditional toys.'' **********Stretching Out Investments **********Most professional money managers, believing that short-term interest rates are moving downward for the near future, are lengthening their investments in money market mutual funds. In the week ended last Wednesday, for example, the average maturity in these funds grew to 46 days from 43, a sizable extension, said Cornelia S. Bugbee, editor of Donoghue's Money Fund Report, Holliston, Mass. **********''The fund managers want to lock in today's short- term funds rates before they decline with the maturing of higher-yielding Treasury bills, commercial paper and other short-term instruments mature,'' she said. ''So do many smaller investors.'' **********Based on figures from the 256 taxable mutual money funds monitored by her group, assets rose to $196.7 billion last Wednesday, up from $187.2 billion a month earlier and the 1984 low of $159.8 billion reported last Jan. 5. Bank bank money market deposit accounts are also growing, but at a much slower rate. They rose by $16.3 billion, to $386.8 bilion, in the past year. **********H. J. Maidenberg

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/28/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge in Uniondale, L.I., yesterday dismissed two suits seeking damages from the trustees of the Grumman Corporation's pension plan for buying Grumman stock at a high price to fend off a 1981 takeover attempt by the LTV Corporation. **********In October 1981, the pension plan bought 1.16 million shares of Gramman stock for $38.34 a share, when the fair market value of that stock was only $22.31 a share, the judge said. The pension trustees refused to tender those shares to LTV, the Texas conglomerate offering $45 a share for Grumman stock. **********Faced both with Grumman's opposition and potential antitrust problems, LTV gave up its $450 million takeover campaign in November 1981. **********The following month, United States District Judge Jacob Mishler ruled that the pension trustees had breached their fiduciary duties, and put loyalty to the company ahead of responsibility to the beneficiaries of the pension fund. **********No Money Lost **********Yesterday, however, he said the pension fund beneficiaries were not entitled to any damages since they had not actually lost any money because of the breach. Judge Mishler dismissed both a Grumman employee suit and a Labor Department suit requesting that the trustees reimburse the pension fund for losses suffered as a result of their decisions. **********''The obligation of the trustee is to make the plan 'whole,' Judge Mishler ruled. ''To make the plan whole, the trustees were required to return the purchase price of the shares of stock and the loss of investment income during the period from Oct. 12, 1981, to March 10, 1983.'' **********The Grumman shares bought for $38.34 later gained in value, and were sold for $47.55 a share in March 1983. Since the net proceeds of the sale of the stock and the dividends earned exceeded the potential loss, the judge ruled, the trustees' purchase of the shares did not result in a loss, so the pension beneficiaries were not entitled to any damages. **********''The court finds the plan suffered no loss as a result of the trustees' violation'' of their fiduciary duty, he said. **********While Judge Mishler's decision solves the Grumman pension trustees' problem, it offers little encouragement to other companies to use similar tactics to ward off unwelcome takeover attempts, since the only reason Grumman was not found liable for damages was that the stock ultimately increased in value.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/11/world.main_headline: POPE SAYS SUFFERING CAN MEAN SPIRITUAL GAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/11/world.print_headline: POPE SAYS SUFFERING CAN MEAN SPIRITUAL GAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/11/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II has issued an apostolic letter on suffering in which he says physical, mental and moral pain pose a mystery that can lead to spiritual growth and salvation. **********At the Vatican, Bishop Fiorenzo Angelini, of the Vicarate for Religious Assistance to Roman Hospitals, said yesterday that the letter represented the Pope's personal meditations on the meaning of suffering and that the document was a teaching guide. **********''It is the first document from a pontiff that, in such an ample and authoritative form, is dedicated to human suffering,'' the Bishop said at a news conference. **********The subject of suffering has long been a central concern of the Pope, and the letter, scheduled for official publication today, returns to themes he has addressed in previous writings.   Can Lead to Helping Others **********The 13,000-word document, titled ''Salvifici Doloris,'' or Salvific Suffering, says suffering can open the way to spiritual maturity and senstitize Christians to the need to help the afflicted. **********Both individual and collective suffering plague humanity, the Pope says. **********Among the perils he cites is ''such a horrible threat of nuclear war that we cannot think of this period except in terms of an incomparable accumulation of sufferings, even to the possible self-destruction of humanity.'' He speaks of ''the world which as never before has been transformed by progress through man's work and, at the same time, is as never before in danger because of man's mistakes and offenses.'' **********''Down through the centuries and generation,'' the Pope writes, ''it has been seen that in suffering there is concealed a particular power that draws a person interiorly close to Christ, a special grace.''  'Do Good by His Suffering' **********''At one and the same time Christ has taught man to do good by his suffering and to do good to those who suffer,'' he says. ''In this double aspect he has completely revealed the meaning of suffering.'' **********The letter, laced with biblical references, is written in John Paul's expansive style and follows his philosophical method of examining theological issues from the standpoint of personal life and its problems. In the context of human experience, he analyzes various functions of suffering and assesses their redeeming aspects. He says suffering can lead to a turning away from evil, a religious conversion and a new persepective on suffering itself. **********The key to the value of suffering lies in the death and resurrection of Christ, the Pope says. While this ''does not abolish temporal suffering from human life, nor free from human suffering the whole historical dimension of human existence, it nevertheless throws a new light upon this dimension and upon every suffering: the light of salvation.'' **********''Christ has led us into this kingdom through his suffering,'' the Pope says. ''And also through suffering those surrounded by the mystery of Christ's redemption become mature enough to enter this kingdom.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/13/busin.body_text: **********People Express Airlines is growing like a gawky teen-ager, bursting its seams. Overflowing its base in the old North Terminal of Newark International Airport, it is filling the skies here with its planes. **********That growth accelerated last week as the low-fare airline announced plans to extend its bus-line-in-the-sky with five roundtrip flights a day to Chicago. That challenges the airline giants United and American, which each have 24 roundtrip flights a day between Chicago and the New York area. **********Fare Wars Forecast **********There were immediate forecasts of ruinous fare wars for the airline industry, for the People Express fares - $79 from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M. Monday through Friday and $59 at other hours - were about 70 percent below coach fares on the full-service airlines. And the risk to People Express, taking on the established major lines, was evident. Analysts recalled other carriers whose swift growth overtook them: Braniff, Laker and Air Florida. **********These recent failures, however, have given no pause to Donald C. Burr, the chief executive and founder of People Express. His philosophy is growth, and he wants eventually to put People Express planes in the nation's skies the way McDonald's puts restaurants on the roads. **********The investment community's awareness of the risks and costs of growth is reflected in a lower stock price for People Express. It closed Friday in over-the-counter trading at $12.875 bid, well below its year's high of $25.50. **********The airline is expecting delivery of 24 more planes by spring. That will give it 76 aircraft - 22 Boeing 737's, 50 larger 727's and 4 jumbo 747's - and a voracious need for new passengers to fill them. **********Confidence in Formula - **********There is no question that Mr. Burr and his associates have zealous confidence in their formula of low-cost operations, in which extra charges are levied for such amenities as checked baggage and meals. The formula allows profits on fares as low as one-third those charged by other airlines. But until now the formula's success has come on peripheral routes, such as Newark to Buffalo, where much of the competition is from small airlines. **********People Express intensified the game when it began international service to London last year. Now it has added domestic service from Newark to such major destinations as Los Angeles, Houston and St. Paul- Minneapolis, and on Aug. 22 it will begin the Chicago service. **********These new routes have taken People Express up against the big airlines. ''It does represent a change in strategy,'' said Alfred Norlin, an analyst at Kidder Peabody. ''They had said they would try to avoid the head-to-head competition as much as they could. But considering the amount of airplanes they have bought, it's pretty clear they had to have that kind of expansion.'' **********The move to Chicago was no surprise within the industry, said Robert Joedicke, of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. It was known that People Express had obtained landing right slots at Chicago's O'Hare airport. **********''They've got to go into big enough markets,'' Mr. Joedicke said. ''With the delivery schedule of aircraft, they've got to keep finding places to put them.'' **********''What will happen has happened in many People Express markets,'' said an airline consultant who asked that his name not be used. ''The total market is so stimulated by their low fares that before the smoke is cleared, everybody benefits.'' **********Indeed, People's main competition in the New York-Chicago market have already responded. United acted first, announcing that it would match People's fares, with some restrictions, on its Newark-Chicago flights, and charge $30 more than People on Newark flights with no restrictions. And, recognizing the preference of many travelers for the other New York-area airports, United offered fares as low as $79 on Chicago flights to La Guardia, Kennedy International, White Plains and Islip, L.I. **********American Airlines then announced it, too, would match People's fares, with some restrictions. In addition, it decided to undercut United on flights to La Guardia, Kennedy and Islip, offering fares as low as $69 each way. **********People Express's low fares tap a market of new passengers. ''They have taken people off the roads and out of buses,'' Mr. Norlin said. ''They generate traffic, no doubt about it.'' **********Stimulating Traffic **********Harold Pareti, People Express's president and chief operating officer, said, for example, that when the airline began to fly to Boston in 1981, airlines on the New York-Boston route carried 1.4 million passengers a year.  Now, 3.8 million fly the route. **********Because so many of the new travelers hauled by People Express are young, it is sometimes called the ''backpacker's airline.'' But now it is seen as trying to attract the ''briefcase'' market by going into routes heavily traveled by business people, such as New York-Chicago. **********Business travelers make up the bulk of New York-Chicago air passengers, and it may be hard to change their habits, such as their preference for La Guardia over Newark because they feel it is more convenient to Manhattan. In any case, some analysts believe People Express will be using its new Chicago route mainly to try to feed its entire system. **********''I believe they're not going to stress New York-Chicago but the connecting traffic,'' Mr. Joedicke, the analyst, said. **********People Express's profits so far this year have not matched its performance in the first half of 1983. Net income in the first six months was $3.8 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with $6.3 million, or 37 cents a share, in the earlier period. **********Long-Term Growth **********As for profitability, Mr. Pareti stressed the long term of ''building net worth and a strong system for the future.'' He said the airline will add other cities, and hopes to create other hubs such as its Newark operation. **********One problem is the inadequate building and equipment at the Newark airport's antiquated North Terminal. This is being solved with a move to the airport's modern Terminal C, where the airline will have as many as 44 gates. **********One of the airline's weaknesses has been its reservation system, which all but broke down under the weight of its expansion and jammed the phone lines. Phone-answering has been beefed up with new operations and equipment and Mr. Pareti, on a busy Friday afternoon, put it to the acid test. He picked up the phone and dialed the reservations number. A look of relief came over his face. The phone was answered after two rings. **********people glance   AT A GLANCE People Express      All dollar amounts in thousands, except per share data  Three months ended June 3019841983 Revenues $135,296$64,304 Net income 3,7604,208 Earnings per share $0.15$0.24  Year ended  Dec. 31 1983 1982 Revenues $286,589$138,859 Net income 10,4341,002 Earnings per share $0.57$0.08  Main Lines of Business   Total assets, Dec. 31, 1983   $415,733 Current assets   *103,783 Current liabilities   **67,220 Long-term debt*   *246,591 Book value per share, Dec. 31, 1983   $5.57 Stock price, Aug. 10, 1984 O-T-C close   12 7/8 Stock price, 52-week range   25 1/2-7 5/8 Employees, Dec. 31, 1983   2,596 Headquarters   Newark * Includes capitalized lease obligations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Doris Cooper Baxter, who is known to her friends as Daiquiri, got her dream job as a United Airlines stewardess in July 1967. **********"I loved United, I loved doing things for people and I loved flying," said Mrs. Baxter, a resident of Greensboro, N.C., who now runs a business called Designs by Daiquiri. **********She only flew for a year, though, because United had a rule that its stewardesses had to remain single, and in September 1968, she got married. **********Now - 16 years, two children and many jobs later - Mrs. Baxter wants to fly again. And like 1,800 other former United flight attendants who left their jobs between July 29, 1965, and Nov. 7, 1968, when the no-marriage rule was changed, she stands a good chance of winning reinstatement. **********As a result of a sex discrimination class action that is costing United Airlines millions of dollars and causing hard feelings among the airline's current flight attendants, these former stewardesses are coming to Chicago, one by one, to try to persuade the court that but for the no-marriage rule, they would have kept their jobs. **********While a few of the former stewardesses tell of concealing their marriages, and even of giving up a child to keep the job, most concede that they accepted the rule and quietly resigned. Most of them took other jobs - one is a lawyer, another a college professor - that they describe as boring compared with flying. **********For the most part, the former stewardesses have kept the eagerness to please, the pleasant mannes and the looks that made United hire them at a time when only 1 in 30 applicants was accepted for what was viewed as a glamour job that could catapult a small-town girl into a world of international travel, celebrity contact and sophisticated urban life. **********Even on the witness stand, many behave more like hostesses than litigants. When the lawyer who is challenging their testimony stands up and says, "I am Mark Bigelow, representing the union," the witness is as likely as not to lean forward with a big smile and say, "Hi¸" Harsh Questions **********The hearings themselves show how much times have changed: Several of the lawyers involved are young women asking the stewardesses harsh questions like "Didn't you think about putting off your marriage so you could keep your job?" or "Wouldn't you have quit your job and followed your husband even if there had been no rule against marriage?" **********The stewardesses who persuade the court they wanted to keep flying - about 71 percent of the nearly 500 flight attendants whose cases have been decided so far - not only win back their jobs, but also get full seniority in pay and vacations, and, if they live near a major United center, get to work out of their hometown. They will also get back pay, although the amount is in dispute. **********United opposes the former stewardesses' claims. "The vast majority of these women would never have come back except that this lawsuit came out of the blue for them, said Paul Tschirhart, an in-house lawyer at United. "There's something kind of unfair about any company being forced to face this kind of substantial liability so long after the event, to people who never even complained the time." **********The union that represents United's flight attendants also opposed the reinstatements. Since the no-marriage rule was a subject for bargaining in negotiations as far back as 1965 - and since the union won reinstatement for the few women who did not quit but waited to be dismissed after marrying - the union argues that any woman who really cared about her job should have filed a union grievance. **********"Anybody who had two ears and two eyes should have known that the union would have fought for them if they had complained," said Nancy Coopersmith of the Association of Flight Attendants. **********"We have gone back and found copies of local newsletters advising women not to quit, but to file a grievance," she continued. "I don't think you can discount what was expected of young brides back then, which was to stay home and have babies. At the time, and even for a few years after the no-marriage rule ended, the job was considered a transitory one, with terrible pay and benefits, and no retirement plan." **********There are some hard feelings between the new generation of flight attendants and the more than 120 former stewardesses who have been reinstated. And there is reason for mutual distrust, since the new generation's seniority is threatened by the former stewardesses - who, in turn, are acutely aware that the current generation only has seniority because the no-marriage rule and another rule that stewardesses had to stop flying at the age of 32 were changed. **********As a legal matter, the injured parties in most discrimination cases get full seniority to put them, in effect, in the same position they would have been in if there had been no discrimination. **********But since, in the United case, that would have meant that women like Mrs. Baxter, who flew for a year, or Cheryl Williams Dailey, who flew for only four months, would be able to bump the current flight attendants from the choices routes, the court has refused to award full seniority in one crucial ara - bidding for flight schedules. **********In that process, the reinstated flight attendants' seniority will reflect only their employment time at United. Because that decision goes against the general legal rule, the seniority question is being appealed to the Supreme Court. United's Difficult Position **********Although United is not the only airline that had a no-marriage rule even after the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibited sex discrimination in employment, it is in a particularly difficult legal position because it had 49 male stewards, all of them Hawaiian, to provide local color on the Hawaiian flights, and they could marry. **********However clear it may now be that the no-marriage rule was discriminatory, Mr. Tschirhart said, the question was once a tough one. In 1966, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission issued a preliminary opinion that the rule was acceptable, and the airline relied on that until two years later, when the agency said the rule was discriminatory. **********While the no-marriage rule was in effect, United was fierce about enforcing it. Former stewardesses who tried to conceal marriages not only had to eschew weddding rings, but also keep two phones, one of which would never be answered by a man, and put their maiden name on the mailbox. There are tales, denied by the airline, of United employees assigned to check newspapers for wedding announcements, and of harassing or grounding women suspected of secretly marrying, or worse, have a baby. **********"Times were different then," Mrs. Baxter said. "I knew one stewardess who concealed her marriage and got caught and fired. When my time came, I told them and applied for a ground job. The man I talked to said, 'You're 24 years old, you're going to start a family and in a year you won't be working.' When I told him we weren't going to start a family for four or five years, he said, 'That's what they all say' and he didn't hire me. It really made me mad."

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/28/busin.main_headline: CREDITORS SEEK TO OUST THE HEAD OF GHR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/28/busin.print_headline: CREDITORS SEEK TO OUST THE HEAD OF GHR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/28/busin.body_text: **********The turbulent command of John R. Stanley, who twice piloted his Gulf Coast energy company into bankruptcy, may be coming to an end at the hands of his creditors. **********Mr. Stanley, who is president, chairman and sole shareholder of the GHR Companies, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code 13 months ago, after huge losses forced the closing of his company's Good Hope, La., refinery - and payments lagged on $1.2 billion in debt. The GHR case is one of the biggest bankruptcies in history. **********Last week, at a hearing on a default motion before a Federal Bankruptcy Court in Worcester, Mass., the banks and unsecured creditors told Judge Paul W. Glennon that they agreed unanimously on a key concept: Mr. Stanley must leave if a reorganization plan were to succeed. **********GHR, once the nation's third-largest privately held industrial concern, owes about $800 million in secured debts to 14 banks led by Continental Illinois of Chicago, Chase Manhattan and Paribas, the French bank. About 1,000 unsecured creditors, including PPG Industries, Ingersoll-Rand and others, are owed an additional $200 million. **********Debts From Earlier Bankruptcy **********To complicate matters, Goodhope Industries, a predecessor company of GHR, which had its headquarters here, owes local creditors several million dollars from a 1975 bankruptcy reorganization. **********The creditors now propose that Mr. Stanley be replaced by Eugene B. Berman, a Springfield attorney, who would become GHR's court-appointed trustee. Under the creditors' plan, Mr. Berman and a board of directors would run the company, with Mr. Stanley serving as a consultant to the board. **********The banks said they would divert 20 percent of their secured party payments to the unsecured creditors in the first year of a 10- to 15-year program. The program would provide a 100 percent payback, plus interest, to all creditors. **********''Any durable plan requires stable economic management'' to develop GHR's natural gas fields, Earl Alpert, a Springfield attorney who represents creditors from the 1975 case, told the court. He said Mr. Stanley has been ''quixotic'' and ''mercurial'' at the head of GHR. **********'New Face' Urged **********Van Oliver, a Dallas attorney who represents Gulf Coast creditors, said his clients supported Mr. Stanley for more than a year. Now, he said, ''a new face must appear on the debtor,'' so that GHR can obtain production loans to develop the gas fields. **********If Judge Glennon approves the default motion, Mr. Stanley faces immediate removal. If he disapproves, or chooses not to act on it, the creditors and GHR will probably offer competing plans for the company's reorganization. **********GHR has continued to operate under Chapter 11, and its natural gas fields in Laredo County, Tex., have been profitable recently. But the refinery remains closed and efforts to sell or lease it have failed.  In a rare courtroom appearance, Mr. Stanley, 44 years old, listened impassively to the demands for his ouster. In an interview later, he said that plunging oil prices a year ago, not poor management, had forced the shutdown of the refinery and the subsequent bankruptcy filing. **********''We lost $180 million on the refinery in 1982,'' he said. ''We had no choice.'' This year, Mr. Stanley said, the gas fields will produce profits of $224 million. **********GHR's Payback Plan **********In any case, Mr. Stanley's role would be reduced even with an alternate 100 percent payback plan that was outlined by GHR last week. While he would not step down as president, he would agree to the appointment of an independent board of directors and would place his stock in trust during the payout period, said Stephen F. Gordon, GHR counsel. **********Starting with one service station here in the 1960's, Mr. Stanley built the 230-unit Gasland chain in the Northeast. He was squeezed out of business, however, as a result of the 1973 Arab oil embargo. In 1975, a plan to build a fertilizer plant in Good Hope, near the now-closed refinery, failed, leading to the first bankruptcy. **********Mr. Stanley appeared to have resolved his problems in 1980, when the bank group lent GHR $750 million to pay off many of its debts and expand capacity at the Good Hope refinery. **********After the second bankruptcy last year, Mr. Stanley sought a $24 million loan to improve the refinery. He later sued the banks for $3 billion, contending that they had illegally diverted assets of GHR into the Bellermine Foundation, a charitable trust that benefits Fairfield University in Connecticut. **********Last week's move to replace Mr.  Stanley came in a request to declare GHR in default of the remaining 1975 claims, and force adjudication of both the 1975 and 1983 cases under the relatively harsh terms of the Federal Bankruptcy Act - in effect when the 1975 case was filed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/22/busin.body_text: **********AFTER lobbying successfully for the right to use financial futures and options for hedging purposes, a number of states, led by New York, finally agreed last year that life insurers needed their own insurance against lending and borrowing risks. **********Last week's spectacular rise in the prices of fixed-income securities and the decline in interest rates again emphasized the volatility of the credit markets. **********But the most important fact as far as the financial futures exchanges and brokers are concerned is that few insurance companies have been using these markets for hedging the huge amount of funds that they, in effect, borrow from policyholders and lend to real estate and other businesses. **********For example, life insurers writing policies that guarantee a fixed yield at maturity have no guarantee that they will have sufficient earnings from their investments to pay the yield, he noted. **********''The most obvious reason why few life insurers use financial futures is that the states that permit such hedging have placed severe limits on the use of futures,'' said Arthur L. Rebell, first vice president of Wertheim & Company. ''In New York, for example, the life insurers can only use futures to hedge 2 percent of their admitted assets. California's regulators set a ceiling of 5 percent.'' **********Moreover, the life insurers based in New York can use futures and options only to hedge specific risks, such as a loan for a fixed period, he said. **********And casualty underwriters are still prohibited from using futures or options to hedge their investment portfolios, although Mr. Rebell noted that New York's insurance regulators, who often set standards followed by other states, say they are studying requests by the casualty insurers to use futures and options. **********But executives of several life insurance companies have told futures and options brokers that they are not optimistic, despite their lobbying efforts, about the chances of New York officials' relaxing the current restrictions. **********Another reason why life insurers have not made much use of financial futures and options, Mr. Rebell continued, ''is that they have traditionally made decisions by committee, rather than giving this responsibility to one person.'' **********Meanwhile, the life insurance business is undergoing a dramatic change, with more policies being written at variable rates. Increasingly, such risks are being hedged between insurers through ''swaps.'' **********Under this arrangement, insurers exchange fixed-rate mortgages for variable-rate policies. ''In effect, this means one insurer or other party is in agreement to pay a fixed rate in exchange for a variable-rate debt,'' Mr. Rebell explained. **********Not only are such swaps often more flexible than hedging with futures, but also they can usually be effected for much longer periods, he said. ''And neither party has to be concerned about tying up large amounts of funds for initial and maintenance margins, as is the case with futures,'' he said, ''nor or do those engaged in swaps have to pay premiums.'' A premium is the cost of buying an option. **********What also makes swaps attractive, Mr. Rebell continued, is that these operations need not show up on balance sheets as credits or - much worse for institutional money managers - debits. This often happens when investment portfolios are hedged with futures. **********The typical hedge for an institution or other investor in, say, Treasury bonds, would be to sell short a like amount of bond futures. During last week's extraordinary surge in bond prices, the futures sold short showed huge losses on paper despite the fact that the value of the actual bonds rose just as much. **********Thus, many institutional portfolio managers had to either put up huge amounts of additional margin on their futures hedges or sell off some of their increasingly profitable holdings. **********''While financial futures and options are not total panaceas for the hedger, neither are swaps because of the safety factor,'' Mr. Rebell warned. ''With the volume of insurance debt swaps now about $100 billion, the insurers should consider the inherent risks involved in this unregulated market.'' **********With any kind of swaps there is no guarantee that anyone will make good if the other party goes under, he said, noting that a number of once- prominent dealers in Government securities who were heavily involved in repurchase agreements, which are similar to swaps, have failed in recent years. But all exchange-traded futures and options are guaranteed by the exchange's clearinghouse.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/16/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland urged Americans today to stop supporting Irish terrorists. **********In a speech to a joint meeting of Congress, Mr. FitzGerald said peace in Northern Ireland ''can be fulfilled only by a corresponding rejection - of revulsion against - the very idea of aid by way of money, or by way of weapons, or by way of moral support, to any of those who are engaged in the act of horrific violence corrupting and destroying the life of a whole community.'' **********This also precludes, he said, ''making common cause for any purpose, however speciously well-meaning, with people who advocate, or condone the use of violence in Ireland for political ends.'' **********BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 15 - Scattered violence continued across Northern Ireland today as a result of the shooting of the leader of the political wing of the Irish Republican Army. **********Several buses in Belfast were pelted with rocks overnight and two were set afire. Protesters in Londonderry threw firebombs in the street. **********Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Provisional Irish Republican Army, who was wounded Wednesday, was reported to be making a satisfactory recovery. **********The police arrested three men who were identified as members of a splinter group of the Ulster Defense Association, a loyalist paramilitary outfit, in the shooting of Mr. Adams, a member of the British Parliament.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/02/busin.body_text: **********The nation's savings and loan associations made loans to home buyers at a record pace in December, closing a total of $14.1 billion in mortgages, the Government said today. **********The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, in its monthly financial statement on thrift units, said the amount of loans closed in December exceeded the previous monthly high of $13.9 billion, set last June. **********The December lending pace was nearly 30 percent above the level of November, and 70 percent higher than in December of 1982, the bank board said. **********In all of last year, savings and loan associations closed a total of $132.4 billion in mortgages, up sharply from $53.4 billion in 1982. **********In the same report, the bank board said that depositors put $3.1 billion more in thrift unit accounts than they withdrew in December, compared with an increase of $1.8 billion in November. When interest was credited to accounts in December, the net deposit gain was $10.4 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/15/busin.body_text: **********Swiss unemployment dropped to 1 percent of the work force in September from 1.1 percent in August, but was up from eight- tenths of 1 percent from 12 months before, the Federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/03/busin.body_text: **********People Express Sets Campaign for Sunday **********Plapler & Associates' new campaign for People Express will break locally this Sunday during the movie ''Chariots of Fire'' on the CBS-TV Network, and then during the Winter Olympics you will be seeing plenty of it because, according to Larry Plapler, People will be the biggest local advertiser. **********And as in the past, the well-made spots will play up the cheerful dedication of People employees, who are all stockholders, and the economy of the fares, with the idea that, since going via People is cheaper than driving, the airline has built a highway in the sky. **********The carrier, which spent $9.7 million for advertising last year, is putting $2.5 million to $3 million into the first quarter of 1984. **********After a seven-week New York flight, the television advertising will move up to New England, while down in Florida the natives must be contented with radio, print and billboard advertising. **********According to Mr. Plapler, his client flies more planes out of New York than any other line and is second in flights to Florida only to Eastern.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/01/world.main_headline: A SURVIVOR'S STORY: 'BLINDING EXPLOSION' AMONG JOURNALISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/01/world.print_headline: A SURVIVOR'S STORY: 'BLINDING EXPLOSION' AMONG JOURNALISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/01/world.body_text: **********Reid G. Miller, a corresponent for The Associated Press who was wounded in the bombing in southern Nicaragua, filed this dispatch from a hospital in Quesada, Costa Rica. **********QUESADA, Costa Rica, May 31 (AP) - About 15 journalists boarded two long dugout canoes powered by outboard motors and rode up the San Juan River for two hours to Eden Pastora's camp on the Nicaraguan shore. **********After arriving, we were led up a steep muddy slope to a two-story frame house that had no wall on the river side - a not untypical style of building in the tropics. **********We found Mr. Pastora on the second floor, and after a round of jovial greetings we began to gather around him for an informal question-and-answer session. **********Mr. Pastora stood at the head of a high, narrow table with most of the journalists crowding around the table's edges two or three deep in places. I was on the edge of the circle, trying to get my tape recorder to work. It had got wet during the boat ride. **********I had just given up on the tape recorder and was starting to step into the tight circle to take notes when there was a blinding explosion that knocked me back about 10 feet into a wall.   From the Middle of the Circle **********The explosion seemed to come from the middle of the circle of journalists. It was 7:30 P.M. I crawled into an adjoining room and found myself at the open front of the building. **********I slid down a 2-by-4 brace to the ground, then rolled into a shallow slit trench that had been dug nearby. **********Many of Mr. Pastora's men stood with their rifles slung, offering no help to the wounded and seemingly stunned. **********Many of the wounded, like myself, had crawled or stumbled from the building and were sitting or lying on the muddy riverbank. **********Not for about a half-hour did there seem to be any organized effort to remove the more seriously wounded from the building's interior.   An Injection for the Wounded **********Linda Frazier was pulled from the house almost an hour after the explosion and laid on a blanket nearby. **********Mortally wounded, she was to lie there another two hours before help came - a doctor and two nurses dressed in the green fatigues of Mr. Pastora's Revolutionary Democratic Alliance. **********She and all of the other wounded received an injection of antibiotic but little else. **********At one point I crawled over to her, unable to walk because of shrapnel wounds in my right leg. **********She took my hand and I could see she was talking to me, but I could not hear her words because the explosion had left me temporarily deaf. I learned later that she had died.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/23/busin.body_text: **********Texaco Inc. and the Amoco Oil Company, two of the nation's largest gasoline marketers, yesterday raised their wholesale prices by a penny a gallon. **********In addition, there were reports that the Gulf Oil Corporation had increased its wholesale gasoline prices by one cent a gallon on the Eastern Seaboard. **********It was the second round of penny- a-gallon increases in nine days. The Mobil Corporation lifted its wholesale gasoline prices by one cent nationwide on Aug. 14, a move quickly followed by several companies, including Texaco. On Tuesday, Mobil again raised its wholesale prices by a penny. **********Analysts said motorists probably would find the wholesale price increases reflected in higher pump prices, which have dropped by 3.4 cents a gallon since mid-May during the peak driving season. **********In Houston, a Texaco spokesman said the company had raised its wholesale prices because of ''market conditions.'' **********A spokesman for Amoco, the Chicago-based subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said, ''Generally our gasoline prices have increased at practically all of our terminals today by a penny a gallon.'' **********He noted that gasoline prices have been at their lowest level in five years for most of the summer. **********''But there is beginning to be a little tightening of supply,'' he said. ''We have seen a large increase in demand this summer.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/25/busin.body_text: **********Generating Low-Cost Electricity **********WASHINGTON **********T HE holder of a number of patents on charged aerosol power **********systems has invented, with Federal support, a so-called power fence that he says can supply cheap electricity in broad areas. **********Alvin M. Marks, president of Advanced Research Development Inc. in Athol, Mass., was granted patent 4,433,248 this week for a power generator that uses charged aerosols, wind, solar energy and gravitation. **********The development was supported by about $300,000 from the National Science Foundation, the Department of Energy and the Solar Energy Research Institute. **********The process is described as working this way: Solar energy is used to distill water and send the steam to a tank atop the fence, where it condenses. Gravity moves the water under pressure to form the charged aerosols, which are then blown by the wind to create electric power. **********Mr. Marks calculates that a fence about five-eighths of a mile long and 300 feet high, with a wind of 12 miles an hour, could provide 25 million watts. **********Cost Put at $10 Million **********The construction cost, including towers and supporting cable, is estimated at $10 million, he said, but the electric power is expected to cost only one-cent per kilowatt-hour. He expects commercial use of the invention to start in about a year. His earlier charged aerosol inventions have been used so far chiefly in air purification. **********Commercial rights are available in the United States and Western Europe through Advanced Research Development. Mr. Marks has donated rights to this and other energy- related patents through the World Energy Foundation for free use by developing countries. **********He was formerly president of the Marks Polarized Corporation in Whitestone, Queens, which operated in the field of three-dimensional motion pictures, using his inventions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/02/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********In his article on the Pastoral Letter of the American Catholic Bishops (''A Plan for Spreading Misery, Not Wealth,'' Forum, Nov. 18) Norman Podhoretz found an irresistible opportunity to castigate liberals in a way that added nothing to the debate the bishops were asking for. **********There are many liberals who agree that American capitalism is far superior to socialism but who are still troubled by evidence that: (1) the poverty class is growing while the middle class is getting smaller; (2) many in the middle range of the middle class have dropped to the lowest range of the middle class, and (3) unenlightened self-interest and greed are on the rise. **********All of this is taking place while the rich continue to get richer. **********Mr. Podhoretz wonders why the bishops have trouble uttering the word ''capitalism.'' I wonder why Mr. Podhoretz has so much trouble with the word ''greed,'' unless he is quoting a liberal in derision. **********In the October 1984 issue of his magazine Commentary there is a long dissertation by Irving Kristol on the ''Politics of Compassion'' (supposedly in response to letters of criticism about an earlier article), but there is no recognition that there might be something like a ''Politics of Greed.'' **********As it has been said, there is always room for another hypocrite.  ISADORE L. RISEN Bethesda, Md., Nov. 19
