https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/05/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices plunged yesterday in accelerated trading after two leading economists predicted that interest rates would continue to rise this year and next. **********The Dow Jones industrial average ended the session 16.22 points lower, at 1,165.31, its biggest decline since April 5, when it tumbled 18.01 points. **********In the general market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that rose, 1,031 to 516. Turnover expanded to 98.6 million shares, from 91.9 million the day before. **********Kaufman Prediction **********Prices began to drop sharply in midmorning after Henry Kaufman, the chief economist of Salomon Brothers, predicted that interest rates would go ''spectacularly higher'' before the end of this year and continue upward in 1985 unless strong measures were undertaken to cut the Federal budget deficits. **********Yields in the credit markets yesterday were significantly higher and contributed to the stock market's malaise. But the dollar moved sharply higher after Mr. Kaufman's predictions. **********Another factor in the market's weakness was the statement by Allen Sinai, the chief economist of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., that interest rates next year would rise between one and two percentage points above current levels. **********Stock prices since January have dropped sharply mainly because of rising interest rates, caused at least in part by the still-strong economy and the large budget deficits. **********Other Indicators Drop **********The two other major market indicators also ended with large losses yesterday. The exchange's composite index dropped 1.08, to 91.75, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks lost 2.09, to 159.11. **********''Unless there is continuing evidence that the economy is slowing down to a more sustainable pace and that yields in the credit markets decline, stock prices are unlikely to advance,'' noted Hugh A. Johnson, senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation. **********Analysts have been hoping that the economy would slow down enough so as to reduce business borrowing, which would ease pressure on interest rates. **********The news yesterday that the nation's civilian unemployment rate was unchanged in April, at 7.7 percent, did nothing to buoy equities. **********The market's big drop yesterday erased the week's earlier gains. For the five trading sessions the Dow average fell 3.76 points. Turnover for the week rose to 480.9 million shares, from 430.2 million shares the week before. **********The biggest losers yesterday were the large capitalization and technology issues. Among the former, International Business Machines dropped 2 7/8 points, to 112 3/4, and International Paper lost 2 1/8, to 52 3/4. Losses of a point or more were posted by Minnesota Mining, Allied Corporation, Procter & Gamble, Union Carbide and General Electric. **********In the weaker technology category, Texas Instruments fell 3 5/8, to 143 3/4, Motorola was off 3, to 119 3/8, and Honeywell lost 2 7/8, to 55 1/4. Cray Research, NCR Corporation, Hewlett- Packard and Teledyne each slipped a point or more. **********Esmark Most Active **********Esmark, which soared 12 3/8 points on Thursday, topped the most-active list and lost 1 1/8, to 56 1/2. The company yesterday agreed to the proposal made Thursday by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts, a New York investment house, to acquire its common stock for $55 a share. Under the proposal holders of Esmark's $2.80 preferred cumulative series B stock would receive $39.05 a share. The entire transaction is valued at $2.4 billion. **********Most of the retailing issues were also under pressure. Sears Roebuck was off 1, to 32 1/8; J. C. Penney lost 1, to 52 1/2, and K Mart lost 3/4, to 27 5/8. **********Colgate-Palmolive, a rumored takeover candidate, was down 7/8, to 25 1/4, after gaining 1 3/8 points on Thursday. **********Stocks of the auto companies ended lower, despite the sharply higher sales for the last 10 days of April, reported Thursday. General Motors was off 1 1/2, to 64 1/4; Chyrsler lost 1 1/4, to 23 1/4, and Ford fell 1, to 35 1/2. **********Binney & Smith, a maker of crayons, toys and games, climbed 3 1/4, to 56 1/2, in active trading. On Thursday, the stock soared 7 3/4 points after the company announced it had retained Morgan Stanley & Company as its financial adviser to examine corporate strategic alternatives. **********Another gainer was Milton Bradley, which advanced 2 5/8, to 47 1/2, after it agreed to be acquired by Hasbro Industries at $50 a share. The latter's stock was up 1 1/8, to 37 1/8, on the American Stock Exchange. **********Prices also finished lower on the Amex with the market-value index down 1.44, to 212.21. The class A stock of Resorts International fell 2 5/8, to 41 3/8, following the news that it lost $1.4 million in its first quarter compared with a deficit of $1.1 million the year before. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index was down 1.66, to 250.89.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/01/busin.main_headline: When a Developer Becomes a Retailer
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/01/busin.print_headline: When a Developer Becomes a Retailer
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/01/busin.body_text: **********With a decline in available sites for new shopping centers, what could be more natural than for a shopping center developer to turn back from the suburbs and take over a department store chain in a major city? **********That is what happened two weeks ago when stockholders approved the merger of Woodward & Lothrop, the Washington department store chain, into Taubman Holdings Inc., one of the country's largest developers of shopping centers. **********The deal, the first major one of its kind, has left retailers, analysts and other developers around the country pondering whether the idea is sound, whether a trend might be in the making, and if so, what the impact would be on independent retailers in various cities. **********In particular, the buyout of ''Woodies,'' as Woodward & Lothrop is familiarly called, has directed new attention to B. Altman & Company of New York, which is currently on the block. **********''The merits of a developer acquisition of a retailer depend pretty much on the particular situation,'' said Jeffrey B. Edelman, analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., New York. ''Developers have a high cash flow. But with the reduction in shopping center sites, it probably is a good idea for the developer to redeploy his cash flow into an operating division in retailing.'' **********'Some Site Priority' **********He added, however, that for the retailer, he did not see ''any great advantage in being acquired by a developer or anyone else except for the additional financing.'' In general, Mr. Edelman said, top retailers can get into most shopping centers, but if a local retailer can be acquired by a developer building in the area, ''it might give the retailer some site priority.'' **********In the case of Woodward & Lothrop, the $320 million purchase by Taubman was in part motivated by concern that the chain might be vulnerable to a takeover by a less-desired company. **********This concern originated when Ronald S. Baron, a New York broker- dealer, proposed a leveraged buyout of Woodward & Lothrop by its management. The proposal was rejected and a settlement with Mr. Baron was achieved, but Woodward & Lothrop's chairman, Edwin K. Hoffman, felt that the Baron maneuver had created a climate in which a takeover move might occur. **********Accordingly, he arranged to meet with A. Alfred Taubman, chairman of Taubman & Company, which in addition to its shopping center interests acquired control earlier this year of the leading auction house Sotheby Parke Bernet. **********Stockholders' Dissent **********A Taubman offer, though accepted in principle by Woodward & Lothrop's board, was contested by dissident stockholders, whose legal actions failed in the courts. An offer by Monroe G. Milstein, chairman of the Burlington Coat Factory Company, and related investors to buy the company also failed to make headway, although Mr. Taubman was compelled to raise his offer to $60.50 a share, from $59. **********Several issues were debated during the eight-month takeover contest. Critics of the Taubman offer said that the original price was too low, that the value of Woodward & Lothrop real estate was greater than had been estimated, that additional merger partners should be pursued and that financial benefits to be received by Woodward & Lothrop's top officers were too high. **********But none of these issues did more than delay the merger. It was resoundingly approved by Woodward & Lothrop's shareholders. **********'We Own It Now' **********''We own it now,'' Mr. Taubman said last week in a telephone interview. ''It's an investment for us as far as we are concerned and a positive opportunity.'' **********He said that the Taubman company, which manages 19 shopping centers around the country, bought Woodward & Lothrop because ''it has an excellent earnings base and excellent growth potential. We think that Washington is the No. 1 retail market in America, because it has the highest per-capita income, and is depression- free because of the high content of Government employment.'' **********Will Woodward & Lothrop, which operates 17 stores in the Washington area, with sales last year of $403.6 million and net income of $15.5 million, expand further? **********''We are not planning any major expansion, but will, as in the past, look for expansion opportunities,'' said Mr. Taubman. **********Asked how the merger would provide mutual benefits, other than through expansion, he said: ''We believe that our knowledge of real estate will help them, and their knowledge of the department store business will help us.'' **********Albert Sussman, executive vice president of the International Council of Shopping Centers, a New York- based trade association, said that it was unusual for developers to acquire retailers, although many large retailers own shopping center subsidiaries. **********A Precursor of the Deal **********The only precedent for the Woodward & Lothrop deal was a smaller transaction five years ago: the purchase by the Crown-American Corporation, Johnstown, Pa., of Hess's Inc. of Allentown, according to Mr. Sussman. **********''There's no reason why more of that sort of transaction shouldn't take place,'' Mr. Sussman said, ''because developers do have more savvy about where to go and can help the retailer they buy work out more favorable terms. Some department stores are even able to get their sites rent free, since the developer feels they will attract a good tenant mix. But no tenant, under the statutes, can dictate to a developer who should be allowed into a center.'' **********Since Hess's Inc. was acquired by Crown-American, its sales, profits and number of stores have doubled, according to Irwin Greenberg, president of Hess's. Sales last year were $254 million, pretax income was $12 million and the total number of stores was 32. **********Interest in B. Altman **********As for B. Altman, at least two shopping center developers are interested in either acquiring it or being part of a purchase group. **********One is Mr. Taubman, who said, ''We are looking at it.'' The other is Melvin Simon, chairman of Mel Simon & Associates of Indianapolis, who said that his company has made inquiries about Altman. **********But whether or not they buy Altman's, there are other department store independents around for them to bring into their sights. These include Strawbridge & Clothier, Philadelphia; D. H. Holmes, New Orleans, and Carson Pirie Scott and Wieboldt's, both of Chicago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/01/world.main_headline: 200 SRI LANKA REBELS ARE SAID TO KILL AT LEAST 42 AT PRISON FARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/01/world.print_headline: 200 SRI LANKA REBELS ARE SAID TO KILL AT LEAST 42 AT PRISON FARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/01/world.body_text: **********The Government of this island nation off India said today that at least 42 people were killed when heavily armed Tamil guerrillas attacked two prison farms in the northern region. **********Officials said the attacks occurred before dawn today at the Dollar Farm and the Kent Farm, both rehabilitation settlements where convicts live with their families before being released. **********The officials said about 200 guerrillas had scrambled from two buses, spraying submachine-gun and rifle fire and throwing grenades as they herded prisoners into buildings and then blew up the buildings. About 450 people, including guards, prisoners and their families, lived at the two settlements. **********After the attacks in Mullaitivu district, the Government declared a national alert and imposed a 10 P.M.-to- 4-A.M. curfew on the entire island as a precaution against retaliatory violence against Tamils.   Death Toll May Climb **********A senior Government official said the confirmed death toll was 42, but he added that the local police had said the number of deaths might climb as high as 80. **********(Reuters quoted official sources as saying the toll in the attacks had reached 110.) **********The senior official said most of the dead were Sinhalese, the majority ethnic group in Sri Lanka. Tamils make up about 16 percent of the population but are a majority in the north, where extremists are leading a guerrilla campaign for a separate Tamil nation. **********The United News of India, in a dispatch from Colombo that was monitored in New Delhi, said 62 people - 42 settlers and 20 Tamil militants - were killed in today's attacks. That report said army troops in helicopters and on the ground were searching for rebels in the area.   Emergency Measures in Force **********The attacks came a day after the Government of President Junius Jayewardene, asserting that India-based Tamil separatists planned to invade northern Sri Lanka by January, announced a series of broad emergency measures. These include the designation of a no man's land along sensitive areas of the coastline and a requirement for information about who resides in a home. **********India has repeatedly denied Sri Lankan accusations that it is arming, training and harboring Tamil guerrillas. **********Last week Tamil militants bombed a police station in the northern Jaffna region, killing at least 37 people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/13/busin.body_text: **********Aided by increases in its industrial, broadcasting and commercial divisions, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday reported a 32.9 percent rise in second-quarter profits. **********Westinghouse said its net income totaled $128.1 million, or 72 cents a share, for the quarter ended June 30, compared with $96.4 million, or 54 cents a share, a year earlier. **********Revenues rose 7.1 percent in the quarter, to $2.56 billion, from $2.39 billion a year earlier. **********Douglas D. Danforth, the chairman, described the sales increase as ''very encouraging, particularly in the industries group, which has suffered from the weak recovery in certain capital goods markets.'' The industries group includes Westinghouse's operations in manufacturing robotics, turbines and motors and welding equipment. **********Mr. Danforth said that new orders increased again this quarter for the corporation, with continuing strong order rates in the commercial group, which includes such companies as Thermal King, the transport refrigeration company, and Longines-Wittenauer, the watch company, and improved order rates in the industries group. **********The company's performance this quarter reflected the ''enormous amount of strength'' of its capital goods divisions, according to David F. Bartlett, an analyst with Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. **********Russell L. Leavitt, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said the company's profits ''are in line with general expectations.'' **********He said company divisions such as the utility group, which makes nuclear reactors, had been hurt by safety questions concerning their use at plants in South Jersey and elsewhere. However, he added that other divisions, such as Westinghouse's defense component, which recently won a $147.5 million engineering contract from the Air Force, had shown improvement. **********''This was the kind of mixed performance that was anticipated,'' Mr. Leavitt said. **********Intel Corporation The Intel Corporation yesterday reported that profits more than doubled in the second quarter. **********The semiconductor maker said that it earned $54.9 million, or 47 cents a share, for the three months ended June 30, compared with $24.3 million, or 22 cents a share, for the second quarter of 1983. **********Revenue for the company, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., increased 58 percent, to $410 million, from $259.5 million a year earlier. **********Gordon E. Moore, Intel's chairman and chief executive officer, noted that shipments of semiconductor products had risen over last year and that he expects to see ''continued growth in our shipment rates, even though the frantic buying has moderated somewhat.'' **********Mr. Moore added that the company intended to expand its worldwide production capacity to accommodate demand and introduce new products now under development.  Adam F. Cuhney, who follows Intel for Salomon Brothers, said Intel's earnings increase resulted from the company's long-term strategy to diversify into other areas of semiconductor manufacturing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/14/world.main_headline: NEW TACTICS ALMOST HALT EXIT OF SOVIET JEWS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/14/world.print_headline: NEW TACTICS ALMOST HALT EXIT OF SOVIET JEWS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/14/world.body_text: **********After four years of waiting, the scientist had despaired of emigration when the passport office called him in for a talk, something it had never done before. **********The scientist, identified by a friend by the initial Z., was offered a deal: withdraw the application, and the authorities would see what they could do about getting him back the job he had lost when he asked to emigrate. **********Z. said yes, and in his case the authorities kept their word. According to his friend, he now heads an office at a cultural institution. **********The friend, whose initial is K., said he received a similar offer, but turned it down. Although he has been waiting six years, he said, he still hopes for a visa. He said he had heard too many stories of people who withdrew applications only to remain without jobs. **********Jewish emigration is at its lowest point since the beginning of detente in the early 1970's, and the authorities seem to be doing what they can to discourage further applications. **********Soviet Jews are reacting in various ways. Some are turning to religious orthodoxy or are becoming more conscious than ever of their heritage, attending clandestine Hebrew language classes. Others circulate petitions. **********In the words of Aleksandr Y. Lerner, a scientist who has been waiting more than a decade: ''We have no choice but to hope. We hope for the best, but things get worse bit by bit.'' **********In addition to offering a few Jews their jobs back, authorities have moved in other ways to end what was for them the bothersome and embarrassing era of Jewish emigration. **********In the last two years they have changed the already complex process by requiring renewal of applications every six months. Each renewal requires a new invitation from abroad. **********The invitations must come through the Soviet mail, but Jews say letters are being intercepted. **********Authorities have also cracked down on the organized emigration movement that thrived in the 1970's, arresting some of its leading figures. **********When party officials in a provincial town had their talk with K., they told him: ''The days of Jewish emigration are over. The door is closed and will never open again.'' **********After 260,000 departures since 1970, peaking at 51,000 in 1979, the numbers dropped sharply, to 1,315 in 1983 and 780 so far this year. In October, 29 Jews left the Soviet Union, according to the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration in Geneva. **********Emigration for Soviet citizens in general has been restricted. Ethnic Germans and Armenians are the two other major groups for which exceptions have been made, in addition to Jews.   A Barometer of Relations **********The pattern of Jewish emigration led some analysts to conclude that it was a barometer of Soviet-American relations, which fell to a low point under the Reagan Administration. Others offer different explanations for the rise and fall in the number of visas issued. **********Soviet officials contend that those applying for exit visas receive them, with the exception of applicants who had access to state secrets and are being turned out because of the security risk. **********Now Soviet officials say that most of those who wanted to emigrate have left. But Western groups, and many Jews here, disagree. **********According to figures compiled in the West, 300,000 Jews - out of a population of 1.8 million Soviet Jews - had asked relatives to send invitations when emigration was reduced after 1979. These figures show that thousands were turned down. **********Would-be emigrants, who are usually dismissed from their jobs, try to do other work. A former computer programmer now fixes equipment in a school for the deaf. The foraer head of a department at an institute does apartment repairs. A scientist has returned from a term of internal exile and works as an elevator operator.   Differences in Approaches **********Their approaches to emigration are as varied as their employment. Some would-be emigrants now argue that the basis for Jewish emigration in the 1970's - founded on the right of family reunification as set forth in the 1975 Helsinki accords - was a mistake. The invitations were not closely scrutinized, and some left on the basis of tenuous family relationships. **********One Moscow intellectual was called in recently for a talk about his application to join his wife's brother in Israel. He said officials had told him: ''But that would not be family reunification; that would be family disunification. Your parents remain in Moscow.'' **********Two petitions signed by would-be emigrants in Leningrad and Moscow argue that Jews should have insisted on the right to live in Israel, which some say they consider their homeland, and that the philosophy of family reunification, with its abuses, was a mistake. **********As a matter of bureaucratic practice, Soviet exit visas list Israel as the country of destination. But, after an early trend toward Israel, most Jews, once abroad, now choose to go to other countries, mainly the United States.   Lerner Applied 13 Years Ago **********Mr. Lerner, a 71-year-old expert in cybernetics, the study of computers and the human nervous system, lost his job when he applied to emigrate 13 years ago. In 1973 his daughter left for Israel, but he and his wife and son became ''refuseniks,'' a term used by some for those denied permission to emigrate. In 1981 his wife died. Mr. Lerner continues to reapply. **********''I have no illusions,'' he said. ''I understand that I might have to wait many more years. But when that day comes, whoever is still alive will go.'' **********Those who wait must learn a new attitude toward life, he said. **********''It's hard to decide questions when you cannot look into the future,''' he said. ''Should you put up your cabbage or not? We have decided to put up the cabbage, and never mind if it goes to waste. We do not think about whether we can take our furniture or books or pictures. We live as if we were going to live here forever, but we are ready to drop everything in a moment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/25/busin.body_text: **********Justin S. Colin, a Wall Street investment banker, has agreed in a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to stay out of certain areas of the securities business. **********Mr. Colin, under the settlement announced yesterday, agreed not to take on responsibilities at a broker- dealer that include supervising back- office operations and the preparation of certain financial reports. **********In addition, he is barred from acquiring an equity interest in any broker-dealer for a year, and after that he must seek permission from the S.E.C. **********In August 1982, Mr. Colin, then the senior partner of the Wall Street firm of the Colin, Hochstin Company, resigned from the firm and filed for voluntary reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws. Mr. Colin's financial problems apparently stemmed from the souring of investments he made in West Cost commuter airlines. **********Ten days after the filing, the large discount brokerage firm of Quick & Reilly Inc. bought the assets of Colin, Hochstin, a small institutional brokerage and specialist firm. **********According to Mr. Colin, his bankruptcy filing triggered an investigation by the S.E.C., and the ''mild, technical violation'' it found did not warrant ''long and costly litigation.'' Mr. Colin is now working as a retail broker at Bear, Stearns & Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/29/world.body_text: **********The renewed failure on Tuesday of the Common Market countries to resolve their budget differences suggests that Western Europe is denying itself the one thing it really needs - a credible strategy for economic recovery.  Because 10 major European nations cannot agree on dividing up their community's cost, these countries are now unable to start carrying out a two-stage strategy they have devised for breaking out of the recession that has gripped their economies for the last 10 years and sent unemployment to record numbers. **********When last week's meeting also broke up in disagreement over Britain's budget rebate, most people overlooked what the 10 government heads present had actually achieved. This was a solemn political commitment to introduce real free trade between the community's member nations and to devote more of its resources to narrowing Western Europe's technological gap with the United States and Japan, instead of featherbedding its farmers. **********This declaration amounted to a promise to rectify a basic failing of the Common Market and one that economists increasingly believe is an important cause of Europe's poor recovery prospects, its technological backwardness and its high and growing levels of unemployment.   Beyond Tariffs, Other Barriers **********Although the 10 have abolished all tariffs on industrial trade, European companies still do not get the advantages their huge Common Market should provide because many other barriers stop them from selling goods, services and skills freely in all the member countries of the Common Market. **********At the Brussels meeting, the 10 government heads promised to create ''a genuine economic union'' in Europe. This means, they said, abolishing the 101 tricks member countries use to keep out imports - tricks ranging from differing safety standards to complex customs formalities and banning foreign companies from bidding for government contracts. **********It also means allowing banks and insurance companies to do business where they will; it means breaking the inflationary stranglehold that state- owned airlines and railways exert over the transport sector; it means new legal steps to help companies merge across national boundaries and it means spending more community money on industrial research and less on subsidizing farmers. **********The overal aim, the Ten declare, is to stimulate Europe's comatose economies.   Commitments on Ice **********While the Ten remain divided over budget changes, these valuable commitments to create ''a genuine economic union'' remain on ice, with individual countries lacking the political will to carry out the painful changes needed.  Meanwhile, the idea that the Ten can improve their economic prospects by creating freer trade among themselves - ''strengthening the internal market'' is the buzz phrase - has become the new orthodoxy among economists in Europe. **********This approach has its dangers and its limitations. Dangers, because instead of wasting taxpayers' money subsidizing farmers, the Ten could just as easily throw it away on uneconomic high-technology projects. **********Limits, because many economic rigidities retarding Europe's recovery can only be diminished at the national level. **********Nevertheless, the Ten's inability to free internal trade is particularly unsettling at present, many officials and economists believe, because it damages one leg of a two-part recovery strategy that is now emerging.   How to Spur Growth? **********So long as the dollar remains strong and American interest rates high, there is little else that European governments can do to stimulate growth beyond improving their internal market - and this is now in doubt. **********But if Washington does cut its budget deficit, permitting interest rates and the dollar to slide, European officials are now broadly agreed on the strategy they should follow to obtain maximum benefits. The plan, worked out at recent meetings in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, at the Common Market's Monetary Committee and among central bank governors at Basel, requires Europe to cut its own interest rates somewhat faster than the United States. **********This would simultaneously strengthen European recovery, prevent a dollar crash while edging inflation lower, and reduce budget deficits by cutting the cost of serving government debt. As a result, officials hope that the conservative governments now in power in West Germany and Britain would feel that they could take the risk of carrying out their promise to reduce taxes next year, and thus further fuel Europe's recovery. **********The combination of a clear commitment to free internal European trade with cuts in interest rates and taxes would unleash powerful recovery forces inside the Common Market, officials believe, allowing these countries to take over the role of world economic locomotive while the United States cools off its economy by reining in its budget deficit. Unfortunately, so long as the Ten remain paralyzed by their budget quarrel and unable to start improving the Common Market's internal workings, half of Europe's recovery strategy is missing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/14/world.main_headline: 2 Groups Say U.S. Violates South Africa Arms Embargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/14/world.print_headline: 2 Groups Say U.S. Violates South Africa Arms Embargo
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/14/world.body_text: **********Two groups charged today that the United States had systematically violated the mandatory United Nations embargo on the sale of military equipment to South Africa by approving licenses worth $28 million for export of parts that could be used for military purposes. **********The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, denied the allegation, asserting, ''We go out of our way to insure that we do not approve the export to South Africa of equipment readily adaptable to military uses.'' **********A report prepared by the American Friends Service Committee and the Washington Office on Africa said the United States ''is sabotaging the international arms embargo by winking at U.S. companies' exports to Africa. The volume of this trade is much greater than has been reported.'' **********At issue is the export to South Africa of items that appear on the so-called munitions control list, many of which can be used for either military or civilian purposes. The embargo was approved in 1977 with American backing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/01/world.print_headline: TURNER SWORN IN AS CANADA CHIEF; TRUDEAU ERA ENDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/01/world.body_text: **********John N. Turner was sworn in today as the 17th Prime Minister of Canada in a private ceremony that ended a 16-year-long political era dominated by Pierre Elliott Trudeau. **********Mr. Turner, until recently a corporate lawyer, pledged a more business- like Government and immediately announced the resignation of 13 Cabinet ministers who had served under Mr. Trudeau. He said at a news conference that he would meet with the full Cabinet and senior ministers individually next week to discuss Canada's serious economic problems. **********The 55-year-old Mr. Turner appeared in high spirits, joking with reporters and talking with passers-by on the street from his car window as he left for a reception. **********No Major Changes **********But he stopped short of announcing the large immediate changes that some politicans had anticipated. In particular, he ruled out appointing unelected ministers to senior jobs, a legal possibility in Canada but considered politically dangerous. **********''I would need a larger mandate from the people of Canada to move farther than I have today,'' Mr. Turner said. **********The new Prime Minister, who was selected as leader of the ruling Liberal Party earlier this month, is not himself a Member of Parliament. He declined to discuss when he might call an election. He must set a date by early March. **********Will Run From British Columbia **********In an unanticipated move, the new Prime Minister said he would run in an electoral district in British Columbia. This, he said, is a demonstration of his commitment to increasing Liberal representation in western Canada. The ruling party currently holds no seats west of Winnipeg. **********Mr. Trudeau was first elected Prime Minister in 1968 and became the longest serving Western leader at the time of his resignation. **********He became a leading spokesman for the needs of poor nations and tried to give a more independent definition to Canada internationally by urging less economic dependence on the United States. Most recently, he engaged in a crusade to end the nuclear arms race. The effort led to visits to Moscow, Washington and various capitals in East and West Europe. **********In Canada, Mr. Trudeau brought the country's Constitution back from Britain two years ago, an act that many consider Canada's true declaration of independence. He also fought to improve the situation of French speakers in Canada, achieved the personal dream of passing a Charter of Rights and Freedoms similar to the United States Bill of Rights, and successfully battled Quebec separatism. **********His sometimes idiosyncratic sense of style was apparent in final comments to reporters Friday. **********''I'll try to remain silent for most of the rest of this year,'' he said. ''It depends on how provoked I get.'' **********Mr. Turner referred to his newly- named aides as ''a phase one Cabinet'' that would be altered after an election. ''Everyone in the present Cabinet will have to fight to keep his job,'' he said. **********Until 1975 Mr. Turner served as a senior minister in Mr. Trudeau's Government, and left after a dispute with the Prime Minister. Although Mr. Turner publicly praised his predecessor during his campaign for the party leadership as ''the most outstanding Canadian of his generation,'' he took the opportunity today to separate himself from Mr. Trudeau in several ways.   Give Cabinet More Powers **********He said, for example, that he would meet with reporters more often. He has also given Cabinet members more power, while cutting the size of the Cabinet from 37 to 29. **********He also made a quip about his long absence from politics, and perhaps the dispute between him and Mr. Trudeau. When asked how he felt while being sworn in, he said, ''I suppose I didn't reject from my mind certain ironies of the situation.'' **********Mr. Turner's decision not to look outside the Government for top aides at this time meant that he retained a number of Mr. Trudeau's ministers. Marc Lalonde, for instance, will continue as Finance Minister. **********Jean Chretien, the Energy Minister who was Mr. Turner's strongest challenger for the Liberal Party leadership, was named Deputy Prime Minister, Secretary of State of External Affairs and senior minister for Quebec. For more than a week, Mr. Turner had been negotiating with the popular Quebecer to secure his support in a new administration.   Praises Opponent **********Mr. Turner praised Mr. Chretien at the news conference today, calling him ''my most important collaborator.'' **********Politically, the new leader's most urgent political task is to determine an election date. Some politicians suggested that the decision not to name unelected ministers indicates a later election, perhaps in November. **********A four- or fivemonth delay before a vote also might give Mr. Turner an opportunity to establish a national image as a Prime Minister, the politicians suggested. **********Arguing in favor of an earlier vote, however, are said to be two polls recently completed for the Liberal Party. Both supposedly show the Liberals leading by 4 to 6 percentage points nationally, a dramatic increase from the more than 20 percentage points by which they trailed just six months ago. **********Additionally, the Liberals tend to do better when turnouts are lighter, and a summer election, perhaps in August, might accomplish this purpose.   Visits by Queen and Pope **********A key consideration are planned visits by Queen Elizabeth II in July and by Pope John Paul II in August. Canadians are worried an election might disrupt the long anticipated visits, and a principal consideration in the timing of an election is making sure this does not happen. **********Only five Members of Parliament were promoted to Cabinet rank. The others are familiar faces, with precedence clearly given to those who supported Mr. Turner. **********For instance, Lloyd Axworthy, Mr. Turner's campaign manager, was made Liberal political chief for the entire West in addition to retaining his post as Transport Minister. Industry Minister Ed Lumley, Labor Minister Andre Oullet and Consumer Minister Judy Erola were all given expanded powers. **********Gerald Regan, who managed Mr. Turner's campaign in the Maritime Provinces, was elevated from trade to energy, a key concern in his native Nova Scotia, which is basing its economic hopes on offshore drilling for natural gas. **********Mr. Turner defended the exclusion of reporters and television from his swearing-in ceremony, despite the fact journalists and cameramen were permitted both when Joe Clark was sworn in as Prime Minister in 1979 for a nine- month period and when Mr. Trudeau returned to office the following year. Mr. Turner said the ceremony would have appeared on television too early in the morning on the Canadian West Coast for all regions to have equal access. **********Whenever an election is called, the Liberals will be up against the Progressive Conservative Party led for the past year by Brian Mulroney, a former businessman. Just as the Liberals are trying to gain in the West, the Tories are concentrating on picking up seats in Quebec, where they presently hold only one of 75 seats. **********The promise of Mr. Turner to run in British Columbia thus represents a challenge to Mr. Mulroney to run in his native Quebec. So far, the Tory leader, who was elected to Parliament in a by- election to a safe seat in Nova Scotia, has been reluctant to say where he plans to run. **********Mr. Trudeau has said he plans to move to a home he has purchased in Montreal and ponder his future. His immediate plans are to be ''a loafer,'' he told reporters Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/26/busin.body_text: **********More than 100,000 people in the United States and Britain who bought discount tickets from major carriers to fly across the Atlantic this winter will have to pay higher fares, the British Government said today. **********The major carriers sold tickets for flights starting Nov. 1 pending British Government approval of reduced winter fares. But last week Britain rejected all applications for cheap tickets. The United States has approved the fares, but approval of both Governments is necessary. **********After last week's announcement, a number of major airlines said passengers who bought tickets at the discount prices would not have to pay the difference. But Aviation Minister Paul Spicer said today that some cheap tickets had continued to be sold, mainly in the United States. He said that all passengers holding tickets marked ''subject to Government approval'' would either have to pay the difference or get a refund. **********''We will be checking at airports to make sure that airlines do not continue to sell tickets at fares which have not been approved,'' he said. **********After the announcement, Trans World Airlines said it would stop selling tickets at the disputed fare, but would continue to sell tickets at less than full fare. **********The fares of the two trans-Atlantic discount airlines, Virgin Atlantic and People Express, are not affected. **********The Department of Transport said it had rejected the applications for cheap tickets because Britain failed to get a guarantee from the United States against possible future antitrust prosecutions of British airlines for setting lower fares. The British Government apparently feared that Virgin Atlantic, Britain's fledgling low-cost airline, might take action in United States courts to block discount fares for the major carriers. **********In Washington, Alan M. Pollock, spokesman for the Civil Aeronautics Board, said the agency was ''very disappointed that the British are not allowing consumers to take advantage of the low fares.'' **********The discount fare proposed by British Airways and matched by Pan American World Airways and T.W.A. was $:259, or $315.98 round trip. That is $:1, or $1.22, more expensive than Virgin's Government-approved, regular round-trip fare of $:258, or $314.76. **********People Express airlines, based in the United States, has an approved fare of $159 each way. **********When the big British and American airlines announced their proposed discount fares, Richard Branson, Virgin Atlantic's chairman, accused them of using the same ''predatory'' practice of dropping fares in slack months that they used to drive Laker Airways into bankruptcy. **********The liquidator of Laker, which pioneered cheap trans-Atlantic travel, is suing British Airways, British Caledonian and eight other European and American airlines in a billion-dollar antitrust suit in the United States. The civil suit charges that the 10 airlines conspired to drive Laker out of business. **********The United States Justice Department is also conducting a criminal antitrust investigation into whether collusion was involved when the trans-Atlantic competitors lowered fares in 1982 to compete with Laker.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/04/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Walesa Says Solidarity 'Is Indestructible'
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/04/world.body_text: **********The founder of Solidarity, Lech Walesa, celebrated the feast of his namesake, St. Lech, by attending a special mass in Gdansk today, and told 10,000 supporters that the outlawed union was indestructible. **********''Solidarity exists and the union is indestructible,'' Mr. Walesa said from the terrace of the rectory at St. Brigid's Church. **********Mr. Walesa, who won the 1983 Nobel Peace Prize, also said the thousands of people who attended the mass proved that Solidarity, banned by the Polish Government after the declaration of martial law in 1981, is still alive. **********Mr. Walesa said Solidarity, although banned, was fighting for the rights of the workers in a peaceful way. **********''We do not have a possibility now to be organized in a strong movement,'' Mr. Walesa said, alluding to the tough post-martial law regulations, which do not permit workers to hold rallies or have their own independent union. **********''But a time will come when we choose a moment, and the outcome of it will be the kind you are dreaming about,'' he said. **********A prominent pro-Solidarity priest, Henryk Jankowski, said a mass at the church for the union leader. **********Father Jankowski urged Polish authorities, who declared in December 1982 that martial law had ended, to ease the stringent post-martial law regulations and promised that the ''totalitarian system of enslaving the people'' would collapse.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/12/world.main_headline: Argentine Protesters Force Out U.S. Warship
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/12/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Argentine Protesters Force Out U.S. Warship
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/12/world.body_text: **********About 2,000 protesters, angry over United States support for Britain in the Falkland war, forced an American warship to withdraw Monday night from a southern Argentine port where it planned to take on supplies, Argentine news agencies reported today. **********The incident took place in Puerto Madryn, 800 miles south of Buenos Aires, the agencies reported. **********United States Embassy officials said they had few details, but confirmed that the ship withdrew because of the protest. **********The news agency Diarios y Noticias said about 2,000 demonstrators gathered at the Puerto Madryn dock shouting ''Yankee go home!'' and ''Killers!'' Some protesters blocked the path of trucks carrying provisions to the ship, the destroyer Thorn. **********It was one of five United States Navy vessels participating with South American navies in maneuvers called Unitas 25.

That post is **********now held by James J. Hartigan, who is 60.  Mr. Zeeman had been the airline's senior vice president for **********marketing. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/24/world.main_headline: BONN CABINET SAID TO OPPOSE SEA TREATY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/24/world.print_headline: BONN CABINET SAID TO OPPOSE SEA TREATY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/24/world.body_text: **********A majority of the West German Cabinet is now opposed to signing an international convention on controlling the use of the sea and its resources, a senior aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl said this week. **********The United States has already announced it will not sign the accord, known as the International Law of the Sea Convention, and Bonn Government officials disclosed last month that President Reagan, in a letter to Mr. Kohl, had strongly urged West Germany to refrain as well because of provisions governing seabed mining. **********Five Common Market countries - France, Denmark, Greece, Ireland and the Netherlands - have signed the convention; three others - Belgium, Italy and Luxembourg - are understood to be awaiting a West German decision before committing themselves. **********The official, who spoke Tuesday, said Mr. Kohl, under a compromise formula, had mustered a clear majority for a decision not to sign the treaty but not to oppose its signing by the European Economic Community as an international organization. **********The official said the British Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was expected to take a similar position when Common Market foreign ministers meet to discuss the treaty early next week. **********The European Community may sign the treaty as a group, provided a majority of its 10 members and its executive body, the Council of Ministers, approve.   Leaders in Technology **********West German companies are leaders in the technology of seabed mining. In 1972 three major metal trading companies - Preussag, Metallgesellschaft A.G. and Salzgitter A.G. - pooled their resources to study the feasibility of mineral recovery from the ocean floor. **********Although a lack of demand for primary metals and low world prices have caused most plans to be put off, West Germany retains a lively interest in efforts to regulate future exploitation of ocean resources. **********Bonn has come under strong pressure from the French to sign the accord, and the issue has badly split Mr. Kohl's Government, pitting Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, a proponent of signing, against opponents in his own business-oriented Free Democratic Party and the Chancellor's Christian Democratic Union. **********Mr. Genscher contends that by ignoring a Dec. 9 deadline to sign, West Germany would alienate third world governments that favor the treaty, forfeit an opportunity to shape the final text of the accord and jeopardize plans to locate an international law of the sea tribunal, to arbitrate disputes, in the north German port city of Hamburg.   Genscher Proposes Changes **********Mr. Genscher proposes that Bonn sign the treaty, but, like Japan and France, refuse to ratify it without substantial changes. Ratification by at least 60 countries is necessary for the treaty to take effect. **********Opposition among Mr. Genscher's Free Democrats has been led by former Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff, who has echoed the concern of West German business, which objects, as does the Reagan Administration, to provisions setting up an international authority to regulate mining of seabed resources. **********Among other things, the convention provides for strict control of seabed mining and transfers of mining technology from highly industrialized to developing countries. **********The convention was framed in nine years of negotiations that were concluded in December 1982 in Montego Bay, Jamaica. **********One hundred thirty-eight United Nations member countries, including many developing countries, the Soviet bloc nations and major industrialized countries such as Japan and Canada, have signed the convention. Most notable among the nations that have not are the United States and Britain. **********Aides of Mr. Genscher said Tuesday that he would continue to press for Bonn to sign the treaty in a Cabinet discussion next Tuesday, when the Government's final decision is expected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/16/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices finished with minor changes yesterday in heavier trading after dropping sharply in recent sessions because of rising interest rates. **********The Dow Jones industrial average closed off 0.21 point, to 1,150.86. The number of stocks that gained on the New York Stock Exchange was identical to the number that declined: 777. **********Analysts said the market was able to contain its losses yesterday because of the modest decline in yields in the credit markets, which had been moving higher for some time. **********The two other leading market indicators posted small gains. The exchange's composite index rose 0.24, to 90.90, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks advanced 0.50, to 158.00. **********Turnover on the Big Board expanded to 88.3 million shares, from 64.9 million shares on Monday, as institutional interest increased. **********There was little in the economic news yesterday to affect prices except the Government report that industrial production rose 1.4 percent in April, the biggest rise since January, when it was up 1.5 percent. Robert H. Stovall, director of investment policy of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said that this strong showing further supported those who believed ''that rising interest rates will continue to place a cap on equities.'' **********Many analysts have blamed the strong economy and large Federal budget deficits for the rise in interest rates since mid-January and the resultant decline in equity prices. **********Mesa Royalty Trust climbed 7 points, to 34 1/2, after Mesa Petroleum said it would offer $35 per unit for all of the 16.3 million units outstanding in Mesa Royalty. Mesa Petroleum closed up 1/4, to 18 1/8. **********Ames Department Stores, which reported much higher first-quarter profits, climbed 1 1/2 points, to 42 1/4. In the same category, R. H. Macy, added 1/2, to 44 7/8, following a report of increased earnings. **********International Business Machines, which introduced a series of personal computer software products, advanced 3/4, to 113, in active trading. **********Southwest Forest Industries lost 2 5/8, to 15 7/8. The company said it had ended its agreement for the acquisition of all its stock by a group organized by Morgan Stanley & Company and members of Southwest Forest's management at $24 a share. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index eased 0.67, to 207.51. After-Six Inc. gained 1 1/4, to 13 1/2, on the news that its officers are discussing a plan to take the company private through a leveraged buyout valued at $15 a share. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index rose 0.13, to 249.00.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/05/busin.body_text: **********In a major rescue operation, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation tonight arranged the takeovers for four failed banks, two in Wyoming, one in Minnesota and one in Texas. The F.D.I.C. is a Government agency that insures individual deposit accounts for up to $100,000 at most of the nation's banks. **********The closures brought the number of banks that have failed this year to 25. The agency closed 48 banks last year. **********In 1983, the agency paid out a record $2.6 billion reimbursing depositors and assisting troubled banks, bringing its payouts for the past three years to $5.3 billion - more than it paid out in the previous 47 years. Current figures for 1984 are not available. **********Loan Losses Cited **********The F.D.I.C. said the First National Bank of Snyder, Tex., was closed by the United States Comptroller of the Currency because of a lack of funds to meet depositors' demands and because of loan losses. It was the fourth Texas bank to fail in the past year. **********The official said the failed bank's $15.2 million in insured deposits were being transferred to the newly chartered American State Bank of Snyder, which will open Monday.  American State Bank is a subsidiary of the American State Financial Corporation in Lubbock, Tex. **********The parent corporation paid the agency a $962,000 premium to obtain the failed bank's deposits and the agency advanced the new bank $15.2 million in cash. **********The F.D.I.C. said it would make an immediate payment to all general creditors of 40 percent of their claims against the failed bank. **********In Minnesota, the agency arranged for the deposit liabilities of the First National Bank of Rushfort to be shifted to the Goodhue County National Bank of Red Wing. The failed bank's single office will reopen Monday as a branch of Goodhue. The United States Comptroller's office cited ''substantial deterioration'' in First National's loan portfolio over the past year. **********Goodhue County National agreed to assume about $20 million in 5,200 deposit accounts and other liabilities of the failed bank, paying the F.D.I.C. a $1.05 million premium to acquire the accounts. The agency advanced $15.7 million to Goodhue. **********Wyoming Banks Closed **********The F.D.I.C. said the Western National Bank of Casper, Wyo., with assets of about $22 million, had been taken over by the Wyoming National Bank of West Casper, a new subsidiary of the Affiliated Bank Corporations. The State Bank of Mills, with assets of about $6 million, was absorbed into the Mountain Plaza National Bank in Casper. **********A bank board official who asked not to be identified said the two failed banks were affiliated through common ownership. **********In closing Western National, H. Joe Selby, Acting Comptroller of the Currency, cited ''substantial deterioration in the quality of its loan portfolio'' in the past year. **********Wyoming National has agreed to assume about $22 million in 5,400 deposit accounts and other liabilities, and to pay the agency a premium of $750,000. The F.D.I.C. will provide a cash advance of $11.4 million and will retain assets of about $14.3 million. **********The State Bank of Mills was closed by Dwight D. Bonhan, the Wyoming state examiner. Mountain Plaza will assume about $6 million in 2,000 deposit accounts and other liabilities, and will pay the F.D.I.C. $102,000. The agency will provide a cash advance of $2.6 million, and will retain assets of about $4 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/09/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Some Analysts See Stock Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/09/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Some Analysts See Stock Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/09/busin.body_text: **********T HE stock market has been a hostage of interest rate fears for the last several weeks, and **********it looks as if the market will remain that way at least a few more weeks. Nevertheless, several analysts foresee a short rally over the next few weeks, and they predict that there will be a prolonged rally if several uncertainties nagging at traders are resolved. **********''The market was being ripped up like a tornado for four months, but now there is a light at the end of the funnel,'' said Charles M. Lewis, vice president of Shearson/American Express. **********Mr. Lewis predicted that the Dow Jones industrial average - which closed at 1,132.22 on Friday, down 32.67 for the week, despite a gain of 1.67 points on Friday - will climb 50 points in a short- term rally over the next two weeks. He said the market hit a psychological barrier just below 1,120 at midday Friday and began a rebound that he says will continue to 1,180. **********After that, Mr. Lewis sees the market stalling for a while, but he predicts that once a Federal budget deficit package is worked out, the market will pick up strength. He said interest rates have reached their peak because many consumers will refuse to borrow at current rates. In addition, he said the Federal Reserve Board's long-anticipated decision to raise the discount rate to 9 percent effective today has reduced investor uncertainty. All this caused Mr. Lewis to say, ''I think you've seen the lows for the year in the market.'' **********Although he was less sanguine about the short term, Newton D. Zinder, chief technical analyst at E. F. Hutton & Company, predicted the market would advance in the second half of the year. He said for most of the spring the market will be in a ''rally-decline phase,'' swinging between 1,070 and 1,200.  According to Mr. Zinder, the weakness in sensitive retail, automobile and transportation stocks indicates a belief that economic growth is slowing considerably. In his view, this factor, together with an outlook for low inflation and the receding of some interest rates, will propel the market higher. **********''The leadership on the next big leg up will be the big capitalization companies, rather than the more speculative stocks,'' Mr. Zinder said. **********Like Mr. Lewis, Martin D. Sass, president of M. D. Sass Investors Services, sees a short rally in the next few weeks. He said expectations of slower economic growth will spark a rally that will lift the market to 1,200. **********But Mr. Sass, whose company manages $1.4 billion in investments, said the rally will be ''short- lived'' if interest rates do not decline, economic growth does not slow and there is no major action on budget deficits. In that case, he said, the market could drop to 1,000. **********At heart he is a little more optimistic, however. ''There's a marginally better than even chance that the economy will slow down sufficiently to cause a reversal in rates beginning this summer,'' he said. ''Every one percentage point decline in interest rates will improve the level of the stock market by 10 percent.'' **********New Shine on Copper **********First, the western world's bloated copper stockpiles started shrinking, then copper prices finally began to rise, and now analysts are touting copper stocks. In recent weeks, the producer price of copper has jumped to 75 cents a pound, from 65 cents, and analysts predict that it may reach 90 cents by yearend. **********''All three of the major copper producers are going to outperform the market,'' predicted Peter Ingersoll Jr., an analyst with Salomon Brothers, referring to the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the Newmont Mining Corporation and Asarco. **********After a severely depressed year, copper mines are expected to turn profitable in the second or third quarter largely because demand is finally in line with world supply. Despite the optimistic outlook for the industry, analysts differ about which copper stocks are worth buying. **********William G. Siedenburg, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, is recommending only Phelps Dodge, the purest copper play. He is more enthusiastic about Phelps Dodge than the others because it is concentrated in rapidly improving copper while Newmont and Asarco are diversified into areas that Mr. Siedenburg does not expect to surge as much. In addition, analysts say Phelps has slashed its costs the most, an effort that helped lead to a painful, nine-month strike in Arizona. **********Peter L. Anker, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation, is recommending all three copper stocks. ''We think Asarco and Phelps Dodge are somewhat cheaper than Newmont,'' he said, although he acknowledged that Newmont is the only one expected to be profitable in the first quarter. That factor, analysts said, has already been discounted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/18/busin.body_text: **********Talks between labor and industry leaders in West Germany's important metalworking industries failed today to resolve a dispute over shorter working hours. Union officials said a rank-and-file ballot on whether to call a general strike could take place early next month. **********Hans Mayer, head of I.G. Metall, the 2.6-million-member metalworkers' union, said employers had rejected union demands for a phased reduction of the workweek to 35 hours from 40 hours. I.G. Metall includes workers in the steel, automobile and machine-building industries. **********The unions, for their part, rejected management proposals for a 3.3 percent wage rise, early retirement for workers over 58, and flexible working hours in some industries. The flexible hours would permit Saturday work but would also increase workers' time off. Linked to these proposals, the employers demanded a continuation of the 40-hour workweek through 1988. **********The union has described the reduced workweek as its prime demand in the contract talks. Union leaders maintain that such a move is needed to bring down German joblessness, now 9.6 percent of the labor force, by spreading jobs among more workers.  Government and business leaders have warned that shorter hours would impair the international competitiveness of German industry by further increasing wage costs. **********The wage commission of I.G. Metall will meet Wednesday to discuss the talks' failure. According to the union's bylaws, 75 percent of the rank and file would have to vote favorably for a strike to take place. **********German labor relations are usually placid. But in the winter of 1978-79, steelworkers walked out at 19 mills in an unsuccessful bid for the 35-hour week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/06/world.main_headline: RUSSINA, AT U.N., BARS TALKS BEFORE REMOVAL OF PERSHINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/06/world.print_headline: RUSSINA, AT U.N., BARS TALKS BEFORE REMOVAL OF PERSHINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/06/world.body_text: **********A Soviet official reiterated today that until the West removed its new nuclear missiles from Europe, there would be no arms limitation negotiations with the United States. **********The official, Vladimir Petrovsky, head of the international affairs department of the Soviet Foreign Ministry, said at the end of the first two weeks of the General Assembly debate that removal of the Pershing missiles was the ''only obstacle'' to such talks. **********Speaking at a news conference, Mr. Petrovsky promised a rich harvest of negotiations, once the weapons were withdrawn, on the limitation of nuclear and strategic arms, on chemical weapons and on banning the use of nuclear weapons in outer space. **********President Reagan, in addressing the United Nations last week, proposed a new Soviet-American framework to chart the course of arms control talks. But the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, said in his speech a few days later that he wanted to see deeds, not words.   Suggests Space Organization **********Mr. Petrovsky said he would ask the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to solicit the views of member nations on a proposed ''world organization for the use of outer space.'' Asked for details, he said it was not a ''ready-made'' project but one that would be formulated once the views of United Nations members were known. **********Earlier, the East German Foreign Minister had offered a series of ''norms'' that he said should govern relations between the nuclear powers. Foreign Minister Oskar Fischer said his schedule would begin with a treaty obligation by all nuclear states ''not to be the first to use nuclear weapons.'' **********Second, he said, there would be a ban on nuclear-weapons testing, thus inhibiting the development of new devices. That would be followed by ''an end to the qualitative arms race in the nuclear field,'' with a special prohibition on the neutron bomb. **********That, in turn, could be followed by agreement on a program for nuclear disarmament and, finally, a treaty on the mutual renunciation of the use of military force. Mr. Fischer advocated establishing zones free of nuclear weapons and said East Germany would offer its entire territory for such a purpose if West Germany did the same. **********The Angolan Foreign Minister, Paulo Teixeira Jorge, denounced the ''unbridled arms race'' and ''those who hinder the efforts of the socialist countries'' to achieve disarmament. He also reaffirmed his Government's agreement with Havana for the gradual withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola, based on the withdrawal of South African troops, the accession of Namibia to independence and the end of all aid to ''counterrevolutionary'' groups in Angola by South Africa, the United States or their allies. **********The Prime Minister of Suriname, Wim A. Udenhout, said, ''The nightmare of the longest and deepest recession of the last 50 years continues unabated.'' He said international economic relations were still based on inequality and the domination of developing countries by industrialized nations. He said reform was an ''absolute necessity.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/12/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Palestinian Acquitted Of Killing P.L.O. Aide
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/12/world.body_text: **********An avowed Palestinian revolutionary was acquitted today of murdering a leading official of the Palestine Liberation Organization here last year. **********The defendant, Mohammed Hussein Rashid, 23 years old, of Jerusalem, was sentenced to three years in prison for using a false passport found on him when he was arrested. On the murder charge, however, he admitted being part of the execution squad sent by a radical P.L.O. splinter group but said he did not do the shooting. **********Mr. Rashid was arrested in a Lisbon hotel April 10, hours after Issam Sartawi, European coordinator for the P.L.O., was shot to death in a crowded hotel lobby while attending a Socialist International meeting in this southern Portuguese resort.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/10/busin.main_headline: Successor to Chairman At First National State
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Successor to Chairman At First National State
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Robert R. Ferguson Jr., president and chief executive officer of the First National State Bancorporation of Newark, has been elected chairman of the board. **********Mr. Ferguson, 60, will continue as president and chief executive officer. **********He succeeds W. Paul Stillman, 86. Mr. Stillman has served as chairman since the bank holding company, the largest in New Jersey, was formed in 1969. First National said yesterday that Mr. Stillman will continue to serve as chairman of the board's executive committee. **********Mr. Ferguson has been president of the company since its creation in 1969 and was named chief executive officer in 1973. **********At the time the holding company was formed it had $883 million in assets, a far cry from the $10.2 billion asset base that First National reported as of June 30, 1984. **********First National is a banking organization comprised of six affiliate banks and the parent company with offices in all 21 counties in New Jersey. **********In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Ferguson said that as a result of First National's growth, the company was well positioned to take advantage of a change in the state's banking laws, a move which he said could come sometime next year.  ''Interstate banking in New Jersey is still a gleam in the eye,'' he said, ''but we have tried to get to a size that would allow us every option we could think of,'' he said, ''including the option to expand by ourselves, to joint venture with someone of similar size in another state, selling the bank, or just sitting here in the state of New Jersey and being totally competitive.'' **********Mr. Ferguson predicted that in the wake of the Federal rescue of the Continental Illinois National Bank, ''Congress will decide that deregulation in terms of product is going to be slowed down. That is a mistake,'' he added, ''but it won't have any meaningful effect on the development of interstate banking.'' **********A graduate of Lehigh University, Mr. Ferguson is chairman of the Governor's Management Improvement Program Inc., a private sector organization established by New Jersey Governor Kean in 1982 to analyze the state government's operations, to recommend ways of eliminating management inefficiencies and to formulate ways of dealing with New Jersey's long-range problems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/06/world.body_text: **********South African Denies Comments on Guerrillas **********HARARE, Zimbabwe, April 5 (AP) - The leader of the African National Congress said today that he had not told Zimbabwe's semiofficial press agency that rebel activity in South Africa would increase significantly within three months. **********The rebel leader, Oliver Tambo, was quoted by the Zimbabwe Inter-African News Agency on Wednesday as saying the guerrilla struggle in South Africa would soon reach its ''highest peak'' because of the nonaggression pact between Mozambique and South Africa. **********The press agency today quoted Mr. Tambo as denying that he made the statement. He also was reported to have denied other statements the press agency quoted Wednesday, including saying that African National Congress guerrillas were deployed for a ''final onslaught'' and that South Africa should brace for a ''bloody war.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/03/busin.body_text: **********Dollar Off as Yen Soars; Prices of Gold Increase **********By The Associated Press **********The Japanese yen snapped out of the doldrums yesterday, soaring 2.5 percent against the dollar to its highest level in more than a year. **********The dollar's drop of nearly six yen in one day also sent the United States currency falling to its lowest levels since October against the currencies of West Germany, Switzerland, France, Italy and the Netherlands. But the dollar was mixed against the British pound. **********Gold prices rose. In late trading at the Republic National Bank in New York bullion was bid at $401 an ounce, up from $394.75 late Thursday. **********Should the yen keep rising, it would enhance the prospects for many American businesses that compete with Japanese products, analysts said. **********Slight Decline in Tokyo **********In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell only slightly, slipping to 233.26 yen from 233.55 on Thursday, which was also the rate last Friday. **********But in late trading in London, the dollar tumbled to 229.15 yen, and by the day's end in the United States, it had plunged to 227.725 yen from 233.325 late Thursday, reaching levels last seen in January 1983. **********David Arbesman, director of international currency markets at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York, said that the yen's rally was sparked by huge transactions by leading Japanese banks in Tokyo, London and New York. He added that, as the dollar slipped below 232 yen, traders who follow price charts ''sent the yen flying in a relatively thin Friday market.'' **********The dollar closed the week at 2.5815 West German marks, its lowest level since Oct. 7, when it was trading at 2.5665 marks. It was also a drop from 2.6085 marks late Thursday and 2.6310 marks at the end of last week. **********Late European Rates **********Other late European dollar rates, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 2.1480 Swiss francs, down from 2.1720; 7.9525 French francs, down from 8.0300; 2.9090 Dutch guilders, down from 2.9440; 1,605.95 Italian lire, down from 1,624.15, and 1.24975 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2509. **********Dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 2.588 West German marks, down from 2.59125; 2.1595 Swiss francs, down from 2.1665; 7.990 French francs, down from 7.9925, and 1.25105 Canadian dollars, down from 1.25115. **********The British pound was mixed, however, gaining ground against the dollar in London but falling in New York. Sterling rose to $1.4835 in London from $1.4775 Thursday and $1.4720 a week ago. But later, in New York, sterling fell to $1.48375 from $1.48525 late Thursday. **********Gold rose $3.22 in Hong Kong to close at $399.16 an ounce. Later, in Zurich, Europe's largest bullion mart, gold briefly topped $400, but ended the trading day at $399.50 an ounce. That was still up from Thursday's late bid of $392.75 an ounce. In London, gold gained $6 to close at $399 an ounce. **********On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery climbed $6 to end the week at $400.80 a troy ounce, up from $396 an ounce at the end of last week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/09/busin.body_text: **********The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation, which lost $52.9 million in the last fiscal year, announced yesterday that Ralph H. O'Brien had resigned as chairman, chief executive and president. **********Officials of the electronic data-processing company, which is based in Parsippany, N. J., said that Francis P. Lucier, a Mohawk director and former chairman of the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, would serve as chairman until a new chief executive was selected. **********Mr. O'Brien, who headed the company for nearly a decade, will remain as a Mohawk director and chairman of its executive committee, according to John C. Walters, the company's senior vice president and chief legal officer. Mr. O'Brien was unavailable for comment, according to Mr. Walters. **********The financially troubled company also said that it was negotiating an increase in its lines of credit with a 10- member bank syndicate led by the First National Bank of Boston, and that it had recently instituted several cost-cutting measures, including laying off an unspecified number of employees. News of the resignation drove the company's stock down 87.5 cents, to $13 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Mr. O'Brien's resignation came shortly after Asher B. Edelman, a New York investor, began to play a more active role in the company. In August, Mr. Edelman's investor group began increasing its Mohawk holdings and now owns 9.2 percent, Mr. Walters said. Mr. Edelman will also be nominated for election to Mohawk's board at the company's annual meeting Oct. 20. **********Telephone calls to Mr. Edelman's New York office were not returned. However, Mr. Walters said Mr. Edelman's increased Mohawk role and Mr. O'Brien's resignation were ''absolutely unrelated,'' and that Mr. Edelman ''did not even suggest such a move.'' **********Rather, Mr. Walters said, Mr. O'Brien's resignation was ''an indirect result'' of the company's substantial loss for its fiscal year that ended April 30. ''Obviously, when you have a result like that, it causes the board to undertake a reassessment,'' Mr. Walters said. **********Analysts, however, said yesterday that they believed Mr. Edelman's increased position in Mohawk and Mr. O'Brien's departure were linked. **********''Edelman pushed O'Brien out,'' said Phil Cavalier of Pershing & Company. ''The course was clear when Edelman increased his stake.'' **********After strong showings in the fiscal years 1980 and 1981, when earnings per share reached $1.53, Mohawk's fortunes have worsened. In the fiscal year 1983, the company earned 79 cents a share, and its performance has declined further since then. **********''Mohawk was buoyed by the activity in the minicomputer market five years ago,'' Mr. Cavalier said. ''But it hasn't kept pace. Their management never showed the foresight to match the dramatic changes occurring in the marketplace.''
