https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/12/world.main_headline: NATO LEADER'S LANGUID AIR MASKS IRON RESOLVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/12/world.print_headline: NATO LEADER'S LANGUID AIR MASKS IRON RESOLVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/12/world.body_text: **********Lord Carrington, the former British Foreign Secretary, who will take over as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization this year, uses understatement, humor and languor to mask an underlying seriousness, commitment and determination. **********One of his favorite remarks is that things are never as bad as people say they are. It sprang to his lips again in an interview last week. But he left little doubt that he believes things are bad enough both within NATO and between NATO and its adversary, the Warsaw Pact, to give him plenty of work when he starts his new job in Brussels in July. **********''This is a fairly important moment in the history of the alliance,'' he said at the unprepossessing office he has occupied for the last year as chairman of the British General Electric Company. ''There are misunderstandings between the United States and Europe and within Europe. There is a climate of opinion on both sides of the Atlantic that must be persuaded all over again that NATO makes sense.'' **********Perhaps even more important, he added, ''there is a mutual distrust between East and West that has caused relations to deteriorate alarmingly, and NATO has to try urgently to remedy that situation.''  Few Public Statements **********Lord Carrington will bring to the NATO offices near the Brussels airport a rare gift for getting along with reporters, and he can be expected to cut a much more public figure than his predecessor, Joseph M. A. H. Luns. But he doesn't talk about that. He puts himself down (''Can you possibly make anything out of all of this prattle?''). And he complains, with the special glee of the millionaire, about the high price of tickets for the 40-minute flight from Brussels to London, which he expects to be making most weekends. **********Heavy-rimmed glasses give him an owlish aspect, and he has that upper- class knack of looking as if he springs from bed each morning perfectly dressed. His eyes sparkle as he passes along - strictly off the record, of course - bits of tasty if never quite malicious gossip about former Cabinet colleagues and prominent members of the opposition Labor Party. **********''I'm glad to be getting back to public life,'' he said, lounging in an armchair, his legs crossed. ''Been a public servant all my life, when the electors had the good sense to elect a Tory Government.'' **********Since his resignation as Foreign Secretary after the Argentine invasion of the Falkland Islands in April 1982, Lord Carrington has made few public statements, but he has continued to meet frequently with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, whose country residence is near his. Yet in his most significant speech, delivered in April of last year, he implicitly criticized not only the Prime Minister but also President Reagan, her ideological ally on major East-West questions.   Against 'Nuclear Accountancy' ''The notion that we should face the Russians down in a silent war of nerves, broken only by bursts of megaphone diplomacy, is based on a misconception of our own values, of Soviet behavior and of the anxieties of our own people,'' he said at that time. **********In an allusion to arguments about the proper way of counting warheads, a key issue in arms-limitation talks, he denounced what he called ''nuclear accountancy.'' And he said it seemed to him ''extraordinary, and against the dictates of common sense and of the evidence of our own eyes, for anyone to claim that the West, in military terms, is in any danger of sinking to its knees.'' **********Despite those comments, the 64-year- old aristocrat had the support of both the British and American Governments for the NATO job, according to diplomatic sources. Lord Carrington's resignation on a matter of principle - his old-fashioned conviction that he must pay personally for the ''humiliation'' of the Argentine seizure of the Falklands - won him many new admirers here and abroad. He has been described in a number of recent newspaper and magazine articles as one of Britain's two best postwar Foreign Secretaries, along with the late Ernest Bevin.   Dislikes Bellicose Statements **********He said last week he was ''not going to begin by criticizing the policies of member-states of NATO.'' But he made it clear he still disliked bellicose statements by leaders in either the East or the West, and he promised he would work as hard on disarmament as he would on any subject. **********The most important development in recent weeks, Lord Carrington said, was the prospect of serious East-West conversations in Stockholm about renewing arms talks. The Stockholm conference opens next week. **********He said he hoped to be able, as a man who knew both Europe and the United States fairly well, to interpret one to the other. He argued that ''any identity of attitude is impossible,'' because of differing history, geography and economic interest, but that ''an identity of purpose can be rebuilt if both will stop to think.'' **********Such incidents as the squabbles between the United States and Europe over Grenada, the Soviet-European pipeline and Lebanon were really only transient irritants, Lord Carrington asserted. But he said there were lasting, deep-seated differences of perception.  'You See Us as Selfish' ''There is a feeling in the United States, to put it very crudely, that many European countries are more interested in material prosperity than in their own defense,'' he said. ''You see us as selfish. To many Europeans, the situation appears very different; we worry about social and economic gains made since the war being eroded, and about a nuclear war fought on our soil. **********''Europeans used to criticize the United States for lack of leadership. Now you have an Administration that is ready to give a lead, and you're criticized for not consulting us and for seeing things in black-and-white terms. But you're always on a hiding to nowhere if you're the big boy in town. You simply can't in that position hope for your reward on earth. The British had a lot of practice at that.'' **********Any dilution of the American commitment to Europe's defense, he said, would be seen in Western Europe as ''a very grave development.'' It was therefore up to Europe, he declared, to do nothing to prompt the United States to reduce its troop strength here, and yet some way must be found to involve Europeans more completely in their own defense. **********''Opinion polls show revealingly nationalistic impulses on defense,'' Lord Carrington said. ''In this country, for example, people are all for us maintaining an independent deterrent at the same time as they are worried about American bases. That's not anti- Americanism, in my view, but a desire for national independence.'' **********The problem with suggestions that spending on Europe's defense beswitched in part from nuclear to conventional weapons, he contended, was that it would mean a cut in the American military budget and an increase in the Europeans' budget, since the Unuted States could not be expected to increase the number of troops it has here. **********''It is desirable, of course,'' he said, ''but it's about money, and one has to be realistic about money. The figures that are quoted seem unrealistically large.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Two inventions that convert sunlight into electricity in space as well as on the ground were patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. According to a spokesman, the devices have proved out during computer tests, but have not yet been built. **********Lynn M. Anderson, a physicist at the Lewis Research Center in Cleveland, was granted two patents for the solar converter and for means of transmitting the electrical energy produced. **********According to patent 4,482,778, sunlight is dispersed over a metal surface, producing electromagnetic waves known technically as surface plasma waves. Patent 4,482,779 covers the structure of the diodes, or one-way transmitters, that carry off the power produced. They are referred to as inelastic tunnel diodes. **********The inventions are regarded as of possible use in future space stations and in sophisticated satellites for communications and weather forecasting. Licenses will be available from NASA for other applications.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/26/world.main_headline: ETHIOPIA JEWS FIND NEW LOT AMID ISRAELIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/26/world.print_headline: ETHIOPIA JEWS FIND NEW LOT AMID ISRAELIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/26/world.body_text: **********In Ethiopia, the indigenous Jews are called Falashas - the Amharic word for strangers or exiles. In Israel, the name sticks to the estimated 5,000 Ethiopian Jews who have survived the perilous trek here, as does the stigma of being different in the society they expected to welcome them home. **********Over the years Israel has absorbed wave after wave of immigrants, about half from Europe and the Americas and the rest from Asia and Middle Eastern countries such as Morocco and Yemen. **********In the resulting spectrum of complexions, the Ethiopian newcomers are the darkest-complexioned. Officials who are concerned with the absorption of immigrants into Israeli society fear that the primitivism uninformed Israelis associate with black Africans will complicate the Ethiopians' integration. **********In addition, the troubles the Ethiopians bring with them make them ''the most problematic group ever to reach the country,'' according to Malcah Elbaum, head of the Ethiopian absorption center in Beersheba.   Difficult Arrivals **********Most of the Ethiopian Jews who reach Israel arrive illiterate, with nothing but the ragged clothes they are wearing, a powerful fundamental Judaism and a scattering of African diseases, including malaria and bilharzia, officials said. Many have never seen televisions, toilets, supermarkets or doors. Couples often split and give each other up for lost along the route, remarry and then awkwardly rediscover each other here. **********At a recent meeting held to introduce the Ethiopians to their new Israeli neighbors in the town of Safad, the objections residents raised centered more on the resources that a ''weak population'' would use up than on racial considerations. The Mayors of Eilat, Tiberias and Upper Nazareth initially refused to receive Ethiopian immigrants. **********At the Safad meeting, one resident said: ''We should be honest. It's because they're not white.'' Few of the residents present agreed with her on that point. But the complaints continued that Safad, where unemployment is already relatively high, would find it hard to absorb the new immigrants. **********When the Ethiopians began to arrive in numbers in 1980, special programs were set up in centers like the complex in Beersheba. The new immigrants are completely subsidized for at least their first year here, given semifurnished apartments, clothes, monthly food checks, medical treatment, language courses and occupational training, all under the supervision of social workers. Eli Artzi, Director General of the Israeli Absorption Ministry, said the Ministry spends roughly 10 times more on Ethiopians than it does on average immigrants.   The 'Color Problem' **********A group of Ethiopian women recently aired their complaints about crowded apartments and cheating husbands. The only surge of indignation came when what they call the ''color problem'' arose. ''A person is a person,'' one said. ''Anyway, black is not dirty,'' she said, holding out her brown hands. ''We got it from the earth.'' **********Other Israelis hint that the Ethiopians are not Jewish - an implication the Ethiopians take as the worst of insults. Their people has observed the teachings of the Torah for hundreds of years, despite persecution. Ethiopians have officially been acknowledged as Jews in Israel since 1972, when the chief rabbi, Ovadia Yosef, published a decree to that effect based on his belief that the Falashas were the descendants of the lost tribe of Dan. **********''When we got here and saw everyone riding around on the Sabbath, we thought we were in the wrong country,'' said Mordechai Tabai, a native Ethiopian who arrived almost two years ago. **********Mr. Tabai, whose Hebrew is already so good that he works as a translator here, said that getting used to modern technology and organization is comparatively simple for Ethiopians. The really difficult adjustments concern cultural and religious customs, he said.   Some Moments Are Painful **********In Ethiopia, for example, menstruating women are considered unclean and are sent to a special hut for a week to avoid contaminating others. Here, the women stay in their apartments with their families. ''It was very painful at first, and it was painful for my wife too,'' Mr. Tabai said. **********An Ethiopian immigrant recently appealed to the Israeli Supreme Court against the Interior Ministry's requirement that Ethiopian men undergo a symbolic circumcision, a pinprick, as part of immigration. **********Such protest is unusual, however. Michael Ashkenazi, an Israeli anthropologist who has worked with the Ethiopians, said that they are generally eager enough to become ''real Israelis'' that they do not raise strong objections to such policies. None of the immigrants interviewed here objected to the new names they were assigned upon arrival. ''I thought it was a good to have a new name in a new country,'' said Mr. Tabai's wife, Aviva. **********The absorption process has produced conspicuous successes - Israeli Army soldiers, university students, marriages with longtime Israelis - and also conspicuous failures.  A young Ethiopian was recently found hanged in a public park in Ashdod; according to the daily Yedioth Aharonoth, he left a note in his room saying: ''It's hard for me in this country. My sister died. Police, don't be afraid.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/17/world.main_headline: BRITISH OFFICIAL CONFERS IN PEKING ON HONG KONG
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/17/world.print_headline: BRITISH OFFICIAL CONFERS IN PEKING ON HONG KONG
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/17/world.body_text: **********The British Foreign Secretary met today with China's Foreign Minister to review the negotiations on the future of Hong Kong. **********Britain's lease over most of the colony expires in 1997. **********Sir Geoffrey Howe, the British Secretary, discussed the issue of Hong Kong in separate sessions this morning and this afternoon with his Chinese counterpart, Wu Xueqian.  A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, Qi Huaiyuan, said the talks were carried out in a ''warm, friendly and earnest atmosphere.'' **********The talks were to evaluate the progress already made and to study what needed to be done to reach an agreement on Hong Kong's future, the spokesman said.   September Deadline for Accord **********China, which intends to reassert its sovereignty over Hong Kong, has said it will announce its own plans if an accord is not reached by September. **********The spokesman gave no details of today's talks, which were conducted with the same air of confidentiality that has covered 12 rounds of direct negotiations on Hong Kong. **********Sir Geoffrey is the most senior British official to visit China since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher first raised the subject in her official visit here in September 1982. **********In a toast at a dinner this evening, Sir Geoffrey said that he was ''heartened'' by the progress that had been made on the issue of Hong Kong since Mrs. Thatcher's visit. **********''The excellent relations which exist between Britain and China encourage me in the view that we can reach an agreement under which Hong Kong's stability and prosperity can be maintained,'' he told Mr. Wu.   Speculation of Breakthrough **********The British Foreign Secretary's visit has raised speculation in Hong Kong that some breakthrough might be forthcoming. Sir Geoffrey tried to dampen this hope Sunday by calling his visit ''only one stage in the complex and difficult process'' of agreeing on the best way to preserve Hong Kong's stability and prosperity. **********After his arrival Sunday aboard a Royal Air Force plane, Sir Geoffrey was quoted by his spokesman, John Goulden, as saying: ''A good deal of progress has already been made by our negotiators. It is now timely to review the position at the ministerial level and to decide how best we can take the process forward from here.'' **********The visit is seen partly as a way to reassure the 5. 5 million inhabitants of Hong Kong. They remain unsure of their future despite recent Chinese assurances that the colony's economic and social system will be left unchanged for at least 50 years after China reasserts its sovereignty. **********For this reason, Sir Geoffrey is expected to withhold any subtantial comments on his talks here until after he arrives in Hong Kong on Wednesday.   Top Company Leaving Colony Hong Kong's stock market fell sharply late last month after one of the colony's leading companies, Jardine Matheson, announced that it would move its legal domicile to Bermuda because of uncertainty over the colony's future. **********On Tuesday, Sir Geoffrey is scheduled to meet Ji Pengfei, a senior Chinese official responsible for Hong Kong, and Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang. He may also meet China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, on Wednesday before flying on to Hong Kong. **********The 12 rounds of lower level negotiations, which resume again on April 27, have been held in virtual secrecy. But Mr. Wu said last Friday upon his return from a visit to Europe that China did not let Britain raise the issue of sovereignty over Hong Kong. Peking says this is not negotiable. **********''The sovereignty of Hong Kong could not be discussed and will not be discussed,'' Mr. Wu said.

India says the fence is being built in its own territory. **********Student activists in the Indian state of Assam have been demanding the expulsion of more than one million people who they assert are illegal aliens from Bangladesh. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/01/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; VMS Realty Fills Post At New Financial Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/01/busin.body_text: **********Stephen J. Berini, 34, has been named president of a new real estate venture, the VMS Development Company. **********The appointment was announced yesterday by Joel A. Stone, president of the parent, VMS Realty Inc. **********Based in Chicago, VMS Realty is a privately held company that has become prominent in the sponsorship of private real estate partnerships. Since its founding in 1979, the company has acquired apartment units, hotels and commercial space that it now manages. It estimates the value of its holdings at $2 billion. **********For the last two years, Mr. Berini, a native New Yorker and 1971 graduate of St. John's University, has been a senior vice president for investments with Olympia & York Properties, the Canadian-based real estate company that has extensive interests throughout the United States. **********''The initial purpose of the new venture, which will be based in New York, is to expand the real estate expertise and opportunities available to VMS Realty,'' Mr. Berini said. ''I don't intend to make this a construction company,'' he said. ''Rather, we will be a financial development partner.'' **********Much of Mr. Berini's career has been in finance. Before joining Olympia & York, he served as vice president and chief financial officer of Ernest W. Hahn Inc., a major developer of shopping centers in the United States. Earlier, he was an officer with Chase Manhattan and subsequently with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/18/world.body_text: **********The White House announced today that Harry W. Schlaudeman, 57 years old, a career diplomat, would become the President's new special envoy to Central America, replacing Richard B. Stone, who is resigning at the end of this month. **********Mr. Schlaudeman, who has served as Ambassador to Venezuela, Agrentina and Peru, was recently the executive director of President Reagan's commission on Central America. **********State Department officials said Mr. Stone, a Democrat and former Florida Senator, had resigned because of personal differences with Langhorne A. Motley, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, and not because of policy differences. **********But some Congressional Democrats contended Mr. Stone had gone farther than the Reagan White House wanted in his assignment as a special envoy for peace negotiations in Central America. **********''They decided that they really didn't want a political negotiator,'' said Representative Clarence D. Long, Democrat of Maryland, chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, which oversees aid to El Salvador. ''They want a military solution, and so they didn't need Stone so much. At first, he was not my choice. But I became impressed with the efforts he was making.'' **********In a dispatch from Managua, Nicaragua, United Press International reported that the United States Ambassador to that country, Anthony C. E. Quainton, announced that he would be replaced in March. A spokesman for the State Department, Kathleen Lang, said tonight that she could not confirm the report.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/26/busin.print_headline: ITT, Times-Mirror In Microwave Link SECAUCUS, N.J., April 25 (AP) - The ITT Corporation's long-distance telephone unit announced an agreement today that will more than double its transmission capability by the end of the year.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/26/busin.body_text: **********ITT Communications Services Inc. will link its microwave transmission network with a similar network owned and operated by the Times- Mirror Microwave Communications Company of Austin, Tex., an ITT spokesman, Michael Hughes, said. **********ITT will lease capacity on the Times-Mirror network for a minimum of 10 years, Mr. Hughes said. **********He would not disclose other terms. The agreement will reduce ITT's reliance on more expensive satellite circuitry, Mr. Hughes said. **********''It provides us with direct service from New York to California and also makes direct network links with several major cities in the Midwest, including Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland, Pittsburgh and Kansas City,'' he added. **********ITT's microwave network currently extends some 2,500 miles between New York and Texas, serving 113 major metropolitan areas. Interconnection with the Times-Mirror network would extend it by 3,500 miles, Mr. Hughes said. **********Completion of the interconnection is scheduled for Nov. 1. **********The ITT subsidiary, which has provided long-distance service since 1976, has about 125,000 business and residential customers. The unit also provides domestic and international telex and data communications, electronic mail and data base services. **********The Times-Mirror microwave company is a subsidiary of the Times- Mirror Company, which is involved in newspapers, cable television, broadcasting, newsprint and forest products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/04/busin.body_text: **********A DIP IN PRODUCER PRICES **********There will be few cheers in financial circles when the Producer Price Index for October appears next Wednesday. The index, which over the past year has been virtually flat, is expected to show a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent for the month.  That would be good news for prices, but not for profits. ''The flat index helps explain the erosion in third-quarter corporate profits, which fell by $10 billion,'' said David D.  Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, Chicago. A rising tide of low-cost imports has prevented domestic producers from raising prices, Mr. Hale said.  He also suggested that the index's drop means that business is being hurt by interest rates - a problem that economists have been on the lookout for during much of the recovery period. **********''Our economy may be losing its ability to live with high real interest rates,'' he said. Traditionally, producers shoulder high rates and pass them on to customers in the form of higher prices. ''But this magic circle is now crumbling, along with corporate earnings.'' **********The Recovery Turns Two **********November marks the second anniversary of the economic recovery that began in l982, and many economists, though anticipating slower growth, expect the news to be generally good. ''The third year is never as sparkling as the first two, but this has been a well balanced recovery, and I think that growth will continue through l985,'' said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Bank. **********Not everyone, however, is as convinced as Mr. Kellner that the recovery is on an even keel. The continued weakness in net exports, for example, represents a disturbing imbalance, according to Allen Sinai, chief economist at Shearson Lehman/American Express Inc. ''In past expansions that lasted as long as this one, the average drop in net exports was $2.4 billion. But since the fourth quarter of l982, net exports have dropped $46.8 billion in real terms. I find that imbalance very threatening to a sustained recovery,'' said Mr. Sinai. The weakness in foreign trade, he said, drains much of the spending power from the economy. **********More Trading, More Hedging **********The New York Stock Exchange is the world's biggest financial market and the Chicago Board Options Exchange would have it no other way. Why? **********''Because the institutions that produce most of the Big Board's volume increasingly lay off, or hedge, their positions in our stock options and stock index markets,'' answered Henry G. Nothnagel, the Chicago Exchange's vice president for marketing. **********Mr. Nothnagel noted that the daily volume of his exchange's Standard & Poor's 100 Index options alone averages 300,000 contracts, each with a cash value of $16,000, which comes to $4.8 billion a day. **********''We couldn't do this if the Big Board's daily volume weren't averaging 92 million shares a day.'' he noted. For the New York exchange, with an average share price of about $33, he said, that works out to a total of $3 billion a day there. **********So confident is Mr. Nothnagel that the Big Board's volume will rise, that he predicted that the turnover of the S.& P. 100 options alone will reach one million contracts a day by the end of the year. **********Few Midnight Traders **********While many brokers talk about offering clients 24-hour service, Lind-Waldock & Company, the nation's largest discount futures and options brokerage house, began doing just that last August. **********''The result thus far has been the waste of a lot of midnight electricity, sleep and money,'' said Charles B. Epstein, vice president. **********Of the 700 calls his house receives each night after the Chicago markets are closed, he said, ''450 are requests for quotes and only 250 are actual orders for us to execute on exchanges in Singapore, Hong Kong or London.'' **********''Traders on the Continent apparently have better things to do at night than trade futures or options,'' said Henry A. Engelhardt, Lind-Waldock's senior vice president in charge of its Paris operation. ''Besides, the brokerage commission war going on in London is so fierce that that is where the Europeans are doing their trading today.'' **********That's also good news for the Chicago markets because the traders in London do their hedging in the Windy City.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/28/busin.main_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; City Offers $250 Million Of Bonds at 6% to 10.3%
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/28/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; City Offers $250 Million Of Bonds at 6% to 10.3%
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/28/busin.body_text: **********New York City's largest bond sale since its return to the public bond market in 1981 is under way through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The city is offering bonds yielding from 6 percent for maturity in 1985 to 8 1/4 percent in 1989, 9 1/2 percent in 1994, 10.2 percent in 2002-04 and 10.3 percent in 2013. **********The bonds, which are rated Baa by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by Standard & Poor's, will be used to refund about $79.5 million of federally guaranteed bonds of the city and to finance about $170.5 million of various capital improvement projects. **********Because interest on New York City bonds is exempt from city, state and Federal income taxes, residents of the city continue to be the largest group of buyers. Arthur Spector, an investment banker at Goldman, Sachs, said ''there has been increased interest'' from out-of state investors as the city has balanced its budget in accordance with generally accepted accounting procedures for the last three years. **********According to the preliminary official statement, the city expects more frequent bond sales to help pay for its capital spending program, which totals $1.33 billion in the current fiscal year, ending Sept. 30, and will rise to $1.63 billion in the fiscal year 1987. **********Sales of general obligation bonds are expected to total $656 million in the present fiscal year, to rise to $700 million in the fiscal year 1985, $1.1 billion in 1986 and $1.28 billion in 1987. Borrowings could be greater if the state does not approve legislation allowing the city to sell the $995 million of water and sewer revenue bonds that are budgeted during 1985 through 1987. **********The Municipal Assistance Corporation will continue to help finance the city's capital spending, but at a diminishing rate, by selling $512 million of bonds this year, falling to $100 million in 1987. An additional $349 million to be provided the city during 1984-87 will come primarily from refundings of outstanding M.A.C. bonds. The M.A.C. issues to be refunded have not been identified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/17/world.body_text: **********Following is a statement today by George Lauder, the Central Intelligence Agency spokesman, on behalf of the agency concerning its efforts to keep appropriate committees of Congress informed of C.I.A. covert operations: **********During the 13 January 1981 Senate Select Committee on Intelligence hearing on the nomination of Mr. Casey to be Director, C.I.A., Mr. Casey said: **********''I intend to comply fully with the spirit and the letter of the Intelligence Oversight Act. I intend to provide this committee with the information it believes it needs for oversight purposes.'' **********Mr. Casey believes the record will reflect that he and his staff have kept that pledge. A chronology of briefings of the Congressional oversight committees in connection with events in Central America reveals that from December 1981 through March 1984, either the director or deputy director briefed the Congressional committees 30 times on Central America. **********Moreover, from 16 September 1983 through 2 April 1984, other officials of C.I.A. briefed either the committees or the committee staff 22 times on Central American developments. Since the first of this year, the subject of mining of Nicaraguan ports has been discussed with members or staffers of the committees and other members of the Congress 11 times. **********Largely in order to keep the Congress satisfactorily informed on the agency's activities, the director has continually strengthened the C.I.A.'s Congressional liaison office. This office has been in virtual daily contact with staffers of the House or Senate oversight committees as well as staffers and members of other committees of the Congress. The obligation to keep the oversight committees fully informed has, as it has evolved in practice, been met by briefings of the staff, responding to their oral and written questions, and by providing updates on developments and answering any and all questions at meetings called by the committees. **********There has been no reluctance to share information with them. As has been reported in recent days, members of both committees have affirmed that this process has made the required information available.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/22/busin.body_text: **********MTV Networks Inc., which operates a cable television music channel, said yesterday that it planned to start a second 24-hour music channel in January aimed at viewers aged 25 to 49. **********The announcement was the latest in a series of recent moves by MTV intended to secure its dominant position in the growing music video field. It comes 10 days after the Turner Broadcasting Company, which operates the Cable News Network and the superstation WTBS, said it was considering plans to start a music service in competition with MTV. **********The existing MTV channel is aimed at viewers aged 12 to 34, the company has said. **********'Untapped New Audience' **********The new channel, as yet unnamed, would be intended to reach ''an untapped new audience,'' Robert W. Pittman, the company's executive vice president and chief operating officer, said yesterday. **********Mr. Pittman said the channel would have ''its own look and identity,'' but he refused to specify how the music and programming would differ from the existing channel. The start-up costs, Mr. Pittman said, would be $7 million. **********Several analysts said it was no coincidence that the announcement came soon after Turner signaled its intention to enter the field. **********''MTV has realized that Turner presents the possiblitity of some real competition,'' said Francine Blum, a broadcasting analyst with Wertheim & Company. ''If Turner can present programming that is as good as MTV's, it could be a race to the wire.'' **********Large Market Seen **********Nonetheless, she said, there could be a large market for programming aimed at that age group. **********''It was a typically feisty MTV response to a challenge,'' said another analyst, who asked not to be identified. ''But this is also a natural evolution for MTV to fractionalize the market and appeal to a broader audiences, like radio.'' **********MTV, founded in 1981 by the Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment Company, was spun off into a public corporation earlier this month. The company, MTV Networks Inc., operates the MTV music channel, which reaches reaches 22 million homes, and Nickelodeon, a service intended for children. **********According to the prospectus, the music channel passed into profitablity this year and is earning more than $1 million in advertising revenues a week. Before going public, MTV also announced that it had agreements with four record companies to give it exclusive rights to some new videos. **********Timing of Turner Announcement **********But the day before the scheduled public offering, Turner announced that it hoped to enter the music video field with its own channel. **********If Turner Broadcasting starts its own service, said Arthur Sando, a Turner spokesman, it would be available to cable system operators at no cost for five years. MTV charges cable operators between 10 and 15 cents per subscriber for the service. Turner Broadcasting hopes to make a decision on introducing the service by Sept. 1, Mr. Sando said, and could begin operations by Dec.  5. **********The new MTV service, Mr. Pittman said, would be available at no extra charge to systems that carry MTV.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/22/world.body_text: **********Is the homely English bulldog, that wartime symbol of British pluck, the cartoonist's favorite personification of the national character, in the process of disappearing? **********Bow-legged, flat-faced, low-slung and burly, somehow simultaneously pugnacious and benign, the bulldog was identified with Winston Churchill just as Fala the scotty was identified with his ally, Franklin D. Roosevelt. But the undershot jaw and the pug nose of the breed are seldom seen these days in a country where dogs are omnipresent on city streets, on country lanes, in houses, in pubs. **********The official figures kept by the Kennel Club show that German shepherds, Labrador retrievers and Yorkshire terriers are the most popular dogs in Britain; no fewer than 20,593 new-born shepherds were registered last year. Bulldogs, however thoroughly British they may be, were well down the list, with only 792 registrations. **********According to F. A. Hamilton, the editor of the weekly Dog World, the fact that German shepherds outnumber English bulldogs results not from a decline in patriotism but from an increase in crime. ''It's the changing times, I'm afraid,'' Miss Hamilton said. ''People want the shepherds as guard dogs.''  Long Out of Top 20 **********Bulldogs were still among the top 20 British breeds as recently as 1954, but then they dropped completely off the list, and for the last two decades there have been fewer than 1,000 registrations a year. **********Originally bred to bait bulls - hence the name - the bulldog was known in Britain as early as 1500. It is a descendant of the mastiff, a Tibetan breed that is one of four types of dog thought to have existed in 3,000 B.C. Although they were often tossed into the air, the dogs kept at it until they finally pinned the enraged bull by the nose. Great sums of money were bet on the outcome of the fights until the sport was finally outlawed in this country in 1835. **********Little by little, bulldogs' legs have grown shorter and their bodies stouter; old prints show creatures that are positively elfin compared with the modern bruisers. But in the process, some critics say, they have become disease-prone, vulnerable in particular to ailments that make breathing difficult. **********''Ridiculous, absolute nonsense,'' retorted G. S. Wakefield, a no-nonsense woman who has been breeding bulldogs at her house in this Cambridgeshire village for 30 years. ''None of my dogs is ever sick. They exercise three times a day, without leashes, just running free, in all kinds of weather. Don't tell me they can't move or breathe!''  Bulldogs All Over the Place **********Mrs. Wakefield, a regular winner at the big Cruft's dog shows in London for more than two decades, is one of those sturdy Englishwomen with a single, rather esoteric passion in life. There are bulldogs in the kennels out back, baby bulldogs in a box in her kitchen and representations of bulldogs all over the house - on cartoons, mirrors, statuettes, ashtrays, prints, paintings, photographs, plates, paperweights, even a fire-screen. **********All her champions are kept outdoors; indeed, that is the prefix to their names. They are called Outdoors Boozer, Outdoors Basher, Outdoors Jubilant, Outdoors Duke, to suggest how hale and hearty a bunch they are. Mrs. Wakefield, a widow, says that ''my dogs are my life,'' but she is not above a little fun: She used to tease her husband occasionally by calling him ''Indoors Boozer.'' **********Wakefield bulldogs have appeared on television, and they help earn their keep by posing for advertising photos. Some have won titles as far afield as the Netherlands, the United States and Brazil.   'Beautifully Ugly Animals' **********''The bulldog will never disappear,'' Mrs. Wakefield, who is in her 60's, said with a determined air. ''The bulldog is the British breed - strong- faced, tough, good-natured. Like a lot of us, they're beautifully ugly animals.'' **********But Rita Stratta, manager of the pet shop at Harrods, the big London department store, says the bulldog is a connoisseur's dog, ''the kind of breed that only appeals to people who want to be a little bit different.'' She likes them herself and finds their temperament ''enchanting,'' she said, but she conceded that she had relatively few requests for them from customers, whatever their nationality. **********''They've become very expensive, for one thing,'' Miss Stratta said, ''as much as $600 or or $700 for a good puppy. They're hard to find. A vet I used to know called them an anatomical disaster.''

The lower house passed the bills Friday. The upper house is expected to approve them by Aug. 7, the end of the current special session of Parliament.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/22/world.main_headline: JEWISH TERRORIST IN ISRAEL IS SENTENCED TO 10 YEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/22/world.print_headline: JEWISH TERRORIST IN ISRAEL IS SENTENCED TO 10 YEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/22/world.body_text: **********An Israeli court sentenced a Jewish terrorist today to 10 years in prison for his role in attempted assaults on Palestinian Arabs and for taking part in a plot to blow up one of Islam's holiest shrines. **********A Jerusalem District Court Justice, Yisrael Weiner, sentenced Gilad Peli, 31 years old, to three years in prison for being a member of a Jewish terrorist organization and five years in prison for taking part in a conspiracy to blow up the Dome of the Rock, one of the Moslem world's most sacred monuments, which is on the site of the destroyed Jewish Second Temple in Jerusalem. The two sentences are to run concurrently. **********The judge also ordered Mr. Peli to serve five additional years for the willful destruction of army property and for illegally transporting old Syrian mines, the explosives from which served to make bombs that were planted in five Arab-owned buses in East Jerusalem last month. **********The attempt to sabotage the Arab buses, which was foiled by the Israeli police, led security forces to crack what is believed to be the largest Jewish terrorist movement since Israel became independent in 1948.   He Pleaded Guilty Mr. Peli pleaded guilty to all of the charges last Thursday as a result of a plea bargain with the prosecution. His lawyers and relatives said they had been expecting a much lighter sentence because Mr. Peli cooperated with the prosecutors and had a relatively minor role in the terrorist movement. **********Mr. Peli is the second person to be sentenced in the case under a plea-bargain arrangement. On June 7 Noam Yinon was sentenced to 18 months in prison for transporting explosives. **********Another 24 Jews accused of being terrorists remain to be tried, most of them on charges far more serious than those against Mr. Peli, including the premeditated murder of Arab students at the Islamic University of Hebron in July 1983. **********The sentencing today appeared to indicate that the courts will deal very strictly with the Jewish terrorists, even though their activities have elicited a good deal of public sympathy. **********A poll published Wednesday in the daily Haaretz indicated that about 32 percent of the Israeli public felt the anti-Arab actions of the Jewish underground were ''totally justified'' or had a ''certain justification.'' Sixty percent of the those polled said the actions were unjustified. **********In imposing the sentence, Judge Weiner told Mr. Peli that the very existence of the terrorist group to which he belonged ''shakes the basis on which a democratic administration is based.'' He added that ''It is inconceivable that a group of men should take the law into their own hands,'' organizing ''to perpetrate violence which is liable to cause death or injuries of persons.''  Ideology Dismissed as Irrelevant **********The judge dismissed as irrelevant the ideology and motivations of the underground and added that the court must ''react commensurately, not only to punish the accused but even more so to deter potential lawbreakers from committing such crimes in the future.'' **********Referring to the plot to blow up the Islamic holy place, Judge Weiner added: ''There is no need to waste words describing the harm which would have come to the state of Israel if the plan had been carried out. The harm to the Moslem people would have been even greater.'' **********Bearded and wearing a skullcap, Mr. Peli sat through the proceedings gripping a book of Hebrew psalms in one hand. An Israeli radio reporter said Mr. Peli appeared ''stunned and pale'' when Judge Weiner read out the 10- year sentence, and he had to be helped to walk out of the courtroom. He refused to make any statement to the press.   Father Reacts Bitterly **********His father, Mattiyahu, reacted bitterly to the sentencing, telling reporters: ''The charge sheet omitted the basic point. Charge number one should have been 'love of Israel.' If they had understood the basis of all that has happened, they would have treated the matter differently.'' The father added that the 10-year sentence was a ''burning insult to all lovers of Israel.'' **********Rabbi Moshe Levinger, a spiritual leader of Jewish settlers on the occupied West Bank, told reporters after the sentencing that ''the arrested will yet go down in history as dear boys who worked for the state at a time when it did not do enough on their behalf.'' **********Supporters of the accused have argued that the defendants were forced to take the law into their own hands because the state did not do enough to insure the security of Jewish settlers on the West Bank. **********One of Mr. Peli's defense lawyers, Moshe Yisrael, denounced the sentences as ''very severe,'' but said no decision had been taken yet on whether to appeal. Mr. Peli's wife, Yehudit, said, however, that she planned to appeal and will continue to raise her three children ''to love the people and the land'' of Israel.   Worked as Farmer **********According to Israeli law, Mr. Peli, who worked as a nature guide and farmer on Moshav Keshet, a settlement in the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights, will not be eligible for parole until he has served two thirds of his sentence. **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was asked in a television interview today for his reaction to an appeal by a member of the Israeli Parliament, Michael Kleiner, that all of those accused and convicted of being Jewish terrorists be given a general pardon - just as Israel's first Prime Minister, David Ben- Gurion, once granted pardons for members of Israel's pre-state terrorist underground. **********Mr. Shamir said: ''I don't think that today there is any room for discussing amnesty, so long as the verdicts have not yet been given and the trials have not been concluded.'' **********Asked if he thought pardons were a possibility later, after the trials are complete, Mr. Shamir said: ''I don't know. Anything is possible. There are certain processes and procedures.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/09/busin.body_text: **********The H. J. Heinz Company said today that its profit for the third quarter ending Jan. 25 rose 9.5 percent, to $50.7 million, from $46.3 million a year earlier. **********The food packing and marketing company said it earned 74 cents a share in the period, up 13.8 percent from 65 cents a share a year ago. **********Revenues rose 2.9 percent, to $889.2 million, from $886.6 million. **********The per-share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Sept. 23, 1983, Heinz said. **********For the first nine months of the current fiscal year, the company said its profits rose 12 percent, to $174.6 million, from $156 million a year earlier. Earnings per share increased 13.7 percent, to $2.49, from $2.19. Revenues rose 3.8 percent, to $2.84 billion, from $2.73 billion. **********Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, president and chief executive officer, said the results were ''especially satisfying given the continuing impact of a strong U.S. dollar on the translation of offshore sales and earnings into consolidated results.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/04/world.main_headline: FRENCH WONDER IF IRAN AIDED PLANE HIJACKERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/04/world.print_headline: FRENCH WONDER IF IRAN AIDED PLANE HIJACKERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/04/world.body_text: **********The passengers from an Air France plane that was hijacked to Teheran three days ago arrived here tonight amid increasing speculation in the French press and elsewhere over the possibility that the Iranian Government may have assisted the hijackers. **********Earlier in the day, the Iranian President issued a warning to France that it should expect further acts of terrorism if it did not change its policies toward Iran. France has been supporting Iraq in its war with Iran and has given political asylum to leading Iranian figures opposed to the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. **********French newspapers across the political spectrum blamed Iran for the incident, and some of the papers charged that the Iranian Government had given logistical assistance to the hijackers. **********Plane Taken Over on Tuesday **********Serge July, the editor of Liberation, a left-of-center paper, charged that ''there was complicity that appears to go as high as the Iranian state apparatus itself.'' **********''The least that one can say is that in the schools of international terrorism, and notably Shiite, it is not imagination that is lacking,'' said Mr. July, who sometimes reflects the thinking of the French Government. ''It is extremely difficult to smuggle arms into a commercial airliner.'' **********A conservative paper, Le Quotidien de Paris, compared the incident to the taking of hostages at the American Embassy in Teheran in 1979. President Francois Mitterrand, the paper said, ''felt the wind of the cannon ball that was fatal to Jimmy Carter.'' **********That view was shared by some of the passengers interviewed tonight, who were virtually unanimous in saying that no heavy weapons had been seen on the plane until well after it had landed in Teheran. **********The Boeing 737 was seized over Luxembourg on Tuesday during a flight from Frankfurt to Paris, and the hijackers, described by the authorities as Arabic-speaking, demanded that they be flown to Iran. **********Iran initially declined to accept the aircraft, and after brief stops in Geneva and Beirut, the plane landed early Wednesday in Larnaca, Cyprus. It flew later in the day to Iran, and the hijackers threatened to start killing hostages unless the French Government freed five Iranians jailed in 1980 for an assassination attempt. France refused to meet the request, and on Thursday the hijackers took the passengers off the plane and set off an explosion that rocked the airliner. They then released the hostages and surrendered to security forces. **********In all, 60 former hostages arrived in France tonight, including 55 passengers and 5 crew members from the hijacked flight. The figure included 14 hostages who were freed between Wednesday and Thursday morning. **********Arriving tonight, the first passengers and crewmen entered the Honor Pavillion of Orly Airport to an almost hushed reception shortly after 10 o'clock. But the mood quickly became one of celebration as more passengers filed in.   Three Machine Guns **********John R. Scott, an American who lives in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, was among the passengers who said heavy weapons had not been seen on the plane until after the arrival in Teheran. Until the plane arrived there, he said, the hijackers ''had what appeared to be a fruit juice bottle with a small fuse and a blasting cap and it was wrapped in tape.'' **********He said they also had ''two other smaller devices'' that appeared to be ''small quantities of plastic explosives.'' **********''We were in Teheran almost 18 hours before one of the passengers knew there was a weapon on board,'' he said. **********Mr. Scott, a former marine, said that eventually the men had three .45-caliber pistols, three machine guns, a box of plastic explosives and a box of grenades, ''and they had an incredible quantity of detonator cable.''  'Excuse to Get to the Hold' **********''I thought it highly improbable that they could have gotten that amount of munitions onto the aircraft,'' he said. **********Several passengers said they believed it was possible that the men had gotten the munitions into the airplane's baggage compartment and retrieved them after the plane had landed in Teheran. The compartment was opened, supposedly to retrieve medicine for a sick passenger. **********But Jane Wallington, a 27-year-old British nurse who also lives in Dubai, said she did not believe anyone on the plane was sick. ''It was an excuse to get to the hold,'' she said. **********Jean Nicol, the pilot of the plane, said he saw no apparent complicity between the hijackers and the Iranian authorities. Several other passengers echoed this view. None of the passengers interviewed, including Mr. Scott, said they were in a position to establish with certainty whether or not there had been cooperation between the hijackers and Iranians on the ground.   'Ignorant and Stupid Leaders' **********The threat of further terrorism against France came from Iran's President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, during a prayer meeting in Teheran. **********The hojatolislam, who made his comments before the passengers had left Teheran, issued a stinging rebuke to the French Government for granting political asylum to opponents of the regime of the Ayatollah Khomeini. He said France's ''ignorant and stupid leaders gave asylum to the ugliest international terrorists, gave them shelter, supported them.'' **********He said the leaders of international terrorism were disguised as the leaders of large nations, including France and the United States, and added, ''They should take note that with their attitude, the wave of terrorism against them will intensify day by day.'' France, he said, was confronting Iran ''face to face.'' **********He referred to the hijackers as ''three young Arabs,'' but gave no indication of what happened to them after they surrendered. **********In a television interview today, Roland Dumas, the Minister for European Affairs and the French Government spokesman, noted that before the fall of the Shah of Iran in 1979, Ayatollah Khomeini himself benefited from France's tradition of granting political asylum. **********The Iranian exiles in France include some of Ayatollah Khomeini's one- time allies, such as former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr and the leader of the leftist Mujahedeen, Massoud Rajavi, as well as former Prime Minister Shapour Bakhtiar and Princess Ahraf, the sister of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.   Harder Line From Paris **********The rise of terrorism in France has been a matter of serious popular concern here and something of an embarrassment for the French Government. For many years, various Western governments criticized France for tolerating the presence of groups that they believed were responsible for terrorist acts outside French territory. **********Over the last two years, however, the Government of President Mitterrand has taken a harder line on terrorism. It has, for example, strengthened cooperation with the Spanish Government in pursuit of Basque terrorists. **********Meanwhile, an extremist group called Direct Action took responsibility for an explosion Thursday just before midnight at the European Space Agency headquarters here. The blast slightly injured six people and reduced a large portion of the building's ground floor to rubble.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/17/world.print_headline: Exiled Ex-Premier of Grenada To Return Home, Aide Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/17/world.body_text: **********The exiled former Prime Minister, Sir Eric Gairy, plans to return to Grenada on Saturday for the first time since he was deposed nearly five years ago, an aide said today. **********The aide, Oliver Raeburn, chairman of the Grenada United Labor Party, said party officials were planning a big reception for Sir Eric, the party leader. **********Sir Eric said last week that he would not take part in general elections planned for this year but that his party, which won seven of eight elections since 1950, would field candidates in all 15 constituencies. **********In the last elections, in 1976, the party won nine seats and Sir Eric became Prime Minister. On March 13, 1979, he was overthrown by his main opponents, the left-wing New Jewel Movement. Sir Eric has been living in the United States since 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/21/world.main_headline: U.S. SEEMS WILLING TO OFFER A TRADE AT THE ARMS TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/21/world.print_headline: U.S. SEEMS WILLING TO OFFER A TRADE AT THE ARMS TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/21/world.body_text: **********A senior Reagan Administration official said today that the United States would be willing to negotiate its long-range missile defense plan along with seeking cuts in offensive weapons systems when arms **********talks with the Soviet Union resume next month. **********He also said that Secretary of State George P. Shultz would be authorized to affirm to Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko that the United States would be ready to consider ''measures of restraint'' in testing the antisatellite weapons now under development. **********The official, as well as Mr. Shultz in a separate briefing for members of Congress today, stressed that the Americans were approaching the negotiations as a comprehensive package with the goal of seeking stability in Soviet and American military strength through tradeoffs in the various weapons. **********Until today, American officials have said they hoped the Geneva talks would lead to negotiations on strategic offensive arms and medium-range offensive missiles, along with ''discussions'' on the Administration's long-term research plans for a defensive shield against missiles. This had led to uncertainty about whether the Administration would be willing to include any curbs on defensive weapons when the talks resume. The senior official said today that the Administration would, in fact, make its so-called Star Wars defensive program subject to negotiation. **********Long Briefing for Reporters For the first time since the announcement on Nov. 22 that Mr. Shultz and Mr. Gromyko would meet in Geneva Jan. 7-8, a long briefing was held for reporters to provide some information on the behind- the-scenes work that has been going on in recent weeks to prepare the American position. **********The official, one of the few senior aides to President Reagan involved in the advance planning for Geneva, spoke at the White House on condition that he be identified only as ''a senior Administration official.'' This is a common Administration practice, particularly on foreign policy issues, when the White House wants to provide background information in a less official way than if the high aide was identified by name. **********It is not done to keep the official's name secret from other governments since foreign correspondents, including Russians, are usually present, as they were today. Officials contend that by speaking on this background basis they can speak somewhat more candidly. **********'Flexible and Constructive' The practice is not followed consistently. For instance, when Robert C. McFarlane, the national security adviser, announced the Soviet-American resumption of talks last month, he spoke at considerable length on the record on events leading up to the announcement. **********The official's remarks today seemed aimed at indicating to the Soviet Union, American allies, and public opinion that the Reagan Administration, despite continuing internal differences, was approaching the Geneva talks in what he called a ''serious, flexible and constructive'' manner. **********''We have identified some ideas and concepts which we think hold promise for bridging gaps which existed heretofore,'' the official said. He added that the United States was continuing to stress reducing the size of each side's offensive nuclear arsenal, but was also ready to negotiate on the research program on defensive weapons as well. **********''We are ready in going to Geneva to exchange thoughts on these ideas, hopefully to receive some from the Soviet Union, and we hope to come away with an agreed plan for the early renewal of formal dialogue and negotiations in each of these areas,'' he said. **********About the same time that reporters were being briefed at the White House, Mr. Shultz was discussing the Administration's Geneva plans with some key members of Congress in a closed meeting. Later Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, the next chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said that the Administration was insistent that both offensive and defensive weapons be considered comprehensively, and not piecemeal. **********''We are hopeful that there will be a comprehensive desire to talk about all offensive and defensive weapons in their entirety and completeness,'' Mr. Lugar said. **********The main goal of the Geneva talks is to set up a format for continuing the negotiations in a detailed way in the three major areas - strategic offensive arms, medium-range missiles and defensive weapons. The official said the United States was flexible on the eventual format.   No Preconceived Outcome **********''We have no preconceived outcome we insist upon,'' he said. ''We have a number of ideas on different formats which hold out promise of making progress in each of the areas. We will listen to their ideas.'' **********The most contentious issue facing the arms control talks are the two programs that the Soviet Union says must be given priority. The first is the current American plan for testing a weapon that could knock out satellites in space. New tests of this system are due to take place this winter. The second is the expensive, long-term research program to develop a defense against nuclear-armed missiles aimed at the United States and American allies. **********Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet Politburo member who has been visiting London this week, has emphasized that the American defensive weapons could upset the nuclear balance and lead to intensified Soviet spending on new offensive weapons. **********On Wednesday Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said in a speech that the strategic defense system, known colloquially as ''Star Wars,'' was vital to American defenses and had to be pursued. He also said that the Soviet Union had an advantage over the United States by already possessing an antisatellite weapon.   Early Accord Is Favored **********State Department officials are known to believe that the defensive programs ought to be pursued but should also be offered eventually as a trade-off for sharp Soviet cuts in the multiwarheaded, ''heavy'' land-based missiles that American planners say give Moscow an offensive advantage. The State Department also favors negotiating an early accord that might include a moratorium on testing of the antisatellite weapons as a way of getting the negotiations moving. **********The senior official today seemed to support the State Department view, but made an elaborate argument as well for pursuing the research program into ''Star Wars'' defense. He said it was crucial to engage the Soviet Union in talks on what constitutes ''stability.'' He said the Administration ''had no illusions that some unilateral U.S. deployment of defensive systems'' would enhance stability. **********The senior official, who said earlier that the Administration looked to trade-offs in the negotiations, was asked if this included the defensive systems, which are still in the very early research phase. **********He said that because there were no actual American defensive weapons to trade at this point, ''it is intellectually obscure'' what the trade-offs would be. **********But he added, ''The research program and our intentions for it have to be on the table and a matter for discussion and agreement and negotiation between us, and they surely will be on the table.''  'Trade-Offs' Considered Fruitful **********The official also said the United States thought ''trade-offs'' would be particularly fruitful in the strategic arms area, where the United States would be willing to see curbs on its bomber force, which is more advanced than Moscow's, in return for Soviet cuts in its land-based missiles, where it has an edge. **********The official said he believed the Russians had agreed to resume talks because it had been Soviet practice to be more forthcoming in negotiations when Moscow felt the United States might use its advanced technology to move ahead of the Russians, as seems to be the case now that Washington is pressing ahead in defensive weapons. **********Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, has called several times for a moratorium on testing of antisatellite weapons. President Reagan, in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly last September and in private comments to Mr. Gromyko in Washington, said the United States would not agree to any curbs in advance of negotiations, but would consider restraints - a possible moratorium - at the actual negotiating table. **********The senior Administration official said that ''the President stands by his commitment.'' **********''Yes, we will consider what measures of restraint are appropriate when the negotiations open,'' he said. He recalled, however, that the Soviet Union violated a moratorium on nuclear testing agreed to in the late 1950's and held extensive testing before finally agreeing in 1963 to a treaty banning atmospheric nuclear tests - the first significant Soviet-American arms control accord. **********''This is not to say that one precedent rules out a moratorium,'' he said. ''The President stands by the commitment in his speech.'' **********He said Mr. Reagan had been given ''a rich panoply of options'' and is expected to make decisions before the New Year on what to instructions to give Mr. Shultz.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/30/busin.main_headline: BRAZIL WILL SEEK FLEXIBLE DEBT PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/30/busin.print_headline: BRAZIL WILL SEEK FLEXIBLE DEBT PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/30/busin.body_text: **********Brazil has decided to follow Mexico's example in seeking to postpone all principal payments coming due on its debts for the next several years, according to officials here. The request is expected to be made when Brazil resumes debt negotiations with foreign banks in New York this week. **********Foreign bankers and economists said that, if successful, the Mexican and Brazilian attempts to obtain multiyear reschedulings could mark a turning point in the two-year-old regional debt crisis by providing the two largest debtors with time to rebuild their troubled economies. **********At the London economic summit conference last month and in other forums, officials of the industrial nations have been urging that those debtor countries that make an effort to control inflation and reduce international payments deficits should receive favored treatment on their debts. **********Models for the Region **********By easing conditions for Brazil and Mexico, analysts say, both nations' austerity programs could become regional models. **********Some bankers also say that an agreement on a more flexible system of principal repayment would help separate Mexico and Brazil from countries such as Argentina that favor a more militant approach to the debt problem. ''This could be the best way of ending talk of a debtors' cartel,'' one Brzazilian economist noted. **********Affonso Celso Pastore, president of Brazil's central bank, refused to disclose last week whether Brazil would request a restructuring of ''two, three, four or five years,'' but he said the objective was to avoid new liquidity crises ''in, for example, 1988 or 1989.'' **********At present, Brazil is committed to repaying some $57 billion of medium- and long-term commercial and Government loans maturing between 1985 and 1989 as well as interest payments of about $12 billion a year. The country's total foreign debt stands at $95 billion, the largest in the developing world. **********''We have information that Mexico is achieving a multiyear payment plan,'' Mr. Pastore told an audience in the Supreme War College July 24. ''It's like a Formula One race. We're letting Mexico take the lead, and we're going to ride in its slipstream, later overtaking to achieve even better repayment conditions.'' **********Earlier this month, Mexican officials met with a 13-bank advisory group in New York and reportedly asked to reschedule some $45 billion in public-sector debt maturing between 1985 and 1989. Mexico is also said to want a repayment period of 15 years, including a five-year grace period on the repayment of principal, combined with a reduction of commissions and ''spreads,'' which are the margins earned by banks above the floating interest rate. **********Months of Negotiations **********Mexico's debt talks are expected to continue for three months. Mr. Pastore is scheduled to present Brazil's case to a 14-bank advisory group in New York on Thursday, although formal negotiations with the country's 500 or so commercial creditors are not scheduled to start until September. **********Regional officials involved with the debt problem said that the outcome of these twin negotiations would determine the next act in the debt drama. They argued that commercial banks had an opportunity to demonstrate a willingness to ''reward'' countries like Mexico and Brazil that have adopted severe austerity measures. **********Such an arrangement would imply recognition by banks that most debtor nations cannot, even over the long term, repay the capital on their debts. **********''People keep asking, 'When is Brazil going to pay off its debt?' '' Brazil's finance minister, Ernane Galv^eas, said last Thursday. ''We're not going to pay off our debt. The bankers know it, the official financial institutions know it, and the governments know it. We're going to pay our interest to the extent of our possibilities, and when we cannot, the bankers will lend us the money and then we will.'' **********Analysts have said that, while the Mexican and Brazilian negotiations are separate, they are linked in the minds of foreign bankers as well as of officials in both countries. ''In a sense, that's what the Cartagena meeting was all about,'' one Brazilian official said, referring to a conference of Latin American debtor nations in the Colombian city of Cartagena last month. ''A joint regional renegotiation was discarded as impractical, but the idea of coordinating strategy was very much endorsed.'' **********If the Mexican and Brazilian demands are met, other Latin debtor nations may request similar treatment from creditors without having first redressed trade and budget deficits through austerity programs. **********Interest Rate Worries **********Also, the coming negotiations will not address the region's overriding fear of a continuing rise in world interest rates. But analysts caution that, once relieved of the burden of almost continuous principal renegotiation, Mexico and Brazil might feel freer to concentrate their energies on obtaining lower interest rates. Early last year, Mexico rescheduled all debt maturing between August 1982, when its financial crisis reached a peak, and December 1984. In contrast, Brazil has been involved in annual renegotiations. **********In his remarks last week, Mr. Pastore said that Brazil's bargaining position had been strengthened by the growth in the country's foreign exchange reserves, which now stand at $4.2 billion and should reach $6 billion by the end of 1984. This was attributable largely to a growing trade surplus that reached $6.1 billion by the end of June and is now forecast to exceed $11 billion for the year. **********The central bank president said that Brazil would be seeking longer repayment and grace periods than those - nine and five years, respectively - obtained during the last rescheduling, as well as lower spreads and commissions. **********Request for 'New Money' **********Planning Minister Ant^onio Delfim Netto said last Thursday that Brazil would also request between $3 billion and $4 billion in ''new money'' for 1985 as part of its renegotiation package - compared with the $6.6 billion needed this year. **********Mr. Pastore explained further that, like Mexico, Brazil would propose that interest rates on the restructured debt be linked exclusively to the London interbank offered rate, known as Libor, rather than the U.S. prime rate, which, he said, was more unstable. **********Referring to Brazil's long-term growth prospects, Mr. Pastore said that much would depend on the industrialized world's ability to maintain its expansion and hold down interest rates. ''These countries must discipline themselves because, if not, there will soon be another 1982 - the world economy in recession and high international interest rates - that will simultaneously break all the debtor countries,'' he warned. ''The result, without any doubt, would then be creation of a debtors' cartel.'' **********Venezuelan Proposal **********CARACAS, Venezuela, July 29 (Reuter) - Venezuela has submitted proposals to its creditor banks to restructure up to $22 billion of debts over 10 to 15 years, Carlos Guillermo Rangel, Venezuela's chief debt negotiator, said. **********In an interview in New York last night with a Venezuelan television station, Rangel also confirmed that the Government had been granted a 90-day extension of its moratorium on public-sector principal payments. **********He said he was certain basic agreement would be reached with the banks during the 90-day period, which starts on Aug. 1. **********''Nevertheless, we have submitted some unconventional proposals which could make the negotiations more complicated than usual,'' he said.  Venezuelan Finance Minister Manuel Azpurua said yesterday his country had included in its rescheduling proposals debts maturing in 1985, in addition to those of 1983 and 1984, in an attempt to reach a longer-term solution to its financial problems. **********Venezuela, which has a total foreign debt of $34 billion, is seeking to become the first Latin American debtor to obtain major rescheduling without an International Monetary Fund agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/world.main_headline: 21 SALVADOR POLICE DIE IN TRAIN ATTACK
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/world.print_headline: 21 SALVADOR POLICE DIE IN TRAIN ATTACK
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/world.body_text: **********Salvadoran military sources said today that 21 Treasury policemen were killed on Saturday when leftist guerrillas attacked a cargo train 25 miles north of the capital. **********At least three civilians were wounded, according to the International Committee of the Red Cross. **********The attack, which took place at 11 A.M. at an isolated spot near the small town of San Antonio Grande, is the latest in a series of guerrilla raids against the country's transportation system. **********Last week, guerrillas blew up another cargo train and issued repeated warnings to motorists to stay off the Pan-American Highway, which is the country's main road for trucks and buses delivering goods throughout the country. Leftist forces also set up roadblocks near the Honduran border. **********Radio Venceremos, the rebel station, said that what appeared to be a new campaign of economic sabotage had cost the country $1 million. The Government has not estimated the cost, but the leftist forces appear to have had some effect in slowing commerce.   Many Won't Drive **********Government forces patrolled the highways last week, and provided some security to motorists. However, the rebel warnings that roads were mined kept many truck and bus drivers from attempting their regular routes. **********Most of El Salvador's commerce is conducted by truck or train. By trying to control the main highways, the guerrillas can affect commerce between El Salvador and Honduras. Moreover, revenues from the large Sunday markets held in many Salvadoran towns decline substantially when people from outlying areas are unable to reach the markets. **********Vice President Rodolfo Castillo Claramont said today that there was no official estimate of the damage. He said the rebels were trying to force a solution to the country's four-year-old civil war ''that the people do not want.'' **********(Government forces and guerrillas clashed briefly at San Felipe, 45 miles east of San Salvador on the Pan-American Highway, where rebels tried to set up a roadblock but were driven back, Lieut. Col. Rolando Ticas of the Fifth Brigade told The Associated Press.) **********The Treasury policemen killed on Saturday were accompanying the cargo train when the guerrillas attacked it, according to Alejandro Salazar, the local commander. **********The train, which carried cement, was headed north when it was derailed by mines set along the tracks. Some of the Treasury policemen were killed by the explosion from the mines, and others were killed later during a firefight with guerrillas. **********It was unclear whether the civilians wounded in the attack were on the train, or lived in a small village along the train's route, the Red Cross said. **********Last March, guerrillas killed 18 Government troopers and civilians aboard a passenger train, also at San Antonio Grande.   Duarte Leaves for Europe **********SAN SALVADOR, July 15 (AP) - President Jose Napoleon Duarte left for West Germany today, the first stop on a 10-day trip to seek economic aid for El Salvador from European countries. He is also scheduled to visit France and Belgium.
