https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/03/busin.body_text: **********While 1983 was a good year for stocks in general, it was an extraordinarily good year for a few stocks, and an unspeakably bad one for several others. **********The Dow Jones industrial average posted a 20.3 percent gain in 1983, but that was as nothing compared with the 25-fold rise in the stock of Dento- Med Industries, an over-the-counter company that has developed a new type of false teeth. Dento-Med had the best percentage gain among the top 10 stocks in New York Stock Exchange, American Stock Exchange and over-the-counter trading. **********Leading the list of stocks upon which fortune did not shine last year was the Baldwin-United Corporation, the piano maker turned insurance conglomerate, which was forced to file for reorganization. Its stock fell a staggering 91.9 percent. **********They All Had Stories **********The spectacular overachievers and underachievers all had stories of their own: striking it rich at a wildcat well, lagging behind competitors in an industry shakeout, enjoying a strong and unexpected turnaround in earnings, investing heavily in new technology and then getting squeezed by a drop in revenues. **********''Some speculative and secondary stocks absolutely took off and others fall out the window,'' said William M. LeFevre, a partner with Purcell, Graham & Company, a securities firm. **********The big gainers were often small companies that only a lucky few had heard about before the stocks began their ascent into the stratosphere. In contrast, the big losers were usually either large corporations, such as Baldwin-United, Mattel or Mitel, whose sagging fortunes were widely reported, or tiny ones whipsawed in intensely competitive industries, such as small computers and oil refining and drilling. **********The APL Corporation is certainly not a household name, but the small diversified company, which makes tissue and plastic products, was the Big Board's top performer, rising 318.5 percent. Having weathered five years of weak earnings and concomitant low stock prices, this Miami Beach company sold several assets and roared back into the black. **********Finishing a strong No. 2 on the New York Stock Exchange was International Rectifier, which saw its stock soar 247 percent. The semiconductor and pharmaceutical company disposed of its low-profit animal products division and invented a low-cost, highly efficient method to power silicon chips. **********The Big Board's third-best performer was the Hesston Corporation, an agricultural machinery company that is half-owned by Fiat S.p.A. of Italy. ''Hesston was the strongest performer in a strong group,'' said Eli S. Lustgarten, an analyst with Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins. **********Harvester in Comeback **********Another strong performer in the agricultural machinery group turned out to be the strongest performer among the 30 Dow industrials: International Harvester. **********''A year ago, people wrote it off as a bankrupt company,'' Mr. Lustgarten said, ''but now the issue of survival has pretty much been put to rest.'' Notwithstanding its strong 1983 gain, the scaled-down company's stock, which closed at $11.50 on Dec. 30, is light years away from its high of $45.50 in 1979. **********Far less fortunate than these superstars but at least more fortunate than Baldwin-United, were Mattel Inc., and Nutri/System, the second- and third-worst performances on the New York Stock Exchange. Mattel stock fell by 69.9 percent, largely because of the unforeseen decline in the video game fad and the company's $222.8 million loss in the first nine months of 1983. Nutri/System, which runs a chain of weight-control centers, was hard hit by the recession and forced to close more than 50 of its centers. **********Two oil and gas-related companies were among the Top 10 losers on the Big Board. The Galveston-Houston Company, a contract driller, was the sixth-worst performer. Analysts said it was financially overextended and nearly crippled by the dropoff in drilling caused by the weakness in oil prices. The seventh-worst performer was Tosco, a California oil refining and marketing company that was squeezed by declining margins. **********Problem-Plagued Utilities **********Two utilities plagued by large delays and cost overruns at controversial new nuclear power plants that might never be operated were the Big Board's ninth- and eleventh-worst performers: the Public Service Company of Indiana, with its Marble Hill plant, and the Long Island Lighting Company, with its Shoreham facility. **********Another sad story was Mitel, a producer of telephone switchboards that was the Big Board's eighth-worst performer. I.B.M. had signed a large order with Mitel but canceled it largely because of a yearlong delay in introducing a sophisticated new switchboard. ''There are three times as many competitors as there were three years ago,'' said Amy Newmark, an analyst with C. J. Lawrence. ''In addition, prices have come way down.'' **********Similarly, companies that make sophisticated computer and communications products populated the Top Ten worst performers in both Amex and over-the-counter trading. **********One of the most interesting stories involves American Medical Buildings, a California-based builder of medical facilities that decided to buy a share of a communications satellite to beam entertainment and educational programs into hospitals. **********The fifth-worst performer on the Amex, the company was pushed into heavy losses because it is having problems finding customers for and paying for the system. Adm. Elmo R. Zummwalt, former Chief of Naval Operations, recently helped oust the head of the problem-plagued company and became its chairman. **********Another one-time glamour issue to have fallen in a big way is Vector Graphic, which was the second-worst performer among over-the-counter issues. Shortly after it was founded by Lore Harp, it was a leader among companies making small computers and many said it would be the first company founded by a woman to join the Big Board. Vector stumbled badly, however, because of a shakeout in the industry and because it was slow to move from 8-bit computers to 16-bit ones. **********''A lot of these computer companies seem very glamorous,'' Mr. LeFevre said. ''But the field is so fiercely competitive that a lot are stumbling,''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/09/world.main_headline: FULL EXTENT OF RELIEF SUPPLIES IN ETHIOPIA APPEARS IN DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/09/world.print_headline: FULL EXTENT OF RELIEF SUPPLIES IN ETHIOPIA APPEARS IN DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/09/world.body_text: **********A question has arisen over the amount of food available in Ethiopia. **********Relief workers returning from Korem, the largest famine refugee camp, say no new shipments have arrived there for more than two weeks and ''it is a question of days'' before reserve stocks are exhausted. Should that happen, they say, the death rate, now 30 a day, would rise. **********Tafari Wassen, a spokesman for Ethiopia's Relief and Rehabilitation Commission, said Korem had not been supplied because there was a general shortage of food in Ethiopia. **********He said that despite promises of 370,000 tons, 210,000 from the United States, ''the situation is no better now than before the food was pledged.'' **********''Time is the problem,'' he added. ''There have got to be more diversions now. Efforts must be made.'' **********However, Kurt Jannson, the United Nations Under Secretary for Emergency Operations in Ethiopia, said 40,000 tons of food were ''now in stock for distribution.'' **********Western diplomats said 70,000 to 80,000 tons moved through the port of Assab in November, and 120,000 tons are to be delivered this month. **********The diplomats said that last week three British transports delivered 64 tons of grain to Alamata, an airstrip serving Korem. They say their records also showed that eight Ethiopian relief flights recently landed in Alamata. **********It was not clear why none of that food has reached Korem, which accommodates 40,000 refugees. Food trucks have also been seen recently along the road from Addis Ababa to Korem. **********And travelers just returned from Assab say that ships had been unloaded there within the last two days. According to official statistics, 6.4 million Ethiopians are ''in serious distress'' because of the famine. **********However, Mr. Tafari said Thursday that more recent calculations showed that an additional one million people now fell in that category. **********''It could be even more than that,'' Mr. Tafari said. ''And if more assistance does not come in, the number is likely to increase.'' **********The Ethiopian Government has said that it will require 1.2 million tons of grain to continue emergency feeding programs for the next 12 months, the minimum duration of the famine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/13/world.main_headline: U.S.-CANADA CASE IS GIVEN TO JUDGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/13/world.print_headline: U.S.-CANADA CASE IS GIVEN TO JUDGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/13/world.body_text: **********A five-judge panel of the International Court of Justice heard final arguments today in the dispute between the United States and Canada about their maritime boundary in the Gulf of Maine, the area of the Atlantic Ocean that includes the rich Georges Bank fishing zone. **********The panel will now deliberate on thousands of pages of testimony going back to November 1981, when the two countries agreed to submit the case to the World Court. **********A decision is expected in August. By mutual agreement, it will be binding. **********In a closing statement, Judge Robert Ago of Italy, the panel's president, praised both countries for ''the serene and cordial'' way they had approached the case. Work on the dispute had been suspended by the Court while its full contingent of 15 judges heard Nicaragua's request for a restraining order to stop United States-supported military activities against the Nicaraguans.   Area May Have Oil and Gas **********The Gulf of Maine case is expected to set important legal precedents because the number of disputed maritime boundaries has grown in recent years with the general acceptance of 200-mile fishing zones. **********At issue is a 30,000-square-mile area of the Atlantic in which it is believed there may be oil and natural gas, although drilling attempts so far have failed. The United States' boundary proposal would give it total jurisdiction over Georges Bank. The United States claims the area was developed in the 19th century by New England fishermen, who fished in it exclusively until the 1950's, when fleets from other countries joined them. **********Canada is asking for half of the disputed area. Its lawyers say some parts of Nova Scotia have a vital economic dependence on the eastern segment of Georges Bank. **********The Canadians contend that the United States does not have any economic dependence on that part of the area, and that its fishing activity is centered principally on the sector that would go to the United States in any case. **********On Thursday, the Interior Department proposed to open 14 million acres in the North Atlantic to offshore oil and gas leasing. The department said the area disputed by Canada would be leased only if the United States received a favorable ruling from the World Court.   Geography of Area Stressed **********The panel, which includes an American and a Canadian in addition to Italian, French and West German judges, will be making the first judicial determination of a 200-mile zone boundary, as distinct from a boundary for the continental shelf alone or for the territorial sea. **********Only the United States pleaded today, Canada having completed its case. Davis R. Robinson, the chief United States legal adviser, emphasized two central points about the geography of the area and the characteristics of the fishing banks there. **********''The coast of the Gulf of Maine,'' Mr. Robinson said, ''is the principal coast of New England, facing the Atlantic Ocean and the outside world. Under the United States proposal, the maritime boundary will proceed in a southeasterly direction perpendicular to the general direction of the coast. **********''Yet Canada persists in advocating a boundary that moves still further south across the front of the United States' east coast, claiming nearly half of the last great fishing bank in the northwest Atlantic Ocean to which United States fishermen have access. **********''If Canada's line is adopted,'' he added, ''the entire Atlantic Coast north of Philadelphia - where one-quarter of the entire population of the United States lives - would face not Europe, not the high seas of the open Atlantic, but Canadian waters.'' **********''This issue of 'cutoff,' '' Mr. Robinson said, ''will be replicated in maritime boundary disputes around the world. This issue raises the most fundamental issues of sovereignty. The question of 'cutoff' posed in this case, not only in a geographic sense, but in a political sense as well, affects the interests of all states.''  Separation of Fish Stocks Cited **********The Americans argue that fish stocks in Georges Bank are separate from those of the Scotian Shelf, an area that would remain Canadian. The Americans, who maintain that the Canadians recognized the Northeast Channel as separating the two stocks, hold that conservation and management of these stocks by a single nation is more effective than joint management. **********If the Canadian proposition was accepted the two countries would divide the Georges Bank area for management purposes. **********The Canadian argument is that it has drawn a line so that every point on the proposed boundary is an equal distance from base points on the coasts of both countries. **********Canada maintains that its boundary is an equitable one that the United States has tacitly accepted. It said the United States failed to protest Canada's issuance from 1964 to 1969 of oil and gas permits up to the line it is proposing. The Canadians also said that evidence indicated that over the same period geophysical survey permits issued by the United States for Georges Bank were granted on the basis of an equidistance formula like the one proposed by Canada.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/04/world.main_headline: FOOD FOR ETHIOPIA BRINGS U.S. DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/04/world.print_headline: FOOD FOR ETHIOPIA BRINGS U.S. DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/04/world.body_text: **********A dispute has arisen between the Reagan Administration and Congress over Administration assertions that food donated by the United States and other countries to fight famine in Ethiopia is being diverted by that country's leftist Government to commercial markets. **********In an interview, two officials of the Agency for International Development contended that proceeds from the sale of donated food were being used by Ethiopia to buy Soviet military equipment for Ethiopia's civil war in two northern provinces, Eritrea and Tigre. **********Representative Howard Wolpe, a Michigan Democrat who heads the House subcommittee on Africa, called the diversion charge baseless. He said, ''It is in total conflict with all the reports from the U.S. Embassy in Ethiopia and all the relief agencies.'' **********The Administration accusations became public after the A.I.D. director, M. Peter McPherson, sent a letter recently to Representative Wolpe that referred to ''allegations of diversions and financial profit by Ethiopian Government officials.''  Congress Considers More Aid **********The dispute has arisen as Congress considers increasing the Administration's request for $90 million more food aid for Africa.  On Wednesday the House Appropriations Committee added $60 million to the Administration's emergency food request for Africa and extended the period for its use until Dec. 31. The committee also made available $90 million of commodities for purchase with guaranteed low-interest loans. The bill is expected to come to the floor next week. **********An A.I.D. official said the Adminitration planned to resist Congressional efforts to increase food aid to Ethiopia. ''In the area controlled by the Government, there is no food shortage right now,'' he said. **********The A.I.D. officials said over 15,000 tons of food had been diverted, which one official said was ''100 times more serious'' than reports of recent diversion of donated food in El Salvador. **********An investigation last April by the European Economic Community found that ''no conclusive evidence has been produced to show that food aid has been systematically diverted to the armed forces.'' A bipartisan group of members of Congress said at a news conference last week that there was no evidence of food diversion.   Estimates of Need Differ **********The A.I.D. officials contended that the Ethiopian Government had misrepresented its reserves and halted imports of grain three years ago. **********''It is very clear that this Administration is very opposed to more spending on food assistance to Africa,'' Representative Wolpe said. He said the Administration was trying to find the lowest accountable figures on Ethiopian food needs to keep spending down. **********The A.I.D. estimates the remaining food needs of Ethiopia in 1984 at less than 37,000 tons. However, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization estimates that 234,000 tons are needed, the United States Department of Agriculture puts the figure at 187,000 tons, while CARE, a private relief agency, said that Ethiopia needed 216,000 tons of food. **********The United States has contributed 22,000 tons, or 8 percent of the 265,000 tons of international food assistance given to Ethiopia this year. A request for 27,000 tons, part of the Administration's $90 million African aid package, would increase that total to 17 percent. **********Conflicting reports have been attributed to the United States Embassy in Ethiopia on the question. **********The A.I.D. official attributed to the embassy the report of the diversion charges, while Representative Wolpe said that Ambassador David Corn told him during a Congressional fact-finding tour in Ethiopia in August that no food diversion had taken place.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/18/busin.main_headline: CAUTION ABOUT HELP FOR FINANCIAL CORP.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/18/busin.print_headline: CAUTION ABOUT HELP FOR FINANCIAL CORP.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/18/busin.body_text: **********Thrift industry regulators apparently are taking a wait-and-see stance regarding any assistance for the Financial Corporation of America, which reported a $107.5 million loss for the second quarter earlier this week. **********A spokesman for Financial declined to comment on whether the company had experienced a net outflow of funds since the loss was announced Wednesday. He also declined to say whether Financial had increased its borrowings from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. **********One executive of a West Coast thrift institution that competes directly with the American Savings and Loan Association, the principal operating unit at Financial, said his staff was advising callers with deposits of $100,000 or less not to pull funds from American Savings and Loan before maturity, since they are subject to a cash penalty for early withdrawal. **********There are indications that regulatory worries extend beyond the situation at Financial, where the company needs to raise about $15 billion in six weeks to replace maturing deposits. **********The company said in its quarterly filing with the S.E.C. Wednesday that it had guaranteed $3.4 billion in loans not yet made. It has already recorded those fees as profit. **********The loans typically are used by developers to pay off short-term bank construction loans. The loan to Financial is repaid as the project is sold, often in parts. **********If Financial were unable to make a portion of the loans, the developers might have difficulty repaying the short-term debt, said an executive at a thrift institution, who asked not to be identified. **********In addition to the $3.4 billion, Financial also has $1.1 billion yet to be paid on loans on which some advances have already been made. **********While Financial's situation is considered precarious by many, some see opportunities for profit. **********The chairman of one West Coast financial services company, who asked not to be identified, said his company was buying Financial debentures, currently priced to yield 22 percent. The debentures also are convertible into Financial common shares at a price of $14 a share. The company's stock rose today on the New York Stock Exchange, climbing 37 1/2 cents, to $4.75. **********The executive said that sources within Financial had told him privately that withdrawals on Thursday and Friday were manageable. **********Futures traders in Chicago told the Reuters news service that Financial sold $250 million in discounted Government National Mortgage Association certificates on Wednesday, and another $500 million today. Financial declined to comment, according to Reuters. **********Industry Impact **********WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 - The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that accounting practices used by the Financial Corporation of America and challenged by the Securities and Exchange Commission are not widespread in the industry. **********The company was forced by the S.E.C. to restate its second-quarter results to show a loss of $107.5 million, instead of a profit of $31.1 million. **********The dispute involved Government National Mortgage Association securities, which the company bought and immediately sold back to the initial holders, pledging to repurchase them at a future date. The company carried them at the original commitment value; the S.E.C. said they had to be carried at the market value. **********The Home Loan Bank Board issued a four-paragraph statement today declaring that ''relatively few institutions have engaged in this type of transaction and the impact on the industry is insignificant.'' **********It said ''institutions involved in typical reverse repurchase agreements will not be required to restate earnings based on the S.E.C. position.'' **********One official acknowledged, however, that the accounting process is ''so complicated'' that some institutions might not know whether their procedures were similar to the ones opposed by the S.E.C.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/30/busin.print_headline: YOUR MONEY; LINKED I.R.A.'S: NOTE OF CAUTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/30/busin.body_text: **********SOME people have opened a type of Individual Retirement Account known as either linked, tandem or Super I.R.A.'s. But these accounts are now under scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service and should be approached warily. **********Among the places where the accounts have been offered by commercial banks and savings institutions to local and out-of-state customers are Illinois, Wisconsin, California and Ohio. Such accounts have been heavily advertised and promoted, particularly in the January-to-April period, when most retirement accounts are opened. **********However, many thoughtful savers are not waiting until next January before starting their 1984 I.R.A.'s. They know that the sooner that funds are deposited in an I.R.A., the sooner they begin to accumulate tax-deferred interest or dividends. **********Individuals who establish retirement accounts at banks, brokerage firms, mutual fund organizations or insurance companies can contribute up to $2,000 of earned income annually, or $2,250 when there is a non-working spouse, on a tax-deductible basis. Non-penalty withdrawals from an I.R.A. can begin once an account holder reaches age 59 1/2. **********The accounts that have drawn the attention of the I.R.S. pay above-market interest rates. However, the financial institution also requires that a balance equal to the amount in the I.R.A. be kept in another account that usually is a low-yielding certificate of depositor passbook savings account or even a no-interest checking account. If the amount in such a companion account falls below the linked I.R.A. balance, the interest rate in the I.R.A. generally drops to a lower level. **********The advantage to those who open high-yielding I.R.A.'s linked to a separate low-yielding account is that the larger return on the I.R.A. is tax-deferred. For the banks, these accounts bring in additional business at little cost. **********For example, if a bank would otherwise have an annual yield of 13 percent for an I.R.A. with a particular maturity, its linked I.R.A. might yield a whopping 20 percent. But at the same time, the yield on a certifcate of deposit linked to the I.R.A. might be 6 percent annually for the same maturity. **********''It's intriguing,'' said Joe A. Mintz, the Dallas- based publisher of NROCA Press, a retirement planning newsletter. ''If I'm rewarded by a high interest rate, I don't see how I've done anything illegal. It's a tie-in sale, like the old days when you had to buy some kind of junky wine and they'd sell you a bottle of whisky.'' **********The I.R.S. may have another point of view, however. Just before the end of the peak I.R.A. selling season on April 15, its Chicago district office issued a strong warning on the accounts to financial institutions in its area. **********''The Internal Revenue Service will consider interest in excess of the regular I.R.A. rate to be taxable interest earned on the companion account,'' wrote J. R. Starkey, the district director. ''In addition, for any year in which the taxpayer has contributed the maximum allowable amount to the Super I.R.A., all 'excess' interest would be considered an excess contribution to the I.R.A. subject to a 6 percent non-deductible excise tax . . . and a 10 percent premature distribution penalty.'' **********Mr. Starkey added: ''The offering of Super I.R.A.'s must be discontinued. Failure to discontinue these plans could result in the entire I.R.A. plan being considered as not qualifying for I.R.A. treatment in any respect.'' **********This approach, believed to be the first direct attack on linked I.R.A.'s by the Federal Government, applies only to the Chicago district, since the national office of the I.R.S. has not yet ruled on the matter. Shortly after the Chicago announcement was issued, a spokesman for the I.R.S. in Washington said that a statement would soon be forthcoming, but nothing has thus far been released. Now the service will only say that ''the issue is under study and something will be coming out in the near future.'' **********W. Wesley Howard 3d, editor of the I.R.A. Reporter, a newsletter published in Cleveland, said: ''My guess is that the national office doesn't have any choice but to go 100 percent with what the Chicago district says. I.R.A.'s lie on the fringe of pension law and for better or worse, I.R.A.'s are subject to some of the areas of law affecting pensions.'' **********The linked I.R.A.'s may very well be eliminated before they become widely accepted by the public. And until a final determination is made by the I.R.S., there will continue to be doubts as to the long-range viability of this marketing tool with a perceived consumer benefit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/05/busin.body_text: **********Italy raised its official discount rate today to 16 1/2 percent from 15 1/2 percent in an effort to curb strong domestic demand for loans and to keep inflation in check. **********Unexpectedly high private credit demand, which rose at an annual rate well above Government targets in the first seven months of this year, made the increase necessary, the Treasury said. **********Treasury Minister Giovanni Goria said, ''The main aim of the measure is to cool domestic demand so as to continue reducing inflation and not allow an intolerable worsening of our foreign accounts.'' **********Price inflation fell in July to 10 1/2 percent, a 10-year low for Italy but higher than rates in major trading partners. **********Today's rate rise reversed a recent decline. The discount rate fell to 15 1/2 percent in May from 17 percent in February.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/12/busin.main_headline: Fed Ruling Spurs First Interstate Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/12/busin.print_headline: Fed Ruling Spurs First Interstate Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/12/busin.body_text: **********The First Interstate Bancorp, the nation's seventh-largest bank holding company, said today that it had asked Federal regulators to approve its plan to open 12 ''consumer'' banks in seven states. **********The request was spurred by the Federal Reserve Board's ruling two weeks ago that the U.S. Trust Corporation of New York could make consumer loans and accept consumer deposits in Florida. **********Last Thursday, the Mellon National Corporation asked to open banks in 15 cities. **********The U.S. Trust decision by the Federal Reserve barred the out-of-state offices from making commercial loans, which is prohibited under the Bank Holding Company Act, but significantly broadened the opportunities for banking across state lines. **********''We've been working on this for some time, but, certainly, the U.S. Trust decision served to speed up our timetable,'' said Paul Minch, senior vice president for public communication at First Interstate. **********First Interstate owns banks in 11 Western states, and, mostly through franchises, operates in the 23 largest metropolitan markets. The company reported $45 billion in assets at the end of 1983. **********Joseph J. Pinola, chairman and chief executive, said ''consumer'' banks were planned for Atlanta; Chicago; Boston; New York; Philadelphia; Pittsburgh; Orlando, Fla., and Austin, Dallas-Fort Worth, Houston and San Antonio, Tex. If approved, the new banks would offer checking and savings accounts, plus consumer and mortgage credit, trust and other advisory services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/10/world.main_headline: CUBA SAID TO RESIST LEAVING ANGOLA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/10/world.print_headline: CUBA SAID TO RESIST LEAVING ANGOLA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/10/world.body_text: **********Cuba has told Angola that it opposes beginning a phased withdrawal of its troops from Angola now because a settlement in southern Africa might help President Reagan's re-election prospects, Administration officials said today. **********Cuba is thought to have 25,000 to 30,000 troops in Angola. Because of its resistance to withdrawing them, State Department officials, who earlier this year were saying they were mildly optimistic about a diplomatic breakthrough, said they no longer expected an accord before the end of the year. **********The officials said their information on the Cuban position had come from third parties who had discussed the matter with the Angolans. Because of the Administration's refusal to negotiate with Cuba about southern Africa, it has been difficult for the United States to obtain a firsthand view of the Cuban position, officials said.   U.S. and Cubans Confer **********After a long debate in the Administration, however, the United States Interest Section in Havana was authorized last month for the first time to explain the American position on Angola and other southern African issues to Cuban Foreign Ministry officials, State Department officials said. ''The Cubans listened but said little,'' one official said. ''Our impression is that we won't get anywhere.'' **********The Cubans were told, an official said, that the United States was supporting efforts to gain independence for South-West Africa, also called Namibia, under United Nations auspices, and that a Cuban withdrawal from Angola, Namibia's neighbor to the north, was necessary to bring this about. **********The apparent Cuban reluctance to do anything that might seem to aid Mr. Reagan's political fortunes follows a pattern set by the Soviet Union, which has also refused to cooperate with the Administration in reducing tension and reaching agreements. **********In February, after months of diplomatic efforts, the Reagan Administration was able to put together an agreement between Angola and South Africa, which administers Namibia in defiance of the United Nations. The South Africans agreed to a phased withdrawal of their 1,500 troops from southern Angola. This was a condition set by the Angolans for progress on Namibian independence, the withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola, the withdrawal of South African troops from Namibia and the entry of United Nations forces into the area.   South Africa Has a Condition **********The South Africans have said they will be willing to go along with the United Nations plan for Namibian independence if the Cubans are withdrawn from Angola. The United States supports the South African demand as realistic. **********The South Africans have now moved their troops to the last of the agreed staging points on the Angolan side of the border, State Department officials said.  The South Africans could be out of Angola by the end of May, one official said.  This would then make the question of Cuban withdrawal acute, officials said, because nothing can happen until such a timetable is worked out. The Cubans began arriving in Angola as soon as independence was declared in November 1975 to support Government forces against rebel forces. **********In March, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola spent three days in Havana with a large delegation discussing strategy with President Fidel Castro and other Cubans. They ended their talks with a reaffirmation that they would carry out ''the gradual withdrawal'' of Cuban troops once their conditions were met. **********These conditions included the withdrawal of South African troops from Angola, acceptance of the United Nations plan and South Africa's ending its raids against Angola and its aid to Angolan rebels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/29/world.main_headline: 19 Are Killed in Fire In a Taiwan Hotel
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/29/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 19 Are Killed in Fire In a Taiwan Hotel
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/29/world.body_text: **********Nineteen people were killed today in a fire in a downtown hotel. **********The police said three of the victims died when they jumped from windows of the 14-story building. **********The police said 53 people were injured in the blaze, the worst fire in Taipei since 1966, when a fire killed 28 people in a theater. **********The police said most of the 90 guests in the 240-room Time Hotel were asleep when the fire began in a second-floor restaurant.  The cause of the blaze was under investigation, the police said. The identities of the dead were not immediately known.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/28/world.body_text: **********Rabbi Meir Kahane, who has won a seat in Parliament on a platform calling for the expulsion of all Arabs from Israel, said today that he was confident any attempt by the United States to strip him of citizenship would be unsuccessful. **********''I would advise the Government not to try,'' Mr. Kahane said. **********''We would go to court and it would be overturned. No one can lose his citizenship unless he says, 'I give it up.' '' **********On Thursday, a State Department spokesman said in Washington that it was possible Mr. Kahane could lose his citizenship under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Under United States law, ''accepting, serving in or performing the duties of any office, post or employment under the government of a foreign state'' can result in loss of citizenship if it is established that a person ''acted with the intent of relinquishing U.S. citizenship.'' **********Mr. Kahane has been arrested 20 times since coming to Israel from New York in 1971. The charges ranged from flouting police orders to inciting anti- Arab demonstrations. Mr. Kahane, a Brooklyn native, often travels to the United States and supervises Jewish Defense League activities there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/24/world.main_headline: LABOR PARTY WINS EASILY IN SOUTH AFRICAN MIXED-RACE VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/24/world.print_headline: LABOR PARTY WINS EASILY IN SOUTH AFRICAN MIXED-RACE VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/24/world.body_text: **********The Labor Party, led by a clergyman who has opposed apartheid, emerged today as the overwhelming victor in elections for the mixed-race chamber in South Africa's new three-chamber parliament. The body offers a limited political role to some nonwhite South Africans but not to the black majority. **********However, a low turnout and other factors indicated the obstacles facing the Labor Party leader, the Rev. Allan Hendrickse, in defending his participation in the South African political system. Critics assert the new Constitution upon which the parliament is based institutionalizes the ostracism of blacks and entrenches the official system of racial division. **********Mr. Hendrickse, a Congregational minister who has opposed apartheid, has said repeatedly that he agreed to take part in what the authorities call a ''new dispensation'' in order to dismantle the apartheid system from within. After Wednesday's voting, he said his task now would be to ''deliver the goods'' to his constituents. **********But South African commentators said his chances of doing so were slim, since the whites will have a veto in the new parliament and the legislation underpinning apartheid cannot be easily modified.   Party Wins 75 of 80 Seats **********With the votes for all but one seat counted, Mr. Hendrickse's party had 75 of the 80 places allocated to the 2.8 million people of mixed race - ''coloreds'' in South Africa's racial nomenclature - in the parliament that is to be introduced next month. Whites, who number 4.5 million and who have already approved the new Constitution, are given 160 seats, while the country's 800,000 Indians are to vote for their 40 seats next week. **********The black majority of more than 20 million has not been consulted about the qualified policy changes, through which the authorities are seeking to widen their political base without losing the power that the dominant Afrikaner group has exercised for 36 years. **********Despite the jubilation of Labor Party supporters, an alliance opposing the new system, the United Democratic Front, said Wednesday's voting had failed to endorse the constitutional changes and granted no legitimacy to those taking part in it. The group considers Mr. Hendrickse a traitor. **********'Unrest and Tension' Predicted **********''I cannot see how the new parliament will ever work and how continuing with it after yesterday's poll cannot cause more unrest and tension,'' said the Rev. Allan Boesak, the most prominent mixed-race opponent of the policy changes and a central figure in the pre- election campaign for a boycott of the vote. **********''The people going into the new system cannot by any stretch of the imagination talk about a mandate,'' he said. **********In Johannesburg today, an explosion thought to have been caused by a bomb destroyed offices of the Department of Education and Training, which administers the country's black schools, the police said. No injuries were reported in the blast, and there was no claim of responsibility.  According to provisional figures, less than 30 percent of the registered mixed-race voters cast ballots Wednesday. Opponents of the elections said only 60 percent of the mixed-race population had registered to vote, so the actual turnout was less than 20 percent of those eligible. **********The immediate challenge to Mr. Hendrickse is to establish the credibility of his participation in the new parliament by exacting changes from it, South African political scientists said. In doing so, he will be confronting a vast body of legislation designed to keep races and tribes apart. Many of the laws are interlocking since they cover almost every aspect of life - where people may live, whom they may marry, where their children are educated and where they are buried. **********Mr. Hendrickse plans to seek the change of laws prohibiting marriage and sexual relations between racial groups. But South African commentators said such changes would be cosmetic unless the entire structure were dismantled. **********Mr. Hendrickse, 57 years old, is widely expected to become the first nonwhite member of the Cabinet. In an interview before the elections, he said: ''Our decision to participate must merely be seen as a point of departure, not as a place of arrival. We want to see apartheid dismantled. Our decision to participate is motivated by this desire. We believe that once the first apartheid law goes, the domino principle will result in the others going too.''  No Plans to Repeal Basic Laws **********The Government, however, has stressed that it has no plans to repeal such basic aspects of apartheid as the Group Areas Act, which determines where races may live. Thus, once in office, Mr. Hendrickse may find he is obliged to share the collective responsibility for Cabinet decisions reinforcing apartheid. **********If he joins the Cabinet, Mr. Hendrickse will be sitting among those who, eight years ago, were his jailers. In late 1976, after riots in Johannesburg's black suburb of Soweto, Mr. Hendrickse was held in solitary confinement for 60 days, marking the long hours, he recalls, by a makeshift sundial in his cell. **********Mr. Hendrickse studied at Fort Hare University in South Africa, where his classmates included such African nationalists as Robert Sobukwe, founder of the Pan-Africanist Congress, and Robert Mugabe, now Prime Minister of Zimbabwe. **********Of his involvement with the new Constitution, Mr. Hendrickse has said: ''If after five years there are no clear movements away from apartheid, we will just leave this new dispensation'' and seek a mandate from mixed-race people for other strategies.   U.S. Disturbed by Arrests **********WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) - The State Department said today that it was greatly disturbed by widespread arrests of South Africans opposed to elections for mixed-race parliamentary representatives. **********Alan Romberg, a department spokesman, said the arrests ''appear to undercut the commitment to reform we consider so vital, and they represent a violation of fundamental human rights and political liberties.'' **********It was the department's second statement of concern over the arrests in two days. **********Mr. Romberg described the election process itself as flawed because South Africa's black majority remains disenfranchised. But he said the administration hoped the election would accelerate the process of change that South African authorities have promised to carry out.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/04/busin.body_text: **********In a poster welcoming international travelers to Dublin Airport, the Republic of Ireland sells its youth. Pictured are four clean-cut students strolling across the cobblestone courtyard of Trinity College; the caption reads, ''We're the young Europeans.'' **********The advertisement, part of a new campaign by the country's Industrial Development Authority to attract foreign investment, reflects Ireland's attempt to cope with an awkward, urgent problem. For Ireland's greatest selling point - a growing population of well-educated young people - is also rapidly becoming its most critical national concern. **********More than half of Ireland's population is now under 25 years of age - a demographic concern mentioned continually by economists and industrial officials here. The population has grown by 22 percent in the last 20 years, and the labor pool is now expanding at an annual rate of 1.2 percent - more than double the overall European rate. **********The result is an increasingly intractable unemployment problem. Those out of work now account for 16 percent of the labor pool, up from 8 percent five years ago, and some economists expect that the level will approach 20 percent next year. **********Large Foreign Debt **********But unemployment is only the most visible of Ireland's economic woes. Indeed, the verdant land that President Reagan toured this past weekend now faces other, less familiar challenges: Though inflation has eased from the damaging levels of three years ago, a huge public deficit remains, and external borrowing by the Government, at nearly $10 billion, now stands at two-thirds of the gross national product - its highest level ever. **********And most agree that these new problems will haunt Ireland for years. ''The problems we have aren't going to be solved in a year,'' said Joseph Durkin, an economist with D.K.M., a Dublin consulting firm. ''We're talking about the long haul.'' **********In the midst of such new economic troubles remains the old: With a per capita personal income of $3,900 in 1982, the latest year available, the Irish people are among the poorest in Europe. And now, many believe that this poverty, exacerbated by increasing personal taxes and the lack of jobs, may renew an 80-year tide of emigration that ended 20 years ago. **********''Migration used to be a bad word here,'' observed Kenneth Whitaker, once the nation's Secretary of Finance and now chancellor of the National University here. ''Now, one might see emigration not as a sad and tearful thing, but as a migration within the European community.'' **********Key Development Agency **********For the last decade, Ireland's primary weapon against unemployment and poverty has been the Industrial Development Authority, a state agency whose aggressive tactics and $225 million budget have made Ireland the most successful European nation in attracting foreign - and especially American - manufacturing investment. **********The agency's efforts have transformed a country once almost wholly dependent on agriculture. Though agriculture still accounts for 69 percent of Ireland's land, manufacturing employs about the same number of people, approximately 190,000. The biggest employment sector in the country, which has a population of about 3.5 million, is services, which accounts for 600,000 jobs. **********Today, the agency says, 850 foreign companies operate manufacturing facilities in Ireland. American investment alone over the last 25 years has totaled $4.6 billion, and American companies now provide 18 percent of all manufacturing jobs. President Reagan acknowledged that investment in a meeting during the weekend with the chief executives of the Irish subsidiaries of 19 American companies. **********The authority's new emphasis on Ireland's youth reflects an attempt to attract more service and high-technology companies - companies, the authority believes, that will provide more white-collar jobs. ''We're not looking for products that depend on cheap labor to be viable,'' said one I.D.A. executive. ''We're not going to compete with the Far East.'' **********Maximum Tax of 10 Percent **********This strategy, spiced with substantial cash grants for plant construction and a maximum corporate tax rate of 10 percent, has already had considerable success, despite the fall-off in American investment in the latest recession. **********Indeed, executives at American companies, in interviews during the weekend, most often cited the availability of relatively inexpensive, trained labor as the primary advantage of operating in Ireland. **********But economists here, while acknowledging the I.D.A.'s success, say that foreign investment is no longer enough to revitalize Ireland's economy. A proposal by the National Planning Board, published in April, called for dramatic changes in monetary and fiscal policy in the period from 1984 to 1987. **********Most believe the Government must rein in public expenditures, which last year produced a deficit of $1.1 billion, or 7 percent of G.N.P. Foreign borrowing by the public sector increased by more than 20 percent in 1983, and some expect the total will reach $11 billion next year. Debt service alone consumed 22 percent of tax revenues last year. **********''The real constraint on growth in Ireland'' is the Government's deficit problem, said Dan Flinter, chief economist for the I.D.A. ''People are still concerned about unemployment, but they recognize the need to restrain'' Government spending. **********Some see hope for significant economic improvement in Ireland as early as 1987, despite expectations that the G.N.P. will not grow at a rate much higher than last year's 2.25 percent. **********The Government has forecast that inflation will drop to 6 percent by year-end - a dramatic improvement from the 20 percent rate of 1981 - and economists predict that development of the large Kinsale gas field off the country's southern coast will have some positive economic effect within five years. **********''From 1987 or 1988 on, I'm very optimistic,'' said Dermot Sugrue, the economist at the Bank of Ireland. ''From now until then, it will be a period of readjustment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/12/busin.body_text: **********FROM the day the Standard & Poor's 100 index **********options started trading on the Chicago Board **********Options Exchange on March 11, 1983, the new market became a phenomenon for several reasons. **********For one, no other options or futures have become so popular in so brief a time as the S.&P. 100, originally named the C.B.O.E. 100 and now known in the trade by its ticker symbol OEX. Last Wednesday, for example, a record 342,297 OEX contracts changed hands, eclipsing the previous mark of 320,529 trades set on Feb. 9. Its daily average volume this year has been 224,000 contracts. **********As another example, last Wednesday the New York Futures Exchange's options on its parent's composite index traded 26,581 contracts and the American Stock Exchange's Major Market Index, 22,994. **********Also typical, the most active futures market last Wednesday was in Treasury bonds on the Chicago Board of Trade, where 195,000 contracts were traded, as well as 22,520 Treasury-bond options. Significantly, the volume of the S.&P. 500 index futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange that day was 59,289. **********''There are several ready explanations for the OEX phenomenon, which is unparalleled in the history of the options or futures markets,'' said John M. Blin, partner in Shatkin Investing Inc., Chicago, and a former economics professor at Northwestern University. ''One reason is that the OEX index of 100 stocks contains 80 percent of the richest, or most heavily capitalized shares in the S.&P.  500 index, against which the investment performance of most institutional portfolio managers are measured.'' **********Another reason, Mr. Blin said, was that many portfolio managers now believe they have found the ''handle'' that permits them to project the overall stock market's moves a few minutes before the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks confirms them. As he explained: ''The fact is that I.B.M. has become the anchor around which the market moves. So 'rich' is I.B.M. that any price change in its stock will greatly influence the popular share averages immediately. Because the OEX has only 100 stocks, including I.B.M., it responds somewhat faster than the other averages. Since the breakup of A.T.&T., I.B.M. has become, for better or worse, the bellwether issue.'' **********By ''richest,'' Mr. Blin meant that no other stock is as heavily capitalized as the International Business Machines Corporation, which has 609 million shares outstanding. At last Friday's I.B.M. close of 108, these shares were worth almost $65.8 billion. **********According to his researchers, I.B.M. represents 12.5 percent of the value of the OEX options; 6.5 percent of the S.&P. 500 index; 4 percent of the Big Board's composite index, and 9 percent of the Amex Market Value Index. **********Because the Dow Jones industrial and Value Line averages are termed ''democratic'' in that all shares are weighed equally, I.B.M.'s price represents one-thirtieth of the Dow and carries as much clout as the cheapest over-the-counter stock in the Value Line, Mr. Blin noted. **********Still another reason the OEX has become a sort of early warning indicator of how the other averages will move is the volatility of the shares in this index. All the OEX blue-chip stocks are constantly being traded, while the broader-based indexes contain many less-active issues or those that trade infrequently. **********Stewart C. Elner, vice president and director of options trading at Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc., offered another view of the OEX options: **********''Aside from the technical factors that have made the OEX the most successful product anyone can think of, we must remember that it was the first of its kind and from its first day enjoyed the expertise and liquidity of the C.B.O.E., the first stock options market. Copy-cat products rarely do as well as the first one off the mark.'' **********Mr. Elner said that the OEX options have also benefited from changes that have been sweeping the equities market. ''Investors today do not think long-term,'' he continued. ''That is why the stock options grew so popular. Now, many investors think in even shorter day-to-day terms and this may explain the incredible OEX index option market. It may also explain why the stock options volumes on the C.B.O.E. and Amex both declined 2.7 percent in 1983, a year of rising share prices.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/26/world.main_headline: Reagan Jet's Exhaust Hurts Several in Guam
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/26/world.print_headline: Reagan Jet's Exhaust Hurts Several in Guam
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/26/world.body_text: **********Several people, including a baby, suffered minor injuries when they were hit by a jet blast from President Reagan's plane shortly after the President's arrival here today. **********The aircraft, Air Force One, was taxiing to a parking position when its jet blast blew several people over and threw tables into the air, according to Nolan Hendricks, safety chairman of the Guam chapter of the American Red Cross. **********Although there was an announcement that people should get out of the way because the plane was going to be turned around, some failed to heed the warning. **********Several people who were cleaning up the tarmac area where Mr. Reagan had been welcomed were treated at the scene for minor injuries, Mr. Hendricks said. Among them was a man who had a badly bruised arm from being struck by a pole from a tent. **********A baby who had been left on a table suffered bruises from falling to the tarmac, Mr. Hendricks said. **********The President had gone into the airport terminal for a reception with Micronesian leaders at the time of the incident at 5 P.M., he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/22/busin.print_headline: ON CAMPUS: AMOS TUCK; INNOVATION THAT CROSSES CULTURAL LINES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/22/busin.body_text: **********Large-scale innovation has received little academic attention from theoreticians more concerned about smaller projects. But Tuck's Professor Quinn has attempted to determine whether the large-scale innovative process is much the same worldwide or whether it differs from culture to culture. **********Professor Quinn has studied major innovations by high-technology companies and governments in the United States (Genentech, I.B.M. and Intel), Japan (Honda, Matsushita and Sony) and Europe (the British Hovercraft and the French breeder reactor). And he has found two important themes common to most large-scale innovations - those costing many millions of dollars and having a significant impact on their environment. **********First, he said, innovation is normally the result of chance and an individual's ''flash insight'' - the kind that struck Masaru Ibuka of Sony, who was visiting the United States when Bell Labs was offered a patent for the transistor. ''He saw its ultimate potential in very small devices in the electronics field'' and went on to invent the pocket radio, Professor Quinn observed. ''In the early stages, invention itself is almost a random process.'' **********Second, in all successful innovations, a company's top management sympathizes with and involves itself in the project. ''Management knows that development is chaotic, and they allow this tumultuous, unstructured progress to go on,'' he said. ''It takes vision, but faith more than vision. And it takes a willingness to have your organization broken up and disrupted a bit.'' A conservative, financially oriented company often finds it difficult to forfeit bureaucracy for innovative chaos, he said. ''But when you're organized to do that, you get tremendous premiums.'' **********Professor Quinn noted that some companies, such as I.B.M., are good innovators even though they may not be the first to develop a particular invention. And many others are ''superbly managed'' but rarely innovate. ''They can sell a good product at a very low cost and do it very well indeed. And we need people like that - people who can turn out a well-made bar of steel.'' **********Recognized internationally as an expert in strategic planning and technology management, the 55-year-old professor has served as a consultant to leading American and foreign companies and governments. **********In 26 years at Tuck, he has designed courses in business policy, technology management and entrepreneurship, and still teaches three courses in both the fall and winter terms. For years, he has warned students about ''birdwatching'' - preparing, that is, for his ''blue eagles,'' or suprise examinations. Last semester, students in his second-year business policy class presented their mentor with ''a baby blue eaglet'' - actually, a parakeet. **********Professor Quinn, a soft-spoken man identified on campus by his perpetual bow tie, played along. He took the bird home, named it ''Stockman'' and dubbed his study the ''Office of the Management and the Budgie.'' His wife, he says, talks of acquiring a second parakeet - to ''narrow the budgie gap.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/25/world.main_headline: ARAFAT EXPECTED TO REJECT JORDAN PEACE PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/25/world.print_headline: ARAFAT EXPECTED TO REJECT JORDAN PEACE PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/25/world.body_text: **********King Hussein's call for a Middle East peace initiative based on United Nations Resolution 242 has little chance of winning approval from Yasir Arafat's wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Palestinian sources and Western diplomats said here today. **********''We're going to ignore it,'' a Palestinian official said today. ''We'll refer it to the new executive committee and drown it in a sea of speechmaking and welter of detail.'' **********Resolution 242, adopted after the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, calls on Israel to withdraw from occupied territory in return for recognition of Israel's right to exist. **********King Hussein made his call in a welcoming address to the Palestinian parliament in exile that Mr. Arafat convened here Thursday night in an effort to preserve his leadership against Syrian-backed rebels. **********Chiding the Palestinians and the Arab world in general for wasting time on disagreement, conflict and recriminations, the King invited the P.L.O. to join him in an effort for international talks under United Nations auspices. **********But he said the initiative should be based solely on Resolution 242, which has long been anathema to the Palestinian movement. **********The Palestinians object to the resolution because it treats them as refugees and makes no mention of a sovereign Palestinian state. **********P.L.O. officials have been politely noncommital in official statements on the King's proposal. The P.L.O. military chief, Khalil Wazir, better known as Abu Jihad, told reporters that the proposal would be considered by the new executive committee, whose selection is expected to be one of the last formal orders of business. **********But privately, many P.L.O. officials said they were furious. They contended that the King had usurped the limelight and put them in a difficult position. **********For Mr. Arafat's supporters, convening the Palestine National Council to reaffirm the chairman's leadership was the single issue at stake here. The meeting had been delayed by months of maneuvering in which Syria pressured other Arab nations not to act as host. **********King Hussein is trying to build a new consensus of Jordan, Egypt, Iraq, and now Mr. Arafat's supporters, to counter Syrian influence in the region. **********But the P.L.O., Palestinian sources said, was reluctant to commit itself to the King's leadership, particularly in a proposal they do not see emphasizing Palestinian sovereignty - strictly read, Resolution 242 could mean returning the Israeli-occupied West Bank to Jordan - and that they feel has little or no prospect of success. **********''The serious flaw is that Israel is not willing to give up land for peace,'' a Palestinian official said. ''This is just not talking realistically. There is no peace process.'' **********The Palestinian objections were underlined during today's session when the P.L.O.'s Foreign Minister, Farouk Kaddoumi, departed from the prepared text of his report on the P.L.O.'s history of the last year to interject, after a mention of Resolution 242, ''which we reject.'' **********In his 36-page report, Mr. Kaddoumi devoted only a page and a half to the most difficult development of the year - the rift with Syria. **********This was in keeping with the conciliatory stance taken in Mr. Arafat's opening speech in which he indicated that the rebels would be welcome to return. Mr. Kaddoumi did allow, however, that ''we have found ourselves in conflict with Syria, which has diverted our struggle against the Zionist, imperialist enemy.'' He also noted Syria's support and sympathy for the dissidents ''who have taken over our offices and institutions'' in Damascus. **********In the Syrian capital itself, the chairman of the Palestine National Council, Khaled Fahoum, who was replaced at Friday night's session of the pro-Arafat meeting, held a three-hour news conference, his second in two days, to denounce the meeting here as illegal and to say he still considered himself to be in office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The stock market's recent advance halted abruptly yesterday as prices fell moderately in slower trading. **********The Dow Jones industrial average ended the session off 5.19 points, to 1,197.77, after having climbed more than 27 points in the preceding four sessions, mainly because of declining short-term interest rates. **********In the overall market, losing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 819 to 743 as volume dropped to 82.9 million shares, from 87.6 million shares on Monday. **********Analysts noted that equities weakened yesterday after Henry Kaufman, the influential economist of Salomon Brothers, predicted that the gross national product will accelerate to an annual rate of between 4.5 percent and 5 percent in the fourth quarter and ''that short-term interest rates would rise moderately.'' **********Many of the other large banks yesterday finally responded to the move by Bankers Trust on Monday in reducing its prime rate to 12 1/4 percent, from 12 3/4 percent. However, they only lowered their rates to 12 1/2 percent, from 12 3/4 percent, and this dampened some enthusiasm. **********Most analysts are doubtful over prospects for further drops in interest rates over the near-term because of the heavy schedule of Treasury borrowing facing the credit markets in the next several days. **********Reflecting the market's weakness yesterday, the exchange's composite index lost 0.44, to 95.16, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.99, to 164.78. **********Joseph A. Feshbach, chief market analyst of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., commented that the bond market's recent rally had peaked over the near-term and would now undergo a consolidation that would probably ''put some downside pressure on equities until after the Presidential election.'' **********Contributing to the market's decline yesterday was the performance of International Business Machines, an institutional favorite, which slipped 1 1/4 points, to 121 1/4, in active trading. **********Midland Energy was under pressure yesterday, dropping 3 1/2, to 22 5/8, following the news that an offer to purchase the company by Freeport McMoran at $30 a share was oversubscribed. The latter's stock eased 1/4, to 16. **********Novo Industri lost 1, to 24 1/4, in heavy trading. The stock plunged 8 5/8 points on Monday after the Danish concern said its third- quarter sales were below expectations and that its 1984 sales would be less than expected. **********Prices on the American Stock Exchange also finished mostly lower with the market-value index off 1.02, to 211.36. In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index was off 0.40, to 247.27.

The cause of the blaze was not known.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/11/world.body_text: **********A 112-nation conference on radio broadcasting opened here today, with developing countries expected to press for greater access to the world's high-frequency airwaves. **********Delegates say the five-week meeting, organized by the International Telecommunications Union, the United Nations world broadcasting authority, is also likely to produce a sharp ideological clash over the jamming of Western broadcasts by Communist and some third world countries. **********The purpose of the gathering, known formally as the World Administrative Radio Conference, is to agree on a more effective and equitable system for apportioning the world's limited but overcrowded supply of short-wave radio frequencies, currently dominated by the West and the Soviet Union. **********These frequencies, which bounce off the ionosphere, are considered best for long-distance broadcasting and are in increasing demand as more and more countries seek to communicate their news and views to the rest of the world. More than 140 countries are broadcasting a total of 25,000 hours a day on the high-frequency wave bands, compared with only 62 countries broadcasting a total of 5,000 hours a day in 1950, according to Telecommunications Union figures. **********''The existing situation is far from satisfactory,'' Richard E. Butler, the secretary general of the Telecommunications Union, said at the opening session of the conference, urging delegates to put aside political differences and try to ''harmonize initially differing views.''  Political Implications Noted **********''Although technical, the issues we are discussing have potentially serious political implications,'' the United States representative, Leonard H. Marks, who heads a 44-member delegation, said in an interview. **********The United States and the Soviet Union, which sent 24 officials to the opening ceremony, were elected conference vice presidents at today's opening session. **********Third world nations attending the conference have already introduced a number of resolutions criticizing the present largely voluntary system for sharing the airwaves, which they say favors the richer industrial countries. **********Instead, they want a strict new planning system that would allocate each country a fixed part of the high-frequency spectrum under the control of the Telecommunications Union, in which they form a majority. **********This demand for a bigger share of the world's airwaves forms part of the ''new world information and communication order'' that third world countries are pressing for in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization as well as the Telecommunications Union and other United Nations bodies concerned with communications.   Plan Called Unworkable **********Their aim is to reduce Western dominance of international communications and establish the right of governments to control the news outlets.  Western delegates say they are anxious to help third world countries broadcast more effectively by improving the present voluntary airwave allocation system, particularly through the use of computers to select the best frequencies for individual users. But they oppose as unworkable calls for a rigid long-term allocation of airwaves by the Telecommunications Union. **********''Every effort to do this has broken down in disagreement since the end of the Second World War,'' Mr. Marks commented. **********Complicating the task of organizing access to the airwaves, delegates say, is the increasing use of ''jamming'' by Soviet bloc countries and some third world nations to prevent their citizens from hearing foreign broadcasts. **********Western nations that believe free access to information is a basic human right say they are entitled to switch to any usable frequency to get their message across if another country jams their broadcasts, even though doing so may upset international efforts to share out the wave lengths.   Dutch Introduce Resolution **********The Netherlands, which complains that Suriname, its former South American colony, is now blocking its broadcasts, has introduced a resolution condemning interference with radio communications and asserting every country's right to get round jamming by changing frequencies at will. **********At the last World Administrative Radio Conference four years ago, member countries of the Telecommunications Union agreed to increase the amount of the radio spectrum allocated to high-frequency broadcasting. But parts of the high-frequency range are virtually unusable at some times of the day, while reception everywhere has deteriorated.  Meanwhile, broadcasting authorities are using increasingly powerful transmitters to make themselves heard, squeezing out new broadcasters in the developing world, Telecommunications Union officials say. **********At present, high-frequency radio waves are allocated on a voluntary basis every four months by the Telecommunications Union, which collects members' broadcasting plans, pinpoints likely areas of overcrowding in the spectrum and then suggests alternative frequency choices. Individual countries are not bound to adopt these.   New Ways Pressed by U.S. **********As a result, Telecommunications Union officials say, the Western industrialized countries and the Soviet Union, which began high frequency broadcasting first, cannot be dislodged from the large section of the spectrum they have occupied. **********Western radio experts say the long- term answer to overcrowding in the high-frequency radio spectrum lies in the so-called ''single sidebar'' technique, which squeezes many more broadcasters into the same part of the wave band than at present. But this is expensive, requiring new transmitters and receivers. **********In the meantime, the United States, with backing from other Western countries, is proposing a number of new technical ways of making the present voluntary allocation system work more effectively, notably by the use of computers to make quick identification of promising parts of the spectrum for broadcasters to use.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/10/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********The article by Michael Jensen and Kevin Murphy (''The Flap Over Executive Pay,'' Business Forum, May 20) must surely rank as one of the more naive analyses of why corporate executives are paid so much. Professors Jensen and Murphy would have us believe that corporate salaries ''are determined by the market.'' **********In the real world a lot more than supply and demand is operating. In fact, a very subtle and highly institutionalized system of rationalizations permits corporations to pay their top executives the very high salaries that so many of them receive. **********Professors Jensen and Murphy are correct that these salaries and other lavish payments of various kinds are approved by corporate boards of directors, who are in turn elected by the corporation's stockholders. What they neglect to mention is that the elections of these boards are, for the most part, sham elections since there is rarely any real opposition to management's slate. Indeed, most corporate directors are carefully selected by corporate executives, who want people on their boards who will be sympathetic to their points of view on many matters - hardly the least of which is the matter of how much compensation top corporate officers should receive. There is indeed an old-boy network at work here, and it functions very efficiently from the point of view of top corporate executives, many of whom serve on one another's boards. **********To further rationalize the system, corporate management hires specialists to appraise how much compensation corporate executives should receive. These compensation specialists make detailed studies of what other executives are paid and generally recommend rather high salaries and other perks for top corporate officers. Should we really be surprised that they come to this conclusion when they are, in fact, hired to produce exactly that result? In fact, if these compensation specialists were to come in with low figures, the likelihood is very great that they would not be invited back to make similar studies in future years, which would, of course, adversely affect their livelihoods. **********The marketplace is not determining what top corporate executives are paid, but rather a system that enables those at the top to take care of themselves very well.  MICHAEL WHITNEY New York, May 30
