https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/06/world.body_text: **********Iraq has informed the West German Government that it is considering a request that Bonn be allowed to inspect the site of a chemical laboratory being built near Baghdad, a a Government official said today. **********But Foreign Minister Tareq Aziz of Iraq, who ended a two-day visit to Bonn today, said details and the date of such a visit had not yet been agreed upon, according to the German official. **********Bonn has been pressing Iraq to allow West Germans to inspect the site west of Baghdad where a West German company is building a laboratory for the manufacture of pesticides. **********The company, Karl Kolb, a major supplier of laboratory equipment around the world, has said that the laboratory would be for use in testing pesticides manufactured in Iraq. But American intelligence officials have said they believed the laboratory equipment was linked to Iraqi plans for nerve gas production.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/28/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, warning of a ''devastating'' effect on its earnings, petitioned the Government today to reconsider two recent decisions involving charges that long-distance carriers are to pay to local telephone exchange companies. **********In a filing tonight with the Federal Communications Commission, the company sought emergency review of commission actions it said would cut its return on interstate investment, now about 11 percent, to less than 5 percent. **********The F.C.C. decisions Feb. 15 and 17 deferred customer access charges, gave A.T& T.'s long-distance competitors a 55 percent discount in their payments to local exchange companies and permitted the local companies to set their charges at levels producing a 12.75 percent return on investment in the facilities providing connections to the long-distance network. **********A.T.& T. said that the commission's revised access plan ''threatens an economic and public policy disaster'' and that if it were to take effect the company's earnings would ''immediately be driven to confiscatory levels.'' **********A.T.& T. said it is not seeking restoration of the residential customer access charges, beginning at $2 a month, that the commission has deferred until June 1985. Rather, it asked the commission ''to reconsider the requirement that, in addition, it pay the exchange carriers for the shortfall they incur in providing the discount connections to their own facilities.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/26/busin.main_headline: RAIL PROFITS UP, BUT STOCKS SAG
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/26/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; RAIL PROFITS UP, BUT STOCKS SAG
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/26/busin.body_text: **********RAILROADS have reported surprisingly good profits for the June quarter, and their earnings are generally expected to climb in 1985. But shares of some of the nation's largest carriers sagged this week to their lowest prices in 12 months or longer. **********So far this year, railroad issues have lagged far behind even the general market's disappointing performance. As of July 18, Standard & Poor's railroad group fell 22.6 percent, compared with a decline of 8.2 percent for its 500-stock index. **********Why are rail issues acting so poorly? **********''It's a paradox,'' Stephen R. Klein, rail analyst for Standard & Poor's, said yesterday. ''Perhaps people have a tendency to sell on good news nowadays. Because of this indiscriminate selling, however, I believe that rail stocks are very close to a bottom.'' **********He continued, ''Issues that appear attractive at these price levels include Burlington Northern, CSX Corporation, Norfolk Southern and Santa Fe Southern Pacific.'' **********In yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange, most rail issues showed fractional gains. **********Union Pacific is another stock that registered a 12-month low this week. Mr. Klein is not so favorably inclined toward Union Pacific, he said, ''because I'm cool on energy.'' Oil and gas are major profit contributors at Union Pacific. **********Richard Fischer, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, carries an ''O.K. to buy'' opinion on all five stocks for the intermediate term (up to one year). In addition, he rates both CSX and Union Pacific as outright ''buys'' for the long pull.  Robert D. Long, who follows railroads for the First Boston Corporation, has expressed a view for some time that ''rail stocks represent excellent value in the current market.'' His favorite, he said yesterday, is Santa Fe Southern Pacific. ''Directors recently approved a repurchase program of 10 million shares, and that limits the downside risk in the stock,'' he said. **********In relation to the rest of the stock market, Mr. Long added, railroads have fallen to their lowest level in several years. ''Fundamentals are no problem for this industry,'' he said. ''Declines in railroad stock prices simply mean that many investors don't want to own cyclical issues.'' **********Moreover, specific factors are seen as affecting individual railroad stocks. CSX and Norfolk Southern are characterized by analysts as ''Eastern coal railroads.'' Coal shipments have increased because of the specter of a strike by coal miners, so recent strong railroad profits may represent borrowing from the future. **********Robert B. Claytor, chairman and chief executive officer of Norfolk Southern, alluded to this factor Tuesday in announcing a second-quarter earnings gain of 42.4 percent from a year earlier. ''Some of the increased coal revenues,'' he said, ''undoubtedly reflect stockpiling in anticipation of a possible coal miners' strike in the fall.'' **********One negative factor at Burlington Northern, some analysts say, is the competition the road faces, starting in August, from a rival coal carrier in the Powder River Basin of Wyoming. As a result, some analysts expect the company to show flat, or possibly a bit lower, earnings next year. **********But Mr. Long of First Boston disagrees with such a forecast. ''I expect Burlington to earn $7 a share this year and $7.50 in 1985,'' he said. **********Earlier this year, in appraising rail stock performance, Mr. Fischer of Merrill Lynch noted that the entire group, led by companies rich in natural resources, ''recorded very favorable relative price action'' in 1979 and 1980 when energy stocks were climbing. In 1981 and the first half of 1982, stocks of most ''pure'' railroads continued to advance while the ''resource'' railway companies generally declined.  ''During the second half of 1982 and for three quarters of 1983,'' Mr. Fischer said, ''the rail group again substantially outperformed the market.'' Over that extended period, railroads benefited greatly from legislative and regulatory changes that increased the industry's operating freedom while improving its financial condition, according to the analyst. **********One odd facet of the present railroad picture is this: The Penn Central Corporation, which made history by going bankrupt as a railroad system, has been making impressive gains in the stock market. It rose one point yesterday, to 46 7/8. Penn Central, now widely diversified in several industries, indicated this week that it would buy back about 25 percent of its outstanding common stock under terms of a recent repurchase offer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/03/busin.body_text: **********4 Nuclear Utilities Seek $1 Billion Standby Loan **********Four utility companies said yesterday that they were seeking up to $1 billion in contingency funds to assure the completion and operation of joint nuclear power plant projects. **********The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company, the Toledo Edison Company, the Ohio Edison Company and the Duquesne Light Company are looking for the funds to continue work on the first unit of the Perry Nuclear Power Plant in North Perry, Ohio, and the Beaver Valley No. 2 plant in Shipping Port, Pa. **********Lee Bailey, a spokesman for Cleveland Electric, said the companies would not need the money until 1985 or 1986. But he said they were seeking the funds to demonstrate to the financial community that not all electric utilities involved in nuclear projects were in financial trouble. **********''This is an opportunity to separate ourselves from utilities that have had financing difficulties,'' he said. **********The $3.5 billion Perry unit, which Mr. Bailey said was 94 percent completed, is about 31 percent owned by Cleveland Electric. Toledo Edison holds a 20 percent stake in the utility, while Duquesne Light has a 13.7 percent share and Ohio Edison a 35.2 percent share. **********The Beaver Valley No. 2 unit is a $3.4 billion project that is about 90 percent completed. With a 41.9 percent share, Ohio Edison has the largest stake in the project, followed by Cleveland Electric with 24.5 percent, Toledo Edison with 19.9 percent and Duquesne Light with 13.7 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/world.body_text: **********Soviet forces trying to capture an Afghan guerrilla leader, Ahmad Shah Masood, killed 200 to 300 of his rebels this month, Western diplomats said here today. **********The attack in the Upper Panjshir Valley came on Sept. 5 as part of a new Soviet effort to crush resistance in the former rebel stronghold north of Kabul, they told reporters. **********The diplomats said a witness had told them that Soviet soldiers kidnapped several women and girls from Ghazni on Sept. 9, stripped them and then threw them from helicopters hovering over the eastern Afghan city. **********They had no further details and the report, the second account of Afghans' being pushed from Soviet helicopters in three months, could not be independently confirmed. **********NEW DELHI, Sept. 18 (Reuters) - Three senior Afghan state airline employees defected here today, protesting what they called the killing of innocent civilians by Soviet and Afghan security forces. The three airline employees were the entire Afghan staff at the New Delhi office of Ariana Airlines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/01/busin.body_text: **********IT will be five years - on July 11, to **********be exact - since Rand V. Araskog, son of a Fergus Falls, Minn., dairy farmer, took over the reins of ITT, the telecommunications giant whose electronic wires span the globe. Mr. Araskog had the tough job of succeeding Harold Geneen, the legendary conglomerate builder who molded ITT into a $21 billion behemoth. But what Mr. Geneen brought together, Mr. Araskog has torn asunder, creating a trimmer, yet still troubled, ITT **********In his tenure as ITT's chairman and chief executive, Mr. Araskog has lopped off more than 65 companies and raised some $1.2 billion in the process, substantially cut ITT's ballooning debt and simplified ITT's unwieldy bureaucracy. For this, he has received high marks. But Wall Street eagerly awaits Mr. Araskog's next act. And, ITT's poor showing in the stock market is a measure of a widespread belief that not much else is waiting in the wings. **********''This is no time for Araskog to rest on his laurels,'' said Harry Edelson, a technology analyst with the First Boston Corporation. ''He's got to do something from here on out. It's time for the company to be reinvigorated. He's sold the cats and dogs. Let's get into the horses.'' Added Brian R. Fernandez, an analyst with Nomura Securities, ''To get a real spark of renewed investor interest, you need either a divestiture or operations will have to turn around.'' **********But ITT is so huge that Mr. Araskog's next move will have to be a stunner to have any impact. He sits at the pinnacle of an empire that resembles a Hollywood version of the multinational mega-corporation. ITT is the king of telecommunications overseas and is just beginning to break into the American market, newly opened to all comers after the A.T.& T. divestiture. Its insurance and information operations include the Hartford Insurance Group and the electronic mail system used by the White House. And it has a grab bag of other diverse businesses including Rayonier forest products, Sheraton hotels, Scott lawn products and the Continental Baking Company, maker of Wonder Bread and Hostess Twinkies. **********ITT is a sleek corporate world where Mr. Araskog jets to meetings h Brussels, London, Washington and New York in a turquoise-and-white 12-passenger Gulfstream III. He meets monthly with his 80 senior lieutenants in a corporate board room of microphones and maps, a setting that looks like everyone's fantasy of a Pentagon war room. Yet behind this facade of high-stakes finance is a company burdened by problems in many important lines of its business. Mr. Araskog refused to be interviewed for this article, but analysts and others familiar with his sprawling domain were, for the most part, critical and impatient with ITT's lumbering progress of late. **********THE company's much-heralded foray into the wild and woolly American electronics market has been characterized as tepid, at best. The strong dollar continues to push down ITT's earnings from abroad, the source of over half its pre-tax income. Storm-related losses - some $15 million from one East Coast storm last March alone - have battered the Hartford Group, ITT's single biggest income source. And, many of its businesses are only marginally profitable: Pretax profit margins in 1983 plunged to 1.3 percent for insurance, were a scant 4.2 percent for hotels and 4.5 percent for bakery operations, and even its core telecommunications business returned only 7.8 percent. **********All the while, Wall Street continues to clamor for ITT to sell even more low-performing businesses in order to raise the cash to further pay down its still-sizable debt and to fund its brighter prospects. In the 1984 first quarter, ITT's earnings fell to 52 cents a share, from 92 cents in the previous first quarter. Analysts have recently been lowering ITT's 1984 earnings estimates to less than the $4.50 that ITT earned in 1983 on sales of $20.2 billion. ''I've described ITT to my clients as either a permanent mediocrity or a turnaround that won't happen,'' said one analyst, who declined to be named. ''On paper, they seem to have a lot of strengths. But those strengths don't seem to pay off.'' **********ITT has made much ado lately about cracking the American telecommunications market, which accounts for about 40 percent of the world market. American telecommunications is the promised land for ITT - it feels it can parlay its overseas expertise in making telephone switching equipment and office switchboards onto American soil. But, to date, ITT has barely gotten its foot in the door.  Most of its domestic sales have been in basic telephones, some 5 million or 20 percent of the market, in 1983 alone. At the high ticket end of the market, its products are few - and dated - and many analysts say that ITT hasn't shown much appetite for competitive battles. Instead, aggressive competitors like Canada's Northern Telecom and Western Electric have left ITT in the dust in critical product areas. **********''ITT is a company that's blown more telecommunications opportunities in the last 10 years than any other company,'' said Harry Newton, president of Telecom Library Inc., a telecommunications research group. ''ITT has faced the same opportunities that hundreds of newcomers have faced in this industry. But ITT has not had the resources or management focus or attention or discipline to do anything.'' **********The company has done poorly in the $3 billion-a-year market for new central office switching systems used by phone companies. It spent over $1 billion to develop its new digital switching product, the 1240, a state-of-the- art entry that has been rolling up sales overseas. But ITT must still pump millions more into the 1240 to adapt it for the American market and the product may not even be available here until 1986. ITT's domestic version, the 1210, is considered the Cadillac of the industry here, but is so expensive that it has fared badly in the face of aggressive competition. In the market for PBX's, automated switchboards critical to the offices of the future, ITT offers only a single low- end product that must do battle in the most competitive end of this market, also estimated to be in the $3 billion range. **********''They've not done well in the central office market or in PBX's, which is the fastest-growing market,'' said William Ambrose, an analyst with Northern Business Information, a research group. ''They offer products of old design and they haven't been quick to react. There going to have to come up with some new products soon or they'll be in big trouble.'' **********MANY of ITT's woes can be traced to its legacy as a supplier to governments and not a marketer to end users. ITT's telecommunications sales overseas have been largely to government agencies. As a result, ITT is well schooled in the ways of wooing governments, but not in facing stiff rivals in wide-open markets. And ITT is being forced to develop these new skills in one of the most turbulent areas of American business. ''They've never had to position themselves in this market and they've never had to face this intense competition,'' said Robert Sullivan, an analyst with Paine Webber. Added Mr. Ambrose: ''They've never had to understand what the end user wanted. They had to understand what the governments wanted and then engineer it to those standards.'' **********ITT, however, shrugs off such remarks. ''There's no reason to believe we won't do well in the American market,'' said M. Cabell Woodward Jr., chief financial officer of ITT ''We've only been up and operating here for a short time, but our worldwide telecommunicatons effort is going well and I would be suprised if we didn't do well here.'' Mr. Woodward pointed to a few recently placed orders - a $150 million sale to United Telephone of Florida of a 1240 system and sales of other equipment to four of the seven Bell operating companies - as evidence of ITT's success. **********ITT is also moving into computers, where it faces many problems as well. The company has gotten low marks for its highly advertised entry into personal computers, the ITT XTRA, an I.B.M.-compatible machine that has been dubbed just another ''me-too'' product in an already crowded field. Tough competition has already forced ITT to slash prices of the XTRA by 20 percent - even before shipping it to stores. ''ITT will have a battle royal on its hands and there's no telling whether they will win,'' said Ulric Weil, a technology analyst with Morgan Stanley. ''This is not the best of times to be a new entry and it is still a fairly hostile environment for I.B.M.-compatible PC's. There are some 50 companies making them and ITT will be going against the likes of A.T.& T., Sperry and I.B.M. The fact that ITT has had to cut prices already shows how treacherous these waters are.'' **********But if Mr. Araskog is having to wade through treacherous waters outside his doors, he's been successful in calming the internal storms left by Mr. Geneen. The lanky Mr. Araskog is widely described as a mild- mannered man of military bearing - in contrast to Mr. Geneen who had the reputation of an overbearing autocrat who ruled through intimidation. Mr. Araskog has gone a long way toward reshaping the culture of a global corporation that carried the personal imprint of Mr. Geneen, for good or bad. In the Geneen era, the company gained notoriety for its political involvement: The famed memo of ITT lobbyist Dita Beard that reportedly implied that Mr. Geneen had used his pocketbook to influence the Nixon White House and Mr. Geneen's attempt to work with intelligence agencies to overthrow the government of Salvador Allende in Chile. **********To the relief of many employees, Mr. Araskog has done away with such Geneen trademarks as the huge corporate meetings in which employees were dressed down in front of the group. Mr. Araskog has also reorganized ITT's hundreds of businesses into four main divisions - corporations in their own right - and has decentralized decision-making and pushed it down into the operating level. He has made ITT more efficient, if a little duller. **********''Instead of a razzamatazz conglomerate doing a deal a minute and having the financial people pirouetting, the atmosphere of ITT is one of a tighter, more traditional business organization,'' said Mr. Fernandez. ''It's less based on star magnetism and more on back to basics. To the outside, the culture used to be one of working 18 hours a day and having an answer to every question. It almost appeared as if internal performance was as important, if not more important, than business acheivement. Araskog reorganized all that and brought the company to a more normal form.'' **********FROM the beginning, Mr. Araskog tried to set a different tone and worked to shrink a corporation that had become overblown in the days of cheap money and conglomerate building. In his first major decision, Mr. Araskog stopped construction of an ill-fated mill by Rayonier and accepted a $320 million write-off. Then, he sold a European foods business and a domestic telecommunications business that had been tied to poor contracts, restructured a troubled Florida condominium development, and backed the company out of coal operations. All totaled, the 65 companies divested by Mr. Araskog had combined sales of more than $2 billion, which accounts at least partly for ITT's drop in sales. **********Mr. Araskog also had to stand by and watch ITT be manhandled by the French, who decided to nationalize ITT's French operations and give the company only $50 million for properties that had been independently appraised by Merrill Lynch at $360 million. ITT has also been selling portions of other overseas investments to local investors, most recently 65 percent of its United Kingdom operations and 20 percent of its Norwegian businesses. **********Sales of ITT's more esoteric - or underperforming - businesses have provided it with much-needed cash to finance its core businesses and slice its still-heavy debt burden. ITT has cut its debt from 42 percent of total capitalization at the end of 1979 to about 38.5 percent today. Analysts, however, contend that ITT still has a long way to go and that it may be mortgaging its future if it doesn't start pulling in more cash through divestitures. **********They point out that ITT's investments in its own businesses have fallen from $1 billion in 1981 to about $825 million in 1983, while its research and development costs have remained steady at $1 billion. They note that the company's long-term debt is still a hefty $4 billion and that it owes about $1.4 billion in short-term borrowings. Since ITT's tax bill is substantially reduced by investments in tax shelters, the carrying costs on this debt hit heavily on the bottom line. And, ITT's cash position has steadily fallen over the last three years, from $143 million in 1981 to $118 million in 1983. ''Araskog is facing some difficult strategic choices,'' said Normura's Mr. Fernandez. ''At the present time, he has too many areas of opportunity to fund and he doesn't want to starve some growth companies. He's going to have to make some difficult choices.'' **********Mr. Araskog has already fumbled the ball at least once and many wonder whether he is even going to try to get to bat again. He tried to sell the Rayonier forest products division in late 1982. But, after getting a bid for the company, Mr. Araskog decided to put Rayonier on the auction bloc to see if he could get a better price. While investment bankers and lawyers spent valuable time tinkering with their calculators, timber prices collapsed, interest rates zoomed and the chance to do the deal died. Since then, Mr. Araskog has not made any other major sales, although ITT's Mr. Woodward contends the divestiture program is coming along quite smartly. ''All I can tell you is that we are committed to divesture and hope to have more completed by the end of the year,'' he said, while declining to say exactly what would be up for sale. The company has hinted that it may have a major announcement - perhaps along these lines - later this month. **********Wall Street would like to see some major sales - Sheraton, Continental Baking, some of the auto parts companies and Rayonier. ''Earnings in some of these cyclical companies are peaking. If he's going to do it, now is the time,'' said Mr. Edelson of First Boston. ''It's reasonable to sell some of the larger businesses, now that the smaller ones are gone.'' And many cannot understand why Mr. Araskog is not exhibiting his earlier toughness - whether he is, once again, waiting too long for the top dollar to arrive or whether he has simply lost his will and succumbed to the huge bureaucracy. Much of this concern is reflected in ITT's stock price; while rival A.T.&.T. trades at a multiple of 12, ITT shares are priced at only 8 times earnings. Should Mr. Araskog not make a major sale, ITT is expected to continue to lumber on with lackluster earnings and uninspired profitability. And divestitures may be the only road to salvation. ''It's not only desirable that he sells these businesses,'' said Paine Webber's Mr. Sullivan. ''It's essential.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/11/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Trade Commission gave final approval to Texaco Inc.'s purchase of the Getty Oil Company for $10.1 billion. The F.T.C. in February tentatively approved the merger and allowed Texaco to buy Getty stock but said Texaco would have to divest itself of some assets to end antimonopoly objections to the merger. **********In today's 4-to-1 vote approving the merger, the F.T.C. allowed Texaco to keep a refinery in Kansas by selling the Wyco oil pipeline that serves the West. Kansas officials had complained to the F.T.C. that a buyer might not be found to keep the refinery operating. Michael Pertschuk was the only commissioner to oppose the merger, the second-largest corporate acquisition in United States history. In the largest, the Standard Oil Company of California, now known as the Chevron Corporation, agreed in April to buy the Gulf Corporation for $13.4 billion. F.T.C. approval of that is pending. With the acquisition of Getty, Texaco remains the third-largest United States oil company after the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/02/world.body_text: **********In the last year, the third year of southern Africa's worst recorded drought, Zimbabwe's peasant farmers - those who through the ages have produced little more than what they needed for themselves - brought to market more food and other crops than ever before. **********It was still a drought year, and one of black Africa's few food-exporting countries once more fell short of the needs of its eight million people. Zimbabwe will have to import, or get in aid, plenty of its staple food, corn, as well as most of the wheat for its cities' bread-eaters. **********But as the beginning of the rainy season raises slight hopes for an end to the drought and a normal growing season for 1984-85, Zimbabwe can reflect on an accomplishment that sets it apart from the rest of a continent whose farmers every year produce less food for more mouths than in the preceding year. **********'Where We Scored' **********It has weathered three dangerously lean years not only because of the expertise of its 4,400 owners of large, modern commercial farms, a carryover of the white-minority rule that ended in 1980, but also because of a dramatic increase in the productivity of its 800,000 to 900,000 peasant farmers. **********''That's where we scored,'' said Agriculture Minister Denis Norman, himself a successful farmer and president of the Commercial Farmers' Union before he became the only white Cabinet member. **********A bit of good luck helped. A harvest that appeared headed for catastrophe when last winter's rains never came was partially salvaged by an unexpected spring rainfall. A corn harvest that had been estimated at 560,000 tons - about a third of a good year's crop - has yielded 925,000 so far, with more still trickling in, Mr. Norman said in an interview in his Senate office. **********Forty-one percent of this total came from the communal, small-scale farmers, the ebullient Mr. Norman continued, jumping up to fetch a pile of statistics from his briefcase. ''We expected 100,000 tons from them - we've got 378,000 so far,'' he said. ''It will reach 400,000.''  A Beacon of Realism **********On a continent over which recurrent droughts, the spreading of its great deserts and population growth unmatched by increases in food production have cast a pervasive sense of helplessness and hopelessness, Zimbabwe is a beacon of buoyancy and realism. **********Unlike most African leaderships, the Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugable did not hide the facts of drought and the threat of famine from its people and the world at large. It cooperates with the governments and private organizations that provide relief, but has not abandoned to outsiders its task of helping those affected by drought. **********''We have a lot of external aid, but we put the program together ourselves,'' Mr. Norman said. ''When you have a viable program it's easy to get the money.'' **********What the official described was a program that African governments shorter on political will, administrative efficiency and functioning public services have been unable to conceive or afford to put into effect.   Food for Work **********''We had a fairly wealthy stock in hand when drought started,'' Mr. Norman said. ''What we did was first a food-relief program for the outlying regions - the farther you are from the center, the worse things were. We distributed free food, then we changed food for work - roads, wells, all things that will help produce more food. **********''For two years running,'' he said, ''we have been distributing packages of seeds, fertilizer and other chemicals and minimal tools - the requirements to grow another crop for the man who had nothing left. This covered 140,000 families. **********''This solves many problems. Above all, it restores a man's self-respect. He provides for himself and his family. No apathy.'' **********''I don't think we had famine anywhere,'' Mr. Norman went on. ''We had a bit of malnutrition here and there.'' **********This view is shared by international relief workers and diplomatic specialists here, with the reservation that the Government seemed less ready to send timely relief to Matabeleland in the south, where Mr. Mugabe's opponents are in armed resistance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that, despite emergency efforts to relieve a huge backlog in phone installations for businesses, unfilled orders grew more than 16 percent last month. **********The company, in a monthly report to the Federal Communications Commission that seemed to confirm widespread reports of worsening telephone service, said that by the end of June it had 41,700 unfilled orders nationwide for private lines, up from 35,800 in May. It also said that the percentage of orders completed on the date promised - a figure that almost always exceeded 95 percent before divestiture took place Jan. 1 - fell to 22.8 percent in June, down from 23.2 percent in May. **********D. J. Culkin, A.T.&T.'s corporate vice president, said the company had yet to ''turn the corner'' on the problem because of a surge of new orders. **********New York Problems Acute **********While no statistics for the New York area were available, A.T.&T. officials said all evidence indicated that problems for businesses here remained acute. **********Yesterday's report prompted new concern that the telephone company's problems would have a sharp effect on customers, who have complained that their businesses have been hurt by their inability to expand or repair telephone lines. And for the first time, one of the five members of the Federal Communications Commission suggested that Government intervention could be necessary. **********The commissioner, Henry M. Rivera, said in a statement: ''In view of this continuing business service deterioration, we must now begin seriously to consider whether a regulatory response is needed to avoid the dire consequences that may lie ahead. Our legislative mandate requires no less.'' **********An Active Role Suggested **********Mr. Rivera, who was traveling in Switzerland yesterday and was unavailable to answer questions, suggested in his statement that the commission take ''an active coordination role'' in reducing the backlog. **********He also hinted that the F.C.C. might have permitted deregulation to go too far, and he urged that the commission consider requiring the ''industry to focus on providing reliable, high-quality basic service before permitting nontraditional business opportunities.'' **********But Mr. Rivera's statement did not specify what actions the commission should take. In addition it is unclear what jurisdiction the commission has over the company's nontelephone-related services. **********Industry analysts and F.C.C. staff members said yesterday that they doubted that Mr. Rivera - one of two Democrats on the Republican-controlled commission - would persuade the other members to intervene strongly in what some termed a ''service crisis.'' **********Comment by F.C.C. Official **********''We have a healthy understanding of our limitations, and I have no reason to believe the Government can do it any better,'' said Michael Slomin, legal assistant to the head of the F.C.C.'s Common Carrier Bureau, which oversees long-distance service. **********He said that ''the problem is a people problem - information is still not being passed correctly'' between A.T.&T. and the operating companies, each of which is now involved in different aspects of installing new private lines, or repairing existing installations. **********Mr. Slomin and others noted that the commission had stepped up the pressure on A.T.&T., asking for more detailed information about its performance and warning of possible action if it failed to resolve some basic issues - such as agreement on a single ordering form to be used nationwide for companies seeking service. **********Deadlock Broken by Staff **********F.C.C. officials say the details of such a form were agreed upon only after commission staff members threatened to draft it themselves to break a deadlock among the operating companies and A.T.&T. **********Although the problems for private line service worsened, A.T.&T. said yesterday that the percentage of orders completed on time for WATS service, including the installation of new toll-free 800 numbers, improved in June. And Donald F. McLaughlin, an A.T.&T. spokesman in New York, said that the number of private-line orders actually filled last month was 15,800, about 1,100 more than in May. **********He added that the A.T.&T. ''strike force,'' recently assembled to coordinate efforts to reduce the backlog, had made agreements among the various operating companies integrating their order-taking operations with A.T.&T.'s. **********Bigger Program for Users Separately, A.T.&T. said it was expanding its ''Opportunity Calling'' program, in which long-distance users get discounts on goods and services in proportion to their telephone expenditures, so that businesses may also receve benefits. Among the incentives for businesses to use A.T.&T. instead of a long-distance rival, the company said, would be discounts on air courier services and office equipment. **********In another action, the Conrac Corportation said it had reached a settlement with A.T.&.T. and the operating companies over a civil antitrust lawsuit filed in April 1982. Conrac said it would receive $24 million in payments over the next six years. **********Dispute Over Assets **********WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) - The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has disclosed that it is locked in a dispute with its former Bell System subsidiaries over conflicting claims to assets totaling more than $3 billion. **********A.T.&T. has filed a 46-page ''motion for declaratory ruling'' here with United States District Judge Harold H. Greene. In the motion, A.T.&T. says the seven regional Bell companies created with its Jan. 1 breakup are demanding payments totaling $3 billion. The claims were submitted, A.T.&T. added, after it filed a claim of its own requesting payments from the Bell companies totaling roughly $659 million. **********Both claims are based on the complex reorganization plan used six months ago to divide the assets and debts of the companies. **********According to A.T.&T.'s brief on the dispute, however, the seven regional companies that were spun off Jan. 1 are ignoring the reorganization plan approved by Judge Greene by trying to reopen the entire question of the assets to which they were entitled at the time of the breakup. **********Those companies, in a joint filing of their own, countered that their claims were based on the fact that A.T.&T. had failed to share any of a $5 billion working capital fund with them at the time of the breakup.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/04/busin.body_text: **********Construction spending rose in October for the first time in five months, climbing 1.7 percent, the Commerce Department said today. **********Total construction spending increased to an annual rate of $315.8 billion, the department said. The gain followed declines in June, July and September. In August, spending was unchanged from the July level. **********While mortgage and other interest rates have fallen since September, economists were divided about whether the construction increase in October heralded a rebound. **********Finishing Before Winter **********Michael Sumichrast, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said construction spending benefited from an effort to finish projects before winter. **********''This gain was a weak number,'' he said. ''It tells me that construction spending in future months will be considerably weaker.'' **********But Robert Ortner, chief economist for the Commerce Department, called the October increase ''very encouraging.'' Mr. Ortner said that the October level was 1.7 percent above the average from July through September. **********''With interest rates back down to where they were in the beginning of the year,'' he said, ''the worst of the problems in home construction may be behind us.'' **********First Rise Since May **********The October increase in overall spending was the first since a 2.5 percent jump in May. It left total spending 18 percent above the total in October 1983. **********In October, residential construction rose 2.1 percent to an annual total of $134 billion. An 8.7 percent jump in apartment construction offset a 1.6 percent decline in spending on single- family homes. **********Nonresidential construction was up 1.8 percent to an annual total of $79.1 billion. The increase was led by a 3.7 percent gain in office construction and a 3.3 percent rise in spending for other commercial structures. Industrial plant construction was down 2 percent. **********Government construction spending rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $57.8 billion. Big increases were recorded in spending on water supply facilities, which rose 20.7 percent, and hospital construction, which was up 15.9 percent from September.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/world.main_headline: 6 NATIONS TO FORM JOINT GULF FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/world.print_headline: 6 NATIONS TO FORM JOINT GULF FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/world.body_text: **********The leaders of Saudi Arabia and five Persian Gulf nations announced tonight that they had agreed to establish a rapid deployment force to help defend themselves against external military threats. **********The statement was made by Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Deputy Prime Minister of Kuwait, who was host of the three-day conference. It was the fifth such meeting of the six-member group of oil- producing nations, known collectively as the Gulf Cooperation Council. **********Sheik Sabah, who spoke at a news conference, provided few details about the group's new military cooperation effort. But he said the force would include all six member nations - Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Oman - and would have a unified command. He also suggested that it would not be a permanent standing force. **********'A Limited Period' **********''It will have a mandate for a limited period of time,'' Sheik Sabah, said. The mandate will be reviewed periodically, he added. **********Shiek Sabah stressed that the new force would not be used to counter internal subversion in one of the gulf nations, but rather would be used to thwart an ill-defined ''emergency that threatens any gulf state.'' **********He declined to specify whether the force would be based in one location, how many troops would be involved or which nation would command it. **********But other officials said each member nation had agreed to earmark several units that would be activated only for joint military training exercises and in the event of a threat to a Gulf Cooperation Council nation. **********The emergency force will number 10,000 to 13,000 troops, the officials said. It will be commanded by a Saudi general who was recently assigned to the council's secretariat.   Goal: To Deter Aggression **********Abdullah Yaqub Bishara, Secretary General of the Gulf Cooperation Council, said the force was intended to help deter aggression against gulf nations. **********''It's a symbolic expression,'' he told reporters after the meeting ended. **********Several officials said the creation of the force was a tentative, but natural, step in the council's effort to improve military cooperation and coordination. This effort has been stimulated, they said, by the threat posed by the Iran- Iraq war, now in its fifth year. **********The conservative gulf nations have been particularly concerned about terrorist threats and possible military aggression by the radical Shiite Moslem regime in Iran. The Gulf Cooperation Council nations, although professing neutrality, have supported Iraq in the protracted conflict. **********Some officials said the force fell short of the kind of standing military unit that some had sought but that others, they acknowledged, had feared.   No Mention of Air Defense **********Sheik Sabah made no mention of a plan to provide a coordinated air-defense system for the gulf. Asked tonight whether the emergency force would be able to protect shipping, he replied, ''We are not one of the superpowers.'' **********Diplomats and Gulf Cooperation Council officials said political differences among member nations and technical incompatibilities in their defense systems continued to hamper military coordination. **********Last summer, for example, when stepped-up fighting between Iran and Iraq threatened gulf shipping, the United States offered Kuwait computer equipment that would give the country instant access to data collected by Saudi Arabia's American-supplied Awacs radar planes. But Kuwait has been unable to work out a satisfactory arrangement on the proposed data- sharing with the Saudis, diplomats here said. **********The conference's focus was also far narrower than many of the group's activists had desired. The meeting did not officially discuss, as Egypt had hoped, growing sentiment in the region for Arab nations to follow Jordan's lead and restore diplomatic ties with Cairo. Diplomats said Saudi Arabia, the council's most powerful member, strongly objected to placing the issue on the meeting's agenda. **********Although the council appealed for an end to the Iran-Iraq war and called on Iran to submit to mediation, it stressed that the gulf nations would not launch a new initiative unless there was some signal from Iran that it would be receptive to their mediation.   Indirect Backing for Arafat **********The council did provide an indirect endorsement to Yasir Arafat and his faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which ended its National Council meeting tonight in Amman, Jordan. The council repeated its support for the ''legality of the P.L.O. as the sole legal representative of the Palestinian people.'' Syria had denounced Mr. Arafat and charged that the Amman assembly was illegal. **********In his farewell address tonight, Sultan Qaboos bin-Said, leader of Oman, hinted at the disappointment some gulf activists felt about the tentative steps taken by this year's meeting. He acknowledged that the council's achievements might appear ''modest in comparison to our expectations.'' **********But he and other gulf leaders maintained that since its creation four years ago in Abu Dhabi, the Gulf Cooperation Council had evolved into a more cohesive group and was now one of the few Arab forums that is not paralyzed by bitter internal feuds. **********Last year, council officials held 65 ministerial-level meetings on political, economic and military cooperation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/20/world.body_text: **********The most powerful earthquake ever recorded in Britain shook buildings, toppled chimney pots and rattled the breakfast teacups today in western Britain and along the east coast of Ireland. **********Ambulance crews reported that a 64- year-old woman injured her back when she fell down stairs at Weston-super- Mare on the Bristol Channel. **********Two women were treated for shock in Liverpool when a chimney pot crashed through their roof. **********Earthquakes are rare in Britain. In 1884, before the Richter scale was introduced, a major earthquake damaged buildings at Colchester in Essex. Britain's most recent previous quake, on April 15, cracked some buildings in Wales. **********''This is pretty large by British standards,'' said Terry Turbitt, a seismologist at the Institute of Geological Science in Edinburgh. ''You would only expect a tremor of this size every 100 years or so.'' **********He added, ''The epicenter was probably between Porthmadog and Caernarvon in northwest Wales and the tremor measured around 5.5 on the Richter scale.'' A severe earthquake would measure more than 7 on the scale. **********Today's quake, which struck at 8 A.M., was felt at police headquarters in Glasgow and on top of the Royal Free Hospital in Hampstead, London. **********There have been no recorded earthquake fatalities in Britain. Ian Mercer, a geologist at the Geological Museum in London, said he and his staff looked up every earthquake recorded in Britain over the past 1,000 years ''and no one was ever killed.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/02/busin.body_text: **********The nation's money market mutual funds again reported record asset growth for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. **********The assets grew by $1.44 billion, to $195.61 billion, making last week the eighth consecutive week of record growth, the institute said. **********All three categories of money market funds increased, the institute said, with the 83 broker dealer funds reporting their largest weekly jump this year, rising $1.06 billion, to $85.63 billion. The 184 general purpose funds increased $280 million, to $61.53 billion, while the 68 institutional funds climbed by $102 million, to $48.45 billion. **********The asset level for the week was the highest reported since Feb. 2, 1983, the institute said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/15/busin.main_headline: ON TV AND IN NOVELS, THE BAD GUY SELLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/15/busin.print_headline: ON TV AND IN NOVELS, THE BAD GUY SELLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/15/busin.body_text: **********ON CBS's ''Dallas,'' the scoundrelly businessman J. R. Ewing flashes his villainous smile. On ABC's ''Dynasty,'' the oil- industry wheeler-dealer Alexis Carrington is vengeful and destructive. **********In Sidney Sheldon's long-time best- seller, the novel ''Master of the Game,'' the main character, Kate Blackwell, is a ruthless conglomerate tycoon. **********Fictional ''bad guy'' business executives are smirking, scheming, cheating and conniving their way across the nation's television screens and the pages of its novels. **********It's become a familiar theme in the long fictional and dramatic history of America - a country that, ironically, was built largely by the efforts of hard-driving capitalists but at the same time lionizes the working-class hero, the fellow who often finds himself in conflict with just such a capitalist. **********But these bad-guys capitalists seem to go over fine with the public: ''Dallas's'' ratings have been stratospheric, and so have the sales of ''Master of the Game.'' Its paperback publisher, Warner Books, has printed more than 4.3 million copies. **********Yet the bad guys have been drawing boos and grumbles from real-life business people - mostly concerned about prime-time network television shows, and much less about novels. Bernard J. O'Keefe, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers' executive committee, complains that when the networks create fictional business folk, ''they are either crooks or greedy or people who shout all the time.'' **********Mr. O'Keefe - he's also chairman of E.G.& G. Inc., a Wellesley, Mass.- based high-technology company with sales of $1 billion a year - argues that ''having a hard-working, unexciting businessman'' or police officer or whatever as a fictional television character ''doesn't sell advertising, and so most of us are caricatured for that reason.'' **********The beef at the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, as Thomas J. Donohue, group vice president, puts it, is that ''there is a tendency in entertainment television to depict many business people as wealthy, unscrupulous and succeeding through less-than-honorable dealings. This is totally incorrect.'' **********But network executives contend that such peeves ignore some basic considerations of their art. ''The viewing public,'' says Alice M. Henderson, a CBS Broadcast Group vice president, ''is a lot more intelligent than some of those people give it credit for being.'' **********Mrs. Henderson, vice president for program practices, says ''the primary function of prime-time fictional television is to entertain.'' Much of the programming being complained about, she contends, ''has done just that - it has entertained people. It's not meant to be a view of business people in real life.'' **********At ABC, Alan Wurtzel says: ''Television tends to deal with larger-than- life situations. With television, as with any dramatic form, there is very rarely a depiction of the day-to-day life of any profession, be it doctor, lawyer or businessman.'' The day-to-day truth, says Mr. Wurtzel, vice president of broadcast standards and practices for ABC television on the East Coast, is that ''the vast majority of businessmen - network executives included, I might add - pay their bills and operate in a highly ethical and appropriate fashion.'' And anyway, he says, ''I don't think that businessmen are all depicted unfavorably'' in fictional television. **********At NBC, M. S. Rukeyser Jr., executive vice president for public information, says catcalls about fictional television characters don't come only from the business world. ''It's probably true that no group likes the way it's portrayed on television or, in fact, in any other part of the media,'' he says. ''The goals of a special interest group, which by definition are special and positive, are often at odds with how that group sees itself portrayed on television, and particularly in entertainment programming.'' **********Conversely, Leonard S. Matthews, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, says businessmen aren't alone in suffering at fiction-writers' hands. ''The writer who sits down to entertain and communicate fast finds his job made much easier if he stereotypes people,'' he says. ''I don't think it's so much a matter of malice as it is that the writer is giving the viewers what they expect, so to speak.'' **********BE that as it may, some scholars have systematically studied fictional depictions of American business people - and have found that those portraits bear more than their share of warts. At the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, for instance, Prof. Emily Stipes Watts of the English department has concluded that since 1945, ''most businessmen depicted in television and serious literature are characterized as greedy, unethical and immoral (or amoral).'' **********At the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg School of Communications, researchers have catalogued more than 2,000 fictional business people shown on prime-time network television in the past eight years. The school's dean, George Gerbner, reports that one in three of the characters is a ''bad guy'' - which, he says, is a much more negative ratio than the bad-guy ratio for doctors (1 in 13) or police officers (1 in 29). **********Other analysts, crunching different sets of numbers, have decided that prime-time television's presentation of fictional business people is even wartier. In a 1982 article in the journal ''Public Opinion,'' Linda S. Lichter, S. Robert Lichter and Stanley Rothman reported that ''the struggle between good and evil dominates television, and businessmen come down squarely on the side of the bad guys.'' **********The three analysts reported that, of the fictional TV business folk they studied, ''60 percent were portrayed negatively, compared to only 28 percent who were depicted positively.'' They concluded that ''if American business has redeeming social values, they rarely turn up on prime- time television. Rather, businessmen are cast as evil and selfish, social parasites.'' **********Drawing on such findings, Herbert Schmertz, the Mobil Corporation's vice president for public affairs, asked a rhetorical question in a speech last January: ''Who are the worst crooks of all on TV after professional gangsters?'' **********''You're looking at one: the businessman,'' he declared. ''Not every crook on TV has an occupation that can be identified, but of those who do, the largest single group,'' he said, is business people. And he suggested that exporting American television's ''crazy-crooked-businessmen shows'' helps fan foreign suspicions ''of American institutions, particularly the multinational corporations.'' **********A similar though milder view comes from George L. Ball, president of Prudential-Bache: ''There have certainly been relatively few pieces of modern fiction or drama'' on television or film ''that I've seen in the recent past that have had as a sympathetic protagonist'' someone from the American business world. **********Such rumbles and grumbles don't come only from Big Business and Big Finance. John E. Sloan Jr., president of the National Federation of Independent Business - an organization of more than 500,000 small- and independent-business owners - said in a speech in February that in some television entertainment, ''there is no mercy shown to small business.'' **********He singled out three fictional small- business owners spotlighted on CBS television in recent years: Archie Bunker, now no longer first-run network fare, but still widely seen on local stations; George Jefferson, the owner of dry cleaning plants on ''The Jeffersons,'' and Mel, the diner owner on ''Alice.'' **********''Bunker is a bigot,'' Mr. Sloan said, ''Jefferson is a conniver, and Mel, a selfish loudmouth who is hard on his employees. Not exactly models of the small-business people I represent.'' **********That sort of depiction, he said, has helped make business widely suspected, and ''as a result, scores of agencies and thousands of regulations have sprung up, imposing checks on the performance of business.'' **********CBS views its fictional children more fondly. Mrs. Henderson argues that Archie Bunker should not ''truly be labeled a bigot.'' ''He's a person you love to hate,'' she says, but ''I don't think that's a negative portrayal of a small tavern owner.'' **********As for George Jefferson, she says he ''may be a little rough around the edges as to how he deals with people, but he's certainly not at all corrupt. He's genuinely a very good person.'' And Mel, she says, ''cares about his employees as much as he irritates them - that's not portraying him as a negative small-business man.'' **********At ABC, Mr. Wurtzel argues that the character flaws of ''Dynasty's'' vengeful Alexis Carrington are balanced by the sterling qualities of another character, her ex-husband, Blake Carrington, ''a very tough but fair businessman who is not involved in anything unscrupulous.'' **********THIS whole artistic issue, if that's **********what it is, flows out of America's **********cultural and commercial past, with many cross-currents. Professor Watts of the University of Illinois wrote in her 1982 book-length treatise, ''The Businessman in American Literature,'' that ''The capitalist has been attacked for any number of reasons throughout our literary history.'' **********She analyzed the 1885 work that has been dubbed the first American business novel, William Dean Howells's ''The Rise of Silas Lapham.'' And her verdict was that the image of Silas, the businessman and main character, ''is one of greed and grasping miserliness, of unethical business dealings somewhere on the way to financial success, of insensitivity to the needs of employees, of emotional atrophy, and of exploitation.'' **********Another early business novel much pored over by literary historians is Frank Norris's 1903 work, ''The Pit,'' about anarchic speculation in wheat. That book, too, gives a negative view of a hard-driving businessman - and it was a best seller in its day. **********But all is not sourness and gloom, Professor Watts reported in her book. Among the cultural cross-currents she charted was what she called ''a growing tendency among our recent writers to treat the businessman with compassion, understanding, and even admiration.'' She suggested in an interview that recent fiction-writers' portrayals of small-business men have become more favorable. **********And Roger W. Straus Jr., president of the publishing house Farrar, Straus & Giroux, argues that ideological currents have favored fictional business folk in recent decades. He says, ''speaking of the top-of-the-line literary novel,'' in the Depression years, ''certain authors of the Steinbeck-Dos Passos school depicted the business executive as a capitalist heavy, but I don't think that's been so true in contemporary times.'' **********The reason, he believes, is that today's writers find ''the present capitalistic society more compatible'' than writers viewed it in the Depression and early postwar years. **********Winthrop Knowlton, chairman of another publishing house, Harper & Row, singles out John P. Marquand, who died in 1960, as having written perceptive fiction about business people. And he says the writer-lawyer Louis Auchincloss is one fictioneer of today who has an ''understanding of how marvelously rich and tensioned'' office lives can be. **********Mr. Knowlton, who has written some fiction himself, also offers one practical explanation of why fictional portrayals of the business world give its real-life denizens a pain: ''There's a great thinness of knowledge about businesmen on the part of people'' writing fiction, he says, ''because most people who are writing fiction are spending their time writing fiction, they're not going to an office. So what we tend to get is caricatures.'' **********And Prudential-Bache's Mr. Ball says the blame for the unlovely portraits may lie partly ''with those of us in the business community who have probably done too little to talk about some of the things of conscience, some of the things of morality, some of the things of honor that we do.'' **********Mr. Ball also argues that the proper reflex for a business person, when riled by a fictional character, is not a gripe, but a stiff upper lip. **********''People in any business,'' he says, ''bridle at seeing fictional portrayals of people in their line of work that are reputationally adverse. But to carp about it really implies a defensive mentality as opposed to a pride that can override pinpricks. Thus, for us to criticize specific illustrations would be, I think, a form of sniveling.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/29/world.main_headline: REBEL SEEKS ROLE IN NICARAGUA VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/29/world.print_headline: REBEL SEEKS ROLE IN NICARAGUA VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/29/world.body_text: **********Eden Pastora Gomez, a Nicaraguan rebel leader, held a series of meetings here today with members of Congress, Congressional sources said. **********They said that he was seeking to mobilize support for an effort to induce Nicaragua to open up the presidential elections scheduled for November. **********Some members of Congress and Central American specialists who have met with Mr. Pastora over the last 48 hours said he was apparently shifting from reliance on guerrilla warfare to political action. **********One of the lawmakers who met with him, Representative Jim Wright of Texas, who is the House majority leader, said Mr. Pastora had indicated that his insurgent group in Costa Rica would lay down its arms if allowed to take part in free and open elections. **********Others described Mr. Pastora as encouraging both Republicans and Democrats to join with politicians in Latin America and in Western Europe to press Nicaragua to liberalize the election rules, as the Reagan Administration has been urging, and to allow former insurgents to take part.   Pact with Ex-Sandinista Reported **********Some Latin American specialists said they considered it potentially significant that Mr. Pastora had apparently joined forces with Arturo Jose Cruz, a former Sandinista leader who is now an economist with the Inter- American Development Bank here. **********Opposition leaders in Nicaragua have mentioned Mr. Cruz as a potential candidate, but he has thus far refused to be drawn into active politics or affiliation with any grouping. **********However, Nicaraguan rebel sources in Costa Rica said Mr. Pastora and Mr. Cruz had agreed to join forces to lobby for negotiations between the Sandinistas and their external opposition as well as for participation in elections. And today Mr. Cruz accompanied Mr. Pastora in the meetings on Capitol Hill. **********In addition to Representative Wright, they met with Representative Bill Alexander of Arkansas, who is the chief Democratic deputy whip. The two House leaders were among a group that wrote in mid-March to Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Nicaraguan leader, to propose ''a fully open and democratic electoral process'' as an alternative to the insurgency.   Pastora Seeks Safety Guarantee **********According to Representative Alexander, Mr. Pastora said today that ''he wants his party to participate in the elections and to be guaranteed safety.'' **********''While Pastora does not say explicitly he will lay down arms, he implies that,'' Representative Alexander said. In the civil war leading to the Sandinista seizure of power in 1979, Mr. Pastora was a guerrilla commander known as Commander Zero.  He served as a Deputy Defense Minister until he broke with the Sandinistas and went into armed rebellion two years ago. **********Representative Alexander said Edward Chamorro, a leader of the rival Nicaraguan rebel group, the Nicaraguan Democratic Front, said last month in Honduras that he also wanted to stop the rebellion and take part in elections. **********''So we have a good beginning and that is the stuff settlements are made of,'' Representative Alexander said. **********Mr. Pastora's efforts, to be discussed at a news conference on Monday, came as the United States completed the first round of talks with Nicaragua, and the Senate joined the House in dropping money for the Nicaraguan insurgents from a spending bill.   Shultz Expects More Fighting **********In a meeting with Washington correspondents of The New York Times, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said that, despite the Congressional refusal to vote more money, he expected the Nicaraguan rebels to go on fighting. He said the United States would give ''moral support'' to their efforts to raise money elsewhere. **********Although he treated the negotiations with the Nicaraguan Government as serious, he gave no indication that he saw evidence of an early breakthrough. **********In a separate development, Roberto d'Aubuisson, the Salvadoran rightist, said at a news conference at the Capitol Hilton Hotel here that he would support an effort by his Government to induce the Salvadoran insurgents to run candidates in elections next year. But he said any talks to share power with the rebels would violate the Constitution. **********''Let the insurgents try to seize power, to share power, in the only permissible fashion, through the ballot box,'' he said. **********Speaking of President Jose Napoleon Duarte's plans to try to arrange for the rebels' participation in local and national assembly elections in 1985, he said, ''If that is what Duarte intends to do, we will support him on this.'' **********Mr. d'Aubuisson, who lost to Mr. Duarte in the presidential election on May 6, held up a map of El Salvador to show that Mr. Duarte had won geographically small, but heavily populated areas, while people in some 85 percent of the country, including guerrilla strongholds, had voted for Mr. d'Aubuisson's party, the National Republican Alliance. **********Mr. d'Aubuisson repeated earlier allegations by members of his party, which is known by the Spanish acronym Arena, that the Central Intelligence Agency and American Embassy officials had aided his rival during the elections. **********Mr. d'Aubuisson also contended that Nicaragua was supplying Salvadoran guerrillas with heavy weapons, including antiaircraft rockets and advanced communications equipment and codes that the Pentagon had been trying unsuccessfully to break. **********Mr. Shultz later said he could not confirm that heavy weapons were moving from Nicaragua into El Salvador and he declined to discuss any code-breaking efforts. Previously American officials have said that the flow has consisted of small arms and munitions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/24/busin.body_text: **********The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 32 percent. Digital's stock rose sharply last week when it said that its earnings would greatly exceed Wall Street predictions. **********Digital was one of three companies whose earnings reports yesterday indicated that the demand for mainframe and minicomputers - refrigerator-sized machines used in offices and research laboratories - surged at the end of 1983. **********The Burroughs Corporation posted a profit of $81.4 million in the latest quarter, contrasted with a $15.6 million loss a year earlier. And Prime Computer said its fourth-quarter profit fell to $10 million, down 18 percent from the same quarter a year ago but up considerably from disapointing earnings posted in the first two quarters of last year. **********''The entire industry is experiencing an orders surge,'' said Ulric Weil, an industry analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company. ''They are up in mainframes and even more in minicomputers.'' But he cautioned that with increased price competition, ''no one should kid himself that profitability will get back to old levels.'' **********Digital **********Digital said its second-quarter profit rose to $80.5 million, or $1.41 a share, against $61.0 million or $1.08 a share a year earlier. The first quarter of 1984 was the company's worst in recent memory with profits plunging to $15.9 million, or 28 cents a share .  Second-quarter revenues rose 40 percent, to $1.4 billion, from $1.0 billion in the same quarter a year ago. **********Analysts said the gains indicated that the company had finally straightened out the production problems that had kept it from filling its orders in its first fiscal quarter, which ended Sept. 30. **********Kenneth H. Olsen, president, said that demand was particularly strong for the VAX line of minicomputers and that there was a sharp increase in demand for its new line of personal computers. He said he was confident that most of the company's problems were behind it and that Digital ''can sustain the momentum established in the quarter.'' **********When Digital said Jan. 13 that its second-quarter performance would be well above expectations, its stock climbed $3.25, to $78.125. It has increased steadily since and closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $87.50, up $1.625. **********Burroughs **********Burroughs, a manufacturer of mainframe computers, said strong demand for its computers and its Memorex 3680 memory disks pushed profits for the most recent quarter to $81.4 million, or $1.81 a share, compared with its $15.6 million loss a year earlier. **********Revenues increased 17 percent, to $1.31 billion, from $1.12 billion. **********For the year, Burroughs's profit rose 67 percent, to $196.9 million, or $4.60 a share, from $117.6 million, or $2.80 a share. Revenues were $4.39 billion, up a modest 5 percent, from $4.17 billion. The company's stock fell 25 cents yesterday, to $50.25, in Big Board trading yesterday. **********Prime Computer **********Prime Computer, a competitor of Digital's that suffered both sharp earnings declines and numerous defections from its executive suite in the first half of 1983, saw its earnings decline in the fourth quarter, to $10 million, from $12.2 million, despite a 21 percent rise in revenues, to $142.8 million, from $118.3 million. ''We are down compared to a very strong 1982, but we see that everything is bouncing back,'' Joe M. Henson, the company's president and chief executive, said in a telephone interview. **********Demand was particularly strong, he said, for the company's 9950 super- minicomputer, which faltered earlier in the year because of a number of production and management problems. **********Prime's earnings for the year were also depressed by the company's major investments in research and development and in the expansion of its efforts in computer-aided design and manufacturing technology. For the full year earnings fell 28 percent, to $32.5 million, or 68 cents a share, against $44.9 million, or 99 cents a share in the previous year. Revenues rose 19 percent, to $516.5 million, against $435.8 million. Prime's stock declined $1.125, to $19.125, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/02/busin.body_text: **********They are angry at the power system for allowing plans for five nuclear plants, costing $24 billion, to spin out of control, for terminating two plants in January 1982, and for defaulting last July on $2.25 billion in bonds for the scrapped plants. **********The default, the largest in municipal bond history, followed a Washington State Supreme Court ruling that contracts of 88 utilities to pay off $2.25 billion in bonds were invalid. **********The bonds were sold to build two plants that then were left unfinished when it became clear that estimates of future demand were wildly overstated. **********''We are trying to make the best of a bad deal,'' said Mr. Halvorson, a 67- year-old Oregon businessman and one-time president of the Association of General Contractors of America. He is trying to stave off bankruptcy so that the supply system can complete three nuclear plants backed by the Bonneville Power Administration, a Federal agency. To pay interest on $6.2 billion of bonds floated to construct these units, electric rates have gone up substantially.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/27/busin.body_text: **********The Control Data Corporation said yesterday that it had formed a company for the Caribbean Basin and Central America and had named Robert C. Chinn to be its president. **********Mr. Chinn, 67 years old, has been senior vice president and assistant to the chairman at Control Data. He will maintain two offices, one at Control Data headquarters in Minneapolis and another at Baton Rouge, La. **********Control Data and its chairman and chief executive, William C. Norris, believe that social problems can be attacked through profit-oriented business ventures. The new company, called Control Data Caribbean Basin Inc., ''will extend Control Data's strategy of addressing society's major unmet needs as profitable business opportunities,'' Mr. Norris said in a statement. **********Mr. Chinn has already been at work in Jamaica creating business ventures between the public and private sectors, in response to a request by President Reagan that companies participate in the United States Business Committee on Jamaica. The new company, Mr. Norris said, ''allows us to build on the Jamaica experience with the public-private partnership approach.'' **********The computer company hopes to profit by selling consulting services to government or private agencies. These typically provide systems to nurture small business with seed money, access to data processing and office needs, and management assistance. **********Mr. Chinn, who was en route yesterday from Baton Rouge to Minneapolis, has worked for Control Data since 1969. He is a lawyer and engineer and before joining Control Data spent 22 years as an executive with the Ford Motor Company. **********''Bob Chinn has been instrumental in establishing cooperative programs in education and training, small-scale agriculture and small business development to meet the needs of the Jamaican people,'' Mr. Morris said. ''His efforts have also made it possible for Control Data to begin a new phase - to bring public and private resources to bear on pressing needs of other countries in the Caribbean and Central America.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/02/busin.main_headline: IRAN PRICE CUT SAID TO LURE TANKERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/02/busin.print_headline: IRAN PRICE CUT SAID TO LURE TANKERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/02/busin.body_text: **********At least six large tankers have loaded oil at Iran's Kharg Island terminal in the last two days or are in the process of doing so, taking advantage of Iran's sizable discounts while risking an attack by Iraq, oil industry traders and analysts said yesterday. **********Iran's offer of discounts of up to $2.50 a barrel from its posted $28 price has attracted tankers chartered by Japanese and Austrian traders, as well as by Marc Rich, the oil trader who is the subject of a huge tax fraud case, to the port in the Persian Gulf war zone, experts said. As a result, they added, Iran's oil exports, which had dropped early in the week by a million barrels a day, to about 500,000, will probably jump to about 900,000 barrels. **********Insurance Costs Up **********Oil company sources said the discounts were helping to compensate shipping companies for about $2 a barrel in extra payments to insurers and ships' crews for entering the Kharg Island area, where a spate of attacks on tankers has occurred in recent weeks. **********Shippers and oil experts said Iran's initial $1.50 discount was not enough for many shippers. With a $2.50 discount, the shippers would make at least 50 cents a barrel, or about $1 million, on a large tanker shipment, sources said.  ''The Iranians have reduced the price of oil enough to offset a lot of the costs associated with the hostilities,'' said Douglas Wolcott, vice president of operations at the Chevron Shipping Companies, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California. **********Two of the large tankers that have headed for Kharg were chartered by the Mitsubishi Corporation, a large Japanese trading company. They are the Atlanticos and the Kypros, with Liberian flags and a Greek owner, said Nobie Nakamura, chief crude oil trader for the Mitsubishi International Corporation in New York. **********He said the two ships together hold four million barrels of crude and that the Atlanticos left Kharg on Thursday. Other sources said the ship was now out of the war zone. **********Other tankers bound for Kharg include the Louisiana and the Alta, both chartered by Boest Alpine of Vienna, and the Canaria, chartered from London by Marc Rich, Mr. Nakamura said. **********The Danish-owned tanker Karoline Maersk was said by other oil industry sources to have headed for Kharg. Oil trading sources also said a Phibro-Salomon trading subsidiary in New York planned to charter a tanker to Kharg. Phibro traders declined to comment. **********Iraq's Pipeline Plans **********As for Iraq, it stepped up plans yesterday to build pipelines to get its oil to world markets. Early in the 44- month-old war, Iran destroyed Iraq's export facilities on the Persian Gulf, so Iraq now can export only about 900,000 barrels a day via a pipeline through Turkey to the Mediterranean Sea. Its exports before the war were more than three million barrels a day. Iraq's new efforts include possible pipelines through Jordan to the Red Sea, and another through Turkey.  John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said that were it not for Iran's actions, Iraq would probably be able to export another million barrels a day, considering the production quotas by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********Iraq's oil revenue loss is about $10 billion a year, he said. He noted, however, that Iraq had received about $35 billion in advances from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and others, helping its war effort. **********Senior Iraqi officials have stressed that they will continue to attack all ships trying to load at Kharg. Various oil analysts, however, said Iraq had not been particularly accurate in its attacks and had exaggerated some of them. **********Some oil analysts, noting the current world oil glut, said Iran's discounts might cause petroleum prices to soften somewhat, even if OPEC's $29 benchmark price is not broken. Philip K. Verleger Jr., an economist and oil expert at Drexel Burnham Lambert, said other OPEC producers might step up their exports if the threat of Persian Gulf disruptions continued. If the hositilies then dissipate, he said, ''we may suddenly wake up and find that the market's been flooded.''
