https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/29/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; New Zealand Opposition Drops Muldoon as Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/29/world.body_text: **********WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Thursday, Nov. 29 (Reuters) - Sir Robert Muldoon, who was Prime Minister for nine years until he was swept from power in an election last July, was ousted today as leader of the National Party. **********Sir Robert, 63 years old, whose autocratic style was blamed for a landslide Labor Party victory, was defeated in a vote by his parliamentary colleagues. **********He will be succeeded by Jim McLay, 39, a former lawyer and Muldoon protege, who was appointed deputy leader early this year before Sir Robert called an election July 14. Former Labor Minister Jim Bolger, 49, was elected Mr. McLay's deputy. **********Sir Robert, who had put himself forward as one of the candidates in the leadership ballot, said he would continue as a member of Parliament. **********He had been due to face a leadership vote Dec.21, but opponents pressed for an earlier ballot after losing confidence in his leadership after the election. he had led the party since 1974.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/21/busin.body_text: **********Cattle inventory declined 1.3 percent during the last year, about in line with predictions, the Agriculture Department said today. **********The July 1 inventory of all cattle and calves was estimated at 121,950,000 head, compared with 123,540,000 a year earlier. **********Matched against the inventory in mid-1982 of 124,140,000 head, the July 1 count was down about 1.8 percent. **********John Nalivka of the department's Economic Research Service said the July 1 figure was ''pretty much what we expected'' although there had been some feeling that the decline might be slightly greater, perhaps around 2 percent. **********After herds peaked at more than 130 million head in the mid-1970's, sagging markets forced producers to cut back sharply for several years. A rebuilding effort was short-lived as new financial troubles sprang up and cutbacks have taken place. **********Today's report, which covered both beef and dairy stock, also showed that this year's calf crop is expected to decline to 43.4 million head, down 2 percent from levels of both 1983 and 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/12/busin.print_headline: Douglas to Build Jetliners in China LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP) - The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent with the Shanghai Aircraft Industrial Corporation of China to build 25 jetliners in China in a deal worth ''several hundred million dollars.''
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/12/busin.body_text: **********The MD-80 airliners, twin-engine jets that carry about 150 passengers, would be assembled by the Chinese corporation, a McDonnell Douglas spokesman, Michael Eastman, said. McDonnell Douglas will provide parts and subassemblies. **********A team from McDonnell Douglas will also provide technical assistance to China on tooling, production and certification of the MD-80's assembled there, and the arrangement also calls for future cooperation in possible joint development of other advanced-technology airliners, he said. **********Mr. Eastman said there would be no legal problem with sharing the technology with China. ''We've sold the aircraft to China and we did have an export license for that,'' he said. ''We have received indications from both State and Commerce that they would look favorably upon this.'' **********The planes would be used by the Chinese national airline for both international and domestic routes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/busin.main_headline: 3 OFFERS ON THE LOW SIDE, REPORTED FOR TIFFANY'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/busin.print_headline: 3 OFFERS ON THE LOW SIDE, REPORTED FOR TIFFANY'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/busin.body_text: **********Avon Products Inc. has received bids for its Tiffany & Company subsidiary from three investor groups, financial sources in New York and London said yesterday. But the offers, ranging from $100 million to $140 million, fall far short of Avon's $160 million price, these sources said. **********The sources, who asked not to be named, said a leveraged buyout offer had been made by a group headed by William R. Chaney, Tiffany's president. They also said a group represented by Dr. Anton Rupert, of Rothman's International Ltd., had made a bid. Rothman's is a British tobacco maker that also controls the Dunhill tobacco store chain. The third bidder was reported to be Sears Holdings Ltd., a British conglomerate. **********Asprey & Company, the English jewelry chain, also is a possible bidder. According to Naim Attallah, the company's financial director, Asprey has been ''looking at Tiffany and we feel it is a great opportunity.'' **********But, reflecting the sentiments of some American retailers who are intrigued by Tiffany's potential, Mr. Attallah said he found the asking price ''outrageous.'' **********Avon declined to comment on the bids or bidders. John Cox, a spokesman, said: ''We aren't holding a public auction. We asked for bids in June and indicated that we expected the buyer to be selected in 60 days. No announcement is imminent.'' Other sources said that Avon will make an announcement by Sept. 15. **********Mr. Chaney could not be reached for comment at Tiffany's. **********Avon Paid $104 Million **********Avon put Tiffany up for sale only five years after it bought the famous jewelry and silversmithing retail chain for $104 million. Avon said on June 19, when it announced the divestiture plan, that it expected to make ''a substantial profit on the sale.'' **********Avon has invested about $53 million in Tiffany. But last year, Tiffany contributed only 4 percent of Avon's $3 billion sales and 1 percent of its $164 million in earnings, earning $2.1 million on $125 million in sales. Avon has said it had reassessed Tiffany's long- term potential and decided that the jewelry chain could not produce enough to justify Avon keeping it. **********In Newport, R.I., where he was vacationing, Walter Hoving, the former chairman and a large investor in Tiffany before it was sold to Avon, said that he had not kept in touch with matters since he had left. But, he added, ''If Avon can get $150 million for it, they ought to grab it.'' **********Tiffany Credit Cards **********Avon attempted to expand and capitalize on Tiffany after the purchase by issuing new catalogues containing jewelry with a wide price range, by starting to offer Tiffany credit cards and developing a direct- mail operation. Tiffany's eight stores will be increased to nine next month with a new store in Boston. **********Some critics of Tiffany have stated that the jewelry chain had introduced too many lower-priced items as a result of the Avon ownership. **********Mr. Attallah said, ''We would like to bring Tiffany back to its former glory. Asprey is a quality, retail jeweler and very forward-looking but we wouldn't be interested in Tiffany if it continues as a market to the mass.'' Asked if Asprey, which had sales last year of $36.5 million and gross profit of $8 million, had the financial capability to buy Tiffany, he replied, ''We do not have that capability, but there are enough companies available for us to form a consortium.'' **********He denied that such a group might include investors from the Middle East.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/11/busin.main_headline: THE RISKY NEW WRINKLES IN LETTERS OF CREDIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/11/busin.print_headline: THE RISKY NEW WRINKLES IN LETTERS OF CREDIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/11/busin.body_text: **********The letter of credit, which has **********been used since the days of the **********Phoenicians to finance trade, is taking on a new role today in corporate takeovers, leveraged buyouts, ''golden parachutes,'' tax shelters - and even as a guarantee that a race horse will perform as promised. **********This modern twist to an ancient instrument of finance developed as an outgrowth of the wave of corporate mergers that started in the late 1970's. It came about this way: target companies insisted on guarantees that their shareholders would be paid the promised purchase price if an acquiring company tried to renege on a merger deal. The problem was how to provide such a guarantee without actually putting millions of dollars into an escrow account. The acquiring companies turned to the big money center banks for a solution and the banks, particularly Citibank, offered the ''standby'' letter of credit. **********Under the standby L.C., as it is called, the bank itself promises to pay the guaranteed merger price, come what may. That can be risky, but over the last five years, the loss rate from these standby letters of credit has been less than from commercial loans, according to a recent Federal Reserve study. And the standby letter of credit has caught on, generating millions of dollars in new fees for the banking industry. **********From guaranteeing merger payments, the banks have expanded into all sorts of other guarantees. For example, they are issuing standby letters of credit that guarantee payment for stock purchased by wealthy individuals. And the standby has become a popular guarantee for golden parachute agreements, thus assuring that executives affected by hostile takeovers can actually collect millions of dollars in severance pay. Even a group negotiating to invest in the offspring of a champion thoroughbred, Secretariat, turned to a standby letter of credit to guarantee repayment of their investment if their horse failed to sire any offspring, a problem that did not develop. **********''Anybody who's a beneficiary of a transaction of any kind would be less than prudent if he didn't demand a letter of credit,'' said Robert Feldman, a vice president of Citibank and head of its international trade services. Citibank has handsomely profited from the fees these instruments have generated in recent years. **********Indeed, the dollar value of standby letters of credit issued by commercial banks jumped to $119.6 billion last year from $46.9 billion in 1980, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported. Citibank has the most outstanding, with a total portfolio of $17.3 billion last year. The Chemical Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company are also major issuers of standby letters of credit. The banks collect an annual fee ranging from one-eighth of 1 percent to 1 1/2 percent of the value of these letters. **********WHILE the standby letter of credit is just now rising to prominence, the commercial letter of credit is almost as old as civilization itself. Inscriptions on stone tablets unearthed by archaeologists indicate that Phoenician sea-traders used a variation of the letter of credit more than 4,000 years ago to finance their commerce. And the commercial letter of credit is the principal method today of paying the billions of dollars involved in international trade. **********But the commercial letter of credit differs from the infant standby agreement in a key aspect. A commercial letter of credit is issued by a bank only after the buyer of some merchandise - the American purchaser of a German car, for example - turns over to the bank the purchase price of the car or takes out a loan for the equivalent amount. The bank, in effect, holds this money and pays it to the German auto maker, through a German bank, once the car enters the United States and all the conditions of the sale have been met. **********That trans-Atlantic shipment might take weeks. The American, in the interim, renounces any right to reclaim the cash if he or she has second thoughts about the purchase. The buyer usually pays the bank fee for the commercial letter of credit, which makes the bank, in effect, the intermediary between a buyer reluctant to pay for goods he has not yet received and a seller unwilling to ship without assurance of payment. **********In contrast, the standby letter of credit binds the bank to make payment without having collected any money in advance. A stockbroker, for example, might require a wealthy client to provide the bank's guarantee that he will, in fact, send payment for the stock that he has just told his broker to buy. The individual buys this guarantee for a fee in the form of a standby letter of credit payable to his broker. The letter of credit promises that the bank will pay the stockbroker's bill, if the wealthy individual fails to do so. In that event, the bank is out the money, unless it can collect on promissory notes or collateral that might have been put up by the individual. **********IN the competitive world of deregulated banking, the standby letter **********of credit has turned out to be a lucrative market niche. ''It is the only instrument in the world that provides irrevocable assurance of payment,'' Mr. Feldman said. Other bankers echo Mr. Feldman's promotional statement, although some acknowledge the dangers involved in issuing standby letters of credit. ''There has been little loss experienced in the area, but there has been concern,'' said William Blanc, a Chemical Bank vice president. **********Still, the standby letter of credit has increasingly become a major tool in corporate takeovers. Companies about to be acquired view the letter of credit as ''a good security blanket,'' said Gilbert Harrison, chairman of Financo, a Philadelphia-based investment concern that specializes in the acquisition of companies with a selling price of $5 million to $75 million. **********Mr. Harrison says that the owners of these small companies, when they sell out to larger corporations, often insist on a standby letter of credit to guarantee a purchase completed with installment payments over a period of months or years. He said that in several recent deals, he had offered the seller the alternative of notes at 11 percent interest, but without the backing of a standby letter of credit, or notes at 10 1/2 percent interest, with the backing of a standby L.C. ''In the vast majority of cases, the sellers choose the L.C. arrangement,'' he said. ''They'd rather sleep soundly at night.'' **********The standby has also become an important tool in the leveraged buyout, in which the buyers - often a company's top executives - pledge as collateral the assets of the company they are buying. Because of the risk involved in this sort of financing, standby letters of credit are becoming a common form of guarantee that the buyers will actually make the purchase payments. **********The letter of credit is also in vogue among the wealthy. Take the individual who has agreed to invest $75,000 in a tax shelter over three years. Instead of paying out $25,000 each year, this investor takes out a letter of credit to guarantee payment of the total amount at the end of the period. In the meantime, he or she gets the benefit of an annual tax write-off, even though no money has been put up. Meanwhile, the postponed $25,000 payments can be invested in Treasury securities that yield more than the cost of the letter of credit. **********In professional boxing, the standby letter of credit, payable to the fighters, has become a promoter's means of guaranteeing to the boxers that he will actually pay the agreed-upon purse at the end of the bout. In turn, the L.C. guarantees that the fighters will show up for the match. The bank pays the fighers if the promoter fails to do so. Muhammad Ali demanded such standby L.C.'s in the 1960's and 1970's when their use was still limited chiefly to guaranteeing payment of construction contracts. **********Most bankers regard the letter of credit as an ideal instrument for their own business. With the range of one- eighth of 1 percent to 1 1/2 percent of the L.C.'s face value, the actual rate depends on the credit standing of the applicant and the amount of money involved. A standby L.C. for $200 million might command a $3 million fee. **********MOST L.C.'s, however, are not that large, and some bankers think fees should not be lowered to less than the average three- quarters of 1 percent currently charged, among them Vincent Maulella, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover. ''What bankers are looking at now is the value to the customer,'' he said. ''The value is more than one-eighth of 1 percent.'' **********He adds that in some cases banks should not write a standby letter of credit at all because they would do much better providing a standard commercial loan at current rates of 12 percent to 14 percent. This represents a spread of up to 4 percentage points, vearsus a maximum of 1 1/2 points for a standby letter of credit. **********''The banks are competing against themselves,'' Mr. Maulella said. **********Still, revenue from standby letters of credit is attractive because it raises income ''below the line.'' Standby L.C.'s are contingent liabilities - possible but not probable future obligations - and banks are not required to hold reserves against them. In fact, a recent Federal Reserve study shows that standby L.C. losses average only three-tenths of 1 percent of the total value of L.C.'s outstanding, which is below the four- tenths of 1 percent loss rate for commercial loans. **********Federal Reserve officials say they are not too happy about the proliferation of standby L.C.'s, which impinge on the Fed's ability to control credit and raise the potential for huge losses, according to bankers. But banking industry officials say they have become more selective about the standby L.C.'s that they issue. ''More and more, the standby is a payment mechanism,'' Mr. Maulella said, in which the client is required to provide enough collateral to assure repayment if necessary. **********The most expansive view of the future for standby L.C.'s comes from Citibank, which has been the most aggressive in leading seminars in various cities to promote the standby letter of credit. ''Anybody from an individual to a conglomerate is a target for one,'' Mr. Feldman says.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/11/busin.body_text: **********Volkswagen A.G. today reported earnings of $18.3 million for the first quarter, in contrast to a loss of $35.9 million a year earlier. **********Carl H. Hahn, VW's chairman, attributed the profit turnaround after two years of heavy losses to brisk sales in North America. **********Volkswagen's consolidated worldwide sales rose 23.5 percent, to $4.2 billion, from $3.4 billion a year earlier, Mr. Hahn said at a news conference. **********Volkswagen, which is West Germany's biggest auto maker, delivered 750,000 cars worldwide in the first four months, he said, or 1 percent more than last year. In West Germany, the company delivered 272,000 cars, up 2 percent. **********Volkswagen delivered 90,500 cars in the United States in the first four months of 1984, Mr. Hahn said, or 38 percent more than in the period last year. Sales of Volkswagen's higher- priced Audi models increased 92 percent, to 24,150.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/07/busin.body_text: **********Traders at Salomon Brothers Inc. were among those who were forced to evacuate the 50- story 1 New York Plaza building in a fire yesterday. **********They fanned out to other brokerage firms in the lower Manhattan area to continue their work. **********A spokesman said that some went to Goldman, Sachs & Company, others to Cowen & Company, ''and various and sundry other places.'' **********The smoky fire broke out on the 19th floor. The Salomon traders, who work on the 40th floor, left at 12:30 P.M. and returned two hours later. At the other brokerage houses, they made contact with Salomon brokers on market floors by phone and conducted business ''in this archaic way,'' the spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/21/busin.body_text: **********Fears of especially frenzied selling in the final hours of stock market trading today - the day when various stock- index futures and options expire - have eased. **********In the past few months, as the options expired, the stock market has taken some wild gyrations. Wall Street firms have been committing tens of millions of dollars to take advantage of price differences between stock indexes and the options or futures on the indexes. Closing out the various positions has apparently caused prices to decline. **********The feeling on Wall Street, however, is that many of these positions were closed out in the unusually heavy trading on Tuesday and Wednesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/busin.print_headline: Doubts on Sale Of Conrail Brokerage analysts specializing in railroads said yesterday that the possibility that the Norfolk Southern Corporation would acquire the Consolidated Rail Corporation was remote because of antitrust problems, opposition from other railroads and other choices open to the Government in disposing of the carrier.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Norfolk Southern said Friday that it was beginning studies ''looking toward the possible inclusion of Conrail in the Norfolk Southern system.'' **********Andras R. Petery of Morgan Stanley & Company said that if Norfolk Southern did bid, he would expect a competitor such as the CSX Corporation ''will fight it tooth and nail.'' **********Mr. Petery noted that Conrail has a virtual monopoly on rail movement in the Northeast, but that under Government ownership, it has played a neutral role, providing access to its system to all the other major railroads on an equal basis. ''If you affiliated Conrail with one railroad,'' he added, ''that neutral access would be eliminated for the others.'' **********Most of the analysts interviewed said Conrail would likely be disposed of in a public offering in which its employees would acquire a stake.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/25/busin.body_text: **********The Consolidated Edison **********Company of New York said yesterday that earnings in the second quarter increased 6 percent, to $82.1 million, or 64 cents a share, from $77.4 million, or 60 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.  Revenues rose 5.9 percent, to $1.25 billion, from $1.18 billion. In commenting on the results, the company said that the earnings for the calendar year will be somewhat lower than the $4.52 a share reported for the 12 months ended June 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/30/world.body_text: **********At Washington's request, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has ordered a full investigation into reports that Iraq is buying equipment from West Germany capable of producing nerve gas and other chemical weapons, the Government said today. **********A spokesman, Alexander Allardt, said the issue was being looked into ''at the request of the United States.'' **********He did not elaborate. **********The announcement coincided with a report in the weekly Der Spiegel that Frankfurt companies had sold Iraq laboratory equipment capable of producing nerve gas. **********The magazine said American specialists believed the plant could be modified to produce nerve gas. **********The Spiegel report said that Karl Kolb Scientific Technical Supplies and its subsidiary, Pilot Plant Engineering and Equipment, delivered the equipment to Iraq in 1981.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/13/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Using Qube To Market Cosmetics
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/13/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Using Qube To Market Cosmetics
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/13/busin.body_text: **********ON Monday, in four cities served by Qube cable television, Warner Cosmetics will broaden its search for customers for its Ralph Lauren cosmetics line. It will thus be using the interactive cable TV system in a way that has already proved highly successful in a single-market test. **********The test was just before Christmas, 1982, in Columbus, Ohio, the first city to get the Warner Amex Qube system. By pressing any of five response buttons, Qube subscribers can participate in such things as consumer research, polls and game shows. **********In the 1982 test, the cosmetics company, working with the Lazarus department store, began running half- hour demonstrations of women getting cosmetic makeover treatments. The demonstrations ended with an offer for viewers to get a free makeover of their own. They were asked to push one of three Qube response buttons to indicate which Lazarus branch they would like to have get in touch with them for an appointment. **********According to Brenda Davidorf, director of Warner Amex Video Ventures, 11,600 people tuned in to the program during the two weeks it ran and 1,682 responded, or ''touched in,'' as Qube calls it. Some 800 of the touch-ins made appointments and 48 percent actually showed up. **********Now the bottom line: Each of those attending bought an average of $50 worth of Ralph Lauren cosmetics. No wonder that Warner Cosmetics (which is no longer owned by Warner Communications) is out to extend the scope of that operation. **********In addition to Columbus, the new program will be in Cincinnati and Pogues department store; Pittsburgh and Kauffman's, and Dallas and Nieman-Marcus. **********The program, which will have Clotilde, Ralph Lauren's official cosmetics model as hostess, will also have a cosmetician doing over three different models. **********The segment will run twice a day in all markets except Dallas, where it will be aired three times. In an attempt to make the advertising more selective, Warner Amex has created a 30-second promotion spot that it will run on the cable network whose audience demographics are closest to the ones that the cosmetics company is looking to attract. **********This is the sort of thing that the ebullient Miss Davidorf does for a living. The former teacher of the deaf, who joined the company seven years ago, is in charge of changing national advertisers' dreams of cable TV into reality as far as the Warner Amex systems are concerned. That also goes for the seven Qube systems (the remaining three being Chicago, Houston and St. Louis), and the 112 regular non-urban cable systems owned by Warner Amex, which is a joint venture of Warner Communications and American Express. **********More than anything else, Miss Davidorf's unit is in answer to advertiser demand, and she has been actively helping out in an informal way for about two years. In January the position became official and she became part of the advertising sales department. **********Miss Davidorf, who appears to be a basically bubbly person, is particularly ''up'' these days over a recent Qube success in Columbus, where she is based. **********The caper, involving Kraft Foods and J. Walter Thompson, Chicago, showed an altogether different capability for Qube. **********Kraft was sponsor of the April 6 CBS-TV special, ''The Magic of David Copperfield.'' With the agreement of the Columbus CBS affiliate, WBNS- TV, a crawl message across the bottom of the screen invited Qube subscribers to touch-in for copies of Kraft recipes. Of the roughly 50,000 Qube homes in Columbus, about 3,000 touched-in to get Kraft recipes. **********To Ronald B. Kaatz, senior vice president in the media research of Thompson, Chicago, the response was amazing. So surprising was it, in fact, that he voiced concern that Kraft would have difficulty filling the orders if such an undertaking was attempted on a broader scale. So it is possible to be too effective.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/28/world.main_headline: PLOT IS REPORTED ON A U.S. EMBASSY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/28/world.print_headline: PLOT IS REPORTED ON A U.S. EMBASSY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/28/world.body_text: **********Reagan Administration officials said today that Italian and American agents had foiled a possible plan by a group of Lebanese to bomb the United States Embassy in Rome. **********Italian authorities said they believed the suspects were linked with Islamic Holy War, the group that has taken responsibility for bomb attacks on American installations in Lebanon. **********In Rome, Police Chief Marcello Monarca said today that seven Lebanese were arrested Saturday near Rome and that one of them had in his possession a detailed map of the American Embassy. He said the map contained notes on supposed ''weak points'' in the large embassy compound. **********Earlier Arrest in Zurich **********Mr. Monarca said another Lebanese man was arrested in Zurich six days earlier and was carrying more than four pounds of explosives. **********He said that although he had no hard evidence to prove the suspects' membership in Islamic Holy War, he based his conclusion on documents the arrested men were carrying. **********In Washington, Administration officials said they were working on the assumption that the Lebanese were linked to Islamic Holy War. But American officials declined to provide much detail, preferring to let information come from the Italian authorities. **********Reports on Carrier Denied **********In another matter, State Department and Defense Department officials denied reports that that the United States had ordered the aircraft carrier Eisenhower to prepare for a retaliatory strike if terrorists in Lebanon struck against American installations again. **********The Washington Post said in its issue today that the Eisenhower was ordered ''shortly before Thanksgiving'' to hold its position in the central Mediterranean for possible retaliatory strikes. But Michael Burch, the Pentagon spokesman, said today that the Eisenhower was on port call in Athens from Nov. 21 to 24 so the crew could have Thanksgiving liberty. **********The New York Times in its last edition today said that the Eisenhower had been held on station in the central Mediterranean for several weeks preparing to respond to terrorist attacks.   No Specific Mission **********Today, State Department and Defense Department officials said that the United States had had a carrier on station in that area for months for possible assignments, such as aiding in the evacuation of Americans in an emergency. They said no specific retaliatory mission had been ordered, but they did not rule out the possibility that in case of an attack on American installations, one could be ordered. **********On Nov. 4, two days before the American Presidential election, a message issued in the name of Islamic Holy War warned of an operation that ''will surprise the Americans.'' **********The group has taken responsibility for bombings of the American Embassy buildings in Beirut in April 1983 and September 1984, and of the American and French military barracks south of Beirut in October 1983. Since the most recent bombing Sept. 20, American embassies and diplomats have been on high alert because of repeated threats of similar attacks. Most of the attention has been focused on the Middle East and Central America. **********Some experts say they believe the name Islamic Holy War has been used by several loosely affiliated Shiite Moslem terrorist groups.   Investigation Continuing **********The State Department, without going into details on how the Italian police were alerted to the possible plot in Rome, said the investigation there was still going on. It confirmed that one of the arrested Lebanese had a plan of the embassy. **********Administration officials said Italian and American security agents had shared information leading to the arrests Saturday. **********The State Department said that ''U.S.-Italian relations have been marked for some time by excellent and growing cooperation in the law enforcement area, including against terrorism.'' **********Mr. Monarca, the Rome Police Chief, said the Lebanese who were arrested apparently planned to attack the embassy with a truck full of dynamite, the method used in Beirut. **********According to news agency reports, the seven Lebanese who were arrested Saturday in Ladispoli, a seaside resort near Rome, had been in Italy for up to a year, and some or all were registered as students. **********They were reportedly charged with belonging to an armed band and plotting a massacre, and were being held in a maximum-security prison outside Rome.   Embassy Is Heavily Protected **********The American Embassy is located on the Via Veneto, one of Rome's major thoroughfares. It has been heavily protected since the advent of the Red Brigades terrorist group in Italy in the 1970's, and threats have been made to attack it in the past, Administration officials said. The four-story structure has cement blocks in the driveways, as well as chains and special barricades designed to keep vehicles from crashing through entrances to the 17th-century building.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.main_headline: THE FIVE-DAY WEEK: CAN JAPAN LEARN TO LOVE IT?
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.print_headline: THE FIVE-DAY WEEK: CAN JAPAN LEARN TO LOVE IT?
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.body_text: **********A Government advisory council has recommended that hard-laboring Japan move more rapidly toward a nationwide five-day work week - a goal not likely to be achieved easily in a country where six-day weeks were the firm standard until recently. **********While it has been the Government's wish for several years that Monday-to- Friday work weeks be adopted, a Labor Ministry study issued last spring showed that only 25 percent of all workers enjoyed a full two days off each week. **********Still, the percentage is rising steadily, and most labor experts assume it is only a matter of time before Japan resembles the West more closely in this regard. **********But major elements of the advisory group's proposal are likely to arouse controversy and are by no means guaranteed to become official policy. They are expected, nonetheless, to give fresh impetus to a broader national debate, long under way, over whether the Japanese toil too hard or whether their well- known work ethic is eroding. **********Changes in Labor Law Urged **********The panel's recommendations call for changes in the Labor Standards Law to reduce the officially sanctioned work week from 48 hours to 45 hours. At the same time, however, the legally permitted work day would be stretched from eight hours to nine hours. **********If adopted, the proposal would mean nine-hour work shifts, five days a week, rather than the present official standard of eight-hour shifts for six days. Although the suggested cut in overall hours is small, the intent seems clear: to nudge Japan toward a five-day week, with further reductions in hours to follow. **********In large companies, defined as those with 1,000 or more employees, a 40- hour, five-day week has already become the norm, as in the United States and other industrial countries. **********But less than one in five workers belong to such companies, Japan remaining a country of shops and small concerns despite the attention given to giants such as Mitsubishi and Toyota. In companies with fewer than 100 employees, the Labor Ministry found that nearly 40 percent of the workers put in at least 48 hours, usually by working all or part of a sixth day each week.   No Change in 37 Years **********The advisory group's proposal is not intended to be its final one. Considerable discussion is likely over the next year before the Government offers specific changes in legal working hours, which have not been altered in 37 years. **********Employers, especially in small and medium-size companies, can be counted on to oppose a reduction in work hours to 45 a week. Labor unions, which have long urged a five-day week, will probably regard a nine-hour day as too great a price to pay. Eight-hour days have been the custom for many years - excluding overtime, which Japanese workers accept as a matter of course. **********Among the major industrial countries, no work force is more diligent than the Japanese. On average, the Labor Ministry said, employees work 2,116 hours a year, compared with about 1,800 hours in the United States. **********That means the typical Japanese works more than an extra month a year compared with the average American. And the figures for Japan do not include overtime or after-hours socializing with colleagues, regarded as critical for maintaining workplace cohesiveness. White-collar workers habitually stay on in the office long after the work day is officially over.   The Drive to Work Hard **********Whether this drive to work is good or bad has been much discussed here for some time. **********More and more Japanese seem to be questioning the continued need for such assiduousness amid obvious prosperity. A woman identifying herself as a 24- year-old housewife in Kawasaki, south of Tokyo, complained in a letter to the newspaper Asahi recently that her husband left home every day at 7 A.M. and did not return until 11 P.M. **********''Can a lifetime devoted to one's work be called meritorious?'' she wrote. ''I want my husband to enjoy his life that he can have only once instead of working like a bee.'' **********In a Government opinion poll last year, people were asked, ''Would you sacrifice your daily life for the benefit of the company?'' Fifty-nine percent of those surveyed said no. The younger the person, the more likely was a negative response - 68 percent among those aged 20 to 29.   Political Considerations **********The Government's reasons for promoting a five-day week are embroidered with political considerations. It wishes to alter the image abroad of Japan as a nation of workaholics, enjoying an unfair economic advantage internationally because of the commitment to long hours. **********Despite all this, the work ethic appears to be deeply ingrained in this country, a point obvious to anyone who observes the enthusiasm with which even menial jobs are usually performed. **********Recognizing the resistance to change, the Labor Ministry advisory council recommended that any reduction in work hours not apply to three important industries - construction, transportation and small service-oriented companies. All have yet to trim their basic schedules to even 48 hours a week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/24/world.main_headline: BIG BATTLE CLEARS STREETS OF BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/24/world.print_headline: BIG BATTLE CLEARS STREETS OF BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/24/world.body_text: **********Druse and Moslem militiamen fought fierce battles in West Beirut for a second day today, transforming the city's western neighborhoods into ghost towns as most civilians abandoned the streets to the young fighters. **********The fighting closed the one crossing point between the eastern and western sectors of the capital and paralyzed West Beirut. **********The battles began when the Mourabitoun militia, a Libyan-backed Sunni Moslem group that lost its headquarters and other positions in fighting Thursday against the Druse Progressive Socialist Party militia, counterattacked early this morning. The most intense battles raged around the Gamal Abdel Nasser mosque, in the heart of the Mouribitoun's old stronghold. **********Tonight a group of Moslem and Druse leaders announced agreement on a cease-fire, and the battles appeared to subside shortly after.   Battles Against Christians **********While the Druse and Moslem militiamen fought each other, they also continued their battle against the forces of the Lebanese Army, predominantly Christians, who have remained loyal to President Amin Gemayel. **********There were sharp exchanges between the Moslem militias and the army along the Green Line dividing East and West Beirut. In the mountains overlooking the capital, the militias and the army traded artillery fire. **********Security sources said the West Beirut battles had left at least 18 people dead. **********The Druse militiamen had withdrawn from the mosque after taking it over from the Mourabitoun on Thursday and had turned it over to Government internal security forces, according to a security forces official. **********Around 4 A.M. today, he said, about 200 Mourabitoun fighters attacked nearby Druse positions and some residents of the area said the Mourabitoun had retaken the mosque. Fighting appeared to subside, but resumed around 9 A.M. **********Ambulances raced through the streets near the mosque as militiamen ran from building to building seeking better firing positions. **********Drivers deserted the broad Corniche Maazra in front of the mosque, and the area's narrow sidestreets reverberated with machine-gun and automatic weapons fire and the blasts from rocket-propelled grenades. **********Though the fighters avoided use of heavy artillery, the battles scared Beirut residents. ''Of all the frightening things that happen here, this is the worst,'' said a resident of the Mseitbeh neighborhood who huddled with his family in a hallway this afternoon to seek protection against the fighting outside. ''When you turn the next corner, you never know if you're going to run into people who'll start shooting.''  Druse Defend Attacks **********The Progressive Socialist Party issued a statement saying it had not lost any positions it took from the Mourabitoun on Thursday. **********In defending their actions against the Mourabitoun, the Druse officials said their rivals had endangered efforts to reach a cease-fire with Christian East Beirut by firing unauthorized artillery rounds. They also said the Mourabitoun had brought Palestinian fighters into West Beirut and wanted to expand the armed Palestinian presense here. **********Both the Druse militia and the Shiite Moslem militia known as Amal - the two are the dominant military forces in West Beirut - oppose the return of Palestinian fighters to Beirut. The Druse militia's strike against the Mourabitoun apparently had the blessing of Amal. **********Sunni, Shiite and Druse leaders representing a variety of political tendencies met this evening in an effort to stop the fighting and preserve what they called ''the unity of Islamic and national ranks.'' **********The group's communique announcing the cease-fire called for ''the withdrawal of all armed men from all parts of Beirut'' and asked the internal security forces to take over the maintanance of public safety.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/21/busin.body_text: **********MONDAY, MAY 21, 1984 **********The Economy **********The historic rescue plan for Continental Illinois brought open- ended assurances from the Federal Reserve and redefined the limits of banking deregulation. After two weeks of turmoil, the crisis was resolved in a hectic 24-hour period. (Page A1.) **********Growth is slowing, economists say, despite April's glowing statistics. The consensus is that the second-quarter advance in the gross national product will drop to between 3 percent and 5 percent, from the first quarter's 8.8 percent. (D1.) **********International **********Heads of four Latin nations protested debt refinancing terms.  Officials of Argentina, Brazil, Colombia and Mexico plan to meet soon to draw up new terms aimed at easing repayment. (D1.) **********Swiss voters rejected a proposed constitutional amendment that would have opened bank records to tax authorities. The measure would have made it easier for foreign authorities to track tax dodgers and others who hide funds in Swiss bank accounts. (D14.) **********Europe's high-technology industry is seeking to reverse its inability to convert innovation into profitable job-creating businesses. (D1.) I.B.M. is becoming Britain's leading computer maker, which has provoked some anguish in political circles. (D14.) **********Companies **********Exercise-equipment sales are gaining strength as thousands of Americans move from crowded and expensive health clubs to their homes to keep fit. Sales of exercise gear to those working out at home have passed the $1 billion-a-year mark. (D1.) **********Today's Columns  The 1984 fiscal year's deficit may be below the $189 billion projected by the Congressional Budget Office because of lower military and Medicare outlays. But high interest rates and aid for Continental Illinois could erase the savings. Washington Watch. (D2.) **********Stock prices closed just above their 1984 lows last Friday, as the market struggled with rising interest rates and trouble in the banking industry. Market Place. (D10.) **********Should traders be allowed to buy options on margin?  Yes, the industry says, because it would increase the shrinking pool of market liquidity. Futures/Options. (D10.) **********The Fed is not expected to tighten credit until the problems of Continental Illinois are resolved. Meanwhile, a large amount of unsold Treasury debt weighs heavily on the market. But the supply of top-grade corporate bonds remains low. Credit Markets. (D11.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/12/busin.body_text: **********YOU follow the brick driveway a **********few feet beyond the white colonnades and there is a bronze plaque that proclaims Herman & Rosner Enterprises. A recent addition to a fabled edifice, it could be a monument to heroism. Or it could be a tombstone to two middle-aged advertising men who instead of following the southerly trek of agencies looking for rent relief below 23d Street in Manhattan, instead screwed their courage to the sticking-place (as once suggested by Lady Macbeth), and moved their $10.5 million agency to Queens. **********There are places you can move an agency, but Queens is not generally considered one of them. Westchester. Fairfield. Fort Lee, N.J., O.K., O.K., O.K., but Queens? **********But, it must be admitted, this is no ordinary part of Queens, for, although it does have a nice mix of modest one- and two-family houses with some of the most beautiful rose bushes to be found in Gotham, and some manufacturing plants, it is the home of world- renowned Astoria studios, originally the Famous Players Laskey Studio, which was Hollywood before Hollywood was Hollywood. It is now Kaufman Astoria Studios, 15 buildings on 12 acres. **********And there is a lot of activity going out there these days, outer walls being refurbished, and on what was once the back lot, workers are finishing up a fancy new office wing, whose ornate canopied front door will face on a street that will be shut off to traffic and enclosed by big gates just like Hollywood studios. **********For this, Harvey Herman, 50-year- old chairman, and Charles E. Rosner, 40 and president, gave up 110 East 59th Street at Park Avenue. The incitement to relocate, according to Mr. Herman, was a $22-a-square-foot rental that was about to go to $42. **********Of course, they looked around down in the lower Fifth Avenue area where such outstanding creative agencies as Geer, DuBois, and Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson have taken up occupancy. But in the end, they were lured across the river by Harold Rand, recently named marketing director of Kaufman Astoria Studios and a friend of long standing. **********And during a tour of the establishment yesterday conducted by Larry Barr, vice president, production, of Kaufman Astoria, one could see how the place could grow on you, even if you do have to wear an I.D. badge. The visible activity going on in the huge sound stages has the vibes of great creativity compared with the sterile confines of midtown office buildings. **********On one stage, workmen were putting together some background material for the 20th Century-Fox film ''Turk 182'' now in production, while on another, carpenters were knocking down a set of Caesars Palace, Atlantic City, in which Buddy Hackett had just starred in a spot done by the Bean-Kahn production company for Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline. **********According to Mr. Barr, every imaginable kind of production specialist has offices in or near the premises, which is in keeping with the desire of George Kaufman, the developer, to make this a communications complex. And the place is already 95 percent to 98 percent rented, according to Mr. Rand. **********But as exciting as it all may seem, Mr. Herman still said of the move, ''This is freightening and risky, but it is pioneering.'' He is in 4,000 temporary square feet preparing to move into 4,500 permanent square feet at $18 a square foot. **********There was a weekend there when they almost did not come to Queens. That is when they measured up the pros and cons and got seven of the former and 23 of the latter. What saved the day for Astoria was their realization that the few juicy pros outweighed the many piddling cons. **********''We think we are going to attract people with a pioneering spirit who can see the future here,'' said Mr. Herman, to which Mr. Rosner added: ''Agencies like to claim they're innovative, but its usually only with the client's money. We're being innovative with our own.'' **********In addition to the N and RR subway trains, which stop at the Steinway station three blocks away, there is a shuttle bus from the East Side that the studio operates during rush hour, and it has been prove that Porsches, BMW's, Mercedes and even stretch limos with one-way rear windows make the trip over the Queensborough Bridge with ease. **********But what is it like to work there? M.J. Kelly of 20th Century-Fox was asked that question during the tour. ''A lot of good restaurants, but no shopping,'' Miss Kelly said. And that's the bottom line.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/09/world.main_headline: SHARDS OF SOLIDARITY: PUTTING THEM TOGETHER AGAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/09/world.print_headline: SHARDS OF SOLIDARITY: PUTTING THEM TOGETHER AGAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/09/world.body_text: **********With more and more hard-core Solidarity activists being freed under the terms of a sweeping Government amnesty, Poland's outlawed trade union movement is finding it even more difficult to unify and reorganize its ranks.  For one thing, it has all but lost its rallying cry, the demand to free political prisoners. For another, Solidarity has sprouted separate and potentially contentious branches since it was banned and its leaders were imprisoned. **********There is now an above-ground but largely inert wing, headed by Lech Walesa, who once built Solidarity into a 10-million-member organization. Mr. Walesa, who has been free but circumscribed in his activities, may soon face challenges from old rivals whose credibility has been enhanced by the time they spent behind bars. Last week, he pointedly conferred with one freed prisoner, Andrzej Gwiazda, who lost an election to Mr. Walesa during Solidarity's heyday. **********Bujak a Defiant Fugitive **********There is also a small but active clandestine organization, headed by Zbigniew Bujak, a 30-year-old former factory technician who has captured the popular imagination by remaining a defiantly outspoken fugitive while his colleagues were in jail. He has rejected the amnesty, whose terms call for Solidarity's underground members to come forward and to surrender clandestine materials. **********Finally, there are several foreign subsidiaries, involved in fund raising, in Western Europe, the United States, Canada and Australia. Each of these segments has its own priorities and programs and adherents. **********Then, too, the social climate has changed while many of the leaders were in jail and many of those emerging are commenting on the apathy, fatigue and fatalism they have noticed in their compatriots. **********All of these factors almost certainly figured in the decision by the Government to announce the amnesty and to extend its term to the end of the year. The Government apparently hopes that Solidarity's internal difficulties, combined with diminished public enthusiasm for disorder and the somewhat successful buyout of such key sectors of the work force as the coal miners, will keep the returning activists from picking up where they left off. **********The position of the Government is that the situation has normalized to the point where dissidents need not be imprisoned, but that they cannot be allowed to organize campaigns that might shake or topple the framework of the Communist system. **********This was asserted again in an editorial in Saturday's issue of Trybuna Ludu, the party newspaper. The editorial noted that Western radio stations broadcasting in Polish had declared that if the amnesty is to make any sense it must be accompanied by the legalization of Solidarity and the restoration of union pluralism. **********Illusion and Reality The editorial said that, while pluralistic approaches remained possible within the ''framework of the socialist state,'' the kind of independent unions advocated by Solidarity were unaccceptable and that ''it is an illusion to think that the past will return.'' **********Indeed, the freed prisoners seem to be suffering few illusions. **********''We are in a period of negative calm,'' said Mr. Gwiazda, and a factory hand associated with the underground faction said, ''Our work will take years.'' **********The initial euphoria of some of the freed prisoners, who sounded at times like cheerleaders urging renewed confrontation, has given way to sober statements of people who recognize that, after two and a half years of isolation from one another and from society, what they need most is a chance to confer and and consult. **********For example, when Adam Michnik, one of the most defiant of the detainees, was expelled from jail by force on Saturday, he demonstratively shunned interviewers and left Warsaw. Friends said he would probably have nothing to say for several weeks while he acquainted himself with the new situation.   Solidarity Meeting Urged **********At the same time, Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, a Solidarity leader from Wroclaw, said he thought a full meeting of activists should be held in perhaps a month. **********He had earlier made a dramatic gesture to affirm unity of the opposition movement, when on his release, he dodged surveillance and made his way to Warsaw where he signed a joint open letter with Mr. Bujak, the underground leader. In the letter, the two men called for a resumption of the struggle ''to achieve union pluralism and freedom of thought and expression.'' Despite appeals for a full reunion, some sources close to the movement said they thought the meetings to be held in the next weeks would be small and private and away from the glare of publicity. Already, they said, polling of activists has begun, with people being asked to suggest approaches for renewed organizing efforts. **********So far, these have reportedly ranged from urgings that Solidarity infiltrate the worker self-management groups now legally established at factories, to calls for greater emphasis on underground activities, such as publishing, clandestine radio and consciousness- raising groups.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/09/busin.main_headline: Three Executives Out In Shake-Up at Amway
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Three Executives Out In Shake-Up at Amway
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/09/busin.body_text: **********The Amway Corporation, the big direct-sales company that pleaded guilty recently to charges of customs fraud in Canada, said yesterday that three senior executives had left and that more might follow. **********''This is a painful experience, but once we get through it we are bullish about the future of the company,'' said Casey Wondergem, director of public relations. **********Those leaving are William J. Halliday, 63, executive vice president for corporate services, who plans to retire April 1; Noel Black, 51, director of international public affairs, and William Flakenstern, 49, treasurer since 1978. **********The privately held Amway, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., is owned by Richard DeVos and Jay Van Andel, who founded the company 25 years ago in June. Sales in the fiscal year ended last July dropped to $1.13 billion from from $1.2 billion a year earlier. **********The restructuring has ''nothing whatsoever'' to do with Amway's recent Canadian problems, Mr. Wondergem said. **********The Canadian authorities last year charged the company and Mr. DeVos, Mr. Van Andel, Mr. Halliday and C. Dale Discher, vice president for investments, with fraudulently altering bills of lading and filing false customs statements to avoid paying duties. The charges were dropped in November when Amway and its Canadian subsidiary pleaded guilty and paid a $20.2 million fine. **********Mr. Wondergem said the decline in sales was responsible for the restructuring. ''The two owners are taking this opportunity to try to turn this thing around and get the curve moving back up,'' he said. **********He said the changes involved the consolidation of some structures and the elimination of others. ''When you are restructuring departments and divisions, you can't avoid the people thing,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/07/busin.main_headline: JAPAN TECHNOLOGY MONITORED BY WORRIED U.S. COMPETITORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/07/busin.print_headline: JAPAN TECHNOLOGY MONITORED BY WORRIED U.S. COMPETITORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/07/busin.body_text: **********American companies and the United States Government, after years of paying scant attention to Japanese technological developments, are now stepping up their efforts to monitor Japanese advances. **********The new efforts stem from a growing belief among American technology experts that the lack of knowledge resulting from the failure to watch such Japanese advances has put the United States at a disadvantage in the growing competition between the two nations in such emerging fields as electronics and biotechnology. **********''It's almost beyond the realm of imagination that companies in the United States don't keep tabs on what's being done by their competitors,'' said Jack L. Osborn, executive managing director for Asian operations for TRW Inc. and former economic attache for high technology at the United States Embassy here. ''But American companies are not keeping tabs on the Japanese competition to the level the threat warrants.'' **********When American technologists do visit here, they are frequently surprised by the extent and sophistication of the work being done in such fields as optical communications, data storage, computer memory chips, advanced ceramics and automation. **********''I must admit that while I was well informed before visiting here, what I have seen since I came here almost frightens me,'' said Roman J. Wasilewski, an expert in advanced new materials who is surveying Japanese work in that field for the National Science Foundation. **********Americans in Japan **********To remedy the situation, American companies such as the Burroughs Corporation, the Eastman Kodak Company, the GTE Corporation and TRW are moving people here or are hiring people to keep track of Japanese work. The American Electronics Association, a trade group, has just opened an office here to monitor technological and political developments. **********The American Chamber of Commerce in Japan also formed a high- technology committee to keep members informed on developments in the field. One of the first actions of the committee was to urge the United States Government to step up its observations of Japanese technology. **********''In a nutshell, our national ability to monitor and understand emerging Japanese commercial technologies of great significance, in a timely manner, is not what it should be,'' the committee said in a statement. **********The Government is also taking some steps. The House Subcommittee on Science, Research and Technology held hearings on the subject in March and is proposing to allocate $750,000 for the translation of Japanese scientific papers into English. The United States Embassy will add more people to monitor Japanese development and the National Science Foundation is beginning a program of sending experts in various fields to survey developments in Japan. **********Still, most American experts say too little is being done. The Boston Consulting Group, for instance, found that of 12 major foreign companies it interviewed recently, only four actively followed Japanese technology. Experts say that if American industry fails to keep track of Japanese technological progress, Japanese companies will leap ahead of the Americans before they realize it. **********''We will continue to be caught by surprise as we were in the steel industry, the automobile industry and the consumer electronics industry,'' said John A. Alic, a project manager for the Office of Technology Assessment in Washington, who has done some studies of Japanese technology. **********One of the major reasons for the failure to watch the Japanese is that Americans have long been the leaders in technology and suffer from what is known as the not-invented- here syndrome, the belief that work done by others is not important. **********''When you think you're number one, it's very hard to get excited about the others until you find you're not number one any more,'' said Justin Bloom, a former science attache at the United States Embassy here and now a consulting engineer in Potomac, Md. **********Almost without exception, American technology experts stationed here say their colleagues in America seriously underestimate the Japanese accomplishments. **********''There is a great gulf of willingness to accept the fact that the Japanese are leading in certain areas,'' said Thomas J. Savereide, technical director of Sumitomo 3M Ltd., a joint venture of the Minnesota company and two Japanese companies, the NEC Corporation and Sumitomo Electric Industries. **********Optical Communications **********Many experts think Japan is ahead, for instance, in the emerging field of optical communications, in which information is transmitted using light traveling through glass fibers rather than electricity traveling through copper wiring. Japanese industry has developed a low-cost method of manufacturing the fibers and is highly advanced in making the electronic components needed for such communications. **********The Japanese expertise in optics also extends into the area of data storage. The Japanese are as advanced as the United States in development of new optical disks, which can store far more computer data than the currently used magnetic disks. **********In electronics, the Japanese lead in computer memory chips, and have more experience than American companies with a process for producing computer chips that use only small amounts of electricity. **********Ceramics and Fast Trains **********Other areas in which the Japanese are ahead of the Americans or are drawing close include advanced ceramics for use in electronics and in engines, supercomputers, high-speed railroads, photovoltaics, information displays used in portable computers, low-priced copiers and printers, and factory automation using robots and computers. **********In some of these fields, according to industry analysts, American companies virtually ignored Japanese efforts until they had lost their dominant share of the market. **********In addition to keeping up with the competition's technology, monitoring Japanese developments can also lead to discovery of new market opportunities to sell equipment in Japan and to influence Japanese policies. **********When the Japanese Government was considering legislation recently that would have been detrimental to United States software and telecommunications industries, American representatives here protested quickly. One bill was tabled and the other changed in a way favorable to the American companies. In the past, officials here say, protests would come largely from Washington and would often be too late to influence the legislation. The Japanese have become more open to such intervention, recently deciding to allow American participation on some of the advisory councils that shape legislation. **********American companies might also spot technology they could use for their own products. ''We're in a position to come over here and copy from them,'' said T. E. Blaszczak, vice president of design and manufacturing technology for Westinghouse Electric Japan. **********Undoubtedly the best example of the benefits of monitoring technology is Japan itself, which has scoured the world for technology it used for its own advancement. Employees of Japanese companies stationed abroad are well-known for the extent to which they monitor patents, hire market researchers to perform studies, and attend scientific meetings and trade shows taking assiduous notes and photographing the insides of computers on display. **********Japanese Use U.S. Advances **********Arthur Heuer, a professor of ceramics at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, recalled that when he did some work with potential application to the development of new types of diesel engines made of ceramics, several Japanese companies were quick to inquire about his work and use it. American companies did not pay attention even when he went to them. For reasons like this, according to experts, Japan leads in many phases of the use of ceramic materials. **********In some cases, the Japanese have gone too far in their quest and have been charged with copying or stealing technology. The most notable example was in 1982, when executives of Hitachi Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation were charged with trying to steal trade secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation. The companies and some employees later were fined. **********Japanese information gathering extends beyond technology to marketing and general business information. One American consultant recalls seeing at Hitachi a book containing estimates of Motorola's sales broken down by product and by state. John W. Cusick, who runs the Japan office of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said Japanese companies often tell him which A.T.& T. officials are visiting before he finds out from his own company. **********American companies have done nowhere near as extensive a surveillance job. Part of the reason is that most American companies have small staffs here whose main job is to sell products, not gather intelligence. **********''The way most American companies operate here, you sort of catch the information on the fly,'' said Edwin W. Schaffner, executive assistant to the president of the Control Data Corporation's Japan subsidiary. **********Language Barrier **********Language is also a problem. While the Japanese are taught English as a second language, few Americans know Japanese and fewer still understand both technology and Japanese. Because of United States military concerns, far more American technical experts know Russian than know Japanese. **********Until now, the most extensive monitoring of Japanese technology has been done by the United States military and, it is believed, by the intelligence agencies. But they are interested mainly in finding technology with military applications, not commercial ones. **********Among American companies, I.B.M. is said to have an extensive force of Japan watchers, both inside its I.B.M. Japan subsidiary and outside it. I.B.M. closed down much of its Japan-watching activities in 1981 in an economy move, according to a source at the company, but recognized the value of the monitoring activities and resumed them a year later. **********Kodak, after leaving most of its Japanese operations to distributors, plans to move people here to offer more technical support to its sales force and to monitor technology. The GTE Corporation opened an office here in January. **********Some market research firms and trade journals also see growing opportunities to provide information to Americans. In the past year, three companies have started publishing English language electronics newsletters focusing on Japan. **********Analysts say another step that must be taken for the Americans to gain the kind of insight into Japanese technology as the Japanese have elsewhere is for American students to study at Japanese universities and work for Japanese companies, just as Japanese students have studied and worked in the United States. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology runs one such student exchange program with Japan and the American Electronics Association is beginning another one this year. **********Joint Ventures **********Another effective way of transferring technology is to engage in joint ventures such as General Motors's arrangement with Toyota to produce small cars in California, the experts say. Such joint ventures between American and Japanese companies are increasing. **********One big obstacle facing American Japan-watchers is that foreigners are generally not permitted to participate in the huge research and development efforts sponsored by the Japanese Government in such fields as advanced computers and optical communications. That situation is changing to some extent, however. **********In addition, just gathering the information is not sufficient. A means must be found to distribute it to the proper people and to use it. **********Perhaps the biggest challenge, however, is to get American industry to become more receptive to ideas developed by others. **********''If we had every single technical word written in Japan I'm not sure American scientists would pay attention to it,'' said Mr. Bloom, the former embassy science attache. **********James C. Abegglen, a Japan expert associated with the Boston Consulting Group here, agreed: ''The top management of the American company has to have the conviction that there is something here worth knowing about.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/14/world.body_text: **********Salvage crews retrieved the first of 30 containers of radioactive material today from the torn hull of a French freighter that sank 19 days ago in the North Sea, officials said. **********The officials also said they were quite certain the 29 other containers carrying uranium hexafluoride were still inside the hull of the 4,210-ton Mont Louis, which broke open during a fierce storm last Monday. **********''We found a lot of them bunched together in the forward part of the ship,'' said Paul Goris of the Antwerp salvaging company of l'Union de Remorquage et de Sauvetage. **********Divers also picked up one more of the 22 empty containers aboard, the 14th to be retrieved to date, said Hans Walenkamp of the Dutch salvaging company of Smit Tak International. **********Thursday was the first day divers were at the stricken vessel after six days of storms and high waves. **********The Mont Louissank Aug. 25 in about 46 feet of water after colliding with a passenger ferry. Heavy storms repeatedly have halted salvage operations that began Aug. 29. **********A sheet of light fuel, measuring about 6 miles by a half mile, spread from the wreck today, but it was brought under control later by four navy vessels, John Huylebroek, spokesman for the Belgian Public Health Ministry, said. **********The Mont Louis had been on a routine voyage to Riga in the Soviet Union where its cargo of lightly radioactive uranium hexafluoride was to be enriched for use in several West European nuclear power plants. **********In Strasbourg, France, meanwhile, the European Parliament urged the European Community to impose strict controls on shipments of radioactive materials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/21/busin.body_text: **********France recorded its first trade surplus of the year last month, and a Government official said today that it showed the success of the Government's export drive. **********Record exports helped to bring about an adjusted trade surplus of $9.8 million in May. **********France recorded a $517 million deficit in April. The Government official, Foreign Trade Minister Edith Cresson, said at a news conference that the trade improvement was also due to an 11 percent decline in the energy deficit, to $1.66 billion in May, and a recovery in the surplus on industrial goods.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/29/busin.body_text: **********William J. Keller, a ruddy, muscular man who grows 50 acres of horseradish near this farm town a dozen miles east of St. Louis, asks himself why he continues to grow this problematic root. **********Harvesting it requires digging deep holes, some 16 inches into the soil. Harvesting continues into the chill of winter, and preparing the bitter root for market brings a larger flood of tears to his eyes than do onions. **********''There's a lot of orneriness to growing horseradish,'' said Mr. Keller, whose father also cultivated the pungent root. ''You're out in the wet and cold harvesting when the corn and soybean farmers around town have their tractors in the barn and have gone off to Florida.'' **********But this is clearly the year to stay with horseradish, as arduous as it is. Mr. Keller, one of 33 horseradish farmers in and around Collinsville - which styles itself the Horseradish Capital of America - predicts that high prices and a bumper crop will make this year the most profitable ever for horseradish growers. **********Last year, by contrast, severe drought and heat hobbled the crop of the nation's 80 or so farms that raise horseradish in big quantities. The roots, which are brown on the outside but white on the inside, were puny compared with their normal 14-inch length and 2-inch diameter. The poor harvest pushed prices about 15 cents a pound above their usual level of 30 cents. **********A Lucrative Crop **********Mr. Keller said it costs him $2,000 an acre to cultivate his crop, or seven times what it costs to grow corn, the crop he rotates with horseradish. His main cost is labor. For planting, he needs 15 people - one person can plant one and a half acres a day - and for the harvest, which is set to start in just a few weeks, he needs 25. **********''In the long run, it is more lucrative per acre than other crops,'' Mr. Keller said. In an average year he will get 8,000 pounds of horseradish per acre, which translates to $2,400 in revenues. This means $400 profit per acre, compared with $50 an acre for his corn. This year, however, abundant late-summer rain is expected to raise his yield to 10,000 pounds an acre - at more than 40 cents a pound. **********The nation's horseradish growers do a lot of haggling over price with the handful of processors, just as their parents haggled with their processors' parents. **********''Right now there's an acute shortage of horseradish,'' said Joseph Dogan, general manager of Thor- Shackel Horseradish Inc., a processor and packer in Burr Ridge, just southwest of Chicago. ''This year is going to be a very expensive year for horseradish, maybe over 50 cents a pound. It's going to be wonderful for growers.'' **********Mr. Dogan, who estimates that his 74-year-old business processes 400,000 pounds a year, said he markets everything from 5-ounce jars, which retail for 69 cents, to 30-pound jars for commercial use. He said prices will likely go up several cents a small jar at the retail level this year. **********About 70 percent of all horseradish is sold straight. The remainder is used in shrimp sauce, in mixes with mayonnaise and in other dressings. Horseradish has its biggest sales around the Jewish New Year, Christmas, Passover and Easter. **********'A Business of Entrepreneurs' **********''The little guys who used to get 50 pounds of roots, fool around with them in their kitchen, and then sell them have died out,'' said Sol Tulkoff, who boasts that his 21-acre family- owned industrial park in Baltimore makes his company the nation's largest horseradish processor. ''It's now become a business of entrepreneurs.'' **********Mr. Tulkoff's parents, immigrants from Russia, founded Tulkoff's Horseradish Products Company in 1928. He said many processors have left the business because their small volume did not enable them to afford the modern equipment required to satisfy Federal inspectors, or the sophisticated ventilation systems needed to prevent workers from getting teary-eyed. **********Mr. Tulkoff, the marketer extraordinaire of the industry, has developed a zesty condiment known as Tiger Sauce, which relies on a healthy dollop of horseradish. **********He estimated that something more than 2,000 acres of horseradish are cultivated in the nation. Appreciable quantities are grown in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Wisconsin and California, in addition to Illinois. No one seems to know exactly how many growers there are, however, or how many pounds are harvested each year. Indeed, the United States Department of Agriculture has no horseradish expert. **********Drawbacks for Growers **********''There's something intriguing about growing a minority crop,'' Mr. Keller said, bending over to examine the 15-inch-high plants. The soil was loamy on top and sandy below - ideal for growing horseradish. **********Growing a minority crop has its shortcomings, however. Chemical companies do not manufacture special pesticides for horseradish as they do for crops like corn. Nor do farm implement companies produce equipment tailor-made for planting or harvesting horseradishes. **********As a result, horseradish growers are often inventors. George H. Willaredt, a grower in Edwardsville, 8 miles northwest of Collinsville, said he had developed a 30-foot-wide rack that attaches to a tractor and carries a dozen fieldhands who plant rows as the tractor inches forward. In addition, he has developed a reinforced potato harvester that gouges 18 inches into the ground to harvest. **********''My father started out with just five acres,'' said Mr. Willaredt, who - thanks to the new machinery - has expanded to 100 acres of horseradish, ''That was all we could do without this specialized machinery because it's such a high labor-intensive crop.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/world.main_headline: ON GRENADA, SOUNDING OFF AGAIN IN PRINT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/world.print_headline: ON GRENADA, SOUNDING OFF AGAIN IN PRINT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/world.body_text: **********- **********''Dear Editor: I have read the first two issues of The Grenadian Voice and I will never read this paper again.'' **********''Dear Editor: I am very apprehensive about the future of Grenada.'' **********''Dear Editor: For quite some time now I have been experiencing problems with the Grenada Electricity Services Ltd.'' **********After years of control under the leftist Government that ended with an American-led invasion on Oct. 25, the people of Grenada are sounding off again in The Grenadian Voice, a revived, low- budget weekly newspaper. **********Its editor, Leslie Pierre, who was jailed for more than two years after publishing one issue of the paper in 1981, is printing letters from varying viewpoints, and they portray an emerging debate about the future of the country. **********'I Express My Congrats' **********Elizabeth Charles wrote in the latest issue: ''I express my congrats to our Lord and Savior. Then lots of songs and praises are going out to the U.S. and Caribbean forces for saving our lives.'' **********''We call on all members of the peacekeeping force to stop all this unnecessary interference,'' wrote Nikki Ann Penny. ''And let us continue our own affair in peace.'' **********One unsigned letter berated meddling outsiders who ''in some cases don't even know where Grenada is.'' **********''People have not had an opportunity to speak for such a long time, and I want to give them the chance to speak their minds,'' Mr. Pierre said in a recent interview in his tiny office near the central fish market.
