His newspaper, which now runs to 16 pages, includes three pages of letters under the heading ''The Village Standpipe.'' **********The first issue, dated Nov. 20, contained a lead article, headlined ''The New Beginning,'' that left no doubt where the paper stands. It referred to the ''tyrranical rule'' of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop and ''two weeks of terror under a bloodthirsty bunch'' who jailed and then killed him on Oct. 19. The headline above its letters page read: ''God Bless America. May the U.S. Heroes Rest in Peace.'' **********The newspaper is beginning to reflect a return to normalcy here with articles on agriculture, a news roundup called ''The World in a Nutshell'' a sports section and sensationalist articles. **********''Our purpose is to provide a vehicle for the freest possible expression of views of the people of the community and to be a sort of, if you like, opposition,'' Mr. Pierre said, ''not for the sake of opposing but to make sure all issues are aired fully.'' **********He said the letters pages were a central part of this aim, letting readers involve themselves in the national debate as Grenada works to rebuild a democratic political system and to prepare the way for new elections, due in a year or more.   Surviving With Outside Help **********Mr. Pierre said he was selling about 6,000 copies of his press run of 7,000. But he said distribution was still a problem and the newspaper was still slow in attracting advertisers because ''people haven't been used to advertising for the past few years.'' **********It is surviving with the help of other regional newspapers like The Barbados Nation and The Trinidad Express, which are printing it at low cost and sending copy editors and business managers on short tours to help out. **********''Nobody has sent us a bill yet,'' Mr. Pierre said.  ''We're operating on advance income and the sale of the newspaper.  The price is 75 East Caribbean cents, or about 30 United States cents, a copy.'' **********Grenada has a history of a lively press dating from colonial days when small presses turned out a variety of little papers and pamphlets. **********In the post-independence government of Sir Eric Gairy, when the Government-owned West Indian and independent Torchlight were publishing, the opposition New Jewel Movement led by Mr. Bishop was inspired in its pamphleteering. To get around a Government ban on unauthorized publication of periodicals issued more frequently than 100 days apart, Mr. Bishop's men changed their pamphlet's title each issue, bringing out a ''new'' publication each week. **********Once in power, though, the New Jewel Movement took over the West Indian, renaming it The Free West Indian, and within five months the party had closed down The Torchlight. The next year, a nonpolitical newspaper sponsored by the Roman Catholic Church, The Focus, was also closed after just one issue, leaving Grenada with only the Government-controlled publication.   A Decision to Publish **********Shocked by the apathy of the public to the shutting off of a free press, Mr. Pierre said, he decided in 1981 with 25 other shareholders to publish an independent newspaper that would conform to all laws and would be, at the start at least, ''deliberately innocuous.'' **********Its first mimeographed run of 2,500 copies was sold out and an additional 500 were printed and distributed, Mr. Pierre said, but it was shut down after the second issue and Mr. Pierre was detained for questioning. When he escaped from detention the day after the Americans landed, Mr. Pierre said, ''I was still waiting to be questioned, two and a half years later.'' **********Like the Grenadians who write letters to his newspaper, Mr. Pierre is concerned about the future. There is no assurance, he said, that today's freedom of the press will not again be restricted. **********''Let's hope it doesn't happen here again,'' he said. ''But I wouldn't put it past an elected government to attempt it again, and what's to stop them?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/21/busin.body_text: **********President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen said today that his country had discovered ''large'' quantities of oil that could be exported through the Red Sea in two years or less. **********In an interview at his residence tonight, President Saleh said that the reserves of the two fields discovered so far and the amounts they could produce had not yet been fully determined. But, he added, the Hunt Oil Company had informed his Government that oil was available in ''commercial'' and ''exportable'' quantities. **********First Confirmation **********His statements tonight were the first official confirmation of rumors that have circulated through this capital and American oil circles for months that a vast amount of oil had been discovered by the Yemen Hunt Oil Company, a joint venture between Yemen's national oil company and the Dallas-based Hunt Oil Company, headed by Ray L. Hunt, one of the Texas Hunts. **********Arab and Western diplomats agreed in interviews this week that the discovery of a large amount of oil would revolutionize the economy of this rugged, backward country and radically alter its diplomatic position. Yemen, one of the world's poorest countries, with a per capita income of $456 a year, has been heavily dependent on aid from Saudi Arabia and the Soviet Union. **********Oil experts say that a production of 100,000 barrels a day is required to make exports economically feasible. Sources in Sana estimated, however, that Yemen would be able to produce at least 200,000 barrels a day, a ''conservative estimate,'' a specialist said. **********Since Yemen consumes only about 20,000 barrels of oil a day, production of more than 200,000 barrels a day would make this country a small, but steady, oil exporter. At 200,000 barrels a day, Yemen's output would approximate the production added by each of several non-OPEC countries since 1981. **********Diplomats said that an added advantage was that, unlike most other states of the Arabian Peninsula, Yemen could export from the Red Sea, not from the Persian Gulf, where oil exports are threatened by the tanker war between Iran and Iraq. **********Last summer Hunt Oil announced that it had made Yemen's first oil strike ever in a 12,600-square-kilometer concession in the Marib al Jauf basin, in the northeastern part of the country. The company initially announced that the well produced 7,800 barrels a day in crude oil, but this figure was quickly revised to 10,000 barrels a day. **********The find prompted immediate interest within oil circles, because Hunt had found the oil after drilling only one well. Oil experts here described this as a 1-in-10,000 probability. **********Hunt has drilled two more wells since then, but it made no announcement about whether oil had been found in those wells. William J. Furr, vice president of operations for the Yemen Hunt Oil Company, said earlier this week that Hunt had brought in a second rig that would enable it to drill more wells at a faster rate. But he declined to confirm reports that vast quantities of oil had already been discovered. **********In Dallas, a spokesman for Hunt Oil declined to release further details, citing a request from the Yemeni Government. Hunt Oil is an independent oil company with interests domestically and abroad. It is also independent of other oil interests operated by Nelson Bunker Hunt and Herbert Hunt, the billionaire Texas businessmen who are brothers of Ray Hunt. **********Refinery and Pipeline Planned **********President Saleh said tonight that two oilfields had been discovered. He said Yemen intended to build a refinery, a pipeline from the fields to the Red Sea - about 150 miles - and ''all the infrastructure required'' to exploit the oil. **********He said that several unspecified companies would be bidding on contracts for the projects, and that construction would take ''no more than two years.'' However, he added, if Yemen faced ''economic pressures,'' the infrastructure work could be completed more quickly. **********He declined to specify the type of pressures that might arise. But Yemen has previously played down the oil discovery, partly for fear that Saudi Arabia and other donors might decrease their aid levels, diplomats said. **********No Sharing With Southern Yemen **********President Saleh also made it clear that he intended the oil to be used for the immediate benefit of Yemen, and would not be shared with the Soviet- backed, Marxist Southern Yemen. **********But, the President added, Yemen was conducting ''studies'' to determine whether joint oil exploration could be carried out in the two countries' ''adjoining areas.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/04/world.body_text: **********The publisher and the editor of Ethnos, the newspaper with Greece's largest circulation, will be tried in December on charges of tapping the office telephone of a Cypriot- born journalist in Athens and of publishing a transcript, lawyers in the case said today. **********The journalist, Paul Anastasiades, who writes under the name Paul Anastasi, is a correspondent for The Daily Telegraph of London and a part-time correspondent for The New York Times. **********The case was brought by the Athens Public Prosecutor, the Greek equivalent of a district attorney, and Mr. Anastasiades is involved as the offended party. If convicted, the Ethnos publisher, George Bobolas, and the editor, Alexander Filipopoulos, could be sentenced to a maximum of five years' imprisonment. In the investigation preceding the placing of formal charges, both men acknowledged the use of material obtained by tapping but said they were not directly involved in the tapping itself. **********Lawyers for Mr. Anastasiades, in making their announcement today, did not say when the two men had been charged or when the court date had been set, but both actions were believed to have been taken in the last several days. **********The disclosure of a taped conversation between Mr. Anastasiades and a lawyer friend followed the correspondent's publication of a book in which he contended that Ethnos received the material support and assistance of the Soviet secret police, the K.G.B. In a suit for libel and defamation brought by Ethnos, Mr. Anastasiades was first sentenced to two years in prison; on appeal, the term was commuted to a fine last May.   Tapes Offered to Press Ministry **********In presenting his charges against Mr. Bobolas and Mr. Filipopoulos for trial on Dec. 13, the Prosecutor, Leonidas Lazarakos, accused the two men of initiating the wiretap and making illicit use of the information obtained by publishing it and by offering the tapes to the head of the Press Ministry, Under Secretary Dimitris Maroudas. **********Mr. Maroudas said the Government had refused to accept the tapes. In recent conversations, a senior official assured The Times that no wire-tapping of its phone conversations was being conducted. The New York Times, which has its own correspondent based in Athens, rents office space from Mr. Anastasiades in the same suite in which he has his office. **********Zissis Constantinou, one of Mr. Anastasiades's lawyers, said today that the trial would be the first in Greece on wiretapping charges. **********The conversation that Ethnos published involved Mr. Anastasiades and Panayotis Zotos. Speaking shortly after Mr. Bobolas had filed suit against Mr. Anastasiades, the two discussed the Anastasiades book and Soviet ''disinformation'' tactics. In an article accompanying the extracts, Ethnos presented the conversation as one between two agents of the Central Intelligence Agency. **********The newspaper asserted that the ''agents,'' Mr. Anastasiades and Mr. Zotos, discussed plans to murder Ethnos personnel, destabilize democratic institutions in Greece and extend such activities to other European countries. Nothing in the published excerpts supported these accusations. **********Ethnos said in its article that it possessed ''tens of tapes'' of Mr. Anastasiades's conversations. It said they had been mailed anonymously to the newspaper by people it described as members of Mr. Anastasiades's ''group of agents who apparently disagreed with the murderous plans of their bosses and decided to warn us against the intentions of this ruthless group.''  Anonymous Caller Cited **********Testifying before a magistrate investigating the case against them, the publisher and the editor said they had not been involved in the wiretapping. They said their only contact with the tappers was an anonymous telephone call advising them of the particular interest of the tape that Ethnos subsequently published. **********Mr. Bobolas and Mr. Filipopoulos said they had considered it their duty to inform the public of the purported conspiracy against Ethnos. **********The prosecutor accused them of initiating the tapping when they failed to produce the parcel in which they said the tapes had been mailed. He accused Mr. Bobolas and Mr. Filipopoulos of violating, ''jointly and with intent,'' a constitutional guarantee of privacy of communications. **********Mr. Filipopoulos and Mr. Bobolas declined to comment on the accusations. **********Meanwhile, Mr. Anastasiades is appealing to the Supreme Court for a new trial in the libel case. In his earlier appeal, the public prosecutor said that Ethnos was ''evidently pro-Soviet'' and that some of the Soviet publishing officials with whom Mr. Bobolas had dealings as a publisher of Soviet books in Greek translation might have been K.G.B. agents. But he said this did not justify the contentions of Mr. Anastasiades's book.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/12/world.main_headline: SHULTZ SAYS SOVIET OLYMPICDECISION IS PART OF PLAN TO 'FREEZE' TIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/12/world.print_headline: SHULTZ SAYS SOVIET OLYMPICDECISION IS PART OF PLAN TO 'FREEZE' TIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/12/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Soviet decision not to attend the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer was part of an overall Soviet plan to put relations with the United States ''in a sort of deep freeze.'' **********Today Vietnam and Mongolia, two of the Soviet Union's Asian Communist allies, joined in the Soviet-backed move to boycott the Los Angeles Games. After the Russians announced their decision Tuesday not to attend, Bulgaria and East Germany were the first two nations to follow suit. Others are expected to do the same soon. **********State Department officials said they had received word that Moscow was applying diplomatic pressure on certain African countries, like Ethiopia, which receive considerable aid from Moscow, to stay away from Los Angeles.   Reports of Soviet Debate **********Some State Department officials said that there were unconfirmed intelligence reports circulating in the West that the Soviet decision on the Olympics was made after a spirited debate within the Soviet leadership. According to these reports, officials said, the Soviet K.G.B., its state security agency, as well as Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Defense Minister, and Grigory V. Romanov, who has jurisdiction over the internal security, argued strongly that the risks of defection and possible harm to Soviet participants made it necessary to avoid the Games. **********State Department officials also said that they had been told by East European diplomats that the East Europeans were not consulted by the Soviet Union beforehand and that the Hungarians, in particular, resented being forced into a position where they will have to go along with the boycott.   Olympic Chief to Keep Trying **********In Lausanne, Switzerland, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the Spaniard who is president of the International Olympic Committee, said he would ''fight to the last minute,'' which is June 2, to change the minds of Soviet leaders. **********He said he was waiting for Soviet permission to fly to Moscow to try to speak directly with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader. He made public the text of a letter from President Reagan to him, pledging that the United States would fulfill all its responsibilities as host of the games. **********Addressing the American Society of Newspaper Editors convention in Washington, Mr. Shultz said the Soviet justifications for staying away from the Games were not credible because ''tremendous efforts have been made and continue to be made by the United States to insure the security for the Olympics and a warm welcome for the athletes.'' **********''Right now,'' he said, ''we see the Soviet Union engaged in a tactic of negotiation that involves withdrawal, that involves a kind of scare campaign, and that involves a sort of deep freeze. We will not be intimidated.''  Election Seen as Factor Other Administration officials said Moscow appeared to have decided to avoid doing anything that could possibly seem to benefit President Reagan's re-election. **********The decision by Vietnam and Mongolia, two countries heavily dependent on Soviet military support, to stay away from the Olympics was not unexpected. It is anticipated that all the Warsaw Pact countries except Rumania will not attend. It is not known whether Cuba, which also depends on Soviet support, will also stay away.   Reagan Letter on Olympics **********Mr. Reagan's letter to the International Olympic Committee president was dated Tuesday, the day the Russians pulled out and also the day Mr. Reagan met with Mr. Samaranch. In the letter Mr Reagan said ''the Olympic Games should not be used for political purposes.'' **********''Athletes and Olympic officials of all countries will find a warm welcome in Los Angeles and will be treated equally and without discrimination,'' he said, ''in accord with the Olympic Charter and Olympic spirit.'' **********He also said all Federal agencies had been ordered to cooperate fully with Olympic and local officials ''to insure the safety of all participants.'' **********Soviet Scorns Reagan Assurances **********MOSCOW, May 11 - The official Soviet press agency Tass today scorned assurances given by President Reagan on the safety of athletes who will compete in Los Angeles.  ''The U.S. President has issued promises and assurances whose name is legion,'' a Tass commentary said. ''In reality, however, they proved to be nothing but a fig leaf to cover Washington's perfidy.'' **********Efforts to persuade the Kremlin to reverse its decision gained momentum tonight with the arrival here of Mario Vazquez Rana, president of the Paris- based Association of National Olympic Committees, who was asked by Mr. Samaranch to make the trip. **********Says Andropov Was Better **********LOS ANGELES, May 11 - The head of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee suggested today that if Yuri V. Andropov, the former Soviet leader, who died in February, were still alive, the Soviet Union would be planning to send athletes to the Games. **********''The change in power there has had a very negative effect on these Games,'' said Peter V. Ueberroth, president of the Olympic Committee. **********He said several high-ranking sports officials in the Soviet Union were replaced by Mr. Andropov after he succeeded Leonid I. Brezhnev as the Soviet leader in 1982. **********From that point, Mr. Ueberroth said, relations with Soviet Olympic officials gradually improved. They reached a high point, he said, when Konstantin Andrianov, head of the Soviet delegation to the International Olympic Committee, praised preparations for the Los Angeles Games in an I.O.C. meeting at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/08/world.main_headline: ARGENTINE PARTIES SIGN A PEACE ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/08/world.print_headline: ARGENTINE PARTIES SIGN A PEACE ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/08/world.body_text: **********President Raul Alfonsin and former President Isabel Martinez de Peron signed an accord today that officials called a triumph in Mr. Alfonsin's drive for national unity. **********The accord, signed also in a nationally televised ceremony by the leaders of a dozen other parties smaller than the Peronists, sets principles for dealing with a host of issues that have been threatening the country's six-month- old democracy. **********Among the principles are that the country should repay its foreign debt, undertake limited economic austerity and use its advancing nuclear technology only for peaceful ends. **********The signing came as presidential aides reported that agreement with the International Monetary Fund was expected soon on an austerity plan that would open the way for refinancing Argentina's $45 billion foreign debt. **********Mr. Alfonsin has ordered that negotiations with an I.M.F. team here end before he leaves on an official visit to Spain on Sunday, the aides said. If no agreement is reached by then, they said, he has ordered that Argentina present its own plan to the I.M.F. board of directors in Washington with the goal of forcing the United States and other industrial nations represented on the board to overrule the I.M.F. staff. **********Agreement Seen as Crucial The accord on national unity and an I.M.F. agreement have been seen as crucial as labor strikes grow, inflation, now at nearly 600 percent, refuses to be brought under control and the international financial community grows increasingly jittery that Argentina might default on its debt, upsetting the world financial system. **********The Government had been dragging its feet in the I.M.F. negotiations, partly because it was waiting to achieve some consensus in the national unity accord. The accord now also paves the way for an expected agreement by the weekend with the country's powerful Peronist unions over union elections. **********''I think that today we have inaugurated a new political style in the country,'' Mr. Alfonsin said in a short address after the signing. He stressed ''the high democratic spirit, the understanding of the necessity of working with a sense of national unity that has permeated the political leadership.'' **********He noted that the agreement did not imply an end to political differences and criticisms, but said it ''is linked to that Argentine spiritual necessity of marching united in the basic and fundamental aspects to achieve among all of us the country we deserve.'' **********The 15-point accord comes after two weeks of almost daily talks between Mr. Alfonsin and opposition political leaders. With the signing by Mr. Alfonsin and Mrs. Peron, the accord brings together the country's two largest parties, the Radicals and the Peronists, who shared 92 percent of the vote in last year's presidential elections. **********Among other parties represented were the Movement for Integration and Development and the left-of-center Christian Democrats, who with provincial parties that also signed are critical in building coalitions in the Congress. **********Some Parties Balk More extreme parties to the right and the left, including the socialist Intransigents, the Communist Party and the conservative Democratic Center Union, boycotted the accord. They mostly complained that it lacked specifics. **********The accord pledges the Government to increase the real wages of workers and reactivate the economy while renegotiating the foreign debt. It calls only for paying the country's ''legitimate'' debt, which means the Goverment may not recognize some loans obtained abroad by individuals and companies entirely for the purpose of speculation. **********The call for austerity was implied in the need to lower inflation, but it was qualified by saying that reactivation of the economy was more important. **********The accord was largely made possible by the evident moderation of Mrs. Peron, who returned two weeks ago from living in Spain to lead the Peronists in the talks. She plans to return to Spain on Friday, however, and it is unclear how lasting the Peronist commitment will be.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/29/world.body_text: **********Vietnamese forces shelled the perimeter of the main headquarters of Cambodian guerrillas today in the fourth straight day of fighting, the Thai military authorities reported. **********Twelve miles to the south, guerrillas fighting to regain a fallen refugee camp said they had destroyed one Vietnamese tank and crippled another. **********Thai military officials said about 20 artillery rounds had fallen near the outer defense line of the rebel headquarters at Ampil, which is strongly fortified and believed manned by 5,000 guerrillas of the anti-Communist Khmer People's National Liberation Front. The rebel group is one of three fighting the Vietnamese and the Government they installed after invading Cambodia at the end of 1978. **********The fall of Ampil would be a serious setback to the Liberation Front and other resistance groups, including the Communist Khmer Rouge and a smaller one loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian head of state. Ampil withstood a Vietnamese campaign in April.   62,000 Civilians Fled **********On Wednesday, the Cambodian guerrillas lost the refugee camp at Rithisen after Vietnamese forces overran and burned it. Before the attack, more than 62,000 civilian residents fled across the border to Thailand. **********Vietnamese infantry, tank and artillery units were said to be closing in on Ampil, and a thousand troops were within a half-mile of the headquarters, Thai intelligence officers said. **********The guerrillas counterattacking at the Rithisen camp encountered heavy, accurate fire from Vietnamese artillery, according to a guerrilla commander. **********The commander, Lia Ne, who was leader of the Rithisen camp, crossed into Thailand and spoke with reporters. He was overheard radioing his headquarters that in some sectors the two sides faced off less than 100 feet apart as the rebels counterattacked Vietnamese inside the camp. **********Shells struck three or four flimsy structures in the camp, and they went up in flames and smoke that could be seen from Thai side of the border. Mr. Lia Ne said the Vietnamese were using long-range 130-millimeter howitzers zeroed in by forward observers, making advances by Liberation Front forces difficult and forcing them to leave some of their wounded on the battlefield.   Half of Structures Destroyed **********The guerrillas are mostly armed with assault rifles, rocket-propelled grenades and mortars. **********Mr. Lia Ne said the fighting was in the northern and southern sections of the Rithisen camp, where the refugees formerly lived in 13 areas of mostly bamboo and thatch structures. More than half the structures have reportedly been destroyed. **********The commander said his troops killed or wounded 70 to 80 Vietnamese on Friday. Officials of the International Committee of the Red Cross said four Cambodians were known killed and 27 wounded Cambodians were evacuated to Thailand on Friday. **********This week's attacks were similar to other campaigns waged by the Vietnamese since their invasion of Cambodia. If they assault Ampil and perhaps other guerrilla bases, the current dry season offensive might prove to be among the most destructive to date. **********''Perhaps they will attack Ampil soon,'' the Liberation Front's leader, Son Sann, said at the Thai village of Nong Samet, opposite Rithisen.   Claims Stronger Support **********Mr. Son Sann, a 73-year-old former Cambodian Prime Minister, told American television that his guerrilla organization was receiving more Chinese arms, greater humanitarian aid from the West and stronger political support worldwide. **********''We will win because we have a just cause,'' he said. ''We have the Cambodian people on our side.'' **********A camp such as Rithisen normally consists of a civilian residential area of simple huts built from thatch, bamboo, plastic sheets and other readily available material. The larger camps may have Buddhist temples, outdoor theaters for cultural performances, clinics, private stores and the like.

But Bernard M. Fauber, K Mart's chairman, said that executives of his company had recently discussed Waldenbooks with Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment bankers, as a diversification move for K Mart.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/28/busin.body_text: **********''It is widely known that K Mart is seeking diversification possibilities in the retail field,'' Mr. Fauber said. ''However, we have had no discussions with Carter Hawley Hale.'' Carter Hawley had previously denied the reports. **********Other reports that had been circulating said that Joseph G. Fogg, managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company, had had a handshake agreement with a Merrill Lynch executive on a $300 million purchase of Waldenbooks by K Mart. Mr. Fogg yesterday denied those reports. **********Despite the denials, financial sources close to the companies insisted for a second day that representatives of K Mart and Carter Hawley Hale had tentatively agreed on a $300 million purchase of Waldenbooks by K Mart. The deal was reportedly struck shortly after The Limited Inc. announced a tender offer for Carter Hawley stock on April 2. The agreement foundered, the sources said, when Carter decided it could obtain acquiescence for its opposition to The Limited's takeover from a smaller company, as it did later with the General Cinema Corporation. **********On April 16, Carter Hawley gave General Cinema a six-month option to buy the Waldenbooks subsidiary for $285 million. The option was part of a transaction under which Carter Hawley sold one million shares of a new preferred convertible stock to General Cinema for $300 million, with substantial voting rights. **********Separately, Carter Hawley said its board will meet today to discuss The Limited's sweetened $35-a-share offer but said that several conditions imposed by The Limited made the offer ''illusory.'' It said the conditions would not enable the board to fairly evaluate the offer. **********In response, The Limited said it was waiving the condition of its new offer that demanded a consent to the merger by General Cinema, which now has 33Y percent voting rights of Carter Hawley shares. The Limited also waived the condition that Carter Hawley insure that there not be a default on its debt. **********General Cinema said yesterday that its board had declared that it would not vote its Carter Hawley preferred shares in favor of The Limited's offer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/11/world.main_headline: FIGHTING GOES ON IN BEIRUT SECTORS

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/11/world.body_text: **********Moslem militiamen and loyalist units of the Lebanese Army clashed here again today as President Amin Gemayel left for the start of a reconciliation conference in Switzerland. The level of fighting was said to be heavy. **********Officials of Mr. Gemayel's Government said they were optimistic the talks would begin resolving the issues underlying Lebanon's nine-year-old civil war. **********But the continued fighting here, and sharp differences among the political leaders, underscored the difficulties Mr. Gemayel faces in trying to assemble a new Government and win agreement on at least the framework for political changes. **********During the day, Mr. Gemayel conferred by telephone with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. Mr. Assad helped persuade his allies in the Lebanese opposition to attend the reconciliation talks after the Lebanese Government agreed to break its troop withdrawal agreement with Israel. **********Other political leaders left for Switzerland from here or from Damascus, where the Syrian-backed opposition politicians met in an effort to harmonize their positions.   Escalation on All Fronts **********Fighting along the Green Line separating Christian East Beirut from the Moslem West continued through the night and into today, with especially heavy battles reported in the area of St. Michael's church near the predominantly Shiite suburbs south of the city. The state television referred this evening to escalation on all fronts. **********Artillery shells, rockets and rocket- propelled grenades slammed into civilian areas, sending many residents into basement shelters, particularly in shell-scarred East Beirut. **********A bank manager in East Beirut said this morning that many of his employees had been unable to sleep because of the fighting and had shown up at work with nerves shattered. ''Some just came into my office and cried,'' he said. **********An artillery shell reportedly killed seven people when it hit a Shiite hospital in the southern suburbs. **********Although fighting in some neighborhoods appeared to abate tonight, there were reports of shelling in residential areas and of new artillery exchanges in the mountains overlooking the capital.   A New Prime Minister? **********The talks in Switzerland, if successful, are expected to produce a new Prime Minister and possibly a new Government. The new Prime Minister is expected to be pro-Syrian, with former Prime Minister Rashid Karami, a leader of the National Salvation Front, a top candidate. **********Even more difficult to arrange will be changes in the political system designed to give more power to the various Moslem groups, particularly the Shiites and the Druse. **********Mr. Gemayel is counting on Syria to press the Moslem opposition to cooperate in the talks. But Syria is believed to be particularly concerned with the formation of a new Government that would be sympathetic to its interests. A new Government is also one of Mr. Gemayel's main goals. **********But the Moslem opposition is thought to be especially interested in the broader political changes. **********The Christian representatives of the Lebanese Front - the President's father, Pierre, and former President Camille Chamoun - have as their goal the protection of Christian interests. **********Although Pierre Gemayel is head of the Phalangist Party, the party's increasingly independent militia has rejected the Switzerland talks and has strongly attacked President Gemayel for breaking the accord with Israel. **********The militia argues that Lebanon's system of centralized government and power sharing among the religious factions is obsolete. As an alternative, it proposes ''federalization'' or ''cantonalization,'' under which power would be transferred to semi-independent regional governments. **********These governments would cover locations predominantly populated by one or another religious group. For example, the Christian areas of East Beirut and nearby Mount Lebanon would constitute a Christian ''canton.'' **********''We do not think reforms, regardless of their nature, can bring a solution,'' Karim Pakradouni, the Phalangist militia's political counselor, said in a recent interview. ''We need a complete overhaul. A revolution, even.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/18/busin.body_text: **********If things were always as they appear, investing would be a harvest, not a roll of the dice. Instead, Wall Street is a place where ''the little guy is always wrong,'' and a contrary outlook on life is elevated into an investment theology. No single source is more perversely surprising than the fruits of academic research. The professors, combing through millions of transactions with their computers, have an affinity for against-the-grain results. **********A Tale of Coattails **********In the executive suites, tender offers, proxy fights, greenmail and other takeover maneuvers are as popular as the closing hour at a college bar. Shareholders may have a warmer view. Whatever they do for the executive digestion, the corporate raiders and their tribe often make money for other stockholders, or so a new study has found. **********The study, from the Alfred P. Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, traced share prices in some 500 cases in which a company or individual acquired a toehold interest - 5 percent or more - in another concern. Richard S. Ruback of M.I.T., working with Wayne H. Mikkelson of the University of Oregon, found that stock prices typically rose about 4.5 percent in the nine days before the toehold was announced and 5 percent in the two days surrounding the announcement. **********In episodes that ended with the target company's being taken over - either by the original stalker or by someone else - shareholders saw their holdings rise another 13 percent between the takeover announcement and the time they tendered their stock. In cases where the suitor sold his shares to a third party, stockholders saw their holdings rise an added 2 percent between the time a toehold was disclosed and the time the suitor sold. And even in cases of ''greenmail,'' where a suitor ended the takeover attempt by selling his shares to the company itself at a premium, the target company's shareholders nevertheless came out ahead. As one would expect, they saw their share prices decline when the suitor was bought out. But the losses were less than earlier gains, and shareholders typically ended up ahead about 1.7 percent. **********Only in one outcome - unsuccessful takeovers - did shareholders fail to gain. Stock prices rose when the takeover try was announced, but those gains were erased when the takeover was thwarted, leaving the price of the shares unchanged. ''Shareholders very much benefit from takeovers,'' Professor Ruback concluded. ''Other evidence suggests that when managers resist advances - when takeovers become hostile - shareholders can get paid bigger premiums over the current value of their shares.'' **********Interest Rates **********Why are interest rates so high? The answers always seem the same: Federal deficits, competition for funds, inflation fears. But a study taking a notably different view is under way at the Amos Tuck School of business administration at Dartmouth College. It stands the conventional wisdom on its head. **********According to Dennis E. Logue, a professor at Tuck, the foreign exchange markets are the key to understanding interest rates. The orthodox view holds that foreigners, attracted by high interest rates here, bid up the dollar's value as they buy dollars to buy dollar-denominated debt. But Professor Logue contends that cause and effect go the other way: that interest rates remain high because foreign investors expect the dollar to fall. They therefore demand a higher return now to compensate them for the day when the dollar will buy less of their own currency. ''There is no doubt that foreign investors are seeking an interest return for the risk of a dollar demise,'' Professor Logue said. **********To forecast interest rates, Professor Logue suggests watching the foreign exchange markets. If the current exchange rate, the spot rate for dollars, is falling, one can expect interest rates to decline. That is because when the dollar has already fallen, foreign investors will be less fearful that a depreciating dollar will erode their earnings. **********Trends in forward rates - the rates on contracts to buy and sell dollars in the future - are also telling. If the forward rate begins approaching the spot rate, that generally implies that investors believe the dollar will be steady in the near future. That, in turn, means interest rates should edge down as fears of a dollar depreciation wane. If, by comparison, a wide difference persists between spot and forward rates, interest rates should remain high as foreign investors try to guard against losses. **********Professor Logue and a team of researchers are working on a model to trace a precise mathematical relationship between changes in interest rates and movements in foreign exchange. ''Most of the pieces you see written about interest rates focus on the U.S. alone,'' he said. ''Yet rates are not determined in a vacuum, and you really have to focus on the foreign-exchange markets to get an idea for what is going on.'' **********'Inefficient' Markets **********Wall Street spends its existence trying to beat the market in a big way, but according to a substantial body of academic research, investors stand very little chance of making a killing, no matter how much research they do. **********According to the ''efficient market'' theory, very few stocks are so undervalued that they can yield outsized profits for individual investors. Money managers and other professionals are probing and evaluating stocks so constantly that pertinent data about any given stock is quickly incorporated into its price. As a result, even if the small investor does his own homework, it seldom pays off. Or so the theory runs. **********Now, a new study from the Graduate School of Management at the University of California at Los Angeles gives addi- tional credence to efficient markets. The study, by Bradford Cornell, focuses on bank stocks. Professor Cornell studied 50 bank stocks both before and after the banks were required to disclose Latin American problem loans country by country. He found that stock prices responded similarly before and after the disclosures, indicating that the market had already figured out a bank's loan problems and reflected that riskiness in the stock price. **********''The response of the market to Latin events was very similar in 1982 and 1983,'' Professor Cornell said. ''The market effectively inferred loan exposure to individual countries.'' Indeed, for small investors, he said, the results suggest that ''time spent picking a stock is not the best use of your time.'' **********''An investor would be wiser to consider things like what it will cost to buy and sell stocks and how much faith he has in his brokerage firm,'' Professor Cornell said. **********Playing a Quiet Corner **********A finance professor at New York University says he has discovered a market that is too new to be always efficient. Thus it harbors the potential for huge profits for those with mathematical expertise. That market, says Stephen C. Figlewski, is stock index futures, in which investors pick the direction of the market as a whole without having to pick the movement of a specific stock. **********Stock index futures, which have been hailed on Wall Street as a way to hedge a portfolio, are so new and complex, Professor Figlewski says, that arbitragers and other professionals do not yet dominate it. As a result, index futures are not always an efficient market. Rather, they are often priced either too high or too low in relation to the index they are based on. In theory, investors can earn substantial profits either by buying stocks and selling index futures or by selling stocks and buying index futures. **********''The risk-return trade-off has in fact been broken,'' said Professor Figlewski, who has himself made a fair amount of money in the market. ''It's a rare opportunity that few people know about, and it won't last forever. In time, arbitrage always sets in.'' **********To understand how it works, assume that stock index futures are priced too high. An investor has, say, a $50,000 portfolio of 15 diversified blue-chip stocks, selected carefully to perform in line with the New York Stock Exchange Composite index, which at the time is at 100. The investor then sells a futures contract based on the composite index at a price of 105 - 5 more than the index. (That contract represents a commitment by the investor to pay $500 times the difference between the selling price of the futures contract - 105 - and the value of the index when the contract expires). **********When the stock index future expires, however, the New York Stock Exchange index, say, did not go up, but remained at 100. As a result, the index future's value dropped to 100. So the investor buys back the futures contract at 100, making $2,500 (the saving of 5 on the index future's price times $500). He also makes money from dividends on the stocks he owns. **********If the index had fallen to 90, the investor would have lost on the stocks he owned but gained handsomely on the index future. **********Conversely, if the index had gone up to 110, his stocks would have increased in value, but he would have lost on the index future. In either case, he would have come out ahead. **********The same example holds true if stock index futures are underpriced, for instance, a future is selling for 95 when the index is at 100. In this instance, the investor would sell his $50,000 in stocks and put the money in, say, a money market fund earning 12 percent, and then buy index futures. **********The trick, of course, is knowing whether the stock index futures are underpriced or overpriced. **********According to Professor Figlewski, a simple formula tells what the stock index future's price should be, if the market were efficient. Take whatever the index is, say 100, and add the interest rate that an investor would make on his money if it were invested in a money market fund or Treasury bills, say 10 percent. Then subtract the dividend rate, for example, 4 percent. In this case the answer is 106, so if index futures were selling above or below that, then clearly the market is inefficient, Professor Figlewski said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/22/busin.body_text: **********Reflecting continued difficulties in the farm implement sector, Deere & Company yesterday reported net income of $29.4 million in its fiscal third quarter. **********The figure included an extraordinary gain of $28.5 million in income tax adjustments, without which net income would have been lower than last year's depressed level of $5.1 million. **********Earnings were 43 cents a share in the quarter, the company said, compared with 8 cents a year earlier. **********Robert A. Hanson, Deere's chairman, said retail sales for farm and industrial equipment continue to be disappointing. Deere, which is based in Moline, Ill., had sales of $1.04 billion in its third quarter, up 4.4 percent from $996 million in the quarter a year earlier. **********''Conditions in our industries continue to be difficult and uncertain,'' Mr. Hanson said. ''Price competition remains intense, dealer inventories are high and capacity utilization is low.'' **********He said that because of high inventories, Deere would shut its combine factory in East Moline, Ill., for 41 production days in November and December. Mr. Hanson also said that the ''extremely high cost'' of retail sales incentives had hurt profitability. **********George S. Dahlman, an analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc., a Minneapolis-based securities firm, said, ''Their earnings were basically in line with our expectations, maybe a little lower.'' He said Deere's weak earnings were ''to be expected as they try to bring their inventories in line.'' **********Deere said net income of its retail finance and leasing subsidiaries and of the John Deere Insurance Group were $22.6 million in the quarter, compared with $18.4 million a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/busin.body_text: **********Showtime/The Movie Channel Inc. said it plans its first network advertising for its Showtime pay-TV movie channel next month. The company will spend about $8 million for a campaign running through November. **********The ''We Make Excitement'' campaign was developed by J. Walter Thompson. The ads will appear during the premiere week for the new fall season on CBS, NBC and ABC as well as on radio, syndicated television and satellite broadcast services. Print ads will appear in TV Guide and other guides. The ads on ABC mark that network's first departure from its policy of not accepting advertising for cable television. **********''Not only do the dollars behind this buy represent the largest advertising commitment in Showtime's history, it is a spending level at par with our competitors' and will insure the frequency necessary to make a meaningful impact on the consumer,'' said Joanne Black, senior vice president, marketing and creative services for Showtime. **********The campaign will be for Showtime only. Showtime, which merged with The Movie Channel last year, is the nation's second-largest pay-television network after Home Box Office. It reaches 5.5 million subscribers over more than 3,000 cable systems nationwide. **********Showtime/The Movie Channel is 50 percent owned by Viacom International Inc.; 40.5 percent owned by Warner Communications Inc. and 9.5 percent by the American Express Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/26/busin.main_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE: CORPORATE NEWSMAKERS OF 1984 ; The Basses Stay Busy
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE: CORPORATE NEWSMAKERS OF 1984 ; The Basses Stay Busy
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/26/busin.body_text: **********The four Bass Brothers of Fort Worth have had a busy year, getting involved with the likes of Texaco, Walt Disney Productions, Conrail and Alexander's Inc. **********In March, they agreed to sell their 9.7 percent stake in Texaco Inc. back to the company for $1.28 billion in a buyout intended to rid Texaco of any possible meddling from the Basses. **********Without skipping a beat, the Basses, led by Sid Richardson Bass, the eldest brother, turned their attention to Walt Disney Productions. They parlayed their controlling interest in the Arvida Corporation, a real estate investment company, into a $200 million block of newly issued Disney stock. In September, they acquired 724,000 more shares, and then they purchased the stake of Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis financier, for $158.1 million. When all the transactions were totaled, the Basses had 24.83 percent of Disney. **********The brothers have also made a $2 billion bid for the Consolidated Rail Corporation, or Conrail, in cooperation with the Marriott Corporation's chief executive, J. W. Marriott Jr. The Basses also own 12.7 percent of Alexander's Inc., the New York retailer, and are seeking to acquire the company with the help of a New Jersey partnership.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/15/world.main_headline: NEW ZEALAND'S PREMIER WON PERSONAL AND POLITICAL BATTLES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/15/world.print_headline: NEW ZEALAND'S PREMIER WON PERSONAL AND POLITICAL BATTLES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/15/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister-designate David Lange is a former criminal lawyer whose road to the top has been swift but rocky. **********Mr. Lange (the name is pronounced long-EE), who will become the country's 32d Prime Minister and, at 41 years of age, the youngest to hold the office this century, entered Parliament seven years ago in a socially deprived area in his hometown of Auckland. **********Within 30 months he was deputy leader of the Labor Party and in February 1983 he took over the leadership from former Prime Minister Sir Wallace Rowling. **********His success in toppling the nine-year administration of Sir Robert Muldoon follows battles within his own party and a dramatic physical transformation.   Weighed 370 Pounds **********Two years ago Mr. Lange weighed 370 pounds but underwent a stomach- stapling operation to reduce his food intake and cut his weight. He said at the time he was inspired to shed pounds by the drive to become party leader. **********Mr. Lange is still a heavily built man but his energy lifted the ailing party, and a change in image with a smartening of his dress and a toning down of his almost evangelical oratory helped the process. **********Although he was elected leader of the Labor Party because his colleagues felt he was the man most likely to mount a successful challenge against Sir Robert, he had less appeal to the public. **********The last opinion poll before the election showed Mr. Lange was first choice as Prime Minister of only 17 percent of voters, against 26 percent for Sir Robert. **********Mr. Lange, who is also a Methodist lay preacher, describes himself as a middle-of-the-road socialist who believes the solution to the country's problems is to get people to work together.   Lawyer for the Poor **********The son of a doctor, he formed his political views in the poorer suburbs of Auckland, New Zealand's largest city. **********He does not pretend to be an economic expert and rejected Sir Robert's criticism of this by saying, ''A Prime Minister should not be a super-technocrat who knows the cost of everything and the value of nothing.'' **********Mr. Lange, who has an English-born wife, Naomi, and three children, graduated with a masters degree in law with honors from Auckland University. **********He spent six years working as a lawyer among the Auckland poor, often representing people who could not afford to pay and who had been denied legal representation. **********His annual income when he was elected to Parliament was reported to be $4,400.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/03/busin.main_headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: OPEC AND ITS VAGARIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/03/busin.print_headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: OPEC AND ITS VAGARIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/03/busin.body_text: **********Anyone wondering why the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has a public image problem need only have attended the group's emergency meeting here this week. **********Beefy bodyguards and surly aides accompany OPEC ministers almost everywhere, brushing past onlookers and sometimes pushing people aside. Ministers travel in private jets, arrive at the Inter-Continental Hotel in Mercedes-Benz limousines and stay in lavish suites. The press is kept behind metal barricades that look out of place in the elegant two-story, shop- lined lobby. **********Once in a while a minister will stop during a meeting day and chat for a minute with the crowd of onlookers. But usually they come and go in silence. **********Meeting agendas are not announced, schedules rarely given. Reporters and other OPEC watchers wait for hours in designated areas patrolled by police and guards, waiting for public statements, which, when they occur, are brief, vague and without warning. Telephone calls to ministers' rooms almost always go unreturned, requests for interviews are almost always rejected. **********One senior OPEC official, who asked not to be identified, explained it this way: ''What you have here are two different cultures. In the United States, communication is a virtue. You come home and can't wait to discuss the day's events with your wife. People who communicate well are respected. But in the Arab world, the opposite is true. Communication is a vice. Secrecy is a virtue.'' **********In the absence of official information, bits and pieces can be collected from the hundreds of people who mill around the lobby during OPEC meetings: reporters, photographers, oil traders, oil company executives. **********Perhaps the best-known unofficial information provider is Harry Neustein, 76 years old, an oil trader. Thin, ruddy-faced, bespectacled and wearing an ascot, Mr. Neustein talks with the intensity and continuity of an auctioneer and flits from group to group pollinating the entire crowd with his perceptions. **********He has been an oil trader for 55 years and it is he who advanced the notion, later widely accepted, that OPEC is producing far below its output ceiling. He talks frequently to oil executives, government officials, OPEC members. To the Iranian officials who sometimes try to brush him off, he throws up the fact that he worked with their grandfathers in the Iranian oilfields in 1935. **********The son of a pushcart peddler, he says he made and lost fortunes trading oil. He lives in New York City, and he always comes to OPEC meetings. ''Do you know why?'' he says. ''Because I'm an old man and I want to be needed.'' **********There is a hierarchy of reporters. A few have attended OPEC meetings for years and know people from the delegations. They can be seen thumbing through their notebooks trading pieces of information with each other - an uneasy alliance of competitors trying to piece together concepts from stray facts. **********Most journalists, however, wait hungrily for a minister walking through the lobby to an exit or elevator. He may stop for a minute and answer questions as 50 reporters reach over one another holding tape recorders that they later replay for a group huddled together, hoping to pull one salient fact from several vague sentences. **********These reporters are often slow to recognize the ministers and their staffs. The Arabs, for example, have forsaken their traditional robes for business suits, and only Prof. Tam David-West, the Nigerian minister, appears in native garb. One day it was a flowing cream-colored, embroidered silk robe with matching hat. **********Often a delegation is almost out of range before someone spots its members, prompting a stampede. **********But not everyone has those problems. Some members of the trade press have attended OPEC meetings longer than the ministers. Sarah Miller of Platt's Oilgram News has been to so many that she writes songs about OPEC and sings them during the hours of waiting. A sample verse: ''The 13 in OPEC all agree/On nothing as far as we can see/Lord have mercy on such as we/Blah, blah, blah.'' **********Despite these diversions, few reporters like the press arrangements. Veronique Mauries of Le Monde, a leading French newspaper, says: ''OPEC despises the press, and so they have no public relations at all; billions of dollars change hands based on what people read and don't read and OPEC really doesn't understand it.'' **********The longest written communication made available to the press from OPEC officials during the conference was not the closing communique but four pages of poetry written by Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, the oil minister of the United Arab Emirates. **********His poem is a kind of ode to OPEC, exhorting its members to preserve the organization. A sample: ''If you seek to retain stable prices/It will entail some great sacrifices/ Lower further your production ceiling/And ban error and violation.'' **********It is not the first time that the bearded, diminutive sheik has committed his oil thoughts to verse. At OPEC's rancorous two-week London meeting in March 1983, Sheik Otaiba caused a stir with his rhymed criticism of the group's slow negotiating habits and the obstinacy of Nigeria, the nation that sparked this year's emergency meeting by cutting its prices. The London meeting resulted in an official price cut of $5 a barrel to $29. **********This year, Sheik Otaiba's poem, titled ''From The London Conference to the Geneva Conference'' and dated Oct. 28, 1984, cautions: ''London's nightmare lives on in memory/Will it, dear friends, regain reality?'' **********Sheik Otaiba was unavailable to explain his poetry. Perhaps exhibiting the traditional poetic whimsy, he slept through his first interview appointment with a New York Times reporter, and he did not return from a daylong trip to West Germany in time for his second appointment. But his poem itself contains some hints: ''In verse I find a bountiful largess/A great refuge at times of much distress.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; 3 Executive Changes Set by Bristol-Myers
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/16/busin.body_text: **********The Bristol-Myers Company yesterday announced three executive changes, including the appointment of John W. Melton, senior vice president, to be responsible for planning and development, effective Sept. 1. **********He will report to Richard L. Gelb, chairman. **********The current executive responsible for planning and development, Charles A. Heimbold Jr., will become president of the Health Care group. **********Mr. Melton is currently the president of Clairol, a position he has held since May 1981. He joined Bristol- Myers in 1975 as vice president-counsel for Clairol and became senior vice president of Clairol on Jan. 1, 1981. **********The widely diversified consumer products company also announced that Robert M. Phillips would become president of the Clairol division. Mr. Phillips joined the company in 1981 as executive vice president of Clairol. Before that, he had been president and chief operating officer of the General Entertainment Corporation, a venture of Nabisco. **********The company also announced that William F. Flatley would become president of its Drackett division, effective Sept. 1. Currently he is senior vice president of marketing and sales for Drackett, a position he has held since January 1983. Drackett makes household cleaners, such as Windex and Drano.
