https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/05/busin.body_text: **********The Greyhound Leasing and Financial Corporation is offering $75 million of senior notes due in 1994 and $100 million face amount of zero-coupon senior subordinated notes due in 1994, both through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. **********The 13 5/8 percent senior notes, rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's, were increased from $50 million and offered at a price of 100 to yield 13.625 percent. **********The zero-coupon issue, rated slightly lower at Baa-3/ BBBx, was offered at a price of 25, or $250 for each $1,000 of face amount, to yield 14.10 percent to maturity. **********A proposed zero-coupon issue due in 1996 was canceled. **********Zero-coupon notes do not pay interest. The investor's return comes from the difference between the price paid and the notes' value at maturity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/01/busin.body_text: **********Representative Fernand J. St Germain, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, today attacked Administration-backed proposals to further deregulate the banking industry and hinted that he was reluctant to pass any major legislation this year. **********The Rhode Island Democrat said in a speech submitted for the record that he wanted to hold hearings on the subject soon, but he set no date. A senior committee aide, asked if the chairman preferred no bill at all this year, parried, saying, ''If you asked the chairman, he would say he won't know the answer to that question until he holds hearings.'' Given the brief time Congress will be in session this election year, Mr. St Germain's schedule appears to leave little time for passage of a major deregulation bill. **********The caustic tone of Mr. St Germain's prepared speech was the clearest indication yet that he is philosopically cool to efforts by banks - that are largely supported by the Administration - to deregulate banking further. **********''The proponents of instant deregulation,'' he declared, ''hang their arguments on a questionable premise - that banks and other depository institutions are just like other businesses.'' **********Last fall, Senator Jake Garn, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, introduced a bill that would let bank holding companies get into a broad array of non-banking activities, including real estate, insurance brokerage and some securities services. **********Senator Garn, a Utah Republican, has vowed that legislation would be passed in Congress this session, but many bankers have questioned whether such a bill could be enacted without the support of Mr. St Germain. Until now, Mr. St Germain has given no indication that he would back such a measure. **********Mr. St Germain also charged that banks had used deregulation as a means for selecting affluent customers at the expense of the poor and elderly. **********''The move to affluent markets, and away from the blue collar, the elderly and the less well-to-do is being accomplished through an elaborate fee system that effectively prices the 'undesirables' out of the banks,'' Mr. St Germain said. **********''Some banks clearly don't like to deal with senior citizens,'' he said. ''One solution is to charge fees of $2 to $3 per Social Security check or in some cases a full 1 percent of the check.'' He did not give the names of any such banks. **********Mr. St Germain suggested that Congress make banks that seek broad deregulation pay a price, the loss of Federal deposit insurance and ''Government assistance.'' The result, he said, would be two classes of banks, a deregulated class ''that operates in the more rarefied air of the affluent'' and a regulated class that offers ''essential utility functions'' and retains Federal insurance.'' He did not explain what he meant by ''utility functions.'' **********Reacting to the speech, Gerald Lowrie, executive director of government relations for the American Bankers Association, said that Mr. St Germain ''has a very interesting way to say he wants to hear from us.'' He added: ''But if this is a way of getting this critical issue to be aired in the House, then we welcome it. It's better than the benign neglect we've been getting up to this point.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/23/world.body_text: **********King Hassan II said in an address to the nation tonight that rioting in at least six Moroccan cities had been fomented by elements he termed Communists, followers of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and Zionist intelligence agents. **********It was the first official admission of the wave of disorders, which began in the southern city of Marrakesh and spread to the northern cities of Tetuan, Al Hoceima, Nador, Oujda and Ksar el- Kebir with particular violence. **********An undisclosed number of people have been reported killed in a wave of unrest in this North African nation that began two weeks ago. Witnesses reported today that about 20 people were killed in clashes with security forces in Tetuan Saturday. **********At the same time, the King assured Moroccans that there would be no increases in the prices of three food staples - bread, sugar and cooking oil. Fears that food prices would rise at a time of severe economic hardship are one of the principal causes of the unrest.   No Mention of Casualties **********The King, who appeared grim while on television, made no mention of casualties in his speech, during which he held up tracts and pamphlets that he said were produced by people who have been stirring up the riots. **********He said somberly that Morocco ''remains a country where the law is to be respected and all lawbreakers will be severely punished.'' **********He attributed the troubles to ''a multifaceted conspiracy perpetrated by Marxist-Leninists, Zionist agents and Khomeinists,'' who he said were seeking the collapse of the conference of Islamic nations being held in Casablanca. **********King Hassan's announcement that there will be no increases in prices of staples seemed to contradict a speech he made last month. At that time, he said that price rises were inevitable but that he would take steps to prevent their causing suffering among the poorest. To that end, he ordered a census of the poor, with the apparent purpose of instituting something like a food-stamp program.   Census Already Completed **********Tonight, the King said that the census had been completed and that its findings had led him to decide against increases. **********The King's actions were similar to those of President Habib Bourguiba in neighboring Tunisia. Mr. Bourguiba doubled the prices of bread and other cereal staples at the beginning of this month. When riots ensued, causing scores of deaths throughout the country, Mr. Bourguiba rescinded the increases. In Tunisia, too, fundamentalist followers of the ideas of Ayatollah Khomeini were accused by Government sources of causing the rioting. **********King Hassan, in his speech, maintained that economic factors were no more than a pretext used by outside agitators to foment political troubles. He did not name Iran or any Communist country. A small Communist party is legal in Morocco. **********As Many as 200 Deaths Reported **********MADRID, Jan. 22 (AP) - As many as 200 people may have been slain in the last few days in Moroccan rioting, according to Spanish press reports. **********Northern Morocco was a Spanish colony until independence in 1956 and there are extensive contacts between Moroccans and the remaining Spanish enclaves in Morocco of Melilla and Ceuta. **********The Spanish news agency E.F.E., quoting travelers in Melilla, said Saturday that more than 100 deaths were reported in Al Houceima, a fishing town halfway between Melilla and Tangier. **********The Madrid newspaper Diario 16, in a report from Tetuan, said that soldiers ''killed over 100 demonstrators'' there and 5,000 troopers were keeping order. **********Diario 16's correspondent was later expelled from Tetuan. Other foreign journalists - Spanish, French, Italian, Belgian and a correspondent for The New York Times - were also ordered out of the area. An Agence France- Presse correspondent was put on a plane to France from the eastern town of Oujda.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/world.main_headline: Black Girl Dies In South African Clash
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Black Girl Dies In South African Clash
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/world.body_text: **********A teen-age black girl died today and several other youths were injured when the police, firing tear gas, clashed with pupils boycotting classes in the black township of Atteridgeville. **********The girl, Emma Sathekge, 15 years old, died in a hospital in this township six miles west of Pretoria. **********Witnesses said she had been run over by a police vehicle in the schoolyard where hundreds of protesting students were gathered. Doctors at the Kalafong Hospital said she appeared to have been suffering from internal injuries. **********Eight other children were treated for the effects of tear gas, a hospital spokesman said. **********A police spokesman in Pretoria said the police fired tear gas after pupils boycotting classes at D.H. Peta High School began throwing stones at them. The police spokesman said a number of children were taken to the hospital, one died and the cause of death was still being investigated. **********Three schools in the township were closed last week after thousands of students boycotted classes to protest what they called excessive corporal punishment and a ruling barring the readmission of over-aged students who failed examinations. **********Miss Sathekge's mother, Sarah, said she was called by another female student and told that her daughter had been taken to the hospital. She said she was told at the hospital that Emma had been X-rayed twice. ''Then they told me that my child was dead,'' Mrs. Sathekge said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/24/busin.body_text: **********''IT is the last mass market left in America; everything else is fractionated. It's not the top. It's not the bottom. It's the fat middle. I'm talking about incomes of $25,000 and $35,000. And they spend, not save.'' **********Lloyd A. Werner was talking about country music fans, a group he has come to know and love. As the new senior vice president for sales and marketing of Group W Satellite Communications, he is in charge of selling The Nashville Network to cable system operators and to advertisers. **********That network, he is quick to point out, has the potential of each day delivering 12 million of those folks, folks who buy American, be it cars or beer or camera film. The cheese people at Kraft love them. So, too, the boot makers at Acme and the jeans makers at Wrangler. **********The network is delivering the heartland and the heartland is everywhere. ''Stand up for your country'' is the new promotion theme that has taken over from ''The network for people who love their country.'' **********TNN is owned by Opryland USA, Nashville's gift to music lovers, and it is Opryland that produces the six new hours of nightly programming that are repeated twice the following day for an 18-hour daily programming package. **********Since Group W gets a commission on all of the advertising it sells and advertising rates are dependent on the number of viewers, Mr. Werner's people are in the midst of a big promotion effort to get more viewers. And since even the most ardent country fan cannot watch if the cable system is not carrying it, the thrust of the advertising is to get viewers to prod operators with what Group W has called a Countrygram. **********Commercials running on six other advertiser-supported cable networks ask that viewers call an 800 number and request that TNN send a Countrygram to the viewer's cable operator. **********The tactic was tested last year from September to mid-December on radio stations in 30 markets and on television in Tulsa, Okla., and Eugene, Ore. It worked, but Mr. Werner and his people were concerned about the amount of waste: all of those people who were being reached who did not have cable. That is when they decided to put the bait where most of the fish are and move their commercials to the advertiser-supported cable networks. **********So there are now a total of twenty 30-second spots running each week on ESPN, Lifetime, USA, CBN, the Weather Channel and WTBS. Missing from the list are CNN, which wanted too much money, Mr. Werner said, and MTV, whose audience is younger than TNN wants. **********Group W is spending $500,000, which is only half of what it put into its fall test, but more than any other cable network has spent for self- promotion on cable, Mr. Werner believes. And this too is a test. **********''If it is successful, I suspect we could be advertising 30 to 40 weeks of the year,'' Mr. Werner said. **********The cable TV advertising is being created in-house and features bits of the programming and shots of the stars. The advertising aimed at the advertising trade has been created by Slater, Hanft, Martin. In addition to appearing in the advertising trade press, it ran in The New York Times, New York magazine and New York regional editions of Time, Newsweek, Sports Illustrated and Business Week. **********Some of the advertiser-supported cable networks charge operators a fee based on the number of their subscribers, so they have two income sources. TNN has only the advertiser's money, and it has eight minutes - sixteen 30-second units - to sell in each hour. The network gives an additional two minutes an hour to the operators. **********According to Mr. Werner, a prime time 30-second spot on TNN goes for $800 to $1,000. And while all of the network's commercial time is being used, only half is purchased by regular advertisers paying regular rates. The rest, Mr. Werner said, features either direct marketers or other direct sales outfits that pay the network a certain amount for each inquiry they get.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/07/world.main_headline: WHERE THE ATOMIC AGE BEGAN, LIFE IS WORKADAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/07/world.print_headline: WHERE THE ATOMIC AGE BEGAN, LIFE IS WORKADAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/07/world.body_text: **********The TalkofHiroshima **********HIROSHIMA, Japan, Feb. 3 - The auto workers could not get to their jobs on time at Toyo Kogyo, the big factory better known to Americans as Mazda. It had snowed, surprisingly and heavily, that morning, clogging traffic. That slowed the assembly line by an hour or two, delaying production of 300 cars and trucks, but the workers put in overtime and the plant was back on schedule by nighttime. **********The day before, the Hiroshima Toyo Carp baseball team hired a new fielding coach, then left for pre-season camp in Okinawa. **********A welfare program for single fathers fell into trouble. The idea was to provide housekeepers for them five days a month, but only six men have taken advantage of the service and now the city wants to spend its money on something else. **********In one neighborhood, residents sought advice on the best use for a community hall that is in demand by too many groups.   The News Is Prosaic **********That's the news from Hiroshima this week - not much for the global- minded, perhaps, but the news nonetheless. **********This is just a workaday city, with 921,000 people, electric trolleys, 2.4 million library books, broad boulevards, a dozen burglaries a year, a few graceful parks, many not-so- graceful buildings, 1,500 bars, an island-studded harbor and a movie house showing a revival of ''Deadline U.S.A.'' with Humphrey Bogart. **********Visitors come all the time, most, probably all, burdened with knowledge of the United States nuclear attack that destroyed the city on Aug. 6, 1945. It is what makes Hiroshima special. It is why they come. But then they stroll around and see that it is a city - better than some, less attractive than others, with shops and restaurants and schoolchildren in dark uniforms - and they are reassured by the ordinariness. Maybe that is how it should be, said Minoru Ohmuta, who writes about atomic bomb survivors for the Hiroshima newspaper, Chugoku Shimbun. **********''People's concerns are basically with the future,'' Mr. Ohmuta said the other day. ''The past is past. It has its meaning. It remains deep in people's minds. But it rarely comes to the surface.'' **********Of course, Hiroshima cannot help looking back. **********Sometimes, the stimulus comes from outside, as it did last weekend when the much-traveled American television version of nuclear war, ''The Day After,'' came to town. The film had been playing elsewhere in Japan for two weeks, and it was greeted with an initial burst of curiosity at Hiroshima's Ritz Theater, although attendance fell away midweek. Still, about 4,500 people went the first two days, more than had gone for the opening of ''E.T.,'' which in Japan, as in the United States, says something. **********Afterward, bomb victims living in Hiroshima said much what survivors elsewhere had been saying - it was good that such a film had been made but the cinematic carnage was ''too pretty,'' in the words of Mitsuko Yoshioka, who writes poems about the nuclear ordeal that afflicted her city when she was 18 years old. **********Heiwa, the Japanese word for peace, is a commonplace here. Heiwa is the name of a park, a boulevard, a bridge and a museum. There are the Heiwa Diner, Heiwa Cosmetic Surgery and Heiwa Garage, just to name a few. There is even a Heiwa Demolition Company. **********Local officials have an idea that Hiroshima should become an ''International Peace and Culture City,'' but what that may mean is hard to tell. It could mean more visitors, and that would be desirable because the city's economy could use a spark. The latest thought came last week - a man- made offshore island, where a convention center and exhibition halls could be built, presumably for use by those wishing international peace and culture. **********To a degree, Hiroshima's problems are the concerns of any big city. **********After the war and the tens of thousands of deaths that it brought, the population was reduced to about 137,000. By 1955, it was back to its pre- war level of 350,000, and now it is approaching three times that number. Fifty-six percent of the people have lived here less than 10 years.   Expansion Peters Out **********For a while, the boom was a blessing. The economy was growing by 20 percent a year, and factories kept being built - 2,800 of them - including major employers such as Toyo Kogyo and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries. **********But the expansion did not last. The oil crisis hurt Hiroshima as it did the rest of Japan, and while the city grew to eight times its prewar size, it was running out of room. It is surrounded on three sides by mountains and on the fourth by the Inland Sea, and so when factories needed more space for expansion they found space was the one thing Hiroshima did not have. Through the 1970's, more than 100 manufacturing companies packed up and left. In the meantime, Hiroshima has had to contend with the full assortment of urban ailments from traffic jams to inadequate sewer systems. **********Inevitably, the road leads to the Peace Memorial Park, astride the center of the explosion that killed more than 100,000 people. **********Last year, 1.2 million visitors came to the adjacent museum. They walked past exhibits demonstrating the atomic bomb's physical properties and giving brief scientific explanations of what had occurred, past fragments of buildings and people's personal lives, past those terrible, familiar pictures of burned bodies and ulcerated faces, of keloids and twisted limbs and bleeding gums and scarred children - it goes on and on, an album of horror. **********Once outdoors again, the visitors see the skeletal remains of the Hiroshima Industrial Promotion Hall, the one central-city building still standing from 1945. It is commonly called the Atomic Bomb Dome. **********''There is a story,'' said Akihiro Takahashi, a bomb victim who heads the Hiroshima Peace Culture Foundation. In 1966, he said, an issue arose over whether to destroy the Dome or to preserve it. Most of the Hiroshima survivors wanted it torn down, but city officials overrode them and so the old hall stands. **********''That was a good decision,'' Mr. Takahashi said. People need physical reminders, he said, that once, not long ago, something happened here.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/22/busin.body_text: **********Saturday Review, once a weekly journal of literature and the arts but moribund since January, was sold today by Jeffrey Gluck to a group of investors headed by Paul Dietrich of Washington, president of the nonprofit National Center for Legislative Research. **********The new owners said they hope to get out a summer issue, then resume monthly publication this fall. **********The 60-year-old magazine has most recently been published as a bimonthly, but no issue has appeared since the January-February number, according to DuPre Jones, who will be a senior editor. **********Mr. Jones said two more issues have been prepared, and they may be combined and sent to subscribers as a double summer issue. Then, this fall, the magazine will appear under a new editorial and design format, published from Washington, he said. **********Saturday Review has changed ownership several times in recent years. Mr. Gluck bought it in late 1982 and later purchased the St. Louis Globe- Democrat. He said he decided to sell Saturday Review because he did not have time to run both the newspaper and the magazine. **********Other principal investors are Jerry Green and David Simpson, both bankers in Kansas City, Mo. **********No sale price was announced, but the investors have said they planned to spend between $1 million and $2 million to buy the magazine, start a direct mail campaign for subscribers, redesign it and hire a staff. **********Mr. Jones, a writer and editor formerly with The New York Times and Congressional Quarterly, said the magazine has about 160,000 paid subscribers and had been selling an additional 80,000 copies on newsstands. **********The former editor, Norman Cousins, will continue to serve as a columnist and editor emeritus, Mr. Jones said. **********The new editor will be Frank Gannon, a writer, editor and consultant formerly with CBS-TV and Fairchild Publications.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/27/world.main_headline: HOW PAPER PAINTS NAMIBIA: AFRICA'S PEYTON PLACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/27/world.print_headline: HOW PAPER PAINTS NAMIBIA: AFRICA'S PEYTON PLACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/27/world.body_text: **********-West Africa - When they buy his newspaper, Hannes Smith says, some people slide its tabloid pages between the folds of a larger publication so as not to be seen in possession of it. Others, he asserts, have shot themselves because of disclosures he has printed about their private lives. Still more, he reckons, live in trembling of what he might publish in the future. **********Mr. Smith, in short, has cast himself as a nation's conscience. **********The Windhoek Observer, now six years old, is one of southern Africa's most talked-about and irreverent publications. Each week, for instance, it carries a full-page picture of a seminude woman, challenging the morality laws that extend from South Africa to this territory under its domination. **********Its editorials rail against Pretoria's occupation of South-West Africa, which the United Nations calls illegal, and against what Mr. Smith calls the duplicity and double lives led by prominent figures in the territory. **********The paper is locked in a running battle with the Dutch Reformed Church, the institution that provides the theological spine of Afrikanerdom and the scriptural justification for the policies of racial separation. Its accusations are sweeping, attributed to ambiguously described sources and laden with innuendo. Mr. Smith says it reflects a white society that lives what he calls a ''pious lie'' in a city with the population - and the proclivities - of Peyton Place.   Journalist for 27 Years **********Mr. Smith has been active as a journalist in South-West Africa for 27 years. His father made a living hauling ox wagons for the Imperial German colonizers who survived here until 1915. His mother belonged to the Afrikaner pioneers who pushed northward, deep into Angola. **********At the age of 51, he is a man much tormented with visions of his nation and its people that verge on the apocalyptic. The language of his anguish is Old Testament rather than New, laced, nonetheless, with intimations of lust. **********Of South Africa's domination of South-West Africa, widely known as Namibia, he said in an interview: ''We are like the little stepdaughter that comes into the house and is told by the stepfather to wash the dishes, and is told how dependent she is. But then, at night, she is raped, night after night.'' Mr. Smith is a fervent Namibian nationalist, seeking a single nation ''under one flag'' without South African rule. **********On what he calls the duplicitous lives of high-ranking clergy and government officials: ''In the day they are upholders of morality. At night they appear in the devil's attire.'' It is a world, it seems, with no grayness between sunlight and satanic night. **********If the Dutch Reformed Church moves against him, he said in an interview at the white-painted bungalow here that is the headquarters of The Windhoek Observer, ''I have told them that I will start a series on the nocturnal lives of certain top office-bearers.'' In his columns, he has been more direct, speaking of church elders ''having nicknames as a result of their sex escapades with women, in some cases little black girls aged 10 to 12.''  Paper Is Widely Read **********In the world of the Dutch Reformed Church here, with its rebuttal of miscegenation and insistence on a messianic role for white morality, that's fighting talk. And in Windhoek's small world, among a population of only 90,000, it spells trouble. Mr. Smith compares his relationship with the authorities to ''running away from a man with a knife and pleading with him not to kill you.'' **********With a print run of between 8,500 and 11,000 a week, The Observer may seem small, but only in circlation. It is probably the most widely read newspaper in the land, and, to outsiders at least, its idiosyncratic style provides a not-to-be-missed break from the slavish loyalty displayed by some, but not all, Windhoek newspapers to various party lines. **********In a recent issue, for instance, Mr. Smith printed, in full, the United States State Department report on human rights in South-West Africa. He highlighted, on the front page, an article on a purported party at which senior military officials entertained the Angolan rebel leader Jonas Savimbi, used a military aircraft to fly in more liquor and decorated the table with about $15,000 worth of Krugerrand gold coins. **********The newspaper, much of which is written by Mr. Smith himself, then went on to question the probity of a Windhoek city councilor. On page 52, as on every back page, the space was occupied by an unidentified woman wearing only the lower part of a leopard- skin bikini. Such brazenness is unrivaled in the southern African press.   'I Am Going It Alone' **********The newspaper also reported fully on Mr. Smith's withdrawal from the National Press Union, an umbrella organization of newspaper proprietors. ''I am going it alone, for such is my fate,'' Mr. Smith wrote. ''What is left for me before I enter the incinerator of the Windhoek Crematorium? Quite simple. To stand up in defense of the truth, and to resist to the last day of my sublunary existence the rot that is the practice in my country.'' **********His editorial, then, revolved around a favored theme: South Africa's ''plundering'' of South-West Africa's resources, and what Mr. Smith sees as the hypocrisy of Pretoria's claim to be a defender of this country against Communist advance. **********''You are hailed as a fighter against the Red Peril when you have stolen masses of the limited natural wealth of a poverty-stricken people who live in oppression in a system that is so criminal that it does not even provide a man with the basics which the country of his birth owes him - schooling, a job and something to eat.'' **********Mr. Smith does not think such broadsides guarantee his newspaper much by way of longevity. He has just received, he said, an order to register with the authorities that could be the precursor of the newspaper's demise. **********His newspaper, he said, ''came into this world not in the garment of the newly born.'' ''It came in the garment of death'' because, he said, of its opposition to South Africa's rule here. ''How far can a man maneuver before he is outmaneuvered?''  A Passion for His Work **********He is a man, it seems, seized with passions for his work. He drives 5,000 to 6,000 miles a month in quest of stories and disclosures, noting where government trucks are heading, probing their business, investigating, recently, an abandoned mine inhabited by poverty- stricken people who eke a living from the last scratches of minerals left there. **********The twin windmills against which he tilts are South Africa's domination and what he says are the moral double- standards among people in office. And that poses questions, for the crusader, after all, should not be given to the same mendacity as his victims. **********So his confession is public. ''I like women,'' he said, ''I like nice girls and nice women and I will like them to the last days of my life.'' No coyness there, in other words, no conflict of interest. He even speaks up in favor of the establishment of a ''proper house of pleasure'' here. **********But what of those of his victims who he says have taken their lives rather than face the opprobrium of publicity in the pages of The Windhoek Observer, serving a community so small and interlocked that names do not need to be named for identities to be established? **********''I have forced certain people to suicide,'' Mr. Smith said in the interview, ''and I'm not unhappy about it because they did nothing to help my country.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/16/world.body_text: **********France called today on the Security Council to act in light of the ''particularly serious'' situation in Beirut and help create an international peacekeeping operation to replace the American, French and Italian troops in the present multinational force. **********The French delegate, Luc de la Barre de Nanteuil, said a United Nations force in Beirut could be made up of United Nations detachments now in southern Lebanon. **********He said that, if a United Nations force was to take over, the present multinational force ''should withdraw together with its accompanying ships,'' an allusion to the United States Sixth Fleet. The withdrawal of the fleet is a condition for Soviet support of a United Nations peacekeeping operation. **********The French delegate said ''it is undoubtedly preferable that the international force in the urban area of Beirut'' did not include soldiers from any country now on the Security Council. The suggestion seemed intended to insure that no Soviet, American, British and French troops would take part. **********France is circulating a working paper that, in addition to the proposal for a new peace force, also calls for a cease-fire and the withdrawal of foreign troops. The Council is scheduled to meet again on Thursday.   Fleet Departure Is at Issue **********PARIS, Feb. 15 - Vice President Bush suggested today that the United States would reject any Soviet attempt to make the withdrawal of the Navy ships off Lebanon a condition for Soviet approval of a plan to send a United Nations force to Beirut. **********When a reporter asked about the chances of the removal of the fleet, Mr. Bush said: ''I doubt the United States has much flexibility on that. We have a long-standing role in the Mediterranean with the Sixth Fleet and that role is not going to change as a result of the situation now.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/08/busin.body_text: **********As Westinghouse sees it, the market for nuclear reactors is not dead - it's merely living in exile. The company is investing heavily on the theory that the market will prosper abroad and will eventually come home. **********The theory runs counter to recent experience in this country, where electric customers, utility regulators and even electric companies are questioning whether more nuclear plants will ever be built. **********About $15 billion has been spent in the United States on plants canceled or abandoned since the late 1970's, and the costs of the surviving construction projects are threatening to raise electric rates by more than 50 percent in some areas. A few utilities are near bankruptcy. **********But the Westinghouse Electric Corporation is anticipating a long-term return to nuclear power in this country as well as orders from abroad and a growing business in servicing existing reactors. Each American reactor annually needs about $20 million for service, the company says. **********Japanese Joined in Project **********To be prepared, Westinghouse is putting new money into research and development. The company is paying for one-fourth of a $150 million project undertaken with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, five Japanese utilities and the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry, to design an advanced reactor. Westinghouse describes it as an ''order of magnitude'' improvement over existing reactors. **********The company has also recently purchased nine small enterprises with highly technical specialties in reactor maintenance. **********''We are making the investment, and we are pushing the technology,'' said James S. Moore, vice president and general manager of Westinghouse's water reactor division. ''When we look at this business, we see a growth business,'' he said. **********Westinghouse dominated the first round of nuclear plant construction, supplying the nuclear portion of 35 of the 86 reactors now operating in this country and 21 of the 33 still under active construction. **********Biggest Reactor Exporter **********The company is the nation's leading reactor exporter, with 15 plants operating and 38 others under construction. Licensees in France and Japan have built additional plants. **********Westinghouse predicts that 25 or 26 plants will be ordered in the next five years in the worldwide market where Westinghouse can compete. That means outside France, Japan and West Germany, where domestic companies will manufacture their own reactors - sometimes under license from Westinghouse - and outside the Soviet Union and its satellites. Of the 25 or 26 projected orders, Westinghouse hopes to win 6 to 10 of them. **********Some experts on electric power, however, are predicting that fewer reactors will be built. At the Worldwatch Institute, a Washington-based research institution, Christopher Flavin, an analyst, declared in a study at the end of last year that nuclear power was ''stillborn'' in the third world and that cancellations would outpace orders. **********A recent survey by William Walker and Mans Lonnroth predicts an average of just two reactor orders a year worldwide for the next few years. **********Outlook for Domestic Orders **********Westinghouse expects no orders in this country in the next five years. **********Part of the company's strategy is that it can do better if it has a better product. The existing reactor model is complicated, and in the United States it is expensive to build. In addition, several of its components are prone to failure, requiring lengthy maintenance shutdowns. Designs have been criticized for safety reasons. **********The advanced reactor that Westinghouse is helping to design will use the same general plan, but Westinghouse believes there is substantial room for improving it. ''The plants coming out today were designed in the early 1970's,'' Mr. Moore noted. The advanced reactor is expected to go into service in Japan by 1993. **********The new design will differ from earlier efforts in this way: In the 1960's and 1970's, many American utilities started building reactors with only 20 percent of the design work done, but the new model is to be 70 to 80 percent designed before construction begins. Previously the idea was to save construction time - and, therefore, money - by starting to pour concrete without waiting for all of the reactor's design details. **********Development Work Pursued **********''We're doing the design, the up- front testing and development work,'' Mr. Moore said. ''These kinds of things we didn't do a lot of in the last few years.'' **********While Westinghouse will do most of the design work, according to Raymond A. George, manager of the advanced reactor program, the Japanese partners play a big role. ''Their contribution is disciplining us to make us follow through,'' he said. ''They're nit-picking us.'' **********The Japanese also contribute management expertise. Westinghouse officials say that reactors in Japan have been completed in 48 months, using 2,500 workers on a single shift. At some plants in this country, twice as many workers laboring twice as long have failed to finish the job. The length of the construction period is important to the final cost, utility officials say, because of the interest expense on tied-up capital. **********But Westinghouse is not conceding anything on design. ''We have not relinquished the technical lead whatsoever,'' said Mr. Moore. His company, he added, is selling robots for reactor maintenance to Japan. Westinghouse acquired Unimation Inc., a robot manufacturer, in early 1983. **********Review in Advance Is Sought **********The company has asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to review the design in advance of the first reactor order in this country, so that a standardized product can be built, with simplified regulatory approval. **********The new reactor is to incorporate a host of changes, such as how to improve the reliability of parts. **********One major change will be to place the nuclear fuel lower in the reactor vessel, below the level of the pipes carrying cooling water, to reduce the risk that a pipe break could leave the core uncovered and let the fuel melt. **********Hardware changes, made to reduce the chance of accident, ''will avert radiation releases to the public as well as protecting a utility's plant investment,'' according to a paper prepared by a Westinghouse engineer, John Iacovino Jr. He said a combination of passive and active safety features had resulted in ''a more forgiving plant design.'' **********The pipes are being designed with fewer bends, to cut the accumulation of radioactive sediment. **********Less Exposure to Radiation **********And with a longer wait between refuelings, the new reactor is supposed to result in personnel radiation exposure totaling no more than 100 rem a year - a rem being a measure of such radiation. The average at existing American nuclear plants is about 680 rem a year, and the best record is 154 rem. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission sets an annual limit for any worker of 5 rem. **********The new reactor's control room will have computers that display extremely detailed information about temperatures, pressures and flows. **********The new design includes more ''dedicated'' equipment, intended specifically for use in emergencies, rather than making pumps and valves used in regular operations serve a second purpose in case of an accident. Thus fewer operator actions in an emergency will be required, according to the company. **********Another improvement, according to Westinghouse, is planned for the steam generators. These transfer heat from the pressurized, radioactive water to cold, clean water, which boils, creating steam. Steam generator leaks and repairs have been a major cause of plant shutdowns. **********Improvement in Availability **********The new reactor is intended to be available 90 percent of the time. Reactors in this country now are available only about two-thirds of the time because of shutdowns for refueling and repairs. **********No reactors have been ordered in the United States since 1978, when Commonwealth Edison ordered two from Westinghouse - and work on them never began. This is part of a general slowdown in the electric generation business, according to Westinghouse. Last year no large power plants of any type were ordered in this country, the company's officials say. But with the economic recovery, they point out, the utilities' load growth has resumed. **********''Nobody wants to talk about building,'' said Mr. Moore. ''But I think what's going on in the back rooms is they're struggling to figure out how to meet load in the mid-to-late 1990's. In a couple of years, somebody's going to be interested in buying something. We'd like them to be interested in buying nuclear.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/18/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates rose yesterday when investors sold government securities because of growing fears that the Federal Reserve may tighten credit availability in response to the continuing strength in the economy. **********Following the upward revision yesterday of the fourth-quarter gross national product, traders reported scattered selling, which met low demand. **********In addition, a rumor that the Fed would raise the discount rate from its current 8.5 percent level encourged another round of selling pressure. As always in the case of such rumors, the Fed refused to comment. **********But David Jones, economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, said: ''There is not any credence for an immediate discount rate increase. The most important influence has been a major shift in market psychology in the direction of expecting a Fed tightening move in the next three to four weeks. **********He added: ''But even if there is a tightening move, which means the Fed increases bank reserve pressure consistent with an increase in the Federal Funds rate from 9.5 percent to 10.5 percent, we would still have a fairly significant delay before the Fed would consider a discount rate increase.'' **********Prices Reflect Concern **********Prices yesterday reflected the concern over Fed policy. The bellwether 12 percent bond due in 2013 fell below the key support par-price level, to an offered price of 99 28/32, to yield about 12.01 percent, compared with 11.95 percent late Thursday. This was a decline of 18/32 from Thursday's closing level. **********The 10.87 percent notes due in 1987 fell about 4/32, to an offered price of 99 14/32, to yield about 11.09 percent. The 11.75 percent note due in 1993 fell 9/32, to 99 6/32, to yield about 11.90 percent. **********Preston Martin, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said at the Women's Bond Club of New York that it was not possible to say that the economy was growing too fast on the basis of the January data. He also said there was no evidence that inflation has returned at a rapid pace and he indicated that he did not think the economic reports justified a change in Fed policy. **********Scott Winningham, at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc., said the revision in the gross national product from 4.5 percent to 4.9 percent for the fourth quarter ''wouldn't have had much effect, but the whole batch of recent economic indicators have completely reversed the tone of the market and the Fed's likely response to the economy.'' **********He added: ''I can't remember when events have so rapidly altered the outlook for Fed policy and the markets. The numbers are saying the economy is stronger and rebounding from an even stonger fourth quarter.'' **********Prices rose and interest rates fell this week with each new economic report. Analysts said all the key reports - industrial production, personal income, retail sales and housing starts - were all much stronger than expected. **********''Essentially the strong economic growth, and strong prospective growth in business borrowing and credit demands, is expected to put near-term upward pressure on interesrt rates,'' Mr. Jones said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/27/busin.body_text: **********This has been a sobering year for the nation's banking system as more banks failed than in any year since the Great Depression. With the collapse last weekend of a small bank in Sandwich, Ill., the number of failures in 1984 rose to 79, the highest since 81 banks failed in 1938. **********To be sure, this year's failures are a far cry from the 4,000 or so banks that failed in 1933, when there was no insurance system in place to cushion the blow, either to depositors or to the economy as a whole. Nonetheless, the rash of failures reflects both the existence of trouble spots in the economy - including agriculture, energy and real estate - as well as the uneven capabilities of bankers. **********But if the numbers loom large, there are some comforting aspects to them. For one thing, most of the failed banks were relatively small institutions. Although their problems may have shaken their local communities, they represented only a small portion of the banking system, smaller even than in recent years. Deposits at failed banks this year totalled only $2.9 billion, well below the $5.4 billion last year and the $9.9 billion of the previous year. **********More importantly, this year's bank collapses had relatively little effect on the overall financial system, and few depositors lost any money. At the start of 1984, there were widespread concerns that loans to developing countries might sour, crippling the banking system. But the ''international debt crisis'' never quite crystallized. And when the giant Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago was threatened by a run on deposits in the face of huge problem loans to energy companies, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Federal Reserve System quickly pumped in money to keep it from failing. **********Problem-Bank List Swells **********Many analysts are surprised, however, that with the economy in its third year of recovery, many banks are still struggling to stay afloat. Indeed, as the year ended, the F.D.I.C.'s list of so-called problem banks swelled to a record 817, a number that has been growing since the beginning of 1983 and that included major banks as well as smaller ones. The previous record was in 1976, when 380 banks were on the list. **********Yet, many analysts believe that the fundamental strength of the banking system has improved considerably in recent months because the nation's biggest banks seem to be in sounder condition. **********''We're pretty close to full health,'' said Ronald I. Mandle, first vice president of Paine Webber Inc.   Third World Debt Crisis Eases **********Most analysts attribute that to an easing of the third world debt crisis. Agreements are being forged between most major debtor nations and the banks, reducing the likelihood of sudden defaults that could wipe out the net worths of a number of this nation's leading banking institutions. **********''No banks have failed because of country-debt problems,'' Mr. Mandle said. ''Even Argentina seems to be making progress.'' **********Rather, the biggest problems have been loans to the once-booming domestic energy and agricultural sectors, and to a lesser degree, real estate. To the surprise of many, including banking officials, most of the failures have been in what had been considered the more prosperous Sun Belt states. **********According to the F.D.I.C., there were no bank failures in New York State, in New England or in Pennsylvania, and only one in New Jersey and one in Michigan. But there were 11 failures in Tennessee; 6 in California and in Texas; 5 in Oklahoma, Texas, Oregon and Kansas, and 4 in Nebraska and Oklahoma. **********''We all sit around trying to figure out why there haven't been more failures in states with high unemployment,'' said a regulator who asked not to be named. ''We speculate that bankers in the Rust Belt have grown up dealing with adversities and know how to survive, and that bankers in areas that have been more prosperous still must learn how to deal with problems.'' **********Regulators say that it is usually difficult to attribute any bank failure to one factor. But in some cases the basic problem is readily apparent. **********An example of a bank that failed mainly because of farm loans was the David City Bank of David City, Neb. The bank had been ''struggling in a down agricultural economy and this factor was paramount in causing its insolvency,'' said Roger M. Beverage, Nebraska's director of banking and finance. The bank had deposits of $17.4 million. **********In the energy belt, the $25.2 million- deposit Community Bank and Trust Company of Enid, Okla., failed largely because of loans to the energy sector. And in California, the Heritage Bank in Anaheim, a relatively large bank, with deposits of $153.3 million, failed in March, mainly because of loans to real estate developers. **********Farther north, the depressed condition of the forestry industry contributed to the failures of two Oregon banks, the Bank of the Northwest in Eugene, and the United Bank of Oregon in Milwaukie.   Brokered Deposits Are Cited **********Banking authorities also attribute some of the problems to brokered deposits. Some bankers, they say, are so eager to grow that they pay brokers such high rates to get deposits that the money must be re-lent at extraordinarily high rates, and to high- risk credits. In most cases the brokers get the money in large denominations from investors and break the deposits down into chunks of $100,000, the maximum amount insured by the F.D.I.C. **********In some cases, banks receive brokered deposits with the understanding that they will make loans to specific borrowers. If the banks fail, the F.D.I.C. repays the depositors. **********At the Heritage Bank of Anaheim, for example, $97.5 million of its $153.3 million in deposits represented brokered funds. Similarly, of the $20.7 million of deposits in the Emerald Empire Banking Company of Springfield, Ore., $11.2 million, or more than 50 percent, came from brokers. **********In other cases, banking officials indicated that imprudent practices, such as loans to friends and associates, and illegal practices, such as embezzlement and fraud, had played a role in failures. **********Questionable practices appear to have been involved, for example, in many of the 11 bank failures in Tennessee this year. Most of these failures were connected to the collapse of the United American Bank of Knoxville, which was owned by Jacob F. Butcher, known as Jake. Mr. Butcher and his brother, Cecil Hilque, or C.H., together had interests in 27 banks with assets of about $3 billion. Jake Butcher has been indicted for bank fraud. **********Among the nation's biggest banks, none technically failed this year, but some were shaken. Government officials privately contend that Continental's takeover by the Government was an effective failure - its top executives were dismissed, most of its directors removed and its stockholders are expected to lose most, if not all, of their investment. But the Government's intervention avoided an actual failure of the nation's eighth- largest bank, which could have caused a chain reaction of bank failures.   Large Banks Not Immune **********In addition to Continental's problems, other large banks were experiencing serious troubles. In the third quarter, for example, the First Chicago Corporation, the parent holding company of the First National Bank of Chicago, the 10th largest in the United States, reported a $71.8 million loss. That was the result of large loan write-offs following a special examination by the Comptroller of the Currency, the chief regulator of federally chartered banks. Similar events occurred at large banks elsewhere in the United States, especially in Texas and Minneapolis. **********Other giant banks, including the Bank of America, in San Francisco, the second largest after Citibank, also reported heavy loan losses. **********At both First Chicago and Bank of America, the Comptroller forced the banks' directors - including some of America's most prestigious corporate executives - to sign legally binding pledges that their banks would be run more prudently. **********On the more positive side, the nation's biggest banks - under pressure from regulators and investors - have been rebuilding their reserves against loan losses and increasing the levels of their stockholders' investments. As a result, there is a bigger cushion between possible loan losses and depositors' money. **********Some analysts say that the pressures on banks to increase their primary capitalization could substantially slow economic growth. **********''The danger to the economy,'' said Lawrence Cohn, first vice president and bank-stock analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., ''is that the banking industry might overreact and tighten up too much. It could starve the economy of credit. I don't lose a lot of sleep over that, but it's something I give some thought to.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/19/world.main_headline: IRISH NATIONALISTS SEARCH FOR A FORMULA FOR UNITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/19/world.print_headline: IRISH NATIONALISTS SEARCH FOR A FORMULA FOR UNITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/19/world.body_text: **********Irish nationalists, after eight months of deliberation and few signs of encouragement from the British, are preparing to make painful and politically sensitive decisions to produce a formula they hope will lead to Irish unity. **********The document that the nationalist New Ireland Forum puts out at the end of March may not entice British Unionists in Northern Ireland or the Government in London to join the Irish Republic in a search for a political settlement to end six decades of the partition of Ireland. But its study of religious, social, economic, constitutional and national security problems associated with ending the division has forced politicians in the republic to examine their own statements on the subject and to try to square them with the harsh realities that any political union with Ulster would bring. **********It has also brought home to them that the violence in Northern Ireland can spill across the border at any time and pose a threat to stability in the republic. **********The New Ireland Forum is made up of the four major Roman Catholic parties that reject the use of violence as a way of achieving Ireland's unity. But they are divided on many other issues. Reaching a consensus has been the key question since the forum was formed last spring. **********It now seems apparent, according to a Government official here, that even the most hard-line nationalists among the participants are ready to agree to some concessions to the Unionist majority in the North. Though pessimistic about their chances of winning Unionist cooperation, they now want to encourage discussions on the future of Northern Ireland that could bring about an end to the conditions that are strengthening terrorist groups. **********''There is a new awareness in Dublin that Northern Ireland is no longer just a problem for Northern nationalists,'' one participant said. ''It's now a Southern problem, and unless something is done now to stop the terrorists they will become a cancer eating away at our society as well.'' **********This prospect was brought home in December when an Irish soldier and a police cadet were killed by members of the Irish Republican Army. The I.R.A. members were sought for the kidnapping of the head of a leading Irish grocery chain. The killers then slipped away from army and police units. **********In the same period, one of Northern Ireland's most wanted terrorists seemed to roam freely around the republic, humiliating the Irish police to the point of capturing several of them on different occasions and stripping them of their uniforms. **********And this week brought the news from the owners of Shergar, the $12 million race horse stolen from an Irish stud farm last February, that they believed that the stallion had been taken by the Irish Republican Army and killed when ransom negotiations failed. **********On the political front, Sinn Fein, the political arm of the I.R.A., has been winning converts away from more moderate parties in the North, and it has shown renewed interest in making political inroads in the republic. **********These events, at a time when unemployment continues to grow while it is flattening out or declining elsewhere, have apparently convinced the forum participants that the threat to domestic political and social stability is real enough to take the initiative to help break the impasse on Ulster. **********''If Britain can be brought around to accept that to do nothing is worse than to do something,'' said a forum participant, ''then movement is possible.'' **********The Unionists in the North, while unlikely to entertain any overtures from Dublin unless pressed by London to do so, would not consider any concessions to be serious unless they dealt with two main areas: first, the role and influence of the Catholic Church in a united Ireland; and second, the preservation of the British culture, or ''Britishness,'' of those who come from a Scotch-Irish tradition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/busin.main_headline: After a 15-Year Quest, Briton Buys Newspaper
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; After a 15-Year Quest, Briton Buys Newspaper
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/busin.body_text: **********Robert Maxwell has finally pushed his way onto Fleet Street. With his acquisition on Friday of the Mirror Group for $148 million, the 61-year-old publishing magnate ended his 15- year-long quest for control of a major British newspaper. **********Mr. Maxwell's pursuit of happiness in London's newspaper district has seemed, at times, almost quixotic. Since 1969, he has attempted to buy The News of the World, The Sun, The Standard, The Times and, last year, The Observer. The only fruit of his travails, until last week, was a 10 percent holding in Fleet Holdings, publisher of The Daily Express. **********With his purchase of the Mirror Group, Mr. Maxwell now has The Daily Mirror, one of Britain's largest- circulation tabloids, and several other newspapers. He also gained a small interest in the Reuters news agency. **********Asked about his apparent fascination with newspaper ownership, Mr. Maxwell said: ''I have a job to do. I am not on an ego trip. I have a contribution to make to the energy and effectiveness of Mirror Group newspapers.'' **********A native of Czechoslovakia, Mr. Maxwell left home when a teen-ager to join the underground resistance to Hitler's armies. He was wounded and captured, but escaped to Britain, where he eventually won the country's Military Cross for heroism. **********Mr. Maxwell founded his private company, Pergamon Press, in 1951. He lost control of the company in 1971, after a report by the Department of Trade termed him ''not a person who can be relied upon to exercise proper stewardship of a publicly quoted company,'' but regained control three years later. In the decade since, he has won several battles with Britain's powerful printing unions, and turned Pergamon into a major publisher of educational and scientific texts, with sales in 1983 of $451 million. **********Mr. Maxwell reportedly works seven days a week, sometimes 16 or 17 hours each day. He enjoys publicity and has become adept at finding his way into print in London's newspapers. Once a Labor Party Member of Parliament, he does not mask his liberal sentiment. He wrote in a message to readers of Saturday's Daily Mirror that the paper would continue ''opposing privilege and standing alone among the popular dailies as the voice of the sensible left.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/22/world.main_headline: U.S. BARS EMERGENCY AID TO ISRAEL UNTIL STRICTER AUSTERITY IS IMPOSED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/22/world.print_headline: U.S. BARS EMERGENCY AID TO ISRAEL UNTIL STRICTER AUSTERITY IS IMPOSED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/22/world.body_text: **********The State Department said today that the United States would not meet Israel's request for an emergency grant of $800 million until Israel adopted a much tougher economic austerity program. **********After two days of talks with an Israeli delegation, the department promised to recommend to Congress ''continued substantial levels of economic and military aid'' for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, 1985. Other officials said this would be at about the same levels that Israel was now receiving. **********For the 1985 fiscal year ending next Sept. 30, Israel has received a total of $2.6 billion in direct grant aid, of which $1.2 billion is economic assistance and $1.4 billion military aid. **********Israel announced this week that it was seeking a dramatic increase in direct aid, to some $4.1 billion for the 1986 fiscal year. Of this amount, $2.2 billion would be military aid and $1.9 billion economic assistance. In addition, the Israelis asked for an immediate grant of $800 million to maintain their foreign-exchange reserves. **********John Hughes, the State Department spokesman, said the Israelis had been told that in response to the $800 million request, ''the United States will defer a decision on this, pending the adoption of an effective Israeli economic stabilization program and a determination of the utility of such additional U.S. assistance in supporting such a program.'' Mr. Hughes spoke at a news conference, which will be his last for the Administration, since he is leaving to return to the newspaper business in Cape Cod, Mass. Bernard Kalb of NBC News has been named to replace him. **********Wage-Price Freeze Imposed **********The Israeli national unity Government of Prime Minister Shimon Peres has taken some steps, such as a three- month wage-price freeze, to reduce its budget and its foreign exchange losses. But American officials who met with the Israelis this week stressed that the United States did not believe the steps had gone far enough. **********Israeli sources said their delegation, headed by Emmanuel Sharon, director general of the Finance Ministry, told the Americans that Israel had to proceed cautiously because its social situation would not permit drastic measures. **********One Israeli said unemployment had reached 7 percent of the civilian work force, a very high figure for Israel. He said that if the budget was cut further and more people were laid off, this would not only cause unrest in the areas of highest unemployment, but would also lead many Israelis to leave for other countries and discourage other Jews from immigrating to Israel.  The American side was headed by W. Allen Wallis, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. **********As to the Israeli request for an increase of more than 50 percent in aid for 1986, Mr. Hughes said the Administration would propose economic aid at about the same $1.2 billion level. He indicated that military aid might increase so Israel could maintain its ''qualitative edge'' over Arab countries. **********The Administration is considering large-scale military sales to Saudi Arabia, which would lead to increased concern from Israel that the equipment, such as additional F-15 aircraft, might be diverted for use against Israel. **********Hope for Support in Congress **********Israeli diplomats expressed disappointment at the inability to persuade the Administration to be more generous. One diplomat said Israel might have to rely on its backers in Washington to persuade Congress to approve the aid over Administration objections. **********A staff member for the Senate Appropriations Committee said he was confident Israel would receive a large-scale increase at least for the 1986 fiscal year. **********In the last two years, the Israelis and the Administration have agreed on the levels of aid and Congress has not tried to tamper with the figures. **********Some of Israel's supporters in Congress said it might be difficult to win approval of the additional aid for Israel - already the largest benefiary of American aid - if Israel does not make more dramatic economic sacrifices. They have said that given the drive to reduce United States budget deficits, it may not be easy to persuade Congress to allow so much aid to one country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/08/world.main_headline: LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT GROUP LINKED TO MINING OF RED SEA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/08/world.print_headline: LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT GROUP LINKED TO MINING OF RED SEA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/08/world.body_text: **********Islamic Holy War, the group that the Iranian radio says is responsible for laying mines in the Red Sea, is so shadowy that its existence is a matter of debate. **********Some diplomats and intelligence officials say it is a pro-Iranian organization, with branches in Arab nations that have large populations of the Shiite sect, the branch of Islam that predominates in Iran. **********Others say that the group as such does not exist and may, in fact, be a cover name for a variety of terrorist groups. **********Many intelligence officials are persuaded that at least some of these groups are sponsored or aided by governments. Although hard evidence is fragmentary - because of the professionalism of the operations and the ease with which plotters can go underground - the consensus is that the governments of Iran or Syria have been involved in some of the incidents. **********The most destructive was the killing last October of 241 American servicemen and 58 French troops serving as part of the peacekeeping force in Beirut, Lebanon. Six months earlier, the group took responsibility for the bombing of the American Embassy in Beirut. **********The group is also said to have been responsible for the murder in January of Malcolm Kerr, president of the American University of Beirut, a symbol of the American presence in the Middle East. **********This is not the first time that the group has taken responsibility for actions outside Lebanon. Islamic Holy War said it carried out simultaneous bombings in Kuwait in December at the American and French embassies, the airport, a residential area inhabited by Americans, and an industrial complex in which 6 people were reported killed and 63 injured. **********Several officials in Washington expressed skepticism that a group without official assistance could lay mines in the Red Sea.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/19/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of residents near the border city of Matamoros were evacuated Monday night when a ruptured hose at a fertilizer company spewed ammonia fumes into the air, police officials reported today. Two people were seriously injured. **********The accident took place at about 6:30 P.M. at the plant of Ucamsa, a chemical fertilizer company, at the eastern edge of the city. About 100 families from four poor neighborhoods surrounding the plant fled their homes as a white cloud of ammonia gas filled the air, according to Martin Pizarro of the Judicial Police in Matamoros. He said most began to return within two hours. **********''It dispersed quickly,'' Mr. Pizarro said. ''Everything is normal now.'' He said that the gas cloud had been about as large as a half-mile in diameter before it dispersed.   Hospitals Treat 70 to 80 **********The police said that 70 to 80 residents had sought treatment from hospitals after breathing the gas, which in minor doses causes irritation to the eyes, skin and respiratory passages. All but two - workers who were transferring the ammonia when the break in the hose occurred - were treated and released. The two remained hospitalized with more serious burns from contact of the chemical with their skin, Mr. Pizarro said. **********The accident took place when a hose being used to transfer the chemical from a railroad tank car ruptured under high pressure, according to officials. A Matamoros fire official estimated that about 8,000 gallons of the chemical were released.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/18/busin.body_text: **********ROBERT L. CATLIN, formerly of Pan American and American Airlines, is currently trying to pilot a load of new business prospects into the hanger at N. W. Ayer, the country's oldest, and 17th- largest, agency. **********As a senior vice president, director of business development, he is the new-business man, and his job includes attracting clients to Ayer's growing international network. **********Jerry N. Jordan, a Princeton grad with a master's in psychology from Penn, is president of the international operation, and was host at a press conference yesterday to talk about the changes. **********Currently the agency, which is committed to growing in the international arena, has increasing equity in, or total ownership of, agencies in 12 countries. It also has affiliations with 25 other agencies in which the aim is to get an equity position and develop that into a majority position. **********''We found that 25 percent equity is great, as long as everything is going well,'' Mr. Jordan said, ''but when there is a problem you have to have the ability to step in. So we have been trying to increase our equity.'' **********He said the reason it works - even with only 25 percent - is because he insists that the contract with the foreign agencies stipulate total control for the lead agency (the agency whose client it is), including the staffing of the account. **********Ayer is 115 years old, and in the 1930's had a number of overseas offices that served its Ford client. All closed up during World War II, and never reopened. **********Then, realizing that the advertising world was passing it by, Ayer moved cautiously abroad by joining the Barker agency of Britian and the Hegemann agency of Germany to form a joint venture in the Netherlands called ABH. It acquired a maximum of 25 percent of five European agencies, and also had a position in each of the parent agencies. **********When Ayer, driven by its new client, Pan American World Airways, to acquire and expand, became too aggressive for its two partner agencies, they, at different times, asked out of the joint venture. So Ayer bought them out. **********Pan Am, which became a client in 1978, also wanted help in Latin America, the Pacific and the Far East. **********Ayer International, as a subsidiary of N. W. Ayer, was started in 1981, the same year the agency lost Pan Am. Its 12 partner agencies include three bought into last year in France, Italy and the Netherlands. They were added to the existing chain in the Netherlands, Belgium, Sweden, Germany, Italy, Spain, Argentina, Australia, New Zealand and Hong Kong. **********Ayer is pushing hard for majority ownership, except where frustrated by government policy, as in Australia and New Zealand. And Mr. Jordan added, ''I think it would be almost impossible to get a majority position in a major Canadian agency.'' **********''And our objective,'' he said, ''is to have ownership, where governments will allow, in the top 20 markets by the end of next year.'' **********For the agencies, the benefit, he said, is their access to the training they will get - as well as the opportunity to exchange information with other shops in the network. **********The reason Ayer pushes for more than the 25 percent ownership originally sought by ABH is that a majority position, Mr. Jordan said, ''helps us protect our investment better'' and placates those clients who think control only comes with majority ownership. **********Ayer's major multinational clients are Deere & Company, the tractor maker, and the Bahamas Ministry of Tourism. And, while there are 32 advertisers who are served in two or more countries by Ayer, only five or six of them are clients of the agency in the United States. This is something that Mr. Catlin - on his return performance at the agency - is out to rectify. Ayer has more than 50 domestic clients. **********The 56-year-old Mr. Jordan is a second-generation Ayerman. His dad, the late Clarence, was a copywriter. The son's first job was at the agency's original heqadquarters in Philadelphia. He stayed for 12 years. He was a senior account man on the United Airlines account. When the agency lost it, he left and went to work for American Airlines for seven years. **********Then he became president of the United States unit of Thomas Cook, the British travel company. When Cook dismissed him, he was available to Ayer, whose Louis T. Hagopian, chief executive, rehired him in 1976 as an executive vice president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/02/busin.body_text: **********Lambsdorff's View of U.S. **********OTTO LAMBSDORFF, West Germany's Minister of Economic Affairs, is in the United States this week, laying the groundwork for a meeting Monday between Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Reagan. **********In an interview in New York, Mr. Lambsdorff made clear that his Government is deeply concerned over the harmful effects of American economic policies on his own country and many others. He sees two risks stemming from big Federal budget deficits in the United States and high interest rates in this country. **********The first is a threat not to West Germany directly but to the developing countries of Latin America, Africa and Asia. ''They are our clients,'' Mr. Lambsdorff said. ''Our capital goods exports have been weakened, and the developing countries cannot buy capital equipment if their financial position is worsened.'' He warned that the debts of the third-world countries, ''already piled high,'' were bound to increase if United States domestic policies kept interest rates high and rising. **********His second big worry is over the ''growing protectionist tendency in the United States.'' He sees this as linked to high interest rates, which he said had made the dollar overly strong, undermining the American trade position and costing this country hundreds of thousands of jobs. He fears that protectionism will spread, here and abroad, if the United States does not set its fiscal house in order. **********But Mr. Lambsdorff conceded that the extra- strong dollar had been an immediate blessing to the German economy. As noted in the latest issue of the monthly report of the Bundesbank, his country's central bank, West German exporters have profited from the strong economic revival in this country and also ''from the fact that their products have been priced very attractively for foreign buyers as a result of the lower valuation of the Deutsche mark against important world currencies, particularly the United States dollar.'' **********A new study by the Commerce Department in Washington shows how powerful price effects have been in the last two years in worsening the United States balance of trade. In the field of machinery and transportation equipment, for example, the dollar prices received by United States exporters rose only 6.4 percent from the end of 1981 to the end of 1983, but the foreign currency prices that foreigners had to pay for those American goods rose 22.8 percent. Conversely, prices of foreign machinery and transportation equipment paid by American importers rose only 1.2 percent in dollars but 16.6 percent in terms of the foreign-currency prices received by foreigners on sales to the United States. **********Mr. Lambsdorff criticized the Reagan Administration and, even more strongly, Congress for yielding to protectionist pressures, especially in steel, as a false and dangerous solution to the trade problem. He warned that this country is courting retaliation from Europe, and he urged positive steps to regain a more ''outward-looking'' attitude through international negotiations. **********Relations between the United States and West Germany have also been strained over this country's criticism of what it considers an inadequate contribution by Europeans to their own defense. Mr. Lambsdorff sharply opposed suggestions - made recently by Lawrence Eagleburger, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, and Henry A. Kissinger, former Secretary of State - that the United States should reduce its military forces in Europe if the West Germans and others did not spend more on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.  Mr. Eagleburger has suggested that the United States might make a relative shift toward the Pacific Basin. And Mr. Kissinger, whom the Germans consider a possible successor to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, has said in an article in Time magazine that the United States should consider cutting its 320,000 troops in Europe by as much as half if the Europeans refused to strengthen their contributions. **********Mr. Lambsdorff said he considered Mr. Kissinger's proposal that the next commander of NATO forces be a European and the next secretary general of NATO be an American as just ''making a show.'' But Chancellor Kohl, disturbed by the critical signals emanating from Washington, is likely to try to reassure President Reagan during his White House visit that he and President Francois Mitterrand of France intend to bolster their cooperation with the United States and their military self-defense. **********Mr. Lambsdorff has a self-defense problem of his own. He has been accused of taking a bribe in the form of a $50,000 contribution for his political party, the Free Democratic Party, from the Flick holding company in exchange for tax waivers of $175,000 on some of its foreign operations. **********The Bonn economics minister acknowledged that Flick had made the contribution and that the tax break had been granted to Flick. (It has since been withdrawn.) But he said there was no connection between the two actions, that the money was ''never given to me'' and that there is no evidence against him except that his name was on a list found in Flick's offices. **********In the interview, Mr. Lambsdorff stoutly maintained his innocence and ''good conscience,'' and he said he intended to ''fight my way through.'' But if he is indicted, as expected, in May or June, he will probably be compelled to resign to defend himself in court. **********Mr. Kohl has assigned Mr. Lambsdorff to the critical effort to strengthen relations with Washington and, at the same time, demonstrate that West Germany is not a humble or pliant vassal of the United States. In doing so, Mr. Kohl appears to be trying to strengthen his economics minister's position - and his own.
