https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/04/busin.main_headline: 8.3% GAIN IN VOLUME FOR CITY'S RETAILERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/04/busin.print_headline: 8.3% GAIN IN VOLUME FOR CITY'S RETAILERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Sales at seven major retailers in New York City rose an average of 8.3 percent in May over the period a year before, a monthly survey has found, but several of the retailers failed to achieve their planned sales because of a combination of cool weather and consumer-buying sluggishness. **********While all of the retailers reported sales gains over 1983, the increases ranged from 3.1 percent to 14.2 percent, the only double-digit improvement. Prices of typical department store goods are up about 3 percent this year. **********In the metropolitan area, including business in both the city and the suburbs, the seven retailers reported an average sales increase of 9.5 percent over May 1983. But once again, the range of gains was wide, from 4.5 percent to 15.2 percent. **********The retailers participating in the survey are Abraham & Straus, B. Altman & Company, Bloomingdale's, Gimbel Brothers, Lord & Taylor, the Macy New York division stores and Saks Fifth Avenue. Monthly sales percentage changes are obtained from the controller's office of each company on a non-attributable basis. **********Generally Disappointing **********The month's results were generally disappointing, as May sales reflected the second-smallest monthly gains in the fiscal year that began Feb. 1. **********February's sales were up 13.7 percent in the city and 15.6 percent in the area over the previous February. The lowest monthly gains came in March, with a 1.2 percent increase in the city and 1.1 percent in the area. The pace quickened again in April, with sales rising an average 12.4 percent in the city and 13.9 percent in the area. **********''What we have had is a bad March, a good April and practically a flat May,'' observed one retail executive. ''All together, it hasn't been a good three months.'' **********While other merchants were not quite so pessimistic, most said that retail inventories have risen sharply in recent weeks because of lagging business. The result has been an effort to clear stocks and promote considerable goods at lower prices. These promotions, particularly in the last two weeks, have helped raise the sales level at the expense of normal profit margins. **********Differing Reactions **********The erratic nature of retail activity was demonstrated during the month by varying sales of the same merchandise at different stores. For example, at one company, furniture and floor coverings were said to be among the strongest departments, but in another major store they were said to have ''flattened out.'' **********While women's accessories had good business, the ordinarily popular area of women's sportswear cooled during the month. **********But concern over the sales figures may be premature and based too much on short-term performance. In the full 1983 retail fiscal year ended in January, the retailers had an average sales gain of 8.5 percent in the city and 10.5 percent in the metropolitan area. Those increases were not much higher than last month's respective gains of 8.3 and 9.5 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/01/world.body_text: **********A 40- year-old Zambian diplomat, J. B. Chiwende, was arrested and accused of drug smuggling at Schiphol airport Wednesday night after 13 kilograms of heroin were found in his luggage, the Dutch state police said. Mr. Chiwende, who is second secretary in the Zambian High Commission in Kenya but lacks diplomatic immunity here because he is not accredited to the Netherlands, denied any knowledge of the heroin, according to a spokesman for the police.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/10/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union and the Yemen Arab Republic signed a 20-year treaty of friendship today. **********The Soviet Union is already an ally of the adjoining nation on the Arabian Peninsula, the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, or Southern Yemen. **********They signed a 20-year amity pact in 1979. **********The treaty with the Yemen Arab Republic was annnounced on the first day of a visit by President Ali Abdullah Saleh. He arrived one day after the departure of the President of Southern Yemen, Ali Nasser Mohammed. Both men met with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader. **********According to the Tass press agency, the treaty with the Yemen Arab Republic says that the Soviet Union respects Yemen's policy of nonalignment, and Yemen respects Soviet foreign policy. The two sides agreed to develop cooperation in all fields. **********Western diplomats saw the agreement as part of a pattern of developing Soviet-Arab relations. **********In July, the Kremlin agreed to exchange ambassadors with Egypt for the first time since 1981. Kuwait signed an arms pact with Moscow in August.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/04/world.body_text: **********Heavy fighting broke out today between Lebanese Army troops and anti- Government militiamen along the dividing line between East and West Beirut. The fighting dashed hopes for a quick cease-fire guaranteed by Syria. **********The intense clashes came as the Lebanese President, Amin Gemayel, conducted another day of negotiations with Christian and Moslem leaders in an effort to win support for his understanding with Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, on a framework for a settlement of Lebanon's political strife. Syria is Moscow's foremost ally in the Middle East. **********In Damascus, Syrian officials were expected to continue their efforts to convince the two key Lebanese opposition figures, Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader, and Nabih Berri, the Shiite Moslem leader, to cooperate with Mr, Gemayel. They had earlier called for his resignation, but Mr. Jumblat said Friday night that they had agreed to drop this demand. There were reports that Mr. Berri and Mr. Jumblat might meet today with President Gemayel, but the Druse leader said that there had been no talks. **********2 More Leaders Endorse Plan **********Experts here said they believed that earlier talks by Syrian officials with Mr. Berri and Mr. Jumblat were partly aimed at securing their agreement for a halt to the violence here before political reconciliation talks in Geneva could begin. **********Meanwhile, the Syrian-Lebanese understanding won endorsement today from two other leading Lebanese opposition figures, former Prime Minister Rashid Karami and former President Suleiman Franjieh. The two men, members of the pro- Syrian National Salvation Front, met today with Mr. Gemayel. **********The meeting with Mr. Karami, a Sunni Moslem, was especially significant because he and Mr. Gemayel had not met since national reconciliation talks broke down last November in Geneva. **********'Historic Turning Point' **********Mr. Karami, a leading candidate for prime minister in a new government, called the Syrian-Lebanese understanding an ''historic turning point'' that marked ''the beginning of the end of the crisis.'' **********As talks went on, fire from mortars, tanks, heavy artillery and rocket-propelled grenades shook buildings around the city and added to the already heavy toll of civilian casualties. **********The crackle of gunfire and the loud report of exploding grenades and artillery shells echoed down the streets in many parts of the capital. In some neighborhoods, residents said the fighting was the worst in some time.  Artillery duels also erupted between Lebanese Army troops and Druse and other anti-Government forces around Suk al Gharb, a strategic mountain village not far from the presidential palace and the Defense Ministry. **********In today's fighting, two 82-millimeter mortar shells struck near the Hotel Alexandre, which houses most of the foreign press corps in East Beirut. The shells wounded one neighborhood resident and damaged eight cars. **********In the meantime, new details emerged here concerning the two days of talks this week between Mr. Assad and Mr. Gemayel.  High-ranking Lebanese officials say the two leaders agreed on a Syrian- guaranteed cease-fire, the scrapping of Lebanon's troop-withdrawal agreement with Israel reached last May 17, the resumption of political reconciliation talks in Geneva as early as next week and the formation of a government of national unity that would include all major opposition figures or their representatives. **********The plan also called for talks with Israel designed to replace the May 17 accord with a much narrower agreement to guarantee the security of Israel's northern border. **********Lebanon is sounding out Israel through the United States on the possibility of such talks. But Christian leaders with ties to Mr. Gemayel said today that the Government was under no illusions that Israel, which has responded angrily to the proposed cancellation of the May 17 accord, would take up any Lebanese offer to negotiate a narrower agreement. **********Even if Israel rejects such talks, the leaders said, Mr. Gemayel plans to go ahead with the cancellation, having made a clear choice for Syria over Israel as the country most likely to guarantee his political survival and the possibility of a new government. **********U.S. Position Is Unclear **********Some officials here familiar with the talks said they believed that the United States had so far expressed neither strong opposition nor strong support for Mr. Gemayel's Syrian opening. **********While Lebanese Christian leaders are generally deeply unhappy with American policy, one of them said today that the United States might see some advantage to Mr. Gemayel's move since it might open the possibility of better American relations with Syria. **********''Sometimes, the United States is good at making the best of its mistakes,'' the leader said. But he added that the lack of a strong American response may also reflect division within the Reagan Administration. Many Reagan Administration officials, notably Secretary of State George P. Shultz, are believed to be wary of any opening to Syria now. **********Conversations with Christian leaders and Lebanese officials here over the last few days revealed that President Gemayel understood his weak bargaining position with Syria after the major defeat suffered by the Lebanese Army last month.   Chance of Political Survival   They said Mr. Gemayel apparently expected little immediate return from Syria for his agreement to cancel the accord with Israel. He believes, however, that by doing so he has increased his chances for political survival, for a cease-fire and for some sort of security guarantees for Christian areas not now under Syrian occupation, they said. **********Beyond that, the Gemayel Government is hoping that by ''opening a new chapter with Syria,'' in the words of one official, it might have a chance of winning major concessions later. **********Such concessions would include the withdrawal of Palestinian and other foreign forces who have been aiding the Moslem opposition, the return of at least some Christian areas to Government control and, ultimately, the dismantling of the Green Line dividing Christian East Beirut from the Moslem West. **********These concessions, however, are not enough for a large segment of the Christian leadership, which cherishes its ties with Israel. These officials fear that Mr. Geyamel's trip to Syria constitutes, in the words of one pro-Israeli Christian, ''only the first mile on a 10,000-mile walk toward the Syrianization of Lebanon.'' **********Mr. Gemayel has sought to appease the fears of these groups, which include the Christian militia founded by his brother Bashir, the National Liberal Party led by former President Camille Chamoun and important elements of the Maronite Church led by the Rev. Boulos Naaman.   Christians Step Up Mobilization **********These leaders met today and issued a statement saying they could not respond to Mr. Gemayel's initiative until he had at least achieved a cease-fire and the withdrawal of troops from the demarcation lines. **********The Christian militia, known as the the Lebanese Forces, recently stepped up its mobilization and reorganized its leadership to prepare for Mr. Gemayel's Syrian opening. Its commander, Fadi Frem, said the group has moved from a ''low profile'' role to a more active stance. **********Mr. Frem has said the militia would maintain its ties with Israel, regardless of what Mr. Gemayel decided. He also said it would strengthen its presence in Christian areas, play an increasing military role in defending Christian neighborhoods and generally form a ''political opposition'' to the Syrian strategy. But what form that opposition will take remains unclear, and several Christian leaders said the new situation could lead to a de facto division of labor between Mr. Gemayel, who is a Maronite Christian, and the Christian opposition.   More Power for Moslems **********Mr. Gemayel's role, experts said, is likely to be to win as many concessions as he can from Syria, but revert to the role of a relatively weak President in a government where Moslems will have more power. The Christian opposition will represent its interests in bargaining with the Druse, Shiite Moslems and other Lebanese groups.  ''The Christians,'' said one political leader today, ''may find that they have more room to maneuver by not having to back the president all the time.'' **********Some Christian leaders have indicated that they are hoping for a far more militant policy of opposition to the President than this leader's predictions would imply. But President Gemayel is relying on his father, Pierre, to use the powerful organization of the Christian Phalangist Party to contain rancor against his Syrian policy in the Christian community. Among other things, Pierre Gemayel, who is 78 years old and the founder of the Phalangist Party, succeeded in keeping the party from opposing Mr. Gemayel's policy toward Syria, despite the party's traditional ties with Israel. Today, the party's central committee again voted its confidence in President Gemayel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/22/busin.body_text: **********The Labor Department reported today that consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same as in September. **********Economists viewed the report as fresh confirmation that inflationary pressures continued in check. **********The latest increase in the Consumer Price Index, the most widely followed gauge of inflation, was attributed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics to a mixture of rises and declines in various categories but mainly to higher gasoline prices for the second consecutive month. Some analysts said, however, that the gasoline run-up would prove temporary and that declines would occur by year-end, reflecting recent softness in prices of crude oil. **********In contrast to the national trend, consumer prices in the New York City area fell one-tenth of 1 percent in October. (Page D3.) **********Analysis of Month's Figures **********Food prices, which had dipped in September, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October. **********Allan Sinai, chief economist for Shearson Lehman/American Express, said the October figures were a bit worse than expected. But over all, he said, he foresees no reacceleration of inflation. **********Citing Wednesday's report that economic growth slowed to 1.9 percent in the third quarter, Mr. Sinai said, ''The economy is growing very slowly, if at all, and for that reason, mainly, inflationary pressures are diminishing rather than accelerating.'' **********In the first 10 months of 1984, today's report said, consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 4.2 percent, compared with 3.8 percent for all last year. **********Outlook for Gasoline Prices **********Analysts also predicted that the recent surge in gasoline prices - which were up 1.1 percent in September and 1.8 percent in October after declining in the preceding three months - would be short-lived. **********''There's room for optimism,'' said Jay N. Woodworth, senior economist with the Bankers Trust Company. He said, ''Recent moves in the energy markets to lower crude oil prices will bring another round of oil price relief, which should show up at the gasoline pumps in the closing weeks of this year.'' **********He predicted that the rate of increase in consumer prices would decline to 3 percent or perhaps 3 1/2 percent by December or early next year. **********All the national price index figures are adjusted to compensate for normal seasonal changes in prices. **********Calculation of Annual Rate **********The rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in October, if it continued for 12 months, would work out to a compound annual rate of 4.2 percent, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. It made the computation from the unrounded increase in the index, which was 0.3508772 percent. **********Patrick C. Jackman, the official in charge of the Consumer Price Index, said the October spurt in gasoline prices was concentrated in the West, primarily in California. In Los Angeles, gasoline prices rose from 115.4 cents a gallon to 121.1 cents, and in San Francisco they rose from 125.5 cents a gallon to 129.9 cents. **********''It appears to be a realignment,'' Mr. Jackman said, ''because prior to October the West was below, and now it's slightly above, the other areas.'' He called it ''tough to figure out why'' gasoline prices rose. He said ''There's some evidence of price wars, but there's no way to confirm that.'' **********Despite the October increase, the Bureau of Labor Statistics noted, gasoline prices were 2.3 percent lower than at the end of 1983 and 13 percent below their March 1983 peak. **********Comparison of Food Prices **********Over all, food and beverage prices were up four-tenths of 1 percent last month, following a dip in September. On a nationwide basis, prices of natural gas for the home fell 1.3 percent and electricity fell 1.7 percent. **********Housing prices rose more slowly last month. They were up one-tenth of 1 percent, compared with four-tenths of 1 percent in September. Other major groups, including apparel and upkeep, entertainment and other goods and services continued to rise last month at about the same pace as in September. **********''We're in a rut right now,'' Mr. Jackman said. ''It's basically a repeat of recent trends, but relative to last three years, it looks pretty good.'' **********For the last three months, the Labor Department said, inflation has run at a compounded annual rate of 4.7 percent. This is a substantial rate by historical standards in the United States but well below the 12.3 percent of 1979 and 11.8 percent of 1980. **********2 Measurements of Prices **********The Bureau of Labor Statistics uses two gauges to monitor prices, and both showed increases in October. The more frequently cited index, for all urban consumers, is called the CPI-U. It showed that prices were up 4.2 percent since October 1983 and were rising at an annual rate of 4.7 percent in the three months ended Oct. 31, 1984. **********An older index, for urban wage earners and clerical workers, is the CPI-W. This gauge, which is widely used for setting cost-of-living increases in industrial labor contracts and Federal benefit payments, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in October and had risen 3.6 percent in the 12-month period. The CPI-W encompasses about half the urban population. **********The October level of the Consumer Price Index, based on 100 in 1967, was 315.3. It means that a list of goods and services that cost $10 in 1967 cost $31.53 last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/15/busin.body_text: **********SIX years ago, two Long Island veterinarians, **********Dr. Evan C. Dribbon and Dr. Sheldon S. **********Schwarzbrott, formed a partnership and purchased the South Shore Animal Hospital in Wantagh, L.I. Less than a year later, the two incorporated their partnership in order to bridge the large disparity between pension benefits permitted corporations and those available to the self-employed. **********But recent changes in Federal tax law - some of which wiped out the tax breaks allowed corporations in the pension area - are forcing physicians, architects and other professionals to re-examine their decision to do business as a professional corporation. The Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982, which became effective this year, for example, now places Keogh plans available to partnerships on par with corporate pension plans. **********''The change in the law was instigated by the proliferation of professionals who incorporate their practices to get corporate benefits,'' said Michael F. Klein, a partner with Price Waterhouse & Company. Congress changed the rules, he said, ''to stop people from running around forming professional corporations.'' **********Do these new rules sound the death knell of the professional corporation? ''The dollar parity in the pension rules makes it less attractive to incorporate than before,'' said Ellen J. Zombek, a tax manager in the Personal Services Group at Deloitte Haskins & Sells. But, she cautioned, there are still some differences in the rules for self-employed versus corporate plans. **********The most important of those differences is the way money taken out of the plan is taxed. While money distributed from a Keogh receives no special treatment, the tax on some corporate plan distributions can be calculated using the ''10-year averaging rule,'' which lowers the tax by treating the money as if it had been received in equal installments over a 10-year period. **********These are some other differences: *********** In a partnership or sole proprietorship, certain employees who also own part of the business cannot take loans from the business's Keogh plan; corporate shareholders are permitted to take loans from their company's pension plan under certain limited circumstances. *********** A Keogh plan can be funded only with cash, while a corporate plan can receive such assets as company stock or real estate. *********** A Keogh distribution cannot be ''rolled over'' into a corporate pension plan, so someone who joins a company after working for herself loses the investment advantage of keeping her entire pension in a large, managed corporate account. **********While many tax breaks for the professional corporation in the pension area were erased by the changes in the legislation, some tax advantages remain. ''There is a big difference between corporations and partnerships or sole proprietorships in the fringe-benefits area,'' said Miss Zombek. A corporation, for example, can form a medical plan or a life or accident insurance plan and take a business deduction for the amount of the contribution. **********The professional corporation also can be used to defer tax. A shareholder who collects $100,000 in revenues, for instance, can take a salary of $75,000 and let the balance accumulate in the corporation at the lower corporate tax rates. **********Incorporating can simply be a good business move as well. While the corporate form is not a complete shield against liability, professionals typically receive more protection than they would in a partnership arrangement. If the business goes bankrupt, for example, creditors normally can reach only corporate assets, not the shareholder's personal assets. **********Unlike a partner, a shareholder in a professional corporation usually cannot be held liable for negligence or malpractice of his fellow shareholders. Similarly, the corporation may be able to sign a lease for office space or equipment without exposing individual shareholders to liability on those leases.  According to Miss Zombek, doing business as a corporation enhances borrowing power. Many states have usury laws that limit the amount of interest that can be charged to an individual borrower; these laws don't apply to corporations. ''If you're starting out and looking for capital,'' said Miss Zombek, ''a bank may refuse to deal with you unless it can charge four or five points above prime.'' **********Professional corporations also are used to assure the continuity of a business. Unlike a partnership, which is legally terminated by the death or resignation of a partner, a corporation has an existence separate from its shareholders, so ''a group of doctors, for instance, could hire new associates without affecting the business structure,'' explained Miss Zombek. **********BUT professional corporations can be expensive. Money earned by the professional is taxed twice, first at corporate rates, then as a dividend when the cash is taken out. Added legal and accounting fees incurred to comply with state and Federal corporate rules may increase day-to- day operating costs. **********Because of those higher costs, some professionals may seek to step back into a partnership. As an incentive for existing businesses, the new law includes a special provision, which expires at the end of this year, that allows professionals to liquidate their corporations with less severe penalties than they would otherwise face. Some professionals who consider liquidation, however, may be deterred by the potentially high costs. **********The special provision that would cut some of those costs permits shareholders who liquidate their corporations within one month to take out earnings accumulated by the corporation as capital gains, subject to a maximum tax of 20 percent. Normally, this money would be taxed as a dividend at ordinary income tax rates. **********Still, professionals can face substantial liquidation costs in the form of potential ''recapture'' of investment tax credits and accelerated depreciation, where certain ordinary business deductions taken by the corporation are taxed when the business is dissolved. Shareholders also may owe a tax on cash and securities distributed by the corporation. The business itself would incur some costs - formally transferring company assets, for example, or printing new stationery. **********''We probably wouldn't bother with a professional corporation today.'' said Dr. Dribbon, the Long Island veterinarian.  ''But since we already have one, it doesn't pay to liquidate.'' **********Carole Gould writes on finance from New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/29/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW FOR WORKERS ABROAD; THE FAMILY ELEMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/29/busin.body_text: **********In Britain, and in those former colonies that still exercize some form **********of British law, a man sent to work by a foreign corporation can secure working papers for his wife automatically. But a woman executive sent to London is not accorded the same privilege: Unless special permission is secured, her husband cannot seek employment. **********The problem is one of many confronted increasingly by corporate personnel managers who send executives overseas. In fact, these managers and other experts say, most unsuccessful foreign assignments - as many as 80 percent - fail because of personal, rather than professional, difficulties. And most often, those difficulties center on the family. **********''To a certain degree, the spouse in America today plays a completely different role,'' Miss Snowdon said. ''In many of the cultures she is relocated too, the woman is not allowed to work, and she now has to take a second seat. Often times that's very difficult for a woman, and it splits the family and the corporation.'' **********Alison R. Lanier, editor of ''Living Abroad,'' a publication for Americans sent overseas, adds that companies give little thought to an executive's children, especially teen-agers. ''They're never considered in the selection process, and never given any orientation. The companies just don't think it's their business - but the minute the company sends that couple overseas, they should become its responsibility.'' **********Mrs. Lanier, Miss Snowdon and others are pushing for companies to allow the spouse and children more involvement in the processes of selection, orientation and training that take place before an assignment. They believe that, in selecting an executive to work abroad, a company should consider the ''survivability,'' as Mrs. Lanier puts it, of the family as much as the executive's professional qualifications. In addition, they say, all members of the family should receive the same training in language, culture and protocol afforded the employee. **********As for the proliferation of dual-career couples, no one has ready solutions. A few employers will assist expatriates in obtaining working papers for their spouses, and some will try to arrange employment. ''But our view is that we're employing an individual,'' said E. Ten Broek, director of executive staffing for Alcan Aluminum Ltd. in Montreal. ''We do not, as yet, compensate for loss of income when a spouse has to move. It's a decision we leave up to the couple.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/08/busin.body_text: **********Commercial banks are becoming increasingly convinced that nearly $3 billion in interest payments owed by Argentina will not be paid by the end of March and that the loans on which those payments are owed will have to be classified as nonperforming. **********Such a reclassification would put downward pressure on the banks' earnings because of how they are reflected under customary accounting practices. **********Under Federal banking regulations, borrowers must be less than 90 days in arrears on interest payments in order for the lending banks to avoid characterizing a loan as nonperforming. At Dec. 31, the most recent data available, Argentina was 86 days in arrears on public sector debt payments. The country has not made any payments on public sector debt since Oct. 17, according to bankers. The arrearage is reported quarterly. **********''It is going to be difficult to get the Argentines under 90 days before the end of the month,'' one banker said. **********Since no payments on outstanding public sector debt have been made since October, for internal bookkeeping purposes most banks have probably been classifying the Argentine loans as nonperforming since sometime in early January, when the 90- day period was broached. **********But the end of a quarter, when results must be made public, is of crucial importance to earnings results. And because of Argentina's problems, analysts say the impact on first-quarter bank earnings could be substantial. **********''The banks will have to add at least $1.1 billion to their nonperforming loan category at the end of the first quarter, and that is entirely due to Argentina,'' said Thomas H. Hanley, a vice president and banking analyst at Salomon Brothers. ''For the first time ever, the banks won't be current on their overseas loans at the end of a quarter, and that will have an impact on earnings.'' **********The rising pessimism about payment prospects stems mainly from a continuing, unresolved debate in Argentina about the direction of the country's economic policy, and the fact that the country seems to be earning more than enough foreign exchange from its grain exports to meet at least some of its interest payments. **********''The Argentines could very well bring the banks more current,'' the banker said, ''but they are building reserve levels to put pressure on us and the International Monetary Fund, saying that we won't pay you off unless you give us better terms.'' **********Mr. Hanley, who recently returned from a trip to Argentina, estimates that by the end of March, the country's foreign currency reserves should be close to $3 billion. **********''To get the U.S. banks current through January 10, which is less than 90 days, the Argentines would only have to disburse about $600 million,'' he said. Argentina has more than $43 billion worth of total outstanding foreign debts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/10/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; HOME OFFICE WRITE-OFFS: UPHILL BATTLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/10/busin.body_text: **********IT is getting tough to land a tax deduction for a **********home office these days, and a string of court **********decisions is making it even more difficult. ''There hasn't been much on the home office front that has been helpful,'' said Leon M. Nad, national tax director at Price Waterhouse. **********A husband and wife who were active investors devoting full time to managing their $13.5 million portfolio were denied the deduction. And so was a newspaper editor who used part of his house to take late-night telephone calls from his staff and prominent news figures. One ray of hope was the deduction granted to an executive who built a lavish lakeside office retreat by his vacation house so that he could conduct long-range planning for his company during the summer, although that decision may not have widespread application. **********But it's not impossible to get such a deduction, of course. If taxpayers who work at home meet all the tests set forth by the Internal Revenue Service, they can write off a variety of expenses relating to home offices, such as depreciation on that part of the home devoted to office use, as well as a pro rata share of utilities and maintenance. To qualify, employees must be able to show, among other things, that the home office is for the convenience of their employer and not for their personal convenience. And they must use the office on a regular and exclusive basis as a place to meet and deal with patients, clients or customers. **********The couple who maintained a home office to manage their large stock portfolio, Joe and Dorothy Moller, lost their bid for a deduction because an appeals court ruled they were not engaged in the business of trading securities. **********Initially, the United States Court of Claims had sided with the Mollers, saying they were ''active investors'' carrying on a business. But late last year, the new Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit reversed that decision. It said that even though the couple were active investors, they were still investors engaged in managing their own portfolio and not traders working for others - and thus they were subject to more stringent rules on what expenses they could deduct in relation to their production of investment income. **********Traders, the court said, are geared to short- term trading, not long-term investing, and their income is primarily from the sale of securities rather than from dividends and interest on those securities. But the Mollers made only 71 sales for the two tax years in question, and more than 98 percent of their income came from dividends and interest, not sales. The court concluded they were investors, and as such were not entitled to a write- off for their home office expenses. **********But Warren S. Shine, a tax principal with the accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney, noted that investors are permitted to deduct a variety of expenses connected with the production of investment income, such as legal and bookkeeping fees. And he said that if the Mollers had rented outside office space rather than using part of their house, ''presumably they would have been permitted to take a deduction for the rental cost.'' **********Max Frankel, editorial page editor of The New York Times, lost his claim for a home office deduction because the United States Tax Court decided that late-night phone conversations with staff members and news figures did not constitute ''meeting and dealing with'' clients. Physical contact is required, the court ruled in a split decision earlier this year. (However, Mr. Frankel's wife, a freelance writer, was permitted to claim the deduction in connection with work she performed as a self-employed person during the same years.) **********Some analysts believe the home office rules should be revised. Present law dates back to the mid-1970's, when Congress enacted stringent rules to curb what it felt were abuses. But ''Congress is going to have to look at the deduction again,'' predicted Mr. Nad of Price Waterhouse. Increasing numbers of people work at computers at home and have no link with their office headquarters except by telephone, he noted. ''The world is changing, and I don't know why these people shouldn't be entitled to the deduction, he said.'' **********THE one positive development in recent court **********rulings concerned a $250,000 office that Ben **********Heineman, president of Northwest Industries, a large Chicago conglomerate, built near his Wisconsin summer home. The 20- by 20-foot office was suspended from the side of a cliff overlooking a lake (so as to not to obstruct the view from the main house 100 yards away) and consisted of one room with computer and phone links to Northwest, plus a rest room and small kitchen. **********For years, Mr. Heineman had set aside the month of August to review his company's long- term plans, retreating to his summer home in Sister Bay, Wis., to escape the heat and interruptions at Northwest's Chicago headquarters. He did not seek reimbursement from Northwest for the cost of constructing and maintaining the office retreat because he did not want his company to have any claim on any part of his vacation property. Northwest paid only the costs of communication between Chicago and Wisconsin. **********But he claimed, as an unreimbursed employee business expense, a total of $51,000 in depreciation and maintenance expenses for his vacation office during the tax years in question. The I.R.S. denied the deduction on grounds that Mr. Heineman could have secured isolation at Northwest's Chicago headquarters by having his staff bar interruptions, that the expenses resulted solely from his personal preference to work in Wisconsin during the summer, and that he failed to ask Northwest to bear the expenses. **********The Tax Court, however, in a decision issued earlier this spring, sided with Mr. Heineman. He had shown that it was appropriate and helpful for him to work in seclusion in Wisconsin, and since he had proved that the office was used solely for business, ''it was of no concern to the court that a less expensive facility could have been found in some less pleasant environment,'' said the accounting firm of Peat Marwick. The court also agreed that he had a good reason for not requesting reimbursement from Northwest: to avoid giving the company a possible claim against his property. **********However, Mr. Nad said the decision will not have widespread applicability because of the work involved. The impact will be confined to ''top-level people of major corporations,'' he said. **********The usual rules did not apply because both parties agreed that Mr. Heineman's office was a separate building, not a dwelling unit. But Mr. Shine of Ernst & Whinney noted that if the office were in an adjoining structure, such as an attached garage, it probably would have been subject to the tougher rules.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/world.main_headline: STATE DEPT. AIDE SAYS 'DOOR IS VERY MUCH OPEN' TO AN ACCORD ON NAMIBIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/world.print_headline: STATE DEPT. AIDE SAYS 'DOOR IS VERY MUCH OPEN' TO AN ACCORD ON NAMIBIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/world.body_text: **********A senior State Department official said today that ''the door is very much open'' to early progress on a package agreement between Angola and South Africa, leading to the independence of South-West Africa and the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola. **********The expression of optimism was not new, since top American officials, starting with former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., have talked of the possibility of a breakthrough in the longstanding southern African problem since the end of 1981. The senior State Department official, who has been directly involved in the diplomacy, said that given the disappointments of the past, it made no sense to venture predictions anymore. **********State Department officials also said there had been only little variation of the basic Administration formula for a settlement - Cuban withdrawal from Angola in return for South Africa's ending its support for guerrillas in Angola and withdrawing its forces from South- West Africa, or Namibia. **********Skepticism Is Wide **********The failure of previous predictions to be borne out have produced widespread skepticism in Washington that anything will come of the Administration efforts. Any breakthrough in the next several weeks would be seen as a tangible accomplishment for the Reagan Administration. In the past, department officials said said they doubted Cuba would cooperate in a withdrawal plan because it might be seen as helping Mr. Reagan in the election. **********The senior official, however, said he was encouraged by a round of discussions this month in Lusaka, Zambia, with senior Angolan officials. He said the talks left the American mediators with the impression that the Angolans were serious in looking for a compromise to break the impasse, which has lasted for three years. **********The South Africans have said they will comply with the six-year-old United Nations Security Council Resolution 435 for the independence of Namibia, but only if the 26,000 Cuban combat troops in Angola are withdrawn at the same time. **********The Angolans, however, have insisted that the Cubans, who have been there since 1975, are necessary for their security and will leave only after Namibia is independent and the South African-backed insurgents in Angola have stopped fighting. **********But the senior American official said that despite this public position, there was more flexibility in the Angolan private stand. **********''The mood in Luanda is one of 'let's try to settle this problem,' '' the senior official said after the latest discussions with the Angolans in Lusaka. **********But he cautioned that ''the exact timing on how this open door would lead to really concrete future steps is not that easy for us to predict.'' The official gave an interview on the condition that he not be named. **********''It looks as good now as it has,'' he said. ''We're not holding back because of our electoral season. We are going full tilt ahead. If others are watching and waiting because of our elections, that's their decision.'' **********The Reagan Administration expressed optimism in February, when Angola and South Africa reached an accord on South African troop withdrawal from Angola. But since then, the South Africans have halted their troop withdrawal 21 miles from the border between Angola and Namibia, pending the next political agreement, the official said. **********Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, returned last week from a trip to Africa that included the talks in Zambia. The senior official said, ''We had a very useful round in Lusaka.'' **********The Angolans, he said, ''brought some ideas.'' **********''We talked them over,'' he said, ''and they're chewing over some of that discussion, and I think we'll be in a position to go to the South Africans and say this is something tangible, and what do you think.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/14/world.main_headline: FOR THE BLACKS IN FRANCE, A FAREWELL TO FRATERNITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/14/world.print_headline: FOR THE BLACKS IN FRANCE, A FAREWELL TO FRATERNITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/14/world.body_text: **********The days when Josephine Baker, the black American entertainer, was the toast of Parisian cafe society seem today like memories from another country. **********''There has been a major shift in France concerning the blacks,'' said Philippe Lafouge, the general director of the Paris Bureau of Social Aid. ''When I was young, they were very much accepted here and the Algerians were not. Today the Algerians are more accepted because they have adapted to French life. But in the last 10 years, especially since 1981, the number of blacks has grown, they have not assimilated, and thus they are not as accepted.'' **********In 1931 the number of black Africans in France totaled 16,401. Today there are officially 138,080, but the total, some officials say, may be closer to 200,000. There are also about 500,000 black French citizens from France's overseas departments in the Caribbean. **********A Cause of Tension **********At a time when France faces severe economic problems, the presence of people whom many of the French consider outsiders has caused tension. **********With 2.2 million people registered as unemployed in France, for example, unskilled African immigrants are suddenly considered competitors for the low-level service jobs that were once beneath French consideration. With French industrial production drastically reduced, thousands of black immigrants, brought over between 1945 and 1974 to work in French factories, are now out of work. **********The French Government has begun a campaign to reduce the number of illegal alien workers in the country. Last year about 7,000 were deported. **********The Government has also proposed a plan to supply aid to legal immigrants who voluntarily seek to return to their home countries. In a recent poll taken by the magazine Hebdo, which opposes President Francois Mitterrand's Government, 72 percent of those interviewed said they wanted the Government to help immigrants return home.   Questions of Racism **********These opinions, according to some blacks who live here, raise questions of racism. There are others who say that they do not sense racism and that they continue to feel loyal to France. **********''The French are becoming more and more intolerant,'' said George Pau- Langevin. Mrs. Pau-Langevin, a lawyer from Guadeloupe, is vice president of the Movement Against Racism and for Friendship Between Peoples, an influential black rights groups here. She is married to a white Parisian. **********''The French can't accept the change in their population,'' she continued. ''The French thought the immigrants would work here, then go back to their countries. But they will never go back. They stay here because there is no work in their countries. For the first time in their history, the French are facing the problem of integrating blacks into their society, as well as the reality that France will never be the way it was.'' **********In a cafe in Barb es, a section heavily populated by Arabs and blacks, a man from Mauritania sat at a table. In his hand he grasped his Livret de Famille, a document proving his origin and that he is in France legally.   Blacks 'Live in Misery' **********''Before, France was great,'' he said. ''Now, it is not so great. The black Africans live in misery. Before, the French were glad to bring us here to work in their factories. They adopted their children. Now that we are grown, they have dropped us. **********''I have worked here 23 years and never been unemployed. But most of the men are out of work. Racism doesn't come from the old, but from the young who replace us with computers. My grandfather and father fought in the war for the French. But the young have forgotten that.'' **********Officials in the social services say their main concern is the welfare of all unemployed people, or those without housing, and they refuse to draw distinctions along racial lines. **********''We do not think of differences,'' said Jasna Romon, technical adviser to the Department of Immigration. ''There is, for example, no black quarter in Paris, like in the United States. The blacks, Arabs and Turks all mix together, and with the French. The only distinction we make is that if you are a French citizen, you can hold a state job. If you are not, you cannot.''  Two Black Populations **********There are principally two black populations in Paris: French Caribbean citizens, known as the Antillais, who come from Martinique, Guadeloupe and French Guiana; and Africans, who come primarily from Senegal, Mali and the Ivory Coast. **********The Antillais have more or less assimilated into French society. Some marry white French, and they hold a wide variety of jobs, including blue-collar and professional jobs and government positions. **********The first black to have his own program on French television, for example, is a young man from Guadeloupe named Sydney Duteil, who goes by his first name. One of the leading film makers here is Euzhan Palcy, a young woman from Martinique who recently won a Cesar, a French film award that is the equivalent of the Oscar. **********Among the best-known Africans in France is Leopold S. Senghor, the poet and former President of Senegal, who recently became the first black member of the French Academy.  Yannick Noah, the French tennis star, who was raised in Cameroon, became a national hero when he won the French Open last June.  He has since moved to New York. **********Although many black Africans in France are highly educated, most are unskilled, uneducated people from rural villages, officials here say. They often find themselves living in urban squalor. **********Although there is no defined black quarter in Paris, many of the unskilled blacks, or the unemployed, can be found in Barb es, in the 18th arrondissement, or in the 14th, the 11th, the 19th, the 20th. They live in projects in the suburbs. They live in the Ilot Chalon, the one-block-square area of slums behind the Gare de Lyons where 6,000 squatters, 4,000 of them illegal, do not pay rent and coexist with gangs and drug dealers. **********Often, they live in one of the country's 300 foyers, or male dormitories. Altogether 150,000 people live in the foyers. Of these, 20,000 are black, the rest Arab, Turkish, Yugoslav and poor French. **********Sonacotra, a semiprivate organization that builds the foyers, has photo albums with pictures of rooms that are bright, well furished and cheerful. ''You could call these pictures propaganda,'' an executive there said. **********Many of the foyers are ''terrible,'' said Luc Fauchoix, a sociologist who is the chief of research at the Mayor's office of St. Denis, north of Paris.   Some Find Little Racism **********Some black Africans who live here report that they have found little racism. **********''For educated black women holding good jobs, racism almost does not exist here,'' said Marie-Ange Sy. Miss Sy, a doctor of parapsychology from Senegal, was sitting at a banquette at Ruby's, the most popular new black club in Paris. ''Racism has become a social question, not a question of skin color.'' **********It is a feeling shared by many of the young blacks, who like the young Arabs are known as the ''second generation.'' **********''There is a growing unity among blacks from Africa and the Antilles,'' Sydney said as he taped a show for Radio 7. ''They are going to the same clubs. They like the same music. They are joined more together than the older people. Our spirits and our minds are more open. **********''A lot of immigrants work here and send money back to their countries. We, the new generation, don't believe in that. We are French and black. Our parents think we are confused and that we do not know who we are. But we do. We are not confused.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/16/busin.body_text: **********The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that shipments of its Personal Computer line this year would be triple the number produced in 1983. The company also said it planned to spend $500 million in 1984 to expand its production capacity and conduct further research and development on small computers. **********The statements, at an meeting for analysts held in Boca Raton, Fla., appeared to confirm industry estimates that shipments of the PC, the PCjr home computer and more advanced desktop models would total more than two million units this year. **********The size of the company's investment, analysts said, was further evidence that other manufacturers will have a difficult time mustering resources to compete with the computer giant in the desktop market. **********I.B.M. also said that, like the Tandy Corporation and Apple Computer Inc., it was now offering a credit card for direct purchases of its equipment. **********Donald Estridge, president of I.B.M.'s entry systems division, which manufactures the Personal Computer line, said the company was now able to produce one machine every 15 seconds during the workday. By the end of the year, he said, the company planned to more than double that pace. **********I.B.M. officials saild they continued to run behind demand on the PC and the PC-XT, but they said that supplies of the new PCjr home computer were in balance with demand, the first indication that it may not be selling as quickly as I.B.M.'s previous models did. **********But I.B.M.'s president, John F. Akers, warned analysts against what he called ''PC myopia.'' **********''The PC is still a relatively small but fast-growing part of I.B.M.,'' he said, adding that he expected the company's traditional large processors, storage devices and work stations ''to carry their fair share of I.B.M.'s growth.'' **********Profit margins this year, Mr. Akers said, would be ''consistent'' with the 22.9 percent margin in 1983. Part of the company's effort to expand margins, he said, was renewed attention to quality control. After a recent study of the cost of repairs on I.B.M. equipment, ''we were surprised and disturbed at what we saw,'' he said. **********I.B.M. officials at the session reconfirmed that the company was spending large sums to develop a ''local area network'' that would link a number of independent desktop computers in a network. But they stopped short of saying when the network would be introduced, despite widespread speculation that it would be available this year. **********Mr. Estridge deflected questions about a future desktop computer using the fast but scarce Intel 80286 microprocessor. A sophisticated version of the PC, expected sometime this year, is believed to be based on this chip. But, Mr. Estridge noted, ''it wouldn't make sense to build a new product based on parts you can't get.'' Some analysts believe I.B.M. may be preparing to make the microprocessor itself, under license from the Intel Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/21/busin.body_text: **********Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit rose to 10.77 percent in the week ended Wednesday, from 10.67 percent the week before, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday. **********Aggressive pricing by New York banks sparked the latest increase, according to The Monitor. Still the highest-paying market, New York banks paid 11.57 percent this week, up from 11.41 percent, on the six-month instruments and 10.07 percent, up from 10.05 percent, on the money market deposit accounts. **********''New York financials are fighting the biggest promotional rate war of any market in the country on six- month and one-year certificates,'' Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said. **********Fueling the rate war, he said, was a lot of rollover money on six-month and two-and-a-half-year accounts. **********New York's average yield on the six-month C.D. has gone up three quarters of a point in the last month. **********Meanwhile the national index on money market deposit accounts stayed flat at 9.40 percent, following a 20-week upward cycle. **********Yields on money market deposit accounts in other markets rose everywhere except Detroit. Los Angeles banks paid 9.05 percent, up from 9.04 percent; Chicago, 9.49 percent, up from 9.43 percent; Philadelphia, 9.33 percent, up from 9.30 percent, and Detroit 9.08 percent, down from 9.16 percent. **********In the six-month certificates, Los Angeles banks paid 10.95 percent, up from 10.78 percent; Chicago paid 10.57 percent, up from 10.56 percent; Philadelphia paid 10.47 percent, up from 10.35 percent, and Detroit trailed at 10.31 percent, up from 10.24 percent. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/04/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Solidarity Activist Is Reported Killed
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/04/world.body_text: **********Sources in the banned Solidarity trade union said over the weekend that that one of their underground activists in Lublin died in a hospital after he was attacked and beaten on the night of Oct. 19, the night that a pro- Solidarity priest, the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, was abducted more than 100 miles away and then killed. **********According to a report made available to reporters this weekend, the former Solidarity organizer who died as a result of a beating was Stanislaw Chac, 42 years old. **********A Roman Catholic priest has also said he was tortured and beaten in his parish near Lublin Oct. 19. The priest, the Rev. Eugeniusz Kosciolko, leader of a group that is trying to put up a chapel at the Maidanek concentration camp outside Lublin, said that he had been tortured and that he had complained to prosecutors about the attack. Union sources said another Lublin area priest was attacked a few weeks earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/21/busin.main_headline: JUDGE ISSUES WARRANT FOR J. DAVID'S FOUNDER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/21/busin.print_headline: JUDGE ISSUES WARRANT FOR J. DAVID'S FOUNDER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/21/busin.body_text: **********A judge issued a warrant today for the arrest of J. David Dominelli, a currency trader, who has apparently left the country saying he would retrieve and return to his clients up to $112 million invested in his now-bankrupt company. **********United States District Judge J. Lawrence Irving also ordered the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate death threats made against a lawyer and a witness involved in the case. **********''The court intends to take every possible step for the immediate arrest of Mr. Dominelli, wherever he is,'' Judge Irving said. **********The judge said a lawyer whose identity was being withheld had received a note saying he would be ''murdered.'' Judge Irving added that ''bizarre incidents have occurred'' at the lawyer's home. **********No Details of Threats **********Judge Irving gave no details of the threats against a witness, but Mr. Dominelli's wife, Antje Dominelli, said death threats against her and her children had prompted her decision not to appear in court today. **********Mrs. Dominelli's lawyer, Radmila Fulton, declined to comment when asked whether Mrs. Dominelli was the witness Judge Irving had mentioned. **********The judge said Thursday that he would issue the warrant if Mr. Dominelli were found in contempt of court for not cooperating with a bankruptcy trustee overseeing the liquidation of his J. David & Company investment concern. **********Mr. Dominelli was reported to be on the Caribbean island of Montserrat in defiance of a court order issued by Judge Irving prohibiting the 43-year- old former stockbroker from leaving California. Immigration officials on Montserrat say Mr. Dominelli has been on the island since last Saturday. **********Jailed for 10 Hours **********Mr. Dominelli was jailed for 10 hours on Feb. 25 for not cooperating with the bankruptcy trustee, Louis Metzger, in retrieving investors' money from overseas. He was released after he agreed to help Mr. Metzger track down the money and to cable five overseas banks to transfer funds to the trustee's account. **********Judge Irving declared J. David bankrupt last month and directed Mr. Metzger to liquidate the firm and its various affiliates and distribute the proceeds to investors and creditors. But so far, Mr. Metzger has said he has been able to recover only about $500,000. **********Mr. Dominelli, who promised an estimated 1,500 people 40 percent returns on their investments in the fluctuating international currency market, left farewell letters for several relatives, friends and associates. **********In the letters, Mr. Dominelli said he was going to the island to gather funds for his clients and creditors. He established a bank on Montserrat before the collapse of his investment enterprises.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/31/busin.main_headline: Rolling Stone Planning An Electronics Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/31/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Rolling Stone Planning An Electronics Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/31/busin.body_text: **********As with most youth-oriented magazines, especially those with a musical inclination, Rolling Stone's stereo and hi-fi advertising is a top category. **********So it is no surprise that the magazine should announce that it is scheduling a Rolling Stone Campus Electronics Expo that will visit 50 campuses during the coming school year. **********A participating company must sign up for a minimum of 15 shows, which will have a total cost of $22,500. All 50, thanks to a frequency discount, will come to only $65,000. **********Further discounts are obtainable to those advertisers who buy space in any two of four special supplements that Rolling Stone will be publishing during the year. Gary M. Reynolds Associates is setting up the shows.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/31/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission, continuing its bid to inject competition into the international communications field, moved today to force a reduction in the rates charged by the Communications Satellite Corporation, known as Comsat. **********It also proposed to allow any company to construct an international satellite earth station. **********In addition, the agency cleared away a regulatory roadblock to the introduction of a new international satellite service for business customers, and authorized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to begin a new overseas video-conferencing service. The new A.T.& T. service will initially be offered between New York and London, using circuits in an underseas cable.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/28/busin.body_text: **********The Broken Hill Proprietary Company, Australia's largest publicly traded company, said today that its net income more than doubled in the latest fiscal year, as its steel division returned to profitability.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/14/busin.body_text: **********Alexander's Inc., the 15-store New York retailer, said yesterday that negotiations on a merger with representatives of the Bass family interests and Interstate Properties had been discontinued. Discussions had been under way since July 30 on a proposed price of $27.75 a share, or a total of about $125 million. **********The merger talks, Wall Street executives said yesterday, may have foundered because of the problems of the Financial Corporation of America, Los Angeles, which reportedly was the financing source for the Bass investor group in the contemplated merger. **********American Savings and Loan, a subsidiary of Financial, has been an aggressive lender on real estate acquisitions, such as the Alexander's takeover would be with its extensive real estate holdings. A spokesman for American Savings and Loan, in Stockton, Calif., said that the company does not comment on any investment activity. **********The termination of the merger talks sent Alexander's common stock down $2.375 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $22.125, on volume of 159,600 shares. **********The Bass group holds about 13.5 percent of Alexander;s stock; Interstate, a real estate developer, has about 14 percent. **********The Bass group includes John Scully, a San Francisco investor and general partner of Texas Partners and San Francisco Partners II; Robert Bass, a member of the Bass family of Fort Worth, and Richard Rainwater of Bass Brothers Enterprises. **********While the Bass family interests have been involved in other corporate investments, the Wall Street sources said, they have maintained a borrowing relationship with Financial Corporation. When Financial fell on troubled times in recent weeks, Wall Street executives said that borrowing line tightened. **********But with Bass's resources, a new line of funds could be established, with the possibility that the Alexander's merger talks might be renewed, the Wall Street executives suggested. **********Robin Farkas, Alexander's chairman and chief executive, said in a telephone interview yesterday: ''Our business has been good and our organization has put initiatives in place which are already showing success. We had, however, put many things on hold pending the outcome of the merger discussions, but now we anticipate moving ahead.'' **********Comment could not be obtained yesterday from either the Bass family interests or Interstate Properties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/17/world.main_headline: South African Miners Said to Come to Blows
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/17/world.print_headline: South African Miners Said to Come to Blows
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/17/world.body_text: **********Violence broke out among black workers at a South African gold mines tonight after they met to discuss a last-minute offer in a pay dispute, a mining company spokesman said. **********A spokesman for Anglo American Corporation, which owns seven of the eight mines affected by the dispute, said one miner was taken to a hospital with a fractured skull after one of the meetings erupted in fighting and stone throwing. **********The general secretary for the black National Union of Mineworkers, Cyril Ramaphosa, said it was not certain if a planned strike, the first official stoppage by black gold mine workers in South Africa, would take place. **********The Chamber of Mines, representing the mine owners, offered the union improved vacation pay today. The union estimated the offer would mean a 2.3 percent increase across the board. **********The chamber has already put into effect a pay increase of about 14 percent, and the union has scaled down earlier demands for a 25 percent increase to 18 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/26/world.main_headline: Czechs Drown in Bid to Flee
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/26/world.print_headline: Czechs Drown in Bid to Flee
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/26/world.body_text: **********Yugoslav authorities have recovered the bodies of two Czechoslovaks who drowned in the Mur River when their family of five tried to swim to Austria, border officials said today. **********Two sisters, aged 15 and 3, reached Austria in the crossing attempt 10 days ago. The bodies of Vera Penka, 38, and her daughter Jaroslava were found, according to Austrian officials at Radkersburg. The father, Ivan Penka, is still missing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/26/busin.print_headline: LEVI TO CLOSE UNITS; SEES PROFIT DECLINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/26/busin.body_text: **********Levi Strauss & Company, citing inefficient plant use and higher fabric and advertising costs, announced plans today to close about 10 percent of its facilities and said its second- quarter profit would drop about 85 percent from a year ago. **********The giant apparel maker also forecast full-year earnings about 50 percent behind those of its last fiscal year. **********The news sent the common stock of Levi Strauss tumbling $4 a share, to $26.75, in late New York Stock Exchange trading. **********Robert D. Haas, the company's president and chief executive, said in a statement that Levi Strauss planned to close ''excess facilities representing about 10 percent of total square footage in the United States and Europe.'' Martin Krasney, the company's director of public relations, said it was not yet known how many employees would be laid off because of the cutback. **********In its second quarter a year ago, ended May 28, 1983, Levi Strauss earned $43.1 million, or $1.02 a share, on sales of $664.8 million. For its full fiscal year ended last Nov. 28, the company earned $194.5 million, or $4.61 a share, on sales of $2.73 billion. Levi Strauss reported fiscal first- quarter profit this year of $10.9 million on sales of $533.9 million. The company is expected to announce its latest quarterly results on June 18. **********The company said sales for both the fiscal second quarter and full year were expected to be about the same as in 1983, and operating results in the second half were expected to be better than those for the first half of the fiscal year 1984. **********''Things have not been going all that well,'' Dennis Ross, retail analyst at the investment firm of Montgomery Securities, said of Levi Strauss. ''Orders are not coming in the way they expected, and they're going to have to lower their sights.''
