https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/05/busin.body_text: **********WHENEVER a new career path develops, an association is sure to follow. The Association of Accounting Administrators, which was formed last January, now has 200 members, according to Clifford M. Brownstein, its executive director. He also heads Brownstein Associates, a public relations and marketing firm in Washington. **********''It is a wide-open field,'' he said yesterday, adding that more and more smaller accounting firms are seeking professional administrators. Law firms have been using administrators for some years, and architectural firms and medical groups have also begun using them. **********The Big Eight accounting firms were probably the first to use professional managers eight or ten years ago, according to John Thornton, national director of personnel and a partner of Coopers & Lybrand. **********His personnel duties can be measured in one way by the fact that in 1984 the firm hired 1,300 new college graduates with either accounting or computer science backgrounds. ''I think that we have had a longer history of hiring professional people in the personnel area than in some of the other areas of accounting firms,'' he said. **********''We have eight to ten professional personnel managers alone who have advanced to partnership rank,'' he said. The firm also has many other professional staff members who may or may not be accountants, he continued, such as the chief financial officer, the head of management information systems, marketing experts and training experts - all positions that might involve partnership rank or can lead to it. ''It's a very big business.'' he said. **********Mr. Brownstein says that the smaller firms hiring their first administrators have needs in two principal areas - financial management and marketing. **********For example, he said, some seek financial managers who can supervise the firm's billing to clients, its payrolls, its payment of rent and other office bills, investment of its working capital and the hiring of its secretaries. **********Often such firms supplement the financial manager by adding another type of manager to handle marketing, or they might use outside help. Some accounting firms tend to hire marketing experts first and then add an office manager to handle business operations. **********''Multiple administrators are found most often in firms that have multiple offices,'' Mr. Brownstein said. These might be middle-sized firms, which he defines as those with 20 to 150 accountants, as well as the large firms. **********He said he noticed that accounting firms were hiring away law firm administrators, probably because these managers have been in the field for 15 years or more. **********He said he has not yet noticed too many ''bright-eyed'' holders of master of business administration degrees in accounting firm management. ''Most firms are more interested in the job experience of their administrators than in whether they have M.B.A.'s,'' he said. **********J. Richard Hoffman, managing partner of a middle-sized firm - Hoffman, Raich, Fine & Company of Great Neck, L.I. (40 accountants plus 7 partners) - says that six months ago he hired the firm's first director of administration, John Duenges, who is paid about $40,000. **********''He has a good knowledge of accounting, a strong background in administration and a fair amount of computer experience,'' Mr. Hoffman said, explaining that Mr. Duenges, who is 40 years old and has a master of science degree in educational administration, had worked some years ago in back office operations at Price Waterhouse, one of the Big Eight accounting firms, and later served as a school administrator. **********''Late in 1985 we will add someone to handle marketing in-house,'' Mr. Hoffman said, contending that this would be more cost-effective than using outside help. Just as law firms can now advertise their services, so, too, have the taboos been lifted for accounting firms. **********That change is a break for the accounting firms, because competition has been growing. Mr. Hoffman said that middle-sized firms like his were getting ''a lot more competition from larger firms and their satellite offices looking to add incremental income.'' **********In addition, he said, sizable accounting firms are adding to their services what he calls ''projective- type thinking.'' He said that clients want, in addition to the usual auditing and tax compliance services, more advice on forecasting where their businesses might be headed.'' **********What is a good background for managing an accounting firm? Obviously, some knowledge of accounting helps, but it is not always required. What is essential is experience in administration and financial management, or in marketing, along with some computer knowledge. **********Good marketing skills are cherished by accounting firms, which require surveys of the needs of the community and businesses they serve. The firms are also interested in developing skills among the accountants for self-marketing, which might involve advising them what clubs and organizations to join to become known in a community; what type of speeches to make; what brochures the firm should publish to attract clients, or where the firm should place advertisements. **********The career path for such a manager might be to start with a small firm if he or she has little experience and then move to a larger one. At large firms, the manager can find salaries in six figures and the prestige of a partnership.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/10/busin.main_headline: ROLM CHIEF SAYS HE SOUGHT I.B.M. LINK
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/10/busin.print_headline: ROLM CHIEF SAYS HE SOUGHT I.B.M. LINK
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/10/busin.body_text: **********When the International Business Machines Corporation announced two weeks ago that it would acquire the Rolm Corporation for $1.25 billion, the move was widely regarded as a strategic coup for Big Blue. Frustrated by its efforts to influence the development of Rolm products after a yearlong joint development effort, the speculation went, I.B.M. had decided it had to make the Santa Clara, Calif., company an offer it could not refuse. **********But yesterday, M. Kenneth Oshman, the co-founder and chief executive of Rolm, said I.B.M. did not make the first move at all. Instead, he said, the takeover came at his initiative, after ''internal territorial battles'' between I.B.M. staff members and Rolm's own employees ''proved to be impediments to progress.'' **********In his first wide-ranging interview since the takeover, Mr. Oshman confirmed industry reports of serious tensions between the two companies. However, he warned against ''making a big deal out of the problems, or thinking that something was wrong.'' Instead, he said, the troubles arose because ''everyone winded up posturing a lot'' in a series of discussions about the features of new products the companies were developing. **********I.B.M. first invested in Rolm last year and before the takeover had built its stake to 23 percent. Rolm makes telephone-switching equipment for both voice and data transmissions. **********''Low-level people here were protecting me and Rolm's interests,'' said Mr. Oshman, who founded Rolm in 1969 with three other electrical engineers. ''Even lower-level people at I.B.M. were protecting Paul Rizzo,'' he added, referring to I.B.M.'s vice president and chief of development.  No Examples Given **********He declined to give examples of particular disputes. But he said most disagreements centered on the question of whether telecommunications products should be designed to meet I.B.M.'s strategic needs - especially in its growing competition with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company - or whether they should meet Rolm's. ''We found ourselves paying less attention to the market and more to what I.B.M. wanted Rolm to do and what Rolm wanted I.B.M. to do,'' he said. **********The problems proved insoluble. Rolm officials worked for six months to ease relations with I.B.M., he said, but found ''there was always something in the way of working together smoothly.'' He added, ''Finally, we decided the best way to work together was to become part of I.B.M.'' **********So about a month ago, Rolm suggested that the two companies discard an agreement they reached last year that limited I.B.M. to a 30 percent share in the company. Negotiations over the merger took place largely on the telephone, Mr. Oshman said, with he heading the talks at Rolm and Mr. Rizzo at I.B.M. ''We really didn't have any negotiating hang-ups,'' Mr. Oshman said. ''The main issue was price.'' **********A spokesman for I.B.M. said that only Mr. Rizzo, who was traveling and not available yesterday, could comment on the acquisition. The traditionally tight-lipped I.B.M. has said little about the deal, while executives at the more freewheeling Rolm have begun to speak more readily.  Uncertainty on Role Expresssed **********Industry insiders have questioned whether that openness, and the ability of Rolm executives to make decisions themselves, will survive. Yesterday Mr. Oshman said he had few doubts. ''We will make our own decisions right here,'' he said. He likened I.B.M.'s role to that of a board of directors, ''which tells you that you are spending too much money, or too little, or spending it in the wrong place; those are things that I.B.M. will have ulimate control over.'' **********While Mr. Oshman said that he fully expected to stay on as Rolm's chief for some time, he admitted to some uncertainty about the exact nature of his role. ''I am committed to Rolm, and I think I.B.M. is committed to keeping it an independent entity,'' he said. ''But I don't want to become an I.B.M. mid-level manager. And if I.B.M. wants me to do that, they will discover I'm not very good at it.'' **********I.B.M., he said, urged Rolm's top executives to sign agreements to stay on, but they declined. ''Those things don't work in anyone's favor,'' he said. ''They guarantee my salary, but not my happiness.'' **********According to Mr. Oshman, Mr. Rizzo also assured him ''that we won't have 10,000 I.B.M. folks'' descending on Rolm. He also said no Rolm employees had left because of the merger.  Antitrust Case Cited **********Mr. Oshman appeared to agree with industry experts that I.B.M. would not have purchased Rolm - or any other company in its field - while it was still fighting the Government's marathon antitrust suit. The suit was dropped by the Justice Department in 1982. ''I've never discussed it with them, but the last thing you want to do during an antitrust suit is merge with another company,'' he said. **********But Mr. Oshman insisted that the Rolm-I.B.M. merger posed no antitrust problems - a view most experts seem to support - and he disputed the contentions of some critics that I.B.M. was taking advantage of a favorable political climate to race into new businesses. **********''It's a company that is increasingly aware of competition from A.T.& T. and from the Japanese,'' he said. ''But there is an enormous amount of restraint within I.B.M., and they are not eager to get into an antitrust situation again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/09/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Philippine Court Orders Release of Journalist
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/09/world.body_text: **********The Philippine Supreme Court ordered the release today of a detained journalist who reported last year that the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was a high-level military conspiracy. A civilian panel said last month that it had found evidence of such a conpiracy. **********The court directed the immediate release of Rommel Corro, editor and publisher of The Philippine Times, a tabloid that reported in September 1983 that a soldier shot Mr. Aquino in a conspiracy involving three generals. **********Mr. Corro, 38 years old, has been held in a suburban military camp for over a year. He was charged with sedition by a Government prosecutor, and an application for bail was denied. **********An official inquiry into the killing of Mr. Aquino last August confirmed Mr. Corro's accusations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/06/world.main_headline: Laos Says It Has Closed Its Re-education Camps
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Laos Says It Has Closed Its Re-education Camps
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/06/world.body_text: **********An American professor said here today that he had been told in Laos that ''re-education camps'' set up after 1975 had been dismantled. **********MacAlister Brown, a visiting professor at Chulalongkorn University here, said he got the information from a Deputy Foreign Minister, Khampai Boupha, on a visit to Laos last month. **********A human rights report issued in 1983 by the State Department said that there were at least 20 camps in Laos in 1980, with a total of 15,000 inmates. **********Professor Brown said the camp closings had been confirmed by American aid officials in Laos. But he said that many people, though released from camps, might still be restricted to certain areas under a system of internal exile.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/29/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Egypt Says Soviet Link Won't Affect U.S. Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/29/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Kamal Hassan Ali said today that a decision to exchange ambassadors with Moscow would not affect ties with the United States and would not lead to greater Soviet influence here. **********His remarks, in an interview, were echoed by a commentary in the state- controlled weekly News of the Day. **********Mr. Ali noted that the United States remained the major provider of arms to President Hosni Mubarak's Government. Last year the United States supplied Egypt with $1.3 billion worth of military equipment. **********''I stress that the United States is our main supplier for weapons,'' Mr. Ali said. ''The exchange of ambassadors between Cairo and Moscow will not change this reality in our policy.'' **********Egypt and the Soviet Union announced this month that they would again exchange ambassadors. Anwar el-Sadat, the late President, withdrew his Ambassador to Moscow in 1978 after Soviet attacks on his policy toward Israel and expelled the Soviet Ambassador in 1981.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/20/world.main_headline: THREE CIVILIANS DIE AS MILITIA GROUPS BATTLE IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/20/world.print_headline: THREE CIVILIANS DIE AS MILITIA GROUPS BATTLE IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/20/world.body_text: **********Three civilians were killed and eight wounded in clashes today between two pro-Syrian Lebanese militia forces in northern Lebanon. **********The Beirut radio said the battles, with heavy and light weapons, broke out between the Arab Knights militia force of the Arab Democratic Party and militia forces of the National Syrian Social Party. **********At the United States base at the Beirut International Airport, meanwhile, a Marine guard fired at a civilian vehicle that ignored orders to halt at the entrance, but no one was wounded and the vehicle turned out to be on an authorized visit, a Marine spokesman said. **********The Marine guard fired a single shot at the vehicle, a Land-Rover, which was carrying a driver and a Lebanese technician who was sent to make a routine inspection of airport radar inside the Marine compound, the spokesman said. The bullet pierced a front fender. **********Guards Yelled Halt 6 Times **********''The vehicle drove through the gate at 15 m.p.h. and guards yelled halt six times before putting a single shot beside the radiator,'' a Marine spokesman said. **********The marines are authorized to shoot to kill when vehicles try to enter the base without stopping, the spokesman said. **********The Land-Rover was permitted to enter after a search. **********In Beirut, United States and French jets flew reconnaissance missions over the capital, the state-run Beirut radio said. **********In Israeli-occupied Sidon, a battle between Israeli troops and attacking gunmen forced shops in the city to shut down for the third day. **********The 30-minute gunfight delayed the funeral of a 14-year-old boy who Israeli security officials said was killed Wednesday after he attacked an Israeli vehicle.   Israelis Open Fire **********Israeli soldiers on rooftops opened fire today after an officer said his men had come under attack. Two armored personnel carriers and three jeeploads of troops then roared up, firing into the air. There were no reports of casualties. **********According to Israeli security officals, the youth killed Wednesday, Nazih Qubrosly, jumped in front of an Israeli jeep in broad daylight and fired a clip from a Kalashnikov rifle. **********Witnesses said he wounded an Israeli soldier before being gunned down. Israel has denied that a soldier was hit. **********Beirut was quiet today as most schools in the city were closed in tribute to the assassinated president of the American University, Malcolm H. Kerr, who was gunned down near his office Wednesday.   Islamic Holy War **********The 52-year-old Dr. Kerr, an American born in Lebanon, died after gunmen disguised as students fired two shots into his head. **********The group that calls itself Islamic Holy War claimed responsiblity for Dr. Kerr's killing and vowed to continue its attacks until all French and American nationals had left Lebanon.  Dr. Kerr was the latest victim in an upsurge of attacks on foreigners in Lebanon. He was the fifth civilian to be shot at or kidnapped this year. **********Raymond Henri Vauthier, 42, the chauffeur of the French Consul in Beirut, died today two weeks after being shot in the head by a gunman. **********A caller identifying himself as a representative of Islamic Holy War, which has claimed responsibility for all major attacks against the French and American contingents of the Beirut multinational force, said Wednesday that it was also holding the Saudi Arabian Consul, Hussein Farrash, who was kidnapped Tuesday. **********Foundation to Aid University **********In the aftermath of the assassination of the president of the American University of Beirut, the Charles A. Dana Foundation of New York has agreed to give $250,000 to help fulfill Dr. Kerr's aim of rebuilding the university and enhancing its educational programs. **********The decision to provide the grant was made yesterday by the foundation's board after members were told of the death of Dr. Kerr, said Robert N. Kreidler, president of the foundation. He said Dr. Kerr undertook last year to raise $23 million to improve the university. **********The 33-year-old foundation, which has more than $100 million in assets, is a significant contributor to activities in higher education and health but, until now, its grants have gone only to American institutions. **********He said board members agreed to make an exception at the suggestion of David J. Mahoney, chairman of the foundation's board. Mr. Kreidler said the board unaimously agreed to support the Beirut institution, which it regarded as ''an oasis in the turbulent Middle East where reason and learning must survive.'' **********Another Foundation director, Donald C. Platten, former chairman of the board of Chemical Bank, said he hoped the philanthropy's initiative would be ''infectious,'' and added: ''This is a particularly important time for people and institutions to step up to the danger of irrationality in the world.'' Mr.  Platten, who is a trustee of the American University, also is chairman of the Executive Committee of Chemical Bank which has been one of the University's supporters and approved a $150,000 grant for the coming three years. **********The fund-raising campaign initiated by Dr.  Kerr so far has obtained pledges of $18 million, according to Dr. Vahe Simonian, vice president in charge of development for the American University, which has an office at 380 Madison Avenue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/18/busin.body_text: **********The Western allies and Japan have reached agreement on ground rules restricting the sale to Soviet bloc countries of computers that could be used for military purposes, the State Department said today. **********A department deputy spokesman, Alan Romberg, called the agreement ''balanced and reasonable.'' **********Another official, who asked to remain anonymous, said the agreement, in part, reflected a European shift toward the long-held United States view that strict controls on larger computers are essential because of their potential for Soviet military use. At the same time, Soviet bloc countries will have easier access to smaller, mass-produced computers under the agreement. **********''We are enormously pleased about it,'' the official said, noting that many had thought that United States differences with allied countries on the computer issue were too great to be overcome. **********The agreement was reached last Thursday at a closed-door meeting of a Paris-based committee of 15 allied nations that attempts to coordinate the sale of high technology equipment to Eastern bloc countries. **********The guidelines, which still have to be formally adopted by member countries, replace regulations made 10 years ago. These are now considered outdated because of rapid developments in the computer industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/03/busin.body_text: **********A continuing surge of buying by many institutional accounts sent stock prices moderately higher yesterday in heavy trading. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, closed up 3.56 points, to 1,186.56. On Tuesday, the average soared more than 12 points in the heaviest trading in six weeks. **********Charles M. Lewis, vice president of Shearson/American Express, said that the market advanced yesterday because most investors believe that ''interest rates have about peaked despite the upward pressure on rates in recent sessions.'' **********He said the rise in rates this week was strictly technical and that they would soon move downward as the ''economy continues to cool off.'' **********In the general market yesterday, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored losers by 1,022 to 592. Volume was 107.1 million shares, down slightly from 110.6 million shares the day before. **********Reflecting the upswing, the exchange's composite index gained 0.22, to 93.09, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.22, to 161.90. **********Ronald B. Koenig, chairman of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, noted that the ability of the Dow average to bounce back over the 1,180 level on Tuesday and increase its gains today was ''technically significant.'' He added that the market's strength in the last two days might incite further gains. **********Eastman Kodak, actively traded yesterday, rose 3 points, to 64 1/2, after it reported first-quarter earnings that were higher than many analysts had expected and predicted ''strong earnings'' for the year. **********Jewel Companies advanced 2 3/4, to 50 1/2. The company disclosed on Tuesday that it was holding talks with another large retailer, American Stores, concerning a possible combination. American closed up 1 5/8, to 33 1/2. **********In the utility group, Central Maine Power advanced 1 3/8, to 10 3/8, after it said it had borrowed $40 million to help its cash flow. Public Service of New Hampshire was up 3/8, to 4 3/4, helped by the news that the owners of the troubled Seabrook nuclear plant had authorized transfer of control of the facility from the utility. **********Prices also moved mostly higher on the American Stock Exchange with the market-value index up 1.56, to 212.77. The Rockaway Corporation advanced 2 1/4, to 32, after its board declared a 2-for-1 stock split. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index advanced 2.75, to 253.01. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/17/world.main_headline: SOUTH AFRICAN FOE OF APARTHEID WINS THE 1984 NOBEL PEACE PRIZE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/17/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICAN FOE OF APARTHEID WINS THE 1984 NOBEL PEACE PRIZE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/17/world.body_text: **********The bells of the Chapel of the Good Shepherd at General Theological Seminary began ringing at 9:05 yesterday morning. In his room on the third floor, Bishop Desmond Tutu sat with his wife, Leah, and listened to them sound with joy over his Nobel Peace Prize. **********''I slept badly last night,'' said Bishop Tutu, general secretary of the South African Council of Churches and the leading spiritual voice of blacks in South Africa. He became a visiting professor in Anglican studies at the seminary at Ninth Avenue and 21st Street last month. **********''It was almost like waiting for exam results,'' he said, holding his wife's hand. ''It had happened twice before that people said I was a strong candidate, and the letdown then was very hard. **********''Inside, we really don't believe it.'' **********Early yesterday morning, before they had heard the news, Bishop Tutu and his wife were visited by Tom Eric Vraalsen, the chief Norwegian delegate to the United Nations, who carried a bouquet of bright yellow lillies, sky- blue irises and red zinnias. **********''It was already a giveaway,'' said Mrs. Tutu. ''I had a big lump in my throat and I thought my heart had stopped.'' **********His first thought, Bishop Tutu said, was to go to the chapel ''to thank God, for I am but his agent, and to share this award with the thousands of people that I am only a representative for.'' In the halls of the seminary, ministers, students and teachers were rushing to class when they heard the bells. They stopped, embraced each other and offered thanks, and many of them went to the chapel. **********When the Bishop walked through the wooden doors, his colleagues and the students rose, and hands that had been clasped in prayer began clapping with pride.   'Bells Were Our Sign' **********''There was great, great applause and there were many tears,'' the Rev. Robert Wright, a professor of church history, said. ''The bells were our sign, and when they rang out we all rushed to be with him.'' **********Hymns were sung and Bishop Tutu had a few private moments to read the 139th Psalm, his favorite, he said. **********''The Psalm says that I am nothing but the Lord's servant,'' the Bishop said, ''that I go where He leads me and where He needs me. 'If I ascend up into heaven, thou art there; if I make my bed in hell, behold, thou art there.' '' **********He then left the chapel to face the celebrity of his award. At a press conference in the seminary courtyard, with the rustling of the fall leaves underfoot and the gentle chirping of sparrows in the trees, Bishop Desmond charged the South African Government to realize that ''justice is going to win.'' **********''This award is a tremendous political statement,'' he said. ''It says that despite all distortions of truth, the world recognizes that we are striving for peace. It is a tremendous affirmation that our cause is just and our methods are praiseworthy.'' **********The award is not a personal one, Bishop Tutu said, adding: ''It is a corporate award. It belongs to all the black people of South Africa who have suffered, to all who have felt and lived with the evil of apartheid and are trying and striving for peace.'' **********Bishop Tutu spent the day giving interviews, taking every opportunity to shift the spotlight from his honor to his cause. He continually repeated his plea for nations to recognize and try to change the course of apartheid through political and economic pressure. 'Our Last Peaceful Chance' **********''What we have to say to those who invest in South Africa,'' he said, ''is that your investment is a moral as well as an economic issue.'' **********''This is our last peaceful chance,'' he said. ''My fears are the fears of so many that we could very well have a blood bath. It is for everyone to speak out - businessmen, bishops, everybody.'' **********He said he felt that there was no ''sense of contradiction'' in the joining of religion and politics. ''In a situation such as in South Africa, or in any question of morals, the church has to be political,'' he said. ''But not party political, only morally political.'' **********He said he was making plans to leave for South Africa to celebrate. He did not fear repurcussions in returning, he said, despite the fact that his passport has been revoked by South Africa and that he is using travel documents that list his homeland as ''undeterminable at present.'' **********He said he did not fear that South Africa would keep him from attending the award ceremony in Oslo. Last year's winner, Lech Walesa, the leader of Solidarity, decided not to attend the ceremony then for fear Poland would not let him return home. **********Apartheid and Communism ''are equal evils,'' Bishop Tutu said, ''but I do not think the South African Government will be too happy to have people draw that parallel by detaining me.''  For Scholarships and Family **********He said the prize money, about $190,000, would be put in a trust for scholarships ''to those who cannot afford education'' and, he said, ''maybe we will enjoy some of it as a family.'' **********The Bishop and his wife have three daughters and a son, and Mrs. Tutu said she spent much of the morning trying to track them down to share the news. Naomi, a student in Lexington, Ky., and Mpho, a student in Washington, were flying to New York to see their parents off to South Africa, where their third daughter, Thandi, and their son, Trevor, are awaiting them. **********After celebrating, Bishop Tutu said, he will return to finish his term at the seminary. **********In the middle of a hectic afternoon, Bishop and Mrs. Tutu took a few quiet moments to read the telegrams that started to arrive after the morning announcement. The greetings were piled on a living room table next to cards that celebrated both of their birthdays earlier this month. **********There were congratulations and blessings from colleagues at Union Theological Seminary on Morningside Heights, from Bishop John Walker of Washington and the Archbishop of Central Africa, Walter Makhuldu. Governor Cuomo wanted to come over to offer his personal congratulations, but Bishop Tutu said he was not sure there would be time. **********''It is quite overwhelming,'' he said. ''It is a very humbling and yet exhilarating experience.'' **********But to Mrs. Tutu, who said she has seen the pain in his eyes after time in jail and watched his frustration with injustice and his fear for the future, the reward was earned. **********''If I was to be on that committee, seeing who deserves it,'' she said, ''I would have to say he does.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/16/world.main_headline: 4 Held in Gaza Slaying Of a Palestinian Mayor
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/16/world.print_headline: 4 Held in Gaza Slaying Of a Palestinian Mayor
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/16/world.body_text: **********Four suspects were reported in custody today in connection with the assassination of the Mayor of a Palestinian city in the Israeli-occupied Gaza. **********The Israeli radio said the police detained 50 Palestinians overnight and quoted Yosef Zechariah, a deputy police commander in Gaza, as saying four were still being held. **********The report did not specify the nationality of the suspects or give further details. **********Abdul Karim el-Mansur Mahmoud Kishta, the Mayor of the city of Rafa on the border between Egypt and Gaza, was shot Friday as he walked home from evening prayers at a local mosque, the authorities said. **********The Voice of Arab Lebanon, a Sunni Moslem radio station, reported in Beirut that ''guerrillas killed him because he was a collaborator'' with the Israeli military government in Gaza. The Israeli radio quoted a similar statement from Damascus radio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/30/world.main_headline: U.S. STEPS UP USE OF SPYING PLANES IN SALVADOR WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/30/world.print_headline: U.S. STEPS UP USE OF SPYING PLANES IN SALVADOR WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/30/world.body_text: **********A Salvadoran Army commander said today that United States planes on reconnaissance missions were providing almost instant intelligence on guerrilla movements before and during combat operations. **********The commander, Lieut. Col. Domingo Monterrosa, whose area covers three eastern provinces where combat with insurgents has been heaviest in recent months, said in a telephone interview that he could not remember when the reconnaissance missions began. He said that in the last two and a half weeks their use had ''increased in a bigger way,'' in advance of the presidential elections last Sunday. **********Looking for Insurgents **********Colonel Monterrosa said the information from C-130 planes was generally relayed by radio to the high command in San Salvador, or could be sent directly to a United States adviser at the colonel's headquarters. **********Washington had announced an increase in the reconnaissance flights as the elections neared to look for insurgents who might try to disrupt the balloting. It has only now been disclosed that the planes have been giving operational intelligence directly to Salvadoran troops fighting insurgents on the ground.  The United States Ambassador, Thomas R. Pickering, said Monday that reconnaissance missions connected with the election campaign would continue at least through the runoff election, which is expected to be held in early May. The runoff is necessary because neither of the two leading candidates, Jose Napoleon Duarte and Roberto d'Aubuisson, got enough votes to win in the first round. **********'Part of the Scene' **********Mr. Pickering confirmed today in a visit to Washington to report on the elections that United States military spotters in aircraft were providing intelligence for Salvadoran Army troops. Responding to reporters' questions at the State Department, he said the action did not represent any expansion of the United States role in the Salvadoran conflict. **********''These kinds of things,'' he said, ''have been part of the scene in El Salvador for some time.'' **********He said United States advisers in El Salvador had come under hostile fire three times since September but said they had not fired back. **********He said there had been no change in the guidelines drawn up by the Reagan Administration to make sure that the presence of United States advisers in El Salvador does not violate the War Powers Act of 1973. The act requires the President to notify Congress when United States military personnel are engaged in hostilities. **********The guidelines, a United States Embassy spokesman in San Salvador said today, prohibit the advisers from working at a base that is likely to be overrun by guerrillas. The spokesman declined to comment on whether the use of United States planes during combat was a change of policy.   'A Step Up' **********One former United States adviser, who has returned to the United States, said in a telephone interview that, in his view, ''radio to radio'' contact between the air and ground represented a ''step up'' in 1984 in United States military support to El Salvador. **********Colonel Monterrosa, the Salvadoran commander, is based in the eastern town of San Miguel. He said the United States planes had frequently been used in reconnaissance missions in operations there and in the neighboring province of Morazan. He is also responsible for the province of La Union. **********He explained that, for operations in San Miguel, a United States adviser there would get in touch with the pilot of the C-130. ''We receive the information nearly instantly,'' he said. **********In an attack against the San Miguel base Sunday, a plane could be heard flying over the base just after the insurgents opened fire. Colonel Monterrosa said the plane was a C-130 that relayed information on guerrilla positions to the command in San Salvador and to the United States adviser in San Miguel. **********The colonel said the pilots of the planes flew high enough that a ground attack would be difficult. He said he did not know if the planes carried weapons, but said they had never given fire support. A United States military official said the planes were unarmed. **********''If you are in the air you can make sure you don't get into combat,'' the official said. ''But if you are on the ground you can get into actual combat.'' **********U.S. Ambassador's Comments **********WASHINGTON, March 29 - Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said today that information gathered by United States planes flying over El Salvador was ''shared with Salvadorans'' but he declined to discuss details of operations or intelligence activity. **********The Ambassador also confirmed three incidents in which American advisers came under hostile fire recently. Those incidents were made known only after Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, had heard of them and asked the Pentagon for a report. **********Plans for reconnaissance flights over El Salvador were announced on Feb. 8 by the Defense Department, which said Army tactical planes would be sent to Honduras. Privately, officials said the planes would fly over El Salvador to collect information. **********The officials also suggested the planes would gather information about shipments of arms believed to be going from Nicaragua to guerrillas in El Salvador, and about guerrilla movements inside El Salvador. It was implied that the information would be given to Salvadoran forces, but there was no indication then that operational intelligence would immediately be given to Salvadoran forces in the field.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/05/busin.body_text: **********Industrial companies reported sharp increases in production, inventories and new orders in February, the National Association of Purchasing Managers said yesterday in its monthly survey. **********But the 250 purchasing managers surveyed also said that prices were higher last month than at any time in the past three years. That may indicate that the economic expansion could renew inflation. **********The price increases cut across several industries: aluminum, steel, and most other metals; industrial fuels and home heating oils, and paper products. Integrated circuits and semiconductors continued to be in short supply, the survey found. **********Confidence on Economy **********The association reported confidence among its members that the economy would continue to improve. Responding to a special question, 66 percent surveyed said that they thought that the first quarter would be better than the fourth quarter of 1983; only 7 percent said it would be worse. **********''Our members definitely indicate strength in the economy after what seemed to be a slight slowing in the rate of expansion in January,'' said Charles T. Haffey, the vice president of corporate purchasing for Pfizer Inc. and the chairman of the association's survey group. **********The association's seasonally adjusted index, which combines its findings about new orders, production, employment, vendor deliveries and inventories, edged up to 61.5 percent from 61.1 percent in January. A reading of above 50 percent generally means that the economy is expanding, according to the association. **********The results are in accord with Government figures released last week about January's economic conditions. Factory orders rose 1.2 percent from December, and the index of leading indicators increased 1.1 percent. The Government will start issuing its February data this week. **********Gains in Jobs Level Off **********The association's report showed a leveling off of gains in employment, with 23 percent of the purchasing managers surveyed saying that their payrolls increased, down 1 percentage point from the January report. Sixty-seven percent said their payrolls remained the same, and 10 percent said they declined. **********Production picked up again after a lag in January, according to the report, with 41 percent reporting higher levels than in January. In January, 39 percent of those surveyed saw an improvement. Only 4 percent reported a decline in production levels. **********The percentage of purchasing managers reporting a rise in new orders jumped to 48 percent, from 41 percent in January. Inventories are also building, the survey indicated, with 25 percent saying their inventory levels had climbed, and only 12 percent reporting lower levels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/06/busin.main_headline: Business and the Law; Antitrust Scene Stirs Questions
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/06/busin.print_headline: Business and the Law; Antitrust Scene Stirs Questions
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/06/busin.body_text: **********FOR decades the main purpose of antitrust law **********has been to promote domestic competition **********and efficiency. In recent years, however, its function has become increasingly blurred as exports have become more important to the American economy and world competitive conditions have been buffeted by the rise of protectionism and the introduction of floating currency rates. **********As a result, business leaders, trade officials and legal authorities have begun to raise questions as to whether antitrust law needs to be updated. **********The issue took on new urgency last month when the Justice Department's antitrust division said it would block, on anticompetitive grounds, a proposed merger of the beleaguered steel industry's third- and fourth-largest corporations - the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation. **********J. Paul McGrath, an Assistant Attorney General who heads the antitrust division, explained the basis of the decision. He said the Justice Department, in calculating the total American market for steel products, had excluded imported steel from Japan and Europe. **********The decision was sharply criticized by the nation's special trade representative, Bill Brock, and the Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige. **********''A decade ago no other Cabinet officer would have dared to comment on this decision,'' said Harald B. Malmgren, an independent trade consultant in Washington. ''But it is fair play for other agencies to speak their minds, because they are involved. This is a policy question, not an abstract legal one.'' **********The Justice Department's ruling was doubly surprising in light of recent legislative and regulatory developments that appear to take the importance of global competition into account. **********After initially raising antitrust questions about the Export Trading Act of 1982, the Justice Department reluctantly allowed the legislation to pass without protest. A series of bills intended to ease the antitrust treatment of joint ventures in research and development are working their way through Congress. And the Federal Trade Commission has looked favorably on a joint venture in which the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation are to build small cars in California. **********Questions about the current relevance of antitrust law were recently expressed at the Conference Board's 23d annual meeting by Judge Richard A. Posner of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. **********At the meeting, where the anonymity of people taking part in panel discussions is assured, the participants acknowledged that fear of antitrust action had in the past prompted a number of distinctly anticompetitive, inefficient reactions by business. **********Vigorous enforcement of antitrust law, they contended, had adversely affected investment and research and development decisions. The participants added that this was also at least partly responsible for the conglomerate merger movement of the 1960's and early 1970's, a trend that took some companies in ill-conceived directions. **********At the same time, however, they acknowledged that the existing antitrust laws were broad enough in scope to allow more general concerns, such as international competitiveness, to be taken into account. But until recently, the conferees said, those sorts of concerns had not been adequately addressed. **********''The strategic issue of competitive advantage has become global in scale,'' one participant said, ''and the issue of competitive advantage is one that U.S. law has traditionally had a great deal of trouble with.'' **********Douglas E. Rosenthal, a partner at the Washington law firm of Sutherland, Asbill & Brennan and chief of the foreign commerce section in the Justice Department's antitrust division during the Carter Administration, does not think the antitrust laws need to be revised. But a broader interpretation would be useful, he suggested, particularly in merger cases. **********''We are still primarily concerned with promoting competition in our own domestic market and don't need any change in antitrust laws or enforcement to reach a result that is consistent with trade and diplomatic policy,'' he said. ''The problem is in the definition of relative geographic markets, and what has been missing up to now is law enforcement which allows for policy discretion.'' **********Mr. Malmgren agreed. **********''It is no longer relevant for regulatory authorities to measure domestic industry concentration ratios,'' he said. ''What is relevant is the world concentration ratio. It is clear that Justice has progressed in its thinking from a decade ago. But they haven't gone far enough. They haven't drawn the conclusion that, to address merger issues, they must take worldwide economic parameters into account and ask the President to decide.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/23/world.main_headline: Legislature Dissolved In South Indian State
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/23/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Legislature Dissolved In South Indian State
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/23/world.body_text: **********The Legislative Assembly in the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh was dissolved today, after completing less than two years of a scheduled five-year term, paving the way for a major popularity test for its ruler. **********A date for the balloting was not immediately set but the chief minister, N. T. Rama Rao, declared that he was seeking a fresh mandate. **********Andhra Pradesh will choose 42 members of the national Parliament in elections scheduled there Dec. 27 and there is speculation that local balloting to the 294-member state legislature will also be held that day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/17/world.main_headline: 117 BODIES FOUND IN LEBANESE VILLAGE RECAPTURED FROM CHRISTIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/17/world.print_headline: 117 BODIES FOUND IN LEBANESE VILLAGE RECAPTURED FROM CHRISTIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/17/world.body_text: **********The bodies of at least 117 civilians were counted today in a mountain village captured two days ago by Druse militiamen. Druse spokesmen said the civilians had been massacred there five months ago when the village was under Lebanese Christian control. **********The bodies, in various states of decomposition, were counted by reporters taken by Druse to the village of Kafr Matta, 10 miles southeast of Beirut. There were reports last fall that a massacre had occurred at Kafr Matta, and international relief agency sources who visited it then said they had seen at least 50 bodies in the street or hanging from balconies. **********Kafr Matta used to be a mixed Druse and Christian village. When the Shuf mountain fighting broke out last September between Christians and Druse, the Lebanese Army, which had been separating the two communities in the village, pulled out of town because it said the village was going to be a heavily contested battle ground and it did not want to be caught in the middle. **********Fadi Frem, a leader of the Christian Phalangist militia, said at the time that his forces ''carried out a military offensive to take control of Kafr Matta from the Druse, which they were successful in doing.'' But, he said at the time, ''no massacre took place there at all.''  Accusation of Massacre **********But a Druse leader, Khawla Arslan, accused the Lebanese Army and the Phalangists of killing Druse men, women and children in the town. **********It cannot be said at this point exactly who killed these people and under what conditions they died. **********Almost all of the bodies seen by the reporters today appeared to have been civilians who had been shot. **********Some of the bodies had been piled up in the rooms of houses, some were found lying in the middle of a field crumpled up in apparently the same spot they were shot and killed more than 5 months ago, while still others were resting in the middle of the street, frozen in death where they apparently had been trying to flee. **********Some of the bodies were just skeletons that had decayed during three months of winter rain, while others were still identifiable. The bodies included what appeared to be women, babies and men of various ages.   Searching Through Remains **********Druse militiamen from Kafr Matta and nearby villages sifted through the decomposed remains trying to identify missing friends and loved ones. **********''This is my aunt,'' one teen-age Druse gunman said, pointing to a body. ''And over here is my mother.'' **********Before it was recaptured by the Druse this week, Kafr Matta had been under the control of the Lebanese Army and Phalangist militiamen since the September fighting. **********Apparently, neither the Christian militiamen nor the soldiers, who lived near the bodies, tried to bury them. **********Reporters also found a death-bed note from Clark Todd, a Canadian free- lance journalist, who got caught up in the fighting in Kafr Matta and was shot and later died in a building there. On his blood-stained pillow case he scrawled, evidently just before he died, ''Please tell my family I love them.''  Report Denied Army Role **********The Lebanese Army commander, Gen. Ibrahim Tannous, had appointed a commission to investigate the massacre report last September and it concluded that there was no army involvement in any mass killing in the village. The Druse had described the report at the time as a ''whitewash.'' **********Meanwhile, the Phalangist militia said in a statement tonight that ''as many as 70 Christians'' may have been killed in the Ras Nabah neighborhood on the dividing line between Christian East Beirut and predominantly Moslem West Beirut. Once a purely Christian neighborhood, Ras Nabha is now heavily populated by Shiite Moslems. **********A Phalangist spokesman said his militia had been unable to establish the precise number of killed, but he said that friends and families had identified 30 bodies in a morgue at the American University Hospital in West Beirut. **********It was impossible this evening to substantiate the massacre report. Sporadic fighting was still going on around Ras Nabah between Shiite militiamen and the Phalangists in East Beirut.   Housewife Tells of Escape **********However, Nadia Kemp, a 52-year-old housewife, told reporters in a news conference arranged by the Phalangist militia of a harrowing escape from Moslem gunmen. **********Visibly shaken, Mrs. Kemp said gunmen came into her neighborhood on the night of Feb. 6 and burst into her apartment house. Her husband, she said, was in their apartment, while she was across the hall at a neighbor's. **********Gunmen knocked on her door, she said, calling out, among other things, ''Open the door, Christian dogs.'' **********She said she jumped out a window and after hiding for seven hours found her way to a Lebanese Army outpost. Her husband, however, Edwin Percy Kemp, 60, a British subject, was found by friends two days later lying on the street outside their home with 30 bullets in his body, Mrs. Kemp said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/29/world.body_text: **********Solomon Asea, the former personal physician of President Milton Obote and former Ugandan Ambassador to the United States, was shot dead in his home here on Sunday by unidentified gunmen, The Star, an independent newspaper, reported today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/busin.main_headline: 4 IN OPEC URGE CURB ON OUTPUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/busin.print_headline: 4 IN OPEC URGE CURB ON OUTPUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/busin.body_text: **********An advisory group for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries urged today that the 13-nation group fight off a predicted oil price drop by reining in production. **********The four-member committee that monitors OPEC's marketing operations met for two hours here at the organization's headquarters under tight security. It said it would present its recommendation to the regular summer conference of all 13 OPEC ministers on Tuesday. **********The members of the committee are the oil ministers of Algeria, Belkacem Nabi; United Arab Emirates, Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba; Venezuela, Arturo Hernandez Grisanti, and Indonesia, Subroto. **********The meeting occurs as two factors are straining OPEC unity - a worldwide oil glut and the war between Iran and Iraq, OPEC members. **********Several oil ministers sought to play down the threat of further declines in prices, but the Venezuelan representative acknowledged that OPEC is currently producing too much oil to assure price stability. **********Price Cut Was Unusual Step **********The oil ministers agreed 16 months ago to hold their production to 17.5 million barrels a day to stave off a price collapse. At the same time, they staged a tactical retreat, decreeing the first price cut in the organization's 24-year history, to $29 a barrel from $34. **********That strategy has worked fairly well, although cheating on production quotas by some member nations is threatening OPEC unity and exerting new downward pressure on the price. **********''That's the reason why the conference will insist on the need to have strict adherence to the production ceiling,'' Venezuela's oil minister, Mr. Hernandez, told reporters through an interpreter. **********Oil market observers estimate that OPEC is currently exceeding its self- imposed production ceiling by about 500,000 barrels a day. As a result, petroleum prices on the open market have dipped as much as $2 a barrel below the official OPEC price. **********Ministers' Diverse Views **********Sheik Otaiba, oil minister of the Emirates and chairman of the market monitoring committee, said OPEC would use ''all ways and means'' to defend its current pricing structure. **********Some ministers appeared to disagree, acknowledging that the financial problems of certain member countries and the stepped-up fighting between Iran and Iraq made Tuesday's meeting one of the more difficult since the present pricing system was adopted in March 1983. **********Indonesia's oil minister, Subroto, said in reference to recent attacks on oil tankers in the Persian Gulf that OPEC would try to ''steer clear of political problems.'' **********Iranian officials have said they would press for returning the base OPEC price to $34 a barrel, but analysts said the most likely outcome of the conference would be a decision to reaffirm the current price and production system.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/20/world.main_headline: U.S. WARNS LIBYA AGAINST ATTACKING AWACS OVER SUDAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/20/world.print_headline: U.S. WARNS LIBYA AGAINST ATTACKING AWACS OVER SUDAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/20/world.body_text: **********The United States told Libya today that there could be ''serious consequences'' if it interfered with the Awacs surveillance planes that have been sent to help deter Libyan air attacks on the Sudan, an Administration official said. **********The State Department and the Defense Department confirmed that two Awacs planes, along with tanker planes, had been sent to Egypt to join Egyptian fighters in patrolling Sudanese airspace. **********Last Friday, a TU-22 bomber, said by the United States to belong to the Libyan Air Force, dropped five bombs on Omdurman, the Sudan's second largest city, and then returned to a base in the Kufra oasis of Libya. **********The target of the attack apparently was the Omdurman radio station, but the bombs missed, and hit other buildings, killing five people. **********Libya Denies Responsibility **********Libya has denied responsibility for the attack. But Alan D. Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said today that ''we have good reason'' to believe Libya carried out the raid. **********''Following the unprovoked attack on the Sudan by a Libyan aircraft on March 16, the Egyptian and Sudanese Governments have requested our assistance to bolster the capability of Egyptian and Sudanese air defense systems by providing early warning of air attacks,'' Mr. Romberg said. **********''Awacs will be part of combined air defense operations being carried out by Egypt and the Sudan. The purpose of these operations is to deter sustained attacks by demonstrating that the three countries can rapidly put in place the assets necessary to deal with such aggression.'' **********Mr. Romberg said the note to Libya, in the absence of diplomatic relations, had been conveyed through Belgium, which represents American interests. **********Another official said the message was, ''Our planes are there and don't mess with them.'' **********''We told the Libyans that we are deploying our own military aircraft in the region and any action against them could have serious consequences,'' the official said. **********The Awacs have two missions: to serve as long-range reconnaissance planes and as command centers directing interceptor fighters against enemy targets. Because the Sudan has virtually no air defenses of its own, Egypt, which has a defense treaty with the Sudan, is responsible for flying interceptor planes in Sudanese airspace and for providing ground air defense, State Department officials said. **********If the Awacs were to come under attack from Libyan planes, it could lead to the involvement of American planes aboard carriers in the Mediterranean. In February 1983, when Awacs were sent to Egypt because the United States feared a Libyan attack on the Sudan, the carrier Nimitz was moved closer to Libyan waters.   Long-Term Aid Being Studied **********Mr. Romberg said the United States was also ''examining what longer-term assistance we could provide the Sudan in the air defense area.'' **********Another official said the Sudan needed radar and antiaircraft weapons, either missiles or guns. The Sudanese are to receive a squadron of American F-5's, but only two have been delivered so far. **********''They had some Soviet radar, but it is inoperative,'' one official said, ''because they have no spare parts.'' **********The Sudanese have been pressing the United States for weeks to speed up weapon deliveries to help them defend themselves against Libyan and Ethiopian help to insurgents in the southern Sudan. The Libyan bombing attack, Mr. Romberg said, has somewhat changed the situation because it made it important suddenly to send the Awacs to meet an immediate problem.   Concern Over Surprise Attack **********''There is no evidence of preparation for a massive attack,'' he said, ''but, as the attack of last Friday shows, there can be surprise attack and we are concerned about that sort of thing.'' **********American officials stressed, as they did last weekend, that the aid was aimed solely at external sources of trouble and was not meant to support the Government in Sudan's civil strife. **********The United States and other powers, the officials said, have urged the Sudanese Government to be conciliatory toward Christians and pagans in the south who have risen in arms the imposition of Moslem law was ordered throughout the country last fall. The rebellion also followed the division of the Sudan's Southern Region into three provinces, in contradiction to an accord that ended a civil war in 1972. **********The Libyan leader, Muammar al- Qaddafi, has long been accused of plotting against President Ghafar el-Nimeiry of the Sudan, and Colonel Qaddafi has made no secret of his hostility.   Speech by Qaddafi Quoted **********On March 2, Colonel Qaddafi said in a speech: **********''We tell the agents in the Sudan that we are allied with the popular revolution in the southern Sudan for the sake of liberating Sudan inch by inch, just as Lebanon was liberated. **********''The United States cannot save that mean man who is hiding in Khartoum. This is because, with the revolutionary forces in Ethiopia, in the Arab homeland, the revolution in Libya has decided to ally itself with the revolution in the southern Sudan. The peoples will march forward and will develop a people's war of liberation in Sudan, and tomorrow in Egypt and in every area that America seeks to dominate. **********''We must force America to fight on a hundred fronts all over the earth. We must force it to fight in Lebanon, to fight in Chad, to fight in the Sudan and to fight in El Salvador.'' **********Libya has been charged with sending arms to all those places, in support of insurgencies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/07/busin.main_headline: Broker's Holdings In Pep Boys, Park
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/07/busin.print_headline: Broker's Holdings In Pep Boys, Park
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Alvin Hoffman, an Oreland, Pa., broker with the Makefield Securities Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he holds 6 percent of the common shares outstanding of the Pep Boys-Manny, Moe and Jack. He also said, in a separate filing, that he holds 5.1 percent of the common shares outstanding of the Park Electrochemical Corporation. **********Mr. Hoffman said that he holds parts of both stakes in his own name as well as on behalf of clients and that the stakes are held for investment purposes. Pep Boys, based in Philadelphia, is a retailer. On the New York Stock Exchange today, it jumped $1.625, to $30.625. Park, with headquarters in Great Neck, L.I., makes electronic equipment. It closed at $28, down 37.5 cents, on the Big Board.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/18/world.main_headline: IRAN SAYS IT WILL RETALIATE IF EGYPT HARASSES ITS SHIPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/18/world.print_headline: IRAN SAYS IT WILL RETALIATE IF EGYPT HARASSES ITS SHIPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/18/world.body_text: **********Iran warned today that it would delay ships in the Persian Gulf if Egypt or its Western allies continued to stop and search Iranian ships in the Suez Canal. **********The warning was issued by Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, during a weekly Friday prayer meeting at Teheran University, according to reports from the Iranian capital by The Associated Press and Reuters. **********Hojatolislam Rafsanjani's remarks came as the Shreveport, an American ship carrying four minesweeping helicopters, began searching at Egypt's request for mines and underwater explosives in the southern part of the Gulf of Suez off Egypt's Red Sea coast. **********Hojatolislam Rafsanjani made his remarks two days after Egyptian officials disclosed that six Iranian ships and other vessels from ''suspect'' nations had been stopped and searched before they were permitted to cross the canal. **********17 Ships Reported Damaged **********The Iranian warning also came four days after President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt backed away from his earlier charge that Iran might have been responsible for laying mines in the Red Sea and Gulf of Suez. Earlier in the week, the Egyptian President said he suspected that both Libya and Iran might be involved. A few days later, Mr. Mubarak said that he viewed Libya as a key suspect. He added that he ''hoped'' that Iran was not involved. **********Underwater explosions in Red Sea waters have damaged at least 17 ships, according to Lloyd's of London, the insurance exchange. **********In his address today, Hojatolislam Rafsanjani repeated that Iran had not been involved in mining the Red Sea, nor did it wish to do so. But, he told a crowd estimated at 500,000, ''if our ship is delayed in the Suez Canal under the pretext of searching, and if our needed goods are delayed, one ship belonging to your gang will be delayed in the Strait of Hormuz in retaliation.'' **********''If you have the sensitive Suez Canal and we have to pass through it, we have the Strait of Hormuz and many have to go through there,'' the Hojatolislam said, according to a translation of his provided by Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency. **********Egyptian officials said this week that about 100 Iranian ships pass through the canal each year. **********The Hojatolislam's use of the term Egypt's ''gang'' was interpreted here as a reference to the United States, France and Britain, which are participating in the minesweeping operation at the request of Egypt and Saudi Arabia. **********The Strait of Hormuz, about 50 miles wide, links the Persian Gulf with the Gulf of Oman and the Arabian Sea. About 20 percent of the Western world's oil supplies pass through the strait.   U.S. Vows to Keep Strait Open **********Iran has repeatedly stated that it does not wish to close the strategic waterway but would retaliate if its own oil exports were blocked, or its major supply terminal at Kharg Island was attacked by Iraq. **********Since late March, Iraq has stepped up its air attacks on ships loading oil at Kharg and other Iranian oil terminals in an effort to force Iran to negotiate an end to the war, which began in September 1980. **********The United States has warned that it would not permit the Strait of Hormuz or other vital international waterways to be closed to commercial shipping. **********Because Hojatolislam Rafsanjani represents Iran's poltical and religious leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, on Iran's powerful Supreme Defense Council, his statements are closely followed by diplomats in Iran and the few Western reporters permitted to travel there. **********Ayatollah Khomeini denied last week that Iran was involved in the mining incidents, asserting that such acts were incompatible with the spirit and teachings of Islam. **********Hojatolislam Rafsanjani, in his remarks today, said retaliation was consistent with Islamic principles. ''We believe that our continued life and the evolution of our society depends on not forgetting this Islamic principle and not letting our enemies be in peace without it,'' he said.   Egypt Backs Iraq in War **********Egypt has supported Iraq in its war with Iran. But it has also tried to play a mediating role by promoting an initiative aimed at resolving the war through negotiation. Iran has repeatedly refused to negotiate an end to the protracted conflict until President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is removed from power. **********Egyptian officials could not be reached for comment tonight on Iran's warning. **********A Suez Canal Authority spokesman interviewed on Wednesday said Iranian ships were being stopped and searched automatically before entering the canal because Iran, like Libya, was on a list of ''suspect'' countries. But, the official added, inspection of the Iranian ships had revealed no irregularities. **********He did not suggest that any Iranian ship had been denied entry to the canal, or that any Iranian vessel had been significantly delayed because of the inspection. **********But the Hojatolislam's remarks appeared to imply that one of its ships had been detained or delayed. The Iranian Speaker did not elaborate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/22/busin.main_headline: CHRIS-CRAFT'S FEISTY CHAIRMAN-HE'S RELISHING THE INTENSE BATTLE OVER WARNER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/22/busin.print_headline: CHRIS-CRAFT'S FEISTY CHAIRMAN-HE'S RELISHING THE INTENSE BATTLE OVER WARNER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/22/busin.body_text: **********HERBERT JAY SIEGEL, the wheeling and dealing chairman of Chris-Craft Industries who is now exchanging blows with Australian mogul Rupert Murdoch in the battle over control of Warner Communications, tells a favorite story about his late father, Jacob Siegel. **********During the late 1940's, the elder Siegel was puzzled and frustrated by his only son's mediocre academic record at Lehigh University. The father had emigrated from Rumania as a teen-ager with less than $5 in his pocket, and had become a rich Philadelphia topcoat manufacturer known in his heyday as ''the king of overcoats.'' He lived austerely lest anyone think him wealthy. Jacob Siegel also esteemed education as only an unlettered man can. **********''He sat me down,'' recalls the younger Siegel, telling the story in his father's East European accent, ''and said, 'If a passing grade is 60, you get 60. Why?' **********''I wasn't interested,'' says Mr. Siegel, answering the old question in a wry voice. **********A photograph of the late Jacob Siegel, with formal black suit and stiff white collar, stands in a silver frame in his wood-paneled Madison Avenue office.  Though he revered his father, the two were very different. The sort of detail and long hours that made the father successful in topcoats didn't interest the son. Nor did academics. But during his college days, Herb Siegel found two consuming passions that would become life-long interests: An unsuccessful school-boy bid for part of the Philadelphia Eagles turned into a fascination with chasing deals. And life in the dazzling world of Ann Levy, his fiancee and the daughter of a founder of CBS, hooked him on the glamour of the entertainment industry. **********Now 55 years old, Mr. Siegel still gets a thrill from those two enduring passions. He loves buying companies, which are grouped in Chris-Craft, his holding company. But he avoids the tedium of running them. And he remains fascinated by show business. **********''Herb's not the kind of guy who's going to get grease under his nails,'' says J. Ira Harris, a former executive managing director of Salomon Brothers who was deeply involved in Mr. Siegel's negotiations with 20th Century-Fox. ''He's a phenomenal asset manager rather than a business manager.'' **********Mr. Siegel's latest move, a deal for 19 percent of Warner in exchange for 42.5 percent of Chris-Craft's television station subsidiary, combines those interests into one adventure. The deal appears intended to blunt Mr. Murdoch's quest for Warner because of limitations on foreign nationals owning television stations. But many on Wall Street are inclined to view the arrangement as a ploy to raise the price of Warner for any would-be acquirer. **********Such an outcome would leave Mr. Siegel in an excellent position to pocket a handsome profit on his Warner holdings. It would continue his shrewd pattern of bailing out with a windfall after becoming embroiled in takeover battles for such big companies as Piper Aircraft, Paramount Pictures and 20th Century-Fox. **********''He's not a killer, he's a game player,'' says David Brown, a movie producer and an old friend. **********Acknowleding this, Mr. Siegel says, ''The name of the game is who owns the tickets. If Mr. Murdoch wants to pay enough he's got it. I'm a major investor but I'm not looking to run Warner.'' **********The Australian's pride could make him a determined bidder. Mr. Murdoch says his News Corporation Ltd. cannot afford ''for people to think we are a patsy that can be run over.'' He owns over 7 percent of Warner now, having increased his stake last week, and has won permission from the Federal Trade Commission to raise the total to 49.9 percent. Mr. Siegel also moved last week, increasing his Warner share to over 20 percent. **********MR. Siegel's personal style reflects his taste for wheeling and dealing. His suits have custom- tailored flourishes like cuff buttons that actually button, but he doesn't seem to mind that the suits are often rumpled. Despite the rigors of the Warner battles he still finds time to dine leisurely at the 21 Club and Le Cirque, washing down his grilled fish with glasses of fresh grapefruit juice. The moments between his puffs on Carlton menthol cigarettes are often filled with laughter. **********He dislikes being alone and spends lots of time with performers and people connected with the entertainment business. **********''The most solitary thing I do is read a book, and even then I like to have my wife in the room,'' says Mr. Siegel, a Reagan conservative and multimillionaire who and received almost $1 million in compensation from Chris- Craft last year. ''I would be insulted if the towel boy at my gym didn't say I was a nice guy. I guess it's a desire to be loved.'' **********''He had a great ability to get along with people,'' says Jackie Gleason, who was a client of Mr. Siegel's when he operated a talent agency in the 1960's - one of his acquisitions that was later sold. But he uses that ability selectively. **********''He's got a reputation for being tough and a little nasty'' in difficult situations, according to Lee Isgur, a communications analyst at Paine Webber. **********When John DeLorean was arrested, Mr. Siegel accompanied Mrs. Christine DeLorean to California. Mr. DeLorean was on Chris-Craft's board and the Siegels were close friends of the Deloreans, who only weeks before had been hosts of a birthday party for Mr.  Siegel. But within days, all ties were broken by Mr. Siegel and there is now no contact at all. **********Mr. Siegel has earned a considerable fortune as a deal-maker and a conglomerateurr of small firms, which he groups as divisions of Chris-Craft,the former boatmaker that Mr. Siegel has transformed into a cash-rich chain of six independent television stations and a hodgepodge of small manufacturers of plastics and fiber products. His television stations comprise the nation's fourth-largest non-network television organization. **********Mr. Siegel started dabbling in acquisitions at Lehigh when he tried to buy 20 percent of the Philadelphia Eagles with $60,000 from his trust fund. But the deal fell through when his older partners said the price was too high. **********Also during college, the world of show business was spread before him through his wife, whom he met when they were both Lehigh students. Through his father-in-law's contacts in the entertainment business, he decided that he liked show business more than manufacturing overcoats. Frank Sinatra, a friend of his father-in-law, Isaac Levy, sang at his wedding, and he took his bride to California for a honeymoon spent working as a production assistant on The Lone Ranger television series. **********HE went to work as a theatrical agent, but soon tired of that and turned to business. One of his first acquisition was a sentimental deal in the 1950's for his father's overcoat factory, a business he quickly sold. Negotiating the financing with his father was sticky, Mr. Siegel remembers. ''He insisted I pay him with a certified check and would take no stock.'' **********During the mid-1950's, Herb Siegel bought and sold companies ranging from a car wax manufacturer to a soft-drink bottling operation whose wild cherry soda, he now says, lost its color after a few weeks on the shelf. **********''He does business like a superb poker player,'' says Sam Chon, the legendary talent agent for International Creative Management who is a close friend. ''He'll sit at the table and ante all night long until he gets the right hand.'' **********By 1958 he had become chairman of Seeburg, a jukebox maker. ''At 28, I was the youngest chairman of a company on the American Stock Exchange and my father came when I was elected,'' he says ruefully. ''He didn't say a word about being proud of me. Instead, he took me aside and said, 'Now, you've really got to watch out, be more conservative, be more careful.' '' **********Through more buying and selling, Mr. Siegel's base became the Baldwin- Montrose Chemical Company, and in 1965 he bid for Paramount. After a year of legal battles, Paramount merged with Gulf and Western, but Mr. Siegel pocketed a $2.5 million profit. In 1968, Baldwin-Montrose merged with Chris-Craft - then a troubled boat manufacturing company that looked like a good turnaround candidate, but proved not to be. The boat operation was sold in 1980. **********Mr. Siegel has suffered other setbacks as well. **********In 1969 he began an eight-year crusade to take over Piper Aircraft. Losing a bidding battle with the Bangor Punta Corporation, he sued Bangor and First Boston, its investment banker, charging securities violations. **********He won a $35.8 million judgment, only to have it taken away by the United States Supreme Court in 1977. The lawsuit cost over $2 million in legal fees and untold energy. Mr. Siegel finally sold his Piper stock for a profit of about $2 million, but the rest of his enterprises had been paralyzed for over eight years. **********That debacle was followed by his greatest coup to date after another battle - this time lasting three years. **********Beginning in early 1978, Mr. Siegel accumulated 23 percent of 20th Century-Fox. After yet another lawsuit, he sold his interest in 1981 for a profit of nearly $74 million, plus 19 percent ownership in United Television Inc. That share has now been increased to 50.1 percent and is part of the television subsidiary.  During the negotiations to sell, Mr. Siegel turned down an early offer from 20th Century-Fox that many of his friends urged him to accept. It would have given him a $40 million profit. **********CHRIS-CRAFT had profits of $6.1 million on revenues of $84 million in 1983, down more than 40 percent from the previous year because of unusually heavy expenses to cover employee stock options plans. **********The company's stock has gone from less than 50 cents a share in 1974 to recent highs of over $31 a share, propelled by the television subsidiary's ability to generate large amounts of cash (profits plus depreciation totaled $40 million last year). **********Chris-Craft is a decentralized company whose managers have great autonomy. ''If you do your job, you won't see me,'' says Mr. Siegel, who spends much of his day checking stock quotes on the Quotron monitor beside his desk in search of other prizes. **********''He's very meticulous and careful,'' says a very close friend. ''He reads Standard & Poor's like other people read Playboy.'' **********Last month he learned that an old friend, Steven J. Ross, chairman of Warner, was in for trouble from Mr. Murdoch, who had just announced his purchase of Warner shares. Mr. Siegel had long been interested in Warner, having tried to buy its movie studio in 1968. **********One late-December Sunday morning Mr. Siegel called Mr. Ross and went straight away to his apartment to discuss his proposal for Warner. ''It was a logical place for us,'' Mr. Siegel says. ''They make feature films and have a large film library. We have mostly independent television stations and the cost of programming is going up. We're hedging our position.'' Chris-Craft's stations now buy programming from Warner. A week after that first meeting, a deal was struck. **********Since December, the struggle has intensified.
