On Wednesday, the Federal Trade Commission approved Mr. Siegel's purchase of 19 percent of Warner, making him the largest stockholder - a position previously held by Mr. Murdoch. **********Mr. Murdoch's reaction to this bone in his throat has been to try to bite it in two. He has deluged the Federal Communications Commission with complaints, filed a lawsuit and threatened a proxy fight. He also successfully sought the Federal Trade Commission's approval to buy up to 49.9 percent of Warner's stock, setting the stage for what analysts say could be a buying war. **********On the day the Chris-Craft's purchase of Warner stock was approved, Mr. Murdoch's company denounced the deal and vowed to continue to fight it. Mr. Murdoch's pride could make the corporate wrangle a long and bitter one.  If Mr. Murdoch, or another bidder, should take control, Mr. Siegel would come away - as usual - with a handsome profit. His agreement with Warner includes an unusual provision that Warner will buy back its stock at a premium price if a third party should obtain 33 percent of the shares. **********''It was a brilliant deal for Siegel,'' said John S. Reidy, media analyst at Drexel Burnham. ''It underscores his opportunism.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/02/busin.body_text: **********Spending on new construction in the United States edged up just two- tenths of 1 percent in April, a much smaller gain than in the previous three months, the Commerce Department said today. **********The value of new construction during the month came to an annual rate of $302.5 billion, up $500 million from March. And if the total were adjusted to account for inflation, April's figures would have shown a decline of one- tenth of 1 percent, the report said. Spending had increased by 3.4 percent in March and 6 percent in February. **********The total construction figure for April was still 22.3 percent above the level a year ago, when the industry was climbing out of recession. **********Although spending on new homes rose 1.3 percent in April, spending for overall residential construction fell 1.1 percent because of a drop in additions and other alterations. **********Rising Rates Cited **********Spokesmen for home builders have said they expected that segment to continue to slow in coming months, largely because rising interest rates have made new houses too expensive for many Americans. The rising rates have also made commercial projects more expensive to finance. **********Robert Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist, agreed with the builders that ''residential construction has probably seen the better part of its recovery with interest rates having moved up.'' **********But he added that the increased rates would not necessarily bring about a decline in total spending on new construction. Some industries are now operating close to their production capacity, he said, so as operating levels continue to move up ''they will encourage some more investment'' in new plants and equipment. **********Office Construction **********He also said that work on new office buildings had continued to rise in recent months despite widespread talk that too many such projects had been started in comparison with the demand. **********In April, according to today's report, spending rose five-tenths of 1 percent, to an annual rate of $248.2 billion, for private construction, but declined 1.6 percent, to $54.3 billion, for public construction. **********Spending climbed 1.2 percent for private nonresidential buildings. The figure included a 7.6 percent decline for industrial construction but a 3.8 percent gain for office buildings. **********Spending on public housing, redevelopment projects and public water supply facilities went down, but rose for public hospitals and other buildings. **********All figures account for normal seasonal variations in building. **********Earlier this week, another Government report said that sales of new single-family houses dropped in April for the third time in four months. Housing starts rose strongly in April, but with completed houses selling relatively weakly, a trade group said builders expected to be starting work on fewer new ones.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/28/busin.body_text: **********The Kaiser Cement Corporation said today that it expected to report a loss of $50 million for the third quarter as a result of the write-off of its 36 percent interest in the China Cement Company, a Hong Kong concern. **********Kaiser also said that shareholders' equity would be reduced by $38.8 million after reversal of previously recognized foreign currency translation adjustments. **********In the 1983 third quarter, Kaiser lost $340,000 after an extraordinary gain of $565,000 on the sale of property. **********Kaiser said that although China Cement's plant had performed well since the start of operations in 1982, cement prices in Hong Kong had been inadequate to generate the cash required to service China Cement's debt obligations. China Cement has been holding discussions with lenders to restructure its bank debt, but no agreements have been reached, Kaiser said. **********It said China Cement had been hurt by widespread uncertainties about the political and economic future of Hong Kong, which have depressed the real estate market and the value of the Hong Kong dollar and restricted new construction activity. **********Kaiser said it believed that shareholders could best be served by the company concentrating more of its management and financial resources on domestic operations. **********Kaiser closed at $19.37 1/2, down 50 cents, in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/29/busin.body_text: **********Ameritech said its capital spending in 1985 was expected to reach $1.88 billion, up from $1.6 billion this year. William L. Weiss, Ameritech's chairman and chief executive officer, told securities analysts in New York that nearly half of the total was planned for the fiber optic and digital facilities. **********Ameritech is the parent of Bell operating companies serving Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin. **********He also said the company was establishing a cooperative agreement with the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan to evaluate the market potential of a system to transmit video signals over ordinary telephone lines worldwide. He added that an Ameritech unit had reached a tentative agreement to purchase a 20 percent interest in Cantel Inc. of Montreal. The joint effort would begin offering cellular radio service in Toronto and Montreal as early as next July, Mr. Weiss said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/23/busin.main_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; General Instrument Adds a Top Officer
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; General Instrument Adds a Top Officer
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/23/busin.body_text: **********The General Instrument Corporation announced yesterday that it had named C. M. Chang, a Texas Instruments executive for 25 years, to be president and chief operating officer. **********Mr. Chang, who is 52 years old, will report to Frank G. Hickey, chairman and chief executive of the New York- based company. **********General Instrument makes cable television electronics, wagering systems and semiconductor and electrical components, among other products. **********The company has not had a president or chief operating officer since Mr. Hickey, who had held the posts, was named chief executive in 1974 and chairman the following year. **********Mr. Chang said his hiring was a result of ''Mr. Hickey's desire to build a greater depth in management.'' **********Mr. Chang started at Texas Instruments in 1958. He has headed the company's semiconductor group and the consumer products group. From 1980 through late 1983, he was Texas Instruments' senior vice president in charge of quality, training and productivity. **********''A few months ago Mr. Hickey got hold of me through a management search firm,'' Mr. Chang said, ''and I startred discussions with him.'' Texas Instruments and General Instrument compete in some microelectronic sectors. Mr. Chang said such areas as General Instrument's wagering systems and cable television products would be relatively new to him. **********Mr. Chang was born in China, came to the United States in 1949 and is now a United States citizen. His full name is Chung Mou Chang, but he is known as Morris to his associates. **********Mr. Chang received bachelor's and master's degrees in mechanical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He worked for Sylvania before joining Texas Instruments. He was the recipient of Texas Instruments' first fellowship and earned his doctorate in electrical engineering at Stanford University.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/23/busin.body_text: **********For decades, the United Mine Workers of America and the National Bank of Washington have been a kind of odd couple. **********The U.M.W. owns National - indeed, is the only major American union to own a bank - under an arrangement that has brought benefits to both as well as a bitter lawsuit in which the union was found guilty of favoring its bank at the expense of its rank and file. **********Now, however, the relationship appears to be ending. Officials of National and the financially troubled union said today that preparations were under way to sell the bank, Washington's third largest. **********No Firm Buyer Yet **********Joseph Corcoran, the mine workers' press secretary, said he could not comment on reports of a planned sale. But another official who is informed about union financial studies - which have reportedly confirmed the wisdom, if not the necessity, of the sale - said that, while there was no firm buyer yet, the transaction could be concluded this summer, perhaps as soon as the end of July. **********The decision to sell the bank was said to be one result of a broad U.M.W. financial study by Goldman, Sachs & Company, the New York investment bankers, authorized earlier this year by the union executive board. Asked to confirm this report, Mr. Corcoran replied that the executive board authorization expressly forbade public comment on the union's financial plans. **********This secretiveness reflected the fact that any plan to sell the bank would be certain to arouse nostalgic sensitivities in the miners' union. The union made its purchase of 76 percent control of the bank in 1949, for $9.1 million, under the leadership of the late John L. Lewis, who for 40 years was the miners' autocratic president. **********Coal Company Investments **********In the 1950's and 1960's, the National Bank of Washington gave - and received - benefits through the unusual alliance. For a time, Mr. Lewis caused the bank to invest in coal companies, which thereupon promptly became union mines - but infrequently at a profit. **********More significantly, after Mr. Lewis won a pioneering, employer-financed U.M.W. health and welfare plan for the union in 1950, hundreds of millions of dollars paid in by the mine operators was kept by the union's bank in non-interest-bearing accounts, which enhanced the bank's profits at the expense of the plan's coal mining beneficiaries. **********This unorthodox practice - reaping profits for the union-owned bank by cheating the ill and needy among the membership - was not ended until it was exposed and ordered stopped by a Federal judge at the conclusion of a long breach of trust lawsuit in 1970. The suit, brought by rank-and-file unionists, recovered millions of dollars in interest proceeds never converted to benefits for miners and their widows. **********That lawsuit was a political debacle for the crumbling mine workers' regime of W. A. Boyle, Mr. Lewis's successor, who was later sentenced to life in prison for the murder of a dissident U.M.W. challenger, Joseph A. Yablonski. Over all, the bank has in recent years become a poor investment. **********In an interview, the annual dollar return to the union today was estimated by Luther H. Hodges Jr., a professional banker installed as the bank chairman through Federal intervention in 1980, as ''no more than 1 or 2 percent, about $1 million a year.'' With the same assets invested in Government securities, he said, the union could be earning $6 million to $8 million a year. **********According to the union's recently filed financial disclosure statement, required by law, the union owns a controlling majority of $48.6 million worth of National Bank of Washington stock, a figure that almost certainly understates its value. **********Mr. Hodges would not estimate the bank's value or a sale price. But he said the bank, which is limited by law to 22 branches within the District of Columbia, listed assets of $1.2 billion. **********The 1980 management convulsion that brought Mr. Hodges to the bank followed the disclosure of a series of failed multimillion-dollar loans made to friends of U.M.W. officials who also occupied bank directorships and other posts. One bad loan of $4.5 million was to a union officer's crony, the owner of a bankrupt race track. **********A succession of increasingly beleaguered U.M.W. chiefs since Mr. Lewis's retirement in 1960 have privately considered selling the bank. But the current president, Rich Trumka, a 34-year-old miner also trained as a lawyer, appears to be the first to feel secure enough politically to try to do so.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/17/busin.body_text: **********They are the consummate image- makers. From soap flakes to Presidential candidates, advertising agencies have sold it all, with ever-increasing sophistication. Yet until lately, Madison Avenue had an image problem on Wall Street. **********The stocks of the agencies were considered unreliable. Assets went up and down as accounts shifted from one shop to another, and employees came and went along with the accounts. Financial management had a reputation of being weak. **********Perhaps most important, most agency stocks were just too thinly traded. Sellers could not be sure of a buyer if they needed to get out fast. And most institutional buyers stayed out, leaving the stocks to individual investors. **********''Three or four years ago, many institutions would not buy ad stocks under any scenario,'' said one industry analyst, who asked not to be identified. ''Now there are few institutions that don't own them. It's been an education process.'' **********Shares Have Jumped **********Wall Street's ''education'' is a result of several factors, not the least of which is simple arithmetic: The eight biggest publicly held ad agencies rose 27 percent in composite value in 1983, outperforming the 30 stocks of the Dow Jones industrial average, which rose about 20 percent. The advertising sector did even better in 1982, rising 34 percent, compared with 20 percent for the Dow. **********Grey Advertising, the 13th-largest American agency in terms of revenues as of March 1983, was the best stock performer, rising 54 percent, while Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc. was the only loser of the eight public agencies in 1983, dropping 11 percent in the year, according to Adweek, a trade publication. **********Encouraged by the new attention, the publicly held companies issued a flurry of shares in 1983. Four concerns offered stock or debt issues in 1983, including a British agency, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, which began selling its American depositary shares in the United States for the first time. **********Last month, Ally & Gargano, the nation's 45th-largest ad agency, became the first United States agency to go public since 1973, with the sale of a million shares. Institutions purchased about 35 percent. **********''There's been a tremendous surge of interest in the last year and a half among institutions that prior to that would not look at an advertising stock,'' said Mary Vandeventer, an analyst at Widmann, Blee & Company, a concern in Narberth, Pa., that tracks the publicly held agency issues. Some of that interest, she added, was a result of stock performance, but more important was improved financial management. **********Financial Management Stressed **********''Up until about three years ago, a number of these companies did not emphasize financial management,'' Mrs. Vandeventer said. ''Some had real financial problems both before and after going public.'' New financial officers - all from other industries - were hired at several of the larger companies. Those changes ''made a significant impact on the analysts that follow these companies,'' Mrs. Vandeventer added. **********Other analysts said that with general elections and the Olympics being held this year in the United States - two events that usually generate substantial advertising - revenue at many agencies is expected to show healthy growth this year. **********Those expectations contributed to the sharp increase in trading last year. In the six months ended Aug. 31, for example, average trading volume of the Interpublic Group of Companies - the industry's largest agency holding company - was 197,000 shares, up more than three times from the 1982 period. **********Yet even with such growing acceptance, the Ally & Gargano issue was not an easy sale. Underwriters said the offering was reduced by 80,000 shares, and the price was cut from a planned range of $14 to $17, to $12 a share. **********''It could have sold faster,'' said Craig Sanger, a vice president in the syndication department at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., the lead underwriter. He said the shares had sold well in Memphis, where the Federal Express Company, a major client of Ally & Gargano, is based. There was also a greater proportion of buyers in the New York area. **********Low Capitalization Issues **********Alan J. Gottesman, a vice president at L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, said attitudes about the advertising business have been slow to change. ''There's a movement,'' he said, ''but it's coming with all due glacial speed.'' Mr. Gottesman believes the biggest problem facing the agencies is a low level of capitalization, that is, the price per share multiplied by the number of shares. The Interpublic Group of Companies, for example, has 5.34 million shares outstanding, selling at about $53 a share, for capitalization of about $283 million. **********Of the 15 largest agencies in the United States, measured by total revenues as of March 1983, 10 are publicly traded or owned by publicly traded companies. But the largest individual agency, Young & Rubicam, is private - and adamant about staying so. **********''We think there's an insuperable advantage in being private,'' said Mark Strook, a senior vice president and director of corporate relations. ''You don't have to worry about quarterly earnings, or stock price. You can take a long-term view.'' **********Although several analysts and spokesmen for competing agencies suggested that Y.& R. was a prime candidate to go public, Mr. Strook said the question was not under consideration. **********The advantages of going public are twofold, analysts say. First, it is often easier for a public agency to raise capital for expansion or acquisitions. Second, it takes pressure off the managers, who in many private agencies are expected to buy stock as they progress upward through the firm, and as older employees retire and sell out. At the same time, those older managers can usually make more money going public than selling shares within the firm. Of the one million shares sold by Ally & Gargano, for example, 857,500 were offered by officers and directors, led by the founders, Amil Gargano and Carl Ally, who sold 270,000 each. **********The disadvantages include closer public scrutiny of agency operations, including salaries and compensation, increased paperwork from regulatory filings and earnings reports and potential internal conflict. At BBDO, for example, the decision in 1972 to go public set off a scramble for shares inside the firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/03/busin.main_headline: GREAT WESTERN ADDS A BROKERAGE PRESIDENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/03/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; GREAT WESTERN ADDS A BROKERAGE PRESIDENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Glen E. McIlvaine, with 18 years of varied experience in securities trading, has been named president of a new discount stock and bond brokerage subsidiary wholly owned by the Great Western Financial Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif. **********Mr. McIlvaine, 43, is to head Great Western Brokerage, which was started in January in California and is part of continuing attempts by its parent to expand its financial services, company officials said. Great Western Financial, with $19.1 billion in assets, is the holding company for Great Western Savings, and also offers services in real estate, consumer finance, insurance underwriting and commercial leasing through 600 offices in the United States, 250 in California. **********The new president said he was hired last August to start the new subsidiary because of his broad background as a floor trader, retail broker, institutional broker and manager of a large trading operation. Although he was named president in January, the announcement was made yesterday. **********''It provides very exciting new challenges for this company and for me personally,'' Mr. McIlvaine said in a telephone interview. ''There are lots of discount brokers, but there are not many major financial institutions'' in the discount brokerage business. He said the new service would help Great Western Financial ''to compete in the changing financial arena'' by offering another convenience to customers. **********Born in Manhattan Beach, Calif., Mr. McIlvaine attended local junior colleges and started in the stock business as a retail broker in 1968 for Paine Webber in Los Angeles. He subsequently held jobs as a floor trader on the Pacific Stock Exchange for IDS Securities, as Weeden & Company's vice president for the Western United States and as an institutional securities broker for William O'Neil & Company. **********He said the new subsidiary was studying expansion into other states and into services such as tax-free investment trusts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/29/world.main_headline: CHAD REBEL GROUP DENOUNCES FRENCH MOVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/29/world.print_headline: CHAD REBEL GROUP DENOUNCES FRENCH MOVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/29/world.body_text: **********French helicopters today patrolled a new strip of territory in central Chad that France took under its control on Friday, and the Defense Ministry said the aircraft had encountered ''no hostile presence.'' **********The announcement came as France continued to reinforce its air strength in Chad. All leaves for French military personnel in the central African country were canceled. **********Tonight the Chad rebel group seeking to overthrow the Government of President Hissen Habre denounced France's latest action and said it had called on Libya to be prepapred to intervene on its side. **********A spokesman for the rebel group in Paris, Abderahman Moussa, accused France of ''choosing to throw oil on the fire in reinforcing its military apparatus and in crossing the red line that it created itself.'' **********On Friday, France ordered its troops to take control of an area extending an average of 60 miles north of the old ''red line'' that seperated Government from rebel territory. **********''France,'' Mr. Moussa said, ''should naturally expect an appropriate reaction on the part of Chadian patriots in struggle for their independence, following the example of the Algerian and Vietnamese people.'' **********According to Western intelligence estimates, Libya has about 3,000 troops in northern Chad, although Libya has denied having any forces there. Mr. Moussa's statement calling for Libyan aid appeared to be a threat of increased military action by both rebel and Libyan forces against Government and French troops. **********The French actions followed a raid into southern Chad last Wednesday by rebel forces that resulted in the downing of a French plane, killing a French pilot. **********Officials here said they had expected France to undertake some sort of reprisal for the attack, which France attributed to Libya. Libya is supporting the rebel forces led by former President Goukouni Oueddei. **********There was uncertainty here today whether the French move north presaged new fighting, or would be regarded by the French Government as an adequate response to the rebel raid. **********French officials said the situation on the ground has been complicated by violent sandstorms. Officials and diplomats here have also said the severity of any French reprisal would be weighed against France's desire to keep open the possibility of a negotiated settlement in Chad. **********One Western diplomat here said the French Government's decision to take control of the new strip of land, which stretches for 600 miles across Chad and varies in width from about 50 miles in the east to about 120 miles in the west, may, in the eyes of the French Government, prove to be a sufficient response. **********''It declares flatly to Libya: We've just taken so many hundred square kilometers from you,'' the diplomat said. ''That's the price you paid for this incursion.'' **********But whatever the political impact of the move, which essentially pushed French forces north to the 16th parallel from the 15th, the diplomat said, its original purpose may have been military. Le Monde reported today that France was particularly worried about a Libyan-supplied rebel buildup in the northwestern part of the new defensive zone. **********Exactly what form French control of the new northern zone will take is likely to depend, officials and diplomats here said, on what strategy France pursues with regard to Libya - whether it chooses to emphasize diplomatic or military steps - and on weather conditions. France sent troops to Chad last August because it feared that a victory by rebel and Libyan forces would presage a major increase in Libyan influence in sub-Saharan Africa. **********One official said the French may be reluctant to move a major share of its northern-most bases into the new zone, which is mostly desert. It may prefer instead, the official said, to go into the area in force only if it is penetrated by rebel forces.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/27/world.main_headline: WESTERN STUDY GROUP CALLS FOR LESS RELIANCE ON NUCLEAR DETERRENCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/27/world.print_headline: WESTERN STUDY GROUP CALLS FOR LESS RELIANCE ON NUCLEAR DETERRENCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/27/world.body_text: **********A group of Western public figures issued a report today that said that although nuclear deterrence had so far preserved the overall peace, it was essential to reduce Western reliance on nuclear weapons in Europe. **********While stopping short of advocating a policy of ''no first use'' - not being the first side to use nuclear weapons - the panel recommended that ''the Atlantic alliance move toward no early use of such weapons.'' It said that ''a consensus appears to be forming in support of this important objective.'' **********The report, called ''Managing East- West Conflict,'' was issued by the Aspen Institute International Group, a panel that included many former heads of government. It was set up by the larger Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies in 1983. The Aspen Institute describes itself as ''an international nonprofit organization,'' which has often brought together prominent citizens from many countries to discuss pressing issues. **********At a breakfast meeting with some reporters today, Robert S. McNamara, a Defense Secretary in the 1960's, who was one of the signers of the document, said he was heartened by some recent moves announced by Gen. Bernard D. Rodgers, the supreme NATO commander, to improve the alliance's conventional forces and to extend the period it would take in a clash with the Russians before the allies faced the choice of defeat or using nuclear weapons.   More Meetings Are Urged **********The report, written before the announcement last week that Secretary of State George P. Shultz would be meeting on Jan. 7-8 in Geneva with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, said that ''all thoughtful people are concerned over the state of East-West relations.'' **********''Hostility runs high,'' it said, ''contacts are sparse; rhetoric has clouded reality, and there are risks of dangerous misunderstandings. The fear of a military confrontation leading to nuclear war looms large in the popular mind.'' **********It recommended that there be more high-level meetings between East and West, including summit meetings. **********''Summit meetings are especially important,'' it said. ''If they are more frequent, unrealistic expectations will thereby be deflated.'' **********The report called for the start of negotiations between the Soviet Union and the United States on controlling antisatellite weapons and for resuming the suspended negotiations on reducing nuclear arms. These are the goals of the Shultz-Gromyko meeting. **********It also recommended that the United States propose to the Russians the creation of a new body to be called a strategic panel. **********''This body would initially be composed of a small number of high-level U.S. and Soviet representatives,'' it said.   What Panel Would Do **********The group would hold confidential, informal talks and ''would be charged with establishing a security dialogue, weaving together the many strands of arms control negotiations and defense policy decisions involving NATO and the Warsaw Pact,'' the report said. **********It said that, initially, the panel ''could explore ways of reducing the numbers of nuclear weapons in Europe, controlling technological innovation, improving verification and treaty compliance, and enhancing stability.'' **********''We believe the East-West arms control agenda is long,'' the report said, ''and time is short. There cannot be winners and losers in this search for viable arms control agreements, for no nation will sign or honor an agreement it believes to be harmful to its vital interests. Arms control is a mutual endeavor whose goal is enhanced mutual security. It is time to move forward.'' **********In defending the policy of mutual deterrence, the panel said that there currently exists ''a cautious stalemate'' between East and West. ''Each side's weapons insure that the other's are not used; each deters the other,'' it said. **********''Such deterrence, in our judgment, is neither immoral nor illogical,'' the report said. ''There have now been almost four decades of nuclear peace, in spite of serious East-West crises. But deterrence may not be eternal, and behind it there always yawns the atomic abyss.'' **********''Any policy which cannot withstand a single major failure, whether of a machine or a fallible human being, is understandably questioned by thoughtful people the world over,'' it said. ''Hence the search for positive alternatives to deterrence should continue, hand in hand, with attempts to strengthen and stabilize deterrence.''  'Star Wars' Plan Criticized **********Mr. McNamara and another signer of the report, George F. Kenan, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, were two of the four authors of an article published today by Foreign Affairs magazine that urges President Reagan to drop his plans to try to develop a foolproof defense against nuclear missiles, a program officially called , the Strategic Defense Initiative, but more commonly known as ''Star Wars.'' **********The article, also signed by McGeorge Bundy, White House national security adviser in the 1960's, and by Gerard C. Smith, head of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency under President Nixon, said that Mr. Reagan's initiative was ''a classic case of good intentions that will have bad results because they do not respect reality.'' **********In March 1983, Mr. Reagan called for intensive research to find a way to make nuclear weapons obsolete. It has been criticized by many experts as a waste of resources because they contend that no defensive system could succeed in blocking all offensive nuclear weapons. **********''What is certainly and fundamentally wrong with the President's objective is that it cannot be achieved,'' the authors said. **********The authors called on Mr. Reagan to reaffirm the American commitment to the existing treaty limiting defensive ballistic missiles and to seeking ways of limiting the size of each side's nuclear arsenals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/19/world.print_headline: 8 SLAIN IN SICILY; MAFIA ROLE SEEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/19/world.body_text: **********Eight people were shot dead in Palermo today in what the police believe was a settling of scores in a Mafia gang fight. **********The authorities said the incident was one of the largest mass slayings in Sicily's series of gang wars. **********''This night's episode was an act of barbarism,'' said Nello Martellucci, the Mayor of Palermo. **********The police said they believed that the killings took place at a stable at about 4 A.M. The bodies were found several hours later after the police were alerted by an anonymous telephone call. **********All of those killed were between the ages of 20 and 30. At least three had police records. The police suspect that all eight had connections with organized crime.   Higher Toll Suspected **********The authorities said that more than eight people might have been shot. When the police arrived, the father of one of those killed was trying to take away his son's body. The police made inquiries at hospitals to see if others might have escaped the shootings alive. **********Five bodies were found inside the stable and three were discovered outside. Witnesses said that the stables and the animals in them were covered with blood. **********The police set up roadblocks around the city and picked up dozens of people for questioning after they discovered the bodies in an area called ''The Courtyard of the Slaughterhouse.'' **********The stables are in a tough Palermo neighborhood that is said to be under the control of a Mafia group led by Filippo Marchese.   Cooperation by Crime Figure **********Mr. Marchese was reportedly identified by Tommaso Buscetta, the organized crime figure whose cooperation with the authorities led to the issuance of 366 arrest warrants at the end of last month, as one of the main leaders of the Mafia in Palermo. **********The Italian news agency ANSA quoted Giovanni Falcone, the magistrate leading the investigations spurred by Mr. Buscetta's confessions, as saying that the killings could not have taken place without the approval of the ''Commission'' that runs the Sicilian Mafia. **********The police theorized that the killings could be part of a settling of scores growing out of a horse-race betting racket. But they also said that the murders might be part of a broader gang dispute. **********At least three of those killed were members of the Quattrocchi family, and another was related to the family by marriage. The police were trying to determine whether the family had crime connections. The Quattrocchi family runs a horse meat shop in Palermo and, the police added, also supplies low-quality horses for use in probably illegal races.   Recent Battling by Gangs **********Fierce gang fighting broke out in Sicily from 1981 to 1983. The gang war is believed to have led to a victory of groups associated with the Greco family, and also an organized crime organization from the town of Corleone. **********The gang war was at least indirectly responsible for Mr. Buscetta's confession, since he was affiliated with groups that lost the struggle for control of Sicilian organized crime. Mr. Buscetta's testimony has implicated the victorious groups in a variety of criminal acts, including murders of public officials. **********The Marchese crime family is believed by authorities to have been split by the gang war, and the area under Mr. Marchese's control has been the scene of many killings. The police believe the neighborhood has suffered violence both from the general gang war, and from the division within the Marchese family.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/11/busin.body_text: **********The challenges that confronted the leaders of the seven nations at their 10th annual economic summit meeting here this weekend resembled to a remarkable degree those their predecessors faced at the first summit meeting held a decade ago in the Chateau de Rambouillet outside Paris. **********The industrial democracies are again trying to sustain an economic recovery that seems alarmingly vulnerable. A decade ago, the threats were renewed inflation and another oil price shock. Today, world recovery is menaced by high interest rates and the debt crisis in the third world. **********But both the nature of the leaders and the nature of these annual gatherings have changed. **********Those who gathered in the library at Rambouillet a decade ago - men such as President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain and President Gerald R. Ford with Henry A. Kissinger at his side - were all more internationalist in outlook, more experienced in macroeconomic affairs and more convinced that the governments could control their economic destiny.  Most of those at Lancaster House this weekend are ideologically opposed to government interference in the economy. And all of them appear more concerned with domestic issues than their predecessors did. **********The Original Purpose **********The summit meetings themselves have become bloated and bureaucratic. Originally conceived by President Giscard d'Estaing as a small, secret and informal meeting between the five top leaders, the roster has grown to include leaders of Canada, Italy and the European Economic Community. The agenda has become bigger and more political, while media attention has increased. **********The question is whether the summit meetings could or should do more to strengthen confidence that the economic recovery can be maintained. **********The record is not reassuring. Unemployment has increased every year since the first meeting at Rambouillet. And most of the agreements made at the meetings have failed the test of time. **********For example, the Franco-American pact on stabilizing exchange rates, which was the Rambouillet meeting's major achievement, did not stabilize exchange rates. **********The coordinated stimulation of the economies of the seven nations, pushed through by President Jimmy Carter at the London and Bonn meetings in 1977 and 1978, was undoubtedly the most ambitious proposal ever adopted at these meetings, with the United States trading unpopular energy-saving measures for stimulative fiscal action by West Germany and Japan. But the Bonn deal is now criticized by monetarist economists for edging the world toward hyper-inflation and recession. **********Overtaken by Events The joint energy savings negotiated at Tokyo in 1979 became irrelevant as the world economy was sent reeling by the second explosion in oil prices. **********The latest meetings, at Versailles, Williamsburg and London, have not saved the allies from quarrels over United States interest rates and trading with the Soviet bloc. Repeated pledges to resist protectionism have mostly been honored in the breach. **********But some argue that the world would be in an even worse mess without these annual face-to-face meetings. As David Watt, a former director of the Royal Institute of International Affairs, told a seminar last week, regular summit gatherings at least ''concentrate leaders' minds on things they would rather not think about.'' **********It is also true that the current economic recovery should make cooperation easier between the allies. From Rambouillet in 1975 to the Bonn decision to stimulate the economies in 1978, the dominant concern was to promote sustainable economic growth. As the Iranian revolution led to a second recession caused by escalating oil prices, the summit leaders found themselves forced onto the defensive, concentrating their attention on saving energy and fighting inflation. **********Original Concerns Resurface **********Now the situation has come full circle, with the need to sustain economic recovery being the major concern at Williamsburg last year and at London this weekend. **********Moreover, the governments clearly can do more about the threats to the present recovery, such as high interest rates and the third world debt, than they could about oil prices linked to Middle Eastern politics.  But the problem is how to persuade today's leaders to take advantage of that power. **********Last week, former British Foreign Secretary David Owen suggested a way. Broaden the meetings' agenda to include defense and security issues, he said. That would, according to Mr. Owen, increase the room for trade- offs in fields that interest today's leaders more than international economics. **********Europe, he argued, should offer to stimulate its economies by spending more on defense, allowing the United States to reduce military spending, cut its budget deficit and lower interest rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/29/world.main_headline: Turk Shot in Teheran; Armenians Claim Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/29/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Turk Shot in Teheran; Armenians Claim Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/29/world.body_text: **********A Turkish businessman was shot and critically wounded today in Teheran, Iran, and Armenian militants said they had carried out the attack, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said here. **********The attack took place shortly before the Turkish Prime Minister, Turgut Ozal, arrived in the Iranian capital on an official visit. **********The businessman, Isik Yonder, was hit by a bullet in the brain when gunmen fired on him and his wife, the spokesman said. He said the Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia claimed the attack. **********In a dispatch from Iran, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency quoted Mr. Ozal as telling reporters: ''We hope Iran will take all the necessary measures against these attacks.'' His talks here are expected to deal with trade and the Iran-Iraq war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/20/busin.main_headline: Citibank, Some Others Reduce Prime to 10 3/4%
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/20/busin.print_headline: Citibank, Some Others Reduce Prime to 10 3/4%
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/20/busin.body_text: **********Several more major banks yesterday cut their prime lending rates to 10 3/4 percent, as short-term interest rates continued to hold at lower levels. Other banks, however, refused to budge from their 11 1/4 percent prime rates, pending clearer indications that rates would stay down. **********Citibank, the nation's largest bank, cut its prime rate to 10 3/4 percent from 11 1/2 percent. Chase Manhattan, Wells Fargo Bank, First National Bank of Chicago, Security Pacific National Bank and Irving Trust were among the other leading banks cutting their prime rates yesterday from the prevailing 11 1/4 percent level. **********Despite sharp declines in short- term interest rates since Friday, banks have generally been slow to match the half-point cut in the prime rate initiated on Monday by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and followed a day later by the Bankers Trust Company. **********Frederick W. Deming, senior vice president and chief economist at Chemical Bank, which has not lowered its prime rate, said many banks were still waiting for a clearer signal as to whether the recent rate declines would be sustained or ''whether it's an aberration.'' **********''It's unclear as to why rates have moved so low so quickly,'' he said. ''It takes time to reach a conclusion as to what it all means, and some banks reach that conclusion at a different pace.'' **********Many economists, like Mr. Deming, have been surprised by the sharp drop in rate levels earlier this week, particularly by the plunge in the rate on Federal funds - overnight money that banks lend among themselves. **********While the drop fueled speculation that the Fed would cut its discount rate - the rate that Federal Reserve Banks charge on loans to financial institutions - many wondered whether the lower rates would hold. **********Leif Olsen, chief economist at Citibank, said the decline in rates since Friday ''doesn't seem to be an aberration.'' He added: ''It appears the Federal Reserve is easing, and it's reflected in the rate movements. Clearly, the cost of funds for banks have come down in the marketplace.'' **********He noted that the rates on 90-day certificates of deposit, an important factor in banks' cost of funds, have declined half of a percentage point since Friday. **********But, he said, ''I think we're beginning to get close to the end of the decline in rates.'' **********Mr. Olsen did not rule out the possibility of further reductions in the prime rate. And Mr. Deming said that if market interest rates remain low a few more days, or if the Federal Reserve cuts its discount rate, other banks would be likely to cut their primes to 10 3/4 percent or even lower. **********The prime rate is a benchmark rate against which rates on many business loans, especially to small and medium-sized companies, are set. At 10 3/4 percent, the prime rate is at its lowest level since August 1983.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/21/busin.body_text: **********During April's failed coup, a rebel spokesman charged the Government of President Paul Biya with having brought about the ''bleakest period'' in Cameroon's history. The Government, the spokesman charged, had participated in ''unmeasurable and unqualified graft.'' **********The charges fell flat. ''People here reacted by asking, 'What are they talking about?' '' a Western economist recalled. ''Everyone knows this is just about the healthiest economy in black Africa and that Paul Biya is Mr. Clean.'' **********In the 24 years since independence, Cameroon, which sits at the juncture of west and central Africa, has been one of the few countries in Africa that can claim even modest economic success. Analysts award the lion's share of that success to the policies of Mr. Biya's predecessor, Ahmadou Ahidjo, who governed for 22 years before stepping aside in 1982. **********Encouraged Agriculture **********Mr. Ahidjo, unlike many African heads of state, eschewed expensive, prestige projects. He exploited Cameroon's petroleum resources without allowing oil earnings to distort economic growth. He also encouraged agriculture. **********''You could always make a buck by growing food,'' one economist said. ''The farmers weren't sacrificed in favor of the urban population as they were in Nigeria and so many other countries.'' **********As a result, Cameroon today is virtually self-sufficient in food and the economy is growing at close to 7 percent a year, after adjusting for an annual inflation rate of between 15 percent and 20 percent. **********Mr. Ahidjo retired voluntarily, handing over power to his Prime Minister and longtime associate, Mr. Biya. As it turned out, though, Mr. Ahidjo was not prepared to relinquish full control, and before long a power struggle broke out. **********Sentenced in Abstentia **********By last summer, Mr. Ahidjo had been forced into exile in France and, early this year, a Cameroon court sentenced him, in absentia, to death for plotting against the Government. The sentence was later commuted to detention for an indefinite term. **********Then, on April 6, sections of the 1,500-man palace guard - which had been formed by Mr. Ahidjo - attempted to overthrow Mr. Biya. After three days of fighting, pro-Government units put down the resistance. **********Officials agree that conflicts over economic patronage was a major factor behind the coup attempt. **********During his tenure, Mr. Ahidjo, a Moslem from the north of the country, favored ''a clique of northern Moslems for power and money positions,'' according to officials here. **********Redistribution of Power **********Mr. Biya, on the other hand, is a Roman Catholic from the south who, according to European diplomats here, has attempted to break Mr. Ahidjo's power base and restore a more equitable regional and religious balance of economic power. He has also waged an energetic campaign against corruption. **********Both campaigns, however, have had an unsettling effect on the day-to- day running of the country. **********''What Biya has been trying to do is certainly laudable,'' a Western banker here said, ''but it has also caused a lot of trouble. Under Ahidjo, the system functioned, not more efficiently, but more smoothly.'' **********Now, businessmen and economists say, the system is in flux. **********''You've got customs officials who don't even know how to do business legal ways, who don't know what the tariff is or what forms to fill out,'' a banker said. ''You've got other officials who are afraid to so much as sign a piece of paper. You can't change everything overnight.'' **********The coup attempt and the tension and uncertainty it generated appear likely to hobble economic activity further, several business executives and economists say. ''Coup attempts, secret trials and executions just don't do much for investor confidence,'' one economist commented. **********Still, there is reason for optimism if the political problems do not worsen. Cameroon has a good balance of payments position, foreign debt is a low $2.3 billion and debt service takes only 12 percent of export earnings. **********In addition, oil production is expected to reach some 60 million barrels in 1984, with almost 80 percent going to the United States. **********''Basically, this country has a lot going for it,'' a Western economist said. ''And Biya seems to be on the right track: he's a liberal, he's against favoritism and in favor of individual initiative and he wants to clean up the economy. That's a breath of fresh air in Africa, but it's also deceptively difficult to accomplish.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/20/busin.body_text: **********A plan by Household International Inc. to issue ''poison pill'' warrants as a means of thwarting any takeover attempt has been challenged by one of the company's directors. **********Household, however, said it was not aware of any takeover attempts and was issuing the warrants as part of a strategy to preserve ''the long-term values'' of the company. **********The director, John A. Moran, who is also chairman and chief executive officer of the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation, a private New York investment company that holds roughly $130 million of Household's stock, filed suit in Chancery Court of the State of Delaware Friday seeking to void the ''poison pill'' warrants, which Household's board authorized on Aug. 14 and plans to issue shortly. **********So-called poison pill warrants would permit the issuer to, in effect, increase the number of the company's shares to the point that it would be extremely costly to a suitor to acquire a controlling position. **********Mr. Moran's complaint alleges that ''the proposed rights would add $6 billion to the cost of acquiring the company, which has a present market value on a fully diluted basis of about $1.75 billion. If such warrants or rights are issued, it would take a company the size of I.B.M. to make a 'raid' on Household.'' **********J. Richard Hull, Household's senior vice president and general counsel, said the company ''was not aware that anyone plans a takeover of our company, nor what Mr. Moran's plans are.'' He added, ''We will vigorously defend the plan to preserve the long-term values of our company.'' **********''Household management's only motive was to discourage the well- publicized techniques of raiders whose sole interest is short-term greed at the expense of target companies and their shareholders,'' Mr. Hull said. **********James. D. Pinkerton, Household's senior vice president, said in a telephone interview, that ''while our proposed new class of preferred stock was not intended to nor will it deter a takeover, it would tend to assure that any takeover attempt would be for cash and for all the common stock.'' **********He added that the proposed ''purchase rights'' would not carry any voting rights and ''thus the plan in no way affects the voting rights of Household's shareholders.'' **********But Mr. Moran's lawsuit charges that the proposed rights would allow Household's directors to ''control the destiny of the company'' and thus insure that management's interests would be placed above those of the stockholders. **********Household International is a conglomerate that includes Household Finance, a leading personal loan company; National Car Rental System; consumer products, including Thermos brand insulated containers, and several retail chains, including T G & Y and Von's supermarkets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/07/busin.body_text: **********Software Arts, based in Wellesley, Mass., said Visicorp had failed to use its best efforts to market Visicalc. **********The program, introduced in 1979, was the first spreadsheet for personal computers, allowing rows and columns of numbers to be manipulated easily. Software Arts said it would market Visicalc on its own. **********Visicorp, based in San Jose, Calif., said it would fight the move. ''We very clearly have the right to the Visicalc trademark and the right to market the product,'' said Daniel H. Fylstra, chairman of Visicorp. **********The companies have been at odds since last fall, when Visicorp claimed Software Arts had not lived up to its obligation to improve the program.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/29/busin.body_text: **********AGIS SALPUKAS **********WHEN Robert Lloyd Crandall, the president and chief operating officer of American Airlines, finished his recent speech to 350 New York-area employees and opened the floor to questions, one of the workers said, ''Mr. Crandall, we think you are a great president: When are you going to stop smoking? We want you to be around a long time'' - and the whole group applauded. **********Given that the man they were clapping for is the hard-driving boss who has slashed the salaries of newly hired pilots and flight attendants by up to 50 percent, cut 7,000 workers from the payroll, and who is so impatient that he has been known to call 4 A.M. staff meetings, there is something paradoxical about the warmth the American Airlines employees feel for their leader. **********For while most people think of Mr. Crandall as the man who attracted notoriety - and Justice Department antitrust charges - with an expletive-filled phone call suggesting that American and Braniff could make more money if they agreed to raise their fares, his employees instead see Mr. Crandall as the man who saved their jobs during a dangerous time for the industry, and they are grateful.  ''If he was not at the helm the company might not be where it is,'' said Josephine Weisdorfer, a passenger service agent whose pay was not slashed. **********Still, most of the employees who came to Mr. Crandall's annual ''Presidential Conference'' at the Marriott Hotel near La Guardia asked questions about how secure their jobs would be and whether the new workers hired at lower salaries were a threat to the security of more senior employees. **********There are plenty of other questions that could be raised about Mr. Crandall's ambitious plan to evolve into what he calls ''American Tomorrow'': the ideas are still untested, but American is gambling on the hope that it can be the first major trunk airline to position itself to compete on both costs and fares against the newer - and cheaper - non-union lines, such as People Express and New York Air, that are attracting an increasing share of air travelers. **********American is not the only airline convinced that its future profitability - and perhaps its survival - hinges on getting its costs down to the level of the new lines. In its current labor negotiations, United is seeking concessions similar to those that American has won. Eastern recently gave its employees 25 percent of the common stock in return for one-year wage concessions of 18 percent, while Continental resorted to bankruptcy to cut wages by up to 50 percent. **********What caused all this turmoil was a combination of deregulation, which nurtured the rise of the new airlines, and the recession, which cut travel and sparked ferocious fare wars that left serious financial scars on the established airlines, scars the recovery can only partly heal. **********American was the first of the major airlines to attack the problem head- on, with a four-year campaign to convince employees that in the long run, the way to save their jobs was to agree to the hiring of new employees at lower wages. Last March, after numerous meetings with employees, Mr. Crandall finally won the new contracts without much bitterness, largely because employees hired before the agreement were guaranteed their jobs for life, with no pay cuts or benefit reductions. **********''We've got to convert the way we relate to our people,'' said Mr. Crandall, who lives in Dallas with his wife and three children, and travels to all the major installations each spring to preach the company gospel and answer questions from 36,000 employees. ''We just cannot have confrontation. If the company is going to prosper and the people are going to prosper we need cooperation. Because when customers get on American Airlines, they have to feel that same sense of enthusiasm that they feel in one of the new entrant airlines.'' **********ALTHOUGH he is neither the **********chairman nor the chief executive of the airline, Mr. Crandall is the one responsible for operating decisions. American's chairman, Albert V. Casey, ex-president of the Times Mirror Company, had no airline experience when he came to American in 1974 to replace George A. Spater, who left after admitting that he had made an illegal $55,000 corporate contribution to the Nixon campaign. **********Both men came from the financial end of their previous companies, Mr. Casey said, so in some fundamental way, they spoke the same language: ''You know, cash flow, controllership,'' he said.  Shortly after arriving at American, Mr. Casey said, he and Mr. Crandall together interviewed top people from such companies as Colgate Palmolive and Gillette, and he was so impressed with Mr. Crandall's skills that he gave him the job - senior vice president, marketing. **********''Through the questioning,'' he recalled, ''I realized that Bob had a better understanding of marketing than those we were interviewing.'' **********Mr. Crandall has made major changes at American, in marketing and other areas. He set up the nation's first frequent-flyer program; supported the expansion of the computerized reservation system, Sabre, now dominant in the industry, and, between 1980 and 1983, cut the payroll to 35,000 workers from 42,000. He is also known for helping shut down Braniff for two years - Braniff began flying again only last month - by matching its fares. **********The 48-year-old airline executive who ''moved and moved and moved'' in his youth - attending 14 schools in 12 years - has moved around a good deal in his career, too. After his 1960 graduation from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, he worked for Eastman Kodak, then Hallmark Cards. In 1966 he joined Trans World Airlines, where he rose to vice president, data services, and later vice president and controller. He left T.W.A. in 1972 and, after a six- month detour to Bloomingdale's, came to American as senior vice president, finance. **********Those who have worked with Mr. Crandall, both at American and T.W.A., say his marketing and organizing skills may give American the lead in reorganizing for the new competition - if employee support for his programs stays strong. **********''He expects people to do what they are asked,'' said Richard Pearson, T.W.A.'s vice president, maintenance and engineering. ''In the process, he creates tremendous high morale and loyalty. We just didn't want anything to fail for him. He made us better than we were.'' **********But, they say, he is no pushover. He can be stern when a task in not going well and impatient with subordinates who do not perform up to his standards. **********While his colleagues say Mr. Crandall resorts to 4 A.M. meetings only rarely, ''there are a lot of 6 A.M. meetings,'' according to Thomas G. Plaskett, senior vice president-marketing. **********''He's extremely competitive,'' said Bob Malone, the president of the Allied Pilots Association, which represents American Pilots. ''It's his personality. He is very dogmatic in his approach. Once he has made a decision he's like a bear to get him to change.'' **********Robert J. Joedicke, the airline analyst for Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., who has known Mr. Crandall many years, describes him as ''a hard-nosed businessman. He's a no- nonsense man. He doesn't suffer any lack of professionalism around him.'' **********Unlike Mr. Malone, though, Mr. Joedicke says Mr. Crandall is more pragmatic than dogmatic: ''He knows what he wants to do but also knows what's possible. He's a realist.'' **********Sometimes, though, Mr. Crandall may want to do more than what's possible. That was certainly the image left by his Feb. 21, 1982, phone conversation with Howard D. Putnam, then chairman of Braniff International - the conversation that led the Justice Department to charge that Mr. Crandall was trying to fix prices and monopolize air routes.  In that call, which was tape recorded, Mr. Crandall told Mr. Putnam, ''I have a suggestion for you. Raise your goddamn fares 20 percent. I'll raise mine the next morning.'' When Mr. Putnam said, ''We can't talk about pricing,'' Mr. Crandall answered, ''Oh (expletive), Howard. We can talk about any goddamn thing we want to talk about.'' **********Although the Federal District Court in Dallas dismissed the charges, ruling that the conversation was just a ''solicitation,'' the Justice Department has gone to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in New Orleans to try to have the case reinstated. The incident is still a sore point with Mr. Crandall. He agreed to be interviewed on the condition that he not be questioned about the incident. **********Still, in the interview, Mr. Crandall, a medium-sized man with light- brown hair, admitted that some people think he pushes too hard. **********''It's not a matter of driving people so much as an impatience to define a problem and get a solution,'' he said. ''It's a matter of impatience. Let's get it done. It's a very fast-moving business.'' **********Mr. Crandall seems to have mastered that pace, though. In 1983 American Airlines had record earnings of $227.9 million, compared with a $19.6 million net loss in 1982, when the industry was deep in recession. **********American has also begun an ambitious expansion program with an order of 67 McDonnell Douglas Super 80 airplanes and an option to buy another 100 - one of the largest airplane purchases in history. The order, valued at $1.3 billion, calls for the delivery of 25 of the fuel-efficient two- crew aircraft in 1985, 25 more in 1986 and the final 17 in 1987. **********The airline plans major expansions in Chicago, where it will increase its gates at O'Hare International Airport to 29 from 16, and, by 1988, increase the number of daily departures to 272 from 154. Earlier this month, American announced plans to establish a new 25-gate hub in Denver. The airline will also increase its coast-to- coast flights, doubling its New York- Los Angeles flight to eight round trips a day. **********Mr. Crandall said that the airline has a great incentive to expand since new employees are hired at much lower salaries under the terms of last year's settlements with the Transport Workers Union, the Allied Pilots Association and the Association of Professional Flight Attendants. **********THE pay differences are dramatic. A Boeing 727 captain who **********was with American under the old contract, for example, earns $140.46 an hour, while a newly hired captain gets only $68.12 an hour. A flight attendant who worked under the old contract earns $31.16 an hour, while a newly hired flight attendant starts at $21.97 an hour. **********Being able to hire new employees at a much lower rate, Mr. Crandall said, gives American the ability to build a low-cost carrier within the shell of the old airline. **********''These new airplanes together with the labor contract allow us to go forward and create this pseudo new entrant,'' he explained, adding that the costs of the revamped airline he calls ''American Tomorrow'' should be fully competitive with other entrants. But unlike a brand new airline, he says, the ''new'' American has all the advantages of the old one - strong identity, computer reservation system, marketing resources and route structure.  Another feature Mr. Crandall considers a great asset, and one he helped develop, is American's emergence as a hub airline. American controls about 65 percent of the traffic at its hub at the Dallas/ Fort Worth International Airport - a much higher percentage than even the classic hub operation, Delta's 45 percent share of the flights out of Atlanta. **********While the hub strategy means fewer direct flights between small, non-hub cities, it also means that travelers who fly American into the hub are likely to use American on the outgoing flight, since so many connecting flights are available. **********''The hub-and-spoke strategy is one that says we must be able to offer a great deal of product,'' Mr. Crandall said. ''We can now carry you between several thousand city pairs.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/15/world.main_headline: MEXICO HAILS ITS MOST CIVIL SERVANTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/15/world.print_headline: MEXICO HAILS ITS MOST CIVIL SERVANTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/15/world.body_text: **********Mexico is trying to put an end to one of its national pastimes: grumbling about the Government and the services it provides. **********Several times a day, Mexican television viewers are being shown touching vignettes about their public servants at work and being told that ''if we want to be better, we must talk about the good things, too.'' **********In one advertisement, a postman approaches a house with a ''For Rent'' sign on the door. Dismayed at being unable to deliver his letter, he determinedly asks neighbor after neighbor where the former resident has gone, and finally tracks her down to a fruit stand in a marketplace. He hands her the envelope and she clutches it to her heart. Then, with a beatific smile, she reaches out and shakes the postman's hand in obvious appreciation. **********Given the speed of the mail here, many Mexicans tend to believe that this type of search goes on even for the recipients of letters that are correctly addressed. But that is not the point. **********''We're not trying to tell people that the postal service is great,'' said one Government official involved in the advertising campaign. ''We're trying to say that there are some public servants who do their jobs well, and they deserve some recognition.''  Showing the Good Things, Too **********Other public servants being recognized include teachers, firemen, doctors and nurses, telephone and electric workers, road workers and agricultural extension agents. **********The advertisements were prepared for the Government's Directorate of Radio, Television and Cinematography, a division of the Interior Ministry. The division's director, Jesus Hernandez Torres, said they purposely lacked the tone of ''triumphalism'' that characterized previous efforts by the Government to communicate with the people. **********''Look, you spend time backed up in traffic on the Periferico, you go to the supermarket and the price of food has gone up a little bit - this bothers people a lot,'' Mr. Hernandez said. ''But we're trying to show there are good things, too. You turn on the light switch and there's light. You pick up the phone and there's a dial tone. Despite the fact that we're in an economic crisis, everything is not bad.'' **********The people who designed the campaign decided, however, that to tell the people this head-on would probably have little effect. A person who can endure the wait and expense of being connected to the byzantine Mexico City telephone system, for example, quickly learns that one of the surest ways to meet a stranger is to dial the telephone number of a friend. **********Similarly, the Government's frequent exhortations that everything was fine as the country plunged into its 1982 fiscal crisis did little to heighten public confidence in its pronouncements.   Aiming for the Heart **********The campaign, therefore, has been designed to avoid the errors of the past by aiming for the heart, not the head. A document describing the strategy says that the advertisements should ''not communicate directly the virtues of Government institutions,'' should ''not underestimate the people's sensibilities'' and should not use ''grandiloquent or moralistic language.'' **********Instead, they carry emotional images - a fireman rescuing a little girl's puppies from a burning building, for example - as a voice says simply: ''Behind every service that functions in this country, there are capable and reponsible Mexicans. To appreciate their daily effort is to promote their excellence. A good way to achieve the quality of service that Mexico needs is to express our recognition of good work.'' (Apparently acquainted at a young age with the way Mexico traditionally has worked, the little girl offers the fireman one of her puppies; he declines.) **********Another set of advertisements is intended to imbue a ''feeling of hospitality and generosity'' among Mexicans, particularly in the often brusque and always overcrowded capital, according to Guillermo Heitler Aroeste, the head of evaluation and analysis for the directorate. **********In one such advertisement, a photographer who drops his equipment is helped in recovering it by a group of young boys. In another, neighbors get together and volunteer their efforts to rebuild a little store that has been damaged by fire. ''Every day,'' the hidden voice says, ''Mexicans demonstrate with actions that to act with nobility is something very much a part of us.''  Reactions Called Positive **********Other efforts planned by the unit will, according to the planning document, increase ''recognition of national heroes and demonstrate how with honest leaders supported by popular will, many of the grave crises in the country's history have been overcome.'' Another, using capsule biographies of historic Mexican figures, is intended to ''reinforce national identity and expand the knowledge of history among the population.'' **********The major goals of the Government advertisements are never expressed outright, however. According to the planning document, they are to ''provide a gradual increase in the citizen's confidence in the Government's institutions and men'' and to ''insure that the statements about the moral renovation of the society are translated into tangible and operative concepts.'' **********Under Mexican law, television stations must give 2.5 percent of their advertising time to the Government, and this is being used to run the commercials at least five times a day on each station. The same theme is being used in radio advertisements. **********According to Mr. Heitler of the Directorate of Radio, Television and Cinematography, the reactions in tests among average people were quite positive. ''People would look at the advertisements and say, 'That's happened to me,' or 'They're right, we have to recognize these things.' '' And even Mexicans with a bit more cynical edge seem to be affected by the advertisements. **********''Of course it's a lie,'' said one Mexican professional as he sat before the television the other night and watched the postman track down the young woman. ''But what a good commercial.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/06/world.main_headline: Taiwan Mine Explosion Kills 2 and Traps 93
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Taiwan Mine Explosion Kills 2 and Traps 93
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/06/world.body_text: **********A coal mine explosion near Taipei killed two miners today and trapped 93 others deep underground, the police said. It was the third major mine accident in Taiwan in six months. **********One miner scrambled to safety moments after the explosion at the Haishan Yikeng Mine, 16 miles south of Taipei. The 93 men are believed trapped in a tunnel 1.2 miles from the mine's entrance. **********Among those trapped were two mining officials who had been checking the mine. The cause of the blast was not known, but it was believed that methane gas, which exists naturally in coal areas, was responsible. **********After seven hours of digging, rescuers reached the two dead men 600 feet into the tunnel, the police said. **********In July 103 miners were killed when a fire swept through a mine near Taipei. In June 74 miners were killed in another mine explosion near Taipei.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/27/world.main_headline: TAX BRINGS LONG LINES IN ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/27/world.print_headline: TAX BRINGS LONG LINES IN ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/27/world.body_text: **********Long lines were reported today at Ben-Gurion International Airport because of confusion over a new 15 percent tax imposed on foreign currency purchased by Israeli citizens for use abroad. **********Starting at midnight tonight, a 15 percent tax will be charged on dollars purchased by Israelis traveling abroad, as well as on rented cars, land arrangements and package tours paid for by Israelis before leaving the country. **********These are among the new regulations announced by Finance Minister Yigal Cohen-Orgad after the inconclusive parliamentry elections Monday. **********The purchase of dollars by Israelis has been limited to $2,000 upon presentation of a flight ticket, with the sum of the purchase then being marked on the ticket. **********Under the new regulations, departing Israelis will be required to present a receipt proving the payment of the 15 percent tax on the sum of dollars stated in their tickets. Those who fail to do so will not be permitted to leave the country. Customs officials said they expcted the airport to be ''very busy'' with last-minute payments. **********The Director of Customs, Mordechai Bareket, met representatives of tourist agencies today to discuss their difficulties in collecting the tax from tourists who have already bought package-tour deals and have not left the country. **********A travel agent, Uri Shmuelof, said in an interview on the Israeli radio that he expected people to reconsider plans to take organized tours from Israel, since it might be cheaper to purchase services outside of the country now that the tax has been imposed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/02/busin.main_headline: STORES IN CITY, SUBURBS POST DECLINES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/02/busin.print_headline: STORES IN CITY, SUBURBS POST DECLINES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Sales by New York City's seven largest retailers slipped 1.5 percent in October from the same month a year ago, a spot check found yesterday. The decline, the first in two and a half years, followed three months of slow business. **********Combined sales at the retailers' stores in both the city and the metropolitan suburbs also dropped for the month, falling four-tenths of 1 percent from October 1983. The city's sales drop was the first since April 1982, when a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent was registered; the area's falloff was the first since a drop in January 1982 of 4.9 percent. **********Sales at national chain stores, reported yesterday, were generally moderate, although there were some sharp gains. The largest rise in New York, however, was only 3.2 percent and three of the big stores reported declines. **********Warm Weather a Factor **********Most merchants interviewed yesterday attributed the month's lag to unseasonally warm weather, which severely hampered sales of coats, and to generally lethargic consumers. Others cited consumer caution because of the Presidential election, although no such sales letdown was experienced in the city in the 1980 election period. Four years before that, however, sales were erratic during October. **********But most agreed that a major factor was a public that has come to expect ''sale'' prices on most merchandise because of the aggressive pricing strategy that retailers have recently been adopting. **********Retailers said that many items were now difficult to sell except at reduced prices because of this change in buyer psychology. **********Retailers participating in the spot- check are Abraham & Straus; B. Altman & Company; Bloomingdale's; Gimbel Brothers; Lord & Taylor; R. H. Macy & Company, and Saks Fifth Avenue. Monthly percentage changes are obtained on a non-attributable basis from each company's controller. **********The month's sales pattern was clear in the disappointing results of such normally popular merchandise as women's sportswear and consumer electronics. Sportswear, for example, had registered monthly gains of 10 percent to 15 percent through most of 1984 but in October was flat or only slightly ahead of 1983 levels. That appeared to be the case also with such consumer electronics as television sets and video cassette recorders. **********But what was particularly upsetting to retailers was that October started well, then progressively worsened. In the last two weeks, sales were down 5 percent to 10 percent at several stores.
