https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/05/busin.body_text: **********Ecuador has reached agreement with the steering committee of its private foreign creditors to refinance $353 million of public sector debt due to mature this year, the central bank said today. **********It said the new eight-year loan, with a grace period of four years, bears an interest rate of 1.5 percentage points over the prime rate in the United States and 1.75 points over the London interbank offered rate. Ecuador has a total foreign debt of $6.7 billion. It is still negotiating the rescheduling of the $270 million of private sector foreign debt due this year. It is also seeking to renew its one- year, $170 million standby loan from the International Monetary Fund, which expires in July.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/12/busin.body_text: **********Continental, First Interstate CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP) - **********The Continental Illinois Corporation has agreed to sell the **********last of its investment mortgage **********banking subsidiaries to First **********Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, the bank holding companies announced. Continental, parent of the **********Continental Illinois National **********Bank and Trust Company, said **********it had signed a letter of intent to **********sell its Republic Realty Mortgage Corporation to First Interstate. **********Republic employs 35 people, **********mostly in Chicago, and has offices in Atlanta, Milwaukee **********and St. Louis, Continental said. It said the subsidiary has **********more than $1 billion in mortgage loans for institutional investors nationwide. First Interstate said the unit **********would operate as a subsidiary of **********its First Interstate Mortgage **********Company subsidiary, which **********has offices throughout California and in Denver, Houston, **********Seattle and Raleigh, N.C. First Interstate said that **********with the acquisition of Republic, it would have $8.6 billion in **********accounts for more than 200 institutional investors.  Republic is the second Continental property to be sold to **********First Interstate. The company **********previously purchased Continental's London merchant **********bank, formerly known as Continental Illinois Ltd.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/19/world.body_text: **********The election committee barred a new party of Palestinian Arabs and Jews early today from taking part in the elections on July 23. The party, the Progressive List for Peace, was barred on the ground that it included subversive elements identified with Israel's enemies. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/02/busin.body_text: **********Britain's seasonally adjusted unemployment total rose to its highest level ever in May - 3,028,600, or 12.7 percent of the work force, the Employment Department announced today. Under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Government, unemployment is at its highest level since the 1930's Depression. But inflation has dropped from 21 percent in May 1980 to just over 5 percent this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/world.print_headline: 16 ISRAEL BOMBERS RAID LEBANON CITY; 100 DEAD, 400 HURT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/05/world.body_text: **********Sixteen Israeli fighter-bombers, flying in four- plane formations, struck targets in eastern Lebanon today, reportedly inflicting heavy casualties. **********The Beirut radio said the raids, flown for an hour in the area of Baalbek, 40 miles east-northeast of here, left nearly 100 dead and 400 wounded. The International Committee of the Red Cross said its casualty count had reached 40 dead and 360 wounded and was still incomplete. Most of the casualties, it said, were civilians. **********In Tel Aviv, the Israeli military command said the targets were two bases used by Iranian-supported Shiite guerrillas in operations against Israeli forces in southern Lebanon. The pilots reported accurate hits, the command said, and all planes returned safely. Shiite Building Destroyed **********A witness in Baalbek said the bombers had destroyed a former police barracks occupied by Iranian-backed Shiite Moslem guerrillas and several shops and buildings, and caused civilian casualties at a sheep market and in a Palestinian refugee camp. **********On Tuesday, four Israeli planes raided Bhamdun, 12 miles southeast of here, and the Israeli command said the targets were bases of Syrian-supported guerrillas. But the police in Bhamdun reported little damage. **********Today's attack in the Baalbek area, which is in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, was the ninth Israeli air strike in Lebanon since Nov. 4, when 29 Israeli soldiers and 32 Arabs were killed in the southern Lebanese port of Tyre by a truck-bombing attributed to Shiites. **********Israeli troops occupying the southern third of Lebanon have been almost daily targets of ambushes, rifle shots and bombs. Reports from Tel Aviv said the Israelis were preparing to thin out their forces, particularly in Tyre and Sidon, to reduce casualties. (The plan for Tyre was put into effect with the evacuation of administrative personnel from the Israeli headquarters there, The Associated Press reported.) Headquarters of Militant Group **********Baalbek, the area bombed today, is the headquarters of the militant Shiite Moslem group known as Islamic Amal. About 350 Iranian Revolutionary Guards have been operating there as well, reportedly helping to train Lebanese and foreign volunteers in terrorist tactics, especially the use of bombs. **********In an interview published in a Beirut magazine a few weeks ago, Hussain Mussawi, the leader of Islamic Amal, said 80 percent of the attacks in southern Lebanon were being carried out by his men. Shiite leaders vowed to retaliate for today's raids. **********According to the Beirut radio, the raids began at 8 A.M. with 16 jets swooping low over Baalbek to deliver their bombs. The town, which dates from Roman times, is seven miles from the Syrian border. **********Ramez Ismail, a Reuters reporter who lives in Baalbek, said the first group of planes seemed to be aiming at the former police barracks, on the edge of town, but missed. The second group, he said, destroyed the barracks ''and all nearby stores and buildings.'' **********He said the bombers also destroyed 30 houses and a mosque in the refugee camp and hit a school where classes had just begun. The Beirut radio said a former vocational school that had been taken over by Shiite militiamen was ''totally devastated.'' **********Mr. Ismail said the town fell quiet for about 10 minutes. But as men and women began dragging dead and wounded from the wrecked buildings, he said, the planes returned with more bombs, ''thus adding to the number of of those killed or wounded.'' **********''Clouds of smoke covered Baalbek,'' he said. ''Men and women ran to schools in search of their children.'' **********Mr. Ismail said that he saw ''lots of children'' in hospitals wounded, and that at least three had been killed. **********The police said three villages on the outskirts of Baalbek also suffered damage. They said many people were believed buried in the rubble. **********Mr. Ismail said the planes dropped balloons carrying devices intended to attract heat-seeking missiles. He did not mention antiaircraft fire. But the Syrian military command, which is in overall control of the area, said in Damascus that its air defenses ''confronted the enemy planes and forced them to flee southward.'' **********Roadblocks prevented Western journalists from approaching Baalbek. **********Sheik Mohammed Mehdi Shamseddin, the leader of Lebanon's one million Shiites, said the raids were an example of ''Israeli barbarism.'' **********''Israel is attacking innocent civilians, hospitals and houses of worship,'' he said. ''It is trying to terrorize the Lebanese people.'' **********The Beirut radio said the Lebanese Cabinet discussed the attack at a meeting that had been called to consider ways of getting the Israelis to observe the sanctity of mosques in southern Lebanon and also to stop blocking the Awali River bridge that gives access to the south, as they did last weekend. **********After the meeting, Prime Minister Shafiq al-Wazzan said in a statement that the ''loss of innocent lives and private and public property'' in the Israeli attack was ''a cause for pain.'' **********Plan to Thin Out Forces **********TEL AVIV, Jan. 4 - The Israeli military reportedly presented to Prime Minister Yitzak Shamir this week a plan to thin out forces in southern Lebanon, particularly in urban areas. **********A senior official said today that the plan was intended to reduce the targets the soldiers present to attacks. He said the redeployment would be limited to the coast and would not extend to the Bekaa, where Israeli forces face the Syrians. **********The informant said the plan, which had been approved by Defense Minister Moshe Arens and the Chief of Staff, Gen. Moshe Levy, would reduce the cost of the occupation, now $1 million a day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/27/busin.body_text: **********I N addition to startling, colorful **********graphics, the new print campaign **********for Alfa Romeo, the Italian sports car, has two other notable characteristics: its special attention to the car's handsome, oval logotype and the new word created to impart a positive connotation: Alfissimo! **********And the new word will never be seen without its exclamation point. **********''It means great to look at, tremendous to drive,'' explained Joseph E. Cooley Jr., director of sales and marketing, who had already been briefed by the word-coiners at his agency, Marsteller. **********And after spending an hour or so with him and his associates, listening to the quirks of the high-performance- imported-car-fan, one could come away believing that the word will be quite understandable to them. **********''This car gives you the drive that the others only promise,'' said David B. Brown, vice president, group management director, at Marsteller. **********''These people wear their cars,'' said Mary Nichols, ad director at Alfa Romeo North America, with headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. **********''It's an extension of their personality,'' added Mr. Cooley. **********At the moment there are two models, the GTV-6, a two-door sedan priced at about $19,000, and the Spider Veloce, a two-door convertible, priced at about $16,000.  ''There is a perception that the car is a lot more expensive than it is,'' said Mr. Brown. **********But at least there is a perception. The names of some high-priced foreign cars frequently invoke a blank stare, according to Mike Slosberg, executive vice president and creative director at the agency. Not so with Alfa Romeo, he said. And the same is true of its logotype, the circle with the name enclosing the cross and the serpent. **********In an effort to break through what Mr. Slosberg described as the clutter and mediocre sameness of advertising in the category, the logotype might show up in one ad on each blossom of a flowering bush, in another on the cape of a matador and in still another in a painting being done by a roadside artist who from the back is a ringer of Winston Churchill. **********And although 30 percent of the Spiders are being bought by females, the target audience for the Alfa Romeo campaign is males in the 25 to 54 age group making at least $40,000 a year. **********Those who are automotive buffs will see the ads, beginning in February issues, in the car buff publications. For greater reach, the ads will be also in Fortune and geographic or demographic editions of Business Week, Sports Illustrated and Newsweek. **********With image in mind, the agency is also putting the campaign in Town & Country, Smithsonian, The New Yorker, Gentlemen's Quarterly, Esquire and Fairchild's new M magazine. **********A fourth level will be a co-op program with the 106 dealers that will use city and regional magazines. **********Last year's media schedule contained 26 publications. That number was trimmed in order to obtain greater frequency against the target. While last year each publication got about three insertions, this year's plan calls for ads in every other issue, according to Mr. Cooley. **********The ad budget this year will be up a quarter of a million dollars from last year's, to $2.25 million. That may not sound like much when compared with the total amounts spent at Mr. Cooley's alma mater, General Motors, but as he pointed out, ''What we're spending on advertising per car is astronomical.'' **********The per-car amount ran $666 last year, when Alfa Romeo sold 3,002 units in the United States, putting it at the bottom of the high-performance European sports car category. **********''But,'' Mr. Cooley added, ''that's the price you have to pay to get back in the market.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/03/busin.body_text: **********Visicorp, which became a star in the personal computer software industry on the strength of its Visicalc spreadsheet program, has become the latest and largest example of the software industry shakeout. **********The company said yesterday that it is merging through an exchange of stock with the Paladin Software Corporation, a small start-up company that is headed by a former Visicorp product marketing manager. **********The new company will be called Paladin Software and headed by Paladin's current president and chief executive, Roy Folk, who worked for Visicorp until founding the new company a year ago. Most senior management will also be from Paladin. **********Daniel H. Fylstra, the chairman and chief executive of Visicorp, will become a director of the new company but will not have an operating position. Mr. Fylstra, who is 33 years old, said he had plans for a new business related to software and computer services ''but outside the mainstream of the personal computer software business.'' **********Visicorp, a private company based in San Jose, Calif., was founded in 1978 as Personal Software by Mr. Fylstra, a Harvard Business School graduate who started selling computer game programs from his apartment. **********In 1979, Mr. Fylstra's company started marketing Visicalc, a program developed by another company, Software Arts. Visicalc was the first spreadsheet program, allowing financial analysts and other office workers to easily manipulate rows and columns of numbers. **********Revenues Soared to $40 Million **********It was a huge success, helping to make personal computers popular in the office. Visicorp's revenues soared to more than $40 million in 1983, with 58 percent coming from Visicalc. **********But the company was never able to duplicate its first success and ran into a series of problems. Visicorp and Software Arts began feuding and neglected to improve Visicalc, which was surpassed by other spreadsheets. In September, to settle a lawsuit between the two companies, Visicorp gave the rights to market Visicalc to Software Arts. Meanwhile, Visicorp invested heavily in Visi-on, a new family of programs that failed in the market and was sold to the Control Data Corporation. **********Paladin, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has no products as yet, but is working on a family of office computer software products that it expects to introduce early next year, according to Richard Melmon, a Visicorp director who will become chairman of the board of the merged company. **********The company will also start selling some of the Visicorp programs, such as Flashcalc, a new spreadsheet program, and Visiword, a word processing program. It also retains the right to sell Visi-on through retailers. **********For Paladin, the merger provides a needed source of cash to help start its products. Although Visicorp was losing money, it recently raised several million dollars through the sale of Visi-on and a venture capital financing and is expected to sell another division to Control Data for about $5 million. **********For Visicorp, the merger is a chance for stockholders to recoup their investment, providing Paladin does well. Said Mr. Melmon: ''I think we have a damn good chance of bringing everything back.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/29/world.body_text: **********A Chinese official said today that Peking would reduce its nuclear arsenal if the United States and the Soviet Union agreed to do the same. He added that China wanted to resume its ties with the international peace movement. **********Li Yimang, head of the Chinese Association for International Understanding, said at a world peace forum here: **********''The small, limited number of nuclear weapons China has to keep at present is solely aimed at resisting nuclear blackmail and intimidation by the superpowers and at helping the struggle for the complete prohibition and thorough destruction of nuclear weapons.'' **********''Our country has long ago undertaken the unilateral commitment never to be the first to use nuclear weapons or to use them against nonnuclear states or nuclear-free zones,'' he added. **********China is believed to have a stockpile of several hundred nuclear weapons, and it is deploying an intercontinental ballistic missile with a range of 8,000 miles. **********Mr. Li said that the Chinese people supported Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang's recent vow to support ''any practical proposal for disarmament that is in keeping with the fundamental principle that the two superpowers take the lead by reducing their arsenals of nuclear and conventional weapons.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/07/busin.body_text: **********The Baldwin-United Corporation, which has been under pressure to generate cash to pay off its substantial debts, said yesterday that it would sell the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, its municipal bond insurance subsidiary, to Ambac's management. The purchase price was not disclosed. **********Ambac Indemnity is the largest insurer of municipal bonds in the United States. Baldwin-United filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws last September, reporting total debts of $1.6 billion. Much of that debt - $542 million - resulted from the purchase of the MGIC Investment Corporation in 1982. Baldwin is also seeking a buyer for MGIC and many of its other businesses. **********Baldwin's problems centered on its sales of popular single-premium deferred annuities. Proceeds from a portion of the sales were invested in other Baldwin businesses, tying up the funds and calling into question the security of the annuities. **********The management purchasers of Ambac include H. Russell Fraser, Ambac Indemnity's president, and some of his key senior managers, according to a spokesman for Ambac Indemnity. The management has already formed a new company, Ambac Inc., to take over the business. **********The spokesman said that $250 million for the purchase would be raised by selling equity interest in Ambac Inc. to investors. The money would also be used to invest more capital in the municipal bond insurer's capital base. Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company is assisting the management team in the structuring and financing of the acquisition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/31/busin.print_headline: YOUR MONEY; CHANGED RULES IN MARGIN DEBT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/31/busin.body_text: **********Buying on margin is a risky business that calls for stock market sophistication, the resources to absorb a substantial loss when the price of the securities declines and the temperament to handle debt. Nevertheless, margin debt by customers of New York Stock Exchange member firms amounts to more than $22 billion, indicating that this technique is widely used by many individuals. **********The rules governing what the regulatory authorities call securities credit transactions have been established by the Federal Reserve Board and promulgated in four regulations designated as G, T, U and X. In a move to update its rules and eliminate obsolete or unneeded provisions, the board has revised and simplified Regulation T, which deals with credit granted by brokers and dealers - the category affecting most individual investors. This shortened regulation will become effective on June 30. **********''This was part of a zero-based review to see what was necessary,'' said Robert S. Plotkin, the board's assistant director of banking supervision and regulation. ''The regulation was overhauled because it was very difficult to follow.'' **********''The basic thrust behind the revision was to clean up Reg T,'' added an official of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. ''It existed pretty much without change for many years and became encrusted. In the language of today, it wasn't a user-friendly document.'' **********Margin refers to money borrowed from a stockbroker, usually for investment purposes. The percentage of cash that must be deposited with a broker to open a margin account is set by the Federal Reserve and has been 50 percent for common stocks since 1974. Thus investors can buy $20,000 worth of stock for $10,000 in cash, borrowing the remainder from - and paying interest to - the broker by using the securities as collateral. **********The revised Regulation T contains a number of signficant changes affecting those who have such margin accounts. The most apparent are the changes in terminology to make the rule easier for the public to read and understand. For example, instead of describing maximum loan value - the most that can be borrowed on the security used as collateral - the new Regulation T talks about equity - the market value of the security minus the cash owed to the creditor. ''We've turned the glass around, saying that it is half-full, rather than half- empty,'' said the Federal Reserve's Mr. Plotkin. **********In addition, the new regulation for the first time covers such recently created financial instruments as options on stock indexes and options on certificates of deposit. Thus the definitions section includes option trading terms, which were not even mentioned when the rule was initially written. **********One of the important modifications of Regulation T is the provision that now lets an investor have more than one margin account at the same brokerage house, as long as all but the first are discretionary accounts controlled by the broker or an independent investment adviser. Previously, an individual could open only one such account at a firm, because of the fear that margin requirements might be manipulated. **********The regulation authorized other changes that are also in keeping with the modern ability of the computer to track efforts at deception by individuals or their brokers bent on avoiding the margin requirements. An introducing broker who deals with the public will be permitted to maintain separate margin accounts for the same person, if those accounts are cleared by different firms handling the back- office paperwork. Similarly, these clearing brokers will be able to maintain separate margin accounts for an individual who is introduced to them by different concerns. **********The effective date of the revision originally was last Nov. 21 and then was changed to today. The March 31 date has been postponed again for three months because of requests for delay by broker- dealers. The Fed adopted the revised regulation in May 1983. **********A related proposal by the Federal Reserve Board - but not included in the simplified Regulation T - would increase the number of marginable stocks. If adopted, the list of over-the-counter securities on which brokers and dealers could lend money to their customers will be broadened to encompass all of the securities designated for trading in the national market system portion of Nasdaq. The public comment period on this proposal is scheduled to end on April 27, after which the board will consider further action. **********To obtain a copy of the new Regulation T, get in touch with the local Federal Reserve Bank. In New York, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York is at 33 Liberty Street, New York, N.Y. 10045.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/05/busin.body_text: **********LAST year, a few months before the **********breakup of the Bell System, **********the American Telephone and Telegraph Company dispatched a cadre of white-collar soldiers to its warehouses to find out why shipments of small office switchboards were running far behind schedule. At one Manhattan warehouse, a group of crates that had sat ignored for no one knew how long turned out to contain 200 of the phone switchboards for which customers had been clamoring. **********The incident is still a celebrated story among A.T.& T. salesmen, especially those pressed by clients to meet promised delivery dates. ''Here's the largest company in the world, a company that's supposed to be so sophisticated and computerized, opening boxes to find out what it had in inventory,'' said one salesman, who had recently resigned. **********The story illustrates the type of problem that still plagues A.T.& T. today, seven months after it spun off its Bell operating companies. Its on- time delivery record, particularly in its old mainstay telephone business, remains poor. **********A.T.& T. is trying hard to become leaner and more efficient. But its staff, both in size and in orientation, remains a major stumbling block. The company's high- level decision makers are more oriented to manufacturing considerations than to speedy customer response. Its marketing and sales staff has had less than two years to develop the skills needed to succeed in an unregulated environment. And its overall labor costs are among the highest in the telecommunications industry. **********A.T.& T is saddled with a cost of $61 an hour to install and maintain products and equipment, compared with $33 an hour for the International Business Machines Corporation and $28 for MCI. Communications, according to the Eastern Management Group of Parsippany, N.J. Analysts say that the huge company could cut more than 10 percent, or 40,000 employees, from its staff of 373,300 people before hitting muscle. **********Although layoffs and firings have in the past been tantamount to culture shock at A.T.& T., which has always prided itself on the job security it offered, the company is beginning to trim staff. On Friday, for example, it announced that it had eliminated 178 financial positions in its equipment sales and marketing division. While some of those people may be relocated elsewhere in the company, there is no guarantee - and little expectation - that all will remain with A.T.& T. **********''We're intent on getting our force and cost reductions done as soon as possible,'' said Edward M. Block, an A.T.& T. senior vice president. ''We want to start into 1985 with all that behind us - that's our goal.'' **********The company has made some progress. It is keeping a watchful eye on expense accounts, and a management wage freeze announced last month is expected to save A.T.& T. $184 million next year as well as to set a tone for 1986 union negotiations. **********Indeed, A.T.& T. held second- quarter costs to just 1.7 percent above its $7.7 billion first-quarter costs. That was undoubtedly a factor in its better-than-expected second-quarter net earnings of $455 million, or 43 cents a share. **********But analysts say that some of those earnings stemmed from transactions that had taken place in the prior three months, and that A.T.& T. actually has a good deal more organizational surgery ahead of it before its cash- draining problems are completely under control, and its marketing abilities are up to speed. As W. Spencer Rice, senior partner with S&R Consultants, a Madison, N.J.-based consulting firm, put it, ''They've got two cylinders running and they've got six more to go.'' **********In line with its much-publicized goal of becoming a major player in both data processing and telecommunications, A.T.& T. has been hustling new products to market at a heady pace. It introduced its 3B series of minicomputers in March. In May it rolled out its System 75 PBX, a computerized office switchboard, and a month later, its version of a personal computer. **********The rapid rollout was designed to signal competitors and customers that the company intends to become a serious force in the computerized office equipment industry. ''Our blueprint is out there,'' said William P. Stritzler, a vice president for new ventures. ''Now it's a matter of improving price and capabilities.'' **********Analysts say that singly, none of the products is electrifying, but together they represent the first component package for a so-called local area network to link telephones, data processors, workstations and other office equipment. ''It's the first time I can remember A.T.& T. being first with anything,'' said Mr. Rice. ''It's given them a wonderful opportunity, if they take advantage of it.'' **********Indeed, A.T.& T. no longer can treat its cost and marketing problems as internal annoyances. The company's attempts to break into the data processing business and to stem the erosion of its position in telecommunications equipment have plunged it into deep competitive waters. The combined market for telephone and computer- equipment already is pegged at $115 billion and is growing at a 15 percent annual clip. **********To hang in, A.T.& T. must go head to head with I.B.M., one of the world's most formidable marketing organizations, against aggressive rivals such as Rolm and Northern Telecom that have grown up in an industry where cutthroat competition is commonplace, and against relatively new forces in long-distance telephones such as MCI and GTE- Sprint (see box). **********A.T.& T. clearly is playing catch-up ball. Even though equipment sales were opened to competition in 1968, marketing is still not the company's forte. Its share of PBX sales, for example, dropped from 51 percent in 1976 to 22 percent last year. **********TO recapture that share, analysts **********say, the company will have to do **********a better job of switching its management orientation from production to marketing. For example, its System 85 PBX, introduced in the spring of 1983, lacked extensive data transmission capabilities and related software. It met with such lukewarm customer response that A.T.& T. hastily announced a revamped model. **********Although the new model is having better acceptance, it arrived at a time that the whole industry was plagued with shortages of computer memory chips. A.T.& T.'s manufacturing executives had failed to foresee the explosive demand for the chips, and had canceled construction of a new chip plant at Orlando, Fla. **********A.T.& T. has since added chip capacity in Allentown, Pa., and Kansas City, Mo., and has revived the Orlando plant. The company claims it has been meeting delivery dates since February, but analysts say that it could have had a valuable edge on the competition if it had designed the right product to begin with. ''If the marketing people had been on top, System 85 would have come out a lot different,'' said Dixon Doll of DMW Group, an Ann Arbor, Mich., consulting firm. ''The people who are thinking about customers need to be put in charge.'' **********A.T.& T. has already gone through a radical reorganization to set itself up as a free-market competitor. The old phone company was organized primarily by function - for example, Western Electric handled manufacturing and Bell Labs handled research. Now the company is structured around two product lines: long- distance service and telecommunications equipment. **********In December A.T.& T. created A.T.& T. Technologies, which is expected to generate 40 percent of expected corporate revenues of $56.5 billion this year, to make and market telecommunications equipment. The new group encompasses the old American Bell, which last year became A.T.& T. Information Systems. This unit, which is dedicated to sales and service, is itself subdivided into three sections - marketing, product development and service - each with its own president. **********A.T.& T. Technologies also serves as the umbrella for A.T.& T. Technology Systems, which includes those parts of the old Western Electric that made computer and electronics products; Bell Laboratories, the research arm; and three units that produce and sell consumer telephone products, international telephone service, and switching equipment for other telephone companies. **********For now, A.T.& T. Technologies is barely profitable, and former A.T.& T managers, all of whom insisted on anonymity, say that at least part of the reason comes from an organizational structure that includes too many divisions and too many layers of management. For example, A.T.& T. Information Systems, which lost $1 billion in its first year of operations, maintains four separate planning departments to map corporate strategies as well as strategies for sales, product development, and service. Former employees say that one or two planning departments would suffice. **********SOME retrenchment has already **********occurred. A.T.& T. Technologies has closed four factories, and is consolidating office space and distribution outlets. Western Electric's Manhattan headquarters was sold for $104 million (actually, an embarrassment for the company, in that the new buyer, a New York real estate partnership, sold the property for $110 million a week later). **********A.T.& T. has sought outside help to plan further retrenchment moves. Company sources report that McKinsey & Company, a leading consulting firm, recently concluded a study of A.T.& T. Technologies. A.T.& T. will not comment on the findings, but rumors are rife both inside and outside the company that McKinsey recommended that some divisions and departments be eliminated or consolidated. That would presage further staff cuts. **********In a nationwide closed-circuit television conference to managers in June, A.T.& T. Technologies chairman James E. Olson ordered a 20 to 25 percent reduction in expenses by year-end. The sector employs about 254,000 workers, about two-thirds of the A.T.& T. work force. Mr. Olson said at the time that layoffs ''haven't been ruled out.'' In recent interviews, he has said they are ''probable.'' **********The company has been holding pep rallies to keep up employee morale and motivation. But several managers, all of whom asked that their names not be used, still paint a picture of a company beset with deep morale problems. ''The whole situation is unsettling,'' says one marketing sales representative, who admits to spending a good deal of time sitting in his office wondering ''Do I have a future with the company?'' **********Further staffing cuts, painful as they may be, are crucial. A.T.& T always has been top-heavy in management, and it still maintains 10 layers of managers between entry level supervisors and the chairman. The company's service ranks jumped by 73,000 workers in January, when people were transferred from the Bell companies. According to Eastern Management Group, a consulting firm, A.T.& T. Information Systems, for one, generates only $39,000 in revenues per employee, compared with $93,000 per employee at I.B.M. **********An early retirement incentive program has fallen far short of its intended mark of trimming 13,000 employees. Only about 5,000 workers have left A.T.& T. through attrition, resignations or retirement since the start of the year. Moreover, the company has had to add more service people to its long-lines division to take care of backlogs and to pick up administrative chores that had been handled by the Bell companies. The net result has been the addition of 1,300 workers since January. **********NEW Federal rules may help A.T.& T. get a better grip on some of its staffing problems. Since 1980, the Federal Communications Commission has required A.T.& T. to keep A.T.& T. Information Systems, which sells and services business telephone equipment, separate from other sales and marketing departments within the company. In June, the F.C.C. agreed to allow A.T.& T. Information Systems salesmen to sell long-distance services. The company has not decided whether it will cut staff as a result. **********A.T.& T., meanwhile, is growing more aggressive in its pricing and marketing. Jeffrey Matros, director of telecom market analysis at Probe Research Inc., a consulting firm in Morristown, N.J., said that A.T.& T.'s average price of $700 a line for its System 75 PBX is well below the industry average for PBX's of $800 a line. **********The company's chairman, Charles L. Brown, has turned out to be a supersalesman in his own right. Last month, when it became painfully clear that Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins would be buying $3 million worth of PBX equipment from Telecom Plus International Inc. rather than from A.T.& T., Mr. Brown paid a last-minute visit to top Paine Webber officials to assure them that, if they did go with A.T.& T., they could be assured of on-time delivery and service. **********A.T.& T. got the order. **********THE MAJOR PLAYER,BUT SLIPPING FAST **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company may be expanding beyond its traditional role as a telephone company, but for now long-distance telephone service still accounts for 60 percent of its revenues and nearly all of its profits. And lately, the mainstay phone business is contributing more than its share of the company's problems. **********A.T.& T. still is the major player in the $45 billion long-distance market, but it has slipped badly. Before divestiture, its on- time record for installing business lines exceeded 95 percent. But it has not yet perfected methods for coordinating installations with the newly independent Bell companies. The result is that A.T.& T.'s backlog of unfilled orders for line installation jumped 16 percent in June, to 41,700, while the percentage of orders completed on time fell to 22.8 percent. **********By its own count, A.T.& T. is losing 5,000 long-distance business and residential customers a day, up from 3,000 daily earlier this year, to competitors such as MCI and GTE-Sprint, which are geared toward speed and responsiveness. Both companies have dropped their monthly service fees for long distance, and ITT has said it will drop its fees in September. **********A.T.& T. has fought back. It has cut long-distance rates by 6.1 percent. It is offering special discounts for evenings and weekends, as well as promotions in which customers can get various kinds of merchandise. **********And it is making headway on cutting down delays in installations. John Blanchard, an A.T.& T. vice president who chairs a strike force to solve the backlog problem, said that more than 800 employees have been assigned to the task. The growth in backlogs for private line installation has virtually stopped, he said, while on-time rates for WATS and 800 service installation jumped to 70 percent in July, from 20 percent in March. **********But the company has a hard effort ahead to bolster customer loyalty. One angry hotel chain manager said that, when he invited A.T.& T. salesmen to make a presentation, they initially balked because they were ''too busy with the Olympics.'' And a telecommunications manager at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette got so fed up with installation delays that he has started using other vendors. ''We won't use A.T.& T. until they straighten up their act,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/02/busin.body_text: **********John S. Herold Inc., the Greenwich, Conn., oil appraiser, disclosed yesterday that it had increased its appraisal value for the Shell Oil Company to $81.50 a share from $69. **********It based the new value on higher values for Shell's oil and gas reserves and acreage together with an increase in working capital and a reduction in debt. **********The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, which owns nearly 70 percent, wants to buy the rest for $58 a share. Shell has called the price inadequate but in view of Royal Dutch's 70 percent interest, has told stockholders that they have to decide for themselves what to do. **********Morgan Stanley & Company, adviser to Royal Dutch, has called the price fair but Goldman, Sachs & Company, adviser to Shell, said the stock is worth $80 to $85 a share. **********The new Herold value could become evidence in pending suits but it was unclear what impact the report would have on Royal Dutch's offering price.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/busin.main_headline: Bank of New York, Northeast Filing
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/busin.print_headline: Bank of New York, Northeast Filing
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of New York Company said it had filed an application with the Federal Reserve Board to merge Northeast Bancorp of Stamford, Conn., with a Bank of New York subsidiary. The Bank of New York and Northeast Bancorp last August announced an agreement for the acquisition, at a price equal to 185 percent of Northeast's book value before the closing. **********There is a general Federal prohibition against the acquisition of banks across state lines. However, the Bank of New York said the Connecticut Interstate Banking Act, by permitting bank holding companies from certain states to purchase Connecticut banks, had removed this prohibition. The Bank of New York has $12.8 billion in assets. Northeast Bancorp, with assets of $1.6 billion, is the parent of the Union Trust Company, which operates 60 branches, mainly in Fairfield County.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/24/world.main_headline: FRENCH TOWN FOILS FORMER AFRICAN EMPEROR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/24/world.print_headline: FRENCH TOWN FOILS FORMER AFRICAN EMPEROR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/24/world.body_text: **********A friend of Jean- Bedel Bokassa, the former leader of the Central African Republic, tried to obtain false French identity papers for the deposed ruler this month but was foiled when a secretary recognized photographs of Mr. Bokassa, a French municipal official said today. **********Another official said the public prosecutor was deciding whether to press charges against the Bokassa friend, but no charges were likely against Mr. Bokassa. **********Mr. Bokassa, who was ousted in a coup in 1979, became a figure in French politics because of a gift of jewels he made to Valery Giscard d'Estaing, then President. Mr. Giscard d'Estaing was deeply embarrassed by the incident and said later that he had sold the diamonds and given the money to charities in the Central African Republic. **********An official in Menucourt, a town of 5,000 people about 20 miles west of Paris, said a butcher named Jean- Pierre Peteaux tried to obtain the papers earlier this month for a man whose name he listed as Abdel Kader Mohammed Aloul. **********The official said a clerk had become suspicious because she did not recognize the man as a local resident. Eventually a secretary realized the photographs with the application were of Mr. Bokassa, who lives in a chateau at Hardricourt, and the case was turned over to the police. **********The story took a further twist when Mr. Peteaux explained his reason for helping Mr. Bokassa. Mr. Peteaux said he had discovered that the woman with whom he is in love was Mr. Bokassa's illegitimate daughter. He said the false identity papers were designed to permit Mr. Bokassa to ''meet his people again,'' presumably by returning to the Central African Republic. **********Mr. Bokassa, 63 years old, arrived in France last December with 15 of his children. At the time of his arrival, the French External Relations Ministry made it known that he was not welcome. But he was allowed to stay. **********In an interview published in the latest issue of the magazine Jeune Afrique, Mr. Bokassa said he felt like a prisoner in France and wanted to return to Central Africa to defend himself against a variety of charges. **********Mr. Bokassa became the object of ridicule and then outrage during his rule. He became the Central African leader in 1966 and named himself President for Life in 1972. **********In December 1976 he proclaimed his country an empire and himself the Emperor. A year later he had himself invested at an elaborate ceremony patterned after Napoleon's coronation. Estimates of the cost ranged from $22 million to $90 million. **********Mr. Bokassa was overthrown in 1979 after charges of a massacre of 100 schoolchildren at a prison. Mr. Bokassa was accused of directly taking part in the killings. After the coup, the nation was again declared a republic.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/06/world.main_headline: Philippine Bar Group Sees Plot in Aquino Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Philippine Bar Group Sees Plot in Aquino Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/06/world.body_text: **********The Philippine Bar Association has concluded that a soldier shot the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. last year in a conspiracy involving ''high echelons of government'' and the military, the association's president said today. **********The bar association's report was submitted Tuesday to an official fact-finding board that is putting the finishing touches to its own report, expected to be published sometime this month. **********''It is our conclusion that a conspiracy existed within the high echelons of government, carried out by the military, to assassinate Senator Aquino,'' said the bar association's president, Raul M. Gonzales, who attended most of the fact-finding board's 10 months of sessions. But he said there were ''no proofs extant that can establish how far this conspiracy will reach.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/08/world.main_headline: Soviet Press Focusing On Negligence Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/08/world.print_headline: Soviet Press Focusing On Negligence Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/08/world.body_text: **********Soviet press reports on the poison gas leak in India have focused on allegations by Indian officials that the American company Union Carbide was negligent. **********The official Soviet press agency Tass reported today from New Delhi that state officials in Madhya Pradesh ''have officially accused Union Carbide of neglect of safety standards, which has led to the death of a large number of people, and instituted legal proceedings against it.'' **********''Arjun Singh, chief minister of the state, held the American-based transnational monopoly's subsidiary in India and the monopoly itself equally responsible for the disaster,'' Tass said. **********Major Soviet newspapers, including the Communist Party daily Pravda, have published the Tass reports. **********The newspaper Sovietskaya Rossiya, in an article that did not specifically mention Union Carbide, said, ''The tragedy in Bhopal is an immediate outcome of the criminal policy of 'profit at all costs,' pursued by Western big business in the developing countries.'' **********Reports of environmental disasters in the Soviet Union are rare.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/09/busin.body_text: **********LOS ANGELES **********Armand Hammer, the legendary chairman of **********Occidental Petroleum, sent Zoltan Merszei, his **********vice chairman and the former head of Dow Chemical, to fetch a glass of water. Ray R. Irani, named to the presidency less than two weeks ago, volunteered that his 86-year-old boss has ''a tremendous amount of vision and wisdom but doesn't get into our hair.'' David Martin, head of exploration and development, spoke bullishly about a big oil find in Colombia. **********For Dr. Hammer, who assembled eight top executives late last week to demonstrate to a reporter that Occidental Petroleum was not a ''one-man show,'' such talk was heartwarming. ''Now that's the kind of optimism I like to hear,'' he said, beaming. ''The one thing that I can't stand is laziness - laziness and indifference. You have to be enthusiastic to work for me.'' **********If not enthusiasm, at least peace once again reigns at the country's eighth-largest oil company. Dissidents on the board and in the executive suite have been banished. And Dr. Hammer, who built the company in the last 25 years from an obscure, nearly-bankrupt concern, is steering it back to its core energy businesses, scrapping the company's recent diversification into beef processing. **********But Dr. Hammer's move to silence the dissidents was so swift - and costly - that the company is still trying to assimilate the changes. In the meantime, an uneasy quiet has taken hold. A. Robert Abboud, who raised vexing doubts about Occidental's direction, no longer roils meetings of Occidental's top executives; he was replaced two weeks ago by Mr. Irani. Board meetings promise to be equally calm. Last month Occidental spent $194 million - $58 million above the market price - to buy back the shares of David Murdock, the company's largest shareholder and a staunch critic of Dr. Hammer. In the process, Mr. Murdock lost his seat on the board. **********And the company's single remaining critic-in-residence, Robert L. Peterson, who did not attend last week's interview, will probably not be around much longer. The profitable meat-packing division that he heads, IBP Inc., has been put on the block with a price tag of $1 billion. **********But if the doubts have been silenced in Mr. Hammer's sumptuous office here, they persist on Wall Street, where the stock retreated more than 20 percent by last week from its 52-week high of 35 3/4. As Occidental continues to adhere to a strategy focusing on such capital-hungry businesses as chemicals, coal mining, and oil and gas exploration, nagging questions remain about what direction the company should take and about the possibility of a capital crunch. The possibility of a cut in the $2.50 annual dividend is another worry. **********Some analysts say Dr. Hammer's undying devotion to projects with long lead times and uncertain payoffs - like the company's $230 million oil shale investment and the assiduous courting of business in Communist countries - absorbs too much of man agement's resources. And there is the persistent joke - no longer amusing to those concerned with grooming a successor to Dr. Hammer - about the ''revolving'' door to the executive suite. Mr. Irani, for example, is the company's sixth president in the past 16 years. **********''For some time now, management and Dr. Hammer have been saying that management had stabilized and that they would concentrate on energy and food. And now all this,'' says Warren Shimmerlik, an analyst for Merrill Lynch. ''They seem to be rambling around without any clear direction.'' **********As far as Dr. Hammer is concerned, however, the direction is perfectly clear. He is adamant about Occidental adhering to its core businesses: its oil and gas properties, the chemicals operation and even the money-losing Island Creek Coal Company. If anything has to go, he says, it will be the meat business. **********''We've come a long way since 1958 and it wasn't done with mirrors - it wasn't done in some helter-skelter fashion,'' he argues. ''We stuck to what we knew best. That was finding oil and gas. We're better off if we concentrate on oil, gas, chemicals and coal rather than trying to become a leading food company or a leading meat company.'' **********That is a decidedly different direction than Mr. Abboud had envisioned for Occidental, and had pushed, with Mr. Murdock's support, until a few days before his departure. **********IN fact, much of the reason for the **********conflict between Dr. Hammerrt to scuttle the deal to build a strip mine in China and to reduce emphasis on synthetic fuel projects. Instead, the two men believed that IBP could, with modest capital outlays, revolutionize the hog slaughtering business the way it once did cattle slaughtering. Last year, Mr. Abboud spearheaded an aborted drive to buy the bankrupt Wilson Foods and expand further into the food business. He also opened offices of IBP in London and Tokyo, the first steps of a new export strategy. IBP - as Iowa Beef Processors - had been 20 percent owned by Mr. Murdock at the time he persuaded his old friend, Dr. Hammer, to buy the company in 1981.  In the diversification move, one of Mr. Abboud's biggest concerns was to cushion the company against downturns in the energy business. Although he agreed that Occidental should stay in oil and gas, company officials say he was less certain about chemicals, coal, oil shale, geothermal energy, Arabian horses, cattle breeding and the many other interests that Dr. Hammer has pursued through Occidental subsidiaries. **********For his part, Dr. Hammer contends that Mr. Abboud's fears were exaggerated. ''He was a good banker,'' Dr. Hammer said. ''He came to us at an important time. He served well the time he was with us, particularly with the Cities acquisition,'' he continued, referring to the company's 1982 acquisition of Cities Service. That controversial $4 billion purchase transformed Occidental into a company that had more than half of its petroleum reserves in the United States. Increasing American reserves had been a major goal of Occidental, which wanted to reduce its dependence on such volatile sources as Libya and Peru. **********Now, however, Dr. Hammer said, things are different. ''We have to pay more attention to operations and recurrent earnings,'' he said. ''Mr. Irani is a good operating man. Together we can steer this company.'' **********Indeed, when Mr. Abboud arrived at Occidental in 1980, harmony with Dr. Hammer was also forecast. According to company executives, Mr. Abboud had been as agreeable in his early years as Mr. Irani is now. **********But early this year relations became strained. Mr. Abboud, who is 55 years old, increasingly found himself on the side of Mr. Murdock at the company's stormy board meetings. Mr. Murdock, whose vision of the company's future was similar to Mr. Abboud's, was not shy about expressing his views. **********A man of huge wealth, who runs his portfolio from an office in Murdock Plaza across Wilshire Boulevard from Occidental's headquarters here, Mr. Murdock was seen as a potential a threat to Dr. Hammer's control. His 5 percent stake made him the company's largest stockholder and there were persistent rumors that he would seek control either through a tender offer or a proxy fight. **********The July board meeting was particularly heated, company officials said, and Dr. Hammer proposed ending the impasse by buying Mr. Murdock's shares, unseating him as a director and forbidding his purchase of Occidental stock for 10 years. Mr. Abboud, who would not comment on the meeting because of restrictions in his $2 million separation agreement, is said to have objected strongly, but to no avail. **********Last week, Dr. Hammer ridiculed the seriousness of Mr. Murdock's threat. ''Our only serious takeover attempt came from Standard Oil of Indiana in 1974,'' he said. ''We fought them so fiercely they dropped out.'' Although he would not discuss details of the buyback of Mr. Murdock's stock - saying he was constrained by a legal agreement - he said the price was not a bad one. ''We think our stock is worth more than $40 a share,'' he said. On Friday the stock closed at 27 5/8. **********By the August meeting, it was apparent that Mr. Abboud, too, had lost Dr. Hammer's favor. The chairman was proposing that Occidental sell IBP, the centerpiece of what Mr. Abboud thought should be Occidental's growth strategy. Dr. Hammer and Mr. Abboud drafted an amicable statement with Mr. Abboud attributing his departure to ''honest differences.'' In his shift, Mr. Abboud lost his second corporate war in the last four years. In 1980 the directors of First Chicago Corporation, revolting against management turmoil and declining profits at the bank, ousted him as chairman. **********Dr. Hammer's victory over Mr. Abboud and Mr. Murdock, however, drew mixed comments on Wall Street. **********''Armand Hammer is a great illustration of the folly of having mandatory retirement at 65,'' said Herbert Hart, an analyst with Rowe & Pitman, a San Francisco-based brokerage. ''But he makes a great case for it at age 86. If I were a shareholder I'd much rather have the exiting group running the company.'' **********But supporters do not agree. ''Their departure eliminates an antagonistic element,'' said Eugene Nowak, an analyst for Dean Witter, the company's investment banker. ''Dr. Hammer is a strong man. He's defied every parameter and rule of thumb.'' **********In fact, Dr. Hammer's unswerving vision about how his company should be run has won him quite a few supporters on Wall Street. They recall the drubbing Occidental earnings took when it went heavily into debt in 1982 to finance its $4 billion purchase of Cities Service. Now, however, it seems that the deal was a very cheap way for Occidental to acquire substantial domestic reserves. **********In a high-wire financial juggling act, in which Occidental divested several businesses in depressed markets without big write-offs, the company repaid about $3 billion in debt last year. The debt retirement was such a high priority that Dr. Hammer hand- delivered a check for $1 billion last September to Roger Anderson, then chairman of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company so that the investment community would take notice. The two men held a news conference, posing for pictures with officials of other banks. **********PAYING off a big chunk of the debt was one major success. But that is not all that needs to be done. Dr. Hammer conceded last week that some strategic and financial restructuring was needed at Occidental. In fact, he said, the proceeds from the disposition of IBP should bring in $1 billion in cash - and that would be used to redeem some of the preferred stock, which annually consumes $244 million in dividend payments. He said the company also wanted to raise cash by selling an electrical generating plant in northern California, which is powered by geothermal energy, for $400 million. **********The strategy that Dr. Hammer has laid out will be left to Mr. Irani, who is 49 and the former president of the Olin Corporation, a chemical company, to put into effect. A Ph.D. and a summa cum laude graduate of the American University in Beirut, he joined Occidental only last year as head of the chemical division and he agrees with Dr. Hammer's position on coal and chemicals. **********Dr. Hammer, he said, is willing to absorb losses on the coal properties because Occidental's investment has been recovered many times over and the reserves will grow more promising as domestic oil reserves are depleted. In Dr. Hammer's view, any sale of those properties now would bring a meager price because the industry remains depressed. **********According to Mr. Irani, the outlook for chemicals is improving. That division, which includes Hooker Chemical of Love Canal infamy, is expected to earn $60 million this year, a sharp reversal from its $70 million loss last year. Occidental's leadership says it is unconcerned about worldwide overcapacity in the petrochemicals industry. **********''If you're good in a commodity you make money,'' Mr. Irani said. ''You can have all the overcapacity you want. If you're the low-cost producer you can make money.'' **********He estimated, however, that it would cost $400 million over the next five years to make Occidental the low-cost producer across the company's entire line of industrial and agricultural chemicals. Despite that cost, he maintained, coal and chemicals are good investments even when they're losing money, because they always generate cash. **********''The name of the game is how much cash an operation can generate and how that cash can be used,'' he said. **********Some analysts say that reasoning is fine for a highly profitable company - but, they stress, Wall Street's patience may be severely tested by several more quarters of mediocre results. Occidental's earning have been extremely weak in the last few years, largely because of the debt it assumed to buy Cities Service and poor performances by the coal and chemical divisions. Return on stockholders' equity was below 5 percent in 1982 and 1983, when the company reported profits of $155.6 million and $566 million (including Cities) respectively. **********In the first six months of this year profits climbed 39 percent, to $231.6 million. But at that rate, earnings still will not reach the $722.2 million of 1981 and the rate of return on equity will remain subpar. Dr. Hammer said he does not foresee any significant earnings jump until 1986. **********And despite Occidental's reduction of the debt it accumulated through its purchase of Cities Service, it still owes more than $3.2 billion. At the same time, it is burdened by total dividend payments of $500 million a year. There is widespread concern that the company may cut its dividend to conserve cash, which would make the stock less attractive. **********But Dr. Hammer says this will not happen. To conserve capital, he said, the company instead will continue to keep a tight rein on capital spending and research and development. ''The dividend is not in jeopardy,'' Dr. Hammer insists. ''We don't care whether the investment community becomes impatient or not. As long as our cash flow is adequate we'll continue our dividend policy.'' **********Nor is the company backing away from its foreign ventures, despite criticism from Wall Street. Recently the company nailed down $400 million financing to help build and operate the world's largest strip mine in China. ''All of the socialist countries have opened the doors to us because I'm considered a hero,'' says Dr. Hammer, whose office is decorated with a mural of Chinese peasants from Deng Xiaoping of China as well as dozens of photographs of Dr. Hammer with leaders from around the world. **********Born on New York's Lower East Side and raised in the Bronx, Dr. Hammer ran his father's drug company at the same time he was attending medical school at Columbia University. After selling the company, which later became Allied Chemical, the idealistic young Dr. Hammer went to Bolshevik Russia in 1921 to fight a plague of cholera and typhus. While there, he married a Russian woman, befriended Lenin - and made his first fortune by bartering furs and minerals for American grain. **********More than 30 years later he obtained control of Occidental for a $50,000 drilling loan he made to the company when it was on the verge of bankruptcy. A year afterward, in 1957, he became president. Building Occidental into a $19 billion company has been a major effort and Mr. Hammer never relaxed his iron grip. **********In fact, he hesitates to do so even now, at 86. ''I won't retire unless they tell me to get out,'' he said last week. ''And if I pass'' - and here he pauses, catches himself, and amends his statement, ''And when I pass, the board of directors will pick a successor. They're a good group.'' **********CANO LIMO:THE BIG DRILL **********Some supporters on Wall Street say Occidental will climb back into favor on the strength of Oxy's recent oil find in the Cano Limo field in northeastern Colombia. Estimates of reserves at the site range up to one billion barrels and Dr. Hammer says it could be a major source of foreign crude for Occidental, second only to Libya, where the company has operated for many years. **********The company has drilled six development wells in Cano Limo and proven reserves are estimated now to be above 400 million barrels, with more drilling to come. Occidental, a partner in the venture with state-owned Ecopetrol, can count half the reserves as its own. **********Paradoxically, the addition of the Colombian reserves comes at a time when the company is trying to reduce its exposure to overseas supply sources, a major reason for the Cities Service acquisition in 1982. But Occidental officials say Colombia is one of the most stable countries in Latin America, despite occasional guerrilla activity. **********The problem now for Occidental, however, is that successful development of the property will require big money. And the company seems to have more commitments than cash. ''Oxy does not have the resources to do everything,'' Mr. Abboud said last week. ''It has to pick and choose between oil and gas and its other businesses.'' **********But some analysts say that when the oil starts flowing, the revenues could avert a cash bind at the company and turn around its poor financial performance of the past few years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 300 Reported Arrested In Peruvian Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/world.body_text: **********The police clashed with demonstrators in several cities today, injuring dozens and arresting more than 300 during a nationwide strike called to protest the Government's economic policies, union leaders said. **********News reports said the 24-hour strike, held despite a state of emergency declared Wednesday by the Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry, was only partly successful. **********Prime Minister Luis Percovich said 92 percent of the nation's 6 million workers were on the job. But Valentin Pacho Quispe, head of the million- member General Confederation of Peruvian Workers, said it was 93 percent effective. **********Riot policemen fired buckshot and wounded an unspecified number of students from San Marcos State University when the students tried to block a major street linking Lima and the port of Callao, the Government press agency, Adina, said. **********The union also said 100 people were arrested in Lima and 200 others in clashes with police in Cuzco, Arequipa, Huancayo and Puno.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/20/busin.body_text: **********Vice President Bush said today that Japan should open its markets to American goods if it wants to avoid protectionist legislation by Congress. **********In remarks to a conference on economic interdependence, Mr. Bush said the Administration would resist protectionist pressures. But he noted that trade restrictions such as domestic-content legislation, which would limit the sale of Japanese cars in the United States, had the support of several Democratic candidates for President. That is not the right course, he said, but in an election year, it is the popular one.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/22/world.main_headline: 2 on Trial in Zimbabwe Say Captives Are Alive
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/22/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 2 on Trial in Zimbabwe Say Captives Are Alive
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/22/world.body_text: **********Two men charged with kidnapping six tourists, including two Americans, two years ago asserted today that the six were still alive and would be handed over in return for properties confiscated by the state. **********Gilbert Ngwenya, 42 years old, and Austin Mpofu, 25, refused to plead to charges of kidnapping and terrorism on the opening day of their High Court trial here. **********Pleas of not guilty were entered for them by the judge. **********''These people are in my hands,'' Mr. Ngwenya said of the captives when asked to plead. **********The two admit they were part of a gang that seized the tourists, including two Australians and two Britons, in western Zimbabwe in July 1982. **********Statements submitted as evidence said they did it to try to force the return of confiscated farms belonging to the opposition Zimbabwe African People's Union of Joshua Nkomo, and to force the release of two jailed Nkomo aides.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/busin.body_text: **********People Express Airlines Inc. said it would begin service between Newark and the Oakland International Airport on Sept. 28 with one round-trip flight daily. **********The tickets will cost $119 one-way for coach and $299 for premium class. People Express started service between Newark and Los Angeles June 15. **********After the People Express announcement, Oakland-based World Airways said it was dropping its fare between Newark and Oakland to $115 each way, based on a round-trip ticket. Generally, the lowest San Francisco-New York one-way fares range from $145 to $200 and usually carry restrictions such as advanced booking and minimum stay.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/02/world.main_headline: DUARTE IS INAGURATED IN EL SALVADOR AND PROMISES TO CURB ABUSES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/02/world.print_headline: DUARTE IS INAGURATED IN EL SALVADOR AND PROMISES TO CURB ABUSES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/02/world.body_text: **********Jose Napoleon Duarte was inaugurated as President of El Salvador today. **********In his inaugural address, he called on Salvadorans to unite in a social pact to achieve peace and promised to ''fight openly to control abuses of authority and the violence of the extremes.'' **********''Today, a light kindles in the long night of horror that El Salvador has lived in,'' said Mr. Duarte, who became the country's first popularly elected civilian President in more than 50 years. ''No one, because I will not permit it, will say that this Government has violated the fundamental rights of my people.'' **********The new President, wearing a dark suit and waving his hands above his head as he took the podium, spoke to more than 5,000 Salvadorans and delegates from 41 countries. Secretary of State George P. Shultz led the delegation from the United States, which included Senators Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts. **********The election of Mr. Duarte has been acclaimed by the Reagan Administration as a victory in its attempt to prevent another Marxist-led insurgency from coming to power in Central America. **********In the last four years, leftist insurgents have battled with the American- backed Salvadoran military to try to force the Government to set up a provisional junta that would include representatives from the left. With the support of the Reagan Administration, Mr. Duarte has said he will not share power with the left, and since his election, the country has received new military aid. **********Mr. Duarte's 30-minute address, interrupted often by applause, was unusual in its repeated overtures to the armed forces and its strong attacks on leftist insurgents and their political leaders. **********During the campaign, Mr. Duarte often criticized the military, who prevented him from taking power in 1972, beat him after his supporters protested and finally let him leave for Venezuela, where he lived until 1980. **********The ceremony was relieved of its formality when Provisional President Alvaro Magana was interrupted three times by chants of ''Duarte, Duarte, Duarte'' when he tried to introduce the new President. **********The new President's opponent in the election, Roberto d'Aubuisson, the candidate of the far right, and Hugo Barrera, his running mate, did not attend. They have challenged the elections and accused the United States of buying the election for Mr. Duarte. **********However, most far-right members of Parliament sat in their appointed places, and every sector of El Salvador, from the straw-hatted campesinos to the High Command, was represented in the auditorium. Peasants leaned against the wire-mesh fence outside to listen to the speech.   Duarte Congratulates Military **********Mr. Duarte repeatedly congratulated the armed forces, whose commanders sat to the right of the podium, saying they had started the development of democracy in El Salvador after the 1979 coup.  He said the army's support of elections had ''changed the course of history, leaving behind the sad past when the armed forces was used as an arm of repression for those political groups that controlled the power.'' **********The 58-year-old Christian Democrat said the armed forces were unable to win the war because ''many Salvadorans watch the conflict as spectators, worried only about their own interests.'' **********''Until now, the people have rejected the violence and the war but have not acted dynamically with the armed forces to defend democracy.'' **********While the new President generously applauded the army, he spoke severely of the leftist insurgents and their political leaders, saying his Government would never share power with them. **********Mr. Duarte said negotiations with the rebels would ''negate the essense of democracy.'' He said, ''If they had the capacity to take up arms, now they must have the boldness to put them down.'' **********Speaking of the political leaders of the five guerrilla groups in El Salvador, the new President said they had ''fallen under the empire and obedience of the guerrilla commanders.'' **********''To have credibility,'' he added of the political leaders, ''they have to demonstrate hegemony over the armed sector.'' He suggested that if the political leaders held sway, the Government could be open to signing a truce with leftists, as the Government in Colombia recently has. **********The crowd reacted enthusiastically to the speech. **********''It is the most beautiful day,'' Miquel Morales, a driver said. ''It is the birth of a republic.'' **********Blanca Rodriquez, 28, said it was the day ''we have all waited for.'' **********Archbishop Arturo Rivera y Damas, who sat with a delegation from the Roman Catholic Church, said before the ceremony that ''the church would be ready to act as a mediator'' in negotiations between the Government and the leftist insurgents. He added that Mr. Duarte had to find a ''nonmilitary solution'' to the war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/21/world.main_headline: New York Supporter of I.R.A. Is to Appear in Dublin Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/21/world.print_headline: New York Supporter of I.R.A. Is to Appear in Dublin Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/21/world.body_text: **********An American supporter of the Irish Republican Army who eluded a police attack last week will come out of hiding Tuesday and make an appearance in Dublin, the I.R.A.'s legal political wing announced today. **********Martin Galvin, a 34-year-old lawyer from New York who had been banned by the British Government from entering Northern Ireland, will meet reporters in the capital of the Irish Republic before returning home, according to the political party, Sinn Fein. **********On Aug. 12, after defying the British entry ban, Mr. Galvin appeared at an I.R.A. rally in Belfast, and the police charged in to arrest him. A 22-year-old Roman Catholic, Sean Downes, was killed by a police plastic bullet, and 20 other people were wounded. **********Mr. Galvin fled and was reportedly given refuge in mainly Catholic West Belfast. Sinn Fein did not disclose his whereabouts today, but he was believed to be in the Irish Republic. **********The Dublin Government has condemned Mr. Galvin's activities as ''responsible for death and destruction in Northern Ireland,'' but it has not banned him.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/05/busin.body_text: **********FRIDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1984 **********Companies **********National Intergroup has agreed to merge with Bergen Brunswig, a drug and electronics wholesaler. National, a steel company seeking to redeploy its assets, said it would be acquired in a stock transaction valued at $550 million. The price surprised analysts, who noted that it was below National's market value and represented a substantial discount from its book value. (Page D1.) **********Phibro-Salomon's co-chairman, David Tendler, resigned, two months after he was pushed aside as co-chief executive. Analysts said John H. Gutfreund, the chief executive who had also been co- chairman, was now completely in control of the investment banking and commodity trading house. (D1.) **********First Chicago's bad loans could create problems elsewhere, the bank's officials indicated to analysts. Other banks participated in many of the loans that First Chicago has written off, and they may decide to take similar write-downs, the officials suggested. (D1.) William M. Isaac, chairman of the F.D.I.C., said First Chicago was in no danger of failing, despite its announcement that it expects a third-quarter loss of as much as $74 million. (D5.) **********Irwin L. Jacobs sold his stake in Disney to the Bass brothers of Texas in a deal valued at $158.1 million. With the sale, Disney shed the label of takeover target, and its stock fell $4.125 a share, to $55.125. The Basses now hold 24.83 percent of the company. (D1.) **********Braniff is selling three airport gates to United for $16 million, according to a company source. The sale would provide the troubled low-cost carrier with an important infusion of cash. (D2.) **********A court has temporarily blocked CSX from taking control of American Commercial Lines. The court will rule on whether the I.C.C. acted lawfully in granting the railroad permission to run the barge line. (D6.) **********Gillette has tentatively agreed to sell its Cricket lighter division to Swedish Match, ending its battle with Bic for a bigger share of the disposable lighter market. (D1.) **********The Economy **********House and Senate conferees continued work on a trade bill, striking out a protectionist provision aimed at trade with China and restraining another that would affect wine imports from Europe. But a separate conference committee adjourned, unable to compromise on a bill authorizing the President to curb exports of sensitive goods and technology to Communist and other countries. (D2.) **********September sales rose moderately, major retailers reported.  They said brisk clothing sales helped offset decreases in sales of big-ticket items. Sears reported the smallest increase, 4.3 percent. K Mart rose 15.8 percent. (D5.) **********Markets **********Stock prices edged higher in a sluggish session, following four straight days of losses. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 4.53, to 1,187.39. Volume fell to 76.7 million shares, from 92.4 million shares, as institutional activity slackened. (D6.) **********Interest rates fell modestly, encouraged by a lower-than-expected rate for overnight bank loans. Prices were little changed after the Fed reported a $2.4 billion decline in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended Sept. 24. (D13.) **********The dollar was mixed, rising abroad but falling in the U.S.  Analysts cited uncertainty about the direction of American interest rates. Gold also was mixed, with the late New York quote at $347.50 an ounce, off $1.75 from the previous day. (D14.) Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed. (D14.) **********Assets of money market mutual funds rose $451 million, to $185.19 billion, their highest level since March 1983. (D12.) **********Today's Columns **********Some economists believe that inflationary pressure has eased more than most people realize. The recent low inflation readings suggest that the economy has the ability to handle existing demand without much strain. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********The outlook for shares of cosmetics companies seems bright , although analysts cite problems, such as excessive start-up costs, that have plagued the industry in recent years. Avon, the industry leader, expects third-quarter earnings to rise. Market Place. (D6.)
