https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/09/busin.body_text: **********FRIDAY, MARCH 9, 1984 **********The Economy **********Martin S. Feldstein predicted 6 percent growth for the economy in the first quarter, well in excess of the 4 to 5 percent annual rate that most economists expected a month or two ago. But the forecast by the President's chief economist was in line with recent strong results for housing starts, auto sales and industrial production. An Administration prediction at this stage is unusual; normally the Commerce Department's ''flash'' report, which comes out in two weeks, is the first official estimate. (Page A1.) **********A cap on luxury car depreciation deductions was reversed in the Senate Finance Committee, a victory for industry lobbyists. The committee voted 10 to 4 last week to limit the deduction to $15,000, but opponents said it was bad policy to single out one luxury item for such treatment. The House Ways and Means Committee last week approved a $21,000 cap. (D1.) President Reagan was reported to have agreed to try to work out a package with Senate Republicans that would include some cuts in his military spending request. (A1.) **********Fears of large corporate mergers are exaggerated, according to J. Paul McGrath, the nation's antitrust chief. The Administration has taken no stand on emerging bills that would block them, he said in a speech, but he seems unsympathetic to such legislation. (D13.) Enegry Secretary Donald P. Hodel said that the recent merger activity in the oil industry would not have any significant impact on the nation's energy security. (D13.) **********Markets **********Interest rates rose. A $1.5 billion drop in the basic money supply seemed to spur most of the increase because traders were disappointed that the decline was not greater. The 12 percent Treasury bond due in 2013, after several swings, was offered late in the day at 97 1/4, to yield 12.35 percent. (D1.) Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose to their highest level since last May. (D4.) **********Stock prices rose for the first time in four sessions.  The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 3.46 points, to 1,147.09, as volume slipped to 80.6 million shares. Analysts said the recovery resulted from bargain hunting and covering by short-sellers. (D4.) **********The dollar was mixed in active trading in the U.S.  after advancing in Europe. Gold again broke the $400 mark, ending the day in New York at $402.25 an ounce, up $3.75. (D10.) Grain futures shrugged off early price losses associated with the stronger dollar and finished at their best levels for the day. (D10.) **********Companies **********Financial Corporation holds 4.9 percent of the American Express Company's outstanding stock. Financial Corporation, which owns American Savings and Loan, the nation's largest thrift institution, said that the shares were for investment only. (D1.) **********K Mart and Dayton-Hudson reported sharply higher profits in the quarter and the year, helped by strong Christmas sales. (D3.) **********The new owners of Faberge plan to shift emphasis at the cosmetics company, shedding some products and making the company more conservative. (D3.) **********The F.C.C. will not overturn the deal that made Chris-Craft the largest shareholder in Warner Communications. The decision, a setback for Rupert Murdoch's bid for Warner, involved overlapping holdings in different media. (D3.) **********International **********Control of the big Hibernia oilfield off Newfoundland lies with the federal Government, not the province of Newfoundland, the Supreme Court of Canada ruled. Oil companies, led by Mobil, have been awaiting clarification of the long federal-provincial dispute before investing the $10 billion necessary to bring the field into production. But a variety of political issues must still be settled. (D1.) **********Today's Columns **********Politics and finance seem to live in different worlds . The President is exuberant over the strength of the economy, but Wall Street is gloomy because of the deficits and the upward pressure on prices. The fall in the long-term bond market is a clear indication of anxieties about inflation. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.)  Many speculators say now is the time to buy Lilco stock.  But some analysts recommend buying the troubled utility only for the very long term and others avoid it altogether. Market Place. (D4.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/17/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; ADVOCATE OF CHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/17/world.body_text: **********For many among South Africa's black majority, Bishop Desmond Tutu, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today, is a voice full of passion for change in this divided land, a man whose humor turns quickly to a sonorous invocation of ''liberation.'' Diminutive in stature, but not in other ways, sharp-eyed and outspoken, the 53-year-old cleric, that is to say, is a man with a message that is yearned for. **********To the authorities, however, such talk falls little short of subversion, a challenge perceived as part of a ''total onslaught'' from within and without on ''white'' South Africa and a voice that is to be stifled. His organization, the South African Council of Churches, of which he is General Secretary, has been scrutinized by three official judicial inquiries. His passport has been repeatedly withdrawn. **********Subject of Criticism **********A former chief of security police, Lieut. Gen. Johan Coetzee, once expressed support for the view that the church council ''is manipulated by a highly politicized leadership, is funded by outside influences hostile to the present system in South Africa and gives itself an importance not reflected in reality.'' **********The award, thus, says something about the conflicting interpretations here of a message translated by the Nobel committee as peaceful. When word came today that the Bishop had won the prize, supporters danced and formed a gyrating human chain through the church council's offices in one of Johannesburg's less glittery thoroughfares. **********The office of President P. W. Botha, by contrast, issued a ''no comment'' that seemed as resentful as it was full of affront. The state-controlled television gave the first announcement 10 seconds of air time as its sixth item of news, and pro-Government commentators in newspapers read mainly by conservative whites prepared editorials heavy with outrage that the label of ''peace'' has been attached to such a man.   Was Baptized a Methodist **********The man at the center of such conflicting passions, Desmond Mpilo Tuto, was born in the Afrikaner town of Klerksdorp on Oct. 7, 1931. He was baptized as a Methodist because his father was teaching at a Methodist school, but later, the whole family switched to the Anglican Church. **********A memory of his youth, he has told interviewers, is of blacks' rummaging through garbage cans in search of food rejected by white schoolchildren. He wanted to be a doctor, but his family could not afford the fees, so he became a teacher after attending a training college run on the segregationist principles that permeate education in South Africa. **********With the high-pitched chuckles that are among his hallmarks, he recalled that black students were housed in circular huts. ''Living in rectangular buildings was Western and, I suppose, not good for our black psyches,'' he said. **********One of Bishop Tutu's early religious mentors was the Rev., later Bishop, Trevor Huddleston, a prominent campaigner against apartheid. Bishop Tutu left teaching at the age of 25 to become a cleric, believing, he said, the church offered ''a likely means of service.''  Studied in London **********He was ordained in 1960, the year of the first riots that convulsed Sharpeville, 40 mile south of Johannesburg, and he studied in London. He became the first black Anglican Dean of Johannesburg in 1975. **********In 1978, he was appointed the first black General Secretary of the South African Council of Churches, representing 12 million Christians. The post did not automatically yield a black constituency, until pro-Government figures began assailing his work at the council amd his calls for economic pressure on South Africa - providing, through South Africa's spectrum, an inverted validation drawn partly from white opprobrium. **********He became the most heard black voice to articulate the churches' opposition to apartheid. ''In the present stage of South African history,'' a spokesman for the council said today, ''we represent the cutting edge of the churches in what we call the liberation struggle.''  'Impish' and 'Feisty' **********Some of his friends say his wife, Leah, the mother of their four children - Naomi, Mpho, Thandi and Trevor - has been a great influence on him. **********The labels most commonly applied to Bishop Tutu are ''impish'' and ''feisty,'' but they do not convey the sense of a man who has escaped the nexus of imposed inferiorities borne by many of his compatriots to assume an assured self-confidence. **********He travels frequently when granted a travel document by the authorities that describes his citizenship as being ''undetermined.'' He spreads a message to Western countries that economic pressure must be brought on South Africa if change is to be produced without violence. **********At home, he has sought to project his voice across the chasm between black and white and, in doing so, faces a problem. Increasingly, in black South African politics, the tone - if not the overall thrust - is set by groups whose language is of the militant left. But Bishop Tutu has occupied a center that is bound to shift as the authorities' seeming intransigeance toward black demands heightens a mood of militant desperation. **********Thus, his anguish: in some perceptions his refusal to acknowledge, in his own words, that ''God's grace cannot operate on P. W. Botha'' may not secure a lasting constituency and may, moreover, force a hardening of his approach dicatated by mounting confrontation where conciliation has failed. And that in turn would conflict with what he sees as essentially a spiritual mission.   Voice of Black Protest **********Under his tutelage the South African Council of Churches has become an increasingly acknowledged voice of black protest. **********''Reconciliation is not saying peace, peace, where there is no peace,'' he said in an interview three years ago with a white reporter. ''We are all involved in the liberation struggle. Jesus Christ is involved in the liberation struggle. He liberated us from the bondage to sin - and oppression is an expression of sin. **********''Black don't believe that they are introducing violence into the situation,'' he said, ''They believe that the situation is already violent.'' **********In an interview with another correspondent during the same period, he said: ''I will never tell someone to pick up a gun. But I will pray for the man who picks up the gun, pray that he will be less cruel than he might otherwise have been, because he is a member of the community. We are going to have to decide: if this civil war escalates, what is our ministry going to be?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Waffen SS Veterans Plan West German Reunion
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/06/world.body_text: **********The town director here said today that 800 veterans of Hitler's elite Waffen SS were planning a reunion at this vacation spa, where the event was billed as a conference of economic experts. **********''We are doing everything possible to stop this meeting from going ahead,'' the town director, Horst Voigt, said in an interview. **********''It's a pity that the organization is not banned.'' **********He said that the four-day reunion was scheduled to start May 17 and that the Waffen SS veterans had booked conference rooms at the town's health resort building. **********The chairman of the Waffen SS veterans' group, Albert Stenwedel, refused to comment on the meeting. ''What has it got to do with you?'' he said by telephone from his Hamburg home.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/06/busin.body_text: **********AT one point in his career, pipe- smoking David I. Weiss wanted to be the best account manager in New York. And for all you know, he might be. **********Then as the years passed by and responsibilities accumulated for him at Ogilvy & Mather, his one and only employer, he came to realize that ''there are no old account managers.'' **********''You don't see any over 45,'' he realized. It was then he decided that, ''if you want to stay in business, you have to be able to run a business.'' **********Luckily, O.& M. is the kind of company that trains its executives for just such an eventuality so Mr. Weiss, at 41, feels ready to move into the presidential pew at Ingalls Associates of Boston, the agency with the best growth record in New England last year but still in the shadow of the giant Ogilvy. And so he will July 1. **********And now that he is committed to leaving for the far north, Mr. Weiss, a Columbus, Ohio, native, is suddenly aware of the pluses of the Boston scene, many of them imparted by S.  Joseph Hoffman, who at 64 will be moving up to chairman and chief executive at Ingalls to make way for the new lad. **********People who know Mr. Hoffman, a copywriter-turned-manager, cite his salesmanship abilities, which he learned in the early days of the agency making cold calls for new business. Necessity then forced him to overcame an almost crippling tendency to stutter. **********In any event, now that he will soon be leaving, the Ogilvy senior vice president said yesterday that he was expecting to find ''certain freedom at work you don't see in New York.'' **********At which point his new mentor, remarked, ''New York has become super-cautious.'' **********And the departee added, ''It is hard to sell the unusual in a New York agency structure.'' **********''It is easier to say 'no' in New York,'' said Mr. Hoffman, who with his associate was framed by the huge Olympic Towers' seventh-floor window against the neo-Gothic glory of St. Patrick's Cathedral. **********Mr. Weiss, with bachelor's and M.B.A. degrees from Ohio State, was recruited by Ogilvy in the summer of 1966 and then went through its training programs, moving steadily upward surrounded by talented people. **********''Such a breadth of talent and depth of talent is fantastic,'' he said. **********Currently as a group account director he is running five or six accounts - he was not quite sure - is on the board of the New York office and the United States management council, runs Eyepatch Productions, an in- house commercial production operation, and is in charge of the account management training program. **********With management as young as it is at the very top - William E. Phillips is 54 and Ken Roman 53 - it is not surprising that an ambitious executive, anxious to try his management wings, would find himself forced into flying elsewhere. **********During the time that Mr. Weiss was moving up at the agency, now the world's fifth largest, and putting deep family roots into Great Neck, L.I., there were major changes taking place at Ingalls, the older of the two agencies, having been founded in 1911 by the late Arthur W. Ingalls, a Harvard man who loved the agency business more than he understood it and died in 1971 at the age of 82. **********Mr. Hoffman, who four years ago took over leadership from Joseph A. Maynard, his art director partner of years ago, has been building the sort of ''whole egg'' communications company that Edward N. Ney of Young & Rubicam talks about. He may not do it in as planned a way as they do at Ogilvy, but Ingalls is getting there all the same. **********For example, it owns Morris, Reilly & Kerasiotes, a political media consulting firm, and Swofford & Scharff, an investor relations company in New York. It also has its own commercial production arm and has just brought in an expert to get it started in direct marketing. **********In addition, it owns 80 percent of Stern Ingalls, a New York joint venture with a Cleveland agency based in the expensive surroundings of Olympic Towers. Ingalls itself, committed to breaking through to $100 million in billings this year, basically serves high-technology, retail and financial accounts, and Mr. Hoffman thinks very little of the talents of New York agencies in the first two categories. **********It is nowhere in package goods, and Mr. Weiss, with his years of experience with the likes of General Foods, is expected to make a difference here, even though he thinks that future advertising growth opportunities will be more with high-technology and financial services and not package goods. A few such accounts, however, would be very handy for paying the rent in New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/03/busin.body_text: **********Companies **********The Bass brothers have increased their stake in Disney to almost 16 percent, making them the biggest holders in the company. In all, the Texas billionaires bought about 2.5 million shares Tuesday, the biggest chunk of which was said to have been sold by Ivan F. Boesky, the arbitrager. Disney said it considered the purchase ''a strong vote of confidence.'' (Page D1.) **********The Navy has proposed that G.E. share technology with a rival , Pratt & Whitney. The move, intended to introduce more competition into Pentagon procurement, involves technology for a jet engine. G.E. has not decided whether to agree to the proposal. (D1.) **********GTE has sold about one-quarter of its low-cost phones to a liquidator at bargain prices. The sale of 500,000 residential units comes amid reports that the company may concentrate on higher-priced home phones and phones for industry. (D5.) **********The trial of J. David Dominelli was delayed after new indictments were handed up. The currency trader, who is charged with bankruptcy fraud, contempt and perjury, may not stand trial until next year, his lawyer said. (D6.) **********Occidental Petroleum has increased its estimate of reserves in a Colombian oilfield. Analysts said the estimate would help the company maintain the dividend on its stock at $2.50 a share. (D6.) **********Two Silicon Valley computer importers have been indicted on charges of smuggling counterfeit Apple computers. (D8.) **********Tandem reached an agreement with the S.E.C.  The agency had accused the computer company of overstating earnings for the fiscal year 1982. The company, which had already restated the earnings, neither admitted nor denied the allegations. (D14.) **********Adams Drug has agreed to be acquired for $24.39 a share, or about $100 million. The company did not identify the buyer. (D5.)  International **********Congressional conferees have agreed on a ban on American bank loans to the South African Government and to companies it owns. They also set new constraints on American corporate involvement in South Africa. But a Presidential veto is considered possible if the conference report clears both houses. (D1.) **********Johnson Matthey's stock price plunged, as expected, a day after the Bank of England announced that it was taking over the British company's banking and gold trading operations. (D22.) The Economy **********Congress was debating whether to keep the synthetic fuels program alive. A bill under consideration would cut the program's budget, thus satisfying President Reagan. The President had insisted on cuts before he would appoint enough directors so that the concern could operate. (D1.) **********New-home sales fell for the second month in a row, dropping 8.1 percent in August, the Government said. Analysts were pessimistic about chances that sales would improve in coming months. (D21.)  Markets **********Stock prices slipped in active trading.  The Dow Jones industrial average was off 7.62, to 1,191.36, its lowest close since Aug. 2.  Volume increased to 89.4 million shares, from 73.6 million. (D10.) **********The dollar fell sharply in a late selling wave, extending broad declines from earlier in the day. Dealers again cited fears of further central bank intervention. Gold was quoted at $347.40 an ounce in late New York trading, up $2.90 from the previous day. (D20.) Corn and wheat futures prices were higher. (D20.) **********Interest rates on Treasury issues were little changed .  Yields rose, however, in the tax-exempt bond market as a heavy supply of new issues caused prices to fall. (D23.)  Today's Columns **********Most forecasters agree that the economy will grow more slowly next year, although their estimates vary widely. Some believe that by late next year the growth could be so slow as to cause a rise in unemployment. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Time Inc. stock has fluctuated amid recurring rumors that the publishing giant is a takeover target. But none of the rumors can be pinned down, and the company has staggered directors' terms among moves to discourage any suitor. Market Place. (D10.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/14/world.main_headline: PROBLEMS PILE UP FOR MRS. THATCHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/14/world.print_headline: PROBLEMS PILE UP FOR MRS. THATCHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/14/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has been thrown onto the defensive, a year after her re-election, by a series of serious economic and political problems. **********In the last two weeks her Government has had to contend with increases in bank and mortgage rates, a slumping pound and stock market, a worsening strike in the coal mines and a new strike on the docks, a sharp political reversal in the House of Lords, a crisis in Britain's relations with Nigeria and other difficulties. Her opponenents are said to sense a new vulnerability. **********The next general election is at least three years away, and so far Mrs. Thatcher's grip on the Conservative Party, which has an unassailable majority in the House of Commons, remains firm. There is no serious suggestion of a move to replace her as leader. But there is growing unrest among the backbench Tories, one of whom said this week that ''we haven't had any good news for a very long time indeed.'' **********'Paranoid,' Tory Says **********Francis Pym, whom Mrs. Thatcher ousted as Foreign Secretary, said this week that the staff at 10 Downing Street was showing every sign of being ''badly rattled'' and even ''paranoid.'' He would be the natural leader of any Tory revolt, and he recently published a book criticizing Mrs. Thatcher's style of leadership as well as the substance of some of her major economic policies. **********Mr. Pym's comments came in response to a ''background'' statement by one of Mrs. Thatcher's senior aides accusing him of complicity in a plot to undermine the Prime Minister. He denied the accusation, which he termed ''the most extreme kind of invention.'' But the mere fact that he chose to issue a formal rebuttal increased the public impression of serious disarray within the Conservative ranks. **********Behind the exchange between Mr. Pym and the Thatcher camp is a belief that the Government has lost its grip on a wide range of issues. **********That feeling has been fueled by adverse comments in the press, including several publications, like The Times of London and The Economist, which have in the past supported the Prime Minister.   Bad Economic News **********One of the most damaging developments for Mrs. Thatcher has been a spate of bad economic news. The pound has been sliding sharply and now stands at $1.32, near its record low. Stock prices have also been tumbling, losing nearly 8 percent of their value in a week. On Wednesday, the big banks increased their basic lending rate by 2 percent, and today the building societies - the British equivalent of savings and loan associations - raised mortgage rates by 2 1/4 percent. That will inevitably lead to a sharp increase in inflation. **********Taken together in political terms, the developments suggest a lack of confidence. The mortgage rate is a particularly sensitive subject in Britain, because there are no fixed-rate mortgages here; every home buyer will now have to pay considerably more each week. **********Nigel Lawson, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, told an apprehensive House of Commons on Thursday that ''this is in no sense a crisis.'' And Mrs. Thatcher, who was remorselessly heckled by the opposition, insisted that the economy was substantially sound, with output, investment and productivity on the upswing. But she said the same thing on Tuesday, and she was taken seriously neither by M.P.'s nor by the big-money men.   Miners Still on Strike **********One reason for that is the continuing dislocation caused by the miners' strike, which has lasted far longer than the Government ever expected and may now last into the fall and winter. Although episodic negotiations had raised some hope of a settlement, the miners hardened their position this week at a delegate conference. **********The miners' hand has been notably strengthened by a strike of longshoremen belonging to the Transport and General Workers Union. Technically unrelated to the miners' walkout, the dock strike is nonetheless part of an developing pattern of anti-Thatcher militancy. If the dockers stop oil imports, which have been relied upon to replace coal by many power stations, the impact could be considerable. **********Unemployment continues at record levels, and it is especially devastating in the north of England, in heavy industrial regions like Liverpool, Newcastle and here along the River Tees. Although joblessness appeared to cost Mrs. Thatcher little in the election, it is coming to the fore again as an issue as signs of distress develop elsewhere in the economy.   A Setback in House of Lords **********But not all of the Prime Minister's troubles are economic. **********She suffered a devastating defeat earlier this month when the House of Lords refused to accept the Government's bill designed to pave the way for the abolition of the Greater London Council and other metropolitan area councils. The bill provided for the cancelation of elections to the councils next year and the appointment of caretaker bodies in their place, with abolition to follow in 1986. The House of Lords, which seldom defies a Government in such a way, defeated the bill on the ground that it constituted a grievous abuse of democracy. **********Patrick Jenkin, the Environment Secretary, who is responsible for local government, had to withdraw the bill. The plan now is to leave the elected councils in place through 1986, but there are doubts as to whether the abolition bill itself will clear the House of Lords. **********Mr. Jenkin was forced to backtrack a second time by the left-wing council in Liverpool, which threatened to bankrupt the city if the Government did not provide more money. After pledging not to give in to the council's threats, he juggled the complex formulas of central Government aid in such a way that Liverpool gained new resources. The council claimed a great victory; Mr. Jenkin denied it. Many of the Tory backbenchers agreed with the statement of one of their number, Neil Hamilton, who accused the minister of yielding to ''extremists.''  The Nigerian Affair **********Finally, Mrs. Thatcher, who has made much of her determination to stamp out the abuse of diplomatic privelege, has had to suffer through the abduction of Umaru Dikko, a former Nigerian Cabinet minister now living in London. **********Despite denials in Lagos that the Nigerian Government had any part in the episode, the Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffery Howe, decided to expel two Nigerian diplomats and to make it clear that the High Commissioner, or Ambassador, Maj. Gen. Haldu Hananiya, who flew home on Wednesday for consultations, would not be welcomed back. **********The Foreign Office confirmed today that the Nigerians had expelled two British envoys from the British High Commission in Lagos, and the Lagos television said today that Nigeria had asked Britain to recall the High Commissioner. The British Government says it also expects retaliation against British companies, which maintain a huge export trade with Nigeria.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/05/world.main_headline: Argentine Says Britain Has Issued a Proposal
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/05/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Argentine Says Britain Has Issued a Proposal
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/05/world.body_text: **********Argentina's Foreign Minister said Friday that Britain had put forward a proposal for improving relations between the two countries, but denied that secret negotiations were under way. **********The Argentine Foreign Minister, Dante Caputo, said the proposal, received through the Swiss Embassy, suggested lifting commercial restrictions and the possible transfer to Argentina of the bodies of 221 Argentine soldiers who were killed in the fighting for the Falkland Islands in 1982 and are buried there. **********Mr. Caputo spoke about the British proposal in Caracas, Venezuela, where he was a member of the Argentine delegation at the inauguration Thursday of Jaime Lusinchi as President. **********The British Foreign Ministry said Thursday that the two countries began secret consultations through neutral parties shortly after President Raul Alfonsin was inaugurated Dec. 10, with the Swiss Embassy here representing Britain and the Brazilian Embassy in London representing Argentina. **********Mr. Caputo denied such talks were being held but said Argentina ''is willing to use all the means and all the paths necessary in order to begin serious discussion of this subject.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/19/busin.body_text: **********A healthy increase in business travel and stiff resistance to profit- eroding fare wars have led airline industry executives and analysts to predict that 1984 will be a strong year. **********George W. James, senior vice president-economics and finance of the Air Transport Association of America, for example, has recently increased his estimate of 1983 industry operating earnings by about $100 million and is increasingly bullish for this year. He said the industry ended 1983 with operating earnings of about $500 million. In 1982, by contrast, the industry had an operating loss of $733 million. **********For this year, Mr. James said, although discount fares are available ''there are proportionaly more people traveling on full fare and less on discounts.'' Last May, he said, 87 percent of the traffic was on discounts, but by November the amount had dropped to 77 percent and is still declining. **********Wall Street, too, is smiling on the airline industry, at least so far. ''My feeling is that the airline stocks will outperform the market in the near future,'' said Hans Plickert, analyst for E. F. Hutton. ''Their earnings momentum is just so strong that it is not reflected in the prices.'' **********Many analysts, he said, are only now upgrading their forecasts. One reason, he said, is that most had underestimated the strong performance of the AMR Corporation, which owns American Airlines. AMR yesterday reported earnings of $115.6 million for the fourth quarter, up sharply from $3.7 million a year earlier. **********Also the Dow Jones transportation average, reflecting strong prospects for airlines among the other issues that it tracks, hit a high early in January although it has slipped slightly in the last week. **********In any case, the drop in discount traffic has increased industry yields to about 12.5 cents per passenger-mile now from about 12 cents in September. This is generally credited to an upturn in full-fare business travel. **********Russell Ray, senior vice president of marketing for Eastern Airlines, said that travel on its shuttle, a barometer of business travel, had been up during the last two months. **********'Judicious' Discounts Found **********''There has not been the wholesale discounting on fares as in the past,'' he said. ''When we have had discounts, they have been judicious.'' **********He added, however, that most travelers were making their bookings closer to the time they travel, making it difficult for the airline to plan for the future. ''We are planning for a modest increase this year,'' he said. **********Traffic, which strengthened in 1983 as the year progressed, continued to increase through the fourth quarter. It was up 8.8 percent in October from a year before, up 6.6 percent in November and up 5.93 percent in December. **********In future months, analysts noted, the traffic increase figures may look weak, mainly because of inflated figures in the early part of 1983 when traffic was high due to $99 one-way fares in many major markets.  So far the discipline in limiting fare wars has been the biggest pleasant surprise for the airline industry. **********Strength of Economy Cited **********''Last summer everyone was afraid that a big fare war would break out, but it didn't happen,'' said John V. Pincavage, analyst for Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins. ''It didn't happen because the economy was much stronger than anyone thought it was going to be. **********''Then the perception was, 'Gee, when we get into the first quarter we'll have big fare wars.' Well, here we are in the first quarter, and there have been some adjustments, but there have not been any major discounts nationwide. **********''If anything, we are seeing pressure the other way - tighten up discounts and increase restrictions on discount fares.'' **********United Airlines has decided, effective Feb. 1, to increase its discount fares $10 for trips up to 500 miles, $20 for trips up to 1,000 miles and $30 for longer trips. The move is expected to affect about 1,000 markets for United and is supported by T.W.A. and American Airlines. **********Continental's Expansion Plan **********But Continental Air Lines, whose reorganization under bankruptcy laws was upheld in court this week, has announced another major expansion of its system at fares that are lower than those of other airlines. **********Though airlines such as United have matched Continental only selectively, the continued expansion could put greater pressure on other airlines to match the lower fares, which could slow the current recovery for some. **********On the other hand, a recent move by one small carrier, Northeastern Internatioal Airways, to cut one-way fares between New York and Florida - to $75 off-peak and $89 on-peak to Fort Lauderdale, West Palm Beach and Orlando - has so far been ignored by the major carriers. **********If such fare discipline continues, Mr. Pincavage said, the airline industry could show a small operating profit in the first quarter, traditionally one of the airlines' weakest periods. Last year the industry lost $611 million in the first quarter. **********3-Way Basis for Improvement **********Candace Browning, analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, said the combination of an improved economy, cost-cutting labor concessions and lower fuel costs had produced ''a very significant improvement in operating earnings for the industry.'' She noted that fuel prices, which were near $1 a gallon early last year, had declined to about 85 to 90 cents a gallon now. **********She said the industry could have an operating profit of $1.6 billion in 1984. **********Andrew B. Kim, analyst for F. Eberstadt & Companny, was even more upbeat, projecting an operating profit as high as $2 billion. He said he expected a continued drop in fuel costs and continued restraint in fare discounting. **********One worry, he said, is that when labor unions see improvement in the carriers' earnings they may become reluctant to grant concessions and may again ask for large wage increases. **********Airlines Seek More Capacity **********And he cautioned that major airlines plan to add capacity this year, with United going up more than 20 percent and American planning expansion of at least 8 percent. **********Lowell Duncan, Jr, vice president of corporate communications for American, said such expansion could increase pressure to cut prices. American, in addition, is expected to be closely watching the revival of Braniff's operations from its Dallas- Fort Worth hub, which could touch off a round of fare-cutting there. **********Even if conditions remain favorable for the airlines, Mr. James noted, in the last three and a half years the industry had operating losses totaling $2 billion. ''We have quite a hole to come out of,'' he said. **********Airlines need about $3 billion in operating earnings this year just to keep up with the average profit margins of American industry, he said. None of the analysts foresee so high a high figure for the airlines in 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/26/world.body_text: **********The Federal Court of Appeals here heard testimony today on whether the constitutional rights of a United States citizen were violated when his ranch land in Honduras was seized to establish an American-built military base for training soldiers from El Salvador and other Central American countries. **********The landowner, Temistocles Ramirez de Arellano, sought redress earlier through a Federal district court, but his suit was dismissed. **********Last December, a three-member panel of the appeals court upheld the lower court's ruling, reasoning that any move to block United States military involvement in Honduras would interfere with the executive branch's conduct of foreign policy. **********In agreeing to hear Mr. Ramirez's appeal, the court, with 10 of the 11 judges sitting, vacated the panel's ruling. **********At today's hearing, the only one to be held before the court renders its decision, Mark R. Joelson, an attorney representing Mr. Ramirez, argued that the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of State and the Chief Engineer of the United States Army Corps of Engineers had unlawfully expropriated parts of the landowner's 14,000-acre ranch in Colon Province. **********Mr. Ramirez contends that the $13 million cattle ranch and food-packing businesses he built up over two decades are now in ruins.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/18/world.body_text: **********Prominent Indians in the New York metropolitan area have issued an appeal for relief for the victims of the violence that followed the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. **********At the same time, the leaders, who are mainly Hindus, have begun a new movement called People for United India with the aim of preserving ''the longstanding bond of brotherhood and harmony'' between the Sikhs and Hindus of North America. **********''Our short-term goal is to pool our resources and support any relief effort for the victims of the violence in India,'' a leader of the new movement, Varinder Bhalla, said last week. ''Our common long-term agenda is to work for a united India.'' **********Members of the Sikh community welcomed the new relief drive. But they reacted cautiously to the proposal for People for United India. In the wake of the Indian Army's invasion of the Sikh's Golden Temple last June, there has been a strong move among Sikhs worldwide in favor of an independent Sikh state to be called Khalistan. **********''You must understand our skepticism when they talk about Hindu-Sikh unity and do not address the Sikh demands for basic human rights and genuine autonomy,'' Dr. Gurcharan Singh, leader of the Sikh Heritage Institute, declared. **********The new movement for better relations between Hindus and Sikhs was initiated by two mainly Hindu organizations, the Association of Indians in America, the oldest ethnic group of its kind with chapters in 41 states, and the Federation of Indian Associations, which is composed of 61 smaller groups. **********Representatives of these organizations first met to hold memorial services for Mrs. Gandhi in Central Park and have since decided that there was the need for a formal organization. There are said to be between 100,000 and 150,000 Indians in the tristate area, including about 16,000 Sikhs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/17/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve's senior policy-making body meets this week to set money- supply targets for the next eight weeks against a backdrop of renewed prodding by the Reagan Administration to drive interest rates down. **********The Fed's Open Market Committee has eased its grip on the nation's money supply since last summer and interest rates have come down significantly, but only last week Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said the Fed had not done enough. **********Mr. Regan's comments, which included a suggestion for bringing the Federal Reserve under Administration control, came before Thursday's report that the M-1 measure of the money supply fell a whopping $7.1 billion in the week ended Dec. 3. **********Pressure Put on Volcker **********Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and an object of Mr. Regan's criticism more than once in the last four years, has acknowledged in recent weeks that inflation was a diminished problem. He is being pushed from all sides to loosen the money supply further. **********In addition to Mr. Regan, two of Mr. Volcker's colleagues on the Federal Reserve Board - Preston Martin, the vice chairman, and Martha Seger, the newest member, both Reagan appointees - have implied in recent speeches that the central bank could be less restrictive. **********The Volcker-led majority on the board has been reluctant to take such a step. But Mr. Martin, Miss Seger and some officials in the Reagan Administration suggest this approach accepts too large a risk of choking off economic expansion. **********Decision-Making Difficult **********Analysts agree that the recent mix of economic news makes the Fed's decision on the money supply unusually difficult. **********Moreover, some people wonder why the money supply has failed to grow even as the Fed has clearly moved to prevent the economy from sliding into a decline. **********The Fed and its defenders assert that critics such as Mr. Regan fail to appreciate how hard it is to know just where the economy stands at a given moment and they also cite the still imperfectly understood interaction, including the time lags, between money and the economy. **********''The simple fact is that it's Monday morning quarterbacking,'' asserted David M. Jones, a money market specialist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. ''It's a reactive process,'' he added, changing the metaphor, ''like a doctor diagnosing a patient.'' **********And, many analysts say, fears that the Federal Reserve will misread what is happening or overreact to it creates uncertainty in the markets that complicates the Fed's task. **********'Cross-Currents' in Data **********In any case, Elliott Platt, senior vice president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., asserted that ''the Fed at the moment has a very difficult judgment call.'' Citing the recent economic reports, he said, ''What I see is a tremendous number of cross-currents in the data.'' **********The present business expansion, now 24 months old, has rapidly slowed from its 8.6 percent growth rate in the first half of 1984, and some analysts think growth in the current quarter will be even less than the third quarter's 1.9 percent rate. **********Initial claims for state unemployment insurance jumped in the latest week, industrial production is below its August level and the Government's index of leading indicators fell in three of the past five months. **********Yet there is also substantial evidence that the economy may soon rebound. Unemployment has fallen to 7 percent, and last week's report of a 1.8 percent gain in retail sales, although not assuring a strong Christmas shopping season, was buoyant. **********Last Spring's Tightening **********Although it is often hard to characterize Federal Reserve policy with assurance - the central bank itself couches its pronouncements in arcane and opaque generalizations - there is little doubt that a tightening move that raised interest rates last spring had an important effect in the second-half economic slowdown. **********Money growth as measured by M-1 (the narrowest but probably most significant gauge since it counts only currency, checking accounts and other easily spendable money) has barely grown in four months. M-1 now stands at $547.1 billion, compared with $546.5 in mid-July. **********Since about Labor Day, however, the Fed has taken a number of modest steps toward easing the money supply. It twice reduced the target for borrowings at its discount window by financial institutions, and the day before Thanksgiving it cut the discount rate by a half-point, to 8 1/2 percent. Then, late last week it allowed the Federal funds rate, the rate for overnight loans between banks, to trade freely below that level. **********But even when the Fed decides it wants to promote money supply growth - thereby presumably lowering interest rates and stimulating economic activity - it has relatively little short-term control over the amount of increase or its timing. **********Delayed Effect of Moves **********When borrowers won't borrow, the Fed's frustrations are sometimes analogous to pushing on a string. **********On some occasions, when the effect of its actions has been delayed, the Fed has been compared to a little boy dragging a brick with a large rubber band. The brick, which at first does not budge, suddenly flies forward and cracks him in the shin. **********As Paul Meek, monetary adviser to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has described the process: ''Monetary growth reflects continuing interaction between the central bank, financial institutions, the money market and bank depositors. The Federal Reserve can govern the pace at which the trading desk supplies reserves to depository institutions, but bank customers determine, by and large, how much money they want to hold and in what form.'' **********In the United States, as in most other countries, commercial banks create money with the stroke of a pen or the punch of a computer key. When a bank approves a loan, it simply credits the borrower's account, while setting aside a small required percentage of the amount as a reserve. **********Potential Borrowers' Role **********The Fed can make it more or less attractive for a bank to make loans, but in the end whether money is created depends mainly on whether potential borrowers find the interest rate attractive in a given economic environment. Autumn's easing is now producing stronger money growth. **********All three of the basic money supply measures, M-1 and the broader M-2 and M-3, advanced smartly in November, and interest rates have continued to decline. M-2 is now in the middle of its 1984 target range of 6 to 9 percent growth. M-3, with the same target, shows an above-range growth rate of 10 percent. **********Several analysts predict that M-1, which remains near the bottom of its 4 to 8 percent growth target, will show a gain of as much as $5 billion when the results for the week of Dec. 10 are reported Thursday. **********Week-to-week movements can be misleading, analysts say.The figures, moreover, may change for reasons that are noneconomic.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/08/world.main_headline: BONN LIMITS EXPORT OF CHEMICAL-ARMS MATERIALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/08/world.print_headline: BONN LIMITS EXPORT OF CHEMICAL-ARMS MATERIALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/08/world.body_text: **********West Germany agreed today to restrict the export of chemical manufacturing equipment that can be used to make chemical weapons, the Government announced. **********It was not clear when the restrictions would take effect. The announcement came as the Government continued an investigation into reports that Iraq bought equipment from West German companies capable of producing nerve gas and other chemical weapons. **********Last March, American intelligence officials said they had evidence that Iraq had used nerve gas in its war with Iran and that a West German company had sold Iraq laboratory equipment that was believed to be linked to Iraqi plans for nerve gas production. **********The company, Karl Kolb, which is situated outside Frankfurt, said it was constructing a $1.1 million laboratory to be used in the manufacture of pesticides at a site 40 miles west of Baghdad, in Iraq, but denied that the laboratory was intended to produce chemical weapons.   Export Licenses Required **********Under the ruling announced today, Government export licenses would be required of companies seeking to export equipment worth more than $10,000 for the ''research, manufacture, processing or testing'' of toxic chemical compounds to countries outside the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. **********The Ministry for Economic Affairs, in what officials said was a reference to the war between Iran and Iraq, said in a statement that the ''danger of such weapons being used has increased significantly in the recent past.'' **********It said the export curbs followed ''recognition of the fact that, in some cases, plant and equipment can be adapted to processes for making chemcial weapons.'' **********In July, the Bonn Government announced that, at the request of the United States, it was looking into reports that Iraq was purchasing equipment from West Germany capable of producing chemical weapons.   Report in Der Spiegel **********That announcement was prompted by a report in the news magazine Der Spiegel stating that American specialists believed the plant being built by Karl Kolb and an associated company, Pilot Plant, could be modified to produce nerve gas. The magazine said the Bonn Government had sought unsuccessfully to convince Karl Kolb to withdraw from the project. **********A Karl Kolb executive said the company had not examined the new restrictions, but it assumed that further deliveries of parts for the plant, which he described as for use in testing pesticides, would be subject to Government licensing. **********He said the company was engaged in ''intense discussions'' with the West German and Iraqi governments to allow German officials to inspect the construction site. The Government spokesman, Peter Boenisch, said on Monday that Iraq had until now refused permission for an on-site inspection by West German officials, but the company executive said that talks were continuing. **********Last April, West Germany joined Britain, Denmark, Belgium and the Netherlands in restricting the export of chemicals that can be used to manufacture chemical weapons, after a United Nations report said an investigative team found traces of nerve gas and mustard gas while inspecting battle sites. **********Bonn has renounced the making of chemical weapons and has pressed recently for an international treaty banning their production. The Government is particularly sensitive to charges that chemical weapons might emanate from West Germany because of Germany's involvement in developing and using the first poison gases during World War I.

Woolworth Company said it considered the purchase of one million shares of its stock by the Rapid-American Corporation an investment. **********Wall Street executives, however, have said they believe Rapid-American may continue to accumulate shares in preparation for a takeover. Rapid-American executives did not return telephone calls. Woolworth stock continued active yesterday, closing at $36, off 12 1/2 cents. **********Separately, in a 10-K filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Rapid-American said the value of its marketable securities had risen in the fiscal year 1984, ended Jan. 31, to $49.9 million, up from $14.1 million in 1983 and from $10.9 million in 1982. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/12/busin.main_headline: Bank of New York Net Is Up 20.6%
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/12/busin.print_headline: Bank of New York Net Is Up 20.6%
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/12/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of New York Company reported yesterday that second-quarter net income rose 20.6 percent, to $26.3 million, from $21.8 million in the period a year earlier. On a per-share basis, net rose 17 percent, to $1.58, from $1.35. **********''It's a healthy gain,'' said James J. McDermott Jr., senior vice president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm that specializes in bank stocks. **********Part of the strength reflected a $19 million net gain from the sale of 29 branches in upstate New York. After taxes and other technical adjustments, the bottom- line gain from the sale was a little more than $13 million, the bank said. **********But the extraordinary gain was used largely to increase the bank's loan-loss reserve, to 1.28 percent of total loans as of June 30, from 0.94 percent a year earlier. This brought the loan-loss reserve to $111.1 million, from $82 million. Actual charge-offs in the latest quarter amounted to $14.2 million, well below the loan-loss provision, but up from $9.8 million in the second quarter of 1983. **********Bank of New York's problem loans dropped a bit from midyear 1983 - to $269.9 million from $286.5 million - and represented 3.1 percent of its total loans. The bank said that none of its $58.4 million of loans to Argentina were in the nonaccrual status, meaning that payments on all its loans to Argentina were made within 90 days of the due date and the bank may continue attributing to its income the interest due on these loans, even if it is uncollected.
