https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/26/world.main_headline: SOMALI JET HIJACKERS SET A NEW DEADLINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/26/world.print_headline: SOMALI JET HIJACKERS SET A NEW DEADLINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/26/world.body_text: **********Three hijackers holding 108 hostages aboard a Somali Airlines plane here tonight set a new deadline for Somalia to free a group of political prisoners. Otherwise, they said, they will blow up the plane. **********It was the third time the hijackers had postponed their deadline since they commandeered the Boeing 707 Saturday as it flew from Mogadishu, the capital of neighboring Somalia, to Jidda, Saudi Arabia. **********The hijackers told Ethiopian officials of their decision soon after the Somali Government issued a statement in Mogadishu rejecting the demands for the present but asking for more time to consider them. **********The hijackers, said to be three Somali soldiers, have threatened to blow up the plane and kill all 108 people aboard if Somalia does not release 21 political prisoners, including seven youths the hijackers say are scheduled to be hanged for anti- Government activities, as well as a former Vice President, five former Cabinet Ministers and two army colonels. **********The Somali Government said no executions had been scheduled for today. Although the Somali statement rejected the hijackers' demands, it added that ''no executions are envisaged.''  'Extremely Outraged' **********Ethiopia's Foreign Minister, Lieut. Col. Goshu Wolde, said the hijackers were ''extremely furious, extremely outraged'' over the Somali statement rejecting their demands. **********But according to a spokesman for the Ethiopian Foreign Ministry, the hijackers ''reluctantly consented'' to extend the deadline until noon Monday (4 A.M. New York time). **********There is one American aboard the plane, but United States Embassy officials have declined to identify him. The plane originally carried 130 passengers and crew, but 22 people - 15 women, 4 children and 3 crew members - were freed at the airport Saturday. **********Colonel Goshu said the hijackers were led by a Somali Army officer, Capt. Awil Adnan Bourhan, and were armed with pistols and explosives. **********The hijackers initially said they would blow the plane up at midnight Saturday if their demands were not met. That deadline was later extended until noon today. Eight minutes before that deadline, they agreed to give Somalia another 12 hours in response to a Somali request for more time to consider the demands. **********The third postponement came 10 minutes before the midnight deadline. **********The plane arrived at Bole International Airport here Saturday after being refused permission to land at Aden, Southern Yemen.   Joined by 2 Passengers **********Colonel Goshu said the three hijackers had been joined by at least two passengers who were said to be sympathetic to their goals. **********This afternoon Somalia issued a statement saying the release of the political prisoners ''cannot be accepted because to do so would be tantamount to submitting to terrorist threats which would encourage terrorism throughout the world.'' The Somali Government also said it would hold Ethiopian authorities responsible for the hostages' safety. **********Pro-Soviet Ethiopia and pro-Western Somalia fought a border war in 1977 over the Ogaden region and now have no direct diplomatic relations. Communications between the two are being conducted through the Italian Embassy, which sends them via Rome. **********Western diplomats say the Ethiopian Government has supported Somali rebels and the Somali Government has backed Ethiopian rebels. **********One crew member, a security guard, was wounded in the midair shootout that led to the takeover of the plane. The hijackers also reportedly beat the pilot, and the co-pilot fell ill. **********The passengers released Saturday were shown on Ethiopian television and were reportedly put into the care of the Ethiopian Red Cross. Foreign journalists were not permitted to speak with them. The Foreign Minister said they were all well. **********The Ethiopian Government has delivered food and provisions to the 108 passengers still on the plane and Colonel Goshu said he believed the hostages were in good condition. **********The hijacked jet, parked just off the runway about 400 yards from the main terminal, is being guarded by Ethiopian soldiers and armored vehicles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/26/world.main_headline: PERSIAN GULF TANKER HIT BY MISSILE IS SAVED FROM SINKING BY TUGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/26/world.print_headline: PERSIAN GULF TANKER HIT BY MISSILE IS SAVED FROM SINKING BY TUGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/26/world.body_text: **********Firefighters today reportedly brought a blaze on a Cypriot tanker in the Persian Gulf under control. The ship was hit by a missile Friday. **********Gulf shipping officials said the quick response of salvage tugs to the 31,280- ton Amethyst's distress call prevented the ship from sinking. But, they added, the vessel was still listing and was low in the water. The tanker was to be towed to the Iranian coast ''at Iran's insistence.'' **********The tanker was attacked six hours after it sailed with 50,000 tons of crude oil from the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island. **********A military spokesman in Baghdad announced Friday that Iraqi warplanes had scored an effective hit on a ''large naval target.'' He reported that attack to have taken place at the same time the distress signals from the Cypriot tanker were picked up by shipping companies that monitor tank movements in the gulf. **********The captain of the vessel, in his distress signals, reported a fire raging aboard his vessel and requested helicopters to rescue his crew. **********Iranian Navy helicopters hoisted the crew members from the sea, but one man, identified as Socrates Mesabeella, was reported missing. His nationality was not given. **********The Amethyst was the 40th merchant vessel to be damaged this year in the so-called tanker war that Iraq began last February to choke off Iranian oil revenues that help pay for the Iranian war effort. It was the 83d merchant vessel to be hit since the Iran- Iraq war broke out in September 1980. **********Iraq declared a 57-mile exclusion zone around the Kharg terminal. **********The Iranians retaliated by attacking vessels in the lower gulf shipping lanes, but most of the damaged tankers were attacked by Iraq.   Arab Officials to Discuss War **********BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 25 (Reuters) - Foreign Ministers of seven Arab countries are to meet here Sunday to discuss the latest moves in the Iran- Iraq war and possible ways to end the conflict. **********Ministers from Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Jordan, Morocco, Yemen and Tunisia are to draw up what the official Iraqi press agency described as a new plan to rally world efforts ''in the face of Iranian intransigence.'' **********The ministers meeting here are all members of a committee set up by an emergency Arab foreign ministers' session in the Iraqi capital in March. The Secretary General of the Arab League, Chedli Klibi of Tunisia, will attend the talks. **********Iraq has said it is willing to negotiate terms for peace, but Teheran has rejected all mediation attempts. **********Iran has demanded that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq be replaced as a condition for negotiations. **********Iran has massed thousands of troops on the southern sector of the gulf war front, but there has been no new push. First Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan of Iraq said today that Iran's leaders had delayed the offensive for fear of huge casualties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/23/world.main_headline: ARCHBISHOP OF MANILA TO VISIT CHINA TO 'PROMOTE HARMONY'
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/23/world.print_headline: ARCHBISHOP OF MANILA TO VISIT CHINA TO 'PROMOTE HARMONY'
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/23/world.body_text: **********Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, said in New York last week that he planned to visit China next month to ''promote harmony and understanding.'' **********Cardinal Sin said the invitation, extended by the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, could help build bridges between the church and the Communist Government. **********''In our Christian beliefs, we should love Communists though hate Communism,'' he said in an interview at Manhattan College. ''Love is a many splendored thing. Let's see what love can do. We cannot just be promoters of hatred.'' **********The 56-year-old leader of 40 million Roman Catholics in the Philippines received an honorary degree from Manhattan College on Friday and was scheduled to take part in several church and cultural events before returning to Manila tomorrow. **********He said he planned to begin an 11-day trip to China on Oct. 27. He would be the highest-ranking Roman Catholic Church official to visit that country in four years. The Cardinal's father was a Chinese shopkeeper from Xiamen, also known as Amoy, which Cardinal Sin last saw at the age of 6. He expects to return there on his visit. **********The Catholic Church in China broke relations with the Vatican in 1957, refusing to accept the authority of the Pope. Cardinal Sin said he felt a responsibility to visit the estimated six million Chinese Catholics but that his main purpose would be to ''be a bridge'' to all Chinese. **********The Cardinal said he expected to meet with Chinese officials. **********As a leading opponent of the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, Cardinal Sin said his experience in church-state diplomacy has led him to some conclusions that might apply to the United States, where a heated discussion of religion and politics has arisen in the Presidential campaign. **********''Separation of church and state is like a railroad track,'' the Cardinal said. ''Both government and church serve the same people on different rails. If the rails are too close, you'll have a derailment. The same is true if they are too far apart. Separation should not be isolation.'' **********Advising the church in America to avoid backing either major party, he said, ''When there is union of church and state and abuses are committed, the abuses are relegated to the church.'' **********''The moment the church marries the state, the church becomes a widow in the next generation,'' the Cardinal said. **********MAKEUP: Last 2 grafs can bite as needed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/30/busin.body_text: **********The Whitney Holding Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire NBC Bancshares Inc. for $85 a share. **********Based on NBC's 656,615 shares outstanding, the deal would be valued at $55.8 million. Whitney is the parent company of the Whitney National Bank of New Orleans. The National Bank of Commerce in Jefferson Parish, an NBC subsidiary, has assets of $382 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/04/busin.body_text: **********FRIDAY, MAY 4, 1984 **********Companies **********Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts bid $2.3 billion for Esmark, which did not immediately respond to the offer, apparently because it is waiting for a better offer. The bid by the New York investment house, $55 a share, pushed Esmark shares up $12.75, to $57.625, in heavy trading. One reason the market price shot past the offered price is that other companies may enter the bidding. (Page D1.) **********A.G. Becker is to get an infusion of capital from Paribas, the nationalized French bank that is the main shareholder. Paribas has also proposed a buyout to give it complete control. (D1.) **********Blue Bell is holding talks about a $50-a-share leveraged buyout headed by Kelso, an investment firm. In response, the apparel company's stock jumped $8.125, to $49.75. (D4.) **********Occidental Petroleum earnings rose fivefold in the first quarter despite a 20.4 percent decline in sales; the 1983 data had included several special charges. General Dynamics had a 36.4 percent gain in profits and American Can rose 37.2 percent. (D5.) **********The S.E.C. case against Carter Hawley Hale begins today.  At issue is the measures it used to thwart a takeover bid. (D5.) **********The Economy **********Bowing to pressure to cut the deficit, the Defense Department offered reductions in the military budget totaling $13.9 billion in the year beginning Oct. 1. That would permit the military budget to grow only 7.8 percent next year. (A1.) **********Sales of new cars made in the U.S. rose 36.6 percent in the last 10 days of April from a year earlier, bringing the annual selling rate for the month to 8.1 million, in line with analysts' projections. (D1.)  The big retail chains reported higher revenues in April, thanks to strong Easter sales. The combined figures for March and April, however, drew a mixed reaction on Wall Street. (D4.) **********The I.R.S. has proposed eliminating a fringe benefit plan that allows workers to use pretax wages to pay for a variety of child care and other personal expenses and take back the unused portion in cash. As many as 3 million workers may use such plans. (D1.) **********The U.S. Synthetic Fuels Corporation has asked the Justice Department to consider criminal charges against its former president, Victor M. Thompson Jr., for asking an oilman who was seeking Federal subsidies to invest in his bank. (D2.) **********International **********The Reagan Administration will support a top French diplomat for the key international economic post of Secretary General of the O.E.C.D., diplomatic sources say. (D2.) **********Markets **********The stock market lost some of its enthusiasm.  A drop in the Dow Jones industrial average of 5.03 points, to 1,181.53, ended a two- day rally. Volume faded to 91.9 million shares. (D6.) **********The money supply fell $3.6 billion, but credit markets did not register the favorable reaction that might have been expected. The price of the Government's long-term bellwether bond dropped, and rates on Treasury bills inched upward. (D15.) Assets of money market funds fell by a sharp $1.24 billion. (D6.) **********The dollar declined broadly in U.S. trading. Gold prices  rose, with the late quote in New York at $378.25 an ounce, up 25 cents. (D14.) Cotton futures for long-term delivery rose to their life-of-contract highs. (D14.) **********Bear, Stearns said it was not involved in options trading on the Chicago Board Options Exchange on April 19, when a number of traders lost thousands of dollars after the S.& P. 100 index moved up unexpectedly late in the day. (D14.) **********Today's Columns **********Time is running out on the ability of the commercial banks to roll over the short-term debt of debtor countries; one expert thinks some major banks are threatened with insolvency. The Federal Reserve of New York has organized a star-studded three-day conference, beginning Sunday, that will search for ways to deal with the international debt crisis. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********T. Rowe Price New Horizons Fund is sticking to its strategy despite the pounding it has taken since mid-1983. The nation's largest mutual fund investing in emerging growth companies feels much risk has been wrung out of the issues. Market Place. (D6.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/10/busin.body_text: **********William G. Patterson, the freewheeling Penn Square Bank officer who became known for wearing Mickey Mouse ears to the bank and drinking liquor from his shoe, goes on trial here Monday on charges of violating Federal bank laws. **********Mr. Patterson, 34 years old, was senior executive vice president of Penn Square and chief of its energy lending division. **********Between 1980 and July 5, 1982, when Penn Square was declared insolvent and closed by regulators, Mr. Patterson's department generated about $2 billion in oil and gas loans at high interest rates and sold most of them to larger banks. **********Loans Soured **********Those loans soured when oil and gas prices plummeted in the spring of 1982, taking the value of the collateral with them. The resulting staggering loan losses brought Seattle's First National Bank and the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago to the brink of collapse. Continental Illinois had purchased more than $1 billion of Penn Square's loans. **********The charges, contained in a 34- count Federal indictment, accuse Mr. Patterson of wire fraud, misapplication of bank funds and making false entries in bank records in an effort to conceal dangerous lending practices and the bank's condition from other banks and Federal examiners. **********Most of the charges relate to several deals in which Mr. Patterson is accused of making loans to customers without their knowledge or permission, then using the proceeds to pay the bad debts of other customers. **********Nine Counts May Be Dropped **********The prosecutor, William S. Price, confirmed Friday that he plans to ask United States District Judge Lee West to approve dropping nine counts from the indictment. **********The Government has subpoenaed 130 witnesses, about half of whom are expected to be used in the trial, which is expected to last a month. The only clue to the defense came more than a year ago in a civil hearing in which the defense attorney, Burck Bailey, characterized his client as the tool of the bank's board chairman, Bill P. Jennings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/03/world.main_headline: AIR AUTHORITIES SAY HIJACKERS CAN EVADE TIGHEST SECURITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/03/world.print_headline: AIR AUTHORITIES SAY HIJACKERS CAN EVADE TIGHEST SECURITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/03/world.body_text: **********Airline and airport officials said today that the hijackers who forced an Air France flight to land in Teheran had a variety of ways to bring weapons and explosives aboard the plane. **********The officials said the incident, which ended today with the release of all the plane's passengers unharmed despite an explosion in the cockpit, demonstrated the fallibility of even the tightest security measures. **********The flight originated in Frankfurt, whose airport is regarded by aviation specialists as having some of the strictest security procedures in the world. Tonight, West German aviation officials said it was still not clear that the men had actually brought their weapons aboard at Frankfurt. **********One theorized that some of the weapons or explosives might have come aboard only after the plane landed in Iran. Another said they might have been put on the plane before it arrived in Frankfurt.   Plastic Explosives Cited **********Several officials, however, said explosives could be sneaked past the X-ray machines that examine hand luggage. These machines, effective against metal guns, can often be fooled by devices such as plastic bombs, they said. **********In addition, hijackers have been known to have confederates who can get aboard planes before they take off by holding maintanance jobs with airlines or airports. These agents can then plant grenades, guns or explosives. **********Information was fragmentary tonight as to what weapons and explosive devices the three hijackers had. **********Initial reports said the men were armed with grenades and knives. But Jonathan Shingleton, a passenger who was interviewed in Teheran after he was released, said the hijackers appeared today with submachine guns, explosives and .45-caliber handguns. Previously, he said, they had had only small explosives. ''This made a totally different ballgame,'' he said. **********Airline officials in Germany, who pride themselves on the security at Frankfurt, offered a variety of theories as to how the men might have carried out the hijacking. **********Klaus Hanicke, director of international relations and security at Lufthansa, said plastic explosives ''can be brought on in very small portions and can then be put together on board.''  Devices Can Be Disguised **********He said such explosives could be easily disguised so a security officer looking at an X-ray of a carry-on bag could be fooled. ''If they were explosives in the shape of a piece of soap or a puppet or a shoe, they might not be noticed,'' he said. ''You can have explosives in the shape of the normal things that people carry in their hand baggage.'' **********An American aviation official here said, ''Explosives are very difficult to detect, if not close to impossible.'' **********Hannsrainer Otto, a spokesman for the Frankfurt Airport, emphasized that it was still not clear if the men brought anything on at Frankfurt.  ''The investigations have not been closed,'' he said. ''We don't know if the explosives were brought on at Frankfurt or somewhere else. Perhaps they had been put on in Paris already. Perhaps they were brought in in Teheran.'' **********But both Mr. Otto and Mr. Hanicke acknowledged that even at Frankfurt, security procedures cannot be entirely certain. ''As a rule, you can say that at an airport where there are 70,000 passengers a day, despite strong controls you will have the possibility of getting something on board,'' Mr. Otto said.   Even Low-Level Workers Checked **********Officials said the possibility that confederates had planted the explosives or guns on the plane could not be ruled out, though Mr. Hanicke said even low- level airport and airline workers were given thorough security checks. ''They are more than 100 percent checked, especially in Europe and North America,'' he said. But he added that the checking of airport personnel was less strict elsewhere. **********The French state television tonight speculated that elements of the Iranian Government might have been in league with the hijackers, though the network was careful not to suggest that the Government had actually assisted them. France is giving substantial assistance to Iraq in its war with Iran, and French-Iranian relations are poor. **********But Frankfurt Airport officials said there were no Iranian planes at the airport on Tuesday, when the Frankfurt- to-Paris plane was hijacked. **********Officials in Washington suggested that the hijackers might have flown in from an airport where security was relatively lax, waited in a transit area and then boarded the Paris flight. But a Frankfurt Airport spokesman said tonight that even if the men had waited in a transit area, they would still have had to pass through a seperate metal detector at the gate before boarding. **********This would also appear to rule out the possibility, which exists at some airports, that the hijackers met someone in the transit area who had carried in weapons by flying from an airport with weak security.   Unable to Block All Hijackings **********Tom Ashwood, first vice president of the Air Line Pilots Association in charge of security, said ''the most likely scenario'' was that the weapons had been brought on the plane somewhere other than Frankfurt. **********But he added that even the strictest security measures were unlikely to prevent all hijackings. **********''How come convicts escape from maximum security jails? How do Brinks holdups occur? Why do you get leaks out of Joint Chiefs of Staffs meetings?'' he asked. ''No matter how much money you spend, no matter how secure you are, you still have the human factor, and with human error, there's always the possibility of a breach. **********''Of course hijackings are dramatic,'' he went on. ''But that has to be measured against the literally hundreds of thousands of successful detections of weapons over the history of the introduction of security.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/14/world.main_headline: SOVIET ANNOUNCES OWN DEPLOYMENT OF CRUISE MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/14/world.print_headline: SOVIET ANNOUNCES OWN DEPLOYMENT OF CRUISE MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/14/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Defense Ministry announced today that it had begun deploying long-range cruise missiles on bombers and submarines. **********It said the move was in response to the deployment of such weapons by the United States. **********( In Washington, the State Department said it was not surprised by the announcement and called for renewed arms talks. Page 22.) **********The Soviet announcement said: **********''Along with deploying ground- launched cruise missiles in Western Europe, the United States is mounting long-range cruise missiles on strategic bombers. From the middle of this year, it has been installing such missiles also on surface ships and submarines of the United States Navy. ''The Soviet Union has warned on more than one occasion that it will not allow the existing equilibrium to be upset and will adopt adequate counter- measures.'' Pentagon Announcement in June **********In late June the Pentagon announced that long-range cruise missiles, known as Tomahawks, were being deployed on United States Navy ships. **********A month later the Soviet newspaper Pravda said: **********''The United States is mistaken, fundamentally mistaken, on a most important point. Its plans to achieve superiority over the Soviet Union, including the field of long-range cruise missiles, are not only dangerous, but illusory.'' **********The cruise missile is an unpiloted drone that can be programmed by computer to follow the surface terrain of the earth to a target after being launched from land, sea or air. **********The United States' deployment of sea-based cruise missiles was a subject of debate in Congress last summer. Opponents of deployment said the missiles made arms control difficult because nuclear and conventional versions cannot be readily distinguished so that any treaty curbs on the nuclear version cannot be verified. **********The nuclear version of the Tomahawk can reportedly carry a warhead with the explosive power of 200,000 tons of TNT to within 300 feet of a target 1,500 miles away. **********The Soviet announcement today said: **********''The armed forces of the U.S.S.R. have begun to deploy long-range cruise missiles on strategic bombers and submarines. In scope, these measures correspond to the growing threat to the security of the U.S.S.R. and other countries of the socialist community from the United States.'' **********The Soviet Union has stressed in recent statements that it will not permit the United States to attempt to gain military superiority. **********At a briefing on Friday, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vladimir B. Lomeiko, said: **********''The Soviet Union does not want military superiority, but it will not allow any superiority over itself. The Soviet Union will do everything it can to insure military equality between itself and the United States.'' **********Diplomats said they saw the Defense Ministry announcement as falling into line with that position. **********The format of today's announcement follows those of previous statements, including one in August announcing countermeasures to the deployment of medium-range missiles, including cruise missiles, in Western Europe. **********The announcement today said: **********''The United States, trying to achieve military superiority over the Soviet Union, continues a crash fulfillment of large-scale programs for developing and deploying new nuclear arms. It attaches great significance to carrying out a massive deployment of long- range cruise missiles of all basing modes.'' **********Air-based cruise missiles were part of a weapons ceiling set in the strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979. Although that treaty has not been ratified, the two nations have said that they are adhering to its provisions. The treaty also placed a three-year moratorium on the deployment of ground- based and sea-launched cruise missiles. The United States interprets that provision as having lapsed. **********In late 1983, the Atlantic alliance began deploying the first of 464 ground- launched cruise missiles in Western Europe, along with 108 Pershing 2 ballistic missiles. **********The deployment led to a Soviet walkout from negotiations in Geneva on both medium-range and strategic, or intercontinental-range, weapons. The Russians say they will not return until the new American missiles are removed from Western Europe. **********On Aug. 25, the Soviet Defense Ministry announced that it was testing its own ground-launched cruise missiles. **********The United States has said its cruise missiles and Pershing 2 deployments in Western Europe are a response to the Soviet deployment of SS-20 medium- range missiles threatening Western Europe. The Soviet Union contends that there was a rough balance and that the new missiles are an attempt to gain military superiority for the West.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/11/busin.body_text: **********News   Analysis **********LONDON, June 10 - What are likely to be the economic consequences of the just-concluded summit conference of the seven leaders of the major industrial countries? **********There were two main issues when this conference began.  One was whether the United States could be moved to a greater sense of urgency and commitment on reducing the huge budget deficits that the six other governments here criticized as a fundamental cause of high and rising real interest rates and, hence, as a threat to world economic recovery. **********The second was what the seven richest countries would do to ward off an international debt crisis - a danger that has been exacerbated by rising interest rates. **********On the first issue, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan stubbornly held to the Reagan Administration's line that no connection had been proved to exist between rising budget deficits and rising interest rates. Mr. Regan held to this line despite protests from such quarters as Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, who contended that the American position was ''simple-minded.'' **********Going Easy on Reagan **********But Mr. Lawson's boss, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, refused to put President Reagan ''in the dock,'' as the British phrased it, in an election year. Nor were the other summit countries prepared, when the showdown over the conference's final communique came, to specifically criticize American fiscal policies. **********They settled for - as, indeed, the United States was glad to settle for - the bland statement that ''prudent monetary and budgetary policies of the kind that have brought us so far will have to be sustained and, where necessary, strengthened.'' **********The conference's budget plank, in its ultimate form, was definitely Reaganite: ''Not the least of our concerns is the growing strain of public expenditure in all our countries,'' it said. ''Public expenditure has to be kept within the limits of what our national economies can afford.'' **********Mr. Reagan made clear that, in his interpretation, budget-cutting was desirable if it involved cutting public spending - but not if it meant raising taxes. And the other countries were willing to take his assurances about a ''down payment'' of deficit-shrinking measures before the November election as an implied promise that there would be further action to shrink the looming deficits after the election. **********Anxieties Over Policy **********But this is a familiar story, if not to the foreign heads of government and state, then to the securities markets that continue to be plagued by anxieties over the Administration's fiscal and monetary policies. **********In mid-1984, the United States economy is in something approaching a full-fledged boom. Real gross national product expanded at an annual rate of 8.8 percent in the first quarter of this year and has continued to grow rapidly in the current quarter, although the pace has slowed considerably. Bottlenecks are starting to turn up in some industrial sectors. Inflation is starting to edge higher. **********In the view of the Administration's critics, tougher monetary and fiscal policies are necessary if the expansion is to be moderated to a sustainable pace. But the Administration has, as Secretary Regan conceded in a news conference here, pursued an ''open mouth'' policy aimed at persuading the Fed not to tighten money so much in an election year. **********Down-Payment Package **********Even if the Administration's ''down payment'' package is enacted by Congress, as it probably will be, the Federal budget would still be running deficits close to $200 billion a year for the next three years. **********The Administration continues to regard the implications of such policies for interest rates with equanimity. Secretary Regan, declaring that the Treasury could find no linkage between budget deficits and rates either in its own or other studies, called on anyone who knew of studies demonstrating such a link to send them to the Treasury. **********He brushed aside the 1984 annual report of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, headed by Martin S. Feldstein, as ''not a study.'' **********New Study on Deficit Impact **********However, a new study, ''Deficits, Borrowing and Crowding Out,'' by David T. King, regional treasurer and senior economist of Citicorp, concludes that funding huge budget deficits while the private economy is trying to expand strongly will have two principal effects: **********- First, the rate-sensitive household sector will be ''crowded out'' of the market for funds, and the resulting decrease in purchases of homes, automobiles and other durable goods will slow economic growth. **********- Second, large foreign capital flows into United States money markets will continue to raise the value of the dollar, reduce the international competitiveness of American goods and services and expose the economy to the instability of international currency markets. **********The study, published by the National Planning Association, a private research and policy group based in Washington, concludes that the persistently high budget deficits confront the Federal Reserve with a dilemma: High rates of monetary growth result in inflation, but restraining monetary growth in the face of credit market pressure results in high real interest rates. **********'Critical Issue of Our Time' **********''In short,'' the report states, ''the budget deficit has set the United States on the road to its next recession. The costs of recession are enormous, worth going to extremes to avoid. The deficit is therefore the critical economic issue of our time.'' **********Closely linked to the deficit issue, via its effect on interest rates, is the international debt problem. The Reagan Administration had earlier intended to try to keep the debt issue off the summit meeting's agenda, but this proved impossible, especially as pressure from the debtor countries intensified and as concern grew about the safety of the lending commercial banks. The near-collapse of the Continental Illinois Bank, though not directly due to its foreign exposure, increased those fears. **********The London summit conference did set forth a package of proposals to help the developing countries with their enormous debt burdens. The leaders of the industrial countries called for maintaining and, wherever possible, increasing flows of money, especially to the poorest countries, through international financial and development institutions. **********The United States was not enthusiastic about that, however; it stressed its own bilateral aid programs, such as to Central American and Caribbean countries. **********Case-by-Case Approach on Debt **********The summit talks stuck to a ''case by case'' approach to solving the problems of debtor countries. But in cases where debtor countries are making ''successful efforts to improve their position,'' the summit communique called for ''more extended multiyear rescheduling of commercial debts and standing ready where appropriate to negotiate similarly in respect of debts to governments and government agencies.'' **********Although critics of the London summit - especially those in the third world - may say it did not go far enough, it still resulted in some looking ahead and a somewhat diminished reliance on a policy of ''muddling through'' and ''fire fighting'' than existed before. **********This willingness to face up to the debt crisis could well be the most significant accomplishment of the 10th economic summit, and could do much, if future actions live up to the implied commitment, rescue the world from a looming breakdown in its financial system.  But it would be premature to maintain that the danger is now past. If the United States were to go through another cycle of boom and bust, thanks to erratic fiscal and monetary policies, it would jeopardize the ability of Latin and other debtor countries to solve their debt problems, with or without more foreign aid. **********Thus, actions by the United States and other industrial countries to adopt policies for more stable economic growth remain the great unfinished business of the 10th economic summit conference.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/05/busin.print_headline: EXECUTIVES IN RETIREMENT; THE GLOBAL VOLUNTEER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/05/busin.body_text: **********EDWARD SWAN took early retirement two years ago from **********his job as vice president and creative director at J. Walter Thompson, the New York advertising agency, because ''I found that I was working for everyone but me. I wanted more personal time. I had set a goal and reached it. I was getting into management and policy directions - okaying things - instead of developing the ideas myself. That's what I enjoyed the most.'' **********Now Mr. Swan, 57, is back on the creative side and working for himself. For the last year and a half, he has been developing a second career in real estate, one that affords him the time to devote to volunteer consulting jobs like the one he recently completed with an advertising agency in Indonesia. **********''Many of my friends are asking what it's like to be looking around, if I'm worried about things, whatever,'' said Mr. Swan. His answer: an emphatic ''No! I mean that. I have such a full life catching up on things that I now wonder how I ever fit J. Walter Thompson into my schedule.'' **********One thing that may give Mr. Swan a bit more freedom than some of his contemporaries is his financial independence. Investments and real estate holdings provide him with enough income for a comfortable lifestyle. ''I've put my two children through school now and I thought, 'Why work for money - there's no need now.' '' **********His financial and professional freedom allowed Mr. Swan to spend a few months in Jakarta on a recent volunteer assignment for the International Executive Service Corps. He helped to develop the creative department of a 30-person advertising agency. ''It was a fascinating experience,'' he said. ''They needed encouragement and advice about everything from literature to press releases - and they needed to know what was going on in their field in places like New York City, Paris and London.'' **********His major problem, he found, was encouraging the employees to disagree with his ideas. ''If you're an American, they seem to think you know exactly how to do things,'' Mr. Swan said. ''I had to keep saying these were only my suggestions, that I wasn't the final word.'' **********The assignment whetted Mr. Swan's taste for change. He and his wife have put a ''For Sale'' sign on their home in Mt. Kisco, N.Y., and may move to New York City, California or Cape Cod. And he is ready to take on another volunteer foreign assignment with the IESC. ''It's like the old man's Peace Corps,'' he said. ''The assignment was one of the most personally rewarding things I've ever done.'' **********Linda Keslar is a New York-based free-lance writer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/31/world.body_text: **********-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 30 (Reuters) - Troops killed three people in Cap-Ha"itien in renewed food rioting on Tuesday, Government officials said today. **********Residents reached by telephone said at least 10 people had died. **********The officials said the troops had entered the town to quell protests after food from CARE, the relief group, was being sold instead of being given away. **********It was the second outbreak of food protests in less than a week. Last week troops were sent to Gona"ives to stop two days of food riots. **********In Cap-Ha"itien, the area prefect, Auguste Robinson, denounced city officials who he said had sold the food for personal profit instead of supervising its distribution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/29/world.body_text: **********The acting secretary general of the Organization of African Unity said here today that the O.A.U. was nearing ''paralysis'' because members had failed to pay more than $43 million in contributions. **********The General Secretariat ''lives literally from hand to mouth,'' the official, Peter Onu, said. **********He told the O.A.U.'s Council of Ministers that only 5 of the 51 member nations had fully paid their contributions. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/02/world.main_headline: Colombian Assassination Brings State of Siege
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/02/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Colombian Assassination Brings State of Siege
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/02/world.body_text: **********President Belisario Betancur declared a nationwide state of siege today and vowed a war on drug dealers after the assassination Monday night of the Minister of Justice. **********The slaying of the Minister, Rodrigo Lara Bonilla, is believed to have been arranged by drug dealers because of his campaign against Colombia's multibillion-dollar narcotics rings. **********He was slain by two gunmen on a motorcycle and others in a car who had blocked the path of his limousine in northern Bogota. **********The Minister of Government, Alfonso Gomez, announced the state of siege after an emergency Cabinet meeting. The declaration enables security forces to make arrests without warrants, empowers officials to suspend the right of public assembly and allows the President to legislate decrees. **********On March 15 a state of siege was imposed in four departments where guerrillas and drug dealers are most active. Today's decree extended it to all 23 departments. **********''The Colombian Government accepts the challenge of the drug dealers,'' Mr. Betancur said in a radio and television speech after the emergency measures were announced.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/10/busin.body_text: **********When long-term interest rates fell in July and early August while short- term rates held steady, many investment bankers and economists expected corporations to storm the bond markets for money. All year long they had been building up mountainous amounts of short-term debt because the dramatically lower rates in 90-day commercial paper or from banks were too tempting to pass up. **********The expected torrent, however, turned out to be a trickle. A few big names such as Texaco, Xerox and Georgia Pacific returned to the bond market, but the vast majority of industrial corporations with balance sheets overloaded by short-term debt have elected to hold out for even lower rates. And in recent weeks, when the cost of borrowing beyond several years moved up again, the calendar of coming bond offerings has taken on a decidedly blank look. **********''Many companies are using the election as a reason to sit back and see if rates will come down,'' said David C. Batten, a managing director of the First Boston Corporation. Although there was some pickup in bond financing over the past several months, he said, ''it was relatively small considering the significant group of companies waiting for lower rates.'' **********Activity in Bearer Bonds **********Some whittling away of short-term debt is going on, however. A few well-known American corporations are taking advantage of the appetite overseas for bearer bonds, which do not require identification of the buyers. Other corporations are tapping the convertible bond market in this country because, in return for the chance to convert the bonds into stock, investors are willing to accept lower interest than they would get on a conventional bond issue. **********By declining to lock in fixed-rate long-term money just now, most corporations are counting on a slowing economy to bring down long-term rates. They are also betting that short-term rates will not abruptly soar - as they have more than once in the past few years. **********But if short-term rates do take off, many companies could be badly burned. Short-term borrowings by nonfinancial corporations have risen twice as fast since the 1982 recession as before, noted Stephen S. Roach, senior economist for Morgan Stanley & Company. And with interest costs already equal to 30 percent of corporate profits, ''the bottom line will be pinched quickly if short-term rates rise,'' he said. ''Corporations now have an unprecedented vulnerability to rising rates.'' **********The heavy short-term borrowing has stemmed from the surge in corporate acquisitions, leveraged buyouts and overall capital spending. Normally, companies would finance much of that activity in the medium- and long-term bond markets. Instead, as John Crosby, a managing director of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, said, ''The short-term debt portion of corporate balance sheets remains out of whack. Long-term market rates came down, and companies did virtually nothing.'' **********The stalemate may not last long, however. Corporate financial officers are generally conservative. And unless the short-term rate advantage is overwhelmingly compelling, as it was in the second quarter, they tend to be nervous about playing interest spreads. If short-term rates rise even moderately this fall, as many economists are predicting, there is likely to be a march of companies into the bond market. **********When the Ralston Purina Company completes its recently announced acquisition of the Continental Baking unit of the ITT Corporation for $475 million next month, for instance, Kenneth N. Kermes, chief financial officer of Ralston, plans to move as quickly as possible to lock in longer- term fixed bond rates - even though it will probably be more costly. **********''I'm from the old school,'' Mr. Kermes said. ''I like to fund long- term projects with long-term money.'' **********Another such financial officer is Edwin A. Huston, chief financial officer of the Ryder System, which recently raised $100 million with a 10- year bond issue. In the first six months of this year, he said, the ratio of his company's short-term debt to long-term debt rose above normal because the lower rates on the short end were ''very tempting.'' **********'Swings in Profitability' **********But since most of the money was to finance three- to five-year fixed-payment truck leases, ''to stay short term on the liability side opened us to swings in profitability,'' Mr. Huston said. **********A great many companies seem to be getting ready to jump in. David A. Wyss, senior financial economist at Data Resources Inc., said: ''Standard & Poor's is seeing quite an increase in the number of companies coming in for a debt rating. That's usually a good indication that more of them will be coming to market.'' **********The interest-rate level at which corporate financial officers will feel comfortably committed for longer- maturity debt is a moving target. Investment bankers said that until this summer's drop in rates, the financial officers had been indicating that long- term rates below 14 percent would cause a rush to the bond market. **********Stronger Cash Flows **********Now, even though most investment grade companies can raise money at 13 percent or 14 percent, the goal is to do so below 13 percent. **********Aside from the heavy dependence on lower-cost, short-term money, the other reason why bond financing is running so low is that many companies are enjoying exceptionally strong cash flows. That eliminates the need to borrow either short or long. **********Cash flows are up because of the drive by so many corporations during the past recession to become more efficient. As sales picked up with the economic recovery, this has meant higher profit margins. In addition, the tax change in 1981 allowing faster depreciation on plant and equipment has chipped in about half of the $100 billion cash flow increase for nonfinancial corporations since the end of the recession, noted Richard D. Rippe, senior vice president and economist at Dean Witter Reynolds. **********The Exxon Corporation, for instance, continues a high level of capital spending, about $9 billion this year. But it has not recently been a long-term borrower, nor does it have any plans to be, reports Allen Harrison, assistant treasurer.   Interest Rate Swaps **********''We have a strong cash flow, resulting in part from a significant amount of cost cutting over the past few years,'' Mr. Harrison said. **********Not all companies raising funds via short-term bank loans or in the commercial paper market are necessarily subject to the risk of rising rates. **********James McKeon, a credit market analyst for Salomon Brothers, for instance, has concluded that a ''good part of short-term financing is for interest rate swaps.'' In such cases, an American company might obtain long-term, fixed-rate money at a relatively low cost by swapping its obligations on short-term, adjustable-rate debt for the fixed-rate obligation of an overseas issuer in the Eurodollar market. **********Even so, many companies are clearly betting that long-term rates will decline as the current economic expansion begins to run out of steam. If high rates persist, corporate treasurers see the advantgage they are now gaining in the short-term arenas as more than offseting any increases they might have to pay for long-term financing later on. **********The time is also coming when many companies will be facing a new round of major capital expenditures. Their plants are nearing full capacity. But, as Edward Hyman, chief economist for C. J. Lawrence & Company, said, ''There is the sense that if rates skyrocket, then the economy will turn down, and there will be no need to build new plants anyway.'' **********Investment bankers are advising corporations not to wait. ''Our economists believe rates will be higher in 1985,'' said Peter M. Sacerdote, partner in charge of corporate finance at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''If a corporation has to finance and can't wait beyond then, it should go now. The real danger is that people try to project what they wish to happen rather than what is likely to happen.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/12/busin.main_headline: A SECOND BIG WEEK FOR WALL ST.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/12/busin.print_headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; A SECOND BIG WEEK FOR WALL ST.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/12/busin.body_text: **********Frenzy, confusion and panic buying continued to mark Wall Street last week, as stock prices cooled down, then roared ahead and cooled down again on Friday. Volume on the Big Board broke all records for the second week in a row, with 754.5 million shares changing hands. Institutions continued to dominate the buying, apparently not wanting to miss out on a rally that has seen the Dow jump more than 100 points in two weeks, but individuals did join the action more. After torrid trading on Monday, and slower trading on Tuesday and Wednesday, Thursday looked like a slow day until trading exploded late in the day. The Dow jumped more than 30 points to close up 27.94 points on the day. Friday saw a continuation of the last hour with the Dow surging 22 points in the morning. But the rally weakened and by the end of the day the Dow had lost six points, to end the week at 1,218.01, up almost 16 points on the week. **********Strength in the bond market was a big stimulus for the stock market. Amid falling interest rates and rising bond prices, investors snapped up more than $16 billion in Treasury offerings last week. Adding to investor confidence about the future course of interest rates, the money supply took a surprisingly large $2.6 billion drop for the latest reporting week. M-1 now stands below the middle of the Fed's target range, signaling that the Central Bank will at least not tighten its monetary policy. **********Turbulence.  The airline industry felt the effects of investor skittishness, when People Express announced that it would begin a Chicago-Newark route for $59 to $79 one- way. The new fares, almost 70 percent below existing coach prices, are likely to touch off a fare war with the big carriers, which include United, American, Delta and T.W.A. Fare- war fears pushed airline stocks lower, but prices recovered somewhat later in the week on the market's strength . . . Pan Am posted a $49.8 million loss in the second quarter, compared with a $10.4 million loss a year earlier. **********National Semiconductor promised   to mend its ways and not sell untested chips to the Government. The chip maker, which was charged with violating U.S. testing rules, agreed to set up an independent unit that will monitor all its Government work and insure that all chips are properly tested. In return, the agency agreed to stop attempts to block National Semi from getting Government contracts and return the company to full contracter status. **********Strike Two.  Trilogy Ltd., the creation of Gene Amdahl and once a darling of Wall Street, has abandoned its second major project in three months - the design and marketing of a high- speed superchip. Mr. Amdahl said the ''wafer-scale'' semiconductor, which is the equivalent of about a hundred chips in one large silicon wafer, had proven too costly. He said Trilogy would instead concentrate on designing and assembling circuit packages for large computer companies. In June, it dropped work on its super computer project. **********Inflation Blip.  After three months of holding steady, prices at the producer level rose in July by three- tenths of one percent. The jump was sparked by the first increase in food prices since March. But economists said the rise showed that inflation was still in check. **********Deficit Adjustments.  The Congressional Budget Office lowered its projections for the nation's budget deficits for fiscal years 1984 and 1985. Citing recent tax increases and spending cuts, it now sees a $172 billion shortfall in fiscal 1984, growing to $178 billion in 1985. Its January estimate called for a $189 billion and $197 billion deficits in the two years. **********Fed Chairman Paul Volcker suggested that certain Latin American nations - particularly Mexico and Venezuela - had made substantial economic gains recently, that they were on time with their interest payments and that bankers might now consider offering more favorable credit terms an extended maturities. But he added in Congressional testimony that such favorable treatment should be granted on a case-by-case basis. Mr. Volcker also said that he sympathized with the idea of interest- rate ceilings on Third World loans, but declined to offer any detailed suggestions to the Congressmen. **********Merrill Lynch plans to buy the struggling brokerage firm of Becker Paribas for $96.9 million in new stock. But the gaint securities firm will keep only about 300 of Becker's 2,000 employees. Merrill will not acquire Becker's retail stock brokerage, which will become a new independent company. Analysts questioned the wisdom of the purchase since Merrill reported substantial losses for the second quarter and Becker has evidently lost as much as $75 million in stock and bond trading during the last year. **********The F.C.C. yielded to some strong- arm tactics by Congress and voted to delay the planned expansion of television ownership for about six months. The Commission had ruled last month that a single owner could buy as many as 12 stations, up from seven under an earlier law. But upon the urging of three members of the House and separate Senate action, the Commission decided not to proceed with implementation of the new rule. The move did not affect an F.C.C. plan to permit expansion of radio station ownership to 12 from seven. **********More Mergers.  I.C. Industries agreed to buy the Pneumo Corporation for $560 million, or $38 a share. The move will increase I.C.'s military business four-fold since Pneumo is a large manufacturer of landing gear and flight controls . . . W.R. Grace and an investor-management group plan to pay $19.25 a share, or $360 million, for National Medical Care Inc., a Boston-based dialysis company . . . Canada's largest fashion retailer, Dylex Ltd., bid $365 million in cash for Brooks Fashion Stores. The offer is supported by the Saul family, which holds a controling interest in Brooks. **********Addenda.  R.J. Reynolds was awarded $49.8 million by the Iran- U.S. Claims Tribunal in The Hague on claims it made against Iran in wake of the 1979 hostage crisis. It was the largest award to date by the tribunal . . . Turner Broadcasing said might start a rock video network to compete with the highly successful MTV Network. The announcement came one day before MTV sold 5.1 million shares to the public.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/13/world.main_headline: U.S. PRODS BELGIUM AND NETHERLANDS TO ACCEPT MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/13/world.print_headline: U.S. PRODS BELGIUM AND NETHERLANDS TO ACCEPT MISSILES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/13/world.body_text: **********The United States told Belgium and the Netherlands today that the chances for progress in forthcoming negotiations with the Soviet Union would be set back if they did not carry out commitments to deploy American cruise missiles. **********American and allied officials said the message was conveyed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz in meetings here with Belgian and Dutch officials. An aide to Mr. Shultz said he had found the meetings ''positive.'' **********''They told us they would do their best to do their duty, but they also pointed out the problems they have,'' the aide said. **********The Belgian and Dutch Governments have encountered domestic opposition to deploying the missiles under a NATO plan, first set forth five years ago, to counter the Soviet Union's SS-20 medium-range missiles by stationing cruise missiles and Pershing 2 ballistic missiles in Western Europe.   48 Missiles Each to Be Deployed **********Belgium is supposed to deploy 48 cruise missiles starting in March, and the Netherlands also 48, in 1986. Britain, Italy and West Germany have already begun their deployment. There will eventually be 464 cruise missiles. In addition, West Germany is supposed to deploy 108 Pershing 2 missiles. **********Allied officials have said that if the Dutch and the Belgians do not live up to their commitment, political pressure may force other countries to scale back their deployment, reducing pressure on the Russians to negotiate. **********''It is harmful if undertakings are not adhered to,'' Mr. Shultz said in a news conference aboard his plane en route from Britain for the annual winter meeting of foreign ministers from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********''And it is certainly the case that, if the Soviets could have their way without giving up anything or engaging in negotiations, it would be discouraging to the negotiations,'' he said.   New Arms Talks Due Next Month **********Mr. Shultz opens a new round of arms talks with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union next month in Geneva. The talks are to cover the suspended negotiations on strategic arms and medium-range missiles in Europe, as well as curbs on space weapons. **********''While the Soviet decision to enter into new arms control negotiations is welcome, the road ahead will not be easy and Western patience and realism will remain the key to concrete progress in the coming months,'' Mr. Shultz said on arriving here. **********One of his seeming concerns is the spate of newspaper articles suggesting that his differences with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger are so wide as to make it difficult to produce a workable set of proposals for the talks with Mr. Gromyko. **********''That is nonsense,'' Mr. Shultz said on his plane when asked whether the State Department would prevail over the Pentagon in preparing for the talks. **********''The point is the President will make decisions on what positions to take,'' he said. ''The issues get full discussion. It is not true that the Defense Department is always on one side of the issue and State on the other. That is not an accurate statement at all. We approach this on the basis of full discussion and lots of agreement and the President will make some big decisions.''  Differences Not Being Denied **********Mr. Shultz's aides later said that he did not intend to deny that differences existed, but to stress his belief that some accounts had been overblown. **********On the issue of missile deployment in Belgium and the Netherlands, the Belgian Government, after first announcing that it intended to go ahead, put off a decision until after Prime Minister Wilfried Martens sees President Reagan on Jan. 14 in Washington. Today Mr. Shultz met with Mr. Martens and Foreign Minister Leo Tindemans, both of whom, according to American officials, said politics forced them to move cautiously. **********The Dutch Government, faced with opposition, has said that it will make a decision at the end of 1985. It said that if the Soviet Union increased the number of SS-20 missiles, this would be a factor in favor of deployment. **********American officials have said that the number of SS-20s has risen to 387, with more being built. Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek of the Netherlands affirmed the Dutch position in conferring with Mr. Shultz today. **********Mr. Shultz told reporters that he would not be able to inform the allied ministers in detail of what he will tell Mr. Gromyko because Mr. Reagan had made no decisions. Mr. Shultz said he wanted to hear the allies' ideas.   Mediation for India and Sri Lanka **********In another development, Mr. Shultz disclosed that the United States had sent Gen. Vernon A. Walters, a roving ambassador, to the Indian subcontinent after Sri Lanka had asked for help in easing tensions with India. **********Sri Lanka has also sought emergency military support from Britain and the United States, but aides to Mr. Shultz said that, for the moment, the emphasis was on diplomacy. The British Foreign Office said Tuesday that it would not meet a Sri Lanka request for patrol boats to prevent Tamil infiltration from India. **********The Tamils are an ethnic group that lives in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu and shares Sri Lanka with the Sinhalese, the ethnic majority. Relations between India and Sri Lanka have become tense because the Tamils are seeking a separate state in their, northern part of Sri Lanka. **********General Walters first went to Colombo for talks on Monday with President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka, and then flew to New Delhi.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/27/busin.main_headline: TARIFF CUTS IN JAPANESE TRADE PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/27/busin.print_headline: TARIFF CUTS IN JAPANESE TRADE PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/27/busin.body_text: **********The Japanese Government today approved a package of trade measures intended to soothe foreign complaints of limited access to Japanese markets. **********The actions, authorized by the Cabinet of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, include new tariff cuts and a speedup of reductions that had been agreed to in the past. **********Other measures would simplify certification procedures for foreign products, broaden the distribution here of foreign cigarettes and create a new Government office to help foreign companies to invest in Japan. **********On several issues important to the United States and Europe, however, the new proposals contained statements of principle rather than indications of clear action. For example, the package raises the possibility of Japan's buying foreign-made communications satellites - something the United States would very much like. But whether such purchases would, in fact, come about was is uncertain. Japan would like to develop its own satellites. **********Prime Minister Comments **********Similarly, an expressed willingness to open up Japan's capital markets contains little of substance, given continued disagreements with the United States over the pace of such liberalization. **********Prime Minister Nakasone said today's Cabinet action took into account ''the role Japan is expected to perform in the international economic community.'' **********He said, ''We hope that other nations fully understand the sincere intention and the efforts Japan has made.'' **********To a certain degree, the contents of the Japanese trade package are less important than its timing. It comes six weeks before the major industrial nations gather for their annual economic summit conference, to be held in London June 7-9. **********Tokyo is hoping to blunt unhappiness abroad over its trade surpluses with the West. Japan says its surplus in trade with the United States totaled $18.2 billion last year, a figure that Washington considers understated. Against the Common Market, the surplus was put at $10.4 billion. **********Recurring Pattern Noted **********The latest trade package follows a familiar pattern, in which Japan waits until just before a major conference to promise reforms to Western industrial countries that blame Japan for many of their economic woes. **********The new tariff reductions affect more than 60 items, including wine, forestry products, color photographic paper and farm equipment. **********An official in the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said 31 items had been designated for special cuts. Tariffs will drop by an average of 35 percent, he said, starting next April 1. In addition, the package calls for cutting tariffs a year or two ahead of schedule for many goods covered by earlier agreements. But Japanese officials cautioned that such changes depend on other countries' ''implementing their own advanced reductions.'' **********Beef-and-Orange Accord **********The Government cited its willingness to import more United States beef and citrus - an issue that has acquired considerable symbolic importance for both countries even though it means little to their overall trade problems. Under the agreement reached earlier this month, Japan will increase its quote on high-grade beef over the next four years to 58,400 tons, from 30,800 tons, and its orange import quota to 126,000 tons, from 82,000 tons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/29/world.main_headline: NEW AIRPORT, STILL UNFINISHED, IS OPEN IN GRENADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/29/world.print_headline: NEW AIRPORT, STILL UNFINISHED, IS OPEN IN GRENADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/29/world.body_text: **********The big jet airport that Cuba began building and that the United States is helping to complete opened today with two-thirds of the terminal unfinished, most of the roads unpaved and acres of raw dirt waiting to be landscaped. **********It also opened without any regularly scheduled jet service by any airline and with the island's few hotels and guesthouses filled with government officials, businessmen and journalists. **********But the several thousand Grenadians who braved sporadic outbursts of rain to listen to speeches and festive music and watch the first commercial passenger planes land on the 9,000-foot- long runway after the opening did not seem to mind that some new problems were raised and that completion of the project was still nearly a year away. **********They were clearly delighted that finally, after engineering studies and debates going back to the mid-1950's, the island had in operation an airport that could accommodate the largest jet aircraft that fly, day or night and in any kind of weather.   Link to Anniversary Seen **********Many Grenadians said the Reagan Administration had been determined to get the airport in operation this week so as to have a major tangible accomplishment on the anniversary of the United States invasion of the island Oct. 25, 1983. **********In a letter to the Governor General, Sir Paul Scoon, that was read over Radio Grenada Saturday night, President Reagan recalled the events of a year ago and said: ''It is good to recall on this promising and happy occasion that the objectives of the rescue mission were achieved.'' **********Grenadian officials put the eventual total cost of the airport at more than $80 million, including about $19 million from the United States. **********In the main address, the Governor General called the airport ''a dream come true.'' He thanked the United States and Canada for their help with the airport but he did not mention the Cubans who, according to Grenadians familiar with the work, completed about 65 percent of the project before the United States troops arrived.   'A Good and Magnificent Thing' **********John Francis, a 49-year-old farmer in the crowd, said he did not know who deserved the most credit for the airport. But, he said, ''to all of those who helped us, we are glad and thankful. This is a good and magnificent thing for bringing business to this country.'' **********''It's going to be fantastic for everything, tourism, trade, everything,'' said Michael McIntyre, who runs a soft-drink bottling company that opened last May, the first major business started since the invasion. **********No disorders were reported during the celebration today. But a handful of women in their early 20's quietly held hand-lettered posters indicating they thought the airport should have been named ''Maurice Bishop International Airport,'' in memory of the late Prime Minister who was killed on Oct. 19, 1983, six days before the invasion. The signs also thanked the Cubans. **********Sir Eric Gairy, a former Prime Minister who is backing a slate of candidates for the coming election on Dec. 3, has said that if his party wins he plans to rename the airport ''Ronald Reagan International Airport.''  Replaces Old, Distant Airport **********The airport is now named Point Saline International Airport, after its location at the southern tip of the island. It replaces the short, unlighted Pearls Airport, which opened on Jan. 16, 1943. The new airport, set alongside a sparkling sea, is a drive of about 25 minutes over mostly level ground from the capital, compared with the old airport, which was about an hour away via winding mountain road. **********For months there had been speculation that President Reagan might attend the opening. But, as announced, he sent as the United States representative M. Peter McPherson, Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, which has coordinated the airport work since shortly after the invasion. **********''This is a day of celebration,'' Mr. McPherson said at a news conference today at the oceanfront hotel that serves as the United States Embassy. ''It's a proud day for freedom.''  Reagan Cited Military Potential **********During the time that as many as 650 Cubans were working on the airport under the leftist Government led by Mr. Bishop, President Reagan maintained that the airport was intended primarily for military purposes and that it constituted a menace to security in the region. In March 1983 the President went on national television and cited construction of the airstrip as evidence of what he called ''Soviet-Cuban militarization'' of Grenada. ''Grenada doesn't even have an air force,'' he said, showing a satellite photograph of the airstrip. ''Who is it intended for?'' **********Many Grenadians say that they are not sure what the Cubans had in mind, but that from the earliest studies by British engineers nearly 30 years ago, the Grenadians always saw the airport as a boon to tourism and development. **********Airport workers say that for months, more than a half-dozen long-range United States military jet and turboprop transport planes have been landing at the airport each week with supplies and equipment for about 250 United States soldiers who are still patrolling the island and helping to train a new Grenadian police force.   Landing Rights Discussed **********As the airport opened, the appointed interim Government that has been governing Grenada since shortly after the invasion was still discussing landing rights with Pan American World Airways, American Airlines and British West Indian Airways. **********Some officials of B.W.I.A. said they hoped to begin operating a DC-9 jet that could carry 112 passengers between Miami and Grenada next week. But other B.W.I.A. and Government officials said approval might not come before December. **********In the meantime, the new airport will be operating with the same 12 daily flights from nearby islands that were being handled at Pearls. **********The new airport, with sophisticated lighting and navigational systems, will operate into the night so that with connecting flights, passengers can reach Grenada from much of the world in a single day. Operations at Pearls Airport ended as the new airport opened. **********Some critics have said that the airport, which has a concrete terminal more than 150 yards long and four stories tall, is more elaborate than is appropriate for Grenada and that operating expenses could further hamstring the island's crippled economy.   Recommended Since 1955 **********Ron Smith, the Grenadian project manager for the airport construction, said colonial engineers recommended in 1955 that the government buy land for an airport at Point Saline. He said he drew the first plans for it in 1966. But, he said, Grenada could never raise the money to start the project until Maurice Bishop and other leftists took over the Government in early 1979 and obtained assistance from Cuba. The Bishop Government said other countries also aided the project, including Canada, Mexico, Venezuela and Algeria. Work began in early 1980, Mr. Smith said. **********Mr. Smith said construction crews sent by Cuba spent most of their time doing ''earthwork,'' leveling ridges, filling in valleys and laying down 10 inches of asphalt for the runway. United States officials acknowledge that a company from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., dredged and filled the bay under contract to the leftist Government and that other American companies provided the asphalt for the runway and designed the huge fuel storage tanks that the Reagan Administration has often cited as evidence of military intentions. **********Starting last summer, United States officials said, the firm of Morrison- Knudsen of Boise, Idaho, which was part of a consortium that did much of the government construction work in Vietnam, put down the final two inches of asphalt on the runway and brought two of the six bays of the terminal to within 95 percent of completion. **********A British Company, Plessey Airports Ltd., working on a $10 million contract, supplied the wiring, finishing materials and furniture for the terminal. It also built the power-generating plant and provided the air-conditioning. A Finnish company installed the airfield lighting and set up fire and rescue equipment. According to United States official, Canada is providing $7 million for finishing some parts of the airport and for training in security, maintenance and airport management. **********The first commercial passenger plane to land, at 6:28 A.M., was a 48- seat, twin-engine Leeward Islands Air Transport turboprop from Barbados with 30 passengers aboard. **********The first passenger off the plane was Robert Francis, the chief of the international division of the Federal Aviation Administration. He said four American air traffic controllers were in the control tower working alongside Grenadians in a training program. **********The pilot, Trevor Neckles, a 38-year- old Grenadian, said the landing at Point Saline was ''very different'' from landing at the old Grenada airport, where ''you had to fly into a mountain and then down into a valley to get into the airport.'' **********Twenty other passenger planes landed, including four jets, one of them a Pan Am flight from New York and another a charter from Frankfurt and London.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/11/busin.body_text: **********Victor Posner, chairman of the Sharon Steel Corporation, which owns 8.9 percent of the City Investing Company, is ''contemplating'' whether to make an offer for City, an attorney for Mr. Posner said. ''He is making an analysis of the company and is contemplating whether he will make an offer and if so at what amount,'' said Bruce Greer, the lawyer, who is based in Miami Beach. **********An investors group headed by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, and including George T. Scharffenberger, chairman of City Investing, has offered to pay $50 a share, or $2.3 billion, for City's shares. John J. C. Herndon, a senior vice president with City Investing, said yesterday that he ''was not aware of any offer'' from Mr. Posner.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/01/world.body_text: **********A West German Nazi-hunter was arrested briefly here today after she led about 30 Chileans in a demonstration urging Chile to expel Walter Rauff, a former Nazi officer. **********Beate Klarsfeld, two Chilean women, and five men, including an American writer, Peter Hellman, were arrested and charged with disturbing the public order. Mrs. Klarsfeld was freed after appeals by the Roman Catholic human rights office and by West German consular officials. **********The demonstration, held in Constitution Plaza across from the Moneda presidential palace, backed a request by the Israeli Government for the expulsion of the 77- year-old Mr. Rauff so he can stand trial on charges of gassing 97,000 East European Jews in mobile death trucks during World War II. Chile's military Government has not replied to the Israeli move. **********The Chilean Supreme Court in 1963 rejected a West German bid to extradite Mr. Rauff for trial, citing Chile's 15-year limit for prosecution of such crimes.   Argument for Extradition **********Mrs. Klarsfeld has argued that there is no legal barrier to Mr. Rauff's expulsion because he is not a Chilean citizen and because he failed to disclose his past activities upon entering Chile in 1958. **********Since her arrival two weeks ago, she has met with political leaders and human-rights activists with the aim of making Mr. Rauff's presence an issue among opponents of President Augusto Pinochet. **********Last Thursday, she led about 30 members of Chilean Jewish youth groups in a demonstration outside Mr. Rauff's home in Santiago. Those joining her Tuesday were older Chileans who are relatives of political prisoners who disappeared after President Pinochet seized power in a 1973 coup. **********Mrs. Klarsfeld and her husband, Serge, a lawyer, campaigned for a decade to get Klaus Barbie, the accused Nazi war criminal, expelled from Bolivia. After Bolivia's new civilian Government sent Mr. Barbie to France for trial last year, the Klarsfelds turned their attention to Mr. Rauff.

Lee, Gulf's chairman and chief executive officer.
