https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/19/world.main_headline: THATCHER VISITS CHINA TO SIGN HONG KONG ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/19/world.print_headline: THATCHER VISITS CHINA TO SIGN HONG KONG ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/19/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher arrived here today to sign the agreement to return sovereignty over Hong Kong to China on July 1, 1997. **********China has billed the signing ceremony, scheduled for Wednesday, as a historic occasion and has prepared for it with glowing press profiles of Mrs. Thatcher and enthusiastic accounts of the reception the agreement has receieved around the world, especially in Hong Kong. More than 100 Chinese representatives from Hong Kong have been flown here as China's guests to witness the signing. **********After a 19-hour flight from London aboard a Royal Air Force VC-10, Mrs. Thatcher received a quiet welcome at Peking's capital airport from Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian and a handful of other Chinese officials. With the Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, she was presented with a bouquet of flowers by Chinese children, then whisked out of the frigid north China night for the drive into the city. **********What the official New China News Agency described as a ''warm, friendly and ceremonious reception'' for the British leader will begin in earnest Wednesday when she inspects an honor guard in Tian An Men Square and receives a 19-gun salute. Later she will confer with Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang; Hu Yaobang, the Communist Party chairman, and Deng Xiaoping, China's pre-eminent leader, before the signing ceremony at 5:30 P.M.   Chilly Talks 2 Years Ago **********It was only a little more than two years ago that a visit to Peking by Mrs. Thatcher to discuss Hong Kong ended in chilly disagreement. Mrs. Thatcher had hoped Britain could extend its sovereignty over the colony beyond the expiration of the 99-year lease or at least to persuade Peking to allow Britain to prolong its administrative control over the colony and its nearly five million inhabitants. **********At a meeting with Mr. Deng there were stiff exchanges over the historical background to British occupation of Hong Kong. This was established by treaties in 1842 and 1860 ceding Hong Kong Island and the Kowloon Peninsula and by the 1898 Convention of Peking, under which the New Territories, accounting for nine-tenths of the land the colony now occupies, were leased for 99 years. **********After those talks, Mr. Deng began talking of a solution imposed by China. **********All this changed rapidly this year when Mrs. Thatcher wrote a letter to the Chinese leaders dropping the demand for continued British control. In turn, the Chinese agreed to guarantee the extension of Hong Kong's capitalist economic system and to give the territory's people a high degree of autonomy for 50 years after 1997. By July, agreement in principle had been reached, and Sir Geoffrey initialed the accord here in September.   Praise for Mrs. Thatcher **********Approval of the agreement last week by both houses of Parliament cleared the way for the signing, and Mrs. Thatcher finds herself greeted here as ''an outstanding stateswoman with vision,'' as she was called in a New China News Agency interview with Ke Hua, the former Chinese Ambassador to Britain. **********Western diplomats say the warmth expressed for Mrs. Thatcher is genuine, reflecting a widespread gratitude that she made it possible for China to redress peacefully what has long been regarded as a symbol of the 19th-century depradations wrought on China. **********Moreover, the diplomats say, British agreement to surrender Hong Kong has added enormously to the personal prestige of Mr. Deng, who needs all the momentum he can muster as he presses his economic modernization program in the face of opposition. **********Chinese leaders have been hinting that Britain will be rewarded with wider trade opportunities, which have lagged behind those obtained by the United States and other West European nations, particularly West Germany. **********The Sino-British Trade Council predicted two-way trade this year of about $720 million, compared with more than $5 billion in trade for the United States and China.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/23/world.main_headline: SEEKS TO EASE TENSION IN RELATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/23/world.print_headline: REAGAN LEAVES ON TRIP TO CHINA; SEEKS TO EASE TENSION IN RELATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/23/world.body_text: **********President Reagan arrived here today from California on the start of what he called ''a long journey for peace'' to China. **********White House officials say the President's six-day visit will include talks on a range of topics aimed at easing tensions that have arisen in America's relations with China over the last two years. Officials also say the results of the trip are likely to be a centerpiece of Mr. Reagan's re-election bid. **********For the first time, Mr. Reagan will be visiting a country that is not a staunch ally; China will be the second Communist country he has ever visited, after East Germany, where he journeyed in 1978. **********Wide Range of Issues **********Much of the news coverage is likely to focus on Mr. Reagan's visits to the sites of Peking, Shanghai and the ancient burial pits of Xian. But Administration officials say the chief significance of the President's trip will lie in how much understanding is achieved in discussions with the Chinese leaders on such issues as relations with the Soviet Union and Taiwan, trade, American investment in China and other matters. **********In almost every area, China and the United States have struggled to overcome disagreements.  ''It's clear that we've had a very up's-and-down's kind of relationship with China,'' a senior Administration official said. He added, however, that the progress in various areas had brought relations to ''a new era'' marked by productive discussions on the issues dividing them. **********Mr. Reagan arrived at Hickam Air Force Base this afternoon after spending the weekend at his ranch in Santa Barbara, Calif. The President, greeted by a few hundred cheering visitors to the base, declared that the trip would ''continue the process of reconciliation'' with China begun by President Nixon. **********The President, who is scheduled to arrive in Peking on Thursday after overnight stops here and in Guam, plans more than seven hours of private discussions with Chinese leaders. Administration aides said no major breakthroughs are expected, but they expressed the hope for progress that can lay the groundwork for better relations in the future. **********Among the topics to be discussed are these: **********- Continued American support for Taiwan, which Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang has called the biggest obstacle to improvement in Chinese-American relations. Mr. Zhao made his comment in the United States in January. **********- Disagreements on a treaty for peaceful nuclear cooperation between the two countries. The agreement is needed before American companies can sell China reactors for its program to develop nuclear power. **********- Impatience and frustration on a range of trade issues. China wants to sell more textile products and buy more high-technology products than the United States wants. The United States wants a new agreement commiting China to buy more grain. **********- Attitudes toward the Soviet Union.  After a period of blaming both Moscow and Washington for world tensions, China has lately suggested publicly that the Soviet Union is more to blame. While China and the United States share an anti-Soviet stand, China resists being seen as a counterweight to the Soviet Union. **********Mr. Reagan is expected to sign a tax treaty in Peking that will eliminate double taxation for American companies doing business in China. In addition, he plans to sign a two-year Implementing Accord of a Cultural Agreement that was originally signed in 1979. The previous accord was suspended by Peking last year in protest after the United States granted asylum to a Chinese tennis player.   Taiwan Is Biggest Issue **********Administration officials agree that the biggest irritant in the relationship with China continues to be Taiwan. The Chinese remain concerned about Mr. Reagan's longtime commitment to the Government there, despite his statements that the United States wants a friendship with ''the people of Taiwan,'' and not the Government. **********Although American arms sales to Taiwan have declined slightly, Peking wants a commitment for a cutoff date. The United States has said only that it expects a gradual reduction in arms sales in response to China's intention to resolve its differences with Taiwan without the use of force. **********Although the history of modern China is marked by disappointment in the West at the failure of markets to open up, United States officials now say that the future of American investment in China is bright. American companies are eager to provide technical help especially in the development of nuclear power, offshore oil drilling, coal mining and hydroelectric dams in China. **********Mr. Reagan has come to look on his trip to China as helping such enterprises. ''I go as something of a salesman,'' he told a group of trade officials in Tacoma, Wash., on Thursday. ''And I'll do anything I can up to the limit of not putting a 'Buy American' sticker on my bag.'' **********Administration officials nonetheless are disappointed that they have been unable to conclude the terms of an investment treaty with China, which would establish protection for American investments from nationalization and regulations that favor domestic Chinese investment. **********In addition, there had been hope that a nuclear cooperation treaty could be signed when Mr. Reagan visited. But the talks have been unable to resolve China's refusal to agree to the American demand that it get consent from the United States for any special use of processed nuclear fuel. **********Sovereignty Infringement **********The demand, which is designed to prevent the spread of weapons-grade material, is opposed by China as an infringement on its sovereignty. **********The most important economic breakthrough with China occurred last year, when Mr. Reagan moved China to a new trade category that permits it to receive a much larger amount of high-technology products. High-technology exports subsequently quadrupled, bringing big profits to American companies. But China is still upset about controls that prevent it from receiving all it wants. **********Another area of disagreement is in foreign assistance. China is seeking low-cost loans from the United States for its development programs. American officials say there are no programs that would permit such aid to China, and that in any case China should rely on private investment for its development needs. **********Mr. Reagan may also sign a scientific agreement with China permitting it to have a Chinese astronaut, or at least a payload, aboard a space shuttle flight in the next several years. Offers to have an astronaut join the American space program have been extended to Brazil, France and West Germany - but not to a Communist country. **********Although China and the United States have similar views on some issues - both oppose the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and Vietnam's actions in Cambodia - there are major differences that are to be discussed. **********China has been an outspoken critic of United States policies in Central America, the Middle East and South Africa. **********Top Reagan Administration officials have said that they welcomed the chance to explain to China that they are acting to counter what the Administration contends is Soviet aggression near the American border. **********Mr. Reagan plans to make extensive use of television in China. His speech in the Great Hall of the People, as well as a question session with Chinese students in Shanghai and with Chinese journalists in Peking, will be televised. **********Just what notes Mr. Reagan plans to sound, however, is unclear. **********Military Assistance **********Equally unclear is how much military assistance the United States will be willing to provide China. Here again, American officials said that Mr. Reagan's discussions will be important in measuring Chinese interest. **********''We're not pushing our stuff on them,'' said an Administration official. He said that up to now, the United States has only sold nonlethal items, such as communications equipment. Discussions may begin on what American officials say will be ''purely defensive'' equipment, such as antitank missiles or artillery shell manufacturing capability. **********Mr. Reagan plans to return from Shanghai May 1, after a six-day visit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/27/world.main_headline: Reagan to Appoint Glitman To Head Vienna Arms Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/27/world.print_headline: Reagan to Appoint Glitman To Head Vienna Arms Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/27/world.body_text: **********President Reagan plans to nominate Maynard W. Glitman to succeed Morton I. Abramowitz as the chief United States negotiator for the mutual and balanced force reductions talks in Vienna, the White House said today. **********Mr. Glitman, a career Foreign Service officer, has been deputy head of the American delegation at the United States-Soviet negotiations on intermediate-range nuclear weapons, which the Soviet Union quit in December. **********His nomination to head the talks on reduction of conventional arms in Europe is subject to Senate confirmation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/busin.body_text: **********LOS ANGELES **********LAST June, the 14,000 agents who **********sell residential real estate for **********Coldwell Banker were handed an unusual sales tool. **********Anyone purchasing a home through Coldwell Banker, the nation's largest real estate company, would qualify for discounts of up to 25 percent on appliances, paint, burglar alarms and other household items purchased from Sears, Roebuck. **********The discount was enough of a drawing card to anger realtors across the country. Their complaints of unfair competition prompted real estate commissioners in 15 states to prohibit Coldwell customers from using their discounts at Sears. The prohibition is being appealed, and Sears has won a favorable ruling from an Illinois judge. ''Ultimately,'' said C. Wesley Poulson, chairman of the Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group, ''we think the discount will prevail.'' **********That promotion is among the most visible of the benefits that Coldwell Banker has reaped since its acquisition by Sears in 1981. But what is billed as the chief benefit of membership in the new Sears financial empire - the opening of Coldwell booths in 121 Sears stores so far - has not yet produced a measurable effect. **********''We don't really see a pattern yet,'' the 53-year-old Mr. Poulson said. ''In our case, it's so long between the point of contact with a customer and the sale, sometimes more than a year, that it's difficult for us to measure the results.'' **********Aside from residential real estate,  however, the Sears tie has benefited Coldwell in its commercial business - and saved Sears money to boot. Coldwell has been made the exclusive broker for Allstate in the insurance subsidiary's many real estate investments. And it handles sales and leasing for the Homart Development Company, a Sears subsidiary that is the nation's largest developer of shopping centers. Thousands of dollars have thus been saved in commissions and brokerage fees once paid to brokers not affiliated with Sears, although Sears won't disclose figures. **********Nor will executives disclose the specific number of Sears customers among the buyers of the 102,000 homes that Coldwell agents sold last year. That was up from 60,000 in 1982, with the housing recovery contributing greatly to the increase. As for the 25 percent discount at Sears stores, company spokesmen say - somewhat vaguely - that it stirred lots of interest among home buyers. Nevertheless, the initial alarm of the National Association of Realtors has died down since last summer. **********The most dramatic symbol of change at Coldwell in the wake of the Sears takeover - for $202 million in cash and stock - is a burst of growth, beyond the company's earlier plans. **********That expansion has already brought Coldwell from 370 commercial and residential real estate offices in 1981 to nearly 1,000 last year - and increased its share of national home sales from 1 percent when Sears bought the company to 3.8 percent last year. Aside from the 121 stores in Sears the growth was managed through franchising or the purchase of local real estate companies. **********COLDWELL'S 7 percent drop in earnings last year - to $48 million in 1983 from $51.5 million in 1982 - looks bad at first blush. But the 1982 results were bolstered by the sale of four regional shopping centers by the Homart subsidiary in the fourth quarter of the year. In fact, profits from Coldwell's ongoing businesses (before taxes and depreciation) rose sharply as the housing market recovered. In the third quarter of 1983, for example, net income rose to $7.8 million, contrasted to a loss of $3.6 million in the comparable quarter of 1982. **********Coldwell acknowledges that Sears provided some of the financing for the expansion. And this help will continue as Coldwell tries to grow toward its goal of 3,000 offices by 1990, a residential sales force of 80,000 - and an ambitious 12 percent of the home resale market. Some 400 of the new offices are to be Sears booths, with the total reaching 250 this year. **********Coldwell Banker, founded in 1906, operated for years only in commercial real estate, which it now does with 1,800 brokers in 73 commercial offices. In 1969 it entered the residential market by acquiring the big southern California firm of Forest E. Olson. **********Coldwell also has two units that make mortgage loans for both commercial and residential real estate. That puts them potentially into competition with the Sears Savings Bank, whose $5 billion in assets ranks it 11th among California thrift units. **********According to Mr. Poulson, Coldwell has not yet exploited the potential synergies with Dean Witter or Allstate - a failure he attributes to Sears's lack of a chief operating officer at headquarters. **********''Don't get me wrong,'' Mr. Poulson said of the lack of control from Sears at the division level. ''I'd prefer to have it that way than the other way around, I assure you.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/27/busin.body_text: **********The United States Gypsum Company and the Masonite Corporation, the country's leading producer of hardwood, announced yesterday that U.S. Gypsum would acquire Masonite for about $380 million in cash. **********The companies said their boards had approved a tender offer by U.S. Gypsum of $38 a share in cash for all the outstanding common stock, about 9,961,000 shares, of Masonite. **********''I think it's a super acquisition and a logical product-line extension into businesses both companies know very well,'' said Laurence H. Hirschhorn, an analyst for the First Boston Corporation. He also said Masonite had received an atttractive price. **********Earnings 'About to Bubble' **********''Masonite is a low-cost producer with a strong position in the market and its earnings are about to bubble,'' Mr. Hirschhorn said. **********''I'm quite positive,'' said Jonathan L. Goldfarb, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. ''It makes sense for both companies. I think Masonite received a good price.'' **********Both Edward W. Duffy, chairman of U.S. Gypsum, and Robert N. Rasmus, chairman of Masonite, said the acquisition would enable expansion, development and efficiencies that would benefit both companies. **********Shareholders of Masonite must still approve the deal. One of the conditions of the offer is that a minimum of 5,386,000 shares, or about 54 percent of the shares outstanding, be tendered. The offer will expire at midnight, Eastern standard time, on April 20, unless extended, and withdrawal rights will expire at midnight on April 13. **********Masonite also announced yesterday that it had granted U.S. Gypsum an option to buy up to 1,842,750 authorized but unissued shares of common stock for $38 a share if for some reason the tender offer was not completed. Excercise of that option would result in U.S. Gypsum owning about 18.5 percent of Masonite shares currently outstanding. **********General Felt's Stake **********Masonite's stock stood at $24.75 a share on Feb. 22, and on Feb. 23, General Felt Industries purchased 6.3 percent of Masonite, driving the stock up $2.50, to $27.25. Masonite said at the time that it would ''aggressively oppose any effort to acquire a large position in its stock at bargain prices.'' **********Masonite stock rose $2 yesterday, to $37.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Thus General Felt, based on the $38 offer by U.S. Gypsum, could realize a profit of about $9 million on its roughly 630,000 Masonite shares. **********A spokesman for General Felt said yesterday that the company had no comment on the U.S. Gypsum-Masonite deal. **********U.S. Gypsum, which like Masonite has its headquarters in Chicago, is a diversified manufacturer and marketer of products and services for the construction and industrial processed markets. **********Salomon Brothers Inc. will act as dealer manager for the tender offer. Goldman, Sachs & Company is acting as financial adviser to Masonite.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/23/busin.main_headline: HOW A STOCK SCANDAL LED TO A PROOFREADER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/23/busin.print_headline: HOW A STOCK SCANDAL LED TO A PROOFREADER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/23/busin.body_text: **********It began, innocently enough, with a series of late-night cab rides. When Kenneth Petricig finished his job as a night proofreader at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, he would often find Stephen L. Wallis driving the cab he rode home. **********Gradually, their conversation turned to corporate takeovers - the firm's specialty. And by November 1982 the two men had formed a partnership that seemed full of promise, but which ended two and a half years later with Mr. Wallis's arrest as he was preparing to leave for Switzerland. **********Their partnership, as outlined in court papers, was simple and, it seemed, foolproof: Mr. Wallis would pay Mr. Petricig for information on planned corporate takeovers that Mr. Petricig gleaned from proofreading Skadden, Arps documents. Mr. Wallis would then trade stock on the basis of this information. **********But before it ended, they and two other Skadden, Arps clerical employees, a stockbroker and the cab driver's woman friend found themselves drawn into a complex scheme that had them acting like characters out of a spy novel. **********Clandestine Meetings **********They held clandestine meetings in bars, movie theaters and even taxicabs. They made midnight calls on pay phones, referred to each other by code names and used foreign bank accounts. **********But unknown to them, they were being watched - by a team of investigators that grew to include the law firm itself, private investigators, the New York Stock Exchange, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the office of the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. **********Investigators rifled garbage cans, retrieving slips of paper with company names and stock prices. A Skadden, Arps supervisor monitored one suspected clerk as he searched through the firm's confidential computer files for takeover information. **********In all, six people have pleaded guilty to a variety of charges related to insider trading and are awaiting sentencing. How much money was involved? According to court records, it is difficult to determine. **********Advance knowledge of takeover battles can prove extremely valuable. Investors acting on such insider information can buy a target company's stock before the announced acquisition bid and then sell when the stock price rises on the basis of the bid, which is generally considerably higher than the going price of the stock. **********Because of the powerful lure of such profits, firms that advise companies on takeover battles are vulnerable to abuse of the inside information they hold, and Skadden, Arps is one of the most important such firms. **********The Skadden, Arps case is but one of an increasing number of insider trading schemes that have led the S.E.C. and the United States Attorney's office to step up enforcement.  Recent cases have led to guilty pleas from, among others, a partner at the law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz and a vice president of mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley & Company, according to Andrew J. Levander, an Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District, which includes Wall Street. **********The Skadden, Arps case shows how a group of clerical employees, lured by promises of wealth from canny investors, succumbed to temptation and circumvented their firms' security precautions. **********Two Separate Schemes **********Investigators eventually uncovered two separate insider trading schemes, linked only by their mutual source at Skadden, Arps. Court papers filed by the S.E.C. and the United States Attorney's office outlined the schemes as follows: **********In one, Mr. Petricig, who is 23 years old, sold the 30-year-old Mr. Wallis information about planned corporate takeovers. Eventually, Mr. Petricig began pooling tips with Alfred T. Salvatore Jr., a 40-year-old Skadden, Arps proofreader and word processing operator. **********In the second scheme, Mr. Salvatore and Steven M. Crow, a 29-year- old word processing supervisor at Skadden, Arps, were sharing the tips with two stockbrokers, Aaron L. Lerman and Stephen G. Karanzalis. **********Using the information they obtained from Skadden, Arps, the brokers, Mr. Wallis and Sharon Willey, a veterinary manager who lives with Mr. Wallis, traded on the stock market. **********Their trades included the following corporate takeover battles: the Mesa Petroleum Company's bid for the General American Oil Company of Texas; the Coastal Corporation's bids for the Texas Gas Resources Corporation and the Houston Natural Gas Corporation; the Maryland Cup Company's bid for Fort Howard Paper; Calvin Klein's bid for the Puritan Fashions Corporation; the Williams Companies' bid for the Northwest Energy Company; the Evmar Corporation's bid for the Midlands Energy Company; the Gulf Broadcast Company's bid for the Conwood Corporation; Kelso & Company's bid for U.S. Industries; a leveraged buyout involving Morgan Stanley & Company and Southwest Forest Industries, and a buyout involving the First Boston Corporation and the Joslyn Manufacturing and Supply Company. **********Six Plead Guilty **********Mr. Salvatore, Mr. Crow, Mr. Lerman, Mr. Petricig, Mr. Wallis and Miss Willey have all pleaded guilty to criminal charges of conspiracy or fraud. No criminal charges will be brought against Mr. Karanzalis, although he is negotiating with the S.E.C. on its civil charges against him and plans to leave the brokerage profession, according to his lawyer, Robert J. Costello. **********The other participants in the case either did not return calls or, through their attorneys, declined to comment.  Mr. Salvatore did not return calls left on his answering machine and his attorney, Paul Grand, did not return messages left at his office. **********The following accounts of the cases are based on papers filed in court and interviews with the United States Attorney's office, the executive partner and managing director of Skadden, Arps and an official at the New York Stock Exchange who asked to remain anonymous. **********Kenneth Petricig was a quiet, reserved proofreader at Skadden, Arps, a graduate of Columbia University with an interest in movies, according to his attorney, Barry Fallick. Mr. Petricig's involvement in the case began after he met Mr. Wallis, a driver for Dial-A-Car, a cab service used by Skadden, Arps for employees who worked late. **********Mr. Wallis, who is dark-haired, bearded, a college graduate and, court papers say, something of an expert on the stock market and foreign bank secrecy laws, promised Mr. Petricig $5,000 or more for each profitable tip. **********'I Foolishly Agreed' **********In court, Mr. Petricig described their meeting this way: ''I met, by chance, someone who suggested to me that he could develop a method whereby we could both benefit financially from my knowledge. And I foolishly agreed to it.'' But Mr. Wallis, during his guilty plea, said Mr. Petricig had asked for his phone number. **********After the two had agreed to their insider trading scheme, they often met in Mr. Wallis's cab to discuss potential takeovers. By 1983, Mr. Petricig had begun pooling information with his Skadden, Arps colleague, Mr. Salvatore. **********Mr. Petricig got in touch with Mr. Wallis by calling Mr. Wallis's beeper and dialing in a pay telephone number. Mr. Wallis would then call him back at that number. During these conversations, the two arranged meetings in the cab or at a movie theater on East 34th Street. Miss Willey, who is 31, would sometimes accompany Mr. Wallis, but he said in his guilty plea that she had often waited outside or in a restaurant. **********Mr. Wallis talked to Mr. Petricig knowledgeably about the legal definition of insider trading, referring often to a famous case in which the conviction of a printer of financial documents who used his knowledge to trade in the stock market was overturned. Sometimes he referred to foreign brokerage accounts in code, saying they were in Iowa or Nebraska. **********When Mr. Wallis placed orders for stocks, he often called foreign brokers from pay phones to avoid having his name appear on brokerage records. But he also placed orders with Charles Schwab & Company and Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc. **********Meetings Recorded **********Last April, after investigators confronted Mr. Petricig with evidence they had accumulated against him, he began secretly recording his meetings with Mr. Wallis. During a cab ride from Brooklyn to Manhattan, Mr. Wallis gave Mr. Petricig $1,000 as a result of profits he made from trades of Houston Natural Gas.  He also gave Mr. Petricig two guides to Swiss bank accounts. **********In early May, Mr. Wallis told Mr. Petricig that he was planning to go to Switzerland and that ''the only person I would trust is going to be accompanying me.'' The two arranged to meet for what would be the last time, on May 19, in the East Side movie theater. **********While the theater showed ''Romancing the Stone,'' a tale of adventure and intrigue in the Colombian jungle, Mr. Wallis handed Mr. Petricig $2,000. Outside the theater, Federal agents waited. When Mr. Wallis walked out, they arrested him. Then they drove to the Brooklyn apartment of Mr. Wallis and Miss Willey and arrested her, suitcases in hand, before their scheduled flight to Switzerland. They pleaded guilty on Thursday and will be sentenced in September. **********It is not known how much money Mr. Wallis and Miss Willey made from their stock market trades. Mr.  Petricig received a total of $5,000. **********Substantial Profits Suspected **********But Mr. Levander, who was in charge of the United States Attorney's investigation, said he believed the two had made substantial profits. Some of that money could be in foreign bank accounts. Mr. Wallis said in court that he had a bank account with a Bahamas branch of a Swiss bank. **********But information from Skadden, Arps was not flowing only to Mr. Wallis and Miss Willey. Mr. Salvatore, who is balding and of medium height, agreed in 1982 to share information about corporate takeovers with Mr. Lerman, a former Prudential-Bache stockbroker who was then his roommate in an apartment on Irving Place and unemployed at the time. **********Mr. Lerman, who walks with a slight limp, also shared his information with Mr. Karanzalis, who was then a broker with Prudential-Bache. In 1983, Mr. Salvatore recruited Mr. Crow, a word-processing supervisor who was studying for a doctorate. Mr. Crow used the code name ''Barbara.'' **********The two Skadden, Arps employees began collaborating in an effort to break the law firm's coded references to its clients. As one of its security precautions, Skadden, Arps routinely referred to its clients by code names, such as Mozart, and avoided disclosing real names until the evening that legal documents had to be typed and proofread. **********Pooled Information **********Mr. Crow worked the 11 P.M. to 5 A.M. shift, and Mr. Salvatore worked a slightly earlier one. Between shifts, they would meet either in the firm's word-processing center or at bars to pool their information.  First Mr. Salvatore and Mr. Crow would try to identify lawyers who were working on tender offers and get access to their confidential computer files. From these they gathered data on stock prices, numbers of shares outstanding and other relevant information, and passed it on to Mr. Lerman or Mr. Karanzalis, who would be able to identify the companies involved. **********But by the fall of 1983, Skadden, Arps knew that some of its employees were leaking information. The New York Stock Exchange's surveillance division, which uses computers to track stock trades, had noticed in the spring of 1983 a pattern of stock trading before the announcement of several mergers. The same brokers handled these trades, and in every one, the law firm involved was Skadden, Arps. The exchange notified the law firm and the S.E.C., which both began investigations. **********'We Were Outraged' **********Peter Mullen, the executive partner at Skadden, Arps, said the firm had included in its security precautions the requirement that all employees sign a pledge of confidentiality that defines insider trading. ''We lawyers are professionally obligated to hold the confidences of our clients in confidence,'' Mr. Mullen said. ''We were outraged to find out'' that some of the firm's employees were violating that trust, he said. **********Private investigators hired by Skadden, Arps followed Mr. Crow and Mr. Salvatore, stationing themselves near the two men's apartments. They saw Mr. Salvatore make late-night calls from pay phones and leave an apartment with a man who walked with a limp - Mr. Lerman. They clocked their meetings in bars in Greenwich Village and even in the lobby of Skadden, Arps's building at 919 Third Avenue. **********On several occasions last February and March, an investigator watched as Mr. Salvatore threw out a large white garbage bag. The investigator fished one of the bags out and found crumpled pieces of paper that included the firm's secret computer codes, telephone numbers of stockbrokers, names of Skadden, Arps clients and amounts of their tender offers, and analyses of the firm's confidential documents. **********In March 1984, a word-processing supervisor at Skadden, Arps secretly monitored Mr. Crow's work. The supervisor watched as Mr. Crow searched through the firm's coded computer files - files on which he had not been assigned any work. Mr. Crow programmed the computer to search for dollar signs and stopped to read all such references. **********U.S. Agents Move In **********With evidence accumulating, Federal agents moved in on March 14. That morning, a private investigator watched Mr. Salvatore walk out of his apartment to a nearby pay phone, carrying a typewritten slip of paper. **********Later that afternoon, Federal agents arrested Mr. Salvatore and Mr. Crow at Skadden, Arps and Mr. Lerman while he was sleeping in Mr. Salvatore's apartment. Mr. Karanzalis was not arrested or charged with any criminal offenses, although he is facing civil charges filed by the S.E.C. Neither his attorney nor Mr. Levander would say why. **********The four men, court papers state, had agreed to share whatever profits they made in stock trading. When Mr. Salvatore made his guilty plea, he said he had received a total of $8,375 for passing on the information. Mr. Crow received only $500, last February. **********At the same time, court papers said, Mr. Karanzalis paid Mr. Lerman $16,000 for profits connected with the Coastal Corporation's bid for Houston Natural Gas. Court papers do not indicate total profits made by Mr. Lerman or Mr. Karanzalis, although they show that the brokers' clients made substantial profits, which may have yielded handsome commissions. **********After the arrest and guilty pleas of Mr. Crow, Mr. Lerman and Mr. Salvatore, investigators discovered the second plot, involving Mr. Wallis, Mr. Petricig and Miss Willey. When Mr. Salvatore was arrested, he told the United States Attorney's office that Mr. Petricig and he had been sharing information, Mr. Fallick said. Mr. Fallick said he had advised Mr. Petricig to cooperate with the Government, which led to the arrests of Mr. Wallis and Miss Willey. **********Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for the Southern District, said his office and the S.E.C. were aggressively prosecuting insider traders, pressing for tough sentences in an effort to curb the practice. However, he said, many of the insider traders prosecuted have received suspended sentences. **********The S.E.C. set up a special unit under the direction of John M. Fedders to ferret out insider trading, and Mr. Fedders said he believed the commission was having some success in deterring potential abusers. **********''A lot of people got to believe that insider trading was risk-free,'' Mr. Fedders said. ''We are raising the level of risk.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/26/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; ; Shearson Tombstones Given to Albert Frank
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/26/busin.body_text: **********In a shoot-out between Albert Frank-Guenther Law and Doremus & Company, Wall Street's best-known agencies, Albert Frank, the smaller, has walked off with the tombstone advertising account of the recently merged Shearson Lehman/American Express. Billings are expected to be in the $6 million-$8 million range. **********The winning agency had been doing what is more properly called financial notice advertising for Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb before it was acquired last May by Shearson/American Express, for whom Doremus was doing the tombstones. **********As you might imagine, it is pretty hard to have a creative shootout between agencies that on the surface seem contains nothing creative. Cathleen Stewart, director of consumer marketing at the client, admitted that it did come down to ''nuances and chemistry.'' But, she said that she also wanted creativity in an area where few expect it. **********''I am adamant that we get more out of this than there appears to be,'' she said, noting that Albert Frank, being the smaller agency, was important because it makes her account even that more important to it. **********Albert Frank is a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding, while Doremus is owned by BBDO International.  McCann-Erickson has about $25 million in billings from Shearson.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/13/busin.body_text: **********Businesses in the United States plan to spend a record $343.6 billion on modernization and expansion this year, up 13.6 percent from 1983, the Commerce Department said today. **********The Administration welcomed the survey as further proof of a ''thriving economy,'' and one private analyst said the nation appeared headed for a ''full-scale capital spending boom.'' **********After adjustment for inflation, the rise in capital spending expected this year is 12 percent - after three years of declines, including a 3.8 percent drop last year - and would be the biggest increase since a 13.4 percent inflation-adjusted gain in 1966. **********The new estimate was based on a Government survey of business investment plans in late January and February. It is more optimistic than a year-end survey that projected a 9.4 percent rise after inflation. **********'Particularly Healthy' Sign **********''These are super numbers that begin to show signs of a full-scale capital spending boom,'' said Jerry Jasinowski, chief economist of the National Association of Manufacturers. ''This is a particularly healthy response with interest rates as high as they are.'' **********Analysts are watching business investment closely because it is expected to keep the recovery going after consumer spending slows. **********Although actual spending is unlikely to rise as much as the planned 12 percent, according to Mr. Jasinowski, about 10 percent is possible. **********''You can quibble about the decimal point, but there is no question that we are going to see strong investment spending in 1984,'' said Robert Wescott, an economist with Wharton Econometrics, a private forecasting firm. ''Consumer spending has been very strong, and manufacturers have to gear up to meet demand.'' **********Comment Issued by Baldrige **********Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said the new forecast showed that a ''thriving economy has encouraged firms to raise their capital spending plans.'' **********He said spending should be 18 percent higher, after adjustment for inflation, at the end of this year than it was in November 1982, at the depth of the recession. **********But Mr. Baldrige warned that the surge in investment could be cut short at the end of the year by high interest rates unless the huge Federal budget deficit was reduced. **********Manufacturing investment is expected to rise 15.7 percent (inflation- adjusted) in 1984, after a 5.3 percent decline last year. Nonmanufacturing investment is expected to rise 10 percent; in 1983 it fell 2.9 percent. **********Record in Constant Dollars **********The total spending, expressed in constant 1972 dollars, is projected at a record $162 billion, up from 1983's $144.6 billion. The old constant-dollar mark was $159.1 billion in 1980. **********The increases in investment are expected to be broad-based, with improvement in all sectors except the troubled airline industry. Its investment is expected to decline 26.2 percent this year in current dollars, before inflation is taken into account. **********The biggest rise in investment is planned by auto makers, with an aggregate increase of 34 percent, in contrast to a 1983 drop of 9.4 percent. **********In the survey, manufacturers said they expected sales to increase 11.5 percent this year, compared with a 7.5 percent rise in 1983.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/26/world.main_headline: 60 Rebels Said to Die In Philippine Flare-Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/26/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 60 Rebels Said to Die In Philippine Flare-Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/26/world.body_text: **********An army commander said today that about 60 rebels had died and 1,000 villagers had fled their homes in guerrilla warfare that swept the southern Philippines over the last three weeks. **********Two army battalions have joined the battle and five more are on alert in case the fighting increases, said Brig. Gen. Jaime Echeverria, commander in the province of Davao del Norte, 500 miles south of Manila. **********General Echeverria, whose troops were shelling rebel positions with 105- millimeter howitzers, said in a telephone interview that the army was in ''full control'' against about 400 Moslem and Communist guerrillas. **********Only two Government soldiers have been killed, he said. **********General Echeverria said about 1,000 people had fled villages in the battle area and taken shelter in schools in Pantukan, a coastal town on the Davao Gulf.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/06/world.main_headline: LAWMAKERS URGE REAGAN TO DELAY SHIPMENT OF PLUTONIUM TO JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/06/world.print_headline: LAWMAKERS URGE REAGAN TO DELAY SHIPMENT OF PLUTONIUM TO JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/06/world.body_text: **********Five Senators and 10 members of Congress have urged President Reagan to delay an order that would allow 417 pounds of plutonium - enough for 30 nuclear bombs - to be shipped from France to Japan. **********The transfer is subject to United States approval because the plutonium originated in nuclear fuel from the United States. Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel has approved the move, but the lawmakers said Mr. Reagan can overrule his energy chief and delay shipment until more secure transfer arrangements can be made. The plutonium is for a breeder reactor. **********''The dangers posed by this shipment cannot be underestimated,'' the lawmakers, all Democrats, warned in a letter to Mr. Reagan that was written Friday and made public today. **********Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin, who circulated the letter in the Senate, said the freighter that would carry the radioactive cargo is unacceptably vulnerable to attack. With several years' worth of plutonium fuel already in Japan, he said, there is no reason to run the risk immediately, particularly when safer air transport methods are being developed and would be ready ''within a few years.''  'Tempting Target for Terrorists' **********Mr. Proxmire, in a statement released with the letter, said United States military forces already are committed to providing security for the Japanese freighter, including a military escort at sea.  But, the Senator added, ''I'm concerned about whether even that security is enough.'' **********''It would be a tempting target for terrorists or a hostile country that wanted to quickly get some fuel for a nuclear bomb,'' Mr. Proxmire said. ''If the ship were attacked or, worse yet, if it were captured, the President would be faced with having to send in U.S. forces to recapture it - and that could result in U.S. military casualties. **********''Should we face the possibility of those casualties - especially since the Japanese don't need the plutonium at the moment?'' Mr. Proxmire asked. ''No way.'' **********Besides Mr. Proxmire, the Senators signing the letter were Gary Hart of Colorado, Alan Cranston of California, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Carl Levin of Michigan. **********Representatives signing the letter were Richard L. Ottinger of New York, Howard Wolpe of Michigan, Michael D. Barnes of Maryland, Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts, Peter H. Kostmayer of Pennsylvania, Howard L. Berman of California, Ted Weiss of New York, Mel Levine of California, Berkley Bedell of Iowa and Edward F. Feighan of Ohio.

In an unprecedented 20-minute trading spree, its stock soared to 89 a share from $35 , setting a record for the fastest pre share price increase in Wall Street ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/18/busin.body_text: **********ON Oct. 14, 1980, Genentech, then a four-year-old biotechnology company, went public.  In an unprecedented 20-minute trading spree, its stock soared to 89 a share from $35 , setting a record for the fastest pre share price increase in Wall Street history.  Five months later, Cetus, the oldest biotech concern, raised $107 million, at the time the largest initial public offering in american corporate history. **********Biotechnology as a business had arrived, with prospectuses and annual reports promising a cornucopls of miracles: wonder drugs, a second green revolution, chemicals and fuels from non-petroleum sources, an environment free of toxic chemicals. **********At last tally, corporate America had invested more than $1 billion in genetic engineering research.  But so far, the product pickings have been meager.  Laboratory breakthroughs have not proven easy to translate into production realities.  Plummeting oil prices have made the economics of petroleum subsitutes less atractive.  Ethical questions about releasing altered bacteria into the environment still abound.  all told, the century probably will have turned before the expected hood of biotechnology products materalizes. **********''The failure to get a lot of products to market right away took some of the wind out of biotech's sails,'' siad Zsolt Harsanyl, a consultant who, in a previous job with the United States Office of Technology Assessment, directed the first wide-ranging study on the impacts of biotechnology.  ''But the technology will eventually keep many of the promises made for it.'' **********The playing field may be less crowded by then, as smaller companies run out of cash and are forced to merge.  It is already happening - Gibco has bought Bethesda Reasearch Labs, W.R. Grace owns Cetus's Madison division, Johnson & Johnson bought Immunotech, and Lubrixol has offered to buy Agrigenetics. **********For now, the list of commercial products is small.  It includes two amino acid components of the artificial sweetener aspartame; human insulin; a genetically engineered vaccine that prevents diarhea in new born pigs; diagnostic kits for several venereal diseases.  And there are some products - a drain cleaner that disolves human hair, for example, and a bacteria generated artificial snow for ski slopes - that few people mentioned when they discussed biotechnology's future. **********Nevertheless, the biotechnology revolution continues to gather steam, and more and more products are making it past the drawing board stage.  ''The thing about biotechnology is that its applications are only limited by our imaginations,'' said Susan Clymer, marketing strategist at Bio-Response, a company specializing in biotechnology-based products.  ''And at the moment, imagination is running unchecked.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/26/busin.main_headline: HOUSE VOTES ANTICRIME MEASURE AND SENATE EASES ABORTION RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/26/busin.print_headline: HOUSE VOTES ANTICRIME MEASURE AND SENATE EASES ABORTION RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/26/busin.body_text: **********The House today approved the Reagan Administration's anticrime package and the Senate voted to widen permitted uses of Medicaid funds for abortion as the 98th Congress rushed toward adjournment. **********Supporters of both bills attributed their success to election-year politics, as well a desire to avoid unnecessary strife in Congress and meet the scheduled adjournment date of Oct. 4. **********Both the House of Representatives and the Senate Appropriations Committee approved emergency spending bills of about $500 billion each, needed to keep some Government agencies operating after Oct. 1, the start of the fiscal year 1985. The emergency spending measure is needed because Congress has thus far approved only 4 of the 13 money bills, or appropriations, that are supposed to be enacted by the start of the fiscal year. **********Maneuver on Anticrime Package **********The House voted 243 to 166 to approve the anticrime package and attach it to the emergency spending measure. The package included new Federal sentencing procedures, preventive detention of defendants considered dangerous, tougher bail and drug laws and a more restrictive insanity defense. **********The measure, sponsored by Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican of upstate New York, was approved by the Senate last February by a vote of 91 to 1. President Reagan has repeatedly urged passage by the House, but its Democratic leaders had steadfastly refused to bring the measure to the floor until Republicans used a procedural tactic to allow consideration of the bill today. **********''This just proves that the Democratic leadership was denying an opportunity for an up or down vote on the President's package, which would pass overwhelmingly,'' said Representative Dan Lungren, Republican of California. **********Bill Has 'Better Chance' **********Representative Robert S. Walker, a Pennsylvania Republican, noted that the White House had threatened to veto the spending bill, which puts Federal spending over Administration budget levels and contains projects of interest to individual Congressmen. **********''The President's probably going to veto a pork bill,'' he said, ''If you put the crime package there, it has a better chance of being enacted into law.'' **********The Senate abortion measure, attached to a different spending bill and approved without debate, would allow the use of Medicaid funds in cases of rape or incest, as well as when the life of the mother was endangered. Under current law, such funds can be used only to save the life of the mother. **********''I don't think anybody wants to stand up in an election year and say that a woman should carry a baby to term when that pregnancy is the result of rape or incest,'' said Senator Lowell P. Weicker, a Connecticut Republican who is chairman of the Appropriation Subcommittee on Labor, Health and Human Services and Education. **********The abortion measure proposed by the subcommittee was approved on a voice vote. It was part of the spending bill for the Departments of Labor and Health and Human Services that was approved by a vote of 71 to 20. **********The Senate Appropriations Committee had voted 12 to 11 today to keep the current restrictions on abortion, but the committee action was superseded by the full Senate. **********The Senate also voted to ease the existing prohibition on the use of Federal funds to prevent organized school prayer. Senator Jesse Helms, a North Carolina Republican, initially proposed language providing that ''none of the funds approved shall be used to prevent the implementation of programs of voluntary prayer and meditation in the public schools.'' **********This stricture is in current law. But rather than risk a floor fight, Mr. Helms himself proposed a modification that read, ''None of the funds appropriated shall be used to prevent individual prayer and meditation in the public schools.''  Some Deplore Speed **********Final action on the stop-gap spending bill is considered imperative before the lawmakers can return home. But some members nonetheless deplored both the haste and questioned the necessity of today's action. **********''None of us here thinks that this is the way we should do business, and I deplore it as well,'' Senator Mark O. Hatfield, an Oregon Republican who is chairman of the Appropriations Committee, said at the panel's meeting. **********The House approved the spending bill by a vote of 316 to 91. But there were expressions of dismay, like Senator Hatfield's, after the House adopted seven amendments that added money for special projects. Some of these funds could be dropped in conference with the Senate. **********Administration officials have warned that the President would veto the bill if Congress, adhering to past practices, loaded it up with pork-barrel projects. The Administration regards as excessive the largest of the seven additional sums, $15.4 billion for water projects. **********''This is the inevitable Christmas tree bill, the last train leaving the staton,'' said Representative Gillis W. Long, a Louisiana Democrat who is chairman of the House Democratic Caucus. **********But the House also reduced some funding, cutting by two percent the funds for all foreign aid programs except those earmarked for Israel and Egypt. The vote was 273 to 134. Representative George E. Brown Jr., a Colorado Republican, estimated that the reduction would save the Government $280 million. **********In a separate action House and Senate conferees approved a $932 billion budget resolution for the new fiscal year, with a deficit of $181.2 billion. House approval of the conference report will constitute approval of an increase in the Federal debt limit, which is a companion resolution. That will obviate the need for a separate debt-ceiling vote in the House, which has been more resistant than the Senate to approving this perennial measure. **********Funds for Special Projects **********Both the House and Senate spending bills were replete with funds for special projects. The House approved, 336-64, a proposal to incorporate a $15.4 billion water projects bill. **********The House bill also included $159.5 million for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting for fiscal year 1987, the level already set for fiscal year 1986; an amendment to ensure that Food Stamp beneficiaries are able to purchase an adequate diet under the Agriculture Department's ''Thrifty Food Plan,'' and $50 million to the states to train child-care staffs. **********The Senate committee bill also included $72.9 million for 23 public works projects, $30 million below the House level. The bill also included $30 million for new military construction, $9.3 million for reclamation projects, $13 million for environmental projects, $75.7 million for the Developmental Disabilities Act and $50 million for refugee resettlement. The committee bill also provides funds for the ''Thrifty Food Plan'' and would authorize the Small Business Administration to guarantee repayment of pollution control bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/16/busin.main_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Foreign Issue Included In Treasury Note Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/16/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Foreign Issue Included In Treasury Note Sale
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/16/busin.body_text: **********The Treasury announced plans yesterday to sell on Nov. 28 about $6.75 billion of new five-year, two-month notes in the domestic market and an additional $1 billion of notes with the same maturity to foreign investors. The issues will mature Feb. 15, 1990. **********The foreign offering will be the second such sale by the Treasury. Last month, $1 billion of four-year notes were auctioned. The four-year issue resulted in an interest rate to the Treasury that was about 32 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, less than the rate on the domestic financing, and Treasury officials hope for nearly as large a savings at the sale of the five-year, two-month notes. **********Although there is no set schedule for Treasury offerings to foreigners, officials said that new issues with maturities between 2 and 10 years would be prime candidates for overseas sales. The issues offered overseas are a cross between registered securities sold in the domestic market and bearer securities commonly used in the Eurobond market. **********Under Treasury rules, owners of the new foreign-targeted notes need not be identified, but securities dealers and banks must certify annually that they are not holding the securities on behalf of American citizens or residents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/17/world.main_headline: RUSSIAN EX-U.N. EMPLOYEE SAYS SOVIET VIOLATES CHARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/17/world.print_headline: RUSSIAN EX-U.N. EMPLOYEE SAYS SOVIET VIOLATES CHARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/17/world.body_text: **********A former Soviet employee here who defected rather than return to Moscow says the Soviet Mission is violating the United Nations Charter by requiring Soviet citizens who work for the Secretariat to follow the mission's orders. **********They also must provide a host of services for the Soviet Government, according to the former Secretariat employee, Vladimir V. Yakimetz. **********Mr. Yakimetz, 47 years old, held a middle-level position in the Office of Program Planning and Coordination, which makes long-range plans for the administration of the United Nations. **********According to United Nations rules, the Soviet Government should have had no control over Mr. Yakimetz. According to Article 100 of the Charter, a Secretariat employee is forbidden to ''seek or receive instruction from any government.'' **********Yet, in interviews here recently, Mr. Yakimetz detailed what is privately conceded by diplomats and officials: that Soviet citizens working in the Secretariat are expected to provide services to their Government.   'Under Mission's Orders' **********''I functioned directly under the mission's orders,'' he said. ''I did not lift a finger without the Soviet Mission knowing about it. We might be asked to analyze a certain report or to prepare materials for a particular agenda item at the General Assembly. You can be asked to spy on your division at the U.N. Certainly, you are asked to report on transfers and promotions, to find out where there might be chances to get in more Soviet employees.'' **********For two years, Mr. Yakimetz was on a six-member committee that advised the appointments and promotions board of the Secretariat. In that post, he said, he operated directly under instructions from the Soviet Mission. **********''It was my direct responsibility to see that every Russian proposed by the Government was admitted,'' he said. Another obligation was to block action on people the mission deemed undesirable. **********Mr. Yakimetz, a former physics instructor at the Moscow Physical-Technical Institute in a Moscow suburb, said Soviet employees were asked to collect scientific and technical data, and for that purpose he joined the American Physical Society. **********''I sent a lot of stuff to Moscow,'' he said. ''They were pretty interested in it. As a member of the American Physical Society, I received newsletters and magazines.''  Products on Strategic List **********He added that, as a member of the Secretariat, he communicated with American companies involved in high technology.  Not one of the papers he saw was secret. But, he said, ''some of the products, I presume, are on the strategic list, because some of the manufacturers I corresponded with were among the companies that were selling strategic equipment to Moscow through third countries.'' **********A spokesman for the Soviet Mission, Anatoly N. Khudyakov, said he had no comment on Mr. Yakimetz's remarks. **********Mr. Yakimetz said he defected because he feared that the Soviet Government was trying to cut short his career at the United Nations. He said that, in late 1982 and early 1983, the personnel director of the Soviet Mission pressed him to return to Moscow and train a replacement. He was granted political asylum in February 1983.   Contract Extension Denied **********Last December, under pressure from the Soviet Mission, the office of Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar refused to extend Mr. Yakimetz's contract. A spokesman for Mr. Perez de Cuellar said that Mr. Yakimetz, having been temporarily assigned to the United Nations by his Government, could not stay against its will. **********Most Western employees of the Secretariat are private citizens, although many have earlier served in their governments. But citizens of most Communist countries are employed by their governments and are detached to work for the Secretariat. **********Some senior Secretariat officials concede that the Russians do not technically adhere to the rules on the independence of international civil servants, and staff members with knowledge of Soviet practices say that, in effect, even when Eastern bloc citizens serve in the Secretariat they are treated as if they are still members of their own government bureaucracies. **********Mr. Yakimetz appealed the decision of the Secretary General's office to a three-person administrative tribunal headed by a Hungarian. Last month, the tribunal, meeting in Geneva, denied the request. **********In the interview, Mr. Yakimetz said that he had spent nearly 15 years pursuing his career. ''I see my life as completely disrupted by this decision,'' he said. ''Of course, the Soviet Government will be glad to hear that.'' **********Mr. Yakimetz left his job when his contract renewal was rejected by Mr. Perez de Cuellar. Since then, he said, his only income has come from occasional translation jobs. Mr. Yakimetz said he and his wife, Alla, a dentist who worked in the Soviet Mission before his defection, have been denied contact with their daughter and their parents in Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/09/busin.body_text: **********Colgate-Palmolive To Pick New Chief **********The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that Keith Crane, chairman and chief executive officer, would relinquish his duties as chief executive on May 3. Directors expect to name Reuben Mark, 45-year-old president and chief operating officer, to succeed him, the company said. **********The company, in its announcement, stressed that the change was one step in a succession program begun by Mr. Crane five years ago. Mr. Crane, who will be 63 on May 2, has been chief executive for five years and a company executive for 47 years. **********The company also announced that responsibility for operations of the global company would be divided between William S. Shanahan and J. Dale Sherratt, currently executive vice presidents. Each will be named senior executive vice president-chief of operations. **********Mr. Shanahan will run ''worldwide Colgate and related businesses'' and Mr. Sherratt will be responsible for ''Kendall and related hospital, industrial and fiber businesses,'' the announcement said. Kendall is a subsidiary specializing in health-care and other products. **********Mr. Crane, a native of New Zealand, joined the company in 1937 in the New Zealand accounting office. After holding several international positions, he was named president of the New York-based company in 1975. **********Mr. Mark, born in Jersey City, joined Colgate in 1963. He was named an executive vice president in 1981 and president a year ago. He is a graduate of Middlebury College and the Harvard Business School. **********A spokesman, Connie Meehan, said that both Mr. Crane and Mr. Mark were out of town yesterday and unreachable. **********As a company policy, Colgate-Palmolive strives to keep a low profile with the press. ''I can't remember the last time Mr. Crane spoke to the press,'' said a person close to the company. **********The company was founded in 1806 by William Colgate, who came to New York from London and started making and selling soap through home deliveries. The company has now grown to a worldwide operation with sales of just under $5 billion annually.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/12/busin.body_text: **********Payments being made by Hitachi Ltd. to the International Business Machines Corporation will decrease as Hitachi develops new software, Hitachi officials said yesterday. **********The monthly payments, which range from $2 million to $4 million each, began last October and are to continue for eight years. They are part of a settlement that ended a lawsuit in which I.B.M. accused Hitachi of having stolen trade secrets. **********Kouichi Kanzaki, a spokesman for Hitachi's office of the president, said at a New York news conference yesterday that I.B.M. would examine Hitachi's new software, or computer programming, to see if it resembled that produced by I.B.M.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/24/busin.body_text: **********Dollar Mostly Lower; Gold Prices Also Fall **********By The Associated Press **********The dollar fell against most other major currencies in United States and European trading yesterday. **********Gold prices also edged lower. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted gold as of 4 P.M. at $386 a troy ounce, down 50 cents from Thursday. **********Currency dealers said the dollar was steady for the most part in Europe before dipping on news that the United States consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent last month, down from an advance of six-tenths of 1 percent in January. The report suggested that the Federal Reserve might be able to avoid tightening credit. As rates rise or fall, so do yields on dollar-denominated investments. **********In Frankfurt trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 2.63 marks from 2.6435. The dollar also declined in the United States to 2.6220 marks from 2.6390. **********The dollar opened its trading day in Tokyo by climbing to 226.40 Japanese yen from 226.05 yen late Thursday. **********Pound Up to $1.4370 **********But later in London, the British pound rose to $1.4370 from $1.43015. The pound also gained in United States trading to $1.4350 from $1.4305. **********Other dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday, included 2.17025 Swiss francs, down from 2.17775; 8.09625 French francs, down from 8.1425; 2.9670 Dutch guilders, down from 2.9840; 1,626.75 Italian lire, down from 1,632.75, and 1.2760 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2748. **********Late dollar rates in United States trading, compared with Thursday, included 2.17 Swiss francs, down from 2.1775; 225.40 Japanese yen, down from 226.65; 8.0875 French francs, down from 8.1325, and 1.2766 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2760. **********In bullion trading, meanwhile, gold fell in Zurich to $388 an ounce from $390 late Thursday, and it declined in London to $388.50 an ounce from $389.75. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell to $388.74 an ounce from $392.99. **********In New York, gold for current delivery on the Commodity Exchange slipped 90 cents, to $386.30 an ounce. **********Silver followed gold in London, dropping to $9.365 a troy ounce from $9.4750 late Thursday. But on New York's Comex, silver for spot delivery managed a 3.5-cent gain, to $9.36 an ounce.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/21/world.main_headline: IRISH SAID TO SINK SPANISH TRAWLER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/21/world.print_headline: IRISH SAID TO SINK SPANISH TRAWLER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/21/world.body_text: **********Irish fishery patrol boats opened fire on a Spanish trawler in a confrontation that developed after the vessel was found fishing illegally in Irish waters, Irish officials said here today. **********According to the Spanish Ambassador, the fishing boat, the Sonia, sank after being hit by the gunfire, the Spanish news agency E.F.E. reported. But this could not be independently confirmed. **********The vessel had radioed that it was taking on water, and British Coast Guard officials said all 16 Spanish crewmen were rescued before dawn off Land's End in southwest England. No casualties were reported. **********Irish Defense Ministry officials said the patrol boats opened fire on the Spanish ship after it tried to ram one of the Irish boats during a five-hour chase that began Friday night in a gale.   Cannon Shells Are Fired **********The Defense Ministry said in a statement that the Irish vessels had fired a total of 596 rounds, ranging from small arms ammunition to 20-millimeter cannon shells. **********An Irish Defense Forces spokesman said the incident began when the fishery-protection vessel Aisling discovered the 330-ton Sonia off Wexford in southeast Ireland. **********The Irish spokesman said the Aisling and another fishery-protection vessel tried to put a boarding party on the Sonia, but were unable to board it because of rough seas and the unpredictable course of the Spanish vessel. **********The spokesman maintained that the Spanish ship had ignored all internationally recognized instructions to halt.   Ambassador Notified Quickly **********Luis Jordana de Pozas Fuentas, the Spanish Ambassador, told the Spanish news agency that he had been notified by the Irish Navy soon after the incident started. He relayed a message to the trawler ordering the captain to surrender to the Irish authorities, the news agency quoted him as having said. **********The Irish spokesman said the fishery-protection vessels began firing ''warning'' rounds of live ammunition in the chase across the Irish Sea. It said that although the first shots were fired over the trawler, shots were later aimed directly at it as it made repeated attempts to ram the Aisling. **********''During the ramming attempts, the Aisling fired shots into the vessel's bows and at the structural part of the vessel's bridge,'' the statement said. It said the shots were aimed to hit the trawler but miss the crew. **********The Irish vessels gave up the chase for fear of causing casualties when the trawler reached British waters, the Irish spokesman said.  West Germans Save 3 **********British Coast Guard said the trawler later radioed a distress call, saying it was taking on water in heavy seas and gale-force winds and was in imminent danger of sinking about 45 miles north of Land's End. **********A West German cargo ship, the 995- ton Achat, rescued three members of the trawler's crew. The other 13 were rescued by a Royal Air Force Sea King helicopter sent from its base at Brawdy in South Wales. Three other British vessels and another helicopter were also sent to the scene. **********The Press Association, the British domestic news agency, said the three trawler crewmen taken aboard the Hamburg-registered Achat were being taken to the Irish city of Waterford. The agency said the other 13, lifted to safety by the British helicopter before dawn, were taken to the Royal Air Force base at St. Mawgan in southwest England. **********One of the 13 Spaniards taken to St. Mawgan said one of the Irish boats had opened fire without warning.   'No Warning Shots' ''They fired directly on our boat and there were no warning shots,'' said Sabino Zubichray, 40 years old. **********Mr. Zubichray acknowledged that the Sonia was fishing inside Irish waters when the incident began Friday. But he said: ''Reports that we tried to ram the Irish ship are rubbish. It would be impossible. We had only a small fishing boat and wouldn't try anything like that.'' He said he knew of no guns aboard the Sonia. **********Speaking through an interpreter at the St. Mawgan base, Mr. Zubichray said: ''Our ship was hit everywhere. All the glass was broken. The bridge was shot to pieces. The ship was covered in holes, some small, some big.'' **********He said: ''We couldn't communicate with the Irish because all our radio equipment was destroyed when they opened fire. They fired immediately, and no warning was given.''  Official Inquiry Planned The spokesman for the Irish Defense Forces said Irish Government officials would get in touch with the Spanish Consul here about the affair. He said they also planned an official inquiry. **********Because Spain is not a member of the European Common Market, it is banned from fishing in the Community's waters. **********On March 7 two Spanish trawlers, the Burgoamendi and Valle de Atxondo, were fired on by a French Navy gunboat while illegally fishing in French waters. Nine fishermen were wounded, two seriously.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/26/busin.main_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN HEALTH CARE COSTS;
WHAT STATISTICS AND SURVEYS SHOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/26/busin.print_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN HEALTH CARE COSTS;
WHAT STATISTICS AND SURVEYS SHOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/26/busin.body_text: **********Employers are grumbling quite loudly about the cost of giving employees a free medical ride. Now Hewitt Associates, management consultants, has quantified those complaints, and has taken a look at how they translate into action. **********The firm surveyed 1,185 companies of all sizes and in all industries, and found that they are indeed spending more on health care these days. The companies said they expected their average medical claims cost per employee to hit $1,498 this year, up 9 percent from last year. **********But employees will be paying a bigger share of their own bills from now on. The Hewitt survey, which asked companies to compare their 1984 health benefits with those they were offering in 1982, showed that 63 percent of companies now ask employees to pay a deductible (an initial amount of the bill) for all hospital expenses, up from 30 percent in 1982. And the deductibles are getting higher - 38 percent of the companies that require one have set it at $150 or more, while only 9 percent asked employees to pick up that much in 1982. **********For now, employers are still trying to shield their people from truly catastrophic medical expenses. About 89 percent (up from 80 percent two years ago) put a cap - typically $1,500 - on the medical bills that an employee must pay in a given year. Full coverage kicks back in after that amount. Moreover, many companies are offering bonuses to employees who spot overcharges on particularly hefty hospital bills. Uniroyal, for one, gives its employees 50 percent of overcharges that they find. **********Still, for minor illnesses, fewer employees are home free after paying the initial deductible these days. In 1982, 67 percent of the surveyed companies picked up the full cost of hospitalization after the deductible was paid. Today, nearly half pay only 80 percent of hospital tabs. **********The purse strings have been tightened on insurance premiums, too. Single people have to pay part of the premiums at 40 percent of the companies, up from 31 percent in 1982. Companies requiring contributions for family coverage rose to 69 percent from 62 percent in the same period. **********In many cases, employees can no longer choose their own doctors and hospitals. Health Maintenance Organizations, which require a hefty annual fee but which make available to members the services of many specialists, have turned into a bonanza for employers. In 1982, the Ford Motor Company saved $5 million in insurance premiums by enrolling about 19,000 employees - only 8.5 percent of its work force - in H.M.O.'s. A Stanford University study says that there are 280 H.M.O.'s operating nationwide, with a total enrollment of 12.5 million people. The university expects that, by 1990, some 50 million people will belong to them. **********Preferred-provider organizations also are gaining favor with employers. These are groups of doctors and hospitals that contract with employers or insurance companies to provide care for prenegotiated (usually discounted) fees. Such arrangements are illegal in about half the states because they restrict a patient's freedom of choice. Still, the American Medical Care and Review Association's directory lists 70 operating preferred-provider groups, 37 about to start, and 40 being formed.
