https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/05/world.main_headline: HARVARD EX-DEAN APPOINTED BISHOP OF STOCKHOLM
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/05/world.print_headline: HARVARD EX-DEAN APPOINTED BISHOP OF STOCKHOLM
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/05/world.body_text: **********A former dean of Harvard Divinity School has been named Bishop of Stockholm in the Church of Sweden, a state-controlled Evangelical Lutheran faith. The appointment has stirred a level of curiosity and hope rarely seen in one of the world's few surviving state churches. **********The new Bishop, Dr. Krister Stendahl, is a Swede who became an American citizen while teaching at Harvard. He is preparing to move assume his new position at a time when many Swedes consider the church only a cultural artifact. Although the Archbishop of Uppsala is technically the head of the Church of Sweden, the Bishop of Stockholm, by virtue of heading the diocese of the capital, probably holds the most visible church post. **********Some church activists argue that a tax-supported, privileged church can no longer be justified and that Christians will not have the incentive to spur a renewal of the church until it gives up its financially secure place. **********While stopping short of total agreement with this, Dr. Stendahl said in a telephone interview from his summer home in Nantucket that ''Swedes have never really been challenged on whether they should be members of the church at all.'' **********One of his immediate goals is to enhance the role of the laity. He said the church has been so controlled by the clergy that, unlike the situation in the United States, lay people rarely refer to it as ''my church.'' **********At stake is the spiritual health of the church rather than its material welfare. Physically, churches so dominate this city that its skyline looks like an exhibit of deluxe fountain pens, and 95 percent of the eight million Swedes are born into the Church of Sweden. **********But fewer than 5 percent of Swedes attend church or are active in any way. Increasingly, the church is used only for rites of passage: funerals, weddings and baptisms. So lax are church standards that baptism is not required for membership if one parent is already a member. A half million members have never been baptized. **********In talks with active laymen, clergy and church officials it becomes clear that they believe Swedish society, to a great extent, has gone its own way without looking to the church as its compass. While a reshaping of values and moral standards has gone ahead, many church officials think the church has stood idly by, largely losing its sense of purpose and meaning. **********''For a long time, the church held on to its past glory,'' said the Rev. Goran Beijer, chaplain of the parish of St. James in the heart of Stockholm, ''and it didn't react quickly enough to these changes.'' **********Soren Ekstrom, who oversees church affairs for the Social Democratic Government of Prime Minister Olof Palme, commented: **********''In Sweden, the church cannot be part of the state if it wants to be respected. If we want to be the church that is needed in the future, we have to be a free church.'' **********Five years ago the Government submitted a proposal to end the compact, which includes a provision that Parliament has final approval over the selection of bishops for the 13 dioceses. Despite backing from most church officials and the Social Democrats, the proposal was defeated because of opposition from local church councils. **********Meanwhile, there are reports that young people are growing more receptive to religious ideas and belief. In the church, the question is whether the church can respond to this interest. Many people say the church-state connection makes the church so comfortable that it has no need to win converts or loyalties. **********Dr. Stendahl, whose wry humor salts his scholarship, leans toward church independence. Many Swedes look to him to bring the lessons gained from his experience in a religiously pluralistic American culture to the problems that beset the Swedish church, but he is cautious about imposing his answers. **********''This has to be worked out in a totally different atmosphere from that in America,'' Dr. Stendahl said. ''Very little can be lifted over by helicopter.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/16/world.main_headline: Policeman Is Killed By Sikhs in Punjab
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/16/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Policeman Is Killed By Sikhs in Punjab
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/16/world.body_text: **********Sikh militants ambushed a mounted police patrol today and killed one officer in the second day of religious strife in Punjab that has left at least 15 dead and more than 150 injured. **********The violence between Sikhs and Hindus led to curfews in five cities and prompted Sikh leaders to suspend talks with the Government on their demands for more political and economic automony for Punjab. **********The disturbances spread into the neighboring state of Haryana, where the police used tear gas and riot sticks to break up a mob attacking the shop of a Sikh Alkali Dal Party official. **********The unrest came a day after the fiercest clashes between Hindus and Sikhs since Sikh militants began a campaign for autonomy from the federal Government 19 months ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/07/busin.main_headline: REAGAN, CABINET SET JAPAN TRADE PARLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/07/busin.print_headline: REAGAN, CABINET SET JAPAN TRADE PARLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/07/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan will meet with his Cabinet next week to try to shape a comprehensive strategy for dealing with the record trade deficit with Japan, Administration officials said today. **********The strategy session will be held on Tuesday, three weeks before Mr. Reagan will see Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan. Among other things, the discussion will touch on trade in autos, copyright issues, access to Japan's high-technology markets and ''transparency,'' or more disclosure of what is being considered by the Japanese Government. **********The two leaders are scheduled to sit down together in Los Angeles on Jan. 2 for their fifth encounter since Mr. Nakasone came to power in late 1982. The importance the White House attaches to shaping an overall strategy was underscored by the decision to convene the entire Cabinet. **********Accord on Steel **********Meanwhile, American and Japanese negotiators in Washington agreed that imports of Japanese finished steel would not exceed 5.8 percent of the United States market. **********American officials said they expect that President Reagan will urge Mr. Nakasone to put into effect policies for faster economic growth in Japan, so as to draw in more imports, including goods from the United States. In July, August and September, Japan's economy expanded at an annual rate of 3 percent, a pace Washington regards as too slow. **********In support of their contention that Japan can reasonably be expected to import more, American officials assert that with the world's second- largest economy, after the United States, Japan imports only about as much as Switzerland, a far smaller country. And while the United States absorbs 52 percent of the imports of developing countries, Japan buys 8 percent, they contend. **********''The trade deficit is threatening to poison the overall relationship with Japan,'' said Clyde V. Prestowitz, counselor to Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and the top departmental aide on Japan issues. **********'Rend the Fabric' **********''The European Community and Korea have similar problems, so it's not just the United States,'' he added, noting that ''this is something that could rend the fabric of the whole trading system.'' **********The United States trade deficit with Japan is estimated at $35 billion for 1984, but in recent months it has been running at a rate equivalent to $50 billion a year. **********Japanese diplomats here said that they, too, were concerned about the deficit and were bracing for more pressures from the Administration. **********These officials said that Japan's desire to be ''cooperative'' was behind the steel trade agreement, which was reached after only three days of negotiations in Washington. **********The First to Settle **********Japan thus became the first country to settle on quotas with the United States under President Reagan's Sept. 10 pledge to cut total imports of finished steel to 18.5 percent of the domestic market. Two weeks ago, the United States acted unilaterally to bar imports of European pipe and tube steel to 5.9 percent of the American market. **********Some American officials and members of Congress have been toying with the idea of imposing a 15 percent surcharge on imports from Japan, as a dramatic way of both cutting the deficit and increasing revenues. **********On the basis of more than $70 billion of imports from Japan, such a measure would raise more than $10 billion. **********According to reports from Tokyo, the Japanese Government has been considering an export surtax that would make Japanese exports more costly in world markets. Such a tax, however, would be pocketed by the Japanese Treasury. Under the import surcharge idea, the United States Treasury would get the money. **********However, both the United States trade representative, Bill Brock, and Commerce Secretary Baldrige have come out publicly against such measures, warning that they would undermine the rules of international trade. **********One of the key American grievances is the reluctance of the Japanese to open up their markets to American telecommunications and other sophisticated products where the United States has a competitive advantage.  ''High-technology products cannot get in, and that has to be dealt with,'' Mr. Brock told a conference today sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/01/busin.body_text: **********France will have a record wheat crop this year and production of other cereals will be sharply higher than in 1983, producers said today. The cereal growers' federation estimated this year's soft wheat production at 26.8 million tons, up 27 percent from 1983 and well above the previous record of 21.6 million tons set in 1982. Production of hard wheat should rise 24 percent, to 474,000 tons, while barley should jump 61 percent, to 673,000 tons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/busin.body_text: **********Trilogy Ltd., a company formed to develop semiconductor, packaging and computer-aided design technologies, yesterday reported a loss of $59.3 million for the second quarter, compared with a loss of $3.2 million in the second quarter of 1983. Trilogy said the latest deficit was after a charge of $43 million, primarily for the writedown of assets related to discontinued development activities and a reserve for future costs of discontinued operations. The company, which is based in Cupertino, Calif., last week abandoned its plans to build a high-speed ''wafer-scale'' computer chip, saying it would instead attempt to design circuit packages made up of conventional semiconductors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/25/busin.main_headline: Anne Klein Designer Sets Her Own Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Anne Klein Designer Sets Her Own Venture
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/25/busin.body_text: **********Donna Karan, one of the nation's leading fashion designers, announced yesterday that she was leaving the Anne Klein Companies to start her own business, the Donna Karan Company. **********For the 35-year old Mrs. Karan, the move represents a further step in a career that has taken her to the heights of the fashion industry. **********As a second-year student at the Parsons School of Design, in the spring of 1968, Mrs. Karan took a summer job as an assistant to Anne Klein, and, at Miss Klein's urging, never went back to school. **********A dispute with her mentor cost Mrs. Karan her job nine months later, but in 1970 she asked for it back, and got it. In 1971 she was named associate designer and in 1974, when Anne Klein died, Mrs. Karan became chief designer. **********When Miss Klein died, major retailers worried about whether her company would survive. **********But in the ensuing period, Mrs. Karan, her creative associate, Louis Dell'Olio, and a new management team put in place by Takihyo Inc., a Japanese apparel textile complex that bought a 50 percent interest in the company in 1973, have put those fears to rest. **********''When I started in 1974 the company was worth around $12 million,'' Mrs. Karan said in a telephone interview yesterday. ''Now, with the Anne Klein collection and Anne Klein II, which we launched two years ago, the company is worth around $100 million.'' **********Aside from enjoying financial success, Mrs. Karan has earned praise from the industry, winning Coty Fashion Critics Awards in 1977 and 1981, and being elected a year later to the Coty Hall of Fame, the industry's highest award, along with Mr. Dell'Olio. **********''The company is so strong right now that it is time for it to be on its own,'' Mrs. Karan said. ''I am going to start my own business, which is the dream of a lifetime.'' **********Mrs. Karan, who will be a principal owner of a company bearing her name, will be joined by Takihyo in the new venture. Her collection is expected to be presented for the fall 1985 season. **********Mrs. Karan will remain a consultant at Anne Klein. The company said that she would be succeeded as chief designer by Mr. Dell'Olio, who is also 35.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/05/busin.body_text: **********The Companies **********Nestle has agreed to buy Carnation for about $3 billion, or $83 a share. Investment bankers said it was the largest non-oil merger in history, topping the $2.8 billion deal between Beatrice Foods and Esmark. Nestle, Switzerland's largest industrial company, is best known for its chocolate and baby food products. Carnation makes evaporated milk, pet food and other products. (Page A1.) **********Digital Equipment has been fined $1.5 million by the Commerce Department for export law violations that may have allowed the Soviet Union to obtain one or two of its computers. (D1.) **********Continental Grain is leaving the futures brokerage business.  The company said it would sell its loss-plagued Conticommodity Services unit to Refco, another Chicago futures broker. (D1.) **********Ford plans to raise prices by 1.9 percent, or an average of $225, for its 1985 models. Previously, G.M. said it planned a 2.3 percent increase, while Chrysler said it planned a 1.7 percent rise. (D1.) **********Comsat plans to take on as partners the Prudential Insurance Company of America and the owners of United Press International to bolster its entry into satellite-to-home TV broadcasting. (D1.) **********Financial Corporation of America's No. 2 executive resigned.  J. Foster Fluetsch, departing as chairman and chief executive of American Savings and Loan, had been aligned with strategies of Charles W. Knapp, who left the company last week. (D5.) **********Cincinnati Milacron will introduce a system using the I.B.M. Personal Computer to tell machine tools how to cut metal. (D6.) **********Hospital Corporation of America plans to acquire the Health Resources Corporation of America in a stock deal valued at about $330 million, the companies said. (D6.)  The Economy **********Fuel oil bills are expected to be lower for consumers this winter because of the oversupply of petroleum. The cost of heating with natural gas is less certain, however, because prices will be decontrolled Jan. 1. (A1.) **********Spending on new construction rose 0.7 percent in July , to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $311.4 billion, after slipping 0.5 percent in June. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 12.03 points, to 1,212.35. Volume on the Big Board was 62.1 million shares, compared with 57.5 million shares on Friday, the slowest trading day of the year. At the weekly auction of new bills, rates on three-month bills rose slightly, to 10.63 percent, from 10.60 percent. Bullion was bid at $337.75 an ounce in late trading at Republic National Bank in New York, off $10.25 from the late bid Friday. (D18.) Livestock and meat futures prices were mostly higher. (D18.)  International **********President Reagan was asked to reject steel quotas and tariffs proposed by the International Trade Commission. The request was made by a group of manufacturers, farmers, retailers and port workers because they would increase consumers' costs. (D9.)  Today's Columns **********Protectionism is an issue absent from the campaigns of the Presidential candidates. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/01/busin.body_text: **********R. J. Reynolds Tobacco International Inc. said it would spend $5 million to $10 million promoting Camel cigarettes in Japan. **********The campaign is the most expensive marketing and advertising effort ever made by an American cigarette company in Japan, according to R. J. Reynolds. Sales of cigarettes in Japan have been tightly controlled until recent years, with foreign cigarette sales representing about 2 percent of total sales. Negotiations beginning in 1980 reduced trade barriers for foreign cigarettes, but Japanese cigarettes still cost about 30 cents less than foreign ones.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/30/busin.body_text: **********The Continental Group, which this week put itself up for sale to fend off a takeover offer by Sir James Goldsmith, the British industrialist, yesterday agreed to merge with a corporation owned jointly by David H. Murdock, a West Coast financier, and Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc., a private mining and construction company. **********Continental said holders of its common stock would get $58.50 a share in cash. It said the total value of the transaction was about $2.75 billion. **********The agreement to sell the Continental Group, which has operations in packaging, forestry, insurance and energy, was reached during a meeting of the Continental board with Mr. Murdock and with two officers of Peter Kiewit: Walter Scott Jr., the president, and Donald L. Sturm, senior vice president. **********'Highest Price' **********In a statement released from Continental's headquarters in Stamford, Conn., S. Bruce Smart Jr., the company's chairman, said that the proposal from the Kiewit Murdock Group was ''the highest price among several alternatives, is not subject to any financing contingencies, and is entirely satisfactory to our directors in other respects, including Kiewit Murdock Group's assurance to continue substantially unchanged Continental's present employee compensation benefits and policies.'' **********Mr. Smart said the Kiewit Murdock team had ''emphasized its intent to continue Continental Group as an independent viable operating company'' although some of its assets may be sold. The statement said 80 percent of the purchasing group is owned by Kiewit, which is based in Omaha, and 20 percent by Murdock Investments, which is based in Los Angeles and which Mr. Murdock heads. **********Sir James's Bid **********For the moment, the agreement appears to end the attempt of Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier, to acquire the company. It was the informal $50-a-share offer for the company Sir James made in early June that precipitated Continental's decision to shop for buyers. **********Sir James subsequently sweetened his offer to $54 a share, or $2.3 billion. **********Calls to Sir James and his advisers were not returned yesterday. Nor were calls to officials of Continental or the Kiewit Murdock Group. Thus, it is not known if Sir James or other bidders attempted to match the bid that won over the Continental board. **********Corneilus W. Thornton, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation, said that the Kiewit Murdock offer was ''a good bid. It indicates that management has put forth a valiant effort to secure the maximum benefit for the shareholders.'' **********Mr. Thornton cautioned that because the agreement remains to be approved by the shareholders, a higher bid may yet surface. **********To give the Kiewit Murdock Group a profit in the event that it is outbid, the agreement grants it an option to acquire about 7.8 million shares of Continental common stock at $58.50 a share. In a move to prevent another bidder from entering the situation, the group has also been granted an option to purchase Continental's most attractive asset, the Florida Gas Transmission Company, and other pipeline operations, for $500 million. **********Continental's stock closed at $51.75 yesterday, up 50 cents, on the Big Board. The announcement of the deal came after the stock market closed. **********The accord stipulates that the Kiewit Murdock Group will pay $29.95 in cash for each Continental series A preference share and $43.875 for each series B preference share, unless holders convert before the deal. Series C preference shares and the $4.25 preferred stock would remain outstanding following the merger, according to the statement. **********Directors Elected **********The Continental board also elected as directors Messrs. Scott, Sturm and Murdock, and Raymond F. Henze 3d, president of Flexi-Van Inc., increasing the Continental board to 16. **********Mr. Henze, 31 years old, has been an associate of Mr. Murdock's since 1979 and is a vice president of the Pacific Holding Corporation, which Mr. Murdock heads. Through Pacific Holding, Mr. Murdock is the largest shareholder in Flexi-Van. **********Mr. Murdock is also a substantial holder in the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, having recently increased his holdings to 4.8 million shares, about 5 percent of that company's stock. **********Last year Continental, which was formerly known as Continental Can, earned $199 million, or $3.66 a share, up 9.5 percent from earnings of $180 million, or $3.20 a share, in 1982. Its revenues were $2.89 billion last year, with 50 percent of that coming from packaging operations and 10 percent from forest products. **********Mr. Scott, chairman of Peter Kiewit, said recently the company had its most profitable year ever in 1983, 99 years after its founding. **********Earning figures are confidential as the company is privately owned. But Mr. Scott said the company has earned ''substantially more than $100 million'' annually for several years and that it has about $1.3 billion in contracting each year plus mining and other interests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/30/busin.main_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Farah Resignation Surprises Analysts
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/30/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Farah Resignation Surprises Analysts
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/30/busin.body_text: **********In an announcement that jolted industry analysts and stock traders, the Farah Manufacturing Company said yesterday that Ray Williams, who had served as president and chief operating officer since 1978, had resigned. **********According to Farah, Mr. Williams, who is 52 years old, resigned last Wednesday ''to pursue personal business opportunities.'' **********The company said that William F. Farah, 64, currently chairman and chief executive officer, would assume the additional posts of president and chief operating officer. **********Mr. Williams and Mr. Farah both refused to answer questions yesterday. **********The news caused concern among analysts, and sent the price of Farah's shares tumbling on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Farah closed at $20.75, down $6.50. **********''The bottom line speaks very well for his performance; he had done an excellent job, '' said Margaret Gilliam, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation. ''But this announcement hit us like a lightning bolt. I wish I knew what was going on.'' **********Mr. Farah, whose father founded the apparel manufacturer based in El Paso, brought in Mr. Williams in 1978, shortly after Mr. Farah had regained control of the company. **********During the 1970's, Farah sales tumbled when its products became the target of a nationwide boycott that grew out of a prolonged union dispute. As a result of those problems, Mr. Farah was forced out as chairman in March 1977. **********Under the direction of Mr. Farah and Mr. Williams, the company has undergone a drastic turnaround. **********In 1978, Farah Manufacturing reported a $4.78 million loss on sales of $85 million. For all of last year, the company reported net income of $14.7 million on sales of $206 million. Farah's current fiscal year has one more month to run, and Miss Gilliam said she anticipated net income this year would be around $15 million. **********''Farah has been very responsive to changes in the marketplace,'' Miss Gilliam said. ''They were at a disadvantage when jeans were popular, because that was not their forte. But they were at the forefront of development of tailored sportcoat separates, and more recently have been leaders in the concept of collection selling - shirts, jackets and slacks that coordinate almost by accident.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/09/world.print_headline: AROUND THE NATION; Heavy Fighting Reported Throughout Afghanistan
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/09/world.body_text: **********The official Afghan radio said that more than 100 anti-Government guerrillas were killed today in fighting with Government forces in 12 Afghan provinces. **********There was no mention of Government casualties. **********The radio reports, monitored here, said dozens of rebels had been captured and large quantities of arms and ammunition, including some with foreign markings, had been seized. **********Earlier, Western diplomats said hundreds of people, including many Soviet soldiers, had died in heavy fighting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/18/busin.main_headline: DOLLAR FALLS AFTER BONN BANK ACTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/18/busin.print_headline: DOLLAR FALLS AFTER BONN BANK ACTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/18/busin.body_text: **********The dollar plunged against major currencies on foreign exchange markets today following intervention by the West German central bank. **********From its high of about 3.1560 marks early in the Frankfurt trading day, the dollar plunged in what currency dealers described as ''hectic and chaotic'' trading to 3.09 marks. It also fell sharply against the British pound and the Swiss franc, although it remained stable against the French franc. **********But the dollar firmed later in the day, to 3.1150 marks at the close of European trading, and currency traders, in unconfirmed estimates, said the bank might have sold about $60 million. **********The dollar continued to regain lost ground in late trading in the United States, winding up at 3.1375 marks. On Tuesday, the dollar closed at 3.1435 marks in Europe and at 3.14725 marks in the United States. **********Bank Declines to Comment **********Officials of the German central bank - the Bundesbank - declined to comment officially on the action. But sources close to the bank described the intervention as ''channeling back dollars from sources outside the Bundesbank.'' **********The bank regularly sells dollars on currency markets to contain the amount of its dollar reserves, which are augmented by earnings on the bank's dollar-denominated investments, and by payments from international agencies in West Germany. **********''This is not a change in intervention policy,'' one source said, noting that bank officials were ''quite surprised at the reaction to a relatively small amount.'' He added, ''It shows how uncertain in general the markets are.'' **********The bank later reported it sold $103.8 million at the midday fixing to stabilize the dollar at 3.11 marks. **********Market nervousness was clearly heightened by the fresh recollection of the bank's huge intervention on Sept. 21, when it sold $450 million to brake the dollar, after the United States currency had climbed to 3.1765 marks, its highest level since freely floating currency exchange rates were abolished in 1973. **********The dollar's erratic movement is expected to be high on the agenda when the Bundesbank's central council meets Thursday in West Berlin. Karl Otto P"ohl, the Bundesbank's president, has voiced growing concern over the possible inflationary effect of the strong American dollar. Many West German imports, including energy oil and iron ore, are paid for in dollars. **********Session Is Stormy **********By The Associated Press **********The dollar's mixed performance came in hectic trading yesterday as currency markets were buffeted by a British cut in oil prices as well as the Bundesbank intervention. The stormy session also saw the British pound sink to a new low. **********Gold prices fell in all markets except London. The Republic National Bank in New York said gold bullion was bid at $336.50 a troy ounce in late trading, down 40 cents from the earlier close of the New York Commodity Exchange and off $2.25 from the late bid Tuesday. **********The pound continued to take a beating amid traders' concerns over prospects for a deterioration in Britain's long miners' strike and over the impact of falling North Sea oil revenue. **********The pound briefly fell to a low of $1.1905 in London before recovering slightly to finish the European session at $1.2007. By the end of the trading day in New York, the pound had dropped to $1.19225. The late rates for the pound on Tuesday were $1.2045 in London and $1.1995 in New York. **********The dollar began its trading day in Tokyo by rising to 250.35 Japanese yen from 249.05 yen late Tuesday, reaching its highest level since Nov. 20, 1982. The dollar was later quoted in Europe at 248.95 yen and wound up the day in New York at 249.40 yen, up from Tuesday's 249.34 yen. **********Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Tuesday, included 2.5525 Swiss francs, down from 2.5712; 9.5387 French francs, down from 9.6225; 3.5125 Dutch guilders, down from 3.5380; 1.918.50 Italian lire, down from 1,933, and 1.3252 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3256. **********Late dollar rates in New York , compared with late rates Tuesday, included 2.56925 Swiss francs, down from 2.57225; 9.59 French francs, down from 9.6325, and 1.32915 Canadian dollars, up from 1.32685. **********Gold fell $1.39 in Hong Kong, to $339.74 a troy ounce. Gold edged up 25 cents in London, to a late bid of $340 an ounce, but slipped $1.50 in Zurich, to $339. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fell $2, to $336.90.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/24/world.main_headline: Israeli Planes Bomb Targets Near Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/24/world.print_headline: Israeli Planes Bomb Targets Near Beirut
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/24/world.body_text: **********Israeli planes bombed targets in the mountains east of Beirut today in what the Israeli radio said was an attack on Palestinian guerrilla bases. **********After the air strike, the Israelis' third since Sunday, clouds of thick smoke rose into the sky over areas around Aleih and Bhamdun, both controlled by anti-Government Druse militiamen. **********A Syrian military spokesman said in Damascus that four Israeli F-15's were involved in the raid, which took place shortly after noon, and that Syrian gunners in the area of the attack had forced the planes to withdraw. **********The Israeli radio said the planes had hit two buildings in Bhamdun used as "headquarters and bases for terrorists," the Israeli term for Palestinian guerrillas, and a 130-millimeter artillery position in Mansuriya. **********The raids came as Lebanon's President, Amin Gemayel, met with Lebanese Christian leaders to discuss opposition and Syrian demands that he cancel a 1983 troop-withdrawal agreement with Israel as part of a plan for easing the Lebanese crisis. Mr. Gemayel is widely expected to do so, but is said to be seeking guarantees from Syria in return that it will eventually withdraw its troops from Lebanon. **********Attending part of today's negotiating session was Rafik al-Hariri, the Saudi mediator who has been trying to arrange an agreement between Syria and Lebanon that would involve canceling the May 17 accord for a withdrawal of Israeli and Syrian troops from Lebanon and for joint Israeli-Lebanese security arrangements in southern Lebanon. **********Mr. Hariri, who also met with Mr. Gemayel Wednesday night, returned to Damascus this evening to present the latest Lebanese positions. **********Meanwhile, anti-Government militiamen and Lebanese Army troops loyal to the Gemayel Government exchanged occasional machine gun, mortar and artillery fire in the Beirut area and in the nearby mountains. **********Reports from Damascus quoted Prince Bandar ibn Sultan of Saudi Arabia as saying at a news conference after an eight-hour meeting with Lebanese and Syrian representatives that negotiators had agreed to a new cease-fire for Beirut, to take effect at 11 A.M. Friday. The Prince, the Saudi Ambassador to Washington, who has been serving as a mediator, said in response to questions that the accord concerned only a cease-fire and had nothing to do with political issues such as the withdrawal of any troops from Lebanon. Reinforcing a Town **********As fighting continued here, a military official said that more Lebanese Army troops had been dispatched to Suk al Gharb, the town loyalists hold on ridge nine miles southeast of downtown Beirut. Most of the new troops are Christian, the official said. The Lebanese Army has suffered from defections by its Moslem soldiers. **********As the Lebanese Army bolstered its defenses, the pullback of the United States Marine contingent fromthe Beirut airport continued, with marines shipping out ammunition, food and equipment as part of their move to Sixth Fleet vessels off Lebanon. **********Explaining the Israeli air strike, the Israeli state radio quoted an expert on Arab affairs as saying that Bhamdun had become the main base for Palestinian guerrilla activity in Lebanon. **********A Lebanese Army official said "at least" 3,000 Palestinian fighters were in the area around Bhamdun. Some Western officials here have said that number would be difficult to confirm; other estimates of Palestinian strenth have been substantially lower. **********The Druse radio station disputed the Israeli radio report and said the objective of the Israeli raid was to provide support for the Lebanese Army loyal to Mr. Gemayel. **********Before the Saudi mediator, Mr. Hariri, returned to Damascus, Mr. Gemayel met for three hours with key Christian leaders, including his father, Pierre Gemayel, the founder of the Christian Phalangist Party, and former President Camille Chamoun. Prominent Christians have continued to oppose any deal with Syria. **********In addition to canceling the May 17 accord, the new plan, which Syria has approved, calls for a new Lebanese Cabinet, including a Prime Minister acceptable to Syria, the resumption of reconciliation talks in Geneva, and changes in the Lebanese political system that would give Moslems more influence. **********At the airport, as the marine pullback continued, there appeared to be some confusion over who would take over the Americans' airport positions. **********Gen. Jim R. Joy, the commander of the 22d Marine Amphibious Unit, the core of the American force in Beirut, told reporters that the marines were planning to turn their positions over to Lebanese Army troops loyal to the command of Gen. Ibrahim Tannous. **********When pressed by reporters as to how loyalist units would be able to take over the base, which is virtually surrounded by anti-Government Moslem militiamen, General Joy said an agreement had been reached with the various parties involved. **********When Ali Hamadan, a spokesman for the Shiite Moslem militia known as Amal, was asked if any agreement had been reached, he said security at the airport would be handled by the Sixth Brigade, which has declared its neutrality and is not seen as loyal to Mr. Gemayel's Government. **********One official said tonight that although General Joy's comments appeared "premature," discussions were proceeding to have the airport position turned over to another brigade that was still loyal to the army's central command, but would also be acceptable to the Shiite Moslem militia. **********General Joy indicated, however, that the bulk of the combat forces still on shore, roughly 1,100 men, would not be moved out to the ships until final arrangements had been worked out for guarding the airport. Strike Hits Lebanon's South **********SIDON< Lebanon, Feb. 23 A general strike called to protest the killing earlier this month of a prominent Shiite Moslem cleric paralyzed much of southern Lebanon today. **********Shops along the coastal highway from Tyre to Sidon remained shuttered. Unidentified assailants launched two small attacks on Israeli forces. Later, Israel announced that one of its soldiers had been killed in an ambush east of Nabatiye. **********The Shiite cleric, Thgaba Harb, was killed in the village of Gebsheit, near Nabatiye. His followers, who say they are inspired by the ideology of the Iranian revolution, blame Israel for the killing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/14/busin.body_text: **********Shares of G. D. Searle & Company dropped sharply yesterday in heavy trading, apparently as a result of disappointing first-quarter earnings. The **********shares tumbled $5.75, to $40.50, **********on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Volume totaled 1.24 **********million shares. E. F. Hutton, disappointed **********by the first-quarter earnings of **********the drug concern, lowered its **********rating yesterday on the stock **********from ''accumulate'' to **********''swap,'' which is one level **********above ''sell.'' Searle, based in Skokie, Ill., **********on Thursday reported first- **********quarter profits of $25.3 million, **********or 51 cents a share, on sales of **********$280.3 million. This compared **********with a restated $17.2 million, or **********34 cents a share, on sales of **********$199.4 million, in the period a **********year earlier. ''Searle's first quarter was **********terrific; unfortunately some **********analysts were looking for even **********better results,'' said David F. **********Saks, pharmaceuticals industry analyst at A. G. Becker **********Paribas. ''Some analysts therefore have cut their estimates **********and so have I. I am lowering my earnings projection for **********Searle for the full year to $3 a **********share, from $3.60 a share.'' **********Last year, Searle earned $2.39 a **********share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/04/world.main_headline: ZIMBABWEANS SEND MORE TROOPS TO PROVINCE AND IMPOSE A CURFEW
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/04/world.print_headline: ZIMBABWEANS SEND MORE TROOPS TO PROVINCE AND IMPOSE A CURFEW
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/04/world.body_text: **********The Government said today that it was sending more troops into the southwestern province of Matabeleland and imposing a dusk-to-dawn curfew in certain areas. **********The Home Affairs Minister, Simba Mubako, declined to say at news conference whether the announcement marked a new military drive against rebels in the province. **********''Troops will be increased to whatever level is considered necessary to deal with increased infiltration,'' Mr. Mubako said. **********Earlier today, Prime Minister Robert Mugabe accused South Africa of training rebels to overthrow his Government.   Says Violence Has Increased **********The Government said earlier in the week that there had been a marked increase in ''killings, rape, mutilations and torture'' of civilians by rebels. **********Last year Prime Minister Mugabe ordered the biggest military operation since the war for black rule ended in December 1979. Churches and human rights groups charged that soldiers had killed hundreds of civilians in a rampage against members of the minority Ndebele tribe. **********Mr. Mubako said more troops and the curfew, effective tonight, were needed to combat ''increased infiltration'' of rebels trained in South Africa. **********Mr. Mugabe, who is also Defense Minister, earlier asked a group of army officers, ''Who is not aware that our nationals have been recruited, train in and armed by South Africa and then infiltrated back into Zimbabwe to carry out a systematic campaign of harassment, rape, murder and arson directed aainst the peasants, white commercial farmers, Government and other workers in rural areas?''  'Second Phase of Terrorism' **********In the past, Mr. Mugabe and his ministers have accused the opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo, who draws most of his support from the Ndebele tribe, of giving orders to the rebels. But this week Information Minister Nathan Shamuyarira absolved Mr. Nkomo of involvement in what he called a ''second phase of terrorism.'' **********The dissidents are accused of attacking both blacks and whites. They have reportedly driven half of Matabeleland's 500 white commercial farmers off the land. At least 30 farmers have been slain in the last year and others have fled their farms. **********In an editorial Thursday, Zimbabwe's biggest daily, The Herald, called for soldiers to be sent into Matabeleland. It noted that last year's military intervention had earned ''widespread condemnation in sectors of the world press.'' **********But the paper said: ''It worked. The bandits were routed.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/world.main_headline: A NEW WHO'S WHO TELLS WHAT'S WHAT IN WARSAW
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/world.print_headline: A NEW WHO'S WHO TELLS WHAT'S WHAT IN WARSAW
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/14/world.body_text: **********A Government publishing house has just issued this country's first modern biographical directory in Polish, and an inspection of its 1,171 pages reveals not only who is who, but also who is not and what is what, at least in the view of the censors. **********Among those missing from the volume are some of Poland's best-known personalities, people whose curricula vitae were ordered excised by Government censors as being politically unacceptable. Other citations were trimmed. **********Such censorship is a fact of life here. But in this case, the determination of exactly who is no longer who - or who is who but with epaulets stripped - is made possible by the existence of another book, Who's Who in Poland. It was printed in English two years ago by the Who's Who Company of Zurich in collaboration with Interpress, a Polish Government information agency. **********That book, printed in Italy and not subject to Polish censorship, formed the basis for the expurgated Polish edition that Interpress has just issued. It invites comparisons, which reveal, often by nuance, what kind of subjects and what kind of people are now not acceptable, at least not in Polish.   Walesa the 'Electrician' There is, for example, Lech Walesa. In the English edition, which was to a great extent collated by the same Government publishers that issued the new dictionary, he is described as ''electrician, trade union leader.'' **********In the Polish version this has been shortened to ''electrician.'' On the other hand, the Polish edition does add the information that Mr. Walesa won the Nobel Peace Prize in the year after the English-language book appeared. **********Then there are people like Jacek Kuron and Adam Michnik, who just came out of prison after two and a half years. They are listed in the earlier book as professors of history and founders of KOR, a Solidarity advisory group. **********They are not listed in the new book. Nor is Bogdan Lis, who was the No. 2 man in the Solidarity underground when he was arrested in June. Mr. Lis, who is still in prison, was described in the English edition as ''mechanic, trade union leader.'' **********Others who were somebodies in the English work but are nobodies in the Polish one are Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, the Silesian Solidarity leader who came out of prison two weeks ago, and Bronislaw Geremek, a medieval history scholar and Walesa adviser. **********Even with the deletions, the publication of the directory - listing the names, addresses and in some cases telephone numbers of Government officials and some Government critics - is very unusual in an East bloc Communist nation, where telephone books are sometimes classified secrets. **********Along with the Sunday broadcasts of Roman Catholic mass on the Government radio, private agriculture and regular news briefings for foreign journalists, the publication of the Who's Who, even in its expurgated form, is being cited by Poles close to the Government as a sign of incremental liberalization. **********By the same token, Government critics see the new edition as a retreat from 1982, when the Interpress publishers could and did lend their imprimatur to a book that listed Mr. Kuron, Mr. Michnik and others among Poland's most prominent figures.   Approval Reportedly Sought **********Though it was widely anticipated that the censors would excise such information, publishing sources here said the new book's compilers tried to get the censors' approval for even spare sketches of dissidents - only to be told that they would not be allowed to list the addresses and telephone numbers ''that would enable people to get in touch with our enemies.'' **********In addition to the question of which people are in print or out, sanctioned or purged, the small type of both volumes also contains much human drama. **********Jacek Maziarski was described in the 1982 book as an award-winning journalist, critic and author. The Polish edition reprints the same information but adds, ''owner of a used-book shop.'' Mr. Maziarski, in the midst of the tentative attempts at democratic pluralism, decided to leave Government-controlled journalism. Before he opened the bookstore, he paid for an advertisement in a Warsaw paper that said, ''Journalist seeks honest employment.'' **********Then there is the sense of betrayal and strain in the separate entries of Dariusz Fikus and Jerzy Urban, once co- authors. Mr. Fikus was on the editorial board of the liberal weekly Polityka until he left the paper, turned in his Communist Party card and became the second in command of the journalists union associated with Solidarity. **********Mr. Urban, as his citation makes clear, was never a party member. He left his association with Polityka to become the chief spokesman for the Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski.   Heat and Passion **********Despite their rather cold, telephone-book typography, the two items still manage to suggest the heat and passion of human affairs. In the biographical sketch offered by Mr. Fikus there is a reference to a book, ''Society in Transit,'' that he recalled having written, with Mr. Urban as his co-author, in 1969. **********For his part, Mr. Urban does not list that book among his published works. **********As for cultural figures, perhaps the most notable gap concerns Tadeusz Konwicki, one of Poland's best-known writers, who is not mentioned in either directory. According to sources at Interpress, Mr. Konwicki did not bother to fill out a questionnaire in time to be included in the 1982 book. **********For the Polish volume, he submitted a sketch with a full list of his works, including ''The Polish Complex'' and ''A Minor Apocalypse,'' both translated and published abroad but banned here. **********The sources said this entry, along with all the others, was sent to the censors, who struck out the references to the banned books. Mr. Konwicki was asked to approve the remaining section but refused, saying a life's work cannot be trimmed to conform to the requirements of political censors. The entire item was ordered dropped. **********If there are obvious omissions in the book, there are also inclusions of people that some Poles consider dubious because the people in question apparently no longer live here. **********For example, Janusz Glowacki, a once-popular playwright, was included although he lives in New York, where his play ''Cinders'' was performed not long ago at the Public Theater. **********The new book also includes Jerzy Grotowski, whose experimental theater of poverty based in Wroclaw drew worldwide attention. A few months ago, the company disbanded with the announcement that it had been left leaderless by the director who, the actors said, had gone to California.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/19/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Defense Minister, Dmitri F. Ustinov, who has not been seen in public since Sept. 27, issued the customary ''order of the day'' for Monday's observance of the Day of Rocket Forces. **********Marshal Ustinov, 76 years old, was not present on Nov. 7 to review troops in Red Square during the Revolution Day parade, although newspapers carried his order of the day then on ceremonies for the country's No. 1 holiday. His absence prompted speculation that he was ill. **********The official press agency Tass said Marshal Ustinov's order of the day was issued today, praising the rocket troops and other military personnel for perfecting their training in the face of a deteriorating international situation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/12/busin.body_text: **********A Federal appeals court today cleared the way for the CSX Corporation, the nation's second-largest railroad operator, to take control of one of the nation's largest independent barge companies. **********Independent barge operating companies, which have already gone to the United States Supreme Court to fight aspects of the case, say that CSX's takeover of the American Commercial Barge Lines Company of Evansville, Ind., would hurt cargo- hauling competition between rail and barge companies. **********Permitting the acquisition will encourage other railroads to buy barge companies and further restrict competition, the independent barge operators contend. **********The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled that the barge operators failed to show that they would suffer irreparable harm by allowing the takeover to proceed. **********The court also noted that the Interstate Commerce Commission said the public interest would not be served by further delaying the takeover. **********A spokesman for CSX, which operates the Chessie and Seaboard rail lines, said the company was moving to take immediate control of the barge company. **********CSX's railroad subsidiaries operate a 27,000-mile system in 22 states. American Commercial Barge Lines operates on about 7,500 miles of the nation's inland waterways.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/25/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average posted an impressive gain yesterday although the general market finished only slightly higher in accelerated trading. **********Analysts attributed the advance mainly to a drop in interest rates and to bargain hunting in some of the depressed large capitalization issues. **********At the conclusion of trading, the Dow average was up 13.40 points, to 1,162.90. The New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 0.62, to 90.85, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 equities was up 1.27, to 158.07. **********In the overall market, however, gainers on the Big Board only outnumbered losers by 836 to 708. Turnover on the exchange expanded to 87.1 million shares, from 73.1 million shares the day before. **********William M. LeFevre, market strategist of Purcell, Graham & Company, said that the main ingredients for yesterday's improved market performance was Bankers Trust's reduction in its broker loan rate to 10 3/4 percent, from 11 1/2 percent, and ''the small decline in interest rates in the credit markets.'' **********Contributing factors for the market's advance yesterday were the slight increases in consumer prices and durable goods orders last month, the smallest in three months, and a lower-than-expected Federal budget deficit of $28.6 billion in March. **********In the blue-chip category yesterday, Minnesota Mining climbed 2 points, to 74 3/4; International Paper was up 1 1/2, to 54 3/4; General Electric, 1 5/8, to 55 1/8; International Business Machines, 7/8, to 110 3/4, and Eastman Kodak, 7/8, to 62 1/2. **********Carter Hawley Hale again topped the most-active list, surging 3 3/8, to 30 7/8. The Limited Inc. said it is arranging financing for an increase in its cash offer to acquire Carter Hawley to $35 a share, from $30 a share. The Limited closed off 3/4, at 20 1/8. **********United States Steel advanced 1, to 29 1/4, after reporting that it earned $171 million, or $1.35 a share, in its first quarter, in contrast to a loss of $118 million the year before. **********Exxon, which announced that its profits in the latest quarter rose to $1.75 a share, from $1.22 in the same period last year, was up 7/8, to 41 5/8. **********Higher first-quarter profits sent Nucor up 1 5/8, to 30 7/8, while American Brands gained 5/8, to 55 3/8, after its board increased the quarterly dividend to 93 3/4 cents, from 90 cents. **********ITT Corporation, which fell 1 3/4 points on Monday, yesterday rose 1 1/4, to 36 3/4, in active trading. **********In the technology group, Motorola, Teledyne and Texas Instruments each lost a point or more. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index rose 0.36, to 207.54. Riblet Products was up 2 7/8, to 13 3/8, in active trading. Spear Leeds & Kellogg said it and an investment group had offered to buy Riblet at $15 a share. However, Riblet said it was unlikely the conditions Spear Leeds was proposing would be satisfied. **********Crompton Company fell 1 7/8, to 12 3/4, after its latest quarterly loss widened to $2.4 million, from a deficit of $1.8 million the year before. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index advanced 0.13, to 244.06. Dynamics Research was up 3/4, to 8 3/4 bid, after receiving an engineering services contract from the Air Force.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/21/busin.body_text: **********The Fortune Systems Corporation, a maker of multi-user office computers, said yesterday that it may acquire North Star Computer Inc. **********In a deal under consideration, Fortune would acquire all of North Star's shares outstanding for 4 million Fortune common shares. **********In over-the- counter trading yesterday, Fortune closed at $3.375, up 12.5 cents. At that price, the deal would be valued at $13.5 million. **********Analysts said the acquisition would strengthen Fortune, which has suffered through months of management turmoil and has had problems with its software that prompted customer complaints. **********While Fortune's main desktop computer, called the 32:16, uses the Unix operating system, North Star's computers use an Intel Corporation microprocessor and MS-DOS, the operating system used by the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal Computers. **********''It would mean that we would have both technologies: I.B.M.'s and our own,'' said James S. Campbell, Fortune's chairman and chief executive, in a telephone interview yesterday. **********Fortune, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., said it had already lent North Star $3.75 million, which would be convertible to a 19 percent holding in the company should the acquisition not be completed.  North Star, a closely held concern based in San Leandro, Calif., has been a consistent if relatively little- known maker of advanced microcomputers, which it has sold primarily to small businesses. **********''It saves Fortune a lot of time and development money,'' said David Lawrence, a technology analyst with Montgomery Securities. After a series of sharp losses and the resignation in October of Gary B. Friedman, Fortune's founder and chairman, Fortune ''posted a marginal profit in the last quarter and seems headed to recovery,'' Mr. Lawrence said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/busin.body_text: **********FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1984 **********The Economy **********The index of leading indicators fell 0.7 percent in October, its third decline in five months. Most analysts, however, said they thought the economy would soon resume its expansion after the recent sharp slowdown, rather than sink into recession. (Page D1.) **********Major retailers' sales were sluggish in November , although some chains that started heavy promotions saw sales pick up after Thanksgiving. Sears's sales rose 3.1 percent, K Mart posted a 16.7 percent increase and Penney gained 5.7 percent. (D1.) **********The President is tentatively planning to freeze overall spending in next year's budget, Administration officials said. The decision would mean cuts of about $45 billion in various programs in the budget that the President will send to Congress in January. (A1.) **********The research and development tax credit would continue under the Treasury's proposals, representing a shift in the use of taxes to promote economic development. The credit emphasizes the growth of high-technology industries. (A7.) **********Wall Street may be encouraging sales abuses with its latest productivity drives, an S.E.C. commissioner warned. (D12.) **********Companies **********Other charges against Harry J. Gray of United Technologies   are being investigated by a special board committee, Mr. Gray said. Only 10 days ago a company statement appeared to clear the chairman of allegations that he bugged conversations of senior executives. He said the charges were without ''a shred of truth.'' (D1.) **********The chairman of the LTV Steel will resign at year-end.  The move by E. Bradley Jones surprised the industry because it came so soon after the company was created by the merger of Republic Steel and LTV's Jones & Laughlin steel subsidiary. (D1.) **********Another bid was made for the Des Moines Register and Tribune. Ackerly Communications offered about $156 million; earlier Dow Jones and a group of investors offered $112 million. (D1.) **********Lilly Pulitzer Inc. has filed for protection from its creditors   under the Federal Bankruptcy Code. (D2.) **********Caterpillar is reducing its tractor manufacturing operations in the U.S. and will concentrate more of them overseas. (D4.) **********I.B.M. has placed an order with Storage Technology for data storage systems because of an inability to meet demand, according to industry sources. Storage Technology, an I.B.M. rival, recently sought bankruptcy protection. (D4.) **********Financial Corporation of America will seek the $2 million it paid its former chairman before he resigned. (D5.) **********20th Century-Fox is reportedly trying to sell a 50 percent film studio interest to Mary Tyler Moore Enterprises. (D14.) **********Markets **********Short-term interest rates rose a tenth of a percentage point.   Most of the gain came after the Fed announced a surprisingly high $6.7 billion increase in the basic money supply. (D15.) **********Stock prices fell sharply after the Government reported a drop in the leading economic indicators. The Dow lost 11.93 (D6.) **********The dollar got a late lift following the Fed's money supply report. Gold was bid at $331 an ounce, up 25 cents in late New York trading. (D16.) Commodity markets spent a quiet day of consolidation after recent hectic trading. (D16.) **********International **********Hans Friderich will step aside as the head of Dresdner, West Germany's No. 2 bank, for the duration of his trial. He faces charges that he accepted money from the Flick conglomerate while he was Economics Minister. (D2.) **********Today's Columns **********Critics are firing away at the Treasury's tax plan - but just the parts that might hurt their own interests. The idea of tax revision has drawn praise in general, but it could die if all the attacks on its particulars hit their mark. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Shares of Commerce Clearing House Inc., which has a hand in tax matters, closed yesterday within a fraction of their 52-week high, even though the Treasury's tax simplification plan has helped unsettle the overall stock market. Market Place. (D6.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/world.main_headline: 'SOME' ARE KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA AS POLICE AND BLACK MINERS CLASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/world.print_headline: 'SOME' ARE KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA AS POLICE AND BLACK MINERS CLASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/world.body_text: **********South African authorities said tonight that ''some'' black gold miners were killed today when the police confronted 8,000 rioters at a mine at Westonaria, outside Johannesburg. A police spokesman described the encounter as ''heavy.'' **********The police also reported finding two unidentified bodies of black men in Soweto, Johannesburg's main black satellite township. **********The deaths coincided with another day of unrest among students and black township residents elsewhere in the country. The violence provided a grim counterpoint to the authorities' avowed efforts to put racial change into effect in this divided nation. **********In Cape Town, meanwhile, President P. W. Botha opened South Africa's first Parliament to include nonwhite people. Addressing an assembly that includes people of Indian and mixed racial descent, but excludes the black majority, he said, ''Our gathering today indicates a continuation along the road we took to create a community of peace, prosperity and justice on the southern tip of Africa and to respect the self-determination of population groups and peoples.''  Police Offer No Numbers **********The police, according to their spokesmen, used rubber bullets, tear gas and shotguns against miners who rioted overnight at Westonaria, stoning and burning buildings. **********The spokesmen declined to give details of the number of dead, saying ''clearing up'' was continuing, 14 hours after the clashes were said to have taken place. Some 30,000 to 40,000 black miners stayed away from work Monday in a pay dispute with employers, a move that was viewed as an inital muscle flexing by black gold miners. The differences were resolved today when the miners accepted a compromise offer on vacation allowances. **********However, a spokesmen for the employers, one of them the Anglo-American Corporation, said more than 350 gold miners were injured at mines in Welkom, south of Johannesburg, and Roodepoort, just outside the city, when the police fired tear gas and rubber bullets Monday and today. **********Neville Huxham, spokesman for Anglo-American in Johannesburg, said the police were called to the Western Holdings mine near Welkom after a night of ''intimidation and picketing.'' **********''Unfortunately,'' he said, ''numerous injuries were sustained in this action, and more than 250 workers were treated at the mine hospital in Welkom, many with fractures and wounds resulting from rubber bullets. Of the 250 injured, he said, about 100 were admitted to hospital, 2 were in intensive care and 11 underwent operations.   Mainstay of Economy **********Despite its current, depressed price, gold has long been the mainstay of the South African economy, and Johannesburg, a city of high-rises built over rich veins of the metal, is fringed with pale pyramids of gold-bearing debris from mining operations. The emblems of great wealth, concentrated in the hands of white-run conglomerates, lie on the approaches to the black satellite of Soweto, home to up to two million and the scene, in recent days, of capricious unrest. **********Since mid-August, South Africa has presented two seemingly irreconcilable images. The white authorities have pressed forward with the new Constitution, which offers people of Indian and mixed-race descent a limited political voice. **********At the same time, those opposed to the new Constitution, who argue that it entrenches the system of racial separation that underpins every aspect of life here have been locked in a gathering confrontation with the authorities.   A Harsh Reminder **********In townships south of Johannesburg, more than 40 people have died in the upheavals, far fewer than in the riots of 1976-77 that spread from Soweto and claimed over 500 lives, but nonetheless a harsh reminder to the white authorities that their concept of change has not appeased the black majority, which forms 73 percent of the population. **********The issues prompting the unrest have varied from rent increases to pay grievances, but seem to reflect a wider dissatisfaction among those who see themselves as spurned by the white authorities under the new Constitution. **********When Mr Botha addressed the new Parliament today, deputies of three races crammed into a paneled chamber with green benches that, hitherto, had been a white preserve. **********Henceforth, however, the deputies of different colors will sit in separate chambers, emphasizing, in the view of its critics, the racial nature of the new Constitution. **********The arrangement gives Mr Both, formerly the Prime Minister, potentially authoritarian powers and insures continued control by the Afrikaners, the dominant white group of 2.8 million people. **********Under the new Constitution, the influence of nonwhites is severely circumscribed so that they may only make final decisions on what are termed their ''own affairs,'' such as the day-to- day running of educational and health services, but not on overall policy.   Support for 'Homelands' **********In his address, President Botha acknowledged the exclusion of black people from the new Constitution and indicated continued commitment to one of the cornerstones of his country's racial policies - the ''homelands'' to which black people are allocated according to their ethnic heritage. **********Mr. Botha, in a break with previous Afrikaner practice, has said urbanized black people must be accommodated, tacitly acknowledging the failure of apartheid - as the overall edifice of racial and ethnic division is called - to absorb all those black people living in ''white'' South Africa. He indicated today, however, that any political concessions to urbanized blacks would fall far short of national influence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/13/busin.body_text: **********On the last day of 1983, a senior Government official was reflecting on news of the military takeover in Nigeria. ''Here in the Ivory Coast,'' he said, ''one needn't worry about such things. Here we have calm and stability always.'' **********If the official's tone was a trifle gloating, that might be understandable. The Ivory Coast and Nigeria have long been engaged in a kind of David-and-Goliath rivalry. **********Nigeria has tropical Africa's largest population and economy and is arguably the continent's most important nation. But the Ivory Coast has long been cited as one of modern Africa's rare success stories, a peaceful and attractive country with a vibrant economy. **********Based on those attributes, the country's capital city of Abidjan has increasingly outdistanced its competitors - including the Nigerian capital of Lagos - as a regional center. **********Confronting Two Crises **********Recently, however, an energy crisis and a financial crisis have descended upon the Ivory Coast at the same time. If not dealt with effectively, business people and economists say, both the capital and the country could lose the special status they have earned over the generation since independence from France in 1960. **********The most visible of the Ivory Coast's problems is the shortage of electricity in Abidjan and other sections of the country. The cause is the drought that now plagues more than two-thirds of the countries in Africa. **********The Government here relied almost entirely on hydroelectric power and prepared no alternative plans as the water level in the dams steadily declined. As a result, most homes and businesses now have electricity for only a fraction of the day, and industrial production has fallen as much as 50 percent. **********Silence From the President **********The Ivory Coast's President since independence, Felix Houphou"et-Boigny, 78 years old, has yet to make any public statement on the energy crisis. European diplomats say that does not mean he is unconcerned about the problem. **********''He's livid about it,'' one diplomat said. ''Building this country up into what it is today has been his life's work and he's not about to let the place crumble down.'' **********But energy experts here see no short-term solution. The Government has purchased four oil-fired, 25- megawatt turbines from the French concern Alsthom-Atlantique. Two of them arrived recently, but will not be in operation until March at least. The other two will arrive several months later. **********The four turbines together will supply only about a third of Abidjan's power needs, however, and some of the hydroelectric turbines that are now working overtime will have to be shut down for maintenance when the new ones begin turning. **********Adding to the Debt **********The new turbines, diplomatic sources say, will cost the Ivory Coast between $20 million and $25 million, all to be financed through French banks. **********''They got a good deal,'' said an American economist who had hoped to see the sales go to a company in the United States. **********Even so, those who keep the Ivory Coast's books cannot be entirely sanguine about watching the new figures pile up on the wrong side of the ledger. The Ivory Coast's total indebtedness is estimated at $7 billion, a fairly high figure for a country of about 8.5 million people. **********In December, Mr. Houphou"et- Boigny asked that the debts be rescheduled, and a series of closed-door meetings is being held in London, where it is expected that a refinancing package will eventually be negotiated. The President ''was very reluctant to do it,'' a Western banker said. ''But it had to be done. It's the only way out.'' **********Reasons for Financial Squeeze **********Economists say that the Ivory Coast ran short of money for three reasons. First, prices fell for its principal exports, cocoa and coffee. Second, the dollar soared, exacerbating the cost of debt servicing. And third, the French franc - to which the country's currency is pegged - has been slipping. **********French, American, British and Japanese banks are involved in the rescheduling talks, and a team from the International Monetary Fund was recently here to study the situation. **********''It's a long and complicated process,'' a senior Western diplomat said. ''It's likely to take at least six months.'' In the meantime, foreign business people here say that their companies are not making new investments or bringing out new equipment.   'No Big Pullouts So Far' **********But there appear to be few if any companies that are deserting the Ivory Coast for other parts of Africa. ''There have been no big pullouts so far,'' said Frederic J. Gaynor, the commercial attache at the United States Embassy here. ''But the pace has slowed. Businessmen are tending to take a wait-and-see attitude.'' **********Another Western economist suggested that those businesses that are turning a reasonable profit here are not about to give up just yet. **********''It's difficult doing business here,'' said an American who has lived in Abidjan for a dozen years. ''And it seems to be getting more so. But name a better place in West Africa to live and work. If you're going to be in West Africa, Abidjan is still basically the only game in town.''
