https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/13/busin.print_headline: End for Pound Note and Halfpenny
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/13/busin.body_text: **********Britain announced today the demise of its one- pound note and its 704-year-old halfpenny. **********Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson also said that the current 20- pound note would be replaced with a newer version that would be more difficult to forge. **********The halfpenny - pronounced ha'penny and also known as the ''tiddler'' - has been on Mr. Lawson's list for extinction for some time. Thanks to inflation, it has for several years cost more to make than it is worth. It will cease to be legal tender on Dec. 31. **********Handful of Transactions **********First minted as a silver coin in 1280, the halfpenny is now used for only a handful of grocery items. Transacting business successfully with the tiny coin requires better than average eye-hand coordination and there are doubtlessly untold thousands lost in the deepest corners of purses and pockets. **********''Most people are glad to get rid of them,'' Mr. Lawson said last February. The delay in ending the halfpenny's long run arose from fears that raising prices to the nearest penny would contribute to inflation. The Treasury now believes that so few transactions will be affected that there will be no measurable impact. **********The one-pound note is a monetary youngster by comparison, having been introduced in 1914 to replace the gold sovereign. It is a victim of its inherent frailty. The average life span of the note is 10 months, compared with a predicted 40 years for the small but thick metal alloy pound coin introduced last year. **********Not an Immediate Success **********The new coin was not an immediate success, although it can be used in machines issuing tickets on London's subways and many other vending machines. However, it is a boon to the blind and is now increasingly accepted. **********The Bank of England has already cut back on the printing of new pound notes. The bank will stop altogether at the end of the year, saving Britain $3.8 million next year, according to the Treasury. The notes will cease to be legal tender at the end of 1985, when the lowest denomination of paper money will be the five-pound note. A pound is now worth about $1.27. **********Traditionalists consoled themselves today with the likelihood that versions of the pound issued by banks in Scotland and Northern Ireland will continue to circulate in those reaches of the kingdom. A Bank of Scotland spokesman said that there was no need to consider getting rid of the notes as long as the public seemed quite happy using them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/09/busin.main_headline: MCI Unit Picks Wells, Rich, Greene
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/09/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; MCI Unit Picks Wells, Rich, Greene
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/09/busin.body_text: **********The MCI Digital Information Services Corporation, a subsidiary of the MCI Communications Corporation, has appointed Wells, Rich, Greene as its agency of record. **********MCI Digital, whose primary product is an electronic message delivery system, had been handled by Ally & Gargano, which still retains MCI's domestic residential, long-distance, international and personal communications businesses. **********The reason for the switch, according to the client, was that Federal Express, another of Ally's clients, has shown interest in getting into the same electronic message business. So to protect itself against a potential conflict, MCI reassigned the account. **********MCI's electronic message delivery system was introduced last September.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/01/world.main_headline: ON SALVADOR HUSTINGS, TWO OLD FOES IN REMATCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/01/world.print_headline: ON SALVADOR HUSTINGS, TWO OLD FOES IN REMATCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/01/world.body_text: **********Two years after their last head-to-head campaign confrontation, the front-runners in El Salvador's presidential election race are ready for a rematch. **********In one corner is Jose Napoleon Duarte, the 57-year-old Christian Democrat who was president of the junta that governed El Salvador after the coup of 1979 and oversaw a sweeping land redistribution program. **********His opponent is Roberto d'Aubuisson, a handsome, nervous man of 40. Mr. d'Aubuisson, a cashiered army officer, rose to prominence in 1982 as the head of a new party, the far-right National Republican Alliance. His backers, primarily the landed oligarchy, were determined to repossess their land and save the country from what they viewed as Mr. Duarte's Communist tendencies. **********In many ways, the campaign messages of Mr. Duarte and Mr. d'Aubuisson, front-runners in a field of six, are the same as they have always been. Mr. Duarte sees himself as the sole democratic leader who can consolidate the changes and deal with the leftist insurgents. Mr. d'Aubuisson is more concerned with eradicating the guerrillas rather than talking to them, and emphasizes the importance of a healthy economy over economic changes.   U.S. Officials Are Worried **********The sharp differences in their political views have American officials worried that a victory by either man could polarize the country. But as the March 25 election nears, both the army and the American Embassy seem resigned to a contest between the two, **********Since neither is expected to win more than 50 percent of the vote, a runoff contest between them is expected early in May. In the elections for a Constituent Assembly in 1982, the Christian Democrats won 40 percent of the vote and d'Aubuisson supporters 29 percent. **********Mr. Duarte is trying to mend his relationship with the army and the private sector and the military seems to have softened its criticism of him in the last month. The United States Embassy, which has found his combativeness little to its liking, has also been more supportive of him recently. **********It was the embassy and the army that headed off a d'Aubuisson presidency in April 1982. At that time, a coalition of conservative parties in the Constituent Assembly seemed prepared to name the former army officer, who has been linked to death squads, as provisional President.   'Stolen' Victory Is Resented **********This time the embassy seems to want to avoid such a delicate situation. A high-ranking United States official said members of the National Republican Alliance, which is known as Arena, had hinted that ''they won't be as complacent'' as they were when ''the electoral victory was stolen from them by the United States in 1982.'' **********Late last year some embassy officials promoted the candidacy of Francisco Jose Guerrero of the National Reconciliation Party. They viewed him as an acceptable alternative because he represented a more moderate approach. But Mr. Guerrero has the disadvantage of being associated with a party that was responsible for decades of corrupt military rule and Salvadorans have not responded enthusiastically to his candidacy. **********Mr. Duarte and Mr. d'Aubuisson seem aware of where their competition lies and have honed their campaign speeches accordingly. Mr. d'Aubuisson's speeches are full of anti-Duarte barbs. An Arena campaign worker said Mr. d'Aubuisson's message could be distilled into a single sentence: ''He is against Commmunism and Duarte is a Communist.'' **********''It is a very simple message,'' the worker said, ''and it is appealing because everyone is against Communism.'' **********So far, Mr. d'Aubuisson has given no specifics on how he would end the war and pull the country out of its economic slump. But it does not seem to matter. He flirts with the women, jokes with the men and plays with the children. **********Where Mr. d'Aubuisson himself fails to engage Salvadorans, his organization is at work. The party seems determined to paint the trunk of every tree in El Salvador with its blue, white and red colors. Throughout western El Salvador, where there are numerous farming cooperatives, Arena has swept through with brushes and buckets of paint. **********Although Mr. Duarte has won the endorsement of the country's largest labor union, his party's green and white colors are nowhere to be seen on the western farming cooperatives and few report he has been there. **********His crowds in the countryside are sometimes smaller than Mr. d'Aubuisson's and they generally seem less caught up in what he is saying. He opens his 15-minute campaign speech with a rebuttal of Mr. d'Aubuisson's sharp words and charges that such polemics is evidence that his opponent is desperate. Most of his speech, however, sounds the ''let's work together'' theme.   Soured Relationships **********Mr. Duarte began the campaign with many army officials and business leaders firmly against him. He alienated those two sectors when as junta president he blamed them for El Salvador's problems. Much of his campaigning is now directed at mending the relationships. **********Some army officials seem to be responding to the campaign or, as some Salvadoran political analysts and politicians suggest, are looking at Mr. Duarte as the lesser of two evils. **********While the Reagan Administration's campaign against right-wing violence fell far short of what many Salvadorans had hoped for, it did make many army officials wonder what will happen to United States aid if Mr. d'Aubuisson is elected.  ''There are a significant number of officers who consider d'Aubuisson to be a liability.'' a Salvadoran political analyst said. **********The subtle turn against Mr. d'Aubuisson does not mean the army is any more enthusiastic about Mr. Duarte. If he is elected, everyone expects him to have serious problems with the conservative military. **********But some politicians believe Mr. Duarte is well aware of the need for care. ''He is not as wild or crazy as he used to be,'' a politician from a moderate party said. ''He understands that the army and the private sector won't stand for it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/10/busin.body_text: **********The Government will sell off 339 companies swept up in a 1982 bank nationalization, but will retain control of 128 other companies seized in the takeover, a Government spokesman said today. **********Carlos Sales Gutierrez, under secretary in charge of the nationalized banks, told reporters that the Government would keep control of 128 companies ''in which the banks had priority participation.'' **********He said the mechanisms of the sell- off will be spelled out Monday, but added that the former shareholders would have preference in buying the shares in the denationalized companies. **********Mr. Sales Gutierrez said the total value of the 339 companies, which was set at $241 million on Aug. 31, 1982, the day before the nationalization, now stood at $470 million. **********The Government of former President Jose Lopez Portillo nationalized the banks, accusing them of capital flight that had cost the country $22 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/27/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; The President's Strategy for '84
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/27/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; The President's Strategy for '84
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/27/busin.body_text: **********''D ID I say something funny?'' President Reagan asked during his State of the Union address to Congress as laughter swept the chamber. The laugh came when the President said he wanted to get specific recommendations for a ''historic'' tax reform - ''by December 1984.'' Great performers know that timing is all, and Mr. Reagan's timing was impeccable, since the election comes in November. **********He had some other amusing lines. For instance, on the eve of submitting a budget with deficits projected to run close to $200 billion a year for the next few years, following a record deficit total of $485 billion for the fiscal years 1982, 1983 and 1984, he kept a straight face in calling for a constitutional amendment ''mandating a balanced budget.'' **********He wants to be made virtuous, but not yet. Immediately, all he seeks is a ''down payment'' on deficit reduction. He has asked House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., to name representatives to work with the Administration on a ''bipartisan deficit reduction plan.'' **********The President's move was described by his own staff as an electoral strategy for sharing guilt with Democrats. Since the Democrats, with Representative Dan Rostenkowsi, the Democratic leader of the House Ways and Means Committee, leading the charge, joined so lustily in the tax-cutting spree of 1981, they must accept their share of guilt for undermining the nation's fiscal structure - and the responsibility for repairing it. **********The bipartisan operation is likely to reduce the deficit in the fiscal year 1985 by only $20 billion, but Mr. Reagan thinks there is a basis for agreement on a plan to cut deficits by $100 billion over the next three years. **********Since his own budget will project deficits of close to $600 billion during those three years - with the Congressional Budget Office estimating the deficits, under existing legislation, to exceed $700 billion in that period - the budgetary tide of red ink would not be much stanched if the President gets the whole $100 billion. **********He said, however, that the vital question was not whether to reduce the deficits but how. He will cut the military budget hardly at all, if he can help it. And, still smarting from the attacks on his former Secretary of the Interior, James G. Watt, and his former head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Anne McGill Burford, Mr. Reagan called for increases in spending to acquire park lands and to protect the environment. **********He also wants money for what he called ''the Jackson plan'' (after the late Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington) ''to implement the recommendations of the Bipartisan Commission on Central America,'' formerly known as the Kissinger Commission before the need to appease the right- wing became so critical. **********To reduce Federal spending, he supported the 2,500 cuts recommended by the Grace Commission (no name problem here with J. Peter Grace) and told Congress he wanted line-item veto power. There is less here than meets the eye: The big cuts in the Grace Commission report would have to come in Congressionally mandated entitlement programs, such as Medicare, Medicaid and Federal pensions, which are well protected politically. **********Since entitlement programs and the military budget constitute more than 80 percent of the total budget, line-item veto power, even if Congress were willing to give it to him, would yield only small potatoes, even assuming the President would exercise it against programs for which there was strong political support. **********Mr. Reagan made blazingly clear that he is still determined to prevent tax increases. He called increasing taxes ''a Band-Aid solution'' (copyright protected). Indeed, he suggested that increasing taxes would be a lot worse than a mere Band-Aid: ''It poses a real threat to economic recovery,'' he said, clinging to his huge 1981 tax cut and his political knowledge that the voters do not want higher taxes. **********But it is worth noting that the Economic Recovery Tax Act, or ERTA, of 1981, which cut taxes by $750 billion over five years, was followed by the steep 1981-82 recession, and that the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act, or TEFRA, of 1982, which raised taxes by $99 billion over the fiscal years 1983 to 1985, offseting 22 percent of ERTA in those years, was followed by the strong recovery of 1983. It is that recovery that has so lifted Mr. Reagan's popularity and strengthened his prospects of re-election. **********Of course, neither the huge tax cut of 1981 nor the lesser tax increase of 1982 was solely responsible either for the downswing or the upswing in the business cycle. The Federal Reserve's tight monetarism of 1981 and early 1982, and the high interest rates, resulting from the Fed's refusal to accommodate big deficits, was the primary cause of the steepest recession of the postwar period. **********And the Fed's abandonment of that policy turned the economy around and hastened the recovery, with the tax increase of 1982 helping to reduce Government pressures on interest rates. **********Mr. Reagan welcomed the Fed's desertion of monetarism and accepted the tax-increasing TEFRA, and the recovery was his reward. Good economics, he should remind himself, may make the best politics. Even in the short run.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.main_headline: Thais Delay Showdown Over Jobs for Generals
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Thais Delay Showdown Over Jobs for Generals
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.body_text: **********A possible constitutional crisis was put off today when the Thai legislature voted to postpone a decision on whether active military officers should be allowed to hold Government posts. **********The proposal to change the Constitution, which at present requires military officers to retire or resign commissions before joining governing cabinets, had been introduced by army officers loyal to their Supreme Commander, Gen. Arthit Kamlang-ek. **********General Arthit is widely assumed to be in line for the Prime Minister's job. **********What has caused concern among civilian politicians here is that the Supreme Commander might be persuaded by army officers to make an earlier-than-expected bid for the country's highest political office during a period in which the present Prime Minister, Prem Tinsulanonda, is ill. **********General Prem, a retired officer, is scheduled to go to the United States for a medical checkup on Sept. 14. He has been out of public life for two weeks, reportedly suffering from early symptoms of heart disease.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/25/world.main_headline: SANDINISTAS' OPPONENTS TELL OF OBSTACLES TO TRAVEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/25/world.print_headline: SANDINISTAS' OPPONENTS TELL OF OBSTACLES TO TRAVEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/25/world.body_text: **********Miriam Arg"uello was planning to travel to Costa Rica for a wedding this week, but when she arrived to pick up her passport from immigration officials, she said she was told it had inadvertantly been sent to a remote part of the country. **********Juan Ramon Aviles said that he wanted to make a business trip, but that the authorities told him he would be granted an exit visa only after a newly-discovered irregularity about his date of birth was resolved. **********Enrique Bolanos Geyer made it all the way to the Managua airport, but as he passed through document control, he said, an official examined his passport in private and then announced that it was missing a page and therefore was not valid. Mr. Bolanos said it was intact when he presented it. **********Mrs. Arg"uello, Mr. Aviles and Mr. Bolanos are leaders of anti-Sandinista political and business groups. They and about a dozen other opposition figures say that for the last three weeks, since the national election that the Sandinista Front won overwhelmingly, they have found an array of obstacles in their way as they try to go out of the country. **********No New Policy Announced **********The Sandinista Government has not announced any new policy on travel by opposition figures, but one appears to be in effect. Senior Government officials did not respond to requests for interviews on the subject. **********Lieut. Miguel Necochea, spokesman for the Interior Ministry, said Friday night that the Government had no list of people to be prevented from leaving the country. ''We have no policy of denying visas to anyone,'' Lieutenant Nicochea said. **********As far as could be determined, all of the opposition leaders currently unable to travel have ties to the Democratic Coordinator, a coalition of political parties, labor unions and business groups that incurred the wrath of the Sandinista Front when it refused to take part in the recent electoral campaign. The coalition nominated Arturo Jose Cruz, an economist, for President, but then refused to register his name on the ground the Government was not allowing political rivals enough freedom. **********At times in the past the Government has temporarily restricted travel for some opposition leaders, but no such restrictions are known to have been imposed in the last year. Under emergency powers adopted after the outbreak of civil strife three years ago the Government has some powers to restrict travel by Nicaraguan citizens, but it has not invoked them.   A Tradition of Travel **********Travel among Central American countries is common, and many businesses rely on commerce within the isthmus. In addition, Nicaraguan opposition leaders, like the Sandinistas themselves, often travel in search of international support for their political positions. **********Some of those who have been unable to leave Nicaragua said they suspected that the Government's motive was to prevent them from denouncing the Sandinistas in foreign countries. Others speculated that because the Government fears an imminent invasion from the United States, it may want to be sure opposition leaders are in the country when it comes and are not able to escape its consequences. **********''Perhaps they would use us as hostages if anything were to happen in the country,'' suggested Mr. Aviles, a lawyer who works for the Superior Council of Private Enterprise, Nicaragua's main business federation.   Business Group Leaders **********Several leaders of the council, which is known as Cosep, are among those who have had trouble leaving the country. Mr. Bolanos, who now carries his mutilated passport as a conversation piece, is the group's president. His brother Nicolas, president of the Union of Nicaraguan Coffee Growers, which is affiliated with Cosep, said he had also been unable to leave for a planned trip to visit a daughter in New Orleans. **********''A military man at the immigration office told me my application was incomplete, but he wouldn't answer questions about what was missing,'' Nicolas Bolanos said today. ''They made me fill out a new form and told me to come back Nov. 28.'' **********Francisco Javier Calderon, executive secretary of another Cosep-affiliated group, the National Council of Professionals, told a similar story. He was planning a trip through nearby countries to meet with sympathetic political and civic groups. As is the custom in Nicaragua, he submitted his passport and other required documentation to the authorities 15 days before he was to leave.   'They Said to Come Back' **********''They told me to pick up the passport on Nov. 16,'' Mr. Calderon said. ''When I got there, they said to come back three days later. When I arrived the second time, a Sub-Lieut. Carlos Granera came out and told me that my passport had accidentally been sent to Special Zone I and could not be found.'' **********Special Zone I is the northern part of isolated Zelaya Province on the Atlantic coast of Nicaragua. **********Sub-Lieutenant Granera, reached by telephone, said he was not authorized to give any information about Government policy on travel for opposition figures. But one of his aides, Sub-Lieut. Ruth Zepeda, said the agency ''is not preventing anyone from leaving.'' **********In at least one case, an opposition leader was able to win an exit visa that was apparently being denied to him after he appealed personally to Interior Minister Tomas Borge. The leader, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Barrios, an editor of the opposition newsaper La Prensa, said he was on his way to Japan last week when authorities at the airport told him his multiple-exit visa was no longer valid. Mr. Chamorro missed his plane. But later, backed by a Japanese diplomat, he spoke with Mr. Borge, obtained the visa, and was finally able to leave. **********One of the first activists to encounter trouble was Mario Rapaccioli, leader of a faction of the Conservative Party, who was turned back at the airport Nov. 12 after an immigration officer found a page of his passport disfigured. Since then at least a dozen applications by opposition leaders for new passports, passport renewals or exit visas have been delayed. **********Mr. Rapaccioli, one of the most outspoken anti-Sandinistas remaining in Nicaragua, said in an interview that his passport was in perfect condition when he submitted it at the airport. Immigration officers at the Managua airport work in opaque booths that do not allow passengers any view of what they are doing with the travelers' documents.   No Response Received **********Several other opposition leaders, such as Luis Rivas Leiva of the Social Democratic Party, Erick Ramirez of the Social Christians and Jose Espinoza of the Confederation for Trade Union Unity, said they had received no responses to requests for visas, new passports or passport renewals. **********''Under their emergency powers, they have the right to keep people from leaving,'' said Mr. Aviles. ''I wish they would just publish a list and tell us which people are forbidden to leave and for how long, so we don't go through this charade. The immigration office is a good distance from where I work, and gasoline is expensive in this country.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/29/busin.body_text: **********Stephen L. Kurtin, president of Protype, a new California-based high- technology company, seems to like starting new companies almost as much as he likes to invent things. **********Mr. Kurtin, who is 39 years old, got his first patent at 14 for a television set that projected three-dimensional images. Such precociousness followed Mr. Kurtin to college, where he earned bachelor's and master's degrees in physics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in four years, quickly following them up with a doctorate in applied physics from what he termed the ''West Coast trade school,'' the California Institute of Technology. **********In 1970, his education complete, the 26-year-old Mr. Kurtin founded a company called Lexitron with $3,000 of his own money. The company's principal product was a video display word processor that Mr. Kurtin invented, ushering in a new concept in office automation. **********Two years later, Lexitron went public, and in 1977 it was purchased by the Raytheon Corporation for $14 million in cash. **********He now has a new company and a new invention. **********''I am a product freak,'' he acknowledged in a recent interview. **********The product Mr. Kurtin is beginning to market is an office typewriter offering much of the power of a word processor complete with a screen on which to edit. It is described as easy to operate. **********Even though he is entering a market dominated by the International Business Machines Corporation, the Xerox Corporation and Canon of Japan, Mr. Kurtin projects that in the first year he will sell $40 million worth of his new machines, which are priced at less than $3,000. **********''We are competing with I.B.M., but with a distinctive product,'' he said. ''This machine will replace typewriters as we know them.'' **********Mr. Kurtin's enthusiasm is understandable, but noted California venture capitalists like Max Palevsky and David Packard thought enough of his new machine to sink $4.6 million into his company, the Protype Corporation. The company is based in Sun Valley, Calif. **********And unlike leaders of other start-up operations, Mr. Kurtin plans almost immediately to move production facilities for his machine off-shore. **********''We are anxious to keep this a United States company, and will start assembling the machines here,'' he said, ''but the economics of building Protype machines in the Far East are irrefutable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/26/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON IN the summer of 1983, the Democratic candidates for President talked a lot about ''industrial policy'' solutions to the ills of flagging businesses and the growing pains of new ones. Republicans said the whole idea reeked of central planning. Even so, Mr. Reagan established a President's Commission on Industrial Competitiveness, which bore a certain euphemistic kinship to the Democrats' terminology. **********The commission, made up of the heads of some of the country's biggest companies and chaired by John A. Young, the president and chief executive of the Hewlett-Packard Company, has been meeting periodically since then. It has put together about 30 recommendations to the President that are intended, in part, to strengthen the ability of American industries to compete with foreign industries. **********To enhance the role of science and technology in policy deliberations, for example, the Young commission proposes a Cabinet-level Department of Science and Technology. It would represent agencies such as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the National Institutes of Health. The commission also urges closer cooperation between labor and management to promote productivity, more generous tax incentives to encourage research and development and a requirement that companies give workers earlier warnings when they plan to close plants. **********Such initiatives would seem to sit well with Democratic industrial policy makers, although the proposals are less ambitious than what some of them sought, such as the establishment of a national development bank to make loans to favored companies. **********Barbara Gleason, an aide to the Young commission, said the group would meet for the last time Dec. 6 or 7 and then submit its report to the White House. The White House said Mr. Young visited Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to the President, earlier this month to discuss the report, which will be made public in late January or early February. **********A senior White House administrator said last week that he was impressed by the commission's work. If the Administration buys the recommendations, Ronald Reagan might become known as the father of American industrial policy.
