https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/23/busin.body_text: **********-exempt financing, a modest surge of new **********rental housing construction is in the offing in Manhattan. One of the buildings, called Carnegie Park, went into construction this month. **********The building will have 462 rental apartments in a tower of 30 stories, plus connected smaller structures of 8, 9 and 10 stories, on the east side of Third Avenue between 93d and 94th Streets. The 60,000-square-foot site was the last one available in the Ruppert Brewery urban renewal area. The architect is Davis Brody & Associates. **********The developer is the Related Companies Inc., which in addition to this site expects to be in construction by February on three sites in the Rector Place section of Battery Park City and one in the West Side urban renewal area, on the east side of Columbus Avenue at 87th Street. **********The total is close to 1,200 apartments, said Stephen M. Ross, the 44- year-old president of Related Companies, who was a real-estate lawyer and syndication specialist when he started the enterprise in 1971. It has built and continues to manage more than 8,000 publicly assisted apartments around the country, and it now does commercial and office ventures as well. **********The financing will be in the form of a $68 million mortgage issued by the Housing Development Corporation, the city's housing finance agency, from a pool of funds that will be raised in a public sale within the next few weeks. The builder will pay a rate about 3 to 4 percentage points below the conventional mortgage rate because the bond issue is exempt from Federal, state and city taxes. **********At Carnegie Park, 80 percent of the tenants will pay market rents. These are expected to be in the range of $2 to $2.25 a square foot per month. At $2 a square foot, a 750-square foot, one- bedroom apartment would rent for $1,500 a month, or $18,000 a year. **********Using the current standard calculation that most households can pay 28 percent of their income as rent, this means the apartment would be affordable to households with annual incomes of about $54,000. **********''You must give people a life style at these rents,'' said Mr. Ross. ''The old days of renting just shelter won't work.'' **********Contributing to the life style will be a health club, a swimming pool and a private park. Above all, however, the developers are banking on the Upper East Side location to attract higher- income tenants, often from two-income households. **********Twenty percent of the apartments will get a Federal Section 8 subsidy and will be rented to people with incomes below 80 percent of the area's median income, currently $24,900. A one-bedroom apartment would rent to a subsidized tenant for about $500. **********Lance H. Wilson, president of the Housing Development Corporation, said the agency would also supply the financing for prospective rental developments on Columbus Avenue in the West Side urban renewal area. **********Some, like Carnegie Park, will have Section 8 subsidies for the lower- income units, which relieves the market-rate apartment of most of the economic burden of carrying the difference between subsidized tenants' rents and the true rent requirement. **********But with the demise of Section 8 subsidies for new construction, future projects with tax-exempt financing and the 80-20 income mix will have to be entirely ''self-subsidized'' in the building. In other words, the higher- rent apartments will pick up the rent requirements above what the lower- income tenants pay. **********Because of the high costs of construction in Manhattan, an unusually high subsidy per apartment must be paid to sustain a 20 percent occupancy by lower-income people. Mr. Wilson estimated that about $200 a month of a market-rate apartment's rent would go toward meeting the rent requirements of the lower-income tenant's apartment. **********At Carnegie Park, which gets the Section 8 subsidy, the development cost is expected to be in the range of $155 to $175 a square foot, Mr. Ross said. This includes $23 a square foot attributed to land costs. **********The tax-exempt financing, as well as reduced property-tax payments in the first 10 years under the Section 421a program, are necessary to keep the rents to higher-income tenants at a marketable level. **********Another forthcoming example of so-called 80-20 housing with tax-exempt financing will be a development called Yorkville Plaza, covering an area of 95,000 square feet on the block between 95th and 96th Streets, from Second Avenue to a point east of Third Avenue. **********Here the state's Housing Finance Agency is providing $120 million in financing for what is planned as 1,100 apartments to be built by the Milstein Organization. The developer is seeking mortgage insurance from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. **********A spokesman for the Housing Development Corporation noted that developers who use the tax-exempt bond financing must pay a bank or some other financial institution to guarantee the bond issue. This costs 1 to 1 1/2 percentage points above the basic interest rate plus fees. Thus neither the state nor the city is at risk on the mortgages in case of default.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/28/world.body_text: **********El Salvador's army high command has ordered a full investigation into an alleged massacre of 68 peasants last month by a United States- trained army unit, military officials said. **********They said the investigation, believed to be the first such military investigation, was ordered yesterday by Defense Minister Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova after he read a report by the Catholic church's human rights monitoring arm, Tutela Legal. **********The church group investigated reports of a mass killing in northern Cabanas Province and said troops of the elite United States -trained Atlacatl Battalion shot 68 peasants to death in a ''search and destroy operation'' between July 18 and 22 in three villages some 25 miles north of the capital. **********Inquiry Started by Duarte **********Military officials said the army investigation was initiated at the request of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, who has said he first learned of the incident at a press conference on Saturday. **********They said the inquiry would be led by Col. Joel Rivas, administrative assistant to the defense minister. **********Western diplomats said they welcomed the investigation, a rare event in the country, but added that military inquiries into lesser abuses of authority in the past had seldom produced results.  Last week, a Defense Ministry spokesman said the army had looked into reports of bombings against the civilian population in Cabanas and found they were ''negative.'' **********He said the accusations of an army attack against civilians were a ''propaganda campaign against the armed forces.''  Previous Massacre Reports **********Human rights groups say the Atlacatl Battalion has been responsible for a string of massacres of peasants, most notably the killing of some 500 peasants in the village of El Mozote in northeastern Morazan Province in late 1981. There was no army investigation of the Mozote incident. **********The probe into the Cabanas massacre reports comes less than two days after Mr. Duarte announced the formation of a special commission to investigate a number of killings in the last four years, including another reported army massacre in western El Salvador.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/16/world.main_headline: Cuba Holds Municipal Voting; 98 Percent Turnout Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/16/world.print_headline: Cuba Holds Municipal Voting; 98 Percent Turnout Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/16/world.body_text: **********Cubans voted today in municipal elections that provide their only direct say in the Government. **********The turnout was expected to exceed 98 percent. **********Some polling stations reported that more than half their registered electorate had voted in the first two hours. **********Almost 11,000 delegates will be chosen to form 169 municipal assemblies, which later elect the provincial and national assemblies. **********Today's election is the fourth since the 1976 Constitution was drawn up, confirming Fidel Castro as head of state, Government and party and decreeing that direct municipal elections should be held every two-and-a-half years. **********Every precinct has at least two candidates nominated in neighborhood meetings over the past few months. **********The delegates are chosen as individuals and though usually around 70 percent are Communist party members, party membership is not a requirement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/24/world.main_headline: LABOR HOLDS LEAD IN ISRAELELECTION BUT RACE IS CLOSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/24/world.print_headline: LABOR HOLDS LEAD IN ISRAELELECTION BUT RACE IS CLOSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/24/world.body_text: **********With roughly 93 percent of the votes counted, computer projections show Israel's Labor alignment winning slightly more votes than the ruling Likud bloc, but the Likud and its allies in a somewhat better position to form the next government. **********The projected results were seen by Israeli political analysts as an upset by the Likud, which almost every Israeli poll taker had predicted would lose decisively, and a major setback for the Labor Party. **********Both Labor and Likud, however, lost seats to the small religious and ideological left- and right-wing parties, who seemed to be the real winners in this election and who will have the ultimate say in determining which of the big parties forms the next Cabinet. **********More Allies for Likud **********Because Likud has more potential allies among the small parties, it was seen by the Israeli television political commentators as better positioned to form a majority coalition - even if Labor alone ends up getting a few more seats than Likud alone. **********Computer projections by the Israeli television, based on the mounting returns and a straw poll conducted outside voting booths, showed the Labor Party led by Shimon Peres winning 45 Parliament seats to 42 seats for the Likud bloc led by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Labor won 47 seats in the 1981 elections and Likud 48. It takes 61 seats to form a majority in the 120-seat Parliament. **********Fragmented Electorate **********Likud's ability to defy the predictions was because many of its predominantly poorer and Oriental Jewish supporters, who had been wavering, in the end decided they simply could not identify with the Labor Party and returned to the Likud fold at the last minute, noted a Hebrew University political scientist, Gadi Wolfsfeld. **********This, coupled with the general decline in strength of both the big parties and the gains made by their smaller rivals, suggests an Israeli electorate that is becoming more deeply divided and fragmented then ever before. **********''The picture painted by these results is of an Israel rigidly divided into two camps,'' said another Hebrew University political scientist, Dan Horowitz. ''Whichever party will form the next government will be very weak. If a national unity Cabinet is formed, then the question is whether it will be under Peres or Shamir. Even a national unity Cabinet could probably not last long. In the long-term, Israel's democracy may be paralyzed.'' **********Since both big parties will be well short of the majority required to form a new government, they will be forced to try to cajole, entice and essentially ''buy'' support from the wide range of small parties, which divided the remainder of the seats. **********''Both parties will have to buy off everyone you can buy to form a government,'' said Daniel J. Elazar, a leading Israeli public policy expert.  This means, the analysts said, that any new Israeli government, whether it is put together by Labor or Likud, will be a highly unstable coalition of large and small parties of widely differing ideologies. Such a government would find it difficult to make any new initiative regarding the peace process or territorial compromise with Israel's Arab neighbors. It would also find it difficult to bring Israel's 400 percent inflation rate under control because it would have to promise ''payoffs'' to win the support of small parties, particularly the religious groups.   National Unity Government **********The only way to possibly avoid this would be for Labor and Likud to join in a national unity government, as Mr. Shamir has requested. But Mr. Peres has rejected the offer. Whether such a Cabinet would really be a stable alternative, however, seems questionable. As the election results indicate, there is simply no consensus in Israel anymore on questions from the economy to what shape the country should ultimately take, and a national unity Cabinet would only be papering over those differences rather then reflecting a real meeting of minds. **********Still, pressure for a national unity Cabinet appeared to be mounting today as the vote totals came in. Zevulun Hammer, the Minister of Education, announced late Monday night that his National Religious Party, which is expected to be a key power broker, would only throw its weight behind the party forming a national unity government because it was the ''only way'' to undertake the drastic changes needed to deal with Israel's economy. **********Ezer Weizman, whose small Yahad Party will also be needed by both Labor and Likud to put together a majority, also recommended the formation of a national unity Cabinet. **********No matter who forms the next government, noted Mr. Elazar, the election results have to be interpreted as a ''major defeat'' for the Labor Party. **********''Labor's ability to throw away victory after everything that has happened under the Likud - the failure of the Lebanon war, the 400 percent inflation rate, the disappearance of its historical founder Menachem Begin - really says something,'' he said. ''I think you could say that the Likud has become the majority party in Israel in the sense that it can hold voters in the face of the most incredible disasters. Labor has to be seen as the party of the last generation and Likud the party of the new generation. Labor is seen as the establishment that people do not want to come back.''  'Great Historical Achievement' **********Both Mr. Peres and Mr. Shamir were closeted in their respective party headquarters in Tel Aviv early today, negotiating with the small parties while they watched the results come in. **********Mr. Peres made a brief appearance before his party's faithful, putting the best face on the returns and telling reporters that he believed Labor could form a majority coalition. But there was already talk in the Labor camp about new elections being called in November, the Israeli television reported. **********A jubiliant Prime Minister Shamir addressed the Likud Party headquarters, talking as though he was certain to stay in power, even though he was projected to win fewer seats than Mr. Peres. **********''It is completely clear now that the Likud achieved in these elections a great historical achievement,'' said Mr. Shamir. ''People said to us, 'Don't worry, the Likud will win,' and the Likud won.'' **********The Prime Minister repeated his appeal for a national unity government and said he had already conducted preliminary discussions with several parties on the subject and received generally ''affirmative'' responses. **********The final vote count is not expected to be completed until Thursday, when the ballots of Israeli soldiers and sailors will have been tabulated. In such a close election, a swing of only one or two seats to Likud or Labor could be critical.   Awkward Position for President **********President Chaim Herzog told reporters today that only on Thursday would he begin consulting with the various parties to see which one was in the best position to form a majority government. **********If Labor continues to hold its small lead over the Likud, President Herzog could be in an awkward situation unique in Israeli political history. **********According to Israeli law, the President, after consulting all of the parties, calls on the party leader he thinks is best positioned to form a government. Since the founding of the state, the President has traditionally called on the party with the largest number of seats, but in the case of this election Labor could win more seats than Likud but Likud could be better able to form a coalition with the small parties. This raises the question of which party President Herzog will call on first to try to form a government. Mr. Shamir's exuberant remarks seemed to be directed more at President Herzog than anyone else. The situation is doubtly sensitive for Mr. Herzog, who is a life-long member of the Labor Party. **********That party leader who is asked by the President to form a government has 42 days to put together a 61-seat majority. If he cannot, the next largest party is traditionally given a chance. **********Judging from the Israeli television computer projections the Labor Party and its close allies among the small parties would gain almost the same number of seats in Parliament as the Likud and its close allies, with Likud holding only a slight advantage.   Breakdown of the Vote **********According to the Israeli television's computer projections and its straw vote conducted outside selected polling stations, Labor would win 45 seats. One close ally, the dovish Shinui Party led by Amnon Rubinstein, would win 3, and the Citizens Rights Party led by Shulamit Aloni, would win 3. Many Labor supporters appear to have deserted Labor in favor of the two small allied parties, whose positions on peace with the Arabs and social issues were much more clearly articulated than the Labor Party's. which tried to obfuscate its views to lure right-of-center voters away from Likud. **********Ezer Weizman's Yahad Party, which could go with either Likud or Labor, was projected to win only 2 seats. Tami, the Oriental Jewish Party, which could also go with either big party, was projected to win 1 seat. **********In other words, Labor with its close allies, plus Mr. Weizman's party and Tami, would have only 54 seats. This would leave Labor in need of several religious parties. **********The two predominantly Arab parties were expected to gain 6 seats - 4 going to the Communist Hadash Party and 2 going to the new Jewish-Arab Progressive List for Peace. The Arab parties traditionally vote against Likud, but Labor would never bring them into a ruling coalition. **********The Likud is projected to win 42 seats, with its hard-line allies Tehiya, led by Yuval Neeman, 4 seats, the pro- Likud one-man party of Yigal Hurwitz 1 seat and the right-wing religious party, Morasha, 2 seats. That would give Likud a total of 49. **********Likud would then have to approach the other religious parties that have been in its Cabinets for the past seven years. The National Religious Party is projected to win 4 seats and the ultra- Orthodox Agudat and Shas parties 6 seats. With the religious parties, Likud would have 59 seats and would then have to win the support of either Tami, Mr. Weizman or American-born Rabbi Meir Kahane who is projected to win 1 seat. **********Weather for the election was ideal and turnout among Israel's 2.65 million voters appears to have been above 75 percent, judging from early projections.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/15/busin.body_text: **********The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said it planned to resume drilling at a Beaufort Sea site that had been an earlier disappointment. Drilling operations are scheduled for late January through April on the east side of Prudhoe Bay. **********That area is within a few miles of the Endicott field, which earlier had been labeled marginally economical by Sohio. **********The well, Niakuk No. 4, is a follow- up to other wells drilled in the area in the late 1970's. Those earlier wells were plugged, but a Sohio spokesman, Hugh Depland, said that ''we've learned some new things'' as a result of recent studies, including more seismic testing in the area. He declined to comment on how much oil Sohio believes is in the field, but added: ''If we didn't expect the well to be productive, we wouldn't drill it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Ambivalence On Tax Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Ambivalence On Tax Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/busin.body_text: **********THE Treasury Department's report to the **********President, entitled ''Tax Reform for Fairness, Simplicity and Economic Growth,'' has been called the biggest trial balloon since the Hindenburg. And ever since the report sailed into view, affected groups, ranging from oil companies and stockbrokers to universities and churches, have been firing away at those parts of the plan that they think would hurt their interests. **********Most of the critics say they favor broadening the tax base and cutting marginal tax rates in general but feel a serious mistake was made when it came to eliminating their tax break in particular. If all the missiles aimed at specific parts of the Treasury proposal hit their targets, however, obviously the whole plan will collapse. **********Indeed, the impression is being created by the uproar over the elimination of some deductions and exemptions that the Treasury plan is already dead. There is genuine danger that, unless proponents (including the President) fight harder to defend an approach that actually has widespread support among both conservatives and liberals, this major effort to revise the tax system and make it more efficient and equitable will collapse. **********Oddly enough, this is not a simple case of the proponents of a fiscal plan being ranged against its opponents. Most people are simultaneously proponents and opponents - proponents in general, opponents in particular. But they may seriously damage their own interests if they do not treat the plan as a whole and ignore its likely effects on their own and national interests. **********There are many examples of this dichotomy over narrow and broad effects of the plan. As Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York said, ''Few would argue against simplifying a Federal tax code that now runs to more than 2,500 pages.'' But he then promptly proceeded, as a New Yorker, to attack one element that would be ''ruinous to our state's economy''- the Treasury's proposal to eliminate the right of individuals to deduct state and local taxes from the income on which they pay Federal tax. Senator Moynihan said he would fight this to the end in the Senate Finance Committee, of which he is a member. **********Governor Cuomo, who is a strong supporter of action to shrink the Federal budget deficit, declared that he, too, would fight against the proposal to repeal deductibility of state and local taxes and would recruit other Governors, especially in high- tax states, to the cause. **********But Representative Charles B. Rangel, who is a member of the House Ways and Means Committee and who represents an upper Manhattan district with many poor residents, hailed the Treasury's proposal, calling it ''the greatest thing that's come along.'' He said eliminating deductions of state and local taxes was relatively unimportant, compared with the improvements the plan promises in equity and simplicity. **********The low-income people in Mr. Rangel's district would benefit from raising the personal exemption to $2,000 for all taxpayers and their dependents and increasing the zero-bracket amount to $2,800 for single taxpayers, $3,800 on joint returns and $3,500 for heads of households. These provisions, as the Treasury report said, would virtually eliminate from taxation families with incomes below the poverty level. **********Obviously, if this entire tax package is being presented as ''revenue neutral,'' then some individuals and businesses are going to lose while others are going to gain as the system is revised. This is what makes the plan so hard to sell politically. However, whether one approves of the relative gains and losses depends on one's social values, and the remarkable thing about this Reagan Administration plan is that it offers advantages for those far down the income ladder. **********But even many of those who regard themselves as losers may find, if they would hold their fire and examine the proposal carefully as a whole, that they may also be gainers, especially if the overall economy is strengthened. More specifically, residents of New York and other states would also benefit from the proposed steep cuts in marginal tax rates. These need to be set off against the loss of income resulting from the elimination of deductibility of state and local taxes. **********Furthermore, the cuts in business tax rates will aid a great many companies, especially small and growing ones. But not all big businesses, even in so- called smokestack industries, have rushed to the conclusion that they would be worse off if this plan were enacted. General Motors, for example, is strongly supporting the Treasury's plan. Apparently at last it has got Engine Charley Wilson's dictum right: ''What's good for the nation is good for General Motors.'' I.B.M. is also supporting the plan, presumably on the same principle. **********One does not have to be a ''special interest'' to rush to a mistaken conclusion about the effects on one's own institution of the changes the Treasury has proposed. Spokesmen for many nonprofit institutions have rushed to the conclusion that the proposed changes in charitable contributions would hurt them. The Treasury proposes to disallow deductions of charitable contributions below 2 percent of adjusted gross income. But its proposal to permit unlimited deductibility above that 2 percent limit, instead of the old 50 percent-of-income limit on contributions, could actually benefit universities, museums, churches and other nonprofit institutions by encouraging much larger and earlier contributions. **********The affected interests would do well not to holler before they're hurt. Many may discover that they have much more to gain than to lose.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/31/busin.body_text: **********Southwest Forest Industries said yesterday that it plans to hold ''exploratory discussions'' with the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation about ''a possible transaction.'' **********W. A. Franke, Southwest's president, said he understood that Jefferson Smurfit had recently acquired about 9 percent of the 9.3 million shares outstanding of Southwest, a maker of paperboard and other products that use wood as raw material. **********Howard Kilroy, chief operations director for Jefferson Smurfit, said the company intends to notify the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it had acquired more than 5 percent of Southwest's shares. He declined to comment further. **********Jefferson Smurfit, which is based in Alton, Ill., is 78 percent owned by the Jefferson Smurfit Group, Ireland's largest industrial corporation. Much of its growth in the last decade has come from acquiring paperboard and packaging concerns in the United States. **********In March, a group of investors led by Mr. Franke and Morgan Stanley & Company announced a $24 a share leveraged buyout of Southwest but withdrew the offer two months later when financing arrangements collapsed. Mr. Franke subsequently retained the First Boston Corporation to explore ''strategic alternatives'' for the company. **********Southwest Forest, which is based in Phoenix, had losses in 1982 and 1983. But it reported net income of $3.4 million on sales of $174.8 million for this year's first quarter, while Jefferson Smurfit earned $4.6 million on sales of $161.9 million. **********Southwest's shares rose $1, to $17.125, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/12/busin.body_text: **********DURING the last several Saturday and Sunday mornings while the staff of Montefiore Medical Center has been on strike, the portly, bespectacled figure of John H. Gutfreund has been seen preparing meals and washing dishes at the Bronx hospital. He resolutely refuses to discuss it, saying only, ''You do what you do because you have to.'' **********Indeed, his compulsion to do what ''you have to'' goes well beyond pitching in during an emergency at the hospital where he serves on the board. Mr. Gutfreund, who has headed Salomon Brothers for the past six years, is a man who likes to be in the thick of things, a ''hands-on'' operator, in business-school parlance. And colleagues and acquaintances on Wall Street said that John Gutfreund again did what he had to do last week when he wrested control of his company from the man who bought it only three years ago. **********''Sometimes, people reach the comfort level when they make enough money, while some have to win the ball game,'' said a former Salomon partner who asked for anonymity. Now, he added, Mr. Gutfreund ''has gotten to be a real hardball player.'' **********On Wall Street, his latest move was viewed as an amazing executive suite coup. Three summers ago, the cigar-smoking Mr. Gutfreund - pronounced GOOD-friend - had orchestrated the sale of Salomon Brothers, then the nation's largest privately held investment bank, to the Phibro Corporation, one of the world's largest commodities traders. **********But last Monday, the man who headed Phibro when it bought Salomon Brothers - David Tendler - was demoted and Mr. Gutfreund was installed as the chief executive officer of the huge and unusual financial empire.  ''John understands risk, reward and timing,'' said another former Salomon partner. ''He waited for the right time in order to make his move at Phibro, and was able to do it without breaking a lot of glass.'' **********The move puts Mr. Gutfreund, who is 54 years old, at the helm of a two- pronged company with $42 billion in assets, $30 billion in revenue, $617 million in annual profits, 6,700 employees and 25,000 shareholders. It has the capability of trading virtually anything, from wheat to mortgage- backed securities. **********But the tasks facing Mr. Gutfreund are formidable. Three years after the merger of Phibro and Salomon, the two halves are yet to jell. Instead, tension has grown between employees of Phibro-Salomon's two divisions. Philipp Brothers, as the company's big commodities operation is known, has continually turned in disappointing profits even as it generates huge revenues. Salomon, a smaller operation, is one of Wall Street's most profitable investment banks. **********The new Phibro-Salomon chief was reluctant last week to discuss detailed plans for blending Philipp and Salomon, but he has mentioned to others a vision of offering financial services on a worldwide basis. He said days after his appointment that he was interested in expanding the market for securities backed by real estate mortgages around the world. Phibro, he added, might also purchase a mortgage insurance company, which could be a help when Salomon packages mortgages for sale. **********Mr. Gutfreund recognizes the challenges of his new job. He must turn around Philipp Brothers, a business about which he admits he knows little. He must also seek peace with Mr. Tendler, 46, who has been a driving force behind Philipp Brothers. Mr. Gutfreund plans to spend 50 percent of his time on parent-company affairs, and expects to set up an office at headquarters in midtown Manhattan in addition to his Wall Street office. He does not promise quick results. ''I'm a very slow person,'' he said. ''I'm not a rocket scientist.'' **********Just how Mr. Gutfreund managed to work his way to the top and topple Mr. Tendler is not entirely clear because of the secrecy that surrounds Phibro-Salomon. Phibro, because of its sensitive trading relationships, has always avoided the limelight, and Salomon, since it was privately held, never felt compelled to say much. Directors who would talk insisted on anonymity, and even Wall Street analysts who follow the company frequently asked not to be quoted by name for fear of losing access to company executives and directors. **********One thing is clear, however: Mr. Gutfreund is seeking total control of the company. ''Mr. Tendler's real job will be to run Philipp Brothers. Period,'' Mr. Gutfreund said in an interview last week. **********The story of Mr. Gutfreund's ascension opened, oddly enough, with an offer by Mr. Tendler. In the spring of 1981, Mr. Tendler and his top aides at Phibro quietly approached Mr. Gutfreund and Salomon's executive committee about the possibility of Phibro acquiring Salomon. Phibro, which traded commodities that included grain, cement and oil, saw an opportunity to move into the trading of financial instruments. **********Salomon, for its part, was also taken with the possibilities. It saw an opportunity to drum up corporate and governmental clients overseas by using Phibro's contacts, to secure additional capital and to free up the money of its 62 partners - some $304 million that they could not withdraw from the firm because it was needed to finance day-to-day operations. **********That August, the stock and cash sale of Salomon to Phibro for $554 million was announced. When the deal was completed in October, the parent company's name became Phibro-Salomon, and Mr. Tendler and Mr. Gutfreund became co-chairmen, with Mr. Tendler remaining as the sole chief executive officer. Mr. Gutfreund's primary duty was to run Salomon Brothers. **********THE two branches ran, for the **********most part, independently. But **********their earnings immediately headed in opposite directions. Commodity prices had fallen - even oil lost its luster - and Philipp suffered accordingly, particularly in the long periods when prices would remain flat, the worst of all worlds for traders. Salomon, meanwhile, was establishing itself as one of Wall Street's innovative forces, developing new products that pushed its profits in 1982 and 1983 to record heights. **********With Salomon's star rising, Mr. Gutfreund began to assert himself more at directors' meetings, questioning whether better controls were needed at Philipp Brothers, according to a source close to the board. The board, with members from both Philipp and Salomon, as well as outsiders, apparently agreed. Last September, it promoted Mr. Gutfreund to co- chief executive officer with Mr. Tendler. Both men said the promotion was only a reflection of how the company was being run. **********But the problems worsened. If tensions did not develop between the two men - they have repeatedly denied all such reports - tensions apparently did develop between the two divisions. Salomon Brothers partners were wondering whether they sold out for too little, given the surge in brokerage firm prices during the 1982 stock market rally and Salomon's terrific results. Meanwhile, Philipp Brothers profits remained depressed, putting a drag on the price of Phibro- Salomon stock, a lot of which was owned by Salomon partners. ''We're contributing more than they are'' to the company's profits, ''so the tensions developed,'' said one Salomon managing director. **********The severity of the resentment became evident in late May. Phibro- Salomon issued a terse statement saying it was considering the sale of the Philipp Brothers commodity trading business, except oil, to a group of executives and employees. Mr. Tendler, an intense, soft-spoken man with a cherubic face and quick mind, was to head the group. **********Ten days later, the deal collapsed. Analysts said the two sides could not agree on a price and how to divide tax credits between the two groups. In addition, splitting off the oil trading business, securing financing and obtaining the necessary trading licenses for the new company were more complicated than apparently anticipated, In addition, after the announcement that the deal was being considered, Phibro-Salomon's stock price suddenly dipped, signaling the market's displeasure with the proposal. **********On Wall Street, the whole episode was viewed with disdain. The long secretive Phibro-Salomon had publicly announced the proposal because word had leaked out, and then withdrew the plan when it looked unfeasible. The immediate speculation was that Mr. Tendler would resign. Some board members, according to a source close to the company, were, in fact, upset that Mr. Tendler's proposal had leaked prematurely. **********They were also upset, the source said, that contrary to Mr. Tendler's predictions, Philipp's profits remained depressed. ''The board was quite concerned about where his interests lay,'' the source said in reference to Mr. Tendler. ''The board was concerned that Tendler didn't spend enough time on Philipp Brothers'' and its day-to-day operations, working instead on the proposed spinoff. **********For his part, Mr. Tendler said last week that he, too, was unhappy about the proposal having leaked out. But he dismissed suggestions that he had spent a lot of time on it. ''It happened quick and failed fast,'' he said in an interview. **********Nonetheless, insiders said, the board was also unhappy for another reason: They saw paralysis at the top of the company. ''Having a pair'' of chief executives ''was acknowledging that there were two divisions,'' Mr. Gutfreund said. ''And if you're talking about one company, one company should probably be run by one person with a very strong group of people'' as subordinates, he added. **********According to another insider close to the board, it considered hiring a third person to head the parent company but feared only exacerbating the problem. ''You don't want to introduce an unknown into a situation,'' this insider said. **********So, last Monday, the Phibro-Salomon board did the only thing it could do, given that the company was sorely in need of repair and that it could not afford to offend Mr. Gutfreund, whose division was so vital to Phibro-Salomon's well-being. Mr. Gutfreund was named the holding company's sole chief executive and Mr. Tendler was pushed aside, given the title of chairman of Phibro-Salomon's executive committee. Mr. Tendler said the executive committee would have new importance, but a company statement said he would ''concentrate his efforts'' on commodities trading, his specialty. **********For Mr. Gutfreund, his first task is to find a way to lessen the tension dividing Salomon and Philipp. ''We want to do everything we can to eliminate those feelings,'' said one Phibro director with Salomon ties. But he added: ''Those feelings down in the ranks die very slowly.'' **********If he can lessen the tensions, the most basic and important job facing Mr. Gutfreund is finding synergy - that is, blending Phibro-Salomon's two independent businesses so that the whole is worth more than the parts. That, of course, was the original goal of the merger. **********So far, according to Mr. Gutfreund, the synergy between the two has been ''modest.'' The companies are physically separated - Salomon is at the tip of Manhattan, Philipp is in midtown - and there are only occasional meetings. Salomon's head equity trader sometimes confers with Philipp's head oil trader to get a feeling for where oil prices and therefore oil stocks may go, Mr. Gutfreund said. Or, he said, Salomon's metals analyst will talk to Philipp's copper traders about the markets. **********But basically the synergy has, to date, only been financial. At the time of the merger, Philipp had plenty of capital, as well as superb access to credit. Since its business was slow, Salomon was able to use some of the money to expand. Phibro not only replaced the $304 million in capital withdrawn by the Salomon partners, it lent another $100 million to Salomon and gave it access to additional credit. ''We would not be in our present position without having had that enormous injection of capital,'' Mr. Gutfreund said. **********Currently, Salomon Brothers, which contributes only 8 percent of the company's total revenues, is contributing 65 percent of the company's earnings and has become one of investment banking's indisputable stars, with its profits steadily growing as other firms suffer with the industry's violent ups and downs. Its basic businesses are marketing new issues of securities for corporations and governments, and trading already issued securities. **********The key to Salomon's success has been its flair for innovation and recognizing changes in the marketplace. While competitors have continued to rely on old-school ties, Salomon has leaped ahead by designing new securities and perfecting its ability to distribute large blocks of stocks and bonds rapidly. Its innovative products have included securities backed by home mortgages - it dominates this rapidly growing market - and Certificates of Accrual on Treasury Securities, which are called CATS and are, in effect, zero-coupon United States Government bonds. **********Salomon is also well known for its willingness to commit large sums of capital to facilitate the trading of already issued securities. It deals strictly with institutions - mutual funds, pension funds, money managers, banks and insurance companies - and these client ties help it to sell new, as well as already issued securities. Last year, Salomon traded more than $2 trillion in securities in the secondary market. **********Philipp Brothers, for its part, trades about 160 commodities, including petroleum, metals, cocoa, sugar and grain. A unit, Phibro Energy, is considered the world's largest non- producing petroleum trader. Philipp Brothers was originally part of the Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation, but grew so rapidly when commodity prices surged in the 1970's that it was spun off in May 1981 as a separate company. With great secrecy, it will move in and out of various goods within minutes and can trade across country borders. **********But flat commodity prices and falling oil prices have pinched Philipp Brothers since the late 1970's. For the second quarter, oil pretax profits apparently fell to nothing, from $25 million in the first quarter, according to J. Clarence Morrison, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. who is close to the company. Total Philipp Brothers profits dipped to $35 million, from $51.5 million in the first quarter. By contrast, Salomon Brothers profits climbed to $68.7 million, from $68.5 million in the first quarter. **********The man who inherits this complex operation has spent his whole adult life at Salomon. He was raised in the affluent New York suburb of Scarsdale, and his father owned wholesale meat and trucking businesses, while his mother was a housewife. He earned an English degree from Oberlin College in 1951, and briefly thought about teaching literature. But the Army drafted him just after graduation and he ended up volunteering for the Korean War. **********Upon his release in 1953, Mr. Gutfreund had lunch one day with William R. (Billy) Salomon, a family acquaintance and son of one of the firm's founders, who ultimately became the managing partner. The young Mr. Gutfreund wound up as a $45-a-week trainee on Salomon's municipal bond desk. ''You had to be able to add and subtract and just get it done,'' he said. ''In the current world, I would not be high on the roster for hire.'' **********DESPITE this modesty, it was during his nine years on this desk that he earned his reputation as a consummate trader, always ready to make a bid or offer. Like a true trader, one acquaintance said, Mr. Gutfreund always orders the first special recited by a waiter in a restaurant without waiting to hear the others. **********Mr. Gutfreund's trading instincts have become so strong, said one Salomon colleague, that he relies little on the personal relationships that other investment bankers cling to. ''He makes decisions very analytically, with little emotion,'' this colleague said. ''I have seen people who are social friends of his given no weight when it comes to business decisions.'' **********But those business skills have served him well. In 1963, at the age of 34, he became the firm's youngest non-family partner. Fifteen years later, he succeeded Billy Salomon as managing partner. Last year, he took home $2.1 million. **********Colleagues say his climb entailed plenty of competition. When William E. Simon, who has also done fine for himself financially, left Salomon in 1972 to become Deputy Treasury Secretary, ''in many peoples' minds, it was because he knew he wasn't going to beat out Gutfreund to be Billy Salomon's successor,'' said one Wall Street executive. **********Nonetheless, some acquaintances say Mr. Gutfreund is more refined than others on Wall Street who made their way up the trading ladder. **********''There's some civilizing, refining capacity here that is not present with some of these other people,'' said one Wall Street executive of Mr. Gutfreund. ''He's extremely tough and extremely competitive in getting clients. But he's held that organization together. He may not be as au courant with corporate establishment as Johnny Whitehead or Felix, but he's certainly beginning to move in those circles, and that shows a capacity for growth.'' John C. Whitehead is a co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company. Felix G. Rohatyn is a senior partner at Lazard Fr eres & Company. **********One of the reasons frequently cited for Mr. Gutfreund's mixing in better circles these days is his second wife, Susan, whom he married in 1981. They live in an opulent cooperative building on Manhattan's East Side, and friends say she has pushed him into the New York social scene. A gossip column in Women's Wear Daily refers to her as ''Social Susie'' and him as ''Solemn John.'' A recent parody in Vanity Fair said that at their home ''everything is vintage, even the Lavoris.'' **********With regard to the social scene, Mr. Gutfreund said: ''I find it relatively boring after a while, but there are some interesting achievers. They're not just the idle rich.'' **********MR. GUTFREUND, the father of three sons, ages 21 to 25, arrives by chauffeur at his Wall Street office at 7:10 A.M. and stays until about 6 P.M. He plays tennis but not golf - it takes too much time, he says - and likes brief, three- or-four-day vacations in Europe looking for antiques and visiting museums with his wife. He reads mysteries while flying and ''detests'' self- improvement books, finding them ''irritating.'' He serves on the boards of the New York Public Library and the Montefiore Medical Center.  Some friends think Mr. Gutfreund and others at Salomon might be interested in taking a post in a Mondale Administration if the Democrats were to be elected in the fall. But he expresses little interest. **********''I'm not very introspective in terms of what I'm doing,'' he said. ''I just want to keep things moving. I've given a lot of my life to the business.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/17/busin.body_text: **********A financial rescue plan for the troubled Seabrook, N.H., nuclear plant will be based on a guarantee of much of the project's debt by the New Hampshire Electric Cooperative, officials said yesterday. **********Backers of the plan met in Washington yesterday with representatives of the Rural Electrification Administration in an attempt to agree on such a proposal, several sources said. **********A top official of the R.E.A., which currently backs the cooperative's Seabrook debt, said at midday that the agency was ''not about to be the guarantor'' for the debt of Public Service of New Hampshire, the nearly bankrupt utility that is the principal owner of the project. **********But last night Robert Hildreth, the Merrill Lynch Capital Markets executive who has proposed the rescue plan, said that ''things had changed'' and that ''there has been no decision one way or the other.'' **********Mr. Hildreth confirmed that the New Hampshire cooperative was the previously unnamed sponsor of the plan announced on Monday. And he said the R.E.A. was not being asked to guarantee the Public Service debt, only to support the desire of the New Hampshire cooperative to do so. **********The R.E.A., a Federal agency, backs the debts of electric cooperatives. It has backed 2.6 percent of the Seabrook obligations through cooperatives in New Hampshire and Vermont. **********'A Little Presumptuous' **********The R.E.A.'s deputy administrator, Jack Van Mark, said yesterday, ''It is a little presumptuous to assume that the owner of 2.6 percent will guarantee billions of dollars in debt.'' When work was halted on Unit 1 at the Seabrook site last month, Public Service of New Hampshire estimated that construction costs, if the plant is completed, would total $6.9 billion. **********Also at yesterday's meeting was Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire, who Mr. Hildreth said was interested in supporting the rescue plan as long as any extra power bought by the sponsor remained in that state. Mr. Hildreth said the R.E.A. was considering the proposal. **********Yesterday's meeting was the latest development in the tangled negotiations that have followed the announcement April 3 by the Public Service Company that it was facing bankruptcy. **********One of the first casualties after the announcement was the ability of Public Service's 15 partners in the Seabrook project to borrow money. No one wanted to finance any investment in Seabrook at a time when the collapse of a single utility could preclude completion of the reactors. **********That is the problem addressed by the newest rescue plan.  The idea is to raise in advance nearly all of the money needed to complete Unit 1, and thus eliminate uncertainty about whether each partner can finance its share. **********But the plan is also intended to assure completion of Unit 1, which is 75 percent complete, even if Public Service is forced into insolvency by the mushrooming costs. It does not address the future of Unit 2, on which work was halted last year after $800 million had been spent to bring it to 23 percent completion. The reactors were made by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. **********New Management Structure **********The arrangement, which would be coupled with a new management structure for the project, will probably require the approval of the public service commissions of six New England states, the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission and other state and Federal agencies.  If it is to work, it will also require inducing investors to risk up to $1 billion, money that the 16 partners are unable or unwilling to raise on their own. **********The financing could not be completed before late summer, although work on Unit 1, which was halted on April 17, could resume sooner on a limited basis. Keeping the construction hiatus short is important because fixed charges on the plant run about $2 million a week, even after the layoff of nearly 6,200 workers. **********While the outcome is far from certain, the plan is probably the only hope for Unit 1. For the partners, who approved the plan unanimously at a meeting in Cambridge, Mass., the plan represents probably the only way they can recover the $2.7 billion already spent on the reactor, which William B. Ellis, chairman of Northeast Utilities, one of the partners, referred to as ''a very valuable, very fragile asset.'' **********''While it doesn't solve all our problems,'' said Nicholas Ashooh, a spokesman for Public Service, ''it does open a door for us to pursue an overall solution to our financial problems.'' **********Plan Called Unprecedented **********The participants believe that the plan is unprecedented. ''We didn't take this out of any business book that I ever read,'' Mr. Hildreth said in a telephone interview from Boston. **********The plan appears to be entirely Merrill Lynch's creation. Mr. Hildreth described his firm as ''the leading investment banker in the electric utility industry,'' but it had not been involved in Seabrook before the project's recent troubles. **********Merrill Lynch would earn a profit by floating the new bonds called for in the plan, according to Mr. Hildreth.  Here is how the rescue is supposed to work: **********First, Public Service, which has been on an unfruitful search for credit since the beinning of April, is to borrow $75 million to $90 million in short- term financing. The hope is that finding credit will be easier now that a plan for the completion of the reactor has been approved. **********Then Public Service would sell $200 million to $300 million in long-term debt. **********Next, a new financing entity, Newbrook, would be set up. Newbrook would float bonds, backed by the project, and use some of the proceeds to buy zero-coupon bonds backed by Treasury securities. These bonds would be held in escrow, to guarantee that when the new Public Service bonds came due, money would be available to pay back the principal. **********Newbrook would also borrow enough money to cover two years of interest payments on the new Public Service bonds. **********In addition, the sponsor would guarantee an additional three semiannual payments, which would carry the project to the end of 1988. ''By that time,'' Mr. Hildreth said, ''we figure the plant will be in operation, and in the rate base, and they'll be a financially healthy utility.'' **********How Sponsor Benefits **********If Public Service were unable to meet the interest payments and had to resort to the guarantee of the sponsor, that sponsor would be entitled to one kilowatt of power for each $1,500 it put up. That represents a bargain when measured against the cost of recently completed reactors. At Seabrook's Unit 1, the owners have already spent more than $2,300 per kilowatt of capacity and now project a final price of about $3,500 a kilowatt.  If the sponsor had to step in, according to Mr. Hildreth, and wound up owning a substantial amount of electricity, ''there's no question in anybody's mind he could get rid of it at a profit.'' If Public Service met the payments, the sponsor would pay nothing and receive nothing. **********A major hurdle may be gaining the participation of investors, who now count Public Service and three other utilities around the country as being near bankruptcy and who may wonder if any amount raised in advance will turn out to be adequate to meet costs that rise with dismaying vigor. **********A Return of 20% Is Seen **********Mr. Hildreth said he believed that the wariness over the risk would be offset by the higher interest rate and predicted a return of about 20 percent. The Newbrook issues, he acknowleged, would be junk bonds, which are sold cheaply and thus yield investors more interest. **********As for completing the plant within the budget used by Newbrook, nearly everyone connected with Seabrook is counting on the new project manager, William Derrickson, who was hired by Public Service from Florida Power and Light after he supervised the completion of St. Lucie 2, an 800- megawatt reactor, in just over six years, an extraordinarily short time for an industry plagued by cost overruns and facing increasingly strict standards. **********Public Service, which was the initiator of the Seabrook project and had retained control even after reducing its ownership to one-third, has relinquished its managerial role. The partners are planning a new entity, led by Mr. Derrickson, to finish the reactor and operate it. That step would require approval of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, because Public Service is the current license holder. **********Also, Mr. Hildreth said, because Unit 1 is so far along, ''you're not starting from zero, where you have a great deal of time and problems involved.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/14/world.body_text: **********A wave of desertions by soldiers in Kabul, the Afghan capital, has followed a Government decision to extend the tours of duty of soldiers in the capital from three to four years, Western diplomats said here today. **********Quoting reports from their embassies in Kabul, they said many soldiers on guard duty near Kabul airport and the main army bases in southwestern Kabul had fled after hearing the news on radio and television last Thursday. **********The Government, which has taken stringent measures in recent months to shore up its dwindling army, announced the duty tour extension along with a series of other measures to fill the barracks. **********Western diplomats say deaths and desertions have reduced the army to half the 80,000-man level it had before guerrilla action began after the Communist coup in April 1978.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/17/busin.main_headline:
ASSESSING THE SYNFUELS PROGRAM;
A CALL FOR LARGE COMMERCIAL PROJECTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/17/busin.print_headline:
ASSESSING THE SYNFUELS PROGRAM;
A CALL FOR LARGE COMMERCIAL PROJECTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/17/busin.body_text: **********WHEN synfuels legislation was enacted in 1980, Congress authorized $20 billion (with the potential for another $68 billion) for a crash national program to produce substantial amounts of synthetic oil and gas. Production goals of 500,000 barrels a day of oil equivalent by 1987 and 2.2 million barrels a day by 1992 (more than 25 percent of our current production) were written into the law. **********These goals were unrealistic then and are now clearly impossible. With the slack oil market making the large-scale commercial production of synthetic fuels increasingly uneconomical and unnecessary, some people are now calling for an end to the synfuels program. Others suggest it be scaled back to a research program within the Department of Energy. **********I disagree. The United States needs, and can afford, a commercially oriented synthetic fuels program. The capability to move quickly into large-scale synthetic fuel production will be extremely valuable when oil prices increase in the future, and Government-sponsored demonstration plans are critical to the development of such capability. Moreover, the program can be structured to minimize the impact on the economy.  Despite the sense of well-being provided by the slack energy market, our economic and national security is likely to be threatened again by oil disruptions and price shocks. Free-world oil consumption will rise in 1984 for the first time in four years, and OPEC production will climb this year by about one million barrels a day. As OPEC's surplus production capacity is used, the question is not whether prices will increase, but when. **********Synthetic fuels can mitigate this threat. The certainty that an alternative technology would begin to erode its market share at a given price level would restrain OPEC's future pricing actions. Unlike the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which is a highly valuable emergency response mechanism, synfuels could be a long-term solution to the problem of diminishing low-cost oil reserves. **********Whether synfuels are a viable solution depends on their costs. In my early days at the Federal Energy Administration, a number of studies concluded oil shale would begin to develop when the price of oil rose from about $4 a barrel to around $6 to $9. Later, as Deputy Secretary of Energy in the late 1970's, I heard the same arguments - but oil had risen to $32 and the price required to bring on synfuels was $36 to $40. This gave way to the mistaken view that an inexorable link between oil prices and the cost of building a synfuels plant would always leave synfuels uneconomical. **********The real reason that synthetic fuels' costs remain too high is that industry has little experience with these plants on a commercial scale. Until a demonstration plant has been built, operated reliably and safely, and produced usable products, the private sector will not consider it ''on the shelf.'' As a Rand Corporation study showed, first-of-a-kind plants take longer and cost more to build than expected. So industry will need an assist from Government - help that is justified because of the ceiling this technology provides on future OPEC oil price increases. **********PERHAPS the original legislation was misguided in assuming that a huge infusion of funds could rapidly create a large- scale synfuels industry. McKinsey & Company's work on new technologies shows that their development is not predictable and often accelerates after an early phase of relatively slow progress. The mistake companies often make is comparing the current cost and performance of a new technology with existing ones and assuming that both will develop at the same rate. **********Building a few plants that use second- and third-generation synfuels technologies could provide the construction and operational experience necessary to evaluate likely future improvements in these technologies. But estimates of gains such as reduced lead times and lower unit costs can come only from demonstration projects; a research program by itself will not be nearly as effective. **********Government involvement in the commercialization of synfuels is thus desirable. With some changes in the Synthetic Fuels Corporation (S.F.C.) policies, it can also be affordable. Assistance should be targeted to projects using truly breakthrough technologies - not carbon copies of existing plants. Further, these plants should use plentiful coal or oil shale; too much has been spent on relatively scarce resources such as peat and tar sands. **********To further limit the budget impact, incentives should be restructured to eliminate loan guarantees (thus requiring the discipline of private-sector financing) and to limit price guarantees to a 5- to 10-year period while capping the payments a project may receive. Congress should retain the ''semi-independence'' of a slimmed- down S.F.C to avoid ''politicizing'' the program. Following these guidelines, a budget authorization close to the Administration's suggested $7 billion should be adequate. **********With such changes, the current program would be more efficient and better suited for the realities of today's environment, and it would provide some relatively low-cost insurance against erratic and inevitable oil price increases. **********John C. Sawhill, who served as the first chairman of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, now heads McKinsey & Company's worldwide energy practice.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/13/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Finding the Right Buyer For Binney & Smith
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/13/busin.body_text: **********A skilled marketer, Jack F. Kofoed has chalked up a big sale, totaling $203.5 million to be exact. **********As chairman and chief executive officer of Binney & Smith Inc., which makes about 1.8 billion Crayola crayons a year, he has negotiated the company's sale to Hallmark Cards. **********Binney & Smith, based in Easton, Pa., had been looking for an amiable merger partner for several years. **********''About three months ago, Newell Companies purchased some of our stock; that was the catalyst for us,'' Mr. Kofoed commented yesterday. ''It made us stop and think.'' Newell makes hardware and do-it-yourself tools. **********Thoughts turned to Hallmark, or actually returned, Mr. Kofoed said. ''We had a previous meeting with Hallmark executives five or six years ago when they visited us here.'' **********Binney & Smith is one of the biggest businesses in Easton, a small city about 50 miles north of Philadelphia. Mr. Kofoed said Hallmark had assured him that it contemplates no changes in management and it will keep the Easton plant open. **********A graduate of Middlebury College in 1948, Mr. Kofoed, 57, started his career with Young & Rubicam, the advertising agency, and then moved to the General Foods Corporation in product development. From there he went to the Diamond Crystal Salt Company, where he became a general manager of a division in 1963. **********''Then I raised some venture capital with some other people and bought Venus Pencil Corporation and became its president and chairman,'' he said. ''I left in 1968.'' **********Following that, he spent several years as a division manager of Knomark, a unit of the Papercraft Corporation. **********He put his marketing skills to work as executive vice president of Binney & Smith in 1975, president in 1978 and chairman in 1982. Beside crayons, the company markets items like Silly Putty, chalk, artists' supplies and educational materials.
