https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/18/busin.main_headline: CARGO LIABILITY RULING HELPS AIRLINE INDUSTRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/18/busin.print_headline: CARGO LIABILITY RULING HELPS AIRLINE INDUSTRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/18/busin.body_text: **********The Supreme Court, in a decision greeted with relief by the airline industry, ruled today that the limits on liability for commercial air cargo established by the major international aviation treaty will remain enforceable in American courts. **********The 8-to-1 decision overturned a ruling by the Federal appeals court in New York that the liability limit was no longer enforceable because there is no longer an official price for gold in the United States. **********While the case before the Supreme Court involved cargo, the decision was also expected to remove legal questions about the enforceability of existing limits on airlines' financial liability for passengers' lives. **********The Warsaw Convention, the treaty in question, defines an airline's liability for lost commercial cargo according to a formula based on gold, to be translated by each member nation into its national currency. During the years when the official price of gold in the United States was $35 an ounce, the formula translated into $7.50 for each pound of cargo. In the 1970's, with a $42.22-an-ounce official gold price, the limit was $9.07 a pound. **********In 1978 the United States abandoned an official price for gold. In the open market, gold is now about $380 an ounce, although it has gone as high as $800 in recent years.  The Government, however, has continued to use $42.22 an ounce to calculate liability under the Warsaw Convention, which was ratified by the United States in 1934. **********The limit was challenged in a 1979 lawsuit filed by the Franklin Mint Corporation after Trans World Airlines lost a shipment of 714 pounds of coins. Franklin Mint said compensation for the loss, which it placed at $250,000, should be based on the current market price of gold. But the Federal District Court in New York limited T.W.A.'s liability to $6,475, based on the last official price of gold. **********On appeal, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld the limit for that case. But it ruled that in future cases the Warsaw Convention's liability limit was ''prospectively unenforceable in United States courts.'' **********In a technical sense, today's decision by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor affirmed the appellate court's ruling because it upheld the limit on T.W.A.'s liability that the appellate court had applied. **********But the Supreme Court, with only Justice John Paul Stevens dissenting, rejected the appellate court's prospective ruling. Justice O'Connor said that Congress had never acted to repudiate the Warsaw Convention and that such a repudiation should be undertaken only by ''the political branches,'' not by judges. **********The Federal Government filed a brief, warning that the ''regime of completely unbounded liability'' indicated by the Court of Appeals threatened ''adverse repercussions in the international community.'' **********The airline was supported in its appeal (T.W.A. v. Franklin Mint, No. 82- 1186) by the International Air Transport Association, an organization of 123 international air carriers, as well as by the Air Transport Association, representing most domestic airlines. They argued that international commerce would be hampered by the appellate court's decision.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/27/busin.body_text: **********The Manville Corporation, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization in August 1982 because of the large number of asbestos health- related lawsuits against the company, yesterday reported a 37 percent drop in first-quarter earnings. **********It cited increased expenses associated with the reorganization and litigation. The Denver-based company also attributed the earnings decline to increased selling, general and administrative costs. **********Earnings in the quarter fell to $12.7 million, or 27 cents a share, from $20.3 million, or 59 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 2.6 percent, to nearly $423 million, from $412 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/15/busin.body_text: **********The ad sales staff of Fortune **********magazine has been traveling the **********major markets of late singing a song of creative media buying. That's the kind that doesn't need numbers to justify, numbers that deal with the economic efficiency of an advertising purchase. **********The staff's audience in nine different cities, at breakfasts, luncheons or cocktails, has been young impressionable agency buyers. Yesterday in the Hemisphere Club atop the Time- Life Building at a Continental breakfast the team replayed its pitch for some of the graybeards of the business just to let them know what was going on. The presentation, starring Bruce McNaughton, manager of agency relations, was both pleasant and meaningful, but the bagels weren't chewy. **********Then at lunchtime more of this town's constant advertising activity bubbled to the surface at the Four Seasons Restaurant, where Marshall Ackerman, vice chairman of Rodale Press, and publisher of Prevention magazine, presided at the premiere performance of his 15-minute promotion film, ''The Health Life Style in America: New Directions For The 1980's,'' and John Naisbitt, author of ''Megatrends,'' spoke. **********That's the way it is in the ad game, one excitement after another. **********And, incidently, the Fortune gathering was especially rewarding since word leaked out about the business publication's new ad campaign before its management wanted it to, and that gives the information a special sweetness. **********The campaign will be the first advertising from its new agency, Needham, Harper & Steers, and the first general advertising effort in the history of the magazine. It will be an overall promotion of the magazine, not just pushing it as something to subscribe to or advertise in. **********The advertising will promote the magazine's readership - ''the youngest, best paid audience of a business publication'' - and will christen the group ''The Business Class.'' And with it comes the new advertising theme line, ''Required Reading for the Business Class.'' **********In addition to running in the advertising trade press where it customarily runs, the advertising will also be in the sister publications of Time Inc.; the other news weeklies; lifestyle magazines covering such areas as tennis, golf and skiing, and in newspapers in four major markets. The addition of consumer media including some outdoor will mean a healthy, although undisclosed, jump in the ad budget. **********The audience of the magazine is what the presentation ''Media is Creative'' is all about. While Mr. McNaughton was quick to aacknowledge that Fortune's advertising cost per thousand rates were higher than the competition's and its reach is not all that great, the question to be answered, he said, is ''How does a magazine communicate?'' To be creative you must figure out just who it reaches based on its editorial format and content. **********''You have to bring more to your work than CPM's,'' he said, going on to imply that the difference between Rolex and Timex, a Mercedes and a Ford, and Paris and Philadelphia is the same difference that exists between Fortune and its competitors. **********The Prevention story is an interesting one since here is a 34-year-old national magazine that only started going after national advertising in late 1981, and only because the world was catching up with it. The magazine, which now has 2.75 million circulation, started out promoting good health through natural vitamins. And since there were few places to buy such vitamins, Prevention became the natural place to run direct marketing ads for such products. And, in fact, it carried as many as 100 pages an issue with as many as 32 pages from a single advertiser. Then when the American people decided that good health was not such a bad idea and health food shops started opening around the corner, Prevention began finding one of its revenue sources slowly drying up. At the same time, however, major food companies began to get health conscious and they are just the crowd that Mr. Marshall and his team are after. **********Prevention, which was revamped in January and got a new subtitle, ''America's Leading Health Magazine,'' will carry 980 pages of advertising during the year ending July 31, and about 200 of those pages will be national ads. That's healthy. But the $13.7 million in net advertising revenues is healthier still.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/22/world.main_headline: SALVADOR COLONEL TAKES OFFENSIVE AGAINST REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/22/world.print_headline: SALVADOR COLONEL TAKES OFFENSIVE AGAINST REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/22/world.body_text: **********For nine hours, 600 Salvadoran troops walked 10 miles over rugged terrain to arrive here the night of April 13. **********Small reconnaissance squads were sent ahead of the three-column formation, and the commander of the eastern region consulted often by radio with the battalion leader. **********As the young soldiers approached the town in northern San Miguel Province, one column went ahead to circle it. Shots were fired, and the commander later found that the troops were unable to surround the town fast enough to trap the guerrillas. **********''Yes, I was upset,'' said Lieut. Col. Domingo Monterrosa. ''But it's more important to give them confidence in doing these night operations than to get too upset when something goes wrong.'' **********Guerrillas Have Spread **********In December Colonel Monterrosa was named commander of the country's easternmost region, where guerrilla forces have spread from their stronghold in northern Morazan to the neighboring provinces of San Miquel and La Union. **********The 43-year-old colonel, who is taunted almost daily on rebel broadcasts as a ''fool'' and held up by American advisers as a model officer, has been given the task of pushing the rebels back and regaining control of the east. **********Colonel Monterrosa criticized both the rebels, saying that at least their station should ''have some seriousness,'' and the Americans, for their need always to have a model. That model changes monthly, he said, and causes problems in the officer corps. **********Of his military mission, he said: ''They talk about areas of persistence. Well, we are going to persist here too.''  Improvement Is Marked **********On a three-day trip through San Miquel Province, where the colonel is based, the army showed marked improvements in its operations. But it is unclear if the commander will be able to make progress fast or long enough to substantially change the four-year-old civil war. **********By keeping his men in the field, he has made it difficult for the guerrillas to receive supplies and to mass for any major offensives in San Miguel in the last five months. **********Morale is high, even among soldiers who say they were forced into service. **********''He doesn't push us out of the barracks, but he's with us,'' said one of the soldiers. Most of the men seem to like their soft-spoken commmander, who often grabs a soldier by the hand after he is greeted with a salute. **********But while his men are still building up confidence for night operations, the guerrillas, who have lived in the hills for years, know the terrain and melt into the wooded mountainsides when there are large numbers of Government troops present. For the most part, it is still the guerrillas who decide when and where to fight.   Rebels Have Advantages **********The army has the benefit of American-piloted C-130's flying overhead to report on insurgent positions. But intelligence from villagers is often more timely and important, and the insurgents have had at least a six-month advantage in establishing a relationship with the residents. **********The guerrillas also keep pace in numbers. When the army began recruiting several months ago and increased its forces in the east by 25 percent to 5,000, the guerrillas also began taking new members. Officials estimate that 3,000 insurgents operate in the east. Counterinsurgency experts say a government force needs a ratio of 10 to 1 for success against guerrillas. **********While Government troops are substantially better equipped than the insurgents, difficiencies exist that affect movement in the field. Helicopters break down, and the wounded are sometimes left for hours before they can be evacuated. Like the guerrillas who commandeer trucks to move men, the army also finds it necessary to depend on local vehicles. At the San Miquel base, which has 2,000 men, the commander has one helicopter and seven or eight trucks. **********Although Colonel Monterrosa's men were unable to circle San Luis de la Reina fast enough the night of April 13, the operation was not a complete failure, he said. They managed to keep the insurgents moving and to spend time in town trying to win the people's confidence. But while the army has been through here every eight days for the last several months, the guerrillas come in almost daily, according to the people who live in San Luis de la Reina.   Few Complaints About Rebels Soldiers talked with the villagers, and some flirted with the women, one racing to get a piece of paper to write down information on a young lady he had met. While the people seemed to be comfortable with the army's presence, most did not complain about the 25 to 30 guerrillas who come in to buy supplies and occasionally hold political meetings. **********''The muchachos come every day,'' said a 26-year-old man who was setting out his goods at the Saturday street market. ''The people here don't get involved with anyone.'' **********Even the man's use of ''muchachos,'' or ''boys,'' for the guerrillas indicated tolerence. In towns where they have no influence, the people refer to them as ''subversives'' or ''terrorists.'' **********Public relations for the army is not always easy. When Colonel Monterrosa walked into San Luis de la Reina, he found more than 20 large sacks of grains unloaded from pickup trucks, and he suspected that such a large shipment might be for the guerrillas.   Lined Up, Then Excused **********The men who drove the trucks were ordered out of their boarding house at 4 A.M. and were told to line up. National identity cards were checked, and questions were asked in a blunt manner. When the men said they wanted to sell the grain to the village, they were excused to go back to bed. But once the army leaves, some of the supplies are likely to end up in guerrilla hands. **********Colonel Monterrosa seems aware that the army badly needs to improve its reputation with the population. Most officials refer to the insurgents as ''subversives,'' but at a speech in Moncagua, seven miles northwest of San Miquel, the colonel referred to the guerrillas as ''errant brothers.'' **********He later said he wanted to show the people in Moncagua, some of whom may have relatives with the insurgents in the hills, that the army was willing to forgive and accept them back. **********At the same time, the colonel has set up 20 civil defense troops in Moncagua. ''They won't be able to protect the town, but they can pass on information,'' he said.   Public Relations Goals **********The army's operations in San Miquel often mix public relations with military objectives. The weekend of April 14, Colonel Monterrosa began an offensive along the southern coast of San Miquel to prevent the guerrillas from setting up roadblocks to collect war taxes from people going to the beach. **********The result, he hoped, would be to cut off funds for the guerrillas, show the people the army could protect them, and keep the guerrillas, who often dominate the region south of the Coastal Highway, on the move. **********The operation began with 400 soldiers moving toward El Cuco Beach. By the time the army arrived, most of the guerrillas had left. The troops settled in to stay through the Easter Week holiday, guarding the roads and keeping a presence in a place where the army had not been for more than a month. **********Three guerrillas were killed in battles along the way to El Cuco. One of the rebels left behind a love letter to his girlfriend saying that they were only separated ''because of the situation'' and that things would get better.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/12/world.main_headline: A FORMER SALVADORAN REBEL CHIEF TELLS OF ARMS FROM NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/12/world.print_headline: A FORMER SALVADORAN REBEL CHIEF TELLS OF ARMS FROM NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/12/world.body_text: **********A former Salvadoran guerrilla commander who was captured in Honduras said today that virtually all the arms received by the guerrilla units he led came from Nicaragua. **********The former guerrilla, Arquimedes Canadas, known in the rebel movement as Comandante Alejandro Montenegro, also bolstered the Reagan Administration's disputed assertions that Salvadoran guerrillas have their headquarters in Nicaragua by saying that he went there secretly in 1981 and met with his top commander, the Nicaraguan Army Chief of Staff and four Cuban advisers. **********Mr. Canadas said in an interview that in 1981 and 1982 guerrilla units under his command in San Salvador and north of the city received ''99.9 percent of our arms'' from Nicaragua. **********This contradicts what several guerrilla commanders, including Mr. Canadas, said in interviews at their mountain base near Guazapa volcano in February 1982. **********Armed with American-made M-16 rifles, the Salvadoran guerrilla commanders said their weapons were either captured from Government forces, bought on the black market or purchased directly from Salvadoran Government officers. Only one admitted having gone to Nicaragua and none said they had been to Cuba.  But today Mr. Montenegro said through an interpreter that he had been under orders from his guerrilla commander in chief to give false information in 1982 by saying that the arms were captured or purchased when in fact they had come from Managua by truck aross Honduras into El Salvador. **********In a three-hour interview Tuesday night, Mr. Canadas, who was captured in August 1982 by Honduran Army units in Tegucigalpa while he was en route to Nicaragua, said he had gone to Cuba once and to Managua twice to meet with Joaquin Villalobos, commander in chief of the People's Revolutionary Army. **********The P.R.A. is the largest of five guerrilla forces linked together under the Farabundo Marti Liberation Front. **********Accepted Government Amnesty **********Mr. Canadas, who has been under death sentence by Salvadoran guerrilla forces since accepting a Salvadoran Government amnesty, was under a round-the-clock security escort arranged by the State Department's office of public diplomacy and appeared today at a White House briefing on Central America for Reagan supporters. **********Refusing to say where he was now living for his own safety's sake, the 29- year-old Salvadoran gave a long account of his personal falling out with Mr. Villalobos over what he said he saw as the increasing Cuban domination of the Salvadoran guerrilla movement starting in mid-1980. **********Last year, Administration officials who had been embarrassed when a Nicaraguan publicly recanted statements given to the State Department and Central Intellience Agency, said they had checked out information provided by Mr. Canadas and were satisfied it was reliable. At present, his availability to news organizations, arranged indirectly by the State Department, is an apparent effort to buttress the Administration's charges that the Salvadoran guerrilla movements get aid and direction from Nicaragua. **********In the interview, Mr. Canadas said that in 1981 and 1982 urban commandos and 200 guerrillas under his command in Guazapa received monthly arms shipments from Nicaragua that were trucked across Honduras, hidden in false panels and floors. He said the trucks moved through the normal customs checkpoint of Las Manos at the Nicaraguan border with Honduras and the checkpoint of Amantillo at the Honduran border with El Salvador. **********Each truck, he said, carried roughly 25 to 30 rifles and about 7,000 cartridges of ammunition. The rifles, he said, were American-made M-16's captured in Vietnam and FAL rifles formerly used by the Nicaraguan Army under Somoza. **********Sometimes the trucks arrived without rifles and carried just ammunition and in that case, he said, a typical load would include up to 15,000 cartridges, Soviet-made grenades, and explosives like TNT for sabotage attacks against Government installations. **********Since the time of his capture, American officials have said that Honduran authorities put on major efforts to halt the relatively open flow of arms traffic on Honduran highways. American military officials have now contended that the outside arms flow comes from Nicaragua on nighttime air drops or in canoes or power boats operating in the Pacific coastal waters between Nicaragua and El Salvador. **********Mr. Canadas said his one visit to the Salvadoran guerrilla command post in Nicaragua came in October 1981, when he was summoned by Mr. Villalobos, regarded by Salvadoran Army officers as the shrewdest and most important guerrilla commander.   'Taken There Blindfolded' **********''I don't know exactly where it was because I was taken there blindfolded,'' he said. ''We went perhaps 15 minutes on the highway south of Managua where we changed vehicles. Then we went another 10 or 15 minutes. We came to a very large private home with a very large garden with metal benches.'' **********''To the right of the main entrances was an office where Villalobos worked,'' he went on. ''Further in the house was a large room where the commanders of the other guerrilla groups met and where the Cubans and Sandinistas came. There were four Cubans there.'' **********He added: ''We had one meeting about two hours long one night with the Sandinista Army Chief of Staff Joaquin Cuadra.'' **********''Cuadra spoke almost entirely about the Nicaraguan situation. And they were interested to know what kind of rebellion was taking place in El Salvador, a peasant rebellion or all elements of the population. In Nicaragua, they said, it had been all elements. But the meeting was not to discuss aid. By that time, aid had reached its peak.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/26/world.main_headline: Mrs. Gandhi Calls For Punjab Unity
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/26/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Mrs. Gandhi Calls For Punjab Unity
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/26/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Indira Gandhi appealed in the Indian Parliament today for reconciliation between Hindus and Sikhs in Punjab and declared that army troops would not be withdrawn from the area until both groups felt safe from Sikh terrorist threats. **********''The army should come out as soon as possible, but we must also create the conditions that people feel safe - not only the Hindus but also the Sikhs,'' she said. **********Describing sectarian feelings as ''the greatest threat'' to India's unity, Mrs. Gandhi urged all political parties to help heal the hurts of the Sikhs. Many Sikhs have been alienated since the army raided the stronghold of armed militants at the Golden Temple in Amritsar last month and killed at least 600 people. Unconfirmed reports have put the toll was as high as 1,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/28/busin.body_text: **********Administration officials said today that the United States may sell satellite monitoring equipment to Rumania if a Commerce Department proposal is approved by President Reagan. **********The proposal, supported by Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, has reportedly met stiff opposition from Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, who maintains that the equipment could be converted for military use. **********The equipment would be the most sophisticated satellite machinery ever sold by the United States to an Eastern European country, the officials said. It includes a ground station as well as computer technology to analyze information from the American system known as Landsat, which surveys land for agricultural and scientific purposes. The system is already used by the United States and 10 other countries. China is expected to have access to it by 1986. **********One of Two Cameras **********According to officials at the Commerce Department, the Rumanians have been requesting the facilities for several years. The equipment under consideration, one official said, could analyze data from a camera on the satellite that is capable of detecting objects about 300 feet wide. **********The Rumanians would not be able to use the satellite's more advanced camera, which can distinguish objects as small as 100 feet across. Both systems are expected to be in the package sold to China. **********An engineer at the Commerce Department, Douglas Ballard, said that Landsat equipment similar to the Rumanian request is designed to be ''just outside of what the military considers useful.'' But the system's computers ''could be converted for military use, if they're smart enough and want to do it,'' he said. **********The Rumanian sale would not be affected by legislation, now before Congress, to sell the five satellites operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The bill, which could reach the House and Senate floors by the end of this week, provides for the sale of the Landsat system by the Secretary of Commerce. **********If enacted, the bill would enable the Secretary to receive bids for private marketing of data gathered by the satellites over a six-year transition period. **********Weak Market **********The sale was first recommended by President Reagan in 1981 as another effort to transfer ownership of such projects from the Government to the private sector and save money. But because of the weak market for such an expensive satellite system, the legislation will provide a Federal subsidy of between $10 million and $75 million to help private industry develop future satellites during the period of change of ownership. **********The Government has owned the system since 1972. Its annual operating cost is projected to be $30 million this year, with an amortizing cost of about $150 million a year expected during the transition period. Under the proposal, the Government would become a customer of the company that wins the bid to take over ownership. The company would not be able to limit access to the data, but the Government would be able to impose curbs on access by foreign countries. **********In March, the last satellite of the system, Landsat 5, was launched. It is expected to operate until 1987.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/23/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  Microrim's President Cites Management Skills
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/23/busin.body_text: **********Kent C. Johnson, 40, has been named president of Microrim Inc., the company that in April brought to market Clout, the first artificial intelligence product for microcomputers. **********He was Microrim's seventh employee when he joined the Bellevue, Wash., company in 1982 as executive vice president and chief operating officer. His task was to bring management skills to Microrim, which had been formed a year earlier by Wayne Erickson, a ''technical guru'' who remains chairman and chief executive. **********''My main strength is that I am a businessman,'' said Mr. Johnson, who is a certified public accountant. ''I have built a company that now employs 85 people, has depth of management, a product direction and I've raised financing.'' The Mitsubishi Corporation owns 5 percent of Microrim, representing the Japanese company's first stake in the American computer software business. **********Clout allows computers to learn English, rather than forcing humans to learn computer jargon. ''It's called artificial intelligence because the computer learns interactively as you work with it,'' says Mr. Johnson. If the computer user tries the word ''gimme,'' the computer would ask for a synonym to learn the meaning and then store ''gimme'' in its memory for future use. **********As a youth, Mr. Johnson was a logger, like his father. But, he recalls, ''after almost getting killed twice, I decided there must be a better way of making a living.'' **********He was graduated from the University of Washington in 1967 and received a master's degree in accounting and finance from Seattle University in 1971. He joined Arthur Andersen & Company as an auditor and manager in the consulting division and later was vice president of finance and chief financial officer at Fiberchem Inc. **********He said that he and Mr. Erickson ''brought to Microrim a small-town ethic which we feel is important.'' He relaxes at a lakeside cabin in the Cascade Mountains where he hopes to teach his sons, now 2 and 7, ''some of the same principles and philosophies, just the way I was reared.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/29/busin.body_text: **********Rising exports and a sharp drop in imports of oil and manufactured goods narrowed the nation's trade deficit in May to $8.84 billion from a record $12.2 billion in April, the Commerce Department reported today. **********Despite the improvement, Government officials and private economists said they did not expect further declines in the deficit anytime soon. **********''I expect higher trade deficits in coming months before we see further improvement,'' said Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige. Mr. Baldrige said he still expects a $130 billion deficit for all of 1984, nearly double last year's record $69.4 billion. **********Five-Month Deficit **********The May figures brought the trade deficit for the first five months of the year to $50.85 billion, a pace that would produce an imbalance of about $122 billion for the full year. **********The deficit has been worsened by the high value of the dollar and by the faster rate of economic recovery in the United States relative to other nations, analysts say. **********A strong dollar makes American goods expensive for foreigners to buy, and makes foreign goods cheaper and more attractive in the United States. **********Some improvement in the deficit is expected by the end of the year, as foreign economies get stronger and offer better markets for American exports. Nonetheless, Government officials have refused to predict a lower deficit next year.   'More Bad News Later On' **********According to David Ernst, an economist with Evans Econometrics in Washington, the gap could widen if interest rates climb and cause the dollar's value to remain strong. ''With both the dollar and the economy so strong, I would expect more bad news later on,'' he said. **********The Commerce Department report said that May imports fell 9.8 percent from April's level, to $26.8 billion. The decline reflected a sharp drop in oil imports, to 4.9 million barrels a day from 6.2 million in April. **********Imports of manufactured goods, including steel plates and sheets, clothing, non-Japanese autos, footwear and organic chemicals, also fell $1.4 billion in the month. **********Exports rose 2.4 percent, to $17.95 billion, led by gains in oil products, power generating machinery, auto and tractor parts, wheat and fertilizers, the department said. **********All figures were adjusted to discount for normal seasonal variations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/15/world.main_headline: SWAZI KILLED IN RAID ON APARTHEID FOES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/15/world.print_headline: SWAZI KILLED IN RAID ON APARTHEID FOES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/15/world.body_text: **********A police officer was killed in a gun battle today as the authorities in Swaziland and Mozambique, black-ruled countries that have security agreements with South Africa, moved against activists of the African National Congress. **********It is the most active and best known of the exile movements fighting South Africa's policies of apartheid. Its operations have been severely limited recently, particularly by Mozambique's nonaggression agreement with South Africa, which was signed March 16 and effectively closed the group's main route from black-ruled Africa into South Africa. **********The actions against the group today, Western diplomats said, underscored how precarious its new position is among black-ruled neighbors. **********Police officers in Swaziland, a former British colony surrounded on three sides by South Africa, said a police inspector was killed and a second officer was seriously wounded in an exchange of fire at Manzini in the center of the country, 15 miles from the capital, Mbabane. **********The officials said a police squad had found a house in which there were several people thought to be members of the African National Congress. After surrounding the house for five hours, the police moved in, the officials said, and 11 men surrendered. A 12th man refused to surrender and fired on the police, killing the inspector, the officials said. In the ensuing confusion, three people suspected of being activists in the group escaped and nine were said to have been arrested. **********In Mbabane, meanwhile, five more people thought to belong to the group were arrested today, the police officials said, bringing to 30 the number of suspected guerrillas in Swazi police custody. The Swazi authorities are also said to have ordered 50 officials of the group to leave the country recently. **********The gun battle was the second in four days. On Wednesday the police traded shots with people suspected of being members of the group who were among 15 who escaped from a police station in Simunye, northern Swaziland. The 15 were said to have belonged to a group of 21 activists of the group arrested after crossing the border from Mozambique after the signing of the nonaggression pact in what appeared to be an effort to avoid action against them by Mozambique. **********Swaziland signed its security agreement with Mozambique in a secret ceremony in 1982. It disclosed the existence of the pact two weeks ago. Mozambique's accord with South Africa commits each side not to support on its soil the internal foes of the other. **********Reporters based in Mozambique said 25 officials and supporters of the black group flew out of Maputo, the Mozambican capital, today for Lusaka, Zambia, apparently as part of Mozambique's campaign to curb the group's military activities in accord with the treaty. **********In return for Mozambique's action against the group, South Africa, southern Africa's biggest economic and military power, is supposed to halt its clandestine support for the Mozambique National Resistance, which has been fighting a widening bush war against the Marxist leadership of President Samora M. Machel. **********The movement was reported this week to have infiltrated up to 1,000 men into Mozambique before the signing of the nonaggression pact, prompting a major Mozambican military sweep through the south of the country. Despite the operation, however, the insurgents are reported to have hit the power lines supplying Maputo twice in the last 10 days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/08/busin.body_text: **********Much as the business it covers, the computer magazine industry is in the midst of a shakeout that has already eliminated several publications and is likely to wipe out all but the strongest within a year, according to publishing experts. **********In the last six months, the corporate carnage has been daunting. The Hayden Publishing Company, citing inadequate advertising, folded its 11- month-old Personal Software magazine into Personal Computing. Soft Talk, an independent publication based in North Hollywood, Calif., filed for bankruptcy when it, too, could not attract enough advertising. **********A North Carolina-based publishing unit of the American Broadcasting Company canceled PC & PC Jr magazine when the International Business Machines Corporation's PCjr computer proved a disappointment. And the International Thomson Organization's List magazine will appear twice yearly, after floundering as a monthly. **********''The rate of failures will increase,'' predicted James R. Callan, vice president for marketing at C Systems Ltd., a magazine industry research firm. ''Whereas now we are seeing one computer magazine fold each month, the rate could go to two or three times that in the next year.'' Gene W. Simpson, the publisher of Byte and Popular Computing magazines, agrees. ''I would expect to see 15 more fold by year-end,'' he said. **********A Glut on Newsstands **********The main reason for the magazine publishers' distress becomes apparent with a glance at newsstands: There are far too many computer magazines. No one knows precisely how many titles there are, but the most commonly cited figure is 200. Many started before the machines they cater to were even available, and last year a computer magazine was introduced every week, according to Mr. Callan. **********What is clear, experts agree, is that there is not enough advertising revenue to support such a vast supply. **********Although the magazines' total advertising revenues have increased more than fivefold, from roughly $16 million in the first six months of 1982 to $85 in this year's first half, the proliferation of magazines has been so fast that even this increase is not enough to support the industry. **********And with the personal computer industry itself becoming more competitive each day, most experts predict that winning advertising dollars will get tougher, not easier. **********'It Is Ridiculous' **********''It is ridiculous to have so many publications in a market like this, in which 75 percent of the magazines that reach the newsstand are not sold,'' Mr. Simpson said. ''Many of them have got to go away.'' **********Not all computer magazines are in trouble. Older, established publications, such as CW Communications' Computerworld and the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation's Datamation - both aimed at data-processing managers, not consumers - have apparently never been healthier. **********Moreover, a handful of consumer journals, notably McGraw-Hill Inc.'s Byte, Hayden's Personal Computing, the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company's PC and AHL Computing's Creative Computing, are reportedly gold mines, earning as much as 25 cents of profit for every dollar of sales. In general, the magazine industry's return on sales is less than half that. **********These four titles are in the top 400 magazines in America when ranked by total revenues, according to Folio, an industry trade journal. Byte is the largest computer magazine, with $36.6 million in 1983 revenues and profits of roughly $9 million. **********A number of big publishers, however, have been burned by acquiring magazines - and then seeing them crumble. **********Probably the best example is CW Communications. According to industry sources, the Framingham, Mass., publisher paid $16 million for seven computer magazines from Wayne Green, a publishing entrepreneur. CW has since closed three of the journals, including one called Jr, aimed at PCjr users, after only five issues. **********''People thought that I.B.M. would repeat the success it had with its Personal Computer,'' said Debra Wetherbee, a CW vice president. ''Instead, PCjr flopped and so did all of us who produced magazines around it.'' A source at the company, who asked not to be named, said CW lost $1 million on Jr alone. **********A Peculiar Market **********Among the reasons that a few magazines are flourishing, while most are struggling or going under, is the peculiar nature of the computer magazine market. In part, the contraction reflects the typical consumer's habit of buying computer magazines more for ads than articles. This tendency fattens already prosperous journals and weakens marginal ones. **********The disappointing sales of home computers have also tilted the scales in favor of already successful titles. **********Moreover, all computer-magazine publishers are competing for advertising dollars with television, radio and general-interest publications. The computer magazines are being hurt because many computer manufacturers prefer to advertise in general-interest outlets, most of whose readers do not yet own machines. The specialty computer magazines are primarily aimed at computer owners. **********Only a handful of the computer publications have circulations of 500,000 or better. Some barely sell 1,000 copies. Most are losing money. ''We are seeing all the signs of a maturing market,'' said Daniel A. McMillan, vice president for publishing at the Lotus Development Corporation. **********The question now, most publishing specialists say, is how many computer magazines will continue, and in what form. Most experts agree that at least a dozen journals - those that have mass audiences, that cover a broad range of computer issues, and that are presently choked with ads - will probably survive. **********The October issue of Byte, for example, will have roughly 300 pages of ads, with an average price of $6,000 a page, said Mr. Simpson, publisher. **********Beyond the giants, a half-dozen or so narrowly focused magazines catering to users of successful home computers will also survive, experts say, although they are reluctant to pick winners from these ''machine-specific'' titles. That brings the total number of survivors to around 20. **********Ads at a Discount **********As the consolidation continues, some publishers have reportedly begun offering deep discounts on ads to keep the cash flowing in. Others are said to be giving away ad space, just to have the appearance of financial strength. **********Even healthy publishers are trying to fortify their position. American Broadcasting, which produces Compute magazine, will soon begin selling disks with programs on them. **********And Byte will not take an ad unless it is paid for in advance and the advertiser is known to be financially sound, according to Mr. Simpson.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/21/busin.body_text: **********At its peak, the Charter Company had interests in publishing, broadcasting, insurance, real estate and - above all - oil. It was one of the highest flying of the high-flying energy companies of the 1970's. **********But as the ambitions of its founder and chairman, Raymond K. Mason, led Charter into other ventures, the company began to founder - and its problems were fatally compounded by the volatile businesses, oil refining and marketing, that had brought Charter its fortunes. **********Charter had its genesis in a Jacksonville, Fla., lumber company founded in 1919 by Mr. Mason's father. In the 1960's, the younger Mr. Mason changed its name to the Charter Company, tore down the near- bankrupt lumber yard and began making deals. **********Embargo Aided Company **********In 1970, when California's Signal Oil rid itself of some losing assets, Mr. Mason picked up 900 gasoline stations and an aging Houston refinery. When the Arab oil embargo hit a few years later and greatly increased profit margins on oil, Charter was in an enviable position. **********With money rolling in, Mr. Mason struck out in new directions. He set out to become a communications leader, with the acquisition of The Bulletin of Philadelphia, Redbook, The Ladies' Home Journal and Sport, seven radio stations and Dayton Press, one of the nation's largest magazine printers. **********In an attempt to make this rapid diversification into communications work, he brought in Karl Eller, a colorful media consultant. But the two strong personalities did not see eye to eye, and within six months the business relationship was dissolved. **********Mr. Mason diversified further into insurance, buying Crum & Forster. In 1979, he took perhaps his biggest gamble, with the purchase from the Carey Energy Corporation of a refinery - the fifth largest in the world - on Grand Bahama Island. **********Finances Stretched Thin **********Thus the company's finances were stretched exceedingly thin when problems came - and they came with a vengeance. A real estate venture in Florida collapsed. A worldwide oil glut left refineries with smaller profit margins. Charter's foray into communications proved incompatible with the corporate culture of an oil company, and it proved costly, too. The Bulletin was losing $2 million a month by the time Charter closed it in January 1982. **********In the past two years, Charter had been busy dismantling its far-flung empire. In July 1982, the president and three senior executives of Charter were killed when their helicopter crashed in Ireland after leaving a corporate planning session at Mr. Mason's castle. The revamping - with Mr. Mason fully in charge - continued as Charter sold off the remnants of its communications and insurance business. Last Sunday, it announced that it was seeking a buyer for its life insurance group. **********With the Chapter 11 filing, Charter is now seeking to protect its original source of wealth: oil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/04/world.body_text: **********On the night of July 22 leftist guerrillas entered this small village and abducted seven of its leading residents. Three weeks ago the rebels returned, several villagers say, and announced that the men had been executed for political reasons. **********Those said to have been killed were the Mayor, the former Mayor, the village clerk, two municipal policemen and two truck drivers. Two other men taken previously were also said to have been shot. **********The reported killings followed the forced recruitment of about 150 village men by the guerrillas early in June, according to residents. They said that up to 100 of the men were later allowed to return because they were considered unsuited for military service. **********The two events have deeply shocked villagers. Speaking with fear, confusion and sorrow, they offered an account of the underside of this country's five-year civil war, in which more than 50,000 civilians have died and over a million have fled into internal or external exile.   Past Confidence Recounted **********The villagers said they had always been terrified of the Salvadoran Army, but never, until now, of the guerrillas. **********''One had the most confidence in them,'' said 32-year-old Rita Eli Rivera de Flores, the wife of the missing Mayor. ''But if they don't respect human rights they are like the army.'' **********''We are sad here, sad and afraid,'' said 34-year-old Maria Vicente Guevara. **********As Mrs. Guevara spoke, peasants crowded into the whitewashed church nearby to hear a mass for the Day of the Dead, the day when Latin Americans carry flowers to the graves of relatives and friends. A rebel slogan on the wall behind Mrs. Guevara said, ''Death to Informers.'' **********The events in Cacaopera appear to be part of a series of incidents in the last six months in this bitterly contested northeastern corner of El Salvador in which guerrilla units are reliably reported to have conscripted peasants, executed deserters and either forced suspected political opponents into exile or executed them. **********Highly reliable outside observers who know the region around Cacaopera well and who are not associated with either the Government, the rebels or the United States Embassy say that in the last year the guerrillas have adopted a more militaristic and less tolerant attitude toward villagers in the area, which lies more than 100 miles northeast of the capital of San Salvador.   Under Increased Pressure **********Rebel officials said last month that forced recruitment of peasants had ended. Several attempts were made to speak to rebel leaders about the events in Cacaopera. One official was contacted by telephone, but failed to call back to make a comment. **********The region around the village is the center of operations for the People's Revolutionary Army faction of the rebel military Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. The People's Revolutionary Army is considered the largest, most militarily effective rebel group, and has traditionally relied more heavily on combat than on political propaganda to make its presence felt. **********Recently, however, the group has been under increasing pressure from the Salvadoran Army and has changed some of its senior commanders, possibly accounting for its hardening tactics in the area. **********One reliable source in the region said guerrilla units had forcibly removed suspected political opponents from this village and the villages of San Luis de la Reina in San Miguel province, Nueva Esparta in La Union province and Corinto in Morazan province in the last four months. **********Reporters were not able to travel to all the villages named, but the account appeared to be accurate in Cacaopera.   Boy Reported Beheaded **********Several residents said about 100 rebels of the People's Revolutionary Army entered the village at about 10 P.M. on July 22. The rebels claimed to be army soldiers, the witnesses said, and forcibly entered the homes of the seven men they abducted that night. But the guerrillas later identified themselves as rebels and witnesses said they had seen some of them in the village before with rebel units. **********The villagers repeatedly said they had feared the army more than the guerrillas. One observer said an army unit last month beheaded a 7-year-old boy whose parents were suspected of being rebel sympathizers. And villagers said the army had killed several other residents in the last year. **********Relatives of the abducted men appeared bitter as they told how they had not opened their doors when the rebels first knocked because the guerrillas had warned them in the past that only army death squads would knock on their doors at night. **********Relatives of three of those abducted said the rebels had tied the men's thumbs behind their backs and had then led them to the village square with a lasso tied around their waists. The men were kept in the square overnight before being taken away the next morning, the relatives said. **********The relatives insisted that the men had been neutral in the conflict and had never informed against the guerrillas. **********But an outside observer familiar with the town said several of the men were suspected of being Government informers or with being involved in stealing land from peasants. The source said a previous army commander had told neighboring villagers to be like the people of Cacaopera who told the army whenever the rebels passed through. **********The observer's account could not be confirmed. Even if it were true, the rebels' apparent decision to execute the men appears to be a new tactic. **********Rosario Emperatriz Fuentes, 14 years old, said she did not know if her father, Casimiro Fuentes, was alive or dead. Mr. Fuentes was one of the two policemen taken away. Miss Fuentes said she had moved to the provincial capital of San Francisco Gotera, eight miles away, because she feared being taken by the rebels as well.  War Is Like This' **********Mrs. Flores said she had begged the rebels to tell her why they were taking her husband. The guerrillas assured her, she said, that they respected human rights and intended only to ''investigate'' him.  Each time rebel units passed through the village, Mrs. Flores said, she asked them for news of her husband but never received a reply. **********Then on the afternoon of Oct. 8, a unit of 50 guerrillas entered the town, she said, and told the relatives of the seven men abducted in July and two others taken in June to come to the town square.  Mrs. Flores said a rebel told them, ''Don't ask for them anymore because they have been executed.'' **********''We asked them why they had done this since they had never done anything before,'' Mrs. Flores said. ''They said war is like this. In war you have to do these things.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/16/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from a White House transcript of a question-and-answer session between President Reagan and reporters at the White House today: **********Q. Mr. President, when Mr. Chernenko made his speech the other day, he said he wanted to maintain the equilibrium between East and West. What does equilibrium mean to you? Is there now a balance? **********A. I think that we've gone a long way toward redressing what was a great imbalance with the Soviet Union. Back in the campaign, I was referring to our problem as having opened a window of vulnerability. I think we had. I think we've gone a long way toward redressing that. But we still haven't done it to the extent that part of our redressing is still promised, that is of the deployment of the MX missile, the putting on line of the B-1 bomber. Those things, I think, are necessary to give us what I believe would be a sufficient deterrent power. I don't think it still makes us equal to them. And I still am determined that the answer for both of the superpowers is to arrive at an agreement on real reduction of nuclear weapons. And my hope is that once started down that road, we will realize those weapons should be eliminated. **********Relations With Soviet **********Q. Do you feel more optimistic this week than you did last week, as a result of Mr. Chernenko's speech? **********A. Yes, I do. Yes. **********Q. Why? Has anything happened between Mr. Chernenko and the Vice President? **********A. No. Well, they had a meeting, a half hour meeting, and I have heard from the Vice President about that meeting. While Secretary Chernenko did not retreat from his - from the basic Soviet positions, at the same time he expressed a desire for better relations. He felt that we must both take a part in seeing that regional conflicts did not get out of control, that there should be safeguards against any inadvertent use of nuclear weapons. In other words, he spoke - his whole tone and his words were such that indicated that he believed that there was an area for us to come to agreement.   Lebanese-Israeli Accord **********Q. There are reports out of Beirut this morning, Mr. President, indicating that President Gemayel of Lebanon may be on the verge of abrogating the May 17 agreement with Israel. If it were necessary for the Gemayel Government to survive, would your Administration be willing to accept the abrogation of that agreement? **********A. I have to say with regard to the agreement, since we're not a party to it, we did help and encourage the development of it; we're not a party to it, so there's no way that we should have a position one way or the other on whether it is abrogated or not. That is up to the parties involved. And, no, it would not change our position that as long as there's a chance for peace there, we're going to keep striving.   Length of Marine Tour **********Q. Mr. President, in the week before you announced the redeployment of the Marines in Lebanon, you used very strong language to criticize Speaker O'Neill and others who were calling for a pull out. There's two questions about that. One is, do you think that your statements at a time when you were, in fact, considering strongly redeployment, if not a total pullout, has created any credibility problems? And secondly, how long do you anticipate the Marines staying on the ships off the coast? **********A. The length of stay will be determined by what happens and whether we succeed or not. And it will be no different in length than it would be if they stayed in their positions on shore. **********The remark, and maybe it was facetious in a way of flippant when I responded to a question out in the Rose Garden about the Speaker's position versus ours, was because my understanding was that he was suggesting that we bug out, that we just turn tail and run. And all that we were considering and had been planning for quite some time was how to continue the mission, but with a restationing of our forces, an improvement in that. **********Q. So in other words, you expect them to stay possibly up to the full 18- month period of the authorization? **********A. Yes. We hope that it won't be that long.   Missile Deployment **********Q. Mr. President, as a gesture of good will toward the new leadership in the Soviet Union and in an effort to break the ice on the nuclear arms negotiations, would you consider suspending further deployment of U.S. Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe for a period? **********A. No, I don't think we should. The intermediate-range missiles of the Soviet Union number well over a thousand, someplace in the neighborhood of 1,500, 1,350 or something of that kind, with nothing comparable as a deterrent force for NATO. **********Now, NATO - our allies asked for this deployment of missiles in 1979 and it was agreed to by the Administration at that time. We inherited that situation and agree with the fact that there should be such a deterrent policy - or force - there. I think that the Soviet Union made it very plain during the negotiations that their target was the prevention of our deploying those missiles. **********I still believe my original proposal of zero option on both sides was the most sensible answer to get them completely, on both sides, out of Europe. But I think the best chance of getting agreement from the Soviet Union is dependent on us having that deterrent force. And I think it would be a retreat and it would not do anything to speed up negotiations with them if we now fell back and delayed deploying.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices, which were under pressure last week, retreated further yesterday in slower trading. **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.51 points yesterday, to 1,267.59. Last week, the average dropped almost 17 points, including a loss of 9.21 points on Friday. **********In the overall market yesterday, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that rose, 893 to 734. Turnover on the Big Board dropped to 93.8 million shares, from 101.8 million on Friday, as institutional interest waned. **********Analysts said many investors were concerned that the economic recovery was slowing too abruptly and that corporate earnings may be lower than predicted as a result. **********Other Indexes Rose **********The two other leading market indicators ended slightly higher. The exchange's composite index of 1,500 common equities rose 0.09, to 96.75, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 issues added 0.16, to 167.18. **********Some of the biggest price moves yesterday occurred among the technology issues. The big gainer was Digital Equipment, which soared 7 5/8 points, to 85 3/4, in very heavy trading after climbing 3 1/4 points on Friday. After the close Friday, the company announced that its profits for the second quarter, ended Dec. 31, would show an increase over the same period last year. **********In the same group, Commodore Technology tumbled 2, to 45 3/4, following the news late Friday that Jack Tramiel had resigned as president and chief executive and as a director. Mr. Tramiel founded the company and was closely involved in day-to- day decisions. **********Most of the other technology issues finished higher. Rolm, Computervision, Texas Instruments, Data General, Perkin-Elmer, Hewlett-Packard, International Business Machines and Prime Computer each rose a point or more. **********Royal Crown Benefits **********Royal Crown was up 2 1/4, to 35 1/4, after the company agreed in principle to be acquired by two top officers and a director of the company for $37 a share. Late in the day, Victor Posner, the financier, offered to buy all of the outstanding shares at $40 a share; the company had turned down his offer of $45 a share for just the management's stock. **********Commonwealth Edison fell 3 5/8 points, to 22 5/8. On Friday, Federal regulators denied the company a license to operate a $3.35 billion nuclear power plant near Rockford, Ill. The utility said it might contest the decision. The stock topped the most- active list on a turnover of 4.6 million shares. **********In the same category, Public Service of Indiana lost 1 5/8, to 10, after the utility said it would cancel its Marble Hill nuclear power project because of increasing costs. Reflecting the weakness in the utility issues, the Dow Jones utility average fell 3.95, to 130.35. **********Meanwhile, some of the recently spun-off companies of American Telephone and Telegraph made impressive gains. Pacific Telesis rose 2 1/8, to 61 3/4; U S West was up 2 1/8, to 64 3/4, and Southwestern Bell rose 1 1/4, to 64 3/4. The ''old'' A.T.& T. gained 1 1/8, to 66 3/4, and was the second most heavily traded. **********Some analysts speculated that investors were selling some of the nuclear utility issues and putting some of the proceeds into nonnuclear utilities such as the spun-off telephone equities. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index gained 0.09, to 226.91. The class A stock of Movie Star Inc. rose 1 7/8, to 17 3/8, after the company reported sharply higher profits for its latest quarter. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.56, to 286.29.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/02/busin.body_text: **********Citibank and the Standard Chartered Bank have agreed to defer temporarily their applications to become members of the Bankers Clearing House until it can review its procedures, the clearing house said today. **********The 10 present members will cooperate in a major study of the organization's clearing system, noting recent developments in technology. **********Both the New York-based Citibank and Standard Chartered, a British institution, applied for membership late last year. People in the banking industry regard Citibank's request as an effort to enhance its presence in the London banking community.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/01/busin.print_headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Diagnostic Field Lags
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/01/busin.body_text: **********D IASONICS INC., a maker of medical diagnostic equipment that went public early last year as a ''hot new issue,'' said yesterday that it expects to report a pretax loss of $60 million to $65 million for 1983. **********In the offering last Feb. 23, the company sold 6,088,000 shares at $22 apiece. Heavy demand pushed the price up $4.75 in the first day of trading, and it soon reached its record, $29.75. By the end of December, however, the stock had tumbled to $8.25 and ranked among the most prominent fallen angels of the new-issue sector. **********In yesterday's over-the-counter trading, Diasonics fell $1.25 more, to $5. **********The Milpitas, Calif., company also announced that it was phasing out sales of its line of add-on digital image processors. These radiography units represent a computer-based technique for enhancing conventional X-ray images. In essence, the computer and associated software are added to existing X-ray systems. **********Diasonics said its 1983 deficit was due primarily to operating losses in the discontinued lines and to write-offs and reserves for future operations associated with its decision to phase out that business. Also there were losses of approximately $15 million from other operations, as well as a loss in the ultrasound division. **********''The digital add-on market is no longer financially viable,'' said Albert S. Waxman, chairman and chief executive officer. ''As of right now, we are devoting our resources to competing in the whole-room digital systems and conventional X-ray markets.'' **********Demand for digital add-on units, according to Mr. Waxman, has fallen sharply, primarily as a result of perceptions by the medical community that certain applications are not clinically viable or cost-effective. **********''Our reallocation-of-resources plan calls for us to integrate our digital add-on operations with our new X-ray division in Denver,'' he said. **********The add-on market enjoyed a ''robust'' business in 1982, said Timothy R. Craig, a vice president and investor relations officer for Diasonics, but it also attracted competition. **********''By the second quarter of 1983,'' he said, ''there was shrinkage in demand, and this was followed by heavy price discounting. The price of units that originally cost over $200,000 dropped to an industry average of about $160,000.'' **********ADAC Laboratories of Sunnyvale, Calif., also makes computerized image-processing systems used in medical diagnoses. Last week ADAC announced a 35 percent drop in sales for the three months ended Dec. 31, resulting in a net loss of $3,519,000, against earnings of $1,617,000, or 19 cents a share, a year earlier. **********''The most significant reduction in sales,'' Charles W. Cantoni, ADAC's president and chief executive officer, noted at the time, ''resulted from a shortfall of orders for digital radiography add-on systems, which in the recent past have accounted for approximately 60 percent of our business.'' **********Shares of ADAC, traded over the counter, also plummeted last year. They rose from $6.25 in March 1982 to a high of $27.375 last February, then finished 1983 at $9.375. Yesterday ADAC closed at $6, down 25 cents. **********Other domestic companies engaged in the digital radiography add-on market include Johnson & Johnson, General Electric Company, Squibb Corporation, Medtronic Inc. and Xonics Inc. **********Larry Haimovitch, a medical technology analyst with Woodman, Kirkpatrick & Gilbreath in San Francisco, gave this assessment: ''At best these other companies are having a tough time in this particular market, and at worst I'd say they are losing money.'' **********A number of foreign companies also compete in this market. They include Elscint of Israel, Siemens A.G. of West Germany and Philips N.V. of the Netherlands. **********When Diasonics was preparing to go public last February, demand for its stock proved so heavy that underwriters raised the initial offering price from $18 a share to $22. One dealer was quoted as saying, ''Everybody was dying to get as much stock as they could.'' **********In what was described at the time as one of the largest initial public offerings ever, the syndicate was led by F. Eberstadt & Company. The two other major underwriters were L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin and Hambrecht & Quist Inc. **********Diasonics has about 52 million common shares outstanding, with an estimated 27 percent controlled by officers and directors. In 1982 the company earned 30 cents a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/16/busin.body_text: **********DAVID E. SANGER **********The Hewlett-Packard Company, seeking to bolster its late entry into the personal computer market last year, will introduce a lightweight ''lap'' computer in the next few weeks. Industry analysts say it will be significantly more advanced than any now made by the major computer manufacturers. **********Company officials hope the machine, code-named Nomad, will increase sales of the HP 150, Hewlett's first personal computer, which has met a mixed sales response. **********Industry sources, some of whom have seen the new machine, say it will weigh 9 pounds, will run nearly all the programs written for the HP 150 and will include at least two programs built into its permanent memory: the Lotus 1-2-3 financial spreadsheet-and-graphics package and a word processing program. **********Easy to Use, Analyst Says **********''It will be very easy to use, very elegant,'' said Adam F. Cuhney, a technology analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc. ''Most of the other lap computers we have seen are somewhat clumsy machines.'' It will also be more powerful. Like the HP 150, the Nomad is a high-speed microcomputer, capable of processing 16 bits of information at a time and including a minimum of 256,000 characters of internal memory. **********Officials of Hewlett-Packard decline to discuss the new machine, other than to confirm that a portable computer will be announced next month. Analysts, however, expect the Nomad to carry a base price of about $3,000 and appeal primarily to the professional market. **********Apple Computer Inc. is expected to introduce a less powerful, $1,300 lap computer next week, aimed primarily at more casual home and professional users looking for a portable version of the popular Apple II. **********Growth Expected for Sector **********Thus, Apple and Hewlett are staking out positions at the low and high ends, respectively, of what many analysts expect may be the fastest-growing sector of the microcomputer industry over the next few years: the market for battery-operated computers weighing less than 10 pounds and designed for business executives or writers who travel a lot. **********The first such machines appeared last year, marketed by a number of small American and Japanese manufacturers, including Sharp and the Nippon Electric Company. So far the industry leader, the International Business Machines Corporation, has announced only a 30-pound ''luggable'' computer, although it is rumored to be working on several lightweight portables. **********Hewlett reportedly hopes that beating I.B.M. to the lap model market will help Hewlett's own developing line of personal computers. **********Sales Falling Short of Goal **********But initial sales of its first entry, the HP 150, have been sluggish. One analyst, Michael J. Krasko, reported last week that Hewlett was falling 50 percent short of its goal of shipping 8,000 HP 150's a month. The company has also had trouble making some programs work with its unusual ''touchscreen'' technology. This lets a user move a column of numbers, for example, just by pointing to it on the computer screen. **********''Hewlett is still defining its role in the computer market,'' Mr. Krasko said. ''They hope Nomad will give dealers the feeling that the company is committed to the business.'' **********Like the HP 150, the appeal of the nine-pound Nomad is expected to be its advanced features, particularly its built-in programs. On most desktop models, software is installed through disk drives and loaded in the computer's temporary memory. **********Some Programs Permanent **********But Hewlett-Packard, working with the Lotus Development Corporation and other software vendors, etched Lotus 1-2-3 and other programs on permanent chips known as ''Read Only Memory'' chips, or ROM's. Thus, when the power is turned on, these programs are read automatically by the machine. **********Such technology has been used before, as on the Radio Shack Model 100, currently the best-selling lap model. But it has never been used with a program as complex as 1-2-3. **********Moreover, the Nomad is able to display graphics, such as pie and bar charts created by Lotus, on its flat screen display, which is reportedly supplied by Sharp. The screen is known in the industry as ''electroluminescent,'' meaning that it utilizes a new technology to create a sharper image and pose less of a drain on the computer's batteries. **********The Nomad is expected to include one floppy-disk drive, using the same 3 1/2-inch disks incorporated in the HP 150 and Apple's new Macintosh.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/07/world.main_headline: IN IRAQI PORT, SULLEN MOOD AMID SHELLING
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/07/world.print_headline: IN IRAQI PORT, SULLEN MOOD AMID SHELLING
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/07/world.body_text: **********Whenever a shell crashes into this port city, people instinctively duck their heads and glance briefly toward the area struck. **********They then proceed about their business, glum for a brief spell and talking little to those with them. Their normal pace returns until the next shell lands, perhaps an hour or two later, day and night. **********One foreign resident said that since last month, when Iranian forces began shelling Basra from their nearest positions, about 10 miles to the east, the pace of this sprawling city of around one million people had been slow and sullen. The port has been idle since the war with Iran began in 1980 and Iran cut off its use. **********To see freighters from many nations riding empty and high at their moorings for more than three years, knowing that between here and the Persian Gulf there are 80 such vessels rusting for a fourth year, does little to cheer the people of Basra, since the port and their livelihoods were one.   No Serious Food Shortage **********Many shopkeepers have padlocked their shutters and gone away, and the majority of shops that remain open have little to offer. Sharp import restrictions, because of the high cost of the war, have reduced Iraqi consumption largely to what their own country produces. **********Although some items are in irregular supply, there seems to be no serious food shortage. The smell of roasting mutton pervades the center of what was once a bustling city, and the piles of flat bread and sticky pastries seem ample. **********The local fertilizer factory has put its sacks at the disposal of those who fill them with sand and pile them in front of their shop windows. Sandbag shelters are constructed near bridges for the soldiers guarding them. **********Despite the barricade of sandbags, the Sheraton Hotel has some broken windows around its entrance doors.   Shell Hit a Hospital **********At that, the hotel was more fortunate than the hospital a few hundred yards farther down the Shatt al Arab, the waterway formed by the confluence of the Tigris and the Euphrates. Some patients at the hospital were killed last week when a shell hit, and others were wounded. **********A local information official said he thought three patients were killed. Total casualty figures, however, were not available. **********At least one civilian was killed Monday, at midmorning, and perhaps nine others wounded in shelling. **********Iraqis say they believe the Iranian gunners are intentionally hitting such targets as the hospital. The information officials said the Iranians had tried to hit the hospital for weeks. **********Maj. Gen. Mamer Abdel Rashid, who commands Iraqi troops in this sector, said his gunners had not hit a single civilian target in Iran. But if the orders come from Baghdad, he said, his gunners are ready to shell all Iranian cities within their range. **********''For each 100 enemy shells,'' he said, leaning on a heavy, straight cane ending in a large wooden loop, ''they will receive 3,000 Iraqi shells.''  Suspicion About Foreigners **********Basra is dirtier than Baghdad, and much rotting garbage fouls its streets. Foreigners are nowhere met with the friendly curiosity that is generally customary, and shopkeepers do not invite foreigners in for a cup of tea. Soldiers dominate the city scene and grimly inquire about a stroller's business. **********The many men trying to make a living shining shoes find few customers, and beggars get few alms. **********Although military officers briefing reporters express the belief that a battle for the city may be near, General Rashid said there was no possibility of such a battle. **********''We don't have to defend Basra,'' he said. ''We wait impatiently for the enemy to cross the border. We will annihilate him before he gets here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.main_headline: Nigerians Say British Papers 'Fabricated' Crate News Item
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.print_headline: Nigerians Say British Papers 'Fabricated' Crate News Item
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/04/world.body_text: **********The Nigerian High Commission here said today that the British press had 'fabricated' a news item about a crate to embarrass Nigeria. **********In a statement, the High Commission referred to a report in The Times of London on Saturday that Bernard Banfa, managing director of Nigeria Airways, was thought to have left London in a crate marked as diplomatic baggage. **********The Times said Mr. Banfa was wanted for questioning about the attempted kidnapping of a former Nigerian Transport Minister, Umaru Dikko, who was found July 5 drugged in a crate about to be loaded on a Nigerian plane. **********Mr. Banfa's wife said Saturday in Lagos that her husband was in Nigeria, but she would not comment further.
