https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/21/busin.main_headline: GINNIE MAE CONTRACTS DOWN IN VOLATILE DAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/21/busin.print_headline: FUTURES/OPTIONS; GINNIE MAE CONTRACTS DOWN IN VOLATILE DAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/21/busin.body_text: **********Ginnie Mae futures fell sharply yesterday after a day of unusually broad price moves on the Chicago Board of Trade. At the close, the spot March contract was down 14/32 for the day, at 69 7/32, after having ranged between 70 10/32 and 69 3/32. The Ginnie Mae contract for June delivery fell 11/32, to 68 17/32. **********''There were several factors causing the volatility, none of which represented any surprising or significant changes in the interest rate situation,'' said Richard L. Sandor, senior vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert in Chicago. **********As one factor, for example, Wednesday is the expiration date for the March contract. Many traders switched out of this Ginnie Mae contract and into Treasury bond futures, Mr. Sandor said. **********Also, many traders and hedgers in Government National Mortgage Association certificates may have been preparing for the introduction on Thursday of Ginnie Mae II futures in the same trading pit at the Chicago Board of Trade. Mr. Sandor said people in the financial markets expect the new contracts to be more successful than the present Ginnie Mae futures, which will continue to be traded. **********Different Kind of Instrument One reason for the optimism is the fact that the Ginnie Mae II futures will be directly deliverable instruments. The present contracts represent collateralized depository receipts, which the recipient must then exchange for an actual Ginnie Mae certificate. **********Michael P. Kamradt, the Board of Trade's financial marketing chief, said: ''Although the difference may seem technical to the average trader, who only cares whether prices go up or down and never takes delivery of the underlying instrument, they are very important to banks and other institutional hedgers. The Ginnie Mae II futures were designed to reduce and simplify the hedging costs of the growing number of mortgage originators, dealers and investors in this rapidly exapnding market.'' **********If those who grant or invest in mortgages can conveniently and economically insure their portfolios with the futures and the soon-to-be-introduced options on the Ginnie Mae II futures, they will be more willing to originate and invest in mortgages despite the uncertainty of interest rates, Mr. Kamradt said. **********Basically, Ginnie Maes are created when grantors of mortgages package them into units of $100,000 or more and sell them to the quasi-Government agency. The mortgage lender may receive a point or so above the rate homeowners pay and then presumably will have fresh cash to lend to home buyers. **********Banks and other lenders also enjoy the fees they receive for processing the monthly payments homeowners make on the mortgages. **********As for the Government National Mortgage Association, it deposits the packaged mortgages with a bank, issues certificates on the package and then sells them to investors, many of whom are attracted by the relatively high monthly interest yields on these instruments. The funds received from investors are then used to buy more mortgages from banks and other lenders, thus completing and widening the circle of available money for home buyers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/27/world.main_headline: 4 U. S. Jews Charged In Palestinian Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/27/world.print_headline: 4 U. S. Jews Charged In Palestinian Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/27/world.body_text: **********Four American Jewish immigrants were formally charged in a district court today with carrying out attacks on Palestinians in the occupied West Bank. **********Three of the four were accused of wounding six Palestinian workers as they rode a bus March 4 near the city of Ramallah. **********They also were charged with arson and firebombing of Palestinian property. **********The three were identified as Matthew Leibowitz, 21 years old, Levi Hazan, 23, and Yehuda Richter, 21. Previous reports have said Mr. Richter and Mr. Hazan immigrated to Israel from Los Angeles and Mr. Leibowitz came here as a tourist from New York City. The prosecuting attorney, Michael Shaked, said Mr. Leibowitz was the only one of the three who did not hold dual Israeli- American citizenship. **********Mr. Shaked said the three faced up to 20 years in prison. **********A fourth defendant, Yekutiel Gosovsky, 20, an immigrant from the New York City area, was not charged in the bus attack. Mr. Gosovsky was accused of being involved in four other attacks on Palestinians and faces a possible 15 years in prison. **********A fifth suspect, identified as Craig Leitner, also a dual American-Israeli citizen from Los Angeles, was arrested with three of the accused on March 4 but is serving as state's witness.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/busin.main_headline: DOW POSTS SHARP DROP OF 10.57, TO 1,150.13
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/busin.print_headline: DOW POSTS SHARP DROP OF 10.57, TO 1,150.13
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices took another beating yesterday in holiday-slowed trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping sharply and closing at its lowest level in 10 months. **********The Dow average ended off 10.57 points, to 1,150.13, as late bargain- hunting erased some of the earlier losses in the depressed blue-chip group. The average had been down almost 17 points at 3 P.M., The close was the lowest in the 30-stock average since April 12, 1983, when it finished at 1,145.32. **********The general market was also hard- hit, with declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscoring those that rose by almost a 3-to-1 ratio. **********The two other major market indicators also ended lower yesterday. The exchange's composite index of 1,500 common equities fell 0.79, to 89.28, while Standard & Poor's 500 stock index dropped 1.35, to 154.95. **********''Increasing investor pessimism is fueling the market's decline as evidenced by today's broad-based selling,'' said David M. Polen, president of David M. Polen Securities Inc. He predicted that the selloff would continue unless there are definite signs that interest rates will not rise. **********Since Jan. 6, the Dow average has plunged 136 points amid investors' fears that interest rates might advance as a result of continuing huge Federal budget deficits. **********The concern has led many of the pension, bank and mutual funds to sell their equity holdings. This in turn has depressed prices, touching off a sharp increase in margin selling by many small investors. **********Alfred Shoenberg, chairman of Shoenberg & Hieber Inc., suggested, however, that with the market so oversold ''it is more than likely that a strong technical rally will occur in the next few sessions.'' **********Turnover on the Big Board yesterday dropped to 78.5 million shares, from 92.2 million shares on Friday. The market had staged a mild rally that day with the Dow closing up 7.96 points, although it was off more than 36 points for the week. **********But analysts noted that yesterday's volume was far heavier than expected, given that many banks and investing institutions were closed in observnce of Lincoln's Birthday. They said the pace was evidence of investors' anxiety. **********Eastman Kodak was the big loser in the blue-chip group, dropping 1 7/8 points, to 68 1/4, in heavy trading. The company reported sharply lower fourth-quarter net of 70 cents a share against $1.94 a share the year before. **********In the same category, General Electric lost 1 1/8, to 52 3/8; Western Union was off 1 3/8, to 29 3/4, and International Business Machines, which made the most-active list, fell 7/8, to 109. **********Although most of volatile technology issues finished with minor price changes, there were a few exceptions. Cray Research tumbled 2 3/8, to 43 3/8, following the news that the Japanese are developing supercomputers that will mean increased competition for the large models being made by such manufacturers as Cray. **********Among the utility issues, Long Island Lighting was off 1 3/8, to 6 7/8, on heavy trading. The company, which is beset with problems concerning its Shoreham, L.I., nuclear plant, had said it was ending its participation in the Nine Mile Point nuclear plant in upstate New York. **********In the weaker transportation group, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines fell 3, to 55 1/2; Rio Grande Industries was off 1 1/4, to 42 1/2, and Burlington Northern lost 1 7/8, to 85 1/4. **********Getty Oil climbed 3, to 127 1/2, on the news that Texaco had completed the purchase of all the Getty shares tendered to it for $128 a share, after receiving tentative clearance from the Federal Trade Commission. Texaco closed down 3/4, to 39 3/8. **********Prices on the American Stock Exchange also ended mostly lower with the market-value index off 1.95, to 205.02. Park Chemical, which declared a 2-for-1 stock split, advanced 2 1/4, to 34 1/2. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 3.47, to 250.57.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/30/world.main_headline: PERES AND SHAMIR STEP UP TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/30/world.print_headline: PERES AND SHAMIR STEP UP TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/30/world.body_text: **********Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Shamir, contenders to head the next Israeli government, agreed today to step up their negotiations to form a national unity administration centered on their parties. **********After their fourth attempt since the July 23 elections, they scheduled meetings for Friday and Sunday and said they hoped to conclude an agreement at the second meeting. **********In separate interviews in the King David Hotel in Jerusalem, the two leaders spoke of substantial progress in narrowing areas of disagreement. But they said they had not yet tackled the trickiest issue, the composition of the government and would leave that for the meeting Sunday. **********Mr. Peres, leader of the Labor Alignment, received a mandate from President Chaim Herzog to form a government and claims the top position for himself. Mr. Shamir, the incumbent Prime Minister and leader of the Likud bloc, demands the post be rotated between them. **********Mr. Peres said his party's opposition to rotation had not changed, but he added, ''If the idea is raised, the Labor alignment will have to discuss it again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/22/world.body_text: **********A pro-Solidarity priest appeared tonight to have lost his battle to remain in his parish here despite a transfer order from the Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp. **********''It is my duty to obey, so no one is hurt, not the church, the parish or the fatherland,'' the priest, the Rev. Mieczyslaw Nowak, told reporters tonight. **********''My place is in the new parish.'' **********Since last weekend, more than 2,000 people have packed the Church of St. Joseph the Worker for masses protesting the Cardinal's order. Twelve people went on hunger strike demanding that the order be reversed. **********''My task in the first place is to show my adherence to the bishop,'' Father Nowak told the congregation when he made an unexpected appearance at a protest mass tonight.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/06/world.main_headline: JACKSON URGES U.S. NOT TO 'SHUN' DIRECT TALKS WITH SYRIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/06/world.print_headline: JACKSON URGES U.S. NOT TO 'SHUN' DIRECT TALKS WITH SYRIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/06/world.body_text: **********The Rev. Jesse Jackson, continuing to press his views of United States policy in the Middle East, said today that he had told Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that the Administration should not ''shun'' direct talks with Syria on easing tensions in the region. **********The 42-year-old contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination met for a half hour with Mr. Weinberger a day after Mr. Jackson's return from Syria, where his talks with Syrian officials led to the release of a captured Navy flier. The meeting was a followup, Mr. Jackson said, to his meeting at the White House Wednesday with President Reagan. **********''My analysis is that we should not shun a nation because it is receiving Soviet assistance,'' Mr. Jackson said on the Pentagon steps after the meeting. He said direct talks between President Reagan and President Hafez al- Assad could go a long way toward improving relations between the two countries and would be an important step in a ''comprehensive'' Middle East strategy.   Urges Ties to Arab Nations **********A Pentagon spokesman said Secretary Weinberger found it ''interesting'' that Mr. Jackson had observed President Assad to be in much better health than reports reaching Washington in the past few months would suggest. Mr. Jackson said it was wrong to have a Middle East policy that ''excites'' one country, meaning Israel, and ''incites 21 countries,'' meaning the bulk of the Arab nations. The best way for the United States to help Israel, he said, is to establish ties with the other nations and thus help reduce the number of countries hostile to Israel. **********United States officials have expressed concern in the last year as Soviet military aid to Syria has increased dramatically. Last spring several Soviet SAM-5's were reported installed at a base near Homs, marking the first deployment of the antiaircraft weapon outside of the Soviet Union. Last month Pentagon officials said the number of Soviet advisers, technicians and air defense personnel in Syria had grown to 8,000. **********Mr. Jackson was criticized today by M. T. Mehdi, president of the American-Arab Relations Committee, who led an unsuccessful effort to seek the release of the Navy flier two weeks before Mr. Jackson's trip. **********In a telegram, Mr. Mehdi first congratulated Mr. Jackson on his success, but then pointed to reported statements by him saying that ''the Arab war against Israel must be stopped'' and expressing the hope that Israel become the capital of democracy and commerce in the Middle East. Mr. Mehdi said such statements showed ''utmost contempt for the feelings of the Arab people.'' **********''You are a disappointment, brother,'' the telegram said. **********Meanwhile, the freed flier, Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr., met today with Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman, who praised the 27-year-old navigator-bombardier for ''superb'' conduct during his captivity. **********In a brief news conference, Lieutenant Goodman said he expected to be flying again soon, but Navy officials said he would be grounded while receiving therapy on a knee wound he suffered on ejecting from his A6-E Intruder on Dec. 4 when it was hit by a surface-to-air missile. **********The lieutenant defended the plane, which has been criticized by some as too heavy and too slow. He said it was fast enough to be used in attacks like the one in which it was shot down. He noted that only 2 of the 28 planes in that raid had been downed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/13/world.main_headline: ACCORD REPORTED REACHED ON ISRAELI COALITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/13/world.print_headline: ACCORD REPORTED REACHED ON ISRAELI COALITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/13/world.body_text: **********After an 11th-hour crisis in their negotiations to form a Cabinet, Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, and Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud leader, early this morning seemed to have cleared the last obstacles to a broad-based coalition. **********Labor Party officials said that barring any last-minute difficulties, the national unity Government - Israel's first in 14 years - would be presented to Parliament for a confidence vote today. **********The two leaders had been forced to postpone their planned introduction of the Cabinet to Parliament Wednesday. **********Time is running out for Mr. Peres, whose second 21-day mandate to form a new Government expires on Sunday. If he is unable to form a Government by then, President Chaim Herzog of Israel is likely to give another party a chance. **********''With this deadline looming, Mr. Peres and Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud leader, negotiated all Tuesday night in a hotel in Tel Aviv. By Wednesday morning, they were still in disagreement on several key issues, including which religious faction would win control of the Ministry of Religious Affairs.    Atmosphere of Crisis **********The atmosphere of crisis Wednesday was heightened by the fact that, just 24 hours earlier, it seemed that both parties had completed agreement on the formation of a national unity government that would have had the support of more than 80 of the 120 members of Parliament. ''We had the champagne on ice,'' said one Labor Party official.  But the celebrating was premature. Instead, the two parties spent Tuesday night locked in tense talks in the Dan Hotel in Tel Aviv. The immediate point of disagreement was whether the Ministry of Religious Affairs, with its considerable patronage and influence over the nation's religious schools and institutions, would be given to the Sephardi Torah Guardians Association, known as Shas, a right- wing ethnic splinter of the Orthodox Agudat Israel party. Mr. Shamir revealed Tuesday that Likud had promised the portfolio to Shas, while Labor had pledged to hold it in reserve for three months, ostensibly for the National Religious Party. The two religious parties, each with four seats in Parliament, are fierce rivals. **********After another long day of negotiations Wednesday, Labor Party sources said tonight that the problem had been overcome by a compromise under which the Ministry of Religious Affairs would be left vacant and would be administered temporarily by the Prime Minister's office. **********Control of the Religious Affairs Ministry is a sensitive issue here. Moreover, the dispute masks a major struggle for power within the Likud bloc between Mr. Shamir and former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon. **********Mr. Sharon, who is challenging Mr. Shamir for the Likud leadership, created a furor Tuesday evening at a meeting of the Likud Central Committee by demanding that the bloc stick by its commitment to Shas. Anything less, he charged, would be a failure of leadership. Allies of Mr. Sharon quickly took the floor during the tumultuous meeting to echo the charges against Mr. Shamir. One pro-Sharon member, David Magen, shouted that Mr. Shamir was ''not built to be number one anymore.'' **********On the defensive, Mr. Shamir returned to the negotiations with Mr. Peres. With his leadership at stake, he was under intense pressure to extract more concessions from Labor, including a commitment to go ahead with a number of new settlements on the occupied West Bank. The draft agreement worked out with Labor commits the proposed national unity Government to build only six new settlements in the first year. Likud has built 120 such settlements since taking power in 1977 and has vowed to put more than 100,000 Jewish settlers in the West Bank. Labor wants to freeze the construction of new settlements. **********When it became clear that Labor and Likud could not reach agreement on this and a number of other points, the National Religious Party announced that it would be willing to commit its four seats to a narrow coalition led by Labor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/15/world.main_headline: HONDURAN SAYS U.S. COPTER FLEW OVER NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/15/world.print_headline: HONDURAN SAYS U.S. COPTER FLEW OVER NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/15/world.body_text: **********The commander of the Honduran Armed Forces has acknowledged that the American helicopter whose pilot was killed Wednesday near the border with Nicaragua was over Nicaraguan territory when first attacked. **********Gen. Gustavo Alvarez Martinez said Friday night that the pilot, Chief Warrant Officer Jeffery C. Schwab of Joliet, Ill., did not realize he had strayed into Nicaragua. He said heavy cloud cover had made it difficult for the pilot to verify his location. **********''When he descended over Nicaraguan territory, he came under machine-gun fire,'' General Alvarez said. ''The helicopter was damaged and had to land on a road inside our territory. When the helicopter was on the ground and the crew members got off, there was more machine-gun fire, and the American pilot was killed.'' **********The Nicaraguan Defense Ministry said Wednesday night that its troops had fired on an unidentified military helicopter over Nicaragua that was later forced to land 200 yards inside Honduras. **********Tensions surrounding the incident appeared to have calmed, as all parties involved publicly declared their hope that it would not lead to further escalation. Secretary of State George P. Shultz said Friday in Washington that the United States was not contemplating any punitive action, and President Roberto Suazo Cordova of Honduras told reporters here that his Government ''remains firm in its peaceful intentions.'' **********In Managua, the capital of Nicaragua, the Sandinista junta coordinator, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, said he did not accept the version that suggested Mr. Schwab had been killed after his helicopter was on the ground in Honduras. He also said there had been no satisfactory explanation of why the helicopter was flying over Nicaragua. **********''We never imagined that the helicopter which violated our airspace was North American,'' Mr. Ortega said. ''We thought we were shooting at an aircraft provided by the C.I.A. or a Honduran helicopter bringing military supplies to the counterrevolutionaries.'' **********Nicaraguan exile groups based in Honduras and supported by the United States are engaged in continuing combat with Sandinista troops. Nicaragua has contended that they receive air and artillery support from Honduran forces. **********An American Embassy spokesman said there are now about 2,600 United States troops in Honduras participating in joint maneuvers with the Honduran military. American troops are not working with anti-Sandinista guerrillas in any way, the spokesman said. **********General Alvarez said preliminary talks had begun for the construction of ''a mixed military base with the United States'' somewhere in Honduras. He said the base would be temporary and would remain in operation ''while the Honduran security situation remains delicate.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/13/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; RETIREMENT: BALANCING THE SCALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/13/busin.body_text: **********THE first Federal legislation aimed at improving private pension benefits for women **********is slowly moving toward passage in Congress. Among other things, it would require wives' written approval if their husbands decided not to provide them with widows' pension benefits, protect women workers against loss of their accrued pension rights during leaves for childbirth and child-rearing, and provide pension benefits to women whose husbands died before they reached early-retirement age. **********With the women's vote a major consideration in this election year, the legislation is considered as American and noncontroversial as apple pie. Passage is considered almost certain by summer, unless Congress becomes enmeshed in controversy over the pending tax bill, and already both political parties are claiming credit for it. **********But even supporters say there may be less there than meets the eye. ''The Administration is going to get a lot of political mileage out of something that is pretty hollow, and the Democrats are jumping on the bandwagon, too,'' said Robin Block of William M. Mercer-Meidinger Inc., a New York employee benefits consulting firm. **********She and other pension experts say that while the legislation is long overdue, it will help a relatively small number of women and that further changes will be necessary before women achieve true pension parity with men. ''It will not have much impact on the ability of women workers to earn meaningful pension benefits,'' said Judith F. Mazo, vice president of the Martin E. Segal Company, another New York benefits consulting firm. **********There are three legislative proposals under consideration, but they are nearly identical. There are two versions of the Retirement Equity Act, each passed late last year by the Senate and the House Education and Labor Committee, and the House Ways and Means Committee is currently drafting a third version. All three would try to improve benefits both for women workers and the wives of men workers. First, the bills would require a spouse's written consent if the working partner decided to waive something known as the joint and survivor's option. **********This option guarantees that the widow or widower of a worker will receive a pension after the worker's death. But some workers elect not to take the option because it means they receive a somewhat smaller pension while they are alive. **********Although the joint and survivor option is automatically provided in most private pension plans, current law permits workers to waive the provision without informing their spouses. Under the proposed legislation, a spouse's written consent would be required, and the signature would have to be notarized or witnessed by a plan official. **********''It gives a spouse a controlling say about what happens to an employee's pension,'' said Miss Mazo. ''It is the harbinger of a national community property law, but only with respect to retirement plan benefits.'' **********The bills would also try to protect the accrued pension rights of women workers who take leaves for childbirth and child-rearing. Under the proposals, any pension credits that a person had earned toward his or her pension would have to be restored if the person returned to work within five years after leaving the job. Ironically, this provision might help men more than women, according to Miss Block. ''Many more men than women leave - usually for other jobs - and return within five years,'' she said. **********In addition, the bills would protect parents, including adoptive parents, who take maternity or paternity leaves. Under the bills, absences during the year or the year after a child is born would not constitute a break in service for pension purposes. **********The legislation would also allow women, who tend to enter the work force earlier than men, to join private pension plans and get credit for their work at a younger age. Workers would be allowed to participate in plans at age 21 rather than the current limit of 25. Credit for vesting (or the right to a pension after a certain number of years even if you leave your job before retirement) would begin at age 18 instead of 22. **********Third, the bills would provide survivors' benefits to women whose husbands die before reaching the earliest retirement age under their company's plan. Currently, women whose husbands die before reaching early-retirement age, usually 55, receive no pensions at all, even if their husbands had worked for the company for 25 or 30 years. **********THE three bills would ''lock in'' pension benefits for survivors at a much earlier age, although the starting times for such protection differ. Under the Senate bill, benefits would be payable once a worker reached age 45 with 10 years of service; under the House Labor Committee bill, at any age after 10 years of service, and under the House Ways and Means bill, at any age once a person had a vested right to his pension. **********Some pension consultants contend that the benefits afforded by this proposal are so small that they are meaningless. ''It's a very trivial form of protection,'' maintained Lloyd S. Kaye, a principal with Mercer-Meidinger. ''Survivors' benefits are not worth very much, even at age 55 with a substantial amount of service.'' **********He gave the example of a husband with 20 years of service to a company, who dies and leaves a wife five years younger than he. ''We're usually talking about a survivor annuity of 5 to 10 percent of the employee's annual compensation,'' he said. ''It's not nothing, but it's not much more than chopped liver.'' **********But some pension experts disagree. Anne E. Moss, director of the the women's pension project at the Pension Rights Center in Washington, estimated that the provision would provide benefits to some 70,000 women over a five-year period - ''a whole class of women who never received them before.'' **********The bill ''will make a dramatic difference'' to those it does help, said an aide to the House Subcommittee on Labor-Management Relations. ''Our files are replete with letters from women whose husbands died weeks, days or hours before turning 55. For such women, it will mean a difference between nothing and something.'' Finally, all three bills would codify the differing state rules regarding the right of a divorced spouse to an ex-mate's pension when the worker is in arrears on alimony or child support. **********Most pension experts agree that many more changes are needed before women's pensions are on a par with men's, but they differ on the prescription. ''My own feeling is that women's pensions are much smaller than men's because of the types of jobs they take, but that's a salary issue and we can't solve that here,'' said Miss Block.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/15/busin.main_headline: Ex-First Chicago Chief Starts Own Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Ex-First Chicago Chief Starts Own Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/15/busin.body_text: **********Wherever A. Robert Abboud has worked, he has created a stir. Best known for his exits from the chairmanship of the First Chicago Corporation in 1980 and the presidency of the Occidental Petroleum Company this August, Mr. Abboud is now beginning his own investment company in a suburban Chicago office complex. **********A. Robert Abboud & Company will be involved in transactions that are ''fun, friendly and professional,'' said Mr. Abboud in a telephone interview. **********He said he would be going after business in leveraged buyouts, corporate restructurings, employee stock ownership plans and refinancing plans. **********While admitting he had ''honest differences in policy'' with Dr. Armand Hammer, Occidental's chairman, Mr. Abboud stressed that his departure from the oil company was entirely voluntary. Mr. Abboud has a $500,000-a-year consulting contract with Occidental that lasts until 1988. **********He added that the impetus to start his own business came from meeting entrepreneurs on the West Coast whom he admired greatly. ''I decided that at 55, I'd like to jump in the water and give it a try,'' Mr. Abboud said. **********Mr. Abboud's business career began as a management trainee at the First National Bank of Chicago in 1958. He rose through the ranks, working in almost every phase of banking, to assume the chairmanship in 1975. **********''I had no advantage, no money and no family connection,'' Mr. Abboud recalled. His tenure as chairman was marked by efforts to pare troubled loans and restore First Chicago's tarnished reputation. **********Mr. Abboud said he ws forced out in 1980 because ''the board wanted a more expansive loan strategy and I didn't want to do it.'' He said, ''I wasn't going to chase the Continental,'' referring to the Continental Illinois Corporation. **********Mr. Abboud, a native of Boston, received a B.S. degree in 1951 from Harvard College. Then, between 195l and 1953, he served as a Marine platoon leader and company commander in Korea. He received a law degree from Harvard in 1956 and an M.B.A. in 1958, also from Harvard.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/08/world.main_headline: A TRIM TORONTO DEBATES SHAPE OF THINGS TO COME
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/08/world.print_headline: A TRIM TORONTO DEBATES SHAPE OF THINGS TO COME
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/08/world.body_text: **********Jane Jacobs, one of the world's most respected experts on cities, moved to Toronto from New York in the late 1960's and delivered this observation: ''Here is the most hopeful and healthy city in North America, still unmangled, still with options.'' **********Toronto has since become the largest city in Canada and the nation's financial capital. But even as it grew into a metropolitan center of more than three million people, it clung tenaciously to a modest sense of scale. **********When growth threatened to spurt uncontrollably a decade ago, the city put a two-year moratorium on the construction of buildings taller than 45 feet. Residents have repeatedly succeeded in stopping the building of expressways and other big developments; inner-city housing has grown even faster than the metallic skyline, and the St. Lawrence neighborhood, where groups ranging from labor unions to Soviet emigres have joined to form low-cost housing cooperatives on an abandoned industrial site, has drawn worldwide recognition. **********'A World-Class Way' **********But what Walt Whitman, after a visit in 1880, called ''a lively, dashing place'' is today perched on the brink of a new kind of future, even as it celebrates its 150th birthday this year. The talk is grand, and the plans grander: a domed stadium, giant office complexes, a monorail. The goal, Mayor Arthur Eggleton says, is to grow ''in a world- class way.'' **********The centerpiece of the Mayor's plans is his proposal to turn land now occupied by railroad tracks into an enormous real estate development. In the next 20 years, billions of dollars would be spent to create new office space for 40,000 to 50,000 workers and thousands of new housing units. There would also be parks and recreation and cultural centers. **********The proposal combines a convention center and hotel now being built, a new headquarters for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and continued building along the waterfront. **********''A boom city idea is beginning to take hold,'' Jack Layton, an alderman, said.   The Project Has Critics **********Critics, including Mr. Layton, say they believe the project is antithetical to the sort of measured growth that once prompted the United States Committee on Economic Development to urge American cities to be guided by ''the Toronto experience.'' **********Among other things, foes say that the development ignores the interests of 10,000 Toronto families in urgent need of public housing, that it would lead to the building of more freeways and that all the offices are not needed anyway. If they are, the critics say, they should be built elsewhere. **********Opponents say the project's biggest weakness is that much of the housing construction will not be completed until perhaps 1995, if ever. They contend that housing should be built first, arguing that since the need for housing is greater than for offices - the commercial vacancy rate is already high - more immediate jobs would result. **********Opposition is strong, reflected by the fact that 53 of 60 people who testified in public hearings opposed the proposal. **********''Do we want to be Dallas?'' said John Sewell, a former Mayor who opposes the project. ''If Toronto is successful, it's because we worried about the people who lived here, not our image.'' **********Mrs. Jacobs still lives in Toronto, but seldom appears in public and declines to talk to the press. Thus, no one is sure exactly what she thinks of the railway land development.   City Council Backs Plan **********The development, approved by the City Council in December but still requiring other regulatory approvals, parallels similar efforts in Vancouver, Calgary, Montreal and Halifax to convert under-used railway land to more economical purposes. **********In Toronto, removal of the tracks would serve an even more important purpose than simple economic advantage. The tracks effectively block the rest of the city from Lake Ontario, the geographic feature that Whitman said he thought gave Toronto its character. **********''You can say Lake Ontario is on the wrong side of the tracks,'' Mayor Eggleton said in an interview last week. He argued that his proposal would ''turn a barrier into a gateway,'' opening up ''a new frontier.'' **********His enthusiasm is matched by the two railroad companies - Canadian Pacific Ltd., Canada's biggest company, and Canadian National Railways, owned by the Government - that are putting up the land. The companies, in turn, would be allowed to develop the real estate.   Railway Station Will Remain **********Significantly, opponents may have a more difficult time this round. Their earlier success was mainly a result of concern over historic Union Station, which would have been demolished under the first proposal but not under the latest one. Most council votes have favored development by a 15-to-8 vote. **********Still, Mr. Sewell, the former Mayor, suggests that opponents can use various regulatory forums to cause the project to be halted. The way things are accomplished in Toronto, he said, is for all factions to hold seemingly endless meetings, laboriously striving toward a consensus, as was done in planning the St. Lawrence neighborhood a decade ago. Instead, Mayor Eggleton announced the project, illustrating his remarks with an elaborate scale model.   A Matter of Process **********''We've got far past that in Toronto politics,'' Mr. Sewell said. ''People will say: 'You've excluded us. We'll get you!' '' **********Indeed, many of the opponents' concerns seem to be as much over process as substance. In the 1970's, Toronto developed a broad plan gearing development to decentralized conglomerations of office buildings along public transportation lines. The idea was to ease pressure on commercial development in the core, while encouraging people to live there. **********Planners agree that the concept is beginning to work. The worry now is that extensive railway lands development will again crowd people downtown, reversing hard-won gains. **********The Mayor's thinking is that as the project goes ahead, specific problems can be addressed. He appears to have considerable support, even from some of his public opponents. **********Walter Majeski, the president of the Labor Council of Metropolitan Toronto, politically supports the project's opponents. His bottom line, however, is clear. ''In the final analysis,'' he said, ''we'll support it, because it does create jobs.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/world.main_headline: SPACE ARMS: DEBATE OVER VALUE OF A TREATY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/world.print_headline: SPACE ARMS: DEBATE OVER VALUE OF A TREATY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/world.body_text: **********A dispute within the Reagan Administration over whether an antisatellite weapons pact with the Soviet Union can be verified appears to be clouded by two factors: the parties to the argument within the Government are talking about different kinds of treaties, and they are governed by different motives. **********The argument within the Administration is proceeding against the background of a dispute between the United States and the Soviet Union over the topics to be discussed at a meeting on space weapons that the Russians proposed to be held in Vienna in September. **********President Reagan indicated a willingness to accept, but reserved the right to bring up other subjects as well, such as the discussions on medium- range and strategic nuclear missiles that were interrupted last year. **********The Soviet Union has accused the United States of setting preconditions for the proposed talks, and has said that there will be no meeting unless the two sides agree beforehand on what is to be discussed. **********Although the United States has yet to reach a bargaining position for negotiations on space weapons, some influential officials are expected to insist that any treaty at most only limit, rather than halt, the development of antisatellite weapons. When these officials say that a treaty cannot be verified, they are speaking of one that would ban possession of such weapons.   Scientists Favor a Treaty **********Advocates of a treaty include American scientists banded together in such groups as the Union of Concerned Scientists and the Federation of American Scienists, scientists acting in their own capacity, and a number of, mostly Democratic, members of Congress. **********These advocates agree that a ban on possession is probably impossible to verify. However, they want an accord that would prohibit testing of antisatellite weapons in space and deployment on the ground. **********A prohibition of testing and deployment, these advocates argue, would be verifiable, and would halt weapon development. **********Understanding the debate depends, in part, on some knowledge of the progress the United States and the Soviet Union have made in the development of these weapons and their longe- range goals. **********United States officials detected 20 tests of a Soviet ground-launched antisatellite weapon system between 1968 and 1982. American officials believe that 45 percent of these tests were successful. However, the more advanced modifications in the system that would make it more difficult to foil with American countermeasures have failed. The Soviet weapon is launched from the ground by a 150-foot intercontinental ballistic missile and, in its only successful configuration, must make two earth orbits to approach its target, an undesirable system militarily. **********The United States is now developing a more advanced weapon that permits direct ascent to the target within a matter of minutes. It consists of a small, 18-foot rocket launched from an F-15 fighter plane. There was a test of the rockets in January, but it will not be tested against a space target until late this year. Both nations' weapons can now reach only low earth orbit targets, which makes many valuable satellites immune. **********The warhead of the American weapon is a cylinder only about 11 inches in diameter and 11 inches in length. The warhead of the Soviet weapon, discounting the 150-foot booster rocket, is slightly more than 18 feet long and weighs about 4,500 pounds. **********The United States reportedly plans to build 112 antisatellite weapons, to be stationed at two F-15 wings near Washington, D.C., and in Washington State. However, a special modification kit would permit any F-15 to be converted to an launcher within six hours and any jet airfield could become a base. **********Advocates of a treaty counter arguments about verification problems by saying that if the United States weapon is fully developed, Soviet verification of United States treaty compliance would become impossible because of the relatively small size of the rocket and almost minute size of the warhead, as well as its potential deployment on any airfield.   Problems of Concealment **********But such advocates tend to agree that the 4,500 pound Soviet warhead could probably be concealed also. Such figures as Richard L. Garwin and Kurt Gottfried, two physicists who recommend a treaty, say that a treaty that prohibited space testing and ground deployment would work to the United States' advantage. They say that satellites could readily identify the deployment of the 150-foot Soviet launchers and other sensors could catch any test against a target in space. **********These and other figures argue that the present Soviet weapon is not really capable and could not be used in a conflict without further testing. **********Administration officials, on the other hand, have consistently described the Soviet weapon as already ''operational.'' **********As for motives, they have made clear that they want no treaty that would halt the development of a promising, probably superior, United States weapon. One suggestion is that they might recommend to President Reagan a treaty limiting the altitude of antisatellite weapons to low orbit targets, but no more.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/12/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission repealed a rule today that was intended to prevent broadcasters from building a monopoly in a specific region of the country. The agency, by a 4-to-1 vote, agreed with its staff that the so-called regional concentration rule was arbitrary and unnecessary given other existing ownership restrictions. **********The rule, adopted in 1977, essentially limited the number of radio or TV stations a single company or individual could own within a 100-mile area. It specified a broadcaster could not own three stations - radio or TV - if the service areas of two of the stations overlapped and the third was within 100 miles of the others. Current local ownership standards still prohibit the ownership of two AM or two FM or two TV stations in the same area, bar the ownership of a local TV station and cable TV system in the same city, prohibit the purchase of a broadcast station and daily newspaper in the same city and bar the purchase of radio and TV stations in the same city.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/31/busin.print_headline: CHIEF EXECUTIVE AT LILCO RESIGNS; SHOREHAM STANCE WAS CRITICIZED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/31/busin.body_text: **********Charles R. Pierce resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the Long Island Lighting Company. No reason was given, but recent reports had indicated that the company's directors were displeased at his handling of problems with Lilco's $4 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant. **********Mr. Pierce, who is 61 years old, will be replaced by William J. Catacosinos, a Long Island computer executive who has been a member of Lilco's board for six years. Mr. Pierce's resignation was accepted yesterday at a meeting of Lilco's board in Mineola, L.I. **********Mr. Pierce resigned when state and local officials and the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission are approaching crucial decisions on whether to approve operating licenses for the nearly completed Shoreham plant and how much Lilco should charge for its electricity. **********The Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, one of Lilco's harshest critics, said he hoped the changes would mean a ''fresh look and a new approach to the Shoreham problem.'' **********A board member who asked not to be identified said last week that while the directors admired Mr. Pierce's leadership, they felt his tough stance on Shoreham and his refusal to compromise with critics had eliminated any possibility of settling the issues that stand in the way of the plant's opening. **********The board member also said the board's displeasure was compounded earlier this month when Lilco decided to withhold more than $26.2 million in property tax payments to Suffolk County and the Town of Brookhaven, in which Shoreham is situated. **********Late last year, reports said, the board went so far as to ask Mr. Pierce, whose salary was $215,000 a year, to leave one of its meetings. **********Other reports indicated that Mr. Pierce had offered to resign last year, but no action was taken.  The Shoreham project, the most ex pensive in the country, has suffered repeated technical setbacks, the most recent being the failure of the emergency diesel generators that must be approved before the plant can obtain the operating license. Last year the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Lilco had improperly tested the generators and fined the utility $40,000. **********The 809-megawatt reactor, 55 miles from Times Square on a bluff overlooking Long Island Sound, is more than 10 years behind schedule and more than 15 times over budget. Lilco has proposed increasing its rates by as much as 56 percent to cover the $4 billion cost of Shoreham. **********Shoreham's cost overruns have led to speculation that Lilco might be unable to continue paying dividends to its shareholders, and while Mr. Pierce and other Lilco executives have denied mismanaging the project, some brokerage houses have rated Lilco's stock speculative and have advised their clients to sell it. **********Regulatory Requirements Cited **********Mr. Pierce had long attributed Shoreham's problems to regulatory, construction and financial requirements that he considered unnecessarily stringent, as well as to design changes resulting from ''the lessons learned from Three Mile Island.'' That was the site of the power plant near Harrisburg, Pa., where a nuclear accident occurred in 1979.  In a two-sentence statement, Lilco's 11 directors said: ''We are deeply grateful to Charles Pierce for his dedicated service to Lilco throughout his 34-year association with the company. We express our sincere admiration and appreciation for his past leadership.'' **********Members of the board declined to discuss their deliberations yesterday and Jan K. Hickman, a company spokesman, refused to relay requests for interviews to Mr. Pierce or Mr. Catacosinos. She said Mr. Catacosinos would outline his plans for Lilco at a news conference on Feb. 8. **********She said the rest of Lilco's management team was unaffected by the changes.  Mr. Cohalan, the Suffolk County Executive, said, ''It seems that this is an opportunity for all of us to sit together to begin to hash out the economic solution that everyone recognizes must come about with respect to the Shoreham nuclear power plant.'' **********Analysts' Concerns **********But some utility analysts were concerned that the changes did not come soon enough. **********''If they had done this five years ago, it probably would have been a good move,'' said Charles Komanoff, a Manhattan economist who specializes in utility rates and who has been critical of Lilco. **********He added, ''I think the company has suffered from a kind of insularity, where everybody in a top managerial position throughout the whole Shoreham episode has been with the company and only with the company for a very long period of time.'' **********Mr. Pierce, who was a World War II bomber pilot, joined Lilco's legal department in 1949, shortly after he received his law degree from Columbia University. He was named president and a director in 1974 and chairman in 1978. **********Over the years he earned a reputation for smoothing the way for power plants that local residents did not want in their backyards. He also gained public recognition in 1982 and 1983 by making strongly worded radio commercials in favor of Shoreham. **********Mr. Catacosinos began working by sweeping and mopping floors in his father's grocery store in Harlem. Thirty years later, in 1969, he founded Applied Digital Data Systems Inc. in Hauppauge, L.I., and sometimes found himself sweeping floors again as he worked to get the company off the ground. **********Applied Digital lost $2.2 million in its first three years. But Mr. Catacosinos pledged his home and cars to guarantee a $350,000 loan to the struggling company, which grew to be a profitable manufacturer of computer terminals. In 1980 the NCR Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, bought it for $60.5 million. **********Mr. Catacosinos was also a founder of Corometrics Medical Systems Inc., which was sold to American Home Products in 1974 for $20 million, a deal that netted Mr. Catacosinos $2 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/13/world.body_text: **********Cameroon Says 70 Died In Attempt at Coup **********ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, April 12 (AP) - Cameroon said tonight that 70 people were killed and 51 wounded last week in an unsuccessful attempt by part of the presidential palace guard to take over the West African nation. **********The Government communique was read over the Yaounde radio and monitored here. In an earlier broadcast today, the radio announced that President Paul Biya had disbanded the elite palace guard. **********The communique said eight loyal guards and four civilians were among the dead. It said 1,053 rebels were taken prisoner and one was still at large. Western diplomats have indicated the death toll could be much higher.
