https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/13/world.print_headline: GUERRILLAS' THREATS CRIPPLE ROAD TRAVEL IN MUCH OF SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/13/world.body_text: **********Leftist guerrillas crippled traffic across most of El Salvador today by threatening to destroy vehicles caught on the highways, the authorities said. **********In another development, the United States Embassy denied visas to four Salvadoran women to visit Washington to receive the Robert F. Kennedy Prize for their human rights work, spokesmen said. **********A bomb destroyed a pickup truck of the Government-owned telephone company as a crew was working on phone lines in western San Salvador, the police said. The explosion went off about two blocks from the Camino Real Hotel, which houses offices for most American news organizations that cover the war in El Salvador. **********The police said no deaths or injuries were reported in the explosion. **********The rebels' new sabotage campaign halted public transportation between San Salvador and the nation's four easternmost provinces, bus dispatchers said. **********Radio Venceremos, a guerrilla shortwave station, repeated warnings today that drivers should stay off highways. Rebels had been announcing the sabotage campaign since Saturday. **********The four women denied United States visas represent an organization called the Committee of Mothers and Relatives of Political Prisoners Disappeared and Murdered of El Salvador. They were to receive the prize on Nov. 20 in Washington. **********Maria Teresa de Canales, one of the four women, said an embassy employee told the women the visas were denied because the women could ''put the security of the United States in danger and that our visit could have links with anarchist or Communist parties.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/06/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;  $200 Million Issue From Sallie Mae
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/06/busin.body_text: **********The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, announced that it is selling $200 million of floating rate notes due Sept. 16, 1984, through various dealers. **********Interest on the notes will be paid at maturity, but the rate will be adjusted weekly to 15 basis points above the average bond equivalent yield set at the weekly auction of 91-day Treausry bills. Based on yesterday's bill auction, the interest rate for the first week is 9.74 percent. **********A similar issue sold last month was also priced at 15 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above the bond equivalent yield of 91-day Treasury bills.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/13/world.main_headline: HOW APARTHEID UPROOTS AND TRANSPLANTS MILLIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/13/world.print_headline: HOW APARTHEID UPROOTS AND TRANSPLANTS MILLIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/13/world.body_text: **********In parts of South Africa's brushlands, there stand, incongruously, row upon row of modest tin buildings, glimmering in the heat, morose sentinels of hard policies. **********The structures are outhouses, and they are the first things to be erected in some areas where South Africa's white authorities seek to relocate black people away from ''black spots'' - settlements encircled by white-owned land. **********Often, the outhouses far outnumber the windowless tin homes the authorities provide for resettled blacks and which the outhouses are supposed to serve. So those who monitor the involuntary resettlement of blacks count the outhouses, not the homes, to reach an estimate of how many people the Government ultimately wishes to resettle. **********Over the last 20 years, the tally has mounted to 3.5 million people prevailed upon by the authorities to leave ancestral lands and implant frail tendrils in new, unchosen places.   Successes for Civil Rights **********In recent months white civil rights groups appear to have scored some successes in slowing some resettlements, playing on the authorities' sensitivity to adverse publicity: television footage of bulldozers flattening homes, churches and schools does not, it is calculated, help South Africa's image. **********The victories, however, have been ambiguous, for they have not deflected the authorities from a policy designed to offset the arithmetical threat of the black majority by moving black people into what are called homelands: geographical creations of Pretoria's fashioning, in which blacks automatically cede South African citizenship and thus any legal claim to influence the nation's future. **********Moreover, civil rights workers concede, their victories apply only to those ''black spots'' that come to public attention, not to those where removal is enacted without public scrutiny. Even in those places where the authorities are temporarily restrained from evicting settled populations, the delay produces more anxiety about a fickle future than relief at a postponement of uncertain duration. **********Thus, at a place called Mathopestad, close to the town of Boons, 60 miles west of Johannesburg, a community ''has been living under the threat of removal for years,'' according to a white civil rights worker from an organization called Black Sash. The authorities, and the people there, know removal is scheduled, but no one will say when it will take place.   Resistance Is Scattered **********At Magopa, 30 miles to the southwest, some of the 300 families resisted a Government edict ordering them to move late last year. The rebellious villagers, whose ancestors bought the land 70 years ago, are still at Magopa, clinging, despite the bulldozing of schools and churches after some of their clanspeople left and resettled where the Government instructed.  On Wednesday 300 families at a place called Badplaas refused to leave their homes in the Eastern Transvaal, 200 miles east of Johannesburg, a region associated by most whites with vacations in the hills, trout fishing and mineral spas. **********The authorities had given them until Wednesday to move or face eviction. They did not move, indeed vowed to stay on, and they were not forcibly removed, apparently because activists had been able to publicize their plight. **********Their case, thus, is pending, somewhere in the void between official intent and official action. In the temporary standoff, black resistance faces attrition, for the threat of eviction is not removed. All in all, Black Sash officials said, some two million blacks are still on the Government's waiting list for removal.   13 Percent of the Land **********Critics dispute the process by which millions of blacks will be herded into the 13 percent of South Africa's surface area that forms the homelands. **********But in the logic that obtains here, a senior official said that if black-ruled Africa's great showcase of democracy - Nigeria - could not survive, why should one man, one vote fare any better in, or be urged upon, South Africa? **********The arguments derive from the ideology of apartheid, which holds that those of differing skin pigmentation, and even those of the same color but of different tribe, must be kept apart. **********At Badplaas the justification for the eviction is derived from a law stipulating that blacks with certain rights may only reside in what are called ''prescribed areas.'' Badplaas is, indeed, a prescribed area. But, under a related law, blacks must also live in areas formally proclaimed as townships. The Badplaas settlement has not been proclaimed a township, despite the fact that the people have lived there since the end of the 19th century, because the Government chooses not to do so. Their residence, thus, is deemed illegal. **********The authorities want to move them to another place 20 miles away that lies, by the Government's cartography, not in South Africa itself but in KaNgwane, the ''homeland'' set aside for people of Swazi descent, an entity recognized only by Pretoria.  Poor Opinion of 'Homelands' **********The leader of the Badplaas families is Chief Johannes Dhlamini, who is also the chairman of the Swazi Council of Chiefs in South Africa. He would not, it seems from interviews, oppose the incorporation of Badplaas into Swaziland, the recognized, independent kingdom that lies close by, from which he claims ancestry. But he does not want to move away from his ancestral lands and he does not want to go to a homeland. Life in the homelands is viewed as hard. **********His opposition to the eviction, assisted by Black Sash activists, was made easier by what may be an irredeemable flaw in the authorities' own tactics. When the Government served eviction orders, they set a deadline for departure. The deadline, in turn, enabled Chief Dhlamini to determine the day to invite the press along as a deterrent to the authorities. **********A Black Sash worker said that, in the past, the authorities used deadlines as a way to intimidate people into moving ''voluntarily'' instead of awaiting eviction. Now that the deadlines had effectively become a tipoff for activists, the Black Sash worker said, civil rights workers feared the authorities would enforce their will without advance notice. **********The people at Badplaas are required to move to one of three farms in KaNgwane. At one of them, the authorities have built 75 tin homes whose walls are too hot to touch at midday. But that may not fully represent the Government's long-term plan for the place. Beyond the 75 homes the rows of outhouses march resolutely on, as far as the eye can see.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/06/busin.body_text: **********The Defense Department says it is ''pressing hard'' to encourage developing countries to purchase fighter planes that are made specifically for export and are relatively cheap to buy and easy to maintain. **********At the same time, department officials conceded in Congressional testimony last week that not one of these FX, or fighter export, aircraft has been sold. Instead, they said, in the last three years the United States has sold 1,100 of the more complex and expensive jet fighters now used by the Air Force and Navy. **********By some estimates the market for export fighter planes could reach $30 billion or more in the next few years because of the need of many foreign countries to replace their aging air forces. **********The Northrop Corporation, which will have spent more than a quarter of a billion dollars by the end of the year on one such export fighter, The F-20 Tigershark, complains that Government efforts to promote FX sales have been ''notably lacking.'' **********Several members of the Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs of the House Foreign Affairs Committee have also been critical of the Administration's efforts. **********Despite the stated policy, the Administration overturned longstanding United States practices and began in 1981 to sell so-called inventory jet fighters, specifically General Dynamics' F-16 and McDonnell Douglas's F-15 and F-18 planes, to some less developed nations. Before that, Northrop's F-5 Freedom Fighter, made specifically for export, was the plane sold primarily to foreign countries. **********William Schneider Jr., the Under Secretary of State for Security Assistance, told the House panel that once Washington began making exceptions to established policy, the acquisition of United States ''inventory'' aircraft became a matter of prestige among the leaders of third- world countries. The result, he said, was that marketing efforts by the makers of two FX fighters ''have met stiff resistance.'' **********Mr. Schneider testified, however, that the United States would now begin what he called ''comparative briefings'' to foreign governments, pointing out the benefits and superiorities of an FX fighter force over the costly, hard-to-maintain planes in use by the United States.  He conceded that until now the Government had been reluctant to offer such advice to some countries on the ground that they were the best judge of their own security needs. **********Two aircraft have been officially designated export fighters, or FX's, by the Air Force. One is Northrop's Tigershark, the first combat aircraft wholly designed and financed by a private company in 32 years. **********The other is the F-16/J79, built by the General Dynamics Corporation. It has the same airframe as the Air Force's F-16, but has an older engine and fewer electronic refinements than the two models of standard F-16's. **********Big Market Seen **********For Northrop and General Dynamics a pro-FX effort by the Administration could produce a lot of business. ''What is really at stake is a competition among the aerospace companies for a market of at least $30 billion, but maybe much more, in the next few years,'' said a Government official, who asked not to be identified. **********For example, about 2,500 relatively simple F-5 Freedom Fighters, which have been built since 1964 by Northrop and sold to many countries, are now aging and will need to be replaced, along with other aircraft nearing obsolescence in foreign air forces. **********The breakdown of the FX policy has been more frustrating for Northrop than for other aircraft companies, because it has all but eliminated its foreign sales. **********General Dynamics, on the other hand, has sold F-16's to Pakistan, Venezuela, South Korea and Turkey. And McDonnell Douglas has sold its new Navy fighter, the F-18, to Spain, Canada and Australia, and previously sold 52 of its F-15's to Saudi Arabia. **********Singapore's Plans **********The small island nation of Singapore recently expressed an intent to buy eight F-16/J79's, but officials said that if Washington ultimately agreed to sell Thailand and the Philippines the regular F-16's, which they are requesting, Singapore would probably ask for the same treatment. **********Northrop's inability to sell any F-20's does not appear to be related to any shortcomings in the combat capability of the aircraft. In fact, the Administration refused permission for its sale in two potentially lucrative markets, Taiwan and India, on the ground that it was too good. **********Its high performance was believed unacceptable to the Chinese Communist Government for sale to Taiwan, and the Air Force refuses to permit the F-20's advanced combat electronics to go to India, where there are ''too many Russians.'' **********''What Northrop is doing is the best I've ever seen,'' the Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. Charles A. Gabriel, told the House Appropriations Committee last month. **********A Key Problem **********Both Government officials and Northrop executives agree that a major problem inhibiting purchase of the F-20 is that foreign leaders conclude that because the Air Force has no plans to buy any F-20's it must not be as good as inventory airplanes. **********Brig. Gen. Thomas Baker, the Air Force FX program manager, told the committee that the Air Force did not plan to buy the F-20 in part because it was not designed to have exceptionally long range and thus did not meet Air Force requirements for ''worldwide commitments.'' **********Thomas V. Jones, the chairman of Northrop, said that less developed countries, on the other hand, did not need long-range fighter planes because ''their enemies are so near.'' **********Northrop argues that the F-20 has a faster ''scramble,'' or takeoff time, than other fighters, and generates more daily flights because of its reliabililty and ease of maintenance. General Baker testified that ''we find the Northrop numbers very reasonable'' on such factors. **********Another Explanation **********Despite General Baker's brief explanation, another Pentagon official, who did not want to be identified, said that both the Air Force and the Navy had preferred to promote sales of their own fighters to ''amortize costs and to keep production lines open.'' **********This official and other authorities said that the Pentagon ''procurement community'' disliked privately designed aircraft, like the F-20, no matter how capable. **********Mr. Jones of Northrop testified that the corporation believed that no real attempt had been made to promote the F-20, and said that ''passive approval'' of the aircraft would not overcome the urge for prestige among third-world buyers. The Northrop chairman said that the White House should order the Air Force to tell other governments of the low costs and high performance of the plane. **********The testimony of Mr. Schneider and conversations with other officials made clear that one reason the Administration had not strongly pressed foreign governments to buy FX rather than inventory aircraft was the determination by the Reagan Administration in 1981 to stress what it perceived as a strong increase in the ''threat'' posed by the Soviet Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/24/busin.main_headline: Chrysler Rebounds In Quarter and Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/24/busin.print_headline: Chrysler Rebounds In Quarter and Year
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/24/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation reported today that it earned $118.3 million, or 91 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1983 and a record $700.9 million, or $5.79 a share, for the year. **********Chrysler said the sharply improved results came despite a $223.9 million write-off to reflect the declining value of its 15 percent stake in P.S.A. Peugeot-Citroen, the financially troubled French automaker. **********In 1982, Chrysler posted a fourth-quarter loss of $96.1 million. For the year, it earned $170.1 million, or $1.84 a share, but only with the aid of a one-time $239 million gain from the sale of tank-making operations. **********Sales for the quarter rose 70.6 percent from a year earlier, to $3.77 billion, from $2.21 billion. Full-year sales rose 31.8 percent, to $13.24 billion, from $10.04 billion in 1982. **********Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, called 1983 a year of "dramatic" improvement. "Chrysler won its long battle for independence in 1983," he said. **********With the Chrysler report came confirmation that 1983 was a record year for the domestic auto industry. The four big Unite States-based companies together posted an aggregate profit of $6.15 billion, or nearly $1 billion more than the previous record of $5.2 billion set in 1977. **********The four Companies - General Motors, Ford, Chrysler and American Motors - also posted record earnings for the quarter: $2.43 billion, vs. $1.73 billion in the second quarter of 1977, the previous quarterly record. **********But analysts noted that the domestic industry has been protected by restraints on the import of Japanese cars, which has permitted them to end rebate programs and effectively increase car prices and margins. **********Analysts predicted that Chrysler, which skirted bankruptcy several times in 1980 and 1981, could earn as much as $2 billion in 1984. Record 1984 Earnings Seen **********"As good as 1983 was, the numbers will look anemic compared to 1984," said Scott Merlis, an analyst with Shearson/American Express. **********He pointed out that Chrysler produced its record 1983 profit on unit sales of only 1,493,961. The auto maker's previous record profit - $422.6 million in 1976 - came on sales of 2,370,509 units. **********Chrysler's earnings for the year were helped by a tax credit of $399 million, carried forward from the $3.5 billion the company lost during the slump in auto sales that lasted from mid-1979 through late 1982. Robert S. Miller, Chrysler's executive vice president for finance, said the company still had available for use $1.6 billion in tax loss carry-forwards, plus $260 million in unused investment tax credits, which all but assures that the company will not pay taxes this year. **********Chrysler wrote down the value of its Peugeot stock, which it received in exchange for its European operations in the 1970's, on the recommendation of its auditors, Mr. Iacocca said. As a result, the auditor, Touch Ross & Company, gave the company a "clean" opinion on its financial statement, eliminating the qualifications included in recent years. **********Chrysler's return to prosperity will be reflected in its executives' paychecks. The company has earmarked a $52 million bonus pool for the 1,300 executives eligible, or an average of about $40,000 each. Most Chrysler executives had their pay frozen when the company had federally backed loans outstanding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/16/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; HOME BUILDING ISSUES ADVANCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/16/busin.body_text: **********-term interest rates generally easing, some analysts are suggesting that investors take a closer look at home building stocks, a sector that has been bubbling since the rate decline began to accelerate near the end of June. **********''We believe long-term interest rates will continue to come down over the remainder of the year and that between now and the end of the year short- term interest rates also will come down,'' said David Wilson, first vice president-research at Shearson Lehman/American Express. ''Clearly this is positive for home building stocks on a short- term basis.'' **********The amelioration of interest levels, which really began in May, and the eventual frenetic stock market rally have indeed been a boon for several home building stocks. Some have risen as much as 20 percent above their recent lows, and many analysts feel those issues could climb another 20 percent over the short term, should interest rates continue to fall. **********On Monday, for example, the Veterans Administration lowered its rate ceiling on basic home loans to 13 1/2 percent from 14 percent. **********The ''bulls'' maintain that over the long haul, say 18 to 24 months, prices of some home building stocks could easily double. With economic growth likely to slow by that time, they reason, interest rates should decline further, setting the stage for another strong housing cycle. **********All the same, even the most optimistic analysts stress the inherent vulnerability of home building equities. Indeed, the long-term rates have just jogged a bit upward, a development that some analysts expect will be short-lived.  And then, of course, there was last year's sudden turn, a catastrophe investors in home building are not likely to forget. The stocks surged to all-time highs in mid-May 1983. Then the prices of several of the better-known issues plummeted more than 70 percent and are still down in excess of 50 percent from their highs of 1983. The drop was precipitated by a pervasive rise in interest rates that many experts felt might bring the home building boom to an end. **********More recently, although some of the home building stocks have made impressive gains, traditional uncertainty over the course of rates has caused many analysts to lower their short- and long-term earnings estimates. **********Mr. Wilson of Shearson Lehman noted that while home building stocks tend to be very volatile - moving inversely with interest rates - there is relatively litle opportunity to hedge because only U.S. Home has options. He added that the investor could, of course, always sell another home building stock short to protect profits. **********At least for the moment, however, a sense of optimism has returned to the home building sector. ''A continuation of the bond market rally would permit a further increase off the lows for selected home building issues,'' said Michael Millman, senior vice president at L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin. ''In the next interest-rate driven cycle, these stocks have the potential to more than double from current levels.'' **********He believes certain home building stocks should be scrutinized because of their long-term potential and because they are attractively priced relative to the value of their assets. **********A comparison of stock prices yesterday with those in a June 22 report issued by L.F. Rothschild shows how four stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange have climbed: **********- The Centex Corporation, with headquarters in Dallas, is a major factor in real estate development, residential and nonresidential construction and related activities. The stock, trading at about 24 5/8 on June 21, closed yesterday at 25 1/2. **********- The Ryland Group Inc. is a large builder of moderately priced on-site and factory-built single- family homes based in Columbia, Md. Ryland has risen from 14 1/2 to close yesterday at 17 5/8. **********- Ryan Homes Inc., a major Pittsburgh-based builder of on-site homes in 10 Eastern states, was selling at 19 3/4 on June 21. Yesterday, Ryan closed at 22 3/8. **********- The U.S. Home Corporation, the country's largest home builder, with on-site housing sales of nearly $1 billion, sold at 5 7/8 on June 21 and closed yesterday at 6 7/8. **********Analysts say other stocks that investors might consider include the Pulte Home Corporation, a large builder of moderately priced single-family homes, town houses and condominiums based in West Bloomfield, Mich., as well as Hovnanian Enterprises, the Lennar Corporation, the M.D.C. Corporation, the Presley Companies and the Standard Pacific Corporation. **********Also benefiting from the present easing of long- term rates are producers of manufactured housing, where prices range as low as $10,000. This group includes such companies as Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. and Ocilla Industries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/05/world.main_headline: TALK OF NEW VOTING RULES STIRS FEAR IN BRAZIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/05/world.print_headline: TALK OF NEW VOTING RULES STIRS FEAR IN BRAZIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/05/world.body_text: **********Brazil's departing military Government is studying possible changes in the rules for indirect presidential elections next January, and some politicians and commentators fear that the aim is to frustrate an opposition victory. **********Speculation about the changes has alarmed the opposition and spawned rumors of an impending coup - not against President Joao Baptista Figueiredo, but against moves to return the country to democracy after two decades of military rule. **********''Coups aren't proclaimed, they are carried out,'' said Jose de Magalhaes Pinto, a Government party deputy who, as Governor of Minas Gerais, played a key role in the 1964 coup. ''And if I had power in the my hands,'' he said, ''I would carry one out now.'' **********For the first time since General Figueiredo promised in 1979 ''to make this country a democracy,'' Brazilian newspapers are also talking openly about a coup. In Jornal do Brasil, the respected columnist, Carlos Castello Branco, has described the ruling group as ''restive and insecure.''  Extension of Term Suggested **********The scenarios so far discussed in public have included extension of General Figueiredo's six-year term and replacement of the official nominee, Paulo Salim Maluf. There is also talk of requiring members of the Electoral College, who will pick the next president on Jan. 15, to vote either in secret or along party lines. **********The irony is that the present succession rules were drawn up by the Government two years ago to guarantee the election of a pro-military civilian. Earlier this year, the Government refused to heed a widespread demand for immediate direct elections for fear that opposition parties would sweep to power. **********But while the governing Democratic Social Party enjoys a 36-seat majority in the 686-member Electoral College, defections in protest at Mr. Maluf's nomination have given the opposition candidate, Tancredo Neves, a seemingly unbeatable lead. At least 70 Congressmen and 35 state delegates to the College who belong to the governing party have switched sides.   Opposition Seen Likely to Win **********After it began to appear likely that Mr. Neves would win the presidency, even under the Government's rules, reports began circulating that changes in the rules were being prepared. **********Establishment of the principle of party loyalty in Electoral College voting could upset the opposition's calculations because 361 members of the College formally belong to the Democratic Social Party. Brazil's Supreme Court is expected to rule on the issue this week, although some opposition spokesmen believe their candidate could still win a majority of the votes cast if pro-Neves members of the governing party boycotted the College. **********Mr. Maluf, a wealthy 53-year-old former Governor of Sao Paulo, has also suggested replacing the planned roll- call vote with a secret ballot. The opposition fears this would enable Mr. Maluf - who has been accused of trying to buy support - to recover votes from some College members who would not back him publicly.   Some Officers Favor Changes **********Foreign diplomats here said moves to change the rules had the sympathy of several Army officers and civilians in top positions in the departing administration, including the Army Minister, General Walter Pires; the head of the Presidential Guard, General Newton Cruz; the chief of military intelligence, General Octavio Medeiros, and the Justice Minister, Ibrahim Abi-Ackel. **********The diplomats said these officials were anxious to prevent leftists from recovering political ground and were concerned that a Neves government might be unable to prevent investigations into allegations of corruption or human-rights abuses under recent military Governments. **********But the diplomats stressed that most senior generals opposed perpetuation of the military Government and could tolerate a victory by Mr. Neves, a 74- year-old former Governor of Minas Gerais who is an avowed anti-Communist and who has promised to preside over a moderate transitionary Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/09/world.body_text: **********Only about 30 deputies braved shelling and shooting in central Beirut to attend the meeting. The 99-seat Assembly requires a quorum of 46, so the Speaker, Kamel al Assad, postponed the session. **********A new date was not set. **********Radio stations of left- and right-wing factions said the grenades had been fired to intimidate deputies. **********Shells crashed into residential areas of both Moslem and Christian sectors of the city Wednesday night, and fighting continued throughout the day today. **********An official at Beirut Airport, which has been closed since early last month, said it might reopen on Friday, provided there was no new security threat. But the right-wing Lebanese Forces militia said it would oppose the reopening unless the safety of aircraft, passengers and airport staff could be firmly guaranteed. **********Meanwhile, leaders of Lebanon's warring factions worked out strategies for a second round of reconciliation talks due to begin Monday in Lausanne, Switzerland. **********Libya Restoring Relations **********TRIPOLI, Libya, March 8 (AP) - Libya said today that it was renewing diplomatic relations with Lebanon as a result of the cancellation of its troop withdrawal accord with Israel. **********Libya, a fierce opponent of Israel, froze relations with Lebanon after the agreement was signed last May 17. **********Lebanon announced Monday that it was cancelling the agreement, clearing the way for a Syrian-guaranteed cease-fire and reconciliation talks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Your excellent column, ''Third Party in a Divorce: The I.R.S.'' (Personal Finance, Jan. 15), fails to mention that significant changes in divorce-taxation rules are imminent. Part of the unfinished business of the last session of Congress, the Domestic Relations Tax Reform Act of 1983, contains divorce tax revision unopposed by the I.R.S., the White House and both sides of the aisle, and probably will be adopted in 1984. **********This bill would eliminate the **********Davis  rule by which transfer of appreciated property as part of a divorce settlement results in a capital gains liabiity to the transferor. Instead, the transfer would be treated as a gift. The **********Davis  rule has been a thorn in the side of many a divorce settlement negotiation and a trap for the unwary. It has been said that the divorce lawyer who doesn't know divorce taxation is engaging in malpractice. This reform is long overdue. Meanwhile, some pending settlement negotiations should be delayed to avoid capital gains taxes that probably will be eliminated by act of Congress before the end of 1984. **********Transfer of the family home to the custodial parent as part of the settlement will be facilitated when the I.R.S. no longer has a seat at the equitable distribution table. **********The pending legislation would make other important changes in divorce taxation, including the excessively complicated rules as to who may take the dependency exemptions for minor children. The new rule, if enacted, would give the custodial parent the right to take the dependency exemptions for the children regardless of the amount of child support being paid by the noncustodial parent, unless the custodial parent had waived the right in writing. The bill also would eliminate the ''periodic'' requirement in the definition of alimony. JOHN V. LONG Bethesda, Md., Jan. 17

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/04/busin.body_text: **********An appellate court is considering arguments presented Monday by Warner Communications Inc. and Polygram Records Inc. that their proposed merger could not monopolize the record industry because people who tape music at home keep the market competitive. **********The companies are asking the court to remove its preliminary injunction against the proposed merger of Warner, the second-largest distributor of recorded music in the United States, and Polygram, the fifth-largest. **********''Home taping has kept prices down 20 percent in real terms,'' Stuart Robinowitz, an attorney for Warner, said during Monday's hearing before the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. ''You can't have tacit collusion and raise prices'' because of the taping, he said. **********The case will be decided in September in a trial before an Federal Trade Commission administrative law judge in Washington. The F.T.C. opposes the merger, contending that it would create the largest recorded music distributor in the world, with the potential for monopolizing the $3.5 billion-a-year United States record industry. Merged, the companies would control 26 percent of that market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Strong demand for floating-rate notes in the Eurobond market has allowed Sweden to sell a $500 million issue with the longest maturity ever seen in the Euromarket and with a much lower interest rate than it paid last October. **********A reduction in syndicated bank loans has caused many investors such as banks, to invest in floating-rate note issues this year, analysts said. **********They added that floating-rate notes were especially attractive at a time when many investors are worried that interest rates might rise, and cause steep price declines on fixed-rate notes. **********Sweden's latest financing, which was handled by a Merrill Lynch Capital Markets group, pays interest at 1/8 percentage point above the London interbank offered rate for six-month Eurodollars, with a minimum of 5 1/4 percent. The notes may be called by Sweden after one year at a price of 100. The issue has a maturity of 40 years. **********The cost of the latest borrowing was well below what Sweden paid last October, when its $1 billion floating-rate issue due in 20 years was offered with an interest rate set almost 33 basis points above the London interbank rate. A bais point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/29/world.main_headline: GROMYKO RECEIVED BY THE PRESIDENT FOR OVER 3 HOURS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/29/world.print_headline: GROMYKO RECEIVED BY THE PRESIDENT FOR OVER 3 HOURS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/29/world.body_text: **********President Reagan and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko held what was called a ''forceful and direct'' discussion today of the sharp differences between the United States and the Soviet Union. **********After the three-and-a-half-hour White House meeting and lunch, it was announced that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Mr. Gromyko would hold further talks Saturday at the State Department. Mr. Shultz and Mr. Gromyko met for three hours in New York on Wednesday. **********Mr. Shultz, who spoke to reporters after the White House meeting, said Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gromyko had repeated their known positions at some length and with some force. He did not hold out the likelihood of an early narrowing of the gap between the two nations. **********'An Intense Discussion' **********''At the end of an intense discussion like this, it's not the sort of thing where you agree, 'All right, we'll do x, y and z,' '' he said, defending the value of a meeting in which there were apparently no tangible accords. **********(In Moscow, the Soviet public was told for the first time of the meeting during the national evening news broadcast, which included a two- minute videotape of Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gromyko chatting before a White House fireplace. The broadcast did not include any commentary on Mr. Reagan's first formal meeting with a top Soviet leader, The Associated Press reported.) **********Mr. Gromyko issued a statement later through the Soviet press agency Tass in which he said the Soviet Union was still unconvinced ''about practical positive changes in the foreign policy course of the U.S. Administration.'' He noted that the President had called for more frequent meetings of senior officials from the two countries as a way of improving relations. He indicated that this would be a positive step, if it were combined with changes in the American stances at important negotiations. **********''But this is not the case,'' he said. **********Looking for 'Practical Deeds' **********''The Soviet Union will continue to judge real intentions of the U.S. side by its practical deeds,'' he said. ''The future will show whether Washington intends to adjust its political course.'' **********Tass said Mr. Gromyko had repeated the Soviet concern that the United States was seeking military superiority over the Soviet Union and was stepping up the arms race. But it added that Mr. Gromyko ''reaffirmed that the Soviet Union is ready for normalization and all-around development of relations between the U.S.S.R. and the U.S.A. on the basis of equality, mutual respect and noninterference in the affairs of each other.'' **********''Such development of relations would make it possible to start serious talks on limiting and reducing arms, which would be of decisive importance in the entire international situation as well,'' Tass said. **********A White House official said Mr. Reagan opened the meeting by reading a statement he had written himself, in which he said the United States recognized the Soviet Union was a ''superpower'' and although the two countries differed in their political systems, they shared a moral responsibility to insure that their competition was peaceful. The official said Mr. Reagan said they also shared a responsibility to act together in reducing arms and in curbing regional disputes. **********On specific issues, he told the Soviet Union that if negotiations were held on banning the militarization of outer space, the United States would be willing to adopt ''restraints'' - suggesting a moratorium, as advocated by the Russians. But he said it was important to make progress in all areas of arms control, a reference to the American desire to combine talks on arms control in outer space with the resumption of negotiations on medium-range and strategic arms, suspended by the Soviet Union last year. **********Administration officials had been cautioning reporters not to expect breakthroughs, given the deep-seated distrust between the two sides, and the pending American elections. And afterward, Robert C. McFarlane, the national security adviser, said the discussions ''went about as expected.'' **********State Department officials said they hoped Mr. Reagan's strong appeal for the two sides to work together would be acted upon after the Nov. 6 election. They said that given the Soviet Union's preference for the arms-control positions held by Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential candidate, it was unrealistic to expect any positive response now to Mr. Reagan. **********Today Mr. Mondale issued a brief statement expressing disappointment that Mr. Shultz had not revealed more about the meeting. ''I hope that we are going to hear more about what was accomplished than what we heard from Secretary Shultz this afternoon,'' he said, ''and I hope they make progress in their meeting tomorrow.'' **********Mr. Shultz said the President's objective was to stress to Mr. Gromyko, as a member of the ruling Politburo, that ''we need to have a more constructive relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union and to express the many ways, again, he believes this can be done.'' **********''I'm sure that from the President's point of view, this position was made clearer,'' he said. Mr. Reagan, since last January, has been saying that because American military strength has been improved, he felt it important to seek better relations with Moscow. Last Monday, he devoted most of his speech at the United Nations to outlining ways that Soviet-American relations could be enhanced. He also stated his desire for arms-control accords. **********Mr. Gromyko, in his speech to the United Nations on Thursday, repeated the Soviet position that it wanted the United States to produce ''concrete deeds'' and that ''verbal assurances'' were not sufficient. He blamed the United States for wrecking the framework of arms-control negotiations and said it was up to the United States to repair the situation. **********Mr. Shultz said the exchanges were ''intense'' and ''forceful and direct.'' **********''The meeting was a very strong personal interchange between two individuals,'' he said. At one point, at the close of a two-hour meeting in the Oval Office, Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gromyko met alone for about 10 minutes, speaking in English, without interpreters. Mr. Shultz said the President had some thoughts he wanted to address to Mr. Gromyko without any advisers listening.   Heavy Press Coverage **********''Mr. Gromyko, of course, expressed his views very powerfully and aggressively, as he always does,'' Mr. Shultz said, indicating that the Soviet official had covered in private what he had said publicly. **********The discussions, which included a 90- minute working lunch, took place against a background of extremely heavy coverage by reporters and cameramen, which at times seemed to unsettle both Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gromyko. **********Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said there was ''a record number'' of television cameras at the White House today. Mr. Gromyko at times seemed to tease the cameras, holding his hands high over his head, clasped, as if he had won a fight, as he departed the White House after the meetings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/04/busin.main_headline: GROUP WITHDRAWS BID FOR SOUTHLAND FINANCIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/04/busin.print_headline: GROUP WITHDRAWS BID FOR SOUTHLAND FINANCIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/04/busin.body_text: **********The Southland Financial Corporation said yesterday that the Carpenter family group was withdrawing its previously announced proposal to acquire the company ''in view of current stock market conditions.'' **********The proposal, made Sept. 14, had called for Southland Financial to be acquired by a company to be formed by certain members of the Carpenter family, including Ben H. Carpenter, Southland Financial's chairman and chief executive officer. **********The family group, along with certain related trusts, holds about 5 million shares of Southland Financial's common stock, or 30 percent of the 16.7 million shares outstanding. **********Under the plan, each share of Southland common, other than shares already held by the family group, would have been purchased for $22 in cash and $20 principal amount of a new issue of subordinated discount debentures. **********Alternatives Weighed **********J. M. Lewis, senior vice president and treasurer of Southland Financial, would not elaborate on why the Carpenter group had withdrawn its bid for the company. Telephone calls to Mr. Carpenter's office were not returned. **********In over-the-counter trading yesterday, Southland Financial closed at $36.50, down 50 cents, on a volume of 462,000 shares. **********Southland Financial, which is based in Irving, Tex., said that the Carpenter group had advised the company that it intended to explore various alternatives to the original proposal, including a revised plan for the acquisition of Southland Financial alone or with other participants. **********On Tuesday, a group of companies controlled by Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 5.7 percent, or 953,723 shares, of the common stock of Southland Financial in September for $33.7 million. **********Life Insurance Unit Sold **********The Boesky group said it had bought the shares for investment purposes and not to acquire the company. **********Last January, Southland Financial sold its Southland Life Insurance Company subsidiary to American Brands Inc. for $352 million in cash. The unit accounted for 75 percent of the parent company's revenues and all of its earnings in 1982. **********Southland Financial now is primarily involved in the development and operation of real estate properties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/13/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Key Positions Filled at Trilogy
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/13/busin.body_text: **********Trilogy Ltd., which has been experiencing financial difficulties stemming from its unsuccessful attempt to build a high-speed ''wafer-scale'' computer chip, has named a financial consultant to head its parent company yesterday and its top engineer to run Trilogy Systems, its operating arm. **********Henry C. Montgomery was named president and chief operating officer of Trilogy Ltd., which is based in Bermuda. Paul McEnroe was named president and chief operating officer of the Trilogy Systems Corporation, based in Cupertino, Calif. **********Mr. Montgomery, who is 48 years old, succeeds Frederick T. White, 49, who had held those positions for the last two years. Mr. White will become vice chairman, the company said. **********''Mr. Montgomery's experience has largely been in finance and in helping companies who have gotten into financial difficulties,'' said Gene Amdahl, Trilogy's chairman and chief executive officer. ''We expect him to function in that role here, and to determine how best to maximize the use of our resources.'' **********Mr. Montgomery was out of the office yesterday and could not be reached for comment. Most recently, he has been president of his own management consulting company, Henry C. Montgomery Inc., and has served as an officer and director of a number of California-based companies. From 1974 until 1979 Mr. Montgomery was a vice president of finance at the Memorex Corporation and has held positions with the ITT Corporation and McKinsey & Company. He started his career with Arthur Andersen & Company, the Big 8 accounting firm. **********Mr. McEnroe joined Trilogy earlier this year as a vice president for engineering and until his appointment yesterday had been executive vice president and chief operating officer at Trilogy Systems. **********In the 23 years before he joined Trilogy, Mr. McEnroe held a number of technical and executive positions at the International Business Machines Corporation, most recently as director of I.B.M.'s Raleigh Development Laboratory. **********''Immense accomplishments were made in the very complex development of the superchip,'' Mr. McEnroe said in a telephone interview. ''But it was not possible to complete the project in an economically viable way.'' **********Last month Trilogy abandoned its superchip project, which would have powered a superfast mainframe computer to rival I.B.M.'s top-of-the-line machines, after four years of development. **********When it ended its effort to develop a superchip, Trilogy said it intended to design circuit packages made up of conventional semiconductors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/09/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union, in announcing today that it would not take part in the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles, did not use the word ''boycott'' to describe its action. **********A statement by the Soviet Olympic Committee said the ''participation of Soviet athletes is impossible.'' **********The Russians have avoided the word ''boycott'' in discussing whether they would stay away. They said the Soviet Union did not engage in politically motivated actions such as the American decision in 1980 not to participate in the Moscow Olympics as a protest against the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. **********On April 16, Marat V. Gramov, head of the Olympic Committee, said: ''We never use the word 'boycott' and we will never use it. We have no intention of boycotting. We make a difference between boycott and not attending.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; North Castle Partners Wins Additional Clients
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.body_text: **********North Castle Partners of Greenwich, Conn., a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., announced yesterday that it had won three new clients, who it will be billing between $8 million and $10 million. **********One is an existing client, H.P. Hood Inc. of Boston, which is consolidating all of its dairy business in Greenwich. **********Another, and probably the biggest, is Tetley, which includes a number of teas as well as five brands of coffee. The third is Coupon Counter, Hingham, Mass., which places coupon dispensing machines in supermarkets. **********The previous agency for the Hood products was Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, and for Tetley, Hicks & Greist. The third client did not have a previous agency. **********The Tetley coffee brands are Martinson, Savarin, Medaglia D'Oro, Brown Gold and El Pico.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/19/world.body_text: **********Iraq said its planes hit another merchant ship in the Persian Gulf today, and it vowed to turn a war zone around the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island into ''a graveyard'' for any vessels entering the area. **********A military spokesman in Baghdad said Iraqi planes had hit a ''large naval target'' - a term used in the past to refer to oil tankers - south of Kharg Island. There was no immediate independent confirmation of the attack.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/09/busin.body_text: **********Data Access Systems Inc. said it had completed its plan of reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. **********The company will report a profit for the year ended Aug. 31 and has enough cash from operations to repay its debt, according to David Cohen, chairman and chief financial officer. He said Data Access expects revenues for the fiscal year 1985 to exceed the $34.5 million in the latest fiscal year. The company, a distributor of personal computers, computer peripherals and related equipment, said it had paid $5.5 million to creditors in partial settlement of their claims of $35 million. In addition, the company issued notes and shares to satisfy creditor and shareholder claims.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/28/busin.body_text: **********General Motors' latest and perhaps most important gamble, analysts and company executives say, is that buyers will accept the smaller size and wedge shape of its top-of-the-line luxury cars being introduced this week. **********Within the company they are called the ''C'' bodies. In dealers' showrooms they will be the new Cadillac DeVille and Fleetwood, Oldsmobile 98 and Buick Electra. **********The gamble is especially important for G.M. since this is the second generation and most radical downsizing of its largest and most profitable cars. **********It represents a major step toward converting virtually all of the company's cars, with the exception of specialty and sports models, to front- wheel drive. Packaging all engine, transmission and other propulsion components in the front of the car permits smaller, lighter vehicles while still preserving interior roominess, automotive engineers say. **********''We want to expose the rear-wheel- drive buyer to everything he is saying 'no' to now, before he drives out in a rear-wheel-drive model,'' said John O. Grettenberger, vice president for the Cadillac division. But he added that traditional Cadillac buyers particularly would be in for a shock when the new front-wheel-drive DeVille and Fleetwood models go on sale April 5. **********The new cars are two feet shorter than the rear-wheel-drive models they replace, and have much of the wedge-shaped styling of G.M.'s recent smaller models, in contrast to the formal, boxy look of recent Cadillacs. The difference is not quite so pronounced for Olds and Buick because the styling of the new 98's and Electras is closer to existing models. **********Look-Alike Styling Criticized **********In any case, the cars have received only a lukeware welcome from the auto enthusiast magazines, which are an important influence on some buyers and often an early indicator of consumer acceptance. One particularly sharp criticism has been the look-alike styling that makes it hard to distinguish between versions of the car being sold by different divisions. **********''At first glance, Oldsmobile's version of the C car, the new 98, may look virtually identical to Buick's Electra,'' Motor Trend magazine said. ''At second, third and fourth glances, it still does.'' Leon Mandel, the editor of Autoweek, said: ''The car is an expression of wind tunnel ugliness. It is arrogantly drab and arrogantly utilitarian.'' **********However, auto executives and dealers say buyers in the past have gotten over the shock of different-looking, smaller cars. ''We did it in 1977, the first time the C body was downsized,'' said Denzil W. Rose, who operates dealerships in Hilo, Hawaii, selling the full line of G.M. cars. ''People will find out that the new cars have more head and hip room than the old ones.'' **********Fuel Economy a Factor **********The new C-body cars were designed in 1980 and 1981, at a time when it was anticipated that gasoline would cost as much as $2 a gallon by the time they were introduced. The assumption was that buyers would be willing to pay a premium for fuel economy of 21 miles a gallon in city driving, compared with 17 in the older model. **********But fuel prices have remained steady, at about $1.20 a gallon, and large cars have increased in popularity. As a result, Cadillac is keeping its large, rear-wheel-drive Fleetwood Brougham for another year. **********Oldsmobile and Buick, however, are dropping their old Electra and 98 models. Prices for the new front- wheel-drive cars will not be announced until next week, but it is possible that the highest-priced models in those divisions will not be the largest for the first time in many years. The slightly downscale Oldsmobile 88 model, for example, is 218 inches long, compared with 196 inches for the new 98. **********Analysts noted, however, that G.M. had little choice but to proceed with the smaller cars, since it is already falling below the Federal corporate average fuel economy standards. **********G.M. has estimated its fleet average at from 23.5 to 25.1 miles a gallon for the 1984 model year, compared with a standard of 27 miles a gallon. Only credits built up in the years when small cars were most popular is keeping the company from paying millions of dollars in fines. **********Younger Buyers Sought **********G.M. executives say they hope to lure younger buyers with the new cars, since the average age of current buyers of luxury models is over 50. The new cars, whose total development cost is estimated at more than $2 billion by Donald DeScenza, an auto analyst with Nomura Securities International, are also aimed at the better educated professionals who have been buying European luxury cars in increasing numbers. **********Mr. DeScenza said General Motors' decision to build the C-cars at new assembly plants outside Pontiac, Mich., and St. Louis was an indication that the company felt it had to improve the quality of its luxury cars to match the imports. **********Mr. DeScenza estimated the company's profit margin on the C-cars at about 20 percent of the wholesale price, or $3,000 on a car wholesaling for $15,000 and carrying a $17,400 sticker price. The luxury cars probably account for 15 to 20 percent of G.M.'s total profit, he said. **********Whether the company's claim to better quality will be enough to woo buyers from imports is questioned by some analysts. ''People who used to buy an Olds 98 every three years, but who switched to an import will be hard to get back,'' said Harvey Heinbach, who analyzes the industry for Merrill Lynch. ''The people who bought the BMW's and Volvos and Saabs seem to be pretty happy with them.'' **********G.M. is also introducing the cars into a market whose appetite for luxury models appears to be increasing. The company is estimating that luxury-car sales by all manufacturers will top 1.1 million in 1984, compared with 980,000 in 1983.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/28/busin.body_text: **********Texas Instruments Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter rebounded sharply from the previous year's deficit that reflected losses in the company's home computer business. **********Earnings totaled $85.9 million, or $3.57 a share, in the latest period,compared with a loss of $119.2 million a year earlier. **********In last year's second quarter, the company's pretax loss from its home computer business was $183 million, The company formally bowed out of the home computer business last October. **********Sales jumped 32.7 percent, to $1.46 billion, from $1.1 billion. **********The company, which is based in Dallas, attributed its strong showing to increases in sales of semiconductors, military electronics, metallurgical materials and electrical controls. **********The company said its semiconductor orders and shipments set records during the quarter. Orders for calculators and electronic learning aids also rose, but results from geophysical exploration services remained depressed because of the world oil glut and weak oil prices, the company said. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Texas Instruments' shares rose $3.625, to close at $121.875.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/22/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Iran Reports Crushing Iraqi Counterattack
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/22/world.body_text: **********Iran said today that its forces had crushed a renewed Iraqi attempt to stop its five- day-old offensive, killing 200 Iraqi troops. **********The Teheran radio, monitored in London, said Iranian troops repulsed the new Iraqi counterattack and killed 200 Iraqis, forcing others to leave behind tanks, vehicles and weapons. **********In Baghdad, Government officials charged that Iran was massing troops near the two nations' 733-mile border for yet a new attack in the 41-month-old war. **********WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) - The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, reaffirmed President Reagan's pledge to keep the Strait of Hormuz open by ''doing what's necessary.'' **********Pentagon officials, responding to reports that an American naval task force was steaming for the war zone, said a battle group led by the aircraft carrier Midway had been patrolling the northern Arabian Sea for six months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/31/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Port Authority Sets $100 Million Offerings
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/31/busin.body_text: **********The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is offering $100 million of bonds and $100 million of notes though underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Investment bankers said sales were modest with most of the buying by individual investors. **********Interest on Port Authority issues is exempt from Federal, state and city income taxes. **********The 11 percent bonds due in 2019, and the 7 3/4 percent notes due June 1, 1987, are both offered at a price of 100. The bonds are rated A-1/Ax, while the notes have the highest rating of MIG-1 by Moody's Investors Service. **********Although the Port Authority has more than $2 billion of bonds outstanding, its revenues from bridge and tunnel tolls and other fees, plus interest earned on investments, are well over twice the amount needed to pay interest and principal on its bonds. Because of its strong financial condition, analysts at Prescott, Ball & Turben, a securities firm, estimated that the authority's bonds are of double A quality, or slightly higher than the ratings assigned by Moody's Investors Service or the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********A recent research report by Prescott, Ball said the chronic deficits from operating the Port Authority Trans-Hudson rail service should be reduced by a forthcoming fare increase. Port Authority officials have considered selling the World Trade Center and are awaiting a financial consultant's report.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/31/world.main_headline: SYRIA'S LEADER REPORTED TO BREAK UP POWER BASE OF BROTHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/31/world.print_headline: SYRIA'S LEADER REPORTED TO BREAK UP POWER BASE OF BROTHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/31/world.body_text: **********President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has dissolved the main bases of power of his brother Rifaat in an effort to halt the infighting for succession and make his brother more ''manageable,'' authoritative Israeli sources said today. **********The Israeli sources, who are familiar with internal Syrian politics, said that in the last three months President Assad had disbanded almost all of the Defense Companies - a Praetorian Guard outside the army chain of command that his brother used to head. **********Rifaat Assad is said to remain in Switzerland, where he has essentially been banished since June by his brother. The Israelis said he was involved in intensive negotiations with President Assad to allow him to return to Damascus, possibly in the near future. **********Only a Small Core Is Left **********If he goes back, however, he will find little left of his old power network, the Israeli sources said. All that remains of the once 10,000- to 15,000-man Defense Companies is a small core, and it is not clear at this time who is even commanding it, they said. **********Most of the soldiers who made up the Defense Companies - most of whom belonged to the same small Alawite Moslem sect as the Assad family - have been transferred to a variety of regular army units, according to the Israeli sources. **********''Rifaat was a power because he had a dagger in his hand,'' a senior Israeli official said. ''He was a man feared and hated and created enormous controversy inside Syria when Hafez was ill. Hafez, because he needed to keep his house in order, had to take the dagger from him. But he is still Hafez's brother. He is still Rifaat, and I would not write him off.''  Instrument of Intimidation **********The Defense Companies were Rifaat Assad's main power base and the tool he used to try to intimidate his rivals for power in the Syrian Army and political leadership after President Assad fell ill last November. In the power vaccum that developed during President Assad's hospitalization, Rifaat Assad and his rivals maneuvered their troops and tanks around Damascus, trying to get maximum tactical advantage for a quick seizure of power if the President died. **********The Defense Companies had primary responsibility for protecting Damascus and providing security for the Assad family - tasks that also appear to have been turned over to regular trusted army units.   Rivals Retain Their Power **********Not only has Rifaat Assad lost his main sources of strength, the Israeli sources said, but, equally important, his two rivals have not been deprived of their power bases. Despite earlier expectations that President Assad would cut down the rivals to compensate for his brother's reduction in stature, that has not happened, they said. **********Gen. Ali Haidar, the commander of Syria's elite Special Forces, and Gen. Chefik Fayyad, the commander of Syria's powerful Third Division - Rifaat Assad's main competitors for power when President Assad was ill - were both said to have retained their command positions.
