https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/01/busin.body_text: **********Employees refer to the black cloud that hangs over the company. Or an executive might mention how well everything is going for the A. H. Robins Company, and then add, ''Except for that one thing.'' **********That one thing is the Dalkon Shield, an intrauterine birth-control device that the company hasn't made for a decade but that continues to haunt it. **********One of the most tainted names in the annals of consumer products, the Dalkon Shield was touted for its exceptional reliability in preventing pregnancy. But thousands of women who used the plastic oval suffered infections, sterility and septic abortions (badly infected miscarriages) that they say stemmed from the Shield. The device has been blamed for 21 deaths. **********30 New Claims a Week **********These sorry events touched off a blizzard of liability lawsuits against A. H. Robins, and the suits show no signs of letting up. In recent months, an acceleration in the disposition of pending cases along with a growing number of hefty jury awards, many of them not covered by insurance, have begun to have a jarring impact on the company's finances. Litigation costs so far this year are already more than double those for all of last year, and about 30 new claims a week are being filed. In addition, the company received a recent tongue lashing from a Minneapolis Federal judge, Miles Lord. **********The nova-like history of the Dalkon Shield is a graphic illustration of how a product of fringe benefit to a company can imperil its very future. **********Between 1970 and 1974, Robins sold 4.6 million Dalkon Shields throughout the world. Profits from the sales amounted to about $500,000 - far less than those from its Chap Stick lip balm or Robitussin cough medicine. **********Since Robins scrapped the Shield - so small a part of its operations that nobody was laid off - the contraceptive has cost it $101 million in litigation expenses. Its insurer has paid out an additional $132 million, and it is anyone's guess how mammoth the final bill will be. **********Morale a Problem **********Moreover, the Shield has rocked Robins's corporate culture and bruised its morale. **********Various employees are periodically summoned to testify. Two have suffered minor heart attacks that the company feels are linked to the stress. ''No matter how much we would like the legal department to handle this,'' said E. Claiborne Robins Jr., the company's president, ''it still enters into other peoples' decisions and lives every day.'' **********Robert Watts, Robins's executive vice president, said, ''I was a teen- ager during World War II. I would read the papers, and any time I'd read that we lost something, I would get depressed and I'd go outside and look up in the air for the planes.'' Similarly, when Robins's employees read about the Shield litigation in the newspapers, he said, morale has ''some aberrations. It shows itself in lunchroom conversation. What's happening to us? people want to know. Are we really sick? It's like a kid with a sick parent.'' **********Though Robins says it has little turnover and doesn't know of anyone who has spurned a job offer because of the Dalkon Shield, it has no way of knowing how many potential recruits sidestep the company. ''I think that if I were out in the marketplace looking for a job, I wouldn't come to this company,'' said Mr. Watts. ''I could go to another company and not have to worry about this thing.'' **********'Monstrous Mischief' **********It's unclear to what extent A. H. Robins is to blame for the Dalkon Shield debacle. Opposing lawyers have charged that the company inadequately tested and knowingly sold a deadly product. The most cutting blow was delivered in March by Judge Lord. **********After approving settlement of a number of Dalkon lawsuits, he told A. H. Robins: ''Your company, without warning to women, invaded their bodies by the millions and caused them injuries by the thousands. Your company in the face of overwhelming evidence denies its guilt and continues its monstrous mischief. You have taken the bottom line as your guiding beacon and the low road as your route.'' **********The judge also instructed several top officers to read an astringent speech on corporate irresponsibility he had delivered to a church group, and told them ''I hope it burns its mark into your soul.'' **********In retaliaton, A. H. Robins filed a complaint with the court system, accusing the judge of ''a gross abuse of judicial discretion and power.'' Mr. Robins devoted much of his remarks at the company's recent annual meeting to a rebuttal of Judge Lord, declaring that he ''wasn't prepared to be impartial, as befits a judge. Instead, he was prepared to destroy, to tear down and to demean.'' **********Harassment Charged **********Plaintiff attorneys have also accused Robins of harassing defendants by posing embarrassing questions about their sex lives to dissuade them from going to trial. Philip Zauderer, a Columbus, Ohio, lawyer, says that one woman dropped her suit after Robins asked her if she had had group sex. Robins argues that sexual habits are germane. **********''There are other causes of infection,'' said William A. Forrest Jr., the company's general counsel, ''one of which is the sexual life style.'' **********Robins acquired the rights to the Dalkon Shield in June 1970 from the Dalkon Corporation, a group of investors that included the two doctors who invented it. Robins says it tested the device rigorously. The use of any I.U.D. entails risk, it adds, and those risks were disclosed to the public. **********Indeed, something of a feeling of persecution pervades the company's headquarters here. ''Why doesn't the American public realize that a company that is over 100 years old would n't make a decision that could destroy it in a matter of minutes?'' Mr Robins muses. ''Yet the people, the courts, the newspapers are trying to destroy it. It bothers me that the integrity of my father is being questioned. I don't like the image being projected about A. H. Robins. It hurts.'' **********E. Claiborne Robins Sr., the chairman of Robins, won't talk about the tribulations of the Shield. His son said the elder Robins wouldn't even discuss it with him. **********Though A. H. Robins went public in 1963, much of the stock remains in family hands. The elder Mr. Robins owns about a quarter of it. The company likes to make much of its benevolence. In 1969, Mr. Robins donated $50 million worth of Robins stock to the University of Richmond, his alma mater. At the time it was the largest individual bequest to a university. On their birthdays, employees receive a card from the chairman and president, along with a check for $25. **********Dalkon Shield lawsuits were filed as early as 1972, but the litigation stepped up in late 1974, after Robins withdrew the product and offered to buy back any Dalkon Shields in the marketplace. By now, 7,350 cases have been disposed of - virtually all by out-of-court settlements - and 3,675 are pending. **********In the 37 trials, Robins has won 19 and lost 18. The biggest award was $6.8 million to a Colorado woman who said she suffered a septic abortion and nearly died after using the Shield. **********The Aetna Life and Casualty Company has been Robins's insurer, though the limits of coverage have largely been exhausted. The company has no insurance beyond 1978. Robins is currently in the throes of litigation with Aetna over the manner in which the insurer assigns cases to specific years and over its policy of deducting defense expenses from liability limits. Should Robins prevail, it could pick up millions of dollars in additional coverage. **********Record Operating Earnings **********Robins's executives, who remain sanguine that the company will survive the Dalkon threat, have tried to keep the Shield problem from hindering other operations. And the company, apart from the litigation, has been sailing along. **********Last year, revenues reached a record $563.5 million, and operating earnings a record $100.4 million. But Dalkon Shield expenses amounted to $18.7 million. In the first half of 1984, when operating earnings climbed 33 percent, litigation costs came to $42.3 million, almost quintuple the burden in the first half of last year. **********Despite Robins's strong operating results, no Wall Street brokerage house recommends the stock. ''It's frustrating trying to follow them,'' said Joseph Riccardo, an analyst at Bear, Stearns. ''The company appears to be doing exceptionally well. Its product line appears to be strong. But that's clearly not the issue. The issue is the Dalkon Shield. You can't estimate their litigation expenses.'' **********Many analysts would like to see Robins set up a reserve fund to cover litigation costs. But the company thinks it cannot do so until it has an idea of what those costs might be. It thinks it may get one once it detects a decline in the filing of new cases. Although the rate seems to have leveled off, there has not been any clear evidence of a slackening. **********Shield Still in Use **********One of the wild cards in the Dalkon Shield saga is that, strangely enough, the Shield has never been banned. And there are surely women who continue to wear them. ''Who they are, how many there are, where they are, we don't know,'' a company official conceded. **********A. H. Robins traces its roots to an apothecary shop founded by Albert Hanley Robins, the grandfather of E. Claiborne Robins Sr., in downtown Richmond in 1866. After World War II, it emerged as a company of some substance, having introduced Robitussin and a product called Donnatal for gastrointestinal disturbances. **********In 1963, the company began to move toward its present-day form when it acquired Morton Manufacturing, maker of Chap Stick, the biggest-selling lip balm and the fastest-moving product in drugstores. In 1967, the Polk Miller Products Corporation was bought, which made the Sergeant's pet-care line of flea collars and animal shampoos. Prescription drugs continue as the company's major sales generator, spearheaded by the Reglan family of promotility agents. **********Robins recently entered the medical instruments and broadcasting businesses, since the younger Mr. Robins wants to steer the company into markets less heavily policed by the government than drugs. Robins bought two radio stations in Greensboro, N.C., as well as the Quinton Medical Company, which makes such things as stress-testing equipment. **********To the younger Mr. Robins, there is no product that wouldn't conceivably pique his interest - save one. ''If you said you have an intrauterine device you'd like me to look at,'' he remarked, ''I'd have to say, no thank you. No thank you.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/19/busin.body_text: **********TECHNOLOGY stocks took a beating yesterday, for two unrelated reasons, and helped to **********keep the market on the downside. **********First, worry over problems with a disk drive hurt Control Data and Burroughs. Second, the semiconductor issues were battered by a bearish brokerage house report on Motorola. **********Burroughs opened down 2 3/8 yesterday morning after an order imbalance. The drop in Burroughs, which closed the day at 53, off 3 5/8, followed Control Data's slide. On Monday, Control Data dropped 2 1/8 points, and it lost an additional 3/8 yesterday, to close at 26 1/8. **********Control Data, according to analysts, encountered problems with a thin coating on the disk. ''If that chemical compound is not virtually perfect, trouble ensues,'' said Ulric Weil, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''We are talking about tolerances the thickness of a human hair.'' **********Control Data had shipped 500 of the 33800-series disk, which is compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's units. If the media, or chemical compound, is not right, the disk drive can stop suddenly. **********Analysts heard of the Control Data problem Monday and began to cut earnings estimates of the company. Then they realized that Burroughs might have a similar problem and turned their attention there. **********Control Data and Burroughs have two joint ventures, said Michael Geran, an analyst at E. F. Hutton. One is a media joint venture, and the second is the disk drive head joint venture, with Burroughs responsible for the media side and Control Data for the head side. ''As they attempted to escalate the production of the media with new equipment and new people, they kind of lost the recipe,'' Mr. Geran said. ''When you put the media on the heads, there apparently is a problem.'' **********Both companies independently ship 33800-series equipment to I.B.M. plug-compatible markets. Burroughs's Memorex subsidiary, which makes the 3680 disk drive storage system, said it had suspended shipments but expected to resume them in two weeks. **********What is surprising about the media problem, Mr. Weil said, is that I.B.M. had the same situation three and a half years ago when it was developing its high-performance disk drive and was able to solve it. ''You would have thought they would have hired somebody from I.B.M.'' to solve the problem, Mr. Weil said of Burroughs and Control Data. ''When you're working at the leading edge of technology, things can go wrong.'' **********Analysts cut earnings estimates for both companies, with Control Data getting the worst of it. Mr. Weil, for example, cut his estimate for Control Data on an operating basis to $1.70 a share from $3.35. Jay Stevens of Dean Witter Reynolds reduced his Control Data estimates to $2.40 from $3.40 this year and to $3.50 from $4 next year. Mr. Stevens reduced the rating on Burroughs to a hold from a buy/hold. Control Data was already a hold, which is a neutral stance. **********The analysts were kinder to Burroughs, in part because of the strength of the rest of the company. Mr. Geran, for example, took 15 cents a share off this year's earnings estimate. Mr. Weil adjusted his Burroughs estimate to $5.50 from $5.75. **********As for semiconductor producers, Stuart Johnson of Wertheim & Company has become bearish on Motorola. After Mr. Johnson took the stock off the recommended list, it fell 2, to 40 5/8, in active trading. **********Among other declining semiconductor issues, Texas Instruments dropped 3, to 133; Advanced Micro Devices 1, to 39 1/4, and National Semiconductor 3/4, to 14 3/4. Electronics distributors were also hurt. Arrow Electronics, for example, dropped 1 7/8, to 20 1/2. Mr. Johnson said his decision on semiconductors reflected concern that orders in the fourth quarter would not turn up ''with a great deal of vigor.'' **********Other analysts disagree. Adam F. Cuhney of Salomon Brothers maintains his recommendation on Motorola, as well as on Texas Instruments, Advanced Micro Devices, Intel and National Semiconductor. He expects an order upturn in the final quarter if the economy is not hurt by a strike at General Motors. **********Richard Billy, an analyst at L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, said the summer months into September were ''pretty weak,'' with an ''ongoing inventory correction and seasonality.'' **********His firm is recommending some of the companies that have a niche in the industry. He specifically mentioned Advanced Micro Devices, Monolothic Memories, National Semiconductor and some of the electronics distributors. But Rothschild is not recommending Motorola or Texas Instruments. Mr. Billy said these companies were exposed to the problem of too much capacity should the economy soften. **********The recent problems of Texas Instruments with the Government hold no fear for Mr. Cuhney of Salomon Brothers. He said the press had exaggerated the situation, in which the Defense Department said Texas Instruments microchips had been faultily tested. Mr. Cuhney recommended using weakness in the stock as an opportunity to load up.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/16/busin.body_text: **********Dome Chief to Reassure Japan's Utilities on Gas J. Howard MacDonald is off this week to Japan in an attempt to reassure prospective customers about Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s agreements to deliver $2 billion of liquefied natural gas to Japanese utilities. **********Mr. MacDonald, 55, has been chairman, chief executive and chief financial officer of Dome since Oct. 1 and has been striving to get the beleaguered company back on track. **********Dome last year changed the completion date for the natural gas project to 1987, from 1986, and there have been reports that one Japanese utility, Chubu Electric, is considering canceling an accord with Dome because of the delays. **********A Dome spokesman said Chubu had agreed to extend an earlier deadline and the length of the extension would be one subject that Mr. MacDonald will take up in Japan. **********The price at which Dome will purchase the gas from Canadian producers is said to be one of the main snags in the projects. Delays have also been caused by Dome's preoccupation with efforts to reshape its heavy debt load. **********Refinancing that debt is Mr. MacDonald's major task. Mr. MacDonald took over from John P. Gallagher, 67, who built the company into the largest Canadian-controlled oil and gas group. William E. Richards, 57, the company president who helped Mr. Gallagher build the company, also resigned. **********Dome's problems began after an aggressive acquisition program loaded it with debt just as the world oil market turned down. As Mr. Richards said when he resigned in October, ''The world changed under our feet.'' **********Mr. MacDonald, a finance specialist brought in to try put Dome back in working order, has spent most of his career at the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, where he was group treasurer. He has said that he was approached last April about the job and thought hard about it before accepting. What attracted him was the challenge, he said. **********Mr. MacDonald was born in Rhu, Scotland, and first went to work for a Glascow accounting firm, Thomson & McClintock. In Calgary, where Dome has its headquarters, he lives fairly modestly and has said his management style is to work in the background and stay out of the spotlight.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/04/world.body_text: **********President Reagan thanked President Hafez al- Assad of Syria today for releasing Lieut. Robert O. Goodman Jr. and declared that the flier's return presented ''an opportune moment to put all the issues on the table'' between the United States and Syria. **********''All of us here are delighted, of course, that this has taken place,'' Mr. Reagan told reporters this morning shortly after speaking by telephone with Lieutenant Goodman and with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, whose visit to Damascus ended in the flier's release. **********A week ago, White House officials warned that a trip to Syria by Mr. Jackson could hinder rather than help the Administration's efforts to gain Lieutenant Goodman's release. **********Praise From Both Parties **********Today Mr. Jackson was extolled by Democrats and Republicans alike, and it appeared likely that his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination would benefit. Administration officials also said they were pleased that the United States had not had to make any diplomatic concessions in return for the flier's freedom. **********The White House said today, for example, that the United States would ignore Syrian protests and continue aerial reconnaissance missions over territory held by Syrian-backed forces in Lebanon. **********Mr. Reagan praised Mr. Jackson for the success of his mission. Asked if the civil rights leader and Democratic Presidential candidate had performed well, the President said, ''You don't quarrel with success.'' **********This afternoon, Mr. Reagan announced that he had sent a message to President Assad expressing ''appreciation for this action'' and calling on Syria to ''work with the United States to bring greater stability to Lebanon and withdrawals of foreign troops.'' **********Mr. Reagan offered no new proposals, however, and White House aides said he continued to oppose a withdrawal of American marines from Lebanon, in spite of rising appeals from Congressional leaders that such a step be considered. **********White House officials had said earlier that Mr. Reagan was considering ''new ideas'' to break the stalemate in Lebanon, but today they declined to specify what these were. The officials said Mr. Reagan had instructed his staff not to make them known, but suggested that no changes in approach were imminent.   President Sees Mideast Envoy **********Mr. Reagan met this morning with Donald Rumsfeld, the special Middle East envoy, in preparation for a trip by Mr. Rumsfeld to the region. The special envoy was to fly to London tonight but the Administration refused to give out his subsequent itinerary. **********A White House official said there was widespread doubt in the Administration that the release of Lieutenant Goodman portended a warming in the relationship with Syria, although he said that the recent climate of threats and hostility might change for a time. **********The official noted that Syria had taken other positive steps in the past. Last July, for example, the Adminstration credited the Syrians with assisting in the release of David S. Dodge, acting president of the American University in Beirut, who had been abducted a year earlier by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslems. **********The United States has blamed Syria, however, for providing military support to the Shiite and Druse factions in Lebanon that oppose President Amin Gemayel's Government.   Flier Was on Bombing Mission **********Syrian antiaircraft batteries have fired on American reconnaissance missions in Lebanon, and the United States has responded with air strikes and naval shelling. Lieutenant Goodman, a 27-year-old navigator-bombardier, was shot down Dec. 4 while on a bombing mission. **********Adding to the tension with Syria has been the Administration contention that there was evidence of Syrian backing for the terrorist group that blew up the Marine headquarters in Beirut on Oct. 23, killing 241 American servicemen. **********Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, emphasized today that the reconnaissance flights over Lebanon would continue. He said one such flight was carried out this morning shortly before the announcement of Lieutenant Goodman's release. **********Mr. Speakes said Mr. Reagan spoke for 10 minutes with Mr. Jackson and Lieutenant Goodman this morning. **********He quoted the President as having told the civil rights leader: ''It is a great day here in Washington. All Americans thank you. There have been a lot of prayers in Washington. I have been praying for you. I couldn't be happier.''  President Sees Progress **********In his statement this afternoon, Mr. Reagan said that ''progress has been made'' toward achieving the ''twin goals of national reconciliation and troop withdrawals'' in Lebanon. **********''We are continuing our support of these efforts,'' he added. ''The work ahead is difficult. But with determined international effort, and the good will of all the parties, we believe that continued progress will be made.'' **********Mr. Speakes, speaking at a regular White House briefing, was careful to play down a suggestion that the flier's return might improve the Administration's negotiating efforts in the Middle East. **********He said only that the United States remained ''hopeful'' President Gemayel could resolve differences with his political opponents and that this could lead eventually to a withdrawal of American troops from Lebanon.   Plea for Patience **********Another White House aide said Mr. Reagan was hoping that the Administration could persuade skeptics in Congress to wait two or three weeks more to see if Mr. Rumsfeld's new mission could bear fruit. **********Administration officials generally assessed Lieutenant Goodman's return as a plus for Mr. Reagan, even if it was also a plus for Mr. Jackson, who has been one of the President's most acerbic critics. **********''Everybody gets something out of this, and it doesn't cost anybody anything,'' said a White House official. **********He said it came as an enormous personal relief to the President that Lieutenant Goodman was coming home. ''He could have gone through the summer and fall and still have this poor guy locked up over there,'' the official said. **********Last week, Mr. Reagan suggested to reporters that a trip by Mr. Jackson to Syria could be ''counterproductive.'' **********Today, however, a White House official noted that Mr. Reagan, Mr. Speakes and others who had expressed similar sentiments had been careful never to ask Mr. Jackson to abandon the trip. **********''We always said it was up to him whether to go,'' said the official.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/07/world.main_headline: 63 Students Arrested During Clash in Chile
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/07/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 63 Students Arrested During Clash in Chile
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/07/world.body_text: **********Riot policemen arrested 63 students during two hours of clashes Friday between hundreds of pro-Government and anti-Government demonstrators at the University of Santiago. **********Eleven students and employees were reported injured and university officials said there was $70,000 in damage to campus facilities. **********The clash erupted between participants in two rallies on the campus. One group of about 400, organized by political parties opposed to the military Government, was demanding that the university's army rector be dismissed and that 18 students who had been expelled for political reasons be reinstated. A rival group of at least 100 gathered to hear Angel Bates, a university professor, speak against ''violent minorities that try to paralyze our university.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/04/world.main_headline: TWO GERMANYS SAID TO DISCUSS BROAD ACCORDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/04/world.print_headline: TWO GERMANYS SAID TO DISCUSS BROAD ACCORDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/04/world.body_text: **********In a development that appeared to presage a significant improvement in their relations, the two Germanys were reported tonight to be negotiating an ambitious package of agreements. **********The accords were said to include a new private bank credit to East Germany and a reduction of the obligatory foreign exchange demanded of West German visitors to the Communist state. **********The news of the package, which was reported by West German television and broadly confirmed by diplomats and banking sources, came as a tense situation was defused at the West German diplomatic mission in East Berlin. **********All but 6 of 55 East Germans who had taken refuge in the mission were said to have left the building. They were reportedly reassured by commitments that they would eventually be allowed to emigrate to the West. **********Bonn Aide Voices Optimism **********In East Berlin, where he has been engaged in wide-ranging talks, Ludwig Rehlinger, a senior Bonn official, suggested to journalists that the ultimate resolution of the problem at the mission could open the way to wider agreements between the two governments. **********''There is reason to assume,'' he said, using the German initials for the German Democratic Republic, ''that the appropriate authorities in the D.D.R. will grant emigration departures in the context of family reunification when the situation in the mission is normalized - that is, when the last ones are gone.'' **********The entry into the mission by East Germans desperate to flee to the West forced Bonn last Wednesday to close the building, after several scores of people seeking asylum had been turned away. The closing followed an unsuccessful attempt by a young East German to set himself on fire in front of the mission. **********Mr. Rehlinger's talks, according to a number of accounts, were broadened to cover agreements between the two German states that both sides would like to conclude before Erich Honecker, the East German chief of state and Communist Party leader, makes an official visit to West Germany in late September. **********According to West German television reports and other information available tonight, the tentative agreements touch on these points: **********- A new private bank loan to East Germany, to be guaranteed by the West German Government. A consortium led by the Deutsche Bank, according to banking sources, has put together the loan, which is said to be somewhat smaller than a $396.8 million credit extended last year. **********- A reduction of the mandatory foreign exchange required of West German visitors to East Germany, which is a major deterrent to closer human contacts between the two states. The newspaper Bild will report in tomorrow's issue that the daily amount will be reduced from 25 deutschemarks, or about $9, to 20 deutschemarks, or $7.20. **********- A reduction in the age at which most East German women are permitted to visit West Germany. According to various accounts, the limit would be dropped from 60 to 45. **********- Permission for 5,000 more East Germans to emigrate legally to West Germany in 1984.  So far, in the biggest wave of legal emigration since the building of the Berlin wall in 1961, more than 25,000 East Germans emigrated to the West earlier this year. **********- The complete dismantling of the deadly, booby-trapped automatic firing devices along East Germany's walled and fenced frontier wih West Germany.   Bonn Offers No Denial **********Without denying the reports, the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl issued a mild disclaimer tonight, saying they were based on ''speculation.'' **********But the statement conceded that the two German governments were engaged in discussions over ''further practical arrangements'' to improve ties ''in the interest of people in both parts of Germany.'' **********''These discussions are not yet concluded,'' the statement added. **********According to Western diplomats, Mr. Honecker is eager to have the accords concluded before he becomes the first East German party leader to visit West Germany. He is said to believe that in an atmosphere of general good feeling he will be guaranteed a warm reception. **********The trip has not been officially announced. In an interview last week with the Swedish newspaper Svenska Dagbladet, Mr. Honecker said he ''did not want to participate in speculation over whether I will visit'' West Germany ''this year or not.''  Tension at Mission Reduced **********The relaxation of tension at the West German mission in East Berlin appeared to enhance the possibility of a broader agreement. Last weekend, after Mr. Rehlinger began talks with Wolfgang Vogel, an East Berlin lawyer with close ties to Mr. Honecker, some of the East Germans in the building started to leave it. **********A number of those seeking asylum had been sheltered in the modern edifice on Hannoversche Strasse for weeks, straining its diplomats' capacity to work normally. **********At his news conference, Mr. Rehlinger clarified that the four adults and two children remaining in the embassy did not include three ''problem cases'' - a navy deserter, an army reserve captain and an official said to be familiar with the layout of the East German state security headquarters. The three, like others, had ''returned to their home areas'' in East Germany, Mr. Rehlinger said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/world.main_headline: GUATEMALANS IN MEXICO: NOT WHERE THE HEART IS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/world.print_headline: GUATEMALANS IN MEXICO: NOT WHERE THE HEART IS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/world.body_text: **********Horacio Perez and his family arrived here today to settle reluctantly into their second home in as many years. **********The first was in the jungles of the Mexican border state of Chiapas, to which Mr. Perez, his wife and their four children fled in February 1983 from the Guatemalan village of Gracias a Dios - ''Thanks to God'' - after deciding that the safest choice between the Guatemalan Army and the leftist guerrillas was not to choose at all. **********The second was to the well-hidden encampment growing slowly outside this tiny community south of Campeche, farther away from his homeland than Mr. Perez ever expected to be. ''It was an order from the Government,'' he said. ''We had to agree.'' **********After two years of trying to decide what to do with the growing numbers of Guatemalans seeking sanctuary along its southern border, Mexico has started moving some 46,000 refugees to new villages being constructed in the interior of the country - whether they like the idea or not. **********The Government says that here it will be able to supply them more easily with food and medicine, allow them to lead more productive lives and protect them from attackers who, it says, have crossed the border from Guatemala to assault and sometimes kill the refugees in their camps.   'They've Arrived' **********But the move has bewildered many of the refugees, as well as the residents of the small village to which they are coming. Florencia Che, a short, squat resident of the village, stood barefoot on the railroad platform as some 250 refugees - the first Guatemalans she had ever seen in her ''more or less'' 40 years - disembarked before her. ''We don't know why they are coming,'' she said, ''but they've arrived.'' **********The embankment below her was abuzz with refugees, hauling about cloth and burlap sacks containing all the worldly goods they had managed to carry with them or collect since leaving their homeland, looking for family members who had come ahead of time to help construct their new camp, breast-feeding babies or simply chatting in Spanish or Canhubal, an Indian language common to the Guatemalan highlands. **********Francisco Felix Mendez had just been reunited with his father, wife and seven children and had a clear idea of why he was here: ''So that the Government and army of Guatemala don't kill us,'' he said. ''Thanks to President Miguel de la Madrid!'' **********Mr. Felix Mendez, 52 years old, had come here from the camp at El Chupadero on the southern border. ''They killed six of our countrymen,'' he said. ''They castrated the men they killed.'' **********The attack, which took place the night of April 30, provoked an angry diplomatic exchange between Mexico and Guatemala, and gave the final impetus to the Mexican Government's decision to move the refugees from the border.   Some Didn't Want to Go **********Not all the refugees were as sanguine about the move as Mr. Felix Mendez. Some who arrived here today said that as many as half the people of their border encampments had not wanted to leave; several told of heavy pressure from the Mexican Government, of being offered a choice of either moving here or returning to Guatemala and an even more uncertain future. **********Those who arrived here, however, did not find the accommodations wanting. Despite complaints about the warmer, more humid weather - one woman's arms were full of sores that she attributed to the change in climate - all of those interviewed said the camp was equal to or better than their living situation at the border. **********Many said they looked forward as well to the creation of plots of land, promised by the Mexican Government, on which they will be able to grow some of their own food. The rest of their needs will be provided for, as they have in the past, by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. **********The camp itself is carved out of a swath of national forest. Long rows of rectangular huts made of inch-round branches are covered with corrugated tar-paper roofs of alternating red and black color and shaded by stands of trees. A larger building along one end will serve as a meeting hall and school, according to officials of the Mexican Commission for Assistance to Refugees.   Sharing Schools, but Not Jobs **********The Governor of Campeche, Eugenio Echeverria Castellot, said that in cases where the refugee camps were close to Mexican villages, the refugees would share schools and medical offices with Mexicans. What they will not share, he said, is employment, particularly in the petroleum industry, which is one of this state's major sources of work. **********''They are not capable of it,'' the Governor said. ''They are capable of agriculture, cattle raising - this is what they are capable of.'' The restriction is also intended to prevent the development of the type of job competition between Guatemalans and Mexicans in southern Mexico that now exists between Americans and illegal Mexican immigrants in the southern United States. **********The first group of refugee families, who moved here earlier this week, appear to be well settled in. Teresa Miguel Pascual, who worked in a bakery in Guatemala, is already running a Pepsi concession at the entrance of the hut where she lives with four other members of her family. In many of the huts, straw mats are spread over mounds of dirt for beds; guitars are commonplace, one way of passing the long idle hours.   'Don't Know What's Happening' **********Despite what comfort may be found here, however, thoughts still turn to Guatemala and the idea of going home, a place that seems increasingly distant, both physically and mentally. Some talk of relatives they have not seen or heard from in years. ''Really, we don't know what's happening there,'' said Miguel Angel Garcia, a grizzled-looking 45-year-old peasant wearing sandals and a straw hat typical of the countryside. ''We don't hear anything.'' **********Many, like Francisco Diego, a 31- year-old refugee from San Miguel Acatan in Guatemala's Huehuetenango Province, said he heard on the radio that ''the war is still continuing.'' Mr. Perez, from Gracias a Dios, said that ''the Government here said they will tell us'' when it is safe to return. **********Mexican officials, meanwhile, say the flow of new refugees has just about come to a halt. When asked why this does not mean it is safe for the refugees to return to Guatemala, an Interior Ministry official answered with a shrug. **********Some have resigned themselves to living out their lives as refugees in a foreign land. At 95 years of age, Felix Francisco of Nanton, in the Guatemalan province of Quiche, sat with a small plaid-cloth bundle of his belongings near his 75-year-old wife, Elena. ''We came because of the war,'' he said, his moustache quivering. His wife added, ''We came happily, because we were afraid.'' **********Of returning to Guatemala, he no longer had any hopes. ''No more - no more,'' Mr. Francisco said. ''Once we are here, here we will stay.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/09/busin.body_text: **********The British Government is still considering plans by British Telecom and the International Business Machines Corporation to form a jointly owned British electronic information network, an Industry Department spokesman said, but it might take several more weeks for a decision to be reached. The project has been heavily criticized by British electronics manufacturers and software companies. The project would offer an array of network services to the banking, retailing and insurance sectors, such as computerized ordering and payments, through a company equally owned by the two companies, a British Telecom spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/25/world.main_headline: STRICT NEW PRESS RESTRICTIONS ARE IMPOSED IN CHILE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/25/world.print_headline: STRICT NEW PRESS RESTRICTIONS ARE IMPOSED IN CHILE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/25/world.body_text: **********The Government issued tough restrictions today on press coverage of demonstrations by opposition groups. **********The measures come in the wake of stepped-up bombing incidents and will also affect the coverage of a national strike planned for next week. **********Six bombs went off Tuesday, including one near Concepcion that halted rail service for a few hours, according to the Government press agency. Last week, three dynamite blasts blacked out Santiago for nearly 24 hours. The Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, a Communist group, took responsibility for the blackout. **********The press guidelines, which were issued by Gen. Rene Vidal, the military commander of Santiago, ban the reporting of statements from opposition groups taking responsibility for a ''terrorist'' act. **********Newspapers and magazines are also prohibited from placing reports about demonstrations on the front page. Moreover only Government photos and graphics may be used to illustrate articles about demonstrations. **********Radio stations, according to the decree, must report demonstrations in the ''most disengaged way possible so as not to alarm people.'' Radio Chilena, which is owned by the Roman Catholic Church, is barred from broadcasting any news reports. **********The sanction against the Catholic station was precipitated by a broadcast Tuesday saying that Gen. Fernando Matthei, the air force commander and one of the four junta members, had offered his resignation. General Matthei had denied the report on Monday, and today's decree said the station had ''alarmed the populace.'' **********There had been speculation that General Matthei might resign because of what appeared to be a disagreement within the Government over the timetable to return Chile to democracy. In early October, General Matthei said he favored early legislative elections. President Augusto Pinochet said he would adhere to the timetable in the 1980 Constitution, which calls for presidential elections in 1989. **********The air force commander has since denied that he said anything new or anything that disagreed with General Pinochet. **********Foreign diplomats said that there did not appear to be any split in the junta, and they were perplexed by General Matthei's statement. **********General Vidal has the authority to impose press restrictions under the state of emergency that was put into effect in March 1983. **********Last March, General Vidal restricted the coverage of four magazines run by opposition parties for one month. After demonstrations in September, the military barred two radio stations from broadcasting news programs for two days. At the same time, the opposition magazines were prevented from printing photographs. The retriction on printing photographs, was the only remaining restriction against the press. **********The latest restrictions affect nearly all the news organizations. **********Radio Chilena said the Government's restrictions were unjust and arbitrary. It was unclear how they would affect support for the national strike on Oct. 30. **********So far, the strike has had difficulty winning support from any of the major unions such as the copper workers or the oil workers unions. **********The strike order was issued by 160 union activists, but was not supported by the rank and file. **********So far, only a few merchants and the Democratic Popular Movement, a Communist-led coalition, has come out in support of the strike. **********The strikers are demanding a ''prompt return'' to democracy. Under the state of emergency, unions are prohitibed from striking unless the strike is the result of a breakdown in collective bargaining. **********A strike last year resulted in some 5,000 copper miners losing their jobs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/25/busin.body_text: **********Consumer prices in the 10-nation European Economic Community rose five- tenths of 1 percent in September from August and 6.6 percent from 12 months before, Eurostat, the community's statistics agency, said today. Eurostat said Greece recorded the largest increase over the month at 2.8 percent, while prices fell one-tenth of 1 percent in Luxembourg, for the best performance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/world.main_headline: U.S. SAYS THE CHERNENKO SPEECH HINTS DOOR MAY BE OPEN TO TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/world.print_headline: U.S. SAYS THE CHERNENKO SPEECH HINTS DOOR MAY BE OPEN TO TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/14/world.body_text: **********The United States said today that it welcomed some apparently conciliatory comments in the speech by the new Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko. American officials said the comments suggested that the door might be open to reviving a dialogue. **********Senior Reagan Administration officials said Mr. Chernenko's speech, which he gave after being chosen as the new General Secretary of the Communist Party, broke no major new ground. But they said it appeared to respond indirectly to President Reagan's call for a new ''constructive dialogue.'' **********Late this afternoon, President Reagan arrived at the Soviet Embassy in Washington and signed the condolence book for Yuri V. Andropov that was opened to the public this morning. The White House said Mr. Reagan signed this message: **********''Please accept my condolences on the death of Chairman Andropov and convey my sympathy to his family.'' **********The White House said Mr. Reagan had signed a similar book after the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev in 1982. **********In responding to Mr. Chernenko's speech, State Department officials glossed over his tough-sounding words. Instead they focused on his comments about Soviet readiness to ''cooperate with'' countries that were prepared to help lessen tensions ''through practical deeds.'' **********From the context of his remarks, he could have been placing responsibility on the United States to come up with ''practical deeds,'' a position voiced earlier by Mr. Andropov in responding to Mr. Reagan's overture. **********But the State Department chose to put a more positive interpretation on Mr. Chernenko's remarks by making it appear that it was the Soviet Union that was ready to offer ''practical deeds.'' **********The senior Administration officials said they expected Mr. Chernenko to move cautiously in foreign affairs and rely, perhaps more than had any previous Soviet leader, on collective decisions within the ruling Politburo. **********Nevertheless, the intelligence officials, who are experts on the Soviet Union, said Mr. Chernenko appeared committed to the policy of detente fostered by his mentor, Mr. Brezhnev. **********The intelligence officials said Mr. Chernenko, 72 years old, who took part in the last Soviet-American summit meeting, set a more moderate tone by avoiding detailed criticism of American policy. **********The State Department, in a statement that deliberately avoided any mention of Mr. Chernenko's criticism of ''some leaders of the capitalist countries,'' said, ''We do of course welcome his expressed support for solving international disputes through negotiation.'' **********Mr. Reagan, in an interview with the Knight-Ridder newspapers, today rejected the idea of a ''get- acquainted'' summit meeting with Mr. Chernenko but expressed interest in a meeting with the Soviet leader that would consider an ''agenda'' of substantive issues. **********Visit Possible in '84 **********Under an agreement with Knight- Ridder, the White House is not making public the text of the interview with the President until Tuesday. The thrust of his comments were reported tonight by The Washington Post, a Knight-Ridder news service subscriber. **********Mr. Reagan's remarks were consistent with recent statements by the White House. Shortly after the death of Yuri V. Andropov last week, a White House official said that one of the reasons Mr. Reagan had decided against going to the funeral was his hope that he could visit the Soviet Union later in the year, but only after he had received some assurances that there was a good likelihood for a successful outcome to the meeting. **********In the last months of Mr. Andropov's tenure, substantive talks between the two countries virtually ceased and relations seemed to harden on both sides. Now, on the basis of President Reagan's emphasis in the last month on opening serious talks and the hints in Mr. Chernenko's speech, the mood within the Administration is clearly one of sensing that an opportunity might develop.   Bush Asks to See Chernenko **********Vice President Bush, who will be in Moscow for the Andropov funeral on Tuesday, has asked to see Mr. Chernenko, and State Department officials said Mr. Bush was authorized to stress an American desire for talks that might lead to a summit meeting. **********''I think we have bottomed out in relations,'' one senior State Department official said, ''and we're probably going to see a gradual probing on both sides, leading perhaps to enough progress to warrant a meeting between Reagan and the Soviet leaders later in the year.'' **********The official said he used the term ''Soviet leaders'' because it was possible that Mr. Chernenko may have to share power, as occurred in the first years of Mr. Brezhnev's tenure.  American analysts of Soviet affairs, in examining the text of Mr. Chernenko's speech, said they were struck by the lack of any direct criticism of either the United States or Mr. Reagan. His criticism instead pointed at ''some leaders of the capitalist countries.'' Mr. Andropov, in his statements in recent months, often singled out the Reagan Administration for attack.   Chernenko Comment is Quoted **********Mr. Chernenko said the Soviet Union ''will cooperate in full measure with all states that are prepared to assist through practical deeds to lessening international tensions and creating an atmosphere of trust in the world.'' **********The State Department statement spoke of the Soviet Union's own ''readiness to 'assist through practical deeds in lessening international tensions' '' and went on to say: **********''As the President has stated, these are our goals as well. What is needed is to move from words to deeds in building a more constructive U.S.-Soviet relationship.'' **********Mr. Chernenko has built his career as a senior apparatchik, mostly under the direct patronage of Mr. Brezhnev, whom he first met in Soviet Moldavia after World War II when Mr. Brezhnev headed the party there.  Mr. Brezhnev promoted him in the late 1970's to become a party secretary and then to be a member of the ruling Politburo. **********Over all, one authority on Soviet affairs said today, Mr. Chernenko has developed the reputation of being a ''team player.'' Mr. Brezhnev relied on him completely, the analyst said. **********In Mr. Brezhnev's last years in office, when he was physically able to work only an hour or two a day, Mr. Chernenko was inseparable from him, an analyst said, performing tasks that would usually be assigned to personal aides rather than to a Politburo leader.   Role at Vienna Talks Recalled **********He was with Mr. Brezhnev at the Helsinki conference on security and cooperation in Europe in 1975 when Mr. Brezhnev met with President Ford. And he was in Vienna in June 1979 when Mr. Brezhnev and President Carter signed the treaty on limiting strategic arms. **********At the Vienna meeting, Mr. Chernenko did not leave much of an impression on the American participants, who said they tried and failed to engage him in serious conversation at a dinner Mr. Carter and Mr. Brezhnev held with only a few aides. Zbigniew Brzezinski, then the national security adviser, said Mr. Chernenko ''was jovial and quite amiable in private conversation'' on peripheral matters, but cautious and close-mouthed on significant issues. **********Former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said Mr. Chernenko was ''very much in the background at the dinner and did not say anything of significance.'' **********''However,'' he said, ''in recent years I have talked to a number of officials in the Soviet hierarchy who have told me that in the last few years, Mr. Chernenko has assumed a stronger and more positive role and has not hesitated to speak out.''

Both had owned 50 percent of the venture, which is at the Geysers geothermal field about 90 miles north of San Francisco. **********The companies expect to complete the deal Jan. 1, when Union will buy the stock of a Shamrock subsidiary, the Thermal Power Company. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/19/busin.main_headline: MEXICAN BORDER PLANTS BEGINING TO HIRE MEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/19/busin.print_headline: MEXICAN BORDER PLANTS BEGINING TO HIRE MEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/19/busin.body_text: **********After years of being a nearly all-female preserve, Mexico's border assembly plants have begun to employ men. **********The move is being taken not only to meet a steadily rising demand for labor, according to officials and businessmen here, but also to try to repair the social damage done by putting nearly all the available women into the work force while leaving many men unemployed. **********''We had become a matriarchy,'' said Arnulfo Castro Munive, president of the Association of Maquiladoras, the Mexican name for the border assembly plants. ''It had ruptured the social equilibrium.'' **********Established in 1966 **********The maquiladora industry was established by law in 1966 to bring development to Mexico's northern border. **********Under Mexican law, manufacturers are allowed to import parts without normal duties or restrictions for assembly here so long as the assembled products do not remain in Mexico. Under United States law, the companies pay duties on the return trip only on the value added in the assembly process.  Thus many companies produce parts in a factory on the American side of the border, ship them to their plants in Mexico for assembly, and then ship them back. **********Employment in the assembly industry in this city soared by 19 percent last year, to 63,000, largely because the steady devaluation of the Mexican peso has made labor costs increasingly attractive to American business. An assembly line worker here now earns the equivalent of $28 for a 45-hour workweek. **********Border-wide, the growth was about 11 percent in 1983. Some 140,000 people were employed in the assembly industry at the end of the year, producing about $900 million worth of goods. More than half consisted of electrical and electronics products. **********Why Women Are Employed **********The companies involved, which include RCA, Sylvania, General Motors and Chrysler, say they have traditionally employed women because women are more suited to the repetitive tasks involved in the assembly process. A 1979 study by a Stanford University political scientist, Michael Van Waas, also found that the ''passivity'' of Mexican women made them more attractive to the American concerns. **********But as the industry grew, labor shortages developed and ''the women began to take advantage of the situation,'' Mr. Castro said. ''If they didn't like what they were doing, they would just quit because they knew they could find work someplace else.'' **********In addition, because employment outside the maquiladoras is hard to find in Mexico's hard-scrabble border towns, many men found themselves with nothing to do while their wives went to work. This led to ''a type of social disequilibrium,'' said the city's new Mayor, Francisco J. Barrio, that brought increases in crime, alcoholism and divorce. **********Mr. Castro said that by the end of last year, nearly one in three workers at the assembly plants were men. The goal is to raise the proportion of male workers to 60 percent by the end of the decade, he added. **********Men Now Cautious **********Word of the change has been slow in getting out, and many men are hesitant to seek jobs in an industry identified as ''women's work.'' **********Only about 10 percent of the maquiladora workers in Juarez are unionized, far below the national average. ''If you don't feel the need, you're not going to unionize,'' Mr. Castro said. ''All you have to do is treat them like human beings - people who have feelings, who cry, who get sick.'' **********Mr. Van Waas's study found that payoffs to union officials and a few well-publicized shutdowns in the wake of strikes also helped to diminish union activity. **********Few Mexican Products Used **********Thus far, the maquiladora industry's benefit to Mexico has been almost solely in providing employment. Few Mexican products are used in the assembly process, according to a study by the Banco Nacional de Mexico, partly because of ''restrictive practices'' of the manufacturers and partly because of ''poor quality, insufficient supply and deficient deliveries, as well as lack of interest on the part of local manufacturers.'' **********So while several of the border plants assemble high-quality, moderately priced televisions, for example, a similar product remains dear - and often shoddy - in the Mexican marketplace. A 12-inch black-and- white set in Mexico City costs 30 percent to 50 percent more than its counterpart in New York City. **********The National Association of Manufacturers recently estimated that as a result of this discrepancy in price and quality, one of every two appliances in Mexican households was reported to be contraband. **********''The industry here has not had enough time in the country for us to share our skills with the rest of the country,'' Mr. Castro said. He added that import restrictions also limited its ability to produce high-quality, competitive goods for local buyers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/19/world.main_headline: U.S. READY TO TRY TO LIMIT THE WAR IN PERSIAN GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/19/world.print_headline: U.S. READY TO TRY TO LIMIT THE WAR IN PERSIAN GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/19/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration today reaffirmed its determination to try to limit the war between Iran and Iraq. **********The statement came amid growing international alarm over attacks on oil shipping in the Persian Gulf and a new assertion by Iraq that its warplanes had damaged more vessels there. **********The spokesman for the State Department, John Hughes, said the United States was ''prepared to work with others, particularly the states of the region, in common efforts to contain the effects of this tragic war,'' but sought to minimize any appearance of a military crisis. **********3 Tankers Hit This Week **********Iraq said today that its planes had attacked and damaged two large ships in the Persian Gulf, but Pentagon officials said they could not confirm the report. At least 17 ships have reportedly been attacked in recent months by Iraqi or Iranian warplanes. One Saudi tanker and two from Kuwait were reportedly hit by Iran this week. **********The Teheran radio today quoted Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, as saying that if the United States and the Soviet Union intervened in the conflict Iran ''should prepare itself for war throughout the world.'' Japan expressed worry over attacks on tankers in the gulf and urged restraint by Iran and Iraq. But a Foreign Ministry official said Japan did not regard itself as a possible mediator in the war, even though it is the only major industrial country that maintains friendly relations with both sides. (Page 5.) **********Tass Accuses the U.S. **********In Moscow, the official Soviet press agency Tass accused Washington today of ''taking advantage of the deterioration of the situation'' in the gulf and of preparing for ''a fresh aggression.'' **********President Reagan has vowed to keep open the Strait of Hormuz, which leads from the Persian Gulf into the Indian Ocean, and is a vital passageway for Western oil supplies. **********According to a spokesman for the Navy, American warships in the gulf currently consist of one guided missile destroyer and four frigates. An aircraft carrier task force led by the nuclear- powered Kitty Hawk is operating routinely in the North Arabian Sea; it includes two destroyers, two frigates, one cruiser and a supply ship. **********Although they normally operate at a higher level of readiness than American warships in other parts of the world, none of these vessels, or any Navy ships in the Mediterranean, have been specially positioned in recent days because of tensions in the region, the Navy spokesman said. **********Officials have refused to speculate on military contingencies for American forces, other than to say that Washington has discussed with gulf countries the possibility of providing air cover for commercial oil tankers. But if the United States was called upon to defend gulf shipping against further attacks, the most crucial factor would be availability of bases in Saudi Arabia, according to military experts. **********A source on the House Armed Services Committee familiar with military operations in the gulf region said that there were enough United States forces in the area now to provide protection but that the problem was bringing them close enough to operate efficiently. Maintaining continuous air support over gulf ports from the Kitty Hawk stationed in the Arabian Sea, for example, would be technically feasible but very expensive. **********Eugene J. Carroll Jr., a retired Navy rear admiral now with the Center for Defense Information here, who commanded the Sixth Fleet carrier group from 1975 to 1977, said a likely contingency if United States forces were called into action would be to pull the Kitty Hawk into the throat of the Gulf of Oman. Combat air patrols of F-14 jet fighters, probably requiring airborne refueling by the Kitty Hawk's KA-6 tankers, would then be continuously maintained. **********A far superior alternative, Mr. Carroll said, would be if Saudi Arabia agreed to permit American military operations on its territory. In this case, he said, squadrons of Air Force F-15's could be flown out of Dhahran on the Persian Gulf's western shore. It would take about 36 hours, he added, to bring the F-15's from Air Force bases in the United States. **********Although the United States imports only about 5 percent of its oil from gulf countries, Western Europe and Japan are heavily dependent on supplies from the region. Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan called today for an international halt on arms supplies to Iran and Iraq. **********A study issued today by the House Committee on Government Operations concluded that the United States would be ill prepared to meet its obligations to share oil with its allies if the Iran- Iraq war led to a cutoff of Persian Gulf supplies. **********Arab countries have appeared to accept attacks on shipping in the Iran- Iraq war zone, becoming enraged only when strikes occurred in neutral waters or coastal areas claimed by nonbelligerents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/11/busin.body_text: **********A $46.9 million issue of Dallas general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 6.50 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.20 percent in 1994 and 10.30 percent in 2004. The underwriters are led by the Interfirst Bank Dallas. **********Because of the city's strong economic base, rapid growth and history of strong finances, Dallas bonds are among the highest-quality bonds in the tax-exempt market. **********Analysts at Prescott, Ball & Turben noted in a recent research report that the bonds were secured by the city's ability to levy property taxes within a limit of $2.50 per $100 of assessed value. For 1985, the Prescott, Ball analysts added, the city's tax rate is to be only 49 cents per $100, and it has declined 13.1 percent since 1981. **********Dallas and Los Angeles are the only cities among the nation's 30 largest to carry the highest Aaa rating from Moody's Investors Service. Last April, Houston's bond rating was lowered by Moody's to Aa-1 from Aaa. Standard & Poor's also assigned its highest AAA rating to the Dallas bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/13/world.main_headline: SHARON IS BEATEN BY SHAMIR IN VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/13/world.print_headline: SHARON IS BEATEN BY SHAMIR IN VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/13/world.body_text: **********Yitzhak Shamir was nominated by the Likud bloc today to run for a second term as Prime Minister in elections July 23. He defeated former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, 407 to 306. **********The margin of Mr. Shamir's victory was far narrower than had been expected, and added to speculation that Mr. Sharon had begun laying the groundwork for a political comeback. **********Mr. Sharon, who is a member of the Cabinet without portfolio, was relieved of his defense duties last year after an inquiry commission said he was indirectly responsible for the massacre of Palestinians in Beirut refugee camps. **********Mr. Sharon, who had not expected to win, indicated that he went into the contest to gain support for his demand to be restored to a policy- making Government role.   Cheering and Sustained Clapping **********Some political commentators speculated tonight that the unexpectedly large number of votes for Mr. Sharon reflected a feeling that he had not been treated fairly. Experts interviewed on television before the vote was announced said a 20 percent showing would be considered impressive. **********Mr. Sharon's supporters rose to their feet cheering and clapping rhythmically for several minutes when the result was announced. After the vote Mr.  Sharon called for the party to stand 100 percent behind Mr. Shamir in the election campaign. **********The Prime Minister, thanking Mr. Sharon for his statement, said he hoped a new chapter would be opened in their relationship. **********Earlier today, in interviews with news organizations, Mr. Shamir firmly resisted committing himself to assigning his rival a position of leadership in the next administration. **********The vote was conducted by the central committee of Herut, the largest component in the Likud bloc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/27/world.main_headline: AFGHAN DRIVE: A COSTLY GAIN FOR RUSSIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/27/world.print_headline: AFGHAN DRIVE: A COSTLY GAIN FOR RUSSIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/27/world.body_text: **********Intelligence analysts studying the often conflicting reports from Afghanistan have concluded that Soviet forces won a considerable but not decisive success in their recent offensive there, but at a higher cost in casualties than they expected.  One British source put Soviet losses in the Panjshir Valley at 500 men, plus 2,000 more throughout the country since the offensive started in mid-April. **********The analysts - in Washington, in other NATO capitals and Pakistan - said the losses were considered serious for a force that reportedly had lost only 5,000 men since the Soviet intervention began in late 1979. **********Some experts on the Soviet order of battle said they believed that, as a consequence, Soviet forces were being strengthened by the addition of fresh units. One estimate is that the reinforcements will push total strength to about 120,000 men. **********Militarily, the most significant development of the operations has been the extensive and successful use of the air force. According to neutral observers citing insurgent information, Soviet pilots performed with efficiency against insurgent strongpoints and troops caught in the open.   Firebombs Reported Used **********According to Jane's Defense Weekly, the Russians also used liquid firebombs.  These burst into flame on contact with the ground. There have been reports, never verified, that munitions of this type had been used earlier. **********The bombing, both at high altitude and at low level, appears to have been effective. Camouflaged and well protected rebel positions have been taken out by fighter-bombers guided to their targets by forward air controllers flying in helicopters and marking the targets by smoke. Casualties among civilians are believed to have been high. **********The Su-25, code-named Frogfoot by NATO, appears to have been the most effective fixed-wing aircraft. Operating in pairs, the Su-25's have used their guns, rockets and antipersonnel bombs against key targets. The tactics are to come in at a low level after the target has been marked and the results were described by one analyst as devastating.   Up to 100 Sorties a Day **********At the height of the operations, the source said, the air force was flying at least 100 sorties a day. A sortie is one mission by one aircraft. **********Some of the planes flew from bases in the Soviet Union, a British source said. Others were based in Afghanistan. **********One result of the success of the Soviet air tactics has been the movement of thousands of refugees into Pakistan. Common misery, a Pakistani source said, has not brought unity among the insurgents. **********He and other well-qualified sources report that rivalry among insurgent bands continues to the detriment of the military effort. He said he knew of cases in which one insurgent group, learning that another was about to attack the Russians, would inform the Soviet side to insure the defeat of the rival faction. **********American military sources, reviewing the offensive, noted that the Russians appear to have achieved a marriage between their helicopter forces and ground troops.   Coverage of Ground Attacks **********Infantry and armored fighting vehicle attacks were invariably covered by helicopter forces that engaged hostile ground forces and prevented attacks on the Soviet flanks. The ground attacks, allied sources report, customarily followed bombing by fixed-wing bombers carrying out carpet bombing of the operations area. **********The Russians also used helicopters successfully to land ground forces on mountain summits commanding the Panjshir Valley and its tributary valleys. Ground forces were also landed when reconnaissance reported insurgent units gathering for attack. In one such operation, south of the Salang Tunnel on the main highway from the Soviet Union, it is estimated that an insurgent force of 1,500 men was routed by helicopter-borne infantry. **********In contrast to American operations in Vietnam, helicopters with or without infantrymen aboard are able to spot insurgents unshielded by jungle. Many intelligence sources believe that the recent operations were evidence of a higher sophistication in planning and maneuver than earlier operations.   No Way of Checking Rebel Claims **********The quality of the rebels is difficult to assess, intelligence sources say. **********By their own testimony, the guerrillas inflicted serious losses on the Soviet forces, but there is no way of checking their claims. Their own losses, intelligence analysts said, probably were high and they must expect to take similar losses until they are armed with the antiaircraft and antitank weapons they require to check Soviet attacks. Few such weapons have been reported by neutral obseervers. **********Disunity among the guerrilla bands and a low level of training remain their weakness. One Pakistani source, familiar with the situation, said that in his opinion the insurgents' combat efficiency was well below that of the Vietcong in Vietnam or the Algerian insurrection against the French. **********His view of the future, echoed by Western intelligence analysts, is that the Russians have now cleared the Panjshir Valley to the extent that convoys can move through it. The Russians, these sources agree, are unlikely ever to completely pacify Afghanistan. **********''No one ever has,'' the Pakistani said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/24/busin.body_text: **********The pace of the current economic expansion clearly slowed in the third quarter, but after sifting through the latest data a number of analysts are suggesting that the period of deceleration was short-lived. Rather than continuing to moderate between now and year-end - as projected by many governmental and private economists - the rate of economic growth, some analysts now predict, will increase instead. **********In their interpretation, these economists tend to play down recent Government reports as well as activity in the credit markets that suggest softening conditions. Rather, they focus on renewed vigor in consumer spending, on the positive aspects of speedy resolution of labor negotiations with the automobile and coal workers and on a stabilization and possible improvement in the nation's foreign trade deficit. **********As a result, these analysts now suggest that the gross national product, after adjustment for inflation, could expand at an annual rate of 4.5 percent to 6 percent in the fourth quarter. **********The Summertime Slowdown **********If realized, that would represent a substantial jump from the 3.6 percent rate of rise the Commerce Department announced last week as its ''flash'' estimate of third-quarter growth. **********''There was a definite slowdown in the economy during the summer, particularly in consumer spending, which was at its worst in early August, when we were watching the Olympics,'' said M. Kathryn Eickhoff, executive vice president at Townsend-Greenspan & Company, an economic consulting firm. ''But a reacceleration is already under way. Consumer spending has picked up, auto sales will continue to be strong and the softness in nonresidential fixed investment is not likely to continue.'' **********Miss Eickhoff said that six weeks ago she was projecting a 6 percent growth rate for the third quarter, falling to 4 percent in the fourth quarter. Now she expects output in the fourth quarter to be around 5 percent. **********Contrasting Opinions Held **********But the view that business conditions will firm up during the next three months is not universally held. Many economists continue to stand by their earlier forecasts, which call for a further moderation in growth in the fourth quarter to between 2.5 percent and 3 percent. The Commerce Department's third-quarter estimate, which showed the economy expanding at barely half its pace in the second quarter - a revised 7.1 percent - is no aberration, they contend. **********''In all of the data there is a clear, soft undertone to business at this time,'' said Allen Sinai, a managing director at Shearson Lehman/American Express. ''We don't just have here a pause with a rebound to 4 percent to 5 percent growth in the fourth quarter. We have something more fundamental.'' **********He and others find support for the position that economic growth may stay subdued by noting a reduced level of housing and residential construction activity, a less active consumer and a marked reduction in private credit demand. **********Big Banks' Actions Watched **********The latter development prompted the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company to shave its prime rate by one- fourth percentage point last week, to 12 3/4 percent. **********''I still think that we will have a pretty strong expansion that will continue into late next year,'' said Francis H. Schott, chief economist at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. ''But when major banks judge that something important has happened that warrants a cut in rates, then I have to wonder if they know something that I don't.'' **********As is often the case, the main battle among economists trying to foretell the future centers on consumers, who after six quarters of heavy spending appear to have contributed little to growth in the third quarter. **********''Consumers decided to take a vacation over the summer, especially when the Presidential candidates were talking about messing around with their taxes and there weren't enough cars around to satisfy demand,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities. **********Consumer Spending Outlook **********''If the auto industry goes full throttle and the cars they produce get bought up,'' he said, ''you could possibly see a 6 percent G.N.P. number in the fourth quarter.'' **********Mr. Sinai disagreed. ''Consumers are shifting away from purchases of big ticket items like houses, cars and appliances and are moving toward greater savings,'' he said. ''And if consumer sales slow down, that has to reverberate back to production, orders and employment and income growth.'' **********In its ''flash'' estimate, the Commerce Department said it did not make any adjustment for the effects of the automobile strike, adding that if the strike had continued for the final 10 days of the third quarter, it could have reduced G.N.P. growth by as much as three-tenths percentage point. **********However, Mr. Yardeni and others pointed out that the threat of a prolonged strike did have an effect, as businesses slowed hiring and production plans. And had the walkout continued into the fourth quarter, the effect would have been considerable. **********If the Strike Had Continued **********''If the strike had gone on for all three months of the fourth quarter, it would have knocked the growth rate down by 6 percentage points at an annual rate,'' Townsend-Greenspan's Miss Eickhoff said. ''Now that the strike has been settled, a lot of the risk has been removed from the fourth quarter.'' **********By comparison, a walkout by coal workers, who agreed to a new pact before their strike deadline, would have had a modest effect on the economy, Miss Eickhoff said. **********''If the steel industry was operating at a high rate and coal went out on strike, then it would have had an effect,'' she said. ''But steel is producing so little. And the electric utilities, which were buying up coal in anticipation of a strike, appear to have enough to get us through the winter.'' **********In spite of their differing views on output, economists of all stripes seem agreed on one thing: Inflation will remain quite moderate. **********''The inflation numbers still look terrific,'' said Donald Straszheim, a vice president at Wharton Econometrics. ''As measured by the Consumer Price Index, an inflation rate of between 4 percent and 5 percent is likely in the fourth quarter.''
