https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/12/busin.main_headline: BOON TO SMALL BUSINES: ELECTRONIC LEDGERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/12/busin.print_headline: BOON TO SMALL BUSINES: ELECTRONIC LEDGERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/12/busin.body_text: **********The booming use of personal computers is enabling thousands of small enterprises - lumber yards and law offices, small banks, shops and farms - to do a better job of running their businesses. **********With a speed and precision that was once enjoyed only by the nation's largest companies, they can now figure finances, control inventories and compute costs - in short, get a better grip on their own business destiny. **********''There is nothing the computer does that we couldn't do before,'' said Albert P. Oliveira, who uses it to track a score of salespeople for the Equipment Sales Company here in Lowell. ''But it is so incredibly fast, and easy, that we can do far more.'' **********Driving this headlong overhaul of business practices are not the small computers themselves, but the remarkably popular genre of personal computer programs known as electronic spreadsheets. **********The spreadsheet software is an electronic version of the pale-green columned paper, pencils and erasers that small companies have used for generations to lay out, in neat rows and columns, sales for the month or pending orders - all in an effort to figure out where their business stood at any particular moment. **********The task was tedious and uninviting. Changing one number in one column could require recalculating dozens of other entries. **********Now, with the press of a button, the computerized spreadsheets can execute tasks that used to take hours. The spreadsheet programs have led the flourishing software market and, experts say, spurred sales of personal computers. **********The spreadsheets have also opened up dozens of new applications. Some owners of small businesses, who concede that until lately they would not have known what software was, say they now crave statistical information they never before knew they needed.  It is not uncommon today, for example, for the shoe store owner to turn to a computer to figure the value of his inventories, product by product, in an effort to keep costs down. Nor is it rare for a small-town builder to use the computer to prepare a bid for building a house, breaking out each component of costs for labor and materials, rather than relying on guesswork. **********''It has been something of an amazing revolution,'' said Douglas F. Cobb, vice president of the Que Corporation, an Indianapolis publisher that turns out a newsletter for spreadsheet users. ''I have never seen a single tool that people tried to use for more different things than an electronic spreadsheet.'' **********Nowhere is the effect of this quiet revamping of small-business practices more visible than in Lowell, a revived mill town, at the offices of Equipment Sales, which both sells equipment that tests electronic circuit boards and assembles many boards at its factory. **********For years, Mr. Oliveira, executive vice president of Equipment Sales, kept track of his 20 traveling salesmen with a calculator and a wide, green sheet of paper he spread across his desk. He painstakingly created half a dozen columns across the page and detailed who sold what, how much each of the salesmen was owed in commissions for each of 30 separate products and how their performance compared with the previous year. **********'An Unspeakable Pain' **********It was boring, repetitive work that Mr. Oliveira dreaded. ''An unspeakable pain in the neck,'' he said. **********Now the ruled pad and calculator sit untouched in a desk drawer, replaced by an International Business Machines Corporation Personal Computer and 1-2-3 software from the Lotus Development Corporation. Mr. Oliveira has become so enthralled that he uses the computers and software to track the whereabouts of thousands of circuit boards the company assembles. **********Thousands of executives have purchased electronic spreadsheet programs, which sell for $100 to $600, and modified them to fit the exact needs of their companies. The financial data must still be entered by hand, but the endless process of revision and recalculation is gone. **********Hit on Wall Street **********The programs are a particular hit on Wall Street for designing and testing financial models. But they are also a hit in less likely places, like Caldwell, Idaho, where Johnson's Llamas maintains its modest offices. **********The Idaho enterprise is run by O. David Johnson, a physician who decided a few years ago to raise llamas on the side, selling them as pets and to companies that run pack trips. But keeping track of more than 70 animals and figuring the cost of feeding and boarding them in summer and winter became an overwhelming task. Now all of that information is stored in his Apple II and a spreadsheet called Visicalc. **********''At any moment, I have a printout of what llama is where, and how much it costs me to keep him,'' Dr. Johnson reported. ''There is no question it has saved me money.'' **********Spreadsheets were orignally intended to save time, not money. The first, Visicalc, was the product of a Harvard Business School student's frustration at endlessly erasing and recalculating numbers used to analyze corporate strategies in the school's case study methods. The student teamed up with a computer programmer, and the result was Visicalc, a ''first generation'' spreadsheet. It has been followed by ''integrated programs,'' such as Lotus 1-2- 3, which not only keep track of the numbers but also spit out pie charts and line graphs that illustrate the data, or merge the financial information into a letter or report. **********A Coach's Blackboard **********No matter what refinements are added, however, the programs are as instantly recognizable to business people as a blackboard would be to a football coach. ''It's something every businessman has created sometime, even if he didn't know what to call it,'' Mr. Cobb said. **********A typical use might be in an auto parts store, where the owner has to take inventory. He might start by making at least three headings across the top of a piece of paper. The first might be marked ''Number of Units in Stock'' and the second, ''Price Per Unit.'' The third, arrived at by multiplying the figures in the first two, might be marked ''Value of Units in Stock.'' Additional columns might figure the cost of sales - such as the overhead involved in storing the part - and the profit margin on each item. **********On each line, the store owner would enter the figures: on one line sparkplugs might be listed, on the next rear-view mirrors, and so on for hundreds of items in stock. By tallying the values in the third column, the worth of all the store's stock could be determined. **********If done on paper, a revision of any single number on the spreadsheet could throw off all the totals, and the records could quickly fall out of date. But in electronic spreadsheets, whenever a single number is changed, all those below it are automatically refigured. **********'What If' Projections **********That is why the ''what if'' projections are so popular: A food manufacturer, for example, could figure out how much it would cost to change ingredients, and how that would affect profit. **********The electronic spreadsheet is no panacea. It takes users of most of the programs a few days to get accustomed to what can appear to be an intimidating new language. And all of the data must be entered into the computer, a task no less tedious than writing them out on paper. **********But the calculations, the hardest and most error-prone steps, are done by the computer. Many who use the systems say they find themselves getting so proficient ''speaking the language'' of computers that they have quickly designed customized spreadsheets that answer questions they never before had time to ponder. **********Alan Axelrod, for example, never before had an efficient way to keep track of the dyes he uses to color yarn at the Crown Yarn Dye Corporation of South Attleboro, Mass. **********''The dyes keep changing all the time, and so do their prices,'' he said recently. ''We used to keep that on paper, but it was a mess - cross outs, scribbles, a real disaster.'' **********Now he keeps that information on a spreadsheet that runs on his sophisticated Fortune Systems computer. He also uses the spreadsheet to track how much oil and steam he uses; when the figure on steam jumped one week, he discovered a leaky pipe. **********At Equipment Sales in Lowell, the results have been dramatic. The company, which last year became a unit of the Esterline Company, not only sells electronic test equipment to other manufacturers, but ''stuffs,'' or inserts components onto printed circuit boards that form the core of computers and other equipment. **********A Spur to Salesmen **********The spreadsheets were first put to use in tracking sales. ''I essentially made the same sheet that I used to do on paper,'' Mr. Oliveira said. But he added a few things: not only does the sheet determine sales and commissions, but it also calculates this year's sales as a percentage of last year's. Each month the charts are printed and mailed to the salesmen. **********''It's a fabulous tool for us and for them,'' he said. ''There is also a subtle pressure. They see that line,'' he said, pointing to the place at which commissions total more than $100,000, ''and they really go for it.'' **********It is also a diagnostic tool, used for early warning of troubles. By analyzing the reports quickly, Mr. Oliveira discovered recently that sales in parts of California, a prime market for the company, were faltering badly. ''It's something we otherwise would not have seen for several months,'' he said. **********But the real efficiencies did not begin until last October, when the company spent two weeks modifying a spreadsheet to track each of the thousands of printed circuit boards it assembles. While large manufacturers often have automated inventory controls, Equipment Sales was never big enough for that. **********''We used a clipboard and white- lined paper,'' said Valerie Comerford, data services manager for the company. **********Every day, someone would wander through the factory, counting up how many of dozens of different types of boards were still awaiting assembly, how many were assembled but not soldered, how many had been tested, and how many were sitting on the loading dock. ''Even while you are counting, people were picking up the boards and moving them to the next stop,'' she said. ''It was a mess.'' **********Now every afternoon each unit in the factory takes a census that is reported to Miss Comerford and entered into a spreadsheet. The next morning, the data are ready for the daily production meeting, where the company tries to overcome bottlenecks. The data are also used to determine the cost of each step in the manufacturing process, crucial information when the company is bidding on assembly projects.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/13/busin.body_text: **********Fourteen years ago, as the American economy dawdled, an economics professor, Solomon Fabricant, coined the term ''growth recession'' to describe a period in which the economy slows dramatically but keeps sputtering forward. While the economy was still growing, he suggested, the decline in the rate of expansion could seem almostas traumatic as an outright contraction. **********Not everyone approved of the term. Herbert Stein of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers suggested that one might as well call a dog ''a growth horse.'' But the concept stuck, and in the last few months it has became fashionable to describe the current economic slump as a growth recession. (Gross national product grew at an annual rate of only 1.9 percent last quarter, compared with 10.1 percent in the first quarter and 7.1 percent in the second quarter.) **********The problem in many growth recessions has been that the readjustment that takes place has been painful. Even though the economy continues to grow, some production lines are closed down and unemployment often rises. The question that typically arises, then, is what to expect next. Does the growth recession require the kind of measures that would be taken to revive an economy that is contracting, or is the growth recession likely to be self-correcting? **********For the most part, economists today see the slowdown as a useful phase following a period of rapid growth. And while there has been a consensus that faster monetary growth is called for to help revitalize the economy, the pain from the slowdown seems to have been less than might have been expected. Unemployment, for example, has remained almost steady this fall and actually dipped to 7 percent in November. **********The best advice, said David A. Levine, an economist with Sanford D. Bernstein & Company, is ''to be very philosophical'' about the current slump. Slowdowns of this sort tend to be largely self-correcting, he noted, expressing a view held by many economists. And since inflation is not a threat, he added, there is room for a more relaxed monetary policy. **********Economists Optimistic **********In fact Mr. Levine and others say that it is quite common for an expanding economy to move into a period of subdued growth. In most cases, such a pause has allowed the economy to digest its previous growth, and to spring forward with new vigor. So far as the current growth recession goes, economists are optimistic that it will be a beneficial one that paves the way for further growth. **********''Is it bad? Is it good? Is it a prelude to a recession? That really depends on what else is going on,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of Shearson Lehman/American Express, of the current pause in growth. ''It's not necessarily bad; indeed in this case - it sounds perverse - but I think it is positive. Less than potential growth sets up diminished demand- pull inflation. Less inflation suggests lower interest rates. The pair, less inflation and lower interest rates, would lengthen the expansion.'' **********Saul Hymans, professor of economics and director of forecasting at the University of Michigan, also believes this growth recession will lead to nothing worse. He predicts a strong surge of growth next year, fueled in part by declining interest rates. **********Each Cycle Is Different **********Each business cycle is different. In most recoveries, however, various segments of the economy bound ahead, some more strongly than others. This eventually leads to imbalances. Inventories may begin to mount faster than sales, or interest rates may soar to levels that discourage borrowing. As business is reined in, the economy slows. In the current slowdown, inventories accumulated and the trade deficit deteriorated, both of which acted as a drag on growth. **********A growth recession usually returns to full steam by some of the same mechanisms that return a real recession to growth. Typically, interest rates are tugged down by declining economic activity, until eventually they are so low that people start borrowing again. In addition, inventory surpluses are gradually eliminated, and new orders pick up. Moreover, the slow growth usually eases worries by the Federal Reserve about inflation, so it eases its grip on the nation's money. **********One reason why many economists are bullish for 1985 is that the record of past growth recessions is encouraging. In most growth recessions, the economy grows at an average of 2 percent or less for two or more quarters. (Economists use varying criteria to measure growth recessions.) Of the 19 quarters between 1950 and 1984 when economic growth was positive but less that 2 percent, 13 were followed by quarters in which the gross national product increased at an annual rate of 2 percent or more. **********Geoffrey H. Moore, an expert in business cycles at Columbia Business School, identifies three growth recessions and seven true recessions since World War II. The slowdowns he isolates occurred in 1951 to 1952, 1962 to 1963 and 1966 to 1967. **********''This resembles more the growth recession than the real one,'' he said, referring to the present slowdown. ''But we haven't completed our research. This is still preliminary.'' **********Likewise, Goldman, Sachs & Company expects the economy to bounce back next year, based in part on comparisons with growth recessions in 1962 to 1963, and in 1976. In 1976, for example, G.N.P. boomed at a 9.1 percent clip during the first quarter, but then fell to a rate of about 2.5 percent for the next six months. After climbing to 3.7 percent in the fourth quarter, the economy registered a zippy 8.9 percent in 1977's first three months. **********Helpful Decline in Rates Seen **********Rosanne Cahn, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, said she expected the declines in interest rates to help pull the economy back into gear next year. But she, like other economists, does not expect more of the 8 percent growth that the United States enjoyed from mid-1983 to mid-1984. **********Mr. Levine of Bernstein said that most of the period since the Korean War could be divided into ''booms'' followed by slowdowns. He isolates 11 booms - of which the latest recovery was the last - and believes we are now entering the 11th slowdown. **********Because these slowdowns have lasted an average of 3.3 quarters, depending largely on how quickly inventory growth slowed, he believes the present slowdown will last about a year. Inventories continued to pile up in the third quarter, after the growth recession began, he noted. **********A minority of economists believes the present phase in the United States is not a growth recession at all but simply a transition to a real recession. Roger Williams, former chief economist at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, who now publishes an economic newsletter in Orangeburg, N.Y., said he expected a recession because of the drag on the economy from the trade deficit, large inventories and other factors. **********''Because of the lag in reporting, we don't know how far the slide has gone,'' he said. ''And it may well have slipped into the negative column this month. This means, of course, the beginning of recession by any definition of the word.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/16/busin.body_text: **********For major stock groups, the market's plunge in the last five weeks has brought mostly gloom, but there have been slight glimmers of light here and there. **********The worst performing stocks - almost without exception - have been those that had performed the best in the early days of the bull market. Building materials companies, appliance manufacturers, savings and loans and other ''interest sensitive'' businesses tied to the housing industry have rapidly fallen from favor. Likewise, large electronics and computer companies, aluminum manufacturers and transportation companies that saw their stock prices rise steadily last year have fallen back. **********But domestic oil companies, up 7.9 percent and international oil companies, up 2 percent, have performed better, in the last five weeks, than every other segment measured by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, although analysts are quick to point out that ''doing well'' in such a market becomes relative. And the analysts recall that the oil companies, as a group, were not only lackluster when the bull market began rolling forward in the second half of 1982, but also declined in value when most other issues were soaring. **********Besides the two oils segments, only New York City banks, copper companies and property insurance companies generally avoided stock value declines. That is just five categories of the 89 followed by S. & P. **********'It's a Complicated Market' **********''It's a complicated market, but, generally, stocks that have been the hardest hit are those where expectations were too high last year,'' said A. Marshall Acuff Jr., director of portfolio management for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. He added that stocks that have either gained value or declined only slightly in the downturn are issues ''where expectations have been low all along.'' **********Indeed, changing expectations have meant that ''high beta stocks,'' or those that tend to respond in an exaggerated way to changing economic conditions, have been among the worst performing issues, said Elaine M. Garzarelli, a senior investment strategist for A. G. Becker Inc. Among these ''high beta'' issues, all of which had performed well early in the bull market, were electronics companies, airlines and building materials concerns, she said. **********Among decliners, mobile home makers and aluminunm companies, which had been the earliest and most dramatic beneficiaries of the bull market, fell the most. Air freight companies, furniture and appliance manufacturers, and agricultural machinery companies, other stellar performers early in the bull market, also ranked among the five biggest losing categories on the S. & P. list. **********Yesterday, the stock market resumed its bearish trend, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing off 5.13 points. On Tuesday, in a widely unexpected advance, the average rose more than 13 points. **********No Rally Seen **********But many of Wall Street's ranking money managers and investment strategists said they expected stock prices to continue declining for at least another month and then rise slowly, if at all. Their reasoning: Mounting fears about the huge Federal deficit and possible higher interest rates will force institutional money managers away from the stock market into bonds and other fixed-income instruments. **********''It may be a case where the big money managers are so anxious to get out of equities that they can't squeeze out the same exit,'' said L. Howard Nichol, who follows the electronics industry for Advest Inc. **********In fact, some of the large electronics companies, whose stocks had been rising steadilly since the onset of the bull market, have fallen for the first time during the last five weeks. These include International Business Machines and Control Data. Institutional accounts have tended to be heavily weighted with these stocks. **********Interest-sensitive stocks, which tend to rise in value when rates fall and consumer credit becomes more obtainable, have almost all plunged. The exception: The automobile group, usually hurt by the expectation of higher rates but ''holding up well because auto company earnings had been underestimated,'' said Mrs. Garzarelli of A. G. Becker. **********Analysts said the oil companies, which have stood out as the best performing stocks in recent weeks, have benefited from a spate of merger and takeover proposals, and the expectation of more to come. In addition, a relatively cold winter here and in Europe has raised oil demand and apparently made stability of international oil prices more likely. **********Banks and Insurers **********The two other stock groups that performed relatively well - both of which would normally be hurt by the expectation of higher interest rates - were New York City's major banks, and insurers that specialize in property and casualty policies. **********In the case of the New York banks, the analysts said stock prices were supported because fears that some underdeveloped nations would default on their loans have been reduced. As for insurance companies, Donald E. Franz Jr. of Smith Barney said stock prices had fallen sharply between mid-December and mid- January, and the slight rise in recent weeks was merely a correction. **********Meanwhile, reflecting the complexity and changing expectations in the current market are the conflicting performances of aluminum company stocks, which have recently ranked among the worst performers, and copper stocks, which have been among the best. **********William G. Siedenburg, who follows both industries for Smith Barney, said aluminum stocks had far outpaced the bull market. **********''The aluminums still look good, but the market apparently thinks they moved too high,'' he said. **********On the other hand, the stocks of copper companies rose far below the average of the bull market last year, he said. And now, with new orders for copper coming in from Europe, where the economic recovery is now picking up steam, investors are belatedly looking at the copper companies with favor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/25/busin.body_text: **********Mrs. Fields's Chocolate Chippery spent a long and frustrating year trying to rent space for a store in Tokyo before turning to its bank, the Bank of California. **********In short order, the bank's parent, Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. of Japan, helped the Fields organization rent a storefront in the Ginza shopping area - not a major business transaction, perhaps, but a clear demonstration of how Mitsubishi can help the Bank of California attract the medium-sized corporate clients it wants as the core of its business, according to BanCal's chairman, Ross P. Williams Jr. **********For Mitsubishi Bank, the deal provided a valuable glimpse of how to tap a segment of the American market, one in which Mitsubishi has very little experience, according to Junji Hatano, BanCal's new executive vice president. **********''One of the main purposes in buying the bank,'' Mr. Hatano said, ''is to have a better approach to the American 'middle market' '' - one he defined as companies worth $5 million to $200 million. **********Mitsubishi and BanCal are also collaborating on several other projects similar to the Fields cookie deal, in which Mitsubishi is using its Japanese contacts to draw in business for BanCal, Mr. Hatano said. The bank helped Avalon Bay Food Inc., an Oakland-based seafood packager, begin operations in Singapore, for example. **********Shareholders of the Bank of California, the state's eighth largest, approved its $282 million merger with Mitsubishi Bank, now ranked seventh in the world, last January. The board's recommendation to accept Mitsubishi's $50-a-share offer, following a higher last-minute offer from Wells Fargo Bank, drew criticism from analysts, who questioned why BanCal chose the lower offer and a foreign company over a domestic one. **********Japanese Presence on Coast **********The merger brought to nine the number of Japanese banks, wholly or partly owned, in California, according to Gary Palmer, a spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco. Of the state's 10 largest banks, three are Japanese-owned: California First, ranked seventh and owned 76 percent by the Bank of Tokyo; BanCal, and Sumitomo Bank of California, ranked 10th. **********The attractions for Mitsubishi and the other Japanese banks are evident, said J. Richard Fredericks, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. ''The Japanese are part of the whole Pacific Rim, there is a very large Japanese population here, and California itself is a tremendous marketplace,'' he said. **********But so far, according to both Mr. Fredericks and Donald K. Crowley, a senior vice president with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in San Francisco, the state's Japanese-owned banks have kept a low profile, reporting moderate earnings and, in some cases, slight declines in profitability.   Earnings Had Slipped **********When Mitsubishi bought BanCal, the 120-year-old bank had been reporting lower earnings, in part because the bank had decided to sell all but 20 of its 49 branches and concentrate instead on building up its ''private bank'' - a range of services for corporate clients and wealthy individuals. **********The bank's assets as of June 30 of this year were $3.5 billion, down from $3.9 billion in the comparable quarter last year. It reported a second-quarter loss of $3.64 million, in contrast to an $11.56 million profit in last year's quarter. The loss reflected merger expenses and some bond trading losses. **********But BanCal had attractions for Mitsubishi, which already owns the Mitsubishi Bank of California, a retail bank. Mr. Hatano cited BanCal's emphasis on corporate banking for medium-sized companies, a charter that predates the Glass-Steagall Act and allows operations in Oregon and Washington as well as California, and its experience with financial deregulation. **********Through its ''private bank,'' BanCal has offered a number of investment and other services that Mr. Hatano said could position Mitsubishi to compete better in the Japanese market, now slowly being deregulated. **********''This is sort of a pilot,'' he said. ''Financial services, discount brokerages, trusts, the whole area of how to react to deregulation is one of the interests that Mitsubishi has.'' **********Nevertheless, Mr. Hatano and Mr. Williams said they would like to see BanCal report better earnings, expand its three-state activities and increase its share in the middle market.  ''Our bottom-line results have not been particularly spectacular,'' Mr. Williams acknowledged. Nor, he said, had the bank taken full advantage of its right to operate in three states. **********Tough Competition **********Richard Rosenberg, vice chairman of the Crocker Bank, said that BanCal would face tough competition in the middle market - some of it from Mitsui Manufacturers Bank, another Japanese-owned bank. **********Mitsui, he said, ''is one of the best of the middle-market banks.'' He added: ''Middle-market companies have enormous loyalties. I think it's a very tough go.'' **********But Mr. Fredericks of Montgomery Securities said that the bank's new strategy had begun to pay off. ''Mitsubishi should leave BanCal alone on that one,'' he said. ''They were just about to turn a corner. The reputation building in the marketplace was quite good.'' **********Mr. Hatano said that Mitsubishi not only approves of that strategy but also intends to continue it. He and Mr. Williams cited a number of steps BanCal had taken to move toward these goals. First, Mr. Hatano said, Mitsubishi had to reassure BanCal's employees - especially the women in the company - that personnel matters would be ''completely American style.'' In general, women in banks in Japan hold secretarial positions. **********Next, Mr. Williams said, the bank was reorganized to trim overhead costs. Mitsubishi has also encouraged BanCal to make long-term investments in systems development, advanced technology and promotional materials to expand its reach in California, Washington and Oregon, Mr. Williams said, even if it must forgo short-term profits to do so. **********Mr. Williams added that one way the bank was trying to increase its presence in Washington and Oregon was by providing introductions in Japan for the ports of Tacoma, Wash., and Portland, Ore., which are both eager to attract more international business. **********One project that Mitsubishi and BanCal have in the works involves a large American ice cream manufacturer that wants to distribute in Japan, where most ice cream, being low in butterfat, tastes like American ice milk. **********Mr. Hatano acknowledged a personal interest in that deal. When he and his family came to the United States more than a decade ago so he could study at the Stanford Business School, they were delighted by the taste of American ice cream. Now, although Baskin-Robbins has outlets in Japan, he said he would be pleased to see more American ice cream in his homeland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/10/world.body_text: **********President Reagan told Prime Minister Shimon Peres today that the United States would ''cooperate the best way we can'' to resolve Israel's pressing economic problems. He specifically promised to provide emergency help if Israel was faced with a balance-of-payments crisis. **********After listening for two days to Mr. Peres's detailed plea for billions of dollars in additional American financial support over several years, the Administration, however, put off until next year any move to increase Israel's military and economic aid above the current annual level of $2.6 billion. **********Instead, Mr. Reagan announced an agreement to form a Joint Economic Development Group of government and nongovernmental experts from the two countries to examine questions dealing with aid, investment and other financial issues. This group is not expected to reach any conclusions before January, a senior American official said. **********Lebanon Also Discussed **********One official said the group would take on many of the functions of the International Monetary Fund in trying to force austerity on a country seeking more loans. Mr. Peres, in appearances on Capitol Hill and elsewhere in Washington, has stressed that Israel recognizes that it must tighten its economic belt but wants to do so with the certainty of more American aid. **********Although Israel's economy dominated the talks here, the Israelis and Americans also discussed in detail the prospects for an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon. Mr. Reagan indicated, however, that the United States remained unwilling to become a mediator between Israel and Syria. One official said there was no point in the Administration mediating until all parties knew the result of the Presidential election on Nov. 6. **********Through the joint economic group, the Administration hopes to halt Congress's practice of increasing aid to Israel in an unstructured way, a State Department official said. In recent years, pro-Israeli members of Congress have been able to increase aid to Israel by hundreds of millions of dollars above Administration requests. The Administration hopes that by having aid recommendations come from this panel, it can persuade Congress not to tamper with its recommendations. **********Israel's Next Step **********With Congress ending its session this week, it would be impossible for a new aid program to be approved now, a senior State Department official said. The prospect, other officials said, is for Israel to press in the coming year for a major increase in aid, perhaps as much as 50 percent. That would inevitably lead to a similar request from Egypt, which receives more than $2 billion annually. **********Mr. Peres went out of his way to stress his satisfaction with the results of the meetings and was liberal in his praise of Mr. Reagan. Mr. Peres plans to meet Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic challenger to the President, before leaving the country at the end of the week. **********''I found in the White House,'' Mr. Peres told reporters in the Rose Garden, ''a true friend of Israel who understands our problems and dilemmas.'' He said that in his meetings here he found that relations between the United States and Israel ''have reached a new level of harmony and understanding, which I am very grateful for.''  Private Meeting Reported **********In a private briefing later for Israeli journalists, Mr. Peres said he was particularly pleased by the President's statement that the United States would help avert any balance-of-payments crisis for Israel as it tries to solve economic problems, such as the 400 percent annual inflation growth and mounting trade deficits. **********According to an Israeli journalist, Mr. Peres also said he had met with Mr. Reagan today with no advisers present, and additional promises were made. He declined to say what they were. **********With Mr. Peres standing next to him, Mr. Reagan said, ''We've made clear our willingness to continue our dialogue and to cooperate with Israel in the best way we can as Israel proceeds with its plans.'' **********He noted that Israel had already taken some steps - such as a cut of $1 billion in its $23 billion budget, a curb on imports of foreign luxury goods and a limit on how much foreign exchange can be taken abroad.   Short-Term Solution **********Congress has just passed $2.6 billion in aid - $1.2 billion in economic aid and $1.4 billion in military aid - for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Mr. Reagan stressed that the Administration would make available the full $1.2 billion immediately, without Israel having to wait for quarterly disbursements, as other recipients do. **********This money ''will enable Israel to develop its programs without having to divert undue attention to balance-of- payments problems,'' Mr. Reagan said. **********''Should such problems arise,'' he promised, ''the U.S. Government will work closely with the Israeli Government to avert them.'' **********The Treasury Department has authority in emergency situations to provide stop-gap loans to help nations keep their credit rating, State Department officials said, in explaining what Mr. Reagan meant. **********The two men also agreed to tell their negotiators to complete within 30 days the details on creating free trade zones between the two countries. **********A senior Administration official said that Mr. Reagan raised with Mr. Peres the American concern about maintaining good relations with moderate Arab states and supplying them with military equipment. The Israelis replied, the official said, that they did not oppose arms being given to Egypt, the only Arab country to sign a peace treaty with Israel, but did oppose arms for other Arab countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/14/world.main_headline: CHERNENKO SHUNS ALLIED OVERTURES ON NUCLEAR TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/14/world.print_headline: CHERNENKO SHUNS ALLIED OVERTURES ON NUCLEAR TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/14/world.body_text: **********Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, today rejected a call by the leaders of the industrial democracies for renewed talks on nuclear arms and other issues, saying their proposal was not ''backed up by anything tangible.'' **********In an interview with Pravda, the Communist Party daily, Mr. Chernenko called the overture made at the London economic meeting a ''screen'' to cover up the deployment of American missiles in Western Europe. **********The text of the interview, prepared for Thursday's issue of Pravda, was read tonight on the television news. **********The London economic meeting, which ended Saturday, was attended by the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan, the United States and West Germany. **********Allies Urged Renewal of Talks **********Their declaration on East-West relations, one of several statements adopted at the end of the three-day meeting, said that each of the seven nations ''will pursue all useful opportunities for dialogue'' with the Russians and it expressed the hope for ''speedy resumption'' of arms control talks now suspended. **********Late last year the Soviet Union declined to continue two sets of talks with the United States in Geneva on the limitation of strategic, or intercontinental, nuclear weapons and of medium-range missiles in Europe in protest against the start of deployment of American missiles in Western Europe. **********Western diplomats in Moscow had not expected a positive response to the London declaration in view of the Soviet Union's withdrawal from contacts with the United States. **********Pressure Building Up in U.S. **********While the Russians have dismissed American overtures as pre-election politics, pressure has been building up in the United States to look for renewed approaches. On Tuesday, two Senate Republican leaders, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee and Charles H. Percy of Illinois, urged President Reagan to seek a meeting with Mr. Chernenko to ease East-West tensions. **********In restating Moscow's position, Mr. Chernenko said that when more realistic proposals are made, the Soviet Union stands ready for ''a dialogue that is honest, and talks that are serious.'' **********He called the London declaration ''a screen to somehow cover up the transformation of the territories of some of the Western European countries into launching pads for the new United States missiles.'' **********The position of the United States and its allies has been that the American missiles were deployed under a NATO decision of 1979 to begin countering existing Soviet missiles with new American weapons in late 1983 unless an agreement on limitation could be reached. **********The Soviet Union has said it is prepared to return to the Geneva arms control talks if the American missiles are removed. The United States has offered to restart the talks ''anywhere, at any time, without preconditions,'' but has declined to cancel the missile deployment. **********In response, Mr. Chernenko said today: **********''We hold that these issues be considered in earnest at the negotiating table as soon as the American side withdraws its essentially peremptoryconditions for talks. **********''To aim new United States nuclear missiles at the Soviet Union and its allies and, at the same time, to urge talks - is this not political duplicity?'' **********While the Soviet Union has declined to resume the Geneva talks on strategic and medium-range missiles, it has been pressing the United States for negotiations aimed at a ban on antisatellite and other space weapons. **********Washington has been cool to such negotiations, partly on the ground that such an accord could not be verified. On Monday, Mr. Chernenko, in calling again for such talks, insisted that a ban could be verified. **********In the interview with Pravda, Mr. Chernenko also commented on some of the economic aspects of the London meeting, saying that its participants had failed to address the ''acute socio- economic problems that are intrinsic to the capitalist system, particularly unemployment, inflation and rising living costs.'' **********He defined the West's economic philosophy as ''the rich get richer and the poor poorer,'' and was critical of what he called ''ruthless exploitation by the industrially developed capitalist countries, mainly the United States, of the economically weak countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America.'' **********Much of the evening news program on Soviet television was given over to ceremonies in connection with a three- day economic meeting being held here by leaders of the Soviet bloc. **********No substantive reports on the work of this meeting have been issued so far, but several political and economic declarations are expected to be released when it ends Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/busin.body_text: **********Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds continued their surge, rising $2.76 billion, to $208.04 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. **********The assets have grown in 12 consecutive weeks by $28.2 billion to reach their highest level since Dec. 29, 1982, when assets stood at $211.24 billion, the institute stated. **********Assets of the 68 institutional funds accounted for the largest increase, $1.68 billion, climbing to $54.48 billion, the institute said. **********The 85 broker-dealer funds posted a $753 million increase, to $90.12 billion, and assets of the 184 general purpose funds gained $332 million, for a total of $63.43 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/02/busin.print_headline: PROSPECTS; KEEPING THE SHARKS AT BAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/02/busin.body_text: **********''Shark repellents'' - antitakeover changes in corporate charters and bylaws - will be used with increasing zeal by companies facing unfriendly suitors, investment bankers say. And, if the recent past is any indicator, stockholders will embrace such moves. **********The most common on the shopping list of such defenses is the board of directors with staggered terms so that a company with a newly acquired stake cannot elect too many new directors at one time. **********Defensive tactics are even being adopted by companies not directly under a takeover threat. Household International Inc., the holding company for Household Finance and National Car Rental, recently created a new series of preferred stock for purchase by those who already own Household common stock. Donald C. Clark, chairman, said that the stock ''is designed to protect against a third party seeking to take advantage of short- term market conditions and speculation.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/05/world.body_text: **********The Government today released a former Prime Minister after 10 months of detention.  But it warned that he could be detained again if he involved himself in activities the Government deemed subversive. **********After his release, the former Prime Minister, Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa, made a short statement from his home, saying, ''It's a great relief to be free again.'' The Bishop, who is leader of the Zimbabwe branch of the United Methodist Church, added that he ''had been praying hard for my freedom for a long time.'' **********He said he would respond in a few days to Government assertions that he had been involved in subversive activities. **********At the time of his arrest last November, the Government asserted that Bishop Muzorewa had been involved in a plot against the state involving agents from South Africa, the United States and Israel. But no charges were ever filed against him. **********Bishop Muzorewa, who was the Prime Minister of the short-lived, transitional Zimbabwe-Rhodesia Government of 1979, was detained last year shortly after returning from a visit to Israel for Bible studies and after criticizing the Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe for what he termed repressive activities.   Held Under Emergency Powers **********The Bishop was held under Zimbabwe's sweeping emergency powers, which were inherited from the previous white minority Rhodesian regime and permit indefinite detention without trial. **********Acting Home Affairs Minister Moven Mahachi, who announced the minority politician's release, said Bishop Muzorewa would be free to take part fully in political affairs as the leader of the United African National Council, which holds three seats in Parliament. **********Mr. Mahachi said the Bishop is allowed to make public speeches and campaign for his party in the upcoming national election expected before next April. **********But Mr. Mahachi warned that the clergyman must not use his position as the head of the Zimbabwe branch of the United States-based United Methodist Church to spread political doctrines. Mr. Mahachi added that the Bishop would be detained again if he got involved in further subversive activities. **********''The Government wishes to impress on Bishop Muzorewa that his political activities should be conducted openly and not in secret, whether inside or outside Zimbabwe,'' Mr. Mahachi added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/23/world.main_headline: A HORROR STORY IN INDIA: SURVIVORS TELL OF ATTACK
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/23/world.print_headline: A HORROR STORY IN INDIA: SURVIVORS TELL OF ATTACK
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/23/world.body_text: **********The Hindu attackers came over the rise in the late morning sun last Saturday, hundreds of them, brandishing daggers, swords, firebombs and guns. **********They shouted as their battle cry ''Jai Bhavani!'' - meaning ''Long live Bhavani!'' **********Bhavani was the patron goddess of Sivaji, the Hindu leader of the Marathas who made war against the Moslem Mogul emperors three centuries ago. **********For more than three hours, a modern-day Moslem named Ibrahim Ansari and a son stood off the Hindu attackers with a pistol and a shotgun. Other Moslems at the housing compound near Mr. Ansari's weaving and dyeing factory were not as fortunate. **********As Mr. Ansari and his son fired shots from the windows of a barricaded living room, they caught glimpses of swords flashing into necks and stomachs and heard the screams of wounded men as they were set on fire alive. **********When it was all over, as Mr. Ansari told it in a mournful return to the killing ground today, 27 Moslems lay dead in his yard or nearby, hacked or burned to death. It was the most gruesome single incident in the wave of Hindu-Moslem fighting and rioting that has swept the Bombay area since last Friday. And more than any other single incident, it has sent tremors of horror and revulsion across the country over this latest round of strife that perennially plagues India.   Three Hours of Carnage **********A large part of the more than 130 people who have been killed so far in the riots that later spread to Bombay died in those three hours outside Mr. Ansari's bungalow next to the now ruined factory. Much the same has happened elsewhere, with Moslems usually the victims in predominantly Hindu areas, and Hindus the victims in Moslem areas. **********The situation appeared tense but less deadly today after a deployment of army troops across the area. But sporadic violence and destruction continued in northern Bombay and along the industrial corridor stretching northeastward from there to this prosperous textile and pharmaceutical manufacturing town 30 miles from Bombay.  On the road out of Bhiwandi this afternoon, visitors passed a factory, a private house and two trucks, all freshly set afire and blazing. Lines of refugees, suitcases and bundles on their heads, trudged out of town, many of them leaving behind homes that had been burned to the ground. About 12,000 people in the Bombay area have been left homeless as a result of arson. **********In Bhiwandi, where more than 65 people died, all seemed quiet. But evidence of the battle Saturday could be seen outside the burned-out home where Mr. Ansari and his family were rescued by the police just as their final defenses were about to be breached. **********In the front yard, charred clothing lay alongside a puddle of congealed blood, the only reminder that a man was run through on that spot with a sword, doused with kerosene and set ablaze. **********Nearby, the small factory that had been the livelihood of Mr. Ansari and many workers in this town of 250,000 people lay in smoking ruins.  ''I never thought that his could happen,'' the 50-year-old manufacturer said as he looked around. ''The last time I protected my Hindu neighbor, and I never thought this would happen.'' **********The last time was 1970, when Bhiwandi went through similar violence. Later, some townspeople say, relations between Hindus and Moslems appeared to improve in this town, where Moslems are in the majority. **********But as Mr. Ansari said, ''Bad feelings have been there right from the partition'' of India and Pakistan in 1947, and nothing has really changed that much. **********Last week, Moslems, in an expression of group pride and assertiveness, raised the green flag of Islam over their homes in a symbolic battle with the followers of the Hindu Maratha activist organization, the Shiv Sena, who had raised their own saffron flags. Soon stones and bottles were being thrown, and then the killing and burning began. **********Other residents say that as Bhiwandi has grown and prospered as a vital part of India's rapidly industrializing economy, it has attracted many unsavory characters. Among them are criminals who have been driven out of other states and now live in the sprawling shantytowns on the outskirts of town. **********The criminals, along with unemployed youths, are being blamed for much of the killing and burning.   Knew Some of the Attackers **********All Mr. Ansari knows is that there were a lot of them who atacked his home and that most of them were young. He said he knew many of them personally and some pursued trades like liquor making. He insisted he knew of no personal animosity any of them bore toward him. **********On the morning of the killing, he said, about 50 Moslem families, fearful of being attacked in their homes nearby, sought refuge in the Ansari factory and bungalow compound just outside town. The women and children joined the Ansaris in the house. The men remained outside. **********The Hindus attacked at about 10:30 A.M. Mr. Ansari said he was not sure how long it took for the 27 men to die, but it was probably not long. Some were cut down where they stood, and others were killed as they tried to flee. **********The attackers systematically destroyed the factory, he said. ''Every 10 minutes a jeep would bring some kerosene,'' he said. **********A few of the attackers were arrested, but most escaped and are presumably in hiding. **********''They are misguided,'' Mr. Ansari said of the attackers who destroyed his livelihood and made his home ground, where he had planted every shrub and tree himself, a slaughterhouse. **********All that is gone now. ''I don't have the heart to stay in Bhiwandi any longer,'' Mr. Ansari said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/20/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union today honored the nation's leading psychiatrist, who has been accused by the World Psychiatry Association of abusing his science to punish political dissidents. **********The psychiatrist, Dr. Andrei V. Snezhnevsky, was given the Order of the October Revolution on his 80th birthday in recognition of his work in medical science and in public health. **********Dr. Snezhnevsky came under criticism at the 1977 meeting of the World Psychiatric Association, which accused him of directing abuses of psychiatry against dissidents. **********The Soviet Psychiatric Association withdrew from the world organization in February 1983. The move was thought to have been made to pre-empt efforts to suspend or expel the Soviet Union from the organization. **********Since 1962, Dr. Snezhnevsky has been a member of the Academy of Medical Sciences and director of its Psychiatry Institute, which provides treatment and investigates all aspects of schizophrenia. **********In 1974, he was made a Hero of Socialist Labor, the nation's highest civilian honor. Two years later he won a State Prize of the U.S.S.R. for his work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/02/world.body_text: **********Greek and Turkish Cypriots both have approved the new United Nations proposals for peace talks the divided Eastern Mediterranean island. **********Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader, said the Turkish Cypriots had informed the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, that they were ready to start talks ''at any time, anywhere'' on the basis of ''working points'' that the Secretary General submitted to both sides in August. **********An announcement from the Greek Cypriot side said, ''Our reply to the questions posed by the U.N. Secretary General is positive.'' **********Informed sources who spoke on condition they not be identified said the U.N. effort sought to lay the groundwork for a resumption of peace talks that have been conducted intermittently since Turkey occupied the northern part of Cyprus in 1974. Turkey said the invasion was intended to protect the island's Turkish minority after a Greek-led coup. **********UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 1 - Mr. Perez de Cuellar's office announced today that the talks would begin Sept. 10 in New York and that both the Cypriot President, Spyros Kyprianou, and Mr. Denktash would attend.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/26/world.main_headline: ITALY SAYS 7 BULGARIANS AND TURKS WILL BE TRIED FOR PLOT ON THE POPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/26/world.print_headline: ITALY SAYS 7 BULGARIANS AND TURKS WILL BE TRIED FOR PLOT ON THE POPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/26/world.body_text: **********An Italian judge has decided to order three Bulgarians and four Turks to stand trial on charges of taking part in a conspiracy to assassinate Pope John Paul II, Italian officials said today. **********The judge, Ilario Martella, will also order Mehmet Ali Agca, who was convicted in 1981 of shooting the Pope, to stand trial again on new charges. Officials said they believed that the new charges would involve the illegal importation of the weapon used in the shooting. **********Officials said the judge's decision was scheduled to be announced at Rome's central courthouse on Friday. **********Bulgaria Denies Any Role **********The decision sets the stage for a potentially sensational courtroom test of a purported Bulgarian role in the wounding of the Pope on May 13, 1981. **********Bulgaria has denied any connection with the shooting. **********The central witness for the prosecution will be Mr. Agca, who has given the Italian authorities elaborate, if sometimes contradictory, descriptions of the purported role of the Bulgarian secret services in the shooting. **********The prosecution's case is expected to rest to a major degree on Mr. Agca's credibility as a witness, and the changes in his testimony over time are expected to play a major role in the defense's case. **********What has become known as the ''Bulgarian connection'' is a matter of bitter controversy and enormous political importance. **********State Prosecutor Antonio Albano, who wrote a report to Judge Martella this year recommending that the case be brought to trial, said in June that he doubted that Bulgaria would have acted without the approval of the Soviet Union. **********The motive for the involvement of Bulgaria, the Soviet Union's most loyal ally, was the Eastern bloc's concern over the rise of the Solidarity trade union movement in Poland. **********The rise of Solidarity, according to Mr. Albano, was ''perceived as a mortal danger'' by East European Communist leaders, who believed the dissidence was ''mostly due to the fervent religious character'' of the people, strengthened by the election of ''the first Polish Pope in history.'' Killing the Pope, according to this theory, would help curb the Polish opposition.  Only one of the three Bulgarians indicted, Sergei Ivanov Antonov, is in Italian custody. Mr. Antonov, the former deputy director of Balkan Air in Rome, was arrested on Nov. 25, 1982. **********The two other Bulgarians, Todor Stoyanov Aivasov and Zhelyo Kolev Vasilev, are both in Bulgaria. The judge has asked for their extradition, but Italy has no extradition treaty with Bulgaria. **********Mr. Antonov's defense counsel, Giuseppe Consolo, said in an interview tonight that he expected the cases to go to trial. He predicted that Mr. Antonov would be cleared. **********Credibility Challenged **********Mr. Consolo said Mr. Agca's lack of credibility as a witness would be central to Mr. Antonov's defense. He said he would cite Mr. Acga's frequent shifts in testimony and his retractions of various charges. **********''Sixty to seventy percent of what he said he denied himself, and the other 30 percent is credible?'' Mr. Consolo asked rhetorically. ''Why? If he's a liar on 70 percent, he's a liar on everything.'' **********Mr. Consolo said he hoped the case would come to trial soon, but he feared that a backlog in the Italian courts might delay it for up to a year. **********The defense attorney said he believed that the Italian judiciary, having invested so much in the case, felt an obligation to bring the men to trial. **********'Didn't Know How to Dismiss It' ''I think they created this case and they didn't know how to dismiss it,'' he said. ''Otherwise, everyone would have said they had been investigating the case for two years and now they dismiss it. They didn't have the courage to dismiss the case.'' **********In his report, Mr. Albano acknowledged shifts in Mr. Agca's testimony but argued that a preponderance of the details he provided had been independently confirmed in the investigation. **********''Every statement by Agca, every circumstance he reported, every detail offered to the investigation was subjected to verification, to comparison, to checks, to inquiry,'' Mr. Albano said in his report. ''Agca is convincing in his reconstruction of the historical case of the attempt on the Pope's life.'' **********The prosecutor acknowledged ''changes, discords, contradictions'' in Mr. Agca's testimony but said they were ''never contingent to the juridically and penally relevant aspects'' of the case. **********25,000 Pages of Testimony **********Although Judge Martella was not obliged to follow Mr. Albano's recommendations, his report - based on 25,000 pages of evidence - is expected to follow the logic of the prosecutor's position. **********The four Turks who will be brought to trial are Oral Celik, who is at large; Bekir Celenk, a reputed leader of the Turkish mafia who is now in Bulgaria; and Omer Bagci and Musar Cedar Celebi, who are in Italian prisons. **********On May 13, 1981, the Pope was standing in the back of an open car moving slowly among more than 10,000 people who had gathered in St. Peter's Square for his weekly general audience. At 5:19 P.M. shots rang out and two bullets struck the Pope. He was wounded in the abdomen, right arm and left hand. Two passers-by were also wounded. **********Mr. Agca, who fired the shots, was set upon in the square by bystanders, who knocked the pistol out of his hand. He was then arrested. **********Another Man Seen Fleeing **********There were initial police reports declaring that Mr. Agca had acted alone, but witnesses said they saw a man fleeing from the scene. **********Later, it emerged that an American tourist and television executive, Lowell Newton, had taken a photo of a young man with his back to the camera running out of St. Peter's Square a few seconds after the shooting.
