https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/28/world.main_headline: REFUGEE INFLUX STRAINS SUDAN'S FRAGILE FABRIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/28/world.print_headline: REFUGEE INFLUX STRAINS SUDAN'S FRAGILE FABRIC
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/28/world.body_text: **********The United States said it was sending emergency aid by sea and air to the Sudan. Page A6. **********KASSALA, the Sudan - Refugees by the tens of thousands are streaming into this desert nation from neighboring Ethiopia, fleeing drought, famine and war. **********They walk for as many as eight weeks from their villages and cross the frontier to reach the wretched patch of hills and sand that is the refugee center of Tekl el Bab, outside this town in eastern Sudan. The bleakness of the place that to them is a balm eloquently underscores the degree of misery they escaped. **********For most of the more than 25,000 people in this place, the only shelter is provided by the looming crags that shield them from the chill of the night and the small, scraggly bushes that give meager respite from the piercing sun. Their ever-growing numbers have seriously strained supplies of food, water, drugs and the energy of relief workers. **********According to relief workers, government officials and humanitarian organizations, they are also straining the limited resources of the entire country, where, as in huge swaths of the continent, millions are suffering from hunger because of drought. **********In addition to the problems posed by the current wave of refugees, this pro- Western nation is sapped by enormous development problems: an economic quagmire, an insurgency in its southern region, and the demands placed on it by a previous tide of refugees. There is growing concern that, with the continuing influx of refugees and their impact on the social and economic fabric, the nation may soon be overwhelmed. **********An Open-Door Policy **********The Sudan, the largest country in Africa and one of the world's most impoverished, has traditionally had an open- door policy toward refugees. It has taken in more than one million in recent years. **********The country's Office of the Commissioner for Refugees is responsible for administering many projects of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. And the Sudan's law on the right of asylum is considered a model in Africa. **********The majority of the refugees are Ethiopians, mainly from the northern provinces of Eritrea and Tigre, who began arriving in 1967 to escape guerrilla wars. But there are also Ugandans, Chadians and Zairians. Their arrival highlights the plight of a nation.  For even as the Sudan's borders serve as a magnet for thousands of refugees, an estimated 4.5 million of its own 22 million people have also been victimized by the drought. **********The majority of those now flocking into the country are children, whose pencil-thin bodies, clothed in little more than rags, transmit tales of suffering and tragedy. About two members of every family, most often the very old and the very young, die struggling to make their way here. Each day, measles, malaria, malnutrition, tuberculosis and other ailments claim the lives of about 20 of those who do make it. **********These refugees are among more than 110,000 from Eritrea and Tigre, where guerrilla warfare complicates the process of getting food to people. **********Since Nov. 1, they have been entering at the rate of 1,200 a day. Relief officials say that another 50,000 may now be on their way. At the same time, more than 100,000 victims of drought and armed conflict have crossed Sudan's western border from Chad. **********There have been rumors that the Government would close its border with Ethiopia, spurred by a measles epidemic among the refugees. But the Sudanese Commissioner for Refugees says he does not believe that this will be considered, especially if the nation receives enough international aid. Others, however, fear that there may be increased internal pressure from drought-affected Sudanese to limit or stop the flow of people coming in.   'A Big Problem' **********''I'm expecting tens of thousands to come in the coming few weeks,'' Abdel Beshir el Ahmadi, the Commissioner for Refugees, said. ''It is a big problem that is going to face us. There should be a balance in really helping Sudan. When you have between 1,000 and 1,500 a day crossing the border to come to us and this number will be multiplied in the coming weeks, we hope the international community will come and help so these people will not come and die in the Sudan.'' **********Thousands of the new refugees are traveling to drought-affected areas, making an already serious situation worse. Refugees who came in previous years and were relocated in permanent rural settlements, with the aim of avoiding pressure on already overburdened urban services and helping the refugees to become self-sufficient, are now experiencing total crop failures and may need additional support. **********New arrivals have been chopping down trees for fuel, contributing to the problem of desertification that aggravates Africa's food problems. In the Sudan, the Government says the desert is advancing three miles a year. The whole situation has led some to ask whether the generosity of the Sudan toward refugees is ultimately in the best interests of its people. **********''Some of the area the new refugees are living on here is usually cropland,'' said Mohmed Osman Ali, a Sudanese refugee counselor. He stood at the border of the Wad Sherifie refugee center, near Tekl el Bab and a short distance from a Sudanese village that has been virtually abandoned because of crop failure.   33,000 Refugees at Center **********More than 33,000 are said to have found their way from Ethiopia to Wad Sherifie on foot, by donkey or camel in recent weeks. **********It is estimated that the drought in the vast Sudan, almost one-third the size of the continental United States, would result in a deficiency in food production of from 800,000 to up to 1.2 million tons, excluding the needs of the arriving refugees. **********The worst-hit areas are, in essence, the nation's granary. Figures provided by Western donor nations suggested that the harvest of sorghum would be 700,000 tons short of the 1.8 million tons reaped last year. Production of millet was expected to drop from 300,000 to 250,000 tons. The wheat harvest, the victim of the worst shortage of river water in more than 70 years, is expected to be cut from about 160,000 tons to 15,000. **********The drought has caused people to flee the worst-hit areas, driving tens of thousands of them into the cities in search of food. More than 50,000, by some estimates, have camped on the periphery of Omdurman, a city on the Nile a short drive from the capital, Khartoum. **********According to William R. Smyser, the United Nations deputy high commissioner for refugees, who arrived in the Sudan from Geneva to assess the situation, problems in the camps, including water and food shortages and inadequate health care, were being immediately addressed. He said that measles vaccine brought in recently had diminished the epidemic. The primary medical problems arise not after the people arrive in refugee camps but are a result of the trip to get there, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/01/world.body_text: **********The writer of this article is executive editor of The New York Times and was its correspondent in India from 1954 to 1958. He has revisited India often, most recently in January and February this year. **********In India's great years of hope, when Jawaharlal Nehru was Prime Minister and the people called him their beloved jewel, the young woman was almost always with him, usually not at his side, but a few steps behind. **********Indira, Mr. Nehru's only child, appeared with him at receptions and meetings in New Delhi, smiling, nodding, holding her hands together gently to her forehead in greeting, murmuring a word now and then. **********In villages far from New Delhi she walked behind him down dusty roads. She sat motionless on platforms while he talked to city crowds of hundreds of thousands, millions sometimes, usually scolding them for their faults, a father quite loving but quick to anger. **********Boosts Up the Ladder **********She was close to him and he favored her. He gave her boosts up the political ladder within his Congress Party. Then, in 1964, Jawaharlal Nehru died, and two years later, Indira Gandhi was Prime Minister. **********And now she is dead herself, one more victim of the religious hatreds of India against which her father used to harangue the crowds. Now she is dead and her son Rajiv is Prime Minister. Rajiv, whom she had selected as her heir when her first choice, her younger son, Sanjay, died in a wild, senseless airplane stunt over New Delhi, almost within sight of his mother's offices. **********Because of Indira Gandhi's open and obvious preparation to turn over rule to one of her sons, the theory of Indian dynasty has been growing and now will become written into history. Father to child to grandchild, just like the old Indian rajahs.   Closeness and Aloofness It is a neat theory, fitting comfortably into the stereotypes of India, but at best it is only half true - and it will take time to discover whether even that half holds. **********For the fact is that there is no evidence that Jawaharlal Nehru ever really thought in dynasty terms, of turning over office to Indira. **********There was a closeness between them, but also a certain aloofness. For years - the years he spent in fighting for Indian independence and the years in prison that were part of that struggle - he was remote, a father she knew mostly from his jail cell letters. Then her mother, the lonely, sad, often neglected Kamala, died and Indira went off to school abroad, far from home and father. **********All this was in the 1920's and 30's, and it was only when Nehru became Prime Minister after independence in 1948 that Indira and her father seemed to become close. She became his hostess, his comrade, his helper. But she was shy and withdrawn, and Indians with long memories cannot recall that they ever thought of her as his real confidante, that he turned to her for advice, or that he thought of her as his successor. **********Her duties as a sort of First Daughter of India kept her close to him and distant from her home, from her husband, Feroze, and from her little boys. The marriage withered. Indira became president of the ruling Congress Party in 1959. Nehru always insisted that he did not groom her for the job and was not terribly keen on it at all, but it seems a realistic assumption that her relationship to him did her no harm. Krishna Nehru Hutheesing, younger sister of Jawaharlal and no admirer of her niece at all, wrote that Jawaharlal had said that he did not want to encourage a dynasty and that it would be ''wholly undemocratic and undesirable.'' **********When he died there was no real talk of her succeeding him. Lal Bahandur Shastri, Nehru's successor, made her Minister of Information. It was not much of a job, and to this day Indian politicians say she got the job not because she was powerful, but because she was powerless - Nehru had left her little estate, and she needed the job and the house in New Delhi that goes with ministerial posts. She seemed bent and always full of sorrow, not a figure of power at all. **********Then suddenly in 1966 Mr. Shastri died. Almost condescendingly, India's national politicians turned to Mrs. Gandhi. She was to be a figurehead, a bridge between the past and the future, while the great big men of power figured out what the future was to be.  First the Office, Then Power **********It turned out that Indira had decided that the future was to be Indira. First she took office, then power. As the years passed and India and Indira seemed inseparable, it became quite plain that she intended not only to stay on in the office but live on in it through Sanjay. **********It was only then that the dynasty theory became a reality. Sanjay was crown prince and acted like one. He had his own toughs, his own political entourage, his own picture on billboards, his own political funds. Seeing Sanjay - if he would see you - became the way to get things done in India. **********Sanjay did not follow demurely behind his mother, as she did her father. When he spoke to his mother he did so with confidence, full voice and swagger. She simply adored him. **********Parlor psychiatrists in New Delhi liked to say that she was full of guilt feelings toward her sons because in the years that she was her father's shadow she was distant from them. Nobody knows, nobody can say, but it was plain she thought the Indian sun rose and set in her Sanjay.  Quiet Until His Death There were Indian politicians who loathed him and saw him as a danger to India. But they did not say much about it at all until he was safely dead, and even then softly, softly so Indira would not hear. **********Even as her grief for Sanjay was deep and searing, Mrs. Gandhi turned at once to Rajiv, who was an airline pilot. He was two years older than Sanjay, but unlike his brother had never shown the slightest interest in politics. **********But immediately, all India knew that Rajiv was the man to see, the man to wheedle and flatter, the man who could get things done. Soft-voiced and much less openly arrogant than his brother, Rajiv became the heir apparent, and yesterday, the heir. **********So the dynasty theory seems half borne out - Mrs. Gandhi planned it though her father did not. But whether Rajiv was selected because Indian politicians want him permanently, or think he will be a convenient time-server will take time to tell. And it will take time to discover whether Rajiv will be docile or, his mother's son, take power as well as office.  Harshness and Gentleness In some ways, Jawaharlal and Indira were quite similar - both aristocrats born, both very much aware of it, both capable of harshness, rudeness and of considerable gentleness. **********Nehru laughed a lot, and told jokes and had a roving eye. It was only in her last years, and then briefly, before the tragedy of the Golden Temple of Amritsar, that Indira Gandhi seemed to allow her neck muscles to relax in public. **********Both were strong leaders, without much confidence in their subordinates. Perhaps Mrs. Gandhi was even the stronger, for where Nehru grew to power and nobody ever questioned him, Mrs. Gandhi, in effect, took it from men who had made the terrible mistake of underestimating and patronizing her. **********The great irony of the story of the father and daughter who in turn ruled one of the largest nations in earth is that they would probably have turned out to be political opponents had Jawaharlal lived while Indira reigned. For what the father lived by, the daughter tried to destroy.  Fought for Democracy For all his irritability - he used to slap his bald pate in sheer annoyance a dozen times a day - Jawaharlal Nehru to the day he died fought for and believed in an India growing under democracy, and only under democracy. **********The people would plead with him to rule them forever and he would brush them aside as he used to brush away the sticky garlands of marigolds that Indians love to drape around the shoulders of guests. He would shout at Indians, berate them, denounce their own religions, but he preached and lived a democratic philosophy and consistently refused to become dictator, something he probably could have accomplished by telephone. **********But in 1975 Mrs. Gandhi, as Prime Minister, suddenly created a political coup d'etat, and swept away the democratic guarantees of her father and his independence generation, established authoritarian rule, and arrested thousands. That iron rule ended, and India returned to democracy, when Mrs. Gandhi, misjudging her hold on the people, put her Government to the vote, and was swept out of office. She returned later, and nobody knows whether she would have tried rule by fist again. **********But there was a bitter joke in New Delhi during the days of her dictatorship - ''Indira is in the Prime Minister's house and Jawaharlal is back to writing letters to her from jail again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/27/busin.body_text: **********THE Mitsubishi Electric corporate print advertising campaign **********that begins today will be another offering from Chiat/Day, the creator of last year's most honored ad, worldwide. **********And like the TV commercial ''1984'' for Apple Computer's Macintosh model, the Mitsubishi work has the impact to break through the clutter around it. Although similar in format, with much illustration and little copy, the print campaign has startling graphics, with each so different that they almost seem to come from different campaigns, even though all have the Mitsubishi Electric logotype. **********The first ad, keyed to the spirit of the season, is dominated by a huge picture of a baseball infielder in intense action. The copy talks about the company's Diamond Vision, those large picture boards that can follow the play in stadiums and arenas. **********The other three ads in the campaign feature the company's projection TV, its digital compact disk player, and its semiconductors. The seen message is one of superior, quality products. The unseen one is that the products are worth the premium price being charged. **********According to Robert H. Wolf, the agency's general manager in New York, and Joseph P. Palladino, management supervisor, the campaign is out to reach and impress upscale consumers who might buy the products and top management at the corporations that are potential customers or suppliers. The two also hold the titles of executive vice president and senior vice president, respectively. **********Jay Chiat, chairman, chief executive and late arrival at the meet-the- press session, suggested that the campaign might also be a way for the giant parent, Mitsubishi Electric, a public company in Japan, to prepare the American financial community for a listing on a stock exchange here. But when Mr. Palladino checked with the client later in the day, they said that was not really what they had in mind at this time. **********The campaign is not print alone. Of about $4 million put behind it, some $2.5 million will be spent on news and information shows on network television aimed at both target audiences. **********While the print campaign was created in the agency's New York office, the Los Angeles shop, the original Chiat/Day installation, created the single, eye-catching 30-second spot, which was directed by Brent Thomas. Mr. Thomas, who now works on a freelance basis, was the art director for the widely acclaimed ''1984'' commercial. **********The Mitsubishi TV ad is a triumph of computer animation, as it follows the electric pulse of a picture from deep in the depths of a TV picture tube until it explodes into sight as a picture, first on one, then another and then the third of the company's electronic picture-producing products. **********The spot ran for the first time during ''Night Line'' a late-night show on the ABC-TV Network, which will get all of the Mitsubishi spending, because, according to Henry Antosz, vice president, media director in the Los Angeles office, it was the most efficient buy for the news and information programs that would deliver the desired audience. The spot will be on during ''20/20'' tonight. **********Checking its files, the Television Advertising Bureau could not find any record of another Japanese company doing corporate TV advertising in this country. But a number of those companies are quite active in print, especially in business publications. **********NEC Electronic, Hitachi, Sumitomo, Matsushita, Mitsui and Toshiba are all corporate advertisers, according to Don Garson, director of corporate communications at Forbes, while James Hoefer, associate publisher of Fortune, said he gets more action from Japan than he does from all of Europe. **********Fortune is on the Mitsubishi schedule, along with Business Week, but The Wall Street Journal is getting the big bite, half of the entire print budget. **********The copywriter-art director team for the television spot was Bill Hamilton and Rick Bayko. In New York, John Salvati did the writing, while Mario Guia served as art director and is therefore responsible for dreaming up the eerie concept of crowding a chamber music quintet into a human concha.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/02/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer Inc., like many other companies with active international operations, faced a problem recently. It agreed to make purchases from Japan, with payment due in yen several months later. The difficulty was that the value of the yen could - and did - swing sharply in those intervening months, altering Apple's dollar costs. **********Usually, to hedge such risks, companies agree to buy the yen, marks, pounds or other currency needed several months later at a fixed price in the forward market, paying in dollars. Apple, however, chose a new hedge, the currency option. **********Options are the right to buy or sell a set amount of a currency at a specified date. They eliminate the risk of a loss due to exchange movements, but unlike a forward contract, still give the holder a chance to come out ahead if the currency fluctuations are in its favor. **********As a result, Apple calculates, it saved $3 million. The company's head of foreign exchange operations, Robert Saltmarsh, now speaks of options like a religious convert. **********''Options have significantly reduced our foreign exchange risk,'' he said. ''They are perfect for giving you peace of mind over movements in the market.'' **********Mr. Saltmarsh's enthusiasm sets him apart, but not his interest in this complex financial instrument. There is much questioning in corporate treasuries about how to use them, but it is generally agreed that, for hedging certain kinds of transactions involving foreign currencies, they are better than forward or futures contracts, and that their use will become commonplace. **********''These things aren't a panacea for all companies, but when used properly, they're the ultimate hedging tool,'' said Scott N. Dillman, manager of options at the Marine Midland Bank, a major operator in the market. **********Although the Eastman Kodak Company does not use currency options yet, Eric Nelson, director of foreign exchange planning, said ''They are a terrific foreign exchange management tool and will occupy a significant portion of hedging activity somewhere down the road.'' **********Seemingly Whimsical Turns **********Foreign exchange fluctuations can play havoc with corporate planning. Hard-won operating gains can be wiped out by the seemingly whimsical turns of the currency market, or profits can be created. But the changes often cannot be forecast accurately. **********For the past year especially, the market has been a minefield, with the dollar defying predictions it is about to drop and constantly rising. ''We think all of our advisers are good, but all of them have been wrong on their forecasts,'' said Lawrence J. Lanza, assistant director of international treasury operations at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. **********Many experts regard currency options as one potential solution to currency rate volatility, although there has been initial corporate resistance to their use. First, the term ''options'' can scare away more conservative corporate managers, who associate options with speculators. **********''I can tell people at companies that options are the safest way to hedge,'' said S. Waite Rawls, managing director of the capital markets group at the Chemical Bank. ''But about three- fourths of them will look at me like I'm crazy because of the reputation.'' **********Premium at Beginning **********Also, currency options require that a premium be paid when the contract is entered into, whereas forward contracts generally involve a cash transaction only at maturity. **********''If you treat that premium as an insurance policy, it becomes far more acceptable,'' said John Prout, director of options trading at the Continental Grain Company. ''The purchase of an option can be far less risky and more flexible than a future or a forward.'' **********Forward contracts, which are the obligation to buy or sell a currency, are traded on a very well-developed and efficient interbank market, not an exchange floor. They have also been formalized as currency futures, which are traded in the pits of several international exchanges. Most corporate users say that the net result of the two is almost identical for hedging purposes. **********A currency option reduces risk to the premium paid, while still allowing the user to enjoy the benefit of favorable rate movements. The premium can run from about 1.5 percent to 5 percent of the contract's value, depending on the term of the option. As enticing as currency options sound, there is still a lot of educating to be done before they become more accepted. **********'Difficult to Explain' Paul Newhart, head of foreign exchange operations at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said that the company was studying options and was likely to become a user. But he needs to do more convincing first. ''They are difficult to explain, especially in detail,'' he said. **********A company as large as Du Pont could enlarge the market significantly since it handles several hundred million and up to $1 billion in foreign exchange exposure at any one time, Mr. Newhart said. ''We feel we don't have a choice but to consider options seriously,'' he added. **********Most experts agree that currency options are not likely to replace forward contracts completely. Their primary application is where the full extent of foreign currency payments or receipts is not certain or for longer- term contracts. **********''They are best for us when bidding for a contract denominated in a foreign currency,'' Mr. Lanza said. ''If we think we have a chance of winning the contract, we may still want to go ahead and hedge our exposure. With the option you buy protection but are n't locked into buying or selling the currency. When the exposure is defined, we would go to a forward.'' **********The currency options market still shows signs of its relative youth, which is another factor keeping some potential users on the sidelines. **********At Banks and Exchanges **********Companies can buy or sell options at the two exchanges where they are traded, or go directly to a bank. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange has been trading options in the Canadian dollar, pound, Swiss franc, West German mark and yen since 1982. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange trades just a mark option at present but expects to offer others this fall.  The Philadelphia exchange is enjoying the greatest activity. In July, it had record volume of 137,271 contracts and open interest of more than $2 billion, the exchange announced. **********But most of the writing of currency options is being done by banks, which will customize the option, with maturity dates and sums beyond the standard exchange contract. Many companies would also rather deal with a bank because they do not like the exchanges' margin requirements. **********Banks, in turn, have developed a nascent over-the-counter market where they trade options among themselves. They are also the largest players on the exchanges, where they hedge the risk they take when they sell an option to a customer. **********Relative Inexperience Seen **********Some corporate treasurers, however, say that the banks' relative inexperience shows in a number of ways. **********Mr. Saltmarsh of Apple said that when he shopped for options he found prices varied widely from bank to bank. ''They really don't know how to price them yet,'' he said. Mr. Saltmarsh takes the lowest price at the banks, but will not deal with the exchanges because he cannot get a customized contract there. **********Also, many banks are said to be doing a poor job of hedging their risk. ''The only perfect hedge for an option is another option,'' Mr. Prout of Continental Grain said. Nonetheless, many banks try to protect themselves with spot or forward contracts, which experts say amounts to trying to hit a constantly moving target with a fixed instrument. **********Citibank leaves its currency options positions almost completely unhedged, according to Bruce Krasting, head of options trading. At the opposite extreme is Marine Midland. Mr. Dillman said that the bank was at least 50 percent hedged at all times. ''If we sell an option, we try to buy an option,'' generally on the Philadelphia exchange, he said. **********Banks Expanding Role **********Aware of this weakness, banks are taking a more active role on the Philadelphia exchange to build expertise. Citibank, Marine Midland and the Bank of America are expected to take part soon in joint ventures with experienced traders as market specialists, said Arnold Staloff, director of new products on the exchange. **********The developments are being greeted with optimism, even if many continue to call currency options an emerging product. But the benefits are regarded as so attractive that there is little doubt options will become a normal risk management tool within several years and perhaps sooner if the dollar remains volatile. **********''At a cost,'' Mr. Prout of Continental Grain said, ''the company has a chance to have its cake and eat it, too.''     forex A hypothetical example of an American manufacturer making a purchase paid for in Japanese yen  If the Yen Rises After the three months the yen rises to 220 yen per dollar.  Since the dollar buys fewer yen the American company must pay almost $10.9 million to purchase 2.4 billion yen.  The American company exercises the option and purchases the necessary 2.4 billion yen at 240 yen per dollar.  Savings: about $700,000 (the $900,000 in added cost because of the higher yen exchange rate, less the $200,000 cost of the option).   If the Yen Is Stable After three months the yen stays at 240 yen per dollar. Since the rate is unchanged, the American company's purchase price stays at $10 million.  The manufacturer allows the option to expire unexercised.  The cost of the transaction is increased by the $200,000 cost of the foreign currency option.   If the Yen Falls After three months the yen falls to 260 per dollar.  Since the dollar buys more yen, the American company can now buy 2.4 billion yen for about $9.2 million.  The Americans buy the yen at the more advantageous rate in the spot market.  Savings: about $600,000 (the $800,000 savings in the purchase price less the $200,000 cost of the option).

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/20/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates declined yesterday as new data confirmed a slowdown in economic growth at the same time as the Federal Reserve showed its willingness to help sustain the recent drop in overnight interest rates. **********By late in the day, rates on Treasury bills and other short-term securities were lower by as much as a tenth of a percentage point, with the six- month issue bid at 10.31 percent, down from 10.41 percent. Lower short-term rates, plus a modest amount of investor buying, helped raise note and bond prices by amounts ranging from 1/8 to 3/4 point. **********Among active issues, the 12 1/2 percent bond rose to its highest price since it was auctioned in August, and was offered at 103 19/32, to yield 12.05 percent. The 12 3/4 percent notes due in 1989 were offered at 101 26/32, up about 6/32, to yield 12.23 percent. **********Two-Year Treasury Notes **********At the regular monthly auction of new two-year Treasury notes, the 11 7/8 percent issue sold at an average yield of 11.94 percent, well below the 12.27 percent level that prevailed a week ago, and down from 12.43 percent at last month's sale. The two- year issue was offered at 11.97 percent. **********The move to higher prices and lower interset rates was helped along shortly before noon when the Federal Reserve temporarily bought Treasury securities, thereby adding reserves to the banking system. Since the rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market was 11 1/4 percent at the time of the Fed's purchases, traders concluded that the central bank was satisfied with an overnight Federal funds loan rate of less than 11 1/2 percent. **********''Those who doubted that the Fed wants funds below 11 1/2 percent ought to be convinced now,'' one Government securities dealer said after the Fed's temporary purchases. Over the last week, the overnight funds rate, which is a benchmark for other short-term interest rates, has averaged about 11.45 percent, down from 11.52 percent in the previous week and 11.62 percent in the previous six weeks. **********Today the Commerce Department is expected to announce an early estimate for the gross national product for the third quarter that will be well below the 7.6 percent inflation-adjusted growth rate for the second quarter and the 10.1 percent rate during the first quarter. **********Weakness in economic data published over the last week has led many economists to revise downward their forecasts for economic growth during the current quarter to 4 percent or less, compared with 5 percent or more when the quarter began. A rate of 4 percent or less helps reduce interest rates because traders and investors associate slower economic expansion with weaker credit demands by businesses and consumers, less inflation and slower money supply growth. **********Raul Nicho, a vice president at Money Market Services of Belmont, Calif., noted that the economic analysis firm expected third-quarter growth of 4 1/2 percent as recently as Sept. 6. But that forecast has been revised downward as employment data and retail sales were weaker than expected. The latest reducton to 3 percent growth from 3 1/2 percent was made yesterday in response to a modest five-tenths of 1 percent gain in personal income. ''The data suggests that the increase could actually be less than 3 percent,'' Mr. Nicho said. **********New Housing Issues **********Among this week's new single- family housing issues, the Colorado Housing Finance Agency's $150 million of Aa/Ax rated bonds were tentatively priced by a Smith Barney group with yields on serial bonds ranging from 7.25 percent in 1986 to 9.50 percent in 1995. Longer-term bonds, all of which may be put, or redeemed by investors in 1995, included 9 3/4 percent bonds due in 2002 and 2012 offered with a yield of 10 percent. A zero coupon bond due in 2015 was offered with a 10 percent yield, and may be put by the investor in 1995 when the issue is convertible into a long term fixed rate bond. **********An $80 million issue of the North Carolina Housing Finance Agency was tentatively priced by a Salomon Brothers group with yields ranging from 7 percent in 1986 to 10.10 percent in 1999 and 10 3/8 percent in 2007. The financing, rated Aa/Ax, included zero coupon bonds due in 2016 offered at a price of 2.88, or $28.80 per $1,000 to yield 11.50 percent. **********Following are results of yesterday's auction of new two-year treasury notes: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) Average Price99.887Average Yield11.94%Low Price99.939High Yield11.97%High Price99.836Low Yield11.91%Accepted at low84%Total applied for$18,159,305Accepted$8,510,195N.Y. applied for$14,328,240N.Y. accepted$6,533,760Noncompetitive$1,192,000Interest set at11 7/8%The two-year notes mature Sept. 30, 1986.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/27/world.body_text: **********The telephones are ringing again in Setagaya. **********The Asanoya noodle shop is again taking orders by telephone. Businesses are moving their computers back from employees' homes to the office. And workmen have dismantled the emergency telephone banks where, braving the cold and the rain, people stood with hands cupped over their ears, shouting into the receivers. **********It took 22,800 repairmen working night and day to restore telephone and telecommunications services knocked out by a fire in a Tokyo underground utility tunnel on Nov. 16. Telephone company officials first predicted a monthlong wait for service in Setagaya, one of 23 wards in Tokyo. But as complaints flooded in from the area of more than 815,000 people, officials quickly stepped up the pace. **********Over the weekend, telephones began to ring in homes and offices throughout Tokyo's Setagaya ward, three weeks ahead of schedule. On the other end of the line was a formal apology, in extra- polite Japanese, from the telephone company. **********It was a week that did not do wonders for Japan's image as the ultimate in efficiency. The fire left hundreds of thousands of people without telephone service and many bank customers unable to withdraw money, particularly if they wanted to use electronic cash machines.   Rains Add to Discontent **********But if it was urban breakdown, it was urban breakdown Japanese style - no more inconvenience than absolutely necessary, and no effort spared by the legions of workmen deployed by the telephone company. **********In one of those nasty coincidences that seem to dog such disasters, the phones went out just as Japan ended a monthlong drought. Torrential rains from a passing typhoon soaked Tokyo - and the people using outdoor emergency telephones. At one such phone bank in Setagaya's Nozawa neighborhood, people huddled under umbrellas as they squatted to use telephones placed on low rocks. **********But by the end of the first day of rain, tarpaulins sprang up over every emergency phone bank. Each bank was equipped with lights, tables and a list of important phone numbers. **********The phone company provided facsimile services and posted signs on public telephones declaring them out of order. Even at Narita airport, lists appeared of telephone exchanges that were not working, an advisory to the unsuspecting traveler.   Calls Routed Through Sapporo **********But some problems persisted. The telephone company set up special lines to allow people to call the Setagaya ward office for emergencies or information. The plan backfired when people discovered that a 10-yen call - the equivalent of about 4 cents - lasted only a few seconds rather than the customary three minutes. **********The calls were able to go through because they were first routed to Sapporo, in the northern island of Hokkaido, and then were bounced back by satellite to Setagaya. But the customers were being charged the normal long- distance rate to Sapporo, rather than the local rate. That mistake, too, was quickly rectified. **********Marooned without telephones, businesses all over Setagaya were driven to new heights of ingenuity in an effort to stem their losses. Some businesses temporarily relocated, posting their new telephone numbers on vacant office windows. Others packed word processors in trucks bound for homes of employees with working telephones. **********A sushi shop near Komazawa University that relies on telephone calls from students for business decided to get their orders in person. Every morning employees walked over to the university to take lunch orders. **********But businesses were still estimating serious losses from the fire. Mitsubishi Bank's national banking network was paralyzed, with full service not restored until last Tuesday. Although the bank would not specify the damage, it is thought to run in the millions of dollars. **********Muto Kogyo, a drawing instruments company, lost communications between its head office in Setagaya's Ikejiri neighborhood, its plants and 15 branch offices. The company set up a provisional office and used air freight for messages, at a cost of more than $30,000. **********Small businesses suffered as well. Asanoya, the noodle shop, relies on telphone delivery orders for more than half of its business. For a week, it delivered no noodles, said Sayoko Natsui, whose father runs the shop. ''When they were estimating one month without phones,'' she said, ''my father said he felt as though his life had been turned upside down.''  Free Message Service **********The obliging telephone company set up a free message service, with clerical employees dispatched by bicycle and car and taxi to deliver important messages. By 10 P.M. Sunday, when the service was disbanded, employees had delivered 19,300 messages, according to a spokesman for Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Japan's public telephone company. These ranged from the tragic to the mundane: **********From a family to a relative: ''Grandma died. Funeral on the 20th.'' **********From a magazine to a writer: ''Is your story done yet?'' **********From a husband to a wife: ''I will return at 7 P.M. Have dinner ready.'' **********For some, the week without phones proved an unexpected windfall. The emergency phones may have been outdoors, but they were free, and customers could call anywhere in Japan. Every night at the Nozawa outdoor telephone bank, teen-agers monopolized the telephones, engaging in seemingly interminable conversations punctuated by giggles. One student who lives in Nagasaki, in the southern island of Kyushu, said he had called home an unprecedented three times in one week. **********Patience wore thin, however, as the lines grew longer. One elderly woman was seen happily chatting on the phone while a man in business clothes waited behind her. Finally he lost his temper and began to upbraid her as people nearby pretended not to hear. **********With the phones back in order, the question of how to compensate customers for lost service remained. The telephone company said it had decided to compensate all affected customers. But there was one catch. Since the company is a public corporation, levels of compensation are set by law. N.T.T. estimates that it will make payments of about $6.25 for household users and about $17.90 for business customers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/07/world.main_headline: SAUDIS TRY TO PLAY DOWN AIR BATTLE OVER GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/07/world.print_headline: SAUDIS TRY TO PLAY DOWN AIR BATTLE OVER GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/07/world.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia tried today to play down the significance of its air clash on Tuesday with Iranian jet fighters, in which at least one Iranian plane was downed. **********Press commentaries stressed what they said was the Saudis' longstanding role as a mediator in the 44-month-old war between Iran and Iraq. **********Iran remained silent on the incident. Instead, it lashed out at Iraq and its Persian Gulf allies for the bombing attack on the Kurdish town of Baneh, in which the Iranians said 600 people were killed or wounded. **********Iraq said 21 civilians were killed and more than a hundred wounded when the Iranians bombed Basra and three other towns that they had warned would be struck in retaliation for the Baneh raid. **********Iran said that Iraq had shelled Abadan, but that there were no casualties. **********On the aerial battle over the gulf, Western and Arab experts said the Saudis were evidently trying to adopt a conciliatory stance to avoid provoking Iran into further attacks. **********''They appear a bit stunned by their own success,'' a Western European diplomat said. ''They also appear anxious that this kind of military confrontation was necessary at all.'' **********Typical of the Saudi commentaries was one in the newspaper Al Riyadh, published in the royal capital, that stressed the defensive nature of the action. **********''We do not shed the blood of a Moslem brother unless he publicly enters our borders or our territorial waters,'' the paper said. **********Similarly, the newspaper Okaz of Jidda said Saudi Arabia desired good relations. **********''If we in the kingdom seek peace, this does not prevent us from practicing our right to repel any aggressor,'' an Okaz editorial said. ''Despite this, Saudi Arabia will adhere to its policy, which is based on respect of neighborly ties and work for peace.'' **********The Saudi press made no mention of the detailed accounts from Washington about the air battle that said two Iranian planes had been shot down. The Saudi press said only one ''aerial target'' had been hit, without identifying it or the location of the incident. **********According to the Iranian press agency, Prime Minister Hussein Musavi of Iran said the Baneh raid represented a ''turning point'' for the Islamic revolution. **********Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, said in a statement broadcast by the Teheran radio that Iraq would not be the only party held responsible for the raid. **********''We consider also those who encouraged the Iraqi regime to carry out the crime by means of their decisions, positions and assistance, partners in the crime,'' he said. ''There is no doubt that we will avenge the dastardly shelling of Baneh.'' **********Iran declared a national day of mourning. **********President Saddam Hussein of Iraq made no mention of the Baneh raid. But he telephoned King Fahd of Saudi Arabia to pledge support for the downing of the Iranian plane, according to the Iraqi press agency. The Emir of Kuwait also called to support King Fahd. **********An Iraqi communique said Iraqi gunners had hammered Iranian troops across the border.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/30/busin.body_text: **********Britain had its worst-ever trading month in April by running **********up a deficit of $:588 million, or **********$811 million, the Government **********said today. **********This was in contrast to a $:23 **********million, or $31.7 million, surplus in March. And it exceeded **********the previous worst month, February 1979, when there was a **********deficit of $:479 million, equal to **********$910 million at foreign-exchange rates then. Officials attributed the latest **********shortfall partly to the 12-week **********coal miners' strike, which has **********forced Britain to import $:100 **********million, or $138 million, worth **********of fuel oil, switching power **********plants from coal. But Britain's **********own oil exports fell by $:250 million, or $345 million.  Exports fell 6 percent in **********April; imports rose 4.5 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/02/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of a draft resolution on Lebanon that was endorsed at a caucus of House Democrats today: **********To bring about the prompt and orderly withdrawal of the United States armed forces participating in the multinational force in Lebanon. **********Resolved by the House of Representatives (the Senate concurring) that **********A **********The Congress finds as follows:  (1) **********Lebanon is important to United States interests in the Middle East, and the goal of United States policy with respect to Lebanon remains the territorial integrity and independence of Lebanon. **********(2) **********There is, however, widespread confusion among the American people about the mission of the United States Marines in Lebanon, and the President has been unable to present a convincing rationale for continued participation by United States armed forces in the multinational force in Lebanon under present circumstances.   (3) **********As the situation in Lebanon has deteriorated in recent months, it has posed increased dangers to the United States armed forces participating in the multinational force in Lebanon and has prohibited them from performing the peacekeeping mission which was the original justification for their presence in Lebanon. **********(4) **********As the Department of Defense Commission on the Beirut International Airport Terrorist Act of 23 October 1983 (commonly known as the ''Long Commission'') concluded, United States policy with respect to Lebanon has emphasized military options and the expansion of the United States military role and there is an urgent need for a reassessment of alternative means to achieve United States objectives in Lebanon in light of the changed circumstances.   (5) **********The Investigations Subcommittee of the Committee on Armed Services of the House of Representatives, in its report dated Dec. 19, 1983, concluded that, ''Sustained deployment of personnel in the situation of almost certain further casualties should only be undertaken if the policy objectives are visible, profoundly important and clearly obtainable. Failure of the Administration to adequately re-examine its policy and relate it to present conditions will only mean that such re-examination will have to be done by Congress.''  (6) The United States Marines in Lebanon have performed superbly despite the lack of a realistic United States policy and the confusion about their mission, and every effort must be made to insure that, pending their withdrawal from Lebanon, measures are taken to protect their security which are commensurate with the risks of further terrorist and other attacks.   (7) **********The situation in Lebanon, which is mired in internal domestic stalemate because of internal fighting and the refusal of the parties to the conflict to make the promises necessary to promote progress toward a peaceful resolution of the country's problems, requires a United States policy which gives higher priority to diplomatic and political solutions.   (8) **********The situation in Lebanon is drifting out of control and the Administration's policy regarding Lebanon is not working. The United States is reacting to events rather than implementing policies which are in the national interest of the United States.   (9) **********The Administration has failed to impress upon the Government of Lebanon the urgent need for it to develop a viable reconciliation plan, which might include such objectives as more equitable power-sharing, early parliamentary elections, a new census and the formation of a government of national reconciliation.   (10) The Administration has allowed the situation in Lebanon to dominate the United States agenda in the Middle East to the detriment of efforts for progress in the broader, and ultimately more important, Middle East peace process.   (11) **********The failure in the Administration's policy has led to widespread concern among the American people that continued participation by United States armed forced in the multinational force in Lebanon is not in the national interest. **********B **********Therefore, the Congress declares that United States policy toward Lebanon should include the following elements:  (1) **********The prompt and orderly withdrawal of the United States armed forces participating in the multinational force in Lebanon, in consultation with other members of the multinational force.   (2) **********A concerted diplomatic effort at the United Nations to replace the multinational force in Lebanon with another international peacekeeping force under United Nations auspices as called for in Section 5 (C) of the Multi-National Force in Lebanon Resolution, such effort to include discussions with the Secretary General of the United Nations, the President of the Security Council and all members of the Security Council. If this is not successful, the United States must intensify efforts to obtain agreement by other countries to assume peacekeeping responsibilities in the Beirut area.   (3) **********Advising the Government of Lebanon of the urgent need for that Government to develop a reconciliation plan which recognizes the legitimate aspirations of all confessional groups.   (4) **********Development of intensified diplomatic efforts with Syria, as soon as possible, to achieve acceptance by Syria, and the factions it supports in Lebanon, of a reconciliation plan for Lebanon.   (5) **********Promotion of continuing dialogue between the Governments of Israel and Lebanon concerning security arrangements and a reconciliation plan for Lebanon.   (6) **********Continuation of other efforts to achieve the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Lebanon and the re-establishment of a sovereign independent Lebanon, taking into account the legitimate security concerns of Syria and Israel.   (7) **********Renewal of efforts to pursue vigorously a broader Middle East peace to reduce tensions through the region as a step in facilitating peace and reconciliation in Lebanon.   (8) **********Intensification of United States efforts to retrain and re-equip the Lebanese armed forces, including efforts to increase military assistance and the delivery of defense articles and defense services to enable the Government of Lebanon to assume the responsibilities of the multinational force in Lebanon and enable local security forces to assume internal security functions among various communities in the country.   (9) **********Implementation of an economic assistance program for Lebanon with funds already appropriated and with the immediate assistance of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to start sound economic reconstruction and development projects and energize the Lebanese Government to provide better services and more presence in as much of the country as possible.   (10) **********Implementation of a series of plans, including military contingency plans, to protect against the increasing threat which terrorism poses to the United States and its friends and interests in the region. Such plans should include improvements of United States intelligence gathering, coordination and assessment capabilities in Lebanon in order to protect United States interests, citizens and armed forces in Lebanon to guard against terrorist attacks. **********C **********Not later than 30 days after the adoption of this resolution, the President shall submit a written report to Congress on the actions he has taken to implement these policies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/08/busin.body_text: **********The Sony Corporation of America, as expected, said it would build a laser videodisk facility in Terre Haute, Ind., provided it can get tax-exempt financing and Federal grant funds. Akio Morita, chairman and chief executive officer of Sony, said the company decided to locate in Indiana because of a pledge signed by state officials that the state would not impose a unitary tax against Sony. The unitary tax allows states to tax corporations based on their worldwide earnings, not just income earned within the state's boundaries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/21/busin.main_headline: COAST UTILITY'S WRITEOFF ON NUCLEAR PLANT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/21/busin.print_headline: COAST UTILITY'S WRITEOFF ON NUCLEAR PLANT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/21/busin.body_text: **********The Pacific Power and Light Company, trying to extract itself from its involvement in northwest nuclear plants that have been closed or are undergoing a construction slowdown, said today that it wrote off $228 million in 1983. **********The write-off brought earnings down to $71 million, or 45 cents a share, from $197 million, or $4.50 a share, in 1982. **********Revenues rose 14 percent, to $1.6 billion. **********''We wiped the slate clean on nuclear,'' said Gayle Zeber, senior vice president and chief financial officer. **********The company wrote off its $292 million investment for its 10 percent ownership in the Washington Public Power Supply Systems Nuclear Unit No. 3, on which construction was halted last July for three years because of a lack of financing. **********Net after tax investments reduced the write-off to $199, and Mr. Zeber said about $41 million of this might be recovered from the utility's ratepayers, leaving a balance of $158 million. **********In May 1983, the utility wrote off a $82 million investment in the supply system's terminated Unit No. 5 and in four other nuclear units that Pacific and other private utilities in the region had planned to build in Oregon and Washington. **********The company said its dividend of $2.16, the same amount paid in 1982, would not be affected by the write-offs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/27/busin.body_text: **********President Resigns At Goldhirsh Group **********Neil R. Goldhirsh, president of the Goldhirsh Group of Boston, confirmed yesterday that he had resigned his position because ''it's time for me to move on.'' **********The 37-year-old executive had joined the holding company that owns the companies that publish both Inc. and High Technology magazines at the behest of his older brother, Bernard A. Goldhirsh, the founder-chairman. **********Although he said he would stay but a year, he has been there three years. **********The younger brother is a successful publisher in his own right, having started Ski Earth Publications, which grew to be the home of three publications, Ski, Tennis and Golf Directories, the first an annual and the other two published twice a year. He started them in 1972 and sold them to Ziff Davis in 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/17/busin.body_text: **********Mr. Day spent 26 years with Chrysler, most recently as executive vice- president, corporate staff and international. He was in charge of Chrysler's military operations until that subsidiary was sold in 1982, and has served as controller and in various other financial and operating positions in the United States, Europe and Latin America. **********Mr. Day's responsibilities will be divided among Harold K. Sperligh, president of North American automotive operation; R.S. Miller, who becomes executive vice president of finance and administration, and Bennett E. Bidwell, executive vice president, international sales. All three were previously with the Ford Motor Company. **********Mr. Day was born in Chicago and graduated from Northwestern University. He is 50 and lives with his wife and two children in the northern Detroit suburb of Birmingham. His appointment with Allied is effective Feb. 1. **********Allied merged with the Bendix Corporation a year ago, and was reorganized into five major groups. Allied Auomotive consists of Fram and Autolite, formerly Bendix products, and Prestolite, North American Seat Belts and Woodstock Die Casting. **********Mr. Day was in Europe yesterday on business for Chrysler and was not available for comment, a Chrysler spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/05/busin.print_headline: PATENTS ; Helmet Projector Helps To Orient Naval Pilots
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/05/busin.body_text: **********Equipment has been invented for the Navy to train student pilots as to what they may see when flying. **********Denis R. Breglia and Frank J. Charek at the Naval Training Equipment Center in Orlando, Fla., received patent 4,446,480 this week for what is called the head position and orientation sensor. **********The student is to wear a helmet with a projector mounted on it. He is surrounded by a large blank screen. When he looks in a given direction, detectors in the screen indicate to a computer in which direction he is looking. The computer provides proper imagery for the projector, so the student sees what he would normally view at that angle from an aircraft.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/27/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Top Yield 10.20% On Alabama Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/27/busin.body_text: **********The Alabama Highway Authority is selling $411.95 million of bonds, which are tentatively offered with a maximum yield of 10.20 percent for bonds due in 1998 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. For shorter maturities, yields range from 6.57 percent for bonds due in 1985, to 8 percent in 1987, 8.75 percent in 1989 and 9.75 percent in 1994. **********Proceeds of the bonds, which are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.'s, will be used for highway improvements and to refund $206.5 million of outstanding bonds. After the refunding, the principal and interest of outstanding bonds of the authority and the Alabama Highway Finance Corporation will be backed by United States Treasury securities. **********The new bonds are backed by various taxes and fees, including the motor vehicle tag tax, gasoline and other motor fuel taxes and inspection fees. In 1983, the total of pledged revenues was about $128 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/30/busin.body_text: **********The Metromedia Broadcasting Corporation is offering four debt issues to raise about $1.3 billion to repay bank debt incurred in the leveraged buyout of Metromedia by its senior management earlier this year. **********The offering, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., consists of $940 million face amount of zero coupon notes, due from 1988 through 1993, which will raise about $397.5 million; $335 million of senior exchargeable variable rate debentures due in 1996; $225 million of 15 5/8 percent senior subordinated debentures due in 1999, offered at 99 1/4 to yield 15.756 percent, and $400 million of adjustable-rate participating subordinated debentures, offered at a discount to raise about $349 million of cash. **********The $960 million of zero coupoon notes, which carry a speculative rating of B-1 from Moody's and B plus from Standard & Poor's, were offered withe yield ranging from 13.75 percent in 1988 to 15.25 percent in 1993. The $225 million of 15 5/8 percent debentures due in 1999 are not refundable for five years and are rated B-3 by Moody's and B- by S.&.P. **********The $400 million of debentures, rated B-3 by Moody's and B- by Standard & Poor's, mature in 2002, and are offerd at a price of 87,299 with a 13 1/4 percent coupon to yield 15 percent on Dec. 1, 1989, and beginning in 1990 the company may make additional interest payments based on increases in its cash flow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/world.main_headline: SYRIA CALLS ABROGATION OF PULLOUT AGREEMENT ESSENTIAL TO PRESIDENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/world.print_headline: LEBANON IS WARNED BY BOTH SIDES ON ITS SECURITY ACCORD WITH ISRAEL; SYRIA CALLS ABROGATION OF PULLOUT AGREEMENT ESSENTIAL TO PRESIDENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/12/world.body_text: **********Two senior Syrian officials said today that cancellation of Lebanon's security pact with Israel was essential for President Amin Gemayel's political survival and for any progress toward resolving the Lebanese and Arab-Israeli conflicts. **********One of the officials, Farouk al- Sharaa, acting Minister of Information, also said Syria was prepared to ''study'' the placement of a neutral international military force in Lebanon to help maintain order and to speed the withdrawal of the French, Italian and American forces there. **********Moscow's Position Is Unclear **********Walid Jumblat, the Druse political leader and one of Syria's key Lebanese allies, said tonight that such a force might be acceptable if the United States would remove the Sixth Fleet from Lebanon's coast. **********Mr. Sharaa said he did not know if the Soviet Union would agree to such a plan. But one Foreign Ministry official said Moscow and Damascus were prepared to accept a United Nations force under certain conditions. **********The comments today by Mr. Sharaa and Mohammed Haider, director of the Baath Party's foreign affairs section, were the first official statements of Syria's position on two critical issues affecting Lebanon's future: the fate of Mr. Gemayel and finding a replacement for the multinational forces. The two men spoke in separate interviews. **********Gemayel Is a Domestic Matter **********Regarding the political prospects of President Gemayel, the two officials had slightly different positions. Both asserted that his fate must be determined by the Lebanese. But Mr. Haider said that if Mr. Gemayel canceled the May 17 pact with Israel and worked toward a government of national reconciliation, he would be able to stay on as President. Mr. Sharaa said that although canceling the agreement was ''the only way he could survive,'' Syria's Lebanese allies were bitterly opposed to him. **********''They don't want to express their disappointment in him publicly,'' Mr. Sharaa said. ''But they believe he's a liar. They can't trust him.'' **********Syrian officials invariably argue that the Lebanese must decide internal Lebanese issues. But the presence of up to 50,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon and Syria's support for Lebanese factions opposed to Mr. Gemayel gives Damascus significant weight in shaping political developments in that country. **********Mr. Haider made a number of other points: **********- Syria has neither ''demands nor ambitions'' in Lebanon. He said Syria's troops would be withdrawn from Lebanon ''within hours'' if Israeli, American and other foreign forces were pulled out and a national reconciliation government asked the Syrians to leave. **********- If the United States continues shelling opposition and Syrian-held positions in Lebanon, Syria will ''respond and repulse this aggression with all the force we can muster.'' **********- The emergence of a coalition of Arab powers - Egypt, Jordan, and the Palestine Liberation Organization - which are seeking a joint plan for negotiations with Israel was ''the most dangerous'' political development to date. Because it was aimed at ''liquidating the Palestinian question once and for all,'' Syrian resistance to such a coalition would be ''stronger than to any other previous development.'' **********- Damascus was deeply saddened by the death of the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, in part because it forced the postponement of joint high-level planning meetings here at a critical time in the region. **********- If the United States changes its policies in the Middle East, Syria will be willing to ''meet America more than halfway'' in finding ways to resolve the Lebanese and the broader Arab-Israeli conflict.   American Strategy Criticized **********Mr. Haider said President Reagan's two-pronged decision on Tuesday to move the marines to ships offshore and to shell Syrian and Lebanese rebel positions that fire on Beirut was not a change in American policy. The Administration's approach to the area, he said, was based on ''aggression and imposing an American view by force.'' **********''America is still looking at the Arab- Israeli conflict in pieces,'' he said. ''It believes in partial solutions to the problem.'' **********He said Syria, by contrast, supported a comprehensive solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict based on resolutions approved by the United Nations and by various Arab summit meetings, especially the one held in Fez, Morocco, at the end of 1982.   Peace Agreements Opposed **********Syria has long opposed the peace agreements signed by Israel and Egypt in 1979 and the peace plan put forth by President Reagan in September 1982 as piecemeal solutions to the conflict. Mr. Haider did not mention either of them today, but other Syrian officials privately expressed anger that neither the Camp David peace process nor the Reagan plan explicitly contained provisions that would enable Syria to reclaim the Golan Heights, lost to Israel in the 1967 war. **********Western analysts here said Syria's fear of being excluded from American- sponsored Mideast efforts was also responsible for Mr. Haider's expressions of alarm today over the recent emergence of an Arab coalition seeking negotiations with Israel. Mr. Haider warned that Syria would fight this ''most dangerous'' trend with ''different methods.'' Asked to elaborate, he replied: ''Political steps and others.'' **********King Hussein of Jordan has accused elements in Syria of responsibility for the recent spate of attacks against his ambassadors abroad and bombings at home. Syria has denied responsibility.   Friendship With Soviet **********Mr. Haider said Syria and the Soviet Union, which has an estimated 7,000 military trainers and advisers in this country, would continue their ''coordination and search for common interests between friends.'' **********At the same time, he emphasized at several points in the interview Syria's desire to improve its relations with the United States, provided the Reagan Administration was prepared to ''modify'' its policies here. **********Specifically, he called upon the United States to drop its support for the May 17 accord. This, he maintained, would be the ''first step forward'' toward a resolution of the conflict in Lebanon, and an indication of the ''fundamental modification'' of American policies that Syria has been seeking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/29/busin.snippet: Methods of dry etching metals by use of gas and a laser beam were patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation, Armonk, N.Y. Patents 4,490,210 and 4,490,211 were granted to Lee Chen and other inventors.
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/29/busin.main_headline:
PATENTS;
Dry Etching of Metals By Gas and Laser Beam
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/29/busin.print_headline:
PATENTS;
Dry Etching of Metals By Gas and Laser Beam
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/29/busin.body_text: **********Methods of dry etching metals by use of gas and a laser beam were patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation, Armonk, N.Y. Patents 4,490,210 and 4,490,211 were granted to Lee Chen and other inventors. **********Etching has potential use in the fabrication of electronic components for computers. **********The metal to be etched is placed in a reaction chamber. The pressure is reduced and a selected gas is introduced that reacts with the metal. A laser radiation beam is then aimed at the surface to cause the etching. The second patent differs from the first by specifying the laser as an ''excimer,'' which is explained as meaning ''excited dimmer.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/03/busin.body_text: **********The General Accounting Office recommended today that the Social Security Administration reconsider a decision to purchase $16.2 million of additional equipment from the Paradyne Corporation of Largo, Fla., a data-processing equipment company. **********In a 39-page report, the Congressional auditors said there were ''serious flaws'' in the Social Security agency's management of a $100 million contract it awarded Paradyne in 1981, the biggest purchase the agency has ever made. **********The G.A.O. questioned the agency's decision in March to purchase additional units of computer equipment whose ''failure rate is still three to four times that of similar terminal installations.'' **********The G.A.O. report was requested by Representative Jack Brooks, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, and was released by him at a hearing. Mr. Brooks took testimony from G.A.O. and Social Security officials. A request by Paradyne to testify was denied. **********Agency Defends Decision **********Paradyne's Washington lawyer, Harvey Pitt, said that since March, the Social Security agency has purchased about half of the $16.2 million in additional computer units. Officials gave the committee no indication today that they intended to reconsider purchasing the additional units. **********Marshall S. Mandell, a Deputy Commissioner of Social Security, told the committee that his agency ''is highly dependent on the performance of the Paradyne equipment,'' and switching brands would be costly. **********Paradyne's ability to fulfill its contract has been the subject of much speculation since March 1983, when the S.E.C. accused the company of violating the securities laws. The S.E.C. charged in a civil suit that Paradyne, in vying for the contract, violated the securities laws by making misrepresentations about its ability to perform. **********The S.E.C. has also charged that Paradyne intentionally misled Social Security officials by repackaging the products of another company and demonstrating an information-coding device that was ''nothing more than an empty box with blinking lights.'' Paradyne has vigorously denied the charges. **********Mr. Brooks said that the Social Security agency ''relaxed its testing requirements'' in awarding the contract to Paradyne. ''As a result, the system acquired from Paradyne continuously failed to meet contractual performance requirements for at least two years after the first terminals were installed and serious questions remain over the operation of this equpment.'' **********The G.A.O. report, however, did say that there had been improvements in the equipment's performance in the last several months. **********In a statement issued before the hearing, Robert S. Wiggins, chief executive of Paradyne, said, ''The most important fact, the crucial, dispositive fact concering Paradyne's performance under this contract, is that the Paradyne equipment works, and works extremely well.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/13/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices surged in late trading yesterday in the market's biggest rally in more than a month as institutional investors shrugged off early hesitations and rushed to buy. **********The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 1,157.14, up 26.17 points, marking its biggest daily gain since Feb. 24, when it rose 30.47 points. Volume swelled to 96.3 million shares from Wednesday's 80.3 million. **********Analysts said that good first-quarter earnings reports, indications that the economic expansion was slowing and a rally in International Business Machines' stock snapped the market out of a morning slump. **********Factors in Turnaround **********The analysts added that hopes of a large drop in the money supply and optimism about the continued strength of the bond market may also have contributed to the turnaround. **********After the close of trading, the Federal Reserve reported a $5 billion decline in the M-1 measure of the basic money supply for the week ended April 4, twice as much as had been expected. But analysts noted that April data are particularly erratic because of the flows of income tax payments and refunds. (Page D14.) **********Other overall market indicators also rose yesterday. The exchange's composite index climbed 1.40, to 90.64, and Standard & Poor's index of 500 equities closed at 157.73, up 2.73. **********Gainers on the New York Stock Exchange outscored losers by a 2-to-1 margin. The biggest advances were made by the blue-chip, technology and transportation stocks. **********Prices Opened Higher **********The market opened with prices rising in response to the announcement that March retail sales had fallen 2.2 percent from February, the sharpest monthly drop in 10 years. The news indicated that the economy was slowing, which would reduce upward pressure on interest rates. **********Prices then began declining after I.B.M. announced a 23 percent increase in first-quarter earnings. By 11:30 A.M., the industrial average was down 5.97 points, to 1,121.02, its low for the day, as investors apparently decided that the profits rise was disappointing. **********Then, in midafternoon, prices began climbing; in the last hour of trading, the Dow soared more than 20 points **********''It was as if someone pulled a trigger,'' said Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst of MKI Securities Corporation. ''All of a sudden, all hell broke loose.'' **********A Second Look **********Analysts said they could not pinpoint why the market took off, but suggested that investors took a second look at I.B.M.'s earnings and other positive economic developments. One analyst suggested that the late upswing was spurred by rumors that the nation's money supply had fallen more than anticipated. **********Such declines take pressure off the Fed to impose credit restraints, which push up interest rates and are generally negative for equities. **********Marshall Acuff, portfolio strategist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said that investors might also have been encouraged by news that Congress was moving closer toward a compromise on the Federal budget and continued good performance in the bond and futures market. **********Mr. Acuff and Mr. Jensen also suggested that the market's ability to stay above 1,120 pleased technicians. ''The market survived a critical technical test, and the recognition that this occurred encouraged increased buying during the course of the afternoon,'' Mr. Acuff said. **********Heavy Volume in I.B.M. **********I.B.M., traditionally a bellwether stock, led the market both down and up; it finished the session with a gain of 3 5/8, to 112 1/2, in heavy trading. Also responding to earnings reports, Lockheed rose 3, to 36, while TRW Corporation rose 5/8, to 63 3/8. **********In the stronger blue-chip category, Eastman Kodak was up 2 3/8, to 62 7/8, and Union Carbide gained 2 1/8, to 56 5/8. Advances of a point or more were made by International Paper, Merck, Minnesota Mining and Procter & Gamble. **********NCR, up 4 1/8, to 102 7/8, was the biggest gainer among the better-performing technology issues, nearly reversing yesterday's 6-point plunge. **********Texas Instruments was up 3 1/2, to 131 1/2; Honeywell was up 3, to 56 7/8, and Cray Research rose 3, to 41 1/2. The big loser was Teledyne, which tumbled 6 7/8, to 150 3/4. The company reported a 50.2 percent drop in first- quarter earnings. **********Transportation Group **********In the transportation group, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines rose 2 5/8, to 59 1/2, while Delta, AMR, Burlington Northern and Union Pacific each rose more than a point.  Morton Thiokol soared 4 1/2, to 79, helped by rumors that Dow Chemical was considering a takeover. **********After dropping for three consecutive days, Marsh & McLennan finished up 1 3/8, at 43 5/8. The stock had dropped following news that the company would lose $60 million in bond trading. **********Prices on the American Stock Exchange also finished mostly higher, with the market value index rising 1.51, to 205.49. Verbatim rose 1 1/4, to 10, despite reporting lower earnings in its third quarter ended March 30. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index rose 0.77, to 242.56.
