https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/15/world.main_headline: CLASHES IN LEBANON EASR AFTER SYRIA THREATENS TO INTERVENE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/15/world.print_headline: CLASHES IN LEBANON EASR AFTER SYRIA THREATENS TO INTERVENE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/15/world.body_text: **********Fighting between two pro- Syrian militia forces in northern Lebanon slackened today after President Hafez al-Assad of Syria threatened to order his army to intervene. **********After an overnight cease-fire, however, there were reports of new artillery fire in some parts of the Koura district in the afternoon. There were no immediate reports of casualties. **********The radio station of the Maronite Christians' Marada Brigade accused the National Syrian Social Party of using artillery against Koura villages in the early afternoon. **********In Beirut, a Christian Phalangist radio station reported artillery exchanges in the areas and the state-run Beirut radio also reported gunfire. **********Militia and hospital sources said about 28 people had been killed and 130 wounded in the latest of round of fighting between the two militias. **********President Assad, disturbed that fighting between friendly forces was occurring in an area controlled by the Syrian Army, issued an ultimatum for a truce by 1 A.M. today, saying the army would step in otherwise. **********Mr. Assad sent an envoy to work out a cease-fire on Thursday, but that broke down swiftly. On Friday night he told the leaders of the two forces to travel to Damascus for peace talks. **********The Marada Brigade commander, Robert Franjieh, and Inaam Raad, head of the National Syrian Social Party, arrived in Damascus to meet under the auspices of Vice President Abdel Halim Khaddam, Syrian sources said.  There is uncertainty about the reason for the fighting. On Friday, Mr. Raad accused Mr. Franjieh, son of former President Suleiman Franjieh, of trying to establish a Maronite district under his control.   Beirut Editor Wounded **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 14 (Reuters) - The editor of a leftist Lebanese newspaper was shot and wounded today, and newspapers here announced they would not publish Monday to protest the shooting. **********The editor of the newspaper As Safir, Talal Salman, was hit in the jaw in front of his West Beirut home before dawn. Two bodyguards were wounded. **********The head office of Mr. Salman's newspaper, which receives Libyan financing, has been the target of two bomb attacks this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/21/busin.body_text: **********An international group of investors, led by Morgens, Waterfall, Vintiadis & Company, a New York investment advising firm, said it had purchased the equivalent of 2,029,175 common shares, or 5.2 percent of the shares outstanding, of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire. **********According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group purchased the shares only for investment. **********Members of the group include the Arabian Investment Banking Corporation, a banking corporation based in Bahrain; several of Arabian Banking's affliliates, and Investeam and Phaeton International N.V., two limited liability companies based in the Netherlands Antilles. **********The group purchased warrants to purchase the shares for $5 a share in private and open market transactions between Nov. 19 and Dec. 10. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/18/world.main_headline: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL C.I.A. PRIMER FOR LATIN REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/18/world.print_headline: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL C.I.A. PRIMER FOR LATIN REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/18/world.body_text: **********Democrats in Congress reacted angrily today to reports that the Central Intelligence Agency had prepared a primer for Nicaragua's anti-Sandinista guerrillas that includes advice on how to kidnap and kill government officials. **********Representative Edward P. Boland, the Massachusetts Democrat who is Chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, announced that his committee is conducting an investigation. He said the C.I.A. had never told the committee of the primer and that he was ''appalled by the image of the United States that the primer portrays.'' **********Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is Vice Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said he has directed a senior C.I.A. official to report to the Senate committee by Friday on what the agency ''has learned about the facts surrounding this document.'' **********A C.I.A. spokesman said the agency would comply but offered no other comment. **********Among the advice included in the 42- page booklet are instructions for blackmailing Nicaraguan citizens so they can be coerced to work for the anti-Sandinista rebels, arranging the deaths of fellow rebels to create ''martyrs'' for their cause, staging violence by armed mobs and arranging public executions of Nicaraguan Government officials. **********All that, the primer says, is to ''improve the public attitude of the people'' toward the guerrillas. **********Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat, said: ''The fundamental question is, did President Reagan know about the C.I.A.'s role in the preparation of this reprehensible document, and if he didn't, what is he going to do about it now?'' **********The White House declined to comment today. **********A House Intelligence Committee staff member said the C.I.A has ''given us some answers'' about the primer ''but certainly not everything we want.'' **********Mr. Boland, in a letter to Representative Thomas J. Downey, the New York Democrat who requested an investigation, wrote that like the mining of Nicaragua's harbors, ''the manual is a disaster for United States foreign policy.'' **********The C.I.A. directed the harbor mining last year, but did not inform Congress. ''Like the mining,'' Mr. Boland wrote, ''the manual was not revealed to the committee.'' **********He added that it ''never should have been produced by any element of the United States government. It embraces the Communist revolutionary tactics the United States is pledged to defeat throughout the world.'' **********One of the questions the committee has been considering, the staff member said, is whether the primer violates Presidential and C.I.A. directives forbidding involvement in assassinations. **********The primer never uses the word assassination. It advises the rebels to ''neutralize'' selected public officials, such as ''court judges, police and state security officers.'' **********Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who is ranking minority member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said: ''The Administration has launched an aggressive anti-terrorism campaign, and yet we seem to be engaged in the very same terrorist activities which we deplore elsewhere.'' **********Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the Connecticut Democrat who is a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, pointed out that twice this year he had offered amendments in the Senate that would forbid the C.I.A. to use any money in Nicaragua for terrorism or terrorist-related activities. Both times, in April and October, the amendments have been narrowly defeated. **********Today Senator Dodd said, ''This administration has been vociferous in its condemnation of state-supported terrorism. But this document makes a mockery of that position. If this isn't state supported terrorism, then I don't know what is.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/16/world.body_text: **********A young Swiss priest presented a giant safety pin to Pope John Paul II today at a meeting in the Benedictine abbey here with Swiss priests, two of whom suggested concern that the Pope is too conservative on church issues. **********The gift was symbolic, the Rev. Markus Fischer said as he removed it from a wooden case before presenting it. ''We want to show you our readiness and our good will,'' he said. **********''It serves well,'' the priest continued, holding up the pin. ''but only when it has been opened.'' **********The Pope accepted the gift with evident bemusement. But in his speeches during the day, he overrode criticisms of the church and its policies by seeming to reject or ignore them. **********Father Fischer made his gesture at the end of a speech in which he, as representative of the German-speaking priests of Switzerland, laid 10 grievances before the Pope. They largely concerned issues in which priests, like many other Roman Catholics, believe John Paul takes stands that are too conservative. **********In his reply to Father Fischer and the priests who had spoken for the French, Italian and Romansch linguistic communities of this country with four official languages, the Pope cast doubt on whether the priests were truly representative.  ''I do not know whether they correspond to the thinking and the concerns of the majority of the clergy in Switzerland,'' John Paul said. He added that rather than address most of the issues that had been raised, he would speak about atheistic materialism, which he called ''the crucial problem.'' **********On at least one issue that Father Fischer had raised, celibacy of priests, many of his colleagues showed by applauding the Pope emphatically that opinions among the Swiss clergy were indeed divided. **********The ovation came when John Paul reaffirmed that he opposed any weakening of priestly vows of chastity. ''In a sense, fidelity to a state of life that one has accepted is required for the very dignity of the person,'' the Pope said. **********But he joined in general laughter when Father Fischer, noting that even the Apostle Peter had been married, asked, ''Why did our Lord Jesus heal the mother-in-law of Peter?'' **********The Pope dealt summarily with a series of the young priest's grievances that asked in effect that the status of laymen in the Roman Catholic Church be raised. The Pope declared firmly that he rejected what he called ''attempts to 'clericalize the laity' or 'laicize the clergy.' '' **********To underscore his points, Father Fischer, as well as many of the other priests, wore a business suit instead of priestly clothes. The Pope has made known his strong dislike for priests' not wearing cassocks or at least clergymen's suits and has ordered them to be worn by all priests in Rome. **********Together with the Rev. Gianpaolo Patelli, representing the Italian-language clergy, Father Fischer pleaded on behalf of priests who were disqualified from priestly functions because they have married but have not been allowed to return to the lay state and thus remain in disgrace in the eyes of the church. Previous Popes have granted such requests, but John Paul has taken no action on several thousand cases before him.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/28/world.main_headline: SWISS TANKER IS REPORTED HIT IN GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/28/world.print_headline: SWISS TANKER IS REPORTED HIT IN GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/28/world.body_text: **********A Swiss-owned supertanker was hit in the Persian Gulf today, apparently by an Exocet missile fired from an Iraqi warplane, and the ship's engine room was set on fire after the vessel had loaded Iranian oil at the Kharg Island terminal, shipping sources said. **********Iraq said its warplanes had successfully attacked ''two very large naval targets'' - the phrase it usually uses to designate a tanker. The sources could confirm only that one ship was hit. Iraq also warned that it planned to step up strikes against ships calling at Kharg Island, the only point in the Persian Gulf where Iran can still deliver oil to its customers. **********Early this morning the 260,000-ton Swiss-owned and Liberian-registered tanker Tiburon put out a distress call, saying its engine room was on fire and several crewmen were injured. Shipping sources in Bahrain and in Zurich said they believed the ship had been hit by an Exocet missile fired from an Iraqi warplane. A salvage tug was on its way from Bahrain to give assistance. **********Iran's Islamic leadership immediately vowed revenge for the attack. **********After a Cabinet meeting in Teheran, Iran's Prime Minister, Mir Hussein Moussavi, said, ''We will deliver a blow for every blow we receive.'' He also warned that Iran would strike back at other gulf nations that support Iraq, saying, ''Security in the gulf must apply to all or to none.''  Lull Ended Sunday **********The attack on the Tiburon was reported to have occurred about 100 miles south of Kharg Island, where several other ships have been hit by Iraqi planes this year. The attack came three days after Iraq first broke a two- week lull in attacks on gulf shipping. On Sunday an Iraqi plane damaged the Greek-owned tanker Alexander the Great with an Exocet missile while the vessel was loading oil at Kharg Island. Some oil-loading installations at the terminal were also reportedly damaged in the attack. **********An Iraqi military spokesman said today on the Baghdad radio that the latest attacks showed ''Iraq is tightening its blockade of Kharg Island and other Iranian ports on the gulf.'' **********He called the strike ''further proof of Iraq's resolve to carry out its previous warnings to all shipping companies to end their dealings with the Iranian regime.'' The spokesman said future attacks would be ''even more severe.'' **********The Iraqi Government of President Saddam Hussein, at war with Iran since September 1980, is trying to weaken the Iranians by cutting off their oil sales, which Teheran relies on to pay for arms and munitions.   Backing for Iraq **********The leaders of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other gulf nations are backing Iraq, contributing billions of dollars to its war effort, because they fear the destabilizing effect of an outright victory for Iran's revolutionary regime. **********Iran's leaders have responded to the attempt to blockade Kharg Island by launching several air strikes against tankers carrying Saudi and Kuwaiti oil. They have also made a vague threat to blockade the gulf by closing the Strait of Hormuz, through which 17 percent of the non-Communist world's oil supplies pass. **********Since April 18 Iraq is believed to have attacked 10 tankers moving through the gulf and Iran is believed to have attacked 5. **********In the last few days Saudi Arabia and other gulf nations have sent their air forces to fly protective patrols over tankers and other ships using their ports. These fighter planes are being helped by Awacs reconnaissance planes on loan from the United States.   No Response So Far **********So far this protective air shield has deterred Iran from trying to retaliate for the two Iraqi attacks this week. But diplomats in Bahrain say they remain apprehensive that Iran might soon seek revenge, further heightening the war. **********It is unclear whether the two latest Iraqi air attacks are deterring vessels from going to Kharg Island. Earlier this year Iran was reported to have seen its Kharg Island sales fall from the usual level, about 1.8 million barrels a day, to under a million barrels a day as a result of the fighting. **********Kuwait and Saudi Arabia suffered less, partly because they offered to replace lost oil free of charge and also because they used their own tankers to ferry supplies down the gulf to foreign vessels waiting in the safe waters of the Arabian Sea. **********In the two-week lull in the fighting, Iran's exports were reported back to normal levels.   Accord on Civilian Targets **********Earlier this month Iran and Iraq accepted a limited cease-fire in their land war, with each side agreeing not to hit civilian targets. But Western intelligence has reported that about half a million Iranian soldiers are now massed along the front line with Iraq, apparently in preparation for a new offensive. After the Iraqi attack last Sunday on the Alexander the Great, the Baghdad radio warned that Iraq would destroy the Kharg Island terminal if Iran launched a new ground assault. **********Further evidence of support for Iraq came today from Jordan, where the official press agency quoted King Hussein as telling King Fahd of Saudi Arabia that Jordan would ''stand by its brothers in defending their lands, waters and sovereignty.'' The two Kings met in Jidda on Tuesday. **********U.S. Arms Sale to Kuwait **********WASHINGTON, June 27 - The Defense Department notified Congress today that it plans to sell Kuwait improved antiaircraft equipment worth $82 million. **********The sale would provide Kuwait, a Persian Gulf nation that says it believes it is threatened by possible attack from Iran, with improvements in its Hawk antiaiacraft mnissiles and its radar equipment. **********There are no plans to sell to Kuwait the shoulder-fired Stinger antiaircraft missiles sold last month to Saudi Arabia. Congressional critics of the Stinger sale have argued that the Stingers could fall into the hands of terrorists for use against civilian planes. **********In another development, the White House said that Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Arabian Ambassador, met for 15 minutes with President Reagan and conveyed a message from King Fahd about the situation in the Persian Gulf. **********Afterward, Prince Bandar said the Saudis were hoping that ''common sense will prevail'' in the region and prevent the war from escalating.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/busin.main_headline: STORES REDUCE PROBLEM OF LOSSES IN INVENTORIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/busin.print_headline: STORES REDUCE PROBLEM OF LOSSES IN INVENTORIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/16/busin.body_text: **********The nation's retailers call it ''shrink,'' and it costs them a fortune every year. They don't know whom to blame most - crooks, clerks or ghosts. **********Shrink is retail inventory shortage, the billions of dollars worth of goods that seem to evaporate from stores each year through shoplifting, internal theft and bookkeeping errors. **********But shrink may be shrinking. **********For the third consecutive year, retailing experts say, inventory shortages have declined. The shortage rate in 1983 was the lowest in at least five years, despite the retail industry's higher sales. **********Even so, the experts estimate, last year the nation's department, general merchandise and apparel stores lost goods with a wholesale value of about $1.8 billion or a retail value of about $3.6 billion. **********Retailers' Hopes Brighten **********Though still staggering, These numbers may represent a narrowing trend, raising retailers' hopes of trimming shortages further and thus improving profitability. **********''The lower trend in shrinkage will improve the retailers' bottom line and take some pressure off their need to increase their margins,'' said Jay Scher, vice president of the financial executives' division of the National Retail Merchants Association, a trade group. ''Therefore, the consumer should benefit by not having to pay higher prices.'' **********Touche Ross & Company, the accounting firm, says the 1983 shortages of $3.6 billion were 1.82 percent of retail sales, totaling $197 billion. The 1982 shortages of $3.66 billion were 1.99 percent of $184 billion sales. The 1981 shortages of $3.73 billion were 2.09 percent of $178.5 billion sales. **********Trend Continuing This Year **********Irwin Cohen, head of Touche Ross's national retail industry group, said, ''The lower trend in inventory shrinkage is continuing in 1984 so far.'' **********Merchandise that vanishes is merchandise that cannot be sold. Reducing the shrink, therefore, slows the potential-sales drain. According to retailing experts, this means higher profits for many retailers. For some, where the problem is so severe that shrinkage has equaled profits, the slowing could actually create profitability where there had been none. **********A retailer typically sets aside a reserve fund to compensate for shortages. A declining shortage rate would mean that less money must be diverted to such funds. **********Surprisingly, the decline in inventory shortages comes despite increases in both inside theft and shoplifting, according to specialists. **********Inventory Control Improved **********Many merchants credit the decline to new computerized merchandise information systems that allow tighter inventory control with fewer bookkeeping errors, such as ringing up the wrong amount, incorrect recording of goods received and failure to keep track of goods returned to suppliers. **********''Shrinkage is more a function of back-office discipline than of shoplifting,'' said Herbert Wittkin, a New York retailing consultant and a former group vice president at the Allied Stores Corporation. **********''During the recent recession,'' he said, ''there were more reasons for bookkeeping mistakes, such as many more markdowns, producing twice the amount of paper than in better times. Last year there was less merchandise shrinkage because of exceptionally good business compared with 1982's recession.'' **********Problem of Theft Persists **********But theft is still serious. Pilferage, by customers and employees alike, grew about 10 percent last year, according to another accounting firm, Arthur Young & Company. **********Experts disagree about how much of the stores' shrink is due to theft. **********According to Touche Ross, internal theft accounts for about 33 percent of shortages, external theft 32 percent, record-keeping errors 31 percent and other reasons 4 percent. **********But other experts come up with sharply different figures. Mr. Wittkin, for instance, estimates that shoplifting and internal theft account for only about 15 percent each of shortages while bookkeeping errors are responsible for about 70 percent. **********Stores Found to Vary Widely **********''I've been in some stores where 100 percent of the employees were found to be stealing,'' said Peter D. Berlin, head of shrinkage control for the Price Waterhouse retail industry services group. ''I've been in other stores where I didn't believe any employee was dishonest.'' **********Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the 670-store discounter based in Bentonville, Ark., expects to cut its shortages to only 1.2 percent this year from 1.5 percent in 1983 and 2.2 percent in 1979. **********David Glass, Wal-Mart's president, attributes much of the decline to an incentive program for employees; they obtain up to $200 each for recommendations that work. Some of their adopted ideas include posting a ''greeter'' at each store's entrance as a sort of quasi-watchman. **********''A lot depends on making the employees aware of the problem,'' Mr. Glass said in an interview.''We tell them that a big part of shrinkage is in sloppy paperwork, such as markdowns that aren't recorded or price changes that do not go into the computer. And we find that people have lots of ideas when they are involved in solving the problem.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/11/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Guatemala's Opposition Criticizes High Official
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/11/world.body_text: **********Guatemalan opposition leaders are calling for the resignation of Interior Minister Gustavo Adolfo Lopez Sandoval, saying he has been unable to halt a recent surge in political violence. **********A communique issued on Thursday by the Guatemalan Christian Democratic Party said ''it is evident that the Interior Minister has shown irresponsibility and negligence in the face of the growing wave of violence that has hit the country.'' **********The communique called for the official to resign, a move it said would help secure guarantees for the coming Constituent Assembly elections. There was no immediate response from the Interior Ministry. **********Church, opposition and human rights groups have complained that political violence in Guatemala has increased since the military Government of Brig. Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores took power in a coup last August.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/11/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Michelob Accounts To Bates and Needham
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/11/busin.body_text: **********Anheuser-Busch, the nation's leading brewer, announced yesterday that it was moving its Michelob and Michelob Light brands out of D'Arcy MacManus Masius in St. Louis and into Ted Bates Advertising, New York, and Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, respectively. **********For Bates it served as an endorsement for its recently fashioned new- business system in which stress is put on solving the prospect's problem, not selling the agency. **********Although Leading National Advertisers, the media measuring company, puts 1983 advertising spending for Michelob at $33.6 million and for Michelob Light at $24.1 million, it is understood that the budget is far more than that. **********Bates told the brewer that the brand's problem was that it was being ''middled,'' meaning that as a superpremium it was being squeezed from above from the imported superpremiums like Heineken and from below from the aggressive premiums like Budweiser, Michelob's sister brew, and Miller High Life. **********Although it still maintains it is the leading superpremium, Beverage Industry reported that the brand had a 4.6 percent share of the beer market in 1982, which dropped to 3.8 percent the following year.  Bates made its contact with Anheuser-Busch through Michael G. McDonald, chairman of McDonald & Little, a Bates subsidiary that had once been agency for a Busch Gardens theme park. Mr. McDonald lost the account but maintained the contacts. **********The Bates team went to St. Louis last April 24 to put on a 40-minute exposition on the beer market and Michelob's problems, and about 20 minutes on the agency. They had with them, according to Donald M. Zuckert, president of Bates, New York, film footage that he described as a ''mood piece'' that covered suggested strategy. **********Whatever it was it could be tested against consumers, and after the Bates team left for New York it was throughly tested, apparently quite a number of times, and, said Mr. Zuckert, ''the results were outstanding.'' **********When Needham heard what Bates was up to, as hear competitors always do, it asked to be in on a pitch. And that's how they ended up with a piece of the action. N.H.& S. has been doing ads for Busch Beer since 1977 and Bud Light since 1982. **********For Bates the assignment fills the beer category that has been vacant since Coors left last year after a four- year stay. **********Anheuser-Busch is apparently not concerned about the fact that the Ted Bates Worldwide subsidiary, William Esty Company, has Genessee beer and its Campbell-Mithun subsidiary has a number of Heileman brands. Nor is it concerned that Ted Bates, New York, serves ITT Continental bakery and it has just purchased Campbell Taggart, a Texas-based bakery.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/12/busin.body_text: **********THURSDAY, JULY 12, 1984 **********The Economy **********Sweeping new protection for the U.S. steel industry was recommended by the International Trade Commission. It voted, 3 to 2, to urge President Reagan to impose stiffer quotas and tariffs for five years on 70 percent of the steel entering this country. Such protection could lead to higher prices for steel and steel products in this country, experts say. (Page A1.) **********The Government said airbags or automatic seat belts would be required on all new cars within five years. The decision, after 15 years of controversy, was welcomed by the auto industry, but criticized by insurance companies and consumer activists. (A1.) **********Markets **********The stock market plunged as ITT shares lost almost a third of their value. Reacting to the company's announcement of a dividend cut and an earnings drop, ITT fell 9 7/8 points, to 21 1/8, sparking a general selloff that pushed the Dow Jones industrial average down 18.33 points, to 1,180.55. Volume expanded to 89.5 million shares. (D1.) Bond prices ended unchanged after a day of volatile trading. (D15.) **********The dollar rose to new heights against major currencies despite intervention by foreign central banks. The West German mark fell to a 10-year low against the U.S. currency, closing at 2.8590 to the dollar. The Canadian dollar fell below 75 U.S. cents for the first time, and the French franc hit a record low of 8.74 francs to the dollar. Gold fell $4 an ounce in New York, to $341. (D16.) Frozen pork bellies fell sharply, while meat and livestock prices also declined in futures trading. (D16.)  The Big Board is rethinking its requirements for listing companies, amid competition from other exchanges and actions by a number of corporations that challenge its guidelines. (D1.) **********Companies **********The future of broadcasting television programs directly from satellites to homes has dimmed, now that two major corporations - Western Union and CBS - have withdrawn from the field. A third company, RCA, wants to cut back its project. (D1.) **********Upjohn announced a 30 to 35 percent price cut on Motrin, its best-selling pain killer and anti-inflammatory drug. Analysts questioned the move, which they saw hurting earnings. (D15.) **********General Electric's profits rose 11.1 percent in the second quarter, to $579 million. The company cited strong consumer appliances and components sales. (D7.) Conrail net soared 84 percent to $179 million, helped by increased rail traffic, cost controls and wage concessions. (D7.) Kaiser Aluminum reversed a year-earlier loss, posting a $32.5 million profit. (D19.) **********Air Florida and three Central American airlines were indicted for fixing fares between 1982 and 1983. Separately, Air Florida flight attendants accepted a 25 percent wage cut.(D5.) **********Consumers Power directors authorized cancellation of the Midland nuclear power plant if no agreement is reached by Friday with opponents of the project. (D4.) **********International **********Saudi Arabia agreed to cut its oil output 100,000 barrels a day to give financially strapped Nigeria bigger sales without changing OPEC's overall production. Prices will stay at present levels, the organization's oil ministers decided. (D1.) **********A small British bond trading firm sued Bear, Stearns in an effort to recover money it lost in a Eurobond trading scheme. Total losses from the scheme could total as much as $8 million. (D14.) **********Today's Columns **********Robots shooting highly pressurized streams of water are trimming and cutting holes in hard plastic slabs for use on Chevrolet pickup trucks. The main advantage is that retooling involves just changing the software program. Technology. (D2.) **********The selling wave that hit ITT's stock yesterday mostly reflects the market's low tolerance for surprises and insistence on high yields. Both are signs of a bear market. Market Place. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/28/busin.body_text: **********City Federal Savings and Loan Association, New Jersey's largest thrift institution, said it was seeking permission to open 54 branches in two dozen states. Under the proposal submitted to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, City Federal seeks to open deposit-gathering branches in existing loan offices, a spokesman, Michael Rust, said. **********The loan offices are run by the savings and loan's subsidiaries, City Mortgage Services and City Consumer Services, which along with City Federal are units of the Cityfed Financial Corporation, a holding company based in Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Rust said that the application to the bank board was the ''first request of its kind'' and that City Federal believes the board has the authority to approve such a request, although it has not done so before.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/02/busin.body_text: **********The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has signed a letter of intent to sell its West Seattle plant to CEM Associates, CEM said. Bethlehem officials in Seattle could not be reached for comment. **********Joe Trethewey, CEM's vice president and general counsel, said he expects the sale to be closed by the end of August. He declined to give the exact price, but said the entire transaction would require about $100 million. Mr. Trethewey said the sale would be a leveraged buyout, in which the plant is put up as collateral for a loan. **********Mr. Trethewey said CEM plans to invest at least $10 million in the plant and to keep 750 to 1,000 workers employed. However, he said mill employees have been asked to accept a reduction in wages and benefits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/busin.body_text: **********Poland has exported more than 23 million metric tons of coal so far this year, which if sustained will make 1984 a record year for coal sales abroad, the official P.A.P. press agency said today. The agency said 14.5 million metric tons had been sold to buyers paying in hard currency. **********Last year Poland exported 35.2 million metric tons of coal, with half going to hard-currency buyers. Poland's record year for coal exports was 1979, when it sold 41.4 million metric tons. One metric ton equals 2,204.62 pounds. This year Poland has relied on coal sales to make up for a weak exporting performance by engineering industries, which in 1983 were a principal earner of the hard currency needed to pay the country's foreign debt of about $28 billion. According to Foreign Trade Ministry statistics, the coal industry had fulfilled 43.7 percent of its annual export target to hard-currency customers by the end of May, whereas engineering industries had reached only 24.1 percent of theirs.$

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/busin.main_headline: ST. REGIS SAYS MURDOCH LINES UP FUNDS FOR BID
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/busin.print_headline: ST. REGIS SAYS MURDOCH LINES UP FUNDS FOR BID
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/10/busin.body_text: **********The St. Regis Corporation said yesterday that while Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born publisher, was saying publicly that he had ''no present intention'' of trying to take over the company, he was secretly negotiating with a group of banks, including the Midland Bank of London, to raise $750 million for a possible acquisition of the big forest products company. **********The charge came in an affidavit filed by the Manhattan-based company in a 31-page suit in United States District Court in Dallas against Mr. Murdoch and three of his companies. The suit seeks to block any takeover, or further purchases of St. Regis stock, by Mr. Murdoch. **********In anticipation that Mr. Murdoch would buy more stock, St. Regis shares jumped $2.125 yesterday, to $39.875, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Through a number of his own companies, the publisher already has 1.8 million shares, or 5.6 percent of the company. **********A switchboard operator at Mr. Murdoch's office in The New York Post said late yesterday that the publisher had left for the day and that he could not be reached. **********Phone Call Cited **********The affidavit, signed by Gert E. Schumann, senior vice president of internatmional operations for St. Regis, said Mr. Schumann got a phone call on July 4 from ''a European bank officer of unquestionable reliability.'' He said the banker told him he had learned that ''a consortium of banks was putting together a $750 million credit facility to be raised for the possible takeover of St. Regis.'' **********Mr. Schumann said the banker phoned him two days later to say he had attended a meeting of several banks in London that same day and that Midland was ''a coordinator of the meeting'' and that ''a bank from Boston was also involved.'' **********The main reason for the meeting, Mr. Schumann said, was to hear a presentation from Mr. Murdoch. **********''Up to $55 Per Share' **********As related by Mr. Schumann, Mr. Murdoch told the bankers that he had ''not yet made a final decision'' about his plans for St. Regis but ''would like to be in a position to proceed promptly'' to buy enough stock to give him 50.1 percent of St. Regis ''at a price of up to $55 per share.'' **********Mr. Schumann said Mr. Murdoch had told the group he needed about $950 million for such an acquisition, and that $750 million of the total would be in bank credits. **********The deadline for them to commit themselves to take part in the bank loan, Mr. Murdoch was quoted as having said, would be tonight. He was quoted as stressing the need to move quickly because of ''his belief that St. Regis was building its defenses.'' **********The affidavit said ''Mr. Murdoch mentioned that he had retained Allen & Company,'' the Wall Street house, ''as his investment advisers.'' **********Mr. Schumann said the publisher had told bankers that once he acquired 50.1 percent, he might seek the rest. **********He said Mr. Murdoch had told the bankers that St. Regis was worth between $3.6 billion and $3.8 billion and that its timberlands were worth $1.7 billion. **********He said Mr. Murdoch forecast that St. Regis would resist, and that it might find a friendly company to buy it, possibly at more than he would pay. In that event, Mr. Schumann related, Mr. Murdoch said he would not get into a bidding contest but would take a profit on his investment. **********Mr. Murdoch was further quoted as saying that he would be willing to dispose of interests he holds in an Australian airline and the Reuters news service, if necessary, to raise additional funds. **********'True Intentions' **********St. Regis, contending in its suit that Mr. Murdoch did not disclose his ''true intentions'' to stockholders, said it would ask Mr. Murdoch to testify in Dallas on July 16. It said it would subpoena Stanley S. Shuman of Allen & Company, a personal adviser to Mr. Murdoch, to produce documents dealing with the transaction. St. Regis sued Mr. Murdoch in Texas because the company owns the Angelina Casualty Company, a Delaware company operating largely in Texas. **********The Florida Insurance Commission earlier obtained a Federal court order in Tallahassee preventing Mr. Murdoch from buying more stock. He is contesting the order. **********Before deciding to fight Mr. Murdoch, St. Regis gave Sir James Goldsmith, the British industrialist, some $50 million in profits by buying back his 8.6 percent St. Regis stake. The company then made a deal to sell the Georgia-Pacific Corporation a plant it wanted in exchange for Georgia-Pacific buying another block of St. Regis held by the Loews Corporation, giving Loews a $38 million profit.  The Bass brothers of Texas also have 6 percent of St. Regis, but that is regarded as an arbitrage investment of no danger to the company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/01/busin.body_text: **********WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1984 **********The Economy **********A dispute over reorganizing bank regulation was resolved with an agreement initialed by Paul A. Volcker and senior Administration financial officials. The plan, subject to Congressional approval, would establish a Federal Banking Agency to supplant the Comptroller of the Currency and assume some of the authority over banks now held by Mr. Volcker's Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Volcker had resisted such a reduction in Fed control. (Page D1.) **********The index of leading indicators rose six-tenths of 1 percent in December. Much of the rise in the index, which usually foreshadows the economy's performance, was attributed to expanded borrowing by business and consumers. The gain encouraged economists who were concerned about November's decline. (D1.) **********Sales of new homes jumped 28.5 percent in December from November, raising sales for all of 1983 by 53 percent from the low level of 1982. The rise for the year was the sharpest since the Commerce Department began keeping statistics in 1963. Opinion was mixed about whether the gain could be sustained. (D3.) Prices farmers get for raw products climbed 2.1 percent in January from December and were 12 percent higher than the January 1983 figure. Poultry, beef, eggs, tomatoes and hogs led the gain. (D3.) **********A study sponsored by the auto industry in the U.S. and Japan says the success of Japanese companies owes more to gains in technology and human relations than to Government aid. (D15.) **********Companies **********U.S. Steel reported a fourth-quarter loss of $983 million, the fourth-largest in corporate history. The loss stemmed largely from a write-off for plant closings announced in December but was worsened by weak steel and oil results. (D1.) **********Xerox's net rose 35.2 percent on a 2.3 percent sales gain in the quarter. But with per-share earnings flat and the company's 1984 forecast cautious, the stock slid $5 a share, to $44. (D4.) **********Houston Natural Gas counterbid for Coastal.  The $924 million offer was intended to create a cross-ownership that would force Coastal to withdraw its unwelcome bid for Houston Natural. (D4.) **********I.B.M. filed copyright-infringement cases against two companies that market computers similar to the PC. Both agreed to stop marketing the computers. (D4.) **********Martin Marietta won a $684 million contract to supervise a $10 billion to $20 billion modernization of the nation's air traffic control program. Martin Marietta and its six subcontractors beat a bidding group led by Boeing and Lockheed. (D4.) **********National Semiconductor expects to be charged in a Federal investigation of its testing of computer chips sold to the military, a company official said. The charges may involve fraud. (D2.) **********Tosco's shareholders approved a debt restructuring that will give a group of banks 43.7 percent ownership of the troubled oil refiner. Tosco also reported a big quarterly loss. (D4.) **********Markets **********Stock prices dipped at the end of a record trading month.  The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.94, to 1,220.58. Volume expanded to 113.5 million shares, from 103.1 million the day before, bringing the total for January to a record 2.22 billion. (D6.) **********Interest rates were little changed , with positive economic news appearing to have minimal impact on the credit markets. Analysts and dealers are nervous about the terms of an expected $16 billion to $17 billion Treasury refunding. (D15.) **********The dollar dropped in U.S. trading after rising in Europe.  Gold advanced $3.25 an ounce in New York, to $373. (D16.) Cotton futures prices soared when analysts forecast tight supplies. (D16.) **********Today's Columns **********Suddenly, President Reagan has decided that deficits matter, and he is stressing that closing them is the most important unfinished business of his Administration. A look at his Administration's role in enlarging the budget gap, however, suggests how elusive this new goal may be. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Diasonics Inc., ADAC Laboratories and other makers of diagnostic equipment are suffering from a slump in demand for their add-on digital image processors. Losses have resulted, and the companies' shares are far below their peaks. Market Place. (D6.)

WHAT'S NEW IN OFFICE POLITICS?;
PICKING THE RIGHT FACTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/14/busin.print_headline:
WHAT'S NEW IN OFFICE POLITICS?;
PICKING THE RIGHT FACTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/14/busin.body_text: **********-win situation: You get along well with your boss, and he has every reason to believe you'll follow his orders. **********His boss thinks the orders are idiotic, and makes it clear that, to get ahead in the company, you should ignore them. **********It's not easy to remain neutral in that sort of situation, nor is it always the wisest course. However, it is the route that Janice Brown, now a New York freelance textile stylist but once an employee for a large manufacturer, chose when she was hauled on the carpet by an executive who, she quickly discerned, represented a large faction that was out for her boss's hide. **********''I was told they didn't support him, they felt his direction was not correct,'' she said. ''My choices were to defend my boss, whom I personally liked, or to turn on him with 'inside' evidence of his unsuitability. I could only lose. I would alienate one or the other side.'' **********Miss Brown felt like a conspiracy suspect who had been asked to turn state's evidence. When she got home that night, she wrote a two-page letter to the executive who had put her into this uncomfortable position. In that letter, she distinguished clearly between her boss's authority and her own, delineated those areas in which she felt unable to comment on his abilities, and, as she decribes it, made it quite clear without saying it in so many words that she had absolutely no intention of either fingering her boss or protecting him. **********Miss Brown removed herself from the line of fire by choosing a middle ground between the two factions. Indeed, as she remembers it, ''Once it was in writing that I did not intend to either protect my boss or attack him, I never heard another word on it.'' **********The ploy saved her from unpleasantness in the short run, but it probably scuttled her chances for getting ahead in the job. A few months later, her boss was fired and she was passed over for his job. It was at that point that she realized that ''the political balances could shift at any time and I'd be back at square one.'' **********Distasteful as choosing sides might be, it often is the only way to stay on the corporate promotional track. Middle-management loners are nearly always doomed to stagnation or failure. **********Picking the right faction with which to align oneself can be a truly crucial career decision. Many executives who have found themselves in this position say that the best way to select the group is to focus on risks rather than opportunities. In other words, rather than pick the group that might give you what you want - a promotion, say - pick instead the group that could help you avoid what you dread - a demotion or a transfer. **********Most veterans of corporate political wars say that choosing the faction that looks as though it will win is a short-sighted maneuver. It is unlikely that anyone who goes where the wind blows will be accepted as a true insider in the group he or she has suddenly chosen. By the same token, a reputation for turning against friends the minute the going gets tough is unlikely to help the cause of a budding executive who wants to get ahead in the corporation. **********It makes more sense, they say, to support peers and higher-ups whose policies seem best. Even if they lose out in the current battle, they might always wind up at a different company in a better job - and take their loyal supporters along. **********POLITICAL DO'S AND DON'TS DO **********Look at the downside of linking up with powerful factions **********Let friendsd offer advice about political problems **********Speak up to your boss if it means keeping peer respect **********Discern what your boss wants in return for a raise or promotion **********Establish your walkaway point-and stick to it **********Admit your mistakes before the boss discovers them himself DON'T **********Assume your boss always has your best interests at herat **********Get involved in a showdown you are pretty sure to lose **********Try to imitate the social graces of a smooth rival **********Accept blindly anyone's claim that he is the boss's friend **********Talk about things you are not officially supposed to know **********Respond in kind to smear campaigns-they can backfire **********Be a corporate loner.  You do need friends to get ahead **********Robert Bell is the author of ''You Can Win at Office Politics.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/26/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in slightly busier trading. The biggest losers were the semiconductor issues. **********Mobil Corporation moved higher on merger rumors. It was the most actively traded stock. **********The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 5.41 points, to 1,211.02. In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 946 to 612. **********The two other leading market indicators also fell. The exchange's composite index was down 0.47, to 95.93, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 0.89, to 166.31. **********Mobil Rises by 1 3/8 **********Mobil finished ahead 1 3/8 points, to 31, on unconfirmed rumors that T. Boone Pickens, chairman of Mesa Petroleum, and Carl H. Lindner, head of Penn Central, planned a bid for Mobil. Mobil, the largest of a handful of oil producers believed to be vulnerable to a takeover attempt, said it had no indication that anyone was accumulating its stock other than for investment reasons. Mesa had no comment on the rumor and Mr. Lindner could not be reached. **********The surge in Mobil's stock occurred despite the company's announcement yesterday that its third-quarter net fell to 59 cents a share, from 99 cents the year before. **********Turnover on the Big Board expanded to 92.8 million shares yesterday from 91.6 million the day before. **********Jon Groveman, head of equity trading at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said that the inability of equities to respond to the recent bond market rally ''discouraged many traders today.'' **********The semiconductor issues were under pressure on reports that several brokerage firms had lowered their estimates on the stocks. **********Texas Instruments tumbled 4 7/8, to 126 5/8; Advanced Micro Devices 2 3/8, to 33 1/8; Motorola 1 1/8, to 35 1/4, and National Semiconductor 1 1/4, to 11 7/8. Teledyne, another technology issue and the highest-priced stock on the exchange, dropped 5, to 273; Data General was off 2 3/4, to 52 3/8, and Hewlett-Packard 1 7/8, to 37 3/8. **********Slowing Economy Cited **********Roy Blumberg, director of portfolio strategy at Advest Inc., said that today's market weakness resulted from concern over the slowing economy plus the failure of institutional investors ''to continue their recent stampede into stocks and the reluctance of the public to participate in the market.'' **********Alleghany Corporation slipped 1 7/8, to 83 1/8, following the news Wednesday that it had sweetened its bid for Conrail. **********Textron, which climbed 5 points on Wednesday after receiving a buyout offer from Chicago Pacific for $43 a share, or a total of $1.6 billion, was off 2, to 39. The offer had been termed ''completely unacceptable'' by Robert P. Straetz, chairman of Textron. **********Federal Express lost 2, to 38 1/2, following the news that Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette had reduced its estimates for the company's fiscal year 1985 earnings to $2.30 a share from $2.70. **********Phibro-Salomon lost 1/2, to 31 1/4, in active trading. After the close Wednesday, the large commodities and securities trading firm announced a 1.7 percent gain in its third quarter. **********General Mills, having forecast a 15 percent decline in profits for its fiscal quarter ending Nov. 25, dropped 3 3/8, to 54 1/2. **********Two other food companies were actively traded and fell slightly. General Foods dipped 1/4, to 57 1/4, while Nabisco Brands eased 1/4, to 52. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index was off 0.01, to 210.40. One exception was Canandaigua Wine Company, which soared 5 1/4, to 35 1/2, after its board gave preliminary approval for sale of the company in a leveraged buyout at $39 a share to a group of investors. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index fell 1.83, to 249.00.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/25/busin.body_text: **********The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, reported better- than-expected earnings yesterday, with net income rising 25.6 percent in the second quarter. The increase came largely from a strong performance in its foreign exploration and development operations. **********But earnings from refining and marketing operations were weak, following an industrywide pattern. Analysts said this pattern was likely to continue through the third quarter. **********Ashland Oil Inc. yesterday reported a 2.4 percent drop in quarterly earnings. It cited a poor market for refined products. The Amerada Hess Corporation said its earnings fell 33.4 percent, while at the Pennzoil Company earnings jumped 76.1 percent. **********ExxonExxon announced second-quarter net income of $1.35 billion, up from $1.08 billion in the 1983 quarter. Earnings per share rose more sharply, to $1.63 from $1.25, because Exxon bought up shares, reducing the number outstanding. Revenues totaled $24.31 billion, up 6.2 percent from $22.88 billion the year earlier. **********C. C. Garvin Jr., the company's chairman, said: ''Second-quarter earnings reflected higher levels of economic activity than in the comparable 1983 period. Increased crude production, mostly in foreign operations, accounted for a significant portion of the increase.'' **********He added: ''Worldwide refining and marketing earnings of $82 million declined, despite cost savings realized from rationalization steps and a 2 percent increase in petroleum product sales. As the quarter progressed, the markets became increasingly more competitive due to surplus supplies and spare capacity. These marketplace pressures depressed product selling prices and reduced margins.'' **********Paul Mlotok, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, said Exxon's earnings were ''about a dime better than we expected'' on a per-share basis. ''It was a very good quarter,'' he said. **********Mr. Mlotok said the price of crude oil, usually sold on long-term contracts, was steadier in the first half than the prices of refined products. Although there was an oversupply of both because of overproduction worldwide, margins for refined products were squeezed tighter. ''This situation will probably get worse in the third quarter,'' he said. **********Exxon benefited from its share buyback, according to Sanford Margoshes, an analyst at Shearson Lehman/ American Express. In the first half of the year, Exxon paid $1.26 billion for 31.46 million shares. **********''They got a real bonus from this program,'' Mr. Margoshes said. ''It improved the stock's performance and could keep it a little ahead of its group.'' **********AshlandAshland Oil, primarily a refiner and marketer of oil products, said net income in the third fiscal quarter, ended June 30, slipped to $36.2 million, or $1.01 a share, from $37.1 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier. The latest results included an extraordinary gain of $15.6 million, compared with a $6.1 million gain the year before. **********John R. Hall, Ashland's chairman, said, ''The quarter's decline in net income was principally due to a decline in operating income from petroleum operations.'' **********Amerada Hess **********Amerada Hess, also principally a refiner and marketer, reported a 33.4 percent drop in net to $45.4 million, or 54 cents a share, from $68.2 million, or 81 cents a share, the year earlier. The latest results were after a special $16 million net gain. **********Revenues rose 5.8 percent, to $2.01 billion, from $1.90 billion. **********PennzoilPennzoil, involved in oil, natural gas and minerals, said second-quarter net income increased to $51.6 million, or 91 cents a share, from $29.3 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues climbed 7.1 percent, to $607.8 million, from $567.4 million. **********''Those are super numbers,'' said Marc D. Cohen, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody. ''I'm sure they 're even ahead of what the company expected.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today broke a long truce with the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, by expressing worry that the central bank chief might be pursuing a policy leading to higher interest rates. At a Congressional hearing, Mr. Regan, a frequent critic of Mr. Volcker in the past, voiced concern about the Fed's move on Friday to increase the interest it charges member banks for loans. **********''I think the economy can stand it, but I'm concerned,'' Mr. Regan said after the hearing. **********The Fed raised the discount rate from 8 1/2, to 9 percent, in the first increase in that key rate since May 1981. Often the discount rate signals to financial markets that the Fed is embarking on a tighter policy. **********WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) - Mr. Volcker told Congress today that failure to quickly cut Federal budget deficits would risk new, economy- damaging rate increases. **********He also indicated that the Federal Reserve remains committed to keeping inflation under control - a policy some members of Congress say could lead the board to restrain American monetary growth too tightly and cause a new recession.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/01/world.main_headline: RELIEF SHIPS FROM NORTH DOCK IN INCHON
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/01/world.print_headline: RELIEF SHIPS FROM NORTH DOCK IN INCHON
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/01/world.body_text: **********Four North Korean cargo ships loaded with relief supplies sailed into this port today, an unprecedented event that went unnoticed by virtually everyone who lives here. **********Never before had a North Korean vessel entered a South Korean harbor for peaceful purposes. The four ships pulled up alongside a large cargo terminal in darkness early this morning, and then allowed dozens of South Korean laborers on board to unload 25,000 tons of cement intended to aid flood victims in nearby Seoul. **********It was a landmark contact between countries that have been implacable enemies, maintaining a steady war of propaganda and mutual denunciation since their three-year shooting war ended in 1953. **********Yet for all the novelty, Inchon residents seemed to pay no attention to the North Koreans, whose ships carried Red Cross banners and not the national flag. The unloading dock lay well behind closed gates, protected by a few guards. Outside, no one gathered on the sidewalks or streets to peer across the terminal for a possible glimpse of the visitors.   Port Was 1950 Invasion Site **********From the decks of their ships, 190 North Korean seamen, officials and journalists got only the most meager view of Inchon, where United States forces landed in September 1950 and helped repel northern invaders who had overrun the South. **********On the dock, where they discussed details of the transfer of the supplies, South Korean Red Cross officials invited their counterparts from the North to rest at a downtown hotel. But the North Koreans turned down the proposal and went back to their main ship, the Zang San. **********South Korean customs officers stood at the heads of gangways to keep unwanted visitors from boarding and, presumably, to prevent unauthorized people from leaving. There was little conversation between the northern sailors and southern workers, who all day long hoisted sacks of cement by crane onto dockside trucks. **********Four other ships, carrying 35,000 tons of cement, arrived this afternoon at the port of Pukpyong on South Korea's eastern coast. Yet another four are due in Inchon on Monday. Meanwhile, more than 650 North Korean trucks resumed shipments of rice, medicine and cloth that began Saturday through Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone at the border.   Gifts Sent by the South **********They returned home with truckloads of gifts from the South, 800 suitcases that South Korean officials said each contained $500 worth of transistor radios, wristwatches, cosmetics, clothing and household items. **********The northern aid had been volunteered for victims of severe floods that killed 190 people and left 200,000 homeless in Seoul early this month. It was a surprising offer and - just as surprisingly - South Korea accepted, saying it was doing so to reduce tensions on the divided peninsula, not because it needed help. **********The exchanges over the weekend produced hopeful speculation that they might lead to more substantive discsssions, but South Korean officials and foreign diplomats warned against expectations of sudden political breakthroughs. Although the aid offer was one of several conciliatory gestures by North Korea this year, the South called it a propaganda device intended to soften the North's hard-line image.   Fifth Ship Reported Aground **********They went along, officials in Seoul said, because they wanted to show their interest in improved relations. **********The four ships that arrived today had departed from the North Korean ports of Nampo and Haeju. A fifth ship had set out, too, but it reportedly hit a reef and ran aground soon after starting its southward journey. **********Whatever ultimate significance the events of today may have, they served immediate publicity purposes for each side. Photographers and television cameramen from both Koreas stood for a long time on the ship and the dock, training their lenses on one another. **********All the North Koreans wore lapel pins on their jackets or uniform blouses that bore pictures of their country's leader, Kim Il Sung.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/04/busin.body_text: **********A Federal bankruptcy judge threatened to appoint a receiver for Air Florida unless it came up with a ''realistic plan to get back into the air'' by Aug. 27. **********Judge Sidney Weaver said he had been disappointed in the failure of the airline to devise a workable plan to resume operations since it filed for protection from creditors on July 3. **********The appointment of a receiver was opposed by several of the airline's larger unsecured creditors, including Interfirst Bank of Dallas, the largest unsecured creditor, and the General Electric Credit Corporation. **********Earlier today, Air Florida's chairman, Jon R. K. Tinkle, told Judge Weaver that the airline and Northeastern International Airlines of Fort Lauderdale were working on a merger plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/25/busin.body_text: **********A fugitive Hong Kong businessman who pleaded guilty in Seattle and Los Angeles to smuggling high-technology goods out of the United States has been indicted here on charges of illegally exporting computer components. **********Man Chung Tong, 37 years old, was charged by a Federal grand jury Tuesday with three felony counts of conspiracy, making false statements and illegally exporting the components to Hong Kong. **********A second Hong Kong businessman, Kenneth Wong, was also named in the indictment. If convicted, each man would face up to 20 years in prison and $70,000 in fines. Neither is now in the United States, according to Eric Fisher, an Assistant United States Attorney. **********''Tong was a major player in this whole illegal transfer of high technology out of the Silicon Valley to either the Soviet bloc or the Far East,'' Mr. Fisher said. **********In plea-bargaining agreements earlier this year in Seattle and Los Angeles, Mr. Tong pleaded guilty to smuggling high-tech goods out of the country. Bench warrants for his arrest were issued in both cities in August after he failed to appear for sentencing. Mr. Fisher said Mr. Tong probably would be arrested only if he returned to the United States, adding, ''I don't know of anybody who's been extradited for an Export Act violation.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/29/world.body_text: **********Thousands of mourners reportedly crowded the airport at Conakry, the capital of Guinea, today as the body of President Ahmed Sekou Toure arrived from the United States, where he died on Monday. **********Other thousands lined the route taken by the cortege during a two-hour procession from the airport to the People's Palace, diplomats in Conakry said. **********The body of Mr. Toure, the West African country's only President since it achieved independence from France in 1958, is to lie in state at the People's Palace until the funeral on Friday. **********In Washington, the White House announced that Vice President Bush would head the United States delegation to the funeral. After a service at the main mosque in Conakry, the Guinean leader is to be buried in the National Heroes Mausoleum.   City Reported Subdued **********Reports from Conakry said Government offices, businesses and stores were closed during the day, traffic was light and the city seemed exceptionally subdued. **********Many Guineans are too young to recall a time when President Toure, a charismatic and authoritarian radical, was not the country's leader.  Waves of Guineans emigrated during his rule, and thousands of his opponents were believed to have been jailed or killed. **********Mr. Toure, who was 62 years old, died on Monday during heart surgery at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, where he was rushed after becoming ill on a visit to Saudi Arabia. **********From the Conakry airport, the President's coffin was transported to the People's Palace on a gun carriage, with six armored cars carrying an honor guard leading the way. Joining in the procession were leaders of the nation's only legal political organization, the Democratic Party of Guinea, Government officials, members of the armed forces and diplomats.   'The Head of State' **********The mourners were led by Acting President Louis Lansana Beavogui, 61, who has been Prime Minister since the post was created by Mr. Toure in 1972. Dr. Beavogui, who studied medicine in Senegal before entering politics, is also deputy secretary general of the Democratic Party. **********A close friend as well as a follower of Mr. Toure, Dr. Beavogui was mentioned in some reports from Conakry on Tuesday as ''the head of state.'' But Western diplomats expressed doubt that he would accede to the presidency, noting that he had been in poor health. **********According to Guinea's Constitution, on the death of the President the new head of state is to be chosen through elections within 45 days. **********A statement issued by the Democratic Party's national political bureau said the nation of more than five million was in deep mourning for Mr. Toure, ''the immortal fighter of just causes, the valiant and glorious son of Africa in progress.'' Condolences came in from around the continent. The President of Senegal, Abdou Diouf, called Mr. Toure his ''brother and friend,'' and said, ''History will remember him as a courageous and indomitable fighter and an intransigent defender of the dignity, independence and the freedom of Africa.'' **********The President of the Ivory Coast, Felix Houphou"et-Boigny, who was often reviled by Mr. Toure, said the Guinean leader ''would always inspire those who believe in the dignity and the grandeur of Africa.'' **********In Morocco, King Hassan II called Mr. Toure's death a ''great loss for both the African and Islamic peoples.'' **********In Lagos, Nigeria, the National Council of State observed a minute's silence. The Guinean leader had been one of a handful of African heads of state to visit Nigeria since the military coup there three months ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/04/busin.body_text: **********The Treasury today released its proposed schedule for writing off plant and equipment, and Secretary Donald T. Regan predicted it would pleasantly surprise business because of what he portrayed as its generosity. **********Under the present depreciation system, enacted in 1981, assets are placed in one of five categories and written off in from three to 15 years, but under the new system - if Congress adopts it - there would be seven categories and the depreciation period would range from five to 63 years. **********However, the new system would allow for the first time the indexing of assets according to inflation. The Treasury contended this allowancewould provide a more generous depreciation for many properties than did the 1981 system. **********By 1990, according to the Treasury, the new depreciation schedule would yield an additional $80 billion a year in revenues at the lower corporate tax rate the Treasury has proposed. It would also, the Treasury contends, remove biases in the tax code toward heavy, capital-intensive industries, the main benefactors from the 1981 business tax cuts. **********The depreciation proposal was part of the second volume of the Treasury's tax simplification plan, the first volume of which was published last week. The second volume, out today, also provided details on the proposed repeal of various tax breaks for banks, timber, coal, insurance, farming and oil companies. **********The Treasury tax plan has elicited a lot of interest in the White House and in Congress, but budget cuts and the deficit are regarded as a more important priority. Consequently, Congress may not write a tax bill until the 1985 session is some months old. **********Secretary Regan, speaking at the National Press Club, asked businessmen to compare the new depreciation plan with the old system, called the accelerated cost recovery system, or A.C.R.S., and to take account of the Treasury's companion proposals to cut the corporate tax rate to 33 percent from 46 and allow a partial deduction for dividends. **********'Equal to or Better' **********''Volume Two will show that our plan is equal to or better than A.C.R.S. that was enacted in 1981, period,'' the Treasury Secretary said, adding that ''I think people are going to be pleasantly surprised.'' **********But John K. Meagher, a lobbyist for the LTV Corporation who leads a multicompany lobbying group, took a dim view. He also challenged a basic tenet of the Treasury plan, that tax rates should be more nearly equal. **********''The basic problem with the Treasury proposal is that it doesn't account for the fact that U.S. companies have to compete with foreign companies who have greater incentives and thus less costs,'' said Mr. Meagher, who is chairman of the Basic Industries Coalition, a group of heavy industry companies and trade associations. **********As to the Treasury's goal of narrowing variations in tax rates among American companies by eliminating preferences such as A.C.R.S., he said: ''There is little or no relevancy in saying a McDonald's franchise should pay the same tax rate as a steel company.'' **********New System Applauded **********Some businessmen said they needed more time to study today's report, while some tax experts who support the Treasury proposal applauded the new depreciation system. **********Joseph J. Minarik, a research associate with the Urban Institute and a former tax analyst with the Congressional Budget Office, said the new depreciation system was one of the ''salient'' points in the whole proposal and that the current system ''is quite generous given the current state of low inflation.'' **********Mr. Minarik added, though, that the new depreciation schedules could be ''more complicated and troublesome for small-business men'' and that the Treasury proposal, on the whole, might not raise so much business revenue as intended if inflation exceeded the Treasury's assumption. **********According to the Treasury, the new depreciation rules, called the Real Cost Recovery System, would allow cost recovery of the ''real,'' or inflation-adjusted, cost of business assests, rather than only the original, or nominal, cost. For years, business complained that inflation made recovery of original cost inadequate to finance replacement of old equipment. That was one of the arguments for the acceleration enacted in 1981 at the behest of capital-intensive industries. **********The Treasury plan would also revise the assignment of property among recovery classes. **********Most of that reassignment would involve business equipment. For example, assets now assigned to a single category of business equipment and depreciated over five years would be assigned to one of four classes and written off over five to 25 years. **********Rates Vary Year to Year **********Under the 1981 system, depreciation rates vary from year to year of an asset's write-off period, with most of the recovery occurring in the early years. Under the new proposal, recovery would be spread uniformly over the allowed write-off period. **********In summarizing its rationale for its new cost recovery system, the Treasury maintained that the lowering of the overall corporate tax rate, the introduction of indexing and the allowance of a 50 percent credit for dividends would remove differences in effective tax rates among all forms of investment, regardless of inflation. **********For ''many types of property'' the proposal ''is more generous than the alternative approaches, including current law,'' the Treasury said. **********Other Details in Report **********Today's report includes details on these other business tax proposals: **********- Instituting year-to-year uniformity in the accounting rules for long- term contracts so that expenses and income are more evenly matched. Currently, according to the Treasury, there is a ''mismatching of receipts and expenses'' in a number or industries, such as timber, farming, coal, oil and vineyards. The new rules would be phased in over periods ranging up to 10 years. **********- Repealing the special treatment of royalty income from coal, iron ore and timber, which can now be treated as a long-term capital gain. The Treasury would end this ''preferential treatment'' following a three- year transition period for assets held prior to Jan. 1, 1986. **********- Repealing the ability of banks to deduct interest costs incurred in buying or carrying tax-exempt bonds. Starting in 1983, banks and other financial institutions were denied 20 percent of these dedcutions. The Treasury would allow the 20 percent disallowance to apply to obligations acquired between 1983 and 1985 and repeal all deductions for obligations acquired thereafter. **********The Treasury would repeal by 1986 a series of preferences for energy and natural resources, including energy tax credits, percentage depletion, expensing of intangible drilling costs and hard mineral exploration and development costs, and deductions for mining and solid waste reclamation. Most of these preferences, according to the report, are used to an unfair extent by upper-income taxpayers or are not economically necessary.
