https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/09/busin.main_headline: ARGENTINA UNSURE HOW MUCH DEBT IS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/09/busin.print_headline: ARGENTINA UNSURE HOW MUCH DEBT IS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/09/busin.body_text: **********After four months in office and an international flurry over a near default in its interest payments abroad, Argentina's new Government is still unable to decide the exact size and breakdown of its foreign debt or how much it is willing to recognize. **********Although the country is listed as having the third-largest foreign debt in the developing world, after Brazil and Mexico, Argentina's previous military regime apparently kept no central records and left behind what Government officials and financial experts have described as an ''administrative nightmare.'' **********''We still don't know the debt - there were no registers in the central bank,'' said Bernardo Grinspun, Argentina's Economics Minister, before leaving Friday night for the United States for crucial debt talks with the International Monetary Fund. **********''With most loans,'' Mr. Grinspun said, ''we could not identify the purpose, the amount, the interest or the grace period.'' **********In Argentina's central bank and justice ministry, more than a hundred of ficials are still searching through stacks of papers piled six feet high on marble floors. Argentina owed $6.4 billion abroad when the military came to power in a 1976 coup and an estimated $45 billion when it stepped down after eight years of rule. **********''It is not clear whether we're dealing with the results of massive looting or chaos or both,'' said Judge Miguel del Castillo, who presides over a court investigation involving as many as 1,500 cases. **********The results of several months' polling of creditors could be ready within one week, said Elias Salama, who is in charge of the debt investigation at the central bank. A full accounting, he added, is not expected until May. **********Since the elected Government of President Raul Alfonsin took over in December, it has asked for a six- month suspenion of Argentina's foreign debt payments, and it has bargained hard and played for time to gain better repayment terms. **********Bankers' View of the Morass **********Foreign bankers here have recognized that the Government needed breathing space not only because of a lack of funds but also to sort out its books. **********''We ourselves and the new Government underestimated the mess here,'' said the vice president of a large United States bank who asked not to be named. The banks were drawn ever deeper into the Argentine morass, he said, partly because ''we were always reading information more than 12 months old and inaccurate.'' **********Officials said the maze included the debts of Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales, the state-owned oil company and the nation's largest debtor, as well as the conglomerate of military industries that employ 40,000 people and have been managed by the military for the last 40 years. **********''We believe the military ran up some debts which may not exist or never entered the country,'' said one financial expert involved in the debt puzzle. ''They had no traditional accounting principles and no external auditing.'' He declined to give details ''before completion of our report.'' **********He said the latest military junta had appointed a commission to investigate the foreign debts in 1982, ''but it did not produce anything.'' **********As the Government examines official wrongdoing - it has already arraigned a former Economics Minister, Jose Martinez de Hoz, and a former President, Gen. Jorge Videla, on charges of mismanagement - it apparently also hopes to recover part of the vast sums that left the country through speculation against the peso. **********Argentines have long played off their unstable currency against the United States dollar, but never as extensively as over the last five years. Economics Minister Grinspun has said that $10.7 billion fled the country between 1980 and 1982 because of loose foreign-exchange regulations. **********Mr. Grinspun believes that the Government need not recognize about $3 billion of Argentina's private foreign    Argentina's Foreign Minister, Dante Caputo, visits New York for wide-ranging talks. Page A3.    debt since this capital involved so- called ''back-to-back'' loans. These dollar loans were obtained by Argentine individuals and companies abroad entirely for the purpose of speculation and were already guaranteed by the collateral of dollar deposits maintained by the borrowers in the creditor banks. **********Exploiting Currency Conversion **********''The devaluation was not keeping up with inflation or interest rates,'' said one American banker, ''so people borrowed money and invested it here, and when it was converted back into dollars you might have 50 percent profit. Through the Government foreign-exchange insurance, people could get dollars at a subsidized rate and pay off their loans.'' **********Several foreign bankers said they knew about the arrangement, and they said many Argentines had made fortunes through this and various other schemes. **********The back-to-back loans ''were perhaps unethical but not illegal,'' said a Canadian banker. ''It was a great way for the banks to lend money and make an easy buck because, with the collateral, there was no risk involved.'' In Argentina the scheme was known as ''la bicicleta'' - the bicycle. ''The idea was that you kept pumping your dollars round and round,'' the Canadian financier said. **********Mr. Grinspun said the nation's central bank would not sell dollars to pay off any debts guaranteed by collateral abroad. **********Paying Debts That 'Really Exist' **********''We will only pay legitimate foreign debt,'' he said, ''no debts that do not really exist.'' **********Of Argentina's total foreign debt, close to one-third, or $14.5 billion, is believed to be in private hands. **********While Government investigators said they were trying to trace the speculative schemes, foreign bankers said they believed it would be very difficult without full disclosure of the accounts held abroad. Many of the back-to-back loans, foreign bankers said, were arranged through banks in the United States, Uruguay, Panama and Switzerland. **********Financial experts said they believed the Government investigation was not only an economic one but also a political and moral exercise. **********In his office in the turn-of-the-century Palace of Justice, Judge del Castillo appeared to agree. ''We must investigate because all Argentines have to understand how the debt came about,'' he said. ''How else can the Government justify the austerity that will come? And the investigation is necessary so these things may not happen again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/30/busin.body_text: **********British Airways said today that it would begin flying its supersonic Concorde passenger jets from London to Miami and back three times a week starting March 27. The flights, with a stopover in Washington, will trim the total flight time from London to six hours and 35 minutes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/27/busin.body_text: **********For the past five years, the depressed farm equipment industry has been hoping for an upturn. But this year's high interest rates, drop in exports and weak grain prices have aggravated many farmers' cash-flow problems and have kept equipment orders extremely low. **********Dealers, company officials and Wall Street analysts say one or two companies may go bankrupt or abandon production of farm equipment in favor of their other operations. **********The industry - which employs 100,000 people, only half as many as in 1979 - remains one of the few in the nation that is losing money almost two years after the economic recovery began. ''Everyone is trying to keep their head above water,'' said Paul Whelan, an analyst with Pershing & Company. **********Last week Deere & Company, the world's largest maker of farm equipment, reported a loss in its basic business. The previous week the International Harvester Company, which has restructured its debt to help stave off bankruptcy, announced another loss. **********The other leading manufacturers - the Allis-Chalmers Corporation, Massey-Ferguson Ltd. and Tenneco's J. I. Case division - are either losing money or just breaking even. **********According to the Farm and Industrial Equipment Institute, a trade association, sales of grain combines so far this year are down 25 percent from a year earlier. Last year 12,755 combines were sold. **********''Unless demand picks up in the fall, it looks as if it will be the worst year for combine sales in probably 20 years,'' said Emmett Barker, president of the institute. **********Weak Tractor Sales, Too **********Tractor sales are doing somewhat better than combines but are still extremely weak. In the first seven months of the year, tractor sales were up 1.9 percent from a year before. In all of 1983, tractor sales were 116,933. **********''Business is a lot poorer now than it was a few years ago,'' said Vernon L. Holland, who runs a Massey-Ferguson dealership in Ada, a northwest Minnesota town in the Red River Valley. ''Farmers want to buy, but they just don't have the money to.'' **********A number of analysts said the industry's problems stem from the worsening financial situation of the nation's farmers. Their balance sheets have deteriorated as a result of declining land prices, and their cash flows have been squeezed by deteriorating commodity prices. **********''All this means that the farmer just plain doesn't have any money to buy new equipment,'' said Larry D. Hollis, an analyst with Robert D. Baird & Company in Milwaukee. **********Comment by Deere Official **********L. Neel Hall, Deere's senior vice president for farm equipment, expressed hope. ''Perhaps with the advent of the better harvest this year, even though prices may not be quite all they'd like to have, our customers will be fairly satisfied,'' he said. ''This, we hope, will be reflected in some recovery of sales in the late fall.'' **********John E. McGinty, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation, predicted that, among the top five manufacturers, Deere would best weather the industry's storm. ''They have 40 to 45 percent of the market,'' he said. Deere is the lowest-cost producer and has the most sophisticated manufacturing techniques, he added. **********For the short term, however, said Mr. Hollis, the Milwaukee-based analyst, Deere will have more problems than the others. ''They have one of the worst inventory levels,'' he said. **********Last week Deere reported net income of $29.4 million for its fiscal third quarter, ended July 31. The latest results included $28.5 million in extraordinary income from income tax adjustments and income of $22.6 million in its retail finance, leasing and insurance operations. **********The Outlook for Harvester **********''I've very optimistic about the industry for next year,'' Mr. McGinty said, ''but if I'm wrong International Harvester may go bankrupt.'' **********But Pershing's Mr. Whelan took a rosier view. ''There's no question Harvester is making a lot of progress,'' he said, attributing most of its gains to sales of heavy trucks. **********Two weeks ago Harvester announced a loss of $7 million for its fiscal third quarter, ended July 31. This was sharply narrowed from its loss of $131 million a year earlier. **********J. I. Case is doing a fine job now, Mr. McGinty said, but he is not so sure that Allis-Chalmers will stay in the farm equipment business. **********Several analysts said Massey-Ferguson would keep a strong role in the industry, especially as farm equipment supplier to the third world. **********In its latest quarter Allis-Chalmers had a loss of $12.5 million, and Massey-Ferguson, based in Toronto, earned $2.4 million, its first quarterly profit in four years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/18/busin.body_text: **********INTENSIVE programs for master **********of business administration degrees are becoming increasingly popular. Generally, students are selected and financed by major corporations with the idea that the graduates will climb higher on the management ladder. **********One unusual accelerated program has been started recently by the General Electric Company with Purdue University's Krannert graduate school of management. **********Explaining how candidates are picked, Roger W. Hessenius, manager of G.E.'s professional development programs in its corporate information systems operation, said: ''We get managers involved. We have asked for high-performance individuals.'' **********A few are middle managers, while others are what Mr. Hessenius calls ''individual contributors,'' such as systems designers and project leaders who work independently under the supervision of a manager. **********Knowledge of computers is one ability the students share, according to Mr. Hessenius. ''Those selected all have been working with computers, some in heavy manufacturing, some in engineering, some in the management information systems area,'' he said. ''We are trying to draw from all functions.'' **********The reason for the program is that G.E. wants its technical people to develop a business perspective along with the ability to communicate more effectively with general management. **********''We have found that the changing technology has forced our people to become more business-oriented,'' Mr. Hessenius said. ''The program gives them a broader perspective of business and allows them to compete with other business managers on a functional basis. The students will become more integrated into the business function.'' **********Like other accelerated programs for managers at business schools at the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia University, the Purdue- G.E. program requires outside study plus class attendance for short, intensive periods. **********For example, the first G.E. class consists of 24 students who began a year ago. They started with a 10-week period in the spring of 1983, when they received books, reading lists and assignments. While working at their jobs, they were expected to do homework at nights or weekends and transmit it by computer to Purdue professors. **********The program required two weeks of intensive study on campus at West Lafayette, Ind., early in the summer and another two weeks a month later. On campus, the students attended classes six hours a day for six days a week and had four hours or so of homework at night. **********''In many courses the case method is used and students often work in teams,'' Mr. Hessenius said. **********When back on the job in the fall, the students again underwent a period of additional reading for six weeks and homework assignments sent to Purdue by computer. Then they were free until this spring, when the routine was repeated. **********The class that began in the spring of 1983 will complete the program next summer, after the third round of summer work, or a total of 12 weeks of intensive on-campus work, plus the periods of homework. Then they will receive master of science degrees in industrial administration, which is Purdue's equivalent of the master of business administration degree elsewhere. A second class of 23 students began this spring. **********The background of the students and the intensive use of computers for homework makes the G.E. program a little different from most other M.B.A. management programs. **********Most of the G.E. students have undergraduate degrees in business, engineering, computer science or liberal arts, with computer science as a minor, but a few have not completed requirements for a bachelor's degree. They, too, will receive a master's degree once they complete the program. **********The students range in age from 27 to 45 years, with an average age of 37 in the first class. In the second class, one person is 50 years old, according to Mr. Hessenius. **********''The basic management information systems course is too elementary for this group,'' he said. So Purdue designed a special advanced program of lectures focusing on such subjects as artificial intelligence, office automation and telecommunications, as well as on such social issues as job displacement because of computers. **********What does G.E. hope to get out of the program? ''I hope that they are getting a little mind-stretching,'' Mr. Hessenius said. ''Technology is so pervasive that we need technical people with a business perspective.'' **********He hopes, too, that G.E. can ultimately get more general managers out of this area - managers who combine technical knowledge of information systems with management ability. He said that was ''something we have not been so successful in doing in the past.'' **********Dr. Dan E. Schendel, who heads the program at Purdue, said that such an executive program was also available for other companies, small as well as large. He said the other program had 21 students enrolled from companies such as TRW, Dow Chemical, Hewlett-Packard, Ford, Eli Lilly and Honeywell. The Coast Guard is also represented. **********Stressing the importance of the electronic linkage, he said, ''We try to monitor the work the students are doing by using the computer.'' Students are selected on the basis of college marks, Graduate Management Aptitude Test scores of 550-600 or better, and job experience.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/16/world.main_headline: GORBACHEV STARTS A VISIT TO BRITAIN WITH SOVIET GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/16/world.print_headline: GORBACHEV STARTS A VISIT TO BRITAIN WITH SOVIET GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/16/world.body_text: **********Mikhail S. Gorbachev, widely regarded as second in command in the Soviet Union, arrived here today to meet British officials and said he hoped for a slowdown in the arms race and an improvement in East-West relations. **********''There are no types of armaments that the U.S.S.R. would not agree to see limited and eventually banned in agreement with other countries on a reciprocal basis,'' Mr. Gorbachev said in a prepared statement on his arrival. **********Moscow will not ''be the one to start a new round in the arms race,'' he added. **********In Washington, the State Department had no comment on Mr. Gorbachev's statement. Privately officials said there did not appear to be anything new in his remarks. **********Will Meet With Mrs. Thatcher **********Mr. Gorbachev, who at 53 is the youngest member of the Soviet leadership, came to Britain with a delegation of legislators and will meet with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. **********He said he hoped ''to have a frank exchange of opinion on ways to overcome the present dangerous development of the international situation and make things in the world healthier again.'' **********''I would like to assure the British public,'' he said, speaking through an interpreter, ''that we have come with good will and good intentions.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev, who has been a member of the Soviet leadership since 1978, is the second-ranking secretary of the Communist Party and has emerged as the man apparently next in line to succeed Konstantin U. Chernenko as the General Secretary. Opportunity to Gauge Attitudes **********His visit is viewed by British officials as an opportunity to gauge the thinking and the attitude of the Soviet leadership before the Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko meets with Secretary of State George P. Shultz in new arms control talks on Jan. 7 and 8 in Geneva. **********President Reagan is said to be facing key decisions on how forthcoming the United States should be in the talks with the Soviet Union on a ban on space weapons development that the Russians have been demanding. (Page 3.) **********Mr. Gorbachev's arrival statement, while in line with stated Soviet policy, emphasized good will and peaceable intentions, as did the NATO foreign finisters at a meeting in Brussels this week. **********Mrs. Thatcher is expected to report on Mr. Gorbachev's visit when she sees President Reagan next weekend. She will stop off in Washington on the way from Peking, where she is going to sign an accord transferring Hong Kong to Chinese rule in 1997. **********The group with Mr. Gorbachev includes Yevgeny P. Velikhov, a physicist who is a vice president of the Academy of Sciences, and Gen. Nikolai F. Chervov, a spokesman on strategic and medium-range missiles. **********The Soviet Union has made it clear that progress toward a treaty banning space weapons is a priority in negotiations with the United States. The United States wants to give priority to resuming the suspended talks on strategic and medium-range missiles. **********In addition to meeting Sunday with Mrs. Thatcher, Mr. Gorbachev will meet with the Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, on Monday. His program includes talks with farm and trade officials, a visit to the Austin Rover plant in Oxford, a luncheon at the London Chamber of Commerce, and a visit to Edinburgh. **********Mr. Gorbachev is the highest Soviet official to visit since Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin's trip in 1967. The British are eager to have a closer look at Mr. Gorbachev and hope to show him, as one official said, ''how a Western democracy with a free or mixed- market economy operates.'' **********Since Mr. Gorbachev's delegation consists nominally of members of the Supreme Soviet, the national legislature, there are several meetings scheduled at the House of Commons. During a visit to Canada last year, Mr. Gorbachev took part in two hours of give-and- take with Canadian legislators. **********Today he visited the Karl Marx Memorial Library, where Lenin worked, and the British Museum reading room used by Marx. Mr. Gorbachev joked, ''If people don't like Marxism, they should blame the British Museum.'' **********He smiled for the television cameras, even when passing demonstrators waving placards on behalf of Soviet Jews, Ukrainian nationalists and the Solidarity movement in Poland. One of the banners read, ''Parliamentarian Gorbachev, who elected you?'' **********Soviet legislators are elected on a single official slate of one candidate for each seat in the Supreme Soviet. **********Mr. Gorbachev's trip is being sponsored by the Inter-Parliamentary Union, a Geneva-based group that seeks to foster contacts among legislators. Mr. Gorbachev, in addition to his high position, is also chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Council of the Union, one of the two chambers of the Supreme Soviet. **********British officials have said that human rights will be raised as an issue, as it always is with Soviet visitors, and it is likely that Mr. Gorbachev will also be asked about Afghanistan. December 27 is the fifth anniversary of the Soviet military intervention there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/02/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 6 Die as Kashmir Crowd Battles the Police
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/02/world.body_text: **********At least 6 people were killed and 58 wounded today when protesters throwing rocks and shouting slogans battled policemen in the streets of Srinagar, capital of Kashmir, news reports said. **********The wounded included 43 policemen, and several were listed in critical condition with severe head wounds, Indian news agencies said. The state authorities imposed an indefinite curfew in the troubled area only one day after an earlier curfew had been lifted. **********The violence today involved supporters of Dr. Farooq Abdullah, the former Chief Minister who was ousted by the state's Governor last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/07/world.main_headline: GUATEMALAN CALLS ON THE U.S. TO BACK ELECTIONS SET FOR '85
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/07/world.print_headline: GUATEMALAN CALLS ON THE U.S. TO BACK ELECTIONS SET FOR '85
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/07/world.body_text: **********A prominent Guatemalan politician said here today that the Reagan Administration and Congress could help end years of military rule in his country by increasing foreign assistance and supporting the presidential elections that are tentatively planned for next year. **********The politician, Jorge Carpio Nicolle, publisher of the newspaper El Grafico, is the presidential candidate of a centrist party. He said in an interview that recent voting in Guatemala to elect a constituent assembly had produced ''a momentum for democracy that even the military cannot turn back.'' **********If elected, Mr. Carpio Nicolle said, he would not support United States aid to Nicaraguan rebels and would not lead Guatemala into a military alliance with the United States or its allies in Central America, including Honduras and El Salvador. **********Guatemalans voted on July 1 to elect 88 legislators to serve in a constituent assembly. The assembly is empowered to write a new constitution, Guatemala's fifth in 40 years, that is supposed to lead the country back to civilian rule. **********Mr. Carpio Nicolle was in Washington for meetings with White House and State Department officials and Congressional leaders. His party, the newly formed National Union of the Center, finished strongly in the election last month and is expected to provide the main opposition to the left-of-center Christian Democratic Party and the rightist National Liberation Movement if elections are held next year. **********Administration officials said Mr. Carpio Nicolle, 51 years old, is among a small group of moderate Guatemalan leaders that Washington considers capable of holding together a civilian government. ''He's a genuine democrat who believes in the decentralization of power,'' one official who follows developments in Guatemala said. **********Mr. Carpio Nicolle, whose party was accused by opponents of being secretly supported by the Central Intelligence Agency, said he came to Washington to seek United States support for elections, not for the National Union of the Center. He denied links to the C.I.A. **********''International opinion makes it very difficult for the military to suspend the process or block the elections,'' he said. ''That is why it is important for the United States to make clear that it supports the holding of elections.'' **********Mr. Carpio Nicolle said he would ask the United States to increase economic assistance to Guatemala.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/25/busin.main_headline: Auto Sales Fall 6.5%; G.M. Strikes Blamed
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/25/busin.print_headline: Auto Sales Fall 6.5%; G.M. Strikes Blamed
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/25/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new American-made automobiles, held down by strikes at the nation's largest car maker, fell 6.5 percent in the Oct. 11-20 period, according to figures released today by the nation's six major automobile manufacturers. **********Selected General Motors Corporation assembly plants in the United States were shut down for six days late last month by the United Automobile Workers when negotiators failed to reach an agreement on a new labor contract. And workers in Canada walked off the job Oct. 17, when talks stalled on a new labor contract there. Many American assembly plants are dependent on components produced only in Canada, and G.M. began closing those plants late last week. **********''The strikes have broken the momentum of the long, general increase in sales that is now in its 27th month,'' said Arvid Jouppi, an automotive analyst. **********The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate, according to the Commerce Department, fell to 7.2 million units, from 7.6 million units in the comparable period last year. The annual rate for the first 10 days of October was 6.6 million units. **********Some analysts, including Mr. Jouppi, said they would revise their retail sales forecasts for the year because of the strikes. Mr. Jouppi said he now expects sales of American-made cars to reach 8.1 million units, down from his previous forecast of 8.3 million. **********In the mid-October period, which had nine selling days both this year and last, the major car makers had combined sales of 220,112 units, down from 235,334 in 1983. **********G.M. new-car sales fell 15.9 percent, on deliveries of 120,566 this year versus 143,368 in the comparable 1983 period. In a statement, James G. Vorhes, vice president of sales, said that while sales had been hampered by the strike, ''dealers report sustained enthusiasm and substantial orders for the 1985 G.M. cars introduced on Oct. 2.'' **********A 10% Ford Gain **********The Ford Motor Company's sales of 61,211 were up 10 percent from 55,658 a year ago. **********The Chrysler Corporation reported automobile sales of 29,377, up 8.1 percent from 27,175, while sales by the American Motors Corporation were off 12.9 percent on deliveries of 4,175 this year, against 4,800 in 1983. **********Sales at Volkswagen of America Inc. plunged 56.1 percent, from 2,567 last year to 1,123 new cars sold in the period this year. Subcompact cars have not been selling as well as larger cars this year. The Rabbit, the only car VW makes in the United States, is a subcompact. The Rabbit's replacement, the Golf, is due out next month. **********The American Honda Motor Company said sales of its domestically produced autos more than doubled from 1,766 last year to 3,660. **********In the mid-October period, sales of light trucks, commonly used for personal transportation, were up 9.2 percent in the period, with G.M. reporting total light truck sales of 38,534, up 3 percent from 37,415. Ford truck sales of 31,764 were off five-tenths of 1 percent, from 31,918. **********Chrysler truck sales, including the popular mini-van models, jumped 54.7 percent, from 9,204 to 14,239 this year. A.M.C. Jeep sales were up 63.6 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/14/busin.body_text: **********The International Harvester Company said today that it had earned $7 million in its fourth fiscal quarter, the first quarterly profit by the ailing agricultural equipment manufacturer in four years. **********Donald D. Lennox, chairman and chief executive officer, said International Harvester's profit, paced by a 36 percent increase in sales by its truck manufacturing division, came despite depressed worldwide agricultural equipment markets. Harvester said it had earnings of 3 cents a share on sales of $1.3 billion for the quarter ended Oct. 31. In the period a year earlier, the company lost $84 million on sales of $1 billion. **********Harvester last reported a profit in the fourth quarter of 1980. **********''We, of course, are gratified by the results for the fourth quarter of 1984,'' Mr. Lennox said. ''It represents a culmination of two and a half years of concerted dedication and effort by everyone associated with International Harvester.'' **********For the latest year, Harvester said it lost $55 million on sales of $4.8 billion, compared with a loss of $434 million on sales of $3.6 billion in 1983. **********The results for the fourth quarter did not include the effects of Harvester's recent decision to sell its agricultural equipment manufacturing operations to Tenneco Inc. Harvester said the quarterly results would be restated when the sale, which is valued at $430 million, was completed. **********The company said income from continuing operations was $15 million. Results also included a $10 million charge associated with operational restructuring, and $2 million of extraordinary income from tax provisions of foreign subsidiaries. **********During the quarter, Harvester's truck shipments increased 49 percent from the period a year ago and truck sales increased to $988 million from $679 million. **********Shipments of agricultural equipment fell to $316 million from $322 million. But Mr. Lennox said dealer inventories of large tractors declined by 9 percent and combines by 22 percent. **********Production was reduced during the fourth quarter because of the weak demand, Mr. Lennox said. Wholesale shipments were held to about 40 percent of demand, he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/25/world.main_headline: IN INDONESIA, A WILDERNESS IS NOW HOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/25/world.print_headline: IN INDONESIA, A WILDERNESS IS NOW HOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/25/world.body_text: **********It has been called the largest organized peacetime relocation of people in recorded history. But to a 42-year-old farmer named Sukardji, Indonesia's ''transmigration'' program has a more concrete definition: his own home, on his own piece of land; a kerosene lamp, a radio and a new life. **********A year ago, Mr. Sukardji was a landless farm laborer in Java, living with more than a dozen people in a house he did not own. In February, he and his wife, Suhartini, and their three children were one of 600 pioneering families to open a settlement called Koya Timur, on virgin farmland carved from a relentless jungle here in West Irian, Indonesia's part of the wild, remote island of New Guinea. **********The Indonesian Government has set a goal of moving about 750,000 families over next five years from the country's overpopulated islands - Java, Madura and Bali - to sparsely populated and undeveloped corners like this one in the vast Indonesian archipelago. More than 500,000 families, or about 2.5 million people, were ''transmigrated'' during the last five-year plan, ending on March 31, 1984, the Government says.   Land, Food and Fertilizer **********In a program now and then reminiscent of the homesteading of the American West, each family gets a plot of land, a house and a year's supply of basic foods and fertilizer in return for its commitment to open new territory. **********Human rights groups, environmental organizations and community development workers have criticized the project for a variety of reasons. **********There are concerns that people thrown into new and often hostile environments do not get adequate support services; some of them have reportedly gone hungry when land proved infertile. **********There are criticisms that fragile and often primitive local societies - particularly here in West Irian, with its native Melanesian population barely a generation out of a stone-age culture - will be overrun by the country's predominant ethnic Malays, especially the Javanese. **********Tribal landowners are not always compensated. Eko Sarwoko, who directs the transmigration program in West Irian, said in an interview that the tribal chief who relinquished the thousands of acres of hunting land around Koya Timur ''didn't ask for money.'' All he wanted, Mr. Eko Sarwoko said, were a house, a school, a clinic and a building for his clan's cultural activities.   Separatist Group **********Diplomats in Jakarta say that the Free Papua Movement, a separatist group fueled by opposition to transmigration in West Irian, may pose a long- term problem for Indonesia because dissidents seek to draw support from and find refuge in neighboring Papua New Guinea, an independent nation of ethnically similar people. **********There are also charges, which transmigration officials have denied, that some migrants are moved involuntarily, or that resettlement is used to rid the cities of undesirables. **********Java, Madura and Bali, where more than 90 percent of Indonesia's 160 million people live, already have at least 23 million more people than the land can support, officials say. While there are about 690 people per square kilometer in Java, the larger neighboring island of Sumatra has only 59 per square kilometer; the Moluccas have 19; Kalimantan, part of Borneo, has 12, and West Irian has 3. **********Vast areas of land are available for development, but spontaneous, unassisted migration, now also being encouraged, has been negligible in Indonesia's nearly 40 years of independence. Many Indonesians blame the Dutch colonizers for creating a labor- intensive plantation system in Java, leading to the island's overpopulation, and for total neglect of other parts of the country. Many of Indonesia's islands are without docks, roads or any forms of communication.   Preparing for Second Crop **********In Koya Timur, at the end of a muddy, 25-mile drive from this small provincial capital of Jayapura, Mr. Sukardji was preparing his rice paddies for this year's second crop when visitors arrived at his new home. He and his neighbors are lucky to be within a few hours of an established town. Many settlers in West Irian are in the trackless wilderness, reached only by air. **********Mr. Sukardji's home is the standard three-room, dirt-floor wooden house allocated to each migrant family. He had filled his with furniture he made himself from wood cleared from the fields. Mr. Sukardji said his first rice crop had brought him enough money for the kerosene lamp and transistor radio. **********Behind the house, he was building a coop for the chickens that would be his next major purchase. Flowers bordered his small fields of rice and beans; a friend had given him the seeds. **********Officials hope that farmers like Mr. Sukardji will set an example for local people who have come to live at Koya Timur. Government policy, partly in response to criticisms of Javanization, is to populate new settlements with one-third Javanese, who are known for their farming skills; one-third migrants from other islands, and one-third local people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/16/busin.main_headline: THE COLLISION OF BULLS AND BEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/16/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; THE COLLISION OF BULLS AND BEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/16/busin.body_text: **********IN a report issued early this month, Joseph C. **********Generalis, vice president of technical analysis **********at the First Boston Corporation, told clients that he was expecting a ''bounce'' in the stock market. In fact, he even predicted that this would begin last Monday, Dec. 10. **********As it turned out, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed nine points that day and six on Tuesday. But Mr. Generalis, like some other technical analysts these days, is mostly negative about the longer-term prospects for the stock market. He thinks that the market's climb to slightly more than 1,200 should last only four to seven days and will be over by Christmas. By April or May of next year, he said, the Dow should trade in the 1,020 to 980 range. **********Like other technicians, Mr. Generalis follows the dynamics of the stock market, charting price patterns, advance/decline ratios of stocks and investor sentiment, among other statistics. Some more traditional investors consider analysis by technicians to be comparable to astrological charts, but the numbers of technical analysts on Wall Street are significant enough to merit attention. **********Just as with their more traditional counterparts who analyze the fundamental aspects of stocks such as profits and sales trends, there is wide confusion about the direction of the market among those who study technical data. The numbers, like fundamental information on a stock, can be interpreted to mean different things by different people. **********But many of Wall Street's technicians, including Mr. Generalis and Alan R. Shaw, senior vice president of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company are still pessimistic about the market's prospects over the coming six months. For example, Mr. Generalis said that according to his indicators, ''leg two'' of the 1982 bull market is ''not on the horizon.'' **********He sees the market going up in early 1985 but not hitting a ''marginal new high,'' which would be above 1,287 on the Dow, the high reached in 1983. After that mild rally, the market should drop in reaction to a continued weakening of the economy, he predicts. ''You do not need an economic collapse for the Dow to trade at 1,020,'' he said. ''You merely need a perception starting to evolve that you are in a recession or that this is the last chance to lock in double-digit interest rates in bonds.'' **********At Delta Financial Management in Hingham, Mass., president Frank J. Weldon Jr. describes himself as neutral. ''What we're looking for are extremes,'' he said. In analyzing institutional investors' cash levels and pricing activity of the 15 most active stocks on a daily basis, he said that he and his partner ''haven't seen the fear'' on the part of investors that typically signals a time to buy. **********Delta's analysis indicates that the stock market will continue to be ''locked in this trading range for a while longer.'' And while Mr. Weldon concedes there may be a year-end rally, he does not think it would be sustainable. **********He admits that he does not care about such things as a company's earnings record, its dividend or economic prospects for its industry, when the firm invests its $30 million in client assets. Rather, he looks at price patterns of the stocks and their patterns relative to the 700 other stocks they monitor. **********AS a result of this analysis, Mr. Weldon sees attractive pricing patterns in some drug, cosmetics and photography stocks. In addition, he still likes the interest-sensitive groups such as utilities, some banks and insurance companies. Groups he avoids include energy and technology. **********In the bullish technical camp is Richard Eakle, vice president at Morgan Stanley & Company. Describing himself as very bullish, Mr. Eakle claims the current market is in an ''intermediate pullback,'' but he thinks that this phase will be followed in the next three or four months by an ''explosive move on the up side.'' He is looking for the Dow to reach the 1,380 to 1,420 range in the next four months. ''For all intents and purposes, the market has seen its lows,'' he said. **********Mr. Eakle is encouraged that there was ''no follow-through'' selling when the Dow traded around 1,160 on Monday. ''Some people started to sober up,'' he said. While he admits that he thought I.B.M. would drop only to 118 a share (it closed at 116 1/2), he was relieved that the low ''didn't really produce any volume or selling intensity.'' He believes that I.B.M., as well as other blue chips such as General Electric, General Motors, Eastman Kodak and Westinghouse, have all seen their lows. **********Stock groups that have been strong and that Mr. Eakle believes will remain so are airlines, autos, banks, mobile homes, savings and loan companies, retailers, brewers and computer companies. ''A lot of these groups should come back with a lot of strength when the market reasserts itself,'' he said. Stocks that he thinks should be avoided include those of the energy companies and commodity- based companies, such as the metals and mining companies. Further, he said he was turning negative on food stocks and grocery chains, which have been strong performers this year. **********A Boon for Small Stocks **********DESPITE the poor performance of the small- capitalization stocks since June 1983, pension funds have poured hundreds of millions of dollars into funds managed by Dimensional Fund Advisors, a firm that specializes in buying an index of these smaller stocks. The Chicago-based firm has been so successful in attracting business, in fact, that it has had to limit its new client funds to $100 million a month this year. Its portfolio was down almost 8 percent through November, compared with the 3.5 percent increase of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. **********Last month, D.F.A. received approval on a new trust fund and has already attracted almost $100 million from two clients, including I.B.M.'s pension fund. This new fund will invest in an index of stocks that are larger than the small stocks it now buys but smaller than most of the stocks in the traditional index funds patterned after the S.&P. index. The fund will invest in stocks of companies that have market capitalizations of between $100 million and $300 million. **********ALONG with the Union Carbide Corporation, the **********chemical industry in general is suffering, and **********not just from the tragedy at Bhopal, India. Some analysts aren't very sanguine about the prospects for the group's stocks. James M. Arenson, vice president at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, in fact, is recommending only four chemical stocks: Monsanto, Imperial Chemical, Morton Thiokol and Sealed Air. And in most cases, he favors these four because of their specialty niches, such as agriculture and health care. **********Mr. Arenson's lack of enthusiasm stems from price cutting in the industry, which has penalized profit margins, as has the strong dollar. Mr. Arenson thinks that chemical stocks were better investments early in the recovery. ''I think it's late in the cycle for the chemicals,'' he concluded. **********But Emily S. Plishner, senior analyst at New York's Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc., has become more bullish on the group in the past month. She expects price cutting to stop early next year with a resulting improvement in profit margins. And like Mr. Arenson, she is recommending Monsanto because of its relatively low price. **********Anise C. Wallace writes on finance from New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Defense Department investigators here are trying to determine whether faulty electronic parts from a major West Coast counterfeiting operation have gotten into the military supply chain. **********The counterfeiting, which reportedly took place at a small Los Angeles electronics parts distributor, was uncovered by the General Electric Company, according to documents G.E. filed in United States District Court in Los Angeles. **********G.E. charged last month that the tiny S.J. Corporation, which does business as Aero Electronics, had produced faulty look-alike components - some used in commercial aviation - that bore the trademarks of G.E. and other manufacturers. **********G.E. charged it was the victim of an operation that in some cases put G.E.'s trademark on parts General Electric did not make, and that in other instances recycled used G.E. parts to make them appear to be new. **********Through its attorney, Gerald I. Neiter, Aero denies any wrongdoing. **********Defense Supply Center **********Defense investigators are concerned that some Aero parts may have been sold to the Defense Electronics Supply Center here, which buys from private vendors and supplies the military services, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Federal Aviation Administration. **********G.E. is asserting, in documents on file in Los Angeles, that some Aero counterfeits of tubes that are used in navigational systems for commercial aircraft were sold to the Rockwell International Corporation, which then sold them to Delta Air Lines. **********The documents state further that the counterfeiting was discovered following numerous complaints that ''tubes were not working properly in Delta Airlines equipment.'' **********In Atlanta, a Delta spokesman said the company rejected the entire batch of parts before any were installed in its airplanes, after the first 80 that were tested failed to meet standards. **********Letter to F.A.A. on Logotypes **********Another indication of the operation's size emerged in a letter G.E. sent to the F.A.A. last month. The letter asserted that Aero had equipment that would allow it to duplicate the logotypes of 20 electronics-related manufacturers, including RCA, ITT, Litton, Sylvania, Raytheon and Western Electric. **********Counterfeiting has become a major concern of the Federal Defense Criminal Investigative Service, a special unit, which began looking into bogus parts operations last year. Yet despite reports that counterfeiting has proved to be a problem for both military and industrial users, few instances have come to light. **********The General Electric case was an exception, although it went unreported last month when the company sought a Federal court order against Aero. Details of G.E.'s actions were reported today in an article in The Dayton Daily News. **********Restraining Order Imposed **********According to court documents, Aero was barred by a restraining order from further use of the G.E. trademark after Federal Judge A. Wallace Tashima concluded that Aero had ''replated and rebranded'' used G.E. tubes to make them appear new. **********Judge Tashima also ordered United States marshals to raid Aero's facility. The May 11 raid confiscated records, parts and equipment. Details of Aero's operation emerged in descriptions of the raid filed in court. **********Court documents portrayed Aero as a sophisticated outfit that employed sandblasting and buffing equipment to remove trademarks from old parts. Then, according to G.E.'s court filings, old parts were replated to make them appear new and stamped with fresh logos. **********Confiscated records indicate that Aero had ordered the recycling of more than 20,000 General Electric parts of 50 different types.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/23/world.main_headline: MITTERRAND AND KOHL HONOR DEAD OF VERDUN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/23/world.print_headline: MITTERRAND AND KOHL HONOR DEAD OF VERDUN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/23/world.body_text: **********The leaders of France and West Germany visited this battle site today to pay silent homage to the millions of their compatriots killed in two world wars. **********President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany chose the site of the 1916 battle of Verdun for a symbolic day of reconciliation. **********Driving rain soaked the hundreds of war veterans from both countries who stood waiting for several hours at the Douaumont Ossuary, a cemetery that holds the remains of more than 130,000 French and German dead. **********A group of French veterans from Nancy said it was the first time they had stood shoulder to shoulder with their German counterparts from World War II. **********There were no political speeches, a decision that the veterans approved. **********''De Gaulle shook the hand of the Germans 20 years ago and it is right that today we just have a simple ceremony of friendship,'' one Frenchman said. **********''If we had had ceremonies like this before World War II, we might have avoided it,'' another said. **********The ceremonies today were preceded by a joint military exercise by 2,800 French and West German troops in eastern France. **********Before visiting the Ossuary and the graves of French soldiers, President Mitterrand and Chancellor Kohl paid tribute to the German dead at Consenvoye, one of the many German cemeteries in the Verdun region. It holds the remains of 8,700 soldiers. **********President Mitterrand invited Chancellor Kohl to Verdun last May. The invitation was widely viewed in France as having been improvised to soothe feelings after the West German leader had been left out of the 40th anniversary celebrations of the Allied landings in Normandy in World War II. **********There was no time scheduled for political consultations between the two leaders. But they were expected to meet again in Bonn next month. **********The battle of Verdun lasted 300 days and was one of the bloodiest of World War I. **********Of the two million thrown into the battle, about half a million men died and hundreds of thousands more were wounded. According to French figures, 360,000 French and 335,000 German soldiers were killed. **********The French troops were commanded by Henri Philippe Petain, later disgraced after he led the Vichy French Government that collaborated with Nazi Germany during World War II. At Verdun he coined and made good his famous slogan: ''Ils ne passeront pas'' (''They shall not pass''). **********Mr. Mitterrand, a soldier in the French Army, was captured by the Germans in World War II during fighting in 1940 near Verdun. **********The two leaders made a detour to visit a corner of the battlefield where Mr. Kohl's father fought in 1916. **********France and West Germany have been close allies since Chancellor Konrad Adenauer signed a treaty of friendship with President Charles de Gaulle in 1963. Today's ceremony reflected efforts to take the process further. **********Previous French presidents visited the military shrine of Verdun without inviting representatives from West Germany. **********Earlier this year President Mitterrand and Chancellor Kohl took another step to bring their countries closer together by abolishing frontier formalities for their citizens. **********''The Chancellor and I will feel we have contributed to making history for our two peoples and have given new energy to a political construction which, if better understood, should transform the world balance,'' Mr. Mitterrand said in a statement Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/02/world.main_headline: WHEN TERROR THREATENS: WHAT U.S. HAS LEARNED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/02/world.print_headline: WHEN TERROR THREATENS: WHAT U.S. HAS LEARNED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/02/world.body_text: **********Shortly before the Nov. 6 election, American intelligence detected what officials describe as hard evidence that Shiite Moslem terrorists planned to attack yet another American installation in Lebanon. **********The target this time, officials said, was the American Ambassador's hillside residence in Yarze, a Beirut suburb overlooking the Mediterranean. ''We knew who was planning the attack and generally where in West Beirut they were located,'' said Robert B. Oakley, the director of the State Department's Office of Counterterrorism and Emergency Planning. **********Little was written about it at the time, but American officials point to the swift response to the threat as an example of what has to be done if the United States is to counter the continuing threat of international terrorism. **********Armed with advance intelligence, American and Lebanese forces mobilized. Half the American staff was evacuated, the Ambassador was secretly flown out of the country, the perimeter defense at the residence was reinforced and pushed outward, antiaircraft weapons were put on the grounds and the air lanes above the residence were closed to all traffic. **********It is impossible to know for sure whether these measures blocked the terrorists from making good on their announced plans to hit another American target before election day, but the fact is that Nov. 6 passed quietly. The only scare occurred about a week later when a private Saudi Arabian plane strayed over the residence and nervous guards opened fire. **********The sense of relief in the State Department the day after the election was palpable. ''It's not that the danger is over - it isn't,'' Mr. Oakley said. ''But in this case, at least, effective preventive action succeeded in blocking an attack.'' **********Ever since a truck laden with explosives devastated the United States Embassy near East Beirut on Sept. 20, counterterrorism has been a top item on the official agenda in Washington. In fact, the Sept. 20 bombing had at least one result that the terrorists never intended: It seems to have galvanized the Reagan Administration, the bureaucracy and Congress into concerted action against the continuing threat of international terrorism. **********In the 10 weeks since the embassy bombing - the third terrorist attack on an American installation in Lebanon in 18 months - Administration officials say they have taken specific steps to improve intelligence, enhance the protection of American embassies and diplomats abroad and increase the readiness of secret counterterror teams that are trained to rescue hostages, storm hijacked airliners and break up terrorist cells overseas. **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz has made counterterrorism a top priority by conducting personal security inspections of embassies he visits on trips abroad and demanding daily status reports on conditions at high-risk embassies. In addition, Congress moved quickly after the attack to adopt antiterror legislation and authorize $356 million in the current budget to enhance security abroad. **********Interagency teams have visited 22 embassies in the Middle East, Latin America and elsehwere to try to identify the most vulnerable. Eleven embassies are being built around the world with blast-absorbing walls and new technological devices to increase security. The National Academy of Sciences is working with the State Department to design a prototype embassy of the future that is both functional and secure.   New Attitude Reported **********''We've accomplished more in the last two months than we have in a long time,'' said Mr. Oakley. ''The Sept. 20 bombing was a watershed. There is a completely different attitude now about the problem, a kind of interagency and intergovernmental cooperation that didn't exist before. The danger is still there, but we're more alert.'' **********At the same time, interviews with top Government officials indicate that there remains a basic policy split in the Administration on whether the United States should use military force to pre-empt or retaliate against terrorist attacks. **********Mr. Shultz has made the case for pre-emptive and retaliatory action in recent speeches, arguing that the United States must be prepared to use force lest it become ''the Hamlet of nations, worrying endlessly over whether and how to respond.'' **********Key Administration officials disagree with the Secretary, however. **********Vice President Bush and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger have both spoken out against the Shultz approach. The Joint Chiefs of Staff are also said to oppose it. **********''You don't want to shoot a gun into a crowded theater in the hope that somebody's there who might have done something,'' Mr. Weinberger said recently, echoing an argument made earlier by Mr. Bush.   Reagan Has Reservations **********President Reagan has not come down conclusively on either side of the argument, but he has repeatedly expressed his reservations about using force. ''You don't want to just carelessly go out and maybe kill innocent people,'' Mr. Reagan said in an interview last week in response to a question about why the United States had not retaliated for terrorist actions. ''Then you're as bad as the terrorists.'' **********Although the policy dispute is unresolved, many officials and private experts on terrorism express the belief that the United States is closer today to taking pre-emptive or retaliatory action than it has ever been. **********''We're moving toward a consensus on using force to deal with terrorism,'' one senior official said. ''We're not there yet, but we are close. For one thing, our intelligence is better now, so pre-emption becomes a more achievable thing to do.'' **********Militarily, the United States has been poised for some time to make a retaliatory or pre-emptive strike. In the Middle East, for instance, the 90,000-ton, nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Eisenhower has been on station in the eastern Mediterranean for two months. Its aircraft could easily strike targets in Lebanon should the political decision be made in Washington. **********Brian Jenkins, a counterterrorism expert for the Rand Corporation, also believes the moment of retaliation is not far off. ''There's a red line somewhere in all of this,'' he said in a telephone interview, ''a line that, if crossed, will produce a response of the kind Shultz is talking about. Is it after 5 embassy bombings? Or 25? I don't know.   Concern About 2 A.M. Decisions **********''My concern is that we will cross that line before thinking through our options,'' Mr. Jenkins said. ''I'm afraid we'll end up with the kind of decisions that are made by Presidents in their pajamas at 2 A.M.'' **********A similar concern expressed by Robert H. Kupperman, a terrorism specialist at the Georgetown Center for Strategic and International Studies. **********''There are the gravest risks in following the Shultz scenario too literally,'' he said in an interview in his office here. **********''Just imagine what might have happened if we had retaliated after the bombing of the Marine barracks by sending a team into Baalbek,'' he said. Baalbek is the suspected headquarters in Lebanon of the Hezballah, or Party of God, a militant Shiite Moslem group that American intelligence has identified as being involved in all three of the bombings in Lebanon. **********''Suppose four or five of our team had been caught, tried and hanged,'' he continued. ''Then we'd have to raise the ante militarily, the Soviets would match it and the situation would escalate very quickly.'' **********Effective retaliation, Mr. Kupperman said, would require a careful conditioning of public and international opinion in advance, along with consultation with other nations. ''Shultz is laying the groundwork for that now,'' he said.   Talks With Allies Begin **********William E. Colby, the former Director of Central Intelligence, said he was surprised that the Administration had not retaliated already for the attacks in Lebanon. ''We have the tools to do it and we've identified the target,'' he said. ''I think public opinion would support it 100 percent.'' **********On the international scene, the record of concerted action against terrorism is spotty at best. **********At the economic meeting in London last June, the seven leading industrialized democracies pledged themselves to a new effort to fight terrorism. An ''experts group'' held a follow-up meeting in London in September, and American officials say intelligence-sharing and coordination has improved, especially with Britain and Italy. **********A prime example of international cooperation came last week when the Italian police rounded up seven Moslem terrorists who were reportedly plotting to blow up the American Embassy in Rome. **********The Italians acted in response to a tip from the Swiss authorities, who had arrested a man in Zurich as he tried to board a plane for Rome with four pounds of explosives. In the man's pocket they found a note with the names and address of his accomplices in Rome. When the Italian police moved in on the group in a hideout near Rome, they found more explosives and photographs and maps of the embassy grounds.   A Warning at Dinner **********The first word of the roundup reached Maxwell M. Rabb, the American Ambassador to Rome, as he was eating dinner in a restaurant the day after Thanksgiving. It came in the form of an urgent call from Marcello Monarca, the Rome police chief. **********''He wanted me to be very careful because he didn't know for sure how many terrorists were involved,'' the Ambassador recalled in a telephone interview. ''It was a prime example of two governments working together to do something about terrorism,'' **********But a coordinated response to terrorism, especially state-supported terrorism, still elludes the alliance. This was underscored recently when the United States and France were unable to agree on measures against the Libyan Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, whom Washington accuses of fostering subversion and terrorism worldwide. **********The latest French-American consultations on the subject followed a week in which Egypt revealed a bungled Libyan plot to assassinate a former Libyan Prime Minister in Cairo and in which France was forced to admit that Libya had reneged on its pledge to remove its troops from Chad. Top American officials, meeting with Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson in Washington, argued that the Libyan actions reinforced the need for Western nations to ostracize the Qaddafi Government with sanctions and other means.   U.S. Officials Disappointed **********The French were not persuaded. Mr. Cheysson emerged from his meetings to tell reporters that France wanted normal relations with Libya, from which it obtains substantial supplies of crude oil. The logic of the American argument, the Foreign Minister said, could lead to military action against Libya that ''no one would recommend.'' **********The French reaction was a keen disappointment to American officials dealing with counterterrorism. ''The Libyans have been identified as terrorists for a long time,'' one official said. ''But the Europeans have their own agenda with Libya and nothing, it seems, is going to upset it.'' **********The lack of a coordinated Western strategy for dealing with state-supported terrorism is a major problem, in the view of Benjamin Netanyahu, the chief Israeli delegate to the United Nations. Mr. Netanyahu is one of the founders of the Jonathan Institute, a joint United States-Israeli organization with offices in Washington that is named after his brother, Jonathan Netanyahu, the Israeli commander of the raid to rescue hijacking hostages at Entebbe airport in Uganda in July 1976. **********''The Western nations have enormous economic and political clout if they could ever act together,'' he said. ''When a country is known to support terrorism, like Libya, the Western nations should isolate it by cutting off trade and closing their ports to them. **********''Nations that sponsor terrorism,'' he said, ''have to realize there is a cost to waging this clandestine war.'' **********NEXT: How new security measures are changing the look and feel of embassies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/13/busin.body_text: **********Harte-Hanks Cable Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. of San Antonio, said yesterday that it had begun a public offering of $50 million worth of subordinated debentures and zero- coupon subordinated notes. **********The offering consists of 50,000 units, each priced at $1,000. **********Each unit consists of one $1,000 13 5/8 percent subordinated debenture due July 15, 1994, and one $309 principal amount zero-coupon senior subordinated note. **********Drexel Burnham Lambert acted as sole underwriter for the offering. **********Each unit was priced at par, but the bonds were priced at a discount. According to a Drexel spokesman, the stripped yield of the 13 5/8 percent bond is 16.53 percent, while the stripped yield of the zero-coupon bond is 16.5 percent. **********The issue has been rated B-3 by Moody's. S.& P. has not yet rated the issue, the Drexel spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/20/busin.body_text: **********AT 24 years old, Diane Ryan is too young to qualify for the investment program at Mutual Life Insurance of New York, the company for which she has worked since graduating from high school. But next year she will be eligible, and whatever she puts into the plan will be matched 100 percent by her employer. **********Mrs. Ryan has already taken advantage of an interest- free car loan and she can receive $7,000 toward the purchase of a co-op as an outright gift from MONY provided that she stays with the company for five more years. These incentives were offered to encourage employees to move to Westchester when the company relocates, beginning in July. MONY's benefits are ''a reason why I've been with the company six years,'' says Mrs. Ryan. They also illustrate how an employee benefit package can increase an individual's wealth. **********''We were interested in attracting and keeping better- than-average employees,'' said Leo F. Lewis, MONY manager of benefits research. ''Knowing that we have a better- than-average benefits program helps make that clear.'' **********Often, more than 40 percent of the net worth of senior executives comes from benefits, such as stock options, deferred pay programs and savings and investment plans offered by their employers. Financial planners say that middle-income individuals can also add to their net worth by understanding and using the benefit package. **********''The most under-utilized asset of the middle-income family is employee benefits,'' said George E. L. Barbee, executive director and co-founder of the Consumer Financial Institute, an independent financial planning company in Newton, Mass. ''The problem starts with the little booklet they give you when you first go to the company. It is not often written in layman's language.'' **********MONY runs seminars and constantly updates employees on the changes and additions to its benefit package, but employees of other companies often hardly know what their plans offer. ''If you don't understand something about your benefits, you should schedule an appointment with personnel to see what it is they have,'' suggested Mr. Barbee. **********Timothy J. Sullivan, 63, a field vice president in Chicago for the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, estimates that company benefits account for more than 40 percent of his wealth. ''You would have to have closed your eyes and ears to not know what was going on in this company,'' said Mr. Sullivan. He added that the company regularly sponsored employee forums, sent out newsletters and had slide shows to inform the staff of uses for benefits and changes in the plan. **********When he started with John Hancock 38 years ago, he said, ''They offered modest life insurance. Now everybody has two- times-salary, company-paid life insurance,'' and health insurance went from contributory to noncontributory. **********Just recently he accepted the company's offer to defer up to 12 percent of his salary toward his retirement years, a measure that will result in lower tax on earnings now, because the current salary is reduced. **********Mr. Sullivan also plans to take early retirement and leave John Hancock at the end of the year. For accepting this company offer, he will receive a year-and-a-half's salary beyond his actual retirement date, and will still be on the payroll for the length of the payment, enjoying all company benefits. Because of these and other different incentive savings plans, he believes he has had many opportunities ''to accumulate money in addition to pension and Social Security.'' **********Mr. Barbee said that this opportunity was available in most companies. ''The failure to recognize and integrate profit-sharing plans and pension plans that are available to people at fairly low levels in a company has caused many peo ple to miss one of the greatest hidden assets a company has to offer,'' said Mr. Barbee. ''The tax-advantaged nature of these benefits is extremely useful,'' he continued. **********''You can't isolate the benefit handbook. As in any kind of worthwhile financial planning you have to evaluate your company benefits as a part of your overall financial package,'' said Neil B. Kauffman, partner in Kauffman & Drebing, a firm of financial advisers in Philadelphia. **********Since many companies now offer employees a choice of benefits, planners advise that personal and family goals be taken into consideration when selecting options. **********''There are many things the company can offer employees that are responsive to needs of the individuals,'' said Robert H. Felder, director of corporate benefits at the American Can Company in Greenwich, Conn. ''That's what human resources is all about,'' One example is the yearly cash allowance of $1,000 to $1,500 for day care that American Can offers employees. ''It's an important support system to a dual income family,'' said Mr. Felder, who has a working wife and a four-year-old child in day care.  In 1979, American Can was the first company of its kind to offer what is known as the ''cafeteria plan,'' encompassing the major benefit areas - medical, life, disability, vacation, retirement and capital accumulation. **********Under the plan, the company offers each employee a choice or ''menu'' of benefits, instead of providing the same package of benefits for everyone working there. All employees receive the same amount of ''credits,'' and can allocate them among the various benefits as they see fit. Most companies require that their employees take certain minimum benefits before selecting their personal preferences. **********At American Can, people devise their own packages. Someone who wanted more retirement money and less life insurance would put more credits into retirement and less into life insurance. An employee with no children might take a less expensive medical program. Similarly, in a joint income family in which the spouse has a fixed plan that provides medical coverage for both, the partner with the ''cafeteria'' plan would be able to choose another benefit. A person with health problems could take extra disability; a young healthy worker might want more vacation days. **********The cornerstone of the benefit package is the pension plan, said Mr. Kauffman. There are two basic types: the de fined contribution plan, which usually includes a profit-sharing plan, a stock-purchase plan or, in the case of the 401(k) a deferred salary plan, and the defined benefit plan. **********The 401(k) is a defined contribution plan that is becoming increasingly popular, according to Mr Kauffman. It allows an employee to save part of his earnings and not pay taxes on it until it is withdrawn. Mr Kauffman explained that under plan 401(k), people who make, say, $40,000 a year can take part by contributing up to a certain limit annually. If, for example, they contribute $2,000, at the end of the year their W-2 lists earned income as $38,000, instead of $40,000, so taxes are reduced, and $2,000 goes into an interest-bearing fund. **********The 401(k) is like an I.R.A. except that it is only done through a company. Individuals cannot set it up on their own. ''It's the biggest thing since sliced bread,'' said Mr. Kauffman. ''Except for administration, there may be no direct cost associated with the plan, and from the employee's point of view, it's a nice convenient way to save and get a tax break at the same time.'' Some employers have matching programs, by which they make either partial or equal contributions to be added to those of the employee. **********One disadvantage of contributory plans is that there is no way of knowing for certain how much money will have been accumulated by retirement. The only way of arriving at any kind of figure is to calculate the amount invested, assume a rate of interest and work out an approximate answer.  Most companies offer defined benefit plans rather than the contributory plans, because this was the way they were traditionally set up in early negotiations between employers and unions, said Mr. Kauffman. These plans provide workers, upon retirement, with a fixed sum that is paid at regular intervals (usually once a month) for the rest of their lives. Employees receive a yearly statement that shows, how much they have accumulated so far. Projecting ahead from these figures, however, assumes continued employment with the company and calculation of expected salary increases, as well as accounting for projected inflation rates. **********If a company offers a pension plan, it is important to know how long it takes to become vested - to acquire undisputed right to one's portion of the plan. Mr. Kauffman advises people, all things being equal, to favor companies whose plans vest early. Many companies vest after three years, but faster vesting is becoming the trend, he added. **********Benefits Near One-Third of Total Wages **********According to a 1983 U.S. Chamber of Commerce survey, approximately $510 billion in employment benefits was paid to workers across the country in 1982.  This represented 32.5 percent of total wages and salaries, estimated at $1.6 trillion. Employees in private industry received $406 billion in benefits, while public sector employees received $104 billion. **********Legally required benefits, such as unemployment and workers' compensation, amounted to 9.5 percent of total wages and salaries, or $149 billion.  ''Agreed-upon'' benefits were 8.5 percent, or $133 billion. **********Among the most common agreed-upon benefits were pensions, which accounted for 3.6 percent of total wages and salaries, and insurance, such as health and life, at 4.4 percent. Benefits paid during time not worked - for example, during vacations and holidays or while employees took sick leave - amounted to 9.8 percent of total wages and salaries. For disabilities not covered by law, employers paid an estimated $9.4 billion. Bonuses and profit-sharing payments were $14 billion, or 0.9 percent of total wages and salaries.
