https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/28/busin.body_text: **********Kuwaiti sheiks, Saudi princes and Nigerian bureaucrats live mainly on hope these days - the hope that oil production will fall everywhere but in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. And in fact there is substantial evidence that this is slowly happening. **********Their hope also is that the rate of energy conservation will slow in the industrial nations and that the substitution of coal, nuclear power and natural gas for oil will reach its limits - and these trends are already evident. Their ultimate hope, of course, is that prices will rise. **********Simply put, these hopes and dreams are OPEC's strategy. The 13 OPEC members hold most of the world's oil reserves; theirs is by far the cheapest to produce, and they are biding their time until the non- OPEC countries run out of crude, putting OPEC once again in the driver's seat. **********But while they wait, ample supplies are available elsewhere and that will be the case ''until the early 1990's,'' says James Schlesinger, former Secretary of Energy. Adds John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation: ''All the pressure on oil prices is down in this decade.'' **********That downward pressure was dramatically evident earlier this month when Norway, then Britain and finally Nigeria cut the prices of their high-grade crudes by as much as $2 a barrel, and oil company stocks plunged for a few days as fear spread that the drop would have no bottom. By far the biggest blow to OPEC was the action of Nigeria, one of its own. ''For all practical purposes, Nigeria has left OPEC,'' says Stephen A. Smith, a senior vice president of Data Resources Inc. **********The OPEC oil ministers are meeting tomorrow in an emergency session in Geneva to keep the initial price cuts from sparking a pell-mell downward price spiral. They are likely to be successful this time, even though the Mobil Corporation last week took the extremely unusual step of lowering its domestic oil prices on the eve of an OPEC meeting. **********NEVERTHELESS, there is a lingering concern that someday later this decade, perhaps even next year, oil prices might suddenly unravel, plummeting downward in uncontrolled fashion. If that were to happen, the world would experience an oil shock as severe in its economic impact as the two it suffered when prices rocketed upwards in the 1970's. **********''It would kill off Mexico - a major non-OPEC producer - along with some banks down in Texas,'' says a former high government official. Other national and regional economies would be virtually flattened, oil companies would give up most of their drilling as unprofitable and scores of banks with huge loan portfolios tied to energy would face the prospect of failure. **********Not the least of the casualties would be OPEC, which is hardly eager to lose huge chunks of income while it awaits the turnaround in the 1990's. Indeed, in the new economics of oil, the United States and the OPEC nations are beginning to share the common goal of a stable, relatively high oil price, although they part company on details. The United States would applaud a moderate decline in prices; the OPEC nations would resist even that. **********''A precipitate fall in oil prices by a substantial amount, to say $15-to-$20 a barrel, could have an immediate impact on many countries,'' said Walter J. Levy, an energy analyst. ''Major banks would be very worried. It would effect Britain disastrously. And oil states such as Texas and California would be severely harmed.'' **********But if an unraveling of prices is to be avoided, there are also powerful arguments in favor of a moderate decline in oil price - one that might eventually settle at about $24 a barrel, or $5 below the current benchmark price of $29 a barrel that OPEC is trying to preserve. Already, economists are talking about the beneficial results of the last OPEC price cut, in the spring of 1983, when similar pressures from Nigeria and Britain prompted OPEC to cut its crude prices by $5 a barrel. **********That 1983 price cut helped to push down the inflation rate in the United States and, in the opinion of many economists, may have been as much a reason for the current economic recovery as President Reagan's tax cuts. It ''added $22 billion to the spendable income of Americans, an increase roughly equivalent to the first two rounds of the Reagan tax cuts combined,'' said Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. ''The cut strengthened what looked to be a fragile recovery,'' he said. And he added that with the economic recovery once again showing signs of petering out, the Reagan Administration would probably like to see OPEC give in this week to a $2-a-barrel price cut. **********INDEED, Data Resources Inc. is already calculating the effect on the American economy if OPEC **********somehow agreed to a $5-a-barrel price cut before the end of this year. The forecasting firm said that the Consumer Price Index would drop by half a percentage point in each of the next three years and so would general interest rates. There would be an equivalent rise in the Gross National Product and auto production would rise by 700,000 vehicles - about 10 percent of current annual production - over the entire three years. **********Airlines, truckers, fast-food merchandisers and land developers also would profit from less expensive energy. Other benefits would be so indirect that analysts would spend months figuring them out. For instance, aluminum makers, although they do not use petroleum in production processes, gain because commercial airline manufacturers - heavy users of the metal - would do brisker business with cheaper oil. **********Even the losers - oil companies, coal producers, some coal-carrying railroads and banks with big loans to drillers or third world countries - would not suffer too much from a moderate price decline, in the opinion of many economists. ''A $1 or $2 cut can be handled,'' Mr. Levy said. And the chief economist of a major oil company says that ''a modest price reduction contributes to a stronger general economic performance.'' **********Ironically, the Federal Government might be hurt the most by a moderate price decline. Washington absorbs up to 80 cents of the first $4 reduction in the price of every barrel of oil, because of its windfall profits tax. Britain and Norway have the same problem, making their recent price reductions bitter medicine. **********It is no wonder then that this week's OPEC meeting assumes something of the character of a sporting event with fans rooting for opposing sides - the start of a moderate price slide vs. the status quo. But that is probably a distorted view of the larger reality. What is going on is a complex betting game, with multifarious players and interests clashing against the changing facts of geology, economics and demography. **********Here is OPEC's problem: Companies and countries do not like tying their purchases to a group that would truly love to be the tight cartel it has never quite succeeded in being. So they buy oil from non- OPEC producers first. As a result, OPEC has seen its share of world oil output plummet to 32 percent in 1983 from 54 percent in 1973. This is the consequence of two things: First, non-OPEC output from the North Sea, Mexico and elsewhere has soared. Second, consumption in the face of high oil prices fell in 1983 to its lowest point in 12 years, with approximately 35 percent of that reduction being attributed to conservation. Partly as a result, nearly one-third of the world's refining capacity is not being used. **********All this is already common knowledge in the new economics of oil. What is just emerging as equally important involves the kinds of oil now being produced and purchased. The oil industry has invested huge amounts of money - $18.2 billion in 1982 alone - to build or renovate refineries to process heavier, viscous petroleum that OPEC and other producers sell more cheaply than their benchmark brand, Arab light crude. The thick stuff has traditionally been used as the fuel burned by utilities and industry, and now it is being used to make gasoline, aviation and other products once produced almost exclusively from higher-quality light oil. **********THE upshot is that producers of **********the once-prized lighter crudes - **********Britain, Norway and Nigeria - are having trouble peddling their wares and are taking the logical step of shaving prices. **********International banks, although clearly nervous, see some blessings in this situation. They have billions in loans outstanding to Mexico and Venezuela, two major non-OPEC oil producers, and they might welcome a reduction in the price of light oil, if it strengthened the price of the heavy crude these financially troubled nations pump. **********But from OPEC's perspective, Nigeria's willingness to act unilaterally, as it did this month, is a troublesome chink in the armor of OPEC strategy. That country's financial woes were enough to topple a government recently and OPEC allows Nigeria to produce just 70 percent of what it is capable of pumping. Meanwhile, Mexico, not an OPEC member but certainly financially strained, pumps merrily along at a 90 percent clip. The wages of OPEC fidelity at a time of shrinking energy demand are crystal clear: Its members saw their export earnings tumble from $267.7 billion in 1980 to $149 billion in 1983, with a further reduction expected this year. **********A waiting game is the result. Currently, decreases in the use of ''stationary'' oil - that is, oil used for heating and power, but not in transportation - is more than offsetting slight gains in the transportation sector. But at some point, all the large- scale substitutions of coal, nuclear power and natural gas for ''stationary'' oil uses will be mostly completed. Then, the upward movement in transportation demand is expected to continue and to become dominant. OPEC's expectation is that this turning point will come within a decade. **********Similarly, OPEC looks forward to the day that Alaskan and North Sea production begins a steep decline, an event that is likely to occur by the end of the decade. They could only rejoice that such promising prospects as Sohio's Mukluk property in the Beaufort Sea and Exxon's Destin Anticline in the Gulf of Mexico turned out to be dry, and that expensive technologies may be reaching their limits in wringing black gold from existing fields. **********MOREOVER, such insurance policies as synthetic fuels have become almost fading memories, while inventory levels have become much, much tighter - not because the oil glut has abated but because companies don't want to finance these inventories at high interest rates and are confident that oil is readily available. It is also the case that OPEC is, in a sense, reluctantly banking its oil, with a production level of only 17.5 million barrels a day - just over half the amount of a decade ago - while the rest of the world produces all out. **********But, to most analysts, that hardly seems enough to make OPEC influential in the current situation. In today's world, the new wisdom is that oil revenue in the bank is worth more than a depreciating asset in the ground, a reversal of the thinking of OPEC's founders. **********What helps to make oil in the ground less valuable is that worldwide reserves have risen in comparison to production, a surprisingly favorable trend. In fact, this year's oil production - about 44 million barrels in the non-Communist world - would be even weaker were it not for the exceptionally cold weather last winter and the long British coal strike. **********But perhaps the most important factor working against OPEC's long- term strategy is that the world seems likely never to need as much oil as most people once thought it would. A major oil company as recently as the mid-1970's was positing that demand for OPEC oil in 1985 would be as much as 50 million barrels daily. Instead, it is slightly over 17.5 million. **********The lack of demand for Saudi Arabia's oil is more dramatic still. The predictions were that the world would be guzzling some 20 million barrels a day of Saudi crude by now, and American policymakers less than a decade ago were making nervous trips to the desert kingdom to urge the royal family to quickly increase its production capability to handle this demand. Instead, the Saudis, although still OPEC's biggest producers, have tightened the faucet to 4.5 million barrels daily, and might go as low as 3 million barrels as a result of tomorrow's meeting. That's roughly 25 percent of capacity. **********A major reason for the decline in demand is the gains that have been made in conservation and energy efficiency. And these gains will not likely be lost, mostly because these gains are largely the result of technology not the behavior of people. For instance, although Americans are using slightly more gasoline this year than last year - partly because it is cheaper - the automobile companies are adopting such technologies as an automatic transmission that is as fuel- efficient as manual shift. Already a big car like the Buick Electra gets 17 miles a gallon in city driving, compared with the 9 or 10 miles that similar models got in the mid-1970's. **********Roger Sant, a former top energy official in the Ford Administration and now head of a company selling energy-efficiency equipment to industry, said this process would continue as long as the price of oil remains above $15 a barrel. **********Moreover, the very structure of the market has become so competitive that a return to OPEC price-setting power might be difficult. Flexibility, not the security of a guaranteed source of supply, is what concerns buyers. Today, contracts are written for a maximum of three months, rather than five years as formerly. As much as half the oil in the world is probably traded on a spot basis, rather than through the traditional contract purchases. That's up from 5 to 10 percent at the beginning of the decade. **********Indicative of the change has been the tremendous growth in the trading of crude oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange. These contracts, representing a promise to deliver a fixed amount of oil at an agreed-upon price at a fixed date in the future, are even more sensitive to price change than the spot market and therefore have become a major vehicle for oil purchases. Since the new contracts began to be offered in March 1983, daily volumes have grown beyond the amount of crude produced in the United States in a day. **********''When the market speaks, OPEC now listens,'' Mr. Yergin said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/21/busin.body_text: **********The Economy  The economy grew at a 4.5 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter and inflation remained subdued, the Commerce Department reported. The rate, although less than half the 9.7 percent surge of last spring, was seen as encouraging by officials. However, they said high interest rates and the high- valued dollar, linked by many economists to Federal budget deficits, had caused a sharp deterioration in the trade balance and had stunted what otherwise would have been much stronger growth in the economy. Moreover, New York City has joined the state and Federal governments in taxing some of those individuals who exercised such options last year. (27.) **********Markets **********The basic measure of the money supply rose $3.8 billion in the week ended Jan. 11, the Fed reported. The move marked a further erosion of the law barring interstate banking. Citicorp immediately consummated the acquisitions, which were bitterly opposed at the local level. (27.) I.B.M., denying any problems, indicated it had cut its Miniscribe orders because it had taken on other suppliers of the devices. I.B.M.'s stock fell, too, however, as did that of many of its suppliers. (27.) **********Wilson Foods, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, rejected a reorganization proposal by Occidental Petroleum. The company has been hurt by bad weather, fluctuating sugar prices and a hotel and retailing slump. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Audi, the luxury car division of Volkswagen, is trying to change the image of four- wheel-drive cars, from ungainly vehicles best suited for off-road use to sleek, sure-footed boulevard cruisers. **********The experiment is too new for an assessment of its success, but the attempt is an indication of how technology is replacing styling as the way to differentiate car models, particularly in the higher-priced end of the market. **********The Audi system has already prompted imitations in Europe and at least one American auto company, Chrysler, has four-wheel-drive models under development. **********Early this year Audi introduced its 4000 Quattro model in the United States. It resembles the older 4000S model on the outside, but all four wheels are power-driven, instead of the usual two. **********Audi officials say the car is different from jeeps and other four-wheel- drive vehicles of the past because it is as low to the ground as conventional passenger cars, is always in four- wheel-drive operation and is not intended for off-road use. **********'A Performance Car' Unlike conventional four-wheel- drive vehicles, which get significantly lower gas mileage when in four-wheel drive, the 4000 Quattro's rating is 21 miles a gallon in the city, only one mile a gallon less than Audi's comparable two-wheel-drive car, according to the 1984 gas mileage guide of the Environmental Protection Agency. **********''This is a street car, a performance car,'' said Peter Fischer, vice president for Volkswagen of America's Porsche-Audi division. ''All- wheel-drive gives a consistent handling response under all conditions. The advantage is greatest in ice, snow and rain, but we feel it handles better even on a dry road.'' **********The 4000 Quattro, which is priced at $16,830, is a toned-down version of Audi's $35,000 turbocharged Quattro model, which has dominated international rallies for the past few years. Audi officials say they plan to make four-wheel-drive available in all models in the next few years. **********The success of what is known as the ''big Quattro'' has prompted imitations from Porsche and Mazda for rally competition, and it has other companies trying to decide if four- wheel drive is going to become a basic characteristic of higher-priced sports sedans, or if it will just be an interesting technological exercise with limited appeal, like Mazda's rotary engine. **********Chrysler Project **********Carroll Shelby, a former racing driver who now develops high-performance cars for the Chrysler Corporation, is working on four-wheel- drive derivatives of the company's familiar front-wheel-drive sedans. ''At some point you need four-wheel drive just to get the power to the ground,'' he said. ''Above 200 horsepower, you can't do it with two wheels, even using fat tires.'' **********Mr. Shelby said he estimated that 30,000 sporty four-wheel-drive sedans could be sold a year in the United States, and he expects the market to grow. ''I think we are looking at hundreds of thousands a year worldwide,'' he said. **********At least 18 European, Japanese and American car companies displayed prototype four-wheel-drive models at last year's auto show in Frankfurt. **********''We are interested enough in it that we are studying our own technology,'' said James Hamilton, an engineer with BMW of North America. **********Added Carl Flesher, a BMW marketing specialist: ''There is a technological confrontation occurring, and Audi will use this to say they are the technology leader. The question is: Will it sell cars?'' **********Subaru's Success **********It has for Subaru, although in a much lower price range. The Japanese car maker has four-wheel drive available in all of its subcompact cars and pickup trucks, although the technology involved is more conventional than Audi's. Officials of Subaru of America said about half of its sales of 156,000 last year were four-wheel- drive vehicles. **********Subaru, which advertises its products as ''inexpensive and built to stay that way,'' is edging up into the more profitable sport sedan market, as are other Japanese car makers. Subaru's top-of-the-line car this year is a four- wheel-drive hardtop, with a fuel-injected, turbocharged engine, costing $11,063. **********Most auto industry analysts say the principal appeal of four-wheel drive for on-the-road vehicles will be in the North, where snow-covered and wet roads are more of a problem. **********''Once a driver has spent a winter with four-wheel drive he would not want to be without it,'' said David E. Davis Jr., editor of Car and Driver, an auto magazine based in Ann Arbor, Mich. ''The benefits in this kind of a climate are unarguable.'' He said Audi in particular had ''decided the way of the future is technological difference rather than cosmetics.'' **********The 4000 Quattro model costs about $3,600 more than the two-wheel-drive 4000S model, and about 400 a month have been sold in the United States since its introduction in January.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/21/busin.body_text: **********Many executives endowed with incentive stock options may soon discover that these most cherished of company perks, already eroded by new Federal laws, are being subjected to higher state taxes as well. Sometimes, the state tax bite is worse. **********In leafing through 1983 income tax return booklets, executives who work in New York City will learn that the state and city have quietly followed the lead of the Federal Government in taxing some individuals who exercised incentive stock options last year. Even executives who escape Washington's alternative minimum tax on such options may find themselves facing state and city tax obligations. **********The reason is that the state and city ''minimum taxes'' are imposed on top of the taxpayer's regular tax bill and the thresholds for being subject to the taxes are so low that executives who had hoped to reap just a $5,000 gain in exercising their stock options will have to at least go through extra computations to determine if they are liable. **********''It's a sleeper,'' said Richard Stricof, a tax partner in the accounting firm of Seidman & Seidman. ''An individual may be facing an additional and unexpected tax at the end of the year just for the privilege of exercising an incentive stock option. It is another indication that working and residing in New York is very costly when it comes to taxes.'' **********'Preference Items' **********The state and city minimum taxes are imposed on certain so-called preference items, including the gain or ''bargain element'' of an incentive stock option at the time of exercise and the 60 percent untaxed portion of long-term capital gains. The total amount of these preference items can generally be reduced only by a $5,000 specific deduction and the individual's New York State personal income tax. The remainder is then taxed by the state at a rate of 6 percent and by the city at a 2.5 percent rate. A 10 percent income tax surcharge in effect for 1983 in New York City effectively raises the city levy to 2.75 percent. **********Furthermore, with New York State, unlike the Federal Government, still taxing unearned income at higher rates than earned income, the tax preferences will have a detrimental effect on the calculation of New York State's regular income tax. The situation arises because the preference items will reduce the amount of earned income taxable at a lower rate and increase the amount of unearned income taxable at a higher rate. **********Created in 1981 **********Companies have long awarded stock options as an incentive to key employees, giving them the right to purchase a specified number of shares at a set price over a fixed period of time. Congress made the options more attractive in 1981 by creating ''incentive stock options'' as a new tax-favored breed. Employees could exercise their incentive options and buy the shares - which could have greatly appreciated in value - without having to pay tax on the gains until they finally sold their holdings. **********And if the stock was sold after holding it a year and a minimum of two years after the option was granted, profits would be taxed at capital gains rates of no more than 20 percent, rather than at ordinary rates of up to 50 percent. **********This generous tax treatment was similar to that accorded ''qualified'' employee stock options, which were phased out by the Tax Reform Act of 1976. But incentive options were deemed even one step better because they were not included on the list of preference items that might subject an individual to an extra tax liability in the form of Federal, state or city ''minimum taxes.'' Qualified options had been on that list. **********Beginning with 1983 returns, however, executives who exercise their incentive stock options will again face the potential threat of being hit by the Federal, state and city minimum taxes on their gains. **********Minimum Tax Broadened **********In the search for ways to raise revenues and trim the Federal deficit, Congress decided in 1982 to broaden the scope of the alternative minimum tax as a means of reinflating the tax bills of many more upper-income individuals who made heavy use of various tax benefits to reduce or eliminate their regular tax liability. **********Under the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982, the ''bargain element'' at the time of exercise of incentive options was added to the list of preference items that can trigger the alternative minimum tax. Taxpayers with preference items have to compute their tax liability under both the regular method and the alternative tax method and pay whichever bill is higher. The alternative tax rate is only 20 percent but it is assessed on a much broader base of income, including items that are not taxed under the regular method, such as the bargain element of incentive options and the 60 percent portion of long-term capital gains. **********As is automatically the case under New York statutes, the state and city tax laws were changed to conform with the Federal law, and incentive stock options were added to the list of minimum tax preference items. **********The state taxes are imposed not only on residents but also on those from out of state who work in New York, subject to calculations based on the number of days worked in the state. The city taxes affect only New York City residents. **********Added Risk **********The new taxes create an added risk for option holders should the price of the stock fall after the option is exercised. Because the taxes can be imposed at the time the options are exercised on a gain that may never be realized, an individual could find that more was paid in taxes than was gained from the sale of the stock. ''And you'd never be able to get the tax back,'' said William Katz, a partner in the accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney. **********Mr. Stricof of Seidman & Seidman gave the example of an executive in the top tax bracket filing a joint return who exercised an option to buy 1,000 shares of company stock for $15 each when the stock was trading at $35. The paper profit came to $20,000. **********If the executive had no other big preference items, the alternative minimum tax probably could be avoided, partly with the help of a $40,000 personal exemption. But the state and city taxes might still have to be paid because the bargain element can generally be offset by only the amount of the specific deduction - $5,000 - plus the amount of regular state income taxes paid, which in this executive's example is assumed to be $11,000. **********Thus, $4,000 of his $20,000 gain would be subject to the state minimum tax of 6 percent and the city minimum tax of 2.75 percent. The tax bill would total $240 for the state and $110 for the city. To reduce the pain, these taxes could be claimed next year as an itemized deduction on the executive's Federal return.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/24/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********In a ''Prospects'' column observation on Father's Day, a cosmetics industry analyst, Jack Salzman, seemed unable to decide whether wives give Dad fragrance because they can get a ''free or reduced-price umbrella'' at the same time, or because of a feminist plot to get even with those men for giving them perfume, presumably on Mother's Day. **********In Mr. Salzman's world of power and money, it may be impossible to understand the historic appeal and pleasure of fragrance. True, they don't make anyone richer, thinner or younger - only happier.  ANNETTE GREEN Executive Director The Fragrance Fondation New York, June 18

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/28/busin.body_text: **********Scovill Inc., which is now on center stage in Wall Street's latest takeover drama, was not always such a sought- after property. **********The company had humble beginnings as a maker of brass buttons for Civil War uniforms. It spent a century as a brass fabricator in Waterbury, Conn., and a decade ago was floundering with others in the brass industry. It was then that Malcolm Baldrige, who is now Secretary of Commerce, shook it out of its lethargy and redirected it as a diversified manufacturer. **********Today, the company makes Hamilton Beach appliances, Yale locks and Nutone door chimes and security systems. From its strikingly modern headquarters building in Waterbury it directs some 80 plants throughout the world. **********Leader in Major Markets **********''It is No. 1 or No. 2 in all of its major markets,'' said David Leibowitz, an analyst at the American Securities Corporation. ''It has a strong balance sheet, an excellent consumer franchise, good distribution and good shelf space. **********''Wall Street, however, did not particularly value the company at a high price,'' Mr. Leibowitz continued. ''Taken together, these factors make it an attractive company to potential buyers.'' **********The Belzberg brothers, the Canadian investors, apparently would agree. They have offered $35 a share, or $430 million, for Scovill. But the company appears ready to fiercely protect itself. **********Defensive Measures Considered **********Scovill has called the Belzberg offer, made through First City Properties Inc. of California, inadequate and is exploring defensive measures, including a sale to someone else, liquidation or an acquisition of its own. **********The Belzbergs are said to be considering an increase in their offer. Wall Street arbitragers, who seek to make a profit in the outcome, believe that, one way or another, Scovill will bring more than $35 a share. The stock closed yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange at $39, unchanged on the day. **********However, not everyone thinks the company is worth that much. One analyst, who did not wish to be identified, said the book value of the company was $20 a share. ''That's a 75 percent premium over book, for openers,'' he said. ''Unless there's an oil well under company headquarters, the Belzbergs may be paying through the nose for it.'' **********Of course, as the analyst pointed out, the Belzbergs may have other fish to fry. They might need Scovill's earnings to offset tax losses, or they may hope to profit on their move even if their bid if not successful. **********Analysts Praise Management **********Scovill's management gets fairly high marks from analysts. Its balance sheet, Value Line said, ''is looking better and better,'' with long- term debt now 26 percent of capital, a marked improvement from 44 percent in 1979, and earnings that are expected to increase in 1985. **********''It got that way in part by pruning an awful lot of dead wood over a few managements,'' said John W. Adams, an analyst at Adams, Harkness & Hill Inc. of Boston. **********He credited Mr. Baldrige for getting out of the original brass business - ''a pretty good decision in retrospect,'' he said. Mr. Baldrige sold his stock in Scovill when he became Commerce Secretary, his daughter said yesterday at the Baldrige home in Woodbury, Conn., and Mr. Baldrige now stays out of Scovill affairs. **********William F. Andrews, who took over as chairman when Mr. Baldrige went to Washington in 1981, continued the pruning of smaller and unprofitable operations, Mr. Adams noted. **********Three Divisions Called Strong **********Currently, the company has six divisions, characterized by Mr. Adams, the Boston analyst, as three above-average achievers and three below - results that are better than most diversified companies, he says. **********Mr. Adams said the stronger divisions are Nutone, Hamilton Beach and the apparel fastener unit. **********Nutone, in addition to making door chimes and security systems, also produces radio intercoms, exhaust systems and bath cabinets. The unit has performed well in the past as starts in housing have risen. **********Hamilton Beach products, which include blenders, food processors, knives, drip coffee makers and irons, are generally priced at the lower end of the market and have been helped by extensive advertising. **********Scovill's link to the past, brass buttons, have been largely replaced by plastic. But Scovill is still one of the world's largest makers of apparel fasteners. An upsurge in this business began a year ago and is attributed to more designer use of snaps and zippers for functional and decorative use. **********The other three divisions are security products, including Yale locks; the automation group, including pneumatic equipment, and the automotive group - Schrader tire valves and other accessories. **********Scovill's Yale unit, acquired in 1979, is a leader in electronic locks for the hotel industry. In the modern units, cards have replaced the standard brass key. A code on the card is scanned by the room lock and, if correct, the card will open the door. **********The automation group sells products to manufacturers of machinery and equipment for rubber, fabricated metals, transportation, paper, chemicals and oil and gas. **********Scovill has been having problems with the automotive group, according to the company, because the shift in tire and tube production overseas has created too much domestic capacity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/01/busin.main_headline: STOCKS ARE MIXED AS THE DOW LISES 2.51
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/01/busin.print_headline: STOCKS ARE MIXED AS THE DOW LISES 2.51
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/01/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices ended mixed yesterday in heavier trading following their sharp selloff on Tuesday. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which is made up of 30 major companies, ended the session down 2.51 points, to 1,154.63, after tumbling almost 23 points the day before. **********However, in the overall market, advancing equities on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered those that fell by a ratio of almost 4 to 3. On Tuesday, losers outscored winners by more than a 5-to-2 margin. **********The market's weakness on Tuesday was attributed mostly to reports that Administration officials had denied that President Reagan had relaxed his opposition to tax increases to reduce Federal budget deficits. **********'Dominated by Speculators' **********Michael Metz of Oppenheimer & Company said the market's extreme volatility in the last several sessions indicates that serious investors have withdrawn to the sidelines and ''the area is now dominated by speculators and short-term traders.'' **********Reflecting the improved performance yesterday, the two other major market indicators finished higher.  The exchange's composite index of 1,500 issues rose 0.20, to 90.44, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks advanced 0.24, to 157.06. **********Turnover on the Big Board expanded to 92.8 million shares yesterday, from 91 million shares the day before. **********Before trading began, the Commerce Department announced that its index of leading economic indicators rose 1.1 percent in January, the best showing in three months and up from a revised gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in December. **********Most analysts had expected a large increase in the economic indicators because of very favorable economic reports in the last several weeks. Although a robust economy generally buoys corporate earnings, it decreases the possibility that the Federal Reserve will loosen its credit reins and thus lower interest rates. **********Mr. Metz of Oppenheimer also noted that an advance in equities is very unlikely in the immediate future because ''bonds offer too much competition currently because of their higher yields.'' **********Rumors Spur Texaco **********The best gainer in the most-active list was Texaco, which advanced 1 1/2 points, to 45, on a unconfirmed report that Bass Brothers, which now holds a 9.8 percent stake in Texaco, was forming a consortium with the Pennzoil Company to purchase Texaco. Pennzoil rose 3/8, to 38 3/8. **********The Gulf Corporation topped the most-active list and eased 1/8, to 69. After the close, the company reported it was holding preliminary merger talks with several unidentified companies. Mesa Petroleum, which has begun a partial tender offer with several partners for Gulf, gained 5/8, to 18 3/4, in active trading. Two companies often mentioned as suitors for Gulf finished slightly lower: Atlantic Richfield fell 5/8, to 45, and Standard of California eased 1/2, to 37. **********Vulcan Inc. was a big percentage gainer, rising 3 1/8, to 12 3/4, after the Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation proposed a merger with Vulcan. Ampco inched ahead 1/8, to 17 5/8. **********Connecticut Energy Up 2 3/8 **********Connecticut Energy was up 2 3/8, to 29 5/8, after its board increased the quarterly dividend to 76 cents a share from 70 cents. **********Although most of the volatile technology issues finished with minor price changes, Motorola, Data General and Texas Instruments each rose a point or more. **********Prices on the American Stock Exchange were higher, with the market- value index up 1.42, to 210.22. Prairie Oil Royalties gained 2 3/8, to 21, after the company said its profits for 1983 rose to $3.24 a share, from $2.92 a share the year before. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index added 1.02, to 252.57. The RSR Corporation was up 1 3/4, to 8 1/4 bid, on the news the company had received a $9-a-share takeover offer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/04/world.main_headline: SOVIET PRODUCTON OF OIL SHOWS AN UNUSUAL DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/04/world.print_headline: SOVIET PRODUCTON OF OIL SHOWS AN UNUSUAL DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/04/world.body_text: **********The output of oil in the Soviet Union, the world's largest producer, has started an unusual downward trend in the last five months, according to official statistics. But Western experts are divided on whether this represents a temporary dip or a long-expected peaking of production. **********According to official Soviet statistics received in the United States, the declining trend began in October. Through the winter and into January, monthly figures reported in the Moscow economic weekly Ekonomicheskaya Gazeta have shown a performance below that of the corresponding period a year before. **********The trend appears to have continued through February. In the past, output in any given month generally improved on the previous year's production level. **********Although daily output is still reported to be in excess of 12 million barrels a day, compared with 8.7 million barrels in the United States and 6 million in Saudi Arabia, future oil production is a matter of some importance to the Soviet Union. The Russians export one- fourth of their oil output and derive 60 percent of their foreign exchange earnings from oil shipments to the West, mostly to Western Europe. **********The oil earnings are used to buy high technology and grain, and if the recent decline were the beginning of a trend, it might ultimately affect Moscow's ability to pay for these imports. **********''It is too early to call,'' said Jan Vanous, senior economist of Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates, a Washington-based research organization that specializes in the Soviet economy. **********Mr. Vanous said there had been reports of a mild winter that might have caused transport problems and slowed oil production in the marshy forests of West Siberia. Despite temperatures dropping regularly to 40 degrees below zero, winter is a period of high activity in the region, because the freezing of the normally soggy ground makes possible cross-country hauling of drilling rigs and other heavy equipment. **********The oil industry, like other Soviet economic activity, generally starts the year slowly and works up to a peak in the last quarter, both because of the winter operating conditions and because of the practice of ''storming,'' a last-minute effort to fulfill the annual plan. But in 1983 fourth-quarter output fell below that of the second and third quarters. **********Another American specialist on Soviet energy, Prof. John W. Campbell of Indiana University in Bloomington, said Soviet drillers had been pressing the potential of the West Siberian fields to make up for declines in older fields. **********''The effect of that pressure had to end sometime, and that time may now be at hand,'' he said. He also noted that the Russians had traditionally injected large amounts of water into oilfields to stimulate the oil flow, and that the share of water in the emerging fluid might have risen to the point where less oil was now being extracted. **********The heavy use of water injection was one of the factors cited in the late 1970's, notably by the Central Intelligence Agency, in predictions that Soviet oil production would reach a peak some time between 1978 and 1982. **********The dip in oil output that has been officially reported since October is the first such sustained decline since the Soviet Union, with the aid of the West Siberian discoveries in the 1960's and early 1970's, surged into first place among world oil producers in 1974. **********The growth was aided by the large Siberian reserves concentrated in a single giant field, Samotlor, near the new town of Nizhnevartovsk, which alone yields 3 million barrels a day, or one- half of Siberian production and one- fourth of the Soviet Union's total oil output. But Soviet oil production growth slowed after 1980, when the Russians had to turn to smaller fields, each of which had to be reached across trackless forest. **********Last year West Siberia fell short of its output plan for the first time since its oil development began.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/05/busin.body_text: **********A lottery originally scheduled for today to allocate options trading on individual stocks, including the seven new telephone company stocks, has been delayed pending a decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission on the application by the New York Stock Exchange to trade listed options. Currently options on listed stocks are traded at the American Stock Exchange, the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and the Pacific Stock Exchange. **********The S.E.C. wrote those exchanges in early March and suggested that they make a provision to include the Big Board in the lottery selection process, or defer making the allocations until the S.E.C. decides whether to grant the Big Board's request to trade options on individual stocks. The exchanges decided to delay the lottery. **********Under the lottery procedure, when new stocks come up for options listing, the four exchanges call a lottery and each exchange gets a turn at picking the stocks in which it will be the principal market maker.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/01/world.main_headline: MANILA JUSTICE IS STILL STUDYING AQUINO FINDINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/01/world.print_headline: MANILA JUSTICE IS STILL STUDYING AQUINO FINDINGS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/01/world.body_text: **********The Government ombudsman said today that he had begun evaluating evidence against the armed forces Chief of Staff and others implicated in the Benigno S. Aquino Jr. assassination, but had not decided whether to hold public pretrial hearings. **********The ombudsman, Justice Bernardo Fernandez, whose office investigates criminal complaints against Government personnel and prosecutes them before the courts, said he could not say how soon his office could make a ruling on whether there was sufficient evidence to bring the case to trial. **********The Chief of Staff, Gen. Fabian C. Ver, who has gone on a ''leave of absence'' to prepare his defense, has waived his right to a preliminary investigation to speed up proceedings against him, the Philippine News Agency reported. **********The Government agency quoted General Ver as saying a delay in the proceedings would be prejudicial not only to him ''but also to the broader interest of justice and the prestige of the noble profession of arms.'' **********A majority opinion of the civilian board that investigated the August 1983 killing of Mr. Aquino, Ferdinand E. Marcos's chief rival, found General Ver and 25 other military personnel ''indictable for the premeditated killing'' of the former senator and Rolando Galman, the man the Government says killed Mr. Aquino. **********General Ver has denied the charges. **********Justice Fernandez said he might call public hearings if he found a need for further clarification on the charges to enable him to decide if there is a ''probable cause'' for trial. **********''But the moment I don't find anything there, I can dismiss the case,'' the ombudsman said. **********If Justice Fernandez finds sufficient evidence against any of the accused, the case will go to trial before a special court that tries civil servants. The court has previously handled mostly graft cases. **********Justice Fernandez talked with reporters after a closed-door meeting with the chairman of the board the investigated the slaying, Corazon Agrava, and a board lawyer. Justice Fernandez said they discussed ''details'' of how the board could help the ombudsman's office in evaluating the case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/01/world.main_headline: GORBACHEV'S HIGH RANK IN SOVIET IS AFFIRMED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/01/world.print_headline: GORBACHEV'S HIGH RANK IN SOVIET IS AFFIRMED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/01/world.body_text: **********Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the youngest member of the ruling Politburo and the one considered closest to Yuri V. Andropov before the Soviet leader's death, seemed to affirm his high standing in the hierarchy today when he addressed voters only two days before Konstantin U. Chernenko, the party leader. **********Speaking in connection with elections next Sunday to the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, Mr. Gorbachev focused on economic issues, listing many of the experiments and programs that had been begun under Mr. Andropov in an effort to rouse the Soviet economy. **********The emphasis suggested to Western diplomats that Mr. Gorbachev, who originally joined the Politburo as an expert in agriculture, had been given broader responsibility over the economy, perhaps to pursue the changes initiated by Mr. Andropov. **********Mr. Gorbachev passed only lightly over foreign affairs in his speech, which was published in Izvestia, the Government newspaper. **********He seemed to strike a less strident tone in referring to the United States than either Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko or Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov, and he declared that Moscow was ready ''to use any real chance for fair negotiations, for reaching practical accords.'' There had been earlier signals that Mr. Gorbachev, who is 52 years old, had assumed a strong position in the Politburo after Mr. Chernenko was named the party leader. Mr. Gorbachev had made the closing comments at the Central Committee session that voted Mr. Chernenko into office, and he stood to the right of the new leader after his appointment. **********Western diplomats said the timing of Mr. Gorbachev's election speech seemed to be the strongest evidence so far of his standing. In the weeks just before the elections, in which all candidates are officially designated and unopposed, members of the leadership make speeches in the constituencies to which they have been assigned. **********Mr. Gorbachev spoke in the North Caucasus village of Ipatovo, in his home province of Stavropol, which he headed as the regional party leader from 1970 to 1978 before being summoned to Moscow and rising to national prominence. **********The leaders generally make their election speeches in ascending order of importance, and the last two are reserved for the Prime Minister, Nikolai A. Tikhonov, and the party chief, Mr. Chernenko, who is scheduled to speak Friday. By speaking just before Mr. Tikhonov, and after such senior members as Mr. Gromyko and Marshal Ustinov, Mr. Gorbachev seemed to establish his high ranking. **********In his speech, Mr. Gorbachev listed many of the priorities Mr. Andropov had set when he came to power in November 1982 - modernizing industrial technology, improving management, bolstering labor discipline, fighting corruption, increasing farm output. **********Mr. Gorbachev was generally regarded as the Politburo member who was responsible for carrying on many of Mr. Andropov's projects as his health deteriorated. Mr. Gorbachev also played a role in efforts to bring new blood into regional party machines and in cracking down on corruption. **********In his speech, Mr. Gorbachev spoke of ''further enforcing order, being more exacting, organized and disciplined, and waging an uncompromising struggle with negative phenomena that come into conflict with our morals and with socialist legality.'' **********Mr. Gorbachev's treatment of foreign affairs was too brief to give diplomats much grist for analysis. **********However, the Government press agency Tass drew attention to the stiff stances already assumed by Mr. Gromyko and Marshal Ustinov in their speeches. **********Tass quoted them to the effect that, before relations could improve, the United States had to take ''practical steps,'' which they said had not yet become evident. **********A similar theme was struck today by Yuri Kornilov, a Tass analyst, who said Washington had shown no readiness to start rectifying relations with Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/21/world.main_headline: Peace Corps Volunteer Is Killed in Philippines
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/21/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Peace Corps Volunteer Is Killed in Philippines
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/21/world.body_text: **********An American Peace Corps volunteer on the central Philippine island of Cebu was shot and killed at his beachfront cottage during an apparent robbery this week, the authorities said today. **********Charles Turner, a 40-year-old former Air Force officer from Omaha, Neb., was found at dawn Wednesday with a bullet wound in the back of his head, the officials said. Investigators said cash, an electric typewriter, a fan, a ring and two cameras were missing. **********The United States Embassy in Manila said the incident was under investigation. ''There's no evidence this was a political incident,'' Alan Croghan, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Manila, said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/26/world.main_headline: SEARCHING OF BAGS OF LIBYANS BARRED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/26/world.print_headline: SEARCHING OF BAGS OF LIBYANS BARRED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/26/world.body_text: **********Leon Brittan, the Home Secretary, said today that he could do nothing to stop those occupying the Libyan Embassy from taking with them evidence relating to the shooting of a British police constable when they leave in the next few days. **********Facing questions about the affair in the House of Commons for the first time, Mr. Brittan refused to commit himself to a public inquiry and said he could give no assurances that guns would not be carried out of the embassy in diplomatic bags. **********He evaded a series of questions about reports that American intelligence had given advance warning of the probability of an armed response to the demonstration against the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that was held outside the Libyan Embassy in St. James's Square last Tuesday. **********Mr. Brittan confirmed that the police would be unable to search diplomatic baggage carried by the 20 to 30 Libyans in the People's Bureau, as the embassy is called. They have been given until midnight Sunday to leave the country. **********No Violation of Protocol **********He said their luggage would not even be X-rayed, because that would violate protocol and because it would be of ''limited utility'' in any case. **********The Home Secretary, who has been coordinating the British Government's response to the killing a week ago Tuesday of Police Constable Yvonne Fletcher, promised that this country would press for revision of the Vienna Convention, which deals with diplomatic immunity. He suggested that in its present form it was inadequate and impossible to enforce. **********With the departure of the Libyans and the return of the British Embassy staff from Tripoli still the subject of delicate negotiations, Mr. Brittan gave only bare details of developments during the last week, and potential critics in the House held their fire. But they made it plain that they would pose very sharp questions next week. **********At a coroner's inquest today, Comdr. Bill Hucklesby, the head of Scotland Yard's antiterrorist branch, said several witnesses had told of seeing ''an automatic or semiautomatic firearm being pointed from the first floor of the Libyan People's Bureau, with smoke and flames coming from the barrel.'' The shots, he said, wounded 10 Libyan dissidents and killed Miss Fletcher. **********''I believe the person or persons responsible are still inside the People's Bureau,'' Commander Huckleby said at the brief inquest.   No Signs of Progress **********There were no signs of progress in arranging a timetable for the Libyans' departure, although a three-man team from Tripoli, headed by Col. Abd al- Rahman Shaibi, discussed the situation at length with officials at the Home Office and the Foreign Office. Colonel Shaibi, who has close ties to Colonel Qaddafi, also talked by telephone with the Libyans who have been besieged in the embassy for nine days.  Julia Miles, wife of the British Ambassador in Libya, Oliver Miles, said in a telephone interview from Tripoli that wives and children of British diplomats hoped to leave on a flight to London on Thursday. **********But she said she was not sure they would be permitted to do so, since 10 Britons are currently confined to the embassy by the Libyan police.   Diplomatic Relations Broken **********British officials here expressed concern that the Britons would be permitted to leave only after the Libyans have departed from Britain. Britain broke diplomatic relations with the Qaddafi Government on Sunday. **********The police announced the arrest of a fourth member of the Libyan ''revolutionary committee'' that took over the embassy in February, Matooq Matooq, but he was not immediately deported, as were two of his colleagues earlier this week. Another member was already in Libya. **********In the Commons, Mr. Brittan described the shooting of Miss Fletcher as ''a barbaric outrage,'' but he conceded that the police had concluded that without the cooperation of the occupants of the building, there was no way they could make a criminal charge stand up. He said the British were taking as ''robust'' an approach to the case as possible in the circumstances.   Support From Laborite **********Gerald Kaufman, the spokesman on home affairs for the opposition Labor Party, supported Mr. Brittan's approach, but served warning that next week he would ask a series of detailed questions about the course of negotiations with the Libyans and other matters. Other Members of Parliament, including David Steel, the leader of the Liberal Party, and David Owen, the leader of the Social Democrats, also said they wanted much more information later. **********Mr. Brittan indicated that he would oppose a banning of all demonstrations by foreigners in London, asking whether the House would support the prevention of Eastern European protests at the Soviet Embassy. **********Expressing the views of some of his colleagues, a Tory backbencher, Ivor Stanbrook, who is a lawyer, said that because the Libyans had violated international law they could not expect protection under the Vienna Convention. He suggested that, under the doctrine of ''hot pursuit'' of criminals, the police should have burst into the embassy immediately after the shooting and arrested the gunman.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/02/busin.main_headline: THE TOUGH JOB OF SELLING TRACTORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/02/busin.print_headline: THE TOUGH JOB OF SELLING TRACTORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/02/busin.body_text: **********ALGONA, Iowa **********IT is 7 A.M. The cars and pickup **********trucks out on Highway 18 still **********have their lights on in the chilled darkness of the early prairie morning. But inside Ernie Williams's John Deere dealership here, another desperate business day is already under way. And the 78-year-old farm equipment dealer himself is pressing his assembled troops. **********''These sales don't come to you anymore, boys,'' he says in a now familiar pep talk in the conference room. ''We gotta be like coon dogs and go out and find the customers. You can't wait like you used to.'' **********Nowadays Mr. Williams's management and sales team meets at dawn every morning before scattering across the 13-acre dealership and its five-county sales area in north central Iowa, about 400 miles west of Chicago. It is but one sign of the new aggressiveness and organization adopted by some farm equipment dealers in their struggle to survive the chronic depression in the farm equipment industry. The Williams employees exchange notes, suggest contacts and learn of new sales incentives and discounts in an effort to sell everything from an 8-cent cotter pin to a $194,000 combine. **********''During the peak business back in the 1970's,'' said Ed Wilcox, a 45-year- old former farmboy and the dealership's general manager, ''we had a 20 percent markup. Now it's anything above cost. We're just trying to carry ourselves through the tough times until the turnaround.'' **********It may take longer than expected. John Deere, Allis-Chalmers, International Harvester, Massey-Ferguson and J.I. Case, the major farm implement manufacturers in this $9 billion industry, are several years into tough times. High interest rates and operating costs, stagnant or declining crop prices and a strong dollar curbing agricultural export sales have spawned an era of financial uncertainty across the nation's heartland, the worst since the Depression of the 1930's. Farmers are keeping old equipment, or at best, buying used equipment. And analysts and industry insiders alike are wondering whether the farm equipment industry can ever recapture the financial vigor it had as recently as five years ago. **********ERNIE WILLIAMS Ltd., one of **********2,130 Deere dealers across **********North America and 141 in Iowa, is among the largest and most aggressive outlets in the Deere network. Mr. Williams, an energetic Iowa native who talks like the Pontiac dealer he once was and dresses in the yellow and green of the Deere zealot he now is, bought the dealership in 1950, when a new tractor cost $1,200, and a five- man, quarter-acre operation was big enough to sell them. **********Today, the dealership has 25 employees and does around $10 million in business annually. But new tractors cost nearly 10 times as much as they did in the 50's, and those few farmers who are buying new equipment are driving hard bargains. Mr. Williams says he will be very lucky to make $100,000 profit this year. Several nearby dealerships have closed. In fact, the number of farm equipment dealerships nationwide declined to 15,142 last year from 15,682 in 1981. And the purchase of International Harvester's farm equipment by Tenneco's J.I. Case Inc., announced last week, could accentuate the continuing decline in dealerships. **********Still, ''the business is out there,'' said Mr. Williams, motioning toward the flat grainlands that surround this community of 6,000. And so, on a dreary Wednesday recently, the assorted salesmen, managers and other employees embarked on yet another day of fighting for survival in the Darwinian world of American agriculture. **********By 8 A.M. salesman Dwight Rasmussen was enroute with one of Deere's new $9,500 mulch tillers to Edmond Otis's farm 10 miles east of town for a free plowing demonstration. Mr. Otis promised to be a hard sell. His wife, Judy, felt a new washing machine had a higher purchasing priority than new farm equipment, and these days, few farmers have the option of buying both. **********But Mr. Otis had just finished his corn harvest, the rain prohibited much field work, and Mr. Rasmussen was a friend. So the farmer agreed to the demonstration, and even invited his brother and son over to watch. **********Knowing the smaller size of Mr. Otis's current tractor, the salesman just happened to show up in a new 190- horsepower Deere tractor, which provided an opening for a subsidiary sales pitch. For two hours Mr. Rasmussen and one of the Otis men drove back and forth across part of the 80- acre cornfield. The salesman showed how the plow would save one complete pass over the field each year because it chops the old stalks as well as turning the soil for the next spring's planting. The new wider tool also plows four feet more per pass and distributes residue on the ground to combat winter wind erosion. **********The men also talked about the weather, crop yields, football and a possible special price for special customers. The farmer decided to see how the 10 newly plowed acres compared with the other 70, come spring. He figured he might need a new tractor too in a year or so. And this 190- horsepower model with the special transmission, digital readouts and sound insulation, he said, ''is a real Cadillac.'' **********Later, the salesman would add, ''We plant some seeds now and then ourselves.'' **********BACK at the dealership, Dave Ludwig, who runs the Deere lawn and garden shop, was arranging a sales display of toy tractors and combines, which match the real ones down to the letters D-E-E-R-E. ''If they play with John Deere equipment when they're little boys,'' he said with a smile, ''we figure they'll play with John Deere equipment when they're big boys.'' **********Neil Brandenburg, meanwhile, was painting a used combine head the familiar Deere green. It was an increasingly common chore, in that more than 90 percent of all sales now involve trade-ins. The other day the dealer even took a plow and old grain truck in trade toward a used tractor. ''We're making deals now we'd normally never think of doing,'' noted Mr. Wilcox. Often, the idea is just to get a farmer to step up from his aging tractor or combine to one a little less used. It's extra bookkeeping and finance-hunting, but it turns inventory. **********Many of the deals that Ernie Williams offers originate with the manufacturer. Through its dealerships Deere leases some equipment, and rents others. It gives discounts for cash. And it can provide financing, as 75 percent of today's buyers want, up from 50 percent 20 years ago. **********For some new equipment, Deere waives all interest for one year and requires no payments for 18 months. As a result, just as the first interest payment comes due, some farmers trade in the year-old machine for a new one; it's more expensive, but it's interest-free for 12 more months and no payments come due until well after the first harvest. **********On this particular Wednesday Roger Evans, a leading salesman who rarely spends a day in the office, was hunting financing for corn farmer Larry Gray. Mr. Gray wanted to trade his 1965 Deere gas tractor toward a more fuel-efficient 1965 Deere diesel. With $2,500 in cash Mr. Gray needed $6,000 in financing, $1,000 too much according to the tractor's book worth. Mr. Evans could not find the money; neither could Mr. Gray. The deal died stillborn. **********Usually, Mr. Evans spends his days pounding the backroads stopping at farmhouse after farmhouse seeking sales. ''Cold calls are the hardest,'' he says, ''They're on the defensive from the start.'' So Mr. Evans drives in, appearing to seek directions. The casual conversation moves through the weather, football, crops and, oh, by the way, he says, I'm with the Deere dealer in Algona. **********Mr. Evans did this for six months earlier this year without making one sale. Then he sold one tractor to the Krantz family, who mentioned him to many of their neighbors. The result: Mr. Evans sold three tractors in one month, plus 10 plows, cultivators and combines. Mr. Evans gets no commission, just a salary. ''Commissions cause pushing among team members,'' says the owner. **********Indeed, sales have become very much team efforts these days. Jerry Janssen, the service manager, spends several hours a day on the phone advising farmers on repairs. When he hears one farmer is looking for a particular implement, he'll mention it at the next morning's meeting. When the right tool shows up, a salesman makes a call and, hopefully, a sale. **********Each morning Wendell Phelps, the dealership's computer expert, distributes a 32-page computer printout of equipment and spare parts inventory. The big machinery still represents the largest share of sales - 39 percent for new equipment and 42 percent for used - but these days, as strapped farmers fix old machines rather than buy new ones, the 65,000 spare parts that Williams carries are pulling a larger share of the burden than in the past. Parts this year will account for 5.4 percent of total Williams sales, nearly twice the 1981 share. Repairs will bring in 5.1 percent. Non-Deere equipment sales such as augers and Harley-Davidson motorcycles will take up the remaining 8.5 percent. **********''HEY, Ed,'' came the eager voice of Mr. Williams from the parking lot on Mr. Wilcox's pocket radio, ''Harold Frideres is coming in.'' It was hopeful news. **********''Today you gotta know every farmer, his equipment and his tastes in machinery,'' said Mr. Wilcox. Mr. Wilcox knew that Mr. Frideres and his son Howard were shopping for a combine to replace their old International Harvester. **********Mr. Wilcox was stuck with 16 of the 30 combines he ordered this year, anticipating an upswing that never swung. Similarly, the dealer's tractor sales are off, from 48 new tractors in 1982 to 39 last year and only 20 so far this year. **********Part of the problem is financing. The rate with 30 percent down payment is 2.75 percent above prime, adjusted monthly during the contract's five- or six-year life. Another part is price. The same tractor that sold in 1974 for $14,360 now lists for $54,700 while the price Mr. Frideres gets for his soybeans has gone from $10 a bushel in 1974 to under $6. **********''We're desperate to move this inventory,'' said Mr. Wilcox. ''The factory will carry it only so long.'' For the 1985 model year he's ordered only five combines and one tractor. **********Despite Mr. Wilcox's flattery and cajoling, Mr. Frideres was not in a jolly mood. He did want the combine. He knew it was listed for $112,000. But he didn't know it cost the dealer $88,000. **********Mr. Wilcox was asking $93,000 that day minus a $23,000 trade-in on the used combine. Mr. Frideres wanted $10,000 more on the trade. **********The farmer left to consider the deal overnight and, he hinted, to visit another Deere dealership two counties away. He would call the next day. Mr. Wilcox was sorely tempted to lower the price further. ''I'd get him for sure if I came down $5,000 more,'' said Mr. Wilcox, ''but that's cutting it too close on the trade.'' The next morning Mr. Frideres didn't call. No news was not good news. **********MR. CAMP'S NEW COMBINE:A RARE PURCHASE **********''Well, now,'' said Jerry Camp, the farmer, ''you can dicker all you want if you want. But it doesn't usually do you much good.'' Then, he laughed. And Ed Wilcox, the John Deere dealer's general manager in Algona, Iowa, laughed too. **********And they reminisced about a rare thing these days - a farm equipment sale involving a combine that listed for $194,000. It had made the sales month for Ernie Williams, owner of the dealership here. And it made Mr. Camp's harvest a more efficient one. ''I was surprised and pleased with the machine,'' said Mr. Camp, ''And I'm not normally surprised and pleased at the same time.'' **********The deal will end in March 1989. But it began last February when Mr. Camp inquired about a trade-in on his two fairly new International Harvester combines. The awkward-looking combine, a mechanical staple on any grain farm, moves slowly down crop rows, combing the plants into whirling wheels that rip the grain off the stalk, dump it in a bin or accompanying truck and spit the stalks back out to decompose by next spring. **********Mr. Camp got about $154,000 credit on his two machines last winter. They were overhauled and put on sale even before Mr. Camp's new combine arrived last July 31. He didn't take possession, however, until the fall harvest began, giving him fuller use of the one-year warranty. The interest on the remaining $40,000, arranged through a Deere finance subsidiary, didn't begin until September either. And under a Deere sales plan the five annual payments don't start until next March, giving him use of his harvest money until then. **********The combine works 12 rows at once, twice the old machines' rate, which speeds up the harvest and frees one man for other work. It also allows efficient concentration of Mr. Camp's grain trucks. One good day they brought in 22,000 bushels, about 1.54 billion kernels. According to the combine's digital readout, it took Mr. Camp only 38 hours to harvest 2,000 acres. Mr. Camp was very excited for a farmer. ''I'm satisfied,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/15/busin.main_headline: CREDIT CRAD DRIVES WOOING THE AFFLUENT

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/15/busin.body_text: **********The swirling Congressional debate over credit card surcharges has focused attention on an industry that, more than ever, is looking for new ways to expand and reach higher-income customers. The three major cards, American Express, Visa and Mastercard, have all, for example, recently begun national advertising campaigns, stressing their versatility and aimed directly at the luxury travel and entertainment market. **********Of the three, American Express, for now, is probably the most aggressive marketer. The simple reason is that American Express is not yet the king of the credit card heap. **********It falls far behind Visa International or Mastercharge International in both card members and total charges. But both Visa and Mastercharge have the advantage of thousands of member banks, which own the credit card system and collect fees and issue cards as independent members. **********'Terrific Advantage' **********American Express is a single entity, with one billing procedure and one clearing house. ''We have a terrific advantage over the bank cards like Mastercard or Visa because they are a loose confederation of banks with accounting done all over the place,'' said Jerry Welsh, senior vice president of marketing services for the Travel Related Services Company of American Express. **********According to analysts, American Express's fast central billing is the reason for its dominance of the highly profitable travel and entertainment segment of the market. In this market American Express is the leader in corporate accounts. **********And American Express has obtained a firm hold on the prestige end of the card market, even though both Visa and Mastercard quickly matched American Express's introduction of its gold card with prestige cards of their own. **********But two weeks ago, American Express announced its platinum charge card. This month, the company will invite 5 percent of its biggest spenders to become platinum charge card holders. For a fee of $250 annually they will receive personalized travel services, and access to large amounts of money while traveling, among other services. **********The other card issuers, primarily the banks, are eager to derail the runaway Amexco express. ''More and more banks realize that their competitor is American Express,'' said Russell E. Hogg, president of Mastercard International Inc., which issues its cards through its member banks. **********A High Interest Rate **********And banks do have an important economic reason to promote their cards. American Express cannot charge interest. ''I suspect that right now bank cards are more profitable to us than American Express cards are to them,'' said Richard S. Braddock, executive vice president of Citibank. **********Bank cards charge consumers nearly 20 percent interest, seven percentage points higher than the average borrowing rate. ''The banks should be doing rather well,'' Mr. Braddock added. Bank cards make money on the interest, the annual fee, and on the merchant discount of about 3 percent. American Express gets an annual fee and a merchant discount. **********Carte Blanche and Diners Club, both owned by Citicorp, are no-interest charge cards like American Express. And they, too, are used primarily for dining, traveling and buying theater tickets. But neither has been much of a challenge to American Express. ''Diners Club is going through a shakeout, '' said Michael Lewis, vice president at E. F. Hutton & Company. ''Carte Blanche is doing very little.'' **********American Express, however has begun to selectively and successfully encroach on its competitors' markets - middle-income and young consumers - as well as its more traditional market of those in their mid-30's and mid-40's with incomes of $35,000 or more. **********Last year, the company reported a 21 percent increase in the number of new green cards as a result of several new card promotions. One encouraged new college graduates to apply. **********Another program sought female applicants, and increased their membership after sponsoring educational seminars for women ranging from careers and investment planning to computers and coping with stress.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/28/world.body_text: **********The Supreme Court ruled tonight that civilian judges can try nine former leaders of the armed forces who are accused of violating human rights during Argentina's years of military rule. **********The high court said the three-man Federal Court of Appeals acted properly in deciding to take control of the cases from a military tribunal that had failed to act in nine months. **********It rejected defendants' arguments that jurisdiction should be returned to the tribunal. **********The ruling clears the way for public trials before the appeals court that local news organizations have likened to the Nuremburg war crimes trials that followed World War II. The defendants are accused of involvement in the abduction, torture and disappearance of at least 9,000 people during a campaign by security forces against leftists in the late 1970's. **********On trial are the generals and admirals who made up three successive three-man juntas that ruled after a coup in 1976. They are Jorge Rafael Videla, Roberto Eduardo Viola and Leopoldo Galtieri, who were Presidents and Army commanders; ; Emilio Massera, Armando Lambruschini and Jorge Anaya, who were Navy commanders, and Orlando Agosti, Omar Graffigna and Basilio Lami Dozo, who commanded the Air Force. **********President Raul Alfonsin ordered their prosecution three days after his inauguration, on Dec. 10, 1983, ended nearly eight years of dictatorship. **********He ordered that the summary trials be carried out by the Armed Forces Supreme Council, the country's top military tribunal. But it failed to reach a verdict and, on Oct. 4, the appeals court took charge, ruling that the council was guilty of ''unjustified delays.''
