https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/01/busin.body_text: **********In separate bond sales this week, New York State and Nassau County made use of outside insurance policies that allowed their bonds to be sold with lower interest rates than would otherwise have been required. **********Nassau County's bond sale of about $53 million was in two parts, both of which were offered through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities and were insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association. Although the two parts are equally secured by the county's credit and the insurance policy, yields were slightly lower for the $31.8 million of general improvement bonds than for the $21.4 million of sewer district bonds. **********The general improvement bonds are not callable before maturity and had coupons, or stated interest rates, that were more attractive to investors. They were offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.75 percent in 1985 to 8.40 percent in 1994, 9.30 percent in 2004 and 9.50 percent in 2010 through 2014. **********The sewer bonds are callable after 10 years at a price of 103, and were offered with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.50 percent in 1994, 9.40 percent in 2004 and 9.50 percent in 2007 through 2014. **********New York State's $100 million bond issue, which was offered beginning Tuesday by a Chase Manhattan Bank group, included bonds due in 1985 through 1994 that were not insured and that carried yields ranging from 5.75 percent in 1985 to 8.40 percent in 1994. Longer-term bonds, however, were insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association, and were offered with yields ranging from 8.40 percent in 1995 to 8.90 percent in 1999, 9.10 percent in 2004 and 9.35 percent in 2012 through 2014. **********All bonds insured by the M.B.I.A. are rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. One securities dealer estimated that without the backing of the insurance policy, the state's long-term bonds might have sold with a yield of about 9 3/4 percent. He added that yields of 10 percent are available on other long-term bonds of New York issuers. **********Although the insurance is the same for the state and county bonds, one underwriter said the state bonds could sell with a lower yield because there are many investors who still prefer state bonds to those of counties or cities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/09/busin.body_text: **********It is a more sober and wiser home computer industry that greets a visitor to this winter's consumer electronics show. Gone are the emphasis on cut-rate prices and the flurry of dazzling product introductions. Instead, at least the manufacturers hope, there will be profits. **********Bloodied by price wars and heavy losses last year, the industry is now waiting for the next phase of competition, over higher-priced machines. **********Only one significant product was introduced at the first day of the show today - a new line of computers from Commodore International that features built-in software. It did not elicit the excitement of products like Coleco Industries' Adam when it was introduced at last June's show. **********I.B.M. vs. Atari **********Home computer makers seem resolved to concentrate on making products they have already announced - and doing it profitably. **********All agree the battle will move to more expensive and more useful machines. Two of the strongest players are expected to be companies that lead in business computers, ones that are far more expensive than the under- $200 machines that have dominated the home computer market so far. They are International Business Machines, whose PCjr is scheduled to be available this quarter, and Apple Computer, which is preparing to introduce an inexpensive version of the Apple IIe for the home market. **********Last year, home computer sales doubled to about five million units, but oversupply and price cuts led to losses of hundreds of millions of dollars from major companies like Atari and Texas Instruments. Texas Instruments ended up pulling out of the market. Its booth here was a fairly desolate one, populated by calculators and electronic learning aids, but not the home computer. **********Now, things appear to be looking up. Indeed, James J. Morgan, the chairman and chief executive of Atari, said today that he expects the company to be profitable in 1984, although it will lose money in the first six months. Atari lost more than $500 million in the first nine months of 1983. **********Industry leaders agree that it is an opportune time to move to more expensive home computers. Strong Christmas sales, combined with production delays affecting Atari and Coleco, have cleared out inventories and taken the pressure off prices. Even the huge inventory of Texas Instruments home computers, sold at bargain basement prices, is now mostly gone. **********''Christmas was a sellout and everything was in short supply,'' said Tricia Parks, of Future Computing Inc., a Dallas market research firm. She predicted, ''There's going to be some sanity in pricing this year.'' **********Both Atari and Coleco started the year by increasing prices on their home computers, and officials of both companies say the increases appear to have stuck. ''We don't have to go into a downward death spiral on prices to get the public to buy our products,'' said Mr. Morgan of Atari, which is part of Warner Communications. **********Nevertheless, it is somewhat early to judge whether the price rises will hold once supply increases to meet demand. It is also unclear whether retailers will pass on the price increases to consumers. **********New From Commodore **********Commodore introduced two computers, the 264 and the 364, both of which will come with some software built into the machine on chips. Such built-in software has been used in briefcase-size computers, like the Radio Shack Model 100, but not in general-purpose home computers. **********Both computers will have 64,000 characters of internal memory. The 364, in addition, will have a built-in speech synthesizer, allowing the computer to talk when used with software geared to that capability. **********Commodore officials said the computers will be available in April but they did not disclose the price. It is believed that the 264 will sell for $300 to $500, in comparison to $200 for its Commodore 64. **********Company officials did not say what software would be built into the machine. But they said that there may be several versions and that the software would be geared toward business-like applications for the home, including record-keeping and word processing. **********By including software, Commodore is joining a trend toward offering bundle packages rather than bare-bones machines. In home computers, this trend was started with the introduction of Coleco's Adam. **********Some analysts, however, were puzzled by Commodore's moves since the machines do not appear much different from the existing Commodore 64. ''I'm at a loss as to what they're doing really,'' said one analyst. Moreover, analysts said, the software written for the 64 will not work on the new machine without modifications. **********Apple's Resurgence **********The big factor in the home computer market, however, could be Apple. Its IIe had a resurgence at Christmas, with more than 100,000 units sold in December alone, though many at discount. **********Apple is now believed to be close to unveiling a less expensive version of the IIe for the home market. The company also is working on a high- end version of the Apple IIe, using a more powerful version of the micro- processor used in the Apple IIe. This is in addition to the introduction of the McIntosh later this month. That computer, featuring easy-to-use integrated software like in Apple's Lisa but at a lower price, is not expected to be aimed at the home market. **********Coleco, meanwhile, plagued by quality and production problems, is still trying to produce enough Adams. Analysts believe Coleco will report a loss for the fourth quarter and question whether the company achieved its latest goal of shipping 125,000 computers by year-end. **********Arnold Greenberg, Coleco's president, would not comment on financial performance or shipment rates. **********Coleco also announced a disk drive attachment for the Adam, to supplement the tape drive that is included in the machine. It also said there would be a way later in the year to allow the machine to use software written for the I.B.M. personal computer and PCjr. **********Atari does not appear ready for the battle. Only two of four computers it announced in June are in production - the 700 XL and the 800 XL. One of the others, the 1400 XL has been scratched and the other, the 1450 XLD, which was on display here, may never be produced. Atari has also dropped plans for an I.B.M.-compatible home computer. **********The lineup for 1984 suggests that there will be no quick standardization in the home computer market. In the business personal computer market, the industry seemed to be solidifying rapidly around I.B.M.'s design, and most manufacturers now offer some ability to use software written for the I.B.M. machine. But the home computer market is likely to have at least three strong players - I.B.M., Apple and Commodore, whose computers will not be able to use software written by the others.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/15/world.body_text: **********Troops searching for leftist guerrillas dragged six men from a church in a mountain village and shot them to death outside while other soldiers forced the rest of the congregation to sing hymns, the pastor said today. **********The deaths bring to 147 the number of people killed in guerrilla-related violence in the last two weeks in the South American country. **********In response to the increasing wave of violence, President Fernando Belaunde Terry today extended for 60 days military control and a state of emergency in 13 provinces in and around Ayacucho. **********The Rev. Saturnino Gavilan said the troops, part of an anti-insurgent force battling the Maoist guerrilla group Shining Path, burst into his Protestant church in the Andean village of Callqui, 27 miles northeast of Ayacucho, last Wednesday in search of suspects. **********He said they apparently did not find who they were looking for, rounded up all six men in the congregation and took them to an outside plaza. **********While two of the soldiers forced the women inside the church to sing hymns, a burst of machine-gun fire rang out, the pastor said. After the troops left, villagers found the bodies of the six men in a ravine, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/08/busin.body_text: **********Metallgesellschaft, the giant West German mining and metals conglomerate, has been struggling. **********Demand for ores and metals has revived, thanks to the economic recovery. But the market for ready-to- use industrial plants is still sagging because of the recent recession, the debts of the third world and the smaller revenues of oil-producing countries. **********Lately, in an effort to re-establish order in its operations, Metallgesellschaft has embarked on a strategy that some analysts describe as a return to its roots. The company is developing one-step trade and financing packages. These combine its extensive trading resources with prowess in exploration, mining and plant construction. **********Broader Trading Activity **********The company is broadening its trading activities beyond ores and metals to include energy products, like coal and oil, and financial instruments, such as foreign exchange and government securities. It is also developing its ability to arrange countertrade deals or barter arrangements with countries that are short of foreign exchange. **********As part of this course, the company has expanded its presence in New York, hiring Siegfried Hodapp, a former Citibank official, to head Meta llgesellschaft Inc., its trading unit, and George S. Horton, a former General Motors executive, to serve as an adviser on countertrade. **********The strategy underlines the problem facing trading companies the world over as debts of the Eastern bloc and third world prevent these nations from purchasing goods abroad. But Metallgesellschaft's troubles take peculiar twists. **********The company, founded more than a century ago by William Merton, who came from an English metal trading clan, was a supplier of raw materials to German companies. Over the years, it grew into a conglomerate involved in mining and smelting, manufacturing and plant construction. **********Company officials acknowledge that the shift accelerated under the Nazi regime - which drove experienced Jewish traders, including the founder's family, from the company - and then continued during West Germany's postwar rebuilding period. **********Today, natural resources, the big division that includes trading in ores, metals and other commodities, accounts for slightly more than half of the company's sales. The rest comes from manufacturing, plant construction, chemicals and shipping. **********Poor Management Decisions **********Metallgesellschaft has had its share of management gaffes - badly timed investments in copper and molybdenum. But the real jolt came when the recession of 1981-82 depressed metal prices, wiping out margins on producing metals such as zinc and lead. At the same time, severe payments problems in Eastern bloc and developing countries dried up orders for ready-for-use plants. **********In 1982, Metallgesellschaft reported a loss equivalent to $7 million, its first since World War II, as sales dropped nearly 7 percent, to $3.59 billion. The company introduced a series of economy measures, and the policy has begun to pay off. For the fiscal year 1983, which ended Sept. 29, the company posted earnings of $9.2 million, reversing the loss a year earlier, though sales rose only one-half of 1 percent, to $3.6 billion. **********Dietrich Natus, the 57-year-old head of the Lurgi division who has just taken over as chairman of Meta llgesellschaft, said the renewed emphasis on trading did not represent a ''spectacular shift.'' Rather, he said, ''you have to be in financial trading if you want to offer a full program of services today.'' **********The company's hopes ride largely on projects in Eastern Europe and the third world, where resources are abundant but cash, engineering skill and marketing ability are in short supply.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/22/busin.main_headline: OPEC OIL MINISTERS GATHER IN EFFORT TO AVOID PRICE CUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/22/busin.print_headline: OPEC OIL MINISTERS GATHER IN EFFORT TO AVOID PRICE CUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began gathering yesterday in Geneva to prepare for an emergency meeting called for next Monday after three countries cut their oil prices last week. **********Several of the 13 OPEC members, led by Saudi Arabia, are expected to start today to draft a plan to try to avert a price war. Some oil-producing countries that are not members of the organization have also been invited to participate in the talks. **********In a weekend statement released by OPEC at its Vienna headquarters, the organization said its members were ''determined to maintain and strengthen the price and will take every necessary measure in this respect.'' The only way OPEC can do this, oil analysts say, is to slash production immediately. **********Responding to Recent Cuts **********The emergency conference has been called in response to the price cuts announced last week by two non-OPEC members, Norway and Britain, and one OPEC member, Nigeria. But oil analysts say the organization is facing a much more serious crisis than just the possibility of a reduction in its official price. **********OPEC is facing deep fundamental changes in worldwide oil production and use, according to oil analysts, and these changes are threatening the group's ability to control oil prices. **********Since 1979, when OPEC doubled oil prices after the Iranian revolution, there has been a shift by oil-consuming nations away from OPEC as a supplier. Higher prices made it more economic to develop some marginal oil and gas fields and brought into focus both economic and security reasons to develop other energy sources. **********Expansion of Output Noted **********As a result, oil production in the non- Communist world outside of OPEC jumped 25 percent in five years, to 25 million barrels a day from 20 million barrels a day, according to the International Energy Agency. **********At the same time, demand for oil dropped 15 percent because of permanent shifts to natural gas, coal and energy conservation. **********The only way OPEC has been able to keep its prices high has been to continually cut production to keep supplies tight - from 31.6 million barrels a day in 1979 to 23.5 million in 1981 and as little as 16.5 million in the third quarter of this year, according to various oil experts. **********But this has had the effect, the analysts say, of OPEC's tightening a noose around its own neck. In an effort to control prices and hang onto its customers, OPEC is selling far less oil, reaping far less money and prompting internal fights between its members, who must sell less than they are able to produce. **********''OPEC pushed prices too high in 1979, and it set in motion a series of events that are now coming back to haunt them,'' said Paul Mlotok, an oil analyst at Salomon Brothers, the investment house. ''It took a while for other countries to adjust, because the lead times are relatively long. But once they have adjusted, it will go a long way.'' **********The economic effect of those cutbacks on OPEC has been severe. The oil revenues on which its 13 member nations depend dropped 42 percent, or $141.4 billion, in 1983, compared with the peaks of 1978 to 1981, according to Petroleum Intelligence Weekly. **********Nigeria has especially suffered. Its economy depends almost entirely on oil, and the country has had trouble paying even the interest on its $20 billion international debt. Nigeria's OPEC-set production quota of 1.3 million barrels a day is about half of its peak output over the past few years. **********During the recent oil oversupply, Nigeria often has been first to offer secret discounts to suppliers and raise production to keep its markets and economy intact. This year its production averaged 1.4 million barrels a day, according to the country's central bank. By violating OPEC's production quota, Nigeria has achieved a balance-of-payments surplus of $325 million, about the same size as its deficit in 1983. **********When Britain followed Norway's lead last week by cutting the price of most of its North Sea oil by $1.35 a barrel, to $28.65, Nigeria was quick to respond with its own $2-a-barrel cut, to $28, prompting OPEC's emergency meeting. It was Nigeria, following Britain, that sparked the OPEC cut in its official price, to $29 a barrel from $34 for the benchmark Saudi Arabian light crude, in March 1983. **********Several Offer Discounts **********Other OPEC nations have also found discounts irresistible. Libya, Abu Dhabi and Iran have cut their prices for key customers. **********Saudi Arabia, OPEC's acknowledged leader, is economically healthier than most of the other members, and reportedly has contingency plans to drop its production to 3 million barrels a day in the next few weeks, far below its recent daily output of 4.5 million to 5.5 million and its capacity of 10 million barrels a day. **********But analysts say the Saudis cannot keep output that low for long without threatening their own internal stability. None of the non-OPEC oil-producing nations have appeared to help OPEC by tightening supplies except for brief periods. **********''Whenever new capacity outside of OPEC is ready, it is produced immediately,'' said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. ''OPEC has become the swing producer, and it continues to be squeezed.'' **********Production Outside OPEC **********According to the Wall Street firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, oil production since 1979 has been increased by 75 to 100 percent in Norway, Britain, India, Malaysia, Mexico and Egypt. Brazil has more than doubled its output. **********The Soviet bloc, which was expected in 1979 to become a net oil importer by 1985, has instead increased its exports by an estimated 600,000 barrels a day, to 1.7 million. Production in the United States has not dropped, as predicted, but instead has increased slightly. **********Major new oil exploration efforts are occurring in developing countries. Earlier this year the Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced a major oil discovery in Colombia, for example. **********''It will be years before the large overhang of spare capacity - all of which is concentrated in OPEC - is substantially diminished,'' said William L. Randol, an analyst for the First Boston Corporation. **********Even if OPEC does cut production now and succeeds in keeping prices up because cold weather is approaching, it will still face another crisis next spring when seasonal demand begins to slacken, according to oil experts. Few see any solution for OPEC, except to realize that the oil world has changed and to adjust to it. **********''OPEC's existence will be threatened otherwise,'' said Frederick P. Leuffer, an oil analyst for C. J. Lawrence Inc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/13/busin.main_headline: WARNING ISSUED BY I.M.F. ON THE DOLLAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/13/busin.print_headline: WARNING ISSUED BY I.M.F. ON THE DOLLAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/13/busin.body_text: **********The record level to which the dollar has risen is ''unsustainable'' and potentially ''detrimental'' to the United States and the rest of the world, the International Monetary Fund said today in its annual report. **********The report appeared to presage another spirited debate about the dollar and Washington's policies when the fund's 147 member countries meet here later this month. The joint annual meeting of the fund and the World Bank starts Sept. 24. **********The report also repeated earlier I.M.F. criticism of the large United States budget deficit, but went a step further by warning of some of the perils of the high dollar. **********The 203-page report noted that at around midyear, when the study was being drafted, the dollar had risen to about 15 percent above its average value for the period 1973 to 1982 in relation to the Japanese yen and the British pound. It was up 40 percent over the West German mark and nearly 50 percent over the French franc. **********In recent days the dollar has reached record levels against the pound, the franc and the Italian lira and an 11 1/2-year high against the mark. **********Impact of the Deficit **********The I.M.F. document, whose key passages are negotiated by governments and represent a consensus of the membership, said the United States budget deficit, by intensifying competition for savings, contributes to high interest rates, which in turn increases the value of the dollar. **********The Reagan Administration does not endorse this causal relationship. It argues that the dollar's popularity is spurred by low inflation, high growth of the American economy and profitability of American investments. **********The report cited the dollar's strength as ''an important factor'' contributing to the deterioration in the American trade accounts - to an estimated $130 billion merchandise trade deficit this year. **********The I.M.F. study said the trade deficit ''could have disquieting implications for the international allocation of world private saving,'' by drawing in savings to the United States from the rest of the world to finance the deficit. **********Easing of Debt Crisis **********At the same time, the international agency, which has more than $30 billion of short-term credits outstanding to more than 40 countries, said that the trade deficit had contributed to an easing of the world debt crisis. The huge American appetite for imports has spurred economic activity abroad and has especially helped many third world countries improve their cash position and pay their debts, the I.M.F. report notes. **********The I.M.F. also noted that, largely following patterns set by the United States, the average of short-term interest rates in the major industrial countries rose to 9 3/4 percent in the first half of 1984. The rates had fallen to 9 1/4 percent in the first half of 1983, from a peak of some 15 percent during 1981.  ''The recent rise in interest rates,'' the report said, ''has been strongest and most persistent in the United States, where both short-term and long-term yields in the spring of 1984 reached levels roughly two percentage points higher than in the early months of 1983.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/01/world.main_headline: 300 FRENCH TROOPS LEAVE LEBANON, CLOSING OUT THE MULTINATIONAL FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/01/world.print_headline: 300 FRENCH TROOPS LEAVE LEBANON, CLOSING OUT THE MULTINATIONAL FORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/01/world.body_text: **********Three-hundred French soldiers, the last members of the multinational force, left Lebanon today. **********Their departure by ferry came after ceremonies marking the formal end of the 19-month-old effort by France, Britain, the United States and Italy to help bring peace to Lebanon. At its height, the four-nation force had 6,000 members. **********On Friday President Reagan announced in Washington that the American role in the multinational force had formally ended, a move that freed American marines on ships offshore for duty elsewhere. The ships - which had been reduced to 15 from 25 recently - had been stationed about 20 miles off Lebanon. **********The departure of the French troops was heralded by military bands that marched between empty cargo containers at Beirut's desolate port. **********Intent on showing that the French departure was different from the American, Italian and British withdrawals, France tried to inject what pomp and grandeur it could under the unusual conditions in this divided and dangerous city. **********Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson and Defense Minister Charles Hernu were on hand to receive salutes from the 300 French soldiers and hear slightly off-key renditions of the Lebanese national anthem and ''La Marseillaise.''  Last Leaves at 5 P.M. **********The last man to leave was Maj. Jean- Paul Amidi, 35 years old, a commando officer who boarded an inflatable speedboat at 5 P.M. and roared off into the Mediterranean to join his comrades on the French ship Ouragan. **********The French, Americans and Italians arrived in August 1982 to oversee the withdrawal of Palestine Liberation Organization troops. They left but returned in September after the mass slayings of civilians at the Sabra and Shatila Palestinian refugee camps. In early 1983, Britain sent a small number of troops to join the contingent. **********After victories in February by anti- Government militias, the American, British and Italian troops withdrew, and President Amin Gemayel turned to Syria - the key Soviet ally in the region - for help in saving his Government and bringing about a truce. **********There were heavy casualties for the French and the Americans. The French had 89 dead and 110 wounded; the American force had 260 dead and more than 130 wounded. Most of the deaths came on a single day, last Oct. 23, when 241 Americans and 58 French troops died in suicide bomb attacks. From then on domestic pressure built in both counties to pull the troops out of Lebanon.   The French Promise **********Today, however, the French dignitaries insisted that France would continue its commitment to Lebanon. **********''With honor, you have borne testimony of France's role in this troubled region,'' said Mr. Hernu's order of the day, which was read to the assembled troops by the army's chief of staff, Gen. Jannou Lacaze. ''That role and that presense endures.'' **********''France has been here for several centuries,'' Mr. Cheysson said, speaking of France's old imperial role in Lebanon, ''and she hopes to be here several centuries more.'' **********Mr. Hernu added: ''The withdrawal of the contingent is not the departure of France.'' **********Mr. Hernu's order of the day noted that France is leaving behind 40 observers to help oversee the cease-fire here, and he said France would listen favorably to any Lebanese requests for more observers. **********The hazards Mr. Hernu and Mr. Cheysson endured to offer testimony to France's honor were brought home by occasional explosions and the sound of sporadic machine-gun fire at the demarcation line between East and West Beirut, about a half mile away. **********Although the French controled security at the port, they could not supervise the hundreds of artillery batteries around town and in the mountains that are in the hands of the militias. Just Friday several shells landed near the port.   Militias Attend Ceremony **********The ceremony was attended by the Lebanese Defense Minister, Issam Khoury, and representatives of all the warring militias except the Druse Progressive Socialist Party. A French spokesman said the Druse feared for their safety at the dock, which is in Christian territory. However, Druse representatives were expeted at a reception on the Ouragan. **********The militia representatives who were there gave each other small hugs and at one point joined hands. Mr. Hernu said their presense ''material proof of national reconciliation.'' **********After the ceremony, one French infantryman leaning against sandbags called the day's festivities ''a big ceremony for public opinion to show we're leaving with our heads high.'' **********But he said that while there were some differences between the French withdrawal and the other withdrawals, all were basically similar because the multinational force had not fulfilled its mission. **********''I regret leaving,'' he said. ''First, because I love the country and I have many friends here. Second, because we fooled a lot of people. We inflated their hopes and then let them down.'' **********But most of his comrades expressed unqualified joy at shipping out, and a transport-load of soldiers - a mass of organge life preservers - let up a cheer as they pulled away from shore. **********The troops took their mascot with them, a three-month-old dog called Grad, after the popular name here for the Soviet-made artillery rockets used by Lebanon's militias.   Reaction Is Muted **********Reaction to the French departure and to President Reagan's statement was muted. The French departure was announced in advance, and most Lebanese assumed that the American commitment ended when the marines went to their boats. **********''It's like announcing someone's death a month after he died,'' said one Arab, referring to Mr. Reagan's statement. **********Mr. Gemayel was reported today to have sent a letter to President Reagan expressing hope that the United States would continue to provide political, economic and military support. **********Nabih Berri, the Shiite Moslem leader, said today that the American withdrawal ''just removes cover for Israel.'' Mr. Berri said, ''We need a U.S. President who follows his conscience rather than electoral considerations.'' **********Beirut residents, in the meantime, seemed to express their confidence in a three-day-old cease-fire by clogging the sidewalks in the capital's shopping districts and causing traffic jams on many streets that had been emptied by fear only a few days earlier. **********By local standards, the cease-fire appeared to holding well. The higher security committee, which is headed by Mr. Gemayel and includes army and militia representatives, managed to contain a sudden outburst of artillery and mortar fire Friday around the mountain town of Suk al Gharb. The exchange between the army and Druse left two Lebanese soldiers dead and four wounded. **********Tonight the general calm was marred by reports of more shelling around Suk al Gharb, and there were some exchanges of fire along the Green Line between East and West Beirut.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/21/world.main_headline: Rocket Fired in Beirut Strikes Soviet Embassy
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/21/world.print_headline: Rocket Fired in Beirut Strikes Soviet Embassy
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/21/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Embassy here was hit by a rocket tonight, causing damage but no casualties, the police said. **********It was the second attack on the Soviet diplomatic compound this year. **********In April rockets were fired at the Soviet cultural center. **********In the attack tonight, a B-7 anti-tank rocket, a weapon commonly carried by many militiamen here, was fired at the fenced-off embassy on Cornish Maazra in a predominantly Moslem section of West Beirut. **********Responsibility for the attack in April was claimed by the Islamic Holy War organization, which said it was in retaliation for Soviet policies in Afghanistan. **********BEIRUT, July 20 (AP) - A male telephone caller told The Associated Press bureau in Beirut about an hour after the attack that it had been carried out by the Organization of the Sharp Sword, a group not heard of before. He said such attacks would continue unless the Russians stopped ''interfering in Lebanese internal politics.'' **********The caller read a statement that said the attack was directed against the ''Soviet espionage center.'' **********The statement he read added, ''The will which forced the Marines and French out of Beirut is capable of shaking the earth under the feet of the Russians.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/13/world.main_headline: U.S. AND IRAQ REPORTED READY TO RENEW TIES AFTER 17 YEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/13/world.print_headline: U.S. AND IRAQ REPORTED READY TO RENEW TIES AFTER 17 YEARS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/13/world.body_text: **********The United States and Iraq have agreed to announce the restoration of diplomatic relations next Monday, Reagan Administration officials said today. **********The officials said the announcement would be made during a visit to Washington by Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister. **********They said that Mr. Aziz, who also is Foreign Minister, is scheduled to meet Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, and a statement will be made then, ending a 17- year interruption in relations. **********The Iraqis severed diplomatic relations with the United States in June 1967 in coordination with many other Arab countries. They said the United States was helping Israel in its defeats of Egypt, Syria and Jordan. **********Although Jordan and Saudi Arabia did not break relations after the 1967 war, many other Arab countries, including Egypt, Syria and Iraq, did. Ties were eventually restored with Egypt, Syria and other countries, but Iraq kept relations to the level of an interests section until now. **********The move was not unexpected. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said in a newspaper interview in Al Watan al Arabi last month that Iraq would move to restore relations after the American Presidential election. American officials said today that when Mr. Aziz met with Mr. Shultz in New York on Oct. 1 during a session of the United Nations General Assembly, they discussed the move. **********Aware that establishing formal diplomatic relations with Iraq might create the impression that Washington was now taking sides in the four-year- old war between Iran and Iraq, Administration officials insisted today that there was no change in their official policy of neutrality. The United States has had no diplomatic relations with Iran since President Carter severed ties during the hostage crisis of 1979-81. **********At one time, Iraq and the United States were sharply antagonistic. Iraq was a leader of those countries opposed to any negotiations between Israel and Arab countries, and it was the Soviet Union's closest ally in the Middle East. But since the Iraq-Iran war started in 1980, Iraq has changed its opposition to Israel's existence, has tried to present a more moderate image to the West and has limited its ties to Moscow. **********The diplomatic interests sections of the two countries were enlarged in Washington and Baghdad, and senior American officials began visiting Iraq. The most recent was Richard W. Murphy, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, who met with Mr. Aziz last week and discussed the visit, State Department officials said. **********Of more importance to Iraq than the improvement in political relations has been United States steps to make it easier for Iraq to import American- made, nonstrategic goods. Iraq was removed from the list of countries deemed to provide haven for international terrorists three years ago and has been able to buy civilian aircraft and other industrial goods. Over the last three years, the United States has extended $1.6 billion in credits and credit guarantees to Iraq for American agricultural goods. **********The State Department said, ''Since Iraq broke relations in 1967, our position has been we would resume relations when they are ready to do so, and we affirm that.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/20/busin.print_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE; ACTING TO AVERT DEBTOR CARTEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/20/busin.body_text: **********THE meeting of Latin American finance **********ministers and foreign ministers in Cartagena, Colombia, which started yesterday, was preceded by some adroit maneuvering by Western countries and financial institutions to prevent the Latin Americans from ganging up on them. **********First, Jacques de Larosi ere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, let Mexico know that it would receive easier terms than other debtors as a reward for putting its economic house in order. Then Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citicorp and a close adviser of President Reagan, let Brazil know that it, too, would receive favored treatment for its sacrifices. **********At the London economic summit conference earlier this month, the leaders of the seven industrial countries endorsed these overtures to Mexico and Brazil by agreeing that ''in cases where debtor countries are themselves making successful efforts to improve their position,'' the summit countries would encourage ''more extended multiyear rescheduling of commercial debts.'' They also agreed to encourage the substitution of ''more stable long-term finance, both direct and portfolio, for short-term bank lending.'' **********After the London conference, a senior United States official, who insisted on being identified in that way, appeared to repudiate this agreement, asking who would want to acquire this ''lousy debt.'' But Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, pointedly asked how much power the senior official had to reverse United States and international policy for helping to rescue debtor countries willing to work with their creditors. **********Mr. Volcker has stressed that ''we cannot expect borrowing countries to make necessary adjustments to get their houses in order without reasonable prospects that good performance will result in continuing access to the new credit and the debt restructuring they need.'' **********The Cartagena meeting will show whether Mexico and Brazil, and probably Venezuela as well, have been convinced that they have more to gain by continuing to cooperate with their Western creditors and the I.M.F. than by forming a debtors' cartel with Argentina to threaten the lenders. **********The Westerners feel that if they have indeed separated Mexico and Brazil from the other Latin debtors, they have chopped the international debt problem down to manageable size. Those two countries alone owe more than one-half of the total Latin debt and over one-third of the debt of all developing countries. **********Despite divisions among the Latin countries on how to deal with the debt problem and further their own economic development, the presence of the foreign ministers in Cartagena could result in strong political support for Argentina. The Argentines will stress how crucial their neighbors' support is for the survival of the Alfonsin Government, with its commitment to democracy. **********The United States and other Western countries recognize that if too much pressure is put on Argentina its democratic Government could fall, dealing a severe setback to democratic trends in Latin America. There is growing recognition that what is economically required in Argentina may be politically impossible for the Government to deliver. **********The I.M.F. is refusing to be painted into a corner by rejecting the Alfonsin Government's offer of a new letter of intent, circumventing the fund's economic experts. Argentina insists that it is committed to real wage increases of 6 to 8 percent, which the fund's economists regard as likely to worsen the inflation, running at over 500 percent a year. **********The I.M.F. keeps asking for clarification, raising questions about internal consistency in Argentina's program. It is carefully avoiding any possible accusation that it is driving Argentina to the breaking point. But a breaking point could be approaching. For if the Alfonsin Government does not restore order to its economy, the inflation may accelerate and itself cause a breakdown of the society. **********However, without the support of the Peronist unions and other groups, possibly including the military, to put the economy in order, the Alfonsin Government may be driven to default, inflicting heavy losses on some major banks. **********The near-collapse of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has made foreign depositors in American banks extremely jumpy. Though the Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation have said they would protect all depositors, the threat of large-scale withdrawals from abroad remains. A serious weakening of the dollar would exacerbate that risk. **********These are hazardous times. Crisis management has worked thus far, most importantly in Mexico and Brazil, and world recovery is moving, although interest rates are climbing, offsetting the favorable effects of rising trade. **********The Cartagena meeting, even though likely to produce some fiery rhetoric, does not seem likely to bring into being an aggressive debtors' cartel, a confrontation between debtors and lenders, and a wide wave of defaults. Even an Argentine default appears unlikely to tear the system apart. But it is not a prospect anyone relishes. **********For the other debtors to hold in place, they could use greater assurance that the current phase of ''muddling through'' is ending, to be replaced by policies for more stable growth, lower interest rates and the flow of new credit to countries prepared to pursue sensible economic policies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/30/busin.main_headline: OPEC PLANS TO CUT OUTPUT BUT LACKS ACCORD ON QUOTAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/30/busin.print_headline: OPEC PLANS TO CUT OUTPUT BUT LACKS ACCORD ON QUOTAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/10/30/busin.body_text: **********The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today agreed to cut its oil production by 1.5 million barrels a day, to 16 million, to bolster dropping prices. **********But the group failed to agree after a day of talks on the critical issue of how to distribute the cuts among its members. **********The decision to cut production was greeted with skepticism by many oil analysts, who said the 13 OPEC nations are already producing 1.5 million barrels a day less than their agreed-upon production ceiling of 17.5 million barrels because of an oversupply of oil. **********Thus the agreement to cut production to 16 million barrels is meaningless, the analysts said, at least until demand rises substantially during the winter. **********Problem of Members' Cheating **********When demand does rise, they added, it is unclear whether OPEC's member nations will be able to stick to their new lower quotas without cheating - a continuing problem that helped cause the current oversupply of oil. **********In the first day of an emergency meeting here, OPEC oil ministers began their private talks by accusing each other, and particularly Nigeria, of damaging the group's credibility and price-setting power by cheating on production or price agreements with each other, according to sources at the meeting. **********The discussion was ''extremely frank'' although civil, one source said. Ministers continued to meet late in the evening in an attempt to mend their differences and agree on specifics. **********Oil trading today reflected the industry's skepticism. Prices in the so-called spot market, where oil not sold under contract is traded, and in the futures market generally closed lower. **********Comment by Chevron Trader **********''OPEC is doing nothing, and that is precisely what the market is saying,'' said J. Richard Perkins, regional trading manager for Chevron International in New York. **********Some traders accused OPEC of trying to prop up the market with rhetoric. Several of the OPEC ministers declined to grant interviews to respond to the charges. **********Nigeria prompted the emergency meeting by cutting the price of its premium oil by $2 a barrel, to $28, on Oct. 18 after price cuts for competing petroleum had been announced by Norway and Britain, which are not members of OPEC. Canada, also not a member, followed the three others last week. **********Nigeria's move was the first official break in OPEC's pricing structure since the organization set the present levels in March 1983. **********Subroto, Indonesia's oil minister and president of this conference, told reporters in an evening briefing that all the OPEC members would make some production cuts and continue them until prices firmed. **********Afterward, however, Nigerian officials reiterated the position stated Sunday by their country's oil minister, Tam David-West, that Nigeria would not cut production ''by even one barrel'' from its present 1.4 million barrels a day, which is 100,000 above the quota it has been assigned by OPEC. **********Other OPEC sources said today that cuts in output by several of the member nations would be ''token'' and ''symbolic'' and that the bulk of the reduction over all would be borne by Saudi Arabia, the organization's biggest producer. **********Subroto also said that, for the first time, OPEC would formally address problems in the group's basic pricing structure, whereby producers of high- quality light oil are hurt by greater demand for lower-quality, cheaper heavy oil. **********But analysts and other OPEC officials said that this issue would be very difficult to resolve because some producers would have to cut the price of some of their grades of oil. One of those grades, analysts said, could be OPEC's benchmark grade, Saudi Arabian Light crude. The group has pledged to defend its official price of $29 a barrel. **********In an allusion to the perennial problem of cheating, the Indonesian oil minister also declared that OPEC was trying to ''restore and strengthen discipline among member countries so decisions will be followed strictly.'' **********But discipline repeatedly has been hurt by pressures on oil ministers from their governments to continue bringing in oil revenues, on which their national economies depend. After each break in today's meeting, ministers rushed to their rooms to telephone their heads of state for guidance, according to various sources. **********These pressures were underlined when Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, oil minister of the United Arab Emirates and head of the market monitoring committee, suggested Sunday that his country would unilaterally cut the price of its light crude to increase flagging demand if OPEC does not solve the basic pricing problem of ''differentials.'' His widely reported comments added to the dissention in today's meeting, according to people who were there. **********There were also accusations by OPEC members that Nigeria was siding with non-OPEC producers and against the organization by cutting its price, sources at the meeting said. Nigerian officials repeated that they had to cut the price to keep their customers while waiting for OPEC to act, but other ministers were not satisfied with that answer, the sources added. **********Although all of OPEC's deliberations are conducted in secret, some details of today's session emerged from delegates and OPEC staff members. **********They said the ministers sat in an oval on sofas set up in a room created by partitioning part of the large ballroom of the Inter-Continental Hotel here. Although they spoke in English, the official OPEC language, each minister had an interpreter sitting behind him to help with difficult phrases. Coffee, tea, mineral water, orange juice and soft drinks were served. **********The meeting began with Subroto welcoming representatives of Egypt and Mexico, not members of OPEC, who are here as observers. He also welcomed new OPEC oil ministers from Ecuador and Libya. **********Sheik Otaiba then reviewed the recommendations of his market monitoring committee to cut production, bolster prices and solve the differential problem. **********Next Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, oil minister of Saudi Arabia, reviewed for about half an hour his trips to Lagos, Nigeria, and Oslo, Norway, to muster support for OPEC's aims. An hour of round-robin discussion followed. **********In the afternoon the ministers conferred privately in small groups and met jointly again about 5:30 P.M. **********Various sources who were at the meeting described its tone as cordial but the differences as often sharp. **********The conference, which is open- ended, is to continue Tuesday and perhaps for additional days to allocate production cuts and try to solve the basic pricing problem. **********Skepticism about OPEC's pledges to cut production has been mounting over the last three days amid a cascade of contradictory figures supplied by oil ministers. On Sunday night Subroto said OPEC was producing its quota of 17.5 million barrels a day. On Monday Sheik Otaiba said OPEC was producing 18 million barrels a day. **********Under today's agreement, the Saudis would be expected to cut about 1 million barrels a day from their current quota of 5 million barrels, according to OPEC sources. But Sheik Yamani said his country was already producing only 4 million barrels a day. Later the Iranian oil minister, Mohammad Gharazi, said Sheik Yamani had told him that Saudi Arabia was producing 3.5 million barrels. **********Moreover, Mr. Gharazi said Iran was producing only half of its quota of 2.4 million barrels a day. Oil traders said other OPEC nations were also producing less than their quotas. **********Mr. Perkins of Chevron said his ''intelligence in the marketplace'' agreed with the 16-million-barrels- a-day production figure. Kuwait, he said, is at least 150,000 barrels a day under its quota, and Iraq is at least 200,000 under, besides the Saudi and Iranian underproduction. **********Another oil specialist, Jay M. Amberg of Oil Buyers Guide International, a trade publication, said talks with traders today corroborated the 16- million figure. **********''They are not making any cuts - they are just trying to create a market for their oil by saying they will tighten supplies,'' said Harry Neustein, an oil trader who has been in the business more than 50 years. **********Even if OPEC does come up with a firm agreement, it is uncertain whether it can be enforced, many oil analysts said. **********''It may be a short-term rescue mission by OPEC, but it doesn't solve their longer-term problems,'' said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. ''The market is structurally oversupplied.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/18/world.main_headline: A SOVIET DESERTER IN AFGHANISTAN, LIVING IN U.S., WILL RETURN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/18/world.print_headline: A SOVIET DESERTER IN AFGHANISTAN, LIVING IN U.S., WILL RETURN
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/18/world.body_text: **********A young Soviet soldier who defected in Afghanistan 18 months ago has decided to return to the Soviet Union from the United States. The State Department said today that it was satisfied he made the decision voluntarily. **********Soviet Embassy officials brought Nikolai Ryzhkov, 20 years old, to the State Department this morning, and American officials questioned him about his decision. **********Department's Comment **********Later Alan D. Romberg, a department spokesman, said, ''We have held a meeting in the State Department with Ryzhkov at which he declared that he wished to return to the Soviet Union, and that he made that decision voluntarily.'' **********The Soviet Government appears to be encouraging Russian expatriates to return home lately and is giving them high visibility and remarkably respectful treatment. (Page A5.) **********Soviet Account **********Mikhail Lysenko, a spokesman for the Soviet Embassy, said Mr. Ryzhkov, one of two Soviet Army privates who deserted from their military construction unit in Afghanistan in June 1983, came to the embassy recently to ask for help in returning home. **********The other defector was Aleksandr Voronov, who lives in the Washington area and was reported by friends to be distraught over Mr. Ryzhkov's move. **********'His Personal Decision' **********''Mr. Ryzhkov asked the embassy to arrange for his return home and he plans to do this,'' Mr. Lysenko told reporters. ''He is a Soviet citizen and he wants to go back home. It was his personal decision.'' Mr. Romberg said he had no details on the State Department meeting with Mr. Ryzhkov, but he reiterated that the young man had ''stated firmly'' that his decision was made freely. **********''I don't have details on who was present, but I don't think that in the view of those people who spoke with him there was any question regarding his ability to make an independent judgment,'' Mr. Romberg said. **********State Department officials said they had no information on where Mr.  Ryzhkov had been living for the past year, or where he was living at the time he requested assistance from the Soviet Embassy to return to the Soviet Union. **********Spoke of a 'Dirty War' **********When Mr. Ryzhkov arrived in the United States a year ago, he held a news conference in New York in which he denounced what he called the ''dirty war'' being waged by the Soviet Union in Afghanistan. **********He said then that he had been told his unit was being sent to Afghanistan to repel American and Chinese mercenaries there. **********''When I arrived my opinion changed completely,'' he said. ''I didn't see any mercenaries. Only Afghan people. I didn't want to be part of that dirty war, and that is why I defected.'' **********John Ashton, executive director of the Committee for a Free Afghanistan, said he had met Mr. Ryzhkov twice and was not surprised to hear of the young man's decision to go home.   'A Real Culture Shock' **********''Anyone who comes to this country from the Eastern bloc gets disillusioned very quickly,'' Mr. Ashton said in an interview. ''It's a real culture shock for them, and there are very few organizations or programs in this country to help these people.'' **********He said Mr. Ryzhkov, who speaks no English, seemed ''distraught and upset'' over his inability to find and keep a job and adjust to American life. **********Mikhail Makarenko, a Soviet dissident who lives in Washington, said he last saw Mr. Ryzhkov on Thursday. He said the young defector handed him his car keys and said, ''I can't live any longer in this country.'' **********Mr. Makarenko, speaking through an interpreter, added: ''I don't think he left because he wanted to leave, but because of the fact that people didn't let him live in America. He was forced 11 times in the course of a year to change his place of residence and 7 times to change his place of work.'' **********Marina Evdochenko-Wells of Arlington, Va., who said that both young defectors had visited her family regularly, said today that she did not believe Mr. Ryzhkov was returning willingly to the Soviet Union. **********''The Nikolai I know talked about how glad he was to be out of the Soviet Union,'' she said. ''He never mentioned any desire to go back. They did something to him, I know it.'' **********Mrs. Evdochenko-Wells said that Mr. Voronov ''fell apart when he heard what Nikolai had done.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/28/world.main_headline: HONDURANS URGE TOP NICARAGUAN REBELS TO UNITE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/28/world.print_headline: HONDURANS URGE TOP NICARAGUAN REBELS TO UNITE
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/28/world.body_text: **********High-ranking Honduran officers told Nicaraguan rebel leaders this week that they were eager to unite the three principal groups fighting the Government in Managua, the military authorities say. **********ww The authorities said the Hondurans, at a meeting Thursday attended by a United States intelligence agent, told four leaders of the Honduran-based rebels that they would like to bring the military leader of the Costa Rican- based insurgents, Eden Pastora Gomez, to this country to form the alliance. **********The third anti-Government group, is composed of Miskito Indian factions. **********The insurgents based here, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, depend heavily on the good will of the Honduran military, which allows them to move freely in the border area. **********They also depend on aid from the United States. The United States intelligence operative said to have been present at the meeting Thursday did not speak, but his presence was taken as an indication that the United States strongly favors unification of the three groups, a participant in the meeting said.   Seen as Too Close to C.I.A. **********Mr. Pastora, a former Sandinista hero who heads the insurgent Democratic Revolutionary Alliance, has resisted efforts at unity in the past on the ground that Honduran-based insurgent groups contain too many veterans of the defeated national guard in their ranks and are too closely tied to the Central Intelligence Agency. **********Mr. Pastora asserted that his bases in Costa Rica had been raided by the police, and he said he had directed his family to seek political asylum in Panama. **********A spokesman for the insurgents based here, Edgar Chamorro Coronel, said in an interview today that Honduran military leaders ''want Pastora to come here,'' and ''they feel that he is being pushed out of Costa Rica and needs a place.'' **********Mr. Pastora, however, has insisted that former guardsmen be removed from command posts before he could agree to any merger. The only former guardsman who holds a key position in the Honduran-based Nicaraguan Democratic Force is Enrique Bermudez, a former colonel. The leader of the Democratic Force, Adolfo Calero Portocarrero, said in an interview last week that he had ''great confidence'' in Mr. Bermudez and was not prepared to ask for his resignation. **********Col. Cesar Elvir Fierra, spokesman for the Honduran military, said the presence of Mr. Bermudez had damaged the image of the Democratic Force and that bringing Mr. Pastora into a united anti-Sandinista front ''would be an advance for the cause.'' **********But Mr. Bermudez, who has been one of the principal organizers of the Democratic Force and who is considered its most capable military strategist, has shown no inclination to step aside in favor of Mr. Pastora. In an interview this afternoon, he noted that he had been out of Nicaragua during the insurrection of 1978-79 and had never led combat forces against Sandinista troops.   'Ready to Make Any Sacrifice' **********''I abandoned my family and came here ready to make any sacrifice to eliminate Marxist-Leninist tyranny in my homeland,'' Mr. Bermudez said. ''I didn't come here looking for fame or publicity. How are they going to push me out?'' **********Asked if the C.I.A. and the Honduran military had sufficient power to demand his removal, Mr. Bermudez replied, ''If there are powerful forces who want to impose their will on us, they will be responsible for what happens to Nicaragua.'' **********In addition to the Democratic Force, the predominantly Indian insurgent group Misura was represented at Thursday's meeting. Its leader, Steadman Fagoth, endorsed the view expressed by the Democratic Force that Mr. Pastora would be welcome here, but only if he came without imposing conditions, according to an officer present at the session.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/03/23/world.body_text: **********A Northern Ireland man was arraigned under heavy guard today in the bombing of Harrods department store last Dec. 17. The blast killed 6 people and wounded 94. **********About 20 policemen, some with trained dogs, stood guard outside magistrate's court in London's Lambeth district as 29-year-old Paul Kavanagh was escorted inside. **********Mr. Kavanagh of Belfast, the first person to be charged in the Harrods bombing, entered no plea and did not apply for bail. Magistrate Ralph Lownie ordered him jailed for a week pending a further hearing. **********Scotland Yard said Mr. Kavanagh was charged Wednesday night with six terrorist-related crimes from Oct. 6, 1983, to Jan. 25, including conspiring with others in the car bombing outside Harrods. The Irish Republican Army took responsibility for that explosion.
