https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/19/world.main_headline: 4 DISSIDENTS TRIAL IN POLAND PUT OFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/19/world.print_headline: 4 DISSIDENTS TRIAL IN POLAND PUT OFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/19/world.body_text: **********A military court today adjourned the trial of four Solidarity advisers accused of plotting to overthrow the Polish system. The court cited a pending decision in Parliament on an amnesty for political prisoners. **********As the four men, Jacek Kuron, Adam Michnik, Zbigniew Romaszewski and Henryk Wujec, were taken back to Mokotow prison, where they have spent the last year of their two-and-a-half- year-long detention, associates emerged from the closed proceedings to tell foreign reporters what had occurred. **********They said Lieut. Col. Jan Przygodzki, the presiding judge, had adjourned the trial in view of an announcement Tuesday that Parliament would consider an amnesty proposed by the Communist-sponsored Coalition for National Unity. Parliament will meet in a special session Saturday. **********Anniversary of Communist State **********The coalition, which includes nonparty people and pro-Government Roman Catholics, asked Parliament to release political prisoners and those convicted of minor criminal offenses in connection with the 40th anniversary Sunday of the formation of the Polish People's Republic.  A statement by Interpress, a Government information agency dealing with the foreign press, later said: ''The reconvening of the trial is not certain because it is not known what the scope of the amnesty may be.'' **********According to associates of the accused, Mr. Kuron was unhappy with the decision. **********''For two and a half years, I have been working on my speech for the 40th anniversary of the People's Republic,'' he was quoted as having said. ''Never mind, it will be published anyway.'' **********Mr. Michnik, who in letters from prison had said that he would oppose an amnesty, was quoted as having said: **********''Whatever the Government does will be wrong, whether they let us go or whether they hold us.'' **********Mr. Romaszewski was said to have added, ''Yes, but it has been that way for the last year.''  Political Prisoners Put at 660 **********Jerzy Urban, the Government spokesman, in announcing plans for an amnesty, said Tuesday that there were 660 political prisoners, of whom 58 had been sentenced. **********The announcement had spurred speculation whether an amnesty would affect the four Solidarity advisers. Several people associated with the Solidarity movement, which is now banned, said that the extent of the amnesty would be signaled by what happened in court today. **********''If they go ahead with the case this morning and let Jacek testify,'' a former Solidarity official said, ''it would indicate that the powers will let the trial run its course. If there is an adjournment, it would suggest that they do not want Kuron and Michnik to use the trial as a forum and that the four could be amnestied.'' **********The trial, which opened Friday and then adjourned until today, was to have resumed with a statement by Mr. Kuron, who was expected to deliver his own indictment of the Government. Many people believe that he forced the Government to convene the trial by staging a brief hunger strike to further his demand for a hearing.   Poland Is Called Stabilized **********The Government has linked the prospective amnesty to its contention that the situation in Poland has stabilized since the social tremors of the Solidarity period of 1980-81 and the martial law that followed. **********Mr. Urban, the spokesman, said the decision to move toward an amnesty was rooted in Polish traditions and had nothing to do with the international situation. This was apparently an allusion to statements in the United States that economic sanctions against Poland might be eased if political prisoners were freed. **********The court session today differed from the earlier one in that several associates of the defendants were admitted in addition to two relatives for each man. The associates included Tadeusz Konwicki, the author of books such as ''The Polish Complex'' that have been translated around the world, and Bronislaw Geremek and Tadeusz Mazowiecki, associates of Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/world.main_headline: STRONGMAN FINDS SURINAME ISN'T EASILY SUBDUED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/world.print_headline: STRONGMAN FINDS SURINAME ISN'T EASILY SUBDUED
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/world.body_text: **********Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, a former physical education instructor who seized power here in 1980, promised recently to make the army ''the vanguard of the struggle of our people for national liberation.'' **********The colonel added that he wanted to form a new official party to serve ''the great mass of the people'' of this tiny country, a former Dutch colony of 350,000 people on the northern coast of South America that became independent in 1975. **********But despite Colonel Bouterse's plans, life in the capital has gone on much as before, with most people quietly bypassing calls to political action despite an atmosphere of intimidation created in part by informers, telephone taps and a weekday curfew from midnight to 4 A.M. **********Paramaribo is a town of porticoed Dutch colonial wooden houses punctuated by Hindu temples and mosques, side by side with Protestant Bible societies and one of the oldest synagogues in the Western Hemisphere.   A Shared Sense of Order **********The highly literate population, divided between the descendants of Asian Indians, Javanese, blacks, Chinese and Europeans, hardly seems to be revolutionary tinder. The people observe four major religions and share a Dutch-inherited sense of order and social decorum. As evidence of this, it is noteworthy that Suriname is the only country in the Latin American region where a law requiring motorcyclists to wear helmets is universally obeyed. **********Despite official criticism of the United States, American culture predominates. A late-night international flight is met by a guard of uneasy young soldiers; the baggage handler talking to the army commander wears a cap emblazoned ''I Love New York.'' **********Though the press is censored, book shops carry Time and Newsweek; the shelves offer a selection ranging from Graham Greene to George Orwell. Che Guevara, Marx and Mao are not in evidence. **********One week in December, a Paramaribo marquee promised ''Porno and Strong American Sex.'' The nearby Nas-Kip restaurant offers Kentucky- style fried chicken. The state-run television broadcasts National Basketball Association games as well as ''Sanford and Son'' and ''Dynasty'' for an audience that speaks English as well as Dutch.   Memory of Killings Persists **********A tough sense of humor helps many face the daily worry of new Government repression. A wee-hours trip to a distant nightspot - curfew is lifted Friday and Saturday nights - brought a carload of revelers face to face with a patrolling army armored personnel carrier on a narrow street. ''Traffic control Suriname style,'' the driver of the car quipped, nonchalantly swerving around the squat military vehicle. **********Sometimes the humor doesn't help. The memory of the killing in 1982 of 15 of Colonel Bouterse's political opponents dimmed Christmas celebrations in some homes in this small and close- knit community. The men were killed by Government troops and militia members in an effort to crush growing demands for a return to electoral democracy. **********The first anniversary of the deaths on Dec. 8 was by all accounts quietly observed by many and openly marked by few. The followers of a trade union leader who was shot wore black armbands. A group of friends who tried to visit the graves of the slain men was turned away by a squad drawn from the 3,000-strong army that is Colonel Bouterse's main base of support. Later the mourners were allowed to pay their respects to the dead. **********In December, the colonel was confronted by the first challenge to his rule since the killings a year earlier, a walkout by 4,000 bauxite workers. Their strike stilled the country's aluminum and bauxite works, the backbone of the economy.   New Violence Is Feared **********Though Col. Bouterse sought to negotiate an end to the dispute, people said they were deeply afraid that he might resort to violence again to cow the many opponents to his one-man rule. ''This man says he wants to be friends now,'' an auto mechanic said. ''But how are we going to shake hands with a machine gun?'' **********Over the last year, blossoming relations with Cuba brought a flood of delegations, projects and promises. The Cuban Ambassador, Osvaldo Cardenas, was described as the toast of Paramaribo. In short order, he was involved in virtually every aspect of Government business, according to Government officials and outside observers. **********But the expanding ties with Cuba were swiftly cut after the United States invasion of Grenada. The timing was a coincidence, according to Western and Latin American diplomats. Mr. Bouterse reportedly already feared the Cubans were undermining his personal authority, training a peoples' militia and giving headstrong army men and local leftist politicians too many ideas. **********On Oct. 25, the day United States Marines landed on Grenada, he expelled the Cubans, complaining in a broadcast speech of ''the increasingly unmanageable relations between the two countries.''  Listing the Cubans' Faults **********Now everyone seems to have a complaint against the Cubans. They were pushy, a Government spokesman, Sgt. Maj.  Charlo Doedel, said in an interview. The Government asked five Cubans to come to Suriname to learn Dutch; the Cubans sent 40. Mr. Cardenas, the Ambassador, distributed a calling card identifying himself as ''Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the Republic of Cuba.'' This was seen by some Surinamese as more than a bit officious in a land where warbling contests between pet songbirds is a national pastime and tennis shoes are worn to church. **********A monthlong trip to Cuba was distressing, Sergeant Major Doedel said. ''I didn't like the food, I didn't like the movies with politics in everything, I didn't like standing in line all the time.'' **********''They wanted me to stay for three more weeks to see the whole island,'' he added. ''I told them no, no. I wouldn't stay for even one more day. We're not Marxists. We're Surinamers.'' **********The big question now facing many Surinamese is whether to stay or to go. Staying means political uncertainty, possible violence, certain economic hardship. But because of currency restrictions, leaving means leaving most things behind. **********Many of the country's doctors, lawyers, teachers and engineers left before the Government tightened travel regulations, and an estimated 180,000 Surinamese now live in the Netherlands. Others say they have found it less easy to drop profession and sentiment in a move abroad. **********''Everything I've worked for is here,'' one businessman said. A professional spoke of being torn between his desire to emigrate and his wish to help his country get back on its feet. **********''If I go into the Government, I have to walk over 15 bodies,'' he said. ''But we need people from outside to join in. Maybe step by step we can do something.'' **********Colonel Bouterse, who is reported to have bought his fifth house, appears determined for now to stay on, though he seldom appears in public, reportedly fearing an attempt on his life. **********''His back is a little bit against the wall,'' a Latin American diplomat here said. ''He is a sergeant who wound up running a country. It is not an easy job.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/09/11/busin.body_text: **********Using special couriers instead of cables, Citibank yesterday began sending the proposed agreement for restructuring Mexico's foreign debt to about 550 banks around the world. **********Final agreement was reached over the weekend between Mexico and 13 leading international banks, the so- called steering committee that negotiates on behalf of all banks that have lent money to Mexico. Now it is necessary for each of the lending banks to ratify the accord. **********Because the documents were so thick, Citibank - which heads the steering group - decided to deliver them by hand. Each bank was to receive four sets of the documents and each set consisted of four documents: a message from Jesus Silva Herzog, Mexico's Finance Minister; a message from Jacques de Larosi ere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, which will monitor Mexico's economic performance; a message from the steering banks, and a ''draft of the financing principles.'' **********Decisions Within Six Months **********A detail of the agreement attracting attention in the currency and credit markets yesterday would allow non-American banks to switch up to half their dollar-denominated loans into their own currencies. The banks would have to make their decisions within about six months. **********To avoid a serious impact on the foreign exchange markets, however, the banks are encouraged to stretch such currency shifts over several years. Under the agreement, 50 percent can be switched from dollars to other currencies if the bank agrees that the change be done over 42 months. The permissible amount drops to 40 percent if the switching is done over 30 months, and to 30 percent if it is accomplished over 24 months. **********If the switching was all done immediately, it could unsettle the foreign exchange markets, pushing up the value of the dollar. This is because Mexico, in effect, must pay off the dollar loan and substitute for it a loan denominated in the currency of the lending bank. **********New Loan Would Be Made **********This is accomplished by the bank making a new loan in its native currency to Mexico. Mexico then sells the currency to obtain dollars, which it uses to repay its dollar loan from the non-American bank. **********The eligible currencies are Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, West German marks, Dutch guilders, European currency units, Italian lire, Japanese yen, British sterling and Swiss francs. In addition, banks wanting to convert into dollars loans denominated in other currencies would be allowed to do so. **********Bankers said the concept was not new and that this had been done before. However, the move has been formalized under the latest agreement. One effect could be a substantial lowering of interest costs for Mexico, because in some countries, such as West Germany, interest rates are considerably lower than they are in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/07/11/busin.body_text: **********Singapore will refuse work permits to foreigners who earn less than 1,500 Singapore dollars a month - about $700 - or are not graduates of recognized universities, the Government said today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/06/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM; HART: LET'S FOCUS ON GROWTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/06/busin.body_text: **********FOR a decade, the American economy has been struggling with change. The challenge facing our leadership is meeting that change and mastering it, to make this country more competitive and compassionate. **********Signs of change are everywhere. The internationalization of our marketplace, the rise of service industries and the boom in new business are creating new kinds of jobs. The increasing participation of women in the work force is dramatically altering our labor market. **********At the same time, basic industries drift into crisis. Skilled workers swell unemployment lines in an economy that still excludes millions of black, Asian and Hispanic Americans. **********Restoring a 1950's economy is not a viable policy for the 1980's. Yet that is the choice offered by the competing prescriptions of conventional politics. **********The Reagan Administration has relied on massive fiscal stimulation to generate a temporary, uneven recovery and a tight-fisted monetary policy to temper its pace. The seeds of the next recession are already sown; a bumper crop of Federal deficits stretches into the future. Tax breaks for the privileged, primarily encouraging investment in tax shelters, substitute for a coherent strategy to modernize American enterprise and retrain American workers. **********By contrast, the Democratic policies of the past, of Band-Aids and bailouts, offer merely the chance to move America back - to insulate our economy and freeze it in patterns of an earlier time. Not only will this resistance jeopardize our best prospects, it will quickly worsen our present distress. **********On balance, the wholesale revival of old programs without any plan to improve or finance them is either a false promise or an impossible policy. Trade barriers such as domestic content legislation will set off trade wars, destroying many more jobs than could possibly be saved. We cannot advance new industries or rebuild manufacturing assets with a special-interest approach that preserves a few jobs, but dooms our industrial heartland to wither and finally die. **********THE 1984 election should not be reduced to a contest between two visions of our economic past. Politicians of the past fought over how to redistribute a stagnant pie; now we must focus on making the pie grow again, while keeping that growth equitable. This will require six steps. *********** First, we must set new priorities for a fair and leaner Federal budget. We can cut $139 billion from defense over the next five years and actually improve our national security. We can cut $23 billion in energy outlays over the next 20 years, including unnecessary subsidies for nuclear power and synfuels. Reworking our health system stressing health maintenance can yield major savings. **********We should spend less in some areas, and invest more in others: $20 billion a year through 1989 in education, nutrition, job retraining and the nation's basic infrastructure - our bridges, highways and railroads. *********** Second, we must raise revenues through a fair tax system that includes partial deferral of tax indexing adjusted to protect poor and moderate-income taxpayers; a $750 cap on the third year of the Reagan tax cut, and a 5 percent surcharge on joint returns of over $100,000. I favor a 10 percent surtax on corporations, which pay a lower percentage of their earnings in income taxes than many low- income families. We must seek far- reaching reforms, close the loopholes and reward savings and investment. Cumulatively, these changes could increase revenues by $300 billion or more over the five-year period. *********** Third, we should invest selectively and effectively in programs directed at causes rather than symptoms of our economic problems. Federal investment can be a catalyst for private and public research and development. Instead of maintaining people in idleness, underemployment or underachievement, Federal policy should invest in human potential. We can establish the American Defense Education Act to strengthen our schools, and individual training accounts so workers can match their skills to an evolving economy. *********** Fourth, we must shape a strategy to modernize our keystone enterprises - steel, autos, machine tools and others. Rather than bailouts for individual companies, we must bring labor, management and capital into the White House to forge industrial modernization and growth agreements industrywide. *********** Fifth, we should move agriculture into the new economy of the 21st century. A comprehensive farm policy can build overseas markets, stabilize income at home and insure research and soil conservation. By targeting commodity assistance, we can limit agriculture outlays to $6 billion to $8 billion, while restoring prosperity to America's farm belt. *********** Sixth, we must negotiate fair and free trade agreements. The answer is not to close this nation's markets but to open international ones. Trading partners must play by the same rules - and a modernized American economy can compete with any country. **********We dare not resist change; we must harness it to America's hopes. We can't stay mired in the failing policies of Ronald Reagan or the failed policies of the previous Administration. For Democrats to win the next election, we must speak to the issues of this and the next generation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/23/busin.main_headline: MANAGEMENT MAY BUY BALDWIN'S MGIC UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/23/busin.print_headline: MANAGEMENT MAY BUY BALDWIN'S MGIC UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/23/busin.body_text: **********The management of the MGIC Investment Corporation is preparing an offer to acquire the unit of the troubled Baldwin-United Corporation, a commission of insurance regulators said yesterday. **********The Special Masters Commission, a group appointed by the courts in Arkansas and Indiana, where Baldwin has six of its insurance operations, said it had requested MGIC management to present a formal proposal. MGIC is the leading mortgage insurer in the United States. **********The commission is an independent body that is trying to maximize the company's insurance opportunities. It said it would welcome other bidders but would make no recommendations as to MGIC's sale. **********Neither the commission nor the management of MGIC would comment on the plans for the acquisition of the Milwaukee-based company. There was no mention of a price. **********Ford Denies Interest **********Under pressure from regulators to generate cash, Baldwin put MGIC up for sale last September. No formal offers have been made, but it has been rumored that Ford Motor Company's credit unit has offered $900 million. But Ford has denied an interest, and John Ochotnicky, a spokesman for MGIC, said that the offer is ''just a rumor.'' The principals in the proposed deal were not identified, but they are presumed to include Max H. Karl, who founded MGIC in 1956 and is its chairman, and John McCormack, who became president of MGIC after Gerald L. Friedman resigned two years ago. Mr. Friedman opposed the merger of MGIC and Baldwin in 1982. **********Analysts say it was the purchase of MGIC for $1.2 billion that complicated Baldwin's problems, which centered on its sales of single-premium deferred annuities. The purchase saddled Baldwin with $542 million in debt. A year later Baldwin began selling assets in order to raise $500 million to pay off debts. On Sept. 26, Baldwin filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Its total debt was $1.6 billion. **********Under its reorganization, Baldwin's management outlined a plan to sell MGIC and dozens of smaller companies. The plan ultimately envisions paring Baldwin until it consists of only six life insurance subisidaries. Those insurance operations were taken over last summer by insurance regulators in Arkansas and Indiana for ''rehabilitation''. **********The sale of all or parts of MGIC would be closely monitored by the Special Masters Commission, made up of insurance commissioners of several states. The commission's task, it said, is to obtain maximum value for Baldwin companies, maintain their insurance business under existing management and obtain additional capital from outside sources. The commission asked Goldman, Sachs & Company to continue discussions with other parties interested in either MGIC or the American Municipal Bond Assurance Corporation, MGIC's municipal bond guarantee subsidiary.  According to Victor H. Palmieri, who was hired as Baldwin's president a year ago, the sale of MGIC may not be easy. Numerous legal complications could delay the sale, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/08/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation reported today that it earned a record $1.3 billion in the fourth quarter of 1983, almost nine times as much as in the comparable 1982 period, and a turnaround from three years ago, when the company was reporting losses. **********For all of 1983. G.M., the nation's largest auto maker, reported record earnings of $3.73 billion, compared with $962.7 million for all of 1982. **********In 1980, G.M. lost $763 million, its first deficit since the early 1920's. **********Analysts attributed the rapid improvement in the company's fortunes to restraints on the import of Japanese cars, the ending of rebates, the strong performance of its financing subsidiary and reduced labor and materials costs. **********The strong results are also likely to mean large bonuses for G.M. executives, who have gone without such incentives during the three lean years. Roger B. Smith, the chairman, could receive a bonus of $666,000 - more than his 1982 salary. (Page D4.) **********Mr. Smith reported the earnings during a speech at the National Press Club in Washington. He noted that the improved profits came on a sales unit volume that was just 10 percent greater than 1980. **********'Import Quotas Were Critical' **********''The import quotas were critical,'' said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst and investment manager with Vilas-Fischer Associates. ''Without the quotas, there would not be any record earnings, because the Japanese would be pursuing their usual volume-based strategy and holding down prices. Without the quotas, G.M.'s revenue per unit would have been significantly lower.'' Mrs. Keller noted that the company managed to largely withdraw its costly rebate programs last year without harming sales, effectively increasing prices. **********Mr. Smith termed 1983 as ''the turnaround year we have been working for.'' He said 1984 is expected to be another good year for G.M. **********G.M. was the first of the Big Three auto makers to report on what is expected to be a record year for the industry. Analysts have predicted that, for the year, the Ford Motor Company may earn as much as $1.8 billion and the Chrysler Corporation nearly $900 million, when they report later this month. **********G.M.'s quarterly earnings amount to $4.11 a share and compare with $145 million, or 45 cents a share, in the final quarter of 1982. For the year, the company earned $11.84 a share, compared with $3.09 a share for 1982. **********G.M.'s sales in the fourth quarter totaled $20.8 billion, a 49.6 percent increase over the $13.9 billion reported in the comparable quarter a year ago. Sales for the year were $74.58 billion, compared with $60.03 billion in 1982, an increase of 24.2 percent. Unit sales for the year totaled 7.8 million vehicles, compared with 6.2 million, an increase of 25.8 percent. **********Fewer Shares in 1978 The fourth-quarter earnings exceed the previous G.M. record of $1.26 billion set in the first quarter of 1979, and the yearly profit surpassed the old record of $3.5 billion, set in 1978. The sales total surpassed the previous mark of $66.3 billion recorded in 1979. But the per-share figure for the year was below the record $12.24 set in 1978, when fewer shares were outstanding. **********Analysts are estimating that 1984 earnings could exceed $4.5 billion for G.M., $2.2 billion for Ford and $1.5 billion for Chrysler. The American companies will continue to benefit from import restraints on Japanese cars which were extended for a fourth year until March 1985, although the quota was increased slightly to 1.8 million cars from the 1.68 million level of the previous three years. **********In his talk, Mr. Smith devoted a great deal of emphasis to the company's profit-sharing plan with the United Automobile Workers union. The $322 million generated by the plan, he said, will result in a payment of $640 to $700 for each unionized and lower- level white-collar worker. **********The profit sharing plan, he said, should motivate workers to greater effort and end resentments that profits only benefit shareholders. **********''Profit sharing puts entrepreneurship back into the free enterprise system,'' Mr. Smith declared. **********'Sweetening the Formula' **********Donald Ephlin, director of the U.A.W.'s G.M. department, described the record earnings as ''good news for workers'' and added, ''We at the U.A.W. believe it is sensible to divide the economic pie after it has been baked.'' He said the union will advocate ''sweetening the formula'' for profit sharing when talks on a new contract begin this July.  G.M.'s nonconsolidated subsidiaries, principally its General Motors Acceptance Corporation financing unit and the Motors Insurance Company, contributed almost $1 billion to the parent company's profit, earning $982.5 million in 1983, compared with $687 million in 1982 and $348.4 million in 1981. Analysts said the subsidiaries, which provide wholesale and retail financing for car purchases, benefited from the decline in interest rates on large-scale borrowing while consumer loans remained high. **********Although G.M.'s earnings were helped by accounting practices related to overseas operations, the company said its 1983 earnings were reduced by $348.4 million, or $1.35 a share, by adjustment to reflect the effect of foreign currency translations. In addition, the company said actual currency exchange operations produced a loss of $52.3 million in 1983 compared with $348.4 million in 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/14/busin.main_headline: Kaiser Steel to Sell Its Fontana Works
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/14/busin.print_headline: Kaiser Steel to Sell Its Fontana Works
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/14/busin.body_text: **********The Kaiser Steel Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Fontana steel works to the Pacific Steel Corporation for more than $100 million. **********Kaiser said the companies are negotiating a definitive purchase agreement, which is expected to be completed in about 30 days. **********Kaiser said the purchase price would be paid over a five-year period. Pacific Steel, which is controlled by Michael Wilkinson, an investor, said it intends to reopen and operate some of the facilities at Fontana if the agreement is completed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/06/world.body_text: **********A judge investigating the killing of a French Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Andre Jarlan, during anti-Government protests in September indicted a policeman on charges of manslaughter today, the church's lawyer said. **********The lawyer, Hector Salazar, said that the judge, Hernan Correa, had indicted Cpl. **********Leonel Ovea, accusing him of having fired the shot that killed Father Jarlan inside his wooden house. The lawyer said Corporal Ovea was under arrest in a paramilitary police academy. **********''He is identified as the person who fired the shot,'' Mr. Salazar said. **********Father Jarlan was reading in his room in the district of La Victoria during protests Sept. 4 when he was hit in the neck by one of two bullets that came through the wooden wall. **********The Government promptly denied charges by his colleague, the Rev. Pierre Dubois, that security forces had been responsible, and the incident strained relations with the church. **********Father Dubois maintained that the police had regularly opened fire during protests in the district of La Victoria, with little regard for the inhabitants. Almost 100 people have been killed over the last 18 months in such protests, called to press for a quick return to democracy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/07/world.main_headline: U.S. LINKS IRANIAN-BACKED GROUP TO HIJACKING OF KUWAITI AIRLINER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/07/world.print_headline: U.S. LINKS IRANIAN-BACKED GROUP TO HIJACKING OF KUWAITI AIRLINER
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/07/world.body_text: **********American officials said today that the hijackers holding a jetliner at the Teheran airport were closely connected with the Iranian-backed Shiite terrorist group that is believed to have bombed the United States Embassy and the Marine barracks in Lebanon last year. **********''We have intelligence that leaves no doubt that the hijackers are connected with the Iranian-sponsored terror network in Lebanon and elsewhere,'' a senior State Department official said. He specifically mentioned the Party of God, a militant Shiite Moslem group that has been involved in the bombings in Lebanon and in an attack on the American Embassy and other targets in Kuwait last December. **********The officials also said the Iranian authorities appeared to be cooperating with the hijackers by facilitating press access to the plane and transmitting their demands through the Iranian press agency. **********Iranians Called 'Sympathetic' **********''The Iranians seem very sympathetic to the hijackers,'' a senior official said. ''They certainly have made no move to capture them.'' **********The officials said that it was not clear whether the Iranians had in fact planned the hijacking, but that they had abetted the hijackers after the plane reached Teheran. **********''Whether or not there was complicity before the fact,'' one American official said, ''there is clear complicity and sympathy for the hijackers after the fact.'' **********Direct U.S. Intervention Unlikely **********The officials said there appeared to be little opportunity for direct American intervention. They noted that any military action would have to be extensive and would certainly result in the loss of more lives among the hostages. **********Similarly, the hostage rescue teams that have been trained for situations like this require the cooperation of the host government if they are to have any chance of success. ''There is no way for us to insert a team into a hostile environment like Teheran,'' one official said. **********Nonetheless, the incident seemed likely to revive the debate in Washington over the wisdom and effectiveness of using military force to respond to terrorism abroad. **********For several months Secretary of State George P. Shultz has been warning that the United States must be prepared to use force to combat terrorism, even if some innocent people are hurt in the process. His policy has been sharply opposed by key Administration officials, including Vice President Bush and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger. **********At least six Americans were known to have been aboard the plane at the time it was hijacked, including three officials of the United States Agency for International Development. Two of the A.I.D. officials apparently have been shot, according to a statement today by the State Department. A third official and an American businessman are still being held captive, the statement said. **********Two American women, a mother and her daughter, were among the hostages released and flown to Pakistan earlier today on an Iran Air plane. **********The statement said, ''It appears that two A.I.D. employees have been murdered at Teheran airport.'' But it cautioned: ''We cannot absoutely confirm that the murders took place, nor can we absolutely confirm the identities of these individuals and officially release their names.'' **********The State Department said it was holding up the release of the names of the Americans until positive identification could be obtained from Teheran through the Swiss Government. The United States broke diplomatic relations with Iran during the hostage crisis that began in 1979 and conducts business with Teheran through the Swiss Embassy.   'Definitely a Passenger' **********Edwina Hegna, the wife of an A.I.D. official, told The Associated Press this afternoon that State Department officials had told her they were ''99 percent sure'' that her husband, Charles, had been shot by the hijackers. Mr. Hegna, 50 years old, is based in Pakistan. **********''They came and told me that they were 99 percent sure that the first person thrown off the plane was my husband,'' Mrs. Hegna said. ''He was definitely a passenger.'' **********American intelligence officials said the hijacking appeared to be part of a continuing effort by the Party of God to win the release of 14 of its members who are in jail in Kuwait. The 14 were tried and convicted of the Dec. 12, 1983, bomb attacks on the American Embassy and French Consulate in Kuwait and other targets there. Two of the 14 have been sentenced to death. **********The Party of God has repeatedly demanded their release, and has offered to exchange them for three Americans it has been holding hostage in Lebanon since early this year. **********The three Americans are Jeremy Levin, the Middle East Bureu Chief of Cable News Network; William Buckley, the political officer at the American Embassy in Beirut, and the Rev. Benjamin Weir, a Presbyterian minister who has lived in Lebanon for 20 years. All three were kidnapped in separate incidents off the streets of Beirut, and the United States believes they are being held by the Party of God in Lebanon. **********A 'Clear Link'American officials said they were persuaded that the same group was behind the current hijacking both by the similar nature of the demands and by specific intelligence. They declined to reveal the nature of the intelligence, except to say it pointed to a ''clear link,'' as one official put it, between the hijackers and the Party of God network. **********Some of the information reaching the West from the scene was provided by Michael Gurdus, an Israeli radio expert who monitors cockpit-to-ground conversations around the Middle East from his studio in Tel Aviv. **********A Gurdus tape of sounds from the interior of the aircraft was broadcast on Israeli radio today. Listeners heard a man's agonized screams and hysterical weeping as he was apparently beaten by the hijackers. The Israeli radio reported that it was the voice of a Kuwaiti who was apparently killed later. **********American officials said they had received reports of ''terrible brutality'' on board the hijacked airliner. People are being badly beaten,'' one official said. ''It is a gruesome, terrible scene.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/11/world.main_headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; East German Defends Talks With the West
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/11/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD ; East German Defends Talks With the West
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/11/world.body_text: **********East Germany published a top-level defense of discussions with the West today, despite Soviet attacks on its efforts to improve relations with Bonn. **********Herbert Haeber, East Germany's senior expert on relations with West Germany, was quoted by the Communist Party newspaper Neues Deutschland as calling for a return to ''peaceful economic and political relations through dialogue.'' **********''It must be the aim of every sensible policy,'' he said, ''to stop rearmament and oppose confrontation and turn the wheel back towards disarmament and detente.'' **********His comments were published as the Soviet press resumed its attacks on closer links between the two Germanys, in what Western diplomats interpreted as an attempt to increase pressure on the East German leader, Erich Honecker, to cut back on his policies of easing tensions. Next month Mr. Honecker is scheduled to make the first visit to West Germany by an East German Communist leader.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/12/busin.body_text: **********Two Austrian auto makers said today that a continuing shortage of auto supplies caused by the five-week-old metalworkers' strike in West Germany would force them to make further cuts in production. BMW-Steyr, a subsidiary of BMW, said it would halt production indefinitely on Tuesday, idling 1,000 of its 1,300 employees. The Vienna subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation said 300 more employees would be added Tuesday to the 1,200 on shorter shifts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/15/busin.body_text: **********The Petro-Lewis Corporation, citing the impact of a $12.8 million write- off of expenses related to the company's Yield Plus Fund II limited partnerships, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $2.3 million in the second fiscal quarter of 1984, which ended Dec. 31. This contrasted to earnings of $9.2 million, or 38 cents a share, a year earlier. **********Petro-Lewis, an oil and gas company based in Denver, said revenues in the period fell 10.3 percent, to $83.1 million, from $92.6 million. **********Oil and gas revenues, however, increased 16.5 percent, to $67.1 million, from $57.6 million, because of higher production of oil and gas. **********The company earlier announced that it was withdrawing its Yield Plus Fund II in order to reduce corporate and partnership bank debt by about $1 billion through the sale of a portion of the producing properties that the company and its partnerships own. **********Petro-Lewis said it was projecting losses for the rest of the fiscal year 1984, unless such losses could be offset by a gain from the sale of producing properties. **********Petro-Lewis was started in 1968 by Jerome A. Lewis to introduce the idea of buying producing oil properties and selling equity in them through oil income funds. **********Petro-Lewis is paid a management fee equal to 15 percent of program subscriptions. The company reinvests its management fee in each partnership to buy a 15 percent general partnership interest. During the fiscal year 1983, $802 million was raised through public partnerships. **********Petro-Lewis produced 18,200 barrels of oil and 70.4 million cubic feet of gas a day in the latest three months, up from 14,500 barrels of oil and 64 million cubic feet of gas a day in the comparable period a year earlier. **********Dresser Industries **********Dresser Industries, citing ''cost reduction and efficiency measures instituted during the past two years,'' announced that it had a net income in the first fiscal quarter of 1985, which ended Jan. 31, of $9.6 million, or 12 cents a share, contrasted to a loss of $7.4 million a year earlier. **********Dresser, a major supplier of technology and energy resources products based in Dallas, said revenues in the latest three months slipped 4.6 percent, to $795.1 million, from $833.6 million. **********The company said that its backlog of unshipped manufacturing orders showed improvement in the latest three months, increasing 10.7 percent, to $993 million at Jan. 31, from $897 million three months earlier, but was still 3.6 percent below the $1.03 billion level of Jan. 31, 1983. **********Earnings tables, D23.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/16/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT; COMMUTER PLANE LIFTS SAAB'S HOPES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/16/busin.body_text: **********BARNABY J. FEDER **********LINKOPING, Sweden - It is tempting to describe Saab-Scania A.B. as the ''other'' Swedish vehicle manufacturer. Volvo A.B., Scandinavia's largest industrial concern, makes more cars, trucks and buses than Saab, Sweden's sixth-largest company, and Volvo is better known in most parts of the world. **********But Saab has a long aerospace tradition and is now deep in a project that could go a long way toward wiping out any misconception that it is Volvo's kid brother. On Thursday, Saab and its partner, Fairchild Industries, a major aerospace company based in Germantown, Md., will deliver the first of what they hope will be hundreds of propeller-driven commuter and executive aircraft in the 34-seat to 45-seat range. **********The first Saab-Fairchild 340 will go to Switzerland's Crossair. Late in April, Comair, a commuter airline based in Cincinnati, is scheduled to get the first of 12 planes it has ordered. By the end of the year, Saab and Fairchild plan to deliver 24 planes, costing about $5.3 million each. Philip Morris Inc. and the Mellon Bank have signed on as the first customers for the executive version. **********New Generation of Planes **********The 340 is the first of a new generation of pressurized cabin commuter planes tailored to a market that has mushroomed in the wake of deregulation in the United States, and it is the only one being built with an American partner. **********Saab and Fairchild contend that they have a six-month lead over the 36-seat Dash Eight, being developed by state-owned De Havilland of Canada, and considerably longer over Brazilian, French-Italian and Spanish-Indonesian planes that are also under development. The worldwide market, they estimate, is for more than 2,000 aircraft in the next nine years. **********''The 340 has had the highest priority with top management,'' said Thomas Turner, president and chief executive officer of the Saab-Fairchild venture. ''Saab is very anxious to make a name in commercial aviation.'' **********But Saab is also working hard on the introduction of an antiship missile this year and the development of a multicapability combat aircraft, the Gripen, which is scheduled to go into production in 1992. Saab's concentration on aerospace is coming after a decade of dependence on trucks and cars for the overwhelming proportion of its profits and sales. **********Last year, despite a 5 percent decline in its truck, bus and engine sales, the Scania division accounted for 45 percent of Saab's $2.7 billion in sales and just over half of its $263 million pretax profit. The Saab car division provided an additional 40 percent of the revenue and a like share of pretax profits. **********Handicaps for Swedish Company **********Saab was founded through mergers of several companies in 1937 when the Swedish Government, worried about defense, wanted to create a military aircraft industry. Ever since, Saab's aerospace division has been preoccupied with military aircraft sold to Sweden and a handful of other nonaligned nations. **********Saab's problem is that the military market is a stifling one for a manufacturer in a country that has limited domestic needs, tight controls for deciding which nations are acceptable buyers and little weight to throw around in the world of international arms sales. **********Moreover, while Saab confidently describes its current flagship, the Viggen, as an all-weather combat plane comparable to the McDonnell Douglas F-15, the ony Saab ever tested in combat was a vastly different J-29 ''Fighting Barrel,'' which supported United Nations troops in the Congo in 1959. **********Direction Changed in 1979 **********In 1979, though, the Swedish Government scrapped a Saab proposal for a night attack and trainer jet and dropped hints that it would be happy to see the company enter the civil aviation field. Saab executives found themselves pushed in a direction they had been considering on their own. Almost 30 years in the car business and the 1969 merger with the truck maker Scania gave them a strong base to finance the investment. **********But Saab was wary. The company had developed a slightly smaller passenger aircraft than the 340 in the late 1940's, and it sold poorly. Before improvements could be made, the company was forced out of the civil field by Government demands that it concentrate on a new generation of military craft. **********This time, Saab wanted to enter the civil field to stay and it looked for a partner. ''We wanted risk-sharing and we wanted access to the markets,'' said George Karnsund, Saab's president. It found both in Fairchild, which had already developed the 19- seat Metro and was working on initial designs for a 30-seat plane. **********Partnership Seems Amicable **********By all accounts, the partnership has been a happy one. Fairchild makes the wings, engine housing and tail at its Farmingdale, L.I., factory, and Saab is responsible for the fuselage, the assembly of subsystems and the flight testing. The first 340 flew just three years from the time the project was announced. **********Whether the project will succeed commercially is not so clear. **********Saab executives say that each partner will invest roughly $130 million through the first production and that 200 planes must be sold to break even. The venture has 100 orders and options it considers firm, but that represents an increase of just 10 percent on figures reported in June 1981. **********In addition to its competitors in new pressurized planes, the partners have to worry about Short Brothers, a British state-owned company in Northern Ireland. It has been in the market for well over a year with a nonpressurized, but less expensive, 36-seat plane that is adequate for many of the runs on which commuter airlines and companies might use the 340.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/12/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in continued slow trading. **********Several brokerage stocks moved higher, fueled by takeover rumors. Most of the technology issues remained under pressure. **********The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 7.33 points, to 1,130.97, after a 4.40-point gain Tuesday. **********In the overall market, decliners on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered gainers, 921 to 645. Volume expanded to 80.3 million shares from 79 million on Tuesday. **********Analysts said that investors remained wary of rising interest rates, although rates in the credit markets have dropped slightly in recent days. **********The two other market indicators also fell yesterday. The exchange's composite index dropped 0.47, to 89.24, and Standard & Poor's index of 500 equities closed at 155, down 0.87. **********''Takeover stocks appear to be the only game in town,'' said Alan R. Ackerman, an analyst at Herzfeld & Stern. ''The current low market volume and negative technical factors are giving evidence that new lows are possibly in the offing. At the moment, what you have is less confidence but not a crisis of confidence.'' **********Ralph Block, vice president for investments at the Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Holding Corporation, said that investors remained nervous about interest rates. **********The market, which had been holding steady, dropped after Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted that short-term interest rates would go higher at year's end. **********Many of the depressed technology issues continued under pressure. NCR tumbled 6, to 98 3/4, and Cray Research dropped 4, to 38 1/2. Losses of up to a point or more were made by International Business Machines, Perkin-Elmer, Honeywell, Computervision, Data General and Sperry. **********Caterpillar Tractor, which was heavily traded, tumbled 4 1/8 points, to 46, after the company announced a first-quarter loss of $109 million. Although this was narrower than the loss a year earlier, analysts had predicted that the company might break even or record a profit. **********J.P. Morgan advanced 1 1/4, to 66 1/4, after it announced a 23.9 percent rise in first-quarter profits. **********Many brokerage stocks moved higher, apparently in response to the acquisition of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb by Shearson/American Express and in anticipation of future mergers. The Advest Group rose 7/8, to 10 7/8, after its announcement yesterday that it would acquire Burgess & Leith. Quick & Reilly, a subject of takeover rumors, rose 1 5/8, to 18 3/8. Paine Webber rose 1 5/8, to 34 3/4. **********Takeovers of oil companies also spurred trading. Felmont Oil, which agreed Tuesday to merge with Homestake Mining, climbed 7 5/8, to 34 3/8, on the American Stock Exchange and was the most active issue of the day there. Homestake fell 2 3/8, to 31 1/4, on the Big Board. **********Prices on the Amex fell, with the market-value index down 0.39, to 204.43. In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.66, to 241.79.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/25/world.main_headline: MAKING AN ISLAND BLOOM: ISRAELIS HELP IN JAMAICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/25/world.print_headline: MAKING AN ISLAND BLOOM: ISRAELIS HELP IN JAMAICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/25/world.body_text: **********Two years ago the vast Clarendon Plain here, 35 miles west of Kingston, was covered with thick jungle and underbrush. **********Now, more than 5,000 acres of the reddish brown earth are plowed in neat furrows that yield tomatoes, melons, peppers, cucumbers and flowers. More than 100 acres have been carved into fish-breeding ponds. **********The farm, which is using an irrigation system developed 15 years ago at a kibbutz in Israel, is regarded here as a technological wonder, producing 50 to 75 percent higher yields than Jamaican experts had anticipated. **********It is all the work of as many as 1,600 Jamaican laborers working for daily wages and a group of 32 Israeli agricultural experts. **********Japanese and Americans, Too **********The involvement of the Israelis is part of an effort by Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga to attract enough foreign investment and technology to put more than 237,000 acres of idle or under-used land into cultivation. **********Besides the Israelis, Japanese farmers are here growing Jamaica's renowned Blue Mountain coffee, Americans are growing rice and bananas, and Englishmen are tending honeybees. **********Mr. Seaga has said most of the foreign farms, includng the Israeli project, are supposed to serve as ''mother farms'' that will provide technology and marketing assistance to neighboring Jamaican farmers, most of whom are working on plots of 10 acres or less. **********At present, more than 62,000 acres in Jamaica are being worked with varying degrees of foreign involvement and a total of about 25,000 Jamaican laborers. There are 18 projects in which foreigners are directly involved.   Seedlings for Jamaicans **********Eli Tisona, managing director of the project involving the Israelis, says he is planning to give seedlings and lend technicians to 100 Jamaican farmers this winter. He plans to buy their crops at guaranteed prices and ship them through his big packing house. **********One of the main aims of the Prime Minister's farm program is to produce vegetables and other crops for sale in the United States and Europe to earn foreign currency, badly needed in Jamaica. Another is to grow rice and other staples for local consumption so that imports of food, which now run to more than $100 million a year, can be reduced. **********The farm program is part of an overall plan to diversify Jamaica's economy, which for the last 20 years has focused on the bauxite mining industry. **********When Mr. Seaga took office in 1980, he said he found the country was nearly bankrupt. The country was spending much more than it was earning and, to make matters worse, a slump in world demand drastically reduced income from bauxite.   A Neglected Industry **********Agriculture was clearly an area where the country could do better. Production of sugar and bananas, traditionally two of its main crops, had fallen to record lows. While money poured in from bauxite, the fields had been neglected. They had also been battered by storms. In the 1960's Jamaica was selling about 300,000 tons of bananas a year. Last year the country exported 23,000 tons, even though it had a standing offer from Britain to take 150,000 tons. **********Vegetables like tomatoes, peppers and cucumbers, which are in demand in New York, London, Paris and other temperate-zone capitals during the winter and can be grown here year- round, had never been produced on a large scale for export. Over the years, rice fields had been abandoned, and imports gradually increased. **********In the spring of 1982, Mr. Tisona recalled, he was in Florida visiting friends. He had made a fortune selling fast-food hamburgers and hamburger- chain franchises in Israel and was looking for a place to invest his money. He was watching television one evening when pictures of President Reagan on a visit to Jamaica came on the screen.   'Never Seen Anything Like That' **********''Everything was so green,'' Mr. Tisona recalled the other day. ''I'd never seen anything like that in Israel. They said Jamaica was looking for foreign investment in agriculture. So I came here to see the Prime Minister.'' **********By October Mr. Tisona had entered into a partnership with the Jamaican Government and was breaking ground as the first foreign investor in Mr. Seaga's new farm program. Mr. Tisona knew nothing about farming, he said, but he hired two experts from the Hazerim kibbutz near the Negev to direct local workers. **********''My business is putting together everything they need to work,'' Mr. Tisona said. ''You have thousands of things to do here besides growing.'' **********October was late to be aiming for the winter market in New York, so Mr. Tisona speeded the growing process by shipping in seedlings from Miami. When word came that a freeze had damaged Florida crops, he planted 50 additional acres, increasing his project to 200 acres. **********In mid-January he was sending peppers and tomatoes to the Hunts Point Market in the Bronx. **********''Because of the bad weather in Florida, we were almost alone in the market,'' Mr. Tisona said. ''They were paying us $29 for a 25-pound box. Normally the price is $12 to $13.''  And Then It Rained **********With such success, he put in several hundred more acres of vegetables and started on the fish ponds. But in the midst of the harvest this year, the farm was hit by the heaviest rains in 25 years. ''It was a disaster,'' Mr. Tisona said. **********Apart from the rain, however, the farm has gone well, and he said he had no intention of turning back. **********With the special irrigation system, a ''drip'' technique developed at the Gavat kibbutz near Haifa, a narrow polyethylene hose studded with little nozzles is stretched the length of the seed beds with a separate nozzle directed at the roots of each plant.  On a schedule controlled by mini-computers, water and fertilizers are fed to the plants from central pumping stations. **********''With the drip system we can push much more fertilizer to the plants, and this allows many more plants per acre,'' Mr. Tisona said. ''Also the surface of the soil stays dry, so it is difficult for insects and disease to develop.''  Israelis Designed Farm **********Israeli engineers laid out the entire farm, taking maximum advantage of topographic features, Mr. Tisona said. To shelter a seedling nursery and fields for carnations and other flowers, they cut into the side of a low ridge, a natural windbreak. They put the fish ponds on high ground so that drainage from them would flow by gravity to the vegetable fields. **********''We don't waste one gallon of water,'' Mr. Tisona said. **********The ponds are aswarm with five varieties of fish and some huge shrimp. **********''We're stocking at seven times the density of most fish farms,'' said Roy Manning of St. Albans, Queens, who has a master's degree from Auburn University and is one of five American aquaculturists working on the farm.   Packing by Computers **********An acre and a half of the farm is occupied by a computerized packing house that Mr. Tisona says is the largest in the Caribbean and one of the most advanced in the world.  At the flick of a switch, fruit and vegetables are sorted according to color and size, washed, dried, waxed and packaged. The packing house was designed and built at the Eilow kibbutz in the western Galilee at a cost of $2 million, shipped to Jamaica and assembled in one month by a dozen Israelis and 25 Jamaicans. **********Mr. Tisona has been working this month with an Israeli produce-marketing cooperative based in London, trying to line up enough cargo jets to handle the coming crop. Most of the fruit and vegetables, Mr. Tisona said, will be sold in Europe, with some going to Baltimore and possibly Atlanta. He said he hoped to avoid New York. **********''The brokers in New York are very tough to deal with,'' he said. ''They try to find excuses to reduce your price. Last year I sent two containers of melons on the same day to New York and Baltimore. In New York they paid us $5 a box. In Baltimore we got $11. In New York they had thousands of excuses, not one broker but all the way through. So we decided not to touch this market.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/world.main_headline: A Threat in Honduras To Kill G.I.'s Reported
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/world.print_headline: A Threat in Honduras To Kill G.I.'s Reported
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/10/world.body_text: **********A little-known leftist guerrilla group has threatened to ''exterminate'' 150 American military advisers and 1,200 Salvadoran soldiers training in northern Honduras, a top police official said today. **********Maj. Manuel de Jesus Trejo, regional police chief, said the Honduran military had adopted security precautions as a result of the threat, but he refused to offer any details. **********The threat by the Peoples' Armed Forces was contained in leaflets spread around the capital over the weekend in ''propaganda bombs'' - low-power explosive packages. **********''We will exterminate all the Yankee imperialist military advisers and the Salvadorans being trained at C.R.E.M., violating our sacred sovereignty to then return to their country to assassinate patriots who fight there against a corrupt government,'' the leaflets said. **********American advisers are training Salvadoran soldiers in antiguerrilla tactics at a regional center, known by its Spanish initials as C.R.E.M., at Puerto Castilla, 315 miles north of the capital. **********Major Trejo said the leaflets were spread Saturday night outside the Chilean Embassy in Palmira, a residential section on the east side of the capital, and at a park named El Obelisco, near the armed forces general staff headquarters. **********''Up to now, we didn't know of the existence of this ultra-leftist group,'' Major Trejo said. ''Despite that, our army has adopted a series of measures during the past 48 hours to prevent any attacks against the American and Salvadoran military,'' **********The United States set up the camp last July to train Salvadoran troops in anti-insurgency tactics to help the provisional President, Alvaro Magana, fight a civil war that has been raging in El Salvador for more than four years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/18/world.body_text: **********President Reagan conferred with his senior advisers again today on what the United States position will be at Soviet-American talks next month on arms control, White House officials said. **********It was the latest in a series of meetings on the subject. **********With the Administration divided on how far to go in meeting Soviet insistence on talks to curb development of new defensive weapons in space, some annoyance was voiced here over statements in Paris and London suggesting that key allies were opposed to the so-called Star Wars program for a space- based defense against missiles. **********British spokesmen were quoted in some news reports this morning as saying that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher shared the views of a high visiting Soviet official, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, that weapons in outer space should be banned. President Francois Mitterrand criticized the American program, calling it overarming, and said France supported talks to prevent the militarization of space. **********The State Department supports research into such defensive programs but sees the ''Star Wars'' program as a bargaining device in talks with the Soviet Union. The Defense Department is opposed to talks that might limit the ''Star Wars'' program or the testing of antisatellite weapons. **********A White House official said he thought Mrs. Thatcher was receiving poor advice and said he hoped that when she and President Reagan met on Saturday at Camp David the British and American positions could be aligned. He said Mr. Mitterrand's statements were unhelpful.
