https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/23/busin.body_text: **********Finding a company to purchase an annuity from without worry of risk might well seem an elusive quest in light of the financial problems surrounding two of the leading issuers of a popular type of retirement policy - the single-premium deferred annuity. **********Despite concerns over the safety of this type of annuity raised by the Charter Company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing last Friday and the Baldwin-United Corporation's filing last year, there are ways for individuals to ferret out insurance companies with a long history of financial strength. And there are steps individuals can take to bail out of an annuity contract with minimum financial loss if the policy appears endangered by a company's deteriorating financial condition. **********The Charter reorganization filing mainly involves its oil refinery operations. The bankruptcy action does not include Charter's insurance subsidiaries, which sold $4.6 billion in deferred annuity policies to about 175,000 people. **********Charter's insurance business had been suffering from a surge of policy redemptions in the wake of the company's overall difficulties and the experience of Baldwin-United policyholders, who still do not know exactly how much their policies will pay out. But Charter officials and state insurance regulators say the insurance units are financially sound and their assets secure and untouchable by the bankruptcy proceedings. **********'We Could Pay Off Everybody' **********''The strongest statement we can make about our financial condition is our ability to pay each and every policyholder in full if necessary,'' Thomas E. Gibbs, chief operating officer of Charter's insurance subsidiary, Charter Security Life, said in a telephone interview yesterday. ''If they all walked in the door tomorrow, we could pay off everybody and still have substantial funds left and we would realize significant additional profits at their expense'' due to withdrawal penalties. **********Terence Lennon, chief of the Life Insurance & Companies Bureau of the New York State Insurance Department, said Charter Security Life's New York subsidiary has a ''good portfolio and will be able to meet their obligations.'' **********He stressed that the Charter situation was not comparable with Baldwin, which had 20 percent of its insurance portfolio invested in Baldwin-related companies. **********Mr. Gibbs said that only one-half of 1 percent of Charter Security's portfolio consists of unsecured obligations of the parent company. **********An Insurance Best Seller **********Offering investors the opportunity to earn high interest rates on a lump- sum payment and have taxes on the earnings deferred until the money is withdrawn, usually at retirement, the single-premium deferred annuity became one of the best-selling insurance products in years. **********Despite the recently tarnished image of the product, many financial advisers believe deferred annuities can be profitable investments. But as policyholders have learned while watching state regulators ''rehabilitate'' the Baldwin-United insurance funds, the investment is only as sound as the company that issues the policy. **********Determining how sound a given policy is can be a difficult task, as evidenced by the failure of many state insurance regulators and investment brokers to see trouble looming early enough at Baldwin-United. Independent research is recommended nonetheless. **********Joseph M. Belth, an insurance professor at Indiana University, recommends not buying from a company unless it has an Ax rating from the A. M. Best Company, which publishes ''Best's Insurance Reports - Life/ Health,'' an independent rating guide available in most public libraries. Further, he suggests, the company should have been awarded the top rating for 10 consecutive years. **********Mr. Belth counted 112 companies that fit the criteria. Neither Baldwin nor Charter was on his list. Charter of New York has a Bx rating; the New Jersey subsidiary has an Ax rating. **********State protection of policyholders varies widely. A number of states, including New York, administer industry-funded guaranty pools to reimburse holders if other remedies fail. **********Withdrawal Penalties **********James A. Barry Jr., chief executive officer of the Barry Financial Group, a Boca Raton, Fla., financial planning firm, said he would sacrifice withdrawal penalties imposed by the company, which can run up to 7 percent, and immediately pull his annuity money as soon as he saw financial problems developing at an issuing company. **********Normally, an individual withdrawing annuity funds also would be subject to tax on the accumulated interest, plus a 5 percent tax penalty if under age 59 1/2 and the policy is less than 10 years old. But Mr. Barry said an individual could avoid any tax consequences by immediately transferring the money to a similar annuity policy with another company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/19/world.main_headline: A TALE OF LONDONDERRY, A CITY WITH TWO NAMES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/19/world.print_headline: A TALE OF LONDONDERRY, A CITY WITH TWO NAMES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/19/world.body_text: **********This is a city so divided that it is not even possible to mention its name without choosing sides. **********Protestant loyalists call it Londonderry, and so it is called on maps. Roman Catholic nationalists, including the majority on the city council, cut London out of the name and call it Derry. Outsiders find themselves awkwardly saying both names, calling the place Londonderry-Derry, or vice versa. **********On a hillside on the east bank of the River Foyle, in an area known as the Waterside, there are two housing projects, one Catholic and one Protestant, divided by a small patch of green and years of conflict. Houses on the dividing line have wire mesh over their windows to keep the bricks and firebombs out.   William of Orange on Horseback **********On the Protestant side there are curbstones painted red, white, and blue, the colors of the Union Jack. A mural shows King William of Orange on horseback. **********On the Catholic side one wall of a vandalized house is painted orange, green and white, the colors of the Irish tricolor, and graffiti praise the Irish Republican Army. **********On the Protestant side there is a family with a retarded child in his 20's - too large to carry out in case of fire - that is afraid to add to the risk by having carpets in their home. When there is trouble at night they put cotton in their son's ears to keep him from being afraid. **********On the Catholic side the mother of an infant and two toddlers said she puts them in a back room when there's trouble because their cribs have been showered with glass at 3 o'clock in the morning. **********Violence is down in Northern Ireland this year, with half as many shootings as last year and slightly more than half as many bombings. But the bitterness, the divisiveness and the potential for extreme violence remain.   2 Premiers Meeting **********It is with great hopes of eventually ending that conflict that Garret FitzGerald, the Irish Prime Minister, and Margaret Thatcher, the British Prime Minister, are meeting Sunday and Monday for a conference on Northern Ireland. Last summer, after a firebombing incident in the Waterside district, some residents urged local politicians to promote the building of a wall between the Catholic homes in Gobnascale and the Protestant homes in the Irish Street area down the hill. Such walls have been built in Belfast and elsewhere to reduce the violence between opposing factions. **********But when word got out that a wall had been suggested, the residents of both the Irish Street and Gobnascale areas met and decided it would just make things worse. **********''I was approached by some of the Protestants about would we be interested in getting people together,'' said Bob Concannon, a Catholic who lived in a house facing the Protestant neighborhood until a hooded gunman was surprised by Mr. Concannon's daughter and fired six shots at her after she dived for cover under her car. The house is now bricked up, and the letters U.V.F., for the Protestant paramiliary Ulter Volunteer Force, painted on the side have been crudely and somewhat ironically repainted L.O.V.E.   The 'Flashpoint' Area **********''When we had our first meeting, everybody wanted a wall,'' Mr. Concannon said. ''We could have built nine walls. Then we had another meeting and said: 'We are divided. Would it not be a good idea to forget our differences?' And everyone started talking about peace.'' **********He added: ''We intend to have further meetings. But since the meetings we have had no violence at all.'' **********Albert and Edna McKechnie are Protestants. They live in what is called the ''flashpoint area.'' Their house is closest to the Protestant section of the city and is shuttered with reinforced wire mesh. **********There are times when the family is awake with anxiety until 5 o'clock in the morning, when they call the police and they don't arrive until the fighting is under way, when she thinks, ''Maybe the wall would be good,'' Mrs. McKechnie said. **********''The community's divided enough,'' said Raymond Philson, 44, who has lived in a row house on the Catholic side all his life. ''By putting up a wall you'll be dividing it more.''  'There's Nothing You Can Do' **********He put reinforced wire mesh on the rear of the house 16 years ago, and it is still there. ''The Irish Street people get the front, we get the back,'' he said. ''My kids have been born and reared with the troubles - petrol bombs, stone-throwing.'' **********''There are good people and bad people down there and up here. You live with it. There's nothing you can do. The politicians are not doing nothing. The kids know nothing but Catholic and Protestant. They hear their brothers and sisters.'' **********''This business of Protestant and Catholic is nonsense,'' said Mrs. McKechnie. ''There's no work. They're sleeping all day, and they're up all night. They're bored. It's more or less an amusement.'' **********''It's worrying,'' she added. ''If my two sons grow up, I'll push them in the army.'' **********''There is a struggle going on,'' Mr. Concannon said, ''and it is for the youth. What we need here are jobs.'' Mr. Concannon, who is unemployed, often tries to help families whose children are in trouble with the law. **********''If you talk to the youth,'' he added, ''the majority have an anger.   Relations at a Low Point **********''You see the poor wee fellows here,'' Mrs. Concannon agreed. ''They have no life. They can't talk on the corner at night. The police are on them.'' **********Although the level of violence is the lowest in years, Gobnascale is still regarded by the police as ''an extremely dangerous area,'' according to Chief Inspector Roy McCune. Patrolmen who go into the neighborhood do so under army guard. **********Relations between the police and residents of Catholic neighborhoods in this city with two names have deteriorated to the point that The Derry Journal said in editorial today that ''The city is no longer policed but garrisoned.'' **********Nonentheless, it was through police- community relations meetings that Mr. McKechnie and Mr. Concannon first met. **********''I don't talk about wall-building, I talk about bridge-building,'' said Inspector McCune, who also opposed building a wall but conceded that ''if the police are promoting something, it can fail.'' **********''Politics,'' said a young Catholic mother whose children have watched the world through wire mesh since they were born. ''It's just an excuse. There's nothing else for them to do. They're passing time.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/03/world.main_headline: BACKERS RETHINK EFFORT TO SHIFT ISRAEL EMBASSY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/03/world.print_headline: BACKERS RETHINK EFFORT TO SHIFT ISRAEL EMBASSY
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/03/world.body_text: **********Several backers of a bill to move the American Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem said privately today that they expected to avoid a direct confrontation with the Administration by making the legislation a ''sense of the Congress'' resolution. Such legislation is not sent to the President for his signature and is not binding. **********President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz have said that the Administration would not move the embassy from Tel Aviv, and they have strongly suggested that Mr. Reagan would veto the current bill if it is adopted by Congress. **********Supporters of the bill said their plan now was not to alter the wording, but rather to leave the legislation as it stands pending hearings starting next week by two subcommittees of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and at the end of the month by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. **********''There's no hurry,'' a House co-sponsor of the legislation said. ''Let's give everyone a chance to be heard on the issue, and then we can speak to the Administration and see what kind of language would be most suitable.''  Originated by Moynihan **********Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who originated the legislation, so far has 38 co-sponsors in the Senate. He said last week that, with the prospect of a Presidential veto, there would have to be consideration of the sense-of-the-Congress approach. **********Several others who back the bill, such as Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, have said they wanted to avoid a fight with the Administration and saw no point in bringing the current bill to a vote now. **********The issue is a difficult one for the Israel lobby in Congress, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee. Some members of the group have been privately critical of Mr. Moynihan for introducing the bill without consulting them, then later asking for their support. Mr. Moynihan, in turn, has been upset because Administration officials discussed the Jerusalem bill with the lobbying group and not with him directly. **********The Israel lobby is usually more interested in such issues as obtaining as much foreign aid for Israel as possible and in blocking arms sales to Arab countries not at peace with Israel. In both these areas, the group has recorded major successes in recent weeks. Both the House Foreign Affairs Committee and the Senate Foreign Relations Committees have substantially raised the amount of economic aid for Israel in the 1985 fiscal year. **********The Administration had originally sought $850 million in economic grants for Israel, in addition to $1.4 billion in military grants. The House committee raised the economic figure to $1.1 billion and the Senate group increased it to $1.2 billion. **********In the current 1984 fiscal year, Israel is receiving $910 million in economic grants and $1.7 billion in military aid. But while the $1.4 billion in military aid for 1985 is all grants that do not have to be repaid, the 1984 figure of $1.7 billion includes $850 million in loans that must be paid back. **********Under pressure from Israeli supporters, the Administration dropped plans to sell Jordan and Saudi Arabia advanced Stinger antiaircraft missiles. Remarks by King Hussein of Jordan, critical of the United States, contributed to the Administration's decision not to press the issue with Congress. **********There are 215 co-sponsors of the Jerusalem bill in the House. The legislation, as currently drafted, ''requires'' the embassy building and the ambassador's residence to be moved from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem ''hereafter.'' **********Since the bill does not set a specific date and does not include any penalty if the embassy is not moved, such as a cut in funds for the embassy in Tel Aviv, some backers of the current bill have said that it was already ''nonbinding'' on the Administration and could be approved and signed by the President. **********But the Administration wants to head off a vote because of concern that such a move, even if the President vetoed it or refused to move the embassy, would be misinterpreted abroad and could touch off anti-American actions throughout the Moslem world.   Arab Group to Increase Efforts **********David J. Sadd, executive director of the National Association of Arab Americans, said at a news conference this afternoon that his group's lobbying against moving the embassy to Jerusalem had resulted in a shift of Congressional sentiment toward the nonbinding resolution. **********''We will now accelerate our efforts to block even a nonbinding Congressional resolution,'' he said. ''It would undermine America's interests for the Congress to lend its moral authority to illegal Israeli claims on Jerusalem.'' Israel contends that Jerusalem, including the eastern part captured from Jordan, is its undivided capital. **********The issue has been dramatized by statements by two Democratic Presidential contenders, Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart, that if elected they would move the embassy to Jerusalem. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the other Democratic contender for the nomination, has opposed such a move, as has Mr. Reagan. **********Many members of Congress have said they hoped the bill did not come to a vote or was not adopted. But they said that publicly they would support the legislation. **********The Senate Majority Leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., has been urging Republicans not to support the Moynihan bill. Some senators have said they would support the bill if it is a sense-of- the-Congress resolution, because they do not think Congress has the right to compel the President to establish an embassy in a particular place.   The President's Prerogative **********The Administration has asserted that it is the President's prerogative to decide when to recognize a country and where to place the embassy. But, in practice, Congress controls the funds necessary to run an embassy. **********The main argument given by those favoring the shift to Jerusalem is that Jerusalem is Israel's capital and Israel is the only country with diplomatic relations with the United States in which the embassy is in a place other than the host government desires. Moreover, they have said that not to move the embassy would demonstrate lack of support for Israel and only encourage Israel's enemies to think they could drive a wedge between Israel and the United States. **********All Presidents since 1949 have refused to put the embassy in Jerusalem. They have held that the status of the city should be decided by negotiations between Israel and Arab countries and that to move the embassy would seem to prejudge the negotiations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/05/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan completed his decisions on spending cuts in domestic programs for his 1986 budget, leaving him to decide whether to cut the military budget. That decision, which is not expected until next week, is central to the budget the President will send to Congress in January. Some top aides have said they expect him to accept a military slowdown. Rohatyn, M.A.C.'s chairman, said the Treasury's plan would be ''lethal'' for New York where taxes are high because of ''Federal neglect.'' (D23.) **********Sales by the nations' major auto makers fell 14.2 percent in the last 10 days of November, surprising analysts who were expecting continued gains. (D1.) **********Factory orders fell 2.5 percent in October, the third drop in a row and the steepest decline since last April. (D13.) **********Sales of new homes rose 2.1 percent in October, following a much stronger performance in September. (D1.) **********State and local regulation of cable TV subscription rates is being studied by the F.C.C., which will decide whether some regulation should continue when a deregulation order takes effect. Boone Pickens will offer to buy Phillips Petroleum shares, bidding $60 each for at least 9.7 percent of the nation's 12th-largest oil company. Mr. Pickens said that he and his partners already own 5.7 percent. His goal, he said, was to get control of Phillips and ultimately to acquire substantially all of it, with stockholders receiving the equivalent of $60 a share. That values Phillips at $9.3 billion. https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/05/busin.body_text: **********DIRECTORY assistance has usually been viewed by telephone companies as a necessary evil - something that must be provided to stimulate calling. But the Bell System breakup has changed that. As the Bell operating companies seek to enter new businesses, they are beginning to view directory assistance as a potential source of profits. **********The result is a scramble to come up with new ways to sell the computerized data base of names, addresses and telephone numbers used for directory assistance. Some companies, for instance, are already starting to offer services in which they give out the addresses of customers instead of the phone numbers. **********''Directory assistance was never intended to be a money maker originally,'' said Richard I. Moore, a product marketing director for Computer Consoles Inc., a leading supplier of directory assistance equipment to telephone companies. ''Now, with the divestiture taking place, that directory assistance data base is very valuable,'' **********The new services are causing protests, however, from those who think the phone companies should be restricted in what information they can give out. The offerings are also likely to raise objections from potential competitors, who might think the phone companies, by virtue of their monopoly status, have an unfair advantage in obtaining information about customers and in distributing it over the telephone. Similar protests arose over previous plans to offer electronic Yellow Pages, and the Bell operating companies are prohibited from offering electronic information services by the consent decree that split them from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********Among the potential new directory assistance services, one would be the reverse of traditional directory assistance. The caller would give the operator the telephone number and receive the name and address of the party with that number. Illinois Bell has been offering such a service in Chicago for 12 years for 25 cents, plus regular distance charges. Many other companies, including Northwestern Bell and Pacific Northwest Bell, are now starting to offer it. The biggest users are law enforcement agencies and credit-checking bureaus, although consumers use it for such things as getting addresses for Christmas card lists, according to phone industry officials. **********Under a a variation on this service, the caller would give the operator the address and receive back the name and number of the person there. Printed directories containing such information are available in many cities, but this service would put such information within reach of the general public. Southwestern Bell has done a survey to see if there is a market for such a service in Texas and has already stirred up a protest. **********''This has too much potential for abuse,'' said James C. Harrington, legal director of the Texas American Civil Liberties Union. Southwestern Bell, which serves Texas, has done a survey to see whether there would be a market for such a service. He said, for instance, that a burglar staking out a house could obtain the telephone number and call to see if anyone were home. **********Another service would allow customers to connect their own computers to the phone company computers to obtain listings without having to ask the operator. In theory, this would allow those with home computers to look up numbers by connecting to the phone company computer. At first, however, such a service is likely to be offered to large organizations like the Internal Revenue Service and law enforcement agencies. **********Telephone companies with surplus computer capacity might also allow customers to keep their internal phone lists on the phone company computer. The University of Nebraska keeps its listings on Lincoln Telephone Company computers. **********Other such services might include these: **********- Dial-up Yellow Pages: Pacific Northwest Bell recently started a service in which callers can get Yellow Pages-type information for $1.55 a call. A caller, for instance, might request the names of hotels in a particular town that are on the beach and that accept a particular credit card. **********- Other data bases: Phone company operators could offer other information in addition to listings. Pacific Northwest Bell, for instance, offers ZIP codes over the phone. And some newspaper publishers may be considering joint ventures with the local telephone companies to offer such things as classified ad information over the phone. **********- Specialized lists: Phone companies may sell lists of names to businesses that want to do solicitations. The phone companies could, for instance, provide lists of newcomers to a city. **********- Advertising: Computers that now give out the numbers in electronic voices could be programmed to deliver advertising messages as well. A caller requesting the number for Joe's Deli, for instance, might also hear a message such as, ''We have a special on pickles today.'' **********- Rent-an-operator: In addition to exploiting their data bases, the phone companies are considering making extra money from their operators. Some think operators could be used to dial wake-up calls, to place periodic calls to check up on elderly people, or to conduct opinion polls. Various Bell operating companies have talked to the MCI Communications Corporation about providing operators for MCI, which might want to offer operator services to better compete with A.T.&T. in the long-distance business. **********Also likely is a general rise in directory assistance charges. A.T.&T. last year proposed to charge 75 cents for interstate directory assistance calls, which are now free. The proposed charge has been reduced to 50 cents but has been delayed, along with telephone access charges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/03/world.main_headline: Sudanese Rebels Seize Chevron Oil Installation
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/03/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Sudanese Rebels Seize Chevron Oil Installation
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/02/03/world.body_text: **********Secessionist guerrillas overran the American-operated Chevron Oil Company complex at Bentiu in the southern Sudan today, killing three foreign workers and wounding at least seven others, Western diplomats said. **********One American was slightly wounded in the attack. The predominantly Christian guerrillas are seeking independence for the southern Sudan from the Moslem-dominated Government. **********About 20 attackers crept into the lightly guarded drilling area, 500 miles southwest of the capital of Khartoum, and then stormed houses occupied by the workers, opening fire with automatic weapons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/07/world.main_headline: Weinberger Answers Queries Of Callers on BBC Talk Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/07/world.print_headline: Weinberger Answers Queries Of Callers on BBC Talk Show
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/07/world.body_text: **********Some 400 callers from Europe, Africa, Asia and Australia jammed phone lines to the BBC World Service today to ask Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger about United States policies. **********Mr. Weinberger was the first foreign official to appear on ''It's Your World,'' a program in which callers phone in questions to be answered by the guest. **********The new program is broadcast worldwide by the British Broadcasting Corporation. **********Mr. Weinberger, who arose before dawn in Washington in order to appear on the show, which originates in London, answered questions for 45 minutes, mostly from Europeans asking reassurance on the United States commitment to the defense of Europe. **********''There's not the slightest intention on the part of this Administration to withdraw or reduce our commitment to NATO and the defense of Europe,'' Mr. Weinberger told one caller. ''It is essential that freedom be maintained in Europe if freedom is to be maintained in the United States.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/10/world.main_headline: EUROPEANS AND LATINS TO DISCUSS CLOSER TIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/10/world.print_headline: EUROPEANS AND LATINS TO DISCUSS CLOSER TIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/10/world.body_text: **********West Germany reported today that foreign ministers from Western Europe and Latin America would meet in Costa Rica next month to discuss broader political and economic cooperation. **********Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said that Nicaragua and El Salvador had expressed readiness to attend the two-day gathering, scheduled to open Sept. 28. This willingness, he added, has ''political significance.'' **********Honduras, Guatemala and Costa Rica will take part, he said, as well as the four nations that have been working together to seek a solution to the Central American conflicts - Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela. **********Meeting with the Latin American representatives will be the foreign ministers of the 10 members of the European Economic Community, plus Spain and Portugal, which are seeking Common Market membership.   Mild Criticism of U.S. Dominance **********In remarks suggesting mild criticism of United States political and economic dominance in the Latin American region, Mr. Genscher said at a news conference here that the officials would seek ways for Central America to ''diversify its foreign and trade policy relations with the cooperation of Western Europe.'' He said the United States Government, informed of the initiative, had reacted with a ''positive echo.'' **********''Stability in Central America is an important contribution to international stability and to securing world peace,'' the Bonn official said. **********He added that the meeting was aimed at insuring ''the independence of the region.'' He described the motives of the European Community members as ''free of any suspicion'' and stressed that the Central American governments had expressed interest in ''political support from Europe.''  Political Dialogue' **********Mr. Genscher said the European Economic Community favored a ''political dialogue'' with the Central American governments. He added that the ministers would try to lay the groundwork for an agreement on economic cooperation that might include preferential European tariffs for Central American goods and increased European development aid for the region. **********The West German Foreign Minister said he did not expect the meeting to produce a written agreement. Any such agreement, he went on, would have to be worked out in detail at later meetings of lower-level officials. **********The model for any agreement, Mr. Genscher said, could be the five-year pact on preferential tariffs between the European Community and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/14/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Saatchi & Saatchi Acquires Hay Group
https://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/14/busin.body_text: **********The Saatchi & Saatchi Company of London, Europe's largest advertising agency and parent of Saatchi & Saatchi Compton in the United States, has acquired the business and assets of the Hay Group of Philadelphia, a management consulting company with a network of 94 offices in 27 countries. **********The price was $100 million, $20 million of which will be placed in escrow to be released following publication of the audited accounts for the year ending next Aug. 31. **********Saatchi, a public company, has acquired three United States agencies since 1982: Compton Advertising, McCaffrey & McCall and Cochrane, Chase, Livingston & Company. Last month it acquired the YSW Group, parent of the Yankelovich, Skelly & White research firm.
